{"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "In hyper-partisan Washington, Danielle Pletka of the conservative American Enterprise Institute and Brian Katulis of the liberal Center for American Progress are an anomaly. Despite working for think tanks at opposite ends of the political spectrum, the two foreign policy experts not only talk to each other, they like each other and respect each other.\n\nSo much so, in fact, that in 2016, when they were to appear on a panel together in Florida and an emergency forced Mr. Katulis to bow out, Ms. Pletka felt compelled to be \u201cextra fair,\u201d since the event was billed as a bipartisan discussion. She tried to give the audience a sense of how Mr. Katulis, the liberal Democratic yin to her conservative Republican yang, would answer the questions posed, as well as conveying her own views.\n\nSome partisan listeners objected. But such experiences haven\u2019t swayed Ms. Pletka and Mr. Katulis, or their friends and colleagues Vikram Singh of CAP and Michael Rubin of A.E.I. from a collaborative relationship. While it is not unusual for such groups to cooperate, these experts have developed a robust partnership on national security that includes formal projects as well as informal conversation.\n\nTheir aim is to foster rigorous and respectful debate, not to forge a bipartisan foreign policy, they told me during a round-table discussion I organized at the CAP office. They are looking to brainstorm new solutions to problems, plug holes in their own policy arguments, avoid \u201cgroup think,\u201d and be challenged in ways they aren\u2019t when they associate mainly with their respective conservative and liberal allies.", "title": "Opinion | One Thing They Can Agree On \u2014 They Need to Listen", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-15 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThe Women\u2019s March is really iconic and of course we want to be a part of that,\u201d she said. \u201cBut March On has a great tool kit. Most of us have never done this before. We need all the guidance we can get.\u201d\n\nThe dispute over branding gives a glimpse of how much has changed since ad hoc committees of volunteers put together the marches in the weeks after President Trump\u2019s election.\n\nThe marches grew out of a Facebook post by a woman in Hawaii who floated the idea, attracting widespread interest. A core group of organizers in New York City planned the march on Washington, while hundreds of other women organized similar marches in their own communities.\n\nThe organizers of the march in Washington made a point of picking leaders from communities who have historically been ignored by mainstream feminist groups. Of the four national co-chairwomen of the Washington march, three were minorities. But the group\u2019s leadership had very little geographic diversity. Nearly all of the board members of Women\u2019s March Inc. are from New York City.\n\nAfter the march, Women\u2019s March Inc. used its powerful platform to advance social justice causes, urging marchers to hold conversations about racial injustice, protest the deportation of undocumented immigrants, attend vigils for Syria and participate in a national strike called A Day Without Women. Women\u2019s March Inc. activists said they saw social justice protests as crucial to forming effective and diverse coalitions.\n\nYet many of their protests failed to catch on in red states.\n\n\u201cWhat they are doing is great, but it\u2019s difficult to tap into here,\u201d said Kelly Smith, a librarian from Berea, Ky., who organized buses from Kentucky to Washington for the march last year. A general strike could not work in Kentucky, a state where many women depend on hourly wages and do not have union protections, she said.\n\nWomen \u201cwould have come back to work the next day and had no job,\u201d she said. \u201cI can\u2019t be on board with that.\u201d", "title": "One Year After Women\u2019s March, More Activism but Less Unity", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "PRAGUE \u2014 With its soaring Gothic cathedrals and ancient alleyways lined with baroque architectural marvels spread beneath a majestic castle that overlooks the city, Prague can seem a place frozen in time.\n\nBut for more than 600 years, one clock has been measuring the passing hours, noting when day turns to night as well as the position of the sun, moon and stars.\n\nUntil last week.\n\nPrague\u2019s famed Astronomical Clock, the Orloj, in the city\u2019s Old Town, has been stopped for repairs.\n\nIt is not the first time it has been stopped, but every intervention is fraught, given the clock\u2019s age and fragility. And this one is the most ambitious in years. So for Prague\u2019s clock master, Petr Skala, it is a little like being a surgeon at work on a very old patient.", "title": "One of the World\u2019s Oldest Clocks Stops Ticking, Briefly", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "But there is something wrong with it. In reality, students who complete these courses tend to do quite poorly on subsequent tests of academic knowledge. This suggests that these online recovery courses often give students an easy passing grade without teaching them very much.\n\nConsider a study conducted in the Chicago high schools. Students who had failed algebra were randomly assigned either to online or to face-to-face recovery courses. The results were clear: Students in the online algebra courses learned much less than those who worked with a teacher in a classroom.\n\nOnline courses have many real benefits, of course. They can help high achievers in need of more advanced coursework than their districts provide through other means. This is especially true in small, rural districts that offer few specialized, traditional courses for students working ahead of their grades.\n\nA study in Maine and Vermont examined the effect of online courses on eighth graders with strong math skills in schools that didn\u2019t offer face-to-face algebra classes. Students were randomly assigned either to online algebra or to the less challenging, standard math offered in traditional classes.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nBoth groups of students were tested at the end of the school year. The online algebra students did substantially better than their counterparts in standard classrooms. They were also twice as likely to complete advanced math later in high school.\n\nIn colleges, especially in nonselective and for-profit schools, online education has expanded rapidly, too, with similar effects. These schools disproportionately enroll low-income students who are often the first in their families to attend college. Such students tend to drop out of college at very high rates. Students with weak preparation don\u2019t fare well in online college classes, as recent research by professors at Harvard and Stanford shows.\n\nThese scholars examined the performance of hundreds of thousands of students at DeVry University, a large for-profit college with sites across the country. DeVry offers online and face-to-face versions of all its courses, using the same textbooks, assessments, assignments and lecture materials in each format. Even though the courses are seemingly identical, the students who enroll online do substantially worse.\n\nThe effects are lasting, with online students more likely to drop out of college altogether. Hardest hit are those who entered the online class with low grades. Work by researchers in many other colleges concurs with the DeVry findings: The weakest students are hurt most by the online format.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFor those with strong academic skills, by contrast, online learning can open up amazing opportunities.\n\nThe Massachusetts Institute of Technology offers a set of free, online courses in the economics of developing countries. Students who perform well in these classes can apply for a face-to-face master\u2019s program in economics at M.I.T. In fact, the online courses are the sole route into this special degree program. With online credit, students need to spend only one semester in Cambridge to graduate.\n\nThe M.I.T. approach reverses the high school model in which students who fail in a face-to-face class are shifted into a more challenging online format. In M.I.T.\u2019s program, students must first demonstrate that they can tough it out in an online class. Only then are they admitted to a rigorous, face-to-face master\u2019s program.\n\nOnline education is still in its youth. Many approaches are possible, and some may ultimately benefit students with deep and diverse needs. As of now, however, the evidence is clear. For advanced learners, online classes are a terrific option, but academically challenged students need a classroom with a teacher\u2019s support.", "title": "Online Courses Are Harming the Students Who Need the Most Help", "authors": ["Susan Dynarski", "Economic View"]} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 Nearly $800 million worth of fentanyl pills were illegally sold to online customers in the United States over two years by Chinese distributors who took advantage of internet anonymity and an explosive growth in e-commerce, according to a Senate report released on Wednesday.\n\nA yearlong Senate investigation found that American buyers of the illegal drugs lived mostly in Ohio, Pennsylvania and Florida. The Chinese sellers primarily used Bitcoin, the digital currency, as their preferred method of payment and shipped the drugs through other countries to reduce the risk of the opioids being seized by customs officials, Senate investigators said.\n\nThe 104-page bipartisan report was produced by the Senate Homeland Security Committee\u2019s investigations arm. It was requested by Senators Rob Portman, Republican of Ohio and the panel\u2019s chairman, and Tom Carper of Delaware, the committee\u2019s top Democrat. They will discuss the report\u2019s findings in a hearing set for Thursday and are expected to press law enforcement and Postal Service officials for details on plans to combat the growing opioid shipments.\n\nChina has a large pharmaceutical industry and hosts thousands of illegal labs that manufacture counterfeit and illicit drugs, Senate investigators said. The country has long been identified by American officials as the source of much of the illegal opioids flowing into the United States.", "title": "Online Sales of Illegal Opioids from China Surge in U.S.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-21 00:00:00", "text": "Dear Diary:\n\nI was on the subway when the train stopped at a station that wasn\u2019t mine.\n\nA man who was getting off dropped his hat on the floor of the car as he exited. I grabbed it, ran to the door, yelled \u201cHat!\u201d and threw it to him.\n\n\u201cGlasses, too,\u201d said a man who had been sitting next to me.\n\nI picked up the glasses and ran back to the door.\n\n\u201cGlasses, too!\u201d I yelled before throwing them to the man.\n\nI returned to my seat, smug in my belief that I had done a good deed.\n\nOf course, I had just thrown the man my glasses.", "title": "Only Trying to Help", "authors": ["Tom Beckett", "Metropolitan Diary"]} {"date": "2018-01-09 00:00:00", "text": "Ms. Scipio returned to her seat. \u201cIt\u2019s good to talk about it,\u201d she said, and dabbed her eyes.\n\nAt the station, her uncle, seated across from her, denied her retelling. He had been her main caregiver, walking her to school and helping her with homework. Ms. Scipio said that up until the moment her uncle looked her in the eyes and said, \u201cYou know that never happened,\u201d she had hoped to return home.\n\nKings County Family Court established a finding of sexual abuse against her uncle in August 2013, according to court records. The case was dismissed in criminal court, which requires a higher standard of proof to prosecute.\n\nFrom 2012 to 2016, close to a third of the nearly 3,000 arrests in New York City in sex offense cases involving child victims did not lead to convictions, according to the state\u2019s Division of Criminal Justice Services. (This includes only arrests in which sex offenses specifically against children were the top charges.)\n\nThe police records in the case were sealed because of the dismissal, so Ms. Scipio\u2019s story was reconstructed through foster care files that she provided, as well as an order of protection and records from family court. Contacted about this article, her uncle denied the allegations but confirmed details of the police investigation.\n\nAfter questioning by the police, Ms. Scipio was removed from her home and went to an intake center run by the Administration for Children\u2019s Services. Five days later, she was placed with JCCA, an organization licensed by the city to provide child welfare services and a beneficiary agency of UJA-Federation of New York, one of the eight organizations supported by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.\n\nMs. Scipio would never return home, but stayed in touch with her aunt, whom she had grown up calling \u201cMom,\u201d through phone calls and sporadic trips to celebrate birthdays and visit other relatives.\n\nMs. Scipio was shuttled among four foster homes in three years. In the first, she shared a room with five other people. Then out of district from her high school, Brooklyn Theater Arts, she commuted an hour and a half each way, using three buses. She found comfort in keeping her school life consistent, and theater offered an escape from the constant moves; she performed in each spring musical during her four years at the school.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe changes in foster families took a toll. One talked of adopting her, but when her aunt became ill, their relationship soured. In summer 2014, as Ms. Scipio headed into her senior year, her aunt canceled a coffee date, citing food poisoning. Later, Ms. Scipio learned her aunt had been hospitalized, and when she went to see her, she thought she had the wrong room.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI was like, \u2018Who is this woman in front of me?\u2019\u201d Ms. Scipio recalled. \u201cI told the nurse, \u2018This woman is not my mom.\u2019 She was frail and skinny. She couldn\u2019t move. I just wanted her to open her eyes and look at me.\u201d\n\nHer aunt died about a month later, but Ms. Scipio never learned the cause. She saw her uncle, against whom she had an order of protection until she turned 18, at the funeral. She still fears running into him. If she sees someone resembling him or driving a similar type of car, \u201cmy heart goes crazy,\u201d she said.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nJCCA, where Ms. Gonzalez is the education manager, helped move Ms. Scipio into her current apartment and provided her with $343 from the Neediest Cases Fund to prevent her electricity from being turned off in October. She pays $109 in subsidized rent and utilities.\n\nThe studio apartment holds mementos of her moves: a photo album from her childhood, a laminated memorial card with her aunt\u2019s name. By the window is a framed print of a red cape with a lightning bolt down the center reading \u201cFind Your Superpower.\u201d\n\nShe is inspired by the success stories of people who have been in foster care, like the comedians Tiffany Haddish and Eddie Murphy.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cI just want to perfect my craft,\u201d Ms. Scipio said of acting. \u201cAnything to do with theater. It doesn\u2019t have to be like crazy Broadway. But maybe if I start now, I\u2019ll get in.\u201d\n\nMs. Scipio now works part time as a receptionist at JCCA, and attends Borough of Manhattan Community College, where she made the dean\u2019s list this fall. A theater major, she performed in a re-envisioned production of \u201cFool for Love\u201d by Sam Shepard in December.\n\nMs. Scipio turns 21 this month, the cutoff age for receiving foster care services in New York. In December, she learned that her request for a six-month extension of services had been denied, effectively dismantling her safety net, as well as access to her sociotherapist and the $40 monthly stipend she receives from the Administration for Children\u2019s Services.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nLast month, she went to family court in Brooklyn with her lawyer, Martha Pollack, and pleaded her case.\n\n\u201cIt discounts her history,\u201d Ms. Pollack told the court, adding that the agency that took responsibility for Ms. Scipio, the Administration for Children\u2019s Services, \u201cis now not seeing it through.\u201d\n\nThe judge, Susan S. Danoff, agreed. \u201cI\u2019m really baffled by this denial,\u201d she said, ordering a final conference to reconsider the case. That appeal was denied on Dec. 22.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m heartbroken,\u201d Ms. Scipio said of the decision, adding, \u201cIt isn\u2019t the ending I was looking for.\u201d", "title": "Onstage, Escaping the Pain of Her Childhood", "authors": ["Emily Palmer", "The Neediest Cases Fund"]} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Brown\u2019s accusers told CTV News the a 39-year-old bachelor and well-known teetotaler, had served them alcohol and made advances on them in his bedroom when they were just teenagers and he was already an established politician.\n\nThe network shielded the identity of both accusers. One of the women was in high school more than 10 years ago when, she said, she returned from a bar to Mr. Brown\u2019s home, where he exposed himself and demanded oral sex.\n\nThe other woman was a 19-year-old summer staff member in Mr. Brown\u2019s office in 2013 when, she told CTV News, the politician kissed her and laid her down on his bed while she was inebriated. When she told him to stop, he did and drove her to her parents\u2019 house, she said.\n\nAt the time, Mr. Brown was a member of the federal Parliament.\n\nShortly before CTV showed its report on Wednesday night, a visibly shaken Mr. Brown called reporters to the provincial legislature to deliver a brief statement in which he called the accusations \u201ccategorically untrue.\u201d He vowed to defend himself \u201cwith all means at my disposal.\u201d\n\n\u201cI reject these accusations in the strongest possible terms,\u201d he said, his voice quivering with emotion. \u201cIt\u2019s not my values, it\u2019s not how I was raised, it\u2019s not who I am.\u201d\n\nBut hours later, after meeting with party leaders and after a conference call in which his fellow Conservative legislators unanimously agreed that he must go, Mr. Brown said he would quit as party leader while staying on as a member of Ontario\u2019s provincial legislature.\n\n\u201cAfter consulting with caucus, friends and family I have decided to step down as leader of the Ontario PC Party,\u201d he said. \u201cI will remain on as a MPP while I definitively clear my name from these false allegations.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOn Thursday, Ontario\u2019s premier, Kathleen Wynne, told reporters that residents of the province had been \u201cshaken\u201d by the accusations against Mr. Brown. She declined to say whether she would change the election date. While it is scheduled for June 7, Ontario premiers still have the option of calling a vote at any time.\n\nRecent polls showed Ontario conservatives under Mr. Brown\u2019s leadership running neck and neck with Ms. Wynne\u2019s Liberals, who have governed the province since 2003. The Conservatives rise appeared to have less to do with Mr. Brown\u2019s leadership than growing disaffection with Ms. Wynne\u2019s government.\n\n\u201cThere are lots of political questions that are going to come forward,\u201d Ms. Wynne said in her office. She added, \u201cIt is really, really important that we understand how deeply troubling this is to human beings, people.\u201d\n\nThree of Mr. Brown\u2019s top aides also quit on Wednesday, after urging him to resign.\n\nHis party\u2019s press secretary also resigned, as did his deputy campaign manager, Joshua Workman, and Ken Boessenkool, a prominent Conservative strategist who previously advised Stephen Harper, a former prime minister.\n\nThe Conservative caucus in the legislature will pick an interim leader perhaps as soon as Friday. Because there is not much time left before the election, whoever is chosen is likely to lead the party during the campaign.\n\nThe accusations against Mr. Hehr are from his time as a member of Alberta\u2019s provincial legislature and surfaced mainly in the form of a series of posts on Twitter from Kristin Raworth, who describes herself as a public servant and an \u201cadvocate for sexual violence survivors.\u201d\n\n\u201cMy first day working at the Alberta legislature I was told to avoid being in an elevator with Kent Hehr,\u201d Ms. Raworth posted. \u201cHe would make comments. He would make you feel unsafe.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nOne time, Ms. Raworth wrote, she was in an elevator with Mr. Hehr and he said, \u201cYou\u2019re yummy.\u201d\n\nMr. Hehr, who is quadriplegic, was demoted in a recent cabinet shuffle and had previously been accused more than once of making other insensitive remarks.\n\nMost recently members of a thalidomide survivors\u2019 group said last month that Mr. Hehr told them, \u201cWell you don\u2019t have it so bad, everyone in Canada has a sob story.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn a statement issued in Davos, Switzerland, where he was attending the World Economic Forum, Mr. Trudeau said, \u201cHarassment of any kind is unacceptable and Canadians have a right to live and work in environments free from harassment.\u201d\n\nIn Nova Scotia, Mr. Baillie stepped down after an investigator hired by his party found that he had broken workplace harassment rules. Neither the party nor Mr. Baillie, who has led it since 2010, released the report or offered any details about the accusations.\n\nIn Canada, the divisive and heated debate about predatory male behavior erupted into the public consciousness in 2014 \u2014 before the current #MeToo movement \u2014 when several women accused Jian Ghomeshi, a well-known radio host, of sexually assaulting them.\n\nMr. Ghomeshi was found not guilty after a widely covered criminal trial. Nevertheless, the finger-pointing and soul-searching over the pervasiveness of sexual harassment and assault, and the inability of the country\u2019s criminal system to address these issues, have continued unabated.\n\nEarlier this month, one of the country\u2019s most powerful theater directors, Albert Schultz, resigned as leader of the theater company he built after four actresses filed a lawsuit against him claiming that he had sexually harassed, groped, touched and repeatedly propositioned them over 13 years.", "title": "Ontario\u2019s Opposition Leader Quits Over Sexual Misconduct Allegations", "authors": ["Catherine Porter", "Ian Austen"]} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "It would seem unlikely that a single state legislative seat in Westchester County could hold the key to Democrats scoring a government trifecta in Albany, an alignment in which one party controls the governorship, as well as both houses of the Legislature.\n\nBut some political experts say the 37th Senate District may be that pivotal.\n\nIn November, George Latimer, a Democratic state senator from the 37th District, ran for Westchester County executive and trounced the two-term Republican incumbent, Rob Astorino. Many saw that election as a suburban referendum on the record of President Trump in a county where Democrats outnumber Republicans two-to-one.\n\nNow, Mr. Latimer\u2019s former Senate seat is up for grabs, and the special election to replace him has once again assumed heightened implications.\n\nWhile the Assembly has an overwhelming Democratic majority, the Senate is controlled by Republicans, thanks to a power-sharing arrangement between Republicans and several Democrats.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nLast fall, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo helped broker a deal in which the breakaway Senate Democrats, known as the Independent Democratic Conference, would form an alliance with the Senate\u2019s mainstream Democrats. But that deal is predicated on Democrats holding the open seat in Westchester, as well as one in the Bronx vacated by Ruben Diaz Sr., who is now a New York City councilman. (A state official said that special elections for all 11 open legislative seats will be held on Apr. 24.)", "title": "Open Seat in Westchester May Hold Key to Democratic Unity", "authors": ["Lisa W. Foderaro"]} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "Trump is a symptom, not a cause. That is why he may be hard to dislodge. He intuited the extent of American anger better than anyone. He also intuited a kind of cultural despair that made millions of Americans impervious to his lewd vulgarity \u2014 in fact, inclined to cheer him on in sticking it in the eye of the \u201cestablishment.\u201d\n\nHe knew he could turn politics into a reality show, and he was right. In depression, people seek distraction. America\u2019s opioid crisis is not in the pills, it\u2019s in the desperate, atomized circumstances that surround and spread them.\n\nBiglari pointed out that while the unemployment rate in the United States \u2014 the percentage of the population over 16 not employed but looking for work \u2014 is down to 4 percent, the employment rate \u2014 the percentage of the population actually working \u2014 tells a different story. It stood at around 67 percent in the 1990s, and has since declined to about 63 percent of the adult population. \u201cMany people are so discouraged, they have stopped looking for work,\u201d he told me.\n\nThere are echoes of Trump all over the world. Nowhere are they more poignant than in Poland. There, Lech Walesa and the Solidarity movement overturned Communist rule and set in motion the changes that would produce a united and democratic Europe. But, as The Wall Street Journal recently reported, Poland\u2019s nationalist leaders now want Walesa \u201cscrubbed from official memory.\u201d He is seen as the traitorous agent of Poland\u2019s dissolution within the European Union and NATO \u2014 what Kaczynski has called \u201cself-annihilation.\u201d\n\nNo matter that Poland is an economic success story. No matter that most Poles live unimaginably better, freer and more secure lives than they would have without Walesa\u2019s courage. What matters is the nation resurgent against imagined immigrant hordes and multilateral bureaucrats.\n\nThese currents run deep. Their irrationality is a galvanizing force. Trump is a lightning rod for every bully. In Davos, the president said: \u201cWhen people are forgotten the world becomes fractured. Only by hearing and responding to the voices of the forgotten can we create a bright future that is truly shared by all.\u201d\n\nOf course, when the \u201cforgotten\u201d is a refugee, forget about it. Or when the forgotten is a poor child who needs health care, or a woman who needs contraception, or an undocumented immigrant, forget about it. The word Trump did not use was \u201ceducation.\u201d America\u2019s education system has failed to respond to technological disruption. Only huge investment \u2014 what Biglari calls a Marshall Plan for education \u2014 can change that.\n\nBiglari, by the way, was born in Iran. He came here as an immigrant in the 1970s. He went on to become vice chairman of Citicorp. Not Trump\u2019s kind of guy, but a reminder that open societies work.", "title": "Opinion | Open Societies Under Siege", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "Each week, the Open Thread newsletter will offer a look from across The New York Times at the forces that shape the dress codes we share, with Vanessa Friedman as your personal shopper. The latest newsletter appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.\n\nHello and happy first week of 2018! I hope everyone had a good new year. I spent mine in multiple layers of clothing (it was minus 30 in Canada). At least when I wasn\u2019t huddled indoors by the fire \u2014 or thinking about what I am looking forward to this year. There\u2019s a lot.\n\nReally. Here are five examples to start us off. And that\u2019s just in the next six months.\n\n1. All those jobs to be filled! There are designer openings at Burberry and C\u00e9line \u2014 and Fendi still needs a C.E.O. Get ready for a whole new round of fashion musical chairs.\n\n2. Also get ready for a whole new red carpet attitude, starting this Sunday with the Golden Globes, where all the actresses (or most of them) have decided to wear black to make a statement about the treatment of women in Hollywood. Finally, they are using clothes to do more than bolster their bank accounts.", "title": "Open Thread: This Week in Style News", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "First, a number of threads under the story were along the lines of \u201ceverybody knew\u201d and \u201cwho does this surprise?\u201d \u2014 which pretty much illustrates the problem. Everybody might have known, but until now, no one was willing to say.\n\nSecond, there is some questioning of why the young men \u2014 who were stronger and often larger than the photographers \u2014 did not simply push them away. The answer is that this is not about physical power, but professional power: The photographers had it, and the models, most of whom were just starting their careers, did not.\n\nFinally, some people noted, especially when it came to Mr. Weber, they had never seen any such behavior. Isabella Rossellini posted a statement to this extent on Instagram. And I believe her. But the fact that a person can be utterly charming and gracious in one situation \u2014 something almost all the accusers of both Mr. Testino and Mr. Weber acknowledge \u2014 and abusive in another shouldn\u2019t come as a surprise. They\u2019re not mutually exclusive.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIt also speaks to the pattern of the behavior that it was a celebrity on an official shoot who had a good experience with a photographer, and an unknown in a private session who did not.\n\nAnyway, I think there\u2019s more to come on this. In the meantime I\u2019ll leave you to read about it (and other topics) and mull it over at your leisure. But anyone who has further thoughts on the subject, please let me know. And have a good weekend.\n\nYour Style Questions, Answered\n\nEvery week on Open Thread, Vanessa will answer a reader\u2019s fashion-related question, which you can send to her anytime via email or Twitter. Questions are edited and condensed.\n\nQ: I am ALWAYS cold and so hate wearing dresses. That said, if I must wear a dress for a special occasion, how to cover my legs? Nude hosiery feels too dated. Black hose with a black dress feels a bit too (way too) grandmotherly. Although I am a woman of grandmotherly age. \u2014 Sherron, Pennsylvania\n\nA: I am also always cold, so I know what you mean. And though I am not of grandmotherly age, I am of mother-of-teenagers age. So I have a few thoughts.\n\nThe resurgence of long skirts is key here, especially if you opt for one in velvet, wool, knit or tweed, which looks elegant but feels as though you are wearing a blanket on your legs. Modcloth has a nice royal-blue velvet style, Elizabeth & James has a ribbed knit and Lauren Ralph Lauren has a cashmere Fair Isle knit that looks both chic and comfy. Personally, this is my favorite solution, especially with ankle boots, which also keep your feet warm. Then there\u2019s the tuxedo, an always-appropriate solution to the I-don\u2019t-want-to-wear-a-dress-to-a-party problem. Think: what would Charlotte Rampling wear? Or opt for a derivation of the same idea, and pair sparkly pants, either beaded or in metallic brocade (try Tory Burch or H&M), with a simple cashmere sweater.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThat said, I also think you are selling black tights short, though I agree about the nudes. A thick, matte tight with black shoes and a black dress doesn\u2019t necessarily make you look grandmotherly, at least if the shoes are spiky enough. And by spiky, I don\u2019t mean high; I just mean non-nurselike. Check out Anna Wintour, who often wears dark tights with dresses when the temperatures drop. And who, by the way, recently became a grandmother too. \u2014 VANESSA FRIEDMAN", "title": "Open Thread: This Week in Style News", "authors": ["Vanessa Friedman"]} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "Your Style Questions, Answered\n\nEvery week on Open Thread, Vanessa will answer a reader\u2019s fashion-related question, which you can send to her anytime via email or Twitter. Questions are edited and condensed.\n\nQ: My son is in college in Maine, and the temperature is frequently below zero. It seems like every woman is swathed in an ankle-length black puffer coat from November to March, so why do men have so few choices in outerwear that is knee length or longer? Have you come across any knee-length down coats for men? \u2014 Amy, Pelham, N.Y.\n\nA: It\u2019s true: Though dress coats hit at the knee and great coats (especially those that are military-inspired in heavy wool) can be even longer, in general men got the short end of the stick in the coat-length sweepstakes. It\u2019s pretty clear this is one of those sexist fashion things \u2014 a long coat is somehow seen as not manly, unless maybe you live in Russia and it is fur. Because real men\u2026have weatherproof legs? Or something.\n\nGiven that all sorts of gender rules are loosening up when it comes to clothing these days, however, a warmer time may be on the horizon. In the meantime, however, I asked Matthew Schneier, our deputy fashion critic (currently in Milan at the shows) for his advice. Here\u2019s what he said:\n\n\u201cWhere men\u2019s outerwear is concerned, even the hardiest coats seem to come only to somewhere above the knee. To test the theory, I looked around at a range of brands known for their tough winter-wear (the North Face, Canada Goose, Moncler, Duvetica, Stone Island) and struck out at every one. Even L.L. Bean (which knows something about Maine winters, being headquartered there!) didn\u2019t offer much that dropped below the waist. I suspect it\u2019s that floor-length outerwear is pretty unwieldy, especially where there\u2019s snow and slush on the ground, and many men (at the expense of their body temperatures) chafe at the idea of something long enough to be mistaken for women\u2019s wear.\n\nMy solution, for what it\u2019s worth, is to pile on the underlayers. Thermal-wear has come a long way since the days of heavy waffle weaves in one color (though I love those, too). I swear by Uniqlo\u2019s Heattech line, which I wear, tops and bottoms, basically all winter. They\u2019re thinner, softer and warmer than their predecessors, cheaper by far than a new coat, and they disappear under clothes. Friends report that there was a run on them at the New York Uniqlo stores last week when the weather was wretched here. I wouldn\u2019t know; I order mine, as can you, online.\u201d \u2014 VANESSA FRIEDMAN", "title": "Open Thread: This Week in Style News", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-20 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 A North Carolina National Guard infantry battalion called off a training exercise that had been planned for a year. Flu samples from around the country will no longer be collected and tested. A skeleton staff of workers at the Internal Revenue Service girded themselves to answer a deluge of questions about the new tax law.\n\nThe vast machinery of the federal government began grinding to a halt on Saturday morning, hours after the Senate failed to reach a funding deal. But like an aircraft carrier after its propellers stop turning, much of the bureaucracy will stay in motion for a while, and some essential services, like the armed forces, the post office and entitlement programs, will not stop working at all.\n\nTens of thousands of federal workers woke up to notices from their cabinet secretaries informing them that, barring action from Congress, they will be furloughed this coming week. The shutdown is falling unevenly: The Education Department will send home more than 90 percent of its 3,934 employees, while the Pentagon said the entire uniformed military, and half of its civilian work force, would continue to serve. But for now, even the troops will not be paid.\n\nAt the White House, three-fifths of President Trump\u2019s staff will be placed on temporary leave. The National Security Council will stay at full strength, but about 60 percent of the president\u2019s closest aides were to be furloughed. Others could come to the White House or telecommute, but only for up to four hours, and only to execute an orderly shutdown.", "title": "Open, Closed or Something in Between: What a Shutdown Looks Like", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-16 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Grigorovich is the figure most closely identified with the Bolshoi, but Mr. Ratmansky is no stranger here, having served as the ballet company\u2019s artistic director from 2004 to 2008. The day-to-day management of personalities and factions was a struggle \u2014 \u201ca war, almost,\u201d he has said \u2014 and, when he was given the opportunity to become artist in residence at American Ballet Theater in New York, he left, seemingly without regret.\n\n\u201cAt first it was so weird to be back,\u201d Mr. Ratmansky said on a rainy November afternoon, as he rushed through the Bolshoi\u2019s labyrinthine corridors, \u201cbut since then, I\u2019ve just been with the dancers, working.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nIn the studio with Mr. Ratmansky, the dancers appeared eager to try a different approach to their characters and to master his tricky, fast-moving phrases. \u201cHe is a maximalist!\u201d Makhar Vaziev, the Bolshoi\u2019s current director, said. \u201cFor one movement, he can give 10 recommendations.\u201d Mr. Ratmansky pushed the dancers to be swifter, more detailed, more physical.\n\n\u201cDon\u2019t wait for the music, just go\u201d Mr. Ratmansky instructed Ekaterina Krysanova, a highly dramatic ballerina who, along with the limpid Vladislav Lantratov, danced on opening night. (They will also play the leads in the live broadcast.) Mr. Ratmansky wanted them to be almost ahead of the music, to give an impression of spontaneity and freshness.\n\nDespite his demands, he was soft-spoken, even formal, an approach that had not served him well when he was director, the critic Ms. Gouchmazova recalled. Back then, \u201che was so tactful in rehearsals that everybody decided he wasn\u2019t strong enough to be at the top.\u201d But now, as a visiting choreographer, the calm, focused atmosphere seems to suit everyone just fine. The company is a different place than it was 10 years ago.\n\n\u201cAll these people, either I hired them, or they were in the corps when I was director,\u201d Mr. Ratmansky said. \u201cI gave them their first roles, and we worked together many times. So now there is no resistance, nothing negative.\n\nPhoto\n\nDespite his history with the Bolshoi, Mr. Ratmanksy had been away for seven years. It was Mr. Vaziev, hired two years after the acid attack, who brought Mr. Ratmansky back into the fold, commissioning him to stage his \u201cRomeo and Juliet\u201d for the company. The two have a long history \u2014 in the late 1990s, when Mr. Vaziev was the director of the Mariinsky Ballet in St. Petersburg, he was one of the first to commission a large work from Mr. Ratmansky.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Vaziev has made no secret of his desire to freshen up the repertory. Some in Russia see this new \u201cRomeo\u201d as the first salvo in a larger strategy of phasing out Mr. Grigorovich\u2019s ballets.\n\n\u201cWe should not forget in which time period he worked in this theater,\u201d Mr. Vaziev said of Mr. Grigorovich. \u201cIt was difficult, the political ideology was very dominant. As to his work as a choreographer, some I like very much, some less, which is normal. He did what he could.\u201d\n\nAs for Mr. Ratmansky, he may be on the cusp of a comeback at the Bolshoi, where some of his older ballets, like \u201cThe Bright Stream,\u201d are still popular. \u201cRomeo and Juliet\u201d was well received in November, with the leading Moscow critic, Tatyana Kuznetsova, describing the production in the daily Kommersant as \u201cstrikingly musical and sensitive to psychological details.\u201d\n\nThe Bolshoi is, after all, the place that put him on the international map as a choreographer. \u201cI would dream to do something with him every year,\u201d Mr. Vaziev said (and not for the first time). For now, he and Mr. Ratmansky are in talks about a possible premiere for the fall of 2019. Russia calls.", "title": "Opening Wide: The Bolshoi\u2019s New, More Poetic \u2018Romeo and Juliet\u2019", "authors": ["Marina Harss"]} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "On a street lined with garbage trucks, in an industrial edge of Brooklyn, dozens of people started filing into an unmarked building before the winter sun rose. Patients gather here every day to visit the Vincent Dole Clinic, where they are promised relief from their cravings and from the constant search for heroin on the streets.\n\nRobert Perez exited the clinic on a recent Wednesday and walked toward the subway, along the Gowanus Canal. Within the clinic\u2019s antiseptic blue walls, he had just swallowed a red liquid from a small plastic cup. The daily dose of methadone helps Mr. Perez, 47, manage withdrawal symptoms as he tries to put decades of drug abuse behind him.\n\n\u201cI wish I didn\u2019t have to come here every day, but I have to,\u201d Mr. Perez said outside the clinic. \u201cIf you don\u2019t do it, you\u2019re sick. You wake up sick.\u201d\n\nMr. Perez is not alone. For recovering users without money or private health insurance, these clinics are often the only option to get their lives on track, even as less cumbersome alternatives have become available for those who can pay for it.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn New York City, opioid addiction treatment is sharply segregated by income, according to addiction experts and an analysis of demographic data provided by the city health department. More affluent patients can avoid the methadone clinic entirely, receiving a new treatment directly from a doctor\u2019s office. Many poorer Hispanic and black individuals struggling with drug addiction must rely on these highly regulated clinics, which they must visit daily to receive their plastic cup of methadone.", "title": "Opioid Addiction Knows No Color, but Its Treatment Does", "authors": ["Jose A. Del Real"]} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "We\u2019ve been here before, and with similar destructive effect. In 1987, four years after it was determined that H.I.V. could be spread only through sexual or blood-to-blood exposure, there were still doctors and dentists who refused to see H.I.V./AIDS patients out of lingering and irrational fears about its contagion. Even among those unlucky few who experienced needlestick injuries when treating H.I.V.-positive patients, fewer than 1 out of 300 contracted the virus (the number is even lower now).\n\nUnlike in epidemics of the past, we have a commanding medical understanding of the nature of today\u2019s culprit. In contrast to tuberculosis, cancer and AIDS \u2014 in which, as Susan Sontag described in \u201cIllness as Metaphor\u201d (1978) and \u201cAIDS and Its Metaphors\u201d (1989), the medical mystery of these entities contributed to public fears about contracting them \u2014 there should be no need to demythologize the opioid epidemic since we created these powerful synthetic opioids ourselves. And yet, paradoxically, the opioid crisis has perhaps unveiled a diametrical societal inclination: to actively mythologize a well-understood entity, metamorphosing it into a frightful and enigmatic one, bestowing contagion where none exists.\n\nFentanyl and carfentanil are synthetic opioids. They are many times stronger than morphine and have a well-established safety record in medical and veterinary use. When abused they can kill. These substances are dangerous in high quantities when injected or ingested by mouth or vigorous sniffing. But clinical toxicity (let alone a little high) from fleetingly touching even the purest powder forms of these compounds is simply impossible. After all, as our colleague Andrew Stolbach of the Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine has noted, if users could get their fix by touching fentanyl, they wouldn\u2019t bother injecting it.\n\nWhile bogeymanism may effectively serve to discourage some people from abusing these substances in the first place, it would be horrible if it were to dissuade emergency medical workers, medical professionals and civilians from performing noble and lifesaving acts, such as delivering lifesaving doses of naloxone. The tragedy is that it\u2019s already occurring. In some parts of the country, emergency medical workers aren\u2019t being permitted to carry naloxone. Recent fentanyl overdose scenes have crossed an invisible line into absurdity, in some instances resembling chemical war zones, Hazmat suits and all, where gloves and maybe a mouth cover would have sufficed. Policies like the one enacted by courthouses here will only reinforce what appears to be an inclination by at least some local authorities toward alarmist pageantry.\n\nThere are some encouraging signs that reason may yet prevail. Last summer, the two top expert bodies in the nation \u2014 the American College of Medical Toxicology and the American Academy of Clinical Toxicology \u2014 published a position statement debunking the tales that were reported in the press, noting in particular that none of the reported cases have appeared to resemble the constellation of symptoms we see and treat daily in cases of known opioid overdose. We are also heartened to see that local expert groups and even the White House have weighed in on the side of science in attempts to reassure emergency medical workers that they may continue to provide safe and desperately needed care.", "title": "Opinion | Opioid Hysteria Comes to Massachusetts Courts", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-08 00:00:00", "text": "In the imagination of some Democrats, Ms. Winfrey might offer an easy way out of those problems. She inspires crucial groups for the party \u2014 women and African-Americans \u2014 and alienates few. She has cast herself in American culture as an avatar of optimism, not defined in ideological terms. Having made a career out of preaching the values of empowerment and inclusion, she represents in some ways a natural counterpoint to Mr. Trump\u2019s proud pugilism. Senior Democrats in Washington said on Monday they had received no signal from Ms. Winfrey that she hoped to seek the White House.\n\nDavid Axelrod, the former chief strategist for Barack Obama, said Ms. Winfrey was a figure of unique political potential, with \u201ca boundless capacity for empathy and a preternatural ability to communicate powerfully and authentically \u2014 as we saw at the Golden Globes.\u201d\n\nMr. Axelrod questioned, however, whether Ms. Winfrey would be the right fit for 2020: \u201cWould she want to submit herself to the unforgiving, relentless and sometimes absurd process of running for president?\u201d he wondered, adding: \u201cWill there be hunger in 2020 for someone with some experience in government, after Trump?\u201d\n\nSome Democrats expressed skepticism and even frustration about the swirl of fascination with Ms. Winfrey, arguing that the party was jumping the gun with fevered speculation about 2020. Senator Brian Schatz of Hawaii, a young liberal in the chamber, wrote tersely on Twitter: \u201cHey. Let\u2019s focus on winning in 2018. Thanks.\u201d\n\nRebecca Katz, a Democratic strategist from the party\u2019s progressive wing, said it would be a mistake for Democrats to rush toward a magnetic personality rather than hashing out a compelling agenda for the midterm elections and beyond.\n\n\u201cBeating Trump isn\u2019t just about finding the right candidate \u2014 we have to show what we stand for,\u201d Ms. Katz said. \u201cOther than \u2018we all get a car,\u2019 what will an Oprah presidency look like?\u201d she added, referring to when Ms. Winfrey famously gave a car to every audience member at her show.\n\nMs. Winfrey\u2019s sudden prominence in the nation\u2019s political imagination speaks, in some respects, to the merging of politics and entertainment in the American mind. She has occupied a singular role in the television industry, parlaying roles as a local news anchor and a talk-show host in Chicago into a media empire that includes her own cable network and a fortune estimated at close to $3 billion. Gallup polling regularly finds Ms. Winfrey among the country\u2019s most admired women, alongside Hillary Clinton and Michelle Obama.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nRepresentative Nancy Pelosi of California, the House Democratic leader, suggested \u2014 with a dose of skepticism \u2014 that Ms. Winfrey was the kind of political outsider Democrats might embrace.\n\nAlluding to Mr. Trump\u2019s lack of experience, Ms. Pelosi tartly told a small group of reporters that Ms. Winfrey had other qualities going for her: \u201cOprah has read books. She knows how to identify talent.\u201d\n\n\u201cIf we\u2019re going into a place where they are devaluing experience in terms of substance and legislative acumen and stuff like that,\u201d Ms. Pelosi said, \u201cyou might as well have somebody who knows what they don\u2019t know and would get the best possible people there.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMs. Winfrey\u2019s commercial reach transcends race and income level, analysts say, propelling so many books and products to overnight success that it has earned its own sobriquet: \u201cThe Oprah Effect.\u201d In 2015, Ms. Winfrey bought a 10 percent stake in Weight Watchers and assumed a position on the company\u2019s board, a move that instantly doubled the company\u2019s sluggish share price and added $400 million to its market value.\n\nOther investments have eluded that Midas touch. Ms. Winfrey\u2019s cable channel, OWN: The Oprah Winfrey Network, a joint venture with Discovery Communications Inc., initially struggled to gain traction and last year earned an average of 462,000 prime time viewers daily. In December, Discovery said it would take majority control of OWN, purchasing 24.5 percent of the channel for $70 million from Ms. Winfrey\u2019s company, Harpo.\n\nMs. Winfrey\u2019s most potent appeal, industry analysts say, is among somewhat older consumers \u2014 or perhaps, voters \u2014 with women over 55 as her strongest cohort. She is especially popular among African-American women and white suburban women, two groups Democrats will rely on in the 2018 and 2020 elections.\n\nBy Monday afternoon, the White House had responded to the threat of Oprah in 2020. \u201cWe welcome the challenge,\u201d said Hogan Gidley, a spokesman for the president, \u201cwhether it be Oprah Winfrey or anybody else.\u201d\n\nBut Ms. Winfrey has approached politics cautiously over the years, engaging highly selectively. In 2007, she intervened for Mr. Obama, holding rallies for him and hailing him as \u201cthe one.\u201d And in 2013, she hosted a fund-raising event for Cory Booker, in his first bid for Senate in New Jersey.\n\nDuring the 2016 campaign, Ms. Winfrey endorsed Mrs. Clinton but never ventured onto the campaign trail. Though Ms. Winfrey and her staff discussed a possible appearance with the Clinton campaign, none was ever scheduled. Ms. Winfrey\u2019s aides cited her focus on righting her television network as the reason for her difficult schedule.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMinyon Moore, a Clinton adviser who communicated with the Winfrey team, said the campaign had been \u201cdelighted\u201d to have Ms. Winfrey\u2019s endorsement. Should Ms. Winfrey seek to assemble a campaign team for 2020, Ms. Moore said, \u201cI suspect she would have her pick.\u201d\n\nLess certain is whether Ms. Winfrey could navigate the ideological pitfalls of a presidential campaign and give voice not just to broad themes, but actual policy prescriptions. While Ms. Winfrey has aligned herself generally with Democrats like Mr. Obama, her views on a range of issues from financial regulation to drone warfare are opaque. She drew criticism from the left last year after saying in an interview that she felt hopeful and believed Mr. Trump had been \u201chumbled\u201d after meeting with Mr. Obama during the presidential transition.\n\nAlixandria Lapp, a strategist helping lead Democrats\u2019 effort to retake the House, said the profile of a media mogul outsider would be an uncomfortable match for the party.\n\n\u201cI think it\u2019s highly unlikely that Democrats will ever nominate our own version of Donald Trump \u2014 a celebrity with no government experience \u2014 because our party tends to respect government and governing experience,\u201d Ms. Lapp said.\n\nMs. Winfrey has recently taken on political topics as a special correspondent for CBS News\u2019s \u201c60 Minutes,\u201d including a segment on the country\u2019s political divisions and another on the use of solitary confinement in prisons.\n\nBut even to close friends and admirers, the prospect of an Oprah 2020 race appeared far-fetched or impossible as recently as last year. After Mr. Trump\u2019s inauguration, when the traditional barriers to entry into presidential politics appeared to melt away, Ms. Winfrey\u2019s associates dismissed the idea.\n\nA reporter who last March contacted Ms. Winfrey\u2019s best friend, Gayle King of CBS News, got an emphatic reaction to the 2020 question.\n\n\u201cNOT A CHANCE!!!!!\u201d Ms. King replied at the time, adding: \u201cIn caps for a reason.\u201d", "title": "Oprah 2020? Democrats Swing From Giddy to Skeptical at the Prospect", "authors": ["Alexander Burns", "Amy Chozick"]} {"date": "2018-01-09 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nWelcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown that lets you sleep \u2014 and lets us get paid to watch comedy. While two of Trump\u2019s close friends said, \u2018Please don\u2019t refer to us as Trump\u2019s close friends.\u2019\u201d \u2014 JIMMY FALLON\n\nTrevor Noah said he could hardly think of another person more different from President Trump. Late Night Is Intrigued", "authors": ["Giovanni Russonello", "Best Of Late Night"]} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "It was a speech that inspired the fantasies of Democrats across America, all of them centered on a single question: Will Oprah Winfrey run for president in 2020?\n\nNow, less than two weeks after those hopes were raised, an interview has appeared to dash those hopes \u2014 or at least muddy the waters.\n\nIn an interview for the March issue of InStyle, the beauty and fashion magazine, the former talk show host was asked how she felt about the prospect of what would have been a historic campaign to put a black woman in the White House. The interview was conducted three weeks before her speech at the Golden Globes, InStyle confirmed Thursday.\n\n\u201cI\u2019ve always felt very secure and confident with myself in knowing what I could do and what I could not,\u201d she said. \u201cAnd so it\u2019s not something that interests me. I don\u2019t have the DNA for it.\u201d", "title": "Oprah Had Ruled Out Running for President", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-31 00:00:00", "text": "Oprah Winfrey has dropped contributions by the hip-hop mogul Russell Simmons from her latest book, its publisher said, after multiple women accused him of sexual misconduct, including rape.\n\n\u201cThe Wisdom of Sundays,\u201d a spiritual advice book that has been on best-seller lists since its publication last fall, features selections from conversations between Ms. Winfrey and her guests on \u201cSuper Soul Sunday,\u201d a TV series on the OWN network. The words of motivational speakers, religious leaders and authors including Deepak Chopra and Elizabeth Gilbert were excerpted. Mr. Simmons was featured in passages describing the impact meditation has had on his life, as well as musing on the soul, abundance and wealth; future editions of the book, available in stores starting in February, will not contain those segments, Marlena Bittner, a spokeswoman for the publisher, Flatiron Books, said.\n\nThe publisher made the announcement in response to an inquiry from The New York Times. Ms. Bittner said the decision to remove the pages was made jointly by Ms. Winfrey and the publisher, but declined to say when they made that choice. Ms. Winfrey has lately been a vocal advocate of the #MeToo movement, making a fiery speech promoting Time\u2019s Up, the Hollywood initiative to combat sexual harassment and discrimination, at the Golden Globes in early January. In the book, she also writes about being a victim and coming to terms with her own abuse by learning to confront it. \u201cYou can\u2019t win,\u201d she wrote, \u201cif you\u2019re fighting the truth.\u201d\n\nMr. Simmons has been the subject of intensifying misconduct allegations since last November; he has denied all the allegations but stepped down from his businesses and foundation soon after they were made public. Last week, a California woman, Jennifer Jarosik, filed a $5 million lawsuit against him, alleging that he raped her in Los Angeles in 2016. On Tuesday, Ms. Jarosik appeared on \u201cMegyn Kelly Today\u201d and described the incident as well as an earlier assault by Mr. Simmons in New York. She plans to press criminal charges in both cities, her attorney said.
