Flames and thick black smoke were seen pouring from the Sanchi in images released by the South Korean Coast Guard and the Chinese state news media.\n\nGreenpeace said the accident may become an environmental disaster.\n\n_____\n\n\u2022 Beijing\u2019s regulators are cracking down on Amway, the American marketing giant that found financial salvation in China, growing to more than $2.6 billion in revenue.\n\nNow, Amway and other companies that use sales representatives to recruit others below them \u2014 in what\u2019s called multilevel marketing \u2014 face public skepticism, and in some cases investigations.\n\nAmway\u2019s name in Chinese, an li, has even entered the vernacular to mean to \u201cpromote heavily\u201d or to \u201cbe brainwashed.\u201d\n\n_____\n\n\u2022 In Iran, President Hassan Rouhani used the recent nationwide protests to attack his hard-line opponents, saying the people who took to the streets did so because they were seeking a better life.", "title": "Oprah Winfrey, El Salvador, Iran: Your Tuesday Briefing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nAfter a rousing speech at the Golden Globe Awards on Jan. 7, some are speculating that Oprah Winfrey may run for president in 2020. Do you think she should run? Would you vote for her if you could? Why or why not?\n\nTell us in the comments, then read the related article to find out what Democrats are saying about a possible Oprah presidential candidacy.", "title": "Oprah for President", "authors": ["Natalie Proulx", "Picture Prompts"]} {"date": "2018-01-09 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cOprah 2020? The Idea Makes Democrats Giddy and Skeptical\u201d (front page, Jan. 9):\n\nThe conversation around what for some is the tantalizing prospect of an Oprah Winfrey presidential run in 2020 conforms to a familiar pattern in presidential politics.\n\nOften we elect presidents who are very different from their immediate predecessors by their politics and temperament. Examples are Barack Obama after George W. Bush, Jimmy Carter after Richard Nixon/Gerald Ford.\n\nIt would be hard to imagine two more dissimilar candidates in 2020 than Ms. Winfrey and Donald Trump. It would not be surprising if the country turns to someone like Ms. Winfrey next time. She certainly would impart the kind of values and compassion a majority of Americans are now missing.\n\nBut in an effort to achieve radical change and notwithstanding the wide and refreshing appeal Ms. Winfrey or someone like her may have, we should not lose sight of the broad qualifications a president must bring to the office. We must get it right next time.", "title": "Opinion | Oprah, Celebrity and the Presidency", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-08 00:00:00", "text": "Indeed, the magical thinking fueling the idea of Oprah in 2020 is a worrisome sign about the state of the Democratic Party. That Ms. Winfrey could probably beat those considered likely front-runners \u2014 Joe Biden, Bernie Sanders, Kirsten Gillibrand \u2014 is testament to how demoralized and devoid of fresh political talent the post-Obama party has become.\n\nIn a way, the conversation on the left (and the anti-Trump right) around Ms. Winfrey is more troubling than the emotional immaturity and anti-intellectualism pulsing out of the red states that elected Mr. Trump. Those voters have long defined themselves in opposition to the intellectual seriousness Democrats purport to personify.\n\nIf liberals no longer pride themselves on being the adults in the room, the bulwark against the whims of the mob, our national descent into chaos will be complete. The Oprah bandwagon betrays the extent to which social causes and identities \u2014 and the tribal feelings they inspire \u2014 have come to eclipse anything resembling philosophical worldviews. American politics has become just another team sport, and if suiting up a heavy hitter like Ms. Winfrey is what it takes to get the championship ring, so be it.\n\nThe idea that the presidency should become just another prize for celebrities \u2014 even the ones with whose politics we imagine we agree \u2014 is dangerous in the extreme. If the first year of the Trump administration has made anything clear, it\u2019s that experience, knowledge, education and political wisdom matter tremendously. Governing is something else entirely from campaigning. And perhaps, most important, celebrities do not make excellent heads of state. The presidency is not a reality show, or for that matter, a talk show.\n\nTo her credit, last year Ms. Winfrey told CBS, \u201cThere will be no running for office of any kind for me.\u201d But when the conservative columnist and Trump critic John Podhoretz published an essay in The New York Post in September headlined \u201cDemocrats\u2019 Best Hope for 2020: Oprah,\u201d she retweeted it.\n\n\u201cIf any figure in the United States bears watching over the next couple of years as our political culture continues the radical transformation that led to the election of Donald Trump, it\u2019s Oprah,\u201d Mr. Podhoretz wrote. \u201cI believe she\u2019s uniquely positioned, should she wish to commit herself, to seek the Democratic nomination for president and challenge Trump in 2020.\u201d\n\nLet us hope, for the sake of our nation, that she does not want it.", "title": "Opinion | Oprah, Don\u2019t Do It", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "Instead, her essential celebrity is much closer to the celebrity of Pope Francis or Billy Graham. She is a preacher, a spiritual guru, a religious teacher, an apostle and a prophetess. Indeed, to the extent that there is a specifically American religion, a faith tradition all our own, Oprah has made herself its pope.\n\nIn other columns I have suggested that American culture is divided between three broad approaches to religious questions: one traditional, one spiritual and one secular. The traditional approach takes various forms (Catholic and Protestant, Muslim and Orthodox Jewish) but its instincts are creedal, confessional, dogmatic; it believes in a specific revelation, a specific authority and a specific holy book, and seeks to conform itself to teachings handed down from the religious past. The secular approach is post-religious, scientistic, convinced that the laboratory and the microscope will ultimately account for everything that matters, while hopefully justifying a liberal society\u2019s still-somewhat-Christian moral commitments along the way.\n\nBut in between secularism and traditionalism lies the most American approach to matters of faith: a religious individualism that blurs the line between the God out there and the God Within, a gnostic spirituality that constantly promises access to a secret and personalized wisdom, a gospel of health and wealth that insists that the true spiritual adept will find both happiness and money, a do-it-yourself form of faith that encourages syncretism and relativism and the pursuit of \u201cyour truth\u201d (to borrow one of Oprah\u2019s Golden Globes phrases) in defiance of the dogmatic and the skeptical alike.\n\nBecause this kind of faith is not particularly political, because it\u2019s too individualistic and personalized (and comfortable with the post-Me Decade American status quo) to be partisan and programmatic, it doesn\u2019t always get the attention it deserves from a press accustomed to analyzing everything in terms of the clash of left and right.\n\nNot that it doesn\u2019t have partisan tilts and colorations. Some of its manifestations are more common in conservative America \u2014 where they usually have an evangelical and commercial gloss, as with Joel Osteen and his epigones. (This red-state style of spirituality was recently co-opted, with some success, by the prosperity preacher known as Donald Trump.) Others are more common in liberal communities \u2014 where they emphasize Eastern wisdom and Lost Christianities and the New Age and Esalen-style mystical humanism. Where the spiritual worldview blurs into secularism, it\u2019s usually claiming scientific bona fides; where it blurs into traditional religion it\u2019s usually talking about Jesus. And Oprah herself, with her Obama-endorsing, #MeToo politics and her tendency to mix spirituality with pseudoscience, is clearly somewhat on the blue-state side of that divide \u2026", "title": "Opinion | Oprah: Prophet, Priestess \u2026 Queen?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "The long-term use of oral contraceptives reduces the risk for ovarian and endometrial cancers, and the effect is especially evident in smokers, the obese and those who exercise infrequently, a new study found.\n\nEarlier studies have demonstrated an association of previous oral contraceptive use with reduced risk for these cancers in postmenopausal women. This study considered the impact of various health and lifestyle factors, including smoking, obesity and physical activity.\n\nThe study, in JAMA Oncology, included 196,536 women ages 50 to 71, more than half of whom had used oral contraceptives.\n\nCompared with those who hadn\u2019t used oral contraceptives, those who had used them for 10 years or more had a 34 percent reduced risk for endometrial cancer, with the strongest reductions among women who were smokers or obese at the start of the study. Contraceptive users had a 40 percent risk reduction for ovarian cancer, with the risk reduction significant in smokers, the obese and those who got no regular exercise.", "title": "Oral Contraceptives Reduce Risk for Ovarian and Endometrial Cancers", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-03 00:00:00", "text": "Q. Your recent tip on managing iOS apps without the old capability in the new iTunes update did not address seeing apps beyond pages available on a device (I have hundreds more not visible) and organizing them on a computer, as was so easy before iTunes 12.7. Help!\n\nA. By confining apps management to the iPhone, iPad or iPod Touch, Apple has made the process more challenging for those who preferred to organize their collections in the desktop iTunes program \u2014 but there are a few tricks that may help make more of your apps visible and easier to move around. For example, sorting your apps into folders on your home screen (a feature that was introduced for the iPhone in 2010) allows you to keep at least 12 tiny app icons in the same amount of space as a single standard icon.\n\nDepending on the screen size of your hardware and the version of the iOS software you are using, you can have anywhere from 2,160 to 49,140 apps displayed on your device\u2019s home screens. Whether or not your phone or tablet has the storage capacity for a potential 49,140 apps is another matter, but the icon visibility is possible based on the number of home screens, space for folders and number of apps that can be stored in those folders.\n\nTo group apps into folders (like \u201cGames\u201d or \u201cPhoto Editors\u201d), lightly press and hold your finger on an app icon until all the apps on the screen begin to jiggle. Drag the app on top of another app you want in the same folder; while the apps are wiggling in \u201cedit\u201d mode, you can also drag them around into a new order on the screen or tap the \u201cx\u201d in the corner to delete the app from the device.", "title": "Organizing Apps Directly in iOS", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-02 00:00:00", "text": "Senator Orrin G. Hatch of Utah, the longest-serving Senate Republican, announced Tuesday that he would retire at the end of the year, rebuffing personal pleas from President Trump to seek an eighth term and paving the way for Mitt Romney, a critic of Mr. Trump\u2019s, to run for the seat.\n\nMr. Hatch\u2019s decision marks another political setback for Mr. Trump, who lost a Senate seat in Alabama after his preferred candidates were rejected. He also faces an exodus of Republicans from both chambers of Congress and has been warned of a political typhoon in November.\n\nMr. Romney\u2019s potential ascent is particularly alarming to the White House because the former presidential candidate has an extensive political network and could use the Senate seat as a platform to again seek the nomination. Even if he were not to run again for president, a Senator Romney could prove a pivotal swing vote, impervious to the entreaties of a president he has scorned and able to rally other Trump skeptics in the chamber.\n\n\u201cWhen there are things he agrees with him on, he\u2019ll be a big supporter,\u201d Spencer Zwick, Mr. Romney\u2019s longtime fund-raiser, said of Mr. Romney and Mr. Trump. \u201cAnd when there are things he disagrees with, he\u2019ll voice that.\u201d", "title": "Orrin Hatch, Utah Senator, to Retire, Opening Path for Mitt Romney", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "Among the nine, only \u201cDunkirk\u201d and \u201cThe Post\u201d were assembled by major studios. Many have not made a significant mark in theaters. The gay romance \u201cCall Me by Your Name,\u201d for instance, has only taken in $9.1 million.\n\nCampaigning for the 90th Academy Awards has been going on in Hollywood for five months, with films falling over themselves to claim the cultural zeitgeist. Jordan Peele\u2019s \u201cGet Out\u201d is about racism and cultural appropriation, the film\u2019s get-out-the-vote team says, but also (in this #MeToo moment) about the abuse of power. \u201cThree Billboards,\u201d which won the top prize at the Screen Actors Guild Awards on Sunday, sees itself as the most topical: It features a woman demanding attention be placed on a sexual predator; red state anger; and commentary about racist policing. Others say the crown should go to \u201cThe Post,\u201d with its depiction of a woman coming into her own as a leader and taking a stand against attacks on journalists.\n\nPhoto\n\nAnd don\u2019t forget Greta Gerwig\u2019s \u201cLady Bird,\u201d with its nuanced mother-daughter relationship and self-confident central character. Ms. Gerwig received nominations for her original screenplay and became the fifth woman ever nominated for best director. \u201cLady Bird\u201d also received best actress (Saoirse Ronan) and supporting actress (Laurie Metcalf) nods.\n\n\u201cIt feels like something has shifted,\u201d a jubilant Ms. Gerwig said by phone, describing herself as \u201csomewhere in the middle between crying and laughing.\u201d She added: \u201cThe academy recognized a new generation \u2014 authors, filmmakers, actors, storytellers \u2014 in such a beautiful way. It\u2019s unfathomable in some ways.\u201d\n\nMs. Gerwig said her first phone call of the morning was to congratulate Mr. Peele, who is only the third person to receive best picture, directing and writing nominations for his first film. (Warren Beatty did so with \u201cHeaven Can Wait\u201d in 1978, followed by James L. Brooks with \u201cTerms of Endearment\u201d in 1983.) He is the fifth black director to be nominated.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIt feels like a renaissance is happening, and I\u2019m really honored to be a part of it,\u201d Mr. Peele said in a phone interview. Noting efforts by the academy to diversify its membership, he added: \u201cThat has helped a lot of fresh voices and talents be recognized. Given the state of our country right now, we urgently need to encourage those fresh ideas and fresh voices.\u201d\n\nMr. Peele\u2019s film, which cost Blumhouse Productions $4.5 million to make and collected $255 million worldwide nearly a year ago, is one of the few horror movies ever nominated for Hollywood\u2019s highest honor.\n\nThe nominations meant the end of the road for hopefuls like \u201cDetroit,\u201d \u201cBattle of the Sexes,\u201d \u201cDownsizing,\u201d \u201cWind River\u201d and \u201cWonder Woman,\u201d all of which campaigned for votes and were completely shut out. (They can always hope for an envelope mix-up.)\n\nPhoto\n\nMcDormand, Oldman lead acting nominees.\n\nFrances McDormand, a four-time nominee and a winner for \u201cFargo\u201d in 1997, was nominated for her lead performance in \u201cThree Billboards.\u201d She has already won Golden Globe and Screen Actors Guild trophies for the role. Joining her were Ms. Ronan, Sally Hawkins (\u201cThe Shape of Water\u201d), Margot Robbie (\u201cI, Tonya\u201d) and Meryl Streep (\u201cThe Post\u201d). It was Ms. Streep\u2019s 21st nomination.\n\nGary Oldman\u2019s performance as Winston Churchill in \u201cDarkest Hour\u201d landed him a best actor nod. He was joined in the category by the newcomers Daniel Kaluuya and Timoth\u00e9e Chalamet (\u201cCall Me by Your Name\u201d), Daniel Day-Lewis (\u201cPhantom Thread\u201d) and the nine-time nominee Denzel Washington (\u201cRoman J. Israel, Esq.\u201d).\n\nJames Franco (\u201cThe Disaster Artist\u201d) was notably left out. Mr. Franco\u2019s inclusion would have put the academy in an uncomfortable spot; at least five women have accused him of inappropriate or sexually exploitative behavior, allegations his lawyer has disputed. Representatives for Mr. Franco have referred reporters to his statements on late-night shows.\n\nMany academy voters have long insisted that art should be separated from the artist \u2014 that the Oscars should be about assessing the caliber of work and that concerns about offscreen behavior should be cleaved away. Just last year, voters overlooked Casey Affleck\u2019s past settlements with women who accused him of sexual harassment to name him best actor.\n\nBut that stance has been harder to maintain as women have come forward in recent months to accuse men like Harvey Weinstein, Brett Ratner and James Toback of sexual misconduct. Many of these men \u2014 Mr. Weinstein, most notably \u2014 used the Oscars as a shield. The academy kicked him out in October.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhile a hot awards prospect earlier in the season, \u201cThe Florida Project,\u201d about families living in a grim motel, received only one nomination, for Willem Dafoe as a supporting actor. The film\u2019s prospects were hurt after harassment claims were made against one of that film\u2019s producers, Andrew Duncan, who stepped down from his independent production company in December while denying wrongdoing.\n\nAlso receiving a supporting actor nod was Christopher Plummer, who replaced Kevin Spacey in \u201cAll the Money in the World\u201d at the last minute after Mr. Spacey was accused of sexual misconduct by multiple men. Richard Jenkins (\u201cThe Shape of Water\u201d) and the \u201cThree Billboards\u201d co-stars Sam Rockwell and Woody Harrelson rounded out the category.\n\nPhoto\n\nKeeping an eye on diversity.\n\nIn the wake of the #OscarsSoWhite backlash in 2015 and 2016, the academy mounted an effort to double female and minority membership. But even after two years of the initiative, the academy remains 72 percent male and 87 percent white.\n\nActors of color who received nominations on Tuesday included Mr. Kaluuya, Mr. Washington, Mary J. Blige (\u201cMudbound\u201d) and Octavia Spencer (\u201cThe Shape of Water\u201d). Both Ms. Blige and Ms. Spencer were nominated as best supporting actress, joined by the first-time honorees Allison Janney (\u201cI, Tonya\u201d), Lesley Manville (\u201cPhantom Thread\u201d) and Ms. Metcalf.\n\nFor the first time in its 90-year history, a woman was nominated for best cinematographer: Rachel Morrison, who was honored for her work on \u201cMudbound,\u201d Dee Rees\u2019s film about black and white farmers in rural Mississippi in the 1940s. No black woman has ever won a writing award at the Oscars, but Ms. Rees, nominated with Virgil Williams for their adapted screenplay, could change that.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe streaming insurgency.\n\nThe academy\u2019s old guard has resisted a push by Netflix to join the best picture club, arguing that, since Netflix only gives its films token releases in theaters, its offerings should be better considered by Emmy voters. Netflix has doggedly campaigned for Oscars, though, and last year won the documentary short prize for \u201cThe White Helmets.\u201d\n\nThis year, Netflix was hoping for its first best picture nomination for \u201cMudbound.\u201d That didn\u2019t happen, but the film ultimately received attention in four categories, including original song. Netflix, with a total of eight nominations, also has two documentaries vying for the Oscar: \u201cIcarus,\u201d about Russian doping in sports, and \u201cStrong Island,\u201d about the 1992 murder of a young black man.\n\nFor its part, Amazon had aggressively pushed \u201cThe Big Sick,\u201d nominated for best original screenplay, as a best picture contender, despite the academy\u2019s aversion to comedies. But Amazon is already ahead of Netflix in its campaign to be taken seriously by the film establishment. Amazon, which has allowed its films to play extensively in theaters before appearing online, won three Oscars last year. Two were for \u201cManchester by the Sea\u201d and one for \u201cThe Salesman,\u201d a foreign film.", "title": "Oscar Nominations 2018: \u2018The Shape of Water\u2019 Leads the Race", "authors": ["Brooks Barnes"]} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "What is your reaction to the 2018 Oscars nominees? Which films do you hope will win an Academy Award? Are there any that you think got snubbed? If so, which ones and why?\n\nTell us in the comments, then read the related article to find out all the nominees for each category, read movie reviews and even fill out your own ballot.", "title": "Oscars", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "Watching is The New York Times\u2019s TV and film recommendation website. Sign up for our thrice-weekly newsletter here.\n\nMost of this year\u2019s Academy Awards contenders were released late in 2017, and as is often the case, many of the most-nominated films are still in theaters. Several top-category nominees from earlier in the year, however, are available to stream right now. Here\u2019s an updating list of those titles, along with where to stream them:\n\nScripted Features\n\nDaniel Kaluuya and Allison Williams in \u201cGet Out.\u201d Justin Lubin/Universal Pictures\n\n\u2018Get Out\u2019\n\nNominated for: best picture, best director, best original screenplay, best actor\n\nbest picture, best director, best original screenplay, best actor Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nThe stigma against horror films during awards season is so strong that \u201cGet Out\u201d was reclassified as a comedy for Golden Globes contention. But make no mistake: Jordan Peele\u2019s debut feature may satirize the racial posturing of suburban liberals, but the film\u2019s driving force is still the terror of white supremacy. Daniel Kaluuya stars as a young African-American photographer whose white girlfriend (Allison Williams) takes him home to meet her parents. He soon discovers that the welcoming party has some sinister motives.\n\nWhere to watch: HBO\n\n\u2014\n\nA scene from \u201cDunkirk.\u201d Melinda Sue Gordon/Warner Bros.\n\n\u2018Dunkirk\u2019\n\nNominated for: best picture, best director, best production design, best cinematography, best sound mixing, best original score, best film editing\n\nbest picture, best director, best production design, best cinematography, best sound mixing, best original score, best film editing Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nChristopher Nolan\u2019s treatment of the evacuation of more than 300,000 allied troops from the beaches of Dunkirk, France, in 1940 eschews political context \u2014 and a lot of chatter \u2014 in order to draw viewers into a meticulous re-creation of the scene. Presenting the action on three different fronts, each on separate but elegantly dovetailing timelines, Nolan follows the soldiers pinned to the beach by German forces, the British civilian vessels commandeered for the rescue effort and the Royal Air Force pilots working to clear the airspace.\n\nWhere to watch: Amazon, iTunes\n\n\u2014\n\nZoe Kazan and Kumail Nanjiani in \u201cThe Big Sick.\u201d Lionsgate\n\n\u2018The Big Sick\u2019\n\nNominated for: best original screenplay\n\n\n\nbest original screenplay Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nIn a savvy fusion of real-life crisis and rom-com convention, writers Kumail Nanjiani and Emily V. Gordon turned the dramatic story of their courtship into the biggest hit to come out of the 2017 Sundance Film Festival. Nanjiani stars as a version of himself, a Pakistani-born stand-up comedian who\u2019s on the verge of breaking up with his girlfriend (Zoe Kazan) when she falls mysteriously ill and he ends up keeping watch with her parents (Holly Hunter and Ray Romano) in the hospital waiting room.\n\nWhere to watch: Amazon Prime, iTunes\n\n\u2014\n\n0\n\nA scene from \u201cMudbound.\u201d Steve Dietl/Netflix\n\n\u2018Mudbound\u2019\n\nNominated for: best cinematography, best supporting actress, best original song, best adapted screenplay\n\n\n\nbest cinematography, best supporting actress, best original song, best adapted screenplay Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nDirector Dee Rees (\u201cPariah\u201d) dissects the subtle and unsubtle effects of a racist culture in this adaptation of the Hillary Jordan novel about two rural families \u2014 one white, one black \u2014 whose lives become enmeshed in post-World War II Mississippi. Both families have young men returning from war, but the strong bond between those two veterans (Jason Mitchell and Garrett Hedlund) doesn\u2019t transcend the entrenched barriers of Jim Crow or prevent the injustices that ensue. Rees, who also helped write the script, has with her cast produced a beautiful, grand-scale epic for a modest cost.\n\nWhere to watch: Netflix\n\n\u2014\n\nDenzel Washington in \u201cRoman J. Israel, Esq.\u201d Glen Wilson/Sony Pictures Entertainment\n\n\u2018Roman J. Israel, Esq.\u2019\n\nNominated for: best lead actor\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nDan Gilroy\u2019s follow-up to \u201cNightcrawler\u201d offers another obsessive loner on the fringes of society, this time a lumpen relic of criminal defense and activism who is deposited at a large firm after his longtime partner dies. Denzel Washington\u2019s lead performance earned \u201cRoman J. Israel, Esq.\u201d its sole Oscar nomination after an aborted theatrical run, but the film carries the same ragged nobility as its hero, lurching toward some difficult truths about how ideals square with real-world compromise. It deserves a second look \u2014 or at least the first it was denied.\n\nWhere to watch: Amazon, iTunes\n\n\u2014\n\nFrom left, Christopher Rivera, Brooklynn Prince and Valeria Cotto in \u201cThe Florida Project.\u201d A24\n\n\u2018The Florida Project\u2019\n\nNominated for: best supporting actor\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nIn the Magic Castle, a purple budget motel in the shadow of Disney World, a mischievous little girl (Brooklynn Prince) lives a childhood on the precipice as her mother (Bria Vinaite) hustles and scams to make the rent. By turns hilarious and heartbreaking, \u201cThe Florida Project\u201d recalls everything from \u201cThe Little Rascals\u201d to Fran\u00e7ois Truffaut\u2019s \u201cSmall Change,\u201d evoking the wild innocence of kids who grow up without boundaries or safeguards. Willem Dafoe does particularly strong work as the Magic Castle\u2019s put-upon manager, whose compassion is stretched to the limit.\n\nWhere to watch: Amazon, iTunes\n\n\u2014\n\nAna de Armas, left, and Ryan Gosling in \u201cBlade Runner 2049.\u201d Warner Bros.\n\n\u2018Blade Runner 2049\u2019\n\nNominated for: best production design, best cinematography, best original sound mixing, best visual effects\n\nbest production design, best cinematography, best original sound mixing, best visual effects Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nReviving \u201cBlade Runner\u201d for modern audiences seemed like a dodgy idea, running up against the impossible standards of a cult favorite \u2014 and the fact that mainstream audiences didn\u2019t swarm theaters for the 1982 original in the first place. Director Denis Villeneuve couldn\u2019t solve the second problem, but \u201cBlade Runner 2049\u201d does extend and enrich the mythology of this noir-soaked future dystopia, where androids known as replicants are rebelling against their human masters. The ace cinematographer Roger Deakins brings the rainy Los Angeles of the original back to life while also adding brilliant new bursts of color, particularly when the action shifts to Las Vegas.\n\nWhere to watch: Amazon, iTunes\n\n\u2014\n\nJudi Dench and Ali Fazal in \u201cVictoria & Abdul.\u201d Peter Mountain/Focus Features\n\n\u2018Victoria & Abdul\u2019\n\nNominated for: best costume design, best makeup and hair\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nWith seven nominations and one win, Judi Dench has became a perennial Oscar favorite, and the bona fides deepen for this royal drama from director Stephen Frears, who steered Helen Mirren to an Oscar for \u201cThe Queen\u201d in 2007. \u201cVictoria & Abdul\u201d didn\u2019t make Dench a nominee this time around (the film received two nominations in techical categories), but Dench\u2019s performance is still a pleasure: She\u2019s given plenty of latitude here as Queen Victoria, a dyspeptic ruler who takes a surprising interest in Abdul Karim, an Indian Muslim who challenges her assumptions and earns an important role in her court.\n\nWhere to watch: Amazon, iTunes\n\n\u2014\n\nHugh Jackman as the title character (a.k.a. the Wolverine) in \u201cLogan.\u201d Ben Rothstein/20th Century Fox\n\n\u2018Logan\u2019\n\nNominated for: best adapted screenplay\n\nbest adapted screenplay Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nThe glossy, PG-13 homogeneity of superhero movies has needed some pushback for a while now, and James Mangold\u2019s violent, hard-R twist on the X-Men mythology is a welcome shift of expectations, an existential Western that feels more like \u201cUnforgiven\u201d than an effects-heavy mutant team-up. In his final turn as Wolverine, Hugh Jackman plays the washed-up hero of a mutant race on the verge of extinction, logging enough hours as a limo driver to care for the ailing Charles Xavier in exile, but otherwise doing little to aid humanity. That changes when he agrees to drive an 11-year-old with extraordinary powers to a safe haven far to the north, but the journey comes at a steep cost.\n\nWhere to watch: HBO, iTunes\n\n\u2014\n\nAnimated\n\nA scene from \u201cLoving Vincent.\u201d Good Deed Entertainment\n\n\u2018Loving Vincent\u2019\n\nNominated for: best animated feature\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nSeveral major directors have ruminated over the life of Vincent Van Gogh, including Vincente Minnelli (\u201cLust For Life\u201d), Robert Altman (\u201cVincent & Theo\u201d) and Akira Kurosawa (\u201cDreams\u201d), but none with the unique texture of \u201cLoving Vincent,\u201d which bills itself as \u201cthe world\u2019s first fully painted feature film.\u201d The unmistakable colors and swirls of Van Gogh\u2019s work have been used here to illustrate the mysterious circumstances that led to his death. All told, the animators constructed their film out of about 65,000 hand-painted frames.\n\nWhere to watch: Amazon, iTunes\n\n\u2014\n\nTim (voiced by Miles Bakshi), left, and Boss Baby (voiced by Alec Baldwin) in \u201cThe Boss Baby.\u201d DreamWorks Animation\n\n\u2018The Boss Baby\u2019\n\nNominated for: best animated feature\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nThe nation\u2019s children were most likely not crying out for an animated feature full of references to \u201cGlengarry Glen Ross,\u201d but someone at 20th Century Fox must have had the premium leads, because \u201cThe Boss Baby\u201d brought in a half-billion at the box office. Popular success accounts for its nomination more than critical approval, but Alec Baldwin does persuasive voice work as the executive tot, and the plot \u2014 about a pint-size secret agent who goes undercover to thwart a dastardly scheme by the head of Puppy Co. \u2014 has a high adorability factor.\n\nWhere to watch: Netflix, Amazon\n\n\u2014\n\n\n\n0\n\nDocumentary\n\nThomas Sung, the founder of Abacus Federal Savings Bank, in the documentary \u201cAbacus: Small Enough to Jail.\u201d Sean Lyness/PBS Distribution\n\n\u2018Abacus: Small Enough to Jail\u2019\n\nNominated for: best documentary feature\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nNone of the major lenders responsible for the subprime mortgage crisis faced any significant consequences for their role in triggering the 2008 recession. But populist sentiment against the banking industry led the City of New York to bring charges against Abacus Federal Savings Bank, a family-run business that primarily serves Manhattan\u2019s Chinatown. The veteran director Steve James (\u201cHoop Dreams,\u201d \u201cStevie\u201d) explores the facts of the case from the inside, suggesting that a Chinese-American family became an easy scapegoat for a tougher political dilemma.\n\nWhere to watch: Amazon Prime, iTunes\n\n\u2014\n\nBryan Fogel in \u201cIcarus.\u201d Netflix\n\n\u2018Icarus\u2019\n\nNominated for: best documentary feature\n\nbest documentary feature Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nActivist documentaries may raise awareness, but there\u2019s a much shorter history of documentaries that directly affect social or political change. \u201cIcarus\u201d is one of them, stumbling accidentally into a doping scandal that led to Russia\u2019s expulsion from the 2018 Winter Olympics. Setting out to make a kind of \u201cSuper Size Me\u201d for cycling, the amateur cyclist Bryan Fogel wanted to see how he might react to performance-enhancing drugs. To that end, he found Dr. Grigory Rodchenkov, who turned out to be the architect behind a massive state-run Russian doping program. The doctor was willing to share some astonishing secrets.\n\nWhere to watch: Netflix\n\n\u2014\n\nA scene from \u201cLast Men in Aleppo.\u201d Grasshopper Film\n\n\u2018Last Men in Aleppo\u2019\n\nNominated for: best documentary feature\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nComing on the heels of Orlando von Einsiedel\u2019s Oscar-winning 2015 short, \u201cThe White Helmets,\u201d this fly-on-the-wall feature documentary from Feras Fayyad follows a search-and-rescue team as it picks through the rubble of the war-ravaged Syrian city of Aleppo, in search of survivors. Although the courage and dedication of its subjects are an inspiration, \u201cLast Men in Aleppo\u201d doesn\u2019t gloss over the horrors they discover or offer false hope about the ruined lives of the survivors. It also doesn\u2019t underplay the risks involved in joining the White Helmets and possibly coming under fire because of it.\n\nWhere to watch: Netflix, iTunes\n\n\u2014\n\nDirector Yance Ford\u2019s mother, Barbara Dunmore, circa 1958. Yanceville Films, via Netflix\n\n\u2018Strong Island\u2019\n\nNominated for: best documentary feature\n\n: best documentary feature Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nTwenty years after his brother\u2019s shooting death at the hands of a white mechanic, the director Yance Ford revisits the case \u2014 the shooting was determined to be an act of self-defense \u2014 and the ways it tore his middle class African-American family apart. Beyond this personal story about racial injustice and the gradual shift in Ford\u2019s gender and sexual identity, \u201cStrong Island\u201d is a fascinating look at black families on Long Island who got a taste of the middle-class dream, but lived in de facto segregation.\n\nWhere to watch: Netflix\n\n\u2014\n\nForeign Language Features\n\nA scene from \u201cOn Body and Soul.\u201d Netflix\n\n\u2018On Body and Soul\u2019\n\nNominated for: best foreign language film\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nAfter 18 years away from feature filmmaking, the Hungarian director Ildiko Enyedi (\u201cMy Twentieth Century\u201d) returns with this strange and beguiling metaphysical love story about two workers at a Budapest abattoir who meet each other in their dreams. Enyedi contrasts their quiet, delicate courtship as deer in a snowbound dreamscape with their far more awkward chemistry in the real world, where the man has a disabled hand, the woman is on the autism spectrum, and cattle are being led to the slaughter.\n\nWhere to watch: Netflix\n\n\u2014\n\nA scene from \u201cThe Square.\u201d Magnolia Pictures\n\n\u2018The Square\u2019\n\nNominated for: best foreign language film\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nThis Palme d\u2019Or-winning satire from Ruben Ostlund about the pretentious follies of a modern art museum may be akin to shooting fish in a barrel, but the fish had it coming. With the controlled, exquisitely brittle style he brought to his previous film, \u201cForce Majeure,\u201d Ostlund follows a put-upon curator (Claes Bang) as he unveils a controversial exhibit that asks visitors to participate in a social experiment on altruism and trust. Needless to say, society falls short of the challenge.\n\nWhere to watch: Amazon, Google Play, Vudu, YouTube\n\n\u2014", "title": "Oscars 2018: Where to Stream the Nominated Movies", "authors": ["Scott Tobias"]} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "The Globes also took place less than a week after hundreds of powerful women in entertainment unveiled the Time\u2019s Up initiative, which includes a $15 million legal defense fund for victims of misconduct, among other components.\n\nTime\u2019s Up\u2019s timing was, so to speak, golden, as would be expected from women with a firm grasp on the art and power of marketing. News that women would be wearing only black gowns to the Globes and eschewing talk of fashion and brands to highlight gender disparities only whet the media\u2019s appetite. (That said, the Bagger heard ample mention of labels on the red carpet, as she was sandwiched alongside a correspondent from InStyle.) The same novel excitement will probably extend to the Screen Actors Guild Awards on Jan. 21, when, thanks to a plan hatched by two women overseeing the show, the host (Kristen Bell), along with the awards presenters, will all be \u2014 with possibly a few exceptions \u2014 women.\n\nThe Oscars, have a hard act to follow, and not just because they\u2019re a way more snoozy event that doesn\u2019t allow attendees to drink at their seats. The academy and the show\u2019s broadcaster, ABC, have a financial interest in high ratings, and a sense of decorum adds a leaden note to the show. The academy has more than 8,000 members and multiple branches, so even when many people agree on a cause, like fighting #OscarsSoWhite, there can still be all-white acting nominees two years in a row.\n\nWho ends up attending or being invited to the Oscars will also play a big role. The narrative of this year\u2019s Globes was set less by the show\u2019s organizers and host, Seth Meyers \u2014 though he deserves kudos for artfully threading a very tricky needle \u2014 than by the women who attended and were heavily involved in Time\u2019s Up, including America Ferrera, Eva Longoria, Kerry Washington and Reese Witherspoon. Because the Oscars award movies, there will be far fewer television actresses on hand.\n\nAlthough there may be organizing among actresses once the Oscar nominations are announced on Jan. 23, potential nominees like Meryl Streep (for \u201cThe Post\u201d) and Michelle Williams (\u201cAll the Money in the World\u201d), who each brought feminist activists as their plus-ones to the Globes, have a heftier load to carry. And will best actress front-runners like Frances McDormand (\u201cThree Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri\u201d), Saoirse Ronan (\u201cLady Bird\u201d) and Sally Hawkins (\u201cThe Shape of Water\u201d) publicly endorse Time\u2019s Up as heartily? Ms. McDormand delivered a ferocious acceptance speech after winning the Globe for best actress, saying she was delighted \u201cto be part of the tectonic shift\u201d in Hollywood\u2019s power structure, but also that she keeps her politics private.\n\nAnd the Oscars are not happening until March 4, a long way off. Lest we forget, the tone of the 2017 awards seasons was also set at the Globes, when Meryl Streep delivered her \u201chooks in my heart\u201d speech calling out Donald J. Trump a week and a half before his inauguration. The 2017 Screen Actors Guild Awards rode a similar wage of outrage. Held nine days after Mr. Trump became president, and two days after his administration hastily instituted its chaotic Muslim travel ban, the SAGs were suffused with a sense of urgency as actors, one by one, announced their opposition.", "title": "Oscars So Awkward? Click through the slide show to see highlights from the week.", "title": "Our Favorite Photos From the Men\u2019s Shows in Milan", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-08 00:00:00", "text": "The Reader Center is one way we in the newsroom are trying to connect with you, by highlighting your perspectives and experiences and offering insight into how we work.\n\nReaders reacted strongly to our obituary for Thomas S. Monson, who served as prophet and head of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints for nearly a decade. In hundreds of messages to The New York Times and dozens of comments on the obituary, readers, including many Mormons, wrote that the obituary focused too narrowly on the politics and controversies of the Mormon Church and overlooked Mr. Monson\u2019s contributions to the community.\n\nHere are some of their comments, which have been lightly edited for length and clarity.\n\nAs a gay Mormon I can state that while President Monson\u2019s policies were controversial to some, they do not reflect his life teachings, which focused on service and selfless love. That The Times only focused on the politics and not the teachings that defined him is disgusting. \u2014 Zachary, in a message to the Reader Center Hugo Ch\u00e1vez? Hugh Hefner? They had glamorous obituaries compared to this man, who dedicated his life to serving and helping others. \u2014 Jon Wilson, in a letter to the editor Decisions he made (not having women ordained to the priesthood or accepting gay marriage) were included without any fair explanation of his beliefs/Mormon beliefs regarding the subjects and without any context. I would accept it as normal that Mormon beliefs or church standards might be viewed as controversial and might be brought up in this obituary, but it was done without any taste. \u2014 Chantelle Wood, in an email to the newsroom\n\nWe drew questions from readers\u2019 feedback, and William McDonald, our obituaries editor, responded to them.\n\nMany readers have pointed out that much of the obituary focused largely on the Mormon Church\u2019s controversial and politically divisive issues. They say Mr. Monson\u2019s life included strong community and humanitarian work as the leader of a large religious following and wish the obit had reflected more of that. How do you respond to those readers?", "title": "Our Obituaries Editor on Coverage of Former Mormon Leader Thomas Monson", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "WeCroak, Mr. Bergwall said, was born of Bhutanese folklore saying that to be happy, one ought to contemplate death five times a day. For the more than 9,000 users of WeCroak, most in their 20s and 30s, he said, there is no time like the moment to get a grip on life by embracing mortality.\n\nHovering near the top of the App Store\u2019s paid health and fitness chart, the app, which I first read about in The Atlantic, is an exhortation to mindfulness. \u201cMeditation urges you to focus on your breath,\u201d Mr. Bergwall said. \u201cIt\u2019s the same thing with remembering that you\u2019re mortal. You forget, so you need something strong, someone telling you straight out, being blunt about it.\u201d\n\nThat very bluntness is a provocation. Death until recently was often a conversational taboo, dark fodder for goth sites, maybe, but otherwise invoked discreetly, if at all, in spirit-soothing euphemisms.\n\nPhoto\n\nNow it\u2019s trending.\n\nThe app, on iOS and Android, could not be simpler. Ad-free, it is there strictly to remind you that the end is near, its message accompanied by alternately somber and uplifting homilies: \u201cThe grave has no sunny corners\u201d or, more motivating, \u201cBegin again the story of your life.\u201d The words come from a variety of sources, including work by Emily Dickinson, Pablo Neruda, Henry David Thoreau, Charles Bukowksi, Pablo Neruda, Lao Tzu and Margaret Atwood.\n\nIt is but the latest in a flurry of pop culture death fare that is finding a receptive audience: \u201cCoco,\u201d Pixar\u2019s animated feature about a boy exploring the land of the dead, and \u201cThe Gentle Art of Swedish Death Cleaning,\u201d a quirky housekeeping primer encouraging the reader to tidy up while there\u2019s still time, have struck a chord with audiences. The book \u201cDeath, a Graveside Companion,\u201d by Joanna Ebenstein, dense with death-related imagery, may not be sweeping the marketplace, but it sends a strong signal just the same.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nA decade ago, Ms. Ebenstein started a blog about death and bereavement called Morbid Anatomy. Sensing that the subject, long hushed, might put off her readers \u2014 and her employers at Scholastic magazine, where she worked at the time \u2014 she was reluctant to sign her posts, using only her initials.\n\n\u201cNow people are responding,\u201d said Ms. Ebenstein, who is also the founder of the Morbid Anatomy Museum in Brooklyn (now defunct). \u201cThey think the discussion is cool, part of a cultural movement to explore the shadow side.\u201d This is especially true, she noted, among young people trying to connect with their spiritual selves.\n\nPhoto\n\nAn older generation may well be resistant to the outing of death. Boomers especially are attached to the notion that they are their own entrepreneurs, running their bodies like corporations. \u201cTheir idea is to give death the slip, \u201c said Tracy Morgan, a psychoanalyst in New York. \u201cThings may be spinning out of control, but it\u2019s, \u2018I\u2019m eating well, I\u2019m exercising, I\u2019m so damned virtuous, I can do things to my face, I can control my fertility. I\u2019ll survive.\u2019\u201d\n\n\u201cIf you\u2019re the master of death, you\u2019re the ultimate entrepreneur,\u201d said Ms. Morgan, who recently downloaded WeCroak herself.\n\nThis current fascination may attest as well to a saturnine swing in the sociopolitical consciousness.\n\n\u201cIt seems to me that the apocalyptic sensibility of the late 1990s going into the 2000s has continued,\u201d said Lucio Benedetto, a historian who teaches philosophy at the Hockaday School, a private school for girls in Dallas. \u201cThere is this great fear of things coming to an end, a fear of what some people consider to be the demise of traditional American values,\u201d supplanted, he said, by developments like the rise of the alt-right and a perceptible thinning of the blue-collar class.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cIn television dramas like \u2018The Walking Dead,\u2019 dystopia seems to be this constant theme,\u201d Mr. Benedetto said. \u201cIt\u2019s like you\u2019re not just reading a Philip K. Dick novel but actually living it.\u201d\n\nWhen Mr. Benedetto asked his students to download the app, he got little resistance. Some were just curious, while others found it useful to assimilate the concept of finality into their thinking. \u201cFew of these students seemed aware that people are dying around them,\u201d he said. \u201cMost of them don\u2019t even know we\u2019re at war.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFor users like me, WeCroak alerts have become routine enough to ignore, at worst a gnat-like irritant.\n\n\u201cI wanted it to scare me more, to jolt me into sort of tripping the light fantastic,\u201d Ms. Morgan said. \u201cThat\u2019s not happening.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Of the Moment The lifestyle newsletter from the Styles, Travel and Food sections, offering the latest trends to news you can use. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nHer complaint is in line with those of users requesting more somber or harrowing quotations to accompany the central message. Mr. Thomas, who wrote code for the app, finds himself fielding requests for bleaker, grittier messages. \u201cSo far, the quotes are rather tame and contemplative,\u201d one user complained. \u201cI thought they\u2019d be more hard-hitting.\u201d\n\nYet confronting even a sweet-talking reaper can foster a kind of self-mastery. Karen Rosenberg, 50, a corporate recruiter in Miami, finds WeCroak\u2019s daily alerts liberating. \u201cI think, \u2018Oh my gosh, I can wash dishes with a smile. I can talk on the phone,\u2019 knowing all the while that this life is not a dress rehearsal,\u201d she said. \u201cIt helps me enjoy the moment.\u201d\n\nSimon Arizpe, a 27-year-old artist in Brooklyn who makes pop-up books, had his first brush with death in a fire that raced through his office. \u201cBeing so close to mortality in such a surprising way was a rude awakening,\u201d he said, one that was reinforced in a positive way by the app. \u201cIt helped me suddenly realize that, oh, nothing is precious. In a way, that\u2019s kind of relaxing.\u201d\n\nWhen he downloaded the app, Mr. Arizpe got blowback from his friends. \u201cSome of them were kind of disgusted,\u201d he recalled. \u201cThey asked, \u2018Why would you want to do that?\u2019\u201d\n\nChallenged, he dug in his heels. \u201cWith so many stimuli coming at you, it\u2019s nice to have something in your pocket that slows you down, lets you look at the big picture,\u201d he said. \u201cBesides, what could be more alluring than to break a taboo.\u201d", "title": "Outing Death", "authors": ["Ruth La Ferla"]} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cIn Vulgar Terms, Trump Disparages Some Immigrants\u201d (front page, Jan. 12):\n\nWhy do we continue to be shocked by any comment made by President Trump? He has demonstrated his lack of decency, concern for human rights and respect for democracy repeatedly.\n\nWhat should shock us is the fact that Republican leaders say nothing when the president speaks of people from \u201cshithole countries\u201d like Haiti or in Africa. Republicans in Congress have decided they will stick with the president no matter what he says or does in hopes that they can save their seats and their power.\n\nSUSAN SHELTON, FALMOUTH, MASS.\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nPresident Trump should skip Mar-a-Lago and spend a weekend in Mankessim, Ghana, on the farm of my friend Adjei, whom I first met nearly 40 years ago while serving in the Peace Corps. Contrary to his racist stereotyping, the president would learn from Adjei about the brutal economics of successfully farming eight acres using only a machete in the relentless tropical heat. He would see a work ethic that shames our own.\n\nDespite having a small house with no electricity or running water, Adjei and his wife have educated five children on a daily income equal to a cappuccino. There are tens of millions of rural Africans living like Adjei. President Trump should get to know at least one.", "title": "Opinion | Outrage Over Trump\u2019s Vulgar, Racist Slur", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "Tom\u00e1s Guti\u00e9rrez Alea\u2019s \u201cMemories of Underdevelopment,\u201d shot in Cuba some 50 years ago and showing for a week at Film Forum in an excellent 4K digital restoration, is a first-rate movie and a remarkable document \u2014 not least for the reception it first received in the United States.\n\n\u201cMemories\u201d was adapted from Edmundo Desnoes\u2019s novel, published in English as \u201cInconsolable Memories.\u201d An ambivalent account of life in Castro\u2019s Cuba, written in the first person, Mr. Desnoes\u2019s post-revolutionary novel has affinities to pre-revolutionary Russian literature. His protagonist, Sergio, a 38-year-old Havana native, is neither for nor against the revolution. An indolent bourgeois living off the rent from a building his father \u2014 gone to Miami \u2014 left behind, he is what Turgenev might call \u201ca superfluous man.\u201d\n\nSergio imagines himself European, and as played by the urbane Sergio Corrieri, Alea\u2019s protagonist reminded some of European actors like Marcello Mastroianni and Jean-Louis Trintignant. Contemptuous of those who have fled Cuba and indifferent to the Castro supporters around him, Sergio indulges in erotic reveries, entertaining fantasies about his maid and memories of a high school sweetheart.\n\nDrifting into an affair with a flighty teenager, Elena (Daisy Granados), Sergio equates her lack of education with Cuba\u2019s underdevelopment, taking her to museums that, in a particularly sardonic sequence, include Ernest Hemingway\u2019s villa. Late in the movie, reality crashes in \u2014 first with the arrival of Elena\u2019s irate family and second in the form of the October 1962 missile crisis.", "title": "Outside Cuba\u2019s Revolution, Looking In", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-07 00:00:00", "text": "Based on reports from family members and friends outside Evin Prison on Sunday, as well as official sources, dozens of people have been released, but hundreds more remain in prison.\n\nA group of reformist activists wrote an open letter published on Sunday on the front page of the newspaper Etemaad calling for the release of those arrested during the demonstrations, saying that Iranians had the right to protest peacefully.\n\n\u201cPeople feel belittled and hopeless,\u201d the letter said.\n\nMore than 100 people were gathered outside Evin Prison on Sunday: family members and friends of the detained, the women shielding themselves from the snow with umbrellas; a well-known political activist, Mohammad Nourizad; and a group of dervishes who had set up a makeshift camp under one of the prison\u2019s watchtowers, singing an old song from their native province, Lorestan.\n\n\u201cOh mother, mother, it is time for fighting, it is time to make friends with the rifle,\u201d a man with an imposing mustache sang, with others repeating the lines after him.\n\nThey gathered around a campfire, having brought an ample supply of wood and tents in which to sleep. They had, effectively, set up a protest camp in front of the prison.\n\n\u201cThe political prisoners must be freed,\u201d they chanted as people filmed them with their phones, and as guards carrying machine guns on their shoulders looked down from walls and watchtowers above.\n\nEvin Prison, a sprawling complex built partly inside a mountain, is Tehran\u2019s oldest and most notorious prison. It has played an important role in Iran\u2019s contemporary history, housing political and criminal prisoners since 1972. Some of the cells were designed for solitary confinement, and the Islamic Revolutionary Guards Corps and the Ministry of Intelligence and Security control their own sections of the building.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIran is a country where activism or political dissent can often lead to charges and imprisonment. Hundreds of journalists, bloggers and activists have been detained over the years. Charges can come down even against those seemingly not involved in opposition politics, like Jason Rezaian, an Iranian-American reporter for The Washington Post who was held in Evin Prison for 544 days on charges of espionage, a claim he strongly denies.\n\nWhen Iran faced its last major antigovernment demonstrations, the so-called Green Movement of 2009, millions took to the streets and thousands were arrested, requiring temporary holding centers to be opened because Evin was overcrowded. In one, the Kahrizak detention center in Tehran, some protesters were tortured, and three died.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIran\u2019s supreme leader called for an investigation of that case, and several officers were given jail sentences. Not all have served those sentences, however, the local news media has reported.\n\nAli, a plump man wearing a brown beret who would not give his surname for fear of retribution by the authorities, was waiting in the snow outside Evin Prison for the release of his friend Hossein, who was arrested on Dec. 29.\n\nHossein had been at the demonstrations because \u201che was angry, like many people,\u201d Ali said. Hossein soon realized a man had grabbed the cellphone of a woman who had been filming the protesters.\n\n\u201cHossein chased him, but he turned out to be a plainclothes police officer,\u201d Ali said. \u201cI\u2019m bringing the deed of his house so he can post for bail.\u201d\n\nThe entrance of Evin Prison is near a busy highway, and metal sheets have been placed on overpasses to prevent people from looking down. But a side road provides direct access to the prison, and a parade of Iranian-made cars, a garbage truck, motorcycles and a high-end-model Mercedes-Benz drove past at one point on Sunday, with many rolling down their windows to see the people waiting in front of the prison.\n\n\u201cPoor families,\u201d said Hamid Mousavi, a retiree driving a taxi. \u201cThey must be so worried.\u201d\n\nSiavash, who works for the Telecommunications Ministry, said he had come to Evin to bail out his brother-in-law, Siamak, whom he described as a womanizer.\n\n\u201cHe wanted to meet women, I guess, and have some fun,\u201d Siavash said \u201cHe\u2019ll be freed today, I\u2019m happy. He\u2019s been calling us a couple of times a day. He wants to come home.\u201d", "title": "Outside Iran\u2019s Most Notorious Prison, Calls for Loved Ones to Be Freed", "authors": ["Thomas Erdbrink"]} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "Two years ago, the collector Patricia Phelps de Cisneros donated 102 Latin American artworks to the Museum of Modern Art. It turns out that was just the overture: On Wednesday she announced that her organization will donate 202 additional works to six international museums, including MoMA.\n\nThe donation includes work by 91 artists from 22 countries across Latin America, most of whom are still living. They include Jac Leirner (Brazil), Luis Camnitzer (Uruguay), Amalia Pica (Argentina) and Regina Jos\u00e9 Galindo (Guatemala). While the earliest works date back to the middle of the 20th century, a majority of them were made after 2000, and range from sculptures to videos to tapestries.\n\nMs. Cisneros, a prominent collector of Latin American art and a member of the MoMA board, said she has been working on this project \u2014 accumulating art with the intention of eventually bringing it to a wider international audience \u2014 for 40 years. \u201cOur mission has always been to build bridges of understanding between Latin America and the U.S. and the rest of the world, rather than to build walls,\u201d she said in a phone interview.\n\nNinety of the 202 pieces will go to MoMA, where Ms. Cisneros has been involved for decades. \u201cShe has been a catalyst in transforming the way the MoMA thinks about Latin American art,\u201d Glenn D. Lowry the museum\u2019s director, said in a phone interview. He said a team of curators worked with the staff at the Colecci\u00f3n Patricia Phelps de Cisneros to comb through its vast contemporary holdings, with the intention of introducing new artists, like Ms. Galindo, to MoMA\u2019s collection. \u201cIn a way, it\u2019s even more important than the first gift,\u201d Mr. Lowry said.", "title": "Over 200 Latin American Artworks Are Headed to MoMA and Other Museums", "authors": []} {"date": "2017-12-31 00:00:00", "text": "Minutes before Sunday Mass at St. Martin of Tours Roman Catholic Church in the Bronx, as the music began, a man approached the Rev. Cosme Fernandes.\n\n\u201cGood morning, Father,\u201d the man said. \u201cI used to live in this neighborhood and I just drove in a truck full of clothes, but they told us they can\u2019t take any more donations. What do I do?\u201d\n\nFather Fernandes had no answer for the man, who had brought the donations for the survivors of a fire that killed 12 people on Thursday. The fire, the deadliest in New York City in more than 25 years, destroyed an apartment building in the mostly-immigrant neighborhood of Belmont, two blocks from the church.\n\nA collection drive organized by the Police and Fire Departments turned into a remarkable outpouring of support that was ended after just one day because of the overwhelming response. On Sunday, people were turned away.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThe way we\u2019ve received support from the Bronx and beyond is a sign that the victims are not alone, that we are united,\u201d Father Fernandes said during the homily at a Spanish Mass. Father Fernandes, 49, also reminded the congregation that Emmanuel Mensah, an Army National Guard soldier who died trying to get people out of the building, was once a parishioner.", "title": "Overwhelmed by Donations for Survivors of Fatal Bronx Fire", "authors": ["Luis Ferr\u00e9-Sadurn\u00ed"]} {"date": "2018-01-03 00:00:00", "text": "My brief experience thinking of myself as transgender was jarring and confusing. I\u2019d flinch if a girl referred to me as she or her; women often weaponized these pronouns against me when they viewed me as a threat or wanted to make fun of me. But I\u2019d also cringe when boys referred to me as he or him, because those words felt too sharp, as if they were being used to remind me of my place; and when they came from boys I desired, I felt completely undesirable. I didn\u2019t assert my truth in language, because I didn\u2019t know how.\n\nThe older that I got, the less I felt represented in the transgender narrative. It simply did not fit. Some days I felt comfortable being a gay boy. Some days I felt at home as a beautiful girl. There were also times where I felt like neither, or both. When I got to college I started to experiment with androgyny. I cropped my long, bouncy, black weave into a blond and crimson Mohawk. I started to wear my clothes a bit looser so that people couldn\u2019t identify my gender.\n\nIf I\u2019d had access to the right language, it\u2019s possible that I might have felt empowered by this change. Instead, people on campus began referring to me as \u201cit\u201d or \u201che-she.\u201d Eventually I folded into myself. I cut my hair off, wore drastically less makeup and took to wearing all black clothing, because I was constantly mourning the identities I might have had, that the world had slowly killed. I became increasingly depressed and even attempted to end my life.\n\nIn the years since, inclusion in language has blossomed. Now we not only have glorious and complex examples of what it means to be transgender, we also have words for people like me who simply don\u2019t feel at home as male or female, or being referred to as he or she. Now we have words like gender neutral, gender deviant, gender nonconforming and non-binary making and taking up space. Now we have pronouns like \u201cthey/them\u201d and \u201czi/zer,\u201d among many others.\n\nSadly, it feels as though I missed the bus. I am completely at home now with my male identification. I don\u2019t know whether this was a natural progression or if I was beaten into submission by the world. However I got here, I feel comfortable with my \u201che\u201d and \u201chim,\u201d but I know that I lost a lot in my retreat. At times I still fear that I\u2019m not being my most authentic self.\n\nLanguage is meant to be inclusive, but most important, it is meant to expand, to be updated and challenged by the times. However, language can also repress: It\u2019s not a coincidence that the people who are most often allowed to deem the world too sensitive and politically correct are the ones who wield power and privilege over others. For black people, this means white people; for gay people, this means straight people; and for trans and gender-nonconforming persons, this means the world.", "title": "Opinion | P.C. Language Saved My Life", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "LONDON \u2014 Paddle8, the online art auctioneer known for selling a one-of-a-kind Wu-Tang Clan album to Martin Shkreli, has had a rough 12 months, including the bankruptcy of its parent company.\n\nNow Paddle8 is trying a new tack: merging with The Native, a Swiss technology and e-commerce company, and adopting the use of blockchain, the technology that underpins virtual currencies like Bitcoin.\n\nPaddle8 announced on Tuesday that it had taken an investment from The Native, creating what the two say is a partnership meant to adapt online art sales \u2014 and potentially more \u2014 to an age of wealthy millennials well versed in virtual currencies.\n\nTheir first partnership will be Paddle8 Lab, which is meant to help introduce tech to online art and luxury sales and will draw on The Native\u2019s Blockchain Lab division.", "title": "Paddle8, Online Art Auctioneer, Is Merging With Swiss Tech Company", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-22 00:00:00", "text": "Over the 23-year period of the study, the rate of eye injuries caused by nonpowder guns rose by 168.8 percent. Dr. Smith said the study did not explore the reason for the increase.\n\nBut it\u2019s not a new issue; as long ago as 1911, The New York Times reported on an 8-year-old in Washington Heights who had been injured by an air gun and had lost the sight in his right eye.\n\nBasketball is known to be a high-risk sport for eye injuries, Dr. Smith said. Both the American Academy of Pediatrics and the American Academy of Ophthalmology recommend that all players wear protective eyewear with polycarbonate lenses; they\u2019d like to see that required by the National Federation of State High School Associations, which regulates high school sports.\n\n\u201cIt would be rare to see someone wearing protective eyewear in basketball,\u201d Dr. Smith said. \u201cThe culture of that sport hasn\u2019t changed yet. We need to work with the coaches.\u201d\n\nAs far as baseball and softball, the study calls for face masks on batting helmets (currently required in softball but not in Little League or high school baseball) and face guards for defensive players (currently optional).\n\nBut to prevent almost half of the more serious eye injuries, you need to reach the kids shooting the nonpowder guns \u2014 the kinds that some parents may think of as harmless. \u201cEveryone in the group should be wearing protective eyewear,\u201d Dr. Smith said. \u201cIf we are looking at all the sport and recreation eye injuries, the most severe are being caused by nonpowder guns, therefore we should especially focus our efforts to prevent those injuries.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nSo the recommendations are adult supervision and protective eyewear, along with some special gun-related precautions, like teaching children to use targets that prevent ricocheting when they use BB or pellet guns. \u201cThese can be life-altering injuries: In a second, an injury can occur that will be with you the rest of your life,\u201d Dr. Smith said.\n\nToy guns for young children \u2014 as opposed to nonpowder guns \u2014 raise other issues for many parents. Long before children reach the age of BB guns and pellet guns, many are drawn to toy guns, which do not pose these same safety concerns about eye injuries, but bring up questions about behavior and aggression.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nI remember the efforts of my first son to foil the no-guns rule when he was a toddler in a day care center in Cambridge, Mass. His teachers kept a sharp eye out for any child biting away parts of a sandwich to create a gun shape or constructing possible armaments out of Tinker Toys or Legos. But my son \u2014 the child of a predictably liberal pediatrician \u2014 claimed he was building a bird feeder, then pointed it at a classmate and said, \u201cBang, I killed you with my bird feeder.\u201d\n\nBrad Bushman, a professor of communication and psychology at the Ohio State University in Columbus, said the experimental evidence about toy guns shows that \u201cThe mere sight of a gun makes you more aggressive.\u201d This is known as the \u201cweapons effect.\u201d It\u2019s not just that more aggressive children tend to play with guns; in studies where children were randomized to play with a gun or with some nonaggressive toy, he said, playing with the gun led to more aggressive behavior.\n\nIn his study published last year, children from 8 to 12 years old were randomized to see PG movies either with or without guns in them (the movies were otherwise identical). Then the children were observed in a room that contained a cabinet with an unloaded gun in a closed drawer. The children who had watched the version of the movie with guns, Dr. Bushman said, held the gun for an average of 53 seconds, compared to 11 seconds for the children who had watched the no-gun version. And they pulled the trigger on average three times, compared to no times. \u201cOne kid put the gun against his friend\u2019s head and pulled the trigger,\u201d he said. \u201cAnother pointed it out the window at passers-by on the street.\u201d\n\nHe cited a statistic that less than 60 percent of gun owners secure their guns. \u201cLock up the guns and keep the ammunition separate,\u201d he said. \u201cDo so in an opaque container, not a glass cabinet \u2014 just seeing a gun increases aggression.\u201d\n\nAnd not surprisingly, he would not recommend toy guns of any kind, but would advocate using the topic as an occasion for discussion: \u201cI think parents need to talk to their kids about why they don\u2019t want them to play with guns,\u201d he said.\n\nWhatever you decide \u2014 or whatever you think you have decided, whatever your child ends up doing, younger or older, keep those eyes safe. Even if you ban toy guns when your child is young, he may still come up against paintball guns and pellet guns; insist on protective eyewear, and keep those eyes safe.\n\nParenthood is full of challenges \u2014 you often have to find ways to say, don\u2019t do such and such, but if you do, keep yourself safe \u2014 those of you with middle school and high school age children know this, you\u2019ve had those conversations about alcohol and drugs and sex \u2014 or if you haven\u2019t, you should.\n\nSo here\u2019s one more kind of safety to consider: Children using nonpowder guns need to wear protective eyewear. Eyes are worth protecting, whatever you\u2019re aiming at.", "title": "Paintball, BB and Pellet Gun Injuries Pose Serious Risk to Children\u2019s Eyes", "authors": ["Perri Klass", "The Checkup"]} {"date": "2018-01-28 00:00:00", "text": "The decision, which could affect as much as $1.3 billion in annual aid, came three days after President Trump complained on Twitter that Pakistan had \u201cgiven us nothing but lies & deceit\u201d and accused it of providing \u201csafe haven to the terrorists we hunt in Afghanistan.\u201d\n\nStatements from the Pakistan army\u2019s media wing have described General Bajwa as being outspoken in conversations with American generals and government officials. In a call this month with Gen. Joseph L. Votel, the head of the United States Central Command, for example, General Bajwa talked of a \u201csense of betrayal\u201d within the country over Mr. Trump\u2019s tweet, the army said.\n\nThe relationship between Pakistan and the United States has been one of \u201callies with an up and down history,\u201d said Maj. Gen. Asif Ghafoor, the spokesman of the Pakistani military.\n\nSince the announcement from the Trump administration, General Bajwa has stressed that Pakistan will not seek the resumption of American security aid and that the country is not dependent on it. Since last year, he has been reaching out to countries like China, Iran, Qatar, Russia and Saudi Arabia \u2014 building contacts that could help him cement his grip on power and reduce Pakistan\u2019s reliance on the United States.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn the view of the Pakistan military, both General Bajwa and his predecessor, Gen. Raheel Sharif, can point to victories against militants who have attacked the country\u2019s civilian population, which has increased the army\u2019s popularity.\n\nGeneral Sharif during his tenure \u201ccleared leftover strongholds of terrorists in northwestern Pakistan,\u201d General Ghafoor, the military spokesman, said. \u201cGeneral Bajwa is taking it forward to enduring peace and stability not only in Pakistan, but the region as well.\u201d\n\nGeneral Bajwa is also pursuing fencing along the 1,685-mile length of the Pakistan-Afghanistan border to help curb cross-border movements by militants. And he has pushed for the repatriation of Afghan refugees to keep militants from hiding in the country by mingling with refugees in settlement camps.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAnd Pakistan, General Ghafoor said, \u201cremains committed to continue contributing all efforts to bring peace in Afghanistan and understands U.S. concerns.\u201d\n\nOn the domestic front, critics say that General Bajwa is essentially following the same institutional policies that have made the military an overarching influence in the country.\n\n\u201cFor the last one and a half years, civilian-military ties have hit their lowest ebb,\u201d said Zahid Hussain, a widely read political columnist and analyst. \u201cThe army is now much more assertive. It has greatly increased its clout.\u201d\n\nSince being removed from the prime minister\u2019s office, Mr. Sharif has gone on a political offensive. He has drawn enormous crowds at public rallies and, in sometimes veiled and sometimes not-so-veiled references, has accused the judiciary and the military of hatching a conspiracy to remove him from office.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. There are also worries that the vote may be delayed.\n\nPhoto\n\nGeneral Ghafoor, the military spokesman, played down the fears of a disruption of the coming vote. \u201cDemocracy is the way forward,\u201d he said. \u201cElections should take place on time.\u201d\n\nMr. Hussain, the political columnist, echoed that sentiment, saying fears of a coup or delay in elections were exaggerated.
