bitter foe of Mr. Sharif, raved about the job the new army chief has done.\n\n\u201cI have more praise for General Bajwa than General Raheel Sharif,\u201d the opposition politician, Imran Khan, said at his political office in the suburbs of Islamabad. \u201cNever has an army chief so openly supported democracy.\u201d\n\nMr. Khan, a contender to be Pakistan\u2019s next prime minister, said General Bajwa had doubled down on his predecessor\u2019s efforts to curtail militant violence and political corruption.\n\nAs an example, Mr. Khan pointed out that there had been suspicion among the business community of Karachi, the country\u2019s commercial hub, that actions started by the former army chief against criminal political gangs and extortionists in the city might come to a halt. \u201cBut there has been no letup,\u201d Mr. Khan said.\n\nThe relationship between Mr. Sharif and General Bajwa fractured this past spring over leaks to the news media of a meeting at which Pakistan\u2019s civilian leaders confronted the military over its alleged reluctance to fight Islamist groups in the country.\n\nAnd with Mr. Sharif continuing to speak out since leaving office, the military appears in no mood to repair the rift with the still highly influential politician. \u201cNawaz Sharif still has a lot of say,\u201d said Mr. Hussain, the columnist. \u201cAnd the anger against him within the army is greater than before.\u201d\n\nThe army chief is said to have a better working relationship with Mr. Abbasi, Mr. Sharif\u2019s successor.\n\n\u201cThere has been much more institutional contact between Prime Minister Abbasi and General Bajwa,\u201d said Mr. Hussain. \u201cUnlike under Nawaz, when there was a complete breakdown in institutional decision-making.\u201d\n\n\u201cBut this is not to suggest that there is no friction,\u201d Mr. Hussain added. \u201cThe army is in a much stronger position now.\u201d", "title": "Pakistan Army \u2018Has Greatly Increased Its Clout\u2019 Under New Chief", "authors": ["Salman Masood"]} {"date": "2018-01-02 00:00:00", "text": "While describing Mr. Trump\u2019s remarks as \u201ccompletely incomprehensible,\u201d a statement after the meeting was temperate. It concluded that, \u201cdespite all unwarranted allegations, Pakistan cannot act in haste and will remain committed to playing a constructive role towards an Afghan-led and Afghan-owned peace process.\u201d\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s post and Pakistan\u2019s response point to a nose-dive in the relationship between the United States and Pakistan, which has become deeply strained in recent months.\n\nIn several recent high-profile visits, United States officials have repeatedly expressed frustration over Pakistan\u2019s failure to confront terrorist networks within its borders. But Pakistani officials say they have done more than enough.\n\nPrivately, Pakistani officials say that the United States has failed in Afghanistan and is looking to blame Pakistan for that failure. Pakistani officials continue to deny that militants, especially those with the Haqqani network, which is allied with the Afghan Taliban and is responsible for many lethal attacks inside Afghanistan, have havens inside Pakistan.\n\nDuring a news conference last week, Maj. Gen. Asif Ghafoor, the spokesman for Pakistan\u2019s military, warned the United States against taking any unilateral antiterrorism action on Pakistani soil.\n\nPakistan\u2019s military says it is working to build a fence along the Afghan border to curb infiltration. Officials also say that the estimated 2.7 million Afghan refugees living in Pakistan need to be repatriated because their presence in the country complicates action against Taliban militants. Pakistani officials say fighters from the Taliban and other groups are able to hide in settlement camps by mingling with refugees.\n\nPakistani officials also insist that Mr. Trump has his figures wrong, taking aim at his claim that the United States had \u201cfoolishly\u201d given it $33 billion since 2002.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cAbout $14 billion of that $33 billion was part of coalition support fund, which was compensation for services rendered,\u201d said Miftah Ismail, an adviser to the prime minister on finance, revenue and economic affairs, in an interview. \u201cOur billings were for $22 billion and we got only $14 billion. So we think the U.S. owes us $8 billion.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe United States has been withholding $255 million in military aid in hopes of pushing Pakistan to change its behavior. The money was authorized in 2016 and put in escrow in August. In recent days, Trump administration officials have debated whether to announce that Pakistan would not receive the money at all.\n\nMr. Ismail said the $255 million was a tiny fraction of Pakistan\u2019s gross domestic product. \u201cSo, not a great deal of money.\u201d\n\nPakistani leadership was also comforted by a strong expression of support from China.\n\nGeng Shuang, the spokesman of China\u2019s Foreign Ministry, said during a news conference on Tuesday said that \u201cPakistan has made great efforts and sacrifices for combating terrorism and made prominent contributions to the cause of international counterterrorism, and the international community should fully recognize this.\u201d\n\nWhile there was characteristic chest thumping on television talk shows, with guests lampooning the United States threats, some critics said there was indeed a need for greater introspection in Pakistan.\n\n\u201cThere is a need to fill the gaps in our policy,\u201d Muhammad Nawaz Chaudhry, a former Pakistani ambassador, said in an interview. \u201cWe cannot take the bilateral relationship to a dead end.\u201d\n\n\u201cWe are living in denial,\u201d he added. \u201cThe world, especially the United States, is not accepting our narrative.\u201d\n\nAs an example, Mr. Chaudhry pointed to Hafiz Muhammad Saeed, the founding leader of Lashkar-e-Taiba, the militant group behind the 2008 attacks in Mumbai, India, who has continued to live openly in Pakistan despite long being one of the most-wanted militant leaders in the region, with a huge American bounty on his head.\n\nAfter Mr. Trump\u2019s tweet on Monday, a charity run by Mr. Saeed, Jamaat-ud-Dawa, was prohibited from collecting donations, according to a government order. But Mr. Chaudhry said that the order was just playing to the gallery.\n\n\u201cRather than becoming belligerent,\u201d he said, \u201cwe need to be realistic and go with the world opinion.\u201d", "title": "Pakistan Dismisses Trump\u2019s Tweet on Aid as \u2018Incomprehensible\u2019", "authors": ["Salman Masood"]} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "Pakistan has long posed a dilemma for the United States \u2014 should America provide it with aid and treat it as an ally because of its potential to help fight regional extremists, or should ties and funding be restricted, or even severed, because of its connections to those groups?\n\nThe Trump administration\u2019s announcement on Thursday that it would freeze nearly all military aid to Pakistan, roughly $1.3 billion annually, is the latest of several times in the last 16 years that funding has been withheld or modified out of American frustration with Pakistan\u2019s support for certain terrorist groups. But President Trump\u2019s bombast and the precipitous way the decision seems to have been made have led to doubts that Mr. Trump has a serious plan for managing the ramifications of this move.\n\nAlmost every military flight into Afghanistan goes through Pakistani airspace. Most supplies travel along Pakistani roads and rails. Pakistan could shut down American access at any moment, and some Pakistani officials are threatening to do just that. Pakistan could also ally more closely with China, which is already investing in major new infrastructure projects and expanding its international leadership at America\u2019s expense, and be more hard-line in its rivalry with India. Indeed, China could once again be the beneficiary of a Trump decision estranging the United States from longtime partners.\n\nThe president is good at venting grievances, as he demonstrated in his New Year\u2019s Day tweet on the situation: \u201cThe United States has foolishly given Pakistan more than 33 billion dollars in aid over the last 15 years,\u201d he wrote, \u201cand they have given us nothing but lies & deceit, thinking of our leaders as fools. They give safe haven to the terrorists we hunt in Afghanistan, with little help. Protesters said they opposed any contact with American officials, and their actions quickly cut short the meeting. They later kicked the vehicles of the American officials and tried to prevent them from leaving.\n\n\u201cThe Palestinian people came out to forcibly stop this meeting,\u201d said a protester, Ahmed Odeh.\n\nThe Palestinians were outraged by President Trump\u2019s recognition of Jerusalem as Israel\u2019s capital last month, a move that prompted them to reject the United States as an honest peace broker. The Palestinians seek East Jerusalem, captured by Israel in 1967, as the capital of a future state.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe State Department condemned the incident and called it \u201cintimidation\u201d by \u201cunruly protesters.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cThe program was one part of long-term U.S. engagement to create economic opportunities for Palestinians,\u201d it said. \u201cThough no one was hurt, the objective was clearly intimidation. The United States absolutely opposes the use of violence and intimidation to express political views.\u201d\n\nLate Tuesday, the office of President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority condemned the attack on the American diplomats, saying \u201csuch practices contradict the values and morals of our people.\u201d", "title": "Palestinian Protesters Disrupt Meeting With Visiting U.S. Officials", "authors": ["The Associated Press"]} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "Ms. MacKinnon has directed seven Broadway shows in the last six years \u2014 a rare feat for a woman in a commercial theater landscape dominated by male directors. Her shows include \u201cThe Parisian Woman,\u201d a currently running play starring Uma Thurman, as well as last season\u2019s musical \u201cAm\u00e9lie,\u201d starring Phillipa Soo, and the previous season\u2019s \u201cChina Doll,\u201d starring Al Pacino. (\u201cAm\u00e9lie\u201d began its life in the Bay Area \u2014 Ms. MacKinnon directed a pre-Broadway production in 2015 at Berkeley Repertory Theater. She also directed a 2005 production of \u201c3F 4F,\u201d by Victor Lodato, at San Francisco\u2019s Magic Theater, and she has led workshops at A.C.T.)\n\nShe won a Tony Award in 2013 for her direction of a revival of \u201cWho\u2019s Afraid of Virginia Woolf?\u201d and was nominated in 2012 for \u201cClybourne Park.\u201d She is known as an interpreter of Edward Albee, the playwright who wrote \u201cVirginia Woolf.\u201d\n\n\u201cI\u2019ve always been a freelance director, but now I feel ready to build something bigger than myself \u2014 to put myself into an institution, producing a body of work and trying to learn as well as grow from a particular audience,\u201d Ms. MacKinnon said in a telephone interview from San Francisco, where the appointment was announced. \u201cAnd San Francisco is a great city.\u201d\n\nShe said that among her priorities will be producing more new plays by young writers.\n\nMs. MacKinnon said she would continue to direct, both at A.C.T. and in New York. This spring she is scheduled to direct \u201cLog Cabin,\u201d a new play by Jordan Harrison at Playwrights Horizons, an Off Broadway nonprofit, and she said she will \u201cabsolutely continue to direct on Broadway \u2014 I\u2019m so excited to continue that strand of my career, and A.C.T. is excited that I\u2019m in it.\u201d\n\nA.C.T., founded in Pittsburgh in 1965 and relocated to San Francisco in 1967, is a prominent regional theater, with 11,000 subscribers, 100 staff members and an annual operating budget of $23 million. The theater, which won a special Tony Award for regional theater in 1979, produces seven shows each subscription season, as well as a Christmas show and off-subscription events; the theater also oversees a conservatory.\n\n", "title": "Pam MacKinnon, Tony-Winning Director, to Lead San Francisco Theater", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "Six new paperbacks to check out this week.\n\nTHE PERFECT NANNY, by Leila Slimani. Translated by Sam Taylor. (Penguin, $16.) A bourgeois Parisian family and its caretaker depend on one another in insidious ways, with a tragic, and violent, outcome. This domestic thriller touches on racial and economic tensions, women\u2019s ambitions and souring family dynamics. Slimani won the Prix Goncourt, France\u2019s most prestigious literary prize, for the novel in 2016.\n\nSOUTH AND WEST: From a Notebook, by Joan Didion. (Vintage, $15.) Didion\u2019s observations from a road trip with her husband through the South \u2014 including Louisiana, Mississippi, and Alabama \u2014 were for an assignment (never finished) that her editors called \u201cThe Mind of the White South.\u201d In this slim volume, composed of writings from the 1970s, she contrasted California\u2019s resolute gaze to the future with the South\u2019s fixation on the past.\n\nTHE DRY, by Jane Harper. (Flatiron, $15.99) In this debut novel, Federal Agent Aaron Falk returns home to Australia\u2019s parched farmlands for the first time in years. The circumstances are grisly \u2014 Falk\u2019s best friend shot his wife and child before killing himself \u2014 and the surroundings are desperate; Falk\u2019s visit takes on a new urgency as he investigates his friend\u2019s death while guarding a childhood secret.\n\nYOURS IN TRUTH: A Personal Portrait of Ben Bradlee, Legendary Editor of The Washington Post, by Jeff Himmelman. (Random House, $18.) As the editor at the helm of The Post during a transformative era, a friend to the Kennedy family and a linchpin of Washington social circles, Bradlee attained a near-mythological status. Himmelman, who was Bob Woodward\u2019s assistant and later a friend of Bradlee\u2019s, investigates his life, including a look at the editor\u2019s relationship with the Post publisher Katharine Graham.", "title": "Paperback Row", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nSix new paperbacks to check out this week.\n\nHOW TO SEE: Looking, Talking, and Thinking About Art, by David Salle. (Norton, $16.95.) The painter, who was catapulted to fame in the 1980s, offers up a guide to appreciating contemporary art. In an engaging series of essays, he profiles artists including Jeff Koons and Alex Katz, and his mentor John Baldessari. Along the way, Salle sprinkles thoughts about art school, criticism and history.\n\nSWIMMING LESSONS, by Claire Fuller. (Tin House, $15.95.) Ingrid begins writing letters to her husband about their marriage, hiding them in the thousands of books he has collected. Then, she flees \u2014 leaving him along with their two children and a seaside home in Dorset. Years later, Ingrid\u2019s daughter discovers the letters while caring for her aging father, prompting her to examine the circumstances of her mother\u2019s disappearance anew.\n\nWONDERLAND: How Play Made the Modern World, by Steven Johnson. (Riverhead, $20.) In this rollicking study, Johnson \u2014 using an elastic definition of \u201cplay,\u201d which includes beauty, spectacles and mere novelty \u2014 makes a case for entertainment\u2019s role in history. As he suggests, if you\u2019re curious about where the future is headed, just look to where people are having the most fun.\n\nTHE SCHOOLDAYS OF JESUS, by J. M. Coetzee. (Penguin, $16.) In the second volume of Coetzee\u2019s allegorical fable, which began with his 2013 novel \u201cThe Childhood of Jesus,\u201d Dav\u00edd and Sim\u00f3n forge new lives in a country where immigrants\u2019 memories have been washed away. Dav\u00edd, a gifted but difficult child, doubts his new circumstances; his persistent questioning of Sim\u00f3n forms the grist of a philosophical dialogue tinged with intimacy. \u201cThe result is rich, dense, often amusing and, above all, full of inner tension and suspense,\u201d Jack Miles said here.\n\nLONDON FOG: The Biography, by Christine L. Corton. (Harvard, $18.95.) A social history of the city\u2019s storied pollution uncovers how business interests often won out over health concerns. While the fog was killing Londoners, it also inspired, and rankled, artists and writers, becoming a romanticized feature of the city. Corton\u2019s account investigates its lasting cultural impact.\n\nLOLA, by Melissa Scrivner Love. (Broadway, $16.) In South Central Los Angeles, the Crenshaw Six have joined the city\u2019s drug wars, with one of its members\u2019 girlfriends running the operation. Lola, tough and resilient, watches violence play out on the streets of her childhood as she navigates ever-higher stakes. Our reviewer, Charles Finch, praised this debut thriller, calling it \u201cas fast, flexible and poised as a chef\u2019s knife.\u201d", "title": "Paperback Row", "authors": ["Joumana Khatib"]} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nSix new paperbacks to check out this week.\n\nTHE UNSETTLERS: In Search of the Good Life in Today\u2019s America, by Mark Sundeen. (Riverhead, $16.) Sundeen profiles three families \u2014 whom he calls pioneers, of a sort \u2014 who chose to live off the grid. They share an important commonality: \u201cThey had each taken on a fundamental aspect of how the world is broken, and had attempted, with all their might, to address it \u2014 in ways that felt sustainable, maybe even replicable.\u201d\n\nEnigma Variations, by Andr\u00e9 Aciman. (Picador, $16.) Aciman chronicles a lifetime of desire, love and loss. The central character, Paul, has an early infatuation with a craftsman in Italy that provides the story line\u2019s loose framework; the plot skips ahead to find him years later, nearly unrecognizable in an acrimonious relationship. Aciman\u2019s novel is a masterly portrayal of arousal and the selves forged by passion.\n\nLetters to V\u00e9ra, by Vladimir Nabokov. Edited and translated by Olga Voronina and Brian Boyd. (Vintage, $20.) For over 50 years, V\u00e9ra was a \u201csong,\u201d a muse, a protector for her husband. (She was the one to save an early draft of \u201cLolita\u201d after Vladimir tried to destroy it.) \u201cIt is the prose itself that provides the lasting affirmation,\u201d our reviewer, Martin Amis, wrote, \u201cand underlying it all the lavishness, the freely offered gift, of his divine energy.\u201d\n\nLong Black Veil, by Jennifer Finney Boylan. (Broadway, $16.) It\u2019s August 1980, and a band of college friends are looking for mischief in an abandoned Philadelphia prison. But when one of them goes missing, the night ends in tragedy. Years later, the student\u2019s body is found, and one of the survivors risks exposing two long-held secrets to protect the truth. As our reviewer, Marilyn Stasio, put it: \u201cTo the author, the prison is more than a setting, it\u2019s also a powerful symbol for the closeted life she once led.\u201d\n\nPRINCE CHARLES: The Passions and Paradoxes of an Improbable Life, by Sally Bedell Smith. (Random House, $20.) A sympathetic portrait of Charles comes down squarely in his favor, particularly with regard to Diana. He emerges as a thoughtful, intellectually driven man in Bedell\u2019s telling. The author, who has written at length about the royal family, offers a cleareyed view of the monarchy, its privilege and its faltering morals.\n\nOn Turpentine Lane, by Elinor Lipman. (Mariner, $14.99.) Faith Frankel is 32, perhaps more than a little bored, and has set down roots in her Massachusetts hometown. But mysterious objects in her new bungalow draw her into the neighborhood\u2019s past. Lipman\u2019s screwball romance is full of delightfully weird characters, from Faith\u2019s neo-hippie fianc\u00e9 to her father, an amateur artist churning out Chagall copies.", "title": "Paperback Row", "authors": ["Joumana Khatib"]} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "Six new paperbacks to check out this week.\n\nONGOINGNESS: The End of a Diary, by Sarah Manguso. (Graywolf, $14.) Out of a desire to record every detail of her life, Manguso, a poet, began keeping a journal over 25 years ago \u2014 and was so prolific that her entries reached about 800,000 words. In this slim volume, she reflects on the project and her efforts to guard against forgetting, death and \u201cthat great and ongoing blank.\u201d\n\nTHE ARRANGEMENT, by Sarah Dunn. (Back Bay/Little, Brown, $15.99.) Owen and Lucy have fled New York City for the Hudson Valley, settling in a 200-year-old house and stocking the coop with chickens. But paradise has its downsides, and the couple rock their upstate idyll by trying out an open marriage. What begins as an affair with a man in the city develops into love, and Lucy confronts an old question: whether passion or stability will win out.\n\nRUMI\u2019S SECRET: The Life of the Sufi Poet of Love, by Brad Gooch. (Harper Perennial, $17.99.) Few figures have had the same resonance and enduring popularity as Jalal al-Din Mohammad Rumi, the 13th-century Muslim mystic who has been a muse for everyone from Madonna to budding Pinterest spiritualists. Gooch investigates Rumi\u2019s life and theology, with a focus on his life-changing, and creatively rich, relationship with the mystic Shams.\n\nSnowblind, by Ragnar Jonasson. Translated by Quentin Bates. (Minotaur/Thomas Dunne, $9.99.) It\u2019s 2008 and Ari Thor Arason, a recent police academy graduate in a remote Icelandic village, is investigating the death of a local author. \u201cThis classically crafted whodunit holds up nicely,\u201d our reviewer, Marilyn Stasio, wrote. \u201cBut Jonasson\u2019s true gift is for describing the daunting beauty of the fierce setting, lashed by blinding snowstorms that smother the village in 'a thick, white darkness\u2019 that is strangely comforting.\u201d", "title": "Paperback Row", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-04 00:00:00", "text": "Dear Diary:\n\nIn the far distant past, my father and I flew to New York one June for what was to be my first visit to the city that I have now known as home for many years.\n\nWhat a visit it was. We did the usual things: The Empire State Building was amazing. And the Statue of Liberty? We walked up to the crown.\n\nThen there was what may have been one of the last rides anyone ever took on the Parachute Jump at Coney Island. My father was too scared to try it, so, with my shoes off, I went up alone. Once at the top, there was a whoosh, my stomach dropped, my skirt flew up and down I floated, walking triumphantly to pick up my shoes after I landed.\n\nBut the crowning glory of the trip? My father, a professor, liked a restaurant, Prexy\u2019s, that had several locations in Manhattan at the time. It served what it called the \u201chamburger with the college education.\u201d", "title": "Parachute Jump to Prexy\u2019s", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-31 00:00:00", "text": "For decades, it was Fourth Avenue, a sleepy office district that was even more hushed at night when insurance companies and book publishers turned off the lights. The city tried to perk it up in 1959, rechristening the 15-block stretch from East 17th to East 32nd Streets as Park Avenue South \u2014 an extension of the fancy uptown thoroughfare.\n\nThe experiment seemed to fall flat. Mail was occasionally delivered to the wrong addresses \u2014 to that other Park Avenue, residents said \u2014 and the street appeared to be trapped in real-estate limbo. It was neither here nor there, brushing by brand-name enclaves like Gramercy Park and Flatiron, but not belonging to them, and never really developing a personality of its own.\n\nToday, though, the street is packed with upscale apartments and energetic night life. It seems to have finally come into its own, even if some still scratch their heads.\n\n\u201cWhen I\u2019m in a cab, I always just say, \u2018Take me to 19th Street,\u2019\u201d said Sam Greene, 46, who has lived on the street since 2003. \u201cThat\u2019s how I make sure they know where they\u2019re going.\u201d", "title": "Park Avenue South: The Other Park Avenue Comes Into Its Own", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-01 00:00:00", "text": "Whether an East Harlem ballpark will give way to what could be the tallest building between Midtown Manhattan and Boston may hinge upon the definition of a park versus a playground.\n\nThe latest battle between New York\u2019s preservationists and developers is being waged over a 1.5-acre parcel of jungle gym and soccer and baseball fields, known as the Marx Brothers Playground.\n\nPreservationists say there is no question that the space is a park. The city parks department has maintained the lot, wedged between 96th and 97th Streets on Second Avenue, since 1947. The department\u2019s leaf symbol adorns a plaque affixed to the gate.\n\nBut city officials, who plan to partner with the developer AvalonBay to turn the site into a 68-story tower with school facilities, retail space and a mix of market-rate and affordable housing, insist the space is a playground.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThat seemingly minor quibble of semantics is crucial. Parks require the State Legislature\u2019s and the governor\u2019s approval before they can be modified. Playgrounds do not.", "title": "Park or Playground? If Mr. Meehan remains in Congress through the end of his term, the committee would retain jurisdiction to continue its investigation.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Get the Morning Briefing by Email What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox Monday through Friday. Ms. Katz said Mr. Meehan \u201cre-traumatized\u201d the woman by \u201cblaming her for what the public now knows from his own explanations was highly inappropriate behavior.\u201d\n\nRepublicans, who were already facing an uphill battle in retaining the moderate district, welcomed the news of Mr. Meehan\u2019s impending retirement headed into an election year in which sexual misconduct has emerged as a potent issue.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nVal DiGiorgio, the chairman of the Republican Party of Pennsylvania, said in a statement that Mr. Meehan \u201cmade the right decision for the voters of the Seventh District and himself.\u201d Mr. DiGiorgio called it \u201ca sad ending to what was an otherwise noteworthy career of a dedicated public servant.\u201d\n\nRepresentative Steve Stivers, Republican of Ohio and the chairman of the National Republican Congressional Committee, released a statement saying that he was \u201cdisappointed by the circumstances\u201d leading to Mr. Meehan\u2019s retirement, and declaring that \u201cwe must always hold ourselves to the highest possible standard \u2014 especially while serving in Congress.\u201d\n\nThe news could set off a scramble for Republicans before a primary in May. The deadline for candidates to submit petitions to appear on the ballot is March 6.\n\nAnd Mr. Meehan\u2019s decision resets the calculus for a field of at least three Democrats vying for their party\u2019s nomination to run in the sprawling district, which is considered among the most severely gerrymandered in the country and which Hillary Clinton narrowly carried in the 2016 presidential election.\n\nAdding to the uncertainty, Pennsylvania\u2019s State Supreme Court ruled on Monday that the state\u2019s Republican-drawn congressional district map violates the state\u2019s Constitution, and ordered all 18 districts redrawn in the coming weeks.\n\nPennsylvania Republicans have pledged to try to appeal the decision to the United States Supreme Court. If the ruling stands, it is expected to tilt the state\u2019s electoral battlefield further in Democrats\u2019 direction.\n\nMr. Meehan\u2019s announcement makes him the latest in a series of lawmakers to resign or announce their retirements after being accused of sexual misconduct.\n\nSenator Al Franken, Democrat of Minnesota; Representative Trent Franks, Republican of Arizona; and Representative John Conyers Jr., Democrat of Michigan, have resigned. Vogel", "Katie Rogers"]} {"date": "2018-01-20 00:00:00", "text": "The New York Times received the following statement on Saturday from the office of Representative Patrick Meehan, Republican of Pennsylvania, in response to reporting that Mr. Meehan had used taxpayer funds to settle a case of sexual misconduct with a female staffer in his office.\n\nRead the full article on the allegations against Mr. Meehan \u00bb\n\n______\n\nCongressman Meehan denies these allegations. Throughout his career he has always treated his colleagues, male and female, with the utmost respect and professionalism.\n\nIn this case, the employee, represented by counsel, made certain assertions of inappropriate behavior which were investigated. With respect to resolving any allegation made against the office, Congressman Meehan would only act with advice of House Counsel and consistent with House Ethics Committee guidance. Every step of the process was handled ethically and appropriately. At Congressman Meehan\u2019s request, the congressional attorneys handling the case have asked the complainant\u2019s counsel to release all parties from the confidentiality requirements of the agreement to ensure a full and open airing of all the facts. The Congressman is hopeful that they will agree to this request for full transparency.\n\nRep. Meehan believes there must be real reform to the process for resolving complaints so that those who are truly wronged are given a fair forum to be heard and vindicated, and those accused are provided with an ability to respond to baseless accusations. The public to whom elected officials are answerable must be provided with a true sense of the facts and circumstances involved.", "title": "Patrick Meehan\u2019s Response to The Times\u2019s Article on His Settlement for Misconduct", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-21 00:00:00", "text": "The Patriots have won all their titles during the last 16 years, when teams have had to juggle free agency, salary caps and longer seasons. That sets them apart from the New York Yankees of the 1950s, the Boston Celtics of the 1960s and the Chicago Bulls of the 1990s.\n\nThe victories have not always been pretty, including the one on Sunday, when Brady had to engineer his record eighth fourth-quarter playoff comeback. For long parts of the game, the Jaguars appeared poised to pull off one of the bigger upsets in playoff history. The Patriots fell behind by 14-3 in the second quarter and played from behind for much of the game, struggling to establish their running game. They also lost their top receiver, tight end Rob Gronkowski, to a head injury in the second quarter.\n\nBut Brady, who has also appeared in more playoff games than any other quarterback, once again led the Patriots with ruthless efficiency when it mattered most. Facing a 10-point deficit in the fourth quarter, he engineered two scoring drives \u2014 aided by several Jaguars penalties \u2014 and put the Patriots ahead for good with less than three minutes remaining, when he hit wide receiver Danny Amendola with a 4-yard touchdown pass.\n\n\u201cIf you look up \u2018good football player\u2019 in the dictionary, his picture is right beside it,\u201d Coach Bill Belichick said of Amendola.\n\nAs they have done for years, Brady and Belichick did not buckle under pressure when trailing late. The Patriots\u2019 defense provided the necessary support, stifling the Jaguars, blocking passes and rushing Jacksonville quarterback Blake Bortles in the second half.", "title": "Patriots End a Week of Hand-Wringing With Another A.F.C. Crown", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-14 00:00:00", "text": "New England also held Derrick Henry to just 28 yards rushing on 12 carries.\n\nThe Patriots\u2019 victory came on the heels of a week filled with reports of turmoil involving Brady, Coach Bill Belichick and the team\u2019s owner, Robert Kraft.\n\nNone of that showed on the field Saturday.\n\n\u201cIt definitely sounds crazy,\u201d tight end Rob Gronkowski said of how the team handled the news coverage during the week. \u201cBut you have to keep ignoring the noise on the outside, just keep working every time you walk into the building, and just keep grinding.\u201d\n\nLast week, the Titans rallied from an 18-point deficit in the second half and defeated the Chiefs, 22-21, in the wild-card round. That was the largest comeback on the road in the Super Bowl era. But the Patriots did not give them a chance for an encore.\n\nThe Patriots stretched their margin to 14 points just before halftime after a trio of careless penalties by the Titans.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nTennessee initially forced a three-and-out but gave up a first down with a fourth-and-5 neutral zone infraction on Brynden Trawick before New England\u2019s punt attempt.\n\nArmed with a new set of downs, Brady went to work moving the Patriots down the field with a steady diet of short passes. The Titans helped along the way with penalties for illegal contact and unnecessary roughness. The drive culminated in a 4-yard touchdown pass from Brady to Chris Hogan in the back of the end zone that made the score 21-7.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBrady threw a short shovel pass to White, who ran in from the 5-yard line to make it 7-7 early in the second quarter.\n\nThe Patriots appeared to have scored a touchdown three plays earlier, when Dion Lewis caught a pass from Brady and was tackled by Wesley Woodyard at the 19. Lewis landed on top of the defender, then got up and continued to the end zone.\n\nThe officials initially ruled that he had never been down and called it a touchdown. But replays showed Lewis\u2019s backside had hit the ground at the 19.\n\nCorey Davis made a one-handed catch on a 15-yard pass from Mariota in the corner of the end zone to give the Titans an early 7-0 lead.\n\nDavis added an 11-yard touchdown reception with just under two minutes left in the game, and in the Titans\u2019 season.", "title": "Patriots Rout the Titans to Reach Their 7th Straight A.F.C. Title Game", "authors": ["The Associated Press"]} {"date": "2018-01-20 00:00:00", "text": "His most famous dish was truffle soup V.G.E., a heady mixture of truffles and foie gras in chicken broth, baked in a single-serving bowl covered in puff pastry. First served at a dinner at the \u00c9lys\u00e9e Palace in 1975, the soup was named for the French president Val\u00e9ry Giscard d\u2019Estaing, who had just awarded Mr. Bocuse the French Legion of Honor.\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Bocuse, a tireless self-promoter, was a constant presence in the news media and on television. \u201cYou\u2019ve got to beat the drum in life,\u201d he told People magazine in 1976. \u201cGod is already famous, but that doesn\u2019t stop the preacher from ringing the church bells every morning.\u201d\n\nHe parlayed celebrity into a restaurant empire that extended beyond France to embrace the United States and Japan, and in so doing he became a role model for the chef-entrepreneurs of the present day, like Jacques P\u00e9pin.\n\n\u201cCertainly he did more than any other chef in the world that I can think of to bring the chefs in the dining room and to make the profession respectable and to make us who we are now,\u201d Mr. P\u00e9pin said in 2011, when Mr. Bocuse was named \u201cchef of the century\u201d by the Culinary Institute of America. \u201cNow the chefs are stars and it\u2019s because of Paul Bocuse. We are indebted to him for them.\u201d\n\nPaul Bocuse was born on Feb. 11, 1926, in Collonges-au-Mont-d\u2019Or, where his forebears had been cooking and serving food for seven generations. At the age of 8, he made his first serious dish, veal kidneys with pur\u00e9ed potatoes, and as a teenager he began an apprenticeship at a local restaurant. The training was interrupted by World War II, however, when he was assigned to a Vichy government youth camp and put to work in its canteen and slaughterhouse. In 1944, he joined the 1st Free French Division and was wounded in combat in Alsace. He received the Croix de Guerre.\n\nAfter the war, he resumed his apprenticeship at the restaurant, La M\u00e8re Brazier in Le Col de la Lu\u00e8re, outside Lyon. Like its twin in Lyon, it was owned by the legendary Eug\u00e9nie Brazier and had achieved three Michelin stars by serving impeccable renditions of regional classics.\n\nAfter a brief stint at the three-star Lucas Carton in Paris, where he worked alongside the brothers Pierre and Jean Troisgros, Mr. Bocuse spent eight years under Point at La Pyramide in Vienne, near Lyon.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cBack then a lot of restaurants were doing the same kind of old-fashioned Escoffier-style cooking, with lots of sauces hiding the ingredients, and the same dishes night after night,\u201d Mr. Bocuse told The New York Times in 2007. \u201cPoint was a perfectionist who gave value and credibility to the finest ingredients.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn 1956, Mr. Bocuse returned to the family restaurant, the Auberge du Pont de Collonges, which earned its first Michelin star two years later. Despite the paper tablecloths and stainless-steel cutlery, a second star was awarded in 1960.\n\nIn 1966, a year after the restaurant earned its third star, Mr. Bocuse bought back the old family restaurant that his grandfather, in straitened circumstances, had sold in 1921 along with the rights to the Bocuse name. He renamed the building, which once belonged to an order of monks, the Abbaye de Collonges and converted it into a banquet hall. He also hoisted a four-foot neon \u201cPaul Bocuse\u201d sign atop his restaurant.\n\nThe groundswell for nouvelle cuisine transformed Mr. Bocuse into the international face of French cooking. He appeared on the cover of The New York Times Magazine in 1972. In 1975, resplendent in chef whites and toque, he looked out from the cover of Newsweek under the banner headline \u201cFood: The New Wave.\u201d An apprenticeship at his restaurant became a rite of passage for ambitious chefs, including Jean-Georges Vongerichten and Daniel Boulud.\n\nIn time, as a backlash against nouvelle cuisine developed, Mr. Bocuse put some distance between himself and the movement. He referred snidely to \u201cmini-portions on maxi-plates\u201d and at one point dismissed the movement as \u201ca joke.\u201d\n\n\u201cIt is not true that Paul Bocuse invented Nouvelle Cuisine,\u201d he told The Wall Street Journal in 2011. \u201cThere were a few dishes that were developed lighter, but that is normal in cooking. The term Nouvelle Cuisine as it came to be known was nothing to do with what was on the plate, but what was on the bill.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nNouvelle cuisine lost momentum, but Mr. Bocuse did not. In the early 1980s, the Walt Disney Company invited him to create restaurants for the French pavilion at Epcot Center (now Walt Disney World) in Orlando, Fla. With Gaston Len\u00f4tre and Roger Verg\u00e9, he developed Les Chefs de France restaurant, which is now operated by his son, J\u00e9r\u00f4me, a graduate of the Culinary Institute of America. It serves 2,000 meals a day and generates about $30 million a year.\n\nWhen the organizers of Eurexpo, a culinary trade fair in Lyon, approached Mr. Bocuse for ideas on how to promote the event, he proposed a cooking contest in which chefs would prepare two elaborate dishes, one fish and one meat, before a live audience and then submit them to a panel of expert judges for scoring. The Bocuse d\u2019Or, held every two years, made its debut in 1987 and is now regarded as the culinary equivalent of the Olympics, attracting teams from all over the world.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn addition to his restaurant in Collonges-au-Mont-d\u2019Or, Mr. Bocuse operated brasseries in France, Switzerland and Japan, and a culinary school at \u00c9cully, near Lyon.\n\nHis cookbooks include \u201cPaul Bocuse\u2019s French Cooking (1977), \u201cPaul Bocuse in Your Kitchen: An Introduction to Classic French Cooking\u201d (1982), \u201cBocuse \u00e0 la Carte\u201d (1989) and \u201cPaul Bocuse: The Complete Recipes\u201d (2011).\n\nFor many years, Mr. Bocuse resisted writing the story of his life, but he eventually worked with Eve-Marie Zizza-Lalu to produce an as-told-to memoir, \u201cPaul Bocuse: The Sacred Fire,\u201d published in 2005. Even in France, eyebrows lifted a little when Mr. Bocuse revealed that for more than 30 years, he had enjoyed the company of not only his wife, Raymonde, the mother of his daughter, Fran\u00e7oise Bernachon, but also of two mistresses, one of them the mother of J\u00e9r\u00f4me. His wife survives him, as do his two children.\n\n\u201cIt would not be everyone\u2019s idea of married life, but everyone gets on,\u201d he told The Daily Telegraph of London at the time. \u201cThey are all happy, with me and each other, and if I add up the time we have spent together as couples, it comes to 145 years.\u201d\n\nDespite his international status, Mr. Bocuse remained a chef deeply rooted in his native soil. He loved the traditional dishes of Lyon. He slept in the same bedroom where he had been born.\n\n\u201cWhen the time comes, I too will end up in the oven,\u201d he told L\u2019Express in 2005, musing over the multiple meanings of his memoir\u2019s title. \u201cI want my ashes to be scattered in the Sa\u00f4ne, which flows right past my house. It is the river of my life.\u201d", "title": "Paul Bocuse, Celebrated French Chef, Dies at 91", "authors": ["William Grimes", "Mark Bittman"]} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Booth lobbied against President George W. Bush\u2019s proposal to privatize Social Security. He also, with mixed success, resisted efforts by Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin to cripple public sector unions.\n\nMr. Booth told The New York Times last year that service workers were crucial to the survival of the union movement and to the Democratic Party, which trade unions have provided with money and manpower.\n\n\u201cThe effort to strangle this opportunity has been the top strategic priority of the G.O.P.,\u201d he said.\n\nWhile union membership has stagnated, Mr. Booth said that millions of health care, personal service, education and government workers had enrolled in recent decades.\n\n\u201cFor decades, Paul had been one of the labor movement\u2019s key strategists,\u201d the democratic socialist columnist Harold Meyerson wrote on Thursday on the website of the liberal magazine The American Prospect. \u201cPaul devised the nation\u2019s very first living-wage campaign, helped mastermind the 1995 insurgency that ousted the old-line Cold Warriors from the leadership of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., and mentored scores \u2014 perhaps hundreds \u2014 of union leaders and organizers, movement activists and elected officials.\u201d\n\nPaul Robert Booth was born on June 7, 1943, in Washington. His father, Philip Booth, worked for the Labor Department and drafted Social Security legislation and programs for migrant workers. His mother was the former Mary Markowitz.\n\nPhoto\n\nHe majored in political science at Swarthmore College in Pennsylvania and graduated in 1964.\n\nIn addition to his wife, the former Heather Tobis (whom he had met at a sit-in against the draft at the University of Chicago), he is survived by two sons, Eugene Victor Booth (named after Eugene V. Debs, the socialist labor leader) and Daniel Garrison Booth (named for Daniel De Leon, the socialist editor); a brother, Michael; and five grandchildren.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nDespite his early opposition to the Vietnam War, his campaign to register draft resisters as conscientious objectors and his protests against American banks as \u201cpartners in apartheid,\u201d because of their ties to the South African government, Mr. Booth was considered a moderate by S.D.S. standards.\n\nAs the national secretary of S.D.S., he popularized the slogan \u201cBuild, Not Burn\u201d to promote civilian public service work as an alternative to the military draft.\n\nUnlike some of his more militant colleagues, he also believed that by seeking political office and supporting candidates and campaigns, he and his fellow leftists could further the organization\u2019s broader political agenda.\n\nMr. Booth was a chief organizer of the April 1965 Washington march, during which more than 15,000 protesters paraded from the Washington Monument to the Capitol and picketed the White House. The march was also supported by Women Strike for Peace and the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee, among other groups.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re really not just a peace group,\u201d Mr. Booth, just 21 at the time, told The Times in 1965. \u201cWe are working on domestic problems \u2014 civil rights, poverty, university reform. We feel passionately and angrily about things in America, and we feel that a war in Asia will destroy what we\u2019re trying to do here.\u201d\n\nIn his book \u201cSDS: The Rise and Development of the Students for a Democratic Society\u201d (1973), Kirkpatrick Sale wrote that Mr. Booth\u2019s politics, \u201cwhich had always been in the careful center of S.D.S., hardly made him open or responsive to the new, often bizarre, usually romantic, always militant ideas coming up from under.\u201d\n\nMoreover, Mr. Sale wrote, Mr. Booth\u2019s style, \u201cwith a flint-sharp mind, a skillful tongue and years of infighting experience in political groups, was abrasive to the younger and less sophisticated people around the office.\u201d\n\n\u201cThe Booth regime, which lasted the entire school year, was the old guard\u2019s last fling,\u201d Mr. Sale concluded.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAnother leader of the group, Todd Gitlin, now a journalism and sociology professor at Columbia University, recalled in \u201cThe Sixties: Years of Hope, Days of Rage\u201d (1989) that in 1964 Mr. Booth cautioned that \u201cwe must tread delicately on the Vietnam question because lots of S.D.S. people are far from being for withdrawal.\u201d\n\nProfessor Gitlin recalled in an email on Thursday that Mr. Booth had also been one of the authors of a manifesto that argued for moving into mainstream politics.\n\n\u201cUnfortunately,\u201d Professor Gitlin said, \u201cS.D.S. was moving in different directions.\u201d\n\nMr. Booth joined the labor movement in 1966 as research director for the United Packinghouse Workers of America. He became organizing director for the public employees union and then executive assistant to Mr. McEntee.\n\n\u201cSome labor leaders are bombastic,\u201d Mr. Meyerson wrote in The American Prospect. \u201cPaul was quiet, ironic, self-effacing, witty, warm, scholarly, and diligent \u2014 just the kind of guy who\u2019d crunch the numbers to make a point about Latino realignment, whose commitment to a decent future for his nation was such that he\u2019d research and rewrite from his hospital bed on what the Democrats needed to do to win in 2018, who could dismiss his own illness as a trifle indisposition.\u201d", "title": "Paul Booth, Antiwar Organizer and Union Stalwart, Dies at 74", "authors": ["Sam Roberts"]} {"date": "2018-01-03 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cIf the ultimate objective is to continue to try to undermine the credibility of Mueller and his prosecutors, it could have some value,\u201d said Jimmy Gurul\u00e9, a Notre Dame law professor who was a senior Justice Department official in the administration of the first President George Bush. \u201cBut in terms of a legal strategy, it\u2019s highly unlikely to prevail.\u201d\n\nWorse for the White House, the lawsuit also invites Mr. Mueller to give a \u201cdevastating response\u201d that spells out all the ways Mr. Manafort is relevant to Mr. Trump and the Russia investigation, said Peter Zeidenberg, a former prosecutor who worked on a special counsel investigation during the George W. Bush administration. \u201cIf I\u2019m the government, I\u2019m licking my chops to file this response. He\u2019s going to tie a bow on this,\u201d he said of Mr. Mueller.\n\nEven if Mr. Manafort succeeds at every turn, his problems are not over. He could still face charges if new prosecutors decided to bring them. But any court ruling that narrowed Mr. Mueller\u2019s authority would give him less leeway to use unrelated charges as leverage against people close to the president.\n\nMr. Mueller won the cooperation of Mr. Trump\u2019s former national security adviser, Michael T. Flynn, for instance, after investigating him for unregistered foreign lobbying and lying to the F.B.I. on matters unrelated to the election.\n\nThe lawsuit provides fodder for Republicans who are trying to discredit Mr. Mueller\u2019s investigation. As evidence that Mr. Mueller is biased, critics have pointed to Democratic donations by members of his team and anti-Trump text messages sent by an F.B.I. agent whom Mr. Mueller removed from the investigation.\n\nThe accusations in the charges against Mr. Manafort date back years, well before he began working for Mr. Trump. His lawyers argue that Mr. Mueller should be allowed to investigate only matters that directly arise from the Russia investigation. That theory echoes comments made by Mr. Trump, who has said that Mr. Mueller cannot investigate his family\u2019s finances.\n\nMr. Mueller served as F.B.I. director under the younger Mr. Bush and Barack Obama. He is credited with refocusing the F.B.I. on counterterrorism after the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks. And he was widely praised by members of both parties when he was put in charge of the Russia investigation.\n\nMr. Trump has said he has no plans to fire Mr. Mueller, but he and his allies have repeatedly tried to disparage his investigation. Those efforts evoke the scandals of President Bill Clinton\u2019s administration and his White House\u2019s attempt to portray the independent counsel, Kenneth W. Starr, as a partisan who had run amok.", "title": "Paul Manafort Sues Mueller and Asks a Judge to Narrow the Russia Investigation", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "How to avoid trouble? For starters, stop adding to your card balance except for emergencies, and seek better terms. \u201cThere\u2019s nothing wrong with calling your card issuer to see if you can get a lower rate,\u201d said Bill Hardekopf, chief executive of the card website LowCards.com. He suggests borrowers check their credit report before calling, so they know what kind of a rate they might reasonably expect. And, he advises, \u201cbe polite.\u201d\n\nCutting back on card charges isn\u2019t always easy to do. Julie Ford, a fee-only financial planner in New York City who works with clients in their 20s and 30s, said young adults in big cities could get carried away with lifestyle spending and lose track of their budgets amid social pressure to keep up. \u201cThat super-expensive gym membership becomes normalized,\u201d she said.\n\nJanuary is a good time for consumers to peruse credit card statements and consider what\u2019s really necessary, Ms. Ford said. She urges clients to consider why they got into debt in the first place \u2014 was it a one-time medical expense or emergency, or is it a more persistent problem of living beyond their means?\n\nIf it\u2019s continuous overspending, Ms. Ford suggests clients put off wardrobe updates and suspend those gym memberships, perhaps switching temporarily to jogging. The extra cash can go toward their card balances. Most of her clients are able to pay off the debt within a year. \u201cI tell them, \u2018This isn\u2019t forever,\u2019\u201d she said.\n\nLauren Zangardi Haynes, a fee-only planner with Evolution Advisers in Midlothian, Va., suggests setting spending limits for any discretionary items to manage card spending. For instance, she said, she cooks at home frequently and enjoys serving wine with meals. So she established a monthly budget for wine, and makes a trip each month to buy it all at once; when the wine is gone, that\u2019s it until the next month. Buying wine in bulk means \u201cyou get a lot of strange looks,\u201d she said, but helps keep a lid on \u201cbudget bleed.\u201d", "title": "Pay Down Those Credit Cards, Before Rates Rise Further", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "Peggy Cummins, an actress best remembered for her turn as a femme fatale with a hair trigger in the influential low-budget film noir \u201cGun Crazy,\u201d died on Dec. 29 in London. She was 92.\n\nShe died after a stroke, her friend Dee Kirkwood said in an email message.\n\nSlender, blond and young, Ms. Cummins, who grew up in Ireland and moved to the United States in 1945, had more often played innocents before being cast in \u201cGun Crazy.\u201d\n\nIn \u201cGun Crazy\u201d (also known as \u201cDeadly Is the Female\u201d), released in 1950, she played Annie Laurie Starr, a seductive carnival sharpshooter who marries a gun-obsessed Army veteran, played by John Dall, and goads him into an increasingly violent crime spree.\n\nThe script, based on a story by MacKinlay Kantor, was written by Mr. Kantor and the celebrated screenwriter Dalton Trumbo. But because Trumbo was blacklisted at the time, it was credited to another writer, Millard Kaufman. The film was shot in 30 days, cost $400,000 and was released to little fanfare.", "title": "Peggy Cummins, Seductive Star of a Cult Film, Dies at 92", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-31 00:00:00", "text": "Unlike Dr. Nassar, practitioners of pelvic floor physical therapy always wear gloves, which prevent infections but also make patients more comfortable. They manipulate muscles to release and elongate those that are tense and shortened or to strengthen weakened muscles. They often assign patients exercises to do at home.\n\n\u201cThere is nothing sexual about it,\u201d said Rhonda Kotarinos, a physical therapist in Chicago who specializes in the pelvic floor and is an author of several studies on the therapy.\n\nShe, like many other practitioners, now worries that women with pelvic problems who could benefit from the treatment will be reluctant to seek help for fear of being abused.\n\n\u201cThere could be a backlash from this,\u201d Dr. Kotarinos said. \u201cBut if people decide physical therapists should not do this work, a lot of women will suffer with pain and a markedly compromised quality of life.\u201d (Men also develop chronic pelvic pain that can benefit from the treatment, but in that case massage is typically performed through the anus.)\n\nMany cases of muscle-based pelvic pain remain undiagnosed or under-treated, experts say, and patients often turn to medication or surgery instead of first trying more conservative approaches like physical therapy.\n\n\u201cMuch of the general public doesn\u2019t realize what we as physical therapists have to offer them,\u201d said Lori Mize, director of education for the section on women\u2019s health of the American Physical Therapy Association and an assistant professor of physical therapy at Lynchburg College in Virginia.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nSome patients who come to a physical therapist will say they aren\u2019t comfortable with transvaginal manipulation, and therapists say they utilize it only if the patient both understands what\u2019s involved and freely consents. Furthermore, they generally offer it only after other interventions have failed.\n\nKaren Connor, a physical therapist also with University Hospitals in Cleveland, said she uses three-dimensional anatomical models of the pelvis to explain to patients what\u2019s entailed.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI\u2019ve had patients who say, \u2018I\u2019m just not ready for it yet,\u2019\u201d Dr. Connor said. \u201cI say \u2018that\u2019s fine, we can work on hip weakness and tightness in the back, and that can impact the pelvic floor.\u2019 The patient is always in control.\u201d\n\nDr. Kotarinos helped design the protocol for trials comparing pelvic floor physical therapy to other treatments. She is one of the authors of a 2013 study, published in the Journal of Urology, that randomly assigned 81 women with pelvic floor tenderness and painful bladder syndrome to either 10 sessions of pelvic floor physical therapy involving targeted internal and external muscle manipulation or 10 sessions of full body massage.\n\nWomen who received the targeted pelvic floor therapy were more likely to respond to therapy, with 59 percent experiencing improvement in symptoms compared with 26 percent in the full body massage group, though both groups saw easing of pain and urinary problems. (A limitation of these studies is that patients cannot be \u201cblinded\u201d to their form of treatment, which can influence results.)\n\nAnother small study by Dr. Mahajan that examined patient charts from her clinical center found pain scores improved after patients started getting pelvic floor physical therapy and improvement increased in direct proportion to the number of sessions patients had. Of the 75 patients whose cases were examined, 63 percent reported significant pain improvement.\n\nThough many women develop pelvic problems after childbirth or later in life, Dr. Mahajan said gymnasts are prone to pelvic floor problems because they land hard and slam on to the floor repeatedly. She said it was \u201cnot inconceivable\u201d the therapy might be appropriate for them under certain circumstances.\n\nBut several physical therapists said they would suggest the therapy to girls under 18 only as a \u201clast resort\u201d in extreme cases of severe injury, and once other treatments had failed. And it should always be done with safeguards in place.\n\n\u201cI use this every day in my own practice,\u201d Dr. Mahajan said, \u201cbut it\u2019s always with gloves, by a female therapist, with consent, and supervised. When they\u2019re in my office, we have a chaperone. These safeguards must be in place.\u201d", "title": "Pelvic Massage Can Be Legitimate, but Not in Larry Nassar\u2019s Hands", "authors": ["Roni Caryn Rabin"]} {"date": "2018-01-20 00:00:00", "text": "CAIRO \u2014 Vice President Mike Pence and the Egyptian leader Abdel Fattah el-Sisi pledged a united front against terrorism in the Middle East as Mr. Pence, the highest-level American official to visit the United States ally in nearly a decade, began a trip through the region after leaving behind a government shutdown in Washington.\n\nThe meetings focused on security cooperation and economic ties between the two countries as well as efforts to fight the Islamic State. The vice president called it a \u201cvery productive\u201d meeting and said he pressed Mr. Sisi to cut diplomatic ties with North Korea, urged him to respect religious diversity, and said the United States was committed to Israeli-Palestinian peace efforts.\n\nMr. Pence and Mr. Sisi met for two and a half hours at the presidential palace in Cairo. Mr. Pence pointed to President Trump\u2019s efforts to forge stronger ties with Mr. Sisi in his first year in office, \u201cafter a time when our countries seemed to be drifting apart.\u201d\n\nMr. Pence arrived in Cairo hours after Congress failed to reach agreement on a plan to avert a partial shutdown of the federal government. Mr. Pence went ahead with his four-day trip to the Middle East despite the political turmoil at home, citing national security and diplomatic reasons.", "title": "Pence Praises Egypt Partnership in Meeting With Sisi", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cBut we know that in another 24 hours he will not be here,\u201d Mr. Gabbay added. \u201cHe will be on his way to his next destination and we \u2014 I will let you in on a little secret \u2014 remain here. We remain with 4.5 million Palestinians, and this visit does not change this fact, and this visit also does not change our obligation to solve this problem and not to roll it over to our children.\u201d\n\nMr. Pence was the first United States vice president to address the Knesset, or parliament, and members of Mr. Netanyahu\u2019s right-wing government reached for superlatives to describe the event. Ayelet Shaked, the justice minister, thanked Mr. Pence on Twitter for what she called his \u201chistoric, unique\u201d and \u201csupremely Zionist\u201d speech.\n\nIt was all in stark contrast to the discordant years of the Obama administration, when a 2010 visit by Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. ended in bitter recrimination. In an ill-timed move as Mr. Biden was pushing a peace agenda, Israel unveiled plans for 1,600 new housing units for Jews in East Jerusalem, which the Palestinians claim as their future capital.\n\nStill, when Mr. Pence told the Israeli legislators that the Trump administration was committed to achieving a lasting peace between Israelis and Palestinians and would support a two-state solution to the conflict if both sides agreed, Mr. Netanyahu, who jumped up for numerous standing ovations, did not applaud.\n\nNeither did the Palestinians.\n\nEnraged by Mr. Trump\u2019s decision on Jerusalem, a move that overturned decades of American policy and defied international consensus on the holy city\u2019s status, they boycotted Mr. Pence\u2019s visit.\n\nPresident Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority was in Brussels to meet with the European Union\u2019s 28 foreign ministers on Monday. There, he said the only way to achieve peace was through negotiations under international supervision, according to Wafa, the official Palestinian news agency.\n\nBacktracking slightly on previous statements rejecting any American role in the peace process, Riad Malki, the Palestinian foreign minister, said on Tuesday that Mr. Abbas had ruled out any absolute American \u201cmonopoly\u201d of the process. But he did suggest alternative sponsorship, such as the so-called Quartet of Middle East peacemakers made up of the United States, the United Nations, the European Union and Russia.", "title": "Pence Visit Was a Balm to Israelis. Now Back to Reality.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-21 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Pence had delayed his trip to the region amid the furor over Mr. Trump\u2019s decisions, which were seen here as pro-Israel and a slap in the face to Palestinians. Mahmoud Abbas, the Palestinian Authority president, canceled a meeting with Mr. Pence planned for this trip. The Trump administration said the delay was unrelated to the rising anti-American sentiment in the Middle East.\n\nMr. Pence called Mr. Trump\u2019s recognition of Jerusalem as Israel\u2019s capital \u201ca historic decision,\u201d but insisted that the United States takes \u201cno position on boundaries and final status\u201d issues. Those issues are \u201csubject to negotiation,\u201d he said, according to Petra.\n\nHe also said that the United States was \u201ccommitted to continue to respect Jordan\u2019s role\u201d as the custodian of Muslim holy sites in Jerusalem.\n\nThere have been small but persistent protests in Jordan against Mr. Trump\u2019s announcement last month, and over the weekend a small group of protesters held a sign saying that Mr. Pence was unwelcome in Jordan. The protests led to the closing of roads around the United States Embassy in Amman.\n\n\u201cJordan is a small country surrounded by conflict, and there\u2019s tremendous pressure right now from the population to stand against U.S. and Israeli policies in the region,\u201d said Oraib al-Rantawi, the director of the Quds Center for Political Studies in Jordan.\n\nBut doing so is a delicate proposition for Jordan\u2019s government, which signed a peace treaty with Israel in 1994 and is heavily dependent on American aid.\n\nThe United States has provided Jordan with more than $15 billion in economic and military aid since the 1950s. In 2015, the Obama administration and Jordan signed a three-year agreement in which the United States pledged $1 billion annually in foreign assistance, subject to the approval of Congress.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cTrump\u2019s decision on Jerusalem represented Jordan\u2019s worst fears when it comes to the peace process,\u201d said Amer Sabaileh, a political analyst and columnist in Amman. \u201cYet Jordan knows perfectly well it\u2019s impossible to go against the United States.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut recently there have been signs that Jordan\u2019s role in the region is changing.\n\nSaudi Arabia\u2019s strategic shift to align itself with Israel and the Trump administration in recent months, in an effort by all three countries to counter Iran, has diminished Jordan\u2019s role as regional mediator with Israel and power broker in the Israeli-Palestinian peace process.\n\n\u201cNow that the regional axis of power is firmly in the Gulf, Jordan simply doesn\u2019t have the strategic importance it used to,\u201d said Sean Yom, an associate professor of political science at Temple University.\n\nIn another blow to Jordan, the Trump administration announced last week that it would withhold $65 million in aid to the United Nations Relief and Works Agency, which aids Palestinian refugees. Mr. Trump had angrily called American aid to Palestinians worthless after Palestinian leaders said the United States should no longer play a role in peace talks with Israel.\n\nThe State Department said the funding decision was intended to encourage other countries to increase aid and to promote reform at the relief agency.\n\nUnless other countries fill the gap, the reduced funding could have a huge impact on Jordan, which has more than two million registered Palestinian refugees who rely on the agency for education and health services. Several hundred thousand Palestinians live in 10 refugee camps administered by the agency.\n\n\u201cThe economic situation is already quite bad in Jordan, and Trump\u2019s decision will impact people like us directly,\u201d said Abdul Rahman Qanas, 52, a resident of the Baqaa refugee camp, the largest in Jordan, with about 100,000 residents.\n\nThe refugee agency provides Mr. Qanas with blood pressure medicine every month and routine checkups for his family. All of his children attended the agency\u2019s schools.\n\n\u201cTrump and Israel want to end the Palestinian cause; they want to erase the idea of Palestinian refugees,\u201d he said. \u201cThey want to pressure Jordan, the Palestinians and others to give into the demands of an imaginary peace process that benefits only Israel, and that is unacceptable.\u201d\n\nMr. Pence is to continue his trip in Israel on Monday.", "title": "Pence and Jordan\u2019s King \u2018Agree to Disagree\u2019 on Jerusalem", "authors": ["Rana F. Sweis"]} {"date": "2018-01-22 00:00:00", "text": "Pennsylvania is a swing state that has backed governors, senators and presidential candidates from both political parties in the last two election cycles. But as the state\u2019s map is now drawn, Republicans control 13 of the state\u2019s 18 House seats. Outside experts say that a nonpartisan district map could move as many as three of those seats over to the Democratic column.\n\nThe Pennsylvania ruling could also add some momentum to a clear movement in lower federal courts toward reining in the most severe partisan gerrymanders. Three-judge federal panels have already invalidated the district maps for the Wisconsin State Assembly and North Carolina\u2019s congressional map, saying they are unconstitutionally tilted toward one party \u2014 in both cases, the Republicans. Each panel\u2019s ruling broke new ground.\n\nThe United States Supreme Court has stayed those decisions while it considers the Wisconsin case, and one from Maryland challenging a congressional map drawn by Democrats that eliminated a longtime Republican district.\n\nSo unless the Supreme Court intervenes in the Pennsylvania case as well, the state may be the only one where a new court-ordered map will take effect in time for the midterm elections. Primaries for the state\u2019s congressional representatives are scheduled for May 15.\n\nIn Monday\u2019s decision, the Pennsylvania Supreme Court split along party lines in striking down the state\u2019s House map, with the court\u2019s five Democrats in the majority and its two Republican judges in dissent. The majority did not lay out its reasons on Monday, saying they will be explained in a later written opinion.\n\nThe original complaint, filed in June, relied heavily on an argument that the map violated the state Constitution\u2019s freedom-of-speech guarantees, which are broader than those in the federal Constitution.\n\nGerrymander opponents have argued in both state and federal lawsuits that partisan redistricting violates the First Amendment by punishing one party\u2019s voters for speaking with their votes in opposition to the other party. Among the evidence presented by the plaintiffs\u2019 lawyers in the suit, originally brought by the League of Women Voters of Pennsylvania, was that as many as five seats held by Republicans would have been won by Democrats if \u201cneutral\u201d maps had been used, meaning maps that did not contort districts and divide communities.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nPennsylvania is considered one of the most gerrymandered states in the nation, with congressional districts twisted into fanciful shapes, including one that has been described as looking like \u201cGoofy kicking Donald Duck.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe court order on Monday required the Legislature to submit a new map for the governor\u2019s approval or veto by Feb. 9. If new boundaries are not approved by Feb. 15, the court said, it would decide on a map itself, relying in part on suggestions from parties to the lawsuit.\n\nThe state court appeared to be less divided on the central issue of the case than the 5-2 party-line split might suggest. Chief Justice Thomas G. Saylor, a Republican, acknowledged in his dissent that recent federal court rulings \u201craise substantial concerns as to the constitutional viability of Pennsylvania\u2019s current congressional districts,\u201d but he argued that the court should have awaited the federal Supreme Court\u2019s decision in the Wisconsin gerrymander case, expected this spring, before making its own ruling.\n\n\u201cMy position at this juncture is only that I would not presently upset those districts,\u201d he wrote.\n\nA second dissent, by Justice Sallie Updyke Mundy, endorsed Justice Saylor\u2019s views, and added a warning that involving the State Supreme Court in redrawing the map could raise federal constitutional questions.\n\nRepublicans in the State Senate said they would ask the State Supreme Court to stay its order for new maps, and made it clear that they would try to take the matter to a federal court. But legal experts said their chances appeared slim at best, because federal courts generally have no authority to review state court decisions that exclusively involve state law. The State Supreme Court took pains to say that the state Constitution was the \u201csole basis\u201d for its ruling requiring a new map.\n\nThe most likely argument for federal review, election scholars said, is that the court order violated the federal Constitution\u2019s elections clause, which delegates authority over elections to state legislatures. The Supreme Court entertained a similar argument in Bush v. Gore, the case that determined the outcome of the 2000 presidential election. But the court later narrowly rejected the idea that state legislatures have sole authority over elections in a 2015 decision that, fittingly, dealt with redistricting in Arizona.\n\n\u201cThis case was designed from the get-go to get to the Pennsylvania Supreme Court and no further,\u201d said Justin Levitt, an election-law scholar and associate dean at Loyola Law School in Los Angeles. \u201cThere are one or two exceedingly long-shot ways that Republicans might attempt to get this in front of the Supreme Court. But I would not lay odds on that.\u201d\n\nMonday\u2019s decision, should it stand, adds one more cut in a calamitous year for Pennsylvania\u2019s Republican House delegation. Representative Tim Murphy resigned his seat after he reportedly asked a woman who he had an extramarital relationship with to seek an abortion. A special election to replace him is scheduled for March 13, and the State Supreme Court order said it would be held under the existing House map.\n\nOver the weekend, Representative Patrick Meehan was removed from the House Ethics Committee after The New York Times reported that he had settled a sex harassment complaint brought by a former aide. Mr. Meehan represents the \u201cGoofy kicking Donald Duck\u201d district, the Seventh, in the southeastern part of the state.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re going to have a whole series of very competitive congressional elections with a lot of uncertainty,\u201d said G. Terry Madonna, director of the Franklin & Marshall College poll and a longtime analyst of Pennsylvania politics. If Republicans are forced to redraw the boundaries, Mr. Madonna said, they might \u201csacrifice\u201d Mr. Meehan\u2019s district to shore up other Republican districts in a way that could pass muster with the court.", "title": "Pennsylvania Congressional District Map Is Ruled Unconstitutional", "authors": ["Michael Wines", "Trip Gabriel"]} {"date": "2018-01-07 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThis case is particularly heinous because the perpetrator is a public official, sworn to serve and protect the community,\u201d Josh Shapiro, the Pennsylvania attorney general, said in a statement.\n\nPhoto\n\nCourt documents show that Chief Diebold was sent to the Westmoreland County Prison and his bail was set at $500,000.\n\nIn an affidavit of probable cause, the special agent who posed as the girl wrote that he responded to an online advertisement from Chief Diebold in September.\n\nChief Diebold described himself in the advertisement as a \u201cdominate male police officer\u201d seeking a fun and discreet \u201cplaymate,\u201d according to the affidavit. Chief Diebold went by the username \u201cKutecop4you,\u201d the document said.\n\nThe affidavit also provides the text of a message and descriptions of images Chief Diebold sent to the agent who posed as the girl.\n\nAfter Chief Diebold was charged, the affidavit said, he acknowledged that he knew that sexual contact with a 14-year-old girl \u201cwas wrong and illegal and that his life was totally over.\u201d\n\nOne of Mr. Diebold\u2019s lawyers, Duke George, said in a phone interview on Sunday that the bond was \u201cexorbitant\u201d and \u201cunbelievable.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI represent people on homicide cases that don\u2019t have bonds that high,\u201d Mr. George said. \u201cUp until this point in time concerning the allegations against him, there is nothing in his background that indicates he would be a danger to society.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Get the Morning Briefing by Email What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox Monday through Friday.
