View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. George said that arrangements were being made to post bond and that Chief Diebold would plead not guilty at a preliminary hearing on Jan. 16.\n\nIn an interview with The Tribune-Review, Chief Diebold\u2019s mother, Karen Diebold, sought to distance herself from the allegations against her son.\n\n\u201cI just want to say that people have to not blame family members,\u201d she said. \u201cIt\u2019s hard enough as it is to go through this.\u201d\n\nShe added, \u201cIf Mike did it, then he\u2019s going to have to pay the price, but what if he didn\u2019t?\u201d\n\nOn Sunday, she declined to comment and referred questions to her son\u2019s lawyers.\n\nChief Diebold made headlines in June when he lost his left hand and part of his forearm in a fireworks accident. Last year the chief was married and the couple had a baby boy, Wayne Dobos, the mayor of Leechburg, said in a phone interview on Sunday.\n\n\u201cSometimes something is just so shocking that how do you describe it? What do you say?\u201d he said, adding that he had known Chief Diebold \u201call his life.\u201d\n\nFor the time being, Chief Diebold still holds his position at the Police Department, Mr. Dobos said.\n\n\u201cThe community is going to have to heal and everybody is going to have to work together to get this all worked out,\u201d he said. \u201cWho thinks that tomorrow we\u2019ll say, \u2018Gee, the chief of police is going to get arrested for soliciting sex from a minor.\u2019 I mean, that doesn\u2019t just run through your mind.\u201d", "title": "Pennsylvania Police Chief Charged in Undercover Sex Sting", "authors": ["Matt Stevens", "Christina Caron"]} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "It seemed like a nightmare at the time: In late October, a New York advocacy group for people with special needs issued a blistering report that a treatment center in Pennsylvania was breaking the law by restraining its residents, among them, a child with an intellectual disability.\n\nIn less than a decade, the report claimed, negligence by the center, Woods Services, had led to the deaths of two New York residents. One, the report claimed, was run over by several cars in 2009 when staff members failed to supervise him. The following year, the report found, another resident suffocated in a hot car.\n\nOn Wednesday, Woods Services fought back, filing a defamation lawsuit in Federal District Court in Philadelphia claiming that the report by the advocacy group, Disability Rights New York, was rife with \u201cunfounded accusations, misleading characterizations and outright falsehoods.\u201d The suit, which seeks unspecified damages, asked a federal judge to issue two court orders: one declaring that the report was false, the second requiring Disability Rights New York to issue a retraction and an apology.\n\n\u201cWoods has a century-long legacy of delivering on our mission,\u201d a spokeswoman for the center, Cheryl Kauffman, said. \u201cThat includes our obligation to zealously safeguard and protect the individuals we serve and the staff who serve them.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAccording to the lawsuit, the advocacy group\u2019s report, which ended an investigation that began in June 2016, made 34 recommendations for \u201ccorrective actions,\u201d but ignored the fact that Disability Rights New York knew \u2014 or should have known \u2014 that most of the suggestions were already in place, were impossible to install or would \u201cdegrade resident safety.\u201d The suit also said that instead of allowing Woods Services to review and respond before the report was published, Disability Rights New York released it through its website and social media accounts.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn the days and weeks after the report, the lawsuit said, Woods Services saw a decline in resident referrals and received several inquiries from the family members of its residents, inquiring about its practices.\n\nIt was also subject to numerous investigations by oversight agencies.\n\nWhile the investigations found no basis for the allegations of neglect and abuse contained in the report, the lawsuit said, they did require \u201cWoods to invest significant time and energy in responding.\u201d That time and energy, the lawsuit said, could have been devoted to its residents.", "title": "Pennsylvania Treatment Center Files Defamation Suit Against Advocate for the Disabled", "authors": ["Alan Feuer"]} {"date": "2018-01-16 00:00:00", "text": "The Pentagon declined to comment on the draft assessment because Mr. Trump has not yet approved it. The White House also declined to comment.\n\nBut three current and former senior government officials said large cyberattacks against the United States and its interests would be included in the kinds of foreign aggression that could justify a nuclear response \u2014 though they stressed there would be other, more conventional options for retaliation. The officials spoke on the condition of anonymity because they are not authorized to discuss the proposed policy.\n\nGary Samore, who was a top nuclear adviser to President Barack Obama, said much of the draft strategy \u201crepeats the essential elements of Obama declaratory policy word for word\u201d \u2014 including its declaration that the United States would \u201conly consider the use of nuclear weapons in extreme circumstances to defend the vital interests of the United States or its allies and partners.\u201d\n\nBut the biggest difference lies in new wording about what constitutes \u201cextreme circumstances.\u201d\n\nIn the Trump administration\u2019s draft, those \u201ccircumstances could include significant non-nuclear strategic attacks.\u201d It said that could include \u201cattacks on the U.S., allied, or partner civilian population or infrastructure, and attacks on U.S. or allied nuclear forces, their command and control, or warning and attack assessment capabilities.\u201d\n\nThe draft does not explicitly say that a crippling cyberattack against the United States would be among the extreme circumstances. But experts called a cyberattack one of the most efficient ways to paralyze systems like the power grid, cellphone networks and the backbone of the internet without using nuclear weapons.\n\n\u201cIn 2001, we struggled with how to establish deterrence for terrorism because terrorists don\u2019t have populations or territory to hold at risk. Cyber poses a similar quandary,\u201d said Kori Schake, a senior National Security Council and State Department official during President George W. Bush\u2019s administration, who is now the deputy director general of the International Institute for Strategic Studies in London.\n\n\u201cSo if cyber can cause physical malfunction of major infrastructure resulting in deaths,\u201d Ms. Schake said, the Pentagon has now found a way \u201cto establish a deterrent dynamic.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe draft review also cites \u201cparticular concern\u201d about \u201cexpanding threats in space and cyberspace\u201d to the command-and-control systems of the American nuclear arsenal that the review identifies as a \u201clegacy of the Cold War.\u201d It was the latest warning in a growing chorus that the nuclear response networks could themselves be disabled or fed false data in a cyberattack.\n\nSo far, all of the United States\u2019 leading adversaries \u2014 including Russia, China, North Korea and Iran \u2014 have stopped well short of the kind of cyberattacks that could prompt a larger, and more violent response.\n\nThe Russians have placed malware called \u201cBlack Energy\u201d in American utility systems, but never tried to cause a major blackout. They have sent cable-cutting submarines along the path of undersea fiber optic lines that connect the continents, but not cut them. North Korea has attacked companies like Sony, and used cyberweapons to cause chaos in the British health care system, but never directly taken on the United States.\n\nStill, the document recognizes that American, Russian and Chinese strategies have all been updated in recent years to reflect the reality that any conflict would begin with a lightning strike on space and communications systems. During the Obama administration, for example, a secret program, code-named \u201cNitro Zeus,\u201d called for a blinding cyberattack on Iran in the event negotiations over its nuclear program failed and Washington found itself going to war with Tehran.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThere are other differences with the Obama administration policy.\n\nThe draft strategy embraces the American production of a new generation of small, low-yield nuclear weapons \u2014 some of which were under development during the Obama administration. Some experts warn that such smaller weapons can blur the distinction between nuclear and non-nuclear weapons, and, as a result, be more tempting to use.\n\nAnd it states outright that Russia is testing its first autonomous nuclear torpedo, one that American officials believe would be guided largely by artificial intelligence to strike the United States even if communications with Moscow were terminated. It was Washington\u2019s first public acknowledgment of such an undersea weapon, a prototype of which was first envisioned in the 1960s by Andrei Sakharov, the physicist who later ranked among the Soviet Union\u2019s most famous dissidents.\n\nThe torpedo\u2019s development was detected by the Obama administration and has been widely discussed in defense circles, but never publicly referred to by the Pentagon as a significant future threat.\n\nMr. Trump has rarely publicly criticized President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia for Russia\u2019s aggressions around the world. But the Pentagon document describes Moscow\u2019s actions as so destabilizing that the United States may be forced to reverse Mr. Obama\u2019s commitment to reduce the role and size of the American nuclear arsenal.\n\nRussia is adopting \u201cmilitary strategies and capabilities that rely on nuclear escalation for their success,\u201d Defense Secretary Jim Mattis wrote in an introduction to the report. \u201cThese developments, coupled with Russia\u2019s invasion of Crimea and nuclear threats against our allies, mark Moscow\u2019s unabashed return to Great Power competition.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn most cases, the Trump administration plan would simply move forward nuclear weapons that Mr. Obama had endorsed, such as a new generation of nuclear cruise missiles \u2014 low-flying weapons with stubby wings that, when dropped from a bomber, hug the ground to avoid enemy radars and air defenses.\n\nBut the strategy envisions other new nuclear weapons. The draft policy calls for \u201cthe rapid development\u201d of a cruise missile to be fired from submarines. Mr. Obama had retired that class. It also calls for the development of a low-yield warhead for ballistic missiles fired from submarines.\n\nIt is relatively easy for presidents to change the country\u2019s declaratory policy on the use of nuclear arms and quite difficult for them to reshape its nuclear arsenal, which takes not only vast sums of money but many years and sometimes decades of planning and implementation.\n\nThe price tag for a 30-year makeover of the United States\u2019 nuclear arsenal was put last year at $1.2 trillion. Analysts said the expanded Trump administration plan would push the bill much higher, noting that firm estimates will have to wait until the proposed federal budget for the 2019 fiscal year is made public.\n\n\u201cAlmost everything about this radical new policy will blur the line between nuclear and conventional,\u201d said Andrew C. Weber, an assistant defense secretary during the Obama administration who directed an interagency panel that oversaw the country\u2019s nuclear arsenal.\n\nIf adopted, he added, the new policy \u201cwill make nuclear war a lot more likely.\u201d\n\nOne of the document\u2019s edgiest conclusions involves the existence of a deadly new class of Russian nuclear torpedo \u2014 a cigar-shaped underwater missile meant to be fired from a submarine.\n\nTorpedoes tipped with nuclear arms were common during the Cold War, with the Soviet Union pioneering the weapons and developing them most vigorously. One Soviet model had a range of miles and a large warhead.\n\nMr. Sakharov, a famous Russian dissident in the 1970s and 1980s, envisioned a giant torpedo able to travel several hundred miles and incur heavy casualties with a warhead thousands of times more powerful than the Hiroshima bomb. Though his vision was rejected at the time, the new review discloses that Moscow has resurrected a weapon along the same lines.\n\nThe document calls it \u201ca new intercontinental, nuclear-armed undersea autonomous torpedo.\u201d In a diagram labeled \u201cNew Nuclear Delivery Vehicles over the Past Decade,\u201d it identifies the torpedo by its code name, Status-6.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nNews stories have reported the possible existence of such a weapon since at least 2015, but the document\u2019s reference appears to be the first time the federal government has confirmed its existence. The long-range torpedo with a monster warhead is apparently meant to shower coastal regions with deadly radioactivity, leaving cities uninhabitable.", "title": "Pentagon Suggests Countering Devastating Cyberattacks With Nuclear Arms", "authors": ["David E. Sanger", "William J. Broad"]} {"date": "2018-01-29 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cEven though Percoco was physically gone, his power never left,\u201d the prosecutor, Mr. Boone, said last week.\n\nA chart presented by a federal investigator to the jury on Monday showed that between May 1 and Dec. 7, 2014, the period when Mr. Percoco was running Mr. Cuomo\u2019s campaign, 837 calls were made on 68 days from the telephone on the desk he had formerly used in the governor\u2019s executive chamber in Manhattan, a suite of offices at 633 Third Avenue.\n\nDuring cross-examination, defense lawyers on Monday seemed to be trying to show that there was no way of knowing who was actually placing the calls from Mr. Percoco\u2019s office telephone.\n\nAnother chart showed that on Dec. 3, 2014 \u2014 just days before Mr. Percoco was rehired as a top state aide to the governor \u2014 Mr. Percoco\u2019s swipe card was used to enter the executive chamber office on the 38th floor in Manhattan.\n\nIt has been unclear throughout the trial just how much Mr. Percoco used his former state offices during the eight months that he was working on the campaign.\n\nMr. Cuomo, a Democrat, has not been accused of any wrongdoing, and his office has not commented during the trial.\n\nThe governor\u2019s chief of staff, Linda Lacewell, testified last week that after Mr. Percoco resigned in April 2014, she occasionally saw him in the governor\u2019s chamber in Manhattan.", "title": "Percoco Kept His Hands in Albany, Even After Quitting His State Job", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-16 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cAs a young line cook, I\u2019d eat when I could and I liked to feel full,\u201d says Angela Dimayuga, known for her prowess behind a wok and as the former executive chef of Mission Chinese Food in New York. \u201cNow, I think a lot more about what I put into my body and notice how I feel afterward.\u201d In her Brooklyn apartment, she cooks mostly with vegetables and tries to include healthy grains and proteins in her meals; she also enjoys the process of fermenting and thus keeps a steady diet of probiotics through kefir, sauerkraut, kimchi, kombucha and natto (fermented soybeans \u2014 a Japanese superfood). Also perennially on her menu during the winter months: fuyu persimmons, plucked straight from a tree in her childhood backyard in San Jose, Calif., and sent to Dimayuga by her mom each November.\n\nDimayuga says that she didn\u2019t like persimmons as a child, instead (and rather poetically) developing a taste for the fruit as an adult, only when she strayed far from the tree. Also, she adds, \u201cA lot of people don\u2019t know what to do with them.\u201d She eats some as soon as she receives her mom\u2019s package and the persimmons are \u201cin the apple-crunchy stage,\u201d and then stores the rest in her refrigerator, where they slowly ripen throughout the winter.\n\nImage Dimayuga at home in Brooklyn. Credit Matthew Novak\n\nThe fruit ultimately becomes breakfast fare, either as a smoothie or atop porridge. The former calls for persimmons that are soft to the touch and \u201cfeel like a basic unripe grocery-store tomato,\u201d which Dimayuga quarters and blends into a persimmon-sesame milk smoothie. She drinks it with a side of toast smeared with butter, sea salt and nutritional yeast, a recipe from her girlfriend that, Dimayuga emphasizes, only works with good, hearty bread. She also stirs up what she has dubbed People\u2019s Coffee \u2014 a mixture of half drip coffee and half homemade Chai plus a splash of milk, inspired by a recent sojourn in Northern California and trips to Bolinas People\u2019s Store.", "title": "Persimmons for Breakfast, Two (Healthy) Ways", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "The design by Lauren Ver Hage, who gets billing on the cover, also helps make the book appealing by making important ideas and intriguing thoughts jump out. For example, this sentence gets its own page: \u201cThe scariest thing about buying a home, in a lot of ways, is that it requires you do a not-insignificant amount of math.\u201d\n\nWidespread Appeal\n\nSo many finance books are relentlessly masculine in tone and focus that it\u2019s worth mentioning that this one skews female: Most of the experts quoted are women, and many references, to television shows like \u201cSex and the City,\u201d appear to be oriented toward women, too. But her advice is universal.\n\nFor example, she suggests saving a combined 20 percent of your income for both short and long-term goals. And, she notes, \u201cSaving, living below your means, and diversifying your income often make the difference between being stuck in a job you can\u2019t stand and having the freedom to move on to something better.\u201d These ideas apply to just about everyone.\n\nFind Your Fund Explore Fund Results \u00bb See how the largest, leading and lagging funds compare. Search by Category \u00bb Find funds by their type, performance, risk or expenses. For more fund information, search morningstar.com.\n\nSo why does she not get a higher grade? For two interrelated reasons that boil down to this: She seems to advocate putting too much money into investments that are too conservative for younger investors.\n\nThe good news is Ms. Fagan is terrific about emphasizing the need to save. Early on, she creates \u201cA Bank Account Pyramid,\u201d explaining where to put the money and when, and she also makes saving money a significant part of a five-point plan that she describes as \u201cThe Total Idiot\u2019s Guide to Investing.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut if you look at both, it is easy to see the two problems.\n\nA Few Flaws\n\nThe pyramid starts out with a strong base: Have a basic savings account to house your emergency fund.\n\nBut it gets shakier from there. In the next layer up, she calls for putting money in certificates of deposit, which are \u201cgood for things like saving to buy a house in the next few years and other medium-term savings.\u201d\n\nCertainly, you don\u2019t want your down payment to disappear in a market crash the day before the money is due. But having all your money tied up in low-yielding C.D.s for more than three years before you buy a home will make it hard for your money to grow. As I write this, a three-year C.D. yields about just 2.2 percent and a five-year one isn\u2019t much better, 2.6 percent. (Three to five years would seem to fit within Ms. Fagan\u2019s definition of medium-term savings.)\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nSo her argument about where to put money for medium-term objectives is debatable \u2014 my position would be to hold some stock, shifting the money to more conservative investments as your goal draws nigh. For example, have 100 percent of the money in equities when the goal is five years out; 60 percent in equities and 40 percent in short-term bond funds and C.D.s if you will need the money in 36 months, and only move all the money into short-term C.D.s a year before you have to write the check.\n\nMs. Fagan goes on to say that after putting cash into an emergency fund and buying C.D.s for short and intermediate goals, the rest of your savings should be in \u201clonger term investments.\u201d Like what? She doesn\u2019t say. A 30-year bond would qualify, but it\u2019s an awfully conservative place for a millennial investor saving for the long-term.\n\nThe same flaw exists in her investment guide. Her first two points are great. Again, it starts with the emergency fund, followed by working hard to pay off nondeductible debt. That is sound advice. But after that, things get squishy.\n\nHer third point about opening a retirement account is fine as far as it goes, but where do you put that money? Ms. Fagan doesn\u2019t tell us.\n\nAnd her last point is confusing. After taking the first three steps, she writes, \u201cExplore other low-risk options such as mutual funds and index funds.\u201d Now on the surface that\u2019s just wrong. Mutual funds and index funds that invest in equities, and bonds for that matter, have risk. As the prospectus of each always points out, you can lose money.\n\nGiving Ms. Fagan the benefit of the doubt, I think she was trying to say that index funds and other mutual funds carry less risk to your portfolio than investing in individual stocks.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHowever, there are fixed- income mutual funds that offer low yields. Simply saying invest in mutual funds is not helpful.\n\nBut to be fair, Ms. Fagan did not set out to write the definitive investment book, and she emphasizes throughout that if you are confused, \u201cIt\u2019s worth it to pay professionals\u201d to help you with things \u201cyou don\u2019t know how to do and will put off until it\u2019s too late.\u201d These quibbles aside, for the most part her advice and conclusions are solid.\n\n\u201cWe live in a world that encourages us to spend wastefully, accumulate more than we need, and put off things like retirement saving until \u2026 we are basically retired,\u201d she says. \u201d\n\nAnything that can help improve matters is a good thing.", "title": "Personal Finance for Those Who Don\u2019t Have a Clue", "authors": ["Paul B. Brown", "Off The Shelf"]} {"date": "2018-01-03 00:00:00", "text": "Passenger buses and cargo trucks have had no option but to use the Coil of Pasamayo, which is the formal name of the 10-mile stretch of road.\n\nPresident Pedro Pablo Kuczynski announced on Wednesday that he had instructed his minister of transportation and communications, Bruno Giuffra, to stop buses from using the hazardous road and to increase the capacity of the alternative route to accommodate buses.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s very painful to us as a country to suffer an accident of this magnitude,\u201d the president wrote on Twitter.\n\nInequality and poverty in Peru are high, meaning that those who rely on buses are often low-income Peruvians, while better-off people can afford to drive smaller vehicles, or share rides in them.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019ve been building roads for those who can afford cars, not for the people,\u201d said Mariana Alegre, a transit advocate who leads the organization Lima C\u00f3mo Vamos.\n\nPhoto\n\nFor all its danger, the Coil of Pasamayo is an almost unavoidable part of life in Peru. It is part of the country\u2019s main highway, the Pan-American Highway, which stretches along the entire western edge of the country. This particular stretch dates to the 19th century, when it was built as a railway.\n\nBoth the Devil\u2019s Curve and the alternative route are managed by a private conglomerate, Norvial, which has a contract to maintain the roads until 2027 and to collect the tolls.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nNorvial did not respond to a request for comment about the condition of the roads.\n\nOn Facebook, the company said it regretted the accident and expressed condolences to families of victims.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nReports prepared by Norvial for the government show that the company has invested heavily in cleaning up sand that falls from the steep cliffs onto the road, but they do not mention efforts to make the road safer.\n\nA 2011 report from Peru\u2019s Ministry of Transportation and Communications noted that both Pasamayo roads were among the most heavily traveled stretches of highway in the country. The Devil\u2019s Curve ranked as the second-most transited road for buses; the alternative road was seventh among roads used by personal vehicles.\n\nLorenzo Orrego, who runs Sutran, the agency that regulates vehicular transportation, said speed was a factor in the accident on Tuesday as was a tractor-trailer that drove into the lane occupied by the bus.\n\nMr. Giuffra, the transportation minister, said that both vehicles were moving in excess of the speed limit of 60 kilometers per hour, or about 37 miles per hour.\n\nMr. Orrego said any security precautions in the area would have been the responsibility of Norvial, not the government. But a unit within the ministry that oversees Norvial is said to be facing a restructuring in the wake of the accident, according to local news media reports.\n\nAccording to statistics maintained by Luz Ambar, a transportation safety organization, eight to 10 Peruvians die each day from traffic accidents.\n\nKevin Villalobos Rojas, 27, who was returning home on the bus after spending New Year\u2019s Day in the city of Huacho, was one of just a few survivors from the accident. Reached by phone, his brother Eric said that Mr. Villalobos was in intensive care at a hospital.\n\n\u201cThe company hasn\u2019t called us, it hasn\u2019t come to the hospital,\u201d Eric Villalobos said. \u201cAnd the government hasn\u2019t done anything either.\u201d", "title": "Peru Bans Buses From Road Where Bus Plunged, Killing 51", "authors": ["Marcelo Rochabr\u00fan"]} {"date": "2018-01-02 00:00:00", "text": "LIMA, Peru \u2014 At least 48 people were killed Tuesday when a bus tumbled down a cliff onto a rocky beach along a narrow stretch of highway known as the Devil\u2019s Curve, Peruvian police and fire officials said.\n\nThe bus was carrying 57 passengers to Lima, Peru\u2019s capital, when it was struck by a tractor-trailer shortly before noon and plunged down the slope, said Claudia Espinoza, who is with Peru\u2019s voluntary firefighter brigade.\n\nThe bus landed upside-down on a strip of shoreline next to the Pacific, the bodies of its passengers strewn among the rocks.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s very sad for us as a country to suffer an accident of this magnitude,\u201d President Pedro Pablo Kuczynski said in a statement.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nRescuers had to struggle to help survivors and recover the dead from the hard-to-reach area in Pasamayo, about 43 miles north of Lima.", "title": "Peru Bus Plunges Off \u2018Devil\u2019s Curve,\u2019 Killing at Least 48", "authors": ["The Associated Press"]} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cHe faces no limitations, he has regained all of his rights,\u201d Mr. Abad said.\n\nBut V\u00edctor Garc\u00eda Toma, a former justice minister and a former president of Peru\u2019s constitutional court, said there could be limitations to Mr. Fujimori\u2019s political activities.\n\n\u201cHe hasn\u2019t been given a pardon to regain his political career, but to preserve his health in a dignified way,\u201d Mr. Garc\u00eda Toma said.\n\nMr. Fujimori\u2019s doctor, Alejandro Aguinaga, said the former president had a \u201cserious heart condition\u201d and would be following a strict health regimen.\n\nThe pardon was issued three days after Kenji Fujimori led a crucial bloc in Congress that saved Mr. Kuczynski from impeachment. The pardon has been widely seen as a quid pro quo between the two politicians, and it ignited large protests in Lima.\n\nIn supporting Mr. Kuczynski, Kenji Fujimori was openly challenging his sister Keiko, who leads the Popular Force party and who supported impeachment. At the last minute, Kenji Fujimori and nine other lawmakers from the party acted to save Mr. Kuczynski\u2019s presidency, depriving the president\u2019s opponents of the supermajority they needed to remove him from office.\n\nSome of the lawmakers have said that Alberto Fujimori \u2014 who at that point was still imprisoned \u2014 asked them to disobey Keiko Fujimori\u2019s instructions.\n\nAs a result, Kenji Fujimori has emerged as a political leader in his own right, splitting the Popular Force, which had until now had been tightly controlled by his sister alone. The split has also altered the power balance in Congress, where Ms. Fujimori can no longer count on a congressional majority.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nKenji Fujimori, who is 37 and a graduate of Kansas State University, is the youngest of Alberto Fujimori\u2019s children and received more votes than any other Congressional candidate in the 2011 and 2016 elections.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe public brawl between brother and sister has shown the changing face of Fujimorismo \u2014 the political philosophy of Popular Force.\n\nOn Thursday afternoon, Popular Force issued a statement saying that it saluted Mr. Fujimori\u2019s pardoning but that it \u201cdisagreed with the way\u201d the pardon was carried out.\n\nFor his part, Kenji Fujimori has publicly said that his sister and her closest advisers tried to keep his father imprisoned. Of the advisers, Pier Figari and Ana Herz, he said they had \u201csystematically conspired for years\u201d against freeing his father. Popular Force issued a statement reiterating its \u201ctrust\u201d in the two advisers.\n\nCarlos Mel\u00e9ndez, a political scientist who has studied Fujimorismo, said the dispute pointed to the maturation of the party.\n\n\u201cFujimorismo started out as the political project of one man, but has devolved into a family project,\u201d Mr. Mel\u00e9ndez said.\n\n\u201cAlberto Fujimori has elevated political pragmatism to a point where he doesn\u2019t care about democratic values,\u201d Mr. Mel\u00e9ndez said. \u201cKeiko Fujimori is also a pragmatist, but we don\u2019t know if to the same extent.\u201d\n\nHuman rights lawyers have challenged Mr. Kuczynski\u2019s pardoning of Mr. Fujimori, hoping that either a local judge or a judge with the Inter-American Court of Human Rights will send him back to prison. That court has set a hearing for Feb. 2.\n\nMr. Fujimori\u2019s still owes some $8 million in civil penalties that were imposed as part of his sentencing, and the debt has raised questions about his living situation. He is currently staying at a house that, an online listing shows, costs $5,000 a month. The house has a large, terraced garden in the back. While imprisoned, Mr. Fujimori had taken to gardening.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Fujimori hasn\u2019t paid any of the money he owes, said Julio Arbizu, a former top government lawyer on anti-corruption matters who said he had devoted significant government resources to track down Mr. Fujimori\u2019s assets.\n\n\u201cThe problem was we didn\u2019t find any,\u201d Mr. Arbizu said, who tried to find the assets between 2011 and 2014. \u201cWe didn\u2019t find any trail of money saved in local or foreign banks, or assets or properties.\u201d\n\nWhen the government requested information about whether Mr. Fujimori had any source of income, Mr. Arbizu said it was told he had none. Even his legal address belonged to a friend, and Mr. Fujimori had never lived there. So his office couldn\u2019t seize the property.\n\nBut his release could lead to a newfound effort to recover that money.\n\n\u201cNow we know he has good money to pay for the house where he\u2019s staying,\u201d Mr. Arbizu said.", "title": "Peru\u2019s Fujimori Is Released From Hospital, After Outcry Over Pardon", "authors": ["Marcelo Rochabr\u00fan"]} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Holmes said that he had spent the previous week in Maui at a meditation and yoga retreat with the spiritual leader Ram Dass. But the \u201cspiritual cleansing,\u201d as he called it, was apparently no match for the stresses of Los Angeles traffic.\n\nHe was also facing a pile of deadlines. He needed to finish editing \u201cCrashing,\u201d the HBO show he created and stars in, and which returns for a second season on Jan. 14. And there was a mountain of emails in his inbox. The prospect of having to reply to each one seemed to overwhelm him.\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s a subtlety to the \u2018nonresponse response,\u2019\u201d Mr. Holmes said. \u201cSometimes these offers come in and I say, \u2018I\u2019ll think about it.\u2019 And \u2018I\u2019ll think about it\u2019 means \u2018Let me think about it.\u2019\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nHe continued: \u201cBut if it\u2019s a no, I\u2019m not going to write and say, \u2018It\u2019s a no.\u2019 When you\u2019re really hungry or desperate, a nonreply is a really mean thing. And you might hold that against somebody for years. And yet I do it with people who work for me.\u201d\n\nOne is left to imagine how much more frazzled Mr. Holmes would be if it weren\u2019t for his meditation retreats. \u201cI find spirituality so much more essential in a world like the one I live in now,\u201d he said, as he moved to the front porch, where he sank into a love seat, crossed his legs and, for the first time that afternoon, offered his undivided attention. \u201cIt\u2019s not just a Sunday-only thing for me. It\u2019s something I\u2019m constantly reading and thinking about.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSpirituality is in his blood. Raised in the Boston suburb of Lexington, Mr. Holmes attended Gordon College, an evangelical Christian liberal arts school. He married his first girlfriend, at 22, less than a year after graduating, and began performing stand-up comedy.\n\nHis early material was PG rated, but getting divorced six years later forced him to re-evaluate his life. And his comedy.\n\nHe began making a name for himself as a slightly goofy but confessional voice on the stand-up circuit, culminating in an appearance on \u201cLate Night With Jimmy Fallon\u201d in 2010. The next year, he appeared on \u201cConan.\u201d A TBS network executive took notice of his skill set \u2014 a relatable brand of comedy with cross-generational appeal \u2014 and, in 2013, gave Mr. Holmes his own late-night series.\n\n\u201cThe Pete Holmes Show\u201d combined sketch comedy, live performance and in-studio interviews, but ran for only two seasons. Since then, Mr. Holmes has mined his own history for a popular podcast, \u201cYou Made It Weird.\u201d \u201cCrashing,\u201d which started as a self-deprecating joke on his TBS show, came to fruition in the hands of the comedy bigwig Judd Apatow.\n\nWhile Mr. Holmes still embraces his Christian upbringing, he has begun to explore Buddhism. In Hollywood, where he has lived for seven years, \u201cthe pitfall of buying and believing your own hype is a deep, echoing, wet, cold sadness,\u201d he said. \u201cFor me, religion and spirituality is about reintegrating with people, with community, with connection, with union.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Of the Moment The lifestyle newsletter from the Styles, Travel and Food sections, offering the latest trends to news you can use. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIt\u2019s also why he enjoys getting out in his neighborhood. \u201cWant to grab a coffee?\u201d he said suddenly, unfurling his 6-foot-5 frame from the gray couch.\n\nMr. Holmes placed a leash on Brody, opened the front gate and walked down a restaurant-filled stretch of Vermont Avenue. Three blocks away, he arrived at Bru Coffeebar, a third-wave coffee shop that brews its free-trade beans proudly. Mr. Holmes exchanged pleasantries with a barista and ordered a double espresso.\n\nBefore he could sit down, however, his phone rang. It was his publicist. She had arrived at his house and was wondering where he was. He told her he\u2019d be back in 10 minutes.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI always forget they\u2019re coming,\u201d he said with a look of disgust. When he signed a deal for \u201cCrashing,\u201d Mr. Holmes decided it was time to hire publicists. Still, he questions their utility. \u201cIt\u2019s like still somebody who is just there trying not to be there,\u201d he said, as he exited the coffee shop.\n\n\u201cCrashing\u201d draws extensively from Mr. Holmes\u2019s life: It follows Pete, a religious Christian comedian whose wife cheats on him, forcing him to question his faith and dedicate all his efforts to a stand-up career. Not that success has made Mr. Holmes feel like any less of a grinder.\n\n\u201cYou\u2019re always climbing higher and higher, and it\u2019s never enough,\u201d he said. \u201cMore viewers and more money and more magazines and covers.\u201d\n\nReturning home, he greeted his peppy publicist and took a seat again on the front porch, before remembering he had some errands to do, including picking up a Christmas tree. Shopping for a tree, he said, not only reminded him of his childhood, but it was also \u201cone of the last remaining things where you can negotiate the price,\u201d he said. \u201cWell, this and hookers.\u201d\n\nHe hopped into his white Audi S.U.V. for the short drive to Frosty\u2019s Christmas Trees. It was just after 4, and the traffic on Franklin Avenue was already making him tense. He took a deep breath to clear his mind.", "title": "Pete Holmes of \u2018Crashing\u2019 Finds Humor in His Church Roots", "authors": ["Dan Hyman"]} {"date": "2018-01-01 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Martins was charged in Ardsley, N.Y., after a minor accident in the village square, the police chief, Emil J. Califano, said by telephone Monday night. In a previous incident, in 2011, he pleaded guilty to driving while intoxicated.\n\nIn his letter, Mr. Martins said the abuse and harassment accusations by dancers had \u201cexacted a painful toll on me and my family.\u201d He said he had decided to retire to \u201cbring an end to this disruption.\u201d\n\nMr. Scharf said in his statement that the company and its School of American Ballet \u201cwill convene a committee promptly to begin the search for a new ballet master in chief.\u201d Last month it appointed an interim four-person team to lead the company.\n\nFive City Ballet dancers \u2014 one of whom is still with the company \u2014 recently came forward in The New York Times to describe verbal and physical abuse dating as far back as 1993.\n\nHis departure could create more turmoil within the company. As the investigation was being conducted, an apparent split emerged among former and current dancers over the fate of Mr. Martins.\n\nIn recent interviews, 24 women and men \u2014 all former dancers at the company or its school \u2014 described a culture of intimidation under Mr. Martins, which they said has hurt the careers of generations of performers.\n\nThe former dancers said that when they worked under Mr. Martins, they and many peers had been too afraid to complain as he verbally and physically bullied performers and students; shamed them about their bodies; and abused his power by conducting sexual relationships with select dancers.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nVanessa Carlton, a former dancer with the school, recently sent an email to Robert I. Lipp, a vice chairman of City Ballet.\n\n\u201cDancers tend not to talk,\u201d wrote Ms. Carlton, now a singer-songwriter. \u201cI\u2019m concerned that this reticence is being misread as a sign to you and your fellow board members that they are not upset.\u201d\n\n\n\nShe continued, \u201cEvery single ex-dancer that I know, including myself, will be devastated if Peter is allowed to waltz back into his office.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Gender Letter A weekly newsletter on women, gender and society. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn the other camp were several current dancers who, before Mr. Martins\u2019s resignation, said the accusations against him did not jibe with the leader they know and that the complaints were coming from dancers who had left the company.\n\n\u201cHe has been nothing but respectful of me,\u201d Sterling Hyltin, a longtime principal ballerina, said in a recent interview. \u201cIt\u2019s been really upsetting to see former dancers speaking on behalf of current dancers.\u201d\n\nAmong current dancers in the ballet, several defended Mr. Martins. Megan Fairchild and a fellow dancer, Megan Johnson, reached out to The New York Times on their own to say he has always behaved professionally with them.\n\n\u201cI\u2019ve never felt in danger in his presence,\u201d said Ms. Fairchild, who has been with the company for 16 years. \u201cHe\u2019s the person I go to when I\u2019m having trouble in the company or in life.\u201d\n\nCity Ballet is not the only challenging company in which to pursue a career. Many in the dance world have expressed hope over the last several weeks that these revelations will prompt overdue changes to a culture in which bullying, body-shaming and sexual favors have long been part of the business.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIt can feel particularly risky \u2014 both emotionally and career wise \u2014 to be a whistle-blower within our field,\u201d Wendy Whelan, a 30-year star dancer with the company who retired in 2014, said. \u201cWe aren\u2019t encouraged to use our voice to expose the dark side of what is also truly a magical industry for the sake of hurting our father-figure teachers.\u201d\n\n\u201cThe tradition of balletic patriarchy has held a closet full of skeletons,\u201d she added. \u201cIn recent light of things, many artists and dancers are seeing that society is no longer accepting these kind of behaviors as normal, so why do we?\u201d\n\nSeveral former ballet dancers said in the recent interviews that Mr. Martins was known for having intimate relationships with dancers, some of whom seemed to receive better roles. The relationships were complicated by a power dynamic, they said, in which Mr. Martins was widely viewed as a near deity, particularly to young dancers who might go to any length \u2014 from starving themselves to having sex with him \u2014 to earn his praise and attention.\n\nCity Ballet leaders, before the announcement, said the lawyer heading their investigation, Barbara Hoey, was engaged \u201cin a good-faith effort to investigate recent allegations against Peter Martins\u201d; that the company \u201cprohibits retaliation\u201d against participants; and that it encourages \u201canyone with relevant information to come forward.\u201d\n\nBeyond its legendary founder, George Balanchine, there is no one who has done more to shape the company than Peter Martins. His history with City Ballet dates to 1967, when he was invited to dance the title role in Balanchine\u2019s \u201cApollo\u201d at the Edinburgh Festival. He became a principal dancer in 1970, widely acclaimed for his expert partnering and masculine grace.\n\nAfter the death of Balanchine in 1983, Mr. Martins took over leadership of the company with Jerome Robbins; in 1989, he became the sole ballet master in chief. Mr. Martins has also served as the artistic director and chairman of the school\u2019s faculty.\n\nThroughout his tenure, Mr. Martins has had his share of supporters and detractors. Some credit him for balancing the company\u2019s loyalty to Balanchine with the commissioning of new choreography, particularly the opportunities he provided to promising young choreographers like Alexei Ratmansky, Christopher Wheeldon and Justin Peck.\n\nMr. Peck is considered a candidate to succeed Mr. Martins, as is Ms. Whelan and the French choreographer Benjamin Millepied.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSome critics have questioned Mr. Martins\u2019s views of women based on his choreography. In reviewing \u201cT-al-a Gaisma,\u201d in 2005 \u2014 which featured Miranda Weese, Jock Soto and Mr. Martins\u2019s wife, Darci Kistler \u2014 Joan Acocella in The New Yorker alluded to \u201cwhat seems to be his mixed feelings about women.\u201d\n\n\u201cWeese is made into a succubus, Kistler into a pleading pest, hanging on to Soto, getting her hair tangled up in his hands,\u201d she wrote. \u201cSoto finally fights his way free, lowering these harridans onto the floor, where they lie supine, immobilized.\u201d\n\nMr. Martins has been subject to public scrutiny for his conduct in the past. In 1992, he was arrested on charges of assaulting Ms. Kistler; she later dropped the charges.", "title": "Peter Martins Retires From New York City Ballet After Misconduct Allegations", "authors": ["Robin Pogrebin"]} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "Peter Mayle, an Englishman who started a writing career in his 30s with sex-education books for children before making a spectacularly successful switch to the travel memoir genre with \u201cA Year in Provence,\u201d his 1989 best seller about relocating to Southern France, died on Thursday at a hospital near his home there. He was 78.\n\nHis death was confirmed by Paul Bogaards of Alfred A. Knopf, which has published Mr. Mayle\u2019s books since \u201cA Year in Provence\u201d was released in the United States in 1990.\n\nMr. Mayle and his wife, Jennie, moved to M\u00e9nerbes, a village in the Provence region, in 1987, with Mr. Mayle intending to write a novel. But with renovations to the 18th-century stone farmhouse they had bought in full swing, he kept getting distracted. His agent finally told him to shelve the novel and write about the distractions.\n\n\u201cEverything catastrophic became useful,\u201d he recalled in a 1993 interview with The New York Times. \u201cUp to that point, I had kept a halfhearted diary. After that, I took copious notes, and the chapters more or less wrote themselves.\u201d", "title": "Peter Mayle, Who Wrote of \u2018A Year in Provence,\u2019 Is Dead at 78", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-02 00:00:00", "text": "Has Founders Fund made money? The WSJ reports, citing its unnamed sources, that the firm bought about $15 million in Bitcoin and that its stake is now worth hundreds of millions of dollars.\n\n\u2014 Michael J. de la Merced\n\nSo much for Jack Ma\u2019s charm offensive.\n\nSo much for Jack Ma\u2019s charm offensive.\n\nUnited States officials have effectively killed Ant Financial\u2019s $1.2 billion bid to buy MoneyGram.\n\nAnt Financial, the electronic payments company controlled by Mr. Ma, became the latest Chinese firm to have its acquisition of an American company fall apart because it was unable to secure approval from the Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States, or Cfius.\n\nThe deal failed despite a charm offensive by Jack Ma, the Chinese internet. Shortly after President Trump won the 2016 election, Mr. Ma famously stood with the president-elect in Trump Tower in New York City and pledged that his e-commerce empire would help create one million American jobs.\n\nThe attempted purchase of MoneyGram was seen as a test of the Trump administration\u2019s political and regulatory approach to China, and the deal\u2019s failure could spell trouble for other Chinese companies considering major acquisitions.\n\nThe strong flow of Chinese money into the United States has prompted growing worries. Lawmakers from both parties have introduced legislation calling for greater scrutiny of Chinese investments in the United States. They are pushing for a significant expansion of Cfius, a multiagency panel that reviews foreign deals for potential threats to national security.\n\nOf the deal, Richard Beales of Breakingviews writes:\n\n\u201cIt would have been seen as something of a watershed for a successful upstart from the People\u2019s Republic to get its hands on a piece of Uncle Sam\u2019s payments infrastructure. \u201cFor Trump and China critics in his administration, that may have been the wrong message, especially when a similar deal in the other direction would surely come up against Beijing\u2019s tight restrictions on foreign ownership in China\u2019s financial system. Rather than opening the door \u2013 arguably the old American way of showing how things ought to be done \u2013 CFIUS this time kept it closed. If it\u2019s a rebuke, it\u2019s one that\u2019s conveniently unlikely to provoke great resentment.\u201d\n\nMoneyGram\u2019s shares are down 6.8 percent after the close.\n\nTech\u2019s 2017 rally spilled over into the New Year\n\nThe Nasdaq Composite rose 1.5 percent Tuesday to close above 7,000 for the first time.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe gain was driven by Netflix, Facebook, Google-parent Alphabet and Apple, which jumped between 18 percent and 4.8 percent.\n\nTuesday\u2019s rally follows a 28 percent gain for the Nasdaq last year. That beat the 25 percent gain for the Dow Jones industrial average and the 19 percent rise for the Standard & Poor\u2019s 500 index.\n\nSo how stretched are valuations for the Nasdaq? As of Friday, the index was trading at 27.55 times the last 12 months of earnings, well above the S.&P. 500\u2032s level of 18.27 times earnings, according to the WSJ\u2019s Ben Eisen. But the Nasdaq\u2019s current price-to-earnings ratio remains well below 72.2, which it hit in March 2000.\n\nExtra Credit: Yes, Apple, Microsoft and Amazon.com drove the Nasdaq\u2019s run to 7,000. But Riot Blockchain saw the biggest percentage gain between the Nasdaq\u2019s first close above 6,000 in April to its close above 7,000 on Tuesday, writes the WSJ\u2019s Chelsey Dulaney. Shares of Riot \u201csurged more than 640 percent during that period, with the bulk of those gains coming after the company switched its focus to investing in blockchain technology October.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nOur thoughts exactly.\n\nShot: Senator Orrin Hatch, Republican of Utah, won\u2019t run for re-election, according to the NYT. That gives Mitt Romney \u2014 former presidential candidate, former Massachusetts governor, former private equity mogul, current (and increasingly frequent) Trump critic \u2014 a chance to run for the seat.\n\nChaser:\n\n\u2014 Michael J. de la Merced\n\nExpect a \u201cfrothy\u201d and \u201cfrustrated\u201d 2018.\n\nMoney is cheap, the global economy is gaining momentum and markets are at records. \u201cYet things look less reassuring close up,\u201d writes Quentin Webb of Breakingviews.\n\n\u201cThe populist anger that enabled Trump and Brexit is still simmering, fueled by inequality, disruption, immigration and the echo chambers of social media. An unpredictable America is no longer committed to advancing a rules-based, liberal world order. China is growing increasingly assertive under President Xi Jinping, while Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman is flexing his muscles around the Gulf. The risk of a conflagration on the Korean Peninsula is all too real. Business is grappling with self-inflicted scandals and activist attacks, and a backlash is building against Big Tech\u2019s overweening power.\u201d\n\nWith that as the backdrop, here are a few of Breakingviews\u2019 predictions for 2018:\n\nIn investing\n\n\u2022 \u201cFor the first time in years, rich-world bond issuance will outstrip buying by the Fed and friends,\u201d and \u201cbond vigilantes will rise from the dead.\u201d\n\n\u2022 \u201cPassive funds will, despite their name, dethrone a chief executive.\u201d\n\nIn tech\n\n\u2022 \u201cIn tech, investors can consider a tasty new dish: SLAW, for Spotify, Lyft, Airbnb and WeWork, four prospective candidates for public life.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 Apple\u2019s position as a privacy-sensitive hardware specialist will give it some shelter from mounting anger at Silicon Valley\u2019s power and lack of accountability.\n\n\u2014 Stephen Grocer\n\nPhoto\n\nDreaming of an Amazon-Target deal.\n\nWe\u2019re just two days into 2018, and we already have a huge M.&A. prediction, courtesy of the analyst Gene Munster.\n\nFrom his note yesterday:\n\nGetting the timing on this is difficult, but seeing the value of the combination is easy. Amazon believes the future of retail is a mix of mostly online and some offline. Target is the ideal offline partner for Amazon for two reasons, shared demographic and manageable but comprehensive store count.\n\nIt\u2019s a big, if logical, assumption given the ever-expanding empire that Amazon has been assembling \u2014 one that has put more and more industry incumbents on their back heels.\n\nTarget shares were up nearly 4 percent as of this afternoon.\n\nCould Amazon afford Target?\n\nShort answer: Yes.\n\nLong answer: Yes, but it\u2019d be pretty expensive. Target\u2019s market capitalization as of Tuesday morning was nearly $37 billion. Amazon had about $24.3 billion in cash and short-term investments on its balance sheet as of Sept. 30, meaning that the company would have to borrow a hefty amount.\n\nAssuming a 20 percent takeover premium, Target would be almost $40 billion.\n\nAmazon could pay in stock as well as cash, but it hasn\u2019t struck a big deal using stock since its takeover of Zappos in 2009. And stock remains an expensive form of currency, though that hasn\u2019t stopped the likes of Disney from stock deals.\n\n(Mr. Munster asserts that a deal is affordable because the cost of a Target acquisition is just 8 percent of Amazon\u2019s market cap. Obviously, I think it\u2019s a bit more complicated than that.)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe big caveat (other than price)\n\nObviously, it\u2019s antitrust. Mr. Munster notes that a combined Amazon-Target would only have about a 13 percent share of the overall American retail market, compared to Walmart\u2019s 23 percent.\n\nBut it\u2019s hard to determine at the moment what the Trump administration\u2019s yardstick for market concentration is:\n\n\u2022 AT&T and Time Warner say that their proposed deal is a vertical deal that falls within the bounds of acceptable deals. The Justice Department has sued to block that.\n\n\u2022 Disney and Fox have announced a deal that would inevitably lead to lots of layoffs. President Trump has praised that transaction as potentially \u201cgreat for jobs.\u201d\n\n\u201cAs for antitrust, the Trump administration won\u2019t do any favors for Jeff Bezos, but the market share numbers suggest the deal will be approved,\u201d Mr. Munster writes. That\u2019s a potentially big assumption.\n\n\u2014 Michael J. de la Merced\n\nPhoto\n\nAre Amazon and Salesforce moving away from Oracle?\n\nKevin McLaughlin of The Information reports that the two companies \u201care actively working to replace Oracle software running on critical business systems with open-source database software alternatives, and have made significant progress toward getting off Oracle entirely,\u201d citing people familiar with the matter.\n\n\u201cA mass exodus from the Oracle database isn\u2019t likely anytime soon. Yet losing Amazon and Salesforce as customers could pose major problems for Oracle, as it could provide a road map for other large companies that also are looking to cut costs by jettisoning Oracle database software in favor of open-source database alternatives.\u201d\n\nOracle\u2019s shares are down nearly 2 percent. They had been trading about 1 percent higher before the report.\n\n\u2014 Stephen Grocer\n\nPhoto\n\nWhere are stocks heading in 2018?\n\nThe Dow Jones industrial average jumped 25 percent in 2017. Does that mean investors should turn bearish on stocks this year? The answer is no if history is any indicator, LPL Financial\u2019s Ryan Detrick points out.\n\nAlso, is the first day of trading predictive of the stock market\u2019s performance for the full year?\n\n\u2014 Stephen Grocer\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nRemembering 2017, and looking ahead to 2018.\n\nIf you couldn\u2019t recall last year\u2019s highlights over the recent holidays, Andrew can remind you with his annual year-end column (the humor of which is his and his alone). A sample:\n\nThe seating chart is, of course, always a bit complicated. We had to keep Jeffrey Bezos of Amazon from the dais to prevent Mr. Trump\u2019s Twitter war with him from interrupting the festivities. And we had heard that Mr. Bezos had a practical joke planned: He was going to tell Mr. Trump that he had chosen Mexico City as Amazon\u2019s second headquarters.\n\nBut it\u2019s a new year, and here are some important story lines we\u2019ll be keeping our eyes on:\n\n\u2022 Now that the tax fight is over, the White House is turning to trade. Will Gary Cohn and Steven Mnuchin be able to tame President Trump\u2019s hard-line tendencies?\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story The All-New DealBook Newsletter Our columnist Andrew Ross Sorkin and his Times colleagues help you make sense of major business and policy headlines \u2014 and the power-brokers who shape them. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u2022 Can Congress make progress on the many, many other issues it\u2019s facing?\n\n\u2022 SoftBank did its Uber deal. Will the ride-hailing giant make further strides toward going public this year? (Maybe not.) And what will Masa Son of SoftBank and his $100 billion Vision Fund get up to?\n\n\u2022 What other industries will Amazon disrupt this year? And how much bigger can Mr. Bezos\u2019s behemoth get?\n\n\u2022 North Korea is trying to drive a wedge between South Korea and the U.S. And it seems to be working. How will Mr. Trump \u2014 and the global economy \u2014 respond?\n\n\u2022 Stevie Cohen is finding takers for his new hedge fund. But how much presence will he retain in the industry?\n\n\u2022 In the world of M. & A. fights, who will AT&T or the Justice Department prevail? Broadcom or Qualcomm? And will Disney and Fox get their deal done?\n\nPhoto\n\nBusinesses are opening their wallets.\n\nAnd the Trump administration\u2019s deregulatory push looks to be a reason for that \u2014 even if skeptics question whether rolling back government rules stimulates corporate growth.\n\nCorporate leaders always cite \u201cuncertainty\u201d as a reason to hold back on capital expenditures or transformative acquisitions. And fewer than half of the respondents in the National Association of Manufacturers\u2019 most recent survey said they faced an \u201cunfavorable business climate.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nYet some see a bigger phenomenon at work. This is what Mark Zandi of Moody\u2019s Analytics told the NYT:\n\n\u201cThe fundamental backdrop here is that this is a global synchronized expansion lifting everyone\u2019s spirits, from Tokyo to New York.\u201d\n\nThe tax flyaround\n\n\u2022 Corporate America\u2019s great loophole scavenger hunt has begun. (NYT)\n\n\u2022 China has responded to the tax law by temporarily exempting foreign companies from taxes on their earnings in the country \u2014 but there\u2019s a catch. (NYT)\n\n\u2022 Democrats in high-tax states are seeking ways to blunt some of the impact of the tax overhaul. (NYT)\n\n\u2022 The gig economy could get a boost. (NYT)\n\n\u2022 Betting on the dollar continuing to strengthen in 2018, thanks to the tax law. (WSJ)\n\nPhoto\n\nThe Murdoch family tensions behind the Disney deal.\n\nIt may have been a brief sales negotiation with Verizon that prompted Rupert Murdoch to consider selling pieces of 21st Century Fox. But the NYT reports that friction between the media mogul and his son James helped push the family toward the Disney transaction.\n\nFrom the article by Brooks Barnes and Sydney Ember:\n\n\u2022 James Murdoch has privately grumbled about the control that his father still exerted at Fox and has chafed at some of the elements of Fox News\u2019s coverage.\n\n\u2022 Rupert Murdoch was wary of how Hollywood was being reshaped by digital giants like Netflix, Apple and Amazon, and unsure his empire could compete.\n\n\u2022 Lachlan Murdoch, who is more conservative than his brother, has become the heir apparent at what would remain of Fox, but was initially uneasy about a sell-off.\n\nWhat they gain: Beyond easing family tensions among the trio, the deal could make the Murdochs some of Disney\u2019s biggest shareholders.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe mutual fund king bucking the low-fee wave.\n\nYes, Ron Baron has lowered fees on some of his smaller funds. But he\u2019s unapologetic about charging roughly 54 percent more than the industry average.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHere\u2019s what he told Landon Thomas Jr. of the NYT:\n\n\u201cSince inception, 98 percent of our funds have beaten their benchmark,\u201d he said in an interview. \u201cIf you want the lowest fee, you should not invest with us.\u201d\n\nHow he (and other mutual funds) do it: Chalk it up to a combination of looser oversight, the $10 trillion of investor money still dedicated to actively managed funds and a lack of investor awareness that high fees don\u2019t necessarily pay for performance.\n\nCan this go on?\n\nOne fund investor\u2019s take in the NYT:\n\n\u201cI won\u2019t say performance warrants the fees they charge,\u201d said Barry Edelman, a Las Vegas retiree and a 20-year Baron shareholder. \u201cBut I appreciate how they differentiate themselves from the competition.\u201d\n\nTragedy strikes Bridgewater.\n\nBruce Steinberg, an executive at the hedge fund, and his family were among the 12 killed when a single-engine plane crashed in Costa Rica on Sunday.\n\nRay Dalio of Bridgewater posted this to Facebook yesterday:\n\nPhoto\n\nAlso of note: Richard Cousins, the C.E.O. of Compass Group, the world\u2019s biggest catering company, was one of six killed in a plane crash in Sydney on Sunday.\n\nPhoto\n\nHollywood organizes to fight sexual harassment.\n\nWhat\u2019s notable is that Time\u2019s Up \u2014 formed by more than 300 women and including a legal-defense fund \u2014 isn\u2019t focused only on the entertainment industry. It plans to offer help to janitors, nurses, hotel staff and other blue-collar workers.\n\nHere\u2019s what Shonda Rhimes, a backer of the initiative, told Cara Buckley of the NYT:\n\n\u201cIf this group of women can\u2019t fight for a model for other women who don\u2019t have as much power and privilege, then who can?\u201d\n\nWho else is involved: The actresses America Ferrera, Eva Longoria and Reese Witherspoon; Donna Langley, the chairwoman of Universal Pictures; and roughly 295 other women in Hollywood.\n\nWhat\u2019s different: The Time\u2019s Up Legal Defense Fund, which is backed by $13 million in donations and is overseen by Tina Tchen, a former chief of staff to Michelle Obama. It will help provide less-privileged women with lawyers to bring misconduct cases to court and protect them from blowback.\n\nThe misconduct flyaround\n\n\u2022 Take a peek behind the curtain at the monthly drug- and sex-fueled monthly parties attended by some of Silicon Valley\u2019s most powerful men, in an excerpt from \u201cBrotopia,\u201d the forthcoming book by the Bloomberg anchor Emily Chang. (Lloyd Blankfein said so.)\n\nLast week, the NYT reported on how the Metropolitan Transportation Authority ends up with some of the highest construction costs in the world. Some facts:\n\n\u2022 The Second Avenue subway cost $2.5 billion. Expanding Grand Central Terminal is now expected to cost $12 billion.\n\n\u2022 Construction companies inflate their projected costs by up to 50 percent for M.T.A. work. Labor unions have arranged for up to four times the necessary staffing on some projects.\n\n\u2022 Consultants have persuaded officials to spend heavily on design and management.\n\nHere\u2019s what Mr. Blankfein, Andrew\u2019s choice as 2017\u2019s best corporate tweeter, had to say:\n\nPhoto\n\n(Mr. Blankfein has good reasons for pique over the tax law: Goldman Sachs is taking a $5 billion charge in its fourth-quarter earnings tied to the changes.)\n\nThe Speed Read\n\n\u2022 Caterpillar faces a potential tax bill of $2 billion from the I.R.S., which says it has underpaid on profits from parts sales through its Swiss unit. Please email thoughts and suggestions to bizday@nytimes.com.", "title": "Peter Thiel Is a Bitcoin Believer: DealBook Briefing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-03 00:00:00", "text": "The company said on Monday that it was a victim of the bribery scheme and had already recovered 1.475 billion Brazilian reais, or about $449 million, in restitution. Petrobras said it would \u201ccontinue to pursue all available legal remedies from culpable companies and individuals.\u201d\n\n\u201cThe agreement is in the company\u2019s best interest and that of its shareholders, given the risks of a verdict advised by a jury, particularities of U.S. procedure and securities laws, as well its assessment of the status of the class action and the nature of such litigation in the United States,\u201d Petrobras said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission on Wednesday.\n\nThe company said that it would pay the settlement in three installments, but would recognize the total settlement as part of its fourth-quarter 2017 results. It said that the settlement did not constitute an admission of wrongdoing or misconduct and that it \u201cexpressly denies liability\u201d in the agreement.\n\nThe deal would resolve all pending and prospective claims by purchasers of Petrobras securities in the United States and by purchasers of Petrobras securities that are listed for trading in the United States, the company said. The settlement still has to be approved by the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York.\n\nIn a statement, the lead counsel for the plaintiffs in the class-action lawsuit said it was \u201cvery pleased with this historic settlement.\u201d", "title": "Petrobras of Brazil to Pay $2.95 Billion Over Corruption Scandal", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-29 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nThe Stephen Petronio Company\u2019s dance residency center in the Catskill Mountains, in upstate New York, will open in July with its debut class of choreographers: Nora Chipaumire, Will Rawls and Kathy Westwater.\n\nThey are to receive fully funded residencies \u2014 including a travel stipend, a rarity for prizes like this \u2014 for a week each at the Petronio Residency Center, at the 175-acre Crow\u2019s Nest in Round Top, purchased by Mr. Petronio\u2019s company in 2016.\n\n\u201cThe Petronio Residency Center is a retreat in which to study, work and experiment while cut loose from the overbearing pressures inherent in a choreographer\u2019s day-to-day living,\u201d Mr. Petronio said in a statement.\n\nMs. Chipaumire, who was born in Zimbabwe and now lives in New York, is a choreographer and performer whose work taps into her African identity, like her 2016 dance \u201cportrait of myself as my father.\u201d [Read our review of the work\u2019s premiere.]\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Rawls has collaborated with artists like Marina Abramovic, J\u00e9r\u00f4me Bel and Maria Hassabi, and recently worked with the poet Claudia Rankine for \u201cWhat Remains,\u201d which explored surveillance and black experience.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Jaroussky en fit le constat lors d\u2019un entretien r\u00e9cent : \u00ab Que ce soit \u00e0 Hambourg, \u00e0 New York ou \u00e0 Paris, je chante devant le m\u00eame type de public. Et autant j\u2019adore mon public, autant je suis inquiet. Parce que si nous n\u2019apportons pas de mixit\u00e9 sociale sur sc\u00e8ne, nous n\u2019aurons pas de public plus jeune et plus diversifi\u00e9, non plus \u00bb.\n\nLes enfants de l\u2019Acad\u00e9mie ont entre sept et 12 ans. L\u2019instrument qu\u2019ils ont choisi d\u2019apprendre \u2014 piano, violon ou violoncelle \u2014 leur est pr\u00eat\u00e9 pour les trois ans que dure la formation.\n\nPhoto\n\nYassine Souhir a sept ans et a choisi le violon. Ses artistes pr\u00e9f\u00e9r\u00e9s sont Rihanna et le rappeur Ma\u00eetre Gims, mais il aime \u00e9couter les \u00ab Quatre Saisons \u00bb de Vivaldi sur YouTube. Mac\u00e9o Mennesson-Llorente a le m\u00eame \u00e2ge. Son choix s\u2019est port\u00e9 sur le violoncelle lorsqu\u2019il a r\u00e9alis\u00e9, dit-il, qu\u2019il sentait \u00ab les vibrations de l\u2019instrument tout pr\u00e8s \u00bb de son c\u0153ur.\n\nQuant \u00e0 Amine, qui vit dans une famille d\u2019accueil, le violoncelle s\u2019est impos\u00e9 apr\u00e8s qu\u2019il a d\u00e9couvert un bin\u00f4me de violoncellistes croates, les 2Cellos, qui reprennent des morceaux pop-rock. Ses cours de musique s\u2019ajoutent \u00e0 un emploi du temps d\u00e9j\u00e0 charg\u00e9 qui inclut des rendez-vous hebdomadaires chez un psychologue et un orthophoniste.\n\nSa m\u00e8re d\u2019accueil, Marie-Christine G\u00e9rardin, affirme que depuis qu\u2019il a commenc\u00e9 le violoncelle, il chante \u00e0 la maison, il est plus calme et ses insomnies ont presque disparu.\n\n\u00ab Il aime bien faire le clown, mais il se calme d\u00e8s qu\u2019il prend son violoncelle en main \u00bb, explique cette ancienne employ\u00e9e d\u2019usine qui \u00e9l\u00e8ve Amine depuis qu\u2019il a 18 mois.\n\nPhoto\n\nPour son acad\u00e9mie, M. Jaroussky explique s\u2019\u00eatre inspir\u00e9 d\u2019initiatives plus ambitieuses telles que El Sistema au Venezuela, un programme d\u2019\u00e9ducation musicale gratuit qui a form\u00e9 des centaines de milliers d\u2019enfants depuis 1975, ou du projet D\u00e9mos ici en France.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIniti\u00e9 en 2010 et coordonn\u00e9 par la Philharmonie de Paris, ce dernier a \u00e9t\u00e9 \u00e0 l\u2019origine de la cr\u00e9ation de 30 orchestres \u00e0 travers le pays, chacun d\u2019entre eux compos\u00e9 de plus de 100 enfants originaires de milieux modestes. D\u2019apr\u00e8s Gilles Delebarre, l\u2019un des fondateurs de D\u00e9mos et son pr\u00e9sident actuel, environ 4 500 enfants sont d\u00e9j\u00e0 pass\u00e9s par ce programme gratuit de trois ans et la moiti\u00e9 d\u2019entre eux ont ensuite continu\u00e9 la pratique musicale.\n\n\u00ab Quand les enfants s\u2019habituent \u00e0 une pratique culturelle \u00e0 un jeune \u00e2ge, ils la gardent \u00bb, explique-t-il.\n\nPour certains d\u00e9tracteurs, pourtant, de telles initiatives, quoique positives, ne s\u2019adressent qu\u2019\u00e0 quelques milliers de personnes et n\u2019apportent que des r\u00e9sultats limit\u00e9s. Il serait pr\u00e9f\u00e9rable, disent-ils, d\u2019investir davantage dans l\u2019\u00e9ducation musicale \u00e0 l\u2019\u00e9cole ou dans les conservatoires.\n\nPhoto\n\nSt\u00e9phane Dorin, professeur de sociologie \u00e0 l\u2019Universit\u00e9 de Limoges sp\u00e9cialiste de l\u2019\u00e9volution des go\u00fbts musicaux, estime que des projets comme D\u00e9mos ou l\u2019acad\u00e9mie Jaroussky sont trop chers pour \u00eatre appliqu\u00e9s \u00e0 plus grande \u00e9chelle en France. Le budget de D\u00e9mos pour 2018 s\u2019\u00e9l\u00e8ve \u00e0 7,8 millions d\u2019euros pour 3 000 enfants, selon M. Delebarre.\n\nEstimant que de tels programmes \u00ab ne transformeront pas en profondeur la relation que les enfants de milieux populaires entretiennent avec la musique \u00bb, M. Dorin trouve en revanche excellente la d\u00e9cision annonc\u00e9e r\u00e9cemment par les minist\u00e8res de l\u2019\u00c9ducation et de la Culture de la mise en place de chorales dans tous les coll\u00e8ges et \u00e9coles primaires d\u2019ici \u00e0 deux ans. Ce \u00ab plan chorale \u00bb, d\u2019un minimum de 20 millions d\u2019euros, concernerait plus de 10 millions d\u2019enfants par an.\n\nC\u2019est justement \u00e0 l\u2019\u00e9cole que M. Jaroussky est tomb\u00e9 amoureux de la musique. \u00c9lev\u00e9 \u00e0 Sartrouville, dans les Yvelines, dans une famille de classe moyenne \u2014 \u00ab ni riche ni pauvre, sans musiciens \u00e0 la maison \u00bb \u2014 il explique que c\u2019est son professeur de musique de 6e qui encouragea ses parents \u00e0 l\u2019inscrire au conservatoire.\n\nIl a jou\u00e9 du violon de 10 \u00e0 22 ans, a commenc\u00e9 le piano \u00e0 15 et le chant \u00e0 18. A 21 ans, il chantait en professionnel pour la premi\u00e8re fois.\n\nPhoto\n\nM. Jaroussky pratiqua le violon de 10 \u00e0 22 ans, commen\u00e7a le piano \u00e0 15 et le chant \u00e0 18. \u00c0 21 ans, il chanta en tant que professionnel pour la premi\u00e8re fois.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAg\u00e9 maintenant de 39 ans et poursuivant une carri\u00e8re internationale, M. Jaroussky explique vouloir se servir de sa renomm\u00e9e pour inviter des m\u00e9c\u00e8nes \u00e0 soutenir son acad\u00e9mie, une pratique bien moins d\u00e9velopp\u00e9e en France que dans certains pays comme les \u00c9tats-Unis.\n\nLe budget annuel de l\u2019acad\u00e9mie, de 500 000 euros, est financ\u00e9 \u00e0 75 % par des institutions et des dons priv\u00e9s. M. Jaroussky projette de former 100 jeunes musiciens d\u2019ici trois ans et de cr\u00e9er des antennes \u00e0 Lille et \u00e0 Marseille.\n\nL\u2019Acad\u00e9mie Musicale Philippe Jaroussky offre \u00e9galement des master class gratuites \u00e0 des musiciens et chanteurs professionnels \u00e2g\u00e9s de 18 \u00e0 25 ans, dont certaines sont donn\u00e9es par M. Jaroussky lui-m\u00eame, ainsi que des concerts gratuits pour les enfants \u00e9l\u00e8ves et leurs parents. L\u2019\u00e9tude parue en 2015 pour l\u2019Association fran\u00e7aise des Orchestres r\u00e9v\u00e9lait que 12 % des publics d\u00e9couvraient le classique par l\u2019influence de leurs propres enfants. L\u2019acad\u00e9mie Jaroussky encourage par ailleurs les parents \u00e0 suivre les progr\u00e8s de leurs enfants.\n\nLe mois dernier, l\u2019auditorium de l\u2019acad\u00e9mie commen\u00e7ait \u00e0 se remplir d\u2019enfants agit\u00e9s, de parents intimid\u00e9s et d\u2019amateurs de musique venus assister au concert de No\u00ebl des jeunes professionnels.\n\nM. Jaroussky s\u2019installa au premier rang, pr\u00e8s d\u2019Amine, qui tenait difficilement en place et jouait avec une bouteille d\u2019eau. Au milieu du concert, en entendant les musiciens interpr\u00e9ter le \u00ab Trio \u00c9l\u00e9giaque No. 1 \u00bb de Sergue\u00ef Rachmaninov, Amine se calma.\n\n\u00ab Ces sons, ils sont tellement beaux \u00bb, chuchota-t-il, les yeux \u00e9carquill\u00e9s et la bouche entrouverte. \u00ab Peut-\u00eatre que j\u2019essaierai de faire pareil \u00e0 la maison. \u00bb", "title": "Philippe Jaroussky r\u00e9ussira-t-il \u00e0 ouvrir la musique classique \u00e0 la diversit\u00e9?", "authors": ["Elian Peltier"]} {"date": "2018-01-22 00:00:00", "text": "Police intelligence operatives were then dispatched to Angeles and found Mr. Jabouri, who gave up peacefully.
