View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cHe also said that he traveled to Manila to meet a Chinese business group that hired him as a consultant,\u201d Director General dela Rosa said, without identifying the group.\n\nA police intelligence official, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, said investigators were also checking whether Mr. Jabouri had made any connections to local militant groups, noting that his visit came as the country was fighting Islamic State-linked Filipino militants, backed by foreign fighters, who had taken over the southern city of Marawi.\n\nThe fighting, which left at least 1,200 people dead \u2014 most of them militants \u2014 was declared over in October, although security forces have said nearly 200 Filipino militants who took part in the siege escaped and remained at large.\n\nThe arrest came after a year in which the Philippines has grappled with deadly bombings.\n\nIn May 2017, the police in Manila placed the crowded Quiapo district under lockdown after two bombs exploded within hours of each other near a Muslim center. Two people were killed, and six others, including two police officers investigating the first blast, were hurt.\n\nA month before those blasts, a pipe bomb also exploded in Quiapo, injuring a dozen people.\n\nThe Philippine police had sought to play down the attacks, saying they did not appear to be connected.\n\nBut six months earlier, in November 2016, the authorities prevented a bombing when they recovered a powerful explosive device near the American Embassy in Manila. Director General dela Rosa tied that bombing to a Muslim militant faction that would later help lead the Marawi insurgency.", "title": "Philippines Arrests Explosives Expert Tied to Mideast Militants", "authors": ["Felipe Villamor"]} {"date": "2018-01-22 00:00:00", "text": "MANILA \u2014 Philippine officials raised the alert level on the Mayon volcano on Monday as it began spewing an ash plume more than 4,000 feet high from its summit in a spectacular show of destructive power.\n\nThe Philippine Institute of Volcanology and Seismology has raised the alert level to four \u2014 the highest is five \u2014 meaning the cone-shaped volcano was in a stage of \u201cintense unrest\u201d that could set off a hazardous eruption at any time.\n\nThe volcano generated up to 1,600 feet of lava fountains before dawn Monday, lighting up the dark sky with an intense crimson glow. At least two nearby villages experienced ash fall, the volcano institute said.\n\n\u201cThe lava fountains signified an increase in mass eruption rate, as lava was observed to be flowing more voluminously than before,\u201d it said, adding that lava flows had spread more than two miles from the crater.", "title": "Philippines Raises Alert Level as Mayon Volcano Eruption Intensifies", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-15 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cWhat this means for you, and for us, is that the commission is ordering us to close shop, to cease telling you stories, to stop speaking truth to power, and to let go of everything that we have built \u2014 and created \u2014 with you since 2012,\u201d it added.\n\nThe Philippines has one of the region\u2019s most freewheeling news industries. More than 30 newspapers have sprung up across the country since democracy was restored 32 years ago.\n\nRappler said that it had been consistently transparent and that it had told corporate regulators about its company structure when it started operating in 2012. It said that it had two foreign investors, Omidyar Network and North Base Media, but that they had no ownership shares or any role in the operation of the company.\n\n\u201cTransparency, we believe, is the best proof of good faith and good conduct,\u201d said Rappler, which has won local and international awards for its reporting of impunity in Mr. Duterte\u2019s deadly war on drugs.\n\n\u201cThis is pure and simple harassment, the seeming coup de gr\u00e2ce to the relentless and malicious attacks against us since 2016,\u201d Rappler said.\n\nThe president\u2019s office sought to distance itself from the order, saying it was the commission\u2019s job to determine corporate legality.\n\n\u201cWe respect the S.E.C. decision that Rappler contravenes the strict requirements of the law that the ownership and management of mass media entities must be wholly owned by Filipinos,\u201d a presidential spokesman, Harry Roque, said.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nLate Monday night, the S.E.C. said in a statement that Rappler could continue to operate pending an appeal of the commission\u2019s decision.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe Foreign Correspondents Association of the Philippines, formed in the 1970s to work for press freedom at the height of former President Ferdinand Marcos\u2019s regime, expressed \u201cdeep regret\u201d over the move.\n\n\u201cThe decision, which is tantamount to killing the online news site, sends a chilling effect to media organizations in the country,\u201d the group said.\n\nThe National Union of Journalists of the Philippines also denounced the government, calling the move a vendetta by Mr. Duterte and urging media workers in the country to protest.\n\nFrancis Pangilinan, leader of the opposition in the Senate, said the revocation of Rappler\u2019s license was a blow against \u201ctruth-telling and journalistic integrity.\u201d\n\n\u201cIn a time of fear, of relentless attacks on our institutions, the abuse of power, and the feeling of helplessness that this breeds, we seek solidarity,\u201d Mr. Pangilinan said.\n\nThe strongman Mr. Marcos closed down television networks and newspapers during his two decades in power, and he jailed many opposition figures and journalists.\n\nMr. Marcos was ousted in 1986, and his successor Corazon Aquino helped introduce a Constitution that guaranteed press freedom, arguing that such a right was central to democracy.\n\nHer son, Benigno Aquino III, Mr. Duterte\u2019s predecessor, was often criticized by the news media, and he complained about being unfairly treated. He never made a move to restrict press freedom, however.\n\nThe last time a sitting president took aim at the news media was in 1999, when President Joseph Estrada sued the Manila Times over a report about corruption. The newspaper apologized, and Mr. Estrada dropped the suit, but the publication was eventually forced to sell.", "title": "Philippines Shuts Down News Site Critical of Rodrigo Duterte", "authors": ["Felipe Villamor"]} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "In your opinion, should phones come with addiction warnings? Do you think it is up to tech companies to build less addictive devices? Or is it up to individuals to use their phones responsibly? Why do you think the way you do?\n\nWhat else do you think tech companies or individuals could do to prevent bad phone habits?\n\nTell us in the comments, then read the related article to find out one columnist\u2019s thoughts on the debate.", "title": "Phone Warnings", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "Loren Long\u2019s illustrations for \u201cLove,\u201d collaged and painted monoprints, corroborate a child\u2019s paradoxical, simultaneous confusion and clarity. A large family stands in the glow of the TV. Something horrific has happened, again. The adults are processing the bad event through the media and do not see that a child in pink pajamas has sneaked downstairs. \u201cBut when you ask what has happened, they answer with silence and shift between you and the screen.\u201d Here is fear, but here is also love. Elsewhere an older brother makes burned toast for his sibling while their father rides the early bus to work. In the toast\u2019s char, in the father\u2019s absence, we find love even in places that hurt. I am even more moved by these unseen acts of care \u2014 char, breadwinning \u2014 than all the flowers, laughing uncles and buskers de la Pe\u00f1a and Long (the Otis series, \u201cLittle Tree\u201d) also provide. Love that comes untested is perhaps not love strong enough for troubled times. This book looks into the darkness and still find stars twinkling overhead.\n\n\u201cI Am Loved,\u201d a collection for children from the distinguished poet Nikki Giovanni, tackles, among other things, the idea of self-love and social justice. One poem asks us to look in the provided mirror and see all the bravery that came before, the hope, the sweat, the suffering that made us. \u201cAnd for that alone I am loved.\u201d This ancestral pride is perfectly met in the book\u2019s illustrations, by the renowned Ashley Bryan, now 94 and still making indelible art. They are a world of exuberance and color, swirling portraits that show off a fluency with art drawn from multiple eras: 1960s psychedelia, Tibetan mandalas, American quilts, Madhubani paintings. Gorgeous.\n\nA clear favorite from Giovanni\u2018s collection is \u201cDo the Rosa Parks,\u201d a rhythm song both joyful and catchy. I heard my 7-year-olds singing it to one another days after we had read \u201cI Am Loved.\u201d \u201cDo the Rosa Parks / throw your hands in the air \u2026 Do the Rosa Parks / tell them that\u2019s not fair.\u201d Playground empowerment gives me a lot of hope.\n\n\u201cDear Girl\u201d is an epistolary picture book written by Amy Krouse Rosenthal, the author of many books including \u201cFriendshape\u201d and \"Uni the Unicorn,\u201d who died last year, and her daughter, Paris Rosenthal. Their book is a series of reminders I sorely wish we didn\u2019t still need. And yet. \u201cDear Girl, Keep that arm raised! You have smart things to say!\u201d They also use the device of a mirror to discuss self-love. \u201cThank you, birthmark! Thank you, red hair!\u201d \u201cDear Girl\u201d mixes the joy of childhood \u2014 \u201cSometimes you just gotta stop and DANCE!\u201d \u2014 with threads more troubling. \u201cDear Girl, If your instinct is telling you to say no, say no, you know?\u201d Some may find a picture book that touches on consent disheartening, yet it seems abundantly necessary.", "title": "Picture Books About Kindness, Compassion and Peace in a Turbulent World", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "PARIS \u2014 Pierre Herm\u00e9 and L\u2019Occitane en Provence are experimenting with a new recipe. Make that a few dozen.\n\nLast month \u2014 just as the style set had begun to mourn the end of Colette, the original Parisian concept store \u2014 Mr. Herm\u00e9, the \u201cPicasso of pastries,\u201d and L\u2019Occitane, the beauty brand known for products inspired by the Mediterranean lifestyle, stepped into the gap, opening 86 Champs, a 10,000-square-foot lifestyle concept store on Avenue des Champs-\u00c9lys\u00e9es.\n\nIt is the biggest and arguably the starriest in a new breed of luxury spots that includes Prada\u2019s Pasticceria Marchesi in Milan and Buly in Paris. And it may help support a new identity for the Champs-\u00c9lys\u00e9es, long a tourist-trap avenue shunned by Parisians. With the arrival of 86 Champs and the scheduled openings of an Apple store and a Galeries Lafayette flagship, as well as the reopening of a Chanel beauty store on the strip, the Champs is suddenly seeming tasteful \u2014 in every sense of the word.\n\nNamed with its street number, 86 Champs brings together three things for which France is most revered: food, fragrance and the pleasure principle. At least one waste disposal site in London is already seeing a buildup of plastic recyclables and has had to pay to have some of it removed.\n\nSimilar backups have been reported in Canada, Ireland, Germany and several other European nations, while tons of rubbish is piling up in port cities like Hong Kong.\n\nSteve Frank, of Pioneer Recycling in Oregon, owns two plants that collect and sort 220,000 tons of recyclable materials each year. The president can surprise those who think the worst of him, and prove that he\u2019s been underestimated. All he has to do is apologize to his fellow Americans for the shame he\u2019s brought upon this country, and resign effective immediately.\n\nSince that\u2019s not going to happen, I\u2019m begging my fellow pundits not to get too excited should Trump manage to read from a teleprompter without foaming at the mouth or saying anything overtly racist. No matter how well Trump delivers the lines in his State of the Union \u2014 announced theme: \u201cBuilding a safe, strong and proud America\u201d \u2014 he will not become presidential. There will be no turning of corners or uniting the country. At best, Trump will succeed in impersonating a minimally competent leader for roughly the length of an episode of \u201cThe Apprentice.\u201d And if he does, recent history suggests that he will be praised as the second coming of Lincoln.\n\nDuring Trump\u2019s address to a joint session of Congress last February, there was a moment when he singled out the widow of William Owens, a Navy SEAL known as Ryan who\u2019d been killed in a raid in Yemen the month before. \u201cRyan\u2019s legacy is etched into eternity,\u201d Trump said, as the cameras lingered on the widow\u2019s tear-streaked face. He let the applause continue for more than a minute and a half, then said, \u201cRyan is looking down right now, you know that, and he\u2019s very happy, because I think he just broke a record.\u201d\n\nThe president\u2019s words struck me as grossly presumptuous, as if any sort of record applause at Trump\u2019s big speech redeemed Owens\u2019s death. The hollow\n\n\n\nis not menaced by your trilling. It decides to take your body inside it.\n\nYou pile on layers of woolens and fiction, trying to appeal to the hollow\n\n\n\nas it owns you. Everyone asks Why is your voice so drained, so moon?\n\nIt\u2019s because you are feverishly slipping on mantras that should heal the hollow,\n\n\n\nbut it just grows larger, and you flail around inside it. It is shaped so\n\nstupidly like a father. You can\u2019t find your knees to kneel. The hollow\n\n\n\nwill be damned if it gives you a chance to pray your way out, so you\n\nwill yourself limp and succumb to damage. What I adore\n\nis a bug that lives only one day, especially if\n\nit\u2019s a terrible day, a day of train derailment or\n\nchemical lake or cop admits to cover-up, a day\n\nwhen no one thinks of anything else, least of all\n\nthat bug. I know how it feels, born as I\u2019ve been\n\ninto these rotting times, as into sin. Everybody\u2019s\n\nbusy, so distraught they forget to kill me,\n\nand even that won\u2019t keep me alive. I share\n\nmy home not with horses, but with a little dog\n\nwho sees poorly at dusk and menaces stumps,\n\nmakes her muscle known to every statue.\n\nI wish she could have a single day of language,\n\nso that I might reassure her don\u2019t be afraid \u2014\n\nour whole world is dead and so can do you no harm.", "title": "Poem: Not Horses", "authors": ["Natalie Shapero"]} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "Terrance Hayes is the author of five collections of poetry, most recently \u201cHow to Be Drawn,\u201d which was a finalist for the National Book Award in 2015. He was then set to fly to Brussels, where he was scheduled to have a working dinner with the European Commission president, Jean-Claude Juncker.\n\nIn laying out the changes at a news conference on Tuesday, Mr. Morawiecki also reiterated Poland\u2019s stance against Muslim immigrants. The country, he said, needed to be \u201csafe at its external borders as well as inside the country.\u201d\n\n\u201cPoland is a beautiful yacht sailing across the increasingly unknown seas and oceans,\u201d he said. \u201cBut whether it docks safely in the port depends not just on strong cloths, but also our crew.\u201d", "title": "Poland Reshuffles Government, Hoping to Ease Tensions With E.U.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-29 00:00:00", "text": "It is baffling why Poland\u2019s nationalist-controlled Parliament would mark International Holocaust Remembrance Day \u2014 the anniversary of the liberation of Auschwitz-Birkenau, the largest Nazi concentration camp on Polish soil \u2014 with a needless, foolish and insulting draft bill that would penalize any suggestion of complicity by the Polish state or the Polish nation in the Nazi death machine.\n\nApart from raising the very questions about the role of the Poles in the Holocaust that the drafters apparently want to hide, are we not past such self-serving posturing over one of history\u2019s greatest crimes? Whatever dubious motives are behind this measure, Poland would do well to erase it as quickly as possible.\n\nNo doubt it pains Poles, whose country was overrun and occupied by Nazi Germany in World War II, when foreigners refer to Auschwitz and other extermination centers the Nazis set up in Poland as \u201cPolish death camps.\u201d They were Nazi death camps. Along with three million Polish Jews \u2014 about half of all Jews killed in the Holocaust \u2014 at least 1.9 million Polish gentiles were killed. Some Poles tried to help Jews and have been recognized as \u201crighteous among nations.\u201d\n\nYet it is also undeniable that Poles were directly or indirectly complicit in the crimes committed on their land and that Poles were guilty of anti-Jewish pogroms during and after the war. These are the facts of that terrible history, and the Poles, like all other nations conquered by Germany that became embroiled in the Nazi atrocities, have an obligation to the victims and to the future to seek the full truth, however painful.", "title": "Opinion | Poland\u2019s Holocaust Blame Bill", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "ROME \u2014 Police officers in Italy swooped down on a Chinese mafia organization on Thursday, arresting 33 people on suspicion of running a criminal enterprise that dominated the transport of Chinese products in Europe, financed with money from prostitution, gambling and drugs.\n\nThe mass arrests captivated attention in Italy, where the term mafia originated, and provided a glimpse into the extensive economic tentacles of Chinese gangsters in Europe.\n\nThe network\u2019s headquarters was in Prato, a Tuscan city northwest of Florence that has long been home to a large Chinese community that manufactures low-priced garments. It had affiliates in Paris, Madrid and Neuss, Germany, as well as in some northern Italian cities and in Rome, where the group\u2019s leader lived, the police said in announcing results of a seven-year investigation.\n\nThe police operation broke up \u201ca dangerous organization that had used force to take control of trucking, and was financed by its illegal activities,\u201d Interior Minister Marco Minniti said in a statement.", "title": "Police Bust a Chinese Mafia in the Country That Invented the Term", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-29 00:00:00", "text": "The 50th Precinct, where the officers are assigned, is not part of the Police Department\u2019s body camera pilot program, so none of the officers involved were wearing the recording devices.\n\nPhoto\n\nAlotisia Stevens, 42, has a 3-year-old son with Mr. Pritchett and said she wants answers about his death.\n\n\u201cIf I am detained this way, how am I reaching for anything?\u201d she said, placing her arms behind her back like they were cuffed.\n\nMr. Pritchett\u2019s 71-year-old father had called 911 around 5 p.m. on Sunday after his son barricaded himself inside the apartment\u2019s one bedroom, according to the police. When the officers arrived, the son opened the door, and officers saw a handgun magazine on the floor, according to the police.\n\nThe officers went in and handcuffed Mr. Pritchett, who the police said then tried to pull one of the officer\u2019s guns from its holster. They removed him from the bedroom, and soon noticed that he was unresponsive, according to the police.\n\nEmergency medical technicians on the scene tried to revive Mr. Pritchett with C.P.R. and Narcan, an opioid overdose-reversal drug, before taking him to NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital/Allen Hospital, where he was pronounced dead, according to the police.\n\nThe Police Department said its Force Investigation Division was reviewing Mr. Pritchett\u2019s death. The city medical examiner, which will determine the cause of his death, said on Monday afternoon that it had not reached any conclusions.\n\nPhoto\n\nAfter pulling Mr. Pritchett out of the bedroom, the officers laid him on the living room floor between Mr. Garment\u2019s bed and the couch, the roommate said. Surrounding him, one officer put a knee on Mr. Pritchett as his hands were cuffed behind his back. Mr. Pritchett squirmed to his side, grunted and spit at the officers, prompting them to put a mask on his face, according to Mr. Garment.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAfter a short time, Mr. Garment said, an officer noticed that Mr. Pritchett was not breathing and the mask had fogged up. Emergency medical technicians worked on him for almost 30 minutes, continuing as he was loaded onto a stretcher and taken to a waiting ambulance.\n\nMr. Pritchett, who worked as a barber, had come to live with his father early last week after an altercation with Ms. Stevens, she said.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. He refused to open it.\n\n\u201cHe wasn\u2019t all there, he was babbling, he was talking incoherently,\u201d Mr. Garment said.\n\nAfraid that his son would take more heroin, the elder Mr. Pritchett called the police, Mr. Garment said. He faces drug and weapons charges.", "title": "Police Investigate Officers\u2019 Actions in the Death of a Bronx Man in Custody", "authors": ["Ashley Southall", "Nate Schweber"]} {"date": "2018-01-29 00:00:00", "text": "The police had been called at least twice before to Ms. Danner\u2019s apartment in the Castle Hill neighborhood of the Bronx. One time she had barricaded herself inside, forcing the authorities to break down the door. Another time she had threatened to jump out a window.\n\nShe feared death at the hands of the police, her relatives said. She had even written a six-page essay about her illness to a lawyer that mentioned Ms. Bumpurs. \u201cWe are all aware of the all too frequent news stories about the mentally ill who come up against law enforcement instead of mental heath professionals and end up dead,\u201d she wrote.\n\nThe street protests and publicity surrounding the shooting prompted Sergeant Barry to ask a judge to move the trial to another town, but the motion was denied. Now he has waived his right to a jury and put his fate in the hands of Justice Robert A. Neary.\n\nSergeant Barry\u2019s lawyers plan to argue he acted in self-defense. According to his account related in court papers, he arrived at the apartment on Pugsley Avenue on Oct. 18, 2016, to find four officers standing in the living room and Ms. Danner, who was 5-foot-7 and 233 pounds, sitting on a bed in her room, snapping a pair of scissors and cutting paper. The police had learned from a 911 caller and from Ms. Danner\u2019s sister that she was a paranoid schizophrenic.\n\nImage Deborah Danner, 66, a schizophrenic woman, was shot and killed by a police sergeant in 2016 after picking up a bat in the bedroom of her Bronx apartment. Credit\n\nSergeant Barry says he talked Ms. Danner into putting the scissors on a nightstand and coaxed her to the doorway of the room. But she refused to come further.\n\nThen, he motioned to another officer and together they tried to grab her. She retreated into her room and pulled a baseball bat from under the blankets on her bed, according to his account. The sergeant and a second officer went into the room after her. She raised the bat as if she were stepping to the plate. Sergeant Barry pulled his gun and told her more than once to drop the bat. She swung it at his head. He fired twice into her torso.\n\nFor Sergeant Barry\u2019s lawyer, Andrew C. Quinn, the officer\u2019s narrative is a cut-and-dried case of self-defense under state law. Mr. Quinn has argued in court papers that seek to dismiss the indictment that the sergeant was trying to prevent Ms. Danner from grabbing the scissors again when he entered her bedroom. He could not retreat once she picked up the bat, the lawyer has argued.", "title": "Police Sergeant Who Killed Mentally Ill Woman Goes on Trial", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "The groups scout for military veterans, Sandersistas and others. But we found that what they generally do not scout for is competence at governing. In fact, many shy away from experience in government, on the theory that careerists are impure and inauthentic. As a representative of Justice Democrats, a group organized by former Sanders supporters, told us, \u201cWe don\u2019t want career politicians, period.\u201d\n\nAlthough winning public office will never be easy, the proliferation of candidate pipelines is already making it easier for aspirants to run \u2014 and for groups to grow their own politicians. As a political consultant told us: \u201cAccess has been both demystified and democratized. People who used to think there\u2019s no use running, because they would never win or it\u2019s too big an unknown, are much less cowed by those factors.\u201d Another consultant made the point more piquantly: \u201cIt\u2019s become like a clown car. Everyone thinks they\u2019re qualified and everyone jumps in.\u201d\n\nWhen we surveyed political consultants, they told us, by wide margins, that candidates in primary races are becoming more ideological and more inexperienced. Other research finds signs of a downward spiral. Extreme candidates heighten polarization in politics and paralysis in Congress, discouraging moderates and pragmatists (who reflect the preferences of most Americans) from entering politics.\n\nProgressive activists we spoke with said they seek not just to influence policy but also to broaden the very concept of political viability. Though the goal is laudable, inexperience can compound the chaos that is already giving government a bad name. Even a handful of political renegades can have a crippling effect on a legislative body, which is one reason Mitch McConnell, the Senate majority leader, was desperate to keep Roy Moore of Alabama out of the Senate.\n\nTo be effective at their jobs, politicians need know-how, connections and I.O.U.s, which take years to accumulate. President Trump lacked all of those assets, so it is no surprise he has had trouble governing. In Congress and state legislatures, frustrated leaders find themselves saddled with anyone and everyone who prevails in low-turnout primaries, no matter how nutty or disruptive.\n\nIf governing ability and candidate quality matter, and if special interests and purist ideologues are not to become the leading suppliers of our politicians, it is essential that parties and professionals maintain a prominent role in recruiting and screening candidates \u2014 alongside, not instead of, voters. By virtue of their insider status, they have a long-term interest in having parties govern responsibly.\n\nAlas, reformers have been pushing to marginalize professionals still further. In the Democratic Party, so-called superdelegates \u2014 elected officials and party leaders empowered to vote as they wish at the presidential convention \u2014 will not and almost certainly cannot reject a popular victor, but they do encourage candidates to seek the advice and support of people they will be working with if elected. Reducing their role, as progressives have successfully campaigned to do through the Unity Reform Commission (created by the Democratic National Committee to examine the party\u2019s nominating process), may appeal to the public\u2019s populist instincts, but it is shortsighted for those who care about effective government.", "title": "Opinion | Politics Shouldn\u2019t Be Like Open Mic Night", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-16 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThe overall story remains that the president is not getting credit for an economy that has been continuing on an upward trajectory,\u201d said Jon Cohen, vice president for survey research at SurveyMonkey.\n\nOther recent surveys show public confidence in the economy is rising, but less movement on the tax bill. A Quinnipiac University poll released last week found that two-thirds of Americans viewed the economy as excellent or good, up 3 percentage points from December. A Gallup poll published last week found that approval for the law had risen to 33 percent in January from 29 percent in December, an increase that was not statistically significant.\n\nSupporters of the tax law dismissed its poor poll numbers in the fall, saying Americans would like it more once they began to see its benefits in their take-home pay. \u201cThe results are going to be what sells this bill,\u201d House Speaker Paul D. Ryan, Republican of Wisconsin, told reporters in mid-December.\n\nMany Americans won\u2019t start to see more money in their paychecks until February, because the Internal Revenue Service issued new tax withholding guidance only last week. But a series of high-profile announcements, from companies such as Walmart and Wells Fargo, have cited the tax bill in decisions to raise wages or give employees one-time bonuses.\n\nMany analysts, however, say the pay increases were more a result of the strong labor market than the tax law. A Morgan Stanley survey of Wall Street analysts released on Tuesday found that only 22 percent expected the companies they follow to direct at least some of their tax savings to employee compensation. By contrast, 83 percent of analysts said companies would increase share buybacks, dividends or merger activity. (Analysts could select multiple responses.)\n\nStill, the law, which cut taxes for businesses and individuals while eliminating many deductions and credits, isn\u2019t particularly popular. Forty-nine percent of Americans in the Times survey said they disapproved of it, and far more people said they were strongly opposed to it than strongly in favor. And deep political divisions are evident: 86 percent of Republicans approve of the law, but just 13 percent of Democrats do.\n\nMost Americans still don\u2019t think they will see their taxes go down under the new law. According to the survey, 41 percent of Americans expect a tax cut this year, up from 33 percent in December. Most independent analyses estimate that three-quarters or more of households will receive a tax cut in 2018, although those cuts are set to expire after 2025.", "title": "Poll Finds Upturn in Sentiment on Tax Overhaul and Economy", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-29 00:00:00", "text": "These are appearances designed for casual Grammys viewers, the ones who need reassurance that they aren\u2019t out of touch. They acknowledge the Grammys as a big tent, one that needs to accommodate the stars of yesterday and also today. (Seemingly gone, thankfully, are the ill-conceived genre-collision pairings of years past: somehow, DJ Khaled, Rihanna and Bryson Tiller got through their performance of \u201cWild Thoughts\u201d without Santana himself \u2014 or worse, someone not associated with the song \u2014 emerging for an ostentatious lick.)\n\nBut that is a different problem than steadfastly denying the next generation of Bonos and Stings their due.\n\nBlack artists have smelled the disingenuousness for years, and lately, have been protesting. Frank Ocean declined to submit his most recent releases for consideration. Kanye West has long noted that he wins in genre categories, but not in all-genre categories (something Kendrick Lamar can certainly relate to given his Grammys history; on Sunday he swept the rap categories, but otherwise came up empty). Drake all but rejected his Grammy for best rap song last year because he contended that the track, \u201cHotline Bling,\u201d wasn\u2019t really a rap song.\n\nAdd to these dissenters the list of vital talent that didn\u2019t show up this year: Justin Bieber, Taylor Swift, the Weeknd, Ed Sheeran. It is clear that the Grammys are alienating an entire generation of talent with their conservatism. This has always been the case, of course, but the feedback mechanisms are far more efficient now. And overlooked artists have many more ways in which they can seek validation.", "title": "Pop Keeps Changing. And the Grammys Turn a Deaf Ear, Again.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "CHESTER WATSON at Trans-Pecos (Jan. 23, 8 p.m.). A Florida-raised rapper and producer in his early 20s, given to mystical loops and deftly interlaced syllables, Chester Watson is a cult artist who seems bound for bigger things. Listen to his 2016 release, \u201cPast Cloaks,\u201d for a primer if you\u2019re among the uninitiated, then see Mr. Watson at this Ridgewood, Queens, space while you still can.\n\n877-987-6487, thetranspecos.com\n\nYUMI ZOUMA at Baby\u2019s All Right (Jan. 19-20, 8 p.m.). The melodies on \u201cWillowbank,\u201d the album this New Zealand synth-pop band released in October, are as cozy and welcoming as a well-built pillow fort. The group also put out a limited-edition cover of Oasis\u2019 attitudinous 1995 album \u201cWhat\u2019s the Story (Morning Glory)\u201d last year, as if to demonstrate its range. Sink into the plush tones at these Brooklyn shows.\n\n877-987-6487, babysallright.com\n\nSIMON VOZICK-LEVINSON\n\nPhoto\n\nJazz\n\nRAY ANGRY, WARREN WOLF AND FRIENDS at Blue Note (Jan. 22-24, 8 & 10:30 p.m.). Mr. Angry, a powerful pianist, tends toward soul-influenced, sparkling forms of contemporary jazz; Mr. Wolf hews more closely to a straight-ahead style. Together for three nights at the Blue Note, they will convene a rotating cast of all-star collaborators. The band will be different every evening; some of the big names on deck include the trumpeter Sean Jones, the saxophonists Tia Fuller and James Carter, and the drummer Marcus Gilmore.\n\n212-475-8592, bluenote.net\n\nAL FOSTER QUARTET at Smoke (Jan. 19-21; 7, 9 and 10:30 p.m.). Mr. Foster, a drummer, spent a long tenure accompanying Miles Davis in the 1970s and \u201980s, playing on fusion albums such as \u201cPangaea\u201d and \u201cWe Want Miles.\u201d Since then he has been more affiliated with postbop, typically lending his pert and propulsive flair to acoustic jazz combos (with some notable exceptions). Here he celebrates his 75th birthday with a three-night run featuring Dayna Stephens on tenor saxophone, Adam Birnbaum on piano and Doug Weiss on bass.\n\n212-864-6662, smokejazz.com\n\nJAMIE SAFT at the Owl (Jan. 25, 8 p.m.). Mr. Saft, a pianist, has played psychedelic Brazilian dub with his New Zion Trio and dark, foreboding ballads with Iggy Pop (on last year\u2019s \u201cLoneliness Road\u201d). Here he celebrates the release of something a little gentler and more straightforward: a solo piano album, \u201cSolo a Genova,\u201d featuring covers of songs by the likes of Curtis Mayfield, Joni Mitchell and John Coltrane, in a personal patois that wanders from languid to joyful.\n\n718-774-0042, theowl.nyc\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nJAZZ LEGENDS FOR DISABILITY PRIDE AT THE SHEEN CENTER (Jan. 25, 7:30 p.m.). This annual benefit for Disability Pride NYC features an impressive lineup of elders and luminaries, including the saxophonist George Coleman, the pianist Kenny Barron, the drummer Jimmy Cobb and the trumpeter Wynton Marsalis. The organization, which also organizes the annual Disability Pride Parade, was founded by Mike LeDonne, a pianist whose daughter, Mary, is disabled due to Praeder-Willi Syndrome.\n\n212-925-2812, disabilitypridenyc.org\n\nJENNY SCHEINMAN\u2019S MISCHIEF AND MAYHEM at Jazz Standard (through Jan. 21, 7:30 and 9:30 p.m.). Ms. Scheinman takes the violin into jazz, Appalachian folk, experimental rock and many zones between. This weekend at the Jazz Standard she presents Mischief and Mayhem, a quartet that makes experimental music of textural enigma, white-knuckle throb and, occasionally, moments of startling melodic clarity. The expert group features Nels Cline on guitar, Todd Sickafoose on bass and Jim Black on drums.\n\n212-576-2232, jazzstandard.com\n\nJEN SHYU at the Jazz Gallery (Jan. 24, 7:30 and 9:30 p.m.). Ms. Shyu, a multi-instrumentalist and vocalist and movement artist, recently released \u201cSong of Silver Geese,\u201d a nine-part suite that she calls a \u201critual music drama,\u201d sung in a variety of Asian and European languages. Here she performs \u201cNine Doors,\u201d a related solo piece, at 7:30, and then at 9:30 she follows that with \u201cSong of Silver Geese,\u201d featuring Mat Maneri on viola and Dan Weiss on drums.\n\n646-494-3625, jazzgallery.nyc\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSTEPHANE WREMBEL at Joe\u2019s Pub (Jan. 23, 7 p.m.). Perhaps the most creative improviser in Gypsy jazz today, Mr. Wrembel plays the guitar with a rich and colorful lyricism. He\u2019s best known for writing the music to Woody Allen\u2019s film \u201cMidnight in Paris.\u201d At this show, taking place on Django Reinhardt\u2019s 108th birthday, he celebrates the release of \u201cThe Django Experiment III,\u201d an album paying tribute to the famed Gypsy jazz pioneer.\n\n212-967-7555, publictheater.org\n\nZS, OLIVER LAKE AND MORE at H0L0 (Jan. 25, 8 p.m.). Pouring together no-wave, free jazz and electronic incitement, Zs might be improvised music\u2019s ultimate 21st-century cult group. The band, which has gone through a number of lineup changes, currently features Sam Hillmer on tenor saxophone; Patrick Higgins on electric guitar and electronics; Greg Fox on drums and percussion; and Michael Beharie on electronics. Zs celebrate their 15th anniversary with this show, at a basement space in Ridgewood, Queens. The night will see appearances from a range of other performers, including the master alto saxophonist Oliver Lake and the young cellist Leila Bordreuil.\n\nh0l0.nyc\n\nGIOVANNI RUSSONELLO", "title": "Pop, Rock and Jazz in NYC This Week", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "Our guide to pop and rock shows and the best of live jazz.\n\nPop\n\nJANE BIRKIN at Carnegie Hall (Feb. 1, 8 p.m.). Jane Birkin and Serge Gainsbourg had one of the great romances of the 20th century, expressed through two decades\u2019 worth of sly, decadent French love songs \u2014 from the succ\u00e8s de scandale of \u201cJe T\u2019Aime...Moi Non Plus\u201d in 1969 through \u201cAmours des Feintes,\u201d released less than a year before Mr. Gainsbourg\u2019s death in 1991. In recent years, Ms. Birkin has crisscrossed the world performing new orchestral arrangements of her late ex-lover\u2019s music. \u201cIt\u2019s a wonderful feeling, but equally sad, because the most beautiful songs were written when I left him,\u201d she told The New York Times in November. At this Carnegie Hall show, she will be backed by the Wordless Music Orchestra, with a special guest appearance from Rufus Wainwright, one of Mr. Gainsbourg\u2019s greatest stylistic heirs. It\u2019s sure to be a night of bittersweet beauty and high wit.\n\n212-247-7800, carnegiehall.org\n\nJEN CLOHER at Rough Trade NYC (Jan. 30, 9 p.m.). The Australian songwriter Jen Cloher\u2019s self-titled album was one of 2017\u2019s finest rock releases, full of hard-won insights on matters personal (\u201cStrong Woman\u201d) and political (\u201cAnalysis Paralyisis\u201d). The last time Ms. Cloher toured the United States, this past autumn, it was as an opening act for her partner, Courtney Barnett. This month, she\u2019s back for a headlining run that hits Brooklyn on Tuesday night, fronting an exceptionally tight band whose members include Ms. Barnett on guitar.\n\n888-929-7849, roughtrade.com/us\n\nFLEETWOOD MAC at Radio City Music Hall (Jan. 26, 7:30 p.m.) and ELTON JOHN at the Theater at Madison Square Garden (Jan. 30, 8 p.m.). The Grammy Awards are in New York this weekend, for the first time since 2003 \u2014 which means that several platinum-dusted tributes organized by the Recording Academy are in town this week, too. The hottest ticket is a Radio City Music Hall gala for the five members of Fleetwood Mac, who are being collectively recognized as \u201cPerson of the Year\u201d by the Grammy-run charity MusiCares; they will share the stage with Lorde, Harry Styles, Haim and other A-list fans. The second-hottest: \u201cElton John: I\u2019m Still Standing \u2014 A Grammy Salute,\u201d featuring performances by Kesha, Sam Smith, Miley Cyrus and Sir Elton himself at the relatively cozy Theater at Madison Square Garden. These shows aren\u2019t cheap, but they will surely be memorable.\n\n800-745-3000, msg.com\n\nFRUIT & FLOWERS at Rough Trade NYC (Jan. 28, 7:30 p.m.). This Brooklyn psych-rock group was named one of 2016\u2019s hardest-working local acts by one website after playing upward of 30 shows in the city that year. It recently earned the same honor for 2017. Even if such metrics do little to convince you of a band\u2019s artistic merit, though, Fruit & Flowers are worth a listen: Their recent EP \u201cDrug Tax\u201d is full of dark little hooks that are easy to hum along with and harder to forget.\n\n888-929-7849, roughtrade.com/us", "title": "Pop, Rock and Jazz in NYC This Week", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "WAX IDOLS at Elsewhere (Jan. 12, 6 p.m.). This group\u2019s most recent album, \u201cAmerican Tragic,\u201d from 2015, is a minor masterpiece of darkly glamorous goth-pop. If you didn\u2019t hear it then, it\u2019s not too late to discover its delights now \u2014 and you\u2019ll be ahead of the game when Wax Idols\u2019 follow-up, \u201cHappy Ending,\u201d which the band\u2019s charismatic singer-songwriter, Hether Fortune, has described as a macabre concept LP, arrives later this year. In the meantime, this show at the multilevel Brooklyn event space Elsewhere is a good choice for anyone seeking wintry thrills. With Future Punx and Desert Sharks.\n\nelsewherebrooklyn.com\n\nYAMS DAY at New York Expo Center (Jan. 18, 8 p.m.). Three years after the death at 26 of the estimable hip-hop tastemaker and impresario Steven Rodriguez, known to the world as ASAP Yams, the circle of uptown New York rappers that orbited him \u2014 collectively dubbed ASAP Mob \u2014 remains a hub of exciting new ideas and throwback joys. The group will celebrate Mr. Rodriguez\u2019s memory on Saturday with the third annual Yams Day concert, held this year at a cavernous convention center in the Bronx, with a portion of proceeds going to the Always Strive and Prosper Foundation, a substance-abuse education organization founded by Yams\u2019s mother. Expect dynamic performances from the crew\u2019s torchbearers, ASAP Rocky and ASAP Ferg, as well as some high-profile friends: Lil Yachty and Nav are among the confirmed guests.\n\n888-929-7849, asapmob.com\n\nSIMON VOZICK-LEVINSON\n\nPhoto\n\nJazz\n\nHARRIS EISENSTADT\u2019S \u2018POSCHIAVO 50\u2019 AND PLAY at the Owl (Jan. 18, 7:30 p.m.). Mr. Eisenstadt, a drummer, is also possessed of a cinematic compositional voice. He wrote 50 short pieces during a residency at the Uncool Festival in Switzerland last year, and he\u2019s been gradually unveiling them at the Owl, playing one show per month since November. For each concert he\u2019s enlisted one or two different collaborators; at this one he\u2019ll be joined by two fellow percussionists: Patricia Brennan on vibraphone and Chris Dingman on marimba. Also on the bill is Play, a trio led by the drummer Vinnie Sperrazza and featuring the pianist Jacob Sacks and the bassist Masa Kamaguchi. Play investigates the repertoires of mid-20th-century composers, usually in a briskly swinging style.\n\n718-774-0042, theowl.nyc\n\nBILLY HARPER QUINTET at Smoke (Jan. 12-14; 7, 9 and 10:30 p.m.). Mr. Harper was of the most consistently exciting tenor saxophonists to emerge in the late 1960s and early \u201970s. He seemed to wield his horn like hot iron; his book of compositions, meanwhile, read as an insurrectionary tract, while fusing concepts from John Coltrane and Joe Henderson. His powers are undiminished, though we haven\u2019t seen a leadership recording from him in roughly a decade, and he does not headline his own shows in New York often enough. Catch him here with Freddie Hendrix on trumpet, Francesca Tanksley on piano, Hwansu Kang on bass and Aaron Scott on drums.\n\n212-864-6662, smokejazz.com\n\nTOM HARRELL at the Village Vanguard (through Jan. 21, 8:30 and 10:30 p.m.). Mr. Harrell boasts a smoky surety on both trumpet and flugelhorn; at 71, he\u2019s making some of the best music of his career, employing his bop-Romantic sensibility in midsize ensembles that feature some fabulous supporting actors. Through Sunday, he performs with Danny Grissett on piano, Ugonna Okegwo on bass and Adam Cruz on drums. After a break on Monday, the band plays six more nights with Jaleel Shaw joining on alto saxophone, and the drummer Joe Dyson subbing for Mr. Cruz.\n\n212-255-4037, villagevanguard.com\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nKEYON HARROLD AND FRIENDS at the Blue Note (Jan. 15-18, 8 and 10:30 p.m.). In the fall Mr. Harrold released a bold, expansive album, \u201cThe Mugician.\u201d It finds his trumpet coaxing an electrified ensemble into all sorts of approaches \u2014 slow-jam, vague Caribbean groove, contemporary jazz balladry \u2014 then tearing into them with animated, inventive soloing. He will draw on that material here, likely with special guests. (The album features a long list of guest vocalists, and when he played the Blue Note last January, Mr. Harrold brought along the rapper Big K.R.I.T. and the vocalist Bilal.)\n\n212-475-8592, bluenote.net\n\nANNA WEBBER at the Jazz Gallery (Jan. 18, 7:30 and 9:30 p.m.). The compositions of Ms. Webber, a saxophonist and multi-reedist, play in fresh ways with chime and repetition and schematics. The synced-up interactions she has with her band don\u2019t feel clinical or bolted down; they\u2019re open and resonant and exposed to the wind. Here she leads a remarkable septet, featuring Jeremy Viner on tenor saxophone and clarinet, Jacob Garchik on trombone, Chris Hoffman on cello, Matt Mitchell on piano, Chris Tordini on bass and Ches Smith on drums and vibraphone.\n\n646-494-3625, jazzgallery.nyc\n\nWINTER JAZZFEST (through Jan. 17). Temperatures should be unseasonably high this weekend \u2014 good news for the Winter Jazzfest Marathon, taking place Friday and Saturday at clubs and theaters across Lower Manhattan. Corralling over 100 sets of boldly programmed music, it\u2019s your opportunity to catch a gust of the trade winds sweeping across contemporary jazz. Acts include the Comet Is Coming, from London; the flutist Nicole Mitchell, this year\u2019s featured festival artist; and the upstart Onyx Collective. The rest of the festival consists of nightly shows at venues around Manhattan, Sunday through Wednesday, all of them worth considering.\n\nwinterjazzfest.com\n\nGIOVANNI RUSSONELLO", "title": "Pop, Rock and Jazz in NYC This Week", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-22 00:00:00", "text": "On his flight back to Rome, Francis issued a rare apology for what he called a \u201cslap in the face\u201d to victims. He was referring to the crisis he had created in Chile when he said that he had seen no \u201cproof\u201d that a bishop covered up abuse.\n\n\u201cHere I have to apologize because the word \u2018proof\u2019 hurt them,\u201d he said on the plane. \u201cIt hurt a lot of abused people.\u201d He added: \u201cI know how much they suffer. And to hear that the pope told them to their face that they need to bring a letter with proof?\u201d\n\nBut then he wound up making an unclear distinction between proof and evidence, and offered a spirited defense of Bishop Juan Barros Madrid, the Chilean accused by some abuse victims of protecting the Rev. Fernando Karadima, a notorious Chilean pedophile priest.\n\nSome of those victims have said Bishop Barros witnessed the abuse and did nothing, an accusation he denies.\n\n\u201cSomeone who accuses insistently without evidence, this is calumny,\u201d the pope said. \u201cIf I say, \u2018You stole something, you stole something,\u2019 I\u2019m slandering you because I don\u2019t have evidence.\u201d\n\nThe pope revealed that he had twice rejected the resignation of Bishop Barros in recent years, explaining that while an investigation continued into the bishop, whom he appointed to the small diocese of Osorno in 2015, \u201cI cannot condemn him because I do not have the evidence.\u201d\n\n\u201cBut I am also convinced he is innocent,\u201d the pope added.\n\nThe pope\u2019s inaction and missteps on the issue seem to be drying up his once seemingly bottomless well of good will.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIf he wanted evidence, why didn\u2019t he reach out to us when we were willing to reaffirm the testimony that not only us, but so many witnesses, have been providing for more than 15 years,\u201d said Juan Carlos Cruz, a Chilean victim of sexual abuse by members of the clergy.\n\nThe death last month in Rome of Cardinal Bernard F. Law, the disgraced face of a complicit church hierarchy that enabled sexual abuse, drew attention in the Vatican to a rift on the issue.\n\nPhoto\n\nOn one side are those who believe a policy of \u201czero tolerance\u201d and accountability remain vital for the church\u2019s credibility and the protection of minors. On the other are those who feel that the church has already done enough on the issue, and that the problem is behind them and has become a cudgel used by enemies of the church.\n\nFor some advocates, Pope Francis this week moved decisively into the second camp. The website BishopAccountability.org said the pope had \u201cturned back the clock to the darkest days of this crisis.\u201d On Monday, the Survivors Network of Those Abused by Priests, or SNAP, said in a statement that \u201cPope Francis has made his true feelings known.\u201d\n\nEmiliano Fittipaldi, an Italian investigative reporter who has looked into sexual abuse and who is the author of the book \u201cLust,\u201d said \u201cfor Francis, addressing sex abuse is priority in words, not actions.\u201d He said the pope\u2019s belief in zero tolerance seemed to evaporate when the accused were his friends.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cWhen it is people he knows and respects, like Barros, it\u2019s really hard for him to accept the accusations,\u201d Mr. Fittipaldi said. \u201cIn the Vatican they often say his people are protected.\u201d\n\nMany Vatican watchers have suggested that Francis is shaping up to be a less effective reformer on the issue than his conservative predecessor, Pope Benedict XVI, who kicked hundreds of priests out of the church.\n\nWhen Francis was elected in 2013, advocates expressed unbridled optimism that he would take the crucial, and politically delicate, step of holding accountable bishops who covered up for pedophile priests.\n\nThat has not happened. The Vatican scrapped a proposed tribunal to try bishops. Francis brought to Rome Cardinal George Pell, who subsequently became the highest-ranking Roman Catholic prelate to be formally charged with sexual offenses.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn September, the Vatican recalled Msgr. Carlo Alberto Capella, a high-ranking priest working as a diplomat in the Holy See\u2019s embassy in Washington, after American authorities sought to strip his immunity and potentially charge him with possession of child pornography.\n\nLast month, the three-year terms of members of the Pontifical Commission for the Protection of Minors, which the pope created in 2014, expired without any news of renewed terms or appointments. Ms. Collins and another abuse survivor on the commission resigned. The pope said on the plane that he had received a list of possible new members and called the delay \u201cnormal.\u201d\n\nCardinal Sean O\u2019Malley, the archbishop of Boston \u2014 Cardinal Law\u2019s old diocese and ground zero for the global sexual abuse crisis \u2014 leads the commission. After the pope\u2019s defense of Bishop Barros, Cardinal O\u2019Malley released an extraordinary statement chastising the pontiff for doubting victims, calling it \u201ca source of great pain for survivors\u201d that relegates them \u201cto discredited exile.\u201d\n\nOn the plane, Francis thanked Cardinal O\u2019Malley for the statement, calling it \u201cvery just,\u201d and he defended his own record on the issue. He said that since the start of his pontificate he had refused to sign \u201ceven one\u201d request for a pardon from about 25 pedophile priests.\n\nHe sought to turn back the clock to happier days, reminding reporters that he landed in Chile expressing \u201cpain and shame\u201d for children abused by priests.\n\nBut many advocates for victims heard less truth in those prepared remarks than in the pope\u2019s off-the-cuff response to a Chilean reporter\u2019s question about whether Bishop Barros was complicit in covering up crimes of abuse.\n\n\u201cThe day someone brings me proof against Bishop Barros, then I will talk,\u201d Francis said before celebrating Mass outside the northern Chilean city of Iquique. \u201cBut there is not one single piece of evidence. It is all slander. Is that clear?\u201d\n\nOn Sunday, the pope reiterated his doubts.\n\n\u201cHe is showing a very different attitude to those who have been abused,\u201d Ms. Collins said.", "title": "Pope Apologizes to Abuse Victims but Again Doubts Them", "authors": ["Jason Horowitz"]} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "After visiting the churches that were attacked, Archbishop Ricardo Ezzati of Santiago said, \u201cWe are deeply hurt by these events that contradict the spirit of peace that inspires the pope\u2019s visit.\u201d\n\nPresident Bachelet, who is scheduled to leave office in March, condemned the attacks. \u201cIn a democracy people can express themselves, as long as it is in a peaceful and adequate manner,\u201d she said.\n\nPope Francis is to arrive in Santiago on Monday night. On Tuesday he will celebrate Mass at a major public park and meet with Ms. Bachelet, government officials, members of the diplomatic corps and Chilean bishops. He will go to Temuco the following day and then visit the northern city of Iquique on Thursday morning before flying to Lima, Peru.\n\nIn addition to the Mapuche, another source of controversy around the visit is the issue of the complicity of Chilean bishops in the case of the Rev. Fernando Karadima, the former head of El Bosque parish in Santiago, who catered to the elite while abusing teenage boys. The Vatican found Father Karadima guilty of sexual abuse in 2011 and sentenced him to a life of penitence and prayer. The church sentence was the only punishment leveled against the abusive priest. Victims were unsuccessful in an effort to get compensation through civil litigation. But no actions have been taken against the tight circle of bishops whom he trained, and who victims say covered up his crimes.\n\nIn January 2015 Pope Francis appointed one of them, Juan Barros, as bishop of Osorno, 570 miles south of the capital, prompting protests by lay and religious groups that continue to this day.\n\nOn Thursday, The Associated Press revealed a letter sent by Pope Francis to the Chilean bishops\u2019 conference that same month after they expressed concern over the appointment. Francis told them that he had planned to offer a sabbatical to Bishop Barros and two other bishops with ties to Father Karadima in order to cool the heated environment over his controversial appointment. That move ultimately failed.\n\nFather Karadima\u2019s victims criticized the pope for not making time to meet with them during his visit, as they requested months ago.", "title": "Pope Faces Turmoil in Chile Over Indigenous Group and Sex Abuse", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-20 00:00:00", "text": "Ahead of Mass, thousands had camped out close to the beach, some having journeyed for days, to see the pontiff.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cIt has been an odyssey to get here, but we\u2019ve arrived to this promised land,\u201d said Rayna Garc\u00eda Sasi, 43, who traveled from the jungle town of Pucallpa. She came here with her mother and sister, traveling on a boat, on a bus and by foot over three days.\n\nThe papal visit comes at a difficult time for leaders of both the Peruvian government and the Roman Catholic Church. President Pedro Pablo Kuczynski faces ongoing street protests over a pardon given in December to Alberto Fujimori, a former president who was serving a 25-year sentence for human rights crimes.\n\nPope Francis also faces challenges after sexual abuse scandals in both Peru and Chile, including at Sodalitium Christianae Vitae, a powerful Catholic organization in Peru whose former leader, Luis Fernando Figari, is wanted by prosecutors. Mr. Figari is in Rome, and the Vatican has instructed him not to return to Peru.\n\nOn Saturday, Sean O\u2019Malley, an American cardinal, criticized the pope for comments he made about sexual abuse cases on an earlier stop in Chile. There, Francis had defended Bishop Juan Barros Madrid, whom he had appointed in 2015 and who is accused of protecting abusers. Cardinal O\u2019Malley said Francis\u2019s comments \u201cwere a source of great pain\u201d to victims.\n\nBut Saturday\u2019s visits with mudslide victims offered the pontiff a chance to distance himself from the controversy.\n\nIn Buenos Aires, one of the neighborhoods Francis visited, the devastation from mudslides can still be seen. Though a year has passed since the rains receded, many of those displaced by the storms still live in shacks assembled from cardboard, wooden planks and plastic tarps.\n\nPhoto\n\nRoughly 750 houses collapsed here. Many residents of the area had constructed their homes on dry riverbeds that were inundated during flash floods.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cWe are without running water, electricity and toilets \u2014 we don\u2019t even have portable latrines,\u201d said Julian Elia Arenas, 57, an unemployed miner who has been living in a tent since mid-March when a landslide took his home.\n\nMr. Arenas said he, his wife and four children were left with nothing but the clothes on their backs, but he hoped the pope\u2019s prayers would give him strength to move forward.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn El Porvenir, another area affected by the storm, fifty-two makeshift homes offer shelter to a dozen families still live in precarious conditions.\n\n\u201cWe take turns sleeping because we can\u2019t lock our doors,\u201d said Juan Carlos Mendoza, 35, whose adobe house was swept away last year. \u201cWe are living between plastic walls, so anyone can come and steal the little we have.\u201d\n\nA light rain on Friday night had kept Mr. Mendoza and his wife awake, and they collected the seeping water in plastic containers. He said he had mixed feelings about the pope\u2019s visit, saying his family has been neglected and forgotten.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t have any expectations; he\u2019s here today and will be gone tomorrow,\u201d Mr. Mendoza said. \u201cWe\u2019re just here waiting and watching.\u201d", "title": "Pope Francis Comforts Peruvians Who Faced \u2018Wrath of Nature\u2019", "authors": ["Andrea Zarate"]} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "Francis\u2019 trip to Chile in mid-January was overshadowed by his brusque remarks to a Chilean reporter that the claims against Bishop Barros amounted to \u201cslander.\u201d The pope said he would weigh in on the matter if there were \u201cproof\u201d against the bishop.\n\nCardinal Sean O\u2019Malley, the archbishop of Boston and the leader of the pope\u2019s commission on the protection of minors, called the pope\u2019s remarks \u201ca source of great pain for survivors\u201d that relegated them \u201cto discredited exile.\u201d\n\nIn a clumsy attempt at damage control, the pope made a contradictory statement on the flight back to Rome. He apologized for demanding proof from alleged victims, saying that the word was insensitive, but then reiterated that there was no \u201cevidence\u201d against the bishop, who he again said was the victim of slander.\n\nSome victims of Father Karadima, a powerful priest convicted by the Vatican in 2011 for sexually abusing minors, have accused Bishop Barros of standing by as the priest kissed and abused them in the El Bosque Catholic parish.\n\nOn the plane, Francis said he had twice refused to accept the resignation of Bishop Barros, and in January 2015 he moved the bishop from leading Chile\u2019s military ordinariate to the diocese of Osorno. The installation fractured the faithful and clergy of the city, with many opposing a bishop they considered complicit in sexual abuse.\n\nThe pope\u2019s response mystified observers and vexed his supporters. Possible explanations tumbled out. Was he getting bad advice from his cardinal advisers? Was he protecting a friend? Was he a member of a Vatican faction that believes in \u201czero tolerance\u201d or one that considers the abuse issue finished business? Was the pope, someone who faced accusations of supporting a violent regime as a cardinal in Argentina, loath to give into public pressure?\n\nTuesday\u2019s statement suggested that public pressure had forced the pope to act and that far from infallible, Francis had perhaps spoken in Chile without knowing what he was talking about.", "title": "Pope Francis, After Criticism, Sends Sex Crimes Investigator to Chile", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "SIENA, Italy \u2014 The colorful tickets bearing images of an elephant and giraffes behind the Colosseum along with the two iconic tigers of an Italian circus promised an afternoon\u2019s respite from hardship, a gift from the Vatican to thousands of poor people.\n\nBut the announcement on Wednesday that Pope Francis\u2019 charity office was planning to take 2,100 homeless and poor people to the circus, along with refugees and prisoners, did not go down well with animal rights activists.\n\nCarla Rocchi, the chairwoman of Italy\u2019s Animal Protection League, criticized the plan to attend the Thursday show, pointing to what she called the \u201cunnatural condition of detention and exploitation, if not mistreatment,\u201d of circus animals.\n\n\u201cThe vast majority of people and of the faithful believe that love for animals should not be sacrificed to love for the others,\u201d Ms. Rocchi said in a statement.", "title": "Pope Invites the Poor to the Circus, and Animal Activists Protest", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-21 00:00:00", "text": "Prosecutors have sought the arrest of Sodalitium\u2019s founder, Luis Fernando Figari, and a handful of other leaders. Instead, he shared a stage with a Sodalite archbishop, Jos\u00e9 Antonio Eguren, who introduced the pope at an event in the northern city of Trujillo. A December 2017 poll found that 75 percent of Peruvians identify as Roman Catholic, down from 85 percent a decade earlier, according to Peru\u2019s 2006 census.\n\nMore than a million people came to see Francis at his final Mass on Sunday evening, dwarfing the turnout in Chile, which was widely described as poor.\n\nIn his homily, he spoke of the suffering and injustice found in cities and the \u201ctemptation\u201d of leaving or hiding. And he said he hoped \u201cthat degradation be overcome by fraternity, injustice by solidarity and violence silenced by the weapons of peace.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMeeting with a group of nuns on Sunday morning, Francis told them to pray for a church that is \u201ctempted to disunite.\u201d He also offered them advice on maintaining unity.\n\n\u201cGossip is like a bomb,\u201d Francis told the nuns gathered at Las Nazarenas, a historic church near Lima\u2019s main square, adding that the best remedy was \u201cbiting their tongue.\u201d\n\n\u201cA nun who gossips,\u201d he said, \u201cis a terrorist nun.\u201d", "title": "Pope Lauds Peru\u2019s Young, but Stays Silent on Church Sex Abuse", "authors": ["Marcelo Rochabr\u00fan", "Andrea Zarate"]} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Baranda, a psychologist, said that the church \u201cnever believed Karadima\u2019s victims from the start\u201d and that the pope\u2019s support for the bishop \u201creignites the feeling of not being believed, or that they are exaggerating or being deceitful. Dozens of priests and legislators said they opposed the move.\n\nThe pope told a group of tourists visiting Vatican City in 2015 that people in Orsono who protested the appointment were \u201cdumb.\u201d\n\n\u201cThe Osorno community is suffering because it\u2019s dumb,\u201d he said, according to video recorded by one of the tourists. The letter said the pope proposed Bishop Barros and two other bishops go on sabbatical before taking up any new positions, a plan that ultimately fell apart.\n\nFrancis began his visit to Chile on Tuesday morning by publicly apologizing for the sexual abuse involving the clergy, saying he felt \u201cpained and ashamed\u201d over the \u201cirreparable damage\u201d done to their victims. But this year the champagne may be flowing even more freely than usual in the Swiss Alps resort of Davos, owing to a turn in the global situation pleasing to the sorts of people who make the annual pilgrimage \u2014 heads of state, corporate chieftains and those who manage extraordinary piles of money.\n\nThe last time these putative guardians of civilization convened for this festival of internationalist concern, they found themselves in an uncustomary position: in the cross hairs of a global insurrection.\n\nBritain had recently voted to abandon the European Union, dealing a shock to post-World War II European integration. An outsize share of the French electorate was in the thrall of Marine Le Pen and her threats to advance the revolt against European leadership. Donald J. Trump was only days away from his inauguration pledging to use the Oval Office as a war room in a relentless assault on global institutions, including the World Trade Organization, NATO and the Paris climate accord.\n\nFrom inside the World Economic Forum, which starts on Tuesday, these events seemed part of the same storm system, one energized by anger in many major economies over widening income gaps. Those wealthy enough to own jets \u2014 a group amply represented at Davos \u2014 were pulling away from everyone else. The resulting popular fury was threatening to tear down decades-old international agreements.", "title": "Populism Is Waning, Which Is Reason to Party in Davos", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "According to the draft, Ms. Clifford was referred to as \u201cPeggy Peterson\u201d and was represented by a lawyer named Keith Davidson.
