Gitner, told the jury that his client had hired Mr. Percoco\u2019s wife \u201cas a favor to a friend, with no expectation of getting anything in return, and he got nothing in return.\u201d\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s O.K. to do favors for friends, even friends in high places,\u201d Mr. Gitner said.\n\nProsecutors have alleged that about $35,000 in bribe payments came from the two other defendants, Steven Aiello and Joseph Gerardi, executives of COR Development, a Syracuse-area developer that sought Mr. Percoco\u2019s assistance, among other things, to have a decision reversed by the state\u2019s economic development agency.\n\nMr. Boone, the prosecutor, made it clear that the government\u2019s chief witness would be Todd R. Howe, a former aide to Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and a longtime friend of Mr. Percoco\u2019s.\n\nMr. Boone said Mr. Howe, who ran a lobbying firm, had \u201cconnected the businessmen with Percoco\u201d and \u201cfacilitated the bribe payments.\u201d Mr. Howe has pleaded guilty to conspiracy and other charges and has been cooperating with the government in hopes, Mr. Boone said, of getting a more lenient sentence.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nLawyers for all four defendants attacked Mr. Howe relentlessly, calling him a \u201cpathological liar\u201d and a \u201cclassic con man\u201d who had even lied to his children\u2019s school and his dog walkers.\n\nLawyers for Mr. Aiello and Mr. Gerardi, the two executives with COR, a company that has given generously to Mr. Cuomo\u2019s campaigns, also described their clients as innocent victims of Mr. Howe\u2019s charm and mendacity.\n\nMilton L. Williams Jr., a lawyer for Mr. Gerardi, also acknowledged that it was discouraging to hear many of the details of the way Albany works, with well-paid lobbyists leaning on lawmakers and others state officials, like Mr. Percoco, who are responsible for public policy.\n\n\u201cEveryone probably wants this changed,\u201d Mr. Williams said. \u201cBut for right now, it\u2019s legal.\u201d\n\nThe government\u2019s first witness was a forensic accountant from the F.B.I.\u2019s Buffalo office. The accountant testified that Mr. Percoco and his wife had bought an expensive house in Westchester County in 2012, resulting in a negative cash flow for the family \u2014 just months before Ms. Toscano-Percoco received the job through the energy company.\n\nDuring a cross-examination, however, another of Mr. Percoco\u2019s lawyers, Michael L. Yaeger, elicited testimony that appeared intended to show that the Percocos had ample savings to cover expenses, even if their monthly costs had increased with the new home.\n\nAs the opening arguments began, the spectators in the packed courtroom included the newly appointed United States attorney in Manhattan, Geoffrey S. Berman, and his deputy, Robert S. Khuzami.", "title": "Prosecutor Says Ex-Cuomo Aide Sold His Most Valuable Asset: His Job", "authors": ["Benjamin Weiser", "Jesse Mckinley"]} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "After a model and his friend were charged with the murder of Harry Uzoka, also a model, earlier this week, commenters on the internet speculated that the motive was professional rivalry.\n\nBut on Thursday, at the defendants\u2019 first hearing in the central criminal court of England and Wales, the prosecutor said that Mr. Uzoka\u2019s death was the result of a conflict over a woman, according to Lorelei Marfil, a Women\u2019s Wear Daily editor who observed the proceedings from a public gallery.\n\nMr. Uzoka, who has appeared in campaigns for G-Star Raw, Everlane and Levi\u2019s, and was represented by Premier Model Management, was found injured from a stabbing last Thursday afternoon near his home in West London and was pronounced dead shortly after, BBC News reported. George Koh, one of the defendants, has worked with Paul Smith and Hero Magazine and was represented by IMG Models until March 2017.\n\nMs. Marfil\u2019s account includes the prosecutor saying that Mr. Uzoka and Mr. Koh had planned the fight over direct messages on Instagram, and that Mr. Uzoka and a friend were armed with metal pipes, while Mr. Koh and the second defendant, Jonathan Okigbo, arrived carrying knives. A third person, yet to be named, brought a machete-like knife.\n\nThe prosecutor added that Mr. Uzoka was chased by the attackers and stabbed three times in the heart, and that Mr. Koh turned himself in to the police on Monday, saying that he acted in self-defense.\n\nTributes and condolences for Mr. Uzoka\u2019s family and friends poured out on social media, including from Michaela Coel, the creator, writer and star of the British television show \u201cChewing Gum\u201d; and Jacob Banks, a musician.\n\nLeomie Anderson, Mr. Uzoka\u2019s ex-girlfriend and a fellow model, posted photos of herself and Mr. Uzoka on her Instagram page and wrote, \u201cyou\u2019ve been all over the world and been an inspiration to so many. You are proof that you can change your entire life and become a role model, no matter the circumstances. So much I want to say, so much I feel and don\u2019t feel right now but just know you are loved, you are love and light and I just can\u2019t believe this.\u201d", "title": "Prosecutor Says Romantic Rivalry Is Motive in Model\u2019s Murder", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-17 00:00:00", "text": "When evidence is not properly disclosed, experts say, the omission is rarely discovered. The vast bulk of criminal cases never go to trial \u2014 97 percent of federal criminal convictions are the result of guilty pleas. The accused often must decide whether to go to trial and risk the maximum sentence or plead guilty in exchange for a lesser punishment, all without knowing how strong the case against them is.\n\nAfter conviction, the odds that favorable evidence will be discovered in prosecutors\u2019 files is vanishingly small, because it can take hundreds or thousands of hours of legal work. Mr. Banks\u2019s firm worked without pay to overturn Mr. Thompson\u2019s conviction. \u201cWe literally put a couple of million dollars\u201d in time into the Thompson case, Mr. Banks said, \u201cbecause it was a capital murder case.\u201d But \u201cmost of the time that prosecutors hide evidence, nobody ever knows.\u201d\n\nRobert Jones\u2019s ordeal began with a telephone tip to the police. He was convicted in 1996 of the robbery, kidnapping and rape in a trial that lasted but two days. Although most of the evidence indicated that Lester Jones, not Robert, was responsible, two of the victims had identified Robert in a lineup. Prosecutors argued that Lester and Robert knew each other \u2014 Lester Jones had said so in a statement to the police \u2014 and that Robert had used his friend\u2019s car and given him stolen jewelry as compensation.\n\nOnly years later, after the Innocence Project New Orleans took up Robert Jones\u2019s case, did the truth emerge: A lineup from which Mr. Jones was selected had been tainted because it included people that the rape victim knew, thus narrowing the range of suspects. Days before trial, Lester Jones had recanted the assertion that he knew Robert. And Lester had been convicted of two similar French Quarter crimes that happened the same month.\n\nNone of that evidence was given to Robert Jones\u2019s lawyer before the 1996 trial. Nor was a trove of other evidence favorable to Mr. Jones, including evidence that the rapist had told his victim he was taking her to his \u201cneck of the woods;\u201d the victims\u2019 initial descriptions of the attacker, which pointed to Lester; and the fact that none of those descriptions included Robert\u2019s most prominent feature: a mouth filled with gold-capped teeth.\n\nThe prosecution also failed to disclose the conclusion that New Orleans police detectives had reached long before the 1996 trial: The robbery and rape for which Robert Jones went to jail was part of a five-crime spree in the French Quarter that month, all of which appeared to have been committed by the same assailant.\n\nWhen the fifth crime took place, Robert Jones was already in jail.", "title": "Prosecutors Had the Wrong Man. They Prosecuted Him Anyway.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Guzm\u00e1n, who began his career as a lowly marijuana farmer, set himself apart from his competitors, prosecutors have said, by shipping Colombian cocaine into Texas, Arizona and California with such speed and efficiency that he earned the early nickname \u201cEl Rapido.\u201d By the end of the decade, his success encouraged him to expand his territory, a decision, court papers said, that ignited a war with his rivals in the Tijuana drug cartel.\n\nAs part of that war, a Mexican official of the Roman Catholic Church, Cardinal Juan Jes\u00fas Posadas Ocampo, was assassinated in 1993 at an airport in Guadalajara, setting off a nationwide manhunt for Mr. Guzm\u00e1n. Though Mr. Guzm\u00e1n was eventually caught and served eight years in prison, he was able to maintain \u2014 even grow \u2014 his empire, prosecutors have said. But then in a move that would soon become his calling card, he escaped from custody in 2001, hidden in the bottom of a laundry cart.\n\nAfter his escape, prosecutors said, Mr. Guzm\u00e1n fled to the mountains near Culiac\u00e1n in his home state of Sinaloa. To thwart recapture, he assembled what the government has called \u201can army of hundreds of heavily armed body guards\u201c and set up a sophisticated communications network of encrypted devices and \u201cmultiple insulating layers of go-betweens.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nHis escape coincided with a crucial transformation in the drug trade. In the early 2000s, new extradition laws were passed in Colombia, putting the country\u2019s traffickers at risk for prosecution in the United States. As a result, the government says, the Colombians abandoned their American distribution routes. Mr. Guzm\u00e1n stepped into the vacuum, prosecutors said, and soon created his own routes in New York, New Jersey, Texas, Illinois and Georgia.\n\nWith profits pouring in at \u201cstaggering levels,\u201d prosecutors said, Mr. Guzm\u00e1n began to extend his operations not only in the United States and Mexico, but also in Honduras, Costa Rica, El Salvador and Panama, where he established a series of secret landing strips and started using submarines capable of shipping up to six tons of cocaine. Soon after, the government said, he embedded operatives in South America to guard his supply chain and diversified his business into heroin and marijuana. When he became interested in dealing methamphetamine, he dispatched associates to India and China, according to the government, to search for the ingredients that were used to make the drug.\n\nIt was during this period that Mr. Guzm\u00e1n became the mythic figure he remains today \u2014 \u201ca modern-day Robin Hood,\u201d the government said, beloved by \u201cthe downtrodden and extolled in popular songs.\u201d Prosecutors said he surrounded himself with professional assassins who killed and tortured his rivals, and personally carried a gold-plated AK-47 and a diamond-encrusted pistol. According to court papers, he once gave a $1 million bribe \u2014 in cash \u2014 to Mexican law-enforcement officers to protect a single drug shipment.\n\nBut as Mr. Guzm\u00e1n\u2019s infamy increased, so did the efforts to catch him. In 2014, the Mexican special forces tracked him down to a house in Culiac\u00e1n, but ultimately lost him when he escaped through a hatch in his bathtub that led to a maze of tunnels he had built inside the sewer system. After a monthslong search, he was captured in Mazatl\u00e1n and put back into prison. In 2015, however, Mr. Guzm\u00e1n escaped again \u2014 this time, through a mile-long tunnel dug into the shower of his cell. A video made at the time showed him, as prosecutors have put it, \u201ccalmly descending a ladder into the tunnel where a motorcycle was waiting.\u201d\n\nThe United States attorney\u2019s office in Brooklyn indicted Mr. Guzm\u00e1n in absentia in 2009, but after he was rearrested in 2016 \u2014 found in his undershirt and covered in filth near a Walmart in the city of Los Mochis \u2014 they filed a series of additional charges. Those were used to win his extradition from Mexico last January. Though he now resides in a tiny cell in Manhattan\u2019s federal jail, incommunicado and locked in isolation, the government still considers him a threat.\n\n\u201cGuzm\u00e1n\u2019s worldwide fame has resulted in his appearance in Forbes magazine\u2019s most powerful and wealthy person lists,\u201d prosecutors wrote. \u201cThese last few decades have shown that Guzm\u00e1n\u2019s influence knows no bounds.\u201d", "title": "Prosecutors Poised to Tell an Epic Tale at El Chapo Trial", "authors": ["Alan Feuer"]} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "Federal conscience protection laws for health care providers have developed over the past 45 years, generally focusing on the right to refuse to perform, accommodate or assist with certain services \u2014 most typically abortion \u2014 on religious or moral grounds. But the 1973 Church Amendment, the first of these conscience clauses, is broader. Rather than sheltering medical personnel from workplace discrimination only when they refuse to provide abortions and sterilizations, this law also protects those who are willing to do so.\n\nThe Department of Health and Human Services seems to have forgotten these inclusive roots.\n\nIn their zeal to underscore the need for strong conscience protections, none of the speakers unveiling the Conscience and Religious Freedom Division mentioned physicians like Willie Parker, an obstetrician/gynecologist who views providing abortion as religious ministry. But Dr. Parker and his colleagues face enormous obstacles to acting upon their moral convictions. Despite Church Amendment protections, abortion providers are often denied admitting privileges and threatened with adverse employment actions, and they face difficulty getting training. That these obstacles were not highlighted by the department is telling, suggesting that its new enforcement efforts are unlikely to safeguard these exercises of conscience.\n\nHealth care workers seeking to provide services to the transgender community \u2014 care that can be lifesaving \u2014 can also face substantial roadblocks despite their belief in an ethical and professional obligation to act in their patients\u2019 best interest. For example, when Lindsey Dawson set out to provide a hysterectomy to a transgender patient seeking to transition, her efforts were impeded by the Catholic hospital where she practiced. Being forced to refrain from care \u2014 like being forced to provide it \u2014 can conflict with a person\u2019s sense of moral duty. As Dr. Daphna Stroumsa, another physician serving transgender patients, explained to us, \u201cAs a matter of conscience, I am called to do this work.\u201d\n\nIf the new division is as serious about protecting conscience as it claims to be, it should commit to enforcing the Church Amendment\u2019s existing protections for both refusers and providers of abortion and sterilization services, as Congress intended. More generally, it should recognize that conscientious providers encounter legal and institutional barriers to acting on their convictions. The department should encourage Congress to emulate the Church Amendment\u2019s bidirectional protection in all federal conscience clauses and should use its own policymaking authority to protect providers seeking to promote patient access.\n\nIn a landscape littered with obstacles to care, patient access is critical. Yet in the department\u2019s 216-page proposal, patient access is barely addressed outside a request for public comment as to whether \u201cthe existence or expansion of rights to exercise religious beliefs or moral convictions\u201d will affect patient outcomes or result in \u201cunjustified limitation\u201d of access to care.", "title": "Opinion | Protecting Conscientious Providers of Health Care", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "A tireless vigilante who wields the law like a cudgel to enforce his prickly, often paranoid, brand of Egyptian nationalism, Mr. Sabry claims to have filed more than 2,700 such public interest lawsuits in the past 40 years, often firing off several in a day. His legal darts have targeted actors, clerics, politicians and even belly dancers, and may play a decisive role in the next presidential election.\n\nMany cases fizzle out. This was his third suit against the puppet show, which he previously sued for a skit on the novel \u201cFifty Shades of Grey.\u201d A judge threw out that case.\n\nWhen Mr. Sabry succeeds, however, the consequences can be far-reaching.\n\nA clerical televangelist known as Sheikh Mizo, who irked Mr. Sabry with his teachings, was jailed for five years in February. Ahmed Naji, a writer, was thrown in jail for nine months in 2016 based on a complaint that Mr. Sabry supported. (The chief litigant, another lawyer, claimed that racy material in Mr. Naji\u2019s novel had strained his heart.)\n\nIn November, Mr. Sabry helped get Sherine, a smoldering pop diva, banned from performing in Egypt after she had made a biting joke about the quality of the famously dirty water in the Nile.\n\n\u201cEgyptian art is in its worst state ever at the moment,\u201d he thundered. \u201cThey are relying on nudity, swear words, drugs and thuggery, and are showing our Egyptian women as whores. We have to stop them.\u201d\n\nNow the fate of one of Egypt\u2019s few opposition politicians hangs by a thread spun by Mr. Sabry. Khaled Ali, a leftist lawyer, is likely the only real challenger to President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi in elections scheduled for March, even if few believe he can win.\n\nBut his chances are further hampered by his conviction last year on charges filed by Mr. Sabry for having made an obscene gesture outside a Cairo courthouse. If Mr. Ali\u2019s appeal, scheduled for March 7, fails, he will automatically be disqualified from the presidential race.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nCritics say legal crusaders like Mr. Sabry are not only choking the precious little free speech that remains in Egypt, but are hurting one of Egyptians\u2019 proudest attributes \u2014 their ability to laugh at themselves.\n\n\u201cWe are the funny Arabs, the ones who take nothing seriously,\u201d said Hafsa Halawa, a legal expert. \u201cAnd now even that is disappearing.\u201d\n\nMr. Sabry, for his part, relishes his role as moral enforcer. \u201cPeople fear me,\u201d he said.\n\nHe works from an eccentrically appointed office in Cairo\u2019s old city crowded with dozens of tiny figurines, including Roman emperors, Abraham Lincoln, London beefeaters, and the Pope, as well as part of his collection of 3,400 toy cars, carefully arranged on a conference table.\n\nHe stays up late into the night, monitoring a giant television over his desk or prowling the internet on his iPad, looking for anyone he deems to have offended Egypt or Mr. Sisi. For research he turns to his archive: eight rooms filled with towering piles of newspapers and magazines, dating to the 1970s, that provide additional ammunition against his targets.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cJust in case I need to find out what they said previously,\u201d he explained on a tour of the dust-filled chambers. \u201cTo expose their flip-flops.\u201d\n\nSuch an intense pace of work leaves limited time with his wife, Mr. Sabry admitted, but he was never much of a romantic. \u201cAll this love and hand holding \u2014 enough,\u201d he said. \u201cShe knows this is my passion. In any case I buy her gifts \u2014 diamond rings, a necklace and a BMW. It makes for a happy marriage.\u201d\n\nHis ardor for Mr. Sisi, though, is virtually boundless. Both men were born in nearby Gamaliyah, among the winding alleys of the old city, where Mr. Sisi\u2019s father was a trader. When Mr. Sisi, then a general, came to power in 2013, Mr. Sabry said, he offered Mr. Sisi advice over drinks at the Heliopolis Club, and later interviewed him for a newspaper.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe resulting article, \u201cGeneral Sisi: Between Symbol and Legend,\u201d is one of dozens framed in the hallway detailing Mr. Sabry\u2019s exploits attacking enemies of Mr. Sisi.\n\nMr. Sabry went on to file hundreds of cases against the leaders of the Muslim Brotherhood, which Mr. Sisi\u2019s military had ousted from power, and sought, unsuccessfully, to strip 113 Egyptians of their citizenship, including the opposition leader Mohamed ElBaradei and Wael Ghonim, a Google worker who played a prominent role in the Arab Spring protests of 2011.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cAny system has its trolls,\u201d said Mr. Ghonim, now a senior fellow at Harvard\u2019s Ash Center for Democratic Governance and Innovation. \u201cThat\u2019s his way of being relevant.\u201d\n\nMr. Sabry makes few bones of his disapproval for certain people. In 2015, he blocked a belly dancer named Sama al-Masry from running for Parliament on the basis of her profession. \u201cIt\u2019s entirely unsuitable,\u201d he said. He tried to shutter the Cairo operation of the British newspaper The Guardian, accusing it of spreading \u201cfake news.\u201d\n\nHis own record of truth-telling, though, is debatable. In newspapers and interviews Mr. Sabry has claimed to have graduated from Boston University with a Ph.D. in commercial law in 2000. But officials at Boston University, contacted by The New York Times, said they had no record of Mr. Sabry and that they do not offer a Ph.D. in commercial law.\n\nPressed about his claim, Mr. Sabry pointed to a framed certificate issued by Constantinian University \u2014 an educational establishment with an official address at a house in Lincoln, R.I., that, on its website, calls itself \u201can honorary institution.\u201d\n\nMr. Sabry works in a crowded field. In November another lawyer made waves when he moved against \u201cSheikh Jackson,\u201d Egypt\u2019s nomination for best foreign picture at this year\u2019s Oscars, which tells the story of a young cleric who dances like Michael Jackson. The film\u2019s lead actor is being sued for contempt of religion.\n\nLast month another lawyer brought a prosecution that landed a minor pop star named Shyma in jail for two years for a video in which she appeared to fellate a banana.\n\nThis week, an Alexandria lawyer, Tariq Mahmood, filed a complaint against The New York Times, accusing it of undermining Egyptian security over an article about a secret effort by Egyptian intelligence to sway public opinion in favor of President Trump\u2019s decision to recognize Jerusalem as Israel\u2019s capital. On Tuesday, Egypt\u2019s prosecutor general ordered a criminal investigation into the article.\n\nMr. Sabry is generally dismissive of rival litigants, whom he considers inferior patriots, but they give as good as they get. \u201cWhere is he getting his money from?\u201d asks Ahmed Mahran, a lawyer who helped foment a crackdown on gay people last fall when he lodged a complaint against several people who had waved rainbow flags at a concert. \u201cCould it be the security agencies?\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAnother lawyer, Nabeeh el-Wahsh, disparaged Mr. Sabry as a blowhard who uses the cases as \u201ca chance to get famous.\u201d\n\nMr. Sabry denied the accusations, and insisted that he personally finances his lawsuits with no help from the government.\n\nHe claims that two-thirds of his prosecutions have resulted in convictions, an estimate that seems high. But even when his lawsuits collapse, they can have a chilling impact on free speech. Khaled Dawoud, a journalist targeted by Mr. Sabry, said that although he escaped unscathed, the threat of revived criminal charges is ever-present.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s like a sword hanging over my head,\u201d he said.\n\nSuch measures are finding favor in Mr. Sisi\u2019s government. Legislation currently before Parliament would make it easier for the authorities to strip dissidents of their citizenship, which one former member of Parliament has likened to Nazi-era laws.\n\nMr. Sabry sees it as a positive development. \u201cGood news,\u201d he said. \u201cIt will keep us busy.\u201d", "title": "Protecting His Nation From Puppeteers and Belly Dancers", "authors": ["Declan Walsh", "The Saturday Profile"]} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "Q. What kind of software should I use to protect my computer from ransomware?\n\nA. An up-to-date anti-malware program running on your computer is one way to help block ransomware \u2014 that malicious software that wants to invade your system and encrypt your files with demands for payment to release them. Several companies make programs that guard against ransomware and other threats, like Bitdefender Antivirus Plus and Webroot Secure Anywhere Antivirus (both less than $40). PCMag.com is one site that regularly reviews and rates new security software, and you can find reviews from other technology sites around the web.\n\nPhoto\n\nIf you want a specific program to protect your files from online hijacking, you have options there, too. ZoneAlarm Anti-Ransomware is available to download with a free 30-day trial, Trend Micro\u2019s page has free or trial ransomware protection programs, and Bitdefender has a free Anti-Ransomware Tool of its own.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story How Do You Use Tech? Advice and tips on the technology changing how you live. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMost ransomware programs are aimed at Windows computers, and Microsoft has its own online guide to protecting your PC from ransomware. The company also includes its Windows Defender Security Center utility for protecting Windows 10 if you do not want to install a third-party program.\n\nMacs are a smaller target for most virus writers, but Mac-specific ransomware is out there. If Apple\u2019s built-in protections for its operating system do not put the mind at ease, commercial Mac security software is readily available; Bitdefender and Webroot make Mac versions of their programs, too.\n\nIn addition to security software, assuming a stance of \u201cdefensive computing\u201d can help shield you from internet scammers. Steer clear of links and file attachments in messages from people you do not know (or from friends who do not seem to be themselves, possibly because of hacking). Keep your system files backed up regularly so you have copies in case something does happen to your system. The Federal Trade Commission\u2019s OnGuard Online site has tips and videos on protecting yourself from ransomware and other internet threats.", "title": "Protecting Yourself From Ransomware", "authors": ["J. D. Biersdorfer", "Tech Tip"]} {"date": "2018-01-22 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nHONG KONG \u2014 A North Korean delegation wrapped up a rare visit to South Korea on Monday to plan cultural performances there during the Winter Olympics, and was met with both enthusiastic crowds and angry protests as it checked out venues in Seoul.\n\nThe visiting delegation has drawn intense interest and ignited a media frenzy focusing on the North Korean singer Hyon Song-wol. Local reporters have nicknamed her the \u201cgirl on a steed\u201d after one of her most popular songs, \u201cA Girl in the Saddle of a Steed.\u201d\n\nReflecting the passions surrounding the two-day visit, South Korean activists used a blowtorch to burn a large photo of Kim Jong-un, North Korea\u2019s leader, and a North Korean flag as Ms. Hyon\u2019s delegation was traveling Monday through the sprawling Seoul Station. But police officers put out the blaze with fire extinguishers before the photo was destroyed.\n\nPhoto\n\nSouth Korean leaders hope the North\u2019s participation in the Olympics next month in Pyeongchang, along with the cultural events, will pave the way for warmer ties between the two countries and ease tensions over the North\u2019s nuclear program.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe two Koreas have agreed to march together in the opening ceremony of the Olympics and to form a unified women\u2019s ice hockey team, the first inter-Korean team ever fielded during Olympic competition. But a plan to have athletes from the two countries march under a \u201cunification flag\u201d has alarmed some conservative South Koreans, who fear it will distract attention from the North\u2019s rapidly advancing nuclear and missile programs.", "title": "Protesters in Seoul Burn Image of Kim Jong-un During North Koreans\u2019 Visit", "authors": ["Gerry Mullany"]} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "As tourist destinations go, the Republic of Moldova \u2014 tucked between Ukraine and Romania \u2014 probably isn\u2019t on anyone\u2019s bucket list. It\u2019s the poorest country in Europe, with per capita G.D.P. barely exceeding Sudan\u2019s. Sex trafficking and organized crime are rampant. My memories of the place, from a visit 17 years ago, include roads that vanished into deep snow, Transnistrian border guards in Soviet uniforms, and an impoverished Holocaust survivor\u2019s tale of a bleak life under Romanian, German and Soviet tyrants.\n\nLet\u2019s not mince words: Moldova is a hole. Modify with any four letters you wish.\n\nI mention Moldova because it\u2019s where my paternal grandfather was born in 1901. An anti-Semitic rampage in his hometown, Kishinev, soon forced his family to leave for New York, where my great-grandfather labored as a carpenter in the Brooklyn Navy Yard for eight dollars a week. Low skills, low wages, minimal English, lots of children and probably not the best hygiene \u2014 that\u2019s half of my pedigree. The other half consisted of refugees.\n\nI\u2019m not alone. America is a nation of holers. It is an improbable yet wildly successful experiment in the transformation \u2014 by means of hope, opportunity and ambition \u2014 of holers into doers, makers, thinkers and givers. Are you of Irish descent? Italian? Polish? Scottish? Chinese? Chances are, your ancestors did not get on a boat because life in the old country was placid and prosperous and grandpa owned a bank. With few exceptions, Americans are the dregs of the wine, the chaff of the wheat. If you don\u2019t know this by now, it makes you the wax in the ear.\n\nDonald Trump is the wax in the ear.\n\nSome of the fury \u2014 and most of the apologetics \u2014 surrounding the president\u2019s alleged remark about \u201call these people from shithole countries\u201d concerns the nature of the countries themselves. Liberals can be squeamish about calling poor countries bad names, while conservatives such as Mark Steyn chortle that \u201cnobody voluntarily moves to Haiti.\u201d Which, let\u2019s be real, is basically right.", "title": "Opinion | Proud to Live in a Nation of Holers", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cA More Just New York State,\u201d by Andrew M. Cuomo (Op-Ed, Jan. 16):\n\nI applaud Governor Cuomo\u2019s effort to reform New York\u2019s bail system to bring it more in line with the deeply held principle that a defendant is innocent until proved guilty. But there is another, equally critical reform that is necessary to fully realize the governor\u2019s agenda: increased funding for our state\u2019s public defenders.\n\nThese lawyers are among the noblest members of the legal profession and perform a vital function in ensuring that our criminal justice system lives up to its ideals, but they are burdened with crushing caseloads that can make it all but impossible for them to devote the time needed to serve their clients adequately.\n\nThe overwork they face contributes to the plague of backlogs and delays that Governor Cuomo rightly identifies as critical impediments to justice. Increased funding for public defense is a necessary piece of the puzzle the governor\u2019s bill tries to solve.\n\nJONATHAN ATKINS, NEW YORK\n\nThe writer is a lawyer.", "title": "Opinion | Public Defenders in New York", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "What happened to women\u2019s agency? That\u2019s what I find myself wondering as I hear story after story of adult women who helplessly acquiesce to sexual demands. I find it especially curious given that a majority of women I know have been in situations in which men have come on to them \u2014 at work or otherwise. They have routinely said, \u201cI\u2019m not interested\u201d or \u201cGet your hands off me right now.\u201d And they\u2019ve taken the risk that comes with it.\n\nThe fact that such unwelcome advances persist, and often in the office, is, yes, evidence of sexism and the abusive power of the patriarchy. But I don\u2019t believe that scattershot, life-destroying denunciations are the way to upend it. In our current climate, to be accused is to be convicted. Due process is nowhere to be found.\n\nAnd what exactly are men being accused of? What is the difference between harassment and assault and \u201cinappropriate conduct\u201d? There is a disturbing lack of clarity about the terms being thrown around and a lack of distinction regarding what the spectrum of objectionable behavior really is. Shouldn\u2019t sexual harassment, for instance, imply a degree of hostility? Is kissing someone in affection, however inappropriately, or showing someone a photo of a nude male torso necessarily predatory behavior?\n\nI think this confusion reflects a deeper ambivalence about how we want and expect people to behave. Expressing sexual interest is inherently messy and, frankly, nonconsensual \u2014 one person, typically the man, bites the bullet by expressing interest in the other, typically the woman \u2014 whether it happens at work or at a bar. Some are now suggesting that come-ons need to be constricted to a repressive degree. Asking for oral consent before proceeding with a sexual advance seems both innately clumsy and retrograde, like going back to the childhood game of \u201cMother, May I?\u201d We are witnessing the re-moralization of sex, not via the Judeo-Christian ethos but via a legalistic, corporate consensus.\n\nStripping sex of eros isn\u2019t the solution. Nor is calling out individual offenders, one by one. We need a broader and more thoroughgoing overhaul, one that begins with the way we bring up our sons and daughters.\n\nThese are scary times, for women as well as men. There is an inquisitorial whiff in the air, and my particular fear is that in true American fashion, all subtlety and reflection is being lost. Next we\u2019ll be torching people for the content of their fantasies.", "title": "Opinion | Publicly, We Say #MeToo. Privately, We Have Misgivings.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-08 00:00:00", "text": "From a commercial perspective, are you happy about the president\u2019s response?\n\nYes, I think the president\u2019s response has undeniably increased the sales of the book and increased the reach of the book. I think the book is important. The book is a window into how our government under the present administration is working, so the more people who can read it, the better. And that is our concern, both culturally, as publishers, but also financially.\n\nFrom the letter that your outside counsel released this afternoon, it sounds like the company doesn\u2019t give much weight to Mr. Trump\u2019s lawyer\u2019s claim that the book is libelous. Can you elaborate on why it strikes the company as a weak libel case?\n\nI\u2019d prefer not to comment on matters that go around litigation on this. Our letter from our outside lawyer speaks pretty clearly about what our thoughts are, and I\u2019d rather let those comments stand.\n\nIn that case, let\u2019s talk about your own letter, which was a powerful, pro-First Amendment statement that you sent to employees. Why did you feel it was important to send that message to people working for Macmillan?\n\nThe president of the United States tried to stop the publication of this book. We were about to send a very stern letter back to the president, and people here needed to understand why this was such a big problem, why it was more important than the book itself. Free speech is one of the fundamental underpinnings of democracy, but it\u2019s also what we are about as publishers. And everybody in the company, particularly the younger people in the company, needed to understand how culturally important to the country it is that we defend the principles of the First Amendment.\n\nWhy do you think Michael Wolff was particularly suited to covering this presidency?\n\nThey key to the coverage was access. This is about access, and for whatever reason, which I don\u2019t know and can\u2019t speculate on, but for whatever reason, the Trump administration was comfortable having Michael in the White House, and he was in the White House all the time.\n\nNews organizations and administration officials have pointed out some factual errors in the book. Does Holt plan to correct any errors in future editions?\n\nWe, as a policy, always correct errors, if we find them, in reprints of the book. The issue you have here \u2014 and Michael is quite specific about it \u2014 in the course of a day in the White House, there are a lot of people saying a lot of things, some of which are factual, some of which are not factual. So Michael reporting on something that is not factual can easily happen, because he\u2019s reporting on people talking about these things. I think there\u2019s a typo in it.", "title": "Publisher Defied Trump to \u2018Defend the Principles of the First Amendment\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-02 00:00:00", "text": "When it comes to recipes, a beautiful photograph is more likely to influence one\u2019s decision to make a dish than any name or description. It\u2019s simple: If it looks good, you\u2019re going to want to make it. But when NYT Cooking began in September 2014, only some of our 16,000 recipes included photographs, and many of those felt out of date or simply looked unappetizing.\n\nSince then, our editors (often prompted by reader reviews or emails) have uncovered hundreds of recipes from the Times archives that have been restyled, rephotographed and reintroduced to our readers. Here are two of them. Easy and delicious, they\u2019re the kind of dishes that are not only beloved but also apt to get you cooking more in the new year.\n\nThe first, Mark Bittman\u2019s Greek-style broiled shrimp, initially ran in The New York Times Magazine in 2013. It is a perfect weeknight recipe. It relies heavily on garlic, oregano and black pepper as a coating for the shrimp. Serve it alongside a hearty salad or with a stack of flatbread for an easy meal. In the original article, a roundup of shrimp recipes, Mr. Bittman suggested using wild shrimp from the Pacific or Gulf of Mexico, or fresh local shrimp, if they\u2019re available to you. All, he wrote, are \u201cpreferable from a sustainability perspective.\u201d", "title": "Pulled From the Past: Easy, Delicious Recipes for 2018", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-01 00:00:00", "text": "The contract in Mr. Byrd\u2019s case, from Budget, was typical. It said that \u201cthe only ones permitted to drive the vehicle other than the renter are the renter\u2019s spouse, the renter\u2019s co-employee (with the renter\u2019s permission, on company business) or a person who appears at the time of the rental and signs an additional driver form.\u201d\n\nMr. Byrd was none of those. But he testified that he and the woman who rented the car, Latasha Reed, had been together for 17 years, had five children and were engaged to be married.\n\nIn rejecting Mr. Byrd\u2019s appeal, the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit, in Philadelphia, acknowledged that federal appeals courts have differed about \u201cwhether the sole occupant of a rental vehicle has a Fourth Amendment expectation of privacy when that occupant is not named in the rental agreement.\u201d The Third Circuit\u2019s own precedents, the court said, \u201cdetermined such a person has no expectation of privacy and therefore no standing to challenge a search of the vehicle.\u201d\n\nMr. Byrd\u2019s lawyers said this ignored reality. \u201cWidespread noncompliance with authorized-driver provisions is an open secret,\u201d they wrote, which is why rental agreements \u201coften specify that the renter will carry greater risk of loss when an unlisted driver operates the vehicle.\u201d\n\nThe Supreme Court\u2019s decision in the case, Byrd v. United States, No. 16-1371, is very likely to have an outsize effect on black and Hispanic drivers, according to a brief from the American Civil Liberties Union and the National Association of Criminal Defense Lawyers.\n\nPoor people rent a lot of cars. \u201cThere is a commonly held misconception that car rental is a luxury reserved for the wealthiest individuals,\u201d a 2010 tax study found, noting that \u201cmore car rentals occur at neighborhood locations than at airport locations.\u201d\n\n\u201cAfrican-Americans generate over four times as many retail rental transactions as otherwise comparable Caucasians,\u201d the study said. Ms. Williams, who earned a Golden Globe nomination for her role in \u201cAll the Money in the World,\u201d walked the red carpet with Tarana Burke, senior director of the nonprofit Girls for Gender Equity and the founder of the #MeToo movement.\n\nMost contracts with actors include a certain number of reshoot days as a routine stipulation. If additional filming is needed, actors will make themselves available \u2014 as their schedule allows \u2014 to clean up scenes. But Ms. Williams and Mr. Wahlberg, both of whom had agreed to appear in \u201cAll the Money in the World\u201d for less than their standard fee, took different approaches to the reshoots, according to the people briefed on the matter.\n\nBecause of the circumstances, Ms. Williams quickly agreed to return. The people briefed on the matter said that she did so believing that other participants had made the same decision. She ultimately worked over Thanksgiving, racing to London on an overnight flight after arranging for her 12-year-old daughter, Matilda, to spend the holiday without her.\n\n\u201cThey could have my salary, they could have my holiday, whatever they wanted,\u201d she said of the production team at the time. \u201cBecause I appreciated so much that they were making this massive effort.\u201d\n\nAlthough several actors with small parts, including Timothy Hutton, had agreed to return for reshoots for minimum pay, Mr. Wahlberg was not one of them, according to the people briefed on the negotiations. He asked his primary agent, Doug Lucterhand, to push for more money. (Ms. Williams is represented at William Morris Endeavor by Brent Morley.) Mr. Wahlberg was already not thrilled to have worked for roughly 80 percent less than his standard fee, the people said, especially since overseas distributors were using his box office track record to promote the film.\n\nBecause Ms. Williams had already committed to return, Mr. Wahlberg had leverage over the production team: He was the only major missing piece, and the clock was ticking. But as a graduate of a Catholic high school where she had been shown graphic videos portraying abortion as murder, she felt scared and tormented by guilt.\n\nShe had also broken the law.\n\nAbortion is illegal in South Korea with just a few exceptions, such as when a woman has been raped or her health is at risk. It is one of just a handful of the world\u2019s richest countries to have such restrictive abortion laws. Women can be sentenced to a year in prison or ordered to pay fines of two million won (about $1,840) for having abortions, while doctors who perform them can get up to two years in prison.\n\nNow, a group of women\u2019s advocates is pushing to overturn the ban, and the country\u2019s Constitutional Court is set this year to review a case that challenges the law\u2019s constitutionality.", "title": "Push to End South Korea Abortion Ban Gains Strength, and Signatures", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-15 00:00:00", "text": "While Ulysse Nardin\u2019s timepieces don\u2019t receive emails or track health data, they are, in their own way, highly innovative. At the Salon International de la Haute Horlogerie in Geneva this week, the brand intends to unveil watches with several new and patented features, like an escapement that improves a watch\u2019s accuracy. Yet the brand remains a bit of an insiders\u2019 secret, known mostly by watch aficionados and collectors. \u201cIf there\u2019s one thing you can blame Ulysse Nardin for, it\u2019s not making enough noise,\u201d Mr. Pruniaux said.\n\nThe challenge of increasing the company\u2019s recognition is, for Mr. Pruniaux, part of his position\u2019s appeal. \u201cI\u2019ve been following the brand since I started in the watch industry,\u201d he said. \u201cI\u2019ve always thought there was a mystique around the brand. The fact that the brand was strong, but also a sort of hidden gem, I found interesting.\u201d\n\nAnd the watchmaker\u2019s owners were interested in Mr. Pruniaux\u2019s experience to help it succeed in a retail climate that\u2019s increasingly internet based, with as much as 85 percent of all luxury purchases beginning online, according to Albert Bensoussan, chief executive of Kering\u2019s luxury watches and jewelry division.\n\n\u201cWe need someone today who understands how to take that into account,\u201d Mr. Bensoussan said. \u201cYou need people who are really very much aware of the new world and the fact that customers start their shopping process by going online. It also noted \u201cencouraging trends in watches,\u201d including what it called progress at Ulysse Nardin, fueled by its new Marine Torpilleur model, in Western Europe and the Middle East.", "title": "Putting Apple Watch Experience to Work at Ulysse Nardin", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cIn a certain sense, redistricting is the spoils of war,\u201d said Samuel Wang, a professor of neuroscience and molecular biology at Princeton, who runs the Princeton project. \u201cIt\u2019s legitimate as long as it\u2019s a small advantage. But now we\u2019ve seen such a big distortion of the process.\u201d\n\nOne reason is the emergence of mapping software that can draw precise lines to maximize any desired outcome. Another is that the Republicans outsmarted the Democrats in the 2010 elections. The Republican Party focused on 18 states in which control of the state legislature was close. Republicans picked up 22 new state legislative chambers just in time for the 2011 redistricting \u2014 and were able to draw the districts for 193 seats in the House of Representatives. The Democrats controlled redistricting for 44. Control of the rest was either split between the parties or nonpartisan.\n\nThat\u2019s why in Virginia\u2019s state government elections two months ago, Democrats didn\u2019t get to control the Legislature even though they won the statewide popular vote by nine points, a landslide. It\u2019s why Michigan Republicans got 16 more seats in their State Legislature than Democrats in 2016, even though the total vote in the state legislative races split down the middle. It\u2019s why North Carolina\u2019s Republican congressional candidates won 10 out of 13 seats with just 53 percent of the total vote. Democrats also gerrymandered in some states where they got the chance, Maryland being the starkest example. They just didn\u2019t have many chances.\n\nStates will redraw the lines anew in 2021. This time, the Democrats aren\u2019t napping. Former Attorney General Eric Holder leads the National Democratic Redistricting Committee, which seeks independent redistricting commissions but also wants to elect Democrats.\n\nPennsylvania\u2019s judgment is the latest in a series this month. One group of federal judges ruled that North Carolina\u2019s congressional districts had been unconstitutionally gerrymandered for partisan advantage \u2014 the first-ever such ruling. A day later, a different panel found the opposite in Pennsylvania, but that was before the new judgment came down Monday from the state Supreme Court. Other state courts are dealing with lawsuits as well, and the United States Supreme Court has heard arguments on gerrymandering cases from Wisconsin and Maryland.\n\nThen there are nonpartisan citizen campaigns that have nothing to do with Holder\u2019s group. Michigan\u2019s is the furthest along, but citizens are also organizing for ballot initiatives in Ohio, Missouri, Utah, Colorado and South Dakota. In Pennsylvania and Virginia, grass-roots groups sprang up to persuade legislators to establish independent commissions. Other gerrymandered states are still waiting for their Katie Fahey.\n\nFair Districts PA is an arm of the League of Women Voters of Pennsylvania, the lead plaintiff in the lawsuit that yielded Monday\u2019s ruling. The group will continue to campaign for fairer districts for the state Legislature, which was not covered in the lawsuit, and to insure a fairly drawn Congressional map. The legislative district map continues to pose a tough challenge: The Legislature must pass redistricting reforms in two consecutive sessions, followed by a successful ballot initiative. Nevertheless, reform has been doing pretty well; in the lower house of the Legislature, the bill had accumulated nearly enough co-sponsors to pass, including 30 Republicans.", "title": "Opinion | Putting the Voters in Charge of Fair Voting", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "PENN YAN, N.Y. \u2014 Ivan Martin steered his horse and buggy down an empty, rural road near where he and his wife Anna were riding recently when a driver roared up from behind as they were heading back to their farmhouse here in Yates County, a corner of New York State\u2019s Finger Lakes region heavily populated by Mennonites.\n\n\u201cWe heard her tires screech and we were just bracing for the hit,\u201d recalled Mr. Martin, 63, who as an Old Order Mennonite avoids driving cars as part of a modest lifestyle that eschews many modern amenities, the same traditions that are also followed by the Amish who live in the state.\n\nWith regular speeds of less than 10 miles per hour, these quaint conveyances hardly seem dangerous. Yet they have become a chronic traffic concern as the population of Amish and Mennonites has surged across New York State, producing more horse-drawn buggies than ever on its roadways.\n\nOver the last decade, the state has experienced the fastest growth of Amish and Mennonites in the country, said Judson Reid, an agriculture specialist at Cornell University who studies the two groups. With a combined population of about 24,000, the fifth largest in the United States, New York has seen an influx of Amish and Mennonites from Ohio, Pennsylvania and other states, attracted by affordable and productive farmland, he said.", "title": "Quaint Buggies, With a Deadly Side", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cIt\u2019s startling to know there are individuals on the brink of adulthood who have spent their entire lives in a climate that, largely due to human activity, is vastly different from the one their parents experienced growing up.\u201d\n\nRACHEL LICKER, a senior climate scientist at the Union of Concerned Scientists, a research and advocacy group, after learning that last year was one of the warmest on record.", "title": "Quotation of the Day: 2017 an Especially Hot Year, Surprising Experts", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-07 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cYou would think with water mains breaking all over town they would have a contingency plan. In my experience, the reality is that the president knows what he does not know and does not think he needs to know it.\u201d\n\nSAM NUNBERG, a former campaign adviser to President Trump, on Mr. Trump\u2019s management style.", "title": "Quotation of the Day: Vacillating President Complicates Talks", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cRepublicans lost every statewide race in California in 2002, 2010 and 2014, before Donald Trump even announced he was running for president. So anybody who wants to blame Donald Trump for the problems of the Republican Party, which began 20 years ago, is a revisionist historian.\u201d\n\nJIM BRULTE, the California Republican leader, on daunting races the state\u2019s G.O.P. candidates face in the midterm election.", "title": "Quotation of the Day: White House Moves Risk G.O.P.\u2019s California Delegation", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cI\u2019m like, how can I be negligent for kissing my girl?\u201d\n\nGIL ROBERTS, an Olympic gold medal sprinter who was exonerated for failing a drug test by a court that accepted his defense: A passionate kiss with his medicated girlfriend had caused the violation.", "title": "Quotation of the Day: \u2018Passionate Kissing\u2019 Defense Clears Sprinter Accused of Doping", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "By the age of 2, nearly every child has contracted R.S.V. In most children, it presents as a bad cold. But for others, it can cause breathing problems and dangerous lung infections \u2014 and many parents have never heard of it until their child becomes ill.\n\nWhat is R.S.V.?\n\nEvery winter, R.S.V. becomes a common and potentially serious illness, said Dr. Ethan S. Wiener, associate chief of pediatric emergency medicine at N.Y.U. Langone Health.\n\nWhile it affects both children and adults, it is most dangerous \u2014 and can even be fatal \u2014 in babies who are born prematurely and people with weak immune systems, heart disease or lung disease. But even babies who were born full-term and healthy can develop severe symptoms, like Calvin or like Andre, a toddler from Mission Viejo, Calif., who contracted the virus in 2016 when he was three weeks old.\n\n\u201cIt was really scary seeing your son hooked up to so many monitors and not knowing what\u2019s going on,\u201d said Andre\u2019s mother, Alexandria Salahshour, who wrote about the illness to raise awareness.\n\nThey spent Christmas that year at the hospital, where Andre was admitted with a blood oxygen level of 70 percent. It should be close to 100 percent.", "title": "R.S.V.? She Hadn\u2019t Heard of It. Then Her Child Was Hospitalized.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-16 00:00:00", "text": "Whether the plaintiffs have enough evidence in their complaint to show the \u201cassociation in fact\u201d that was more than just a loose agglomeration of individuals who provided assistance sporadically but not in any organized fashion will be the issue. If the case survives this stage, then its settlement value increases substantially because of the potential for more embarrassing information to come to light during the discovery phase.\n\nBusinesses have been hostile to RICO because of the threat of a triple-damage award, and Congress has been receptive to efforts to limit the scope of the law. The dismissal last month of a RICO lawsuit against the private equity financier Lynn Tilton, the so-called Diva of Distress, shows how the law has been limited to keep some disputes out of the federal courts.\n\nThat RICO claim was filed by three funds that Ms. Tilton and her firm, Patriarch Partners, created to raise more than $2.5 billion from the sale of collateralized loan obligations in which the proceeds were used to invest in distressed companies. The funds, named Zohar, claimed that she had misled them about a significant deterioration in the loans and misappropriated the equity in the companies for her own benefit, which constituted mail and wire fraud by stealing their interests.\n\nThe RICO case came on the heels of an administrative enforcement action filed by the Securities and Exchange Commission in 2015. The S.E.C. accused Ms. Tilton of violating the Investment Advisers Act by reporting misleading values for the funds\u2019 investments to collect larger management fees. An S.E.C. administrative law judge ruled in her favor by dismissing the case in September, and the agency decided not to appeal that decision, leaving her victory intact.\n\nOn Dec. 29, a federal district judge dismissed the RICO claim against her because it ran afoul of an amendment adopted by Congress back in 1995 to limit the scope of the statute. The amendment precludes filing RICO claims if they \u201crely upon any conduct that would have been actionable as fraud in the purchase or sale of securities to establish a violation.\u201d In other words, if the alleged violations involve securities fraud, they cannot survive a motion to dismiss even if they could constitute mail or wire fraud.\n\nThough the funds artfully avoided using the term \u201csecurities\u201d in the RICO claim, the judge in the case, William H. Pauley III, concluded that he \u201ccannot ignore allegations that an integral component of that scheme to loot included pillaging portfolio companies of their equity, redirecting Zohar\u2019s equity interests for defendants\u2019 benefit and diverting the equity distributions into defendants\u2019 coffers \u2014 all actions coinciding with the purchase or sale of securities.\u201d So while there might have been fraud, it was close enough to securities transactions that the case had to be dismissed.\n\nRICO lawsuits are tempting. They allow a plaintiff to sue a variety of defendants by claiming that they acted together and seek an award of triple damages, a bonanza in some business disputes that can run into millions of dollars. But these cases should also come with a bright red warning sign: Tread lightly or see your case thrown out of court before it even gets started.", "title": "RICO Lawsuits Are Tempting, but Tread Lightly", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-03 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Johnson carefully acknowledged the remarks.\n\n\u201cThere is no way for me to say I can fully relate to the experience of being a person of color in New York City,\u201d he said. \u201cBut as someone who\u2019s an openly gay man, who\u2019s openly HIV-positive, who did not grow up in a family with a lot of money, I think that experience gives me some more sensitivity.\u201d\n\nMr. Johnson said he would call on the diversity of the body to address various issues.\n\n\u201cWhen there are issues related to race in New York City \u2026 I don\u2019t need to be the main spokesperson,\u201d he said.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nBlack leaders said they would look to Mr. Johnson\u2019s leadership appointments, and not his rhetoric. Mr. Johnson said he wanted to speak to every member of the council before making leadership assignments.\n\nBut according to multiple sources familiar with the negotiations, Councilman Robert E. Cornegy Jr. of Brooklyn, the black runner-up for speaker, could be named as chairman of the Democratic Conference, a newly created position, as well as chairman of the housing committee.\n\nAs chairman of the Democratic Conference, he could also serve as a liaison to Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and the State Legislature, and have a role on the budget negotiations committee. Housing affordability is one of the biggest issues in the city.\n\nThe Rev. Jacques Andre DeGraff, associate pastor of Canaan Baptist Church in Harlem, said Mr. Cornegy\u2019s possible roles were part of \u201ca larger issue about the Democratic Party returning the investment that African-Americans have made in the party.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Cornegy declined to discuss his possible roles but said that \u201cthere have been discussions about black people accessing power and leadership simultaneously.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nRepresentative Hakeem Jeffries said he was not pleased that there would not be a black speaker, but said he was excited about the other possibilities.\n\n\u201cThe black community hasn\u2019t yet achieved its Jackie Robinson moment in the City Council, but the leadership opportunities afforded to members like Laurie Cumbo and Robert Cornegy are a substantial step in the right direction,\u201d Mr. Jeffries said.\n\nA less diplomatic response came from Assemblyman Charles Barron, who was at the meeting to support his wife, Inez Barron. He heckled black Council members as he left the meeting; Mr. Cornegy said Mr. Barron, who once held his wife\u2019s Council seat, called him \u201cspineless.\u201d\n\n\u201cI can\u2019t say what I said to him,\u201d Mr. Cornegy said.\n\nMr. Barron said he was supporting his wife\u2019s right to enter the race and the need for diverse leadership.\n\n\u201cI think there should have been more support from the blacks for her right to run,\u201d Mr. Barron said. \u201cThey all cut deals with the county bosses because they\u2019re still on the plantation.\u201d", "title": "Race Rears Its Head as New York City Council Elects New Leader", "authors": ["Jeffery C. Mays"]} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "Commenters unanimously answered in the affirmative for our Student Opinion question \u201cDo Companies Have a Responsibility to Contribute Positively to Society?\u201d\n\nLeah Schwagerl from Wilmington, N.C., said C.E.O.s should work in unison with other employees:\n\nI feel that BlackRocks push for holding companies accountable is not only going to benefit the popularity of the company but it will also spread a wave of initiative among companies to be aware of their outreach on society. Companies should absolutely have the responsibility to contribute positively to society. A third party overseer might be the key to initially starting the movement of social awareness, however, the tight knit relationships formed in companies between employees, consumers, executives, and CEO\u2019s should work in unison to ensure the positive contributions. Companies can have a social purpose. For example, CVS took the responsibility to stop selling tobacco products in 2014, last year they announced that they would remove certain chemicals from 600 beauty products by the end of 2019, and just recently they stated that they will \u201cstop significant touch-ups of images\u201d.\n\nJosh Failla of Wilmington, N.C., thinks about the topic often:\n\nEvery weekend when my mom goes to shop at Whole foods, I think about all the good that they have done in the community. They created the Local Producer Loan program that provides millions of dollars in loans to local producers. They promote nonrenewable resources and encourage the cleaning of the Earth. They also fight poverty all over the world, and I want to shop at a place that cares as much about their profits as they do for the world. The move that Mr. Fink is making is one that is very needed. If major companies are not going to change their ways for being only profit motive, then someone with enough power like BlackRock need to force them to do so. As a major investor, if you want something down about a business, then you should be able to change how a business is run. If the executives don\u2019t agree with you, then you can just stop investing in the operations. With all the profits that these businesses are making, then they should want to give back to the community even without outside pressure. This movement may change big businesses for the good and it will be beneficial to everyone.\n\nMeghan Miraglia from Massachusetts said business needs to evolve:\n\nThe world, and its consumer market, is changing rapidly. America, I think, was once a child - a toddler with a spoon clenched in its chubby fist, squash and peas dribbling down its bib, screaming for more, more. Now, I think that consumers are more like the slightly more socially conscious ten-year-old - we have deviated, or are attempting to deviate, from the \u201cgive me this, give me that\u201d norm and asking companies and businesses the Big Questions. \u201cWhere does this product come from?\u201d, \u201cIs this brand cruelty-free?\u201d, \u201cDoes this company/manufacturer use sweatshops?\u201d, and \u201cHow does this company/business give back on a community scale as well as on a global scale?\u201d are just a few questions I have seen pop up beneath ads on my social media feed. Even if a company isn\u2019t directly interacting with the public (through selling its products/goods/services, etc), it makes sense to give back and get more involved. People like that kind of thing - they like to see that if they cannot directly help society, at the very least, they are giving money to a company or business that does. However, as the world shifts from a place where all we do is take, to a place where we (at least give the illusion that we) are giving back, it only makes sense that companies and businesses evolve alongside us.\n\nHee Yun Chung from California cited companies that have made a difference:\n\nI think in the past, companies didn\u2019t really have to contribute to society since their employees could be paid a good wage to buy homes and promote economic growth. In the modern economic landscape, it is becoming imperative for companies to contribute to society. After the 2008 Great Recession, people all over the country are still struggling to make ends meet. As a result of the recession and a rapidly changing economy, income inequality worsened. Companies became richer while public disdain for large companies grew. To give credit where credit is due, many companies have taken their own steps to help society in a positive way. Some companies increased their wages and have invested in communities. One example would be Aetna, the healthcare company. The CEO of Aetna, Mark Bertolini figured out that his own employees were financially struggling and relied on government subsidies. He took action by increasing the company\u2019s wage to $16, help pay college debts, and promised to not pass downs the costs on the consumer. Bertolini has said that corporate leaders should step up and create \u201ca new capitalism\u201d by taking the time to understand their workers. Companies don\u2019t have a lot to lose in the current economic climate. When 18% of the American people believe that corporations are good, a serious conversation has to occur between corporate owners, workers, and communities in order for society to improve as the economy changes over the years.\n\nBella Cankurtaran from Wilmington, N.C., has made personal changes in shopping choices:\n\nWhen it comes to shopping I am very picky on who I choose to buy from. Why would I want I want to sponsor a brand who only thinks about themselves? When companies give back to the community, I know they are making the product out of the kindness of their hearts rather than for money. Plus, it\u2019s a win win when you order a product you love and donate to a charity all in one purchase. For example, I used to love Steve Madden shoes until I realized they had no \u2018Our Story\u2019 page on their website for what charities they donated to. It infuriated me that the company of the shoes I wore almost everyday in middle school choose to keep their profits and not think about the countless starving, homeless, and shoeless people around the globe. Here they are selling shoes when millions of impoverished people walk miles around barefoot. That\u2019s why I switched to Toms brand. Not only do they give a pair of shoes to a person who needs it, but the company also provides eye treatment, water, safe birth, and bullying response programs. I feel more than confident strutting around in appealing yet comfortable shoes that help other people who aren\u2019t as fortunate as me.\n\nAnna Cross from Wilmington, N.C., quoted an American economist:\n\nMilton Friedman said \u201cWhat does it mean to say that \u2018business\u2019 has responsibilities? Only people can have responsibilities\u201d, but as a business is created solely for and by people, this statement seems a bit contradictory. Businesses have everything to do with people. People create businesses, work for businesses, purchase goods and services from businesses; all it is is a collection of individuals attempting to make a profit. As the influence and reputation of a business grows, their responsibilities grow as well, for they gain the ability to positively or negatively affect more people. Unfortunately in my city, one business decided their influence should be negative. It was recently made public where I live that a chemical manufacturer had been dumping unregulated chemicals into our source of drinking water for years, most notably a substance called \u201cGen X\u201d, which potentially causes cancer. For some reason, this doesn\u2019t feel right to me. A business, as it is made by humans, should have responsibilities to other humans, if not in the advancement of society, than the preservation of it. For a business to take a risk (ex: dumping mystery chemicals in the river) that may harm a community of people for financial gain is unethical and immoral of every single person who runs it. We need businesses that respects their workers and customers and improves society, rather than be a detriment to it.\n\nFrancesca Altunyay from Wilmington, N.C., wants companies to be held accountable:\n\nThe extent to which corporate greed goes in America has shown itself for decades. From oil companies not holding themselves accountable for pollution and climate change to multi-billion dollar business representatives refusing to even breathe near political opinions for the sake of remaining neutral, it has made itself apparent that corporations value practices that \u201cmake short term sense\u201d but eventually threaten their \u201clong term viability,\u201d as said by Jana in the article. Whether they like it or not, businesses do have societal responsibilities as long as they involve themselves, interact with, and produce things for society. Businesses are not just huge faceless, unidentifiable, artificial entities - they are created by people, run by people, and comprised of working people. They should be held accountable for all products they manufacture and ensure that they are not detrimental to any groups of people in particular or any people in general. BlackRock\u2019s action to push Exxon into releasing climate impact reports was a smart move, and now says to the public, \u201cWe know that we\u2019re actively affecting the Earth in a negative way!\u201d, which gives them liability for any damage they inflict. I think all companies should be honest about whatever it is they provide for society; I\u2019ve boycotted products and businesses for child/slave labor, or if their investors or presidents have openly supported prejudiced organisations against my personal beliefs. My life is better for it.\n\nLogan Bolduc from Wilmington, N.C., wrote about the key role that shoppers play:\n\nI think it is our duty as shoppers to chose what companies are good for our community. Should we shop at a store who employs local people and recycles or should we shop at a store who has their materials shipped in from a sweatshop and charges four times the price it costs to make their clothing. All in all, the customer is the one who decides weather a business stays open, does the customer want good or do they want cheap?\n\n_________", "title": "Race in America, College Amenities and Loneliness: Our Favorite Student Comments of the Week", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "Yet all of it served as a reminder: These were the very cultural dynamics that had allowed Larry Nassar to remain in power.\n\nI knew that the farthest I could run from my abuser, and the people that let him prey on children for decades, was to choose the opposite of what that man, and his enablers, had become. To choose to find and speak the truth, no matter what it cost.\n\nAs the calls began coming in to the Michigan State University Police Department and the number of reports grew, my horror did as well. Victim after victim came forward. Some were abused when they were as young as 6 years old. Some were victimized nearly three decades ago, others only days before my report was filed. Far worse, victims began to come forward who had tried to sound the alarm years before I walked into that M.S.U. clinic to meet the celebrated doctor. Not only were they suffering the devastation of sexual assault; they were suffering deep wounds from having been silenced, blamed and often even sent back for continued abuse.\n\nMore than 200 women have now alleged abuse by Larry Nassar. Even more staggering than that number is the revelation that at least 14 coaches, trainers, psychologists or colleagues had been warned of his abuse. What is truly stomach-turning is the realization that a vast majority of those victims were abused after his conduct was first reported by two teenagers to M.S.U.\u2019s head gymnastics coach as far back as 1997.\n\nSo how did this happen? How, for 30 years, did this monster manage to prey on little girls and young women without being caught?\n\nPartly it is because Larry was an expert predator. He was calculating, deliberate and a master manipulator. Much of the abuse, mine included, took place with our own mothers in the room, their view casually blocked by Larry, his hand hidden under a towel, a sheet or loose clothing.\n\nBut Larry\u2019s cunning is only a small piece of this story. Because most pedophiles present a wholesome persona, they are able to ingratiate themselves into communities. Research shows that pedophiles are also reported at least seven times on average before adults take the reports of abuse seriously and act on them. In many ways, the sexual assault scandal that was 30 years in the making was only a symptom of a much deeper cultural problem \u2014 the unwillingness to speak the truth against one\u2019s own community.", "title": "Opinion | Rachael Denhollander: The Price I Paid for Taking On Larry Nassar", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-07 00:00:00", "text": "Rachel Dara Knipel and Stephen Anthony Thompson were married Jan. 6. Rabbi Uri Goren officiated at Temple Avodah in Oceanside, N.Y.\n\nThe bride and groom work in Manhattan for the New York City Board of Elections, where they met. She is the coordinator of the language assistance programs, and he is the manager of the unit that oversees poll-site devices used to transmit voting results and compile voter issues on election days.\n\nMrs. Knipel-Thompson, 31, graduated from Brooklyn College and received a master\u2019s degree in public administration from the John Jay College of Criminal Justice.\n\nShe is the daughter of Lori Citron Knipel and Lawrence S. Knipel of Brooklyn. The bride\u2019s father is the presiding chief administrative judge for civil matters in Brooklyn. Her mother is a lawyer in private practice, also in Brooklyn, and is a member of the Democratic State Committee, representing Brooklyn\u2019s 44th Assembly District.", "title": "Rachel Knipel, Stephen Thompson", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-09 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nIt may have been an irresistible headline: Radiohead sues Lana Del Rey!\n\nThe old guard versus the new. Lawyers ganging up on an artist. Copyright litigation gone amok.\n\nThe reality is more complicated. But only slightly.\n\nOn Sunday, Ms. Del Rey confirmed a report in a British newspaper that Radiohead was considering suing her over her song \u201cGet Free,\u201d arguing that it sounded similar to Radiohead\u2019s breakthrough 1993 hit \u201cCreep.\u201d The band was said to want songwriting credit, money or both.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s true about the lawsuit,\u201d Ms. Del Rey wrote on Twitter. The band had rejected her offer of 40 percent of the song\u2019s publishing royalties, she claimed, demanding 100 percent. \u201cTheir lawyers have been relentless,\u201d she added, \u201cso we will deal with it in court.\u201d\n\nTweets and news reports quickly embellished this to say that a suit had been filed. At a concert in Denver on Sunday, Ms. Del Rey stoked the fires herself by warning that the song might disappear from \u201cfuture physical releases\u201d of her latest album, \u201cLust for Life.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Louder Newsletter Every week, stay on top of the latest in pop and jazz with reviews, interviews, podcasts and more from The New York Times music critics.
