Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cGet Free,\u201d it seemed, was the latest victim of the so-called \u201cBlurred Lines\u201d effect: a new song accused of stealing from an old one by borrowing chords, texture or \u201cfeel,\u201d the kind of generic elements that have long been considered fair game.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut on Tuesday, after a few days of silence, Radiohead\u2019s music publisher, Warner/Chappell, made a statement confirming that it had requested credit for Radiohead, but denying that it wanted all of Ms. Del Rey\u2019s songwriting money.", "title": "Radiohead Denies Suing Lana Del Rey Over Copyright (but Still Wants Credit)", "authors": ["Ben Sisario"]} {"date": "2018-01-15 00:00:00", "text": "Now it is investing in Propagate, the nearly three-year-old company that created \u201cPlanet of the Apps,\u201d a reality show pitting app developers against each other and starring Gwyneth Paltrow and will.i.am., for Apple, and \u201c#WhatsHappening,\u201d a look at the day\u2019s trending topics, for Twitter.\n\nThe attraction: Propagate\u2019s ambitions to create content for a new world of digital media and international platforms.\n\nPropagate was founded by Mr. Silverman, who is best known as the former NBC Entertainment co-chairman and the television producer who brought \u201cThe Office\u201d and \u201cUgly Betty\u201d to the United States, and Mr. Owens, a former president of National Geographic Channels who previously helped create \u201cThe Biggest Loser\u201d and the American version of \u201cMasterChef.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Propagate is also creating partnerships with the likes of Ms. Paltrow and the singer Zac Brown for more content based on their brands.\n\n\u201cThese guys think global from the very beginning, and the formats and shows that Ben and Howard have developed are some of the best examples of customizing content to different markets and cultures,\u201d said Joseph Ravitch, a founder of Raine.\n\nWith the new cash, Propagate plans to continue expanding, particularly internationally and in digital content, Mr. Silverman said.\n\nRaine joins A+E Networks in Propagate\u2019s corner.\n\n\u201cThis new investment will accelerate their growth and output of content and transform them into a powerhouse indie studio,\u201d Nancy Dubuc, the chief executive of A+E, said of Propagate in a statement.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAs part of the investment, two Raine executives \u2014 Mr. Ravitch and Erik Hodge, the head of the firm\u2019s entertainment practice \u2014 will join Propagate\u2019s board.", "title": "Raine Takes a Stake in \u2018Planet of the Apps\u2019 Creator", "authors": ["Michael J. De La Merced"]} {"date": "2018-01-27 00:00:00", "text": "So we keep going, across prairies, over the Rocky Mountains, through Utah\u2019s Martian wastes, then Nevada\u2019s bleak Basin and Range, as untold millions of years slip past. Finally, scrambling over the Sierras and across the San Joaquin Valley to San Francisco, we arrive at the edge of the continent, more than 100 miles, and tens of millions of years, short of the Cambrian world revealed in Central Park. Having reached the Pacific Ocean, we have covered 10 percent of earth\u2019s history.\n\nIt has been cynically observed by some politicians that over this vast scope of time, \u201cEarth\u2019s climate is always changing.\u201d Indeed, in our transcontinental walk through earth history, it\u2019s true. The planet\u2019s climate in those first few miles of our walk, through the freeze-thaw seesaw of the recent ice ages, is, in fact, far different from the carbon-dioxide infused wasteland inferno of the early Triassic, more than a thousand miles later. Over the grand sweep of earth history our planet has been many different worlds \u2014 a snowball earth colonized by sponges, a supercontinental broiler ruled by crocodile kin.\n\nBut during the brief window of the past few thousand years in which all of civilization has emerged \u2014 those first few steps in our journey \u2014 we\u2019ve enjoyed an almost miraculously equable interglacial climate, the most stable of the past several hundred thousand years. It\u2019s these pleasant few footsteps that allowed complex societies to blossom. But in the next few footsteps, we\u2019re projected to return to climates last seen hundreds, if not thousands of miles in our past.\n\nIn this century alone, a time scale so laughably brief as to effectively not exist to geologists, we could send the planet back to a climate system not seen for many millions of years. One study recently estimated that humanity has the capacity in the next few centuries to make the planet warmer than it has been in at least 420 million years.\n\nThe story of life on earth so far isn\u2019t one of a tidy march of progress, culminating in humanity\u2019s \u201cend of history.\u201d Other alien worlds have claimed this planet for unimaginably longer spans, relinquishing their place only under the duress of mind-bending episodes of chaos, like asteroid hits and large-scale volcanic activity.\n\nAnd contrary to some accounts of our current moment, we\u2019re not even the first, or only, organism to threaten the planet with mass extinction. At the end of the Ediacaran period, 540 million years ago, burrowing animals and filter feeders might have wiped out vast swathes of exotic life clinging to the seafloor. Almost 200 million years later at the end of the Devonian period, the evolution of trees might have driven such convulsions in climate and ocean chemistry that 97 percent of the world\u2019s vertebrates died.\n\nIn the next few decades we will decide whether humanity\u2019s legacy will be a sliver of clay in the limestone strata \u2014 a geological embarrassment accessible only in remote outcrops to eagle-eyed geologists of the far future \u2014 or an enduring new epoch like the reign of dinosaurs. But even if it\u2019s the former, and we collapse almost as soon, in geologic time, as we got started, the record in the rocks of the extinctions we caused will remain, as eternal as the schist in Central Park.", "title": "Opinion | Rambling Through Time", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cI wasn\u2019t at all able to play my game,\u201d he said. \u201cI\u2019ve been worried about a lot more things, trying not to disappoint a lot of people, me included in that, so it\u2019s hard to be leaving the team. But I also feel that what I was putting out onto the ice, I wasn\u2019t giving the guys on my team the best I had.\u201d\n\nShattenkirk grew up a Rangers fan in New Rochelle, N.Y., idolizing his fellow defenseman Brian Leetch. He made it abundantly clear as a free agent last summer that he wanted to be a Ranger.\n\nBut he has struggled in recent weeks. Shattenkirk has no points in the last seven games and has not scored since Nov. 6. He also has a team-worst minus-14 rating.\n\nThus, he decided to opt for surgery, which will take place on Monday.\n\n\u201cI think this is the first step to get back to where I am and come back and have a meaningful impact on this team down the stretch,\u201d Shattenkirk said.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. The Rangers have also been without forward Kevin Hayes the past three games, and the veteran defenseman Marc Staal missed Thursday\u2019s 4-3 win over Buffalo with a hip flexor injury.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nDeAngelo, 22, was acquired last June from Arizona in a deal that sent center Derek Stepan to the Coyotes.\n\nThe offensive-minded DeAngelo had one assist in eight games for the Rangers earlier this season. He had two goals and 11 assists in 29 games with Hartford.\n\n\u201cThis will give an opportunity for a guy like Tony to come up and get some ice time,\u201d Rangers Coach Alain Vigneault said.\n\nVigneault also acknowledged that the Rangers would have to make adjustments in the weeks ahead without their power-play specialist on the blueline and without a timetable for his return.\n\nThe league\u2019s trade deadline is Feb. 26, and the regular season ends on April 7.", "title": "Rangers\u2019 Kevin Shattenkirk Is Out Indefinitely With a Knee Injury", "authors": ["Allan Kreda"]} {"date": "2018-01-29 00:00:00", "text": "Awards shows have also gotten increasingly political, with celebrity presenters and winners playing the role of firebrands at town-hall meetings. The Grammys, which are broadcast on CBS, were no different on Sunday, with several performers bringing up immigration and the #MeToo movement. U2 performed on a barge just outside the Statue of Liberty, a performance not exactly subtle in its symbolism, and Hillary Clinton showed up in a taped segment, reading about President Trump\u2019s preference for McDonald\u2019s food from Michael Wolff\u2019s best-seller, \u201cFire and Fury: Inside the Trump White House.\u201d\n\nNikki R. Haley, the United States ambassador to the United Nations, gave voice to proponents of the \u201cshut up and sing\u201d side of the debate. \u201cI have always loved the Grammys but to have artists read the Fire and Fury book killed it,\u201d Ms. Haley wrote in a tweet during the event. \u201cDon\u2019t ruin great music with trash. Some of us love music without the politics thrown in it.\u201d\n\nTV executives have also suggested that viewership is cyclical, largely depending on whether there are blockbuster movies to promote or superstar singers set to perform. Analysts have also suggested that in the world of streaming, long telecasts packed with commercial breaks \u2014 the Grammys lasted a little more than three and a half hours \u2014 are a much harder sell for TV viewers these days.\n\nThere are also more digital distractions than ever. HQ Trivia, the live streaming smartphone quiz app, said it had 1.6 million players on Sunday night, a record for the game, which went live about an hour and a half into the Grammys telecast.\n\nBetween 2013 and 2017, the Grammys\u2019 ratings fluctuated between 26 million and 28 million viewers, good enough to make it the second-most-watched awards show, behind the Academy Awards.", "title": "Ratings for Grammy Awards Drop 24 Percent", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-07 00:00:00", "text": "Ray Thomas, a founding member of the protean British rock group the Moody Blues, died on Thursday at his home in Surrey, south of London. He was 76.\n\nHis death was announced by his label, Esoteric Recordings/Cherry Red Records. The label did not specify the cause, but Mr. Thomas said in 2014 that he had prostate cancer.\n\nThe Moody Blues\u2019 popularity has endured for decades, during which they recorded traditional rock \u2019n\u2019 roll, psychedelic rock and progressive rock with orchestral arrangements.\n\nMr. Thomas, who played flute, sang and wrote a number of the Moody Blues\u2019 songs, performed in rock and blues bands in Birmingham, England, before founding the group in 1964 with Denny Laine as lead singer and guitarist, Mike Pinder on keyboards, Graeme Edge on drums and Clint Warwick on bass.", "title": "Ray Thomas, Founding Member of the Moody Blues, Dies at 76", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-07 00:00:00", "text": "After being introduced by Reese Witherspoon, she acknowledged the significance of becoming the first black woman to win the award, and said she hoped that the raised voices of her fellow actresses might lead to a world in which \u201cnobody ever has to say, \u2018Me too,\u2019 again.\u201d\n\nHere is a full transcript of Ms. Winfrey\u2019s speech:\n\nAh! Thank you. Thank you all. O.K., O.K. Thank you, Reese. In 1964, I was a little girl sitting on the linoleum floor of my mother\u2019s house in Milwaukee, watching Anne Bancroft present the Oscar for best actor at the 36th Academy Awards. She opened the envelope and said five words that literally made history: \u201cThe winner is Sidney Poitier.\u201d Up to the stage came the most elegant man I had ever seen. I remember his tie was white, and of course his skin was black. And I\u2019d never seen a black man being celebrated like that. And I\u2019ve tried many, many, many times to explain what a moment like that means to a little girl \u2014 a kid watching from the cheap seats, as my mom came through the door bone-tired from cleaning other people\u2019s houses. But all I can do is quote and say that the explanation\u2019s in Sidney\u2019s performance in \u201cLilies of the Field\u201d: \u201cAmen, amen. Amen, amen.\u201d In 1982, Sidney received the Cecil B. DeMille Award right here at the Golden Globes, and it is not lost on me that at this moment there are some little girls watching as I become the first black woman to be given this same award.\n\nIt is an honor, and it is a privilege to share the evening with all of them, and also with the incredible men and women who\u2019ve inspired me, who\u2019ve challenged me, who\u2019ve sustained me and made my journey to this stage possible. Dennis Swanson, who took a chance on me for \u201cA.M. Chicago\u201d; Quincy Jones, who saw me on that show and said to Steven Spielberg, \u201cYes, she is Sophia in \u2018The Color Purple\u2019\u201d; Gayle, who\u2019s been the definition of what a friend is; and Stedman, who\u2019s been my rock \u2014 just a few to name. I\u2019d like to thank the Hollywood Foreign Press Association, because we all know that the press is under siege these days.\n\nBut we also know that it is the insatiable dedication to uncovering the absolute truth that keeps us from turning a blind eye to corruption and to injustice. To tyrants and victims and secrets and lies. I want to say that I value the press more than ever before, as we try to navigate these complicated times. Which brings me to this: What I know for sure is that speaking your truth is the most powerful tool we all have. And I\u2019m especially proud and inspired by all the women who have felt strong enough and empowered enough to speak up and share their personal stories. Each of us in this room are celebrated because of the stories that we tell. And this year we became the story. But it\u2019s not just a story affecting the entertainment industry. It\u2019s one that transcends any culture, geography, race, religion, politics or workplace.\n\nSo I want tonight to express gratitude to all the women who have endured years of abuse and assault, because they \u2014 like my mother \u2014 had children to feed and bills to pay and dreams to pursue. They\u2019re the women whose names we\u2019ll never know. They are domestic workers and farmworkers; they are working in factories and they work in restaurants, and they\u2019re in academia and engineering and medicine and science; they\u2019re part of the world of tech and politics and business; they\u2019re our athletes in the Olympics and they\u2019re our soldiers in the military.\n\nAnd they\u2019re someone else: Recy Taylor, a name I know and I think you should know, too. In 1944, Recy Taylor was a young wife and a mother. She was just walking home from a church service she\u2019d attended in Abbeville, Ala., when she was abducted by six armed white men, raped and left blindfolded by the side of the road, coming home from church. They threatened to kill her if she ever told anyone, but her story was reported to the N.A.A.C.P., where a young worker by the name of Rosa Parks became the lead investigator on her case and together they sought justice. But justice wasn\u2019t an option in the era of Jim Crow. The men who tried to destroy her were never persecuted. Recy Taylor died 10 days ago, just shy of her 98th birthday. She lived, as we all have lived, too many years in a culture broken by brutally powerful men. And for too long, women have not been heard or believed if they dared to speak their truth to the power of those men. But their time is up. Their time is up. Their time is up.\n\nAnd I just hope that Recy Taylor died knowing that her truth \u2014 like the truth of so many other women who were tormented in those years, and even now tormented \u2014 goes marching on. It was somewhere in Rosa Parks\u2019s heart almost 11 years later, when she made the decision to stay seated on that bus in Montgomery. And it\u2019s here with every woman who chooses to say, \u201cMe too.\u201d And every man \u2014 every man \u2014 who chooses to listen. In my career, what I\u2019ve always tried my best to do, whether on television or through film, is to say something about how men and women really behave: to say how we experience shame, how we love and how we rage, how we fail, how we retreat, persevere, and how we overcome. And I\u2019ve interviewed and portrayed people who\u2019ve withstood some of the ugliest things life can throw at you, but the one quality all of them seem to share is an ability to maintain hope for a brighter morning \u2014 even during our darkest nights.\n\nSo I want all the girls watching here and now to know that a new day is on the horizon! And when that new day finally dawns, it will be because of a lot of magnificent women, many of whom are right here in this room tonight, and some pretty phenomenal men, fighting hard to make sure that they become the leaders who take us to the time when nobody ever has to say, \u2018Me too\u2019 again. Thank you.\u201d", "title": "Read Oprah Winfrey\u2019s Golden Globes Speech", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-03 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nWASHINGTON \u2014 The Trump administration on Wednesday released a statement in response to comments that Stephen K. Bannon, the former White House chief strategist, made to Michael Wolff for his book, Fire and Fury: Inside the Trump White House. In the book, Mr. Bannon said that a meeting between members of the Trump team and a lawyer with Russian connections had been \u201ctreasonous.\u201d\n\nAn excerpt from the book was published by New York Magazine.\n\nThe following statement was released from the White House, through the pool report.\n\n____\n\nFrom press secretary Sarah Huckabee Sanders:\n\nStatement from the President of the United States\n\nSteve Bannon has nothing to do with me or my Presidency. When he was fired, he not only lost his job, he lost his mind. Steve was a staffer who worked for me after I had already won the nomination by defeating seventeen candidates, often described as the most talented field ever assembled in the Republican party.\n\nNow that he is on his own, Steve is learning that winning isn\u2019t as easy as I make it look. Steve had very little to do with our historic victory, which was delivered by the forgotten men and women of this country. Yet Steve had everything to do with the loss of a Senate seat in Alabama held for more than thirty years by Republicans. Steve doesn\u2019t represent my base\u2014he\u2019s only in it for himself.\n\nSteve pretends to be at war with the media, which he calls the opposition party, yet he spent his time at the White House leaking false information to the media to make himself seem far more important than he was. It is the only thing he does well. Steve was rarely in a one-on-one meeting with me and only pretends to have had influence to fool a few people with no access and no clue, whom he helped write phony books.\n\nWe have many great Republican members of Congress and candidates who are very supportive of the Make America Great Again agenda. Like me, they love the United States of America and are helping to finally take our country back and build it up, rather than simply seeking to burn it all down.", "title": "Read Trump\u2019s Reaction to Steve Bannon\u2019s Comments", "authors": ["The New York Times"]} {"date": "2018-01-31 00:00:00", "text": "Teacher: Ondrea L. Reisinger, high school English teacher and English department chairwoman\n\nSchool: Central Bucks High School South, Bucks County, Pa.\n\nGrade level: 9-12\n\nWhy we chose it: \u201cIt struck me \u2026 that \u2018The Catcher in the Rye,\u2019 a book I\u2019d taught many times, was its own \u201836 Hours\u2019 \u2014 a travelogue of a teenage boy returning to his hometown for several days, escape on his mind, but seeing it as if for the first time,\u201d Ms. Reisinger writes.\n\nWe\u2019ve seen a lot of \u201cCatcher in the Rye\u201d lesson plans \u2014 in fact, we\u2019ve created our own \u2014 but this one is more creative, interesting and just plain fun than most. As students follow Holden on his journey through New York City and he begins to see his home anew, they also learn to see their own hometowns \u2014 and perhaps themselves \u2014 in a different light.\n\n_________\n\nWhat Ms. Reisinger Did and Why, in Her Own Words\n\nIntroduction\n\nPhoto\n\nMost teenagers are looking to escape: the small towns, big towns or cities they\u2019ve inhabited for years that have become unbearably provincial; the confines of their high schools that \u2014 no matter how big \u2014 suddenly become claustrophobically small; their own homes, where their parents, who care deeply for them, can\u2019t possibly understand them.\n\nI know this. I\u2019m one of those parents who live in one of those towns and send their daughters to one of those high schools. And I teach English to high school students who daily rail against the mundanity of their lives.\n\nIf I\u2019m honest with myself, I feel these same nascent pangs of wanderlust from time to time, which is why each week for years I have found great pleasure in spending part of my Sunday mornings reading the weekly installment of \u201c36 Hours\u201d in The Times\u2019s Travel section.\n\nOn one of these summer Sundays a year ago, reading Seth Sherwood\u2019s tour of Parma, Italy, I found myself, in a Holden Caulfield kind of way, imagining I was in the Camera di San Paolo. (Perhaps not clutching my wounded chest and staggering around, but certainly, in the same cinematographic way, sitting in my Missoni dress conversing with Correggio about plans for a vaulted stone ceiling in my master bath.)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIt struck me then for the first time that \u201cThe Catcher in the Rye,\u201d a book I\u2019d taught many times, was its own \u201c36 Hours\u201d \u2014 a travelogue of a teenage boy returning to his hometown for several days, escape on his mind, but seeing it as if for the first time. For Holden, the Museum of Natural History, the carousel in Central Park and Radio City Music Hall are thrown into sharp relief. (In fact, in 2010, The New York Times actually walked and mapped his route with quotes from the novel.)\n\nI began to see teaching \u201cThe Catcher in the Rye\u201d itself in a whole new way: as a potential parallel version of \u201c36 Hours\u201d and a vehicle for using the Times column as a mentor text to allow my students to try their hands at travel writing and all the voiceful, stylistic and structural techniques that come with it.\n\nAnd perhaps, also, to see their hometowns with new eyes.\n\n_________\n\nSeven Steps to Finished Columns\n\nPhoto\n\n1. Students begin, even before I announce the writing assignment, by examining the \u201c36 Hours\u201d articles over several class periods. I use laminated copies of the original print articles and hang them around the room. Working in groups of four, they first travel the world of my room, reading through the articles, chatting about the faraway places and generally gathering some initial ideas about how travel writing differs from other forms of writing they have encountered.\n\nOn subsequent days, students begin annotating the articles \u2014 noticing surface features, outlining specific structural and organizational elements, marking stylistic devices and talking about aspects of voice.\n\n2. During this time students also begin to read \u201cThe Catcher in the Rye\u201d so that on the day that I assign their \u201c36 Hours\u201d assignment we simultaneously find Holden returning, in Chapter 8, to New York. At this point, students generally think they have figured out that they will be writing a \u201c36 Hours\u201d article, and the room is abuzz with excitement. As a decoy, I even have students share the places in the world they would want to travel to write such an article.\n\nWhen I distribute the assignment sheet, there is a collective intake of breath as the students realize they will not, in fact, be writing an article about Canc\u00fan, Mexico or Disney World (the most commonly suggested exotic locales my students have experienced), but they will, instead, be writing a travel article about their own hometowns.\n\n3. After the initial shock wears off and I listen to the groans about how \u201cthere is nothing exciting about where we live\u201d and \u201cour town is so boring,\u201d I remind them that being a travel writer is about seeing something with new eyes and giving an old place a fresh look. It\u2019s also, as the assignment requires (and as all writing requires), about writing for a specific audience.\n\nIn this case, their \u201c36 Hours\u201d is to be written for a teenage audience \u2014 teenagers who have been dragged, unwillingly, to Bucks County, Pa., where my students have spent their whole lives, for a weekend with their parents. I encourage my students to write so that their audience feels lucky. Make them want to come back.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n4. As we travel with Holden through Manhattan over the next week, my students, in teams of four, begin to travel through Bucks County, making decisions as travel journalists about where to send their audience to eat, play, learn and relax. They begin by making lists of eateries, outdoor spots, shopping locales and historic sites with which they are familiar, as the assignment requires at least one student to have visited the site either before or during the data gathering process. I tell students that just as the original \u201c36 Hours\u201d articles do not send travelers to chain restaurants and shopping malls, they must also avoid these kinds of businesses such that their audiences can experience their hometowns in the most authentic way possible.\n\nThey must also provide three original pictures to accompany the article as well as a guided map and an \u201cIf You Go\u201d section, so students begin to navigate maps, plan out driving routes and consider photo ops.\n\nPhoto\n\n5. Once students decide on their destinations, the legwork begins. Groups send their photographers out to snap photos and their reporters out to taste test pizzas and review the new skate park or visit that museum they once rolled their eyes at when they were 10. In between, we discuss Holden\u2019s visit to the ice skating rink and Central Park as we follow him on his own nostalgic journey.\n\n6. Once students gather their field notes, we return to the annotations we made earlier on the original articles and students work as teams of writers and editors to compose: They argue, revise, question, suggest and edit as a team, playing to one another\u2019s strengths. We use Office 365, which allows them to compose together and allows me to examine their work as they are writing, giving me the opportunity to make comments on their live documents from my desk in my room as they are working in class or from home as they compose remotely together. I also can keep track of which students are contributing what to the articles.\n\n7. Finished articles are printed in columns and mocked up on newsprint to imitate the actual \u201c36 Hours.\u201d As we finish the novel, they finish their travel writing, and all of us, just like Holden, see who we are and where we live in a whole new light.\n\nThe Results\n\nPhoto\n\nHere are excerpts from the work of two of my students to give you a sense of how the final pieces read:\n\nSugar Rush Imagine this on your Snapchat story: you come down after a long night\u2019s rest craving cherry danish and donuts. You hit the last stair to see a nice bowl of \u2026 Raisin Bran your mom just poured from the hotel grab-and-go breakfast? What on earth? So much for your two hundred day streak. Luckily, you are right down the street from the grand old Warrington Pasty Shop. Right at 1380 Easton Rd in Warrington you\u2019ll find breakfast prices that nobody can beat, which is perfect for your meager savings (that shopping trip last week did nothing for your bank account), and sweet morning treats that will make your molars shudder just the way you like. Their cookies are to die for, too, and if you can pass yourself off as a twelve-year old you might even get one for free. Night at the Museum Buried amongst the sleek cosmopolitan exterior of Doylestown\u2019s city center lies a real diamond in the rough: The Michener Museum. You may ask yourself how a museum could by anything more than the opposite of a good use of your time. You\u2019ll have to do the time to understand why \u2014 figuratively for you, thank goodness. You see, beyond being a chill hangout spot with mad intellectual stimulation on offer, this crib was also once a prison. Close your phone and open your eyes to really spot the remnants of this one-time correctional facility behind the spaces for artistic expression: wack bullet holes, a prison courtyard, isolation cells. If that\u2019s not dope I don\u2019t know what is. Only a chicken would be too scared to go \u2014 this place means you no harm or fowl, just fun.\n\n_________\n\nRelated Learning Network Lesson Plans\n\n36 Hours in Learning: Creating Travel Itineraries Across the Curriculum\n\nIdeas for English Language Learners | Recipes, Travel, Idioms and More\n\nText to Text | \u2018The Catcher in the Rye\u2019 and \u2018The Case for Delayed Adulthood\u2019", "title": "Reader Idea | 36 Hours in Your Hometown", "authors": ["Ondrea L. Reisinger", "The Learning Network"]} {"date": "2018-01-17 00:00:00", "text": "Browse all our Reader Ideas.\n\nFor nearly a decade, Marla Sperling Reich has been using The Times to teach students who have mild intellectual and developmental disabilities.\n\nIn this edition of our Reader Ideas column, she explains some of her favorite lessons, including one that uses the Travel section\u2019s annual 52 Places to Go to get her students out of the classroom and into the world.\n\nDo you teach, or learn, with The New York Times? Tell us about it here.\n\n________\n\nIdea: Students use articles from The New York Times as conversation starters about everything from the Super Bowl to body language to where their families should vacation.\n\nTeachers: Marla Sperling Reich is a speech-language pathologist for the Freehold Regional High School District in New Jersey. Among her duties is conducting speech therapy with the Cognitive Mild program at Freehold High School. Mrs. Reich collaborates with Katherine Lyons, a special education English teacher.", "title": "Reader Idea | A Speech-Language Pathologist Makes The Times an Essential Part of Her Classroom", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "For four years, I looked forward to riding the train every morning, because delays and train traffic gave me more time to get to know my mother. I graduated from college four years ago; it was a dream come true for my mom. Now my commute is at best bearable if I get a seat on the train, but I\u2019ll always be thankful for the two-seaters on the C trains that introduced me to my mom. Kio Herrera, Washington Heights, Manhattan\n\nI love the New York subway system. I had a rough year of unemployment and found solace in the subway tunnels. With my monthly pass, I had access to a diversity of neighborhoods and culture, leading me to the end of all the lines. I discovered historical landmarks and community activities in the Bronx, the breathtaking views of Inwood, the magic of the 1964 World\u2019s Fair in Queens and the cultural roots deep in Brooklyn.\n\nEven the advertisements become part of the New York culture. The best friend I have made in the city sprang from a common interest and amusement over the \u201cIf you see something, say something\u201d campaign. It became a challenge to find the cars with our favorite vigilantes. This fun is amplified with the holiday vintage cars in December or at the Transit Museum, where you can see the classic \u201cSubway Sun\u201d ads more classily conveying, \u201cDude, stop the spread.\u201d Sharon Kapitula, Kips Bay, Manhattan\n\nHidden Gems\n\nThe subway often surprises New Yorkers with its never-ending pockets of entertainment.\n\nI was having a stressful day at work: long hours, lots of emails, short deadlines. On the way home, on the F train headed to the Lower East Side, I couldn\u2019t stop thinking about work and was feeling anxious. A gentleman, who had to be in his late 20s or early 30s, got on the train and announced to everyone that he hoped we were all having a wonderful day. Of course, my first thought was, \u201cHere we go.\u201d Then he started singing and happened to have an amazing voice. While no one stared, you could tell the entire car was listening. He sang a soothing song, and for those few minutes, I legitimately felt my stress levels decrease drastically. The guy made my day and reminded me why I love this city. Christian Lopez, Lower East Side, Manhattan\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMy friends and I were waiting for the L, heading to some lame band party. We started talking to this super-nice outgoing woman in her 40s, who ended up giving us a bottle of berry Smirnoff she had customized for her friend\u2019s birthday party (pajama party, her friend was an Aquarius). We are still friends on Facebook. At first we weren\u2019t going to drink the vodka, but after our fake IDs struck out in Bushwick bodegas, we totally did. Paige, East Village, Manhattan\n\nI lived in New York for five years, from 2003 to 2008, and I still have a subway memory that I think about all the time. It happened when I first moved to New York; I was just out of college and scared out of my mind to be in the city. The train ride took forever, so I would read. One day, I was reading \u201cNaked,\u201d by David Sedaris, and laughing hysterically out loud. Suddenly, the guy sitting right next to me started laughing out loud. I thought it was because of me, but then I looked at him and saw he was reading another David Sedaris book (\u201cMe Talk Pretty One Day\u201d)! I looked at his book, and he looked at mine, and we started laughing together. We didn\u2019t talk or exchange numbers. We both went back to our respective books and enjoyed the ride on that sunny summer day. It was such a nice shared moment and probably one of my best memories from my time in New York. Effie K., Inwood and the Flatiron district, Manhattan, and now Paris\n\nWhere New Yorkers Look Out for One Another\n\nMany readers remember a time when a stranger came to someone\u2019s aid while on the subway.\n\nOne night after celebrating the return of friends from abroad, I caught the 4 train headed uptown from Brooklyn. In the car was an older woman, a middle-aged man, a young woman, a passed-out man and a few others. The passed-out man\u2019s backpack was on the ground. We all looked at one another to see if he was O.K. Having some medical training, I went over and checked to see if he was breathing. He was, with a heavy odor of alcohol coming in waves off his breath. The young woman asked if he was going to be O.K. I said he was, and she smiled as I returned to my seat. As the doors opened at our next stop, she grabbed his backpack and sprinted away. The middle-aged man was off like lightning after her. The older woman jumped between a set of doors screaming, \u201cThief, thief!\u201d I jumped between a set of doors as well, hoping to delay the train until the bag returned. Within minutes, the middle-aged man ran back into the car, bag in hand. I roused the passed-out man and showed him his returned bag and pointed out the man who returned it. He gave a bleary smile and passed out again. A thunderous round of applause came from the other passengers, and those of us who helped rode the rest of the way home with smiles. Kunal, Upper East Side, Manhattan\n\nI was on the subway \u2014 the G, I think \u2014 and an older male stranger started talking to me, asking me increasingly personal questions. He was working around to asking for my number and making me visibly uncomfortable. It\u2019s the type of encounter I\u2019ve learned to selectively forget, and the only reason I still remember it is because of the middle-aged woman who, after watching from a few seats over, came over and asked, \u201cWill you be O.K.?\u201d before she exited at the next station. The look she gave me \u2014 a look that said, \u201cI\u2019m here to step in if you need me\u201d \u2014 moved me in a way I didn\u2019t expect, in this space where people usually keep to themselves and mind their own affairs. It was a moment that made me feel that perhaps this vast community of overworked strangers had my back after all. Tao Tao Holmes, Windsor Terrace, Brooklyn\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWe were stuck on the Q train in the tunnel between the Brooklyn Bridge and DeKalb Avenue. It was a long time without any information. A normal-looking man in a suit standing by the door started having a panic attack, basically freaking out. An older woman got out of her seat, went over to him and talked to him in a very calm and caring voice until the train finally started moving again. We applauded when the train doors opened at the station. He got out, and she stayed on. Random people asked her if she was a health care professional, but she was just a regular person who stepped up to help a stranger. It was a beautiful moment in an otherwise miserable commute. Betty, Brooklyn\n\nA Shared Sense of History\n\nFinally, many New Yorkers remember the subway being a place of support during moments of consequence.\n\nThe day after the 2016 presidential election, I cried with other subway riders \u2014 strangers \u2014 on the way to work. Soon after, people began putting up multicolored Post-it notes on the walls of one the walking tunnels at the 14th Street-Sixth Avenue stop. The messages, scrawled in Sharpie, ran the gamut \u2014 some despairing, most hopeful, a few humorous. It sounds dramatic, but that feeling of unity with so many strangers is one of the most powerful things I\u2019ve ever experienced. The subway levels the playing field and, quite literally, brings the city closer together every single day. Ashley Long, Greenwich Village, Manhattan\n\nLate in the day on Sept. 11, 2001, the subways reopened, and I could return home to the Upper East Side. As I boarded the train, I saw a woman in a hijab, a head scarf. I remember marveling at the courage and composure it took, on that day, to be visibly Muslim. But I was more impressed that not only did no one say an angry or intemperate word to her, but also no one even glanced crossly in her direction. The subway is not just an economic engine, a means of mobility, but an agent for tolerance and understanding, as neighborhoods of different hues and accents are fused together. There is too little of that in America today. Haroon Moghul, the Bronx", "title": "Readers Share Their New York Subway Stories", "authors": ["Alice Yin"]} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "Donations are still being taken because Ms. Alfonzo has a new goal: five more new bikes for 2018.\n\nStorefront RAE\n\nThe Brooklyn artist RAE spent three weeks living in a storefront window on Allen Street, which was much more difficult than he\u2019d anticipated. He lost 15 pounds, but he also got much better at roller-skating, one of his pastimes in the very small space \u2014 when he wasn\u2019t making art in front of a constant stream of Lower East Side onlookers. Some people became really invested in the project, following him obsessively, not just from the sidewalk but through the live feed he provided. \u201cThere were some people who felt lost afterward,\u201d he said. \u201cI got messages from them.\u201d Some wedged dollar bills into the crevices of the storefront.\n\nOther people were not so positive. \u201cI was kind of taken aback by people who felt it was their right to be vicious about me being inside this caged environment, treating me like a zoo animal,\u201d RAE said. Drunken revelers banged so hard on the glass one night that RAE worried it would break. Others exposed themselves.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nOverall, RAE felt the project was a success, though re-entry into normal life was a challenge. \u201cOnce I got out, it was definitely culture shock.\u201d\n\nThe Billie Returns\n\nThe newly restored 59-year-old Billie Holiday Theater in Bedford-Stuyvesant held its ribbon-cutting in May with an inaugural program that included Roger Robinson, Sonia Sanchez and Jason Moran and Alicia Hall Moran, followed by three sold-out readings of Zora Neale Hurston\u2019s \u201cTheir Eyes Were Watching God.\u201d In the fall the Billie launched its first full production, \u201cThe Old Settler,\u201d by the Brooklyn playwright Henry Redwood. The newest production, \u201cA Small Oak Tree Runs Red,\u201d begins previews in February. Written by the Brooklyn resident LeKethia Dalcoe, it is set in 1918, its subject is the lynching of 11 African-Americans, including Mary Turner and her unborn baby in Brooks County, Ga.\n\nEssex Crossing Development\n\nThe 1.65-million-square-foot urban renewal project on the Lower East Side \u2014 a space that sat fallow for over 40 years \u2014 has hit several milestones since we reported on it last June. The developers introduced affordable-housing lotteries and so far have received over 320,000 applications for 301 apartments on three sites. A fourth lottery is underway for 11 affordable condominiums on Broome Street. In November, construction started on 92 units of senior housing at 140 Essex Street, and a month later the developers announced mixed-income rentals at 145 Clinton Street, named the Rollins, after the jazz saxophonist Sonny Rollins. This week, 175 Delancey, which is 100 percent affordable housing for seniors and includes the new Grand Street Settlement space and community center, opens.\n\nHunts Point Slave Burial Ground\n\nCommunity members and teachers from P.S. 48 in the Bronx are trying to place a monument at a site where it\u2019s believed several African-American slaves from the 18th and 19th centuries lie buried. After their story appeared, Senator Kirsten Gillibrand\u2019s office contacted the group and suggested they apply for state and national landmark status for the site at Joseph Rodman Drake Park to protect it from destruction. So they did. Since then, they have received a letter from the state saying the site meets criteria and is eligible for landmark status, the first step in the process \u201cto honor the region\u2019s colonial and literary history.\u201d\n\nThe Naked Photo Shoot\n\nThe photographer Angelo Musco shot pictures of two dozen naked New Yorkers back in May and is now using those bodies as elements for his canvas \u2014 an 8-foot-by-20-foot computer-created artwork that should be completed over the next six months. The piece, entitled \u201cAaru,\u201d will be a garden filled with flowers, feathers and butterflies, all made from those stills and shots taken at two other naked photo shoots. Mr. Musco, originally from Naples, Italy, produced a three-minute video about the project this month and hopes to show the work in Paris, Luxembourg and Mexico City.\n\nGrave Trippers\n\nTwo Manhattan brothers, Vincent and Robert Gardino, are still raising money for their television show, which is still in development and features them traveling to cemeteries, pointing out the graves of once famous, but mostly forgotten, historical figures. In the meantime, they\u2019ve landed a book deal. \u201cI\u2019m Telling You He\u2019s Over There!\u201d will be released in spring 2019 by Temple University Press.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nGulliver\u2019s Gate\n\nThe moving, miniature world built on 44th Street near Times Square opened on schedule in April. Tiny (1:87 scale) versions of New York, Moscow, Paris, London, Egypt, Rome, Israel, the Taj Mahal, the Panama Canal, Brazil, China, Japan and other points on the globe drew large crowds of full-size humans from around the world during the holidays and continues to be a draw for tourists and school groups. Admission is $36 for adults and $27 for children. Details include a trapeze school in Chelsea, a woman feeding chickens in Russia, the active Arenal Volcano in Costa Rica and a view inside a pyramid at Giza. Visitors can make 3D models of themselves \u2014 called Model Citizens \u2014 and place their miniatures in the display. The company is now working on creating similar worlds in Dubai, South Korea and Singapore.", "title": "Ready to Roll? A Works in Progress Report", "authors": ["Helene Stapinski"]} {"date": "2018-01-28 00:00:00", "text": "The Trump administration has imposed tariffs on imported washing machines and solar energy cells and panels, products mostly made in China and South Korea. Both countries have voiced anger over the move and could lodge complaints with the World Trade Organization.", "title": "Opinion | Ready, Aim ... Misfire", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "THE ORIGINS OF CREATIVITY\n\nBy Edward O. Wilson\n\n243 pp. Liveright Publishing. $24.95.\n\nThe act of reading alters your brain. It does so, first, because your thoughts are brain processes. When you read, neural patterns come and go as the words pass before you. Some of those patterns also give rise to memories, subtle molecular changes in cells and the signaling mechanisms that link them. And third, your brain is physically transformed by learning to read. The networks that underlie vision and language are changed. Even people who become literate in adulthood, as a team led by the French neurobiologist Stanislas Dehaene has shown, acquire differences that are visible in a brain scan. With and without literacy, the brain is the same basic organ, with the same shape and chemistry, but a reading brain is different in ways that count. As Cecilia Heyes says in her forthcoming book, \u201cCognitive Gadgets,\u201d if one didn\u2019t know that reading is a recent human invention (literate culture is perhaps 5,000 or 6,000 years old), a skill passed on through learning in each generation, it would be easy to mistake the brain patterns seen in reading as evidence for a genetically encoded reading instinct or \u201cinnate module.\u201d\n\nReading is an apt skill to celebrate in a book review, a piece of writing about a piece of writing. E. O. Wilson\u2019s new book, \u201cThe Origins of Creativity,\u201d is about the role of the humanities in an intellectual culture increasingly dominated by science. Wilson values the humanities, but he wants them to have closer ties to some of the sciences, an argument that draws on his view of the relationships between human biology, thought and culture. \u201cIt is becoming increasingly clear,\u201d he says at one point, \u201cthat natural selection has programmed every bit of human biology \u2014 every toe, hair and nipple, every molecular configuration in every cell, every neuron circuit in the brain, and within all that, every trait that makes us human.\u201d But reading itself, the reading of books like his own, shows that this isn\u2019t true. The circuits of the brain are changed by literacy, and the molecular configurations in countless cells are being altered as you pick up new ideas from the page, as they make their way into your memory. If what Wilson says were true, there would be no point in reading, in trying to learn songs or engage in many other activities. We\u2019d have little resemblance to humans at all.\n\nI have much admiration for the work Wilson has done in biology, not for the theoretical side but for the crawling in and climbing around side \u2014 his unearthing of new species, his charting of the quirks of their lives and attempting to get into the worlds of countless small fierce invertebrates. I also admire much of the path his life has taken, some of which is sketched here. His parents divorced during the Depression and his youth was spent roaming the South, attending 14 different schools. But he made it to college and then on to graduate work and a career at Harvard. It\u2019s impossible to begrudge such a person a few literary victory laps. Yet Wilson is so widely read and admired that when he makes a public statement about the relationship between science and the humanities, it has to be taken on its own terms and assessed for what it says. And \u201cThe Origins of Creativity\u201d is an extremely shallow book.\n\nImage\n\nWilson wants the humanities to make more contact with science. By the \u201chumanities\u201d he means the fields that study languages, literature, history, art and so on. What Wilson would like is for these fields to become more scientifically literate and attend especially to developments in paleontology, anthropology, psychology, evolutionary biology and neurobiology \u2014 what he calls the \u201cfriendly ground of science,\u201d where the humanities can seek alliances. Such connections are always welcome, but is there a problem with the humanities that makes these meetings urgent?", "title": "Real Worlds, Possible Worlds and Fantasy Worlds", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-14 00:00:00", "text": "RISHIKESH, India \u2014 In 1968, the Beatles and a crew of hangers-on traded hip London threads for kurtas and wreaths of marigold, trudging through dense forest to an ashram in Rishikesh, India, where they spent weeks writing songs.\n\nThere was George Harrison, a devoted follower of Transcendental Meditation; John Lennon and Paul McCartney, who had started to feud over the band\u2019s direction; and Ringo Starr, the band\u2019s drummer, who was so perturbed by India\u2019s famously spicy food that he packed a reserve of beans for his stay at the ashram. He lasted 10 days.\n\n\u201cScan all the photographs of Ringo in Rishikesh, and you\u2019ll find few in which he\u2019s smiling,\u201d said Raju Gusain, a local journalist who has become something of an expert on the band\u2019s trip to India.\n\nThese days, the forest has swallowed up the ashram\u2019s crumbling buildings, obscuring traces of celebrity from their halls. But the complex is set for a revival, with renovations planned for many of the structures, long unused and only recently reopened to the public.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nA new museum on the grounds will showcase the legacy of the Beatles and Maharishi Mahesh Yogi, the guru whom band members abruptly fell out with toward the end of their stay in Rishikesh. Across the world in Liverpool, England, The Beatles Story, a museum dedicated to the band, is opening an exhibit next month to mark 50 years since their trip to India.\n\nPhoto\n\nOver the years, as more spiritual seekers from the West traveled to India looking for enlightenment, Rishikesh ballooned in size. But when the Beatles arrived, the place was a sleepy town straddling the banks of the Ganges.", "title": "Rebuilding on the Beatles, an Ashram in India Hopes for Revival", "authors": ["Kai Schultz"]} {"date": "2018-01-09 00:00:00", "text": "RECENT SALE\n\n$13.2 MILLION\n\n2372, 2374 and 2376 Amsterdam Avenue (between West 177th and 178th Streets)\n\nManhattan\n\nA private investor has bought three contiguous mixed-use Washington Heights walk-ups, two of them five stories and one six stories. The buildings, which total 41,353 square feet, feature 58 apartments and eight stores and services, including a barbershop and a grocery. They were built between 1906 and 1908, and sold for 13.12 times the annual rent roll, with a cap rate of 4 percent.\n\nBuyer: 2372-2376 Amsterdam Ave NYC\n\nSeller: 2372-2376 Amsterdam Avenue\n\nBroker: Aaron Jungreis, Rosewood Realty Group\n\nRECENT LEASE\n\n$49.20/SQ. The two buildings, totaling 41,000 square feet, have 49 apartments: 36 one-bedrooms, 11 two-bedrooms and two three-bedrooms. Air rights offered by No. 291 are 8,200 square feet, while No. 292 comes with 4,200 square feet. There are one rent-controlled, 34 rent-stabilized and 10 market-rate apartments, as well as four rent-stabilized apartments that are vacant. The buildings sold for a total of 17.29 times the rent roll, with a cap rate of 3.65 percent.\n\nSeller: 291 & 292 Lincoln Place\n\nBuyer: Lincoln Place Property Holding\n\nBrokers: Jonathan Berman, Michael A. Tortorici, Shimon Shkury, Victor Sozio and Orry Michael, Ariel Property Advisors\n\nRECENT SALE", "title": "Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-20 00:00:00", "text": "MUMBAI, India \u2014 They stormed a film set. They pulled the director\u2019s hair. They burned movie posters. They even threatened to behead the lead actress \u2014 or at least cut off her nose.\n\nHindu extremists in India have played just about every trick in their book to block the release of \u201cPadmaavat,\u201d a lavish Bollywood film about a 14th-century Hindu queen.\n\nBut none of it worked, and this coming week, the most potentially explosive Indian film in years will open across the country.\n\nWith many Indians fearing that \u201cPadmaavat\u201d has all the ingredients that could lead to riots, the police are already planning extra security. The film hits two of India\u2019s sorest sore spots: Hindu-Muslim relations and perceived assaults on tradition.\n\n", "title": "Recipe for Ruckus in India: A Queen\u2019s Honor, a New Film and Politics", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-13 00:00:00", "text": "We\u2019re interested in your feedback on this page. Tell us what you think.", "title": "Recipes to Cook Over a Long Weekend", "authors": ["Regina Schrambling", "Melissa Clark", "Sam Sifton", "Margaux Laskey", "Martha Meadows", "Julia Moskin"]} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "From Momofuku\u2019s bo ssam (above) to Melissa Clark\u2019s cardamom cream cake, here are the recipes to cook on a three-day weekend.", "title": "Recipes to Cook Over a Long Weekend", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "Ernaux certainly isn\u2019t a Marxist, but at the same time she sees history as sociological and the economy as determinative. She uses herself as a \u201ccase,\u201d a person who has been conditioned by advertising and consumerism. She marvels at how quickly people have learned to use the mobile phone, computer, iPod and GPS \u2014 and she is unable to imagine the devices we\u2019ll be using in 10 years\u2019 time. People must keep up, acquire the latest gadgets; to fall behind would be to accept aging and dying. She remarks on how goods can freely circulate, unlike refugees, who are \u201cturned away at the borders.\u201d She knows that possessions can\u2019t make people happy, but also acknowledges the popular belief that this \u201cwas no reason to abandon things.\u201d\n\nImage\n\nChange happens so imperceptibly that only big events like the collapse of the Berlin Wall or 9/11 allow us to establish a \u201cbefore\u201d and an \u201cafter.\u201d Closer to home, photographs set a time line, as do family holidays, and both are used as markers throughout the book. But because everything, no matter how obscure or distant, is now available on the internet, we inhabit \u201cthe infinite present.\u201d\n\nErnaux attributes the \u201cI remember\u201d concept that summons up an endless list of events and products, no matter how trivial, to the French writer Georges Perec, but it actually started with the American artist and poet Joe Brainard. Unlike their random lists, Ernaux\u2019s are arranged chronologically, and so she becomes something more than a list-maker: a Greek chorus commenting on politics and lifestyle changes. And yet her recollections are evanescent, unstable, because the media have taken charge of memory and forgetting. And the media have divided people into generations: \u201cWe belonged to all and none. Our years were nowhere among them.\u201d The media have become the gatekeepers of the imagination.\n\nLike Proust, Ernaux is always trying to envisage the book she will write \u2014 this very book we are reading, in a fluent, idiomatic translation by Alison L. Strayer. \u201cShe would like to assemble these multiple images of herself, separate and discordant, thread them together with the story of her existence, starting with her birth during World War II up until the present day. Therefore, an existence that is singular but also merged with the movements of a generation. Each time she begins, she meets the same obstacles: how to represent the passage of historical time, the changing of things, ideas and manners, and the private life of this woman?\u201d\n\nFeelings themselves seem to go in and out of fashion. People now find the words \u201chonor\u201d and \u201cpatriotism\u201d absurd. Other, newer emotions are unnamable: \u201cThere was no specific word for the feeling one had of simultaneous stagnation and mutation.\u201d Life, caught up in meaningless rituals, feels as if it\u2019s slipping by, but at the same time \u201cprogress\u201d has landed us in a place we no longer recognize.", "title": "Reclaiming the Past in the Internet\u2019s \u2018Infinite Present\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-08 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cAssociating it with the \u2018Battle Hymn of the Republic\u2019 was not really something we did,\u201d said Harvey H. Jackson III, a historian of the South at Jacksonville State University who earned his Ph.D at Georgia. \u201cIt was a college football fight song.\u201d\n\nGeorgia football fans are not alone in co-opting the melody. The pro-labor chant \u201cSolidarity Forever\u201d is perhaps the most widely known adaptation. In northern England, certain fans sing \u201cGlory, Glory Man United\u201d for their favorite soccer team. In college sports there is \u201cGlory, Glory Colorado,\u201d as well as the less-used \u201cGlory, Glory to Ole Auburn.\u201d\n\nThe melody originated in the early 1800s with a hymn, \u201cGrace Reviving the Soul,\u201d according to the book \u201cBattle Hymn of the Republic: A Biography of the Song That Marches On.\u201d Its lyrics went, \u201cSay brothers will you meet us,\u201d three times, and then, \u201cOn Canaan\u2019s happy shore.\u201d\n\nIn the spring of 1861, the soldiers of a Boston-based Union regiment pinned the tune to the lyrics: \u201cJohn Brown\u2019s body lies a-mouldering in the grave/His soul is marching on.\u201d It was an ode to the man who was hanged for raiding the Harpers Ferry Armory in protest of slavery not two years earlier.\n\nJulia Ward Howe, a well-to-do Northern abolitionist and poet, heard the tune that autumn while observing Union troops in Virginia. She decided to prettify the lyrics, which had expanded to include such lines as, \u201cWe\u2019ll hang Jeff Davis from a sour apple tree.\u201d\n\nShe wrote five verses \u2014 beginning with the famous \u201cMine eyes have seen the glory of the coming of the Lord\u201d \u2014 and submitted them to The Atlantic Monthly. The poetry editor published them in the February 1862 issue under the title \u201cBattle Hymn of the Republic.\u201d The lyrics became extremely popular \u2014 Abraham Lincoln praised them \u2014 and remained widely known after the war had ended.\n\n\u201cGlory, Glory\u201d emerged at a time when football was just cropping up in the region, said Bruce Schueneman, an author of an anthology of college fight songs. The first game in the Deep South was played in 1892 between Georgia and Auburn (which might explain why they both have versions of the song). There is a published reference to its being played at the 1906 baseball season opener versus Clemson.", "title": "Recognize That Tune? It\u2019s the Northern Accent of Georgia Football", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-01 00:00:00", "text": "OAKLAND, Calif. \u2014 Retail cannabis shops in California opened their doors on Monday for the first time, inaugurating what proponents say will become the world\u2019s largest market for legalized recreational marijuana.\n\nA transaction that remains illegal in many parts of the country seemed almost banal on Monday for the customers at a dispensary in Oakland who picked out their marijuana, showed their driver\u2019s licenses and walked into the brisk morning air with their drugs in a paper bag.\n\n\u201cThis is a whole new world opening up,\u201d said Diana Gladden, 48, who bought marijuana for herself and her aging parents. \u201cMy mother, a very strict Southern Baptist, now thinks it\u2019s O.K. because it\u2019s legal.\u201d\n\nOne customer left with more than $1,000 worth of cannabis in a large grocery bag.\n\nMedical marijuana has been legal in California for more than two decades but the arrival of full legalization in the state is a milestone for the nation\u2019s fast-growing cannabis industry. Pot is now sold legally down the entire length of the West Coast, plus Alaska.", "title": "Recreational Pot Is Officially Legal in California", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\n\u201cSeparate and Unequal Treatments\u201d (Metropolitan section, Jan. 14), about racial disparities in access to opioid treatment, notes that our country\u2019s legacies of structural racism and stigma toward people with substance use disorders affect the availability of methadone and buprenorphine.\n\nWhen available, methadone is dispensed exclusively through tightly regulated programs outside the standard health care delivery system. This separation reinforces structural inequities in health care. In contrast, buprenorphine treatment has fewer regulations, allowing for flexible and personalized care.\n\nTo address this inequity, we are funding 14 safety-net health centers to expand buprenorphine among uninsured or publicly insured patients. These health centers are in low-income black and brown communities.\n\nWe are also expanding buprenorphine treatment availability through syringe exchange programs, training providers to prescribe and increasing public education to promote opioid addiction treatment.", "title": "Opinion | Reducing Disparities in Access to Opioid Treatment", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-27 00:00:00", "text": "A few months ago, Reese Witherspoon realized everything had changed.\n\nHBO\u2019s glossy, seven-episode drama, \u201cBig Little Lies\u201d \u2014 which Ms. Witherspoon starred in and helped produce \u2014 won eight Emmy Awards, including the one for best limited series. From the Microsoft Theater stage in Los Angeles on Sept. 17, to swelling applause, Ms. Witherspoon spoke of how important it was to bring \u201cwomen to the front of their own stories and make them the heroes of their own stories.\u201d\n\nNot long after that night, she found herself in demand.\n\n\u201cIt opened a lot of doors for me,\u201d Ms. Witherspoon said in an interview this past week. \u201cPeople wanted to be in business with me as a producer in the TV space. My mission was to create television for other women, for other female storytellers that are actresses, other directors and other writers. I think it just clicked in people\u2019s minds.\u201d\n\nSince then, Ms. Witherspoon has transformed herself from an actress increasingly frustrated with the roles she was being offered into a producer with a slate of projects that puts her in the company of series creators like Dick Wolf, Shonda Rhimes and Ryan Murphy.\n\nLast month, HBO ordered a second season of \u201cBig Little Lies,\u201d with Ms. Witherspoon\u2019s production company, Hello Sunshine, among the key companies behind the show. Instead, they should prepare to assimilate into Indonesian society as best they can, or consider returning to their strife-torn countries.\n\n\u201cStill no home, and no hope,\u201d said Mr. Ibrahim, 33, who was granted United Nations refugee status in 2015.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nGlobally, there are more than 24 million certified refugees and asylum seekers, the highest levels since World War II, according to the United Nations. Many May Be Stuck for Life.", "authors": ["Joe Cochrane"]} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cWhite House Puts a Bible in Doctors\u2019 Offices\u201d (editorial, Jan. 29):\n\nAs a Catholic committed to religious freedom for all, I share your concern that religious ultraconservatives, including the Catholic hierarchy, are using religion as a license to discriminate.\n\nAs your editorial highlights, when religious freedom is misused to give power to one group of religious special interests, everyday Americans get hurt: a woman refused birth control by her employer; a same-sex couple denied the right to adopt; and countless others.\n\nThat is why 85 percent of American Catholics believe that individuals should not use religious beliefs to deny services to others who hold views they may disagree with. Religious freedom in America is about tolerance and unity in diversity, not about imposing one narrow set of religious beliefs on everyone else.\n\nJON O\u2019BRIEN, WASHINGTON\n\nThe writer is president of Catholics for Choice.", "title": "Opinion | Religious Freedom", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nBowing to the demands of the United States Olympic Committee, U.S.A. Nassar.\n\nThe announcement came one day after the head of the Olympic committee threatened in an email to decertify U.S.A. Gymnastics \u2014 the sport\u2019s national governing body \u2014 if its entire board of more than 20 people did not resign by next Wednesday. Several board members, including the chairman, Paul Parilla, had already resigned by the time the email was sent.\n\nThe email, signed by the head of the Olympic committee, Scott Blackmun, made a total of six demands, which included seating an interim board by the end of February.\n\nLate Thursday, U.S.A. Gymnastics responded to the email saying it \u201ccompletely embraces the requirements\u201d outlined in the letter and pledged to \u201cwork with the U.S.O.C. to accomplish change for the betterment of our organization, our athletes and our clubs.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThen, on Friday night, U.S.A. As weeks turned into months, their agent, Randy Baruh at the Corcoran Group, suggested they talk to the Brooklyn architect Frederick Tang about buying a townhouse that was less than perfect and updating it to suit their tastes. \u201cFred gave us assurances that he would be the one managing the process from start to finish,\u201d Ms. Farah said.\n\nKnowing that his clients didn\u2019t want a multiyear project, Mr. Tang cautioned them about buying a house cut up into multiple apartments or anything too rundown. It took nearly a year, but the Farahs\u2019 agent eventually showed them what appeared to be the ideal compromise: a relatively soulless four-story townhouse built in 2012.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Real Estate Newsletter Every week, get updates on residential real estate news, covering the five boroughs and beyond.
