They introduced dueling measures that would provide a layer of job protection and found Democrats eager to collaborate.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAt a hearing in late September, a majority of the Senate Judiciary Committee appeared to be on board with advancing legislation to add job protections for Mr. Mueller and future special counsels, despite concerns about the constitutionality of such measures.\n\nBoth bills under consideration would empower a panel of federal judges to review the case for firing the special counsel and render a judgment about whether there was good cause to do so \u2014 the standard required by the law governing special counsels.\n\nThe difference is when to do so. A bill written by Mr. Graham and Senator Cory Booker, Democrat of New Jersey, would require the attorney general \u2014 or a deputy \u2014 to essentially ask for the judges\u2019 permission to fire the special counsel. An approach drafted by Senators Thom Tillis, Republican of North Carolina, and Chris Coons, Democrat of Delaware, would allow the counsel to appeal a dismissal after the fact.\n\nSince then, discussions to combine the approaches into a single piece of legislation have made little progress. Senator Charles E. Grassley of Iowa, the Judiciary Committee chairman, said Friday that the two bills would have to be reconciled before his committee could proceed, but suggested that the measures were not on a fast track.\n\n\u201cIf these latest reports are true,\u201d he added, \u201cit seems to me that they show the president listened to good advice from his advisers.\n\n\u201cBased on his statements from the last couple weeks, he and his lawyers appear to be cooperating with Mueller.\u201d", "title": "Republicans Show Little Urgency on Legislation to Protect Mueller", "authors": ["Sheryl Gay Stolberg", "Nicholas Fandos"]} {"date": "2018-01-08 00:00:00", "text": "Children from lower-income families could soon lose access to affordable health care because the Republican leaders in Congress have failed to renew the Children\u2019s Health Insurance Program. This is a travesty.\n\nAfter passing a lavish tax cut for corporations and wealthy families, Congress hastily left town last month without reauthorizing the federal-state health insurance program, which benefits nearly nine million children. Authorization expired in September, and so far states have kept CHIP going with unspent funds carried over from previous appropriations. Before Christmas, Congress allocated $2.85 billion to the program, saying that the money would take care of the children\u2019s needs until the end of March. But that appears to have been a gross miscalculation, because the Trump administration said on Friday that some states would start running out of money after Friday, Jan. 19.\n\nCHIP was created in 1997 and has helped halve the percentage of children who are uninsured. It has been reauthorized by bipartisan majorities of Congress in the past. But Republican leaders in Congress all but abandoned the program last fall and devoted their time to trying to pass an unpopular tax bill that will increase the federal debt by $1.8 trillion over the next decade, according to a Congressional Budget Office analysis released last week. By contrast, CHIP costs the federal government roughly $14.5 billion a year, or $145 billion over 10 years.\n\nRepublicans have held children\u2019s insurance hostage to force Democrats to accept cuts to other programs. Last year, House Republicans insisted that they would reauthorize CHIP only if Democrats agreed to offset spending on the program with cuts to Medicare and a public health program created by the Affordable Care Act. Democrats balked at those demands, given that Republicans did not bother to offset the loss of revenue from their boondoggle tax cuts.", "title": "Opinion | Republicans in Congress Are Failing America\u2019s Children", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nWASHINGTON \u2014 Representative Kevin Cramer, Republican of North Dakota, said on Thursday that he would not challenge the Democratic incumbent senator, Heidi Heitkamp, in this year\u2019s midterm elections. It was just the latest indication of the difficulty Republicans are having recruiting candidates in what had looked to be a highly favorable climate in the wake of President Trump\u2019s inauguration a year ago.\n\nMs. Heitkamp is among 10 Democrats seeking re-election in states won by Mr. Trump in his race against Hillary Clinton in 2016. Mr. Cramer had been seen as a top-tier challenger in a state the president carried by 36 percentage points. He made his announcement during a North Dakota radio program.\n\n\u201cThis is shaping up to be a tough cycle for Republicans across the board,\u201d said Jennifer Duffy, a senior editor for The Cook Political Report who specializes in Senate races. \u201cIt only makes sense that recruiting is going to be difficult. For someone like Cramer, it doesn\u2019t make a lot of sense to give up a safe seat for a difficult race in a lousy environment.\u201d\n\nThat assessment is an abrupt reversal of how most analysts saw the midterm landscape shaping up a year ago.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nDemocrats are defending 24 seats, including those in states Mr. Trump won, compared with eight for Republicans. But the president\u2019s chaotic first term has led to the lowest approval ratings for any first-term president at this time in his tenure in the history of polling, and he is now seen as a drag for many candidates. Two Independent senators, Bernie Sanders of Vermont and Angus King of Maine, are also up for re-election.", "title": "Republicans\u2019 \u2018Tough Cycle\u2019 Now Spreads to Senate", "authors": ["Michael Tackett"]} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "Dear Diary:\n\nI was crossing a busy intersection in the West Village where there was construction going on.\n\nSurrounded by orange cones and sawhorses, I stopped to retrieve a doll that had fallen on the ground, a Sesame Street character with purple hair and a bright blue dress. It looked new and clean.\n\nAs I started toward the curb, I heard a shout. It was a burly construction worker.\n\n\u201cHey, lady,\u201d he called, \u201cwhat are you doing with that?\u201d\n\nI halted in the crosswalk, suddenly feeling like a thief.\n\n\u201cThe baby dropped it,\u201d he said, pointing to a young woman who was pushing a stroller away from the intersection at top speed.\n\nHe held up his hands, ready for a catch. Before I had time to think, Abby Cadabby was sailing above the Seventh Avenue traffic and landing gently in his hands.\n\nHe shot me a grin, raised the doll over his head and ran off toward the stroller.", "title": "Rescuing Abby Cadabby", "authors": ["Rosemary Dibattista", "Metropolitan Diary"]} {"date": "2018-01-03 00:00:00", "text": "Amazon told customers of its Amazon Web Services cloud service that the vulnerability \u201chas existed for more than 20 years in modern processor architectures.\u201d It said that it had already protected nearly all instances of A.W.S. and that customers must update their own software running atop the service as well.\n\nTo take advantage of Meltdown, hackers could rent space on a cloud service, just like any other business customer. Once they were on the service, the flaw would allow them to grab information like passwords from other customers.\n\nThat is a major threat to the way cloud-computing systems operate. Cloud services often share machines among many customers \u2014 and it is uncommon for, say, a single server to be dedicated to a single customer. Though security tools and protocols are intended to separate customers\u2019 data, the recently discovered chip flaws would allow bad actors to circumvent these protections.\n\nThe personal computers used by consumers are also vulnerable, but hackers would have to first find a way to run software on a personal computer before they could gain access to information elsewhere on the machine. There are various ways that could happen: Attackers could fool consumers into downloading software in an email, from an app store or visiting an infected website.\n\nAccording to the researchers, the Meltdown flaw affects virtually every microprocessor made by Intel, which makes chips used in more than 90 percent of the computer servers that underpin the internet and private business operations.\n\nCustomers of Microsoft, the maker of the Windows operating system, will need to install an update from the company to fix the problem. The worldwide community of coders that oversees the open-source Linux operating system, which runs about 30 percent of computer servers worldwide, has already posted a patch for that operating system. Apple had a partial fix for the problem and is expected to have an additional update.\n\nThe software patches could slow the performance of affected machines by 20 to 30 percent, said Andres Freund, an independent software developer who has tested the new Linux code. The researchers who discovered the flaws voiced similar concerns.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThis could become a significant issue for any business running websites and other software through cloud systems.\n\nThere is no evidence that hackers have taken advantage of the vulnerability \u2014 at least not yet. But once a security problem becomes public, computer users take a big risk if they do not install a patch to fix the issue. A so-called ransomware attack that hit computers around the world last year took advantage of machines that had not received a patch for a flaw in Windows software.\n\nThe other flaw, Spectre, affects most processors now in use, though the researchers believe this flaw is more difficult to exploit. There is no known fix for it, and it is not clear what chip makers like Intel will do to address the problem.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIt is not certain what the disclosure of the chip issues will do to Intel\u2019s business, and on Wednesday, the Silicon Valley giant played down the problem.\n\n\u201cIntel and other technology companies have been made aware of new security research describing software analysis methods that, when used for malicious purposes, have the potential to improperly gather sensitive data from computing devices that are operating as designed,\u201d the company said in a statement. \u201cIntel believes these exploits do not have the potential to corrupt, modify or delete data.\u201d\n\nThe researchers who discovered the flaws notified various affected companies. And as is common practice when such problems are identified, they tried to keep the news from the public so hackers could not take advantage of the flaws before they were fixed.\n\nBut on Tuesday, news of the Meltdown flaw began to leak through various news websites, including The Register, a science and technology site based in Britain. So the researchers released papers describing the flaws on Wednesday, much earlier than they had planned.\n\nFor now, computer security experts are using a patch, called Kaiser, that was originally discovered by researchers at the Graz University of Technology in Austria to respond to a separate issue last year.\n\nSpectre will be much more difficult to deal with than issuing a software patch.\n\nThe Meltdown flaw is specific to Intel, but Spectre is a flaw in design that has been used by many processor manufacturers for decades. It affects virtually all microprocessors on the market, including chips made by AMD that share Intel\u2019s design and the many chips based on designs from ARM in Britain.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSpectre is a problem in the fundamental way processors are designed, and the threat from Spectre is \u201cgoing to live with us for decades,\u201d said Mr. Kocher, the president and chief scientist at Cryptography Research, a division of Rambus.\n\n\u201cWhereas Meltdown is an urgent crisis, Spectre affects virtually all fast microprocessors,\u201d Mr. Kocher said. An emphasis on speed while designing new chips has left them vulnerable to security issues, he said.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019ve really screwed up,\u201d Mr. Kocher said. \u201cThere\u2019s been this desire from the industry to be as fast as possible and secure at the same time. Spectre shows that you cannot have both.\u201d\n\nThe Meltdown flaw was discovered by Jann Horn, a security analyst at a Google-run security research group called Google Project Zero, last June. Mr. Horn was the first to alert Intel. The chip giant then heard from other researchers who had also discovered the flaw, including Werner Haas and Thomas Prescher, at Cyberus Technology; and Daniel Gruss, Moritz Lipp, Stefan Mangard and Michael Schwarz at the Graz University of Technology.\n\nThe researchers had been working through the Christmas holiday on a patch, and coordinating with companies like Microsoft and Amazon to roll out the fix.\n\nThe second flaw, Spectre, was also discovered by Mr. Horn at Google and separately by Mr. Kocher, in coordination with Mike Hamburg at Rambus, Mr. Lipp at Graz University and Yuval Yarom at the University of Adelaide in Australia.\n\nA fix may not be available for Spectre until a new generation of chips hit the market.\n\n\u201cThis will be a festering problem over hardware life cycles. It\u2019s not going to change tomorrow or the day after,\u201d Mr. Kocher said. \u201cIt\u2019s going to take a while.\u201d", "title": "Researchers Discover Two Major Flaws in the World\u2019s Computers", "authors": ["Cade Metz", "Nicole Perlroth"]} {"date": "2018-01-08 00:00:00", "text": "LONDON \u2014 The journalist who resigned as the BBC\u2019s China editor to protest the broadcaster\u2019s gender pay gap said on Monday that she was offered a raise before quitting, but one that still did not bring her to the level of her male peers.\n\nThe sudden resignation by Carrie Gracie, the BBC\u2019s top journalist in China, was met with a wave of support from her peers in the British media. It comes with international attention focused on the wider issue of gender disparity, from entrenched differences in compensation to the harassment and, in some cases, assault of women in the workplace.\n\nIt has also fueled renewed criticism of Britain\u2019s publicly funded broadcaster, which last summer published the salaries of its top stars. The data revealed a startling gap in pay between its most senior male and female journalists. In the aftermath of the release of the figures, the BBC\u2019s most senior female journalists demanded the organization take action to close that divide.\n\nOn Monday, Ms. Gracie indicated that any changes so far had not gone far enough. In an interview on BBC radio, she said she had filed an official complaint after the pay data showed that two of her male peers were paid far more than she was.", "title": "Resignation of Carrie Gracie, BBC China Editor, Resurfaces Pay Row", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-13 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Mika and Mr. Robone have talked on the phone about the anonymity they craved after receiving so much attention as victims of high-profile shootings.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t want to be known as Nick Robone, the survivor of Route 91,\u201d Mr. Robone said.\n\nFor Mr. Mika, old acquaintances have stopped and pointed at him when he walks through the hallways of the Capitol. They are, he believes, unsure how to react, whether to ask about Mr. Mika\u2019s recovery or assume he has somehow moved on.\n\n\u201cIt gets old when people say you look good,\u201d he said.\n\nAlong with Mr. Robone and Ms. Anderson, he has become so accustomed to friends\u2019 checking in after mass shootings that Mr. Mika sent the other two a text message the day of the shooting in Sutherland Springs: \u201cHere we go again.\u201d\n\nThe victims of June\u2019s congressional baseball shooting continue to see and counsel one another. Mr. Mika met privately in August with Representative Steve Scalise of Louisiana, the House majority whip, who was gravely wounded. The two compared scars and discussed the small triumphs of their therapy programs.\n\n\u201cHis wife and my girlfriend yell at us because we\u2019re doing too much,\u201d Mr. Mika said with a laugh. \u201cWe\u2019re all trying to get back to some kind of routine, back to what life could be like now.\u201d\n\nHe struck up another unlikely friendship. Jayson Werth, a Washington Nationals outfielder, visited Mr. Mika in the hospital and came away shaken.\n\n\u201cThe baseball field is a sanctuary. That should be a safe place, whether you play it in the sandlot or in high school or college or in the minor leagues,\u201d said Mr. Werth, who regularly exchanges texts with Mr. Mika and meets him for lunch. \u201cI just have a hard time wrapping my head around it.\u201d", "title": "Resisting the Label of Victim, but Forever Scarred by a Mass Shooting", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-15 00:00:00", "text": "When I give pediatric advice to parents, there is always a certain sense of hypocrisy if it was advice that I myself was not consistently successful in following (couldn\u2019t keep a regular schedule for love or money, never successfully put a child in time out, sneaked a borderline sick kid into day care every now and then \u2014 and those are just the ones I\u2019m willing to admit to in public). But once your children are more or less grown up, you are by definition not asking the pediatrician for advice about them. You\u2019re maybe asking your friends what to do \u2014 or quietly resolving not to do whatever your friends are doing.\n\nSo in that friendly spirit, I want to offer some resolutions for parents of grown children, which, like almost all resolutions for parents, will evaporate as soon as my children figure out new ways to test me. That\u2019s the hard thing about family life: Everyone else is always changing the rules on you. Familial resolutions need to be made over and over again. That\u2019s the great thing about family life: You get all those fresh starts.\n\nAnd the special quality of be-a-better-parent resolutions, at any age, is that each contains within it an equal and opposite resolution, in which you realize the limits of conducting family life by rules and resolves, and find yourself swinging back on the great pendulum of life.\n\nResolution No. 1: Be as polite and uncritical as you would be with comparative strangers. I\u2019ve been working on this one for years; it\u2019s the one that encompasses the need to keep quiet about a child\u2019s choice of attire or music or crush object, the way you would about a colleague\u2019s. We are almost all of us able to refrain from needling the people we work with, the people we meet at parties, the people who ask us for directions on the street. It might not seem like a high bar to show that same level of fairly bland and often insincere courtesy toward children, instead of letting them know where there\u2019s room for improvement, but it takes a lot of reminding and a lot of resolving.\n\nEqual and opposite: Go ahead and be yourself every now and then; we\u2019re all family here.\n\nResolution No. 2: Give grown-up children credit for being grown-up. They are more competent than you think. They manage perfectly well when you aren\u2019t around. They solve problems, they manage their lives. If you seize on some convenient (and amusing) example of non \u2014 grown-up behavior (brought dirty laundry home, left the dirty dishes piled up on the counter), you are probably missing a plethora of quiet examples of a young adult navigating the world without making a big fuss about it.", "title": "Resolutions for Parents of Grown Children", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-20 00:00:00", "text": "Resolving the land issue, including compensating white farmers whose properties were later seized, is critical to repairing relations with Western nations and international lenders, which have been virtually frozen for nearly a generation. The new government desperately needs Western assistance to revive the nation\u2019s moribund economy.\n\nDetermining who owns the land is a necessary step to development and democratization in Zimbabwe. Nearly all Zimbabweans who benefited from Mr. Mugabe\u2019s land reform policy lack titles, or legal ownership of their property \u2014 leaving them at the mercy of the politically powerful.\n\nIn his inauguration speech, President Emmerson Mnangagwa \u2014 who, with his military allies, removed Mr. Mugabe, 93, from power \u2014 said that \u201crepossessing our land cannot be challenged or reversed.\u201d\n\nBut Mr. Mnangagwa said that he was \u201ccommitted to compensating those farmers from whom land was taken.\u201d In addition, he said that \u201ccomplex issues of land tenure will have to be addressed\u201d so as \u201cto ensure finality and closure to the ownership and management of this key resource.\u201d\n\nGovernment officials highlighted the case of a white Zimbabwean, Rob Smart, who was allowed to return to his farm in December. But Mr. Smart had lost his farm only six months earlier amid factional fighting inside the ruling party and regained it after Mr. Mnangagwa\u2019s side emerged victorious, not through any policy change.\n\nSo far, the government has yet to take any concrete steps toward compensation or even to meet with representatives of the thousands of former landowners, said Ben Freeth, a leader of white Zimbabweans whose farms were seized.", "title": "Resolving Who Owns What Land Lies at Heart of Zimbabwe\u2019s Future", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "PARIS \u2014 A public letter signed by more than 100 French women that denounced the #MeToo movement has sparked an intense debate in France over everything from the appropriate limits of flirtation to the extent to which the French should absorb American sexual norms.\n\nThe response to the letter, published Tuesday in the newspaper Le Monde and signed by the actress Catherine Deneuve among others, has exposed sharp cultural divides between women who worry about the creation of a culture of victimhood and those who insist that the focus in sexual harassment should be concern for the victims.\n\nAmong those who disagreed with the public letter was Le\u00efla Slimani, a novelist who won France\u2019s top literary award in 2016. \u201cI am not asking to be protected but to exercise my rights to security and respect,\u201d she wrote in the newspaper Lib\u00e9ration on Friday.\n\n\u201cI am not a victim,\u201d Ms. Slimani continued. \u201cBut millions of women are. That is fact and not a moral judgment.\u2019\u2019", "title": "Response to French Letter Denouncing #MeToo Shows a Sharp Divide", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-14 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cFlorida\u2019s 1.5 Million Missing Voters\u201d (editorial, Jan. 3):\n\nWe support the Florida initiative that would re-enfranchise 1.5 million Floridians who have completed their sentences for felony convictions and applaud the editorial board for endorsing it. But the initiative still falls short: Those who have been convicted of murder or sex offenses would still be barred from voting, as would the estimated 200,000 people incarcerated or on parole or probation in Florida.\n\nCriminal justice reform continues to adhere to a false binary of who is worthy versus unworthy. As your editorial mentions, criminal disenfranchisement was adopted to uphold white supremacy. In order for democracy to function, elected officials must be accountable to everyone they represent, which only universal suffrage can ensure. It\u2019s time for Florida\u2019s voters to step up and restore the most fundamental constitutional right to all of their neighbors.\n\nRACHEL COREY, ELLY KALFUS\n\nBOSTON\n\nThe writers are co-founders of Ballots Over Bars, a campaign to re-enfranchise all people incarcerated in Massachusetts.\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nYour editorial is correct that a proposed state constitutional amendment would \u201cautomatically restore voting rights to the vast majority of Floridians\u201d who are disenfranchised because they are felons, but it is quite wrong in asserting that this is a \u201cpointless policy\u201d that is \u201cexplicitly racist.\u201d", "title": "Opinion | Restoring Voting Rights for Felons", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-09 00:00:00", "text": "MEXICO CITY \u2014 Marbella Aguilar keeps her collection of used books tucked into a hidden shelf in her room at Casa Xochiquetzal, a big yellow colonial house in the heart of Mexico City\u2019s bustling downtown.\n\n\u201cI love reading and writing,\u201d said Ms. Aguilar, 61. \u201cPoetry, prose, anything. I can\u2019t go to sleep without my books next to me.\u201d She mentions \u201cLes Mis\u00e9rables\u201d and \u201cLolita\u201d and the works of Pablo Neruda and Leo Tolstoy.\n\nBut her own experiences could fill a book, because she has not had an ordinary life. And Casa Xochiquetzal is no ordinary house: It is a shelter for retired or semiretired prostitutes.\n\nCasa Xochiquetzal, named after the Aztec goddess of beauty and sexual love, opened its doors in 2006 after Carmen Mu\u00f1oz, a former prostitute, discovered some of her former colleagues sleeping under cardboard in La Merced, a popular red-light district nearby. After a lifetime spent working the streets, the women were destitute and alone, and had nowhere to go.\n\nPhoto\n\nPhoto\n\nPhoto\n\nPhoto\n\nMs. Mu\u00f1oz took them in and began looking for allies. A group of prominent Mexican feminists offered to help, and with private and public money, plus a building lent free of charge by the Mexico City Mayor\u2019s Office, they founded Casa Xochiquetzal, a haven where older prostitutes rescued from the streets could live with dignity.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIt is a recurrent fact that family members, even their children, abandon them, even hurt them, when they find out they are sex workers,\u201d said Jesica Vargas Gonz\u00e1lez, the shelter\u2019s director. \u201cIt is still a very stigmatized occupation.\u201d", "title": "Retired From the Brutal Streets of Mexico, Sex Workers Find a Haven", "authors": ["Adriana Zehbrauskas", "Photographs"]} {"date": "2018-01-06 00:00:00", "text": "Milwaukee \u2014 When I retired from daily broadcasting in late 2016, I knew I had to make some serious resolutions. I no longer had to set the alarm for 4:15 a.m., but I didn\u2019t want to sleep so late that I spent the morning walking around the house in a robe. (Trust me, that\u2019ll happen sooner than you think.)\n\nI also knew that I needed to continue to speak out about the bizarre fever that seemed to have gripped my fellow conservatives who had embraced Donald Trump.\n\nOriginally, my plan was to sit in a rocking chair, and after a few weeks to start rocking. But the election wrecked those plans, making retirement in the Era of Trump a complicated affair.\n\nI started thinking about that this past week, when Orrin Hatch, the seven-term Republican senator from Utah, announced that he wouldn\u2019t run for re-election this year. He joins two Republican colleagues, Bob Corker and Jeff Flake, in announcing retirement. Word is that Steve Bannon is also very likely to have a lot more free time on his hands soon, especially since the billionaire Mercer family has cut off his funding, one of the few things that has kept him relevant.", "title": "Opinion | Retirement Tips for the Age of Trump", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-16 00:00:00", "text": "Although a fortunate lack of acute injuries played a role, many in the sport have pointed to the implementation of a new rule that allows injured players to withdraw before taking the court and still receive half of their first-round prize money. The person who takes the injured player\u2019s place, a so-called lucky loser from the qualifying tournament, receives the other half of the first-round money. That money combined with the prize money for reaching the final round of qualifying equals the first-round prize money here: 60,000 Australian dollars, or $47,730.\n\nEven before Mischa Zverev retired in the second set of his first-round match against Hyeon Chung on Tuesday night, there was excitement about the rule\u2019s effect: Four players had taken the opportunity to leave with half of the money.\n\n\u201cWhat has occurred in the first round has shown that the new rule works,\u201d said Craig Tiley, the tournament director. \u201cThe real winner from this is the tennis fan who gets to see high-quality, competitive tennis, and I think the players are embracing it.\u201d\n\nEric Butorac, who served as president of the ATP player council for two years until his retirement at the end of the 2016 season, said the rule change had been \u201ca topic for years\u201d and expressed enthusiasm at its implementation at Grand Slam events, which have been steadily increasing their purses in recent years.\n\nA similar rule at ATP Tour events was introduced last year and proved popular.\n\nThe rules on withdrawals and prize money were thrust into a spotlight at Wimbledon last year, when seven men retired during their first-round matches, including the opponents of Novak Djokovic and Roger Federer in back-to-back matches on Centre Court. That led to disappointed ticket holders and television networks that were shortchanged of hours of premium match play.", "title": "Retirements Are Down at the Australian Open. Is Money the Reason?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "The Justice Department announced on Friday that it intended to retry Senator Robert Menendez of New Jersey, two months after a jury deadlocked on federal corruption charges against him. The move means Mr. Menendez will have to defend himself again in a year when he is up for re-election.\n\nA new trial for Mr. Menendez, a Democrat, who has been in the Senate for 12 years, adds a wrinkle to the political map in this year\u2019s 2018 midterm elections. While the senator has not officially announced that he is running, he has given no indication he intends to retire.\n\nAnother politically damaging trial could put Democrats in the unexpected position of having to spend resources in New Jersey, a reliably Democratic state, in an election in which they are hoping to pick up seats and possibly shift the Senate back to Democratic control. So far, however, no strong Republican challenger has emerged.\n\nMr. Menendez\u2019s office vowed on Friday to again fight the charges, but provided no indication about the senator\u2019s political plans.", "title": "Retrial of Senator Menendez Adds Twist to Midterm Elections", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "BANGKOK \u2014 Two journalists for the Reuters news agency were formally charged in Myanmar with obtaining state secrets, prosecutors said Wednesday, in a case seen as a key test of the country\u2019s nascent political freedoms.\n\nThe reporters, U Wa Lone and U Kyaw Soe Oo, have been accused of violating the Official Secrets Act, a law dating to the British colonial period that carries a maximum punishment of 14 years in prison.\n\nThe journalists were brought to court in Yangon, Myanmar\u2019s commercial capital, where they were arrested on Dec. 12, almost immediately after being given unidentified documents by members of the police.\n\nBefore their arrest, the journalists had been investigating the existence of a mass grave in Rakhine State, where a military campaign against Rohingya Muslims has sent more than 655,000 members of the persecuted minority fleeing to Bangladesh over the past four and a half months.", "title": "Reuters Reporters Are Charged in Myanmar With Obtaining State Secrets", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nA large screen looms over the stage. Projected onto it is a black-and-white close-up on an eyeball, fluttering in a state of nervous distress.\n\nAn overture, powered by distorted electric guitar and staccato strings, accompanies this sooty B-movie-style image. A choir grasps toward high-pitched wails. Everything blares.\n\nGradually, as the onscreen image pulls back, the audience can discern that the twitching eyeball isn\u2019t recorded, but is rather a very much live, high-definition stare at Mikaela Bennett, the soprano at the center of \u201cAcquanetta.\u201d The composer Michael Gordon and librettist Deborah Artman\u2019s old-school-suspenseful \u201cfilmic opera\u201d had its chamber version premiere at the Prototype festival of new opera-theater on Tuesday at the Gelsey Kirkland Arts Center in Dumbo, Brooklyn.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe production\u2019s camera eye \u2014 and the audience\u2019s gaze \u2014 rarely move away from Ms. Bennett over the next 70 minutes in an opera that feels like a major addition to this composer\u2019s canon. A founder of the influential Bang on a Can collective, Mr. Gordon has a history of creating scores that can work alongside moving images. But \u201cAcquanetta\u201d is something different \u2014 and grander.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe plot has a true-story undercurrent. The actress Mildred Davenport, known as Acquanetta, had a celebrated (if necessarily minor) career in 1940s B movies, including the horror film \u201cCaptive Wild Woman\u201d \u2014 elements of which are repurposed in this opera. Its creators describe her career as brief, saying in a program note that she \u201cinexplicably walked away from the Hollywood studio system.\u201d Rather than telling the actress\u2019s biography straight, \u201cAcquanetta\u201d bills itself as a \u201cone-act deconstruction\u201d of the horror genre.", "title": "Review: A B-Movie Starlet Becomes an Opera Diva in \u2018Acquanetta\u2019", "authors": ["Seth Colter Walls"]} {"date": "2018-01-22 00:00:00", "text": "That they have returned makes \u201cThe Homecoming Queen\u201d appear, at first, to be a comedy of deracination. Kelechi is so thoroughly Americanized that when she arrives at her family\u2019s compound she barely recognizes the folkways or even the Igbo words of her youth. A mouthy \u201crough gal\u201d \u2014 as her father, Godwin, calls her \u2014 she can\u2019t help shooing away the interfering aunties who descend upon her to paw through her luggage any more than she can help mocking her father\u2019s grandiosity. (\u201cSeriously, Dad, is the \u2018Coming to America\u2019 chair necessary?\u201d) Cultural appropriation, it seems, is a two-way street.\n\nYou may think from this opening that you know how the rest of the story will go: Kelechi\u2019s alienation will gradually be replaced by a sense of belonging. But the expected trajectory is not the path \u201cThe Homecoming Queen\u201d takes. For one thing, as we learn, Kelechi was not very happy even in the States. Love affairs failed, and the success of her novel, \u201cDe Panta, De Tiger and De Bird,\u201d created too much expectation for a follow-up hit. Her trip home, intended in part to inspire her writing, derails her further. Only with the help of her \u201canxious pills\u201d (as Beatrice, her father\u2019s young housegirl, calls them) does she stave off a breakdown, and then only temporarily.\n\nI don\u2019t want to spoil the surprise of how these four main characters \u2014 Kelechi (Mfoniso Udofia), Obina (Segun Akande), Godwin (Oberon K. A. Adjepong) and Beatrice (Mirirai Sithole) \u2014 are connected beneath the play\u2019s surface. But if the plot is compelling, in some ways echoing Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie\u2019s novel \u201cAmericanah,\u201d it is also sometimes murky; you have to listen hard for the clues to what has happened and also be patient with unmarked detours into flashbacks and fictions. In contrast, too many of the conventionally narrative scenes, especially between Kelechi and Godwin, repeat the same arc, moving predictably from pleasantry to snark to umbrage to apology. They deliver no new emotional information even if they do deliver delight.\n\nThe staging by Awoye Timpo, on a set by Yu-Hsuan Chen that surrounds the audience, could do a better job of ameliorating that problem by differentiating and contouring the material. On the other hand, Ms. Timpo\u2019s work with the principals (who are accompanied by a delightful four-woman chorus playing those gossipy aunties and hymn-singing elders) is exemplary. As Beatrice, Ms. Sithole amply fulfills Kelechi\u2019s description of her as one of those people who, though quiet, \u201cthink loud\u201d; it\u2019s hard not to watch her constantly watching.\n\nI appreciated, too, that the characters\u2019 emotions are not rushed into place as if on a conveyor belt, which often happens in shortish plays. (This one is an hour and 45 minutes.) Though the scene in which Obina asks if he can touch Kelechi appears in the script with no stage direction, the director has encouraged Ms. Udofia and Mr. Akande to take all the time they need. The result is a marvelous three-act opera in the blank space between question and answer.", "title": "Review: A Bumpy Return to Nigeria for \u2018The Homecoming Queen\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "In Debussy\u2019s \u201cLa Mer,\u201d you can almost hear the heaving sea speckled with dawn sunlight, the dancing waves, the gusty winds.\n\nThat\u2019s certainly the painterly, descriptive way audiences are often encouraged to think of this repertory staple. But on Thursday at David Geffen Hall, the Finnish conductor Susanna Malkki led the New York Philharmonic in a performance of the work that was so urgent, detailed and exciting that I forgot all about cresting sea and splashing waves. I was, instead, engrossed by the way Ms. Malkki brought out the colors, intricacies and radicalism of \u201cLa Mer\u201d (1905), which came across as Debussy\u2019s idea for an alternative kind of 20th-century symphony.\n\nMs. Malkki, making her return to the Philharmonic after a belated debut in 2015, certainly drew out the atmospheric sonorities in the subdued music the opens the piece, with the softly rumbling timpani, flecks of harp, heaving low strings and woodwind lines that seem to peek through the mist. But I was more struck by the unusual clarity of the textures, the careful voicing of chords to highlight pungent harmonies. In the final movement, Ms. Malkki deftly balanced the music\u2019s tumultuous frenzy with symphonic majesty, driving headlong to the brassy climax without a trace of cinematic excess.\n\nShe preceded \u201cLa Mer\u201d with the New York concert premiere of Esa-Pekka Salonen\u2019s \u201cHelix,\u201d from 2005, which the composer has described as a nine-minute accelerando. The music starts tentatively, with halting chords, eerie blips and a strange, tolling bass riff. Moment by moment, this dark music gains intensity and volume, as jerky rhythms break out and fragments try to coalesce into phrases. It hurtles to a dizzying, blazing final stretch, played to the hilt here.\n\nThe concert began with a vanishingly rare sight at the Philharmonic: two women appearing together as concerto soloist and conductor. The brilliant Latvian violinist Baiba Skride gave a magnificent account of Tchaikovsky\u2019s Violin Concerto. Her distinctive sound \u2014 full-bodied and sumptuous but never forced \u2014 ideally suited the passages of melting lyricism and nobility. She brought tender grace to the rueful slow movement. And, with the alert Ms. Malkki there to keep the orchestra right with her, Ms. Skride tore through the breathless finale with impetuous energy and impressive precision.\n\nThis season Ms. Malkki began her tenure as principal guest conductor of the Los Angeles Philharmonic. If only she had that post here in New York.", "title": "Review: A Conductor\u2019s Exciting Return to the New York Philharmonic", "authors": ["Anthony Tommasini"]} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "It wasn\u2019t difficult to grasp where she was going with her movement, which was highlighted by loose joints: Knees bent into deep pli\u00e9s and arms rippled out like slippery fabric. The men, at times, became rubbery acrobats, bending, buckling and then springing back to life.\n\nBut where was the composition? The frequent sight of evenly spaced dancers, dressed simply in grays and blacks, was overly static. By the time Ms. Acosta\u2019s solo rolled around, it seemed as if the dance was finally starting. It was too late.\n\nAfter \u201cOcaso,\u201d a duet by Mr. Delgado that he performed with Ms. Carrazana \u2014 a disappointing array of emotionless embraces and melting falls to the floor \u2014 the program closed with Ms. Tayeh\u2019s \u201cFace the Torrent.\u201d Set in an apocalyptic world, it featured eight dancers moving from the back to the front of the stage over and over again under hazy spotlights.\n\nThis repeated action \u2014 steps in slow motion \u2014 was more menacing than mesmerizing. Throughout, the dancer Abel Rojo, striking and sinuous, slipped out of the group clutching his head or hinging down to the floor. A score by the cellist Colette Alexander, with the musical group the Bengsons, featured whispered words \u2014 among them \u201cquivering\u201d and \u201cshivering\u201d \u2014 that gradually became clear with repetition.\n\n\u201cFace the Torrent\u201d did send a certain chill down the spine, but it shouldn\u2019t have lasted longer than a music video. It was aiming for a sinister effect that came down to little more than posturing; this was right out of the \u201cSo You Think You Can Dance\u201d handbook. (Ms. Tayeh has choreographed for the show.) And like every dance on the program, \u201cFace the Torrent\u201d ended with a clich\u00e9: Dancers fixing a stare at the audience before turning away abruptly. In a company with three directors, one of them should have pointed it out.", "title": "Review: A Cuban Troupe\u2019s Strong Dancers, Less Strong Premieres", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-17 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nIs it just me, or has there been a surfeit of bel canto repertory at the Metropolitan Opera in recent years? To judge from the number of empty seats and the lack of buzz at the revival of Donizetti\u2019s \u201cL\u2019Elisir d\u2019Amore\u201d (\u201cThe Elixir of Love\u201d) in Bartlett Sher\u2019s staging on Tuesday evening, despite an excellent cast of singers, others may agree.\n\nThe Sher production itself \u2014 though serviceable and mostly attractive to the eye, with sets by Michael Yeargan and costumes by Catherine Zuber \u2014 breaks no new ground and created little stir when new, opening the Met\u2019s 2012-13 season, or in earlier revivals.\n\nWhat excitement there was here centered on the leads, the South African soprano Pretty Yende, as Adina in her role debut at the Met, and the American tenor Matthew Polenzani, as Nemorino, the role he sang at that 2012 opening. And in Ms. Yende\u2019s case, it was hard not to look past this performance a bit to April, when she will take over the more demanding and telling title role in the company\u2019s production of Donizetti\u2019s \u201cLucia di Lammermoor.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nStill, she brought a winning combination of elegance and spunk to the part of the farm owner Adina in her amorous jousting with the ardent peasant Nemorino and the bullying sergeant Belcore. Ms. Yende sang beautifully from the start, gaining warmth and depth as nonchalance and flirtatiousness developed into love. She deftly executed the acrobatics at the end, with joyous, tumbling high roulades.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Polenzani was a worthy foil, singing with pliant strength and clarion tone while tracing his character\u2019s shifting moods and dispositions, from love-struck, clumsy confusion to puffed-up confidence, owing to what he thinks is a love potion when he is in fact getting drunk on cheap wine.\n\nAfter all that, Mr. Polenzani summoned melting emotion in his second-act showpiece, \u201cUna furtiva lagrima,\u201d fondling and polishing the tone like a fine jewel. As it invariably does when well executed, the aria brought down even this relatively staid house.\n\nPhoto\n\nIldebrando D\u2019Arcangelo was bluff and entertaining as the traveling snake-oil salesman Dulcamara, Davide Luciano proved suitably overbearing as Belcore, and Ashley Emerson was a lovely Giannetta.\n\nThe Venezuelan conductor Domingo Hindoyan, in his house debut, moved things along nicely and drew sharp responsiveness from the orchestra. A slight disunity in the crowd scenes at the beginning and end of Act II will probably sort itself out in future performances.", "title": "Review: A Donizetti Revival at the Met Hints at More to Come", "authors": ["James R. Oestreich"]} {"date": "2018-01-14 00:00:00", "text": "What sounds like an intricate radio drama from the world beyond (Helen Atkinson is the sound designer) occasionally penetrates their activities, as do shards of crazy pop hits and tidal waves of somber, romantic music (by Teho Teardo). But One and Two are so removed from what we think of as reality, that when a buzzing housefly invades their precincts, One doesn\u2019t have a clue as to what it is.\n\nPeople familiar with other work by Mr. Walsh, whose early \u201cDisco Pigs\u201d opened recently in a revival at the Irish Repertory Theater, may sense that they\u2019ve been here before. A dramatist of ferociously specific imagination, Mr. Walsh revels in placing bewildered but feisty characters in hermetically sealed environments, creating what might be described as ontological equivalents of the locked room mystery.\n\nHis \u201cThe Walworth Farce,\u201d in which an Irish family of men repeatedly acts out the same play in a crumbling London flat, is the most obvious forebear of \u201cBallyturk.\u201d Seen at St. Ann\u2019s Warehouse in 2008, \u201cWalworth\u201d was a wild ride of a play, for sure, with its author\u2019s distinctive cocktail (Molotov) of madcap stagecraft and verbal fireworks.\n\nPhoto\n\nBut \u201cWalworth\u201d was \u2014 to use a metaphor Mr. Walsh\u2019s agoraphobic characters would no doubt recoil from \u2014 a walk in the park compared to \u201cBallyturk,\u201d which was first staged in Galway, Ireland, in 2014. The head-scratching ghost of Samuel Beckett, and the more sinister spirit of Harold Pinter, haunt \u201cBallyturk,\u201d which traffics unapologetically in literature\u2019s biggest theme.\n\nI mean the point or pointlessness of life in the face of death, and how we avoid and embrace our ultimate ends. And, particularly, how people block the view of mortality with small talk and its physical equivalents. As Two observes toward the play\u2019s conclusion, all he and One have been doing with their elaborate fantasies of their fantasy village has been \u201cfilling a room with words.\u201d\n\nBy that time, One and Two have been forced into a reckoning of sorts by the arrival of a suave stranger in a trench coat. Call her Three; the script does. Embodied with the silken swagger of a film noir villain by Olwen Fou\u00e9r\u00e9, Three makes one hell of an entrance.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nShe also talks like an infernal angel, shifting to song (the nightclub standard \u201cTime After Time,\u201d with good reason) when a microphone drops from the skies. What she has to say \u2014 about giving \u201clife purpose by reaching its edge\u201d \u2014 is pure poetry and oh-so alarming to a pair of chaps who have been doing their best to sustain their daily rituals of make-believe.\n\n\u201cBallyturk\u201d is so verbally dense that it\u2019s possible to be hypnotized, if not numbed, by some of its lush spoken arias. Even at 90 minutes, it would be better shorter.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFortunately, Mr. Walsh\u2019s plays by no means live exclusively by the words he so adores and reviles. As a director, he knows how to weave a web of images that defy language. And he infuses them with a kinetic charge that equally brings to mind the mayhem of Mack Sennett and the shadows of Ingmar Bergman. (The crucial lighting is by Adam Silverman.)\n\nFor a spirited summing up of the frantic emptiness of our daily routines, it\u2019s hard to match the sight of Mr. Murphy and Mr. Murfi (even the actors\u2019 names match the vaudevillian sensibility) going through the morning motions of getting dressed, having breakfast, cleaning up and exercising. This is all conducted at a fast-forward tempo with the 1982 ABC pop hit \u201cThe Look of Love,\u201d and it is pure, moronic bliss.\n\nIt\u2019s hard to imagine a successful version of \u201cBallyturk\u201d without Mr. Walsh presiding, obsessively, as director. As it is, the line between his characters marking time and a writer filling space can feel irritatingly thin.\n\nBut no matter your immediate response to \u201cBallyturk,\u201d it is likely to take up residence in your thoughts after you\u2019ve seen it. I\u2019ve been finding it hard to banish that first, icy image of Three, seen as if at the end of an airless and light-stripped tunnel. For all the teetering towers of language that the boys of \u201cBallyturk\u201d build for themselves, the last word here, as it is in life, is beyond words.", "title": "Review: A Fantasy Town Builds a Wall Against Time in \u2018Ballyturk\u2019", "authors": ["Ben Brantley"]} {"date": "2018-01-15 00:00:00", "text": "The NYC Winter Jazzfest Marathon presented over 100 sets at 11 locations across two nights last weekend. I saw more than two dozen of those. That sounds like a small fraction, but I probably should have done less.\n\nNow in its 14th year, the festival is a broad and generous sampler of jazz\u2019s new specialty dishes: Everyone from oft-neglected elders to rising voices gets their due. Typically, if you only hear a fragment of every set, that\u2019s O.K. You\u2019re just there to get a taste.\n\nBut this year was different, for a few reasons. Somehow, despite the expanding attendance (nearly 9,000 visitors across two nights), there were rarely any lines outside a show. And once you were inside, the listening experiences were better; crowds appeared less put-upon and more engaged. This was the first year that it seemed like a good idea to stay where you were for a long period of time \u2014 or, at most, walk to one of the venues within a close distance.\n\nThere were trade-offs: The festival these days has an outsize footprint, extending all the way from the Bowery Ballroom on the Lower East Side to the New School on 13th Street, nearly a half-hour away on foot. At some point, you were likely to throw up your hands and accept that you were just going to miss that act you thought you had to see. But these are good problems.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIf you did bounce around, you found happy resonances. Some artists presented multiple projects at different stages (something that hasn\u2019t happened in years past), and headliners often reappeared as side musicians in other people\u2019s bands. That\u2019s something Winter Jazzfest does beautifully: It shows you the interwoven, recombinant flow that has always given jazz its messy social coherence, even in today\u2019s unboxable age.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe British tenor saxophonist Shabaka Hutchings had performed with the Comet Is Coming at Winter Jazzfest\u2019s opening night last Wednesday (outside of the marathon, the festival features nightly concerts through Wednesday), and on Night 1 of the marathon he blasted through a set with Sons of Kemet, a quartet featuring two drummers and a tuba, played by Theon Cross. Mr. Hutchings scraped his way skyward as Mr. Cross took hold of a beat located somewhere between the Balkans and the Middle East, raising the tension as the drummers chafed against him in a stutter-step pattern.\n\nPhoto\n\nAt Nublu, the drummer Susie Ibarra played lovely, wandering music from \u201cPerception,\u201d her new album, accompanied by cello, violin, guitar, voice, bass, Fender Rhodes and electronics. At one point, she hunkered down and focused on the toms and cymbals, playing with alert, custodial care, hitting them with one hand and quickly muting them with the other. Later, as the cello and violin plucked bluesy, hurrying phrases \u2014 like cinematic balladry and Romanticism and Ray Nance all run together \u2014 Ms. Ibarra put down her sticks and played with only her hands and feet, smacking a drumhead with her palm and thumping the kick drum.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Louder Newsletter Every week, stay on top of the latest in pop and jazz with reviews, interviews, podcasts and more from The New York Times music critics. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThere was so much going on in Ms. Ibarra\u2019s set, Claudia Acu\u00f1a\u2019s voice was only one element in a humid swarm. By that point, partway into Saturday night, I was sensing a subtle theme: The role of the voice in jazz is going through a process of liberation these days. It\u2019s tied to a lot of things \u2014 the upending of gender stereotypes; a re-engagement with social questions; a willingness to loosen up on the self-policing instinct that has hemmed in a lot of jazz activity, from the mainstream to the stylistic outskirts \u2014 and at Winter Jazzfest it delivered some welcome surprises.", "title": "Review: A Jazzfest Marathon Where Voices Lead the Way to Resistance and Renewal", "authors": ["Giovanni Russonello"]} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "The solemnity of this exchange \u2014 with its lilting piano chords and the Raphaelite tranquillity of Ariane\u2019s face \u2014 suggests that Mr. Garrel sincerely believes this about women, which would be fine if his characters were more convincingly individual. Yet even though each is given a moment (a near-suicide, one affair and then another), Jeanne, Ariane and Gilles stick to a disappointingly familiar script. While Jeanne embraces her role as the dejected, apparently unconscious daughter with daddy issues, Ariane plays the part of the free-spirited object of a rather different kind of paternal desire. Gilles, meanwhile, settles into the role of the obliging patriarch who\u2019s hot or warm as needed.\n\nThere are times when the characters \u2014 and their director \u2014 surprise and genuinely delight. In one heart-piercingly elegiac sequence, Jeanne and Gilles head off together, leaving Ariane behind. As he does elsewhere in the film, Mr. Garrel introduces this interlude with a lovely piano flourish and a few words from the intermittent narrator (Laetitia Spigarelli): \u201cThat evening, Gilles went out with his daughter.\u201d The voice-over briefly suggests the start of a once-upon-a-time story, yet as Jeanne and Gilles walk and talk, the scene becomes something far more enchanting: two people whose unforced intimacy speaks to a bond that feels shaped by a shared history rather than clich\u00e9s.\n\nAnd then Gilles asks, \u201cWhat will you do with your life?\u201d He and Jeanne have stopped walking, and, as they stand facing each other on a quiet sidewalk, you sense that something consequential is about to happen. They\u2019re in long shot, the dark night holding them as if in an embrace. When Jeanne asks why Gilles cares, the camera begins quickly moving toward them, as if matching your desire to hear the answer. \u201cBecause,\u201d Gilles says, his hands now gently cupping his daughter\u2019s face, \u201cI gave you that life.\u201d Oftentimes in this film, the third in a Garrel trilogy that includes \u201cJealousy\u201d and \u201cIn the Shadow of Women,\u201d the characters merely speak words. Here, they \u2014 and you \u2014 feel them.", "title": "Review: A Man and a Woman (and Another Woman) in \u2018Lover for a Day\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "A pregnant Mexican woman with a small son is determined to reunite her family and join her husband in America. She wants her new child to be born an American, with both parents present. So she hires a smuggler to take her and the boy north. But the arduous journey weakens her. She dies en route in the desert.\n\nThis could be a wrenching personal story ripped from today\u2019s news to illustrate the struggles of undocumented immigrants who feel strong bonds to their homeland but want to get ahead in America.\n\nIt\u2019s actually a central plotline of what has been called the first mariachi opera, \u201cCruzar la Cara de la Luna\u201d (\u201cTo Cross the Face of the Moon\u201d), with music by Jos\u00e9 (Pepe) Mart\u00ednez (who died in 2016) and lyrics by Mart\u00ednez and the playwright Leonard Foglia, who also wrote the book. In its New York premiere, the reconstituted New York City Opera is presenting the work, which opened on Thursday in the Rose Theater at Jazz at Lincoln Center.\n\n\u201cCruzar\u201d was commissioned and introduced by the Houston Grand Opera in 2010. At the time, long-simmering debates over immigration gave the piece enormous resonance. But few involved in the current New York run could have imagined the extent to which these issues would be roiling American politics and society at this very moment.", "title": "Review: A Mariachi Opera Addresses Roiling Issues of Immigration", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-22 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nWhether thought of as an emotional weapon, a psychological state or simply the most profoundly irritating behavior that a colleague or family member can manifest, passive aggression is a fancy name for something we are all familiar with. The term dates to 1945, when it was used by the military psychiatrist William Menninger to define the attitude of sulky, balky soldiers.\n\nBut passive aggression, as a sly and infuriating art, has surely never been practiced as entertainingly as it is in a certain high school faculty lounge in Garrison, Ohio, where a group of teachers are doing their teeth-gritting darnedest to get along. Such is the setting for \u201cMiles for Mary,\u201d a priceless portrait of accumulating anger in the workplace from the Mad Ones, which opened on Monday at Playwrights Horizons.\n\nFirst staged at the Bushwick Starr in Brooklyn in the fall of 2016, \u201cMiles for Mary\u201d unfolds as a series of meetings, held over several months in the late 1980s, to organize a local annual telethon for sports scholarships. (The well-worn, cluttered gym room in which they assemble, designed by Amy Rubin, exudes the claustrophobia of the too-familiar.) Like many office meetings, they are conducted according to specific rules of order.\n\nThese have been established to keep the participants from speaking out of turn, dominating the proceedings at the expense of others, and generally acting \u201cinappropriately,\u201d to use an enduring, catchall catchword. Psychological safety valves have been set up \u2014 under a rubric that includes, in addition to that kindergarten standby \u201ctimeout,\u201d \u201ctake a two\u201d and \u201creal-time check-in\u201d \u2014 to allow for the release and defusing of tensions.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAs anyone knows who regularly participates in that most infernal of time-devouring sessions, the staff meeting, such devices have a way of transforming group encounters into pressure cookers. Putting a jargon-laden lid on aggressive behavior pretty much guarantees that the lid is eventually going to blow.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Subscribe to the Theater Newsletter Every week, stay on top of the latest news, interviews and reviews from Broadway and beyond. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nCreated by the Mad Ones\u2019 ensemble members and its director, Lila Neugebauer, \u201cMiles for Mary\u201d is both a happy product of and a ruthless portrait of the collaborative process. It also turns out to present a most ingenious acting challenge, in which rage and resentment may be expressed only indirectly.", "title": "Review: A Master Class in Passive Aggression in \u2018Miles for Mary\u2019", "authors": ["Ben Brantley"]} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "When accomplished performers bring years of dedication to classic works, it can feel ungrateful to ask for more. Yet I couldn\u2019t help wanting more on Thursday evening, when the pianist and conductor Jeffrey Kahane led the New York Philharmonic in Mozart, Tchaikovsky and Haydn at David Geffen Hall. While the program was finely executed, it felt safe and predictable, a nostalgia trip to 18th-century Vienna, with a latter-day homage to that era by Tchaikovsky tossed in.\n\nIt was all excellently done. Though the dynamic cellist Alisa Weilerstein first played Tchaikovsky\u2019s \u201cRococo\u201d Variations with the Cleveland Orchestra over two decades ago, when she was 13, her performance here had engaging spontaneity and freedom. She brought plenty of grace to the piece\u2019s evocations of rococo style. But during the virtuosic variations, especially the breathless coda, Ms. Weilerstein\u2019s playing had incisive attack, manic energy, and, when called for, rough, bristling tone.", "title": "Review: A Nostalgia Trip at the New York Philharmonic", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "Above all, she respects the bel canto tradition out of which this opera emerged. Her Azucena is a creation of soaring high notes, fluttering trills, seductive legato, chilling low tones. These never feel like effects; they are the building blocks she uses to form the character.\n\nWithout stinting the role\u2019s brutality, Ms. Rachvelishvili is often delicate and responsive to the generous length of Verdian lines. She makes the words bite. She is sometimes ethereal. She is sometimes, even more than earthy, elemental. Amazingly, given Azucena\u2019s unending desperation, she is elegant.\n\nShe is the revelation in this revival of David McVicar\u2019s effective, efficient 2009 production. (This is the fourth McVicar staging at the Met this season and the third this month; surely the company\u2019s audience would be well served by a broader range of directorial approaches than his starkish period-dress naturalism.)\n\nBut Ms. Rachvelishvili is not the only highlight in a treat of a \u201cTrovatore.\u201d Under Marco Armiliato, the orchestra plays with spirited polish. The baritone Quinn Kelsey, an aristocratic but fierce Count di Luna, has a distinctive tone: rich but smoky \u2014 even, excitingly, a little hollow, as if you\u2019re always hearing him in an empty, echoey church.", "title": "Review: A Surprise Star Steals the Met\u2019s \u2018Il Trovatore\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "The act of whispering is always a little mysterious. Someone may whisper to share an intimacy, or make a confession, or be seductive. But if it goes on, whispering soon becomes annoying, even aggressive. You want to shout out: \u201cJust say what you mean!\u201d\n\nThat tense ambiguity permeates David Lang\u2019s \u201cthe whisper opera,\u201d which opened at the N.Y.U. Skirball Center on Wednesday and runs through Feb. 4. Mr. Lang\u2019s aim in this 65-minute piece, he explains in a program note, was to write something so quiet and personal that the audience would need to be right next to the performers to hear anything at all. A few years after its New York premiere in 2013 at Lincoln Center\u2019s Mostly Mozart festival, \u201cthe whisper opera\u201d felt even more eerily intimate in this revival, again directed and designed by Jim Findlay.\n\nA soprano, the closest this opera has to a protagonist, mostly walks across intersecting white platforms, amid white lace curtains that billow as she passes. She sometimes hums softly but mostly whispers cryptic phrases and fragments of sentences. The words themselves are often unclear, especially when she wanders away from you.\n\nPhoto\n\nFour members of the International Contemporary Ensemble, playing a cello, various flutes, clarinets and percussion, produce myriad hushed sounds, sometimes scratching their nails or rubbing their hands on cymbals or on suspended bass drums, and playing halting motifs that almost form lyrical phrases. During more intense episodes, the instruments align into softly pungent chords or a bit of contrapuntal interplay.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMore than mere accompanists, these players are participants in the drama, following the singer across the platforms with their instruments, and often whispering their own indistinct phrases. All of them on Wednesday, especially the flutist Claire Chase and the cellist Chris Gross, were compelling actors. (The soprano Alice Teyssier is alternating performances with the haunting Tony Arnold, whom I heard \u2014 and didn\u2019t \u2014 and other members of the ensemble are also taking on instrumental \u201croles\u201d through the run.)", "title": "Review: A Whispered Opera Requests Your Close-Up Attention", "authors": ["Anthony Tommasini"]} {"date": "2018-01-04 00:00:00", "text": "LONDON \u2014 The most uncanny thing of all about the National Theater production of \u201cPinocchio\u201d \u2014 a show that is wondrously strange from top to bottom \u2014 is how simple it appears. This may seem an unlikely characterization of an obviously expensive musical, replete with special effects that brim well over the edges of the National\u2019s vast Lyttelton stage.\n\nYet this adaptation of the 1940 animated Walt Disney classic, directed by John Tiffany and designed by Bob Crowley, exudes the rough magic of a world that seems shaped, by hand and before your eyes, from rudimentary elements. Step ladders, strings and ropes, blocks of wood, the letters of the alphabet: Such is the basic visual vocabulary that is deployed to retell the familiar story of an existentially challenged puppet\u2019s quest to become human.\n\nIn this regard, \u201cPinocchio\u201d comes into being as if through the eyes of a child, whose gaze transforms the mundane into whatever the imagination (and perhaps the Jungian subconscious) wills. The show\u2019s scale, too, is that of a little boy for whom the world looms dauntingly and tantalizingly large, where grown-ups appear as giants who are not entirely real. Or not as real, in any case, as a child\u2019s own sovereign self.\n\nFor while the marionette of the title is portrayed by a fully grown adult actor (the perfectly cast newcomer Joe Idris-Roberts), he is less than half the size of many of the figures with whom he shares the stage. That includes the artisan father who carved him into life, Geppetto (Mark Hadfield), and the mysterious, otherworldly guardian known as the Blue Fairy (Annette McLaughlin).", "title": "Review: A Wondrous \u2018Pinocchio\u2019 With That \u2018Lion King\u2019 Magic", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-31 00:00:00", "text": "Bare-chested and dressed in loose white culottes, the 13 men of Compagnie Herv\u00e9 Koubi move throughout \u201cWhat the Day Owes to the Night\u201d in ways that suggest the slowly shifting contours of sand dunes or the sudden spins of desert whirlwinds. The juxtaposition of contrasting speeds and shapes is mesmerizing. And the virtuosity of those rotations \u2014 the men turn, upside down, on either both hands or one, so unexpectedly and so fast that you can\u2019t quite see what they\u2019re doing or how \u2014 is a touch of theatrical magic. The costumes, by Guillaume Gabriel, easily flare into the air; the lighting, by Lionel Buzonie, suggests the shimmering heat of a mirage.\n\nOn Tuesday, the production\u2019s opening night at the Joyce Theater, Mr. Koubi prefaced the performance with a charming speech from the front of the auditorium. He explained that he is French-born but (as the name Koubi may suggest) of Algerian descent. When he asked about his ancestry, his father, a man of few words, merely showed him an old photograph of a man in Arab attire.\n\nThis led the audience to expect a work of ethnic nostalgia, a search for a lost culture. Instead, with no sense of longing or loss to frame it, \u201cWhat the Day Owes,\u201d a 2013 work that has been performed at Jacob\u2019s Pillow and elsewhere in the United States, is simply a coherent world, a reimagining of an all-male North African society that offers athleticism but no labor.\n\nPhoto\n\nOthers may see less desert imagery than I do and more urban and extra-African suggestions. These performers, all with powerful upper-body musculature, are street dancers; the upside-down spins like those you find in break dancing. Some of the hurtling upside-down jumps are those usually associated with capoeira, the Brazilian martial arts genre. And, toward the end, some of the men start to spin \u2014 upright this time \u2014 on the spot in the off-kilter upper-body stance of dervishes.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nI doubt whether this diversity of cultural reference is strictly apposite to Mr. Koubi\u2019s Algerian quest. But \u201cWhat the Day Owes\u201d immediately presents itself as a work of fantasy, and is best relished as such. Impersonally, the men support one another; there are some spectacular lifts, throws and catches. It\u2019s a hybrid, not so much timeless as time-traveling, with a score ranging from Sufi music to Bach.\n\nHaving fallen in love with \u201cWhat the Day Owes\u201d in the first two minutes, I found that it didn\u2019t deepen my love after the first 15. There are a couple of moments when you can see what\u2019s coming. (Men held high by others are going to fall and be caught.) And there are several later effects \u2014 those dervish spins \u2014 that look like afterthoughts, not organic parts of the whole. Though the piece goes through changes of tempo, it loses momentum here and there in its 65-minute duration.", "title": "Review: A Work That Conjures Desert Sands and Whirlwinds", "authors": ["Alastair Macaulay"]} {"date": "2018-01-28 00:00:00", "text": "Part thriller, part coming-of-age story, \u201cThe Thing With Feathers\u201d is about chickens coming home to roost. The play fatally falls apart at the end, but Mr. Organ keeps us entertained for a good long while before that, making us guess and guess again about what, exactly, is going on here.\n\nAt the start, Anna and her mother, Beth (DeAnna Lenhart), are thriving. On their own since Anna was little, they are unusually close. They seem to skirt the prickly confrontations that come with adolescence \u2014 though Anna is, in the way of so many teenagers, a master of casually if affectionately withering condescension.\n\nBeth, a real estate agent, has finally found a truly good man, a cop named Tim (Robert Manning Jr.) who is calm, dependable, strong \u2014 and, she\u2019s certain, about to propose. Eric (Zachary Booth) has romantic intentions, too, but he is a far more damaged creature. When he shows up uninvited at their house, forcing a face-to-face meeting with Anna, what he wants and what kind of danger he poses are unclear. He has precisely calculated the detonating impact he intends to have.\n\nAbout that title, though. \u201cThe Thing With Feathers\u201d is also a Dickinson reference, and Mr. Organ is mistaken in clinging to it. The later sections of the play feel contrived in a way that nothing that comes before does; he is determined to let a concept \u2014 the allusion to hope in that poem\u2019s title \u2014 rule the action. But the characters, sprung to life, have long since taken over.", "title": "Review: An Online Chat Turns Unnerving in \u2018The Thing With Feathers\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "But eventually Lydia\u2019s plan goes awry, as does every alternative (a New Age hospital?) she improvises to save it. Same with \u201cCardinal.\u201d It so outstrips its gears \u2014 trying almost anything to keep the story heading toward the author\u2019s themes \u2014 that you may experience severe bumps if you stick around for the whole ride.\n\nThis is surprising, coming from Mr. Pierce. His earlier plays, including his 2012 debut, \u201cSlowgirl,\u201d reflect the qualities \u2014 patience with plot, modesty with character \u2014 that make him a fine short story writer. Working of late with the composer John Kander, he has devised the book and lyrics for musicals, like \u201cKid Victory,\u201d that find grave darkness in the frozen heart of small town America.\n\nBy comparison, the disposition of \u201cCardinal\u201d is antic, even before it gets out of hand. It\u2019s an amusing twist that Lydia, who means to be a do-gooder, is really a classic carpetbagger, tone deaf to the needs of the town she once did everything she could to escape. (She thanks the struggling voters for listening to her pitch by giving them complimentary copies of Italo Calvino\u2019s \u201cInvisible Cities.\u201d) But by the time the plot involves her with a Chinese-American entrepreneur, who swoops in with tour buses and dumpling shops to reap the rewards Lydia hoped would accrue to the town, Mr. Pierce\u2019s concerns have twisted hers into an incomprehensible M\u00f6bius strip.\n\nJeff, too, is dragged down that path, transforming from a sweet underachiever (who once had scurvy) to a vengeful husk \u2014 and then back again. The same thing happens to the characters in both subplots. In the one involving the entrepreneur (Stephen Park) and his son (Eugene Young), a benignly comic caricature veers close to bad-guy Orientalism before veering back for a sentimental ending. And in the one involving a bakery owner (Becky Ann Baker) and her autistic son (Alex Hurt), traits and actions fail to jibe, especially as those actions take a hard right turn toward another genre entirely.\n\nThe tonal lurching makes \u201cCardinal\u201d feel whimsical and even a bit aleatory, like a John Cage sonata. Yet I have to believe that a playwright as sophisticated as Mr. Pierce has made these baffling, disruptive choices meaningfully. Though the bakery is cutely called Bread & Buttons, and sells crocheted monkeys and mittens along with the scones, he is not just satirizing small town America, with its hopeless reinvention schemes and hapless part-time politicians. He\u2019s after something larger about the unintended consequences of capitalism on both individuals and societies: meant to be a cure-all, it is too often a comeuppance.", "title": "Review: Anna Chlumsky and Adam Pally Paint the Town Red in \u2018Cardinal\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-22 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nIt\u2019s a warped sign of progress, perhaps, that the work-obsessed mother who neglects her child has achieved parity on television with the absentee father. The latest example is a detective, Annie Ryder, played by Anna Paquin in the new WGN America series \u201cBellevue\u201d (starting Tuesday). Reckless, relentless and plagued by childhood demons, Annie becomes so deeply involved in the show\u2019s eight-episode-long mystery that she risks losing custody of her daughter.\n\n\u201cBellevue,\u201d originally shown by the Canadian network CBC, is typical of its genre \u2014 the contemporary prestige mystery series \u2014 in some positive ways. It\u2019s handsomely shot, competently directed and, when the writing allows, generally well acted.\n\nBut it\u2019s markedly derivative. Like the fictional English town of Broadchurch, in the BBC America drama of the same name, the fictional Canadian town of Bellevue has a striking topography, an abundance of secrets and an assortment of stock village characters \u2014 the hockey coach, the priest, the suspicious mayor \u2014 that make up the pool of suspects.\n\nThe story also recalls \u201cBroadchurch,\u201d as well as AMC\u2019s \u201cThe Killing,\u201d introducing a missing child and connecting that case to a long-ago murder in a way that dredges up buried trauma in half the town, including Annie.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cBellevue\u201d doesn\u2019t do a bad job with chilly small-town menace, if that\u2019s what you\u2019re looking for. But unlike the better mysteries it evokes, it seems to have been run through a plot-generating machine \u2014 insert number of episodes, number of investigative breakthroughs per episode and extent of conspiracy, and voil\u00e0. The writers decided to spring for not one but two bonus credulity-stretching late twists.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box.
