View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThey also add a little David Fincher flavor by having an unseen character feed Annie information in the form of gnomic riddles. (One clue will be found \u201cwhere the hypocrites weekly wear the mask of good,\u201d for instance.)\n\nMs. Paquin, at her best (as in Kenneth Lonergan\u2019s film \u201cMargaret\u201d), has a rare ability to communicate intensity and complex, conflicting emotions. That\u2019s probably how the show\u2019s creators, Jane Maggs and Adrienne Mitchell, envisioned Annie, but what ended up onscreen is a half-sketched, formulaic character that Ms. Paquin can only occasionally make convincing.", "title": "Review: Anna Paquin Takes Her Turn as a Detective in \u2018Bellevue\u2019", "authors": ["Mike Hale"]} {"date": "2018-01-28 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nWesterners have learned a lot in recent decades about Chinese contemporary music as it relates to our own, mainly through an influx of gifted Chinese composers and performers. But as the Juilliard School\u2019s Focus! Festival 2018 showed over the last week, we still don\u2019t know the half of it.\n\nJoel Sachs, the event\u2019s director, chose the subject, \u201cChina Today: A Festival of Chinese Composition,\u201d because the school is about to establish a campus in Tianjin, a city of 15 million near Beijing. And he unearthed a rich source, to judge from a scintillating chamber concert on Jan. 22 and the sensational orchestral concert that concluded the festival on Friday.\n\nMr. Sachs set out, he wrote in the program booklet, \u201cabove all to feature composers living and working in China.\u201d But the music had to use mostly Western instruments, specifically those taught at Juilliard, since the goal of this annual festival is to involve the students with new music.\n\nThe stunningly visceral final concert, with the Juilliard Orchestra conducted by Chen Lin in Alice Tully Hall, presented three works by veteran composers in their 60s or older (Zhu Jian-er died, at 94, in August). Two of them offered striking exceptions to the exclusion of indigenous instruments.\n\nPhoto\n\nGuo Wenjing\u2019s \u201cWild Grass\u201d (2006), here in its Western Hemisphere premiere, is a concerto for erhu, a two-stringed fiddle played upright in the performer\u2019s lap. Buskers in subway stations have made its penetrating sound familiar to many New Yorkers. As it happens, the Taiwanese-born violist Wei-Yang Andy Lin, who received bachelor\u2019s and master\u2019s degrees from Juilliard, is also a virtuoso on the erhu, and he gave a brilliant performance.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Zhu\u2019s Symphony No. 5 (1991; revised 2001), in its first performance outside China, included an extended cadenza for big dagu drums. By and large, percussionists will happily whack anything that moves, regardless of national origin. But Harrison Honor, a principal percussionist in the orchestra, went beyond that, evidently having mastered a particular rolling-thunder style also heard in performances by the Japanese drumming troupe Kodo.", "title": "Review: At Juilliard Festival, the Stunning Sounds of China Today", "authors": ["James R. Oestreich"]} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nDakota Fanning is now 23, yet still has the air of a fragile child. And in Ben Lewin\u2019s \u201cPlease Stand By,\u201d that sometimes brittle vulnerability serves her well as Wendy, a young woman with autism who dreams of leaving her group home in San Francisco and living with her married sister and baby niece. Yet despite her commitment to the role \u2014 and the generally fine supporting performances \u2014 this timorous tale sidesteps uncomfortable realities in favor of soothing whimsy and preordained uplift.\n\nThere\u2019s nothing wrong with choosing cute over challenging, but it feels condescending to those on the spectrum and insulting to audiences who might prefer not to be cosseted. Wendy herself is a completely credible character: bright and forthright, she holds down a minimum-wage job at Cinnabon and retains an encyclopedic knowledge of \u201cStar Trek.\u201d Observing how the ultrarational Spock processes the emotions of his human colleagues helps her negotiate her own relationships, watched over by her motherly therapist, Scottie (Toni Collette).\n\nVideo\n\nThe story spun around her, though, is a fairy tale of tentative independence with every edge buffed smooth. Rather than investigate, say, why Scottie\u2019s devotion to her patients seems to have alienated her teenage son \u2014 or address the painful realities of protecting infants from tantrum-prone relatives \u2014 Michael Golamco\u2019s script (adapted from his one-act play) sends Wendy off on a picaresque journey to Los Angeles. The competition deadline for her original \u201cStar Trek\u201d script is looming and mild misadventures lie in wait.\n\nIt\u2019s all very comforting and credulity-testing: even the kindly police officer she encounters (Patton Oswalt) is able to calm her down in Klingon. I\u2019ll leave it to dedicated Trekkers to vouch for his accent, but I think Lieutenant Worf would probably approve.", "title": "Review: Boldly Going Toward Independence in \u2018Please Stand By\u2019", "authors": ["Jeannette Catsoulis", "Michael Golamco"]} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "Still, on their own terms both performances were rewarding. Mr. Gatti made the most of the Concertgebouw\u2019s rich sound, especially its mellow, full-bodied string section, during a radiant, spacious account of the Wagner. (Mr. Gatti proved himself an insightful Wagnerian when he conducted \u201cParsifal\u201d at the Metropolitan Opera in 2013, a staging that returns next month.)\n\nBruckner died in 1896 while composing the fourth and final movement of his Ninth Symphony. The three completed movements add up to a score of some 60 minutes. Mr. Gatti\u2019s magnificent account of the sublime Adagio made a convincing case for it as a fitting end to this work: a composer\u2019s farewell. The long first movement is an extreme example of Bruckner\u2019s penchant for writing episodic, unconventional forms, in which a theme can seem less a statement than a strand of a later development section that has crept in too soon. Rather than imposing some sense of order on the movement, Mr. Gatti lavished expressive beauty and majestic restraint on the music.\n\nMs. Jansen chose Bruch\u2019s concerto, a staple of the repertory, for this appearance with the pre-eminent orchestra of her homeland. Her performance was so probing and lucid, and so matched by the refined playing of the orchestra, that this popular piece sounded fresh and bracing. I\u2019ll not soon forget the intimate way she shaped the poignant ruminations of the second movement\u2019s wistful melody. She played a beautifully soft-spoken encore: Manuel De Falla\u2019s setting of \u201cNana,\u201d a Spanish folk song.\n\nFor those who prize flawless playing and clean entrances in Mahler, this performance of his First Symphony would have been a little frustrating. But Mr. Gatti and his players dug deep into this early work. The opening of the first movement hauntingly conveyed the primordial, cosmic elements of the music. The second movement came off like a real, foot-clomping country dance. The finale built inexorably to a brassy, jubilant final flourish, some bloopers notwithstanding.", "title": "Review: Concertgebouw Orchestra Shows Off Its Legacy at Carnegie", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-31 00:00:00", "text": "What was the pianist Stephen Hough doing opening his Carnegie Hall recital on Tuesday, honoring the 100th anniversary of Debussy\u2019s death, with \u201cClair de lune\u201d? The piece has been so overplayed that\u2019s it\u2019s almost past clich\u00e9.\n\nWhy not do the full work from which it\u2019s drawn, Debussy\u2019s early \u201cSuite Bergamasque,\u201d which you don\u2019t often hear? And what were Schumann\u2019s formidable Fantasy in C and Beethoven\u2019s stormy \u201cAppassionata\u201d Sonata doing on a recital dedicated to Debussy, who didn\u2019t have much interest in either composer?\n\nWell, the adventurous Mr. Hough, who is also a composer, knew just what he was up to. His subdued account of \u201cClair de lune\u201d set a contemplative mood in the hall. I think Mr. Hough was also sending another message: Don\u2019t assume anything about Debussy; even this popular early piece reveals a radical in the making. Mr. Hough conveyed the exploratory elements of \u201cClair de lune\u201d by playing it with rhythmic integrity and not a trace of expressive milking. He emphasized the halting flow of the ethereal melody, which unfolds in abrupt phrases that keep stopping momentarily to let a plush harmony linger.", "title": "Review: Cool and Subdued, a Pianist Saves Debussy From Clich\u00e9", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Walsh, a Tony winner for the book of the musical \u201cOnce,\u201d belongs to that essential school of Irish storytellers whose characters find the epic in the everyday, and the monstrous in the mundane. Works like his \u201cMisterman,\u201d \u201cThe Walworth Farce\u201d and \u201cBallyturk\u201d (which receives its American premiere at St. Ann\u2019s Warehouse later this month) are shaped by their characters\u2019 compellingly deluded visions.\n\nIn \u201cDisco Pigs,\u201d this perspective is a folie \u00e0 deux, the shared and sustained creation of a lad and lass who grew up together from infancy in a soul-sapping council estate in County Cork. Their personal mythology begins with an account of emerging from their mothers\u2019 wombs on the same day, in the same hospital.\n\nImprobably enough, these births are given specific physical life here, as Ms. Lynch and Mr. Campbell tear through the back wall of Richard Kent\u2019s bleak and battered-looking set. It is a barren world into which these infants, born Sinead and Darren, emerge.\n\nBut as the self-re-christened Runt (Ms. Lynch) and Pig (Mr. Campbell) they turn the town they call Pork City into a kingdom in which they reign supreme. They speak in their own invented porcine language. And they reach the heady stride of their adolescence as a pair of marauding, hard-drinking hedonists for whom a night on the town is a dangerous collision course.\n\nIt is two such nights \u2014 beginning with a movable celebration of their 17th birthdays \u2014 that particularly concern \u201cDisco Pigs.\u201d The script follows Pig and Runt\u2019s paths of destruction through shops, pubs and clubs \u2014 where they steal, guzzle, dance and beat up on fellow townsfolk; into their bedrooms, where they are mesmerized by reruns of \u201cBaywatch\u201d; onto an empty beach, where their thoughts turn to the adulthoods that await them; and into a palatial discoth\u00e8que that would appear to be the embodiment of their most cherished dreams.", "title": "Review: Dancing to Destruction in Enda Walsh\u2019s Fierce \u2018Disco Pigs\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "It is indisputable that the internet \u2014 facilitated by both vast improvements in access and computing power \u2014 has had a disruptive impact on not just business but politics and many aspects of our daily lives. Demonstrating precisely what that impact is, however, has been remarkably challenging. Pronouncements on the topic have a tendency to be overblown. \u201cTransformational,\u201d \u201cexponential\u201d and \u201crevolutionary\u201d are increasingly favored adjectives, whether they are applicable or not.\n\nThe impression that the world is changing faster today than ever before has become conventional wisdom. Yet the magnitude of change that occurred between when America galloped into World War I on horses and dropped the atomic bomb feels more significant than that undergone since the first dot-com domain name was registered. This observation is not meant to diminish the importance of the seismic changes wrought by the digital age, but rather to suggest the relevance of historical context often absent from the conversation.\n\nA new book by prolific historian Niall Ferguson, \u201cThe Square and the Tower: Networks and Power from the Freemasons to Facebook\u201d (Penguin), goes a long way toward redressing this pervasive lack of perspective to a concept central to the contemporary technological \u201crevolution\u201d: networks.\n\nThe internet itself is a network of networks. The ability to communicate and transact across its vast reach is indeed unprecedented and represents the basic infrastructure of what has been termed the \u201cnetwork society.\u201d Mr. Ferguson\u2019s book does far more than simply track the use of the word \u201cnetwork\u201d from its introduction in English language publications in the late 19th century, when it \u201cwas scarcely used,\u201d to the modern day, when he points out that it appeared in 136 articles in The New York Times during just the first week of 2017. Rather he seeks to reframe the entirety of human history as an endless tug-of-war between eras in which powerful hierarchical institutions predominate (the Tower of the title) only to be undermined by the influence of emerging networks (the corresponding Square). In Professor Ferguson\u2019s telling, these networks are invariably co-opted by reconstituted hierarchies and the process begins again.", "title": "Review: Even on the Internet, What\u2019s Old Is New Again", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-02 00:00:00", "text": "Ms. Kobayashi and Mr. Allen, her co-writer, co-producer, dramaturge and husband, stage \u201cSay Something Bunny!\u201d in a small space in Chelsea up a small flight of stairs. The room only holds 24 people and as your name is called, you can choose a seat at a circular table \u2014 painted black and white to resemble a wire reel \u2014 or behind the music stands arrayed in the back.\n\nMs. Kobayashi, dressed simply in a white T-shirt and white jeans will play the reels for you, inviting you to read along in the script and occasionally pausing to explain her research or to show a photo, a video, a few frames of sprightly animation.\n\nThough audience members are made to stand in for each of the characters, the participation-phobic should know that only Ms. Kobayashi moves and speaks. For the rest of us, presence is enough. (Me? I was cast as a dog. I liked it.)\n\nVideo\n\nI want to tell you so much more about \u201cSay Something Bunny!\u201d but for those of you who will be lucky enough to see it (it\u2019s been playing since the summer, closes in April, tickets are only $40, hurry hurry hurry) ruining its surprises would be like stamping on a souffl\u00e9. I\u2019m not that kind of monster.\n\nI will tell you that Ms. Kobayashi\u2019s tender obsession with this material is as catching as the chickenpox, and if the piece is forthrightly funny and briefly pornographic, it is also sneakily moving. Toward the end I found myself fighting back tears.\n\nI hadn\u2019t really met any of these characters; most of them have been dead for decades. I\u2019d only heard them and seen Ms. Kobayashi\u2019s exaggerated re-enactments. (She is an expert guide and maybe a less than expert actress.)\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address.
