View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIt still felt like a loss to leave them behind and as soon as I was home I Googled one. Because my sleuthing can\u2019t rival Ms. Kobayashi\u2019s I\u2019ll never know if he fulfilled his boyhood dream and became a radio announcer. I hope he did.\n\nIf \u201cSay Something Bunny!\u201d feels sui generis, there are a few theater pieces, like Doug Wright\u2019s \u201cI Am My Own Wife\u201d or the work of W. David Hancock, that have previously meshed drama, documentary and off-kilter investigation. (Some movies and podcasts have done it, too. I was often reminded of the classic \u201cThis American Life\u201d episode, \u201cHouse on Loon Lake.\u201d)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nLike these works, \u201cSay Something Bunny!\u201d is about more than the particulars. It\u2019s a low-key ontological thriller about how we live and what we leave and how we account for ourselves when some kid comes at us with a microphone.\n\n\u201cWhat do you want me to say?\u201d Bunny, the neighbor\u2019s girl, asks at the end of that first dinner.\n\nMore than 60 years later here we are, in a second-floor room on the West Side of Manhattan, breathless to know what she comes up with.", "title": "Review: Everyday Chatter Unveils a Mystery in \u2018Say Something Bunny!\u2019", "authors": ["Alexis Soloski"]} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nFittingly for a benevolent live-action children\u2019s film, \u201cPaddington 2\u201d begins with a gift.\n\nThe amiable bear Paddington (voiced by Ben Whishaw) finds a one-of-a-kind pop-up book filled with intricate illustrations of all the landmarks of London, and he plans to send the book to Peru as a birthday present for his beloved aunt Lucy.\n\nThis treasure will eventually be stolen by the film\u2019s dastardly villain, the egomaniacal actor Phoenix Buchanan (a delightful Hugh Grant), who hopes to use the book as a map to riches. Buchanan\u2019s interference kicks off an adventure that sends Paddington through a trial, a prison sentence, an escape and a daring pursuit by train.\n\nVideo\n\nBut before the book becomes a plot point, the movie pauses to bring it to life through Paddington\u2019s eyes. In a bravura sequence of mixed digital effects, Paddington imagines himself and Lucy as miniatures wandering through the book\u2019s pop-up cardboard pages. He waves from within a paper doll crowd as Lucy arrives on a folding boat. The camera swirls, the pages ruffle and the streets of London unfurl to reveal illustrated lamps and paper cars.\n\nThe introduction of the pop-up book is an early peak for the film, but it is far from the last sequence of arresting originality. The great surprise of \u201cPaddington 2\u201d is that the director, Paul King, creates a whole world of equally adorable objects, any of which might spring to new life with Paddington\u2019s touch. Pipes become telephones, blankets become hot air balloons and people become kinder, happier versions of themselves.\n\nIn one such act of transformation, a group of prisoners, lifted from gloom by Paddington\u2019s marmalade sandwiches and pink prison uniforms, sing calypso to mark his contributions to the penitentiary: \u201cLife would be easier, time would be breezier, if you loved your neighbor.\u201d\n\nNeighborliness is next to godliness in \u201cPaddington 2.\u201d It\u2019s telling that the film\u2019s villain is a performer whose narcissism prohibits collaboration, a man who finds his neighbors a nuisance. For Phoenix Buchanan, the only object worth examining is his own mirror. By contrast, Mr. King and his excellent team of actors and animators spin good writing and seamless digital effects into Rococo children\u2019s entertainment. The gags don\u2019t accumulate; they tessellate. Yet the tone betrays neither effort nor arrogance \u2014 pride being a deadly sin for comedy. Instead \u201cPaddington 2\u201d follows the guileless lead of its earnest, ursine little tramp, suggesting tactfully that cinematic ingenuity is another way of showing good manners.", "title": "Review: Excellence Pursued in \u2018Paddington 2\u2019", "authors": ["Teo Bugbee", "Paul King", "Simon Farnaby"]} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "Even at a time of year when movie companies typically unload their dross, the sheer awfulness of Dito Montiel\u2019s \u201cThe Clapper\u201d stands out. Adapting his second book (\u201cEddie Krumble Is the Clapper\u201d), Mr. Montiel \u2014 a former punk musician whose memoir, \u201cA Guide to Recognizing Your Saints,\u201d was filmed in 2006 \u2014 fails completely to transform sad-sack characters into interesting ones.\n\nInstead, he presents them as borderline dolts, barely functioning adults defined by behavioral quirks and psychological soft spots. Eddie (Ed Helms) and his buddy Chris (an unusually restrained, possibly mortified Tracy Morgan) are bottom-feeding actors in Hollywood whose specialty is playing audience members on low-budget television shows. Clapping and hollering on cue \u2014 and sometimes, if they\u2019re lucky, asking a prearranged question \u2014 they survive with minimal income and even less ambition.", "title": "Review: Finding Unwanted Fame in \u2018The Clapper\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-15 00:00:00", "text": "Mohsen Namjoo\u2019s songs are steeped in Persian classical music and poetry, merged freely with raucous Western rock. He was an acclaimed and sometimes controversial songwriter in Iran who has lived in exile in the West after being sentenced, while abroad, to five years in prison for setting Quran verses to music. Even across the language barrier \u2014 his songs are in Persian \u2014 his commitment was unmistakable, and his chameleonic voice could hold the nuanced clarity of Persian classical singing or turn into a rocker\u2019s howl, an old man\u2019s cackle or a theatrical sob.\n\nThere were smart echoes of tropical\u00eda, Brazil\u2019s iconoclastic (and dictatorship-defying) music of the late 1960s, in the set by Ava Rocha and her band: amiable melodies, poetic lyrics, hints of Brazilian rhythms and taut arrangements that sometimes let the guitars get noisy. Her performance suggested a playful, elusive ritual. She arrived onstage bearing a decanter of what looked like wine, and drank some of it; before she finished her finale, she balanced it on her head. In between, she sang with sultry nonchalance and traced slow-motion gestures both elaborate and inscrutable.\n\nFlor de Toloache, the New York mariachi band that won the Latin Grammy for Best Ranchero/Mariachi Album in November, mingled mariachi tradition with tangents of their own, like Andrews Sisters harmonies, occasional lyrics in English and that Nirvana song.\n\nOther performers hewed closer to tradition. The Iberi Choir, from (the country) Georgia, sang gorgeously harmonized songs, many of them a cappella, with convoluted passages of eerie dissonance; one song had lyrics dating back to the 12th century. Miramar \u2014 with lead singers from Puerto Rico and Tennessee and a Chilean-American keyboardist and composer \u2014 devoted itself to urbanely lovelorn Puerto Rican-style boleros, some vintage and some written by group members.\n\nEva Salina lent her poised, lustrous voice to complexly morose songs from the Balkans in a duo with the Serbian-style accordionist Peter Stan, who backed her with oompah chords and puckish, skittering obbligatos. And Thornetta Davis, a Detroit blues singer, brought backup singers (from her church, she noted) and a horn section for a hearty, formidable set of optimistic blues \u2014 even when the optimism came from finally ditching a no-good man.\n\nFor a musician in the 21st century, those traditions are a matter of choice, not the result of isolation, nostalgia or birthright. Even in a connected world, they\u2019re strong enough to draw new practitioners with their music alone.", "title": "Review: Globalfest\u2019s World Music for a Connected World", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-15 00:00:00", "text": "Jen is a white, 26-year-old architect hoping to \u201cdecolonialize\u201d herself by hooking up with a black man. Gil is a black, 22-year-old caregiver whose goal is to become a stay-at-home dad with a well-paid wife.\n\nDespite their apparent compatibility, their first date, at a restaurant featuring $50 salads, doesn\u2019t go well.\n\nGil seems more interested in Jen\u2019s bread-winning potential than in her painful struggle to regret her advantages. He doesn\u2019t love being part of her decolonialization project. At the same time, Jen is less than impressed with Gil\u2019s frequently touted feminist credentials. \u201cHow, specifically, do you support women,\u201d she asks, \u201cbesides being vaguely personally effeminate?\u201d", "title": "Review: Hipsters Double-Check Their Privilege in \u2018Cute Activist\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nSometimes at night, Pio (Pio Amato), a 14-year-old Roma boy living on the rough edge of the southern Italian town of Gioia Tauro, sees the specter of his grandfather\u2019s horse wandering the streets. It goes without saying that Gioia Tauro, a beaten-down zone of poverty and petty crime, is no place for such a noble animal. \u201cWhen we were on the road, we were free,\u201d says Pio\u2019s grandfather \u2014 glimpsed as a young man in a brief opening scene \u2014 who watches his descendants struggle to hold onto the old ways of their wandering, proudly ungovernable kind.\n\nVideo\n\n\u201cA Ciambra,\u201d the second feature directed by Jonas Carpignano (the first was \u201cMediterranea,\u201d also set in Gioia Tauro), follows Pio\u2019s lurching movement toward manhood and observes his environment with a sympathetic, probing eye. The film, named for the battered apartment complex where Pio lives, provides fresh evidence of the continued vitality of the neorealist impulse as it tries to embed a fictional narrative in the actual world. It has the shape of a fable and the texture of a documentary. The actors are nonprofessionals playing versions of themselves. During the end credits, the frame is filled with more than a few dozen Amatos, Pio\u2019s onscreen (and Mr. Amato\u2019s real-world) family.\n\nKinship is the defining \u2014 and also the confining \u2014 fact of Pio\u2019s life. Home is a hive of siblings and cousins, presided over by Pio\u2019s mother, daughter of the semi-mythic grandpa. Pio trails after his older brother, Cosimo (Damiano Amato), playing the familiar role of sidekick, mascot and occasional annoyance. The younger boy is a natural watcher, a close student of the ways of his elders, eager to emulate them even when he doesn\u2019t quite understand what\u2019s going on.\n\nAfter Cosimo is arrested, Pio tries to fill his shoes and apply the lessons he has absorbed. He steals luggage, ransoms stolen cars to their owners and contemplates bigger scores. He is cunning, though not always smart, and like many adolescents he vacillates between wild overconfidence and childlike na\u00efvet\u00e9. He knows how to drive a car, but not how to read. He goes wherever he pleases, but is afraid of elevators and trains. He is rarely without a cigarette, a habit that apparently begins among boys in his family shortly after they\u2019re out of diapers. Mr. Amato\u2019s brooding man-child features and skinny frame give physical expression to Pio\u2019s in-between, half-formed state.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe story, which emerges slowly through the warmth and noise of Pio\u2019s daily life, leads him toward a wrenching moment of moral crisis. In its mood and methods, \u201cA Ciambra\u201d pays homage to the work of Jean-Pierre and Luc Dardenne, the living masters of European realist cinema. Like the protagonists in their films, Pio faces an ethical dilemma created as much by his own misjudgments as by the harshness of his circumstances. He is forced to decide, before he is ready and at enormous potential cost, what kind of person he wants to be.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nI hesitate to say too much more, since like the Dardennes (and like their great precursor, Robert Bresson), Mr. Carpignano uses the character\u2019s agonizing choice as a way to create suspense. \u201cA Ciambra,\u201d which numbers Martin Scorsese among its executive producers, shows some of his influence as well, in its depiction of crime as a family business and in its attention to masculine codes of loyalty, violence and respect. The most frequent visitors to Ciambra are the police and the gangsters known locally as \u201cthe Italians,\u201d who come to dispense assignments and collect payment. It seems inevitable that Pio will end up in trouble with one or the other.\n\nHis best friend outside the family is Ayiva (Koudous Seihon), an immigrant from Burkina Faso who serves as a surrogate big brother while Cosimo is locked up, and who is nicer to Pio in any case. He is also the boy\u2019s guide \u2014 and the viewer\u2019s \u2014 to a world of refugees and migrants that is both similar to that of the Roma and distinct from it. Both groups exist at the margins of Italian society, despised, pitied and ignored, but they experience that marginality, and their own uprootedness, in ways that reflect radically different histories.", "title": "Review: In \u2018A Ciambra,\u2019 a Young Roma Boy Comes of Age", "authors": ["A.O. Scott", "Jonas Carpignano"]} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "The first game of the first set of the so-called Battle of the Sexes \u2014 the $100,000 winner-take-all tennis match between Billie Jean King and Bobby Riggs in 1973 \u2014 is marvelously reproduced in a new play called \u201cBalls.\u201d The action proceeds in real time, shot by shot, perfectly synchronized to a soundtrack of racket tapping, score keeping, sneaker squeaking and thwacks.\n\nUnfortunately, there are 27 games to go.\n\nOne thing I have to say for \u201cBalls,\u201d which opened on Wednesday at 59E59 Theater, is that it has \u2026 a lot of nerve. Plays about sports are not often very good, plays about tennis even less so, and this particular contest \u2014 recently the subject of the film \u201cBattle of the Sexes\u201d \u2014 would seem to be overmined. Even if stage directors can invoke the audience\u2019s imagination to fill in the blanks, filling in so many gets tiring fast.\n\nThis hasn\u2019t deterred the playwrights Kevin Armento and Bryony Lavery \u2014 he the author of the well-received \u201cPlease Excuse My Dear Aunt Sally\u201d and she of the harrowing and decidedly non-Disney \u201cFrozen.\u201d They insist on depicting the entire three-set match, albeit in mime: straightforwardly on three occasions (as in that first game) but mostly in various theatrical transformations thereafter. Sometimes Ms. King (Ellen Tamaki) is upstage; sometimes Mr. Riggs (Donald Corren) is. Sometimes only one of them is seen, sometimes neither. The net may be parallel or perpendicular or diagonal to the audience, or it may move; occasionally there is no net at all. In one lovely black-light scene, only the ball is visible.\n\nThough this action is cleverly devised by the directors Ianthe Demos and Nick Flint, and executed perfectly under the movement direction of Natalie Lomonte, it is neither tennis nor theater but a kind of hysteria. The whole play seems to be constructed backward, starting with a concept requiring a full 85 minutes of athletic representation and ending with the maddening question of how to fill all that time. Narratives so constructed often leave you thinking, \u201cWhy?\u201d but, in \u201cBalls,\u201d the authors\u2019 solutions, trite and tiresome, have you frequently blurting, \u201cWhat?\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBecause, yes, there are clowns.\n\nTwo, actually: one male (Richard Saudek) and one female (Olivia McGiff). These characters, both wearing huge ties, clashing stripes and dopey moues, often double as line judges, but at other times may be found juggling, doing prop comedy or firing tennis ball bazookas labeled \u201cgay rights\u201d and \u201cwomen\u2019s rights\u201d at Ms. King.\n\nPhoto\n\nAlso filling the time are several other male-female pairs, presumably emphasizing the battle of the sexes theme. When not dashing back and forth along the net, the ball boy and ball girl (Alex J. Gould and Elisha Mudly) portray a couple whose 40-year relationship, from first flirtation through postdivorce amity, unfolds in a different time scheme from the rest of the play. Another pair, Terry and Cherry (Danny Bernardy and Cristina Pitter), are garish, loudmouthed superfans, which is not even the right caricature. And Chris Evert and Jim Brown show up, too, because why not?", "title": "Review: In \u2018Balls,\u2019 Billie Jean and Bobby Come Out Swinging", "authors": ["Jesse Green"]} {"date": "2018-01-16 00:00:00", "text": "As is the case with many conceptual artists, Beuys\u2019s work was best understood with Beuys\u2019s actual presence attached to it. But Beuys has been dead since 1986. This documentary, directed by Andres Veiel using mostly archival footage, makes a strong case for Beuys, emphasizing the social conscience at work in his art more than the postmodern prankishness.\n\nBeuys (pronounced \u201cboys\u201d), whose thin, high-cheekboned face never seemed to age (as a German pilot in World War II he was wounded more than once, perhaps necessitating plastic surgery; the film implies as much) almost always sported a fedora as he made pronouncements like \u201cAnything can be art, especially anything that conserves energy.\u201d As both performance artist and art teacher, he often comes off as a happy warrior: \u201cGive me a place to stand and I\u2019ll move the earth.\u201d\n\nBut the film chronicles the crippling depression and isolation that Beuys suffered in the 1950s as he struggled to formulate his voice. His drawings from that time, the only really \u201ctraditional\u201d art he accomplished, are harrowing, haunting. Even if you don\u2019t need Beuys justified or explained to you, the movie is an exhilarating portrait of a unique truth-teller.", "title": "Review: In \u2018Beuys,\u2019 a Portrait of the Artist as a Socially Conscious Provocateur", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nFor viewers unfamiliar with the rewardingly arduous documentaries of the Chinese filmmaker Wang Bing, \u201cBitter Money\u201d won\u2019t be the easiest place to start. A determined, mostly unobtrusive observer of China\u2019s dispossessed, Mr. Wang works in a demanding mode of v\u00e9rit\u00e9, allowing scenes to play out at length and providing little in the way of exposition.\n\nHis extreme running times often pay dividends. It\u2019s hard to describe the feeling of relief when, after three hours of the nearly four-hour \u201c\u2019Til Madness Do Us Part,\u201d the camera suddenly leaves the mental hospital. In \u201cBitter Money,\u201d which runs more than two and a half hours, the duration seems less purposeful than the vestige of a film in progress. It\u2019s not clear that the director quite found what he was looking for.\n\nMr. Wang\u2019s subject is the mass migration to Huzhou, where a boom in clothing manufacturing seems roughly comparable to the North Dakota oil rush in the United States. Residents from rural areas have gone to Huzhou for jobs. Mr. Wang documents the bustle on a crowded train to the city, though typically, he doesn\u2019t provide statistical details until the closing title cards.\n\nOnly some of the workers, filmed between 2014 and 2016, stand out. The most tense interaction occurs early, when a woman who has left her abusive husband returns to him seeking money. Mr. Wang films the resulting altercation in a 10-minute take, with his camera crouching outside a shop door like a voyeur. The director\u2019s methods are open to ethical debate, but the power of his filmmaking, at its best, is not.", "title": "Review: In \u2018Bitter Money,\u2019 Documenting China\u2019s Textile Boom", "authors": ["Ben Kenigsberg"]} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cDen of Thieves\u201d opens with unfootnoted statistics about Los Angeles, \u201cthe bank robbery capital of the world,\u201d where such heists apparently occur every 48 minutes. That\u2019s about the rate at which this surprisingly long, wildly ambitious, thoroughly ludicrous crime thriller delivers its own big scores.\n\nItself a plundering of \u201cThe Driver,\u201d the original \u201cPoint Break\u201d and \u201cHeat,\u201d the movie is less concerned with the mechanics of police work than with the mind meld that forms between an obsessed cop, Big Nick (Gerard Butler), and his target, Merrimen (Pablo Schreiber), who leads a group of Marines turned bank robbers planning to crack a branch of the Federal Reserve.", "title": "Review: In \u2018Den of Thieves,\u2019 Gerard Butler Trails a Former Marine", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nBenny is a small-time crook with a juicy operation in his sights. \u201cHuge bills,\u201d as he puts it. \u201cIt\u2019s like, just sittin\u2019 there cuzz it don\u2019t belong to nobody.\u201d\n\nOh, poor, dumb Benny: Don\u2019t you know money\u2019s never just sitting there? It usually comes with complications \u2014 pesky people who also want those bills and who you might have to deal with, perhaps in an aggressive manner. And by the way, the two neighborhood buddies you enlist to help? Well, maybe they\u2019re not all that reliable.\n\nIn fact, Benny (Robert Lee Leng) is just the hapless detonator that sets off the drama in Paul Calderon\u2019s \u201cDivine Horsemen.\u201d The explosives are the aforementioned friends, both older: Iffy (David Zayas), the grizzled bear of a man who runs Caballeros Divinos, the titular, dingy Spanish Harlem social club; and Willie (Mr. Calderon, who also directs), a slick thug playing it cool. In tough-guy plays, movies and TV shows, nattily attired men often turn out to be violent sociopaths. Keeping with that tradition, the cocksure Willie calmly slinks into the club, acts much bigger than his schemes deserve \u2014 one involves stealing dogs, then returning them for the reward \u2014 and lords it over Benny and Iffy.\n\nPhoto\n\nIffy, portrayed with gruff assurance by Mr. Zayas (who was in the original productions of Stephen Adly Guirgis\u2019s \u201cJesus Hopped the \u2018A\u2019 Train\u201d and \u201cOur Lady of 121st Street,\u201d as well as in Nilo Cruz\u2019s \u201cAnna in the Tropics\u201d), looks like he could easily stand up to Willie, yet he keeps falling in line with the aging alpha hoodlum.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Calderon writes florid, rapid-fire New Yorkese, which is necessary because his characters\u2019 gift of gab is all they have. Yet it all feels a little forced, as if the play was going down a checklist of tough-guy tropes. (As Chekhov didn\u2019t write, if there is a baseball bat in a show, skulls need to be bashed at some point.)", "title": "Review: In \u2018Divine Horsemen,\u2019 a Checklist of Tough-Guy Tropes", "authors": ["Elisabeth Vincentelli"]} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "Beginning in the 1950s, the writer Philip K. Dick laid down themes for decades of science fiction (and non-science fiction). As technology perfects virtual experiences, what does \u201creal\u201d mean? Is an original necessarily more authentic than its simulacrum?\n\nSo it\u2019s the most Philip K. Dick thing imaginable to find that \u201cPhilip K. Dick\u2019s Electric Dreams,\u201d based on his short stories, pales before some of the author\u2019s recent imitators. But here we are.\n\nI can\u2019t blame the weaknesses of \u201cElectric Dreams,\u201d whose first season arrives on Amazon on Friday, on the source material: The episodes\u2019 writers had great leeway to stray from the originals. (The same happened with Amazon\u2019s Dick adaptation \u201cThe Man in the High Castle.\u201d)\n\nNor is a lack of star power at fault. The credits of the 10 self-contained episodes include Greg Kinnear, Anna Paquin, Bryan Cranston (one of 14 \u2014 14! \u2014 executive producers) and Janelle Mon\u00e1e (the actress-singer who recorded \u201cThe ArchAndroid\u201d plays an arch android).", "title": "Review: In \u2018Electric Dreams,\u2019 the Future Seems Outdated", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nThis rather astonishing movie begins with a lovely young bride-to-be, Josie (Jessica Rothe), abandoned before even getting to the altar by her high-school sweetheart, Liam (Alex Roe), who\u2019s absconded in pursuit of music business fame. Eight years later, Liam is a stadium-filling country music star, as well as a promiscuous drunk. (The credible songs are mostly by Brett Boyett.) His one nonstandard-issue eccentricity is an attachment to an ancient cellphone, which contains Josie\u2019s last voice mail message to him. On a New Orleans tour stop, he learns of the death of his best friend in nearby Saint Augustine, the town from which he bailed. On impulse, he heads there.\n\nWhile the Prodigal Son of scripture returned home after working out a heartfelt plea of forgiveness, Liam just shows up. Are there hard feelings? Sure, but they\u2019re the softest hard feelings you\u2019ve seen in any work of fiction, or nonfiction, ever. Also turns out that Josie, as fresh and lovely as ever, has an adorably precocious moppet of a daughter, Billy, whom she has named after Liam\u2019s long-deceased mother.\n\nThere is no talk of potentially seven years worth of unpaid child support; no mention of formalizing any sort of custody arrangement. This group must somehow form a family, as the \u201cBrady Bunch\u201d theme song says, and so it goes, with one dopey speed bump that presumes to explain and erase Liam\u2019s damage. The rest is pure romance-novel wish-fulfillment. The director, Bethany Ashton Wolf, who adapted the screenplay from, yes, a romance novel by Heidi McLaughlin, can concoct some Hallmark-greeting-card-quality shots, but has little flair for piecing them together. The lead actors are very pretty.", "title": "Review: In \u2018Forever My Girl,\u2019 a Romance Resumes After a Long Break", "authors": ["Glenn Kenny", "Bethany Ashton Wolf", "Heidi Mclaughlin", "Novel"]} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nWhat can you say about an adolescent American boy who is able to accurately quote Oscar Wilde? You can call him precocious, but in the case of Billy Bloom (Alex Lawther), who we first see quoting the Irish writer and dandy in a flashback recalling sunnier times in his childhood, that\u2019s not enough.\n\nBorn into great wealth, the hero of \u201cFreak Show\u201d initially rhapsodizes to the audience about his mother (Bette Midler, going big in her scant screen time), whom he calls \u201cMuv,\u201d praising her as \u201ca living testament to grace, glamour and Gucci.\u201d Life with Muv was sweet, but after she enters rehab, Billy must reside at the mansion of his father (Larry Pine), who\u2019s not happy about Billy\u2019s rejection of conventional masculinity.\n\nThe kids at his new high school aren\u2019t down with it either. Defiant, Billy wears Lady Gaga-style costumes to school, and is brutalized for his trouble. In his recovery, he forges an unlikely friendship with a football star (Ian Nelson). The movie finds its ostensible plot about an hour in, after Billy decides to compete with an evangelical classmate (Abigail Breslin) for the title of homecoming queen. Laverne Cox can\u2019t do a whole lot in her perfunctory role as a local TV news reporter covering the homecoming queen competition.\n\nVideo\n\nDirected by Trudie Styler, making her fiction feature debut, \u201cFreak Show\u201d benefits from a vast array of talents both behind the camera (the cinematographer, for instance, is Dante Spinotti, a regular collaborator with Michael Mann) and in front of it. Mr. Lawther is sympathetic and appealing as Billy, but Ms. Styler seems to mistake broad strokes for stylistic daring, and her colorful but diffuse movie never jells.", "title": "Review: In \u2018Freak Show,\u2019 the Boy Who Would be Homecoming Queen", "authors": ["Glenn Kenny", "Patrick J. Clifton", "Beth Rigazio", "James St. James", "Novel"]} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nLeisurely and deliberate, intelligent and casually cruel, \u201cHave a Nice Day\u201d is a stone-cold gangster thriller whose violence unfolds in passionless bursts. Opening with a quotation from Leo Tolstoy\u2019s last and bleakest novel, \u201cResurrection,\u201d this wittily animated feature from the Chinese writer and director Liu Jian presents a generic, follow-the-money tale as a Darwinian commentary on ruthlessly modern materialism.\n\nThe stolen bag of moola moves briskly from one grasping hand to another, yet the movie\u2019s images are often strangely static. For seconds at a time, the only movement in the frame might come from a single, flashing light on empty train tracks or a blinking neon sign in front of a deserted factory. These lone blips of vivid color emphasize the palely anemic sweep of industrial blight around them, the grubby gray storefronts and trash-lined streets where characters scheme for easy enrichment and a leg up to otherwise impossible dreams.\n\nVideo\n\nZhang (voiced by Zhu Changlong), the initial thief, needs to pay for a redo of his girlfriend\u2019s botched plastic surgery. Yellow Eye (Cao Kou), a depressed hit man, wants start-up cash to finance a career as an inventor. Sundry underworld types scratch and sniff in pursuit, but their harebrained motives \u2014 like the money itself \u2014 are mere tools with which to paint a pitch-black picture of Chinese economic frustration set against the allure of Western opportunity.\n\nChatty to a fault, these gangsters rarely kill without preamble, declaiming everything from philosophy to Fauvism and Buddhism to Brexit. The voice actors rise to the occasion, often portraying multiple emotions in a single, ruminative monologue. The story that frames them is thin, but the animation has a style and restraint all its own, its clean precision and curiously flat aesthetic ensuring our focus on words as well as deeds.\n\nSpeckled with present-day politics and musings on global capitalism, \u201cHave a Nice Day\u201d conjures a small-town landscape of pitiless greed. A marriage proposal is rebuffed, its bearer left unconscious on the roadside while his beloved drives off with their ill-gotten loot. Earlier, we\u2019ve seen the owner of the money coolly torture a childhood friend, even as he fondly reminisces about their shared formative experiences. Cars crash and characters are repeatedly bonked on the head, every brutality erupting on a canvas that\u2019s studiously devoid of affect.\n\nIn a setting this dismal, sex seems a nonstarter, though a hardy few peddle repurposed animal carcasses as procreative aids. \u201cWorks better than Viagra,\u201d one peddler assures his mark, proffering a wild turtle. Even killer-entrepreneurs sometimes need a little help to get the job done.", "title": "Review: In \u2018Have a Nice Day,\u2019 a Follow-the-Money Tale in China", "authors": ["Jeannette Catsoulis", "Jian Liu"]} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "Stanley Houghton\u2019s \u201cHindle Wakes,\u201d an obscure British play from 1912 that\u2019s been dusted off and revivified by the Mint Theater Company, begins with a storm. Lightning flashes, the air rumbles and Sarah and Christopher Hawthorn wait fretfully for their grown daughter, Fanny, to return from her holiday.\n\nInside their kitchen, they light the gas lamps, and it\u2019s all very lulling \u2014 until, out of nowhere, comes a thunderclap so bold and startling that, at the performance I saw, at least a half dozen spectators visibly jumped out of their seats. Bravo, then, to the sound designer, Jane Shaw, but kudos also to Houghton, whose play proceeds much along the same pattern \u2014 gentle as a summer rain until, bam, in Act 2, something electric happens to charge the air.\n\nGus Kaikkonen\u2019s handsome, rough around the edges production, at the Clurman Theater, makes a better case for the play as a curiosity than a forgotten gem, though. This is a paean to women\u2019s sexual freedom from a time before they even had the right to vote.\n\nScandal is brewing from the start. Fanny (Rebecca Noelle Brinkley), a weaver at the local cotton mill, told her parents that she was vacationing with a female friend \u2014 and she was, until she met Alan Jeffcote (the appealing Jeremy Beck), the mill owner\u2019s overindulged son, and went off to have a fling with him.", "title": "Review: In \u2018Hindle Wakes,\u2019 Should a Fling Lead Straight to the Altar?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nIf \u201cdad joke\u201d is an insult, why isn\u2019t \u201cgrandfather joke\u201d? Do people get funnier with age?\n\nSam Hoffman, who founded the website Old Jews Telling Jokes, which was adapted into a book and an Off Broadway show, built a franchise that might persuade you that they do. His comedy avoids the fashionable confessional style in favor of borscht belt standards about hectoring mothers and religious figures walking into bars.\n\nHe has worked on movies for years, but his directorial debut, \u201cHumor Me,\u201d a lightly amusing stroll down some well-worn streets, shares a sensibility with his popular site, with narrative tacked on. It could be called: Middle-Aged Jew Not Telling Jokes.\n\nVideo\n\nIt begins with a terrible day for a sad-sack playwright, Nate Kroll (Jemaine Clement). He loses his job. His wife leaves him for a French billionaire, and \u2014 conveniently, for the purposes of the plot \u2014 he doesn\u2019t realize his lease is up. This forces him to move in with his father, Bob (Elliott Gould), in a retirement community. In an odd-couple scenario, Nate is self-serious, while his dad can\u2019t stop joking. Nate meets a fellow midlife-crisis sufferer, Allison, a thin role played winningly by the singer Ingrid Michaelson, and agrees to stage a production of Gilbert and Sullivan\u2019s \u201cThe Mikado\u201d with older women. Working on this show embarrasses him, but besides being an opportunity for more comic moments from senior citizens, this humble effort inevitably leads to an epiphany.\n\nAmong such old-school plot mechanics is one novel element involving re-enactments of jokes that act as a kind of Greek chorus while underlining a central theme: the power of jokes to bring people together and occasionally keep them apart.\n\nBut don\u2019t get the wrong idea: The movie never gets too deep, which is half of its charm. The other half involves the low-key comic performances by a stellar cast including Annie Potts and Bebe Neuwirth, who plays a theater producer named C.C. Rudin.\n\nMr. Clements works wonders with a deadpan expression, imbuing his role with a repressed melancholy, a nice match for the poignant emotionalism of Mr. Gould\u2019s Bob. Jokes matter to this old man, and he makes telling them seem like an act of vulnerability. One favorite is faking a heart attack, and when his son doesn\u2019t laugh, Mr. Gould looks so wounded you worry he might really have one, suggesting a joke can kill even when it doesn\u2019t.", "title": "Review: In \u2018Humor Me,\u2019 a Dose of Borscht Belt for a Midlife Crisis", "authors": ["Jason Zinoman", "Sam Hoffman"]} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cCarousel\u201d is a problematic musical. Not for its score, which is gorgeous, but because it\u2019s a romance with bruises \u2014 a love story between a spirited young woman and the bullying, short-fuse thug she marries. He hits her. She stays. Not exactly a lighthearted evening.\n\nBut Rodgers and Hammerstein borrowed that trouble from the play they based their show on, Ferenc Molnar\u2019s \u201cLiliom,\u201d whose last line, spoken by a mother to her teenage daughter, is astonishingly dark \u2014 the cycle of dysfunction crystallized. \u201cIt is possible, dear,\u201d the mother says, \u201cthat someone may beat you and beat you and beat you \u2014 and not hurt you at all.\u201d\n\nJust as it\u2019s intriguing to watch how directors confront the challenges of \u201cCarousel\u201d (a Broadway revival opens this spring), it\u2019s interesting to see other playwrights wrestle with adapting \u201cLiliom.\u201d Michael Weller\u2019s new play \u201cJericho,\u201d presented by the Attic Theater Company at the Wild Project, is a case in point, and he acquits himself nicely. The last scene, in fact, is so movingly done that it tempers the impression of this frustratingly uneven world-premiere production, directed by Laura Braza.", "title": "Review: In \u2018Jericho,\u2019 Another Spin of the Romantic Carousel", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "Armed with a webcam and disaffection, Kiya embarks on a videotaped crime spree. The movie\u2019s director, Robert Mockler, mirrors his protagonist\u2019s interests, incorporating Kiya\u2019s footage into the film as she satisfies her voracious appetite for diner food and live-streamed provocation. When a homeless man abandons dinner before Kiya can film him, Mr. Mockler\u2019s colorful, kinetic frames capture what Kiya missed, relishing the grease as it smears across the man\u2019s pallid face.\n\nAs Kiya escalates her on-camera stunts, her gluttony grows with her follower count online. After a hotel worker named Marshall (Larry Fessenden) tries to have sex with Kiya, a minor, she ties him to her hotel bed, fixing her camera on him. We watch through Kiya\u2019s camera as she feeds him junk food, pressing on his stomach until she gets a regurgitation worthy of a hundred thousand clicks. In \u201cLike Me,\u201d vomiting is viral content.\n\nAfter this queasy encounter, Kiya kidnaps Marshall, intent on mining him for trashy clicks. But as their road banter turns to the topic of human connection, \u201cLike Me\u201d provides a reminder that bile and excrement are not substitutes for ideas. With little more than the superficial psychology of shallow characters to guide the movie\u2019s squeamish images, \u201cLike Me\u201d irritates, but it proves unable to provoke more than mild gut reactions.", "title": "Review: In \u2018Like Me,\u2019 Armed With a Camera and Queasifying Pranks", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-08 00:00:00", "text": "Not so fast. In a reversal of the joke that if men gave birth, abortion would be a sacrament, the Big Brother-ish World Power Authority still outlaws pregnancy termination. After his OB-GYN rats him out, Jason is forced to deliver the \u201cCry-Baby\u201d growing inside him by means of a machine that looks like an M.R.I. scanner crossed with a Keurig. But the child, which pops out pre-swaddled, is not what anyone expected.\n\nPhoto\n\nI won\u2019t spoil that part of the busy plot by saying more about the Cry-Baby, except that it somehow becomes, in this full-out patriarchy, the centerpiece of a new feminist religion. By intermission, Jason and Mark are that religion\u2019s unwilling high priests, wearing glittery robes and Ziegfeld headgear (by Dede M. Ayite) that would make a cardinal \u2014 the bird or the prelate \u2014 blush. You may blush, too, if you are a man who does not relish audience participation, as you will be asked to raise your voice in hymn to the \u201cmost merciful Goddess.\u201d (Women aren\u2019t given the prayer cards.)\n\nUnfortunately, the development of this woman-and-baby-worshiping cult hijacks what seemed to be a topical comedy of gender roles and drags it around for most of the second act. Religious ideology and professions of faith, especially Catholic ones, are lampooned as idiotic and venal, but the satire will likely infuriate traditional believers of any stripe. The first of the new Ten Commandments is \u201cAbortion is a human right.\u201d\n\nI wasn\u2019t bothered by that: Surely religion is fair game for mockery. And no one should go to a Robert O\u2019Hara play who isn\u2019t up for some trampling of sensitivities. Deliberate outrageousness is his m\u00e9tier, but he\u2019s an equal opportunity purveyor, eager to rile stray conservatives who venture into the theater, as well as their liberal antagonists.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nActually, Mr. O\u2019Hara has always reserved his most wicked blows for the liberals, puncturing their comfortable pieties and exposing their unexamined blind spots. In \u201cBarbecue,\u201d seen at the Public Theater in 2015, he let the audience laugh at the down-market doings of a white family picnic before continuing the same scene with a black family. In \u201cBootycandy,\u201d an earlier satire of black theatrical tropes and the white people who love them, a stand-in character for the playwright tells audience members at a postshow talk back that he hopes they will \u201cchoke\u201d trying to swallow what he\u2019s written. \u201cThe work should be work,\u201d he says.\n\nBut at their intermittent best those plays were so hilarious that the work was not work \u2014 or if work, then the highly pleasurable kind. Each had a defining gimmick that made it deliciously theatrical: a twist, Mr. O\u2019Hara writes in a program note, \u201cthat gives the play its Shout.\u201d So does \u201cMankind,\u201d in its triumph-of-the-patriarchy premise. The problem here is that the story keeps twisting even when you need it to stay put and shout. Another switcheroo arrives every few minutes, which quickly grows as tiresome as a joker roommate and lets the satire deflate into mere sarcasm.\n\nIt\u2019s a problem of focus. Satire is about the sharpness of the darts but also of the targets. Here there are too many targets to leave a coherent impression. Religion seems to be the intended bull\u2019s-eye, and it\u2019s certainly instructive to see how the church of \u201cShe\u201d (whose name is thought to be unpronounceable) grows into a grotesque expression of mansplained feminism. So is the way casual, catty utterances of Jason and Mark are misinterpreted by apostles and transformed into dogma.\n\nMr. O\u2019Hara also asks you to cackle about the vapidity of talk shows, the clich\u00e9s of dystopian dialogue, bromosexuality, sexism, Trumpism and futurism itself. This pinwheel of snark feels like a stunt, and there\u2019s little that the cast \u2014 which also includes David Ryan Smith, Ariel Shafir, Stephen Schnetzer and Andr\u00e9 De Shields \u2014 can do, under the author\u2019s seemingly distracted direction, to keep a feeling of agitated desperation at bay. Their varying choices to play the material as serious drama or sketch comedy seem almost random.\n\nMr. O\u2019Hara has said that with satire, especially now, you can\u2019t go partway: \u201cYou have to go for the throat.\u201d That\u2019s probably true \u2014 and the viciousness of \u201cMankind\u201d that would offend some people is perhaps its best quality. But when you go for too many throats at once, the result feels less like comedy than mayhem, and hasn\u2019t the patriarchy already shown us enough of that?\n\nMankind Playwrights Horizons 416 W. 42nd St. Midtown West 212-279-4200 website Category Off Broadway, Comedy, Play Credits Written and directed by Robert O'Hara Cast Andr\u00e9 De Shields, Bobby Moreno, Anson Mount, Stephen Schnetzer, Ariel Shafir and David Ryan Smith Preview December 15, 2017 Opened January 8, 2018 Closing Date January 28, 2018 This information was last updated: Jan. 26, 2018", "title": "Review: In \u2018Mankind,\u2019 Men Are Men and Women Are Extinct", "authors": ["Jesse Green"]} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nThe trap in assessing \u201cMy Art\u201d is to assume that it contains more autobiography than it does. That\u2019s true despite the possessive adjective in the title, or the fact that the director, an artist, plays an artist, Ellie. Or even the fact that the filmmaker is Laurie Simmons, who, detractors might scoff, belongs to a family of oversharers. (Ms. Simmons\u2019s daughter Lena Dunham appears briefly as one of Ellie\u2019s former students.)\n\nPart of what seems to separate Ms. Simmons from Ellie is that Ellie is alone, with no children or partner except for a dog with bad hind legs. \u201cMy Art\u201d can be read as a study of how her solitude helps and hinders her creativity.\n\nVideo\n\nEllie travels upstate to spend time by herself at a friend\u2019s capacious summer home. Her latest project comes to involve re-enacting scenes from famous movies. She is helped by two gardeners (Robert Clohessy and Josh Safdie) who are frustrated actors, as well the father (John Rothman) of a student. They mimic scenes from \u201cSome Like It Hot,\u201d \u201cA Clockwork Orange\u201d and \u201cThe Misfits,\u201d among others, making the point, to paraphrase Ellie, that it is impossible for any one performer to truly be another.\n\nYour feelings on \u201cMy Art\u201d may vary depending on whether you find that idea compelling. \u201cMy Art\u201d invests far too much in the conceit. (The re-creations look like unfunny \u201cAirplane!\u201d parodies.) Part of the problem is that Ms. Simmons has surrounded herself with more interesting actors, including a scene-stealing Parker Posey.", "title": "Review: In \u2018My Art,\u2019 the Artist Laurie Simmons Plays an Artist", "authors": ["Ben Kenigsberg", "Laurie Simmons"]} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cWhere there are two Jews, there are three opinions,\u201d Manfred Kirchheimer says in his little gem of a documentary, \u201cMy Coffee With Jewish Friends.\u201d In the film he speaks with more than 20 people and comes away with countless viewpoints, as well as some smiles and bittersweet tales.\n\nMr. Kirchheimer is himself something of a gem. After escaping Nazi Germany with his family, he came to the United States in 1936. Since the 1950s he has worked as a cameraman and editor, and has directed his own independent films, among them \u201cCanners\u201d and \u201cStations of the Elevated.\u201d His skills are keen here, particularly in editing and intercutting conversations that range from wistful to indignant to delighted.\n\nHe\u2019s just as nimble in front of the camera, usually sitting one-on-one with others to consider topics including Israel, marriage and orthodox religion. Touchy subjects are approached in easygoing tones; Mr. Kirchheimer is too gentlemanly to badger his guests, yet he\u2019s not shy about questioning an opinion or seeking clarification.\n\nThe most thoughtful discussions are with those who have lost faith in a god, or those whose beliefs have altered over time. One friend wonders how any creator could allow the Holocaust, and another explains why he holds tight to his Jewishness: \u201cI cannot betray my grandparents. I cannot betray the millions who came before [and] who were murdered.\u201d", "title": "Review: In \u2018My Coffee With Jewish Friends,\u2019 Sit With Me and Talk of God", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nThe action thriller \u201cProud Mary\u201d begins by trying to establish some retro cred, with a vintage Motown tune on the soundtrack (the Temptations\u2019 \u201cPapa Was a Rolling Stone,\u201d not thematically apt but rhythmically bubbling nevertheless) and a title typeface that recalls the one used in the 1974 blaxploitation picture \u201cFoxy Brown.\u201d Under the credits, Taraji P. Henson, as the title character, showers, dresses, puts on makeup and selects a bright blond wig from her wardrobe. Oh, and she also selects a formidable-looking handgun from the formidable arsenal behind her wardrobe.\n\nAfter which she goes on her mission, quickly dispatching a guy who barely gets a chance to gape at her wig. In a room elsewhere in the man\u2019s apartment, she sees a young boy, headphones blocking his hearing, obliviously playing a video game. This gives her pause.\n\nBut she doesn\u2019t intervene in the kid\u2019s life, not just yet. Instead, a year goes by, and Mary discovers the kid, Danny (Jahi Di\u2019Allo Winston), is a runner for a Boston drug dealer referred to only as Uncle. After discovering the boy wounded and starving in an alley, she takes an unorthodox approach to adoption, rubbing out Uncle in a flash of anger.\n\nVideo\n\n\u201cProud Mary,\u201d directed by Babak Najafi from a script by Steven Antin, John Stuart Newman and Christian Swegal, is a rather more somber affair than other movies in the same tradition. Although the plot mechanics are no more or less implausible than any such genre film. Mary is a hit woman for one drug cartel, Uncle was an operative for a rival one, and the scenario eventually spirals into a minor morass of misidentified killers and lethal paybacks.\n\nBut Ms. Henson, ever simmering, takes Mary\u2019s moral conundrum very seriously. Her expressive eyes and nuanced body language work well for the character; she can put across a major change in attitude just by shifting a hip. The script, though, doesn\u2019t give her a whole lot of material with which to credibly enact her character\u2019s crisis. Her exchanges with Benny (Danny Glover), the drug kingpin who took her under his wing, or with Tom (Billy Brown), Benny\u2019s son, heir and an ex of Mary\u2019s, provide some idea of a potentially richer movie.\n\nBy the end, \u201cProud Mary\u201d is of course obliged to hew to the prerogatives of its genre, with a warehouse action sequence scored to a Tina Turner version of the title song. The over-the-top nature of the sequence (Mary\u2019s car gets shot up enough it could double as a sieve) is not served well by Mr. Najafi\u2019s execution. The C.G.I. bullet holes that dot the various boxes and crates on the set look like bad Photoshop.", "title": "Review: In \u2018Proud Mary,\u2019 Taraji P. Henson Is a Hit Woman With a Soft Spot", "authors": ["Glenn Kenny", "Steve Antin", "John Stuart Newman", "Christian Swegal"]} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "Ulysses, the young protagonist of \u201cSaturday Church,\u201d is first seen at the burial of his father, a soldier killed overseas. The New York teen, played by Luka Kain, has delicate features and carries an air of quiet about him. He and his younger brother will now be looked after by both their mother Amara (Margot Bingham) and strict Aunt Rose (Regina Taylor). The latter does not mince words after Ulysses is discovered trying on his mother\u2019s shoes. \u201cIf I ever hear of you even looking at women\u2019s clothing, I will beat it out of you. You are a man. Start acting like one,\u201d she says, enunciating each word with controlled rage.\n\nBut the boy is in no way conflicted about his sexual orientation \u2014 he\u2019s just surrounded by disapproval. As a form of escape, he imagines his life as a musical, and the movie is dotted with song and dance, beginning with a particularly audacious locker-room scene in which Ulysses\u2019 jock tormentors turn into backup dancers. For real-life affinity, Ulysses seeks companionship on the pier by Manhattan\u2019s Christopher Street, where he is enlisted into Saturday Church, a program for at-risk L.G.B.T.Q. youth. (The program in the movie is based on a real one.)", "title": "Review: In \u2018Saturday Church,\u2019 Coming of Age, and Coming Out", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "Dashed hopes, breathless victories and painful regrets make up \u201cShot in the Dark,\u201d a documentary that has the rhythm of some spare yet deeply felt street poetry.\n\nTaking place mostly on Chicago\u2019s West Side, the film centers on Orr Academy High School and its basketball team, the Spartans. Lou Adams, the head coach, trains his athletes in the gym and pleads with them to avoid trouble outside it: We see neighborhood memorials to young men killed in gun violence, and learn that more than 20 people in the community died during the time the documentary was made.\n\nTyquone Greer and Marquise Pryor, two star players, have visions of college careers, but the call of gangs and parties often proves too seductive. The director Dustin Nakao Haider follows them as they navigate their days and nights, on and off the court.\n\nThough the premise is familiar \u2014 see \u201cHoop Dreams\u201d or any of the countless feature films about youth sports \u2014 the excitement still stays high when the games begin. At other times Mr. Haider records his subjects without comment; no one here is prodded to overexplain. This director isn\u2019t afraid of silence, and he\u2019s prepared to let a quiet moment speak for itself. Attentive viewing is required, and rewarded.", "title": "Review: In \u2018Shot in the Dark,\u2019 Two Things Are Unforgiving: Life and Basketball", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-17 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nA genre exercise, the detective movie \u201cSmall Town Crime\u201d relies on the usual time-tested ingredients: the boozy loner lawman, the beautiful female victim and the reliably mysterious, invariably competent villains. The directors and brothers Eshom Nelms and Ian Nelms have obviously made a study of the genre, both in its old and more recent iterations, and while they\u2019re happy to play around with the form, they pretty much leave the basics intact. By far their smartest, most inspired move is to have cleared room for John Hawkes, one of those actors who are more often seen nibbling at the edges of a scene, leaving perfect little teeth marks that sometimes give a movie its primary texture.\n\nVideo\n\nMr. Hawkes plays Mike Kendall, a former cop. He lives alone in a Utah town in nice house with a white picket fence that he\u2019s flattened, doubtless after a hard night. He\u2019s halfheartedly looking for work, but all he seems to want to do is drink and pal around with his brother-in-law (Anthony Anderson). So Mike drinks and drinks some more, tossing back beer until he staggers, stumbles and blacks out. He doesn\u2019t seem otherwise affected by his prodigious consumption and, for some reason, the filmmakers seem amused by it. He looks healthy enough, even when lifting weights between sips.\n\nOne morning, Mike finds a badly beaten woman (Stefania Barr) near a field that he\u2019s slept in after another soused night. She\u2019s an enigma and soon his possible redemption, a sacrifice to the story gods that lets him play lawman again. With a cheap business card and an equally cheap jacket and tie, he smilingly ambles it into the shamus role, knocking on doors and sniffing out leads among all the yammer and serviceable visuals. Before long he is chasing down a familiar dark tale of very young women and very bad men, and trading patter with both a silky rich cat (Robert Forster) and a smooth pimp (Clifton Collins Jr.), who rolls up with a scowl, pummeling first, asking questions later.\n\nThe supporting players slide into their types just fine, though for the most part they remain little more than satellites orbiting Mike or, rather, Mr. Hawkes. Even Octavia Spencer, who plays Mike\u2019s sister and, as a performer, can overpower her scenes, never manages to wrest even the tiniest corner from Mr. Hawkes\u2019s firmly relaxed grip. The Nelmses don\u2019t make enough of their more intriguing ideas (Mike\u2019s familial history) and end up right where you expect they would, bang bang. But Mr. Hawkes keeps you tethered, whether he\u2019s navigating the movie\u2019s uneven tones or peeling down one of cinema\u2019s lonely highways in a muscle car so lovingly shot it deserves a co-star credit.", "title": "Review: In \u2018Small Town Crime,\u2019 Trouble Is His Business (Natch)", "authors": ["Manohla Dargis", "Eshom Nelms", "Ian Nelms"]} {"date": "2018-01-04 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThe Chi\u201d was created by Lena Waithe, a Chicago native who won an Emmy last year for an episode of \u201cMaster of None\u201d that she co-wrote, becoming the first black woman to win for comedy writing. (The executive producers include the rapper Common, also from Chicago; the showrunner is Elwood Reid, of the FX border drama \u201cThe Bridge.\u201d) \u201cThe Chi\u201d exudes hometown affection and tough love.\n\nIt\u2019s a tricky balance. The danger of this kind of story is that it can define its characters as personifications of social ills, so that we know them as problems before we know them as people. The first episode runs that risk, leaning hard into the melodrama and underlining its moments of pathos heavily.\n\nPhoto\n\nWhat emerges as \u201cThe Chi\u201d gets room to breathe is that, while it unfolds from a crime, it\u2019s not really a crime story. It\u2019s about a widening pool of people who would rather be doing anything besides dealing with the repercussions of a murder.\n\nRonnie (Ntare Guma Mbaho Mwine), the father figure to the dead young man, would rather be getting his life together. Brandon (Jason Mitchell), Coogie\u2019s half brother, would rather be advancing his career as a cook in a trendy restaurant. Twelve-year-old Kevin (Alex Hibbert), an unwitting witness, would rather be working up the nerve to talk to his crush at school.\n\nInstead, each of them is confronted by the expectation that to be a man means to take care of business violently. Mr. Mwine is especially remarkable as the precariously balanced Ronnie knocked off his axis by grief.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cThe Chi\u201d gradually builds its female characters as well, like Laverne (Sonja Sohn), Brandon\u2019s mother, who bitterly feels that her son thinks he\u2019s better than her, plating pork belly for hipsters and dating a woman who\u2019s \u201cbourgie as turkey bacon.\u201d\n\nViewers may recognize Ms. Sohn from HBO\u2019s \u201cThe Wire,\u201d and while \u201cThe Chi\u201d is a very different show, it shares some of that drama\u2019s conversational sense of humor.\n\nIt\u2019s also astute about how responsibility for others \u2014 parents, siblings, children \u2014 complicates lives. For instance, there\u2019s Emmett (Jacob Latimore), a charming ladies\u2019 man who learns that he has a toddler son, making him suddenly responsible for something besides his sneaker collection.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThere is a police story, which moves slowly at the periphery and is so far not too distinctive. But in its best moments, \u201cThe Chi\u201d offers a glimpse of the sort of stories these characters might live in if circumstance didn\u2019t make them players in a murder case. A subplot about Kevin getting conscripted into a production of \u201cThe Wiz\u201d is refreshing, and Shamon Brown Jr. is a delight as Kevin\u2019s husky, confident friend Papa.\n\nIn these scenes, \u201cThe Chi\u201d momentarily becomes a kind of South Side \u201cFreaks and Geeks\u201d \u2014 which is bittersweet, because these kids, like any, deserve to have a time in life when unrequited crushes and embarrassing musical numbers are their worst problems.\n\nInstead, they\u2019re involved in matters of life and death. I\u2019m hoping the life wins out, because it\u2019s far more interesting.", "title": "Review: In \u2018The Chi,\u2019 a Young Man Dies, and the Ripples Spread", "authors": ["James Poniewozik"]} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "Manal tries to reason with her husband, as does Tony\u2019s wife, Shirine (Rita Hayek), who is pregnant with their first child. Neither man really intends for things to escalate the way they do, nor can either figure out how to back down without a loss of face that would also feel like a betrayal. And so the movie\u2019s focus shifts from the private world of work and family into the court system and the news media. Tony hires a prominent Christian lawyer (the wonderfully histrionic Camille Salameh), while Yasser is represented by a woman (Diamand Bou Abboud) who turns out to be \u2014 spoiler alert! Metaphor alert! \u2014 the opposing counsel\u2019s daughter.\n\nAs that plot twist suggests, \u201cThe Insult,\u201d is not always subtle. As the trial progresses, it becomes more programmatic, confronting the viewer and the characters with reminders of past atrocities that sometimes feel heavy-handed. But the film derives some of its vital energy from the way that it often seems to argue with itself. The grace and precision of the performances \u2014 not only Mr. Karam\u2019s and Mr. El Basha\u2019s, but also those of the actors playing the colleagues, advocates, surprise witnesses and bureaucrats who populate an increasingly crowded story \u2014 push against the director\u2019s fondness for grand statements and obvious ironies.\n\nThis internal tension brings home the complicated point Mr. Doueiri is determined to make, which is that personal matters are neither separate from political concerns nor identical with them. At several moments, you expect a sentimental, uplifting solution, the hug or handshake that assures everyone that bygones will be bygones, that deep down we\u2019re all the same. But that would be a lie. The more complicated truth is that everyone who holds a grudge does so for a reason, and fears that letting go of it would mean the loss of something precious.\n\nThat may not seem like a very hopeful or happy idea. A hopeful, happy movie about the Middle East may be too much to ask for right now. But \u201cThe Insult\u201d is too energetic to be depressing. Sometimes it\u2019s just too energetic, period. But there is something undeniably exhilarating about the film\u2019s honest assessment of the never-ending conflict between decency and cruelty that rages in every nation, neighborhood and heart.", "title": "Review: In \u2018The Insult,\u2019 the Dispute Is Personal. And Political.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nThe Polish painter Zdzislaw Beksinski is not well known here, but an appreciation of this often funny but also harrowing and heartbreaking film does not require expertise on its subject. I should actually say \u201csubjects.\u201d As per the title, this fictionalized portrait is a family one. The movie opens in 2005, the year of Beksinski\u2019s death, with him making some wry and libidinous comments about future technology to a man we\u2019ll learn was his biographer. It then jumps back to 1977, and Beksinski (Andrzej Seweryn, unimpeachable, as is the rest of the cast) and his wife and mother walk across a plaza from their own apartment block to an unfinished one, where Beksinski\u2019s adult son, Tomasz, will live. At this point Tomasz is already struggling with mental illness.\n\nBeksinski himself, while a painter of apocalyptic, sci-fi landscapes, is a cheerful, sardonic sort. He\u2019s perhaps a little too bluff about Tomasz\u2019s condition. Discussing their son with his wife, he notes, \u201cAt least he\u2019s not running around with a razor, threatening to slice up his grandmas.\u201d Tomasz, who is present, retorts, \u201cI only consider knives and razor blades in relation to my own wrists.\u201d\n\nEntering the camcorder age, the Beksinskis become relentless chroniclers of their own lives. The director, Jan P. Matuszynski, mixes simulated home-video footage with stealthily virtuosic long-take scenes, including a remarkable one depicting an airplane excursion with Tomasz. The tragedies in this family\u2019s life are nearly constant, but Mr. Matuszynski approaches them with a tone that\u2019s matter-of-fact while also partaking in the particular wry irony that has been a hallmark of Polish cinema since the early 1960s.", "title": "Review: In \u2018The Last Family,\u2019 a Polish Artist\u2019s Tragic Home Life", "authors": ["Glenn Kenny", "Robert Bolesto"]} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "Early on, a dashboard camera captures a green light as it burns across the horizon. The men who witness the light as they\u2019re driving debate if they\u2019ve seen a comet or a crashing plane, but on video the flash looks alien, like a probe from a foreign and hostile universe. Even when the danger turns out to be terrestrial in nature, \u201cThe Road Movie\u201d always retains this same senseless strangeness. With every cut to a different camera, a surreal episode unfolds with a new menace. A couple drives through a forest fire so hot, the flames appear purple. When they aren\u2019t avoiding crashes, drivers are threatened with guns, sledgehammers and hatchets. Without explanation, a man jumps on the hood of a stranger\u2019s car, beating the glass first with his fists and then with his head.\n\nPerhaps strangest still is that throughout the bedlam, the drivers rarely betray their shock. They are under constant siege, but the only crack in their collective stoicism is the reliance on cameras to capture the chaos. The camera offers no protection; it only provides a witness. Fortunately for audiences, it\u2019s more pleasurable to witness anarchy than it is to experience it.", "title": "Review: In \u2018The Road Movie,\u2019 Russian Highways Are the Final Frontier", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-08 00:00:00", "text": "Sitting at a situation room\u2019s round table, Ms. Weaver, who also directs, portrays an unnamed President in a blazer, short skirt and sock garters.
