Still, the show can feel structurally wobbly: It has a lot to say and is not always sure how to say it.\n\nInspired moments do bubble up, as when the country ballad \u201cAs Soon As I Hang Up the Phone\u201d plays over a photo montage of world leaders holding receivers, or when the General picks up a ringing red telephone and sternly admonishes, \u201cI told you never to call me here.\u201d", "title": "Review: In \u2018Unexploded Ordnances,\u2019 It\u2019s an Hour to Doomsday. Help!", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nReviewing a film after its lead actor\u2019s death is grim even when the movie is good. The best that might be said about \u201cAbe and Phil\u2019s Last Poker Game,\u201d starring Martin Landau, who died in July, is that it might lead viewers to \u201cNorth by Northwest\u201d or \u201cEd Wood.\u201d\n\nMr. Landau plays Abe, a physician who moves into a nursing home with his deteriorating wife (Ann Marie Shea), an experience he finds humiliating. (In a tiresome motif, he insists on being addressed as \u201cdoctor,\u201d not \u201cmister.\u201d) But Abe becomes fast friends with Phil (Paul Sorvino). Each might be the biological father of a nurse (Maria Dizzia) who knows only that her mystery dad lives at the home.\n\nVideo\n\n\u201cAbe and Phil\u2019s\u201d is the first fiction feature from its writer and director, Howard L. Weiner, a neurology professor at Harvard Medical School who founded a center for multiple sclerosis. That\u2019s noble work, and knowing of it provides context for the movie. The medical tidbits, however awkwardly presented, are the most distinctive aspects of the script. The flat direction, alas, is not the work of a filmmaker.\n\nThe surprisingly many scenes devoted to Abe and Phil\u2019s discussions of their potency (and their efforts to reignite it) mostly just play as embarrassing. The emphasis on the physical tolls of aging might be excused as a bold confrontation of tough truths. It\u2019s as difficult to begrudge Dr. Weiner that effort as it is to watch the results.", "title": "Review: Martin Landau and Paul Sorvino in \u2018Abe and Phil\u2019s Last Poker Game\u2019", "authors": ["Ben Kenigsberg", "Howard Weiner"]} {"date": "2018-01-09 00:00:00", "text": "The two operas are staged in the same small-town Italian square, a few decades apart; a program note, and the transition from candles to electric light, suggests that we go from about 1900 (\u201cCav\u201d) to 1950 (\u201cPag\u201d).\n\n\u201cCav,\u201d in this telling, is a grave tale told on a woozily rotating set, filled with people somberly dancing, dressed in black; \u201cPag\u201d has the antic sparkle that a traveling comedy troupe might indeed have inspired in a country still recovering from war. Nicola Luisotti\u2019s conducting, like the staging, renders the two operas both distinct and of a piece \u2014 lugubrious (just a touch too much so) in \u201cCav\u201d; sunnier in \u201cPag\u201d; both rich and vigorous throughout.\n\nRoberto Alagna \u2014 who at 54 has become that paradox, an underrated star \u2014 plays both tenor leads, the caddish Turiddu of \u201cCav\u201d and the jealous clown in \u201cPag,\u201d with commitment and brightly shining tone. More of a paternal figure these days than a youthful rebel, he gives the show a solemn solidity.\n\nThe mezzo-soprano Ekaterina Semenchuk is an imposingly earthy foil to him as Santuzza in \u201cCav.\u201d In \u201cPag,\u201d the soprano Aleksandra Kurzak, married to Mr. Alagna in real life, is here the wife who betrays him, to her doom, playing Nedda as more headstrong than wistful, her voice vulnerable in texture but firm in presence. The brooding George Gagnidze sings compactly and well in both operas; Rihab Chaieb has a resiny cameo as Lola in \u201cCav,\u201d Andrew Bidlack a charming one as Beppe in \u201cPag.\u201d\n\nIf the Met is going to insist on serving us the stalest selections possible, the least it can do is present them with this degree of polish and professionalism.", "title": "Review: Met Opera\u2019s Dreary January Is Brightened by \u2018Cav/Pag\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "That moment might be more effective if it chilled us. Instead, we\u2019re charmed. By now we\u2019re accustomed to this Puckish lad looking out at us with his can-you-believe-this gaze when his friends and family behave as stupidly as he predicted they would.\n\nPhoto\n\nThat\u2019s our Hamlet. What a cutup! Even when he pulls a pistol out of his chicly oversize cardigan, paired with skinnier-than-thou jeans (Jess Goldstein did the trendy costumes), and talks of being or not being, it\u2019s hard to think of him as a threat \u2014 to himself or to anyone else.\n\nI greatly admire Mr. Urie, whose smart, calculatingly silly performances in both \u201cTorch Song\u201d and \u201cThe Government Inspector\u201d were theater high points last year. And I\u2019d love to be able to say that there\u2019s sly, subversive method in his madcappery here. But if there is, he\u2019s not sharing it.\n\nMr. Kahn, the longtime artistic director of the Shakespeare Company Theater, makes an intelligent choice for the opening scene. He knows that most theatergoers will be familiar with Mr. Urie for his breezy television work (\u201cUgly Betty\u201d). And rather than have us wait, judgmental minds at the ready, for Mr. Urie to show up in Scene II, Mr. Kahn throws him at us, in full monologue, before the play proper begins.\n\nSwathed in shadows and standing next to what appears to be an open grave, Mr. Urie delivers the \u201ctoo too solid flesh\u201d soliloquy (which usually comes toward the end of Scene II) as a prologue. It\u2019s a gamble that pays off. This monologue offers a surprisingly cogent summing up of the state of Denmark we are about to enter. And it lets us see immediately whether Mr. Urie can, well, speak the speech.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nHe can. In those initial moments, he paints a persuasive portrait of a terminally restless young man at odds with himself and the world, wrestling with doubts and losing. It\u2019s a respectable, A-minus audition piece, and you hopefully await the fuller performance to come.\n\nBut very little that follows \u2014 from Mr. Urie and from the production as a whole \u2014 is on that level. The Hamlet who steps into the court of Elsinore is clearly the same guy we just met. But it\u2019s as if he had unleashed himself from some confining mental corset, and he\u2019s grimacing and gesturing up a storm. (He can\u2019t stop moving his hands even when they\u2019re in his pockets.)\n\nPerhaps feeling that there\u2019s no point in competing with a royal tornado, the rest of the cast turns in nigh-invisible performances that lean toward somnolence or stiffness. Even that old windbag Polonius, played by Robert Joy, is less a bombastic grandstander than a dry-as-dust martinet.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAs his doomed daughter (and Hamlet\u2019s sometime girlfriend), Ophelia, Oyin Oladejo exudes such common-sense solidity that she seems shatterproof. Madeleine Potter, as Hamlet\u2019s lusty mother, Gertrude, has a commandingly ripe presence, but her mind often seems to be elsewhere (maybe wondering where she left the crown jewels).\n\nPhoto\n\nAlan Cox\u2019s King Claudius (who murdered his brother, Hamlet\u2019s father) projects very little menace. He\u2019s soft around the edges, like some lazy fat cat who lucked into the throne by accident rather than regicide.\n\nAnd it\u2019s hard to imagine his being in charge of the sinister, all-seeing state summoned by John Coyne\u2019s set, with its walls of video monitors and hidden cameras and microphones. (The same visual motifs were deployed more effectively in Robert Icke\u2019s production of \u201cHamlet\u201d in London last year, starring Andrew Scott.)\n\nThere are also smartphones galore. Hamlet and Ophelia text each other their messages of love. And a game Claudius photobombs a selfie being taken by Hamlet\u2019s college chums, Rosencrantz (Ryan Spahn) and Guildenstern (Kelsey Rainwater).\n\nHamlet uses his phone to make the occasional note-to-self (including that \u201cone may smile, and smile, and be a villain\u201d). If only those notes included the advice Hamlet later gives to the traveling company of players.\n\n\u201cIn the very torrent, tempest and (as I may say) whirlwind of your passion, you must acquire and beget a temperance that may give it smoothness,\u201d he tells the actors as they prepare to stage a Hamlet-tweaked tragedy. Since Mr. Urie is delivering this counsel in full torrent-tempest-whirlwind mode, you can feel the other actors just itching to roll their eyes.", "title": "Review: Michael Urie Puts the Madcap in Hamlet\u2019s Madness", "authors": ["Ben Brantley"]} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "That time was the 1990s, so the ostensible edginess here is pretty stale. For instance, in an early scene, little Josh taunts the family\u2019s Asian housekeeper by referring to her as \u201cCharlie,\u201d the derogatory nickname American soldiers called the Viet Cong, and \u2014 get this! \u2014 she gives back as good as she gets, crabbily shooting back, \u201cI am Chinese. Chinese is not Charlie.\u201d\n\nUgh. Anyway, \u201cMom and Dad\u201d soon reveals its high concept: All the parents in its world go mad and try to start killing their kids. The writer and director Brian Taylor shies away from no possibility here, including a delivery room scene in which a woman begins crushing her newborn. As you can imagine, the homicidal frenzy gives Mr. Cage plenty of opportunity to go full him, which, in this case, doesn\u2019t yield as much fun as you might have hoped.\n\nMr. Taylor was half of the directing team, with Mark Neveldine, responsible for some hilariously crass and irrational movies such as \u201cCrank\u201d and \u201cCrank: High Voltage.\u201d I presume that Mr. Neveldine was the funny one of the duo, because absent his input, Mr. Taylor offers up nothing but glitchy editing and bad vibes.", "title": "Review: Nicolas Cage Goes Homicidally Nuts in \u2018Mom and Dad\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "Ms. Goodwin stays true to her conception of Victoria as a combination of coquettish flibbertigibbet, tough proto-feminist and compassionate, perhaps too-good-to-be-true liberal humanist. She recoils when labeled \u201cpleasingly fecund,\u201d suffers through a bout of postpartum depression, is forgiving of the staff\u2019s peccadilloes and shakes hands with the black American actor Ira Aldridge (Ashley Zhangazha) \u2014 an audacious move in that era \u2014 when he comes to the palace to declaim lines from \u201cOthello.\u201d\n\nLike a Disney princess, the queen has an almost unerring instinct for the right choice, though the script often stacks the deck in such a way that the choices make themselves. (Victoria\u2019s compassion for the starving Irish is helped along when one of her ministers calls the famine \u201can inevitable period of self-regulation\u201d of what he regards as a shiftless population.)\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMs. Goodwin is not immune to clich\u00e9s and on-the-nose metaphors (the constrictiveness of the corset, the sleight-of-hand of French cooking). A too-familiar sickbed scene should not end with the doctor saying, \u201cThe fever has broken,\u201d and yet it does. The need to compress history leads to moments that are maudlin or heavy-handed.\n\nBut she has a Julian Fellowes-like ability to keep a story moving and fill it with interesting, engaging characters. Diana Rigg, no longer needed in \u201cGame of Thrones,\u201d joins the cast in high curmudgeon mode as a lady in waiting, a harrumphing embodiment of British propriety and narrow-mindedness. Mr. Sewell briefly reprises his touching portrayal of Melbourne, and Tom Hughes is still fine as the broody but well-meaning Prince Albert (a marked contrast to the conceited simp Matt Smith makes out of Prince Philip in \u201cThe Crown.\u201d)\n\nBut the engine of the show, the thing that keeps it from being just another period soap opera, is Jenna Coleman\u2019s inexhaustible, tremendously engaging portrayal of Victoria, a performance whose easy charm can obscure the fact that it\u2019s as subtle and witty as anything Claire Foy does as Elizabeth II in \u201cThe Crown.\u201d\n\n\u201cVictoria\u201d is at heart a love story, or collection of love stories, and while Ms. Goodwin occasionally bogs down in history, she can always get back on solid ground with romance. In Season 2 she introduces, as a counterpoint to Victoria and Albert, an unspoken attraction between a courtier and a civil servant (Jordan Waller and Leo Suter) that\u2019s an unusually complex and moving depiction of a gay relationship.\n\nBut every episode comes back, one way or another, to Victoria and Albert, and Ms. Coleman and Mr. Hughes make us believe in their tender (but highly physical) attraction to each other, and root for their success. If the lasting image of \u201cThe Crown\u201d is Elizabeth and Philip retreating to separate beds, \u201cVictoria\u201d gives us Little Vicky and her prince, their beautiful heads of hair impeccably tousled, walking hand in hand in the Scottish Highlands. There\u2019s no wrong choice there, but there\u2019s a more immediately gratifying one.", "title": "Review: One Vote for \u2018Victoria\u2019 Over \u2018The Crown\u2019", "authors": ["Mike Hale"]} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nA handy tip: If you are a character in a play and you are invited to a get-together, don\u2019t go. Don\u2019t go to dinner parties. Don\u2019t go to cocktail parties, reunions, anniversaries or showers. A costume party? Absolutely not. And if a Dublin woman recovering from a suicide attempt throws an inexplicable shindig to celebrate the completion of her new kitchen extension, RSVP no.\n\nThat absurd soiree activates Isobel Mahon\u2019s \u201cParty Face,\u201d an unlikely comedy at City Center Stage II that recently toured Ireland under its original title, \u201cBoom?\u201d Before the evening is out, drinks will have been drunk, insults lobbed, upchuck hurled and a topiary sculpture annihilated. Thanks for coming. Don\u2019t let the canap\u00e9s hit you on the way out.\n\nWhy has an audience been asked over? Well, that probably has something to do with the eternal sweetheart Hayley Mills (\u201cPollyanna,\u201d \u201cThe Parent Trap\u201d), who has been given a plum role and makes a dainty meal of it, all while wearing high heels and pink silk capri pants. No small feat.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn Amanda Bearse\u2019s production, our hostess is the glum Mollie Mae (Gina Costigan), home from the psychiatric unit after suffering a nervous breakdown in the cereal aisle of a supermarket. (Been there.) Joining her are her sister, Maeve (Brenda Meaney); her neighbor Chloe (Allison Jean White); her psych ward compatriot Bernie (Klea Blackhurst); and her mother, Carmel (Ms. Mills), a status-conscious suburbanite with a genius for undermining.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cOh, lovely flowers,\u201d Carmel tells her daughter as she enters. \u201cCourse in my day you never saw a lily outside of a funeral parlor, but sure, that\u2019s progress.\u201d If Ms. Mills doesn\u2019t quite nail the Dublin accent, boy, does she ace the sunny jibe.", "title": "Review: Putting a \u2018Party Face\u2019 on a Suicide Recovery", "authors": ["Alexis Soloski"]} {"date": "2018-01-16 00:00:00", "text": "The death of Mr. Maxwell\u2019s mother figures in \u201cParadiso,\u201d in the first of three extended soliloquies that follow the robot\u2019s prologue. The performer here is Elaine Davis, a middle-aged woman of clean-scrubbed eloquence and an almost accusatory air of detachment.\n\nShe begins with a philosophical abstractedness that shades into a very particular account of the last days of a woman\u2019s life, as witnessed by her son. Its poignancy becomes even more pronounced when the speaker shifts to a consideration of how a domestic landscape changes when the person at the center of it is gone. And from there, it seems natural to progress into a greater vision of life without lives.\n\nThat shifting scale \u2014 among past, present and future; between the personal and the pan-historical \u2014 is essential to \u201cParadiso.\u201d Another soliloquy, delivered by Jessica Gallucci, transforms a view from the window of a train into an eloquent summing up of 600 years of American history.\n\nMs. Gallucci traces the evolution of a people who crossed the water and then the desert, and \u201cbeat back nature,\u201d who were \u201ctolerant so long as we felt we could do what we needed to do.\u201d Another monologue, performed by Charles Reina, is addressed to a God his character describes in increasingly anthropomorphic terms. Such are the reach and limits of our imagination.\n\nThough Mr. Maxwell is cherished by avant-garde European audiences, his work has always been quintessentially American, and never more so than with \u201cParadiso.\u201d His human ensemble members, rounded out by Carina Goebelbecker, arrive in the gallery in a gleaming white truck, like the cast of a television ad that associates driving in open spaces with a frontier spirit of independence.\n\nThe production is punctuated by wordless interludes in which the four performers go through ritualized movements that suggest a classic nuclear family working together and breaking apart, comforting and confronting. The ambivalence of belonging to a clan \u2014 and by extension, to a race of beings \u2014 is pervasive.\n\nThat is true even of that early description of Mr. Maxwell\u2019s relationship with his mother, and scenes that would seem to portray a mother and father dealing with a seriously ill daughter. People are never portrayed as entirely noble here; purity of intention and action doesn\u2019t exist.", "title": "Review: Richard Maxwell Considers Life After Life in \u2018Paradiso\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-14 00:00:00", "text": "As Tim has an epiphany of self-awareness, Mr. Spears dares to envelop these men in rapturous music of almost cinematic lushness, with opulent chords and fidgety inner voices, often floating over droning bass tones and an eerily repetitive inner pulse. Tim is a sweet, soft-spoken radical. Once his sexual desires are drawn out by Hawk, he leaps ahead and knows what he wants: commitment, domesticity and romance, even if it must be kept in the shadows. Hawk, for all his swagger, is actually weaker, someone who accepts the strictures of 1950s American life and gets his highs by his surreptitious defiance of societal mores.\n\nThroughout the over two-hour length, George Manahan drew textured, colorful playing from the American Composers Orchestra. The simple, effective production, fluidly directed by Kevin Newbury, was first seen at the Cincinnati Opera, where \u201cFellow Travelers\u201d had its premiere in 2016.\n\nThe cast of nine included several singers who took two or three roles. I almost wish the role of Mary, who works with Hawk, were larger, especially as sung so movingly by the soprano Devon Guthrie. Mary is a source of common sense, decency and tolerance. Mr. Spears, again surprising me, gives Mary curiously agitated and flighty music. But it somehow works. I kept thinking that Ms. Guthrie\u2019s Mary should be running not just her office, but the whole State Department. We could use her now.", "title": "Review: Risk-Taking New Opera Tells a Tragic 1950s Gay Love Story", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "A musical week that began on Monday with displays of extended instrumental techniques, in the New York Philharmonic\u2019s Contact! concert at National Sawdust in Brooklyn, wound down on Thursday with a show of extended vocal techniques, by the ensemble Roomful of Teeth at Zankel Hall.\n\nRoomful, an a cappella octet founded in 2009, is a veritable repository of such practices, using amplification and close miking to artistic effect. Its guiding philosophy was summed up by its artistic director, Brad Wells, in a preconcert discussion at Zankel: \u201cVoices can do so much more.\u201d\n\nMore of what? The sky may be a limit, maybe not.\n\nRoomful\u2019s great showpiece is the Partita for 8 Voices, a four-movement work by one of its members, the alto Caroline Shaw, which won the 2013 Pulitzer Prize for music. The Pulitzer citation aptly described some of the techniques involved: \u201cspeech, whispers, sighs, murmurs, wordless melodies and novel vocal effects.\u201d It could have added grunts, rasps, throat singing and even a sort of winding twang suggesting a jaw harp.", "title": "Review: Roomful of Teeth Stretches for a Piano Premiere", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "That was just what worried me: the possibility of past-its-prime ham. (Mr. Lithgow has never been uncomfortable with the grand style.) \u201cStories by Heart\u201d seemed to be the kind of quick and cheap show that a theater company, in this case the Roundabout, mounts when there\u2019s a hole in its schedule or budget. (The production, directed by Daniel Sullivan, is luxurious only in Kenneth Posner\u2019s lighting.) Besides, who needs the equivalent of a bedtime fairy tale on Broadway when you can have your phone read you \u201cMoby-Dick\u201d on the subway?\n\nThough golden enough for any nostalgist, \u201cStories by Heart\u201d is neither soporific nor cute. For starters, the two stories that Mr. Lithgow recites \u2014 \u201cHaircut\u201d in the first act and P. G. Wodehouse\u2019s \u201cUncle Fred Flits By\u201d in the second \u2014 are superb, outlandish and, in very different ways, hair-raising.\n\nYou wouldn\u2019t guess that from the opening of \u201cHaircut,\u201d in which a professionally logorrheic barber entertains a new customer with tales of life in his two-bit town. There\u2019s this practical joker, you see, and this gal who won\u2019t give him the time of day and this doctor she likes and so on. But the story soon asserts itself, or rather insinuates itself, as a scathing indictment of good-old-boy-ism: the barely civilized tradition of men playing tricks on one another and arranging nasty traps (including marriage) for women.\n\nThat\u2019s all in the Lardner, but Mr. Lithgow adds another emotional channel by showing us how the barber, himself a good old boy, is implicated in the nastiness he pretends only to describe. An astonishing collection of laughs \u2014 whinnies, giggles, squeals, snorts, heaves \u2014 gradually colors the narrative, until this seemingly harmless man becomes, in effect, not just a witness to savagery, but also an accessory.\n\nThe seemingly harmless man I mean is the one in Lardner\u2019s story, but the same thought applies to the quite real man who plays him. The ease with which Mr. Lithgow inhabits the character, merely untucking his shirt to suggest a barber\u2019s smock, hints at the way all effective storytellers are complicit in their stories.", "title": "Review: Surprise Lessons From John Lithgow\u2019s \u2018Stories by Heart\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "You would think that if there were something newsworthy about \u201cWaco,\u201d a six-episode dramatization of the 1993 Branch Davidian shootout and siege, it would be how it depicts a key event in the radicalization of America\u2019s far right. Or, secondarily, how it resonates as the first major offering of the Paramount Network, a new cable channel. (It\u2019s on your grid where Spike used to be.)\n\nBut in a sign of how quickly one cultural forest fire follows another these days, \u201cWaco\u201d has been in the news because of the channel\u2019s decision to remove from the credits the name of one of the show\u2019s backers \u2014 the Weinstein Company, corporation non grata after the Harvey Weinstein sexual-abuse revelations.\n\nOf course, one of the things that David Koresh, leader of the Branch Davidian religious sect, was known for was his habit of sexually appropriating other members\u2019 wives. In \u201cWaco,\u201d a tepid, movie-of-the-week treatment of a fateful calamity in which more than 80 people died, Koresh\u2019s appetites are a tolerated vexation among the Branch Davidians and an opportunity for the filmmakers to inject some humor. Turning on his irresistible twinkle, Taylor Kitsch, as Koresh, tells a new recruit that he\u2019ll be expected to remain celibate because \u201cI\u2019ve assumed the burden of sex for us all.\u201d\n\nParamount\u2019s publicity materials claim that \u201cWaco,\u201d based on a pair of memoirs \u2014 one by a Branch Davidian survivor, David Thibodeau, and one by an F.B.I. hostage negotiator, Gary Noesner \u2014 \u201cwill forever change the way the dramatic siege will be viewed.\u201d There\u2019s nothing to back up that claim in the three episodes available for review, which follow a familiar trajectory from the earlier Ruby Ridge standoff through the botched raid, by Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms, on the Branch Davidians\u2019 complex outside Waco.", "title": "Review: Taylor Kitsch Is a Charismatic David Koresh in \u2018Waco\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "As in the film, the cast is small and all female. But here it is more diverse. The Rwandan actress Kaneza Schaal plays Petra, and Samita Sinha, a vocalist and composer of Indian descent, plays Karin. The three other performers each portray a character (Petra\u2019s daughter, Petra\u2019s friend, Petra\u2019s mother), but also take turns as the abused, passive Marlene, sometimes embodying her collectively.\n\nThese three wear overalls labeled \u201cstaff,\u201d and the work\u2019s principal choreography consists in how they move the minimal set pieces: foam-board cutouts, a plush, pink rug. The outfits flag a possible analogy: Is the sadomasochistic Petra-Marlene relationship somehow akin to the one between a director and his cast?\n\nThe idea is present, less obviously, in the Fassbinder film. Late in \u201cPetra,\u201d the performer Paz Tanjuaquio brings it up explicitly. In previous scenes, cast members speak as \u201cthemselves,\u201d giving brief monologues about their love for their husbands or for dance, but Ms. Tanjuaquio resists telling her story. Would such a confession, she asks, be for her or for the audience or just for Mr. Moss to use?\n\nThe Petra-Moss parallel, however, lacks conviction, and the true crux is Mr. Moss\u2019s use of the Fassbinder film. Were \u201cPetra\u201d merely a stage adaptation, it would be a terribly flat one. Ms. Schaal\u2019s performance is single note and static, and no one else even tries to act. None of the film\u2019s sexual tension is preserved, none of the pathos beneath the histrionics that makes it at once hilarious and haunting.\n\nPerhaps Mr. Moss was after something else. In place of the film\u2019s stunning ending, he has Ms. Sinha (who also sings several times) lead members of the audience in a group recitation of bureaucratic suggestions for increasing audience diversity. The joke is arch and accurate, but like the rest of the piece\u2019s commentary on race, it\u2019s inert.", "title": "Review: The Bitter Tears of Dean Moss & Co.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-21 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nForgive and forget. That was clearly the prevailing attitude among audience members for the tenor Jonas Kaufmann\u2019s sold-out recital at Carnegie Hall on Saturday night. Actually, Mr. Kaufmann\u2019s many fans in New York have a right to be miffed, given his history of cancellations in recent years.\n\nHe was supposed to be singing the role of Mario Cavaradossi right now in the Metropolitan Opera\u2019s new production of Puccini\u2019s \u201cTosca.\u201d But he withdrew just weeks after the Met announced it. In 2016, he pulled out of the company\u2019s production of \u201cManon Lescaut,\u201d not to mention a couple of sold-out performances of \u201cCarmen\u201d in 2015 as well.\n\nBut, finally, showing up as scheduled on Saturday, he performed Schubert\u2019s song cycle \u201cDie Sch\u00f6ne M\u00fcllerin\u201d with the probing pianist Helmut Deutsch. When Mr. Kaufmann appeared onstage (after a tension-inducing 15-minute delay), the audience broke into prolonged applause and bravos. Mr. Kaufmann apologized for starting late and then, in somewhat confusing comments, he explained why: The work (a cycle of 20 songs lasting some 60 minutes) would be performed without a break, he said, and he wanted to make sure everyone in the audience had arrived. (Officially, no latecomers were admitted.)\n\nThe performance started off strongly. In the opening song, \u201cDas Wandern,\u201d the cycle\u2019s protagonist, a journeyman miller, sings of the joys of his lifestyle, wandering from town to town, taking work at a mill and moving on, just like the babbling waters of the brook. The qualities of Mr. Kaufmann\u2019s voice that have made him the most sought-after tenor in opera were vividly present, especially the unusual combination of burnished, virile sound and slightly covered, dusky shadings. In the second song, \u201cWohin?\u201d (\u201cWhither?\u201d), Mr. Kaufmann brought poignant earnestness to the questions that run through the miller\u2019s thoughts as he looks to the gurgling brook for guidance: \u201cIs this then my path?\u201d \u201cWhy do I speak of babbling?\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSoon, however, some vocal glitches and moments of tightness started creeping into Mr. Kaufmann\u2019s singing. They continued throughout this sometimes frustrating performance.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nOne moment he would take you to the core of a dramatically complex song, like \u201cDer Neugierige,\u201d when the miller, smitten by a maid at a mill he\u2019s come upon, wonders if she returns his feelings. But a couple of times during this song, and in others, Mr. Kaufmann\u2019s voice nearly broke. He reined in his sound tastefully to adapt his voice to lieder. But when he really let go and sang with operatic fervor, he sounded more secure.", "title": "Review: The Elusive Jonas Kaufmann Finally Returns to New York", "authors": ["Anthony Tommasini"]} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "Lines like that really only work in a multicamera format, a structure that relies on present laughter as part of its punctuation. Studio audiences make shows feel bigger, and \u201cOne Day at a Time\u201d is a show that\u2019s big \u2014 maybe even broad \u2014 with its line deliveries, its staging, even in its sad moments. CBS\u2019s \u201cMom,\u201d about a formerly estranged mother-daughter duo, is another current multicamera show with edge and depth (and that network\u2019s \u201cThe Big Bang Theory\u201d remains wildly popular). But otherwise this is a style that\u2019s become unfashionable, something comedy nerds sneered at; \u201claugh track\u201d is shorthand for not merely unfunny but also worthy of scorn.\n\nIf any show could re-establish the format as a place for innovative, modern comedy, it\u2019s \u201cOne Day at a Time,\u201d energetically political and progressive. Partially that\u2019s because the show hails from the executive producer Norman Lear, alongside the creators Gloria Calderon Kellett and Mike Royce. Mr. Lear helped popularize the modern incarnation of the multicam comedy, with shows like \u201cAll in the Family\u201d and \u201cThe Jeffersons.\u201d That rhythm became the standard for family comedies right on up through, say, \u201cEverybody Loves Raymond.\u201d Then the tides turned, and single-camera shows like \u201cModern Family\u201d or \u201cblack-ish\u201d are now the standard bearers.\n\nSo despite its retro vibe, \u201cDay\u201d feels almost daring. Its lack of cynicism makes it easy to marathon and also sets it apart from the revered comedies of the moment, like \u201cVeep\u201d or \u201cBoJack Horseman.\u201d Its devotion to that straightforward sitcom setup makes it more accessible than shows like the highly serialized \u201cThe Good Place,\u201d or the structurally inventive \u201cAtlanta.\u201d It\u2019s suitable for most ages, but without the crushing inanity of a \u201cFuller House.\u201d", "title": "Review: The Euphoria of \u2018One Day at a Time\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nWith so many details of his death in doubt, we may never really know what happened to Michael Brown and why. Incontestably, the 18-year-old was unarmed when a police officer fired 12 shots at him on Canfield Avenue in Ferguson, Mo., on Aug. 9, 2014, two days before he was to enroll in a technical college. The officer, Darren Wilson, was white. Mr. Brown, it almost goes without saying, was black.\n\nWhat the younger man had done earlier that evening, or not done; what racist thoughts Mr. Wilson harbored, or didn\u2019t; whether Mr. Brown was surrendering, with his arms up, or threatening Mr. Wilson through the patrol car\u2019s window: The answers to all these questions seem irretrievably lost in a cloud of contention. What we can say is that one man, having avoided indictment, is free three years later and the other is still dead.\n\nNeither that conclusion nor the uncertainty of what came before it releases us, though, from the burden of trying to understand the meaning of the killing, and in that sense Dael Orlandersmith does a great public service in her new play \u201cUntil the Flood,\u201d which opened on Thursday at Rattlestick Playwrights Theater. Portraying only eight people \u2014 nine if you include her own alter ego \u2014 she nevertheless brings the questions, the pain and even the unspeakable thoughts of hundreds, if not millions, to life. \u201cUntil the Flood\u201d is an urgent moral inquest.\n\nIts technique will be familiar to those who have followed the genre of quasi-documentary, monologue-based theater, particularly as honed by Anna Deavere Smith and, in some of her earlier plays, Ms. Orlandersmith herself. To research \u201cUntil the Flood,\u201d whose title ties together the many images of flow and overflow in the script, she conducted a series of interviews in and around Ferguson. (The play was commissioned by the Repertory Theater of St. Louis, some 15 miles away.) From the interviews she fashioned the local characters \u2014 black, white, male, female, young, old \u2014 she inhabits here.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn their ticktock alternation, they could easily have seemed predictable. Rusty, a white retired Ferguson police officer predisposed to justify Mr. Wilson\u2019s use of his gun, is immediately followed by Hassan, a 17-year-old black \u201cstreet kid\u201d who freestyles his fury about the daily harassment the police inflict on people like him:\n\nHe looked back at me\n\nhis finger on the trigger\n\nDroolin\n\nLike a dog mutt\n\nJust like a hungry dog mutt\n\nI bet Mike Brown saw that too.\n\nThen we move on to Connie, a well-meaning white teacher in a wine bar. Connie can\u2019t understand why her feelings about the case \u2014 she describes it as a tragedy for both Mr. Brown and Mr. Wilson \u2014 have alienated a black friend.", "title": "Review: The Ghosts of Michael Brown, in \u2018Until the Flood\u2019", "authors": ["Jesse Green"]} {"date": "2018-01-02 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nThe experience of watching the documentary \u201cAnatomy of a Male Ballet Dancer\u201d is a lesson for our times. As its title suggests, it is a head-to-battered-toe consideration of a male ballet dancer that takes you from studio to stage and points in between. It is formally conventional and draws on the usual zippy you-are-there moments with lots of gabby talking heads. What elevates it, though, is its charming \u2014 and from all accounts \u2014 deeply talented subject, Marcelo Gomes. So after it was over I eagerly searched Google for him on my phone only to discover that the day before, on Dec. 21, he had resigned from the American Ballet Theater after he was accused of sexual misconduct.\n\nThe details remain sketchy. The New York Times reported that Andrew F. Barth, the chairman of the company\u2019s board of trustees, had announced the bombshell news in an emailed statement: \u201cLast Saturday, A.B.T. was made aware of a highly concerning allegation of sexual misconduct by Mr. Gomes, occurring approximately eight years ago.\u201d Ballet Theater took \u201cimmediate action,\u201d and during its investigation, Mr. Gomes resigned. His spokeswoman told The Times in another emailed statement: \u201cThis is a time of reflection for Marcelo. He is gratified and strengthened by the support he has received from family, friends and colleagues. We have no further comment at this time.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThese revelations aren\u2019t in \u201cAnatomy of a Male Ballet Dancer,\u201d which was produced, directed and shot by David Barba and James Pellerito. And while the accusations don\u2019t invalidate the documentary, they have inevitably transformed its generally breezy, sometimes teary and altogether upbeat portrait. The movie is a classic underdog story, that of a Brazilian prodigy who \u2014 with a great deal of raw talent and drive, along with the kindness and encouragement of family and friends \u2014 matures into a genius of dance. Now, invariably, every painstaking step of that journey, each beat and milestone, comes with an unsettling asterisk as delight at his artistry mixes with doubt about his character.\n\nThe artistry is unassailable. Mr. Barba and Mr. Pellerito began shooting the movie in early 2010. Mr. Gomes had joined Ballet Theater in 1997 at 18 and was promoted to a principal dancer in 2002. He soared. In a 2007 review of \u201cCinderella\u201d in The Times, Alastair Macaulay wrote that Mr. Gomes \u201cis at his finest as her prince: handsome dancing, modest, relaxed, attentive\u201d \u2014 a description that nicely fits scene after scene of his performances here. Much of the documentary\u2019s drama involves the countdown to his 20th anniversary with Ballet Theater and all that entails, including Mr. Gomes\u2019s acute attention to his aging body and his hope that his father will see him dance in New York.\n\nDocumentary portraits of this type often incorporate testimonials from affable, encouraging experts who smilingly help burnish the subject\u2019s reputation. \u201cAnatomy of a Male Ballet Dancer\u201d is stuffed with such enthusiastic recommendations, including from numerous dancers \u2014 Misty Copeland, Julie Kent and Veronika Part \u2014 with whom Mr. Gomes partnered over his career. The love for him just pours off the screen in these moments, as does the respect and admiration. These persuasive testimonials are scattered among the dances, festivals and interstitial sections in which the energetic, very peripatetic Mr. Gomes quiets down and settles in for some intimate on-camera sharing.\n\nMuch of this is agreeable, or at least was. In retrospect, the sheer amount of gush in the movie, all the praise and feverish shouts of bravo, underscores the limits of affirmational documentaries. It is also a reminder that a movie\u2019s meaning is made (and remade) by its viewers, not just its content. Mr. Barba and Mr. Pellerito set out to create a portrait of Mr. Gomes, who comes across as an extremely nice guy. When I saw the movie in December, their portrayal seemed rather too fluffy and fawningly one-note, but it was also hard to resist. Mr. Gomes can be thrilling to watch even when partly obscured by a partner\u2019s dress, but it may be that more of him was hidden from us than this movie suggests.", "title": "Review: The Incomplete Vision of \u2018Anatomy of a Male Ballet Dancer\u2019", "authors": ["Manohla Dargis", "David Barba", "James Pellerito"]} {"date": "2018-01-01 00:00:00", "text": "The stakes could not have been higher. The chaos could not have been wilder. It\u2019s fair to say that no production in the Metropolitan Opera\u2019s history has been more vexed than the new staging of Puccini\u2019s \u201cTosca\u201d that opened on New Year\u2019s Eve.\n\nFirst, months ago, its star tenor pulled out. Then its star soprano. Then her husband, who was slated to conduct.\n\nHis replacement, James Levine, a fixture at the company for four decades, was suspended from the Met last month over accusations of sexual misconduct. And a few weeks ago, for good measure, the opera\u2019s villain canceled too.\n\nIt speaks to the Met\u2019s resourcefulness that it was able to field such an impressive premiere cast \u2014 the rising stars Sonya Yoncheva and Vittorio Grigolo and the stalwart Zeljko Lucic \u2014 on such relatively short notice. But even with some exciting singing, this \u201cTosca\u201d could point the company in the wrong direction.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe production was already, before all the withdrawals, a kind of referendum on Peter Gelb, the company\u2019s general manager. Early in his tenure, in 2009, Mr. Gelb replaced Franco Zeffirelli\u2019s lavish 1985 \u201cTosca\u201d with a grim, irreverent staging by Luc Bondy. The boos were loud; some patrons and most (though not all) critics rebelled. The Bondy \u201cTosca\u201d became a proxy war in the battles that rage in opera between tradition and innovation.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Gelb eventually gave in, calling the production \u201cone of the blunders of my tenure.\u201d In a recent interview he was even more abject.", "title": "Review: The Met Opera\u2019s \u2018Tosca\u2019 Overcomes Months of Chaos", "authors": ["Anthony Tommasini"]} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "The documentary \u201cThe Opera House\u201d celebrates the history of the Metropolitan Opera \u2014 in particular, the construction of the organization\u2019s current Lincoln Center home, which had its 50th anniversary in 2016. Given that Peter Gelb, the general manager of the Met, is one of the producers, and that the movie is opening at the Film Society of Lincoln Center, the Met\u2019s across-the-plaza neighbor, it should probably be taken as a partisan history.\n\nTo its credit, \u201cThe Opera House,\u201d directed by Susan Froemke, only sometimes plays like a fund-raising tool. The meatiest material concerns the building of Lincoln Center. Architecture historians describe the competing visions for the design of the complex, and the movie doesn\u2019t ignore the displacement that came with what Robert Moses called \u201cthe scythe of progress.\u201d Former West Side residents share stories of having to leave their homes. It\u2019s also suggested that Lincoln Center had a specific Cold War role as an institution designed to show off the United States\u2019 commitment to culture.\n\nBut much of \u201cThe Opera House\u201d is less substantial. Alfred Hubay, the longtime box office manager, recalls how he caught the opera bug and took a job as an usher, figuring that would be an easy way to hear more. And Leontyne Price, still a magnetic presence, remembers the chaotic preparation for the Franco Zeffirelli production of \u201cAntony and Cleopatra\u201d that opened the new venue, and having to contend with a malfunctioning tomb.", "title": "Review: The Metropolitan Opera Celebrates Itself in \u2018The Opera House\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-09 00:00:00", "text": "Buddy comedies, odd-couple comedies, will-they-won\u2019t-they comedies, us-against-the-world comedies. All well-worn territory. So props to \u201cAlone Together\u201d for finding a new kind of pairing, even though that pairing is more of a listless inertia than an actual bond.\n\nEsther Povitsky and Benji Aflalo created this single-camera comedy and star as Esther and Benji, two aspiring comedians and purported friends. But they don\u2019t seem like friends \u2014 and not because they seem like a romantic couple, which they don\u2019t. They\u2019ve confused complaining for companionship. \u201cI know trivia about your life and feel comfortable constantly insulting you\u201d is not friendship. Well, maybe for some people it is. But you\u2019d hope that those people enjoyed that aspect of their lives, which Benji and Esther do not seem to, at all.\n\n\u201cAlone Together,\u201d starting on Wednesday on Freeform, is the latest in an awfully long line of autobiographical comedies about comedy, and it embodies some of the genre\u2019s major misconceptions: that comics make good actors, that stand-up comedy is somehow inherently interesting or virtuous, that only comics experience youthful ennui.\n\nEsther and Benji are both fractionally employed and complain frequently about their miserable finances, their singledom and their lousy lots in life. What they mostly do, though, is compulsively talk about food and shame. Esther mentions a need to feel \u201cskinny and pretty\u201d twice in the first two minutes of the show, and throughout the five episodes made available for review, both she and Benji have strict rituals around binge eating and strategies for food hoarding.", "title": "Review: The Moping Comics of \u2018Alone Together\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nContemporary-music showcases typically include a premiere or two, which add a certain flair. But a program like the one at National Sawdust on Monday evening, which presented five works by youngish female composers that had premieres from 2006 to 2015, are hardly less important, since repeat performances are often harder to come by than first ones.\n\n\u201cThread and Fray\u201d (2006), an attractive four-minute work for clarinet, viola and marimba by Sarah Kirkland Snider, opened the evening and set the scene for an exploration of compositional aims and methods. The concert was part of the New York Philharmonic\u2019s contemporary series Contact!, and the conductor and composer Esa-Pekka Salonen, whose \u201cHelix\u201d the Philharmonic is performing in concerts beginning on Thursday, joined Ms. Snider on stage as unscheduled host. Noting that hers was the only work of the five on the program not to use fashionable extended techniques, Mr. Salonen wondered what she might have against them. Was it ideological?\n\nMs. Snider answered that she was more interested in narrative, in \u201ctaking an idea and developing it.\u201d\n\nBut while it was certainly true that the other works, all 10 to 17 minutes long, indulged freely in extended techniques \u2014 playing the strings inside the piano, bowing percussion instruments (including a cardboard box), sputtering pitchless puffs into wind instruments, and the like \u2014 none of that necessarily precluded either storytelling or development.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAshley Fure contributed \u201cTherefore I Was\u201d (2012), an attempt to depict the neural and muscular disconnects of a grandmother suffering from Parkinson\u2019s disease. The brilliant performers \u2014 Carter Brey, cellist; Steven Beck, pianist; and Daniel Druckman, percussionist \u2014 produced all manner of haunting effects: dry scrapes, ominous rumbles, jarring crashes. It was hardly pleasant, but for at least one listener who has seen the condition at close hand, it proved moving and will undoubtedly live in the memory.", "title": "Review: The Philharmonic Focuses on Female Composers", "authors": ["James R. Oestreich"]} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "The performance, part of the final Coil Festival, prompted a number of questions. Since one sequence of slow-changing horizontal patterns kept bringing dancers\u2019 mouths, torsos and groins close together, how erotically suggestive was this meant to be? Since there were eight men and one woman, in what ways was gender an issue? Since the woman and seven of the men performed a central section naked, and since there was no uniform body type, what points about the body \u2014 stationary or in motion \u2014 were being made? I mean it as a compliment to say that answers kept changing.\n\nMore baffling: Why was the piano music accompanying some sections, played by Hank Mason, attributed to Dana Wachs, a.k.a. Vorhees? At least two of the pieces are Tchaikovsky items (well known to dancegoers from George Balanchine\u2019s \u201cTheme and Variations\u201d and Jerome Robbins\u2019s \u201cPiano Pieces\u201d). The work began and ended in silence; one sequence was accompanied by electronic music that built from a quiet hum to an uncomfortably loud whir.\n\nIn a passage near the end, the performers moved in what Ms. Kravas calls, in a program note, a switchback: a simple-seeming phrase that had dancers going to and fro to face one way, then the opposite. This built in scale and complexity, then fragmented into multiple groups, while acquiring embellishments of footwork and arm gesture, all without any sudden gear-change, at all times filling the space.\n\nThen this wound down into a tableau in which all nine dancers (one still naked) stayed as motionless as they could on half-toe. They then left the group in ones and twos to make farewell bows to the audience. You could compare it with the ending of Haydn\u2019s \u201cFarewell\u201d Symphony, in which players one by one leave the orchestra \u2014 but here, Ms. Kravas herself took a bow and left the space (as did most of the audience) while a few dancers carried on regardless.", "title": "Review: To Open Performance Space New York, \u2018visions of beauty\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "We are taught from childhood, if we\u2019re lucky, that individuals are never merely the sum of their biological and sociological parts. But I have rarely seen a warmer or more engaging example of this defiance of statistics than \u201cPanorama,\u201d which was devised and directed by the Italian theater artists Enrico Casagrande and Daniela Nicol\u00f2 in collaboration with members of the Great Jones Repertory Company. (The show is presented as part of the Under the Radar festival, and continues beyond it until Jan. 21.)\n\nMotus (\u201cAlexis: A Greek Tragedy,\u201d \u201cMDLSX\u201d) specializes in what might be called enlightening confusion, blurring our perceptions to improve our vision. The casts of their genre-bending shows are usually small, yet you always leave a Motus production feeling you have spent time amid an ever-multiplying throng. Everybody on stage contains multitudes.\n\n\u201cPanorama,\u201d which is performed mostly in English, is unusually accessible by Motus standards. Anyone who knows the classic American musical \u201cA Chorus Line\u201d will be familiar with the conceptual shape of this show.\n\nPhoto\n\nWhat we\u2019re watching is an audition process that asks more of its applicants than the usual song and dance. The first question posed of the performers being interviewed, before a video camera, is that aforementioned conundrum \u201cWho are you?\u201d\n\n\u201cWho I am is the question I ask myself, often, every time I look in a mirror\u201d goes one response. And \u201cPanorama\u201d turns into one big, double-sided looking glass that keeps reflecting them (on the stage) and us (in the audience), until the mirror cracks.\n\nThe performers we encounter in the flesh are Maura Nguyen Donahue, John Gutierrez, Valois Mickens, Eugene the Poogene, Perry Yung, Zishan Ugurlu and Heather Paauwe. (We meet many others through video interviews, and sometimes the live actors take on the identities of the two-dimensional projections.) And you may well ask what\u2019s in a name, because they certainly do.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn fact, just explaining what their names are \u2014 and whether they are given names or nicknames or stage names or assimilationist variations on what they were christened \u2014 occupy a fair amount of time. And simple nomenclature becomes a gateway onto endless, globe-crossing vistas of family histories and fraught stories of immigration.\n\nBut such words aren\u2019t even half of the story. These people are, above all, performers, whose nomadic lives have lead them to the all-inclusive sanctuary that theater, especially marginal theater, can be. (God bless the urban avant-garde!) And they do a lot of celebratory acting out, and directing others in acting out.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nEvery performer makes use of a camera or projector. Video images and simulcasts, as deft as the hands of a three-card monte artist, keep your eyes moving so you often know where sounds and images originate. (The video design is by Bosul Kim, Sangmin Chae and Billy Clark.)\n\nAnd yes, there is the occasional more traditional audition piece, including the performance of a scene from the Antonioni movie \u201cThe Passenger\u201d (which you may remember was all about escaping identity); some musical numbers (like a Michael Jackson moonwalk) and perhaps the most joyous, non-objectifying strip tease I\u2019ve ever seen.\n\nA strip tease in \u201cPanorama\u201d inevitably involves taking off a whole lot of layers. Once you hit bare flesh, though, you have by no means arrived at the end of the process.\n\nThe shape, texture and color of that skin may offer some clues to the person within. But by now you\u2019ve learned \u2014 more deeply than any ethics class could teach you \u2014 that surfaces are only the beginning, and that skins are made to be shed.", "title": "Review: Who Am I? \u2018Panorama\u2019 Says There Is No Easy Answer", "authors": ["Ben Brantley"]} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\n\u201cKfulim\u201d is an Israeli conspiracy-thriller television series whose Hebrew title translates as \u201cduplicates\u201d or \u201cdoubles.\u201d Its first season comes to Hulu on Friday, and its new English title \u2014 \u201cFalse Flag\u201d \u2014 is even more of a spoiler than the original.\n\nThe show plunges into action, with breathless TV reports that five Israeli citizens, presumably undercover Mossad agents, have been caught on video kidnapping an Iranian government minister from his Moscow hotel room. The suspects \u2014 including a chemist, a preschool teacher and a bride on her wedding day \u2014 watch the fuzzy footage in disbelief and insist they weren\u2019t in Russia and have no idea what\u2019s going on.\n\nThe English title points to the truth that the plot dances with briefly but fairly quickly gives up: The five (or most of them, anyway) are indeed being framed. The show\u2019s salient questions, answered over eight fast-paced, highly entertaining episodes, are by whom and for what purpose?\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Get expert TV and movie recommendations from the Watching newsletter The best of what to watch and where to watch it, delivered to your inbox twice a week. When Walker Loats, bored inmate number 1439, plucks it glistening from her spoon, she doesn\u2019t realize that she\u2019s found some company.\n\nAnd what charismatic company it is. Once hatched, the fluttering white contents of that cocoon steal the show in \u201cThe Echo Drift,\u201d a visually and aurally layered chamber opera about time and punishment at the Baruch Performing Arts Center.\n\n\u201cWell, hello there,\u201d the moth says, introducing himself to Walker. \u201cIt\u2019s me, dear. From the soup?\u201d\n\nWalker (sung by the mezzo-soprano Blythe Gaissert) is a murderer obsessively petitioning the governor for release, sure that the seeming eternity she has served is sufficient payment for her crime. To the short-lived moth (a projected animation spoken by the performance artist John Kelly), time is the enemy, but Walker keeps desperate track of its passage with a metronomic clock she\u2019s built by hand.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe story, though, is the least interesting element of \u201cThe Echo Drift,\u201d which has a libretto by Elle Kunnos de Voss and Kathryn Walat. Directed by Mallory Catlett and conducted by Nicholas DeMaison in its world premiere at the Prototype festival, the production puts music, by Mikael Karlsson, on an equal footing with design, seeking multidimensionality on both fronts. Stark and intricate, propulsive and a little film-noir, \u201cThe Echo Drift\u201d is most exciting when it is fast and cacophonous, nearly overwhelming the senses.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Its reason for being is brotherhood, as belief and way of life. It sings of how men become warriors and of how they can reach across seemingly impossible divides to clasp hands and lock eyes before blowing their mutual enemy to pieces. And while Sept. 11 gives Mitch and his men their mission, the locals aren\u2019t entirely ignored, not exactly. The motto of the Special Forces is \u201cTo Free the Oppressed,\u201d a creed the movie underscores, most forcefully in a scene of a Taliban leader, Mullah Razzan (Numan Acar), terrorizing a family that has educated its daughters.\n\nStill, while the movie largely elides overt politics and policies, both domestic and foreign, they are inextricably embedded in every single narrative turn, each word and image. (They\u2019re also embedded in the credits: Like other movies of this type, \u201c12 Strong\u201d received technical support from the American military.) Written by Ted Tally and Peter Craig \u2014 and adapted from Doug Stanton\u2019s well-received nonfiction book \u201cHorse Soldiers\u201d (2009) \u2014 the movie takes for granted that military action in Afghanistan is essential and justified. The filmmakers make that case mostly with images of Sept. 11 \u2014 cut to a man\u2019s clenching fist \u2014 and through scenes and stories of the Taliban\u2019s violence.\n\nThe periodic references to the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan suggest that the larger picture is, well, awfully complicated. Real complications, though, are for other movies. We\u2019re now almost 17 years into the war of Afghanistan, the longest in American history. That\u2019s a deeply sobering marker but one that has no place in \u201c12 Strong,\u201d which starts as a recruitment ad before settling into a tense, unremittingly brutal combat movie. Mr. Fuglsig\u2019s contribution to this basically well-coordinated mayhem \u2014 which includes fiery explosions, a Bruckheimer trademark \u2014 is hard to gauge. It also scarcely matters when bodies rise and fall to a beat as natural as our circadian rhythms.", "title": "Review: \u201812 Strong\u2019 Believes in the Brotherhood of Battle", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-31 00:00:00", "text": "There\u2019s never been a worse time for a show about an abusive man coercing teenagers into sour sexual discourse and insisting they keep his disturbing behavior a secret. The first three episodes will be available online until then, and given how NBC usually operates, one expects promos for the show to be in heavy rotation during the Games.\n\nAnd in promo-sized bites, some of the caustic cynicism of \u201cA.P. Bio\u201d might seem refreshing in contrast to more wholesome network comedies. In episode form, though, it\u2019s tiring; in the four installments made available for review, the scattershot misery is ironically adolescent. Worse, the show doesn\u2019t seem aware of its fixation on skeezy sexual misconduct \u2014 never a tremendous well for humor, but even less so today.\n\nGlenn Howerton (\u201cIt\u2019s Always Sunny in Philadelphia\u201d) stars as Jack, a Harvard philosophy professor who slinks back to Toledo, Ohio, in disgrace after being denied tenure. He takes a job teaching advanced placement biology at a high school, though he refuses to actually teach anything. He announces this on the first day, and declares that he and his charges will spend their class time developing potential revenge strategies against his nemesis. He wears scuzzy sweatpants. This in itself causes the slimy mooks to take umbrage, and as Mia (Melissa Bolona) is outside calling her fianc\u00e9 (who is at a strip club, with Mia\u2019s approval), they pull up in a van, pull her in, inject her with a potentially lethal drug, and take her to be prepared for human trafficking.\n\nBut as they say in countless movie tag lines, these guys messed with the wrong family. Or words to that effect. In \u201cActs of Violence,\u201d directed by Brett Donowho, Cole Hauser (whose father Wings Hauser livened up many low-budget action potboilers of this ilk a generation ago) plays Deklan, an anguished war veteran who happens to be the future brother-in-law of the kidnap victim. After receiving scant satisfaction from Bruce Willis\u2019s well-meaning cop (the law has tied his hands, you see), Deklan enlists his brothers to find Mia and seize justice.\n\nVideo\n\nThis dopey action thriller harks back to grindhouse pictures of the \u201970s and \u201980s, although it\u2019s too tasteful, if that\u2019s the word, to consistently exploit the more lurid implications of its sensationalist scenario. Which I suppose speaks well of the filmmakers as people. But not that well. The picture moves at a brisk pace, though, and Mr. Hauser\u2019s mostly cool and collected avenger is somewhat fun to watch.", "title": "Review: \u2018Acts of Violence\u2019 Delivers What Its Title Promises", "authors": ["Glenn Kenny"]} {"date": "2018-01-15 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nWhat stands out about \u201cBlack Lightning\u201d are not the scenes in which the title hero zaps a gajillion volts of justice through a crew of murder-minded gang members. You can already see that sort of thing on CW \u2014 home to \u201cThe Flash,\u201d \u201cSupergirl,\u201d \u201cDC\u2019s Legends of Tomorrow\u201d and \u201cArrow\u201d \u2014 and the rest of superhero-supersaturated TV.\n\nWhat you don\u2019t see so often on this youth-oriented network is what happens after. Jefferson Pierce (Cress Williams), the hero\u2019s middle-aged alter ego, lies in bed, sore and moaning from the exertion. \u201cBlack Lightning is getting too old for these streets,\u201d he says.\n\nThe other distinctive part of the show is, of course, the \u201cBlack\u201d in the title. \u201cBlack Lightning\u201d is immersively, not incidentally, black: The good guys and bad guys, teachers and students, victims and criminals and reporters are mainly African-American.\n\n\u201cLuke Cage\u201d and \u201cMarvel\u2019s Runaways\u201d have diversified the comics-TV lineup. (\u201cBlack Panther\u201d arrives in theaters in February.) But this show\u2019s race-forward sensibility and its older protagonist, conflicted about getting back into the game, give \u201cBlack Lightning\u201d its spark.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe series was developed by Salim Akil, who produces with his wife, Mara Brock Akil; the two have worked together on \u201cGirlfriends,\u201d \u201cThe Game\u201d and \u201cBeing Mary Jane.\u201d Producers also include Greg Berlanti, of CW\u2019s other comics franchises, but this show has a different sensibility. It\u2019s pulpy entertainment with a sense of purpose.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMost superhero series, for instance, begin with young protagonists discovering their powers. \u201cBlack Lightning,\u201d airing Tuesdays, is the reluctant comeback story of a hero grappling with heroism\u2019s limits.", "title": "Review: \u2018Black Lightning\u2019 Is Pulp With a Purpose", "authors": ["James Poniewozik"]} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nOne Howard Silk, a meek career bureaucrat who visits his comatose wife every night in the hospital, has \u201ckind eyes,\u201d according to a nurse.\n\nThe other Howard Silk, a sarcastic, deadly spy, does not.\n\nAnd yet the two Howard Silks \u2014 genetically identical but temperamentally diverse characters in the alternate-dimensions thriller \u201cCounterpart,\u201d beginning Sunday on Starz \u2014 have the same eyes. They belong to the actor J.K. Simmons, whose double-barreled performance makes the show the most entertaining new series of the winter.\n\n\u201cCounterpart,\u201d created by Justin Marks (writer of the 2016 \u201cJungle Book\u201d remake), is a clever and suspenseful if somewhat familiar mix of futuristic speculation and retro atmosphere. The setting is Berlin, where a Cold War experiment gone awry made an exact copy of our world, reachable through a passage in the basement of a government office building. (We, along with the meeker of the two Howards, learn about this in the first episode; six of 10 episodes were available for review.)\n\nThe existence of the parallel worlds, which have grown more and more different in the 30 years since the second world\u2019s creation, is a closely (and implausibly) held secret. Privy to it are the senior members of the large, somewhat bumbling bidimensional bureaucracy that manages the portal, who are allowed to pass between worlds using visas measured in hours.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Get expert TV and movie recommendations from the Watching newsletter The best of what to watch and where to watch it, delivered to your inbox twice a week. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe two Howards are part of that apparatus, the meek Howard a paper-shuffler in the original world and the macho Howard a covert agent for the splinter world. They meet \u2014 an almost unheard-of occurrence \u2014 when the macho Howard follows a criminal who manages to cross between worlds and needs to pose as the meek Howard to catch her.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe story\u2019s Cold War allusions and Berlin setting provide an apt \u2014 or maybe too cute \u2014 framework for a story of alternate worlds suddenly developing side by side. They also drive home Mr. Marks\u2019s debt to John le Carr\u00e9 \u2014 \u201cCounterpart\u201d pays hommage to Mr. le Carr\u00e9\u2019s classic Cold War morality tale, \u201cThe Spy Who Came in From the Cold,\u201d while pumping up the dystopian, Orwellian mood and visuals (and borrowing discreetly from the premise of the Fox sci-fi series \u201cFringe\u201d).", "title": "Review: \u2018Counterpart\u2019 Gives Us J.K. Simmons, Times Two", "authors": ["Mike Hale"]} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "If you\u2019re going to fire an agent, make it memorable. That\u2019s what the exasperated yet inexperienced actress Audrey (Claire Armstrong) does when she fires hers. \u201cLook at me, Peter! I\u2019m a miracle,\u201d she yells as she\u2019s leaving his office.\n\nNot long after this scene, Daniel Warth\u2019s \u201cDim the Fluorescents\u201d evolves from a screwball roommate comedy to a melodrama about artistic frustration.\n\nAudrey lives in Toronto with the no-nonsense Lillian (Naomi Skwarna), an aspiring playwright with dreams of financial stability. The two are stuck producing over-the-top live corporate training demonstrations, but dream of more ambitious projects that will garner respect from their artist circles. Now, their luck may change after a major conference offers the friends their largest audience yet.\n\nTheir optimism is short-lived. The women\u2019s working relationship sours under the pressure and they change too. Anti-depressants go untaken, frantic calls are left unanswered and two likable characters become unrecognizable. This jarring change from comedy to tragedy is unsettling, and, as \u201cDim the Fluorescents\u201d languishes in the women\u2019s bitter breakup, becomes tedious.", "title": "Review: \u2018Dim the Fluorescents\u2019 Unites Two Roommates in Art and Commerce", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "A bad-trip \u201cJesus Christ Superstar,\u201d a \u201cGodspell\u201d set to an EDM beat, a paradise that gets very, very lost. This is \u201cElectric Lucifer,\u201d Jim Findlay\u2019s gonzo staging of two albums by the Canadian electronic music pioneer Bruce Haack, who died in 1988.\n\nA children\u2019s music artist and the inventor of the Dermatron, a synthesizer activated by the heat of skin, Haack released \u201cThe Electric Lucifer\u201d on Columbia Records in 1970 and a follow-up eight years later. With their bloops, bleeps and bizarro version of the synoptic gospels, these concept albums ultimately describe an epic battle for the soul of the universe that encompasses Lucifer\u2019s fall, Christ\u2019s passion and the coming Armageddon.\n\nThe production, at the Kitchen, begins with a sweet curiosity, a video of Haack visiting \u201cMister Rogers\u2019 Neighborhood\u201d and demonstrating a synthesizer. Then the lights pulse, the way-out band grooves and a chorus in spandex starts to writhe.\n\nThere are calls of \u201cProgram me!\u201d and shout-outs to electricity, alongside a greatest-hits version of Jesus\u2019s life, which skips from birth to arrest and crucifixion. In a nifty bit of staging, Mr. Findlay has a thorn-crowned Jesus (Robert M. Johanson) swaddled in a high-tech loincloth and then hoisted several feet above the stage to hover and bleed.", "title": "Review: \u2018Electric Lucifer,\u2019 or the Passion of the Bleep Bloop Beep", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "Thomas Kail\u2019s London production, which retains its top-drawer design team, has the gleam and propulsive thrust of the New York original, and it fits beautifully into the exquisitely restored Victoria Palace. (Extra points to its renovators for seat comfort and legroom.)\n\nThis interpretation is also an ideal first experience for \u201cHamilton\u201d virgins and for anyone unaccustomed to the rap and hip-hop that make up much of Mr. Miranda\u2019s score, which sounds richer every time I hear it. The cast, a multiethnic ensemble as it is in all \u201cHamilton\u201d productions, enunciates more precisely than their American counterparts.\n\nAnd am I wrong in thinking that the orchestrator Alex Lacamoire has slowed down the tempo on occasion to make the lyrics easier to follow? In any case, the expository details of this dazzling history are less likely to be lost on Britons who never studied the American Revolution.\n\nMy audience, by the way, was especially tickled by the satirical portrait of the show\u2019s one major British character, King George III, embodied with Hogarthian nastiness by a divinely petulant Michael Jibson. And the crowd went wild for the climactic first act number that finds \u201cthe world turned upside down\u201d when the underdog Americans finally win their war.\n\n\u201cHamilton,\u201d it seems \u2014 especially as led by its incendiary newborn star, Mr. Westman \u2014 can make a traitor of any English citizen for a night.", "title": "Review: \u2018Hamilton\u2019 Conquers London (King George Slays, Too)", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "We also hear accounts, firsthand and distortingly recycled, of their family histories. And while Chris\u2019s is cushioned in an affluence that Kay has never known, they both carry a legacy of racially mixed sexual relationships. Kay\u2019s father was white, and her mother, who is black, died not long after giving birth to her at 15 \u2014 possibly a suicide, possibly a murder victim.\n\nChris\u2019s father, Harrison Aherne, is both an architect of segregation and a man with black mistresses, by whom he has had several children. He has lovingly overseen the creation of the graveyard in which these women and their families can be buried.\n\nKay and Chris grew up watching each other from a fascinated distance. T he play follows their tentative courtship, from the eve of Chris\u2019s departure to New York City (he hopes to become an actor) to the moment of America\u2019s entry into World War II. Human and historic events turn out to be intertwined in unexpected ways.\n\nIt is important to note that while \u201cBox\u201d is a two-character play (three, if you count Chris\u2019s father, who is represented onstage by a cadaverous dummy), it is not really a dialogue. As Chris and Kay relate the facts and myths of their genealogies, it seems as if they are not connecting through shared history but pushing themselves into ever greater isolation.\n\nAs in most of Ms. Kennedy\u2019s work, the narrative is delivered in a kaleidoscope of shards. These take the form of letters, recollections of conflicting tales told by family members, itemized descriptions of a train station, a savage moment from the Brothers Grimm (which gives the play its title), wistful period songs and lines from two very different shows \u2014 No\u00ebl Coward\u2019s operetta \u201cBitter Sweet\u201d and Christopher Marlowe\u2019s lurid revenge tragedy \u201cThe Massacre at Paris.\u201d\n\nOnly Ms. Kennedy, perhaps, could gracefully balance such disparate works as mood-defining reference points of equal weight. And while the implicit connections between Chris\u2019s father and Nazi Germany might feel overly contrived in a more traditional play, here they become natural echoes in a nightmare that enwraps the whole world.\n\nThe physical production may be the most ravishing and organic that a Kennedy dreamscape has ever been given, starting with Christopher Barreca\u2019s weathered wooden set, a synecdoche for the miniature model of the town the audience passes on the way to its seats.", "title": "Review: \u2018He Brought Her Heart Back in a Box,\u2019 Adrienne Kennedy\u2019s Beautiful Nightmare", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "They forged an improbable, temporarily effective alliance with industrial workers, a convergence that many thought heralded a new revolutionary coalition. But Mr. Salles, with the benefit of hindsight and an astute ability to analyze the documentary record, throws cold water on this romantic notion. The witty slogans \u2014 \u201cBe realistic, demand the impossible\u201d; \u201cThe walls have the floor\u201d; \u201cUnderneath the paving-stones, the beach!\u201d \u2014 had the punch of advertising copy. The street demonstrations galvanized the news media and the intelligentsia, but the public craving for order and normalcy was deeper than they or the students realized. And while the students claimed to desire liberation from consumer society, many of the workers wanted better access to it.\n\nThe Prague Spring was an unsuccessful revolution of a different kind, ended by the military intervention of the Soviet Union in August. In China, by contrast, the revolution appeared to be successful, but the full dimensions of its cruelty were not yet visible to the few visitors, like Mr. Salles\u2019s mother, who were allowed into the country. Mr. Salles, who seems broadly sympathetic to the traditions of the international left (his brother is Walter Salles, director of \u201cThe Motorcycle Diaries\u201d), nonetheless disdains the easy sentimentality of lost causes. He elucidates, above all, the ironic dimension of his film\u2019s title, imposing an elegiac, gently pessimistic tone on the energy and immediacy of what he sees and shows.\n\nWhat he reveals, perhaps against his own intentions, is the inevitable aestheticization of the past. The anonymous demonstrators in Paris and Prague, and the people holding the cameras, were caught up in the drama of the present, rushing furiously toward a future they could not comprehend. Those of us living in that future notice their clothes and cigarettes, the beauty of the 8- and 16-millimeter cinematography, the look of cities before Starbucks and McDonald\u2019s. For a few hours, we are caught up in the intensity of then.", "title": "Review: \u2018In the Intense Now\u2019 Revisits the Drama of 1968 in France and Beyond", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "Brutality overrides everything else in \u201cKangaroo: A Love-Hate Story\u201d \u2014 views of beautiful landscapes are hard to enjoy after seeing wild animals, including their young, maimed and slaughtered. But the filmmakers are determined to sound a wake-up siren, and they blast it here with extra strength.\n\nThe documentary, directed by Mick McIntyre and Kate McIntyre Clere, begins with a look at the kangaroo and its place in Australian culture: It\u2019s both a widely used mascot and, to some, a hallowed creature.\n\nBut the animal is considered a pest by farmers and ranchers, and a profit source by pet-food companies and leather processors. Meat exporters are rushing to build a market for human consumption of this marsupial in China and Russia. The filmmakers scrutinize processing plants, where carcasses are butchered by the trailer-load, and deride the Australian government, which they suggest is mismanaging the populations.", "title": "Review: \u2018Kangaroo: A Love-Hate Story\u2019 Exposes a Wildlife Massacre", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "Ms. Makeba\u2019s life was, of course, more than eventful enough to sustain a movie. \u201cMama Africa\u201d remembers her appearance in the film \u201cCome Back, Africa\u201d and performances with Harry Belafonte; her 31-year exile from South Africa after the apartheid-era government revoked her passport; her anti-apartheid activism before the United Nations; her marriage to the black-power activist Stokely Carmichael (a union that\u2019s said to have caused concerts in the United States to be canceled because of controversy surrounding Mr. Carmichael); and her return to South Africa following Nelson Mandela\u2019s release from prison.\n\nMr. Kaurismaki (a brother of Aki Kaurismaki, who made the recent \u201cThe Other Side of Hope\u201d) includes the tributes of family members and former musical collaborators. More crucially, he has considerable footage of Ms. Makeba in concert and in interviews.
