Exiled to the care of her great-aunt while her parents attend to some unspecified business, Mary is a bored, lonely, curious child, and therefore a perfect candidate for a fantastical adventure. Shunted aside by the grown-ups and mocked by the only other young person in the rustic village of Red Manor, a cute boy named Peter, Mary soon acquires a black cat, a broomstick and a cluster of enchanted purple blossoms.\n\nBased on \u201cThe Little Broomstick,\u201d a durably popular novel by Mary Stewart, and directed by Hiromasa Yonebayashi, \u201cMary and the Witch\u2019s Flower\u201d is a charming children\u2019s entertainment that sometimes seems to have been genetically engineered from other such entertainments. The rustling forests and voluptuous clouds recall the work of Hayao Miyazaki, and Mary herself shows an obvious kinship to the young witch in \u201cKiki\u2019s Delivery Service.\u201d (Mr. Yonebayashi worked as an animator on several of Mr. Miyazaki\u2019s films.) Oblivious to occupying the pop-culture equivalent of the bottom half of a double bill, \u201cMaze Runner: The Death Cure\u201d aspires to be a grand male weepie: the \u201cShawshank Redemption\u201d of \u201cMaze Runner\u201d movies.\n\nThe first film \u2014 like all the entries, adapted from a novel by James Dashner \u2014 had a pleasing unity of place and action. (Amnesiac boys attempted to escape from a giant maze.) The draggier sequel, \u201cMaze Runner: The Scorch Trials\u201d (2015), added scale by sending the characters on the run. While \u201cMaze Runner: The Death Cure\u201d continues the trend toward supersizing, at least it moves.\n\n\u201cThe Death Cure\u201d opens with a spectacularly staged train rescue indebted to \u201cMad Max: Fury Road.\u201d It continues with a few too many zombies; the return of a character presumed dead; a lot of sneering from an Ahab-like security officer (Aidan Gillen); a class revolt that\u2019s essentially window dressing; and some of the most homoerotic bromance in a mass release since the \u201cLord of the Rings\u201d films.", "title": "Review: \u2018Maze Runner: The Death Cure,\u2019 an Enjoyably Overstuffed Sequel", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nBefore the opening credits roll in \u201cPadmaavat,\u201d a disclaimer carefully notes that the film is based on an epic poem that is considered a work of fiction. So, please, it continues, don\u2019t be offended or expect authenticity about a long list of things, right down to the dance forms.\n\nIn other words, folks, it\u2019s just a movie. Oh, and one more note: Ladies \u2014 the film does not in any way endorse ritual self-immolation.\n\nThis everybody-please-relax nervousness is well earned. \u201cPadmaavat,\u201d the story of a Rajput (Hindu) queen whose beauty is so great that the sultan (Muslim) lays siege to her kingdom to possess her, has inflamed extremist Hindus since the movie was in production. Was history being honored? Was the queen? (She may or may not have actually existed.) The director, Sanjay Leela Bhansali, was slapped on set and his hair was pulled; the lead actress, Deepika Padukone, was threatened with beheading or having her nose cut off.\n\nBefore the movie was released, a few changes were made. They include the addition of that detailed disclaimer and a revised title, \u201cPadmaavat,\u201d which aligns more closely with the poem, but doesn\u2019t match the name of the heroine, Padmavati.\n\nVideo\n\nAs the film stands now, no one need be concerned about the honor of Rajputs, as warriors or paragons of virtue. This movie is a love letter to all that.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIt\u2019s also something of a bore: a lavish 3-D pageant with the depth of a children\u2019s pop-up book. Those paragons, Padmavati (Ms. Padukone) and her king, Ratan Singh (Shahid Kapoor), dressed in gorgeous silks and bangles, are more heaven to look at than delightful to know.", "title": "Review: \u2018Padmaavat\u2019 and All That Useless Beauty", "authors": ["Rachel Saltz", "Prakash Kapadia", "Sanjay Leela Bhansali"]} {"date": "2018-01-17 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\n\u201cTall\u201d is a compact history of the American skyscraper, an unassuming (though hardly unambitious) examination of a grand, at times grandiose, subject. Divided into clear, concise chapters and conducted in a style that might be called street-corner Ken Burns, this documentary, directed by Manfred Kirchheimer, is more essay than epic, preferring coherence to comprehensiveness. In looking at a smattering of buildings in two big cities, and focusing on the work of a handful of major architects, Mr. Kirchheimer sketches the skyscraper as a feat of engineering, a work of imagination and part of an ongoing cultural argument.\n\nAll of a sudden, toward the end of the 19th century, it became possible to conceive of ordinary urban commercial and residential buildings whose height would surpass the limits of human stamina. The invention of the modern elevator by Elisha Graves Otis was crucial, and so was the development of iron and steel frames that enabled lighter, higher and slimmer constructions. As often happens (see also: the internet and the automobile), technological advances created aesthetic challenges. What were these gigantic new buildings supposed to look like?\n\nOne answer: like the old buildings, only bigger. Mr. Kirchheimer associates this idea with Daniel Burnham, the Chicago planner and architect who is in some ways the villain of \u201cTall.\u201d Burnham, whose legacy includes the grounds of the World\u2019s Columbian Exhibition of 1893 \u2014 part of the backdrop of Erik Larson\u2019s true-crime historical best seller \u201cThe Devil in the White City\u201d \u2014 adapted ornate European styles to new uses and proportions.\n\nBurnham\u2019s foil, and Mr. Kirchheimer\u2019s hero, was another Chicago architect: Louis Sullivan, a brilliant draftsman and theoretician often identified as the father of the modern skyscraper. (\u201cTall\u201d comes with the subtitle \u201cThe American Skyscraper and Louis Sullivan.\u201d) Famous for declaring that \u201cform must ever follow function,\u201d Sullivan tried to find an organic, authentic identity for modern tall buildings. While hardly averse to ornament, he envisioned each structure as a dialectic of utility and beauty. His great disciple, Frank Lloyd Wright, would extend Sullivan\u2019s philosophy in his own writings and architectural projects.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThat philosophy is understood in \u201cTall\u201d to be quintessentially American, partaking of the same democratic spirit that breathes in the writings of Emerson and Whitman. Sullivan appears as a prophet without much honor in his own country, denied the celebrity and the lucrative commissions enjoyed by the Europe-besotted Burnham.", "title": "Review: \u2018Tall\u2019 Is a Little Movie About How Buildings Got So Big", "authors": ["A.O. Scott", "Manfred Kirchheimer"]} {"date": "2018-01-21 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\n\u201cThe Alienist\u201d is a period piece. You\u2019ll gather that pretty quickly from the gas lamps, the cobblestone streets and the still-under-construction Williamsburg Bridge. But the period I\u2019m referring to for the moment is 1994.\n\nThat\u2019s when Caleb Carr published his novel, the film rights to it already sold, thus beginning the long journey to the screen of Dr. Laszlo Kreizler, a serial killer hunter in Gilded Age Manhattan. Scripts were attempted and discarded. This Monday, after a quarter-century, it arrives as a 10-episode mini-series on TNT.\n\nHad \u201cThe Alienist\u201d arrived in the 1990s, when the darkest shade of TV policing was \u201cNYPD Blue,\u201d it would have been something truly different. In 2018, it follows many dramas that have interrogated our romantic ideas of the past (\u201cDeadwood,\u201d \u201cThe Knick\u201d), delved into historical crime (\u201cBoardwalk Empire,\u201d \u201cPeaky Blinders\u201d) and followed eccentric investigators\u2019 descents into the dank basements of the criminal mind (\u201cTrue Detective,\u201d \u201cMindhunter\u201d).\n\nThis is hardly the mini-series\u2019s fault. But it is its problem. Today, \u201cThe Alienist\u201d needs to be assessed for its execution of already familiar genres. Judging from the early episodes, it\u2019s fine: lush, moody, a bit stiff. But it\u2019s nothing to clear your calendar for.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nEven the series\u2019s curious title was defined a couple months ago in Netflix\u2019s \u201cAlias Grace,\u201d but in case you missed it: Alienists, like Kreizler (Daniel Br\u00fchl), were early psychiatrists who believed that the mentally ill, including criminals, were \u201calienated\u201d from their rightful nature.", "title": "Review: \u2018The Alienist\u2019 Is a Period Piece That Missed Its Moment", "authors": ["James Poniewozik"]} {"date": "2018-01-16 00:00:00", "text": "At some point we\u2019ll all have to grapple with the idea that the warped compassion of the modern true-crime boom implicates its audience and that viewers are greedily lining up to be part of a lurid long tail of suffering and despair. If \u201cThe Assassination of Gianni Versace: American Crime Story\u201d were a little more interesting, maybe it would be that lightning rod. But instead it\u2019s a surprisingly inert, if lushly imagined, tale.\n\nRyan Murphy, the show\u2019s executive producer and the director of the first episode, broke out with \u201cNip/Tuck,\u201d a daring plastic-surgery soap. With its Miami setting and toxic superficiality, it is the most direct antecedent to \u201cThe Assassination of Gianni Versace,\u201d more than other creations from Mr. Murphy like \u201cGlee,\u201d \u201cAmerican Horror Story,\u201d \u201cFeud\u201d and even \u201cThe People v. O.J. Simpson,\u201d the widely acclaimed first \u201cAmerican Crime Story\u201d installment.\n\n\u201cTell me what you don\u2019t like about yourself,\u201d the glitzy \u201cNip/Tuck\u201d surgeons would say to potential patients. That\u2019s the undercurrent here, too. Self-loathing abounds, as \u201cAssassination\u201d repeatedly depicts the psychological effects of internalized homophobia and the miserable spiritual contortions required to stay closeted. In one particularly upsetting scene, a panicked Navy sailor is shown trying gouge off his own tattoo, lest he be outed during the \u201cdon\u2019t ask, don\u2019t tell\u201d era. (Straight women get their own brands of insecurity, too, though they exist here as illuminating harmony, not story-driving melody.)\n\nDarren Criss, best known as Blaine on \u201cGlee,\u201d stars as Andrew Cunanan, the spree killer who murdered Mr. Versace and four other men in 1997, before also shooting and killing himself. As such, a film that might once have seemed too big for its breeches \u2014 slow, cryptic, overly enamored of complicated camera movements and crepuscular compositions \u2014 probably looks better than it did then, a necessary step in the evolution of a major filmmaker.\n\nThe plot pivots on a test of a marriage. Vera (Maria Bonnevie) tells Alex (Mr. Levronenko) that she is pregnant with a child that\u2019s not his. Alternately violent and tender, Alex agonizes over what comes next. Mark (Aleksandr Baluev), his brother and confidant \u2014 a shady character who, at the film\u2019s start, seeks Alex\u2019s help with the removal of a bullet \u2014 is indifferent by temperament. (He tells him, \u201cWhatever you do will be right.\u201d)\n\nThe first two-thirds are an extraordinary slow burn that provides ample time to admire Mr. Zvyagintsev\u2019s talent with the wide frame. The movie is marred by an unsatisfying resolution, which has a coyness better suited to literature. Mike is abruptly laid off from his job selling insurance, and has a quietly foreboding encounter with colleagues from his previous job, which was with the New York Police Department. (Of course he\u2019s a former cop. He\u2019s Liam Neeson. His colleagues are played by Patrick Wilson and Sam Neill.) The installments range from an infuriating look at payday lending to an offbeat story about Canadian maple syrup cartels.\n\nThe common thread is the abuse of trust. And \u201cThe Confidence Man\u201d argues that the problem goes all the way to the top.\n\nMr. Stevens\u2019s narrative starts with Trump Tower, the gleaming metonym Mr. Trump hung his name on in brass letters. The splashy project landed him on talk shows and magazine covers as the photogenic shorthand for Reagan-age materialism.\n\nThat served his other big 1980s construction effort \u2014 his media image, for which he poured the foundation in the New York tabloids. The gossip columnist A. J. For \u201cThe Final Year,\u201d the director Greg Barker and his crew were able to follow four vital members of Barack Obama\u2019s administration as they worked to keep the United States out of war, promote better relations with Cuba and deter Iran from pursuing a nuclear weapons program. Secretary of State John Kerry; the ambassador to the United Nations, Samantha Power; the national security adviser Susan Rice; and the deputy national security adviser Ben Rhodes are all seen up close and personal as they globe trot in pursuit of what they see as noble aims.\n\nFor much of its first hour, this movie is tepid and self-congratulatory, a quick-cutting advertisement for itself. Why Mr. Barker thought it worth preserving Mr. Kerry\u2019s \u201cI\u2019ve been very blessed to be able to go through a progression of experiences which underscore the value of experience\u201d sound bite is a mystery. There\u2019s some juice in Mr. Rhodes\u2019s reaction, more bruised than angry, to a profile in The New York Times Magazine, in which he is portrayed as finding the Washington press corps both ignorant and credulous. Current events arguably place some of Mr. Rhodes\u2019s statements in an interesting perspective.", "title": "Review: \u2018The Final Year,\u2019 a Countdown for Obama-Era Diplomacy", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-02 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nAs \u201cThe X-Files\u201d enters its 11th season \u2014 10 episodes beginning Wednesday on Fox \u2014 it\u2019s beginning to look more like a membership club than a television series. It cruises along doing business the way it has since its founding 25 years ago, and it caters to an audience that knows the staff and delights in the many arcane rules and quirks of service.\n\nAnd membership has its privileges. Like the country club that still turns out a good porterhouse, \u201cThe X-Files\u201d still produces excellent stand-alone TV episodes \u2014 tremendously entertaining hours with the show\u2019s familiar blend of spookiness, self-deprecating humor and cleverly conceptual in-jokes that only the initiated can really appreciate.\n\nIn the five episodes of the new season made available to critics, the winner is the fourth, \u201cThe Lost Art of Forehead Sweat.\u201d It was written and directed by Darin Morgan, who also provided the best hour of the show\u2019s revival season in 2016, \u201cMulder and Scully Meet the Were-Monster,\u201d and authored celebrated old-school episodes like \u201cClyde Bruckman\u2019s Final Repose\u201d and \u201cJose Chung\u2019s \u2018From Outer Space\u2019\u201d back in the 1990s.\n\n\u201cForehead Sweat\u201d guest-stars Brian Huskey (\u201cPeople of Earth\u201d) as either a madman or a fellow F.B.I. agent from an alternate dimension who is intimately familiar with the show\u2019s heroes, the alien-chasing feds Dana Scully (Gillian Anderson) and Fox Mulder (David Duchovny). Mr. Morgan uses this premise to provide the ultimate in fan service \u2014 constructing an elaborate meta-story that recapitulates the history of the series, with a cracked version of \u201cThe Twilight Zone\u201d as a framing device, and wallows in specific references to past \u201cX-Files\u201d installments (including \u201cClyde Bruckman\u2019s\u201d).", "title": "Review: \u2018The X-Files\u2019 in a Familiar Groove", "authors": ["Mike Hale"]} {"date": "2018-01-15 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nOnly in the last minutes of their show do the seven young New Yorkers telling their stories in \u201cUndesirable Elements: Generation NYZ\u201d mention the Manhattanite in the White House, the one who spent his childhood in Queens, and whose shadow looms over the production.\n\n\u201cI want to find a way to help, but I can\u2019t go to the protests,\u201d says Monica Victoria Tatacoya Castan\u0303eda, a Mexican-born, 19-year-old feminist from Brooklyn whose immigration status \u2014 she is enrolled in the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals program \u2014 means that she can\u2019t risk arrest. \u201cSo I have to look for another way.\u201d\n\nFor her, this gentle, humane, powerfully moving work of documentary theater by Ping Chong + Company is a form of activism. The conceit of this piece of documentary theater is that each person onstage belongs to a group that is marginalized in the culture \u2014 because of skin color or place of origin, sexual orientation or gender or poverty.\n\nGenerating empathy, defying small-mindedness, this is an inherently political show that arrives at a time of fervently uncivil discourse. Conceived by Ping Chong, \u201cGeneration NYZ\u201d believes in the power of storytelling to create a stronger, kinder culture.\n\nPhoto\n\nWritten and directed by Sara Zatz and Kirya Traber in collaboration with the performers, the show takes the form of a staged reading, with each cast member seated at a music stand holding a script. They tell their own stories and help to tell one another\u2019s, their narratives interweaving. Some of the performers have stage experience, but they are playing themselves, and all are unvarnished enough that their charm comes from their everydayness.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSyl (Andrea) Egerton, an 18-year-old from Queens by way of Europe, mentions being uncertain how to answer when a video game asked him, in middle school: \u201cAre you a boy or are you a girl?\u201d Mohammad Murtaza, also 18, also from Queens, recalls how he hid his depression from his Pakistani immigrant parents, fearing their reaction. De-Andra Pryce, a Brooklyn 18-year-old, speaks of reconciling her law-enforcement ambitions with her blackness.", "title": "Review: \u2018Undesirable Elements,\u2019 Documentary Theater for Uncivil Times", "authors": ["Laura Collins-Hughes"]} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cVazante\u201d is an origin story written in bile and ornamented with reluctant beauty. It takes place in southeastern Brazil in 1821 \u2014 some six decades before the abolition of slavery \u2014 on a squalid farm deep in the mountains. There, a white drover turned farmer, Antonio (Adriano Carvalho), is trying to make a go of it on the backs of enslaved black men, women and children. He\u2019s failed to cultivate the land, blaming it for his defeat, and seems equally terrible at everything else. Soon after the movie opens, his wife and baby die during labor, a tragedy that suggests that here life itself is doomed from the start.\n\nIndolent and apparently untroubled by his multiple failings, Antonio had received the farm as part of his wife\u2019s dowry. Her doddering mother, Zizinha (Juliana Carneiro Da Cunha), came with the place, and presumably so did the slaves who mind the house, like Joana (Geisa Costa), and others who tend the farm, like Porf\u00edrio (Adilson Magh\u00e1). It\u2019s an austere, pitiless world and might be a near-unbearable, unwatchable one if the director Daniela Thomas didn\u2019t hook you early. But she does, starting with the black-and-white cinematography that draws you in, just because it\u2019s so infrequently used these days.\n\nVideo\n\nThe palette is alluringly exotic, but it\u2019s also expressive, with subtle shades \u2014 white, dove, slate, jet \u2014 that soon take on metaphoric resonance. (Inti Briones is the director of photography.) Yet while the visuals and natural world catch the eye, Ms. Thomas, who has directed movies with Walter Salles, rarely lingers to admire the view or her own handiwork. There\u2019s a bracing lack of vanity in how she conveys this long-lost world and not an iota of misplaced nostalgia. She shows you the loveliness, but she also insistently juxtaposes it with the grim sights and clanging sounds of heavily shackled men.\n\nMs. Thomas, working from a script by her and Beto Amaral, plots the narrative coordinates fairly leisurely. The movie\u2019s rhythms are unhurried, though for the most part not indulgently so, and fit both the period and Antonio\u2019s uneasy lassitude (which makes a stark contrast with the slaves\u2019 work). Characters enter and exit, offering up names and filling in the back story. Antonio\u2019s brother-in-law, Bartholomeu (Roberto Audio), slides into the picture with his unhappy wife, Ondina (Sandra Corveloni), and their daughters, Maria Joaquina (Isadora Favero) and Beatriz (Luana Nastas). They\u2019re poor, but while Bartholomeu has resigned himself to his fate, the women around him have not.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn time, Ms. Thomas\u2019s focus narrows on Beatriz, whom Antonio weds. He soon departs on business, leaving his child bride (she hasn\u2019t started menstruating) and addled mother-in-law with his openly restless slaves, a development that makes next to no narrative sense but gives Ms. Thomas ample time to stir up trouble and add some dramatic tension. With Antonio away, Beatriz is soon running through the fields with a young slave, Virg\u00edlio (Vinicius Dos Anjos). His mother, Feliciana (Jai Baptista), is routinely forced to share Antonio\u2019s bed, which suggests that Virg\u00edlio may be Antonio\u2019s son, one more complication in a lyrically minded movie that wafts into schematic tidiness and bluntness.\n\nThis shift is at odds with Ms. Thomas\u2019s embrace of ellipticism. She\u2019s obviously interested in how race influences gender and class, and how they all press against \u2014 and impinge on \u2014 one another until they\u2019re inseparable. (The lack of indigenous people in this story is a curious absence.) It\u2019s also evident that she doesn\u2019t want to make a thesis movie or put speeches in anyone\u2019s mouth. So for much of the movie she comes at her ideas sideways, circling them much as her characters orbit one another and letting her images \u2014 a black boy gently running his fingers over a white girl\u2019s arm \u2014 carry the weight of her meaning.\n\nBy the end, it\u2019s hard not to wish that Ms. Thomas had traded a bit of her art-film drift for something more direct. One of her strongest characters turns out to be an unnamed slave (Toumani Kouyat\u00e9, excellent), who\u2019s part of a new group that Antonio brings to the farm. A ferociously charismatic presence, this man serves as the group\u2019s leader and insistently speaks up, commanding attention with each utterance. In a misguided decision, though, his dialogue hasn\u2019t been subtitled, ostensibly because no one at the farm understands the newcomers. \u201cIt ain\u2019t Bantu,\u201d an older slave says, referring to an African language. The one man here worth listening to has been effectively silenced.", "title": "Review: \u2018Vazante\u2019 Revisits Brazil\u2019s History in Black and White", "authors": ["Manohla Dargis", "Daniela Thomas", "Beto Amaral"]} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "The Israeli director Amos Gitai models \u201cWest of the Jordan River\u201d on his earlier \u201cField Diary,\u201d a 1982 documentary that he filmed in the occupied territories. At the opening of the new film, Mr. Gitai somewhat pretentiously likens his role to that of an \u201carchaeologist\u201d of negotiations between the Israelis and the Palestinians.\n\nThis episodic documentary jumps back and forth in time, mainly between 1994, when Mr. Gitai filmed an interview with Yitzhak Rabin, then the Israeli prime minister, who was assassinated a year later, and 2016, when Mr. Gitai surveys the aftermath of the stalled peace process that Rabin fought for.\n\nIn the Rabin interview, the prime minister explains to the filmmaker how he reached the decision to negotiate with the Palestine Liberation Organization, and argues for the necessity of social and economic development with Arab partners to secure a lasting peace. Other footage from 1994 \u2014 some shot in Gaza and at a checkpoint on the Israeli-Gaza border \u2014 is presented as a reminder that the past was not all that different from the present.", "title": "Review: \u2018West of the Jordan River\u2019 Examines the Mideast Peace Process", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "In \u201cWhat Lies Upstream,\u201d the documentarian Cullen Hoback begins by investigating the 2014 chemical spill that left 300,000 West Virginians without safe tap water. The resulting movie, national in scope, lays out damning (if not always cohesive) arguments about how government regulators tend to defer to the companies they are supposed to supervise, how legislative fixes aren\u2019t permanent and how mandated safety checks are useless if they aren\u2019t performed or performed properly.\n\nSome compelling camera personalities emerge. Randy Huffman, at the time the secretary of the State Department of Environmental Protection in West Virginia, wants to \u201cgive the benefit of the doubt\u201d to organizations. When Mr. Hoback, who has read a report suggesting that tens of thousands of violations of the Clean Water Act went uninvestigated in the state, cites that number to him, Mr. Huffman brushes it off as \u201cnot that many.\u201d", "title": "Review: \u2018What Lies Upstream,\u2019 a Broad View of a Chemical Spill", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-09 00:00:00", "text": "The challenge of going off to college is leaving the nest without coming unmoored. This is also the challenge of spinning off a college sitcom.\n\n\u201cgrown-ish,\u201d the \u201cblack-ish\u201d progeny that airs Wednesdays on Freeform, kicked off its pilot with Zoey Johnson (Yara Shahidi) talking her dad, Andre (Anthony Anderson), through his separation anxiety. (\u201cIt hurts so bad!\u201d he cries. What hurts?, she asks. \u201cMy soooooul!\u201d)\n\nViewers of \u201cblack-ish\u201d had seen that comic opera play out for a year, as Andre planned to send his first (and let\u2019s be honest, favorite) child away. Reprising it here was an assurance. \u201cgrown-ish\u201d would be different, but also the same; it would take some getting used to, but everything would be fine.\n\nIn its early episodes, \u201cgrown-ish\u201d is enough like \u201cblack-ish\u201d in tone and style to please old fans, but not yet as different as it will need to be in the long run.", "title": "Review: \u2018grown-ish\u2019 Comes Into Its Own-ish", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-31 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cPresident Issues Appeal for Unity in State of Union\u201d (front page, Jan. 31):\n\nPresident Trump has demonstrated that for 80 minutes, by following the script on the teleprompter, he is capable of at least appearing presidential. Most of us know by now that this will not last.\n\nMr. President, the moral and ethical underpinnings of our union, far from being renewed and rejuvenated, are decaying. Your incessant demeaning of government institutions, assaults on the free press and prevarication show your true colors.\n\nIt is true that in your first year the state of our union economically has become stronger and the advance in the stock market has added to the wealth of our country, although mostly among a small subset of the population. But what is undeniably also true is that our democratic ideals are under attack from within the Republic and from outside it. Until you accept and deal with this reality, the state of our union will remain in peril.\n\nKEN DEROW, SWARTHMORE, PA.\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nPresident Trump, love him or hate him, hit the ball out of the park in his State of the Union address, leaving Democrats scavenging for criticism. His balcony guests were a mix of stories of heroism, heartbreak and patriotism, all of which registered with Americans.", "title": "Opinion | Reviews of Trump\u2019s State of the Union Speech", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "On the night of July 16, 1918, Russia\u2019s last czar, Nicholas II, was murdered with his wife and five children in a basement in Yekaterinburg, where they had been detained by the Bolsheviks for four months. On orders from Moscow, they were shot and bayoneted, and their mutilated bodies were set afire.\n\nThat much has been generally agreed on, based on overwhelming evidence gathered by numerous experts. Yet the Russian Orthodox Church continues to pose more questions, hinting at the darkest of conspiracies: Were the remains that were later exhumed really those of the imperial family? If not, how many were murdered, and where were they buried?\n\nLate last year, church officials added another twist with dark implications, suggesting that the execution of the Romanovs was \u201ca ritual murder\u201d \u2014 a phrase evoking calumnies directed against Russia\u2019s Jews as part of their persecution in czarist times.\n\nNow those words have come from Bishop Tikhon Shevkunov, during a speech on Nov. 27 at a church-sponsored conference convened to re-examine the circumstances of the Romanovs\u2019 murder. Sitting next to Patriarch Kirill, the head of the church, the bishop insisted that his claim was shared by many members of a committee that has been investigating the czar\u2019s murder since 2015. A representative of the President\u2019s Investigative Committee, the government\u2019s top crime agency, quickly agreed to seek out more expert opinions and \u201cto conduct a psychological and historical analysis\u201d of the matter.", "title": "Opinion | Reviving Old Lies to Unite a New Russia", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "He eventually landing a job in the publicity department of 20th Century Fox, where he had to go into the steam room \u2014 \u201din my starched shirt\u201d \u2014 and read gossip items to the studio head, Spyros Skouras, emerging soaking wet and disillusioned.\n\nThe studio \u201cwas spending millions of dollars to sink Elizabeth Taylor in the Nile in \u2018Cleopatra,\u2019 but at the home office, they were saving on rubber bands,\u201d Mr. Reed recalled. He made $57.50 a week, he said, survived on 35-cent ham salad sandwiches from Woolworth\u2019s and lived in an actress cousin\u2019s apartment on 23rd Street while she was in upstate New York doing stock theater.\n\n\u201cIt was a one-room apartment over a Chinese restaurant, where all the roaches came up to visit at night,\u201d he said. \u201cYou would turn on the lights, they were so brazen they would just stare at you, they wouldn\u2019t even run. I thought, \u2018This is horrible, but it\u2019s New York.\u2019\u201d\n\nThe studio eventually laid him off after budget cutbacks, and in 1965 he fled the city to knock around Europe with friends in a rented red Volkswagen. He ended up at the Venice Film Festival just as his money was running out. \u201cI didn\u2019t know how I was going to get home,\u201d he said. Mr. Reed decided to pose as a journalist and bluff his way into interviews with Jean-Paul Belmondo and Buster Keaton, the aging silent film star who was promoting \u201cFilm,\u201d a 22-minute experimental silent movie written by Samuel Beckett. Mr. Reed sold both articles, making enough to buy a return ticket to the United States.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe Keaton article, which appeared in The New York Times, was hammered out on film-festival stationery. (\u201cBuster Keaton was there, looking for all the world like the kind of man dogs kick. \u2026\u201d)\n\nSettling in New York, Mr. Reed soon became an in-demand magazine writer, then a hot job: churning out swashbuckling profiles of Tennessee Williams, Warren Beatty and many others. His unflinching Ava Gardner profile for Esquire in 1966 portrayed an embittered former screen siren two-fisting Dom P\u00e9rignon and cognac, complaining about her tenure at MGM as \u201c17 years of slavery\u201d in which the studio \u201ctried to sell me like a prize hog.\u201d The article wound up in Tom Wolfe\u2019s 1973 anthology, \u201cThe New Journalism.\u201d\n\nMr. Reed was also becoming a regular on \u201cThe Dick Cavett Show\u201d and \u201cThe Tonight Show\u201d with Johnny Carson.\n\n\u201cHe developed his own fan club on the show,\u201d Mr. Cavett said in a phone interview. \u201cI remember on one show, he said about Nancy Sinatra that she looked like a \u2018pizza waitress.\u2019 I actually began to worry. One of the musicians said to me, \u2018Don\u2019t worry, Frank doesn\u2019t have a temper, ha ha ha.\u2019 I think I went home and ordered a fallout shelter.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Of the Moment The lifestyle newsletter from the Styles, Travel and Food sections, offering the latest trends to news you can use. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. Reed continues to consider physical appearance of public figures fair game. In 2013 he was denounced for calling the actress Melissa McCarthy \u201ctractor-sized\u201d and a \u201cfemale hippo\u201d in his review of the comedy \u201cIdentity Thief.\u201d\n\n\u201cI felt really bad for someone who is swimming in so much hate,\u201d she told The Times then.\n\n\u201cShe went nuts because all her fans came out of the woodwork and were mad at me,\u201d Mr. Reed said. \u201cBut what did she do? She lost 50 pounds. She started doing her own fashion designs. She looks terrific now, and is getting roles that don\u2019t require her to fall down in mud puddles.\u201d\n\nMr. Reed knows firsthand the mercilessness of the camera, and the critics. In 1969 he edged out George Hamilton, he said, for a prominent role in \u201cMyra Breckinridge,\u201d the big-budget film adaptation of the Gore Vidal novel whose protagonist undergoes a sex change \u2014 a scandalous notion then.\n\nIn the film, the sex change was reduced to dream sequence. Mr. Reed played the pre-transition Myron to Raquel Welch\u2019s Myra.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAt the outset, the film, which also starred Mae West and Farrah Fawcett, looked like a blockbuster. It quickly became a very different sort of disaster movie. The original director, the venerable George Cukor, fell out, along with Bette Davis and Burl Ives, Mr. Reed said. Ms. West, then in her late 70s, was entrusted to write key scenes, in which Mr. Reed and Ms. Welch refused to appear. \u201cShe didn\u2019t understand the movie at all,\u201d Mr. Reed said.\n\nNothing made any sense. In one scene Mr. Reed sashayed through an orgy scene \u201cwith a bottle of champagne, and my jacket over my shoulder, like William Holden in \u2018Sabrina.\u2019\u201d But it was \u201ca completely ridiculous orgy, everybody was fully clothed.\u201d\n\n\u201cWhen this picture ended, it was $30 million over budget and they had filmed half of it.\u201d\n\nIf nothing else, the project established him socially among the Hollywood A-list. He recalled dinner parties at Ruth Gordon\u2019s house: \u201cOn my right would be Jean Renoir, and on my left would be Orson Welles.\u201d\n\nOther dinner parties, he was glad to miss. Like Steve McQueen, John Phillips and seemingly half of Hollywood, Mr. Reed claims to have turned down an invitation to dine, along with Jacqueline Susann, the \u201cValley of the Dolls\u201d author, at Sharon Tate\u2019s house the night of the Manson family murders.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cI said, \u2018Jackie, I want to stay home and eat lemon meringue pie in my pajamas, in front of the T.V. at the Beverly Hills Hotel,\u2019\u201d Mr. Reed recalled.\n\nHe was back in New York by the time the devastating reviews for \u201cMyra Breckinridge\u201d rolled in. Howard Thompson of The Times seemed to be channeling Rex Reed himself when he described the film as a \u201cgrim grotesquerie\u201d that \u201ccollapses like a tired, smirking elephant with no place to go.\u201d\n\nWhile there would be other scattered roles \u2014 \u201cInchon,\u201d \u201cSuperman\u201d \u2014 Mr. Reed\u2019s destiny would be to write about movies, not star in them. \u201cI just never had the luck,\u201d he said. \u201cI was never handed a good script. I just think that one of the reasons that movies are so profoundly screwed up today is because the last person who gets any credit for anything is the writer.\u201d\n\nLennon Gave Him TV Guide\n\nMr. Reed may not have made a fortune in the film business, but he is sitting on millions of dollars of real estate. \u201cIt\u2019s an awfully comfortable bachelor pad,\u201d he said of the book-filled Dakota apartment he has lived in since 1969, which he bought for $30,000.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHe found the apartment through his friendship with Ruth Ford, the Broadway actress who lived there with her husband, the actor Zachary Scott, whose family \u201cowned half of Texas,\u201d Mr. Reed said. The playwright William Inge, Judy Garland, Judy Holliday and the saxophone player Gerry Mulligan were all neighbors at various points.\n\n\u201cI moved into this apartment with an A.&P. shopping cart, some books and whatever I could drag over from my little walk-up on 73rd Street,\u201d Mr. Reed said. His only furniture was a corduroy Queen Anne chair and a sleeping bag. The night he moved in, the film star Robert Ryan, who was president of the Dakota\u2019s board, rang the doorbell to welcome him, and the two shared instant coffee, Mr. Reed on the sleeping bag, Mr. Ryan in the chair. \u201cDo you think that happens today?\u201d he asked.\n\nBoris Karloff was another neighbor. Rudolf Nureyev, Leonard Bernstein and Rosemary Clooney lived in the building. \u201cBetty\u201d Bacall, whose spacious three-bedroom apartment sold for $21 million in 2015 after her death the previous year, and Mr. Reed used to eat together regularly, he said.\n\nHe once signed a petition supporting John Lennon when the government was trying to deport Mr. Lennon because of his drug use and political activism. Mr. Lennon thanked him with a one-year subscription to TV Guide, Mr. Reed said, adding, \u201cThat was his bible. All he did was lie around stoned watching television.\u201d\n\nIf Mr. Lennon famously sang, \u201cAll You Need Is Love,\u201d Mr. Reed appears to disagree.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t have \u2018relationships,\u2019 except friends,\u201d he said. \u201cI don\u2019t know, love is not something that I\u2019ve been really good at. I think people are intimidated by people with opinions.\u201d\n\nHe sighed, as if resigned. \u201cI think it\u2019s all over as far as that goes. How do you go start looking for a wife or a boyfriend or a significant other? It\u2019s too late. It would be nice, though, to find somebody who\u2019s really handy with a wheelchair, because that day is coming.\u201d\n\nBut even if his mobility is impaired, Mr. Reed will remain a bucking bull in the china shop of current sensibilities.\n\n\u201cIf I had to give the greatest dinner party of my own choosing in the world, the only person I would invite that I have never met was Adolf Hitler,\u201d he said. \u201cEverybody else, I\u2019ve met.\u201d", "title": "Rex Reed Bangs a Gong on the Mediocrity of Modern Life", "authors": ["Alex Williams"]} {"date": "2018-01-01 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\n\u201cI Am Proud of Our Diplomacy,\u201d by Secretary of State Rex Tillerson (Op-Ed, Dec. 28), is as interesting for what it leaves out as it is for what it claims. There is, for example, no discussion of the United States\u2019 withdrawal from the Trans-Pacific Partnership, the withdrawal from the Paris climate accord, the decision to name Jerusalem as the capital of Israel, immigration restrictions for Muslim countries that have not, in fact, exported terrorists, and the flight of highly trained diplomats from the State Department.\n\nMr. Tillerson may (as my former ambassador friend claims) be a fine fellow, but the Trump administration is clearly making major mistakes.\n\nPETER K. FROST\n\nWILLIAMSTOWN, MASS.\n\nThe writer is emeritus professor of international studies at Williams College.\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nLike Secretary of State Rex Tillerson, I, too, am proud of United States diplomacy. But as a recently retired career diplomat, I am deeply concerned by his support for 30 percent reductions to the State Department and the United States Agency for International Development\u2019s budgets. These, in addition to the extensive personnel cuts in both organizations that Mr. Tillerson is unwisely pursuing, will do long-term harm to our country\u2019s diplomatic capacity.", "title": "Opinion | Rex Tillerson\u2019s View of World Affairs", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-28 00:00:00", "text": "Rosie O\u2019Donnell will not be returning to the stage in February after all.\n\nThe actress, comedian and talk show host has withdrawn from the New Group\u2019s production of \u201cGood for Otto\u201d due to illness. The production announced on Friday that Rhea Perlman will replace her in the role of Nora, the foster mother of a daughter with severe depression.\n\n\u201cGood for Otto,\u201d written by David Rabe, was set to be Ms. O\u2019Donnell\u2019s first steady role in an Off Broadway play. In 2005 she played Golde in \u201cFiddler on the Roof\u201d on Broadway; before that she had roles in \u201cGrease\u201d and \u201cSeussical.\u201d\n\nMs. Perlman won four Emmy Awards as the acerbic waitress Carla Tortelli in NBC\u2019s \u201cCheers.\u201d She\u2019s appeared onstage in \u201cThe Tale of the Allergist\u2019s Wife,\u201d \u201cThe Exonerated,\u201d and \u201cBoeing-Boeing.\u201d\n\nShe joins a cast that includes F. Rehearsals are currently underway, with previews scheduled to begin February 20 for a March 8 opening at the Pershing Square Signature Center.", "title": "Rhea Perlman Replaces Rosie O\u2019Donnell in Off Broadway Role", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-22 00:00:00", "text": "Compagnie Financi\u00e8re Richemont built a conglomerate offering the world\u2019s wealthiest consumers the highest-quality product, often in the most luxurious of settings. Clients walking into a Cartier flagship or a Piaget boutique \u2014 both Richemont brands \u2014 could expect radiant smiles and soft furnishings, as well as impeccable service for as long as was necessary before they made their purchase.\n\nIncreasingly, though, well-heeled clients don\u2019t want that type of service. Cash-rich, time-starved customers want their shopping to be quick, quiet and easy, done in a matter of seconds from their smartphone.\n\nRichemont, which also owns upscale brands like IWC, Montblanc and Van Cleef & Arpels, knows that times are changing. The Swiss luxury group announced on Monday that it was doubling down on its investments in high-end internet retail, making an offer of 2.8 billion euros, or about $3.4 billion, for the online fashion retailer Yoox Net-a-Porter.\n\nThe surprise bid was a significant about-face in Richemont\u2019s strategy and an acknowledgment that wealthy consumers are increasingly comfortable buying an expensive watch or pen with a click rather than a trip to an upscale store. The process of buying luxury goods, which traditionally took place over many hours in lavish shops or department stores, is rapidly transforming.", "title": "Richemont, Doubling Down on Online Luxury, May Buy Yoox Net-a-Porter", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-08 00:00:00", "text": "The Jaguars won Sunday\u2019s game, 10-3, eliminating the Bills from the playoffs.\n\nWhen asked for more details, Ngakoue on Monday told The Associated Press: \u201cHe said what he said. He knows what he said. I don\u2019t have to repeat it.\u201d\n\n\u201cSomebody says something about your ethnicity, that\u2019s really kind of taking it a little too far. I\u2019m all with trash talk. It\u2019s part of the game, but you can\u2019t say certain things.\u201d\n\nIncognito did not respond to a request by The A.P. for a comment.\n\nIncognito\u2019s checkered career includes fights with teammates and opponents at Nebraska and accusations of dirty play in the pros. He was accused of using racial and anti-gay slurs during the bullying of Martin, who is black.\n\nIncognito had not responded to Ngakoue\u2019s charges as of Monday morning.", "title": "Richie Incognito Accused of Using Racial Slurs in Game", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-03 00:00:00", "text": "Rick Hall, the producer who forged the Southern soul style known as the Muscle Shoals sound, died on Tuesday at his home in Muscle Shoals, Ala. He was 85.\n\nHis wife, Linda Kay Hall, said the cause was prostate cancer.\n\nMr. Hall turned small-town Alabama into a crucible of soul, country, pop and rock after he founded FAME Studios in 1959 in Florence, Ala. FAME stands for Florence Alabama Music Enterprises, although in 1961 the studio moved to nearby Muscle Shoals, where it remains. Mr. Hall also started FAME Publishing, which would amass a substantial catalog of hits, and FAME Records.\n\nMr. Hall\u2019s versatile output drew on Southern roots \u2014 country, blues, R&B, gospel \u2014 and on his instincts for concisely emotive storytelling, lean arrangements and solid grooves. He was a proud taskmaster in the studio.", "title": "Rick Hall, Architect of the Muscle Shoals Sound, Dies at 85", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-08 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cI appreciate the Commission\u2019s consideration and effort to further assess the marketplace distortions that are putting the long-term resiliency of our electric grid at risk,\u201d Mr. Perry said in a statement. \u201cAs intended, my proposal initiated a national debate on the resiliency of our electric system.\u201d\n\nPresident Trump has vowed to revive the ailing coal-mining industry, and his administration has moved to relax a variety of climate and pollution regulations on the nation\u2019s coal plants. So far, however, those rollbacks have failed to halt the market forces that continue to drive coal plants into retirement. Last year, utilities announced plans to shut down more than 22 gigawatts of coal capacity across the country, and more retirements are expected this year.\n\nMr. Perry\u2019s proposal was the most aggressive move yet in support of coal and nuclear power and would have shielded a number of plants in the Midwest and Mid-Atlantic from those competitive forces. An analysis by Resources for the Future estimated that the rule, if enacted, would have prevented the retirement of 25 gigawatts of coal capacity and 20 gigawatts of nuclear capacity. The analysis found that the proposal would have cost electricity users an extra $72 billion through 2045.\n\nWhile coal is more polluting than natural gas, nuclear plants do not produce any emissions, and some states like New York have moved to rescue their ailing reactors to help combat climate change. The commission\u2019s decision would not affect those state efforts.\n\nThe commission\u2019s unanimous decision to reject Mr. Perry\u2019s proposal is final. While four of the five members of the commission were nominated by Mr. Trump, the agency has historically operated independently of the executive branch and tends to be protective of the competitive market structure built up over the past three decades.\n\n\u201cThere is clearly a broad consensus among commissioners of both parties that the carefully constructed competitive power markets that FERC has created over the last 30 years are keeping consumer prices low,\u201d said Paul Bledsoe, a former Clinton White House climate change adviser. \u201cThe notion of subsidizing coal and nuclear and thereby raising consumer prices is anathema to Trump appointees and Democrats alike.\u201d", "title": "Rick Perry\u2019s Plan to Rescue Struggling Coal and Nuclear Plants Is Rejected", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "For people like Jean Ryan, who lives in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, and uses a motorized scooter, the taxi dispatch program is one of the few options for traveling to Manhattan. The subway station two blocks from her home is not wheelchair accessible and the bus is often too slow, she said. The city\u2019s Access-A-Ride service, a paratransit service for people with disabilities, requires advance booking and can be unreliable, she said.\n\n\u201cI can\u2019t wheel myself to Manhattan,\u201d said Ms. Ryan, 73, the vice president of Disabled in Action of Metropolitan New York, an advocacy group.\n\nBut even accessible taxis have their limitations, she said. For example, the city\u2019s fleet of Nissan NV200s require that the back seats fold down to fit a wheelchair, meaning that a wheelchair user can only ride with one friend in the front.\n\n\u201cAnd for getting around on a daily basis it\u2019s too expensive,\u201d she added about cabs.\n\nThe Taxi and Limousine Commission spent nearly a decade making improvements to its dispatch program in Manhattan, which arranges 250 trips a day, before rolling it out to all five boroughs.\n\nPhoto\n\nGraham Hodges, a former New York cabdriver and a historian at Colgate University, lauded the expansion, but questioned the city\u2019s slow pace in addressing the needs of the 90,000 wheelchair users in the city.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s a step in the right direction, but why they took so long to do it is a question,\u201d said Mr. Hodges, who wrote a book on the history of New York cabdrivers.\n\nOver the years, the time it takes for a cab to pick up a wheelchair user has decreased. The average wait time for a wheelchair-accessible cab was 34 minutes during a two-year pilot phase in 2008. Today, riders typically wait 13 minutes for a ride, according to Allan J. Fromberg, the commission\u2019s deputy commissioner for public affairs. In the boroughs outside of Manhattan, the average wait time has been 15 to 20 minutes during a test phase launched in September, said Alex Elegudin, the accessibility program manager at the commission.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe expansion comes at a time when ride-hailing companies like Uber and Lyft have overtaken yellow cabs in numbers and popularity. As the companies continue to burgeon, they have also come under fire for a lack of accessibility.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAlthough Uber voluntarily offers wheelchair-accessible cars through its UberWAV service, critics have said that they account for only a fraction of the company\u2019s fleet. For years, for-hire car services were not required to dispatch accessible vehicles.\n\nBut that changed in December, when the commission adopted a rule requiring that ride-hailing companies complete 25 percent of their trips every year using wheelchair-accessible cars by 2022. The rule is meant to increase the circulation of accessible cars for people who need them.\n\nThe rule will go into effect on July 1.\n\nThe Accessible Dispatch Program was started in 2012, when the Bloomberg administration was embroiled in a bitter feud with advocates for the disabled over the wheelchair accessibility of New York\u2019s taxicabs.\n\nIn December 2013, three weeks before Mayor Bill de Blasio was sworn in, the Bloomberg administration settled a class-action suit that accused the city of violating the Americans With Disabilities Act because only a fraction of its taxis were accessible.\n\nThe city agreed to adopt regulations to make 50 percent of the city\u2019s more than 13,000 yellow cabs wheelchair-friendly by 2020. The de Blasio administration approved a 30-cent surcharge on taxi rides to help pay for it.\n\nThere were 233 accessible yellow cars in 2012, Mr. Fromberg said. Today, there are 2,175 wheelchair-accessible yellow cars, he said.", "title": "Riders Outside Manhattan Can Now Hail Accessible Taxis, Too", "authors": ["Luis Ferr\u00e9-Sadurn\u00ed"]} {"date": "2018-01-16 00:00:00", "text": "The political news cycle is fast, and keeping up can be overwhelming. Trying to find differing perspectives worth your time is even harder. That\u2019s why we have scoured the internet for political writing from the right and left that you might not have seen.\n\nHas this series exposed you to new ideas? Tell us how. Email us at ourpicks@nytimes.com.\n\nFor an archive of all the Partisan Writing Roundups, check out Our Picks.\n\nFrom the Right\n\nPhoto\n\nJohn Daniel Davidson in The Federalist:\n\n\u201cAlthough his phrasing was crude and unnecessary, Trump wasn\u2019t wrong about the actual countries in question. Haiti, El Salvador, and many countries in Africa \u2014 and all over the world, for that matter \u2014 are indeed a horrible mess by any objective measure.\u201d\n\nMr. Davidson turns the conversation around the president\u2019s words toward American exceptionalism. It is not because \u201cAmericans are uniquely virtuous or somehow better than people from poor countries,\u201d but because the American \u201csystem of government and the constitutional order our founding fathers bequeathed us\u201d make the United States a country worth immigrating to, he writes. That is why, he says, so many immigrants from those countries \u201ccome to America and prosper.\u201d Read more \u00bb\n\n_____\n\nPat Buchanan in Townhall:\n\n\u201cIn U.S. presidential elections, persons of color whose roots are in Asia, Africa and Latin America vote 4-1 Democratic, and against the candidates favored by American\u2019s vanishing white majority. Not for the first time, liberal ideology comports precisely with liberal interests.\u201d\n\nYou cannot escape race in the immigration debate, Mr. Buchanan argues, while pointing to the demographic composition of the two major political parties. \u201cAmericans have the sovereign right to discriminate in favor of some continents, countries and cultures, and against others,\u201d Mr. Buchanan further argues, \u201cin a tradition as old as the Republic.\u201d A tradition he reviews carefully. Such moments often make clear fundamentally contradictory visions of America. It\u2019s impossible to negotiate with people who believe any change to America-as-they-see-it is an existential threat \u2014 and when they\u2019re direct or boorish enough to say that out loud, it saves everyone the time and trouble of trying to compromise.\u201d\n\nEven if it appears \u201calmost unimaginably hard to figure out a way to \u2018end chain migration\u2019 that would both pass Congress and avoid a collapse of the immigration system,\u201d a policy debate can still be had. But, Ms. Lind argues, \u201cyou can\u2019t negotiate\u201d with those who want no immigration. She sums up: \u201cEither America is a nation of immigrants or it is a nation of blood and soil. It cannot be both.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nRead more \u00bb\n\n_____\n\nEugene Robinson in the Washington Post:\n\n\u201cRepublicans say they want a \u201cmerit-based\u201d system of immigration. That has a nice, neutral sound. Who can argue against merit? But Trump has made clear that what he means to do is halt or reverse the demographic trends that are making this nation increasingly diverse \u2014 trends that are wholly consistent with U.S. history.\u201d\n\nMr. Robinson thinks Mr. Trump\u2019s language creates a wedge between congressional Republican leadership and the president. \u201cThere is nothing inherently racist about the free-market conservatism that Republicans cherish and advocate,\u201d Mr. Robinson argues, \u201cbut there is everything racist about the white ethnocentric theory of American identity that Trump champions with remarkable frankness.\u201d Read more \u00bb", "title": "Right and Left React to President Trump\u2019s Comments on Immigration", "authors": ["Justin Bank"]} {"date": "2018-01-08 00:00:00", "text": "The political news cycle is fast, and keeping up can be overwhelming. Email us at ourpicks@nytimes.com.\n\nFor an archive of all the Partisan Writing Roundups, check out Our Picks.\n\nFrom the Right\n\nPhoto\n\nMollie Hemingway in The Federalist:\n\n\n\n\u201cThere is nothing about Trump now that suggests his mental state is any different or worse or dangerous than when voters elected him, or when they first encountered him on gossip pages and in reality television decades ago.\u201d\n\nMs. Hemingway notes that while some critics of President Trump have suggested using the 25th Amendment to overturn election results they were not expecting or not happy with, the debate has been reignited with the publication of Michael Wolff\u2019s book, \u201cFire and Fury.\u201d Any conversation about the president\u2019s mental fitness, she argues, is merely an attempt by the opposition to undo the democratic will of the American people. Read more \u00bb\n\n_____\n\nJonathan S. Tobin in National Review:\n\n\u201cDoing or saying something stupid is not the same thing as mental incapacity. If it were, no president would ever have escaped eviction from office on those grounds.\u201d\n\nMr. Tobin has no shortage of harsh words for Mr. Trump and his personality. A lack of \u201cpresidential temperament,\u201d according to Mr. Tobin, does not preclude Mr. Trump from \u201cmaking decisions and often getting them right.\u201d The 25th Amendment, he adds, \u201cwas intended to provide for a replacement when a president couldn\u2019t serve, not to dump a man whose behavior offends the sensibilities of the educated class.\u201d Read more \u00bb\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n_____\n\nDavid Frum in The Atlantic:\n\n\n\n\u201cTrump may imagine that he\u2019s Michael Corleone, the tough and canny rightful heir \u2014 or even Sonny Corleone, the terrifyingly violent but at least powerful heir apparent \u2014 but after today he is Fredo forever.\u201d\n\nWhatever Mr. Trump\u2019s flaws and cognitive deficiencies may be, Mr. Frum contends, his \u201cgenius\u201d is undeniable in one particular way: He \u201cunderstands how to mobilize hatred and resentment to his own advantage and profit.\u201d Mr. Frum suggests that instead of focusing on the president\u2019s mental health, we turn our attention to the people and institutions that keep such a president in power \u2014 despite knowing better. Among them is a notion that Mr. Trump\u2019s lawyers are telling their client that the investigation is nearing its end in order to keep the president from firing the special counsel. Sign up for the Morning Briefing Newsletter or the What We\u2019re Reading Newsletter.", "title": "Right and Left React to Trump\u2019s Attempted Firing of Robert Mueller", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-31 00:00:00", "text": "_____\n\nRamesh Ponnuru in Bloomberg:\n\n\n\n\u201cIt was unlike the addresses of most presidents in its nearly total refusal to lay out any ideas for the future.\u201d\n\nPresidents tend to use State of the Union addresses to accomplish a few goals, Mr. Ponnuru writes. Apart from garnering good reviews and shoring up popularity, historically, presidents have used the opportunity to lay out policy priorities and \u201clay the groundwork for future legislative proposals.\u201d In this, Mr. Ponnuru explains, Mr. Trump failed, with one very notable exception. On immigration, the president \u201coutlined an extremely ambitious agenda with enough detail to make for a useful debate.\u201d Read more \u00bb\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Get the Morning Briefing by Email What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox Monday through Friday. One is that Mr. Trump has been governing as the \u201cObama eraser.\u201d Mr. Cillizza takes Mr. Trump\u2019s pledge to keep the prison at Guant\u00e1namo Bay open as \u201ca direct rebuttal to Obama\u2019s long-made and long-failed pledge to close the prison.\u201d Mr. Cillizza gives the president high marks for stagecraft, calling the stories of the families he brought to the State of the Union \u201chaunting and memorable.\u201d Read more \u00bb\n\n_____\n\nThe editorial board at USA Today:\n\n\u201cIt is best to view the \u2018presidential\u2019 Trump more as a one-night wonder than as a champion of compromise.\u201d\n\nThe editors at USA Today warn their readers not to take Mr. Trump\u2019s overtures toward bipartisanship too seriously. They point out that he \u201chas a habit of making bipartisan appeals only to undermine them within days or even hours.\u201d Moreover, they write, \u201chis calls for bipartisan compromise on such areas as infrastructure and immigration are actually major departures in current policy that lack popular support.\u201d Read more \u00bb\n\n_____\n\nWant the Partisan Writing Roundup in your inbox? Trying to find differing perspectives worth your time is even harder. That\u2019s why we have scoured the internet for political writing from the right and left that you might not have seen.\n\nHas this series exposed you to new ideas? Tell us how. Email us at ourpicks@nytimes.com.\n\nFor an archive of all the Partisan Writing Roundups, check out Our Picks.\n\nFrom the Right\n\nPhoto\n\nBen Domenech in The Federalist:\n\n\u201cThe only rational explanation for this shutdown error was Democrats\u2019 belief that President Trump would not be able to resist the urge to intervene and worsen the situation \u2014 either by making some base-splitting promise or saying something objectionable.\u201d\n\nDemocrats made a tactical \u2014 though not all that unreasonable \u2014 mistake, Mr. Domenech says, by pinning the government shutdown on their hope for a deal to protect hundreds of thousands of illegal immigrants brought to the country as children. The Democrats had hoped, he suggests, that President Trump would say or do something that would derail Republican unity on the issue.\n\nMoreover, the party was hampered by a \u201cdistinct lack of clarity in what they are trying to do.\u201d Only the \u201chard-core Democratic base\u201d cares about protection for recipients of the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals program, or DACA, and had the shutdown continued, \u201cit could have damaged their ability to win over independents, who may be more susceptible to voting based on the country\u2019s economic success heading into the midterms.\u201d Read more \u00bb\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n_____\n\nJim Geraghty in National Review:\n\n\u201cThe bottom line is that most Americans don\u2019t like government shutdowns, and will rarely find other political goals sufficient to justify them.\u201d\n\nIf there\u2019s one lesson to take away from the three-day government shutdown, Mr. Geraghty writes, it\u2019s that Americans really don\u2019t like government shutdowns. They didn\u2019t like them in 2013 when Senator Ted Cruz of Texas led his fellow Republicans in a shutdown over the Affordable Care Act. And the same will be true in three weeks when Democrats hope to bring DACA to a vote: \u201cAmericans will still like DACA, but not enough to accept a government shutdown over it,\u201d Mr. Geraghty says. That\u2019s why we have scoured the internet for political writing from the right and left that you might not have seen.\n\nHas this series exposed you to new ideas? Tell us how. Email us at ourpicks@nytimes.com.\n\nFor an archive of all the Partisan Writing Roundups, check out Our Picks.\n\nFrom the Right\n\nPhoto\n\nJim Banks in The Washington Examiner:\n\n\n\n\u201cAs a conservative, I am committed to both protecting our national security and our civil liberties. As a matter of national security, we cannot return to a pre-9/11 footing by reinstituting barriers between national security and law enforcement.\u201d\n\nMr. Banks, a Republican congressman from Indiana, explains why he supports the decision by Congress to reauthorize Section 702 of the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act. The statute allows the government to continue conducting warrantless searches of communications of foreigners abroad, even when they are talking to American citizens. Mr. Banks argues that the provision is an \u201cirreplaceable tool\u201d crucial for the intelligence community to protect the nation. Moreover, he counters arguments that Section 702 compromises the privacy of Americans by explaining that it \u201cis subject to extraordinary checks and balances, including oversight from all three branches of government.\u201d Read more \u00bb\n\n_____\n\nWillis L. Krumholz in The Federalist:\n\n\u201cThe problem, fundamentally, is that Congress has given our intelligence agencies too much power, and refuses to check these agencies even when they flagrantly abuse the vast powers they have been granted.\u201d\n\nMr. Krumholz cites what he sees as abuses of Section 702 as an argument against reauthorization of the provision. He is particularly concerned with the process known as unmasking, wherein government officials can find out the identities of Americans participating in foreign communications picked up by intelligence agencies. Despite their best intentions to prevent terrorism and crime, he argues, intelligence agencies are not immune from a central tenet of human nature: \u201cUnaccountable power corrupts and would be abused by even the best of us.\u201d Read more \u00bb\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Get the Morning Briefing by Email What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox Monday through Friday. To Mr. Shephard, having the president walk back his initial message against reauthorization was a sign that he was out of step with his own administration. More important, perhaps, it also proves that Republican legislators have decided that, on policy, they will just ignore what their party\u2019s leader has to say. Read more \u00bb\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n_____\n\nTrevor Timm in NBC News:\n\n\u201cDemocrats should have had the foresight to roll back the Bush-era surveillance laws under President Obama; it\u2019s unconscionable to now hand Trump even more leverage to seek retribution and give him a green light to conduct unconstitutional surveillance on Americans.\u201d\n\nMr. Timm, the executive director of the Freedom of the Press Foundation, takes aim Democrats who joined with the House speaker, Paul D. Ryan, and other Republicans to extend the N.S.A.\u2019s ability to spy on Americans without a warrant. He singles out the House Democratic leader, Nancy Pelosi, and Representative Adam B. Schiff of California, for being staunch critics of the Trump administration while simultaneously granting it more power. Mr. Timm urges Senate Democrats to correct the mistake their colleagues in the House made in Thursday\u2019s vote. That\u2019s why we have scoured the internet for political writing from the right and left that you might not have seen.\n\nHas this series exposed you to new ideas? Tell us how. Email us at ourpicks@nytimes.com.\n\nFor an archive of all the Partisan Writing Roundups, check out Our Picks.\n\nFrom the Right\n\nPhoto\n\nDavid N. Bossie, Fox News:\n\n\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s time for Republicans in the U.S. House to take decisive action without delay on the issues of immigration reform and government funding that will prevent a government shutdown Friday night.\u201d\n\nMr. Bossie, the president of Citizens United and a former deputy campaign manager for Donald Trump\u2019s campaign, has a very prescriptive view of how to avert a government shutdown: \u201cRepublicans must move forward without\u201d Democrats. Mr. Bossie suggests approving a two-year spending bill to avert confronting this situation again, and he would like to see the immigration bill known as the Securing America\u2019s Future Act, introduced by Representative Bob Goodlatte, attached to the legislation. Read more \u00bb\n\n_____\n\nBen Shapiro of The Daily Wire:\n\n\u201cWhen Republicans pass a continuing resolution Obama refuses to sign, and the government shuts down, that\u2019s Republicans\u2019 fault. When they try to pass a continuing resolution and Democrats prevent that passage, that\u2019s Republicans\u2019 fault.\u201d\n\nEngaging in a little game theory, Mr. Shapiro observes that it\u2019s \u201calmost as though for the media, no matter what happens. Republicans are at fault for failures to fund the government.\u201d Mr. Shapiro focuses his attention for the shutdown on the filibuster preventing a vote for a continuing resolution to reach the floor of the Senate. Read more \u00bb\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n_____\n\nJennifer Rubin in The Washington Post:\n\n\u201cIf he were the chief executive of a private company, the president who was supposed to make government run like a business would be fired. In this case, that would only be a partial solution.\u201d\n\nMs. Rubin does not reserve her ire for the executive branch alone. She sees a lack of responsibility across the board and feels \u201cCongress\u2019s utter dysfunction is wasting the taxpayers\u2019 money and depriving taxpayers of the functional government their dollars have paid for.\u201d Read more \u00bb\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Get the Morning Briefing by Email What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox Monday through Friday.
