It\u2019s a case, all too common in Washington, where the needs of the politicians and those of the people are on a collision course.\u201d\n\nLike Ms. Rubin on the other side of the spectrum, Mr. Louis finds fault with the entire political system for the looming shutdown. And while he lays out the political calculus, he also establishes the stakes: \u201cThe government lost more than $2 billion during the last shutdown, and $24 billion was shaved from national economic output.\u201d Read more \u00bb", "title": "Right and Left React to the Prospect of a Government Shutdown", "authors": ["Justin Bank"]} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "MOSCOW \u2014 In Russia, as in Texas and other energy-dependent regions around the globe, a rising tide (of oil) lifts all boats.\n\nThat helps explain why on Thursday, as four American senators asked the State Department and other government agencies to blacklist two senior officials, the Russian stock market rose.\n\nIt was not the prospect of more sanctions, of course, that was buoying the Moscow markets but the global price of oil, which has been soaring to heights not seen in several years.\n\n\u201cSanctions are important, that is for sure, especially for the market and for debt and equity investors, but for G.D.P. and the life of ordinary Russians, oil is far more important,\u201d said Vladimir Osakovskiy, chief economist for Bank of America Merrill Lynch in Moscow, referring to Russia\u2019s gross domestic product.", "title": "Rising Oil Prices Buoy Russia\u2019s Economy, Despite Sanctions", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-31 00:00:00", "text": "#SpeakingInDance is a weekly visual exploration of dance on Instagram. Watch the video from our most recent post below, and follow us at@nytimes.", "title": "Rites of Passage", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-29 00:00:00", "text": "Both are British, 38, and never met before the production, which had its premiere in 2015 at Shakespeare\u2019s Globe in London. The two men share similar boyish features. If one didn\u2019t know better, they could be mistaken for siblings. Mr. Davies\u2019s jaw is slightly wider and Mr. Crane wears glasses, but onstage, in brocaded waistcoats, powdered wigs and shiny shoes, they are almost indistinguishable.\n\nAnd even now, as they relaxed together offstage, they were reminded of the oddness of the performing task they\u2019ve been assigned.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t relate to Sam onstage \u2014 I enter scenes when he\u2019s doing something else or he stays onstage when I\u2019m singing,\u201d Mr. Davies explained. \u201cI have to sometimes remind myself that we are the same person so I don\u2019t accidentally interact with him.\u201d\n\n\u201cMy side of Farinelli is more aware of you than you are of me,\u201d Mr. Crane said, turning to Mr. Davies.\n\nMr. Davies nodded. \u201cYou\u2019ve inhabited the character, the person, more than I have to,\u201d he said.\n\nThey were sharing a couch in a cavernous space called The Pub, some 30 feet below the Belasco stage. This is where the cast spends most of its limited free time (often still in costume) during the shows. The Pub has foosball and Ping-Pong tables, several couches, a makeshift bar and light-bulbs dangling off wires hanging off the ceiling.", "title": "Rivals on Xbox, Partners Onstage", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-15 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nThe Ritz-Carlton in Riyadh, the 492-room hotel converted into a posh prison for privileged Saudis swept up in what the government calls an anti-corruption campaign, appears set for a public reopening next month.\n\nThe hotel\u2019s website showed on Monday that it was accepting reservations beginning Feb. 14, with double-occupancy rooms starting at 2,439 riyals, or $650. Previous dates showed \u201cNot Available for Check-In.\u201d\n\nBookings had been blocked for more than two months.\n\nThe resumption appeared to signal that the mass arrests of Saudi princes, officials and business executives begun in November are winding down \u2014 at least to the level where the hotel can be restored to its original purpose.\n\nAlthough the Saudi authorities have said the crackdown is tied to corruption, rights groups have suggested that the detentions are a thinly disguised extortion attempt by the government to reclaim assets.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIt was not clear whether the resumption date falls on Valentine\u2019s Day intentionally or by coincidence. The Saudi authorities historically have considered the romantic holiday a sacrilegious Western concept.", "title": "Riyadh Ritz, Converted to Posh Prison by Saudis, Is Reopening to Guests", "authors": ["Rick Gladstone"]} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cPeople talk a lot about the \u201960s,\u201d Mr. Caro said, \u201cbut they don\u2019t really realize what they are.\u201d\n\nThis week he talked about the festival, the decade and the homestretch of his biography. Here are edited excerpts from the conversation.\n\nYou\u2019ve spent decades minutely chronicling American politics. How did you get involved with a festival viewing the decade through the lens of art and culture?\n\nClive Gillinson [Carnegie Hall\u2019s executive and artistic director] and I have lunch, and generally wind up talking about politics and government. One day about two years ago, he said to me, \u201cDo you have an idea for a festival? Go home and think about it.\u201d I said: \u201cI don\u2019t have to think about it. The \u201960s.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThis year brings a raft of big 50th anniversaries, like the Tet offensive, the Columbia student demonstrations, the assassinations of King and of Robert Kennedy. It\u2019s become commonplace to say we\u2019re living through a similar, if less bloody, period of tumult. What parallels do you see?\n\nWhen you read the paper every night, so much of what is under assault right now \u2014 women\u2019s rights, gay rights, voting rights, Medicare and Medicaid, a more open immigration policy \u2014 got started or reached a new intensity in the 1960s. In my book, I\u2019m writing about Johnson passing all these bills, while on the front pages every day they are trying to dismantle these bills. This is an era where there is so much thought that government is bad. I\u2019m writing about a time when people thought government was a force for good.\n\nThis is the first time Carnegie Hall has turned to a figure outside of the musical world to help plan one of its festivals. What are some of the artistic moments from the \u201960s that have stuck with you?\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nTo me, it\u2019s the protest music. I\u2019ve written about what to me is the supreme moment showing the power of music to create social change, which was when Johnson took the title of the most important anthem in his 1965 televised address to Congress a week after the Selma march, when he called for passage of a voting rights act. \u201cIt\u2019s not just Negroes,\u201d he said, \u201cbut really it\u2019s all of us, who must overcome the crippling legacy of bigotry and injustice. And we shall overcome.\u201d The president of the United States takes the key line of the anthem, and uses it to help push the bill through. That\u2019s the power of music.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThere are events relating to protest music, but also performances of more avant-garde work like George Crumb\u2019s \u201cBlack Angels,\u201d a harrowing musical response to the Vietnam War (complete with whispers, shouting and extreme percussion), to be performed by the Friction Quartet at Zankel Hall on March 24. Are there other events that leap out at you?\n\nThe Guggenheim is showing the first [comprehensive] American retrospective of Danh Vo, a Danish artist born in Vietnam whose work looks at social change there after the war, which opens Feb. 9. I\u2019m also really impressed by the New York Public Library\u2019s exhibition on the counterculture, which opens Jan. 19. They are showing manuscripts from Jack Kerouac and Allen Ginsberg, and a typescript of Bob Dylan\u2019s \u201cChanging of the Guards.\u201d They have all these antiwar posters, and material relating to the Black Panthers. They even have Timothy Leary\u2019s notes on his LSD trips.\n\nWe associate the \u201960s with the counterculture and protests against government. But that was also when the National Endowment for the Arts and the National Endowment for the Humanities, so often under attack in recent years, were established.\n\nJohnson was the moving force behind both of those agencies. Obama knows my books, and when he put the National Humanities Medal around my neck in 2010, I thought, \u201cThere are two people in this room who know how this got started.\u201d\n\nKennedy famously invited Robert Frost and Pablo Casals to the White House. Richard Nixon avidly screened movies. What were Johnson\u2019s personal tastes in the arts? Did he have any favorites that might surprise us?\n\nI\u2019m going to ask you to give me a pass on that. I haven\u2019t written that chapter yet!", "title": "Robert Caro and Carnegie Hall: Revisiting the \u201960s", "authors": ["Jennifer Schuessler"]} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "Which genres do you avoid?\n\nThe conventional novel, only readable if the writing\u2019s stunningly or quirkily great. On the other hand, sci-fi, detective novels, westerns, pornography, spy stories, horror and romance, though very conservative forms, are all more like folk and fairy tales, and so much more alluring to a writer trying to burrow inside the collective psyche.\n\nHow do you like to read? Paper or electronic? One book at a time or several simultaneously? Morning or night?\n\nPrefer paper, having been born to it, but in truth I now spend most of my afternoon reading online. Read several texts simultaneously always, one thing leading to another. Save the fun stuff (writing and book reading) for after midnight, staying at it until about 5 or 6 a.m. Every day.\n\nYou taught writing for many years. What was your favorite book to teach? Do you have a favorite book about writing?\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nDidn\u2019t think of it as teaching so much as conversations with other writers, often moved from classrooms into cafes, bars. Did teach a course from time to time called \u201cExemplary Ancient Fictions,\u201d in which we worked our way from creation myths and the Gilgamesh epic through Ovid and medieval romance, writing our own fictions, touching on the various stages of the reading along the way (dream stories, animal tales, transformations, etc.). We also read imaginative contemporary writing (Calvino, Carter, Borges, Elkin, Merwin, etc.), so we didn\u2019t always reach, before semester ended, my favorite text, \u201cLa Celestina\u201d (aka the \u201cTragicomedy of Calisto and Melibea\u201d), probably by a converso Jew named Fernando de Rojas, a beautifully complex 15th-century work that gave rise to both the Golden Age in Spanish drama and the birth of the novel. Best book in the language after Cervantes\u2019s \u201cDon Quixote.\u201d\n\n\u201cOn Being Blue\u201d and \u201cWillie Masters\u2019 Lonesome Wife,\u201d by William Gass, are disguised as novellas, but both are really books about writing, my favorites. His more traditional essay collections \u2014 \u201cFiction and the Figures of Life,\u201d for example, or \u201cHabitations of the Word,\u201d \u201cA Temple of Texts,\u201d \u201cLife Sentences,\u201d etc. \u2014 are also must-reads for young creative writers and scholars. We made a trip out to St. Louis during the fateful election season last year to see Gass (also to give a reading of my fable \u201cThe Cat in the Hat for President,\u201d to be republished in April, but that was only a sidebar), marking a friendship of more than half a century, to tell him what a fine youthful book his new collection of short fiction, \u201cEyes,\u201d was. He died, alas, too soon after.\n\nWhat book might people be surprised to find on your shelves?\n\n\u201cWatchmen,\u201d by Alan Moore, along with Joe Sacco\u2019s reports from the front line, R. Crumb\u2019s \u201cThe Book of Genesis,\u201d and a few other graphic novels. Once had similar ambitions.\n\nIf you could require the president to read one book, what would it be?\n\nHe\u2019s basically illiterate, can\u2019t handle more than 140 characters at a time, and is tied up now with \u201cMein Kampf.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nYou\u2019re organizing a literary dinner party. Which three writers, dead or alive, do you invite?\n\nLimited to three, I\u2019d bring back John Hawkes, Angela Carter and Stanley Elkin, missing them sorely as close friends and frequent dinner companions. But there were many others with whom I\u2019ve broken bread \u2014 Harry Mathews, Carlos Fuentes, Susan Sontag, Sol Yurick, Williams Gass and Gaddis, for example \u2014 and, if there were room at table, they\u2019d all be welcome, too.\n\nOf the books you\u2019ve written, which is your favorite or the most personally meaningful?\n\n\u201cGerald\u2019s Party\u201d and \u201cJohn\u2019s Wife.\u201d Both grew out of \u201cPricksongs & Descants.\u201d \u201cGerald\u2019s Party\u201d began as an effort to write a book length pricksong, piling in all the narrative ideas I had back then. Some got left out and new ones were invented, so I wrote \u201cJohn\u2019s Wife\u201d as a kind of formal sequel, titling it, like \u201cGerald\u2019s Party,\u201d with a proper noun in the genitive, plus a common noun. Again, there was a lot of residue. I like trilogies (a life is one), and wish I had the strength and time to finish a third. May start one, just the same. Already have the title, if little else.\n\nWho would you want to write your life story?\n\nSamuel Beckett. It would be funny and mercifully short.", "title": "Robert Coover: By the Book", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nUntil Robert De Niro took the stage on Tuesday to introduce Meryl Streep at the National Board of Review awards gala, the night had largely been a ho-hum affair, lacking the drama of other events during film awards season, like the Golden Globes on Sunday.\n\nBut past the evening\u2019s two-hour mark, perhaps aware that the event wasn\u2019t being televised, Mr. De Niro unleashed several profanity-laden asides directed at President Trump. He referred to the leader as a \u201cfool\u201d and an \u201cidiot\u201d (adding the same expletive each time), as well as the \u201cbaby-in-chief.\u201d\n\nPolitics were often front and center much of the night, even though anticipation was minimal because the winners, including Ms. Streep for \u201cThe Post,\u201d were announced ahead of time. Mr. De Niro\u2019s remarks were especially caustic, but criticism of Mr. Trump has become standard fare at Hollywood-centric events and several award recipients won applause when they condemned Mr. Trump\u2019s treatment of the news media.\n\nThe attention on Mr. Trump\u2019s policies was contrasted with the emphasis at the Golden Globes, where efforts to combat sexual misconduct were the focal point. While many of Tuesday\u2019s attendees wore black, missing were the Time\u2019s Up pins seen just two nights before (one was spotted on Stephen Colbert, who was introducing Greta Gerwig for best director). Barely any of the speeches discussed the topic.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. De Niro was one of the few to make a glancing reference. \u201cI am still fighting for Meryl to be able to get 79 cents of what a man would get to play Katharine Graham,\u201d Mr. De Niro said. \u201cIt\u2019s shameful, I know. The good news is that I think we\u2019re at a watershed moment and it\u2019s about time.\u201d", "title": "Robert De Niro\u2019s Anti-Trump Screed and Meryl Streep\u2019s Ode to Men", "authors": ["Sopan Deb", "The Carpetbagger"]} {"date": "2018-01-02 00:00:00", "text": "He had cheerfully forsaken a promising solo career for a life in chamber music and \u2014 because that life entails as much \u2014 diplomacy. (A string quartet is nothing short of a quadrilateral marriage in which the spouses rarely see eye to eye on interpretive matters.)\n\nIt was a decidedly unexpected calling for a boy who had wanted only to be a forest ranger.\n\nRobert Nathaniel Mann was born in Portland, Ore., on July 19, 1920, into what he later described as a \u201cvery poor\u201d family. Both of his parents were immigrants: His father, Charles, a tailor, had come from England; his mother, Anna Schnitzer, from Poland.\n\n\u201cMy father knew nothing about music, but he used sense in going to the concertmaster of the Portland Symphony for advice,\u201d Mr. Mann told The Toronto Star in 1995. \u201cIt was the greatest break of my life. He told my father, \u2018Your son is no wunderkind, but if he practices hard, he can make a living.\u2019 \u201d\n\nWhen he was 9, Robert began lessons, at $1.50 each, with a teacher he recalled as an alcoholic. Two years later, the teacher was shot and killed \u2014 an actuarially unorthodox end for a classical musician.\n\nRobert was 13 before another teacher was found, but the new teacher proved transformative.\n\n\u201cUp to then, I was going to be a forest ranger, hopefully in a national park,\u201d Mr. Mann, recalling a boyhood lesson, said in \u201cSpeak the Music: Robert Mann and the Mysteries of Chamber Music,\u201d a 2013 documentary. \u201cBut that day, I thought, \u2018You know, music is very interesting.\u2019 \u201d\n\nAt 18, the young Mr. Mann took up a scholarship at the Institute of Musical Art, a forerunner of the Juilliard School, in New York. The next year, he transferred to the Juilliard Graduate School (likewise a forebear of today\u2019s Juilliard School). There, he studied composition with Stefan Wolpe and violin with \u00c9douard Dethier, a passionate lover of chamber music.\n\nIn 1941, Mr. Mann won the violin competition of the Naumburg Foundation, which carried as its prize a debut recital at Town Hall in New York. As things fell out, the recital could scarcely have been booked for a more inopportune date: Dec. 9, 1941, two days after the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor.", "title": "Robert Mann, a Founder of the Juilliard Quartet, Dies at 97", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "(Want to get this briefing by email? Here\u2019s the sign-up.)\n\nGood morning.\n\n\n\nHere\u2019s what you need to know:\n\nTrump ordered Mueller fired\n\n\u2022 President Trump demanded last June that Robert Mueller, the special counsel overseeing the Russia investigation, be dismissed, but backed down after the White House counsel threatened to resign.\n\nThe president argued that Mr. Mueller had multiple conflicts of interest that disqualified him from overseeing the inquiry into election meddling.\n\nBut the White House\u2019s top lawyer, Donald McGahn, told senior officials that firing Mr. Mueller would be catastrophic to Mr. Trump\u2019s presidency. The president later relented.", "title": "Robert Mueller, Davos, South Korea: Your Friday Briefing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-29 00:00:00", "text": "Robert Parry, a tenacious investigative reporter and author who exposed details of the Reagan administration\u2019s secret support for Nicaraguan rebels in the 1980s, died on Saturday in Arlington, Va. He was 68.\n\nThe cause was pancreatic cancer, said his wife, Diane Duston.\n\nMr. Parry won the George Polk Award for national reporting in 1984 for his disclosures that the Central Intelligence Agency had provided an assassination manual to the so-called contras, the right-wing insurgents who were seeking to topple the socialist government in Nicaragua. Mr. Parry was part of an Associated Press investigative team based in Washington when he broke the story.\n\nFor that reporting, he was also named a finalist for the 1985 Pulitzer Prize for national reporting.\n\nIn 1985, Mr. Parry broke news of the involvement of Lt. Col. Oliver L. North, a deputy director of the National Security Council, in a covert operation to support the contras with proceeds from clandestine arms sales to Iran. Congress had banned such support. The weapons had been sold to Iran to speed the release of American hostages in Lebanon.\n\nIn 2015, the Nieman Foundation for Journalism at Harvard awarded Mr. Parry the I. F. Stone Medal for Journalistic Independence. Last year, he received the Martha Gellhorn Prize for Journalism, named for a 20th-century war correspondent and presented by a trust set up in her name.", "title": "Robert Parry, Investigative Reporter in Washington, Dies at 68", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "When the orchestra\u2019s management, struggling with deficits, locked its players out in 2014, for the second time in two years, Mr. Spano took the rare step for a music director of speaking publicly on behalf of the musicians, more than 40 percent of whom had joined the orchestra during his tenure.\n\nHe lamented that the players had \u201cbeen asked to leave the building,\u201d leaving Atlanta \u201cwith a deafening silence.\u201d When the lockout ended, he worked with the orchestra\u2019s board to raise more than $27 million to restore 11 positions.\n\n\u201cI think that\u2019s a great sign of recovery,\u201d Mr. Spano said in the interview, noting that there was more work to be done. \u201cThere\u2019s a lot of room for hope.\u201d\n\nMr. Spano kept the orchestra\u2019s profile high with tours, including to Carnegie Hall, and recordings. During his penultimate season, in 2019-20, the orchestra will celebrate its 75th anniversary with a series of special projects and events.\n\nHe said that he hoped to be able to devote more time to composing and to conducting opera, and that he plans to continue as the music director of the Aspen Music Festival and School, a prestigious summer academy. Mr. Spano added that he had been particularly gratified by the way Atlanta audiences had embraced new music \u2014 and said that he had gone out of his way to play more than just one piece by the living composers he showcased; to play those pieces more than once; to record them; to play them on tours; and to play them at youth concerts.", "title": "Robert Spano Will Leave the Atlanta Symphony After 20 Years", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-31 00:00:00", "text": "What are the most important things that humans can do now in order to not destroy the planet? We have to accept responsibility for our role. I am trying to keep track of what my carbon impact is this year \u2014 America produces about 20 metric tons per person a year. We also have to encourage all sorts of people to go into science and engineering, because some of the solutions will involve new technologies.\n\nYour stance seems to run counter to the attitude that the planet is beyond help and there\u2019s not much more we can do. Do you think you\u2019re more optimistic than most? Being pessimistic isn\u2019t going to get us there. We have to take action. I\u2019ve been helping review the National Climate Assessment Report, which provides an in-depth look at how climate change affects the country, and it\u2019s fascinating to see how different the impact is in different regions. People are starting to organize at the level at which they live, and that\u2019s probably what gives me hope. New York and California are significant economies and have shown that their governments can act.\n\nDo you think conditions have improved for women in STEM fields since you entered the arena? Things have gotten better. The National Science Foundation has a program called Advance, where instead of just trying to hire individual women, you actually try to change the culture, like instead of dropping individual salmon in the stream, we\u2019re actually trying to change ecosystems so that more salmon will survive. I did that for five years, and we managed to go from having both the teaching and research faculty at Lamont go from having single-digit numbers of women to having double digits. We still don\u2019t see women in as many leadership positions as I\u2019d like, and the harassment issue is probably one of the reasons we lose so many women in the pipeline in particular. Considering the cultural conversation, this is our chance to see if we can address those problems within science and to sit down and say: \u201cWhat have we let go by? What have we not spoken up about? And how can we make it so we can understand what our code of conduct is going to be?\u201d\n\nDo you think you\u2019re a role model for young women entering the field? Part of it is making sure people are connected sufficiently with their planet, to want to make sure it\u2019s still here as a home for us. If we\u2019re going to understand how our planet really works, we need everybody on deck to understand how to respond to it. The planet\u2019s going to survive \u2014 the question is, will we?", "title": "Robin Bell Doesn\u2019t Think Science Should Be Political", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "Autor and his co-authors found that\n\nTrade exposure catalyzed strong movements towards conservative Republicans between 2002 and 2010 in counties with majority non-Hispanic white populations.\n\nThe gains made by hard-right Republicans came at the expense of moderate Republican and Democratic incumbents.\n\nEven more significant, Autor determined that though generally speaking trade shocks did not \u201cfavor conservative politicians,\u201d shocks \u201cthat disproportionately affect white males\u201d did.\n\nThe authors provide more detail, explaining that the\n\nrightward shift is driven by trade shocks to industries that have traditionally employed white men in relatively large numbers, and is largely unrelated to shocks to other industries.\n\nAutor and his co-authors cite research showing that\n\nvoters choose to supply fewer public goods when a significant fraction of tax revenues collected from one ethnic group is used to provide public goods shared with other ethnic groups\n\nand that\n\nvoters in an in-group object to their tax contributions being used to support individuals in out-groups.\n\nThat translates to: white voters, especially white men, oppose paying taxes for programs that primarily provide services to others. In practice, the authors suggest, trade shocks\n\ncatalyze anti-redistributionist sentiment (seen in the election of conservative Republicans) in majority white non-Hispanic locations where taxpayers may perceive themselves as transfer-payment donors.\n\nThis white male effect was critical to the link connecting, as Autor and his co-authors write,\n\neconomic adversity to in-group/out-group identification, as motivated by group-based resource competition or opportunistic use of political extremism.\n\nTheir analysis resonates, they suggest,\n\nwith the themes of recent literature on the political economy of right-wing populism, in which economic shocks to dominant population groups engender a political response that sharpens group identities and enhances support for conservative politicians. This pattern is evident in our finding that the impact of trade shocks on political polarization appears largely attributable to increases in foreign competition facing manufacturing industries that are intensive in the employment of non-Hispanic white males.\n\nAcemoglu, Autor and their colleagues provide a synthesis between the economic and the sociocultural explanations of the rise of the populist right. In doing so, they provide a corrective to the recent tendency in segments of the liberal media to downplay economic factors and to focus instead on racial resentment and cultural dislocation as the primary forces motivating Trump voters.\n\nI myself have written that\n\nRepublican voters have a strong sense of white identity, they harbor high levels of racial resentment and they sometimes exhibit authoritarian leanings.\n\nThe point here is that the two generalized explanatory realms \u2014 the one focused on race and the other on economic shock \u2014 overlap. It is not either/or but both that gave us President Trump.\n\nStill, explanations tend to become monocausal.\n\nTake, for example, the Dec. 15, 2017 headline at the Vox website: \u201cThe past year of research has made it very clear: Trump won because of racial resentment.\u201d According to German Lopez, the article\u2019s author, \u201cemployment and income were not significantly related to that sense of white vulnerability.\u201d What was? \u201cRacial resentment.\u201d\n\nA May 9, 2017 story in The Atlantic asserted that\n\nthat fear of societal change, not economic pressure, motivated votes for the president among non-salaried workers without college degrees.\n\nThose stories were by no means alone. Salon: \u201cLiberals were right: Racism played a larger role in Trump\u2019s win than income and authoritarianism\u201d; The Nation: \u201cEconomic Anxiety Didn\u2019t Make People Vote Trump, Racism Did.\u201d", "title": "Opinion | Robots Can\u2019t Vote, but They Helped Elect Trump", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-01 00:00:00", "text": "If you love space and astronomy, 2018 will be an exciting year. NASA has announced windows of time for sending spacecraft to Mars and the sun. Japanese and American probes already in space are set to enter orbit around two near-Earth asteroids. And a variety of eclipses and meteor showers offer ample opportunities for skygazing.\n\nWe\u2019ve put dates for these events and more on The Times\u2019s Astronomy and Space Calendar. But while some dates are certain or proximate, there\u2019s a lot to be unsure about down here on Earth.\n\nSometimes spacecraft aren\u2019t ready on time for launch. Or their launches get scrubbed because of weather. Some terrestrial space agencies don\u2019t always give much notice when they blast off.\n\nWhile we aren\u2019t ready to say some space launches will happen on a particular date, these are some of the events we\u2019re watching out for, and we\u2019ll update the calendar when we know more.", "title": "Rocket Launches and Trips to the Moon We\u2019re Looking Forward To in 2018", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-29 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Frelinghuysen was facing a challenge from Mikie Sherrill, a former Navy pilot and federal prosecutor, who has the backing of four key Democratic county chairs. And a new super PAC, NJ 11th For Change, was established to help organize a grass-roots effort to unseat Mr. Frelinghuysen.\n\nThe group has been relentless in their efforts, holding regular protests outside Mr. Frelinghuysen\u2019s offices and flooding social media with critical messages. And Mr. Frelinghuysen had not been acting like a candidate girding for what was shaping up to be the battle of his political career. He had not been aggressively fund-raising and he has avoided holding town hall meetings.\n\nStill, Mr. Frelinghuysen would have made a formidable candidate \u2014 he has decades of name-recognition and nearly $1 million in the bank. Now, whoever ends up being the Republican candidate will be starting from scratch financially even as Democrats in the district have raised hundreds of thousands of dollars.\n\nMs. Sherrill announced she began 2018 with more than $820,000 in cash-on-hand, hours after Mr. Frelinghuysen said he would retire. She is one of 18 candidates across the country who the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee has selected to support as part of its \u201cRed to Blue\u201d initiative.\n\nThough Mr. Frelinghuysen had shown signs that he might not run, his decision still caught party leaders by surprise and they quickly got to work trying to identify potential replacements.\n\nFor New Jersey, Mr. Frelinghuysen\u2019s retirement means the loss of someone who could direct resources to the state. Mr. Frelinghuysen has been a strong advocate for one of the region\u2019s most important infrastructure projects, a new rail tunnel under the Hudson River. He had also been instrumental in steering about $900 million to replace the Portal Bridge near Newark, a key piece of the Northeast Corridor that is prone to malfunctions.\n\nMr. Frelinghuysen has often been caught between the direction of the party and the desires of his home state. He voted against the federal tax law, citing the harm it would inflict on many of his constituents by limiting the deductibility of state income taxes and property taxes. His vote reportedly angered Republican leadership, and Paul D. Ryan, the House speaker, threatened to strip Mr. Frelinghuysen of his leadership role.", "title": "Rodney Frelinghuysen, Powerful House Republican, Announces He Will Not Seek Re-Election", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-21 00:00:00", "text": "So how did one decision 45 years ago become synonymous with abortion and nothing else? In part, other privacy fights fizzled when the coalitions backing new rights collapsed. Feminists and libertarians clashed about the line between sexual coercion and sexual privacy. Those who hoped to expand data privacy disagreed about when the government had a good enough reason to collect personal data.\n\nAbortion foes and Republican politicians consciously tried to redefine Roe, equating the decision with abortion and judicial activism. Ronald Reagan had to assure social conservatives that he would pick federal judges who opposed abortion, but he also consistently promised to select nominees based on their accomplishments and judicial philosophy. Labeling Roe an activist decision helped Reagan and other Republicans strike this balance.\n\nAbortion opponents initially did not take much interest in arguments about judicial activism, seeing them as a distraction from the fight for an amendment that would ban all abortions. But by the 1980s, it was obvious that a fetal rights amendment would not pass soon. Delegitimizing Roe suddenly seemed an important step toward the movement\u2019s new goal of overruling the 1973 decision.\n\nOn Roe\u2019s 45th anniversary, we should stop to think about where the right to privacy stands today. The picture does not seem very rosy. Since the new year, there have been fresh concerns about data breaches and the misuse of digital information by giants like Facebook and Google. Privacy and conscience have taken center stage as the Supreme Court considers whether a Christian baker can refuse to serve a same-sex couple. It is easy to believe that the right to privacy is ineffective, more likely to shore up a dissatisfying status quo.\n\nBut part of Roe\u2019s legacy is the many ways conservatives and liberals once reimagined the right to privacy. Social movements hardly felt constrained by what the Supreme Court had written.\n\nSome pointed to privacy not just in asking for freedom from the government but also in demanding financial support from the state. Others asked not just to be left alone behind closed doors but also to get respect for relationships in public. People tried to use the right to privacy to transform attitudes about sexuality, death and the collection of digital data.\n\nAmericans have rethought the right to privacy before. There is no reason we couldn\u2019t do it again.", "title": "Opinion | Roe v. Wade Was About More Than Abortion", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-28 00:00:00", "text": "Though seeded No. 2 behind Rafael Nadal, Federer was the clear favorite coming into this year\u2019s tournament based on his hardcourt results in 2017 and the fragile physical state of his traditional archrivals. Still, he resisted that label.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t think a 36-year-old should be a favorite of a tournament,\u201d Federer said before the Open began.\n\nBut he proved the pundits correct, defending the title he won much more unexpectedly last year, when he was returning from a six-month break to heal a lingering knee problem.\n\nThat surprise victory, earned after a series of marathon matches, meant so much to him in part because he was playing free of big expectations for a change.\n\nBut Sunday night\u2019s five-set win over the sixth-seeded Cilic resonated deeply, too.\n\nFederer broke down in tears \u2014 not for the first time \u2014 during the trophy ceremony in Rod Laver Arena as Laver himself was taking pictures with his phone from the front row.\n\n\u201cThe fairy tale continues, for us, for me,\u201d Federer said, looking toward his team and his family in the players\u2019 box.\n\n\u201cAfter the great year I had last year,\u201d he said, hesitating and fighting to keep his composure, \u201cit\u2019s incredible.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHe continued to struggle, even after he was done speaking as the crowd roared while he and Cilic posed for pictures.\n\nThis has been one of the finest late-career runs in any sport. And though Federer did not lose a set on his way to Sunday\u2019s final, Cilic pushed him to a fifth with his power baseline game and with Federer\u2019s nerves and serves betraying him in patches. He put only 36 percent of his first serves in play in the fourth set.\n\nPhoto\n\nWhat had started as a rout, with Federer winning the first set in just 24 minutes, became much more complex, in part because of Federer\u2019s anxiety and in part because Cilic adjusted to the indoor conditions after playing and practicing outdoors all tournament.\n\nBut Cilic was ultimately too inconsistent and not quite opportunistic enough while Federer, using his backhand chip to fine effect, was often able to put the tall Croatian in body positions and zones of the court where he was forced to be subtle instead of forceful.\n\nStill, it was close, and with the match on the line, Federer fought off two break points on his serve in the first game of the fifth set and then broke Cilic in the next game. He challenged a second serve at 30-30 that turned out to be a double fault, then hit a deep return on the next point that Cilic failed to handle.\n\nFederer held serve to go up by 3-0 in the next tense game and then accelerated to the finish line, one he has crossed more than any man at the major championships that define careers, even more so now than in Rosewall and Laver\u2019s era.\n\nNeither Rosewall nor Laver played a Grand Slam final under a closed roof, and though it was not raining on Sunday, temperatures in Melbourne surged again, hitting 103 degrees Fahrenheit (39 degrees Celsius) in the late afternoon.\n\nThough the final was to begin at 7:30 p.m., when the weather was slightly cooler, the organizers determined one hour before the match that the combination of high temperatures and humidity called for them to put in effect their extreme-heat policy and play the final indoors.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI was surprised to hear they had the heat rule in place for a night match,\u201d Federer said. \u201cI never heard that before. When I arrived to the courts, I was totally ready to play outdoors.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nBoth players said they were not consulted about the decision but were informed in advance. Federer practiced indoors, and Cilic chose to stick with practicing outdoors and then paid the price.\n\n\u201cWith the roof closed, it was way, way cooler than I expected,\u201d Cilic said. \u201cThat was very, very difficult, especially for the final, to be in that kind of situation.\u201d\n\nHe questioned the decision afterward but said he did not argue about it. Some former players, including the Australian star Pat Cash, cried foul, but Tennis Australia officials defended the move. Despite soaring temperatures for a few days during the first week, officials said, Sunday night was the first time all tournament that the threshold on their heat and humidity index had been reached.\n\nThe grueling, three-set women\u2019s final on Saturday night, in which Caroline Wozniacki defeated Simona Halep, was played on a slightly cooler, less humid evening with the roof open. ESPN reported that after the match was over, Halep spent several hours in the hospital being treated for dehydration.\n\nDarren Cahill, Halep\u2019s coach, said on Monday that she was \u201cO.K., and on her way home\u201d to Romania.\n\nTennis Australia officials said Halep\u2019s health problems had not factored into the decision to close the roof on Sunday.\n\nPhoto\n\nFederer trains regularly in the heat in Dubai, but playing conditions would certainly have been slower with the roof open.\n\nHis indoor record is now 273-65; Cilic\u2019s is 109-55. But Federer was still edgy as the 3-hour-3-minute match played out.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI think that\u2019s why I was so bloody emotional again at the end, because I was thinking about the outcome all day,\u201d he said. \u201cDuring the first set. During the second. During the third. During the fourth. \u2018How would I feel if I lost? How would I feel if I won?\u2019 And it just wouldn\u2019t stop, and I think that\u2019s why this match was particularly difficult today.\n\n\u201cIt reminded me a little bit of 2006, when I really got to the finals in a great way and played that match against Marcos Baghdatis that was also nerve-racking. I was the big favorite going in, and in the end you win and you are so relieved.\u201d\n\nFederer cried after beating Baghdatis in the final and receiving the trophy from Laver. He choked up again after being beaten by Nadal in the 2009 final, saying, \u201cGod, it\u2019s killing me.\u201d He eventually backed away from the microphone and was consoled by Nadal.\n\nBut Federer has not needed much consolation of late as he glides on at an age by which nearly all of the great men\u2019s players have moved on. He said it helped that his recurring back problems did not affect him here after troubling him post-Wimbledon last season.\n\n\u201cI was a bit worried at the end of the year,\u201d he said. \u201cI was relieved that after vacation, it was better. I think that\u2019s why I was able to win here.\u201d\n\nFederer said that, unusually, he did not take any anti-inflammatory pills during the tournament. \u201cI know guys my age who took one every day,\u201d he said.\n\nFederer tied Novak Djokovic and Roy Emerson for the most Australian men\u2019s singles titles. He is 9-1 against Cilic, whom he defeated in last year\u2019s Wimbledon final in straight sets.\n\nDuring that match, Cilic, suffering from deep foot blisters of his own, cried in frustration during a changeover at his inability to compete at full strength.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHe and Federer have grown closer since that match. In September, they were part of the winning European team in the inaugural Laver Cup, an event created by Federer and his management company. In late November, they ended up vacationing on the same island in the Maldives, where they socialized and even practiced together twice.\n\n\u201cWe were both looking for a hitting partner, and it happened that we were there,\u201d Federer said. \u201cIt was the weirdest thing.\u201d\n\nOn Sunday, they exchanged tennis blows in a much more public place. And as has been the case so often in the last 15 years, the man who ended up as the champion was Federer, somehow still hungry for more and still moved when it comes.\n\n\u201cI like to care,\u201d he said. \u201cIt\u2019s good I can care about these matches.\u201d", "title": "Roger Federer Wins the Australian Open for His 20th Grand Slam Title", "authors": ["Christopher Clarey"]} {"date": "2018-01-07 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThousands of Rohingya are still fleeing to escape from endless inhumane persecutions of the Burmese terrorist army,\u201d Mr. Atta Ullah said.\n\nTwo security officers and a driver were injured in the ambush on Friday, according to a post on the Facebook page of Senior Gnl. Min Aung Hlaing, Myanmar\u2019s military chief. Ten members of the Arakan Rohingya Salvation Army, or ARSA, took part in the attack, the post said.\n\nThe rebel group, which is known locally as Harakah al-Yaqin, or the Faith Movement, is a small, underequipped group that has struggled to mount significant military operations. But it has claimed responsibility for a few deadly attacks on Myanmar\u2019s security forces, including in August.\n\nRichard Horsey, an independent analyst in Yangon, the economic capital Myanmar, said that while the group is small and poorly armed, its actions provoke major responses from the government.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s uncertain whether they have the capacity to sustain an insurgency, but even occasional small attacks like this will have a big political impact in Myanmar,\u201d he said.\n\nSmall operations by the group against security forces in August prompted brutal retaliation from government forces, which in turn contributed to the mass exodus of Rohingya from Rakhine.\n\nThe international aid group Doctors Without Borders estimated last month that at least 6,700 Rohingya, including 730 young children, had met with violent deaths in the month after the military campaign began in August.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nGeneral Min Aung Hlaing, the country\u2019s most powerful figure, has denied that the army committed atrocities against the Rohingya. In November, the military released the results of an internal inquiry that cleared all soldiers in Rakhine of any misconduct. Not a single innocent civilian had been raped or killed by the security forces, the report said.\n\nThe government has refused to grant access to the region to independent observers including United Nations officials, aid groups, representatives of foreign governments and journalists.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe government of Myanmar, also known as Burma, has denied most Rohingya citizenship and considers them to be \u201cillegal immigrants\u201d from Bangladesh, factors that complicate their status and their ability to be recognized as refugees or to apply for asylum.\n\nU Zaw Htay, a former army major who serves as a spokesman for Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, Myanmar\u2019s top civilian leader, said the ambush on Friday had been intended to derail the repatriation of Rohingya under an agreement between Myanmar and Bangladesh.\n\n\u201cWe will start the repatriation process on Jan. 23,\u201d he said. \u201cThat\u2019s why ARSA carried out a terrorist attack on Jan. 5, just to delay the repatriation process.\u201d\n\nU Win Myat Aye, the minister of social welfare and resettlement, said that refugees would have the choice of living at a temporary center while their homes are being rebuilt, or of returning to their villages to help rebuild the housing themselves, with the government bearing the construction costs.\n\nThe relocation center is expected to accommodate up to 30,000 people in tents from Belgium and China, he said.\n\n\u201cAfter the construction of their original place is done, they can live in their own place and they can work freely as before,\u201d he said.\n\nDespite such assurances, it is unclear how many Rohingya will will continue our legitimate struggles in hand-in-hand cooperation with the civilized international community until all our demands are fulfilled,\u201d Mr. Atta Ullah said. \u201cRohingya people must Romania\u2019s economy was one of the fastest growing in Europe last year, but the country is still one of the poorest in the European Union.\n\n\u201cThe goal of my mandate is for Romania in 2020 to be in the top half of the E.U.\u2019s strongest economies so that young people no longer leave from Romania, and those that have left want to return,\u201d she told lawmakers.\n\n\u201cMaybe she is a very good person, but we don\u2019t know anything about her,\u201d said Cristian Pirvulescu, the dean of the political science department at the National University of Political Studies and Public Administration in Bucharest. \u201cShe hasn\u2019t had any important political experience until now \u2014 she was just a member of a small city council and then after that a member of the European Parliament.\u201d\n\nProfessor Pirvulescu said there was a simple explanation for why she had become prime minister: \u201cAfter difficult experiences with the two previous governments, Liviu Dragnea wants a government he can be absolutely sure of.\u201d\n\nOthers also questioned Ms. Dancila\u2019s experience.\n\n\u201cShe\u2019s not been among the prominent M.E.P.s, and wasn\u2019t very visible in Brussels. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMs. Dancila was nominated after her predecessor, Mihai Tudose, resigned on Jan. 15 after losing the support of his Social Democrat colleagues, in particular Mr. Dragnea. His appointment came after the resignation of Sorin Grindeanu last June, after he lost a no-confidence vote brought about by his own party.\n\nBoth were felt not to have given their full backing to efforts to overhaul the justice system, a party priority, and to have sought more autonomy from party leaders like Mr. Dragnea.\n\nAfter a year of on-again, off-again protests over attempts to weaken anticorruption efforts, the composition of the new government dampened hopes that it would offer a different approach to leadership.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSeveral cabinet members, including the new business minister, Radu Oprea, have faced allegations of corruption. The new minister for European funds, Rovana Plumb, was forced to resign from the same post late last year over allegations related to land transfers.\n\nProfessor Pirvulescu said that the main focus of the new government in the short term was likely to be on completing highly disputed changes to the judiciary, an effort that has been met with strong criticism from the country\u2019s allies, Romania is without a prime minister, after the governing Social Democrat Party pulled its support for the incumbent, forcing his resignation.\n\nThe prime minister, Mihai Tudose, announced on Monday evening that he would step down after party leaders failed to resolve a dispute between him and the party\u2019s powerful leader, Liviu Dragnea, who is unable to serve as prime minister himself because of a 2016 conviction for electoral fraud.\n\nTensions had flared in recent weeks after Mr. Tudose tried to remove a close ally of Mr. Dragnea\u2019s from her role as interior minister, after accusing her of lying to him.\n\nThe Social Democrats won a strong mandate in Romania\u2019s last parliamentary elections, held in December 2016. But since then the country has been rocked by the largest protests in a quarter of a century, when hundreds of thousands of people took to the streets last February to oppose government measures that would have relaxed penalties for official corruption. The government backed down, but it has continued to push for similar measures, drawing protesters back into the streets, albeit in smaller numbers.", "title": "Romanian Prime Minister Is Forced Out, the Second in Seven Months", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nROME \u2014 Rome\u2019s much-derided Christmas tree, scornfully nicknamed Spelacchio, or mangy, for its forlorn appearance, was removed from the central Piazza Venezia on Thursday evening.\n\nBut the 72-foot Norway spruce, which began losing its needles immediately after it was installed in early December and then became a social media sensation, is not bound for a mulch heap.\n\nInstead, the tree is going to be repurposed \u2014 cut up and its lumber used to build a hut in a city park where mothers can nurse their children.\n\nA piece of the trunk will also be used for a not-yet-determined \u201cartistic enterprise,\u201d city officials said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe tree\u2019s defoliation initially prompted ridicule and disdain.\n\nBut after that first wave of insults, popular opinion took a turn, and Romans began leaving messages of support \u2014 thousands of them \u2014 on the tree\u2019s branches. #Jesuissplelacchio became a trending term.", "title": "Rome\u2019s Famous Christmas Tree to Be Reborn as a Baby Nursing Station", "authors": ["Elisabetta Povoledo"]} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "HBO has signed Ronan Farrow to a three-year deal to develop and become the face of a new investigative series, the network announced on Thursday. The deal is set to begin later this year.\n\nMr. Farrow\u2019s reporting in The New Yorker on Harvey Weinstein has helped spur a national discussion on sexual harassment and misconduct in the workplace. His first Weinstein story was published in October, boosting his profile and making him something of a hot property in TV news circles, even though his last stint as a television journalist did not have a happy ending.\n\nA former NBC News correspondent, Mr. Farrow began work on his Weinstein story there but was told to stop reporting the story for the network over the summer. Mr. Farrow continued anyway, and then published the first article just over two months later with The New Yorker, after his contract with NBC expired.\n\nMr. Farrow suggested that NBC had sought to kill the story, and said the expos\u00e9 should have been made \u201cpublic earlier.\u201d NBC countered that the reporting had not been ready to be made public.", "title": "Ronan Farrow to Develop an Investigative Series for HBO", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cWhat\u2019s so heartening about these elections is that there\u2019s a good percentage of Zimbabwean whites who\u2019ve said, \u2018Damn it, let\u2019s get involved,\u2019 and we\u2019ve suffered together with the blacks and feared together with them,\u201d Mr. Bennett told the journalist Peter Godwin in June 2000, the month he was elected to Parliament. \u201cWe\u2019ve made a stand and shown that we\u2019re prepared to sacrifice ourselves for this country. And isn\u2019t that what a patriot is after all? It\u2019s the first time in my life I\u2019ve felt really Zimbabwean.\u201d\n\nIn 2003, the Charleswood Estate in Chimanimani, owned by Mr. Bennett and his family, was invaded. Mr. Bennett condemned the seizure as illegal. In a raucous exchange in Parliament the following year, the country\u2019s justice minister, Patrick Chinamasa, told Mr. Bennett that his ancestors had been \u201cthieves and murderers.\u201d A scuffle broke out and Mr. Bennett shoved Mr. Chinamasa to the ground; he was imprisoned for a year for assault.\n\nGranted early release for good behavior, Mr. Bennett complained of prison abuses, saying that he had been issued a uniform covered in excrement and lice, and made to stand naked in front of guards.\n\nBy then, Mr. Bennett had become a top deputy of Mr. Tsvangirai, and he was named the party\u2019s general treasurer. Fearing rearrest, he fled to South Africa in 2006 and was eventually granted asylum there. But he agreed to return in 2008, when Mr. Tsvangirai defeated Mr. Mugabe in the first round of a presidential election.\n\nMr. Mugabe\u2019s supporters complained that white farmers were returning \u201cin droves\u201d to reclaim their land under Mr. Tsvangirai, a charge that Mr. Bennett called \u201cabsolute nonsense.\u201d But amid rising violence, Mr. Tsvangirai withdrew from the runoff, following a fierce internal debate.\n\n\u201cPulling out of the elections now would be giving in to a violent dictator who is prepared to wage war on his own people to stay in power,\u201d Mr. Bennett, who was acting as the party\u2019s spokesman, said at the time.\n\nMr. Bennett was named deputy agriculture minister under a power-sharing government led by Mr. Mugabe and Mr. Tsvangirai as prime minister. But on his return to Zimbabwe in February 2009, he was promptly arrested and charged with treason, ostensibly in connection with a cache of arms found at his home in 2006. Mr. Tsvangirai denounced the arrest as politically motivated and warned that military intelligence officials \u2014 who remained loyal to Mr. Mugabe \u2014 had plotted to harm Mr. Bennett.\n\nThe government\u2019s case was based mostly on testimony from a witness, Peter Michael Hitschman, who, it later emerged, had been tortured \u2014 his buttocks were burned with cigarettes \u2014 and told that his wife and son would be harmed if he did not implicate Mr. Bennett. The trial began in October 2009. In March 2010, a judge ruled that Mr. Hitschman\u2019s testimony had been coerced. That May, Mr. Bennett was acquitted.", "title": "Roy Bennett, White Zimbabwean With Black Political Base, Dies in U.S. Helicopter Crash", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nNEW PORT RICHEY, Fla. \u2014 An autopsy report says that the retired baseball pitcher Roy Halladay had evidence of an amphetamine, morphine and an insomnia drug in his system when he died in a small plane crash in Florida last year.\n\nThe Tampa Bay Times reported that an autopsy released on Friday showed that Halladay, a two-time Cy Young Award winner for the Toronto Blue Jays and the Philadelphia Phillies, died from blunt force trauma \u2014 with drowning as a contributing factor \u2014 when he crashed his personal plane into the Gulf of Mexico near here on Nov. 7.\n\nThe National Transportation Safety Board has not identified a cause of the crash. Bailey"]} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nA Los Angeles woman has accused the music mogul Russell Simmons of sexual battery and rape in a civil lawsuit filed against him Wednesday in federal court there.\n\nThe lawsuit asks for $5 million in damages from Mr. Simmons, the multimillionaire Def Jam Recordings co-founder who, in the last two months, has been accused of sexual misconduct, assault or rape by at least 10 other women, and has been the focus of a police investigation.\n\nMr. Simmons has strenuously denied any misconduct. In a statement Wednesday, he called the lawsuit allegations \u201cabsolutely untrue.\u201d He added: \u201cI look forward to having my day in court \u2014 where, unlike the court of public opinion, I will have the ability to make use of fair processes that ensure that justice will be done and that the full truth will be known.\u201d\n\nIn the complaint filed in U.S. District Court in Los Angeles, Jennifer Jarosik, 37, said she first met Mr. Simmons, 60, in New York in 2006, and that they became friends based on a mutual interest in meditation, yoga and veganism. Ms. Jarosik was interested in interviewing Mr. Simmons for a documentary she was making; Mr. Simmons agreed and said he would help her produce and finance the film, which they began working on, the complaint says. Ms. Jarosik said that, in 2016, she went to Mr. Simmons\u2019s home in Los Angeles, at his invitation, and he asked her to have sex. She said no. He became aggressive, the complaint alleges, and pushed her onto the bed; when she tried to push back, he knocked her to the floor and raped her, she says.\n\nShe described the incident to the director and editor of her film at the time, the complaint says. It interrupted her work and led her to feel humiliation, fear and depression, for which she needed medication, the complaint says, in the request for damages.\n\nPerry C. Wander, a lawyer for Ms. Jarosik, said in a telephone interview Thursday that Ms. Jarosik also alleges that Mr. Simmons assaulted her in his home in New York in 2011, and that she intends to file a criminal complaint with the New York Police Department, which has been investigating several sexual misconduct complaints by other women against Mr. Simmons, as well as the Los Angeles police.\n\nMr. Wander said that, until other women began describing their experiences with Mr. Simmons, Ms. Jarosik felt guilty about her encounters. \u201cShe was blaming herself,\u201d he said.", "title": "Russell Simmons Sued Over Rape Accusation", "authors": ["Melena Ryzik"]} {"date": "2018-01-29 00:00:00", "text": "The Paralympic decision stands somewhat in contrast to the International Olympic Committee\u2019s ruling on Russia\u2019s participation in the 2018 Winter Games next month in Pyeongchang, South Korea.\n\nUnlike their Olympic counterparts, Paralympic officials had not previously allowed Russian athletes to bypass the ban and compete as individuals outside of qualifying events this fall. Olympic officials, who nominally banned Russia last month, have given 169 Russian athletes special clearance to compete when the Olympics begin on Feb. 9. The Paralympics, the global showcase for disabled athletes, will follow on March 9.\n\nMr. Parsons said Monday that Paralympic officials would allow up to 35 Russian athletes who met \u201cstrict conditions,\u201d including a rigorous history of drug testing, to compete in Pyeongchang as neutral athletes in a handful of sports, including Alpine skiing, biathlon and wheelchair skiing. That number that is roughly half the size of the team Russia typically sends.\n\n\u201cDifferent from the Rio period when we couldn\u2019t guarantee which athletes were clean and which athletes were not,\u201d Mr. Parsons said, referring to the 2016 Games, where no Russian Paralympian competed, \u201cnow we can have a very good understanding of which athletes were clean and which athletes are not.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nEach Russian Paralympian who is approved to compete, he said, will be identified in competition as a \u201cNeutral Paralympic Athlete.\u201d Olympic officials have approved individual Russian athletes to be identified by their nationality, as \u201cOlympic athlete from Russia.\u201d\n\nAsked by a Russian journalist why Paralympic officials were not similarly allowing Russian athletes to show their national pride, Paralympic officials stressed that there were consequences, given that Russia remained suspended. \u201cWe cannot use the name Russia in the title of team,\u201d Craig Spence, spokesman for the International Paralympic Committee, said.\n\nRussia\u2019s state-backed cheating, deconstructed in investigative reports in 2016, corrupted the results of numerous major global competitions across disciplines and years \u2014 most dramatically the 2014 Olympic and Paralympic Games in Sochi, Russia. At those Paralympics, the host nation won 80 medals, nearly five dozen more than the second-ranking country.\n\nImmediately after the revelations that Russian Paralympians had used anabolic steroids to gain an edge over their competitors in Sochi, the Paralympic Committee banned Russia in August 2016, weeks ahead of the Rio Games. Philip Craven, then head of the committee, denounced Russia as having chosen \u201cmedals over morals.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn the roughly 18 months that followed, Paralympic officials outlined criteria for Russia\u2019s path to reinstatement, including that Russian officials accept the detailed evidence of their systematic cheating. Another stipulation was that Russia\u2019s antidoping agency be recertified by the global regulator of drugs in sports. Last November, that regulator denied Russia\u2019s appeal for reinstatement, citing, in part, Russian officials\u2019 lack of cooperation in sharing evidence from Moscow.\n\nRussian officials have apologized broadly for doping problems while refuting that the state directed widespread cheating. This month, hackers tied to the Russian government released a new crop of stolen emails seeking to expose and perhaps stoke discord between global sports officials and antidoping authorities.\n\nRussia\u2019s inability to participate in the last Paralympics in Brazil provoked particularly pointed outcry from top Russian officials. President Vladimir V. Putin criticized the ban as \u201coutside of the law, outside of morals and outside of humanity,\u201d characterizing sanctions against the nation\u2019s handicapped athletes as a Western effort to humiliate Russia\u2019s weakest, most vulnerable citizens.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s just cynical to take it out on people for whom sport has become the meaning of life,\u201d Mr. Putin said in 2016, describing Russia\u2019s banned Paralympians as \u201cthose who by their example give millions of people with limited capabilities hope and faith in their power.\u201d", "title": "Russia Is Banned From Paralympics, Again, for Doping", "authors": ["Rebecca R. Ruiz"]} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "Last Friday, global Olympic officials announced they had cleared 389 Russian athletes to potentially compete in Pyeongchang, a generous pool that some criticized as neutering the sting of the I.O.C.\u2019s punishment on a major sports power that had brazenly breached drug-testing controls.\n\n\u201cTo protect the rights of clean athletes,\u201d antidoping officials from 20 nations said in a statement last week, \u201cit is necessary for the bar to be higher for OAR to compete in the upcoming Olympic Winter Games,\u201d they said, using the acronym for Olympic athletes from Russia.\n\nOn Thursday, the I.O.C. named 17 factors it had taken into account in weighing eligibility for the potential Russian Olympians. Ruiz"]} {"date": "2018-01-08 00:00:00", "text": "MOSCOW \u2014 The main Russian air and naval bases in Syria beat back an attack by 13 armed drones over the weekend, the Russian Ministry of Defense said on Monday.\n\nThe small drones were shot down before they caused any damage and there were no casualties, according to a statement on the military\u2019s Facebook page.\n\nBut the attack could indicate that militants opposed to the government of President Bashar al-Assad were stepping up the violence directed against the Russian military, which intervened in September 2015 to prop up the beleaguered Syrian government, then its main ally in the Middle East.\n\nTwo Russian military personnel died in a mortar attack against the Hmeimim air base on Dec. 31, the military announced last week.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe military denied Russian news media reports that seven military aircraft had been destroyed or damaged by rebel shelling in the Dec. 31 attack, although a few posts on social media showed what was described as damaged aircraft, including a mangled rear stabilizer on one military jet.\n\nPhoto\n\nAside from the aircraft, the Kommersant newspaper also reported that 10 Russian servicemen had been injured.", "title": "Russia Says Its Syria Bases Beat Back an Attack by 13 Drones", "authors": ["Neil Macfarquhar"]} {"date": "2018-01-03 00:00:00", "text": "SAN FRANCISCO \u2014 Russian and Venezuelan officials are hoping virtual currencies can help their countries make an end run around American sanctions.\n\nBoth governments, with ambitions to create state-sponsored cryptocurrencies, are looking to take advantage of the promise that Bitcoin introduced to the world financial system: a new kind of money and financial infrastructure, outside the control of any central authority, particularly the United States.\n\nThe Russian and Venezuelan plans may sound outlandish, even in the financial Wild West of Bitcoin and its online competitors. But they underscore how the rise of virtual currencies is pushing governments around the world to rethink the most basic elements of their own currencies and financial infrastructure.\n\nWhat has seemed like a fringe concept is starting to gain some level of acceptance in global finance. Several of the largest central banks in the world, including the Bank of England and the People\u2019s Bank of China, have said they are looking at using the technology introduced by Bitcoin to track and issue their own digital currencies.", "title": "Russia and Venezuela\u2019s Plan to Sidestep Sanctions: Virtual Currencies", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-28 00:00:00", "text": "\u2022 A decade after the financial crisis, the world has hit a key marker of recovery.\n\nAll of the world\u2019s big economies are growing. But it also added a few important caveats: \u201cautomated election-related content associated with Russian signals represented a very small fraction of the overall activity on Twitter in the ten-week period preceding the 2016 election,\u201d and of tweets from Internet Research Agency-linked accounts, only 8.4 percent were \u201celection-related.\u201d\n\nWhat Twitter does not address is that the trolls will keep popping up. The Kremlin is unlikely to have concentrated all of its information warriors in one building. And according to researchers, up to 15 percent of all active Twitter accounts might be bots, Russian or otherwise. Twitter has a great deal more work to do on the automation front, but Whack-a-Troll is not where its disinformation problem ends.\n\nTwitter does not seem to comprehend that non-automated content, including from American accounts, is a huge part of the disinformation ecosystem. Its amplification of neo-Nazi rhetoric, abusive content and false or misleading stories spread by accounts with huge numbers of followers all affected rhetoric surrounding the 2016 election. Other than supporting a few small media literacy programs, Twitter doesn\u2019t seem to have a plan for eliminating the problematic content that originates within America\u2019s own borders.\n\nFacebook, which played its own round of Whack-a-Troll last year, scrubbing its platform of Internet Research Agency-created pages and accounts, doubled down on efforts to abdicate responsibility for defining high-quality content. On Jan. 19, Facebook announced that it will poll users to determine which outlets they trust and with which they are most familiar, giving those outlets priority in the News Feed.\n\nThese polls seem likely to reinforce existing biases, privilege well-known media giants and leave small outfits in the dust. After a year in which the United States witnessed a 37 percent decline in trust in institutions, the country\u2019s dwindling local newsrooms are more important than ever, interpreting and contextualizing events from Congress to the City Council for their readers in a way that larger news organizations struggled to do. Facebook should place local news in a prominent location, prioritize content from high-performing smaller outlets, perhaps through a competitive application system, and make serious investments in local journalism.", "title": "Opinion | Russian Trolls Are Only Part of the Problem", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-28 00:00:00", "text": "MOSCOW \u2014 Protesters across Russia braved icy temperatures on Sunday to demonstrate against the lack of choice in the March election that is virtually certain to see President Vladimir V. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cHow wonderful it is that our careers today can go beyond 40 years old,\u201d said Nicole Kidman, who won best actress in a television movie or limited series for her \u201cBig Little Lies\u201d performance. \u201cTwenty years ago we were pretty washed up by this stage in our lives. That\u2019s not the case now. We\u2019ve proven that we\u2019re potent and powerful and viable. I just beg that the industry stays behind us.\u201d\n\nIn his acceptance speech, Mr. Rockwell said he welcomed the #MeToo moment, saying, \u201cIt\u2019s long overdue.\u201d Moments earlier, presenting an award, Marisa Tomei lauded her fellow presenter, Rosanna Arquette, for breaking her silence, and Ms. Arquette listed a number of women who have spoken out against the disgraced producer Harvey Weinstein. Another presenter, Brie Larson, said that the Time\u2019s Up initiative was working with SAG-Aftra to hammer out a new code of conduct to ensure safety from harassment on movie sets.\n\nMs. Bell, the SAG Awards\u2019 first ever host, faced the unenviable choice of directly addressing what Mr. Ansari and Mr. Franco stand accused of or making it the elephant in the room. That she opted for the latter was arguably a startling move, though in an interview last month with The Times, Ms. Bell said, \u201cAn awards show is not as serious as the conversation deserves to be.\u201d (She did wear black at the ceremony, a nod of support for Time\u2019s Up, though, unlike at the Globes, many women opted for color.) And the majority of presenters were women, a deliberate decision made by the producers in the wake of last January\u2019s Women\u2019s March and the #MeToo movement.\n\nAt the Golden Globes on Jan. 7, Seth Meyers won praise for threading the needle, referencing Hollywood\u2019s sexual harassment scandals while ginning up genuine belly laughs. But that was before women began making claims against Mr. Franco and Mr. Ansari, who both collected Golden Globes that night. Indeed the accusers said they were inspired by the Time\u2019s Up pins both men were wearing in support of people who had been victimized.", "title": "SAG Awards 2018: \u2018Three Billboards\u2019 Triumphs; #MeToo Gets Stage Time", "authors": ["Cara Buckley"]} {"date": "2018-01-21 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nNicole Kidman\u2019s string of award-show victories continued on Sunday when she won a Screen Actors Guild Award for her role in HBO\u2019s \u201cBig Little Lies.\u201d She had already won an Emmy and a Golden Globe for the part.\n\nA sniffly Ms. Kidman, who said she was fighting the flu, used her speech at the SAG-Aftra ceremony to champion shows and films that include prominent roles for women \u201cbeyond 40 years old,\u201d urging studios and financiers to continue supporting age diversity for female actors.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m incredibly grateful. To receive this at this stage of my life is extraordinary \u2014 and at this time in the industry, when these things are going on, and for this role. I would like to acknowledge the other actresses in this category: Reese Witherspoon, Laura Dern \u2014 my girlfriends, first and foremost, but my beyond-talented acting partners \u2014 I share this with you. And also I want to say, Susan Sarandon and Jessica Lange, I revere you, I\u2019ve watched you, and I\u2019ve learned from you. And there\u2019s others: Meryl Streep, Jane Fonda, Judy Davis, Isabelle Huppert, Shirley MacLaine, Judi Dench. The list is so long and I\u2019d love to say so many more names, but I can\u2019t right now. But I want to thank you all for your trailblazing performances you\u2019ve given over your career.\n\n\u201cAnd how wonderful it is that our careers today can go beyond 40 years old. Because 20 years ago, we were pretty washed up by this stage in our lives. So, that\u2019s not the case now. We\u2019ve proven \u2014 and these actresses and so many more are proving \u2014 that we are potent and powerful and viable. I just beg that the industry stays behind us, because our stories are finally being told. It\u2019s only the beginning. And I\u2019m so proud to be a part of a community that is instigating this change. But I implore the writers, directors, studios and financiers to put passion and money behind our stories. We have proven that we can do this \u2014 we can continue to do this, but only with the support of this industry and that money and passion.\u201d", "title": "SAG Awards: Nicole Kidman Implores Hollywood to Support Female Stories", "authors": ["Giovanni Russonello"]} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "In an industry where the youngest stars radiate the most heat, SZA was a relatively late bloomer. She self-released her first EP at 22 and came to music as a refuge from jobs as a bartender and a sales assistant on the floor at Sephora. She was born to a Catholic communications executive mother and a Muslim television producer father in St. Louis. The family moved to suburban Maplewood, N.J., when she was 10.\n\nAs a child, her life was circumscribed by gymnastics practice and Islamic prep school, realms where discipline and accountability were sacrosanct. Music was freeing, low pressure.\n\n\u201cI was just kind of stumbling through it, very novice,\u201d she said of the first songs she wrote at the urging of her brother, a rapper. \u201cIt was music made in a closet with beats stolen off the internet.\u201d\n\nIn 2011, SZA was working part-time for a streetwear company in New York when she met the president of Top Dawg Entertainment, Terrence Henderson, known as Punch. He was in town for a concert headlined by the label\u2019s star artist, Kendrick Lamar, which happened to be sponsored by her employer. Mr. Henderson heard SZA\u2019s music \u2014 a friend took the initiative and played it for him, to the singer\u2019s horror \u2014 and didn\u2019t bite at first. But he kept in touch and ended up signing her three years later.\n\nThe two EPs SZA released on her own in the interim \u2014 \u201cSee.SZA.Run\u201d (2012) and \u201cS\u201d (2013) \u2014 were early salvos in a revolution in R&B. They shared as much DNA with hip-hop, Bj\u00f6rk and left-of-center electronic music of artists like Toro y Moi and Purity Ring, as they did with Brandy or Jill Scott, inspiring comparisons to contemporary iconoclasts like the Weeknd and Frank Ocean.\n\nHer lyrics at the time were a world away from the open diary of \u201cCtrl.\u201d Songs like \u201cTime Travel Undone\u201d and \u201cAftermath\u201d were saturated in oblique imagery and abstract symbolism. And, as if to complete the obfuscation, her vocals were submerged in reverb and atmospherics, giving them a disembodied quality.", "title": "SZA Almost Quit Music. Now She\u2019s a Grammys Contender.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-02 00:00:00", "text": "NEW ORLEANS \u2014 This started as a Nick Saban column, an assessment of the best college football coach in the game and perhaps the best coach in all of American sports. His Alabama team punished the top-ranked Clemson Tigers, 24-6, in the Sugar Bowl late Monday, sending the Tide to the national championship game for the third time in four years and offering Saban a chance at his sixth championship.\n\nThen the \u201cS-E-C! S-E-C!\u201d chants rang out. Saban remains a worthy topic, but one that can wait another week. He and Alabama have become such a fixture of the national title conversation each year that fitting him with a crown before another championship trophy is in his hands feels a bit unseemly.\n\nThe Tide will meet Georgia next week in the title game, after the Bulldogs came back to beat Oklahoma in a thrilling, 54-48, double-overtime victory in the other College Football Playoff semifinal in the Rose Bowl.\n\n\u201cSo Georgia came back?
