But Can We Pause to Embrace Georgia?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "MELBOURNE, Australia \u2014 Brunswick Street in Fitzroy is known as Melbourne\u2019s epicenter of hipsterdom, a stretch of boutiques and bars and cafes catering to the young and fashionable. In many ways, Saba\u2019s, a restaurant that sits smack in the middle of it all, adheres to the neighborhood\u2019s trendy reputation. The design is sleek and simple, with bright pops of color on the wall in the form of vibrant woven plates. The customers are youthful, as expected, but the crowd is far more diverse than it is elsewhere in the area.\n\nSaba\u2019s, an Ethiopian restaurant, is run by Saba Alemayoh and her mother, Tekebash Gebre. Ms. Gebre grew up in Ethiopia, but spent 13 years in Sudan working as a maid and cook, before immigrating to Australia with her young daughter, Ms. Alemayoh, in 1999. Ms. Gebre\u2019s home cooking became legendary among friends and family, and a restaurant was the next logical step.\n\nMs. Alemayoh recalls a childhood of trips to Ethiopia to visit family, returning to Australia with suitcases packed with spices and traditional Ethiopian teff flour, brought in part to cook for a sister who has celiac disease. (Teff flour is gluten free.) Saba\u2019s opened in 2015, and Ms. Gebre remains the restaurant\u2019s main cook, with two cousins helping out as needed.\n\nThe menu declares that the people in the kitchen cook from their own knowledge and have no written recipes. \u201cHope that they don\u2019t get sick!\u201d it jokes, which on first read seems like an alarmingly honest admission about the perils of food-borne illness. But it is meant to say that if Ms. Gebre and her family were unable to come to work, the restaurant would have no food. There is no recreating the recipes held only in their minds and hands.", "title": "Review: Saba\u2019s in Melbourne, Australia", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cSteep Tariffs Threaten Growth of Solar Industry\u201d (front page, Jan. 24):\n\nThe tariff on imported solar panels strikes me as an intentional sabotage of renewable energy in favor of fossil fuels. The tariff will tip the scale in favor of natural gas by making solar installations for utility-scale power less competitive.\n\nActual manufacture of solar panels accounts for few American jobs, but President Trump can boast about them while ignoring the loss of far more jobs in the solar power supply chain and installation.\n\nLike Gov. Andrew Cuomo in New York, Gov. Jerry Brown in California and others, governors must take their own actions to counter Mr. Trump\u2019s bad energy policies. Solar power sabotage is only the latest.\n\nSTEPHANIE DOBA, BROOKLYN", "title": "Opinion | Sabotaging Solar Power", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cLess Chance to Get Together in the Dark\u201d (Editorial Notebook, Jan. 28): Clyde Haberman makes clear that the shutting down of Lincoln Plaza Cinemas in Manhattan is a myopic act, blind to the reality of an aging Upper West Side community.\n\nMilstein Properties, which owns the property, should follow what other knowing ownerships have done once a property is in decline: Rebuild, as the New York Yankees did with a new Yankee Stadium, or the Whitney with a new museum.\n\nThere is a large audience waiting to be tapped, and a re-energized movie theater showing mostly foreign films still has a devoted following in this city.\n\nPETER SAMTON, NEW YORK", "title": "Opinion | Sad Farewell to a Movie Theater", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "Q. I was trying to install a new version of a program I\u2019ve used for years and Windows 10 gave me a warning box about it not being a \u201cverified\u201d app. What exactly is a verified app, and should I be worried about installing this \u201cunverified\u201d program?\n\nA. In an effort to keep unsuspecting people from inadvertently installing malicious software, Microsoft encourages users to get their Windows 10 software directly from its own online Windows App Store. While shareware sites and developers have traditionally offered software for sale or as free downloads on their own sites, some have bundled in spyware or malware with the goods. Programs purchased from the Windows App Store and downloaded directly from Microsoft have been approved and verified by the company as being safe, compatible and up to the company\u2019s guidelines for Windows software.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story How Do You Use Tech? Advice and tips on the technology changing how you live. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAn up-to-date antivirus program can catch many kinds of rogue software, but if you do not want to worry as much (or have children who may download software indiscriminately) you can set Windows 10 to do more than warn about apps coming from other sources beyond the Windows App Store. You can block apps from anywhere but the Windows App Store \u2014 or go the other way and allow apps from anywhere.\n\nGo to the Start menu to the Settings icon; you can also press the Windows and I keys on the keyboard as a shortcut. In the Settings box, select Apps and then Apps & Features. In the Installing Apps section, use the drop-down menu to choose the sources the computer can use for software shopping.\n\nPhoto\n\nApple has a similar approach to third-party software security for its online storefronts, including those for desktop Mac programs, iTunes Store digital media purchases, iBooks, and iOS apps and games. Google has also stepped up screening of harmful apps in its Google Play store. As with all the online software stores (Apple\u2019s included), creative malware may find new ways to sneak in, even for a short time, so keep your guard up.", "title": "Safely Shopping for Windows 10 Software", "authors": ["J. D. Biersdorfer", "Tech Tip"]} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "On a cold January evening six months later, an email popped into my inbox. \u201cI just spent a bunch of your inheritance by buying back my old boat,\u201d my father wrote. \u201cAnyone for sailing this summer? \u201cSurprised, stunned, I was nevertheless thrilled by his quixotic impulse.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019ve lost so many things over the past few years,\u201d I wrote back. \u201cIt feels good to have \u2018found\u2019 something. Especially something with such good memories.\u201d\n\nIf anything, his purchase was even more foolhardy the second time around. He still lived in Calgary, Alberta, 1,000 miles from the boat; only now the airlines required passengers to arrive at the airport two hours ahead of departure. He still didn\u2019t keep a car in Vancouver, so getting provisions and other logistics were complicated. While he was new to ocean sailing when he first purchased the boat, he now had the experience, but not as much strength and agility. And without my mother as first mate, he needed to search for competent and compatible crew.\n\nStill, we don\u2019t often get second chances in life. For him, it was an opportunity to have a physical connection to something he shared with his wife. For me, Desolation Sound still beckoned. The same rugged wilderness that Capt. George Vancouver reviled when he named the region in 1792 now attracts upward of 40,000 visitors each year. They come by boat or kayak to the largely undeveloped islands and inlets around the sound, enjoying the warmest water on the British Columbia coast, hikes to freshwater lakes and the rich sea life. I still yearned to experience it.\n\nUndoubtedly, there have been changes since my first attempt decades ago. A new Trudeau is prime minister. I\u2019m older now than my father was then. And, this time, the weather was glorious. Arriving to meet my father, I looked out at the forest of masts and immediately spotted the black carbon fiber and our Freedom\u2019s distinctive cat ketch design, with the larger mast at the bow and a smaller one midsection.\n\nI was nearly giddy with excitement as I went below into the cabin. The couple who owned the boat in the interim had replaced the green interior cushions with ones that are navy. The icebox was converted to a refrigerator, a heater was installed, and there\u2019s GPS now. But it felt like I was looking at an old friend wearing a new outfit; the sort of old friend you might not see for years, yet you pick up seamlessly where you left off.", "title": "Sailing Into Today on a Boat From Our Past", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-07 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nSam Rockwell is the kind of actor for whom \u201csupporting actor\u201d categories were invented: a steady, colorful presence in acclaimed movies that are often headlined by higher-wattage stars. So plenty of people were happy to see him take home the Golden Globe for actor in a supporting role Sunday night.\n\nBut not everyone was pleased with the movie, and performance, for which he won the honor. \u201cThree Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri\u201d \u2014 Martin McDonagh\u2019s violent revenge parable starring Mr. Rockwell and Frances McDormand \u2014 has been the subject of fierce debate on social media and among critics who have sparred over both its artistic merits and its racial politics. Mr. Rockwell\u2019s character is a police officer who, among other sins, is deeply racist.\n\nOn Twitter, some expressed disappointment that the Hollywood Foreign Press Association, which produces the Globes, rewarded the film, while others said their enthusiasm for Mr. Rockwell was dampened by their distaste for his character.\n\nIn The Times\u2019s live chat about the ceremony, critic-at-large Wesley Morris put it this way: \u201cYes, everybody, I\u2019m a Sam Rockwell fan who despises the moral and emotional and metaphorical confusion that is \u2018Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri.\u2019\u201d\n\n\u201cThree Billboards,\u201d which also won the Globe for best screenplay (by Mr. McDonagh), was one of the most nominated films at the Globes, with six total nominations, including best drama and best director. A few years later, Romania denied Mr. Hamilton spousal residency rights, however, arguing that he could not be considered the spouse of a European Union citizen given that Romania does not recognize same-sex marriage.", "title": "Same-Sex Spouses Should Have E.U. Residency Rights, Court Is Told", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "SAN FRANCISCO \u2014 In a city where being called conservative can be an insult and where partisanship is often left versus further left, the removal of an African-American interim mayor, and her replacement by a white, male venture capitalist, was bound to set off an uproar.\n\nThe appointment of Mark Farrell, the venture capitalist, and the ouster of London Breed, the interim mayor, by the San Francisco Board of Supervisors on Tuesday in some ways exemplified a larger battle for the soul of San Francisco. In just seven years the median price of a home here has nearly doubled, to $1.3 million \u2014 a transformation, driven by the riches of the tech industry, that continues to push out longtime residents, many of them nonwhites.\n\nBut what may seem on the surface to be a familiar clash between tech and those threatened by its rise is in fact a moment full of complicated alliances and seeming contradictions.\n\nMr. Farrell, who is the managing director of Thayer Ventures, a firm that invests in technology companies, was backed by a faction that has been critical of tech companies\u2019 influence on San Francisco.", "title": "San Francisco Ousts a Mayor in a Clash of Tech, Politics and Race", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-22 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nLONDON \u2014 The French drug maker Sanofi said on Monday that it had agreed to acquire Bioverativ, a biopharmaceutical company focused on treatments for hemophilia and other rare blood disorders, for $11.6 billion in cash.\n\nSanofi has sought use acquisitions to bolster its portfolio of drugs, particularly because it faces declining sales for its diabetes drug, Lantus, which has lost its patent protection. According to the company, sales of Lantus declined more than 16 percent in the first nine months of last year, based on constant exchange rates, and rivals are moving to introduce generic versions of the treatment.\n\nThe Bioverativ deal would enhance Sanofi\u2019s \u201cpresence in specialty care and leadership in rare diseases\u201d and \u201ccreates a platform for growth in other rare blood disorders,\u201d Olivier Brandicourt, the Sanofi chief executive, said in a news release.\n\nBioverativ, based in Waltham, Mass., was spun out of Biogen last year. It markets two products to treat hemophilia in Australia, Canada, Japan and the United States. The company generated $847 million in sales in 2016.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nJohn G. In doing so, they followed the women of Hollywood, who wore all black to the Golden Globes in honor of the Time\u2019s Up and #MeToo movements.\n\nIt was a stark contrast to what has, in the past two years, become the Democratic women\u2019s unofficial color: white. Hillary Clinton memorably wore a white pantsuit when she became the first woman to accept the Democratic nomination for president \u2014 a nod to the suffragists, who adopted it as one of their signatures in 1913. And last February, Democratic women wore all white during Mr. Trump\u2019s address to Congress.\n\nYet on Tuesday, in a strange turn, it was Melania Trump who chose white \u2014 a gorgeous pantsuit by Christian Dior. Was it meant to stand out against the all-black crowd? Was it a nod to women\u2019s rights? Or perhaps a thumb in the eye of her husband, who was recently accused of having an affair with the porn star Stormy Daniels just weeks after Mrs. Trump gave birth to their son? To judge from Melania\u2019s face and the reports that she traveled to the speech apart from her husband, I suspect the latter.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe members of Mr. Trump\u2019s party kept things traditional. Paul Ryan wore the classic American flag pin on his lapel and his equally classic smug face. And many Republican men wore red, white and blue ties.\n\nPhoto\n\nPhoto\n\nPhoto\n\nPhoto\n\nDemocratic senators wore purple ribbons to raise awareness about the opioid epidemic. \u201cAddiction touches all of us, and it\u2019s time for real action to address this public health crisis,\u201d Senator Tom Udall of New Mexico tweeted with a photo.", "title": "Sartorial Stands at the State of the Union", "authors": ["Tariro Mzezewa"]} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "BEIRUT, Lebanon \u2014 Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman of Saudi Arabia has long admired MBC, the media giant of the Arab world, with its coveted array of television channels that deliver hit shows like \u201cOprah\u201d and \u201cArabs Got Talent\u201d to hundreds of millions of homes.\n\nTwo years ago, the crown prince began negotiations to buy MBC, a satellite broadcaster, but in November the talks took a mysterious turn: The company\u2019s Saudi owners and most of its board members were summoned to Riyadh, the capital, arrested, accused of corruption and locked in the Ritz-Carlton hotel, along with hundreds of the kingdom\u2019s other wealthiest and most powerful men.\n\nOn Friday, the tale took another turn, when the company\u2019s chief owner, Waleed al-Ibrahim, was released from the Ritz after 83 days, according to a memo to MBC staff members seen by The New York Times.\n\nTwo and a half months after the start of what the Saudi government has called a crackdown on systematic corruption, the campaign appears to be moving to a new phase. Most of the roughly 350 men detained have been released, after either being cleared or surrendering significant assets to the government. And Crown Prince Mohammed is turning the screws on those who remain, threatening to move them to an actual prison and put them on trial, Saudi officials say.", "title": "Saudi Arabia Frees Media Mogul, but His Company\u2019s Fate Remains a Mystery", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "BEIRUT, Lebanon \u2014 Saudi Arabia has collected more than $100 billion from prominent citizens who were detained in what the government has called a widespread crackdown on corruption, the kingdom said on Tuesday.\n\nSheikh Saud al-Mojeb, the attorney general, said in a statement that 381 people had been summoned as part of the investigation. Many were brought in as witnesses, while others were accused of corruption and released only after handing over significant assets to the government, the statement said.\n\nThe release of many of the detainees appeared to signal the wrapping up of the two-and-a-half-month campaign, in which some of the kingdom\u2019s richest and most powerful men were locked in the Ritz-Carlton Hotel in Riyadh, the Saudi capital, where the authorities pressed them to hand over assets said to have been stolen from the state.\n\nThe detainees included businessmen, current and former government ministers, and at least 11 princes, including Alwaleed bin Talal, the kingdom\u2019s most famous investor, who was released on Saturday.", "title": "Saudi Arabia Says Detainees Handed Over More Than $100 Billion", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "I was astonished when, in late September, Saudi Arabia decided to allow women to drive, putting an end to an old, discriminatory practice. This was only one of several cautious social reforms that have been introduced in the country. In the past two years, King Salman bin Abdulaziz has restricted the powers of the notorious religious police and relaxed male guardianship laws. Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman has spoken about embracing \u201cmoderate Islam\u201d and increasing social freedoms.\n\nPrince Mohammed is being credited for the effort to transform Saudi Arabia, but the changes might not have been possible without the Saudi activists and intellectuals who struggled and suffered over the years \u2014 enduring the loss of jobs, imprisonment and exile \u2014 to increase the freedoms in their country.\n\nAs I look forward to seeing Saudi women drive starting in June, I remember the 47 women who drove their cars in 1990. They were arrested, lost their jobs and were prohibited from traveling. Two years later they were allowed to return to their jobs. Some faded into private life; others focused on helping women at schools and universities and in programs for abused women and children.\n\nThe courage of Wajeha al-Huwaider, a women\u2019s rights activist, is unforgettable. We stopped in front of a relatively modest statue that depicted a black family with an inscription from Maya Angelou below. The statue, Ms. Wortham explained, was a compromise after a yearslong battle with the city. Originally, she said, the monument was to depict a more real, raw picture of slavery in Georgia. The city balked, and the monument\u2019s designer settled on a family of four in church clothes, with chains lying at the family\u2019s feet. The quotation, too, was called into question for its graphic language, but it was, Ms. Wortham said, simply the reality of what happened.\n\nSavannah is a gorgeous place \u2014 Spanish moss drips gloomily from gnarled oak trees and old colonial-style houses line its dignified streets \u2014 but it is also a city of great complexity. Old Southern money coexists with a majority African-American population, who in turn share Savannah with a steady flow of tourists \u2014 some headed to nearby Tybee Island and others hoping to enjoy the city\u2019s relaxed open container laws. Mix in a slew of young business owners and students from the Savannah College of Art and Design and you\u2019ve got a fascinating demographic in a city with no shortage of history, sultry beauty and architectural delights. It\u2019s a place well worth getting to know, and, as I found over a recent weekend visit, it needn\u2019t cost an arm and a leg.\n\nIt is also, apparently, one of the most haunted cities in America. That, according to my friendly Uber driver, Charlene, originally from Tennessee but a 40-year resident of the city. \u201cIn my own house I\u2019ve experienced some stuff,\u201d she said. \u201cI was talking to my girlfriend on Skype and she said, \u2018Do you have a cat?\u2019 I looked and there was like a cloud, dancing beside me. You can sign up here to receive the newsletter each weekday.\n\nThe roughly 200,000 Salvadorans whom the Trump administration is subjecting to deportation are deeply ensconced in American society.\n\nThey have lived here for at least 17 years. Together, they have about 190,000 children who were born in the United States. The immigrants \u201cwork in a wide array of jobs, from defense contractors to school cafeteria workers, commercial office cleaners and restaurant owners,\u201d Maria Sacchetti of The Washington Post writes. The largest group of them lives in the Washington area, followed by Los Angeles, New York and Houston.\n\nNow President Trump has decided to send them back to a country many barely know, which is also one of the world\u2019s most violent, Vox\u2019s Dara Lind notes. Over the last several years, thousands of Americans petitioned their local, state and federal governments to say no to seismic airgun blasting, which is damaging to marine life, and offshore drilling. They called, they signed petitions, wrote letters, went to city council meetings, held rallies and wrote op-ed essays and letters to the editor; some even traveled multiple times to Washington to meet with their representatives.\n\nI have met these people. They are from all parties. Many are Republicans. Many are business owners. Others are fishermen, veterans, faith leaders and even former oil industry leaders. They saw that their government respond to their concerns when the Obama administration removed the Arctic and Atlantic seaboards from its offshore drilling plan. In removing Atlantic coastal areas from the plan, the Obama administration cited \u201csignificant potential conflicts with other ocean uses such as Department of Defense and commercial interests, current market dynamics, limited infrastructure, and opposition from many coastal communities.\u201d\n\nThe Trump administration seems to be ignoring the voices of those communities.\n\nLast year, Secretary of the Interior Ryan Zinke promised to \u201clisten to state and local stakeholders\u201d as his department\u2019s reviewed offshore oil and gas. But this proposal plan tells America that so far, the only stakeholders this administration has listened to are industry lobbyists.\n\nPerhaps this will change. There will be a 60-day window for the public to comment on the Interior Department plan. Early this month, I joined the passenger manifest of Delta Air Lines Flight 9771, with nonstop service from Atlanta to Marana, Ariz., where Delta\u2019s 747 fleet was being retired.\n\nI\u2019ve long been a self-described nerd when it comes to transportation, starting with a childhood love of \u201cThomas the Tank Engine.\u201d These days, I use my free time to look into technical details about how the things that make us go operate, and keep an eye out for stories to cover. When Delta Air Lines and United Airlines both announced last year that they would be retiring their 747s, I wanted to know what would happen to the planes once they were consigned back to earth. I\u2019d heard about the \u201cboneyards\u201d where planes go to die in the desert, and suspected that at least some of the aircraft would wind up there.\n\nI was right about the destination, but I came away with a different idea of what happens there than I\u2019d anticipated.\n\nEarly on Jan. 3, in the terminal at Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport, a small scrum of reporters gathered around the pilots who briefed us on our schedule. The pilots warned that a short runway meant we would have to stop more abruptly than we might be used to. They also noted that the plane wouldn\u2019t be able to move around Pinal Airpark under its own power after reaching the end of the runway. Doing so risked sucking large debris into the engines, which would cause serious damage and could prevent the airline from reclaiming them.", "title": "Say So Long to a Runway Career: Reporting From an Aircraft Boneyard", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "ALBANY \u2014 It read like a maddening instruction manual for a do-it-yourself piece of furniture, with page after page of bare-bones guidance \u2014 and plenty of room for confusion.\n\nIf taxpayers and lawmakers were expecting that a new 37-page report would provide a definitive road map of how New York State might sidestep the effects of President Trump\u2019s new federal tax plan and its sharp reduction in the deductibility of state and local taxes, they instead got a view of just how complicated this is.\n\nThe report, released this week, laid out at least a half-dozen ways New York could rewrite its tax code, with no indication of which option legislators might pursue. There was a potpourri of progressive rates, wage credits and tax-withholding schemes, with officials cautioning that all the options would require further study. No bills have been drafted.\n\nThe possibilities included completely replacing the state income tax with an employer-side payroll tax; introducing a new progressive payroll tax in addition to the existing income tax, with tax credits to make up the difference; or designing a payroll tax only for wage earners above a certain income threshold \u2014 the taxpayers most likely to be hurt by the federal tax plan in the first place. Some versions would be mandatory. Others would be opt-in.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMore than anything, the report illustrated how difficult it may be to turn academic theory into real policy, serving as a cautionary guide to other states contemplating similar options. And it underscored the political challenges that lie ahead for Gov. Andrew M. What has been so infuriating, though, is how few leaders in the industry have been willing to go on record against the behavior itself \u2014 behavior that was, after all, banned by federal law several decades ago.\n\nIf you rounded up all the chefs and restaurateurs who have taken the opportunity to say, in essence, \u201csexual harassment at work is wrong and I won\u2019t stand for it,\u201d they wouldn\u2019t fill the sushi counter at Masa. And the best-known of them is Anthony Bourdain, who hasn\u2019t worked in a restaurant for more than a decade.\n\nFor the most part, chefs are acting as if the sudden willingness of women to talk about what the industry is really like for them is just a temporary condition, that it will blow over soon enough and the party will start up again. This seemed to be the message of the pizza dough cinnamon roll incident.\n\nIn December, several women who worked for Mr. Batali accused him of making unwanted sexual advances. Mr. Batali didn\u2019t agree with every specific account, but he generally acknowledged that he had done things that were not very different.\n\nThe fallout was swift. Mr. Batali stepped aside from managing his restaurants, pending an investigation. A few days later, ABC fired him from \u201cThe Chew.\u201d It looked certain that if he returned to work at all, it would have to be on different terms.\n\nThen Mr. Batali sent a mass email to his fans. It started out as another apology (\u201cI take full responsibility\u201d) until the postscript, which linked to a recipe for pizza dough cinnamon rolls, \u201ca fan favorite.\u201d\n\nThis was one of the more bizarre non sequiturs in the history of cooking. It quickly went viral and generated a fresh round of news articles, most of them mildly aghast at this glimpse into the Batali school of crisis management.", "title": "Scandals Keep Breaking, but Restaurateurs Have Yet to Own Up", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "In a basement laboratory of the Morgan Library and Museum in New York, an X-ray scanner is pumping invisible beams into a clump of charred parchment leaves that looks as delicate as a long dead flower.\n\nThe leaves are the remains of a severely scorched early book, or codex, which was written in southern Egypt some time between 400 and 600 A.D. It contains the Acts of the Apostles, one of the books of the New Testament, possibly bound with another work. The writing is Coptic, the language of Egypt before the Arab conquest in 642 A.D.\n\nThe charred codex was purchased by the Morgan Library in 1962. But no one has opened it for fear of destroying it: The brittle pages have been fused together by a cinder that sank through much of the book, congealing the parchment fibers. Unlike famous codices that have their own names, like the Codex Sinaiticus, this one is known humbly as M.910, its accession number at the library.\n\nPhoto\n\nBut having lain in obscurity for half a century, M.910\u2019s day in the limelight has finally arrived. Last month, a television news crew documented every movement of the little codex and of its two new enthusiasts: Paul C. Dilley, an expert on early Christianity at the University of Iowa, and W. Brent Seales, a computer scientist at the University of Kentucky.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nDr. Seales has spent 14 years developing a technique for reading ancient scrolls that are too fragile to unwrap. Fine-detail CT scanners can visualize the ink of letters inside such scrolls, but the alphabet soup is unreadable unless each letter can be assigned to its correct position on a surface.", "title": "Scanning an Ancient Biblical Text That Humans Fear to Open", "authors": ["Nicholas Wade"]} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "Some of the shootings at schools this year were suicides that injured no one else; some did not result in any injuries at all. But in the years since the massacres at Columbine High School in Colorado, Virginia Tech and Sandy Hook Elementary School in Newtown, Conn., gun safety advocates say, all school shootings seem to have lost some of their capacity to shock.\n\nShannon Watts, the founder of Moms Demand Action, a gun safety group, said that\u2019s because in 2012 in Newtown, \u201c20 first graders and six educators were slaughtered in an elementary school.\u201d\n\n\u201cThe news cycles are so short right now in America, and there\u2019s a lot going on,\u201d she said. \u201cBut you would think that shootings in American schools would be able to clear away some of that clutter.\u201d\n\nGov. Matt Bevin of Kentucky said the gunman who opened fire Tuesday morning at Marshall County High School in Benton, near the western tip of the state was a 15-year-old student. The authorities said the student entered the school just before 8 a.m., fired shots that struck 14 people, and set off a panicked flight in which five more were hurt.\n\nOne girl who was shot, Bailey Nicole Holt, died at the scene; a boy, Preston Ryan Cope, died of his injuries at a hospital.\n\nBryson Conkwright, a junior at the school, said he was talking with a friend on Tuesday morning when he spotted the gunman walking up near him. \u201cIt took me a second to process it,\u201d Mr. Conkwright, 17, said in an interview. \u201cOne of my best friends got shot in the face, and then another one of my best friends was shot in the shoulder.\u201d\n\nHe said he was part of a group of students who fled, kicked down a door to get outside and ran.\n\nThe suspect, who was not immediately identified, was taken into custody in \u201ca nonviolent apprehension,\u201d Mr. Bevin said, and officials said he would be charged with two counts of murder and several counts of attempted murder. But the authorities had not yet decided whether to charge the suspect, who was armed with a pistol, as a juvenile or as an adult.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOf the 18 people injured, five remained in critical condition, law enforcement officials said on Tuesday night.\n\n5 Miles 24 ILLINOIS Tennessee R. Paducah 62 Marshall County High School KENTUCKY IND. ILL. Benton KY. Area of detail MO. purchase hwy. TENN.\n\n\u201cThis is something that has struck in the heart of Kentucky,\u201d Lt. Michael B. Webb of Kentucky State Police said at a news conference. \u201cIt\u2019s not far away, it\u2019s here.\u201d\n\nNot for the first time. The region was scarred about two decades ago by a deadly school shooting in West Paducah, about a 40-minute drive away. Three people were killed when a student opened fire into a prayer circle, and five more were injured.\n\nBenton is a small town about 200 miles southwest of Louisville, and its high school serves students from all over Marshall County, which has a population of about 31,000.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Taylor McCuiston, 21, a manager at the restaurant who graduated from Marshall County High School two years ago, was working when the shooting occurred down the road.\n\n\u201cIt was very scary because, like, 90 percent of the staff that works here goes to that school,\u201d she said. \u201cSo for the first hour we were just scrambling trying to make sure they were all O.K. and accounted for.\u201d\n\nThe town of Italy, Tex., is not any bigger than Benton. On Monday, a 15-year-old girl there was hospitalized after she was shot by a 16-year-old classmate, according to local news reports. That suspect, a boy, was taken into custody by the Ellis County Sheriff\u2019s Department. The authorities said on Tuesday that the victim was recovering.\n\nThe F.B.I. study that Ms. Schweit helped write examined active shooter episodes in the United States between 2000 and 2013. It found that nearly one-quarter of them occurred in educational environments, and they were on the rise.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn the first half of the study period, federal officials counted 16 active shooter incidents in educational settings, meaning instances of a person \u201cactively engaged in killing or attempting to kill people in a confined and populated area.\u201d In the second half, the number rose to 23. (Many, but not all, of the school shootings tallied by advocates so far this year meet that definition.)\n\n\u201cAny time there\u2019s a school shooting, it\u2019s more gut-wrenching, and I think we have a tendency to react in a more visceral way,\u201d Ms. Schweit said in an interview on Tuesday. \u201cBut I really don\u2019t think as a whole, in society, we\u2019re taking shootings more seriously than we were before \u2014 and that\u2019s wrong.\u201d\n\nEven so, jarred and fearful school administrators across the country have been placing greater emphasis on preparing for the possibility of an active shooter. According to a report issued by the Government Accountability Office in March 2016, 19 states were requiring individual schools to have plans for how to deal with an active shooter. Only 12 states required schools to conduct drills, but two-thirds of school districts reported that they had staged active shooter exercises.\n\nSchool safety experts say steps like the drills are crucial, if imperfect, safeguards.\n\n\u201cI think we\u2019ve become somewhat desensitized to the fact that these things happened, and it takes a thing like Sandy Hook to bring us back to our senses,\u201d said William Modzeleski, a consultant who formerly led the Department of Education\u2019s Office of Safe and Drug Free Schools.\n\n\u201cMy fear is that if you don\u2019t hear about a school shooting for a while, educators move on to other things,\u201d he said. \u201cPrincipals are busy. Teachers are busy. Superintendents are busy.\u201d\n\nIn Kentucky, lawmakers have grappled with how to address the risk of school shootings. Last year, state legislators considered, but did not pass, a bill that would have allowed people with concealed-carry permits to bring weapons on to public school campuses, where proponents argue they could be used to respond to active shooters. A similar bill, limited to college campuses and certain other government buildings, has been introduced this year. It was not immediately clear how the shooting in Benton might affect the debate in Frankfort, the Kentucky capital.\n\nBut in Benton, \u201cthis is a wound that is going to take a long time to heal,\u201d said Mr. Bevin, the governor, \u201c and for some in this community, will never fully heal.\u201d", "title": "School Shooting in Kentucky Was Nation\u2019s 11th of Year. It Was Jan. 23.", "authors": ["Alan Blinder", "Daniel Victor"]} {"date": "2018-01-03 00:00:00", "text": "Alex Barrios, a spokesman for the Sacramento City Unified School District, said Mr. Seagraves had been an intermittent employee of the district and was fired on Thursday.\n\nHe had worked since the fall as the coach of the varsity boys\u2019 soccer team, comprising mainly juniors and seniors, at Kennedy High School and was not a classroom teacher, Mr. Barrios said. Mr. Seagraves had also coached the boys\u2019 team from March to May 2016 and from January to March 2017.\n\n\u201cWe have let him go,\u201d Mr. Barrios said. \u201cAfter this announcement, we made the decision that he was not going to be able to fulfill his duties as a soccer coach.\u201d\n\nMr. Seagraves had previously worked for the district as a coach for the girls\u2019 junior varsity team, comprising mainly freshmen and sophomores, at the district\u2019s West Campus High School between September and October 2013 and again from February to May 2014, Mr. Barrios said. It was not known if Mr. Seagraves had a lawyer.", "title": "School Soccer Coach in California Charged With Trafficking Teenage Girls", "authors": ["Liam Stack"]} {"date": "2018-01-22 00:00:00", "text": "This weekend, more than one million people took to the streets nationwide for the first anniversary of the Women\u2019s March. Though not nearly as big as the protests a year ago, it was still a larger public manifestation than anything the Tea Party ever managed. And though the demonstration was meant as a rebuke to Donald Trump, one central demand was that Congress stand up for the young undocumented immigrants known as Dreamers, who were brought to the country as children. They now face deportation because Trump has moved to end Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals, an Obama-era program protecting them.\n\nThe energy of the progressive grass roots should be seen as a valuable resource for Democrats. If Donald Trump\u2019s election taught us anything beyond the salience of white nationalism among our fellow citizens, it\u2019s that passion matters, and that people respond when they see a leader who is willing to champion them even when it\u2019s risky. That\u2019s why it was so infuriating to see the Senate Democratic leadership sell the Dreamers out.\n\nOn Monday afternoon, Senate Democrats made a deal with Republicans to reopen the federal government, which has been shut since Congress failed to pass a budget bill on Friday. Democrats had been using their leverage in budget negotiations to demand that Congress pass DACA protections into law. But almost as soon as the shutdown began, Democrats lost their nerve, and the Senate minority leader, Chuck Schumer, announced a deal to fund the government through Feb. 8. In exchange, he received a vague promise by the Senate Republican leader, Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, to take up some sort of immigration legislation after Feb. 8 if a more wide-ranging compromise on the budget and DACA can\u2019t be found first.\n\nIt\u2019s hard to overstate how disgusted many progressive leaders are. \u201cIt\u2019s Senator Schumer\u2019s job as minority leader to keep his caucus together and stand up for progressive values and he failed to do it,\u201d Ezra Levin, a co-founder of Indivisible, a left-wing advocacy group modeled on the Tea Party, told me. \u201cHe led them off a cliff. They caved.\u201d (An Indivisible chapter is planning a Tuesday evening protest outside Schumer\u2019s Brooklyn apartment.) Representative Luis Guti\u00e9rrez, Democrat of Illinois, said in a statement, \u201cThis shows me that when it comes to immigrants, Latinos and their families, Democrats are still not willing to go to the mat.\u201d", "title": "Opinion | Schumer Sells Out the Resistance", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-29 00:00:00", "text": "CHIP has emerged as a risk for heart attack and stroke that is as powerful as high LDL or high blood pressure but it acts independently of them. And CHIP is not uncommon.\n\nThe condition becomes more likely with age. Up to 20 percent of people in their 60s have it, and perhaps 50 percent of those in their 80s.\n\n\u201cIt is beginning to appear that there are only two types of people in the world: those that exhibit clonal hematopoiesis and those that are going to develop clonal hematopoiesis,\u201d said Kenneth Walsh, who directs the hematovascular biology center at the University of Virginia School of Medicine.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe growing evidence has taken heart researchers aback. Dr. Peter Libby, a cardiologist at Brigham and Women\u2019s Hospital and professor of medicine at Harvard Medical School, calls CHIP the most important discovery in cardiology since statins.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m turning part of my lab to work on this full time,\u201d Dr. Libby said. \u201cIt\u2019s really exciting.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe mutations are acquired, not inherited \u2014 most likely by bad luck or exposure to toxins like cigarette smoke. But there is little that patients can do.\n\nBrian Gear, a project manager at a Boston company that analyzes health care data, was given genetic testing by doctors at Dana-Farber Cancer Institute because his mother had had a blood cancer that can be inherited.\n\nThe diagnosis was CHIP, something he had never heard of. And because it dramatically increased his risk of heart disease, it was life-changing.\n\n\u201cIt is almost like a Ph.D. in letting go of control,\u201d said Mr. Gear, who said he was in his mid-30s. \u201cAs much as you want to have a plan and a destiny, you also have this thing. It\u2019s scary and it\u2019s terrifying.\u201d\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t want to use the word time-bomb, but that\u2019s how it feels,\u201d he added.\n\nCHIP was discovered independently by several groups of researchers who were not even investigating heart disease. Mostly, they were looking at the genes of patients who might develop leukemia or, in one research project, schizophrenia.\n\nThe scientists searched databases from genetic studies involving tens of thousands of people whose DNA had been obtained from their white blood cells.\n\nTo their great surprise, the teams converged on the same phenomenon. Unexpectedly large numbers of study participants had blood cells with mutations linked to leukemia \u2014 but they did not have the cancer. Instead, they had just one or two of the cluster of mutations.\n\n\u201cThis clearly wasn\u2019t happening by chance,\u201d said Steven McCarroll, a geneticist at the Broad Institute and Harvard Medical School. \u201cWe knew we were onto something, but what were we onto?\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe investigators quickly guessed the broad outlines.\n\nWhite blood cells, the attack dogs of the immune system, arise from stem cells in the bone marrow. Every day, a few hundred such stem cells spew out blood cells that begin dividing rapidly into the 10 billion needed to replace those that have died.\n\nSometimes, by chance, one of those marrow stem cells acquires a mutation, and the white blood cells it produces carry the same mutation.\n\n\u201cSome mutations are just markers of past events without any lasting consequence,\u201d said Dr. David Steensma, a blood cancer specialist at Harvard Medical School and Dana-Farber Cancer Institute.\n\nBut others, especially those linked to leukemia, seem to give stem cells a new ability to accumulate in the marrow. The result is a sort of survival of the fittest, or fastest growing, stem cells in the marrow.\n\n\u201cSome mutations may alter the growth properties of the stem cell,\u201d said Dr. Steensma. \u201cSome may just make the stem cell better at surviving in certain less hospitable parts of the bone marrow where other stem cells can\u2019t thrive.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThe mutated stem cells outlast normal stem cells in the marrow, and their progeny \u2014 an increasing percentage of white blood cells \u2014 show up in the blood with mutations.\n\nPerhaps the most extreme example of how this can play out was reported in 2014, when researchers described a 115-year-old woman. Nearly her entire supply of white blood cells was generated by mutated stem cells in her bone marrow.\n\nAt the first she had developed just two mutated stem cells. But over time their progeny came to dominate her bone marrow. She lived about as long as a human can, nonetheless, and died of a tumor.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nBut the big surprise came when researchers looked at the medical records of people with these white blood cell mutations. They had 54 percent increase in the odds of dying within the next decade, compared to people without CHIP And the cause: heart attacks and strokes.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nDr. Benjamin Ebert, chair of medical oncology a the Dana-Farber Cancer Institute, was the first to see the link. He turned for help to Dr. Sekar Kathiresan, a cardiologist and genetics researcher at the Massachusetts General Hospital and the Broad Institute, who had genetic data from four more large studies.\n\nThey confirmed that CHIP doubled the risk of a heart attack in typical patients \u2014 and increased the risk fourfold in those who had heart attacks early in life.\n\nBut how might mutated white blood cells cause heart disease? One clue intrigued scientists.\n\nArtery-obstructing plaque is filled with white blood cells, smoldering with inflammation and subject to rupture. Perhaps mutated white cells were causing atherosclerosis or accelerating its development.\n\nIn separate studies, Dr. Ebert and Dr. Walsh gave mice a bone-marrow transplant containing stem cells with a CHIP mutation, along with stem cells that were not mutated. Mutated blood cells began proliferating in the mice, and they developed rapidly growing plaques that were burning with inflammation.\n\n\u201cFor decades people have worked on inflammation as a cause of atherosclerosis,\u201d Dr. Ebert said. \u201cBut it was not clear what initiated the inflammation.\u201d\n\nNow there is a possible explanation \u2014 and, Dr. Ebert said, it raises the possibility that CHIP may be involved in other inflammatory diseases, like arthritis.\n\nFor now, doctors advise against testing for CHIP, since there is nothing specific to be done to reduce the increased risks of cancer or heart disease that it confers.\n\nBut, he said, if people really want to know if they have CHIP, they can get a blood test that costs a few thousand dollars. (If there is no particular reason for the test, insurance may not pay.)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nDr. Steensma said that if he had CHIP, he would make sure he did his best to control all of his heart disease risks, like cholesterol and blood pressure, and that he had a healthy diet and exercised. Drugs may be developed to help stem the inflammation in arteries, he added.\n\nAs for the cancer risk, Dr. Ross Levine at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center just opened a C.H.I.P clinic in part to explore whether some patients with CHIP have a greater risk of blood cancers, and if so, what to do about it.\n\nAt the moment, CHIP is mostly found accidentally in patients who are genetically tested for other reasons \u2014 like Brian Gear. The diagnosis stunned him, but it also has brought into focus the important things in his life.\n\n\u201cThere are things I love in life and people I love,\u201d he said. \u201cYou try to live that life.\u201d", "title": "Scientists Discover a Bone-Deep Risk for Heart Disease", "authors": ["Gina Kolata"]} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "After the Senate testimony concluded, Mr. Pruitt\u2019s staff issued a statement attributed to him that said: \u201cNow having the honor of working for him, it is abundantly clear that President Trump is the most consequential leader of our time. No one has done more to advance the rule of law than President Trump.\u201d\n\nIt was not yet apparent how Mr. Trump, who prizes loyalty in his inner circle, reacted to the airing of the broadcast. The White House did not immediately respond to a request for comment.\n\nIn his leadership tenure at the E.P.A., Mr. Pruitt has often won praise from Mr. Trump as a key executor of the president\u2019s aggressive efforts to roll back regulations on business and industry. Mr. Pruitt was among the most influential voices urging Mr. Trump to withdraw the country from the landmark Paris climate change agreement, making the United States only nation in the world not party to the accord.\n\nIn a sign of the high regard in which the president holds his E.P.A. chief, Mr. Trump has assigned Mr. Pruitt, rather than his secretary of state, Rex W. Tillerson, to craft the legal tactics to implement that withdrawal.\n\nMr. Pruitt\u2019s 2016 remarks appear sharply at odds with his tenure at the Environmental Protection Agency. Last year, Mr. Trump issued multiple executive orders aimed at undoing environmental regulations on air, water and planet-warming pollution. Mr. Pruitt responded swiftly, drafting a list of legal proposals to undo those rules.\n\nHowever, on the 2016 radio show, Mr. Pruitt said, \u201cThis, if Donald Trump is the nominee and eventually the president, he would take, I think unapologetic steps, to use executive power to confront Congress in a way that is truly unconstitutional.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Pruitt has come under criticism for the swiftness with which he has sought to undo those existing regulations, a multistep legal process that usually takes years, as well as for doing so in secrecy.\n\nIn an opening statement provided to senators on Tuesday, Mr. Pruitt stressed his commitment to process, rule of law and the Constitution. \u201cE.P.A. will seek to improve its processes and reinvigorate the rule of law as it administers environmental regulations as Congress intended, and to refocus the agency on its core statutory obligations,\u201d he said. \u201cI am a firm believer that federal agencies exist to administer laws passed by Congress, as intended.\u201d\n\nThroughout the rest of Mr. Pruitt\u2019s Senate testimony, Republicans heaped praise on him while Democrats hammered him for his push to strip away regulations.\n\nSenator Tom Carper of Delaware, the ranking Democrat on the committee, said: \u201cMr. Pruitt, you often say that the rule of law matters. Well, Congress was very prescriptive when it wrote the Clean Air Act. The law sets timelines that E.P.A. must use to determine whether our country is meeting federal standards for harmful ozone pollution. But your E.P.A. has chosen to continuously ignore and delay that very specific mandate from Congress, which leaves downwind states and vulnerable communities at risk indefinitely.\u201d\n\nSenator John Barrasso, Republican of Wyoming, the chairman of the environment panel, applauded Mr. Pruitt\u2019s legal actions at the agency. \u201cDuring the last administration, E.P.A. administrators created broad and legally questionable new regulations that undermined the American people\u2019s faith in the agency,\u201d he said. \u201cThese regulations have done great damage to the livelihoods of our nation\u2019s hardest working citizens.\u201d\n\nOf Mr. Pruitt, Senator Barrasso said: \u201cHe has balanced the need to prioritize environmental protection with the desires of Americans to have thriving and economically sustainable communities. Tour\u2019s 2017 money list. Jessica claimed her own Australian Open crown in 2012, winning nearby at the Royal Melbourne Golf Club.\n\nPhoto\n\nJessica and Sebastian commemorated their victories here with their father\u2019s signature celebration: a jumping scissor kick.\n\nPetr Korda, speaking in a telephone interview from his home in Bradenton, Fla., said he had mixed feelings about his son following in his footsteps.\n\n\u201cWith Sebi, I\u2019m happy he\u2019s \u2014 to call it in the old way \u2014 in the \u2018family business,\u2019 \u201d said Petr Korda, whose wife, Regina Rajchrtova, was also a professional tennis player, reaching a career high of No. 26. \u201cBut it\u2019s difficult, so we\u2019re trying to make this life easier.\u201d\n\nPetr Korda believes his son\u2019s triumph on Saturday will help him establish his own identity.\n\n\u201cHim winning this junior Grand Slam, I\u2019m very happy because he won it as Sebastian Korda,\u201d the father said. \u201cBecause whenever he went to the tournament, they said, \u2018Oh, you\u2019re Petr Korda\u2019s son.\u2019 No, now he is Sebastian Korda.\u201d\n\nStill, Petr Korda believes it will be inevitable for his son to set his sights on bettering him and his career-high ranking of No. 2.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI also wanted to beat my dad on the tennis court; I wanted to show that I\u2019m the man,\u201d Petr Korda said. \u201cThat\u2019s the same thing Sebi has. Boyd, an assistant attorney general, warned in a letter last week to the committee\u2019s chairman, Representative Devin Nunes of California, that it would be \u201cextraordinarily reckless\u201d to release a memo drawing on classified information without official review and pleaded with the committee to consult the Justice Department. He said the department was \u201cunaware of any wrongdoing related to the FISA process.\u201d\n\nTo obtain the warrant involving Mr. Page, the government needed to show probable cause that he was acting as an agent of Russia. Once investigators get approval from the Justice Department for a warrant, prosecutors take it to a surveillance court judge, who decides whether to approve it.\n\nA Justice Department spokeswoman declined to comment, and a spokesman for Mr. Nunes did not reply to requests for comment. The people familiar with the contents of the memo spoke on the condition of anonymity because the details remained secret.\n\nA White House spokesman, Hogan Gidley, said in a statement: \u201cThe president has been clear publicly and privately that he wants absolute transparency throughout this process. Based on numerous news reports, top officials at the F.B.I. have engaged in conduct that shows bias against President Trump and bias for Hillary Clinton. While President Trump has the utmost respect and support for the rank-and-file members of the F.B.I., the anti-Trump bias at the top levels that appear to have existed is troubling.\u201d\n\nMr. Page, a former Moscow-based investment banker who later founded an investment company in New York, had been on the F.B.I.\u2019s radar for years. In 2013, an investigation revealed that a Russian spy had tried to recruit him. Mr. Page was never charged with any wrongdoing, and he denied that he would ever have cooperated with Russian intelligence officials.\n\nBut a trip Mr. Page took to Russia in July 2016 while working on Mr. Trump\u2019s campaign caught the bureau\u2019s attention again, and American law enforcement officials began conducting surveillance on him in the fall of 2016, shortly after he left the campaign.
