View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. Azar said repeatedly in recent weeks that \u201cdrug prices are too high,\u201d but he placed most of the responsibility on \u201ca system\u201d that encourages price increases. \u201cEveryone shares blame,\u201d he told the Senate health committee in November.\n\nSenator Debbie Stabenow, Democrat of Michigan, was frustrated. \u201cMr. Azar says he agrees that prices are too high, but he does not seem ready or willing to do much about it,\u201d she said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFrom 2012 to early 2017, Mr. Azar was the president of Lilly USA, a unit of Eli Lilly and Company, the global drug maker based in Indiana. Senator Ron Wyden of Oregon, the senior Democrat on the Finance Committee, said Mr. Azar told the panel that \u201che had never \u2014 not even one time \u2014 signed off on a decrease in the price of a medicine.\u201d\n\n\u201cOn Mr. Azar\u2019s watch,\u201d Mr. Wyden said, \u201cthe price of Forteo, a Lilly drug used to treat osteoporosis, more than doubled,\u201d as did the prices for Humalog, used to treat diabetes, and Strattera, for attention deficit hyperactivity disorder.\n\nSix Democratic senators and one independent joined 48 Republicans in voting for Mr. Azar. Opposing him were 41 Democrats, one Republican and one independent.\n\nThe Democrats who voted for Mr. Azar were Senators Thomas R. Carper and Chris Coons, both of Delaware, Joe Donnelly of Indiana, Heidi Heitkamp of North Dakota, Doug Jones of Alabama and Joe Manchin III of West Virginia. Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky was the only Republican to vote no. The independent senators split, with Angus King of Maine supporting Mr. Azar and Bernie Sanders of Vermont opposing him.\n\nMr. Hatch said Mr. Azar\u2019s experience as a drug company executive, far from creating a conflict of interest, was an asset. And he said he hoped Mr. Azar would undo many of the policies put in place because of \u201cpoor decisions made throughout the eight years of the Obama administration.\u201d\n\nMr. Azar will replace Tom Price, who resigned as health secretary in September, in the face of multiple federal inquiries into his use of private and government planes for travel.\n\nRepublicans tried unsuccessfully last year to roll back the expansion of Medicaid authorized by the Affordable Care Act. But the Trump administration is determined to make major changes in the program.\n\nMr. Azar told Congress that states should be allowed to impose work requirements on able-bodied Medicaid beneficiaries. \u201cOne of the best ways to improve the long-term health of low-income Americans is to empower them with skills and employment, for those who are able to work,\u201d Mr. Azar said.", "title": "Senate Confirms Trump Nominee Alex Azar as Health Secretary", "authors": ["Robert Pear"]} {"date": "2018-01-17 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 It was a made-for-TV moment, perfect for a presidential campaign advertisement.\n\nHis fists clenched and his voice rising, Senator Cory Booker, Democrat of New Jersey, delivered a 10-minute verbal thrashing to Homeland Security Secretary Kirstjen Nielsen this week, recalling his \u201ctears of rage\u201d when he learned that President Trump had used vulgarities to describe African nations.\n\nNot to be outdone, Senator Kamala Harris, Democrat of California, who was seated next to Mr. Booker, also skewered Ms. Nielsen, suggesting that Americans could draw a \u201creasonable inference\u201d that she is racist.\n\nThe next presidential election is nearly three years away, but in the Capitol the race is already unfolding, with no fewer than six senators \u2014 Mr. Booker and Ms. Harris, Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts, Bernie Sanders of Vermont, Kirsten E. Gillibrand of New York and Amy Klobuchar of Minnesota \u2014 eyeing the Democratic nomination in 2020, with each angling to get to the left of the others.\n\nThat is not making life easy for the 10 Democratic senators who must run for re-election this year in states carried by President Trump \u2014 so much so that one of them, Senator Claire McCaskill of Missouri, lamented openly in a recent interview that her colleagues running for president were \u201call trying to find their base.\u201d", "title": "Senate Democrats Make Hard Turn Left in Warming Up for 2020 Race", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-16 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nWASHINGTON \u2014 Senate Democrats announced on Tuesday that they were one supporter away from winning a vote to restore the so-called net neutrality rules that the Federal Communications Commission rolled back in December.\n\nBut even if Democrats win that vote, Democrats have a long ways to go before they are able to reinstate rules that prevent internet service providers from creating fast and slow lanes for online users. Here is a look at their difficult road ahead, and some of the motivations:\n\nWhat are the Senate Democrats doing?\n\nSenate Democrats said on Tuesday that all 49 members of their caucus had agreed to sign on to a resolution that would overturn the F.C.C. repeal of net neutrality rules. They are using a tool of the Senate, the Congressional Review Act, which requires a simple majority to overturn a recent order by a federal agency.\n\nThe Democrats also have the support of at least one Republican, Senator Susan Collins of Maine. So that leaves them searching for one more Republican to join their effort to get the necessary 51 votes.\n\n\u201cGiven how quickly we have gotten 50, we have a real chance of succeeding,\u201d Senator Chuck Schumer of New York, the minority leader, said in a statement.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIf this passes, are the rules automatically reinstated?\n\nNo. The House would have to pass a similar resolution, also using the Congressional Review Act, and the chances there are slim. Representative Mike Doyle, a Democrat from Pennsylvania, is leading the effort there and has 80 Democrats on board so far. But Speaker Paul D. Ryan, Republican of Wisconsin, could refuse to bring it to a vote. And 218 signatures would be needed to send it to the floor through a petition.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Interested in All Things Tech? Democrats have largely avoided the internal insurrections that upended Republicans over the past decade. Mr. Schumer is not a figure of derision on the left as Mr. McConnell is on the right.\n\nAnd Senate Democrats have crushed most primary election challenges easily. Senate leaders have intervened freely in a number of 2018 races \u2014 in states like Arizona and Tennessee \u2014 to anoint more moderate standard-bearers.\n\nFormer Senator Byron L. Dorgan, Democrat of North Dakota, said Democrats from the more rural states that make up much of the 2018 map would prefer to battle over issues other than immigration. The Obama-era program that protected young undocumented immigrants \u2014 Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals, or DACA \u2014 is an important issue, he said, but \u201cit isn\u2019t the bread and butter of successful Democrat politics.\u201d\n\n\u201cOur major issues are jobs, Medicare, Medicaid, CHIP, Social Security, infrastructure, supporting domestic programs, clean air, safe drinking water,\u201d Mr. Dorgan said, adding of his conservative-state brethren, \u201cWhile those Democrats do strongly support DACA, I\u2019m sure they would prefer to be discussing different issues.\u201d\n\nBut the patience of the left may be running thin. Many of the Democrats facing re-election in November hail from states that Mr. Trump carried and are more concerned about well-funded Republican opponents than liberal challengers.\n\nOf the 10 Democrats who gathered outside the Senate chamber after the vote to crow about their bipartisan agreement, six are on the ballot this year.\n\n\u201cIf you want results, you have to compromise, and if you\u2019re unwilling to compromise, you won\u2019t get results,\u201d said Senator Heidi Heitkamp, Democrat of North Dakota. \u201cYou maybe get a political issue, but you won\u2019t get results. And I didn\u2019t come here to do politics.\u201d\n\nProgressives, however, are already eyeing one of the Democrats who pushed for a compromise: Senator Amy Klobuchar of Minnesota. On a conference call convened Sunday night by liberal groups, there was notable anger toward Ms. Klobuchar, according to two participants.\n\nMs. Klobuchar, however, illustrates why the Democratic base may find it difficult to inflict payback: She is broadly popular with liberals in Minnesota, and the shutdown fight has come late enough in the congressional calendar to leave any would-be challenger with little time to prepare.\n\n\u201cI have been working hard for the people of Minnesota, and I think the people of Minnesota understand that, including in my party,\u201d Ms. Klobuchar said.", "title": "Senate Democrats\u2019 Vote to End Shutdown Infuriates Some on the Left", "authors": ["Jonathan Martin", "Alexander Burns"]} {"date": "2018-01-29 00:00:00", "text": "The Senate floor debate offered supporters and opponents of abortion rights an opportunity to speak expansively about Roe v. Wade, the landmark 1973 Supreme Court decision legalizing abortion \u2014 and they took it.\n\n\u201cForty-five years after Roe v. Wade, abortions are safer today than getting your tonsils out,\u201d declared Senator Elizabeth Warren, Democrat of Massachusetts. \u201cA lot of women are alive today because of Roe.\u201d She called the ban \u201cpart of a broad and sustained assault by Republican politicians on women\u2019s rights to make decisions about their own bodies.\u201d\n\nBut Senator Thom Tillis, Republican of North Carolina, said it was time for the Senate to act.\n\n\u201cThe life of the unborn is a precious life, and we as members of the United States Senate and the U.S. Congress are tasked with making sure we protect all lives in America,\u201d Mr. Tillis said, adding, \u201cThis is just a very important, precious, helpless part of the population.\u201d\n\nThe 20-week ban, named the Pain-Capable Unborn Child Protection Act, is central to the strategy of the anti-abortion movement, which is newly emboldened under Mr. Trump. The president\u2019s election in 2016 ushered in a wave of anti-abortion victories in states like Ohio, where lawmakers adopted a 20-week abortion ban in December of that year.\n\nAbortion foes say that if enough states pass such bans, Congress will be more likely to follow. They note that it took their movement 15 years to persuade Congress to outlaw the procedure that opponents call partial-birth abortion. They see the 20-week abortion ban on a similar trajectory.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cWe are building momentum for eventual federal legislation,\u201d said Mallory Quigley, a spokeswoman for Susan B. Anthony List, a group that works to elect anti-abortion candidates. She added, \u201cWe want to get vulnerable Democrats who are up for re-election this year on the record once again.\u201d\n\nAbortion rights advocates, meanwhile, say the opponents are badly misreading the political climate. In the era of the #MeToo movement, they say, Republicans will face a backlash for supporting a bill that prevents women from taking control of their own health care decisions.\n\n\u201cI think they fail to recognize the context of the moment and what they\u2019re contending with,\u201d said Ilyse Hogue, the president of NARAL Pro-Choice America, an abortion rights advocacy group. \u201cWe are seeing a rising up of women, unprecedented in my lifetime, and women who recognize that the role of abortion rights is so crucially important for women\u2019s health.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nJennifer Duffy, who tracks Senate races for the nonpartisan Cook Political Report, said vulnerable Republicans \u2014 she cited Dean Heller in Nevada \u2014 might have as much to lose in voting for the measure as vulnerable Democrats had in voting against it.\n\n\u201cSince when\u2019s the last time we saw a Democrat pay for what is essentially a pro-choice vote?\u201d Ms. Duffy asked. \u201cIt\u2019s been a long time.\u201d\n\nPolling by the Pew Research Center shows that backing for abortion is as high as it has been in two decade. As of 2017, 57 percent of Americans said abortion should be legal in all or most cases, while 40 percent said it should be illegal in all or most cases. But the issue animates social conservatives; 71 percent of conservative Republicans said abortion should be illegal in all or most cases, the Pew poll found.\n\nThe United States is one of just seven countries \u2014 including China and North Korea \u2014 that permit elective abortion after 20 weeks, a fact that backers of the failed measure brought up repeatedly on Monday.\n\n\u201cThe United States keeps the company of countries like China and North Korea. They deny unborn children the most basic of protections,\u2019\u2019 Senator Joni Ernst, Republican of Iowa, said on the Senate floor Monday. \u201cThis, folks, is not who we are as a nation.\u201d\n\nSupporters of the ban cite medical studies suggesting that fetuses can feel pain at 20 weeks. But the science surrounding fetal pain is complex. In a July 2013 memo, the American Congress of Obstetricians and Gynecologists wrote that \u201cthe fetus does not even have the physiological capacity to perceive pain until at least 24 weeks of gestation.\u201d", "title": "Senate Rejects Measure to Ban Abortion After 20 Weeks of Pregnancy", "authors": ["Sheryl Gay Stolberg"]} {"date": "2018-01-16 00:00:00", "text": "The vote was close, and was held open longer than expected at a 58-to-38 split while the holdouts fell under heavy lobbying by their colleagues. Ultimately, two more senators \u2014 John Kennedy, Republican of Louisiana, and Claire McCaskill, Democrat of Missouri \u2014 voted for the legislation, getting to the 60-vote threshold.\n\nThe vote was also closely watched because civil liberties-minded liberals have been pressuring Democrats to oppose the surveillance extension without the sort of changes the House rejected last week. Such pressure suggests that the vote could have political reverberations if progressive-leaning voters treat it as a litmus test in future contests like the 2020 Democratic presidential primaries.\n\nFirst enacted in 2008, the law codified a form of the N.S.A. warrantless surveillance program that the Bush administration secretly created after the Sept. 11 attacks. In 2012, Congress extended it for five years without changes. It is now up for renewal for the first time since the 2013 leaks by the former intelligence contractor Edward J. Snowden set off a broad debate about surveillance and privacy.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nBefore the vote, Mr. Wyden and Mr. Paul held a news conference with several other senators who argued that the bill as written was insufficient and who objected to a maneuver by the Senate majority leader, Mitch McConnell, Republican of Kentucky, to prevent lawmakers from getting a chance to vote on amendments to it.\n\nBut introducing the Senate session soon afterward, Mr. McConnell emphasized that the law did not permit warrantless collection targeting Americans or people known to be in the United States and urged his colleagues to permit a vote on the House bill without amendment.\n\n\u201cWith respect to foreigners on foreign soil, 702 gives the men and women who keep us safe a vital tool they need to fulfill their missions,\u201d Mr. McConnell said. \u201cFive years ago, Congress reauthorized the title with overwhelming bipartisan support. It\u2019s imperative that we do so once again.\u201d\n\nRepublicans who broke party ranks to oppose Mr. McConnell\u2019s effort to move forward on the bill without amendments included Ted Cruz of Texas, Steve Daines of Montana, Cory Gardner of Colorado, Dean Heller of Nevada, Mike Lee of Utah, Jerry Moran of Kansas, Lisa Murkowski of Alaska and Mr. Paul.\n\nDemocrats who supported Mr. McConnell\u2019s move included Tom Carper of Delaware, Bob Casey of Pennsylvania, Catherine Cortez Masto of Nevada, Joe Donnelly of Indiana, Tammy Duckworth of Illinois, Dianne Feinstein of California, Maggie Hassan of New Hampshire, Heidi Heitkamp of North Dakota, Doug Jones of Alabama, Amy Klobuchar of Minnesota, Joe Manchin of West Virginia, Ms. McCaskill, Bill Nelson of Florida, Gary Peters of Michigan, Jack Reed of Rhode Island, Jeanne Shaheen of New Hampshire, Mark Warner of Virginia and Sheldon Whitehouse of Rhode Island. Angus King, independent of Maine, also voted to move forward on the bill.\n\nComplicating matters, the bill contains a gesture toward creating a requirement that the authorities get a warrant for such surveillance when F.B.I. agents already have a criminal investigation open into an American with no national-security angle. Mr. Warner, who is the top Democrat on the Intelligence Committee, cited that provision as meaningful reform.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut critics noted that the provision is so narrowly written that it would not apply most of the time when government officials query Americans\u2019 private information, such as security-related searches by any agency, or F.B.I. searches when agents are pursuing ordinary criminal tips before opening a formal investigation. Leahy, Democrat of Vermont, told colleagues it was a \u201csham\u201d requirement.", "title": "Senate, Rebuffing Privacy Concerns, Clears Path to Extend Surveillance Law", "authors": ["Charlie Savage"]} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "With a few more Democrats than Republicans among its members and a goal of bringing more from each side into the mix, the group intends to show that it can produce critical mass behind new immigration legislation as well as demonstrate the power of bipartisanship.\n\n\u201cTwenty-five senators is a quarter of the Senate so that\u2019s a pretty powerful number of people who are able to make a difference with their votes and their voices,\u201d said Senator Susan Collins, the centrist Republican from Maine who led the effort to organize the group.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nFor all their good intentions, the senators are not going to have an easy time. The Senate has become mainly an arena for political warfare, allowing the parties to thrive on doing their best to sabotage each other\u2019s priorities. Breaking those entrenched habits will be difficult, if not impossible. Powerful forces will be aligned to prevent any immigration measure from even clearing the Senate so as to avoid putting pressure on the House and the White House to act.\n\nWhile Mr. Jones just arrived from Alabama, most of the others have been venting their frustrations over the polarized nature and inertia of the Senate. They share a desire to show that Congress can work if given the opportunity for free-flowing debate and contend that party divisions can be bridged.\n\n\u201cMaybe it\u2019s an alternative to some of the constant tribal warfare that goes on around here,\u201d said Senator Joe Donnelly of Indiana, another of the red-state Democrats in the group who will be fighting for re-election this year.\n\nTheir independent push to end the shutdown sprang out of a view that the two respective Senate leaders \u2014 Mitch McConnell, the Kentucky Republican, and Chuck Schumer, the New York Democrat \u2014 were locked in a partisan staredown that was leading nowhere.\n\nLeadership was just \u201c jousting back and forth,\u201d said Senator Joe Manchin III, the West Virginia Democrat who, along with Ms. Collins, played a primary role in assembling the group.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMembers of the coalition say the present Senate frequently operates too rigidly along party lines.\n\n\u201cMy critique of this place is that everything gets run by the caucuses,\u201d Mr. Kaine said, \u201cAnd of course I want the caucuses to be strong and I strongly support my caucus leader. But there\u2019s got to be some noncaucus space where people can work together, not just with folks in the same party.\u201d\n\nIn recent years under both Democratic and Republican rule, the Senate has been a constrained institution, with highly centralized decision making by leaderships that miserly limits amendments to prevent their members from having to take politically tough votes. With just a few exceptions, the major legislative packages that have reached the floor were the product of the majority and any fights were over Senate process rather than substantive policy.\n\nIt is a far cry from the Senate\u2019s storied image as the world\u2019s greatest deliberative body with full-throated give-and-take and rousing speeches that win over opponents.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cI\u2019ve been here since 2009 and I have never seen the kind of the glory days description,\u201d said Senator Mark Warner, Democrat of Virginia, one of many former governors who over the decades has found the chamber a stultifying place to serve.\n\nIn tackling immigration, the group is taking on an issue that for years has defied congressional solutions. Now the group is racing against two deadlines \u2014 Feb. 8, when the current stopgap spending bill expires, and March 5, the deadline set by President Trump to find a way to protect undocumented immigrants brought to the United States as children.\n\nBut members of the group, energized and empowered by their success in shutting down the shutdown, remain positive. They hope the process ends with legislation that could attract as many as 70 senators \u2014 the kind of bipartisan majority that would be difficult for either the president or the House to ignore.\n\nMr. McConnell reiterated again on Tuesday that as long as Democrats agreed to keep the government funded, he would allow a \u201cfair and open process\u201d meant to end with a new immigration measure.\n\n\u201cWhoever gets 60 votes wins,\u201d he said.\n\nThose engaged in the bipartisan effort say they realize the difficulties ahead but are eager to get started.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI\u2019m just glad to have the prospect of legislating again,\u201d said Senator Jeff Flake, Republican of Arizona. \u201cWe don\u2019t have a functioning body right now.\u201d\n\nWhile the possibility of a wide-open floor fight on immigration has no doubt made some senators nervous as they weighed the prospect of tricky votes, others have found it invigorating.\n\n\u201cNow comes the test \u2014 the real test \u2014 as to whether we can get this done \u2014 whether we can be the Senate again,\u201d said Senator Richard J. Durbin of Illinois, the No. 2 Senate Democrat, who will be working with the group, addressing his colleagues on the floor. \u201cFor some of you, it will be the first time you have ever seen it, but believe me, it is worth the price of admission, all it took for you to come to the U.S. Senate.\u201d\n\nIf successful, the bipartisan push could become a model for taking on stubborn issues in the future, one that engages a broader range of voices and ideas from both parties in the outcome. But if it fails, it could mean that intense partisanship has pushed the Senate into a place where even the most determined efforts cannot save it.", "title": "Senators Race to Protect Immigrants, and Restore Their Institution", "authors": ["Carl Hulse"]} {"date": "2018-01-15 00:00:00", "text": "The Hawaii emergency management employee who set off a statewide panic on Saturday morning by sending out a false alarm about an incoming ballistic missile has been temporarily reassigned, but there are no plans to fire him or identify him publicly, a state official said.\n\nThe employee, who has worked for the Hawaii Emergency Management Agency for 10 years, sent the missile alert to cellphones across the state by picking the wrong option on his computer for a routine drill, and then confirming his choice, according to Richard Rapoza, the agency\u2019s public information officer.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re not going to take action till we have all the facts,\u201d Mr. Rapoza said, adding that the employee has been temporarily reassigned to a part of the agency\u2019s emergency operations center where he does not have access to the warning system. Mr. Rapoza declined to describe the employee\u2019s new duties.\n\nDuring the 38 minutes it took the agency to send a corrective alert rescinding the warning on Saturday, residents and tourists in a state that was already on edge over escalating tensions between the United States and North Korea frantically said their goodbyes and took shelter. Fear turned to anger when the alert turned out to be a false alarm.", "title": "Sender of Hawaii\u2019s False Alarm Is Reassigned, but Not Named", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "While Twitter\u2019s stock price has fallen steadily over the last three years, in the last few months it has ticked upward. On Tuesday morning, after Mr. Noto\u2019s departure was announced, the company\u2019s shares fell nearly 4 percent before recovering some of the loss.\n\nTwitter said on Tuesday that other employees would assume Mr. Noto\u2019s responsibilities w while it looked for a replacement.\n\nOn Twitter on Tuesday morning, Mr. Dorsey wrote, \u201cI\u2019m really sad to see @anthonynoto leave us, but I\u2019m happy for him and really proud of everything he\u2019s accomplished at Twitter.\u201d\n\nAt SoFi, Mr. Noto will be responsible for trying to steady a company that was thrown into turmoil by Mr. Cagney\u2019s departure.\n\nAfter cofounding SoFi in 2011, Mr. Cagney turned it into one of the few breakout stars among the thousands of so-called fintech start-ups trying to disrupt the financial industry.\n\nSoFi began by refinancing the loans of elite students, but the company then expanded into personal loans, insurance and wealth management, and was making several moves to turn into more of a full-service bank.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAfter Mr. Cagney\u2019s departure, though, SoFi significantly trimmed its ambitions, pulling back its application to get a bank charter.\n\nMr. Noto suggested on Tuesday that he planned to pick up where Mr. Cagney had left off.\n\n\u201cSoFi has a significant opportunity to build on its leadership position in student and personal loans to revolutionize consumer finance and build a next-generation financial services company,\u201d Mr. Noto said in a news release.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Noto will also need to find replacements for several top executives who left around the same time that Mr. Cagney did, including the company\u2019s chief financial officer and chief technology officer.\n\nMr. Noto\u2019s new job, which will start on March 1, could put him into competition with his old boss, Mr. Dorsey. Mr. Dorsey\u2019s second company, Square, has recently been making moves to become more of a consumer bank, as SoFi had looked to do under Mr. Cagney.\n\nSince Mr. Cagney\u2019s departure, SoFi has been led by the chairman of its board, Tom Hutton. Mr. Hutton will return to his former role.\n\n\u201cWe are simply thrilled to have found someone of Anthony\u2019s expertise and knowledge to lead SoFi,\u201d Mr. Hutton said in a news release. \u201cThe SoFi board unanimously agrees that Anthony\u2019s deep understanding of technology, consumer and financial businesses make him the perfect fit to be SoFi\u2019s C.E.O.\u201d\n\nMr. Cagney was one of the highest-profile executives in Silicon Valley to be felled by the wave of sexual harassment claims that have swept corporate America over the last year.\n\nSoFi employees said the inappropriately sexualized atmosphere of the company ran deep and extended to the company\u2019s satellite offices.\n\nUnlike some other executives, Mr. Cagney did not acknowledge that the claims against him were true, though he did announce the start of an internal investigation before his departure.\n\nSoFi has not yet made public the findings of that investigation. The company\u2019s chief human resources officer, Jing Liao, announced in December that SoFi was creating two working groups to improve the company\u2019s culture and its approach to inclusion and diversity.", "title": "Senior Twitter Executive to Run Troubled Finance Start-Up SoFi", "authors": ["Nathaniel Popper", "Chad Bray"]} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "That\u2019s a start, but it\u2019s not enough. The United States Olympic Committee said it is considering decertifying U.S.A. Gymnastics, but the Olympic committee was also slow to act in the Nassar case. What changes will it implement to ensure that such widespread harm to American athletes doesn\u2019t happen under its watch again?\n\nThe resignation on Wednesday of Lou Anna Simon, the president of Michigan State, where Dr. Nassar\u2019s medical practice was based, was overdue. Though Michigan State has denied covering up Dr. Nassar\u2019s crimes, reporting by The Detroit News found that 14 university officials were told of Dr. Nassar\u2019s sexual misconduct in the two decades before he was arrested, and that at least eight women had reported his actions. Michigan State continued to allow Dr. Nassar to see patients for 16 months while he was under criminal investigation after a 2014 allegation of sexual assault by a patient.\n\nThe athletic trainers, assistant coaches, university police officers and other school officials who let Dr. Nassar\u2019s abuse go on should also step down. The N.C.A.A., which is investigating the matter, should consider sanctions against Michigan State, including banning it from postseason play for some period, as it did Penn State\u2019s football program after the former assistant coach Jerry Sandusky was convicted of molesting children over a period of 15 years.\n\nIn all these instances, including cases detailed by Harper\u2019s Magazine in an article on competitive swimming and other sports, athletic glory, or the glow reflected onto those surrounding and enriching themselves from young athletes, blinded adults to their real responsibilities.\n\nProtecting the image of the Olympic team, a gymnastics program and a university seems to have meant more to these adults than protecting children. In the end they protected nothing and no one and ruined their own reputations as well.", "title": "Opinion | Sentencing Larry Nassar Is Only a Start", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-29 00:00:00", "text": "She has still been present on tour to a degree.\n\n\u201cShe\u2019s been the best female tennis player ever and of course everybody\u2019s speaking about her even when she is not here,\u201d said Wim Fissette, who coaches Angelique Kerber.\n\nWith social media, Williams can be as much a part of the daily conversation at a tournament as she likes, and she weighed in on occasion during the Australian Open.\n\nShe congratulated her friend Caroline Wozniacki for winning her first Grand Slam title and, earlier, she called out Tennys Sandgren, the surprise men\u2019s quarterfinalist from the United States, for past comments he had made on his own social media accounts. Sandgren\u2019s Twitter activity \u2014 since deleted \u2014 included exchanges with figures from what is known as the alt-right, a far-right, white nationalist movement; a post saying his eyes were \u201cbleeding\u201d after a visit to a gay club; and a post apparently critical of Williams that used the term \u201cdisgusting\u201d and may have been referring to her screaming on court.\n\nWilliams, increasingly activist in her public statements in recent years, will soon be a physical presence on tour again, not just a virtual one. Her only competition appearance in the last year was a lucrative, one-match exhibition in Abu Dhabi in late December, which she lost to Jelena Ostapenko.\n\nIt is quite a juxtaposition: Federer, the biggest star in men\u2019s tennis, taking a break while Williams, the biggest star in women\u2019s tennis, returns to action. But it underscores how complementary the men\u2019s and women\u2019s games can be, a symbiotic relationship that remains one of the sport\u2019s core strengths. Though there are distinctions, men\u2019s tennis and women\u2019s tennis are viewed as the same product by many who tune in only during the year\u2019s biggest tournaments.", "title": "Serena Williams Is Set to Reclaim Her Leading Role in Tennis", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cI don\u2019t know if I am totally ready to come back on the tour yet,\u201d she told reporters after that match. \u201cI know that when I come back I definitely want to be competing for championships.\u201d\n\nIn addition to next month\u2019s Fed Cup, she has agreed to play in an exhibition tournament at Madison Square Garden on March 5, and she has stated her desire to play the WTA tournament in Indian Wells, Calif., later that month.\n\nWith 23 Grand Slam titles, Williams is one away from matching Margaret Court\u2019s career record, and could compete for that as soon as the French Open, which begins May 27.\n\nWilliams has also played in four Olympic Games: in 2000, 2008, 2012 and 2016. In order to be eligible for the Olympics, players must make themselves available to for their Fed Cup team in two of the years leading up to the games. To qualify for the 2020 Olympic Games, Williams would also need to play on, or make herself available for, the 2019 Fed Cup.\n\nAlong with the Williams sisters, the U.S.T.A. announced that CoCo Vandeweghe would be on the United States squad, which won the Fed Cup last year for the first time since 2000. She has since returned to the practice court and played \u2014 and lost \u2014 a big-payday exhibition match in Abu Dhabi against Jelena Ostapenko, last Saturday.\n\n\u201cAfter performing in my first match after giving birth I realized that, although I am super close, I\u2019m not where I personally want to be,\u201d Williams said on Thursday in a statement that was first posted to Snapchat. \u201cMy coach and team always said, \u2018Only go to tournaments when you are prepared to go all the way.\u2019\u201d", "title": "Serena Williams Withdraws From Australian Open", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "The Tie Break Tens, which borrows from the faster-paced concepts being used in sports like Twenty20 cricket and Rugby Sevens, pits eight players in a knockout format. The contestants play a 10-point tiebreaker, and the winner advances to the next round.\n\nThe event takes roughly three hours, and the champion gets all $250,000.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s very ruthless,\u201d Barnard said in a telephone interview from Australia. \u201cIt\u2019s so quick and dynamic that it really keeps people on their toes.\u201d\n\nThere have been four previous Tie Break Tens events, including one recently in Melbourne, Australia, in which Tomas Berdych vanquished a field that included Rafael Nadal and Novak Djokovic.\n\nThe organizers say they will promote the New York event in conjunction with International Women\u2019s Day on March 8.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Williams said in the Vogue interview that she intended to play there, too.\n\nShe also expressed her dedication to winning more Grand Slam events and eventually surpassing Margaret Court\u2019s record of 24 major titles.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m well aware of the record books, unfortunately,\u201d she told Vogue. \u201cIt\u2019s not a secret that I have my sights on 25.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nShe described the severe medical complications she suffered after giving birth. Her daughter was born by an emergency cesarean section operation after the baby\u2019s heart rate decreased to dangerous levels during contractions.\n\nBut the next day, Williams said, several small blood clots were discovered in her lungs. She has a history of pulmonary embolisms, and her anticoagulant regimen had to be stopped after the surgery, the article said, and that led to the clots.\n\nLater, the wound from the operation opened up because of the severe coughing caused by the pulmonary embolism, and according to Vogue, Williams needed another operation when it was discovered that she had a large hematoma in her abdomen, caused by the blood-thinning medication.\n\nWilliams then had another procedure in which a filter was inserted into a major vein to prevent clots from settling into her lungs, and she had to stay in bed for six weeks after giving birth.", "title": "Serena Williams to Play at Madison Square Garden in March", "authors": ["David Waldstein"]} {"date": "2018-01-22 00:00:00", "text": "At the Little One, buckwheat ice cream is sandwiched between monaka cookies.\n\nCredit Jeenah Moon for The New York Times", "title": "Serenity and Ice Cream Sandwiches at the Little One", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "In remarks to the media in the Oval Office on Tuesday, Mr. Trump said he was not troubled that Mr. Sessions met with the special counsel and he denied a report that Mr. Wray had threatened to resign.\n\n\u201cHe didn\u2019t at all,\u201d Mr. Trump said of Mr. Wray, adding: \u201cHe did not even a little bit. Nope. He\u2019s going to do a good job.\u201d\n\nThe report, by the website Axios, said Mr. Sessions was pressuring Mr. Wray, at the president\u2019s behest, to clear the F.B.I. of loyalists to Mr. Comey. But Mr. Wray responded that he needed to move at his own pace to make changes, and that if Mr. Sessions and the president wanted replacements made more quickly, someone else would have to do it, a person familiar with the exchange said, adding that Mr. Wray stopped short of threatening to quit.\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Wray\u2019s tenure has been tense as the president has repeatedly fanned suspicion about whether the F.B.I.\u2019s work is politically motivated, including the Russia investigation.\n\nMr. Trump and his allies have focused their ire on Andrew G. McCabe, the bureau\u2019s deputy director. Mr. McCabe\u2019s wife was a Virginia State Senate candidate in 2015, and she received donations from the \u201csuper PAC\u201d supporting the state\u2019s governor at the time, Terry McAuliffe, a longtime ally of Hillary Clinton\u2019s.\n\nOne person familiar with Mr. McCabe\u2019s meetings with the president said there had been a small handful of encounters between the two the week Mr. Comey was fired, as Mr. Trump was deciding whether to name Mr. McCabe the acting director.\n\nAt one of the meetings, another person said that Mr. Trump asked Mr. McCabe who he had voted for in the 2016 presidential election. Mr. McCabe said he had not voted. The meeting was first reported by The Washington Post.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAt their final meeting, Mr. Trump offered him the job and told him he planned to give him the role of acting director, and that the president planned to make a rally-the-troops appearance at the F.B.I. Headquarters that week. Mr. McCabe responded that it would be a risky move for the president to show up at the building after firing a well-respected director, so Mr. Trump scuttled the trip, citing scheduling conflicts.\n\nThough Mr. Wray has resisted the pressure to change Mr. McCabe\u2019s role, he has begun to alter the F.B.I.\u2019s leadership. He removed James Baker, the general counsel for the bureau under Mr. Comey, and replaced him with Dana Boente, the United States attorney for the Eastern District of Virginia and the acting head of the Justice Department\u2019s national security division, according to a person familiar with the move.\n\nMr. Wray also said in a statement on Tuesday that he has replaced his departing chief of staff, James Rybicki, who served under Mr. Comey, with Zachary Harmon, whom Mr. Wray worked with in private practice and who previously served at the Justice Department.\n\nDuring the daily White House news briefing, the press secretary, Sarah Huckabee Sanders, insisted that the president has \u201c100 percent\u201d confidence in Mr. Wray and that it was up to Mr. Wray to decide how to handle the bureau\u2019s leadership.\n\nA Justice Department spokeswoman, Sarah Isgur Flores, confirmed that the interview with Mr. Sessions occurred. He was accompanied to the interview by the longtime Washington lawyer Chuck Cooper.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Breaking News Emails Get the latest on the special counsel investigation \u2014 and other major news \u2014 delivered to your email inbox. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nFor Mr. Mueller, Mr. Sessions is a key witness to two of the major issues he is investigating: the Trump campaign\u2019s possible ties to the Russians and whether Mr. Trump tried to obstruct the Russia investigation.\n\nMr. Mueller can question Mr. Sessions about his role as the head of the campaign\u2019s foreign policy team. Mr. Sessions was involved in developing Mr. Trump\u2019s position toward Russia and he met with Russian officials, including the ambassador.\n\nAlong with Mr. Trump, Mr. Sessions led a March 2016 meeting where one of the campaign\u2019s foreign policy advisers, George Papadopoulos, pitched the idea of a personal meeting between Mr. Trump and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia. Mr. Papadopoulos pleaded guilty in October to lying to federal authorities about the nature of his contacts with Russians and agreed to cooperate with the special counsel\u2019s inquiry.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhen Mr. Trump learned in March that Mr. Sessions, by then the attorney general, was considering whether to recuse himself from overseeing the Russia investigation, the president had the White House\u2019s top lawyer, Donald F. McGahn II, lobby Mr. Sessions to remain in charge of the inquiry.\n\nMr. Sessions instead followed the guidance of career prosecutors at the Justice Department, who advised him that he should stay out of the investigation. When Mr. Trump was informed, the president erupted in anger, saying he needed an attorney general to protect him.\n\nThe special counsel\u2019s investigators have also asked witnesses about the president\u2019s desires to fire Mr. Sessions, whom Mr. Trump has criticized publicly and privately for recusing himself from the inquiry, though he has left Mr. Sessions in charge of the Justice Department.\n\nMr. Trump believes Mr. Mueller would never have been appointed if Mr. Sessions had not stepped aside. After Mr. Mueller was appointed in May, Mr. Trump again grew angry at Mr. Sessions, who offered to resign. Days later, Mr. Trump rejected that offer.\n\nThe questions that Mr. Mueller\u2019s investigators have asked in relation to Mr. Comey were based in part on information he provided during his own interviews with the special counsel\u2019s office last year, according to people familiar with the matter. Here\u2019s what you need to know about the revelations of major security flaws in the chips that run most of the world\u2019s computers.\n\nThe flaws, called Meltdown and Spectre, could allow hackers to lift passwords, photos, documents and other data from smartphones, PCs and cloud computing services.\n\nYep, it\u2019s terrifying, and it affects Apple products, too. Experts say there\u2019s no way to replace all the chips out there, and the best defense is to keep your software updated.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n_____\n\nPhoto\n\n5. Our Tokyo bureau chief went to the Japanese primeval forest that was in the news this week because a YouTube star, Logan Paul, posted a video of a body hanging from a tree there.\n\nAokigahara Forest has a grim reputation as one of Japan\u2019s top suicide destinations, but locals are trying to save lives there. Signs for hotline numbers line the footpaths, and residents patrol the forest, talking to people who appear at risk.\n\nOfficials believe such measures have helped reduce the number of suicides to about 30 a year, down from 100 a decade ago. But they worry that the fresh publicity could attract more of the hopeless.\n\n_____\n\nPhoto\n\n6. The latest jobs report showed the U.S. added 148,000 new jobs in December, making it the 87th consecutive month of job growth. And the unemployment rate was unchanged from November, at 4.1 percent.\n\nSome of the most impressive gains were in blue-collar industries that pay a decent salary, while wages increased the most for people in lower-paying industries. Above, construction workers in Cincinnati.\n\nMarket Snapshot View Full Overview\n\n_____\n\nPhoto\n\n7. Seth Meyers, who will host the Golden Globe Awards for the first time on Sunday, has a tough task: celebrating the television industry while referencing its sexual harassment crisis.\n\nThe women attending the awards have been asked to wear black in solidarity with the #MeToo movement. Jodi Kantor, one of our reporters who broke the Harvey Weinstein story, asks if the red carpet will ever be the same. Above, a red-carpet scene at the Oscars.\n\n_____\n\nPhoto\n\n8. We talked to the actor Daniel Kaluuya, who is up for a Golden Globe for his starring role in \u201cGet Out!\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe 28-year-old grew up in a council estate, the British equivalent of a housing project, in north London. He discussed the impact that improv classes had on him when he was growing up.\n\n\u201cBeing young, working class and black, everything you do is policed,\u201d he said. \u201cIf someone hits you and you hit back, you are aggressive. If you cry, you are weak. You are kind of always pretending to be something. But in those improv classes, there was no pressure to be anything except honest, and that made me happy.\u201d\n\n_____\n\nPhoto\n\n9. Meet Yuzuru Hanyu of Japan, the reigning men\u2019s Olympic figure skating champion and perhaps the greatest skater of any era. Our sportswriter says he\u2019s Michael Jackson on ice, with obsessive fans to boot. Many carry Winnie the Pooh trinkets, in honor of the mascot he keeps rinkside.\n\n\u201cPeople see Hanyu for the first time and they become hysterical or they\u2019re moved to tears,\u201d one blogger explained. \u201cIt\u2019s like their lives are complete.\u201d\n\nHanyu is recovering from an ankle injury, and it\u2019s not clear whether he\u2019ll be able to compete at the Winter Olympics next month. If he does, he could become the first repeat men\u2019s champion since Dick Button of the U.S. in 1948 and 1952.\n\n_____\n\nPhoto\n\n10. Here\u2019s some of the best writing from across the political spectrum on the shutdown.\n\n____\n\nPhoto\n\n3. An earthquake in the middle of the night prompted a tsunami alert for Alaska, British Columbia and Washington State, as well as a tsunami watch all the way down to the border of Mexico and even Hawaii. Luckily, there was no major tsunami or damage.\n\n\u201cWe live in a very prone earthquake and tsunami area, and it\u2019s a beautiful place, but that\u2019s what you have when you live in paradise,\u201d the mayor of Kodiak, Alaska, said at a 4:30 a.m. news conference. Above, evacuees at the local high school.\n\n____\n\nPhoto\n\n4. Vice President Mike Pence was in Jerusalem, where he visited the Western Wall, above. No target thwarted, vexed and bedeviled the Israeli intelligence services more than Mr. Arafat, who died in 2004.\n\n____\n\nPhoto\n\n5. At least two students were killed and 17 other people were injured in a shooting at a high school in Benton, Ky.\n\nThe authorities said the gunman was a 15-year-old student at the school. He was taken into custody. The students killed, a boy and a girl, were also 15.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAbove, parents picked up their children after the episode. It was the second school shooting in the U.S. this week.\n\n____\n\nPhoto\n\n6. A new report found that e-cigarettes that contain nicotine can be addictive \u2014 and that teenagers who use the devices may be at higher risk of smoking regular cigarettes.\n\nIt\u2019s the most comprehensive analysis of existing research on e-cigarettes to date, and it cited conclusive proof that the devices are safer than traditional smoking products and may help smokers quit.\n\nBut it stopped short of declaring e-cigarettes are safe, noting that there were no long-term scientific studies of the devices\u2019 addictive potential or health effects. Above, vaping in London.\n\n____\n\nPhoto\n\n7. New U.S. tariffs are taking direct aim at Chinese solar panels and South Korean washing machines. But the effects will be felt in multiple countries, illustrating the difficulty of targeting specific industries in the complex world of global trade. (Above, a solar panel factory in China.)\n\nPresident Trump is set to speak to world leaders gathered this week at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, and he could drop hints of whether more trade barriers are to come. You can find all of our Davos coverage here.\n\n____\n\nPhoto\n\n8. \u201cThe military has not yet come up with fiber as strong as you.\u201d\n\nThat was Judge Rosemarie Aquilina, speaking to one of the nearly 140 victims who have testified at the sentencing hearing of Dr. Larry Nassar, the former U.S.A. Gymnastics team doctor who pleaded guilty to sex crimes.\n\nJudge Aquilina has emerged as an unusually fierce advocate for the victims, who include several prominent Olympic gymnasts. Originally, 88 of them had planned to speak; that number grew to 158 as the courtroom was transformed into a cathartic forum.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n____\n\nPhoto\n\n9. (Representatives for the Hollywood Foreign Press Association and the Golden Globe Awards did not respond to requests for comment.)\n\nMore seriously, Mr. Meyers said that after a 2017 in which \u201cit\u2019s safe to say Hollywood has been tipped on its side,\u201d his initial reaction was, \u201cOh, this seems to have such a high level of difficulty this year.\u201d", "title": "Seth Meyers Is Ready for the Golden Globes.
