Let us know: thearts@nytimes.com.\n\n\u2018Dreamers\u2019 Deal-Making\n\nSenator Mitch McConnell, the majority leader, promised he would bring a vote to the floor next month on a bill to let the young immigrants called Dreamers stay in the United States legally. It was all part of a deal to keep the government open. Senator Chuck Schumer, the minority leader, said he would hold Mr. McConnell accountable, but Seth Meyers has his doubts.", "title": "Seth Meyers Skewers Chuck Schumer Over \u2018Dreamers\u2019 Negotiations", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-07 00:00:00", "text": "Here is his full opening monologue:\n\nFor the male nominees in the room tonight, this is the first time in three months it won\u2019t be terrifying to hear your name read out loud. \u201cDid you hear about Willem Dafoe?\u201d \u201cOh, God, no!\u201d \u201cHe was nominated.\u201d \u201cDon\u2019t do that! Don\u2019t do that.\u201d\n\nThis was the year of big little lies and get out \u2014 and also the television series \u2018Big Little Lies\u2019 and the movie \u2018Get Out.\u2019 There\u2019s a new era underway, and I can tell because it\u2019s been years since a white man was this nervous in Hollywood. By the way, a special hello to hosts of other upcoming awards shows who are watching me tonight like the first dog they shot into outer space.\n\nGood evening, ladies and remaining gentlemen. I\u2019m Seth Meyers, and I\u2019ll be your host tonight. Welcome to the 75th annual Golden Globes. And Happy New Year, Hollywood! It\u2019s 2018, marijuana is finally allowed and sexual harassment finally isn\u2019t. It\u2019s gonna be a good year!\n\nConsidering what has been going on this year with powerful men and their terrible behavior in Hollywood, a lot of people thought it would be more appropriate for a woman to host these awards, and they may be right. But if it\u2019s any consolation, I\u2019m a man with absolutely no power in Hollywood. I\u2019m not even the most powerful Seth in the room tonight. [points to Seth Rogen] Hey, remember when he was the guy making trouble with North Korea? Simpler times.\n\nThey tried to get a woman to host this show, they really did. They said, \u201cHey, how would you like to come and be judged by some of the most powerful people in Hollywood?\u201d And women were like, \u201cHmm, well, where is it?\u201d And they said, \u201cIt\u2019s at a hotel,\u201d and long story short, I\u2019m your host tonight.\n\nAnd we\u2019re all here tonight courtesy of the Hollywood Foreign Press. Yeah, give it up for the Hollywood Foreign Press. A string of three words that could not have been better designed to infuriate our president. \u201cHollywood foreign press.\u201d The only name that could make him angrier would be the Hillary Mexico Salad Association.\n\nWell, I think it\u2019s time to address the elephant not in the room. Harvey Weinstein isn\u2019t here tonight. Because, well, I\u2019ve heard rumors that he\u2019s crazy and difficult to work with. But don\u2019t worry, he\u2019ll be back in 20 years when he becomes the first person ever booed during the \u201cIn Memoriam.\u201d [oohs] It\u2019ll sound like that.\n\nWell, despite everything that happened this year, the show goes on. For example, I was happy to hear they\u2019re going to do another season of \u201cHouse of Cards.\u201d Is Christopher Plummer available for that, too? I hope he can do a Southern accent, \u2019cause Kevin Spacey sure couldn\u2019t. Oh, is that too mean? To Kevin Spacey?\n\nDaniel Kaluuya is nominated for best actor for his work in \u201cGet Out.\u201d Daniel plays a young man lured to an event full of aging white people desperate to reclaim their youth, [looking around] and \u2014 oh, my God, Daniel, it\u2019s a trap! Get out!\n\n\u201cGet Out\u201d was a great film to see in a theater, and also a great way to tell if your date was a racist. If you walked out after that movie and your date said, \u201cIt was so sad when they hit that deer,\u201d they\u2019re a racist. You went to a movie with a racist.\n\n\u201cThe Shape of Water\u201d received the most nominations of any film this year. Just an incredibly beautiful film, but I have to admit, when I first heard about a film where a na\u00efve young woman falls in love with a disgusting sea monster, I thought, \u201cOh man, not another Woody Allen movie.\u201d It\u2019s like \u201cManhattan\u201d in water.\n\n\u201cThe Post\u201d is nominated for best picture tonight. \u201cThe Post\u201d is a film about journalistic integrity, directed by Steven Spielberg and starring Tom Hanks and Meryl Streep \u2014 [staff member comes onstage carrying a heap of awards] no, not yet, we have to wait. We have to wait and see what happens.\n\nThere was some great television nominated this year, too. We had another fantastic season of \u201cStranger Things.\u201d \u201cStranger Things\u201d reminded me so much of my childhood. Not the sci-fi stuff, and I didn\u2019t really have any friends. I don\u2019t know how to ride a bike. Basically just the part where a guy from RadioShack dated my mom.\n\n\u201cSesame Street\u201d recently released a parody of \u201cStranger Things\u201d titled \u201cSharing Things.\u201d Meanwhile, Bert and Ernie have been doing a parody of \u201cCall Me by Your Name\u201d for years.\n\nI live in New York, so one of my favorite shows of the year was \u201cThe Deuce.\u201d If you haven\u2019t seen it, \u201cThe Deuce\u201d is a show about Times Square in the early \u201970s, when New York was so seedy there were two James Francos.\n\nOprah Winfrey is receiving the Cecil B. DeMille Award tonight. What a tremendous honor, for Cecil B. DeMille. And Oprah, while I have you, in 2011 I told some jokes about our current president at the White House Correspondents\u2019 Dinner \u2014 jokes about how he was unqualified to be president \u2014 and some have said that night convinced him to run. So if that\u2019s true, I just want to say: Oprah, you will never be president! You do not have what it takes! And Hanks! Where is Hanks? You will never be vice president! You are too mean and unrelatable. Now we just wait and see.", "title": "Seth Meyers\u2019s Golden Globes Opening Monologue: Transcript", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nMichael Minnillo, the general manager of the French Laundry, the chef Thomas Keller\u2019s elegant restaurant in Yountville, Calif., had just sabered open a bottle of Dom P\u00e9rignon, leaving the eyes of the teenagers wide. This was a celebratory meal for two of them, who had spent the semester at a nearby art school, a rare splurge to commemorate their studies and a chance to show family and friends what it is the old man does for a living, snooping around restaurants, considering the delicious.\n\nA server glided past Minnillo to place some glistening wafer sandwiches on the white-clothed table. \u201cThese are Ritz crackers, essentially,\u201d he said as Minnillo poured Champagne for the adults. \u201cWith caramelized shallots.\u201d They shatter-melted into our mouths, salty against the intense allium sweetness of shallots enhanced by Cheddar and cr\u00e8me fra\u00eeche. Eyes went wider. No one in our party of five had been expecting what were essentially grandma canap\u00e9s here at one of the most formal and inventive restaurants in the United States, and no one, least of all the teenagers, had been prepared for the experience of eating one. There was silence at the table as we ate, followed by laughter. My eldest looked at me and said, \u201cI think this meal is going to be fun.\u201d\n\nAnd it was. We had little cups of cr\u00e8me de champignons that bolstered feelings of home \u2014 \u201cOur version of Campbell\u2019s cream-of-mushroom soup,\u201d the server said \u2014 and tiny ice cream cones of fluke tartare and cr\u00e8me fra\u00eeche that did not. There was the restaurant\u2019s famous dish of oysters and caviar in a tapioca sabayon, as well as nuggets of king-crab tempura; delicate roulades of Dover sole; poached eggs with celery-root pur\u00e9e and soubise served below shaved white truffles. We ate Parker House rolls with sweet butter and a choice of salts, and duck with collard greens and beautiful sweet carrots. There was charcoal-grilled Wagyu beef and bordelaise sauce; then goug\u00e8res with more truffles and on to dessert: 18 courses of food in all, not counting those delicate little crackers that started the meal.\n\nBut it was the crackers that stuck with us longest, that we talked about, again and again, in the days following the meal. It is a condition of my employment that when a dish does that, I try to make it at home. And so on a recent evening, I caramelized shallots and mixed them with the cheese and cr\u00e8me fra\u00eeche, a splash of sherry vinegar, a dash of hot sauce, then spread them onto actual Ritz crackers and heated the resulting sandwiches in the oven before painting them with melted butter and preparing for transportation back to Napa County in our minds.\n\nPhoto\n\nAnd they were pretty good! But making home-cooked food into restaurant food and then returning it to the home turns out to be more of an equation than a conjuring spell. After all, magic in the world of food is often situational. So while we\u2019ll always remember those crackers at the French Laundry, what we\u2019ll remember about making them at home is the dinner that followed: a simple sausage risotto that, in its way, offered the same transporting delight of our meal at the restaurant. It is a dish that you really ought to try yourself, on one of these dark winter nights when all anyone wants to do is stand around the stove, stirring and talking, waiting to eat.\n\nThe recipe was, after a fashion, my youngest daughter\u2019s. A friend from school made her the dish a few weeks earlier, and she wanted me to make it for her myself, off her memory of the meal. And so I stood at her side, asking questions, taking direction, stirring onions and Arborio rice together with butter until they were translucent, then adding strong chicken stock to the mixture slowly, serially, with endless stirs of a wooden spoon, until the risotto achieved that melting tender consistency the Italians call all\u2019onda, or wavy. We folded grated Parmesan into the pot and topped the whole thing with crisp, crumbled sweet sausage, a drift of parsley and a squeeze of lemon juice against the heft. The result was as incredible as anything a restaurant can provide. There was that silence again while we ate, before the old familiar laughter pealed.\n\nRecipe: Risotto With Sausage and Parsley", "title": "Settle In for Winter With This Sausage Risotto", "authors": ["Sam Sifton"]} {"date": "2018-01-02 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nWEDNESDAY PUZZLE \u2014 What is Bruce Haight saying to us? That we eat too much? That we can\u2019t control our appetites and cannot touch our TOES? Is this my guilty conscience talking to me after a week of sailing on the Queen Mary 2 and enjoying her largess?\n\nProbably the latter. But you won\u2019t leave this midweek puzzle feeling at all peckish, I promise.\n\nToday\u2019s Theme\n\nMr. Haight offers us an eclectic but full meal, based on food puns on common phrases.\n\nFor example, the phrase \u201cIt\u2019s not your problem\u201d gets turned into the appetizer course IT\u2019S NACHO PROBLEM, followed by LET\u2019S TACO \u2019BOUT IT and YA WANNA PIZZA ME as entrees. Dessert follows with I CANNOLI IMAGINE, which you should definitely take to go.\n\nTricky Clues\n\n1A: We need to work off what we\u2019re about to consume. Fortunately, Mr. Haight was kind enough to turn up the heat right out of the box and make us work it off with some Fosse choreography from \u201cAll That JAZZ\u201d in \u201cChicago\u201d:\n\n13A: ALEE is one of those words that can be considered crosswordese, unless, of course, you are a sailor. Most of us, however, really see the word only in crossword puzzles. It means standing on the side of a boat that is out of the wind. If you\u2019d like to see how well you know your crosswordese, try this crosswordese quiz from our \u201cHow to Solve The New York Times Crossword.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n22A: Tricky one! This isn\u2019t ammunition we\u2019re talking about here. \u201cFollower of a bullet\u201d refers to a bullet point in a document, and the answer is ITEM.", "title": "Settle This Dispute", "authors": ["Deb Amlen"]} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "Now Booking, in Los Angeles\n\nLast week, New York City\u2019s \u200bNoMad Hotel went west, opening a 241-room outpost in downtown Los Angeles. For the interiors of the 1920s neo-Classical building, formerly known as Giannini Place, the Sydell Group again tapped the French architect Jacques Garcia, who looked to his own light-filled \u200bvilla in Sicily. \u200bIn the lobby, beneath a 20-foot restored coffered ceiling, potted palm trees and birds of paradise sit alongside jade green velvet drapes by Nina Campbell and floral couches by Matthew Williamson. There\u2019s also an espresso bar modeled after Venice\u2019s Caff\u00e8 Florian. At night, it switches from coffee to cocktails \u2014 try the Martini, made with cocoa-nib infused cognac, Kahl\u00faa, cold brew and cr\u00e8me de cacao.\n\nThe homey, Old World vibe continues on the second floor, where visitors will find a more formal bar, with antique glassware and taxidermy picked up at the Rose Bowl Flea Market \u2014 as well as Daniel Humm and Will Guidara\u2019s much-buzzed-about 110-seat restaurant Mezzanine, currently open for dinner. Classics from the original NoMad menu, such as Humm\u2019s famous roast chicken for two, are available here too, as are more Californian options, including a broccoli dish with black rice and cured egg yolk and a seafood platter with scallops, Dungeness crab and Santa Barbara uni with pear gel\u00e9e.\n\nThis being L.A., a post-meal swim can be had in the rooftop pool, though guests are just as likely to go exploring. \u201cThings are more noir and edgy here,\u201d hotel founder and CEO Andrew Zobler says of the rapidly changing area, just on the cusp of becoming a full-fledged cultural hub. \u201cJust don\u2019t expect it to be Hollywood.\u201d 649 South Olive Street, thenomadhotel.com \u2014 JEANINE CELESTE PANG", "title": "Seven Things T Editors Like Right Now", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-01 00:00:00", "text": "Before coming to Detroit, Caldwell, 62, coached the Colts for three seasons, compiling a 26-22 record.\n\nFox was fired from his third N.F.L. team, although it was the first time he left with a losing record. The Bears were a troubled, losing team when Fox arrived in 2015, and he was charged with rebuilding the roster. He may have accomplished some of that \u2014 the Bears have a promising young quarterback in Mitch Trubisky \u2014 but the team played conservatively and appeared listless and overmatched.\n\nThe crowds at Bears\u2019 home games this season grew more sparse with each defeat as the team finished last in the N.F.C. North with a 5-11 record. In three seasons, Fox, 62, had a 14-34 record.\n\nFox\u2019s overall head coaching record is 133-123. In nine years with the Carolina Panthers, he made the playoffs three times and took the 2003 Panthers to the Super Bowl, where they lost by three points to the New England Patriots.\n\nIn 2011, Fox took over the Denver Broncos and led the team to four successive postseason appearances. The Broncos were routed 43-8 by the Seattle Seahawks in the Super Bowl after the 2013 season. Fox was fired one year later, with a 12-4 regular season record \u2014 and a first-round playoff loss.\n\nArians, 65, compiled a 49-30-1 record in Arizona. But the Cardinals, once considered a rising power, missed the playoffs the last two seasons when they were 7-8-1 and 8-8.\n\nPagano, 57, spent six seasons in Indianapolis but was out after the Colts this season slumped to 4-12. Del Rio, 54, lasted only three years with the Raiders, who made the playoffs last season with a 12-4 record. But this season, the Raiders (6-10) faded badly and were never in serious contention for a postseason berth.", "title": "Several N.F.L. Coaches Depart as Regular Season Ends", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-17 00:00:00", "text": "On Wednesday, a Vatican spokesman, Greg Burke, said in a statement: \u201cThe directive not to return to Peru was issued in order to block any contact of Figari with Sodalitium. The Vatican will in no way oppose Peruvian efforts to detain Figari.\u201d\n\nThe scandal has nonetheless cast a pall over Pope Francis\u2019 arrival in Peru on Thursday. Francis offered an apology to sexual abuse victims this week in Chile, but many Peruvians are asking: If the pope wants to be tough on such crimes, how could the Vatican protect one of its alleged perpetrators?\n\n\u201cThat\u2019s how the church operates, they bring their own \u2018home\u2019 as it were, and then there are no consequences,\u201d said Peter Saunders, an abuse survivor who was suspended in 2016 from a commission that Francis announced in 2013, to much fanfare, to establish guidelines for sex-abuse cases. Mr. Saunders resigned from the commission last month.\n\nMr. Figari, a layman, stepped down as the leader of Sodalitium in 2010, but he remains a member of the group.\n\nIt was one of several communities in Latin America \u2014 like the Rev. Fernando Karadima\u2019s El Bosque in Chile \u2014 allegedly headed by abusive leaders who experts say operated with impunity because the Vatican, under Pope John Paul II, ignored reports of problems. His successors have been accused of moving too slowly to address the issue.\n\nLast week, before his trip to Latin America, Francis ordered a Vatican takeover of Sodalitium, saying he had concerns about its management and finances. But his announcement did not explicitly address victims or abuses.\n\n\u201cThis announced intervention does not take care of us, the victims,\u201d said a former member, who said that when he was 15, Mr. Figari had anal sex with him several times.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe Vatican did not respond to a request for comment.\n\nBut Sodalitium, which commissioned its own investigation in 2016, has laid out chilling details of abuse in a report that it released. The report says that Mr. Figari and other members sexually abused at least 19 minors and 17 adults starting in 1975.\n\nThe report said Mr. Figari had engaged in \u201cmultiple acts of sodomy of a minor male,\u201d instructed a man to kiss his penis and touched and hugged members while naked. Mr. Figari also knew of three adult members who sexually abused minors, the report said.\n\n\u201cFigari told some of his victims the indecent acts were part of his mystical powers, yoga exercises, or an energy generating technique,\u201d Sodalitium investigators found.\n\nPeruvian prosecutors say too much time has elapsed to bring sex-crime charges. Instead, they say Mr. Figari ran a \u201ccriminal organization\u201d that preyed on young men, and have asked a judge to approve his arrest. That would allow them to seek his extradition.\n\nIn October 2016, Mr. Figari, who is now 70, said he was \u201cnot aware that there are any victims.\u201d The Vatican later barred him from speaking to the press, the Vatican documents show.\n\nArmando Lengua Balbi, a lawyer for Mr. Figari, said his client denied the allegations. He said that Mr. Figari was undergoing cancer treatment and that he was \u201cexercising his right to resist\u201d the Peruvian authorities.\n\n\u201cIf he comes back, people will lynch him,\u201d Mr. Lengua Balbi said.\n\nHe said the encounter with Mr. Osterling might not even be considered abuse at all.\n\n\u201cThis could lead you to think, \u2018Well, this man is weird, this is wrong, I shouldn\u2019t have acquiesced, I should have pushed back,\u2019\u201d Mr. Lengua Balbi said. \u201cBut to accuse someone under the label of a sexual crime or sexual abuse? Asking someone to drop their pants is not a crime. That\u2019s not a crime anywhere in the world.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nHe also said the accusations involving the 15-year-old would be impossible to prove in court. \u201cHe should have gotten medically examined,\u201d Mr. Lengua Balbi said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Figari was known to his followers as a foul-mouthed, larger-than-life figure.\n\nHe founded Sodalitium in the early 1970s on deeply conservative values and the promise of a life of obedience. One of the group\u2019s principles said that \u201can independent spirit means the death of our community.\u201d Another said \u201cthe only thing a Sodalite cannot do is give birth.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMembers occasionally sang \u201cFacing the Sun,\u201d the anthem of the Spanish Falange, a fascist party, recalled Pedro Salinas, a member during the 1980s who in 2015 wrote a book with the journalist Paola Ugaz about the organization.\n\nLike Mr. Figari, most members are laymen, but they live together in monastery-like community houses. The group gained a foothold among well-heeled Peruvian families, spreading through Latin America and even to an outpost in Denver. When Francis was still a cardinal, he invited Sodalitium to set up a community in Argentina.\n\nMembers recall that during Mr. Figari\u2019s heyday, Sodalitium focused on discipline and obedience. Recruits were young, usually 14 to 16.\n\n\u201cWhen you lived in community, you couldn\u2019t go out on the streets if you didn\u2019t have permission from a superior,\u201d said Martin Scheuch, who was a member for 15 years.\n\nMr. Osterling, who left Sodalitium in 2011, recalls being asked to send Mr. Figari photos and videos of young men who were potential recruits saluting him. \u201cFigari supposedly would review the film, look into the kids\u2019 eyes and was able to see their souls,\u201d he said.\n\nMr. Figari would then choose which boys to invite to Sodalitium retreats, where he would send them cryptic messages. \u201cI\u2019ve heard much about you,\u201d he might say, according to a legal complaint filed with prosecutors by former members of the group.\n\nObedience and abuse were often intertwined. Mr. Scheuch recalled a night when Mr. Figari suddenly told him to put his hands and knees on the floor and lift up his shirt.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cNo one could tell him, \u2018I\u2019m not going to do that,\u2019\u201d Mr. Scheuch said. \u201cThat was unthinkable. So I did it, and he called another Sodalite to start whipping my bare back. The Sodalite doubted, so Mr. Figari repeated his order and he whipped me with his belt.\u201d\n\nMr. Salinas recalled Mr. Figari once came in with a prospective applicant and made a strange request. He asked for a candle and matches, then asked Mr. Salinas to pull up his sleeve and extend his arm.\n\nMr. Figari proceeded to burn him, he said.\n\n\u201cI had my poker face on because I understood implicitly that the point was to impress the prospective applicant,\u201d Mr. Salinas said. \u201cI ended up with a big red blister and a bandaged arm for a few days.\u201d\n\nAt least 18 people were victims of physical abuse, according to the group\u2019s report.\n\nMr. Figari served as Sodalitium\u2019s superior general until his resignation in 2010. Sodalitium\u2019s internal investigation found that he had left over the abuse revelations.\n\nVictims say it took far too long for the allegations to come to light, and say that in many cases their accounts were not believed.\n\n\u201cI\u2019ve given my testimony to countless people in search of justice since 1978,\u201d said the man who accused Mr. Figari of sexually abusing him as a teenager. He asked not to be named.\n\nIn May 2011, the man filed a complaint with Peru\u2019s ecclesiastical court that was forwarded to the Vatican. More complaints were filed in 2013 and 2014, according to Sodalitium\u2019s internal investigation.\n\nThe Vatican finally acted in April 2015, sending a Peruvian bishop to investigate. But it was not until six months later that Sodalitium publicly confronted Mr. Figari, when Mr. Salinas and Ms. Ugaz published their book. By then, Mr. Figari had left the country.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn January 2017, the Vatican investigators concluded that Mr. Figari had engaged in sexual activity \u201cwith some young men,\u201d at least one of whom was under 16, who were being trained by the group.\n\nStill, the documents say, the allegations contained \u201cinconsistent timelines, contradictions and some aspects were not very clear.\u201d And it said that investigators were \u201cperplexed by the notable, anomalous and not entirely comprehensive echo\u201d the abuse allegations had generated in Peru.\n\nMr. Lengua Balbi said Mr. Figari was appealing the ruling, and had hired two canon lawyers.\n\nThe man who says Mr. Figari abused him when he was 15 said the Vatican\u2019s investigation was a whitewash.\n\n\u201cThe church has never contacted me,\u201d he said. \u201cNever.\u201d", "title": "Sex Abuse Case Shadows Pope Francis\u2019 Visit to Peru", "authors": ["Marcelo Rochabr\u00fan", "Andrea Zarate"]} {"date": "2018-01-01 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\n\u201c#MeToo, Say Wary Afghan Women\u201d (news article, Dec. 11) exposes the disturbing plight of Afghan women who face public humiliation for bringing instances of sexual abuse to light. But the consequences can be even more serious than being shamed by their community, as the state often brings criminal charges against women who speak up.\n\nPublic defenders at my organization, the International Legal Foundation, recently represented a 14-year-old Afghan girl charged with adultery after she told her parents that she was raped by her uncle. Because of the outstanding advocacy of our Afghan lawyers, trained and supported by international experts, the charges were dismissed, but only after the girl was incarcerated for four months.\n\nThe #MeToo movement must prioritize action, including where state institutions are the offender. As countries around the world seek to strengthen the rights of women, support should focus on organizations attacking this problem from all sides: protecting victims and fostering confident, capable female advocates who will shape society and the legal system.\n\nJENNIFER SMITH, NEW YORK\n\nThe writer is executive director of the International Legal Foundation.", "title": "Opinion | Sex Abuse of Afghan Women", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "At diagnosis, quite a few cancer patients spy Eros rushing out the door. I know I did. For some, eroticism vanishes during or after treatment. Anhedonia, the inability to feel pleasure, can afflict both men and women with cancer. We often get more help from one another than from the medical specialists who are beginning to address this challenge.\n\nIt can be difficult to experience desire if you don\u2019t love but fear your body or if you cannot recognize it as your own. Surgical scars, lost body parts and hair, chemically induced fatigue, radiological burns, nausea, hormone-blocking medications, numbness from neuropathies, weight gain or loss, and anxiety hardly function as aphrodisiacs. At 46, the youngest member of my cancer support group put it best: \u201can existential crisis is not sexy.\u201d Although her physicians offered no advice, she eventually attempted to foster a renewed sex life, if only for the caring partner who saw her through treatment.\n\n\u201cSex and Cancer,\u201d a new book by Dr. Saketh R. Guntupalli, a gynecologic cancer specialist, and Maryann Karinch, sets out to help women with gynecologic or breast cancer. Dr. Guntupalli and Ms. Karinch labor mightily to provide scientific evidence for an insight some might consider predictable: \u201cWe found that sex was less pleasurable for women after cancer and that all types of sexual activity \u2014 oral, vaginal and anal \u2014 decreased after cancer.\u201d In patches of ponderous prose, their book describes the ways in which treatment inhibits romance.\n\nMore informative are the sections of \u201cSex and Cancer\u201d in which the authors explain what people can do to ensure that \u201cthe emperor of all maladies\u201d will not rule and wreck their relationships. First and foremost, Dr. Guntupalli and Ms. Karinch urge readers not to \u201cslap a \u2018dysfunction\u2019 label on your love life just because you read something about what is \u2018normal\u2019 or \u2018average.\u2019\u201d This is precisely the advice that prostate cancer patients also receive in self-help manuals.", "title": "Sex After Cancer", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-31 00:00:00", "text": "It was one of those record-scratch freeze-frame moments, because I can almost guarantee that this man did not miss his calling in the pornography industry. If they both want to believe it is huge, great. But the truth is they probably do not have a size problem; they more likely have a medical condition known as dyspareunia.\n\n\u201cDoes it feel like he is hitting a wall?\u201d I asked.\n\nThey both looked at me as if I were psychic. I am not. Women for whom tampons and sex are painful because the vagina feels too tight or small almost always have a condition called vaginismus. This means the muscles of the pelvic floor that surround the vagina are inappropriately taut. Typically these muscles relax with sexual stimulation and then contract rhythmically with orgasm. When they are tight it can cause pain with sex, a fit issue and even pain or difficulty with orgasm. Sometimes the pain can be worse after sex.\n\nThis woman I met briefly is no different than the patients I have been seeing for 25 years. She has pain with sex, she had told multiple providers, and not only had she never been offered a treatment, but she also had never even been given a diagnosis. The best modern medicine has left her with is internet mythology \u2014 and not even vaginal mythology, but penis mythology! This enrages me.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Of the Moment The lifestyle newsletter from the Styles, Travel and Food sections, offering the latest trends to news you can use. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nPain with sex is common; almost 75 percent of women have experienced it. For many, the pain comes and goes and reasons for this transient pain include inadequate foreplay, breast-feeding (which lowers estrogen), infection and other causes.\n\nPain that is more persistent affects 7 to 22 percent of women, and up to 45 percent of menopausal women and 60 percent of cancer survivors report pain with sex. Pain with sex is up there in prevalence with migraine and low back pain, and yet it is woefully understudied and rarely discussed. The number of articles indexed in PubMed, a search engine for scientific literature, for dyspareunia is 3,694, and the number for erectile dysfunction, one type of sexual problem for men, is 19,796.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMuscle spasm (my dinner diagnosis) is one of the most common diagnoses, but other common causes include nerve pain, skin conditions, low estrogen and endometriosis. There are psychological factors, but that does not mean that it is in your head. Ever.\n\nIf sex hurts, many women begin to anticipate the pain, which increases the pain response and diminishes lubrication and libido. If every time I offered you the finest chocolate in the world I hit you with a hammer at your first bite, you would soon learn to dread and fear chocolate. You may also reflexively flinch at the smell of chocolate, or even when I walked into the room, and lose your taste for chocolate altogether. For some women sexual trauma can also be a factor and start a cycle of pain.\n\nGetting facts ahead of fallacies in medicine is hard enough, but with sex there are many more layers. Most people receive a less than adequate sex education, and many do not learn how to talk about sex. When I ask a woman if she has discussed her pain or her sexual needs with her partner, it is not uncommon for me to hear, \u201cI can\u2019t.\u201d That many doctors do not feel comfortable discussing sex only compounds the issues.\n\nThere are also some other solutions:\n\nAddressing the sex itself. Treating pain with sex involves addressing the physical aspects, making sure technique is appropriate, discussing emotional consequences, and, of course, looking at the relationship. If you are deeply unhappy, you may not get the kind of sexual stimulation you need or be able to mount an adequate sexual response. No medical therapy can compensate for not liking your sexual partner.\n\nLubricant can help many women who have pain with sex, and no, it does not mean there is something wrong. The other myth that I frequently dismantle is this idea that women should achieve some kind of fantasy wetness. I have heard many women tell me that lubricant helps their pain, but their male partner does not like it or judges them for it. That, my friends, is messed up. No one thinks you are less if you need glasses. Some people have always needed glasses, and some of us, ahem, need glasses as we age. Who cares as long as you can see?\n\nForeplay is part of the sexual response cycle, but what is needed or desired varies greatly from person to person. At the dinner table the gentleman was quick to note that there was \u201cenough\u201d foreplay. I looked at my plate to keep my professional side-eye in check. This is why I always initially see women for consultation without their sexual partners. While foreplay alone rarely cures painful sex, most people actually want more than they are getting, so doubling up on foreplay is good sex hygiene, and, most important, it is fun.\n\nFinding a good doctor. Many women who find the right practitioners will have their pain with sex treated. In addition to a doctor and physical therapist, a sex therapist and psychologist may be helpful. For some women, treatment can be challenging because they may not find the right providers and a few have conditions that are difficult to treat. Some therapies are costly, and others do not fit with the person\u2019s sense of self. Some women have past sexual traumas that have never been discussed or are simply too painful to address, but doing so can go a long way.\n\nTreating pain with sex is incredibly rewarding; it is the only medical condition I treat in which my patient shows up giggling at her follow-up visit. \u201cI didn\u2019t know it could feel so good!\u201d is a common response. Even when we don\u2019t resolve the pain completely, getting a diagnosis can be incredibly validating and many women tell me just being taken seriously is very helpful.\n\nA woman who experiences painful sex is not broken. She has a medical condition, and she is hardly alone.", "title": "Sex Hurts. Help!", "authors": ["Jen Gunter", "The Cycle"]} {"date": "2018-01-01 00:00:00", "text": "For these lovers, foreplay includes dialogue like, \u201cDo you read much apophatic literature?\u201d Maggie conflates sexual and religious desire, sometimes to memorable effect. More often, these meditations set off the pretentiousness alarm that rests, like a smoke detector, at the top of one\u2019s mind. You may finally have to cover the thing with plastic wrap and a rubber band.\n\nImage Jamie Quatro Credit Stephen Alvarez\n\nDuring sex with James, she reports how \u201cat the deepest point of penetration the room fell away and the sky tore open and we were swept up into electric galaxies.\u201d This sounds less like one of Erica Jong\u2019s zipless romps than technical plans still on Elon Musk\u2019s drafting table.\n\n\u201cBalanced on this precipice we could blow open eternity,\u201d Maggie thinks as she and James consider having sex. Their lives will \u201cexplode outward in a single, effortless, life-changing orgasm.\u201d Indeed there are so many sexual and pre-sexual explosions that reading this book is like learning about one of the terrible disasters that result when a blaze starts in a fireworks store.\n\nThe tortured intensity of Maggie\u2019s longing does remind the reader of what\u2019s lost when sex is unhitched from religion. Young lovers now \u201chook up,\u201d a healthy phrase, if as wan as a piece of Dover sole. How many will know the illicit black-mass pleasures suggested by a word like fornication?\n\nAnd what of Thomas, Maggie\u2019s husband? He\u2019s a good father, we are told, and handsome. He reminds an acquaintance of Maggie\u2019s of the actor Patrick Dempsey. But this McDreamy is in finance and, as Maggie writes to James in an email, \u201cI find the language of business inaccessible.\u201d\n\nThomas is frustrated by the couple\u2019s bed-death, but you understand why he turns Maggie off. He is terrible at taking hints. Early in the novel he hopes to rekindle passion by giving Maggie a flesh-colored vibrator that\u2019s \u201crealistic-looking, veined and arched, a switch at its base.\u201d She despises it.\n\nBefore long he\u2019s shyly back with a \u201ctiny pink pebble vibrator\u201d that\u2019s \u201cshaped like a kidney bean.\u201d She resents this one, too. Finally, incredibly, he returns with a long sleek silver dildo in a drawstring bag. \u201cTell me that isn\u2019t what I think,\u201d she says.\n\nMaggie can\u2019t believe it. Richter, the head of the Captains\u2019 Endowment Association, which represents officers in the rank of captain and above. For those forced to retire, however, particularly those chiefs who \u201chave had highly successful careers and were key players in the resurgence of the city,\u201d it is a disappointing end that is not of their own design, Mr. Richter said.\n\nWith the changes, Mr. O\u2019Neill is promoting a new cadre of commanders to carry on with his overarching goal: to continue to construct the department\u2019s new neighborhood policing by encouraging officers to engage in deeper outreach with city residents.\n\nSo far, the program has been rolled out in 56 of the city\u2019s 77 police precincts and all nine of its housing bureaus.\n\n\u201cWe have to complete the transformation of the N.Y.P.D.,\u201d Mr. O\u2019Neill said in his statement on Monday, \u201cwhich we can only do in partnership with all the people of New York.\u201d\n\nAt the top of his change, Mr. O\u2019Neill said he would name Chief Terence A. Monahan as the department\u2019s highest-ranking uniformed officer, the chief of department, and would promote Assistant Chief Rodney Harrison to fill Chief Monahan\u2019s spot as chief of patrol. Both men have been overseeing the neighborhood policing efforts and consider it a philosophy for policing, more than simply an experiment.\n\nChief Monahan has been a senior commander for more than a decade, and his performance during the police response to protests at the 2004 Republican National Convention prompted a lawsuit by the New York Civil Liberties Union and was later sharply criticized by the city\u2019s Civilian Complaint Review Board.\n\nAndrew Case, a lawyer who was a spokesman for the review board at the time, recalled on Monday that then-Assistant Chief Monahan ordered 227 arrests of people on Aug. 31, 2004, but that all of the cases were later \u201cdismissed\u201d by the Manhattan district attorney\u2019s office.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe agency\u2019s \u201cinvestigation showed that Monahan ordered the crowd to disperse while they were pinned in by a fence on one side and a line of officers on the other,\u201d Mr. Case said. \u201cIn today\u2019s political climate, it is particularly troubling that someone who supervised the arrest of hundreds of peaceful demonstrators has been promoted to the department\u2019s top uniform position.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAnd, for all of Mr. O\u2019Neill\u2019s moves, none of them represent a dramatic break from Mr. Bratton\u2019s vision, as Mr. O\u2019Neill is still surrounded by many of the same top aides and deputy commissioners that the former commissioner had put in place, particularly Dermot Shea, the department\u2019s chief of crime control strategies, and Lawrence Byrne, its top legal official.\n\nStill, such moves are not uncommon within the city police agency, the nation\u2019s largest, when a new leader seeks to brand it with transformative change or, perhaps, settle old scores. When Mr. Bratton became commissioner the first time, in 1994, he ushered in a phalanx of young \u201csuper chiefs\u201d and carried out a smaller shake-up when he took over a second time in 2014. Patrick V. Murphy, who became police commissioner in 1970, began his tenure by asking top commanders, \u201cWhat is your intention?\u201d recalled Robert J. Louden, a New York police officer from 1966 to 1987 who is professor emeritus of criminal justice at Georgian Court University, in New Jersey.\n\nBy contrast, Mr. O\u2019Neill moved slowly in moving those in ranks below him. He could have acted in September 2016, when he succeeded Mr. Bratton, rather than awaiting the election\u2019s outcome. \u201cBut he took his time, and watched as neighborhood policing evolved, and the result is the lowest homicide rate, lowest shooting rate and pushing toward community confidence,\u201d said Chuck Wexler, the head of the Police Executive Research Forum, a Washington think tank.\n\nStill, whether such moves resonate with the public, particularly within an agency that \u201cplods along, irrespective of who is wearing the stars,\u201d is an open question, said Eugene J. O\u2019Donnell, a former officer who teaches at John Jay College of Criminal Justice.\n\n\u201cAll in all, this jockeying and churning consumes an inordinate amount of precious time and energy and creates a roiled environment that drives the agency far away from citizen centeredness and being mission oriented,\u201d said Mr. O\u2019Donnell.\n\nThose being forced out include Joseph Fox, the department\u2019s transit chief; Joanne Jaffe, its chief of community affairs; Diane Pizzuti, its chief of personnel; and Thomas Purtell, its chief of citywide operations, a position created for him but now being discontinued.\n\nAs part of his reorganization, Mr. O\u2019Neill is making departmental history: By selecting Nilda Irizarry Hoffman as chief of community affairs, he is elevating the first Hispanic woman to a three-star chief position. He is also creating an Office of Equity and Inclusion to develop more women and minority policing leaders who better reflect the communities they serve.\n\nTo Edward Mamet, a retired captain, Mr. O\u2019Neill may be the first leader to successfully carry out a form of community policing, which \u201chas been tried several times and failed.\u201d\n\n\u201cHe has the next four years to do so,\u201d said Mr. Mamet. \u201cUnless, of course, he leaves office before that.\u201d", "title": "Shake-Up in Hierarchy of the New York Police Department", "authors": ["Al Baker"]} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "Q. I work for a school that uses Google apps, including Gmail. Although the mail address is @myschool.com, it is a Google account, and I use the Google Calendar almost exclusively. I also have a personal Gmail account, but I almost never use the calendar. I\u2019m retiring in June, and I\u2019d like to get all the old and upcoming appointments, events, birthdays \u2014 everything \u2014 moved to my personal Google calendar before my school access ends. Is this possible?\n\nA. Copying all the events from the school\u2019s Google calendar may be possible, but check with the technical administrator or person in charge of the school calendar to see if your account has permission to do so, or if you can sync the school calendar to your personal calendar. As Google notes in its Calendar help guide, \u201cIf you use Google Calendar through your work, school or other organizations, you may not have the ability to export events.\u201d\n\nIf you are allowed to export events, log into your school account on the web browser on your work computer and open Google Calendar. If you are using the \u201cclassic\u201d view, go the left side of the page to the My Calendars area and find the name of the calendar you want to export. Click the menu area to the right of the calendar\u2019s name to open Calendar settings, and then choose \u201cExport this calendar.\u201d\n\nFor those using Google\u2019s \u201cnew\u201d design for the calendar, go to the My Calendars section on the left side of the screen, click the three-dot Options menu next to the calendar name and select \u201cSettings and Sharing.\u201d On the Calendar Settings box on the next screen, click Export Calendar.", "title": "Sharing Events From Other Google Calendars", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-16 00:00:00", "text": "Q. How do I make sure I am sending a photo at the highest possible resolution when I attach it to an email message on my phone?\n\nA. Before you send the photo, check the image-size settings when you attach the image to the message so you know you have selected a high-resolution picture. If you pick a low-resolution photo from the start, that is what your recipient will get.\n\nImage The Gmail app for Android displays a photo's size when you attach it to a message so you can make sure you are using a high-resolution image. Credit The New York Times\n\nTo help those with slow connections, limited-data plans or internet provider limits on attachment size, some mobile email apps can reduce the size of a photo attached to a message that\u2019s going out. Choosing the \u201csmall\u201d or \u201cmedium\u201d size scales the image down, but also reduces the resolution when it arrives at its destination. Smartphone apps vary, but some can automatically resize photos, so check your default settings.", "title": "Sharing High-Resolution Photos by Email", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "Q. A previous column explained how to download specific files from Google Photos, but I need to know how to upload a specific album to share with a family group. How do I do this?\n\nA. Google Photos can be set to automatically back up all the pictures you take on your smartphone or copy to your computer, so if you have this setting enabled, the pictures have already been uploaded to the online storage space that comes with your Google Account. You just need to select and sort the photos into the album you want to share before sending out a link to the family.\n\nEven if you are not using the automatic backup feature, you can manually upload selected photos you want to share online. If you have a folder of images on your computer that you want to upload to Google Photos through your web browser, log in at https://photos.google.com and drag pictures onto the browser window to transfer them. (As an alternative, you can click the Upload button at the top of the screen and navigate to the folder on your computer to add them.)\n\nPhoto\n\nOn a smartphone or tablet without the automatic backup feature enabled, open the Google Photos app and tap the images you want to share. To place the uploaded photos into an album, select Sharing, and in the menu icon at the top, choose \u201cCreate new share.\u201d In the desktop web browser, click on \u201cStart a new share.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story How Do You Use Tech? View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nWhen the thumbnails of your uploaded images appear, choose the ones you want to add to the album. After you are finished, select the Next button and add the email addresses of the people you want to get a sharing link, and hit the Send button.\n\nIf you would like a more guided approach instead, click the Assistant icon in the Google Photos app or browser window. Click Shared Album, choose the photos you want to use and click the Create button. On the next screen, give the album a name, click the Share button and add the email addresses of your recipients.\n\nIf you have already set up a Google Family Group \u2014 a unit of up to six people managed by one member to share Google-based photos, calendars, Google Play purchases \u2014 you can select the Family Group option in the Google Photos Sharing menu to alert the others. Biersdorfer", "Tech Tip"]} {"date": "2018-01-15 00:00:00", "text": "Congress has been experiencing a rise in states represented by a single party in the House and Senate. The political news site Smart Politics found that after the 2016 elections, 15 states sent delegations to Washington with members all from one party \u2014 double the number from eight years prior. Nine are Republican, six are Democratic.\n\nIn the others, one party typically dominates a state\u2019s delegation. But even in the most lopsided groups, there are members from the other side scattered through the membership \u2014 Republicans outside the urban centers of Democratic states and Democrats representing cities and liberal enclaves of Republican states.\n\nThe diversity can provide benefits to both lawmakers and their constituents. Majority parties have traditionally been reluctant to take too direct an aim at states where their numbers are lower since any repercussions could still hit their own members, often the most vulnerable to challenge.\n\nOn issues such as energy and transportation, geography and parochialism can trump party allegiance. Having members of both parties from a state rally behind a project can help build a bipartisan critical mass of support.\n\nPhoto\n\nOn a personal level, lawmakers of opposing parties from the same state can develop working relationships and friendships while partnering on state issues, forging ties that can pay off in other ways. Given the current level of partisanship of Congress, lawmakers don\u2019t have many other chances to build strong personal bonds.\n\nBut the 2018 outlook poses problems for Republicans, who, like Democrats in the South in recent decades, could find themselves with reduced numbers and influence in some regions of the country.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nTake three states in particular. New York currently has 18 Democrats and nine Republicans, California has 39 Democrats and 14 Republicans, and New Jersey has seven Democrats and five Republicans.\n\nThose Republican numbers are expected to shrink \u2014 perhaps significantly \u2014 in the November elections because of a number of factors, including the new tax law. The law made a number of changes that will fall harder on these higher-tax states, particularly the new prohibition on the ability to deduct state and local taxes above $10,000.\n\nThat could result in a tax increase for homeowners in the Northeast and California who might want to take out their unhappiness on Republicans \u2014 whether they voted for the new law or not. Elections held in 2017 have shown that Mr. Trump\u2019s low standing has already cost Republicans support from suburban voters critical to the Republican coalition.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Get the Morning Briefing by Email What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox Monday through Friday. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nRepresentative Peter T. King, a New York Republican who warned his party\u2019s leadership about the potential tax law ramifications, said there would be negative consequences as voters grappled with their tax situation.\n\n\u201cThe tax bill is going to hurt Republicans in New York and New Jersey and California,\u201d he said. \u201cIt is definitely going to have an impact. We are going to spend the entire campaign defending ourselves against what our own party did. It is entirely self-inflicted.\u201d\n\nIn the past, the party might have been inclined to take steps to protect incumbent lawmakers from areas where legislation would have a negative impact on their voters. But Republican leaders eager for a long-sought tax cut seemed to consider the tax overhaul a higher priority than the political outlook for Republican members in higher-tax states, though they did adjust the state and local tax proposal to try to limit the damage as well as find votes for approval of the legislation.\n\nAfter the tax vote, House Speaker Paul D. Ryan canceled plans to raise money for a centrist New York Republican as punishment for opposition to the tax bill, a response that penalizes a member of the speaker\u2019s party just when help is most needed to win re-election.\n\nMr. King said he was concerned that states like his own could become represented by a single voice. He said he would like to think he would feel the same apprehension if the roles were reversed and it was Democrats who were in danger of being pushed out.\n\n\u201cWe need the clash of ideas,\u201d said Mr. King.\n\nBut given the election outlook and current trends, the biggest clashes to come in Congress could be between state delegations and members who find they have even less to connect them than they do now.", "title": "Sharper State Divide in Congress Seen as \u2018New Civil War\u2019", "authors": ["Carl Hulse", "On Washington"]} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "In a hospital in Minnesota, Carrol Amrich\u2019s mother was dying.\n\nIn Pueblo, Colo., a thousand miles away, Ms. Amrich was frantically trying to get there in time to say goodbye.\n\nHolding a United Airlines ticket purchased for her by her landlord, she probably would have. But minutes before departure, already buckled into her seat, she was ordered to leave the plane. The gate agent told her that her reservation had been canceled. Traveler Help Desk, the online agency that sold the ticket, had rescinded it because the landlord made a change directly through United \u2014 even though United had assured the landlord that it was not a problem to do so.\n\nUnable to fly, Ms. Amrich drove through the night, not stopping even to use the bathroom. Her sister, in the hospital room, held a phone to their mother\u2019s ear, and Ms. Amrich begged her to hold on.\n\nShe was still driving when her cellphone rang again. Her mother was dead.\n\n\u201cI cried the whole way from Pueblo,\u201d Ms. Amrich said in a phone interview on Jan. 18, two days after her mother died. \u201cI\u2019ve been awake for two days. I haven\u2019t had anything to eat in two days.\u201d", "title": "She Boarded a Plane to See Her Dying Mother. Then Her Ticket Was Canceled.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nWhen Jada Yuan got the news two weeks ago that she\u2019d landed perhaps the most coveted newspaper writing job ever, she was, as she puts it, \u201cbasically as far as you can get from the New York media world\u201d: in rural New Mexico, in the single corner of her childhood home where an Ethernet cord provided access to high-speed internet. When Ms. Yuan was growing up there with a nuclear-physicist father and a glass-artist mother, international travel wasn\u2019t in the scope of her experience: \u201cIt took me half an hour biking on a dirt road to get to my best friend\u2019s house.\u201d\n\nSeveral decades later \u2014 she\u2019ll turn 40 this year \u2014 Ms. Yuan has just been named The Times\u2019s inaugural 52 Places correspondent, which will take her to each of the destinations our Travel desk has deemed unmissable in 2018. Her application was chosen from among more than 13,000, a pool representing plumbers, project managers, teachers, basketball players and even State Department officials. The selection committee remained open until the very end to handing the commission to someone other than a journalist, explained Dan Saltzstein, the 52 Places coordinating editor, but in the end, he said, \u201chaving somebody with a robust reporting background is going to be a really important tool.\u201d\n\nThe gig was the first to which Ms. Yuan had applied in 17 years; she started at New York magazine as an editorial assistant in 2000 and has been on staff ever since. Though she\u2019s best known for entertainment writing, her work extends beyond the glamorous demimonde of celebrity profiles and movie premieres: She also covered the 2008 presidential conventions and the Ferguson, Mo., protests for the magazine.\n\nUltimately it was Ms. Yuan\u2019s writerly voice and her keen sense for personal narrative that pushed her to the top. \u201cThe way I thought of it was, whose version of this trip do I want to hear?\u201d Mr. Saltzstein said. \u201cSo much of this was going to be about the journey,\u201d he said, as when something \u2014 a missed flight or a canceled reservation, for instance \u2014 inevitably goes wrong. \u201cReaders will be following along for both the highs and the lows.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFrom Ms. Yuan\u2019s perspective, it\u2019s covering film festivals that has provided the most directly relevant experience for this job. \u201cThat is really exactly what the job description was: parachuting down and being able to churn out a ton of material, not really knowing what the lay of the land was,\u201d she said. Festivals taught her the art, she said, of \u201cknowing how to walk into a room like you\u2019re supposed to be there,\u201d an ask-forgiveness-not-permission approach that has served her particularly well in seemingly impossible reporting conditions. She cites, for example, the French security guard presiding over the entrance to a sold-out screening of Terrence Malick\u2019s \u201cThe Tree of Life\u201d at Cannes in 2011. \u201cThe line was crazy, it was total chaos,\u201d she said. \u201cHe just gave me this look that made me think that he would not stop me if I jumped over several barricades.\u201d So that\u2019s what she did.", "title": "She Has 52 Places to See and One Year to Do It", "authors": ["Raillan Brooks", "Alexandria Symonds"]} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "PARIS \u2014 Having spent the last five years living in Syria, where she joined Islamic extremists, Emilie K\u00f6nig, 33, wants to come home to France. But does France want her back?\n\nThe daughter of a policeman from a small town in Brittany, she converted to Islam as a teenager. After she began covering herself from head to toe in a black abaya and veil, she felt so scorned in France that she left her two small children to go to Syria, eventually becoming a prominent propagandist and recruiter for the Islamic State.\n\n\u201cShe would like to come back; she has asked for pardon from her family, her friends, her country,\u201d her mother said in an interview with Ouest-France, a newspaper in Brittany, after speaking to her daughter by telephone two weeks ago.\n\nMs. K\u00f6nig\u2019s personal story is unusual, not least because she is a convert and gained prominence within the male-dominated Islamic State. Now She Wants to Return. But Can She?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "I read it in the spring of 2011, and I just put a pin in it: I have to come back to this.\n\nThe opera begins in something that might be a representation of some allegorical garden with dancey music. But what I\u2019m trying to reveal is a darker side of allegory and what it might reveal about us. The premise is how little we can know ourselves: You have your reason on one side and your heart on the other. And maybe you have other impulses \u2014 Shame is one of the characters \u2014 and the advice you get from all of them can be corrupted. And the one pulling all the threads is False-Seeming, who is like music, in a way, which makes us feel things we don\u2019t necessarily want to feel. The force of manipulation, of distorting words.\n\nBut it has to end with some sense of hope. Some sense that we can acknowledge that it\u2019s very difficult to know exactly what the right thing is to do, but we have to persist.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nDid you intend it to have political implications?\n\nIt got darker over the last few years. I do feel like it suddenly became this idea of \u201cOh, you can\u2019t win against False-Seeming; you can\u2019t win against someone in power who tells you it\u2019s sunny out when it\u2019s raining.\u201d\n\nWhat do you do? You have to keep going and remember you\u2019re not crazy.\n\nSo how is it progressing?\n\nIn May, I had finished a draft, and we read it aloud, and I just knew it was not right; it was not the story I wanted to tell. So I basically rewrote it. And now there\u2019s a workshop in June. The libretto\u2019s done, and the goal is to finish all of the music and a piano score for June. This is the biggest thing I\u2019ve ever done. I\u2019m not 100 percent sure, but there will be six or possibly seven singers and then an ensemble of about seven, plus electronics.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhat role will you sing?\n\nI don\u2019t really know. I thought I was going to be Lady Reason, because I do empathize with someone who thinks she can use her intellect to answer every question about the human condition, but discovers air or light or moisture can get into that, too, and ruin it. Then I started writing Shame, and she has an interesting trajectory, and her vocal music happens to be a little more suited to me. And the third soprano character is really not my type \u2014 she\u2019s a voluptuous coloratura in a gown \u2014 but that could be fun.\n\nI could also not be in it, but I kind of really want to.\n\n\u201cIpsa Dixit\u201d was a finalist for the Pulitzer Prize last year. Has that led to a lot of new commissions?\n\nI\u2019ve been saying no a lot, and that feels weird, but it\u2019s just because no one was asking me before. The most meaningful work of mine has not been commissioned. Basically most of the stuff I\u2019ve done, I\u2019ve felt compelled to do it, and I\u2019ve been lucky enough to be able to do it. I don\u2019t know how suited I am for commissions for various ensembles, now that I\u2019ve gone down this rabbit hole of writing texts and theater pieces.\n\nOne day, when I get sick of what I\u2019m doing now, maybe I\u2019ll want to see about instrumental music more, and see what I can communicate without language. At 43 West 24th Street, ninth floor.", "title": "Shop Your Way Through the Winter Doldrums", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-29 00:00:00", "text": "On long winter nights, candles can bring warmth \u2014 both visual and literal \u2014 to the dining table. As Adam Hunter, an interior and product designer in Los Angeles, put it, \u201cThey\u2019re crucial: They provide that magical glow that people really associate with home.\u201d\n\nAnd what you choose to hold them can be as important as the candles themselves. Available in a wide range of sizes and styles, from simple, single-taper designs to elaborate, multi-armed candelabra, candlesticks set the stage for a minimalist dinner or a maximalist party.\n\nFor a creative tablescape, Mr. Hunter suggested combining pieces from different sets. \u201cMixing sizes is the key to making the styling look effortless,\u201d he said, although it can take some time to get the arrangement just right.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s like hanging art,\u201d he said. \u201cYou want to make it feel cohesive, but help the individual candlesticks shine.\u201d", "title": "Shopping for Candleholders", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-15 00:00:00", "text": "When your decorating is mostly finished, and the major pieces of furniture are in place, details like decorative bowls often help pull it all together.\n\n\n\n\u201cThey\u2019re something we use all the time to add a finishing layer,\u201d said Catherine Kwong, a San Francisco-based interior designer who searches out statement-making bowls, both vintage and new, to accessorize rooms.\n\n\u201cEspecially in a more minimal space,\u201d she said, \u201cit\u2019s a nice way to add a sculptural silhouette or another layer of texture or color.\u201d\n\nIn the kitchen, they can serve as interesting fruit bowls, while on an entry console or bedside table they can be used as catch-alls. Either a really beautiful meal or a really warm fire.\u201d\n\nFor that reason, fireplaces take center stage in many of Mapos\u2019s residential and hospitality projects, including the Lake House hotel in Lake Placid, N.Y., and the forthcoming hotel The Maker in Hudson, N.Y.\n\nThere are various options for adding fire features to existing homes, Mr. Brice and Mr. Mulvena said, including wood stoves, gas fireplaces and models that burn ethanol. But there are important differences: Some, like wood stoves, can function as the main heat source for a room; others, like ethanol fireplaces, are more about ambience.", "title": "Shopping for Fireplaces and Wood Stoves", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "ARCHIDONA, Spain \u2014 When the Spanish authorities intercepted about 500 Algerian migrants who had traveled by boat to the southeastern coast of Spain, a space shortage in the country\u2019s migrant detention centers left few options for where to send the new arrivals.\n\nSo the government sent them to an empty facility near this whitewashed town in the mountainous heartland of southern Spain, about 35 miles north of M\u00e1laga: its brand-new prison.\n\nArchidona\u2019s penitentiary stands a few miles outside the town, amid olive groves that were covered in snow last weekend. Designed to hold about 2,000 prisoners, with a staff of almost 600, it was due to open in the first quarter of this year.\n\nThe arrival of the migrants, in November, has provoked mixed feelings.\n\nMany of the town\u2019s 8,400 residents helped collect food and clothing for them. Some residents voiced concerns about possible damage to the new prison even before its official opening.", "title": "Short on Space for Migrants, Spain Sent Them to a Town\u2019s New Prison", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "Australia Day is a national holiday at the height of the Australian summer that feels, to many, like a celebration of colonization.\n\nEvery Jan. 26, Australians gather for barbecues and beach parties \u2014 or for citizenship ceremonies and fireworks \u2014 to mark the anniversary of the day in 1788 when the island was claimed by the First Fleet of British ships.\n\nAnd since at least 1938, Aboriginal groups have publicly protested it.\n\nEach year, their call for Australia Day to be moved to another date, or for the day to be recast as one of mourning, grows louder. But with a few exceptions at the local level, Australia\u2019s political class has refused to budge.\n\nThe result: a visible standoff, played out regularly in the local news media, between Australia\u2019s conservative white officials and the leaders of various Aboriginal groups.", "title": "Should Australia Commemorate White Settlement?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "But \u2014 here\u2019s the second issue \u2014 this doesn\u2019t mean that we must reject every offer of a reward. One way to honor a kind act, if you\u2019re the beneficiary, is to express gratitude, as this man did. His offer of money was presumably meant as a further expression of that gratitude. And it didn\u2019t automatically turn your act into a grubby commercial arrangement. Not every gift corrodes moral sentiment.\n\nMoney talks, not just in the unpleasant sense that you can buy compliance but also in the sense that in giving you something of value, I can show that I respect what you have done. A generous act; the offer of a token of appreciation; the grateful acceptance. Each of these can continue a small moment of human connection.\n\nSometimes people feel that to be the beneficiary of a generous act puts them under an obligation, in a way that makes them uncomfortable. Did the man want to reduce his own sense of being in your debt? Were you worried that he thought of you as the kind of person who was motivated only by the desire for a reward? The fact that it\u2019s natural to wonder about these questions reflects the truth that small offers of money like these are attempts at communication \u2014 and, like all attempts at communication, can sometimes fail.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAn acquaintance of mine was recently diagnosed with an incurable cancer. He has health insurance but decided to spend his small retirement savings in a nontraditional medical clinic in Mexico. He was prescribed vitamins and other homeopathic treatments for a sizable sum. As he is now unable to pay his living expenses, he has started raising money online. I am a health care provider and realize the importance of combining traditional and nontraditional medicine. I disagree, however, with his departure from science-based treatment and advice. What duty do I have to help him financially? Name Withheld\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhen you are confronting death, it\u2019s hard to think carefully about the decisions you face. That\u2019s why it\u2019s particularly impressive when people do so with intelligence and resolution. As long as you are mentally competent, though, these decisions are yours to make. What you can\u2019t expect is that other people will pay for you to follow your choices.\n\nThis patient is, you say, an acquaintance. Paying anything at all for the medical expenses of an acquaintance is doing more than you must. It\u2019s an act of supererogation, again. If you do it, it will be because you care about and respect him. And if you respect him, you will want him to act on the basis of a proper understanding of his situation. Respecting people entails telling them when we think they\u2019re wrong \u2014 at least when the issue is ethically significant, and when we think they\u2019re capable of understanding the truth. That you would give people money if they were making sensible choices doesn\u2019t mean that you\u2019re ignoring their right to manage their own affairs when you decline to underwrite foolish ones.\n\nAs a medical professional, you have come to the view that this costly Mexican clinic is offering this man no medical benefit. You also know that good medical treatment, even when it can\u2019t cure a condition, can often provide patients a longer \u201cquality adjusted\u201d life. If the clinic\u2019s nostrums are useless, he\u2019s going to find that he\u2019s continuing to decline. In giving him money, you will be subsidizing peddlers of false hope (whether mercenary or deluded) and enabling your acquaintance to put off important end-of-life decisions. The respectful thing, if you know him well enough, is to help him face the truth.\n\nWhile in the process of purchasing a home, I discovered that concrete for its foundation was supplied by a company whose product has crumbled in tens of thousands of homes in my state. Most homeowners have been ruined, as there is no relief from insurance or FEMA and little to no relief from the state. I did not buy the house, but I worry for the next buyer. What should I do with this information? Name Withheld\n\nThis sounds like something that a prospective buyer should bear in mind, but you can\u2019t be obliged to stand in front of the property with a warning sign. You can, however, formally notify the current owners and their real estate broker of what you\u2019ve found. It\u2019s up to them to do the right thing. At the very least, a formal communication from you will put them on notice that, in the event of future litigation, they can\u2019t safely claim ignorance.", "title": "Should I Accept a Cash Reward for Doing the Right Thing?", "authors": ["Kwame Anthony Appiah", "The Ethicist"]} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "I received these two messages within three minutes of each other recently:\n\nSeveral years back I used to mine Bitcoin, and then I sold most of them off for a down payment for our house. I had 400 BTC at one point, which would be worth $6.8 million today. Needless to say, I am really depressed now. I only kept one Bitcoin. I should have kept more.\n\nAnd this one:\n\nMy husband has invested in Bitcoin, and my son has invested in Etherium! I am debating about switching my 401(k) to Bitcoin.\n\nEveryone, including my mother, is wondering if they should buy Bitcoin or some other cryptocurrency. And since everyone is asking, there are plenty of semi-informed people providing answers. But if you try to find a solid answer to this question, you will probably just end up more confused. Answering the question means guessing where the price of Bitcoin is headed, and nobody who is being honest actually knows.\n\nSo may I humbly suggest that asking if we should all buy Bitcoin is the wrong question, and that we should ask a different one instead. The question we should be asking ourselves is this: Does buying Bitcoin fit into my investment plan?", "title": "Should You Buy Bitcoin? Ask a Different Question First", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "Diamonds, at least in the New York courts, aren\u2019t forever. Diamonds aren\u2019t even dreamy. Diamonds, given after a \u201cwill you marry me?\u201d with a \u201cyes\u201d to follow, are a contract. This is why so many of them end up in court.\n\nThe New York legal system deems, in essence, that a broken engagement is no one\u2019s fault, and the ring should be given back to the giver, with few exceptions. Most states have adopted that approach.\n\nBut Montana hasn\u2019t: It classifies the ring as an unconditional gift. The recipient keeps it.\n\nCalifornia and Texas take a middle-of-the road approach: the recipient of the ring is expected to return it, unless the giver called off the engagement.\n\nWhen will New York courts reconsider?\n\n1. When one half of the couple is already married to someone else.", "title": "Should You Give the Engagement Ring Back?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-14 00:00:00", "text": "Venezuelan leaders have also been preparing for \u201casymmetrical\u201d warfare for more than a decade. And there is no chance that countries in the region would participate in an effort to topple Mr. Maduro \u2014 Brazil has already stated as much.\n\nThere are few good options for addressing the crisis. But while the Maduro government has the upper hand inside Venezuela, two external forces are putting pressure on the regime.\n\nFirst, the most significant countries in the Western Hemisphere \u2014 like Brazil, Colombia, the United States and most of the European Union \u2014 do not recognize the National Constituent Assembly, a body created by Mr. Maduro to rewrite the Constitution and tailor the government to fit his needs. Members of the body were elected in July, despite a boycott by the opposition, but the lack of international recognition has weakened it, and little has been accomplished in the past five months.\n\nSecond, the \u201cdebt sanctions\u201d levied by the Trump administration that prohibit United States citizens or institutions from buying or issuing new Venezuelan debt have hamstrung the Maduro government\u2019s ability to raise new funds.\n\nThese factors are bringing the Maduro government to the negotiation table in the Dominican Republic, where the government and opposition met last week after meeting twice in December. The government wants the opposition to facilitate the lifting of sanctions and enable international recognition \u2014 this gives the opposition significant leverage.\n\nIn addition to the recent debt sanctions, for almost three years the United States has had targeted sanctions on Venezuelan officials accused of human rights abuses or corruption. Versions of this sanctions regime have been adopted by Canada, Mexico and the European Union. The increasingly multilateral character of sanctions makes them more effective.\n\nThe United States and its partners need to avoid the temptation to broaden the scope of the sanctions. Widening economic sanctions to an oil embargo, for example, would further harm a population that is barely hanging on. And such a broadening of targeted sanctions, which are supposed to drive a wedge between those who are sanctioned and those who are not, would dull their effect: If almost everyone is sanctioned, the unity of the Maduro government would be reinforced.\n\nInstead, the American government and its allies should deepen the current sanctions. Tightening the screws on officials who are already sanctioned would be more effective than putting more officials on the list. Getting even more countries on board with existing sanctions would also sharpen their effect.", "title": "Opinion | Should the United States Attack Venezuela?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "The incident occurred after Firmino and Holgate were chasing the ball near the touchline deep inside Everton\u2019s half. Firmino won the race but could not retain control. Holgate, frustrated, shoved him as they followed the ball over the touchline, sending Firmino tumbling off the field and into the stands.\n\nFirmino immediately leapt to his feet to confront Holgate. Slow-motion video suggested that, in his native Portuguese, the Brazilian forward delivered a stream of abuse at Holgate as the referee, Bobby Madley, stepped in to separate them.
