Have it your way. Talk over me. But I hope you know where the rebus key is, because Sam Trabucco is not going to let you get a word in edgewise. He might let you put it on the next line of the puzzle, though.\n\nToday\u2019s Theme\n\nMr. Trabucco seems to like cutting people off in midsentence, and we have three theme phrases that end in HYPHENs. Please note that in some solving formats, I\u2019m told that the answers DASH and \u201c-\u201d (that\u2019s an en dash) are also accepted. That HYPHEN or DASH or \u201c-\u201d at the end of the phrase indicates that the speaker has been interrupted. (The repeated clue is \u201cLine from someone who\u2019s been interrupted.\u201d)\n\nThe neat thing about this is that Mr. Trabucco is gonna let you finish, as Kanye likes to say. But you\u2019ll have to go to the next Across entry on the next line, and that finish is a word unto itself, which is very elegant. Even better, Mr. Trabucco has been able to fill the slots crossing the HYPHEN (or DASH or \u201c-\u201d) with fun, short words.", "title": "Someone Who\u2019s Been Interrupted", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-09 00:00:00", "text": "And now, let\u2019s hand it off to our constructors.\n\nSenator Joe Donnelly: Last month in South Bend, I once again took part in one of my favorite traditions.\n\nIt\u2019s the \u201cJoe versus Joe\u201d basketball game, a now-annual hometown matchup of local teams coached by the former Indiana governor Joe Kernan and myself. The game is a fund-raiser for Kernan\u2019s Heroes, a charity that benefits homeless veterans here in Indiana.\n\nWhether enacting legislation in the Senate to protect service members\u2019 mental health or raising money for Hoosier veterans, I\u2019ve tried to help take care of those who\u2019ve worn the uniform of our country. And it\u2019s no surprise to me that back home in Indiana, that might occasionally involve basketball. After all, sometimes it seems like nearly everything here does.\n\nMay in Indiana belongs to auto racing, but the other 11 months belong to basketball. You\u2019ll find hoops above Gary\u2019s blacktops and on Vincennes farmhouses. Our fandom extends across every generation and level of the game, whether we\u2019ve cheered for Oscar Robertson at Crispus Attucks or Eric Gordon at North Central; pulled for Isaiah Thomas at Assembly Hall or Gordon Hayward at Hinkle Fieldhouse; rooted for Mel Daniels or Victor Oladipo in the Pacers\u2019 blue and gold.\n\nOur pastimes don\u2019t end there, however. Another activity Indiana ought to be known for, in addition to basketball? Believe it or not, crossword puzzles.\n\nThere are plenty of my fellow Hoosiers who are a master of that art, two of whom I had the pleasure to work with: my good friend Mickey Maurer, owner of The Indianapolis Business Journal and author of a book of his own crosswords, as well as Crawfordsville\u2019s own Will Shortz, who needs no introduction. After hearing Mickey talk about the joy of creating his own puzzles, it was a joy to create one with him.\n\nThis was the first puzzle I\u2019d helped create, an experience both very familiar and strange after previously only solving them. Working with Mickey and Will on this to write clues for today\u2019s puzzle required drawing on a depth of knowledge to make a coherent puzzle that brought together two of our state\u2019s passions. That in turn meant plenty of writing, erasing and rewriting. The tools needed to solve a puzzle, then, are not much different from those that are needed to create one \u2014 only on this side, there\u2019s the knowledge that the entire New York Times audience will see your work.\n\nIt was my goal that this is as enjoyable for you to solve as it was for me to help make. Good luck.\n\nMickey Maurer: I am delighted when my puzzle appears in The New York Times, so I always try to maintain three puzzles in the queue to feed that addiction.\n\nPuns and quips are my favorite crossword puzzle themes. We should all know by now that it is difficult to shoot a quip puzzle idea past Will Shortz. I keep trying. Many of my recent puzzles, including this collaboration with Senator Joe Donnelly, are themed puns. Some of these puns made me laugh out loud. See 18 across.\n\nIt was a pleasure to work with Senator Donnelly. I am not making a political statement here, but I was not surprised to learn that Senator Donnelly was recognized as the second most bipartisan senator since 1993 by the Lugar Center, McCourt School of Public Policy at Georgetown University. He is easy to work with. I had originally intended to hide his name in the puzzle (don, nelly) but those letters didn\u2019t mesh well with the theme clues.\n\nWe chose a basketball theme for Indiana, a basketball-crazy state that produced Oscar Robinson, Larry Bird and George McGinnis. McGinnis was recently enshrined in the Naismith Memorial Basketball Hall of Fame (2017). You do not need a deep understanding of the game of basketball to enjoy this puzzle. I hope you like our effort.", "title": "Something Bleeped Out for Television", "authors": ["Deb Amlen"]} {"date": "2018-01-03 00:00:00", "text": "THURSDAY PUZZLE \u2014 If there is one thing that crossword solvers dislike more than anything, it\u2019s spoilers. There is hell to pay if an answer is inadvertently given away on social media (trust me on this). I also don\u2019t think I would be out of bounds if I said that, second to spoilers, cross-referenced clues are close to the top of the list of Things Solvers Find Unpleasant. Third might be sneaking numerals into the grid.\n\nYou can see where I\u2019m going with this.\n\nI was prepared to find this puzzle unpleasant, but I have to admit that the subversive in me loved it. Your mileage may vary, of course. But there is always room for the occasional rulebreaker here at Wordplay, and Daniel Mauer\u2019s puzzle gleefully breaks the rules.\n\nToday\u2019s Theme\n\nLet\u2019s start with the numerals. There are eight numerals in this puzzle, placed in pairs, and their answers, for the most part, refer to answers \u201cfound elsewhere\u201d in the puzzle. Except for 1A, which starts out with the clue \u201cTen cents,\u201d and whose answer is 12 DOWN. Got that? Hang onto it for a moment.\n\nAt the same time, they are part of the answer that crosses them. the \u201c1\u201d and the \u201c2\u201d in 12 DOWN become part of the answers for 1- and 2A: 1SIES (or ONESIES) and 2TORED (or TUTORED).", "title": "Something to Leave at the Post Office", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-13 00:00:00", "text": "OLYMPIC PENINSULA, Wash. \u2014 Somewhere on the Olympic Peninsula, which extends from the northwest coast of Washington, a community has chosen to live independent of the public supply of water, electricity and other utilities on which most residents rely. Linked by a diffuse network of shared friends and land, they would be impossible to locate without insider knowledge. Dense forest obfuscates their dwellings \u2014 tiny houses, trailers, a landlocked houseboat \u2014 often accessible only by dirt roads or footpaths.\n\nWater and mist frame the peninsula, with the Pacific Ocean to the west, the Strait of Juan de Fuca to the north and the Hood Canal to the east. The community here emphasizes the importance of this landscape to their livelihood. Not only do some draw their water for dishes and bathing from the creek down the hill, but many are also financially sustained by the land, working as farmers, fishermen and gardeners.", "title": "Somewhere, Away From It All", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-09 00:00:00", "text": "Headliner\n\nSOOGIL Early in his career, Soogil Lim, a native of South Korea, switched from academia \u2014 biology \u2014 to food, and eventually graduated from the Culinary Institute of America in Hyde Park, N.Y. He became a sous-chef at Daniel, then moved on to be executive chef at Hanjan in the Flatiron district. Now he\u2019s on his own, with a personal take on Korean food. Brussels sprouts are tossed with pan-fried tofu, peanuts and crispy seaweed; a mung bean pancake is made with sprouts, kimchi and lard; root vegetables and soy sauce accompany braised short ribs; flaked cod comes with soy-braised radish; and spicy soft tofu with assorted seafood swim in a seafood broth. His intimate restaurant, seating fewer than 40, is a study in neutral tones, enlivened with art and Korean pottery: 108 East Fourth Street (First Avenue), 646-838-5524, soogil.com.\n\nOpening\n\nTACOMBI The fifth and largest branch of this Mexican restaurant featuring tacos is opening in the Empire State Building. The vibrant d\u00e9cor reflects the building\u2019s Art Deco style. An open kitchen, where Vista Hermosa, the Mexican food company owned by Tacombi, will also be making fresh masa and tortillas, anchors part of the space. Agave spirits and fresh juices are a feature of the bar. The menu offers a dozen tacos inspired by various Mexican regions, but with street food inclinations, thanks to fillings like the classic pork al pastor. Quesadillas, filled flour tortillas (campechanos), rice and beans, and guacamole round out the menu. (Opens Thursday): 23 West 33rd Street, 212-967-5555, tacombi.com.\n\nWEST-BOURNE Camilla Marcus, an entrepreneur in restaurants and technology, is opening this cafe focusing on two culinary styles, vegetarian and Californian. A mushroom Reuben sandwich is among the dishes from the chef, Amy Yi. Through a partnership arranged with the nonprofit Robin Hood Foundation, Ms. Marcus, a Los Angeles native, will donate a portion of every sale to the Door, an organization that offers job training for young people and immigrants, some of whom she employs. (Wednesday): 137 Sullivan Street (Prince Street), 347-534-3050 westbourne.com.\n\nTHE RAG TRADER This garment district newcomer, in a former clothing factory, pays homage to its past not only with its name but also with vintage artifacts like old sewing machines. The multilevel space is divided into a collection of areas for dining and drinking. The chef, Justin Ottervanger, prepares gastro-pub fare like sriracha deviled eggs, baby back ribs, pizza, beef tartare, mussels, and hanger steak frites. The basement houses the Bo Peep Cocktail & Highball Store, taking its name from a company, Bo Peep Manufacturing, that once occupied the premises: 70 West 36th Street, 917-2612-5495, ragtradernyc.com.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n2 SPRING Jesse Schenker, the chef who has closed both his Manhattan restaurants, Recette and the Gander, is opening on Nassau County\u2019s Gold Coast. The menu is American, buffed with touches like a smoked fish dip alongside crudit\u00e9s, linguine with clams in a shellfish bisque, arugula and ricotta salata in the kale salad, and lobster spiced with harissa and served with a savory bread pudding. He plans to continue his program, started in Manhattan, of offering 10-course tasting menus on alternate Monday evenings. It is clear that there were a disturbing number of undisclosed meetings with Russians. It is clear that there are some incredibly curious coincidences of timing between activities by the Russians and activities by the campaign.\n\nWe know that Trump has always hated the F.B.I. investigation into Russian activities in the election. We know that people in the Trump campaign lied to the F.B.I. We know that Trump himself said that the Russia investigation was on his mind when he fired the F.B.I. director James Comey. We know that he is furious at Sessions for recusing himself from the matter, thereby paving the way for the appointment of Mueller.\n\nWe know that Trump also hated the acting F.B.I. director Andrew McCabe, and The Washington Post reported this week that shortly after Trump fired Comey, he summoned McCabe to the Oval Office. He asked McCabe for whom he had voted in the 2016 election and then dressed him down about money his wife (who ran for office in Virginia as a Democrat) received from \u201ca political action committee controlled by a close friend of Hillary Clinton.\u201d\n\nThe list goes on. All that said, it is still not clear to me how any of this will shake out.", "title": "Opinion | Soul of a Nation", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nWASHINGTON \u2014 Much of the world has soured on American leadership since President Trump took office, a loss of faith that has opened up opportunities for other countries like China, Russia and Germany to assert themselves on the international stage, according to an extensive new survey of people living around the globe.\n\nJust 30 percent of people interviewed in 134 countries last year approved of American leadership under Mr. Trump, a drop of nearly 20 percentage points since President Barack Obama\u2019s final year and the lowest finding since the Gallup polling organization began asking the question overseas more than a decade ago. The decline was especially steep in Latin America, Europe and Canada.\n\nThe findings of the survey come just a week before Mr. Trump plans to go to Europe to attend the annual World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, a traditional gathering of political and economic elites. Mr. Trump has alienated many other countries, including longtime American allies, by pulling back from international agreements and organizations, not to mention by issuing derogatory remarks like those last week denigrating Africa and Haiti.\n\n\u201cIt makes it more challenging to lead when people are this down on your leadership,\u201d said Jon Clifton, Gallup\u2019s global managing partner. \u201cBut on the other hand, if we were sitting with President Trump and his leadership team, they would say these results are understandable because we\u2019re making tough decisions.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAmong those decisions has been abandoning the Trans-Pacific Partnership trade agreement and the Paris climate change accord, undercutting the multinational nuclear deal with Iran, assailing NATO allies for not spending more on their militaries and threatening to scrap free-trade pacts with Mexico, Canada, South Korea and others.", "title": "Souring World Views of Trump Open Doors for China and Russia", "authors": ["Peter Baker"]} {"date": "2018-01-09 00:00:00", "text": "CAPE TOWN \u2014 A train crash at a station near Johannesburg on Tuesday derailed one rail car and injured at least 226 people, adding to concerns about rail safety and oversight in South Africa after the second serious accident in a week.\n\n\u201cSix to seven\u201d people suffered moderate injuries, and 159 were taken to the hospital after the crash in Germiston, according to Eric Moloka, a spokesman for the Ekurhuleni Municipality Emergency Services. He added that there were no serious injuries.\n\n\u201cOne train was stationary. The train in motion hit it at the back,\u201d Mr. Moloka said. \u201cThe third coach from the rear then derailed, causing more injuries. But people were not seriously injured.\u201d\n\nThe accident came five days after a train crashed into two vehicles at a crossing, killing at least 19 people and injuring hundreds more, about 110 miles to the southwest, near Kroonstad.", "title": "South Africa Train Crash Injures Hundreds Outside Johannesburg", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "The concern was crystallized by the deaths in 2014 of 20 nursing home patients who had dementia or stroke complications. Many died of smoke inhalation because they could not move on their own when the fire erupted.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe fire in Miryang, about 170 miles southeast of Seoul, was the second major deadly fire in South Korea in recent weeks. Twenty-nine people were killed and 40 injured in a fire that gutted a sports center in the town of Jecheon, about 75 miles southeast of Seoul, in December. Most of the victims in that fire had become trapped in a public sauna on the second floor of the building.\n\nThe deadly fires hit the country as South Koreans remain traumatized over the sinking of the ferry Sewol in 2014, which killed more than 300 people, most of them teenagers on a school trip.\n\nThe series of accidents, including the fires, has eroded confidence in the quality of the country\u2019s public safety standards. Mr. Moon, who took office in May, has vowed to make the country\u2019s institutions safer, and later Friday morning he pledged to take action in the wake of the fire.\n\nIn a statement, the president \u201cexpressed deep regrets\u201d over the loss of life and ordered his government to launch a thorough investigation and take measures to prevent similar fires. Mr. Moon also called for quick medical support for those evacuated from the Miryang hospital.", "title": "South Korea Hospital Fire Kills at Least 37 People", "authors": ["Choe Sang-Hun"]} {"date": "2018-01-02 00:00:00", "text": "Speaking at the United Nations on Tuesday, the United States Ambassador, Nikki R. Haley, appeared to dismiss the potential for bilateral negotiations between North and South Korea.\n\n\u201cWe won\u2019t take any of the talks seriously if they don\u2019t do something to ban all nuclear weapons in North Korea,\u201d she said. \u201cWe consider this to be a very reckless regime, we don\u2019t think we need a Band-Aid; we don\u2019t think we need to smile and take a picture. We think we need to have them stop nuclear weapons and they need to stop it now.\u201d\n\nHeather Nauert, the State Department spokeswoman, said the Trump administration was still assessing whether the United States supported direct talks between South Korea and North Korea that excluded the United States.\n\n\u201cRight now, if the two countries decide that they want to have talks, that would certainly be their choice,\u201d she said.\n\nMs. Nauert added that if Mr. Kim\u2019s goal in proposing direct talks with the South was to divide the United States and South Korea, such a strategy would not succeed. \u201cThat will not happen,\u201d she said.\n\nPhoto\n\nCho Myoung-gyon, the South\u2019s point man on the North, proposed that the Korean governments hold their meeting next Tuesday in Panmunjom, a village straddling the border north of Seoul, the South Korean capital.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cWe hope the two sides sit down for frank talks,\u201d Mr. Cho, the unification minister, said at a news conference.\n\nIf the North responds positively, it will set in motion the first official dialogue between the Koreas in two years. South Korean officials hope the talks will lead to a thaw after years of high tensions between the countries and threats of war over the North\u2019s pursuit of nuclear weapons.\n\nBut analysts cautioned that a sudden move to improve ties between the Koreas could strain relations between Seoul and Washington.\n\nMr. Cho said the South was closely consulting with Washington on its dealings with the North.\n\nPanmunjom has long been a contact point for the Koreas, with both sides exchanging messages through a telephone hotline there. But the North has not used the hotline since President Moon Jae-in\u2019s conservative predecessor, the impeached President Park Geun-hye, shut down a joint industrial complex in the North Korean town of Kaesong in early 2016.\n\nOn Tuesday, Mr. Cho urged the North to restore the hotline so that both sides could discuss the agenda for the high-level talks. The governments held their last high-level dialogue in December 2015.\n\nNorth Korea\u2019s offer to send a delegation to the Winter Olympics, which are to begin in February in the South Korean town of Pyeongchang, represented a breakthrough for Mr. Moon, a dogged champion of dialogue and reconciliation with the North.\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Moon has repeatedly urged North Korea to join the Pyeongchang Olympics, hoping it would ease the military tensions over the North\u2019s nuclear and missile programs. Mr. Moon said the North\u2019s participation would compel the Koreas to open talks, which he hoped would lead to broader negotiations, involving Washington and others, for the North\u2019s denuclearization.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAfter ignoring Mr. Moon for months, calling his South Korean government an American stooge, Mr. Kim used his New Year\u2019s speech on Monday to embrace the South Korean leader\u2019s overture.\n\n\u201cI appreciate and welcome the North\u2019s positive response to our proposal that the Pyeongchang Olympics should be used as a turning point in improving South-North relations and promoting peace,\u201d Mr. Moon said early Tuesday, instructing his cabinet to move swiftly to open dialogue with North Korea.\n\nWith barely 40 days before the Olympics, the Koreas must sort out logistics and other details for North Korean athletes if they are allowed to participate, officials said.\n\nSouth Korea has proposed that the North Korean athletes travel through the 2.5-mile-wide Demilitarized Zone, the world\u2019s most heavily fortified border, a route that would be rich in symbolism. It also wants to discuss the possibility of the two Korean delegations marching together in the Games\u2019 opening ceremony.\n\nIf the North participated in the Games and the Koreas march together, it would be a milestone in inter-Korean relations.\n\nIn 2000, the year the countries held their first summit meeting, their delegations marched together at the opening ceremony of the Sydney Olympics. They again marched together at the 2004 Athens Olympics, using the single name \u201cKorea\u201d and carrying a \u201cKorea is one\u201d flag. But they competed separately in 2000 and 2004.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Breaking News Emails Sign up to receive an email from The New York Times as soon as important news breaks around the world. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nNorth Korea also sent squads to cheer for its athletes in international events in South Korea in 2002, 2003 and 2005. But such scenes came to an end after the conservatives took power in the South in 2008 and instituted tougher measures against the North\u2019s nuclear weapons development.\n\nIn June, Mr. Moon, whose election in May ended the years of conservative rule, said he hoped to see the national teams of the two Koreas march together again in Pyeongchang.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe coming talks with North Korea over its Olympic participation could be a testing ground for Mr. Kim\u2019s intentions.\n\nWhile proposing to send an Olympic delegation, Mr. Kim on Monday said South Korea should end its regular joint military exercises with the United States and stop letting the Americans bring bombers and other nuclear-capable military assets into the Korean Peninsula. Mr. Moon has suggested that South Korea and the United States could postpone their joint military drills until after the Olympics.\n\nMr. Kim also demanded that South Korea stop joining the American-led campaign to squeeze North Korea with sanctions. Instead, he said the South should work with the North to bring peace to the Korean Peninsula, while boasting that his nuclear weapons would prevent the Americans from starting a new war in Korea.\n\nAnalysts said Mr. Kim was using the North\u2019s Olympic participation to try to drive a wedge in the alliance between South Korea and the United States and between Mr. Moon and President Trump. Mr. Trump has taken a much tougher stance against the North, focusing on pressure and sanctions and once dismissing Mr. Moon\u2019s efforts for dialogue with the North as \u201cappeasement.\u201d\n\nIn an analysis of Mr. Kim\u2019s speech, the South\u2019s Unification Ministry said Mr. Kim was seeking an \u201cexit\u201d from harsh sanctions by cultivating ties with South Korea.", "title": "South Korea Proposes Border Talks With North Korea After Kim\u2019s Overture", "authors": ["Choe Sang-Hun"]} {"date": "2018-01-09 00:00:00", "text": "That created an opportunity for Mr. Moon to back out of the agreement, but at the risk of upending South Korea\u2019s relationship with Japan at a time when the countries are united in confronting North Korea over its weapons programs. The United States, the biggest ally of South Korea and Japan, had praised the 2015 agreement, saying cooperation between the two major Asian democracies was important for regional stability.\n\nUnder the \u201cfinal and irreversible\u201d settlement over the sex slaves, Japan was to make an apology in addition to providing the money for the survivors\u2019 care. South Korea in turn pledged to not criticize Japan over the issue.\n\nSouth Korea\u2019s foreign minister, Kang Kyung-wha, said Tuesday that the 2015 agreement could not be considered \u201ca genuine resolution\u201d of the issue. But she added that there was no denying an official deal had been made and said Seoul wouldn\u2019t push to renegotiate it. South Korea will set aside its own $8.8 million fund to care for the survivors, and continue discussions on what to do with the equivalent amount from Japan, Ms. Kang said.\n\nYoshihide Suga, Japan\u2019s chief cabinet secretary, said Tuesday that Tokyo would ask Seoul to carry out the deal under its original terms. \u201cThere is no room for any compromise on that agreement,\u201d he said.\n\nThe treatment of the women, known euphemistically as \u201ccomfort women,\u201d is one of the most painful legacies of Japan\u2019s occupation of Korea from 1910 to the end of World War II in 1945. Tens of thousands and possibly hundreds of thousands of women were compelled to work in brothels that served the Japanese military. In addition to Koreans, women from the Philippines, China and other countries invaded by Japan were forced into sexual slavery.", "title": "South Korea Says It Won\u2019t Scrap Sex Slaves Accord With Japan", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "And he said South Korea and its allies must seize on the North\u2019s renewed appetite for negotiations to persuade it to join broader talks involving the United States over how to end its rapidly advancing nuclear weapons program \u2014 an approach the North\u2019s chief delegate to the border talks angrily rejected on Tuesday.\n\nOtherwise, North Korea made a surprisingly conciliatory gesture during the talks, promising to send a delegation of athletes, cheerleaders and journalists to the Winter Olympics being held next month in the South Korean town of Pyeongchang. The North also agreed to more talks with the South, including a dialogue between their militaries, to ease tensions and improve ties.\n\nThis week\u2019s talks, in the border village of Panmunjom, were the first governmental dialogue between the Koreas in more than two years, and the agreements they produced were hailed as a welcome reprieve for South Koreans after a year of talk of war over the North\u2019s nuclear and long-range missile programs.\n\nBut they also came amid concern that Mr. Moon might end up facilitating Mr. Kim\u2019s strategy of fracturing the American-led sanctions campaign and driving a wedge between Seoul and Washington.\n\nPhoto\n\nAddressing such concerns, Mr. Moon said there was a limit to how far the two Koreas could go in improving ties if North Korea did not move toward dismantling its nuclear weapons program.\n\n\u201dThe two issues \u2014 improving inter-Korean relations and resolving the North Korean nuclear issue \u2014 cannot be separated,\u201d Mr. Moon said. \u201cIf the North provokes again or does not show sincerity on revising its nuclear problem, the international community will continue to apply even stronger sanctions and pressure.\u201d\n\n\u201cMy government has no intention of easing sanctions unilaterally,\u201d he added, dismissing speculation that he might lift some of the sanctions imposed by his conservative predecessors, like the closing of a joint factory park in the North Korean town of Kaesong.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nBut Mr. Moon, a vocal critic of Washington\u2019s plan to use military force to resolve the North\u2019s nuclear threat, reiterated that the ultimate goal of sanctions and pressure must be to force North Korea to negotiate. He emphasized that his top national security and foreign policy goal was to prevent war on the Korean Peninsula.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSince he took office last May, Mr. Moon has faced detractors at home, especially older and conservative South Koreans who fear he may concede too much to the North as he doggedly champions talks. Such concerns have persisted even as Mr. Moon has moved to build more powerful missiles and get new weapons from the United States to counter the North\u2019s nuclear threat.\n\nConservative South Koreans, as well as American policymakers, remain deeply skeptical of Mr. Kim, the North Korean leader, who has accelerated the pace of nuclear and missile tests since taking power six years ago.\n\nIn a New Year\u2019s Day speech, Mr. Kim proposed dialogue with the South to discuss his country\u2019s participation in the Pyeongchang Olympics, which Mr. Moon has called for repeatedly. But he wants North Korea to be accepted as a nuclear weapons state, even boasting in his speech that he now had a \u201cbutton\u201d in his office to launch nuclear missiles at the mainland United States. At the same time, he urged Koreans on both sides to work together for peace.\n\nDuring the border talks on Tuesday, the North\u2019s top negotiator, Ri Son-kwon, categorically rejected the South\u2019s attempt to discuss the nuclear issue, calling it \u201cabsurd\u201d and warning that it could derail efforts to improve inter-Korean relations. He said North Korea\u2019s nuclear weapons were not built to attack South Koreans, Chinese or Russians, but were \u201caimed solely at the United States.\u201d\n\nFor decades, North Korea has refused to discuss its nuclear weapons program with the South, insisting that it is an issue to be addressed only by it and the United States.\n\nOn Tuesday, Canada and the United States will host a meeting in Vancouver, British Columbia, of foreign ministers from countries that supported the United Nations-backed effort to repel North Korean forces after the 1950 invasion of South Korea. China said on Wednesday that it would not attend the meeting because not all of the main parties to the conflict would be in attendance.", "title": "South Korea\u2019s Leader Credits Trump for North Korea Talks", "authors": ["Choe Sang-Hun"]} {"date": "2018-01-31 00:00:00", "text": "A supernatural thriller from John Krasinski, a bawdy sex-prevention comedy, a new TV project from Jordan Peele and odd Bill Murray stories are all part of the South by Southwest film festival lineup, organizers announced Wednesday.\n\nThough movie distribution models are continuing to shift, the festival\u2019s producer, Janet Pierson, said SXSW\u2019s role was unchanged. \u201cOur job is to connect talent with audience,\u201d she said by phone from Austin, Tex., the festival\u2019s home. \u201cAs the different means of delivery and formats change, we\u2019re just looking for people who make compelling work.\u201d\n\nSXSW has long showcased new television series, and this year it will also screen independent TV pilots. But the movies are still the biggest thing. This year\u2019s festival will run March 9-17. Here are five selections from the lineup that are likely to generate chatter.\n\nVideo\n\nA Quiet Place\n\nThe chills are hushed in the festival\u2019s pick for opening night. John Krasinski directs and acts alongside Emily Blunt, his wife, in this horror movie about a family that must stay quiet to ward off a menace that strikes at any sound. The film seems to be a stark contrast (both in tone and title) to that of Mr. Krasinski\u2019s previous directorial effort, \u201cThe Hollars.\u201d The festival does have enthusiastic horror audiences who should have fun with this concept, especially if the movie delivers the kind of tension that its trailer sustains.\n\nPhoto\n\nBlockers\n\nSXSW often makes room for a fun R-rated comedy. \u201cBridesmaids\u201d and \u201cSausage Party\u201d have taken those slots in years past. Now comes the directorial debut of the \u201cPitch Perfect\u201d screenwriter Kay Cannon. It\u2019s about parents who try to prevent their daughters from having sex on prom night. It features Leslie Mann and Kathryn Newton, as well as John Cena, who has been something of a scene-stealer in comedies like \u201cTrainwreck\u201d and \u201cSisters.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSupport the Girls\n\nThe Austin filmmaker Andrew Bujalski has made idiosyncratic films spanning quirky topics like computer chess and personal training. His new movie is set in the world of Hooters-style restaurants, featuring Regina Hall as a manager of one such establishment. An ensemble cast that includes Haley Lu Richardson, Lea DeLaria and James Le Gros certainly has us curious about what Mr. Bujalski has up his sleeve here.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe Bill Murray Stories: Life Lessons Learned From a Mythical Man\n\nRemember that time Bill Murray spontaneously tended bar during SXSW? Or when he joined a kickball game or gave a chef his watch? The stories of regular folks\u2019 random encounters with the actor have piled up, and there\u2019s now a movie about them. The director Tommy Avallone interviewed people worldwide who had fun Murray tales to tell, and includes plenty of footage of the actor.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe Last O.G.\n\nFresh off his Oscar nominations for \u201cGet Out,\u201d the writer and director Jordan Peele will be bringing episodes of this television project to Austin. The series, with some episodes written by Mr. Peele and John Carcieri, stars Tracy Morgan as an ex-con adjusting to life on the outside after 15 years in prison. This will be Mr. Morgan\u2019s first major television role since he was critically injured in a traffic accident, and could be a fun return to the small screen (with a big screen premiere) for Mr. Peele, who first rose to prominence in the Comedy Central series \u201cKey and Peele.\u201d After the festival, \u201cThe Last O.G.\u201d will begin running April 3 on TBS.", "title": "South by Southwest 2018: 5 Titles to Watch For", "authors": ["Mekado Murphy"]} {"date": "2018-01-06 00:00:00", "text": "A federal judge has approved a $15 million settlement between Southwest Airlines and members of a class-action lawsuit who allege that the company, along with three other airlines, conspired to limit the number of seats available to customers and keep ticket prices high.\n\nIn a statement, Southwest said the settlement \u201cdoes not constitute any admission of wrongdoing\u201d and denied having entered into any unlawful agreements with its competitors.\n\nThe move appeared to represent a break of sorts between Southwest and the other three defendants named in the lawsuit: American Airlines, Delta Air Lines and United Airlines. Those companies have also denied doing anything illegal, and they continue to fight the allegations.\n\nAs part of the agreement preliminarily approved on Wednesday, Southwest agreed to make the $15 million cash payment and also to provide what court documents called \u201cextensive cooperation.\u201d Those cooperative efforts, according to the court documents, will include a \u201cfull account of facts\u201d relevant to the plaintiffs\u2019 case as well as a series of informational meetings and interviews with industry experts and Southwest employees facilitated by the company.", "title": "Southwest Airlines Settles Suit but Denies Colluding to Keep Ticket Prices High", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-28 00:00:00", "text": "A spinning, silver geodesic sphere reminiscent of the \u201cDancing With the Stars\u201d mirror ball trophy is moving through space and blinking as it orbits Earth every 90 minutes.\n\nKnown as the Humanity Star, it was built to reflect the sun\u2019s light and \u201cencourage people to consider their place in the universe,\u201d according to its website.\n\nSome astronomers are not pleased.\n\nAlthough the object \u201csounds like jolly nice fun,\u201d it also \u201cfills me with a big dose of dread,\u201d Caleb A. Scharf, director of the Columbia Astrobiology Center at Columbia University, wrote in Scientific American.\n\nSpace is already polluted by artificial light, making it more difficult for astronomers to monitor cosmic events, he wrote.", "title": "Space Gets an Artificial Star. Astronomers Ask: Do We Need More?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "What story could this image tell?\n\nUse your imagination to write the opening of a short story or poem inspired by this photo and post it in the comments.\n\nThen read the related article to find out what this picture is all about.", "title": "Space Travel", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-22 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cWe were pretty na\u00efve about that,\u201d Mr. Musk said in July at a conference in Washington, D.C. \u201cAt first, it sounds really easy. Just stick two first stages on as strap-on boosters. How hard can that be? But then everything changes. All the loads change. Aerodynamics totally change. You\u2019ve tripled the vibration and acoustics.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe central core was redesigned and reinforced to handle the stresses, one of the key reasons that the Heavy is more than four years behind schedule. While the two side boosters are reused from earlier Falcon 9 launches, the core is all new, as is the second stage.\n\nAnother tricky aspect is the large number of rocket engines. A Falcon 9 booster has nine of SpaceX\u2019s Merlin engines, each putting out 190,000 pounds of thrust. The Heavy triples that to 27 engines and a total of more than 5 million pounds of thrust.\n\nAll of the parts of the Heavy finally arrived in Florida late last year. Since then, SpaceX has been modifying the launchpad to handle the larger rocket. In the coming days, the company is expected to conduct a critical test that would light all 27 engines at once with the rocket anchored to the pad.\n\nPhoto\n\nIf the test flight succeeds, SpaceX has four additional Heavy launches on its manifest, including one for the United States Air Force. SpaceX also announced last year that a Heavy would be used to sling two space tourists on a weeklong trip around the moon, although it has offered no further information in almost a year.\n\nGoing big in an era of rockets on a diet\n\nSome wonder how much business exists for a rocket as big as the Heavy. \u201cI\u2019ve always scratched my head, why would you do this?\u201d said Jim Cantrell, who was part of the founding team of SpaceX in 2002 but left soon afterward. He is now chief executive of Vector, which is building rockets much smaller than SpaceX\u2019.\n\nWith advances in electronics and miniaturization, satellites have been getting smaller, and the trend among rocket start-ups \u2014 has been toward smaller and smaller rockets. (Jeffrey P. Bezos\u2019 Blue Origin is a notable exception.)\n\nFor $1.5 million, Vector will launch a 140-pound payload, with flights beginning this year. Other new companies aiming at small payloads include Rocket Lab, which over the weekend had its first successful orbital test flight, and Richard Branson\u2019s Virgin Orbit.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s pretty good financial and technical reasons for going smaller,\u201d Mr. Cantrell said.\n\nSome suggest that NASA could take advantage of the Falcon Heavy as a cheaper alternative to the Space Launch System it is developing to launch robotic probes and astronauts out into the solar system. Although the NASA rocket would be larger and more powerful than the Heavy \u2014 in fact it would rival the Saturn 5 \u2014 it is also much more expensive and would fly only once every few years at a cost likely to exceed $1 billion a launch.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe Trump administration has declared that sending astronauts back to the moon is a priority and has advocated a greater role in the space program for private companies. Its budget proposal for 2019, which will be released next month, should include more details of what it plans to do.\n\nCharles Miller, a former NASA official who served in the Trump administration\u2019s transition team, thinks the agency should consider turning to cheaper, commercial alternatives like the Falcon Heavy.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s the core around which I would build a near-term return-to-the-moon strategy,\u201d Mr. Miller said.", "title": "SpaceX\u2019s Big Rocket, the Falcon Heavy, Finally Reaches the Launchpad", "authors": ["Kenneth Chang"]} {"date": "2018-01-09 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nOn Sunday, SpaceX launched its first rocket of the year. During the company\u2019s webcast of the liftoff, everything seemed to go without a hitch. The second stage of the rocket headed toward orbit as the booster returned to land at Cape Canaveral. But on Monday, word started spreading that something went very wrong with this highly classified mission, code-named \u201cZuma.\u201d\n\nWhat was Zuma?\n\nNorthrop Grumman Corporation built the satellite, and the customer was the United States government. But beyond that, we don\u2019t know much. Zuma is presumed to be some sort of spy satellite. We don\u2019t even know which federal agency hired Northrop Grumman to build it.\n\nThe launch was originally scheduled for November, but was postponed for additional analysis of the nose cone that protects the payload during its passage through the atmosphere. During the webcast, the SpaceX commentator indicated that the nose cone was jettisoned properly.\n\nHow do we know something went wrong?\n\nNeither SpaceX nor Northrop Grumman nor anyone else confirmed successful deployment of Zuma.\n\nOn Monday, Peter B. de Selding, editor of SpaceIntelReport wrote on Twitter:\n\nArs Technica, Bloomberg and The Wall Street Journal followed with stories that reported that the satellite had been lost. The Verge examined what was and was not known.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhat appears to have happened?\n\nZuma apparently never separated from the second stage and plunged back to Earth.\n\nWouldn\u2019t that be SpaceX\u2019s fault?\n\nNot necessarily. According to an article in Wired last November, Northrop Grumman not only built Zuma but also provided the part that connected the satellite to the rocket known as the payload adapter. For most launches, SpaceX provides the payload adapter.", "title": "SpaceX\u2019s Secret Satellite Mission May Have Failed. What Happened?", "authors": ["Kenneth Chang"]} {"date": "2018-01-15 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cTo be sworn in, you have to do so physically,\u201d Mr. Rajoy said. \u201cRealism and common sense should prevail.\u201d\n\nMr. Rajoy\u2019s warning was clearly an attempt to add to the already heavy pressures on Catalonia\u2019s separatist lawmakers, a fractious group who are divided over how to revive their failed independence drive.\n\nThe separatists know that \u201cany benevolent interpretation of the rules to favor Puigdemont could open the door for a ruling by the constitutional court, which could then block everything,\u201d said Pablo Sim\u00f3n, a professor of politics at the Carlos III University in Madrid.\n\nOn the other hand, he added, \u201cif it\u2019s not Puidgemont, then who is the alternative?\u201d\n\nIndeed, the fragile parliamentary majority the separatists won in December is further tested by the fact that eight of their 70 elected lawmakers are either in jail in Madrid or have joined Mr. Puigdemont in Belgium.\n\nOriol Junqueras, the former deputy leader of Catalonia, is among the jailed politicians who have been denied bail by Spain\u2019s judiciary.\n\nMr. Rajoy\u2019s tough stance underscored the larger quandary for Catalonia and its deadlock with Spain, which now threatens to fester indefinitely. Later on Monday, legal experts of the Catalan parliament backed Mr. Rajoy\u2019s position, warning that Mr. Puigdemont could not take office remotely without breaching the assembly\u2019s own rules.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe region\u2019s aspirations for independence have ebbed and flowed for generations. In recent years, those appeals were fueled by grievances that Spain was siphoning off the wealth of the prosperous northeastern region.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nNevertheless, as Mr. Rajoy was speaking, a court in Barcelona found the former governing party of Catalonia guilty of taking bribes worth about 6.6 million euros while awarding building contracts to renovate one of the city\u2019s most famous concert halls, the Palau de la M\u00fasica. Most of the contracts were awarded to Ferrovial, one of Spain\u2019s main construction companies.\n\nThe former treasurer of the party, called Convergence, Daniel Os\u00e0car, was sentenced to four years and five months in prison, while a dozen former officials and consultants who worked for the concert hall also received prison sentences.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nF\u00e9lix Millet, who created and ran the concert hall\u2019s foundation, was sentenced to almost 10 years in prison and fined 4.1 million euros for embezzling public money.\n\nOver all, the court found that 23.7 million euros of public money was embezzled during the decade from 1999 to 2009.\n\nThe case originated during the financial crisis that set off Catalonia\u2019s latest independence drive. The judgment is now certain to be used by unionists who argue that Catalonia\u2019s own leadership has done at least as good a job as Madrid has at siphoning off the region\u2019s wealth, and that separation is no solution.\n\nThe Convergence party was founded by Jordi Pujol after Spain\u2019s return to democracy and Mr. Pujol then governed Catalonia for more than two decades, from 1980 to 2003.\n\nHis successor as party leader, Artur Mas, embraced the independence drive in 2012, after a dispute with Mr. Rajoy over whether the wealthy region of Catalonia should gain better fiscal treatment in a Spanish tax system that redistributes money to the poorer regions from the richer ones.\n\nOn Monday, Mr. Mas defended his party, as well as his former party treasurer, who is among those appealing the sentences. He argued that his party, which was eventually rebranded, had already paid a high price for its corruption links and should not face further prosecution.\n\n\u201cWhat more political responsibilities can there be, when the party itself has disappeared?\u201d he asked.\n\nIn Madrid, Mr. Rajoy is also under increased pressure, after calling a snap election in Catalonia that yielded another separatist victory and instead sank his own Popular Party, which came in last.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Rajoy acknowledged on Monday that his party had made mistakes. But he defended his own handling of Catalonia, saying that he had made decisions that were \u201cgood for the country, if sometimes not for the Popular Party.\u201d", "title": "Spain\u2019s Prime Minister Threatens to Extend Direct Rule Over Catalonia", "authors": ["Raphael Minder"]} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "Dear Diary:\n\nMy favorite hair clip broke, so I made a special trip from Brooklyn to Clyde\u2019s Pharmacy on the Upper East Side.\n\nImagine my dismay when I arrived to find a \u201cgoing out of business\u201d sign in the window. I rushed inside, hoping that I had arrived just in time.\n\nThe rack of hair clips had been cleaned out. There were only a few girlie bows hanging on it. I glanced around. Most of the shelves had been picked bare. Weary sales assistants were being asked about items that were now long gone.\n\nA middle-age woman with smooth skin approached the hair clip rack, sales clerk in tow.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t see any claw clips,\u201d the woman said. \u201cThe French ones.\u201d", "title": "Special Trip for Hair Clips", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-07 00:00:00", "text": "Elisabeth Moss won the Golden Globe for best actress in a television drama for her role in \u201cThe Handmaid\u2019s Tale.\u201d In her speech, she quoted from Margaret Atwood \u2014 whose novel of the same name inspired the series \u2014 and celebrated the marginalized voices that are reaching the mainstream.\n\nThis is from Margaret Atwood: \u201cWe were the people who were not in the papers. We lived in the blank white spaces at the edge of print. It gave us more freedom. We lived in the gaps between the stories.\u201d Margaret Atwood, this is for you and all of the women who came before you and after you, who were brave enough to speak out against intolerance and injustice and to fight for equality and freedom in this world. We no longer live in the blank white spaces at the edge of print. We no longer live in the gaps between the stories. We are the story in print. And we are writing the story ourselves. Thank you.\n\nLaura Dern accepted the award for best supporting actress in a TV series, for her role in \u201cBig Little Lies.\u201d In that show she plays Renata Klein, the mother of a girl who is being harassed at school. She used part of her acceptance speech to express support for those who speak out against abuse and spoke about playing an \u201coutrageous, complicated woman \u2014 a terrified mother.\u201d\n\nTerrified because her little girl was being abused and bullied, and she was too afraid to speak up. Many of us were taught not to tattle. It was a culture of silencing and that was normalized. I urge all of us to not only support survivors and bystanders who are brave enough to tell their truth, but to promote restorative justice. May we also, please, protect and employ them. May we teach our children that speaking out without the fear of retribution is our culture\u2019s new North Star. Bless you, bless everyone who worked on this. All the people who support me and my beautiful children, thank you for all of your work and love.\n\nFrances McDormand, who won best actress in a film drama for her part in \u201cThree Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri,\u201d referenced the #MeToo movement.\n\nSo, many of you know, I keep my politics private, but it was really great to be in this room tonight and to be a part of the tectonic shift in our industry\u2019s power structure. Trust me, the women in this room tonight are not here for the food. We are here for the work. Thank you.\n\nGary Oldman won the award for best actor in a film drama for portraying Winston Churchill in \u201cDarkest Hour.\u201d He said the role made him consider the importance of strong, morally sound political leadership.", "title": "Speeches From Elisabeth Moss and Others at the Golden Globes", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cA congressman walks into a bar ...\u201d\n\nAlcohol \u2014 perhaps more than any product \u2014 has been a perennial target of regulation and a source of public revenue. It has inspired our government\u2019s first tax, subsequent rebellions, consumer product regulations and unrestrained effort at eradicating it as an industry.\n\nJoin us for an event at Wigle Whiskey, Pittsburgh\u2019s first distillery after Prohibition, to learn some of the historical highlights of the wild historical booze ride in the United States \u2014 and to examine what the future holds for drinking in Pennsylvania and across the country.\n\nClay Risen, a spirits expert and the deputy Op-Ed editor at The New York Times, will moderate the discussion with Meredith Meyer Grelli, a co-founder of Wigle Whiskey and Threadbare Cider and Mead; Leslie A. Przybylek, the senior curator at the Senator John Heinz History Center in Pittsburgh; and Paul Costa, a Pennsylvania state representative and the Democratic chairman of the House Liquor Control Committee.", "title": "Spirits, Culture and Politics in America", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-01 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cWhite House Weighs Separating Families to Deter Migrants\u201d (news article, Dec. 22):\n\nThe Trump administration\u2019s plan to separate families caught entering the country illegally is not only cruel, but also runs counter to the tenets of sound, compassionate child welfare practice developed over decades. Doing everything possible to avoid unnecessary removal of children from parents is considered vital because it is in children\u2019s best interest and because it makes fiscal sense.\n\nFor children who must be separated for safety reasons, every effort should be made to place them with families. Child welfare systems everywhere are reducing their reliance on residential care because institutions are no place for children to live even briefly and because they are extremely costly.\n\nSimple humanity tells us that children and families who have endured the fears and dangers of fleeing their homes owing to poverty and violence will suffer lifelong trauma if also subjected to the destruction of the family unit. As a society we will be judged by how we treat the most vulnerable among us, and the draconian policy being contemplated here betrays a decidedly un-American heartlessness.\n\nSUSAN NOTKIN, WASHINGTON\n\nThe writer is senior vice president, Center for the Study of Social Policy.", "title": "Opinion | Splitting Up Families: A Heartless Migrant Policy", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-03 00:00:00", "text": "In the United States, streaming services like Spotify, Apple Music and Amazon Music account for more than two-thirds of the business, according to Nielsen, and are still growing rapidly. According to BuzzAngle, another music data tracker, American listeners streamed 377 billion songs last year, up 50 percent from 2016.\n\nSpotify is by far the most popular audio streaming outlet, with at least 60 million paying subscribers around the world and an additional 80 million who use its ad-supported free version, according to the company\u2019s most recent public statements. Apple says it has at least 30 million subscribers to its Apple Music service, which is available only by subscription.\n\nDespite Spotify\u2019s size, it has never turned a profit, and music licensing costs are still its greatest expense. In 2016, Spotify had about $3.3 billion in revenue, up 52 percent from the year before, but its net loss also grew sharply, to about $600 million, according to its most recent filings with European regulators. The company is based in Sweden.\n\nSpotify would be coming to the public stock markets at an auspicious time. Last year, 138 companies \u2014 including well-known ones like Snap Inc., the parent of Snapchat \u2014 went public, up 45 percent from 2016, according to data from Thomson Reuters. Together they raised $30.6 billion, roughly double the amount raised in 2016.\n\nBut last year\u2019s burst of activity remained well below the decade-high mark set in 2014, as the ease of raising money in private markets has dissuaded big start-ups from pursuing I.P.O.s. Companies like Uber and Airbnb have pushed off market debuts while amassing valuations that rival their publicly traded brethren.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nWhat Spotify is doing is different, however, and has few precedents. Most companies that have pursued direct listings have been much smaller, with the exception of Freddie Mac in 1989. Deal makers and analysts have said a direct listing is available to Spotify because of its already wide name recognition among potential investors, which makes the standard I.P.O. meet-and-greets largely unnecessary.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nA prospectus from Spotify, expected to be made public before the listing, would shine additional light on the company\u2019s finances and on the economics underlying streaming music.\n\nWhen Pandora went public, it, too, was buoyed by rapid user and revenue growth but dogged by a lack of profitability. Last year, short on cash and with its growth slowed, Pandora accepted a $480 million investment from SiriusXM that gave that SiriusXM a 19 percent stake and three board seats. In 2017, Pandora\u2019s stock lost 62 percent of its value.\n\nSpotify is hoping to avoid that fate with newly renegotiated licensing deals with the major record companies that lessened Spotify\u2019s royalty rates by a few percentage points, and by maintaining its growth around the world. The service is available in 61 territories, from Greece to Guatemala.\n\nBut while streaming has lifted revenues at the major record companies, which have minority stakes in the company, musicians and songwriters remain skeptical of Spotify\u2019s model, and of their ability to earn livable wages from Spotify.\n\nIn late December, Wixen Music Publishing, which represents songs by Tom Petty, Neil Young, Stevie Nicks and other songwriters, sued Spotify in a federal court in California, accusing it of using thousands of songs without proper licenses, the latest in a string of such copyright suits. The suit asks for $1.6 billion in damages, $150,000 for each song.\n\nSpotify had no comment on the lawsuit.", "title": "Spotify Is Said to Be Going Public in Early 2018", "authors": ["Ben Sisario", "Michael J. De La Merced"]} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "One way to offset the heavy weighting of tech stocks in exchange-traded funds and index funds that reflect market advances is through an index like the Guggenheim Equal Weight S.&.P. 500 E.T.F., Mr. Brightman said. Equal weight indexes own the same amount of all stocks and so are not overexposed to market highfliers. Over the last decade, the S.&.P. 500 Equal Weight index has returned just over 10 percent annually, while the market-cap-weighted S.&.P. 500. has returned less than 9 percent annually.\n\nFind Your Fund Explore Fund Results \u00bb See how the largest, leading and lagging funds compare. Search by Category \u00bb Find funds by their type, performance, risk or expenses. For more fund information, search morningstar.com.\n\nTom Galvin is lead manager of the Columbia Select Large Cap Growth fund. Though his mandate requires holding growth companies, he has been lightening up on some highfliers. \u201cWe have been trimming back some of the winners,\u201d Mr. Galvin said. The fund has sold off roughly 20 percent of its Amazon stock and roughly one-third of its position in Facebook, he said.\n\nStill, Mr. Galvin emphasizes that the tech rabbits have raced ahead largely because they\u2019ve met or exceeded expectations. Apple\u2019s year-over-year revenue growth has accelerated in recent quarters. Apple cited its revived strength in China, along with better-than-expected unit sales of iPhones, iPads and Macs, in its most recent quarterly report.\n\nSimilarly, a year ago, analysts expected Facebook to earn about $4 a share over the next 12 months, Mr. Galvin said. But Facebook succeeded so well in making its gigantic membership an audience for ads, it earned over $5 a share in the last four quarters.\n\nGrowth stocks may also have fared well because they are suited to current economic conditions. \u201cI think growth stocks do very well in a low-inflation environment, when pricing power is elusive and therefore unit growth is the key driver to profit growth,\u201d Mr. Galvin said. There is a flip side, though: \u201cIf you felt strongly we were moving to a sustained reflationary environment, you\u2019d want more value,\u201d he added.\n\nSebastien Page, head of the Global Multi-Asset division within T. Rowe Price, also sees merit in increasing value holdings. \u201cAs a general statement, value should benefit more than growth from the tax cut,\u201d he said. Financial companies, typically considered value stocks, pay relatively high taxes and will benefit from a tax cut.\n\nBut because the market has risen almost nonstop since 2009, value stocks are also fairly expensive, some argue. \u201cYou don\u2019t want to buy your beaten down, distressed deep value stocks,\u201d said Mike Fleisher, lead portfolio manager of the Legg Mason BW Dynamic Large Cap Value fund. \u201cYou want to buy a value stock with a catalyst.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Fleisher cited Citigroup as a worthwhile stock. \u201cThey\u2019re buying back shares,\u201d he noted. \u201cOur quantitative research finds that when a company has bought back shares over the previous 12 months, it tends to outperform the next 12 months,\u201d he said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFor investors disinclined to pick through hundreds of stocks to find the right value catalyst, there is another way to rebalance. Mr. Page of T. Rowe Price favors stocks in Europe, Japan, Australia and Canada. \u201cNon-U.S. stocks have only been this cheap relative to U.S. stocks 7 percent of the time in the last 15 years,\u201d he explained. Two E.T.F.s that invest in such developed market stocks are the iShares MSCI EAFE E.T.F. and the Vanguard FTSE Developed Markets E.T.F.\n\nMr. Brightman also favors rebalancing across more than just the growth-value axis. \u201cEvery sector of the U.S. stock market is expensive,\u201d he said. \u201cThe fascination of the public with a narrow group of tech stocks is beginning to look a little bubbly.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nSo-called value stocks are also no bargain, he said. \u201cYou will not escape a bear market by being in value stocks,\u201d Mr. Brightman said.\n\nThe market won\u2019t necessarily decline simply because prices are high, he added. \u201cIt just means over the longer term you would get lower returns,\u201d he said.\n\nMr. Brightman urges very broad diversification. He includes United States equities, other developed market equities, emerging market stocks, real estate investment trusts, commodities and government bonds.\n\n\u201cIf you have a long horizon, equal weighting and rebalancing are your friends,\u201d he said.", "title": "Stampede of Tech Giants Gives Rebalancing New Appeal", "authors": ["Norm Alster"]} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "What do you think this image is saying? How does it relate to and comment on current events and society? What do you think of its message?\n\nTell us in the comments, then read the related article to find out what it means.", "title": "Stamps", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "But like Mr. Carter, he said, he had no illusions about the nation\u2019s need for secret intelligence. \u201cLots of people think President Carter called me in and said, \u2018Clean the place up and straighten it out.\u2019 He never did that,\u201d Mr. Turner said in an interview after his retirement. \u201cFrom the very beginning he was intensely interested in having good intelligence. He wanted to understand the mechanisms \u2014 from our satellites to our spies to our methods of analyzing what was happening. He was extremely supportive of the intelligence operations.\u201d\n\nHe added: \u201cThe Carter administration had no bias against covert action. The C.I.A. had a problem with covert action itself, because it was in this state of shock from the criticisms it had gone through\u201d during the 1970s.\n\nImage Mr. Turner as C.I.A. director in 1979. Credit Associated Press\n\nEarly on, Mr. Turner said, he faced a life-or-death question. C.I.A. officers had come to him and told him that they had an agent \u201calmost inside\u201d a terrorist organization. The officers, he said, wanted to ask the agent \u201cto do one more thing to prove his bona fides\u201d \u2014 \u201cto go out and murder one of the members of the government.\u201d\n\nThey asked, \u201cDo we permit him to do that?\u201d \u201cAnd I said, \u2018No, we pull him out,\u2019 \u201d Mr. Turner said. \u201cI was not going to have the United States party to a murder.\u201d\n\nStill, under Mr. Turner, the C.I.A. mounted covert actions aimed at Moscow, Warsaw and Prague, printing and distributing magazines and journals in Poland and Czechoslovakia, circulating the written work of dissidents in the Soviet Union, placing fax machines and tape cassettes in the hands of people behind the Iron Curtain. These acts, approved by Mr. Carter and his national security adviser, Zbigniew Brzezinski, sought to subvert the control of information that was the foundation of repression in the Communist world.\n\nNone of this enhanced the C.I.A.\u2019s understanding of the Soviet Union, Mr. Turner acknowledged. \u201cWe were appreciating as early as \u201978 that the Soviet economy was in serious trouble,\u201d he said after the Cold War was over, but \u201cwe didn\u2019t make the leap that we should have made \u2014 I should have made \u2014 that the economic trouble would lead to political trouble. We thought they would tighten their belt under a Stalin-like regime and continue marching on.\u201d\n\nThe C.I.A. did not see the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan coming in December 1979. But days later, Mr. Carter ordered the agency to begin shipping weapons to the Afghan resistance. During the 1980s, under President Ronald Reagan, the United States poured billions of dollars into that C.I.A.-run effort. The Reagan administration also greatly expanded small covert operations that had begun under Mr. Carter to undermine the left-wing Sandinista regime in Nicaragua.", "title": "Stansfield Turner, C.I.A. Director Who Confronted Communism Under Carter, Dies at 94", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-07 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nIn their push to highlight the problems of sexual harassment and gender inequality, eight actresses at Sunday night\u2019s Golden Globes ceremony are extending their political statements to their plus-ones.\n\nLaura Dern, Amy Poehler, Susan Sarandon, Meryl Streep, Emma Stone, Emma Watson, Michelle Williams and Shailene Woodley say that on the red carpet, they will each be accompanied by activists in a range of fields. The move is part of a widening effort by prominent Hollywood women, who formed the umbrella group Time\u2019s Up, to extend the focus on sexual harassment to women marginalized because of class, sexuality, ethnicity or race.\n\nThe initiative\u2019s efforts range from the establishment of a legal fund to fight sexual harassment to symbolic statements like wearing black on the red carpet and now inviting activists to the Globes.\n\nIn a joint statement, the eight activists said they hoped that by attending the Golden Globes, they would redirect attention from abusers to survivors and lasting solutions.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cWe believe we are nearing a tipping point in transforming the culture of violence in the countries where we live and work,\u201d the women said. \u201cIt\u2019s a moment to transform both the written and unwritten rules that devalue the lives and experiences of women.\u201d\n\nHere\u2019s who you\u2019ll see on the red carpet:\n\n\u2014 Tarana Burke, senior director of the nonprofit Girls for Gender Equity and founder of the #MeToo movement, will attend with Ms. Williams, a nominee for her performance in \u201cAll the Money in the World.\u201d", "title": "Stars Will Take Activists to the Golden Globes Red Carpet", "authors": ["Cara Buckley"]} {"date": "2017-12-31 00:00:00", "text": "Here\u2019s what to expect in the week ahead:\n\nMARKETS\n\nTrading Takes a One-Day Rest\n\nThe question for financial markets in 2018 is whether they can continue to chalk up big gains. Most markets around the world will be closed on Monday, as traders get an extra day of rest. Across much of the United States, 2018 will begin with a continuation of unusually cold temperatures, according to the National Weather Service. Zach Wichter\n\nSMALL BUSINESS\n\nMarijuana Becomes Legal in California\n\nOn Monday, recreational marijuana will become legal in California, the eighth state to legalize the drug. But because marijuana still does not have legal standing with the federal government, it can be difficult for marijuana start-ups to get funding from banks, or generally to conduct business as usual. Zach Wichter\n\nECONOMY\n\nRelease of Minutes of Fed\u2019s December Meeting\n\nThe Federal Reserve was full of optimism at the end of 2017. The Fed raised its benchmark interest rate at its final meeting of the year and issued a revised economic forecast predicting faster growth in 2018, citing the effects of a major federal tax cut. The Fed also said it did not anticipate raising interest rates more quickly in response to faster growth. The question is why the Fed is willing to let the good times roll. The minutes of the December meeting, which the Fed is scheduled to release on Wednesday, may provide some answers. Binyamin Appelbaum\n\nDecember Jobs Numbers Coming Out\n\nThe Bureau of Labor Statistics is likely to report another month of strong job gains on Friday, when it releases December\u2019s data. It is too early to notice the effect of the new tax law, but economists expect that the unemployment rate will hold steady at 4.1 percent. Natalie Kitroeff", "title": "Start of a New Year of Trading, and Jobs Report From December", "authors": ["The New York Times"]} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "Those particular changes struck Senator Andrea Stewart-Cousins, the leader of the Senate Democratic Conference, and the only female leader in either chamber of the Legislature, as tone-deaf amid the clamor of the #MeToo movement.\n\n\u201cTo emphasize the punishment for filing a false report while not emphasizing the seriousness of sexual harassment is exactly the type of intimidation that has silenced so many through the years, and encourages perpetrators to attack accusers,\u201d Ms. Stewart-Cousins, from Westchester County, said in a statement, adding that she was not consulted about the new policy. She called it \u201cproof the Senate leadership is not serious about combating sexual harassment.\u201d\n\nThe new policy, last updated in 2007, comes weeks after a prominent member of the chamber, Senator Jeffrey Klein, who represents parts of the Bronx and Westchester County, was accused by a former aide of unwanted sexual advances.\n\nMr. Klein, who leads the eight-member Independent Democratic Conference, has denied the accusations.\n\nThe Republican leader of the chamber, John J. Flanagan of Long Island, has said that Mr. Klein will not be investigated by the Senate. Mr. Flanagan explained his decision by saying that Mr. Klein\u2019s accuser, Erica Vladimer, who left Mr. Klein\u2019s staff shortly after she accused the senator of forcibly kissing her outside an Albany bar in 2015, had not ever made a formal complaint.\n\nMr. Flanagan works with Mr. Klein\u2019s Independent Democratic Conference and another Democratic senator, Simcha Felder of Brooklyn, to maintain control of the Senate, even though Democrats hold a slight numerical edge in the 63-seat chamber.", "title": "State Senate\u2019s New Harassment Rules Include Warning to False Accusers", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "The distinguished gentlemen from the deep-red congressional districts swamped the aisle first \u2014 claiming their seats some five hours early with paper scraps, jackets and small electronics \u2014 earning televised cameos as President Trump arrived for the handshakes and great-to-see-ya\u2019s.\n\nA cleaning crew worked every corner of the grand chamber, running a vacuum over the royal blue carpet, kneading the underside of a railing with a rag. A man, wearing what appeared to be baseball batting gloves, adjusted a temporary light fixture beneath a less temporary chandelier in Statuary Hall. There, lawmakers spent their Tuesday afternoon staring into cameras and holding forth on what the president might say, should say, couldn\u2019t say \u2014 and why it all mattered very, very much.\n\n\u201cIt is what our country does,\u201d Representative Steny H. Briefly. Kind Of.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-27 00:00:00", "text": "Neil Bradley, the executive vice president and chief policy officer for the U.S. Chamber of Commerce, said he hoped Mr. Trump would offer a vision for how the country could build upon his past successes to seek more growth and opportunity.\n\nPart of that, Mr. Bradley said, should be a forceful case for infrastructure spending, including a dedicated revenue source like an increase in the federal gasoline tax to fund transportation improvements.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019ve been patching over the problems in that system,\u201d Mr. Bradley said. He said public-private partnerships, like the ones the administration has considered, can save money for taxpayers, but he added, \u201cIf we really want to rebuild our infrastructure and modernize, we can\u2019t keep patching it over, and we can\u2019t do it on the cheap.\u201d\n\nMr. Trump is also likely to call for more efforts to combat the opioid epidemic. But aides declined to say whether Mr. Trump would talk about health care in the speech, a subject of debate among administration officials for weeks.\n\nThe White House is proud of the fact that Republicans were able to repeal even a small part of the Affordable Care Act \u2014 the penalties for people who go without health insurance. The president could take credit for that and for regulatory efforts to dismantle other parts of the law that Republicans dislike. But his party appears far away from its yearslong goal of doing away with the law entirely.\n\nIt is also unclear what Mr. Trump might say about the high cost of many prescription drugs. Mr. Trump said last year that drug companies were \u201cgetting away with murder,\u201d but he has not taken many steps to solve the problem.\n\nConsumer advocates and employers, who pay the bills for drug coverage, are hoping to hear more from the president, who could at least point to the work of the Food and Drug Administration to speed the approval of lower-cost generic drugs.\n\nOn national security, Mr. Trump\u2019s aides said the president would make his case for a bigger military, more secure borders and fair trade, which critics say is a euphemism for protectionist policies.", "title": "State of the Union Preview: Will Trump Stick to the Script?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "(Want to get this briefing by email? Here\u2019s our preview.\n\nStephen Miller, known for his far-right, anti-immigrant views, is in charge of writing the speech. Our fact-check reporter offers an assessment of that year.\n\nMelania Trump has kept a low profile since the report that her husband paid a porn star $130,000 to keep quiet about their affair, but she is expected to attend the speech. The Times will have live coverage and analysis.", "title": "State of the Union, F.B.I., Lunar Eclipse: Your Tuesday Briefing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-31 00:00:00", "text": "The Australian cartoonist Ben Ward wrote an absurd tweet in 2016 about the phenomenon that raced across the internet last year.\n\n\u201cThe whole internet loves Milkshake Duck, a lovely duck that drinks milkshakes! *5 seconds later* We regret to inform you the duck is racist\u201d\n\nThe joke poked at the ridiculous ability of social media to accelerate the cycle of adulation and backlash, Mr. Ward told us last summer, when we analyzed the meme\u2019s meteoric rise. \u201cI didn\u2019t mean it to mock anyone \u2014 I\u2019m as susceptible to it as anyone else is,\u201d Mr. Ward added.\n\nIsabella Kwai contributed reporting.\n\n_____\n\nThis briefing was prepared for the European morning and is updated online.
