Contact us at europebriefing@nytimes.com.", "title": "State of the Union, Syria, the Moon: Your Wednesday Briefing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "On Friday, a senior New York police official apologized for sowing doubt in 1994 about the account of a woman who was raped in Prospect Park. Following is the statement the woman issued on Friday, shortly before the police official, John J. Miller, sent her his apology.\n\n\u201cThe arc of the moral universe is long, but it bends towards justice.\u201d \u2014 the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr., quoting Theodore Parker\n\nI\u2019m grateful to Detective Andrea Sorrentino, who worked tirelessly on my case back in 1994, and to Detective Sarah Mathers who solved it 23 years later. I\u2019m grateful that someone believed the four women James Webb raped after he raped me, and that he was finally brought to justice. I\u2019m extremely grateful that James Webb is not eligible for parole until 2070.\n\nImmediately after I was raped, the policemen who responded drove me around the park, stopping and questioning black men who looked nothing like the description I had given them. When I told them that as a black woman that made me uncomfortable, that it made me feel unsafe, they were visibly angry. I also wrote a statement that my friends and colleagues read aloud that weekend at a rally protesting violence against lesbians in Park Slope. I guess that made someone at 1 Police Plaza very angry. To see in print that police sources had called me a liar had a silencing effect on me, to say the least. I paid a terrible, terrible price for my #MeToo.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nToday larger societal issues are framing my personal experience of trauma, just as they did then. There are thousands of cold cases, thousands more rape kits from the 1990\u2019s and beyond that have not been tested with modern technology. Don\u2019t those victims deserve closure, too? There are still victims receiving substandard treatment from cops and ER doctors who don\u2019t know how to deal with assault victims sensitively. Can\u2019t we put training in place to correct that? Most disturbingly, stories of assault are still discounted; cases are not vigorously prosecuted. Schools and workplaces deal with sexual assaults as internal disciplinary matters instead of as what they are - crimes. #MeToo is not a movement, or a moment. It is an ongoing reality women have lived with that MUST CHANGE, starting now.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThat\u2019s the big picture. But I\u2019m not big. I\u2019m small, and brown, and a little insecure. I\u2019ve been told I\u2019m a good friend. I\u2019m a mom. Just a person, really.", "title": "Statement From Victim in a 1994 Brooklyn Rape Case", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-08 00:00:00", "text": "JOLIET, Mont. \u2014 As darkness closed in, one hunter after another stopped at this newly opened game check station, deer carcasses loaded in the beds of their pickups.\n\nThey had been given licenses for a special hunt, and others would follow. Jessica Goosmann, a wildlife technician with Montana\u2019s Fish, Wildlife & Parks Department, stepped outside to greet them, reaching for the neck of each freshly killed deer to cut an incision and remove a lymph node for testing.\n\nOn the edge of this south-central Montana village, where deer hunting is a way of life, the game check station has become the front line of the state\u2019s efforts to stop the spread of a deadly infection known as chronic wasting disease.\n\nIt has ravaged deer herds throughout the United States and Canada and forced the killing of thousands of infected animals in 24 states and three Canadian provinces. It has also been found in Norway and South Korea. With the disease widespread in Wyoming, the Dakotas and the province of Alberta, Montana officials had been bracing for its emergence.", "title": "States Confront the Spread of a Deadly Disease in Deer", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-01 00:00:00", "text": "So South Dakota essentially created a tax to provide a vehicle for the Supreme Court to reverse the Quill decision. The state required certain online retailers that did more than $100,000 worth of business in sales in South Dakota to collect the 4.5 percent state sales tax. When the online furniture retailer Wayfair challenged the tax, the South Dakota Supreme Court ruled against the state, citing Quill.\n\nIn early January, the Supreme Court will decide whether it wants to revisit the Quill case by taking up South Dakota\u2019s appeal in the Wayfair case. I am one of the economists and law professors who have filed a brief urging the court to do so.\n\nThere are compelling reasons to overturn Quill. Most important, according to market analysis, state and local governments will lose about $34 billion in revenue in 2018 because of the physical presence requirement, a number that will rise to nearly $52 billion by 2022. In 1992, in e-commerce\u2019s infancy, the loss was $700 million to $3 billion.\n\nFor their part, retailers say that out-of-state retailers should not be deputized as an agent of the state. That job, they say, is for the state to do, through the enforcement of the use tax. This is essentially the same argument made in Quill.\n\nBut Quill arguments are less compelling now than in 1992. For example, the administrative and record-keeping burden didn\u2019t disappear under the physical-presence rule \u2014 it was merely shifted to consumers, who are left to comply with tax obligations on their own. And improvements in technology mean that collecting sales tax for different states isn\u2019t nearly the burden for retailers that it would have been in 1992.\n\nThe Quill decision has now not only hurt states but also distorted behavior of big retailers: It discourages them from establishing a brick-and-mortar location (and creating jobs) in a new state and being liable for collecting its sales tax. Online retailers also enjoy state services \u2014 like roads that allow their products to be delivered efficiently to customers \u2014 without contributing to their upkeep.\n\nNormally, one does not have an opportunity to fix a mistake. Let\u2019s hope the Supreme Court in Wayfair takes advantage of that opportunity.\n\nIf not, you may notice worse roads because most consumers are not voluntarily reporting the use tax.", "title": "Opinion | States Pay the Price When You Buy Online", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cPeople should not be intimidated by the F.C.C. simply saying it has pre-emptive authority, and we need to dig into the sources of that claim, which are a lot weaker than the F.C.C. makes it out to be,\u201d said State Representative Drew Hansen, a Democrat who has introduced one of two net neutrality bills in Washington in recent weeks.\n\nThe Federal Communications Commission declined to comment but pointed to the section of its order that pre-empts states from creating their own net neutrality rules.\n\nSupporters of net neutrality are attacking the agency\u2019s repeal of the 2015 rules in other ways as well. On Tuesday, Senator Chuck Schumer of New York, the Democratic leader, announced that he had enough support to force a vote on a congressional resolution to bring back the rules. He gained an important Republican supporter, Senator Susan Collins of Maine, who said she would vote in favor of it. Such a measure is a long shot in the House, however, and would also need President Trump\u2019s signature.\n\n\u201cNet neutrality will be a major issue in the 2018 campaigns, and we are going to let everyone know where we stand and where they stand,\u201d Mr. Schumer said at a news conference, warning Republicans to vote in favor of the Democratic-led resolution.\n\nIn addition, lawsuits against the commission are expected shortly after the policy becomes official. Last week, a lobbying group for big technology companies including Facebook, Google and Netflix announced that it planned to join the lawsuits, giving the opposition substantial new resources. More than a dozen state attorneys general have also announced plans to sue the commission.", "title": "States Push Back After Net Neutrality Repeal", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-17 00:00:00", "text": "This is the original poem inscribed on the Statue of Liberty.\n\nWhat do you think this image is saying? Under a deal with the Interior Department, New York State will pay about $65,000 a day out of its tourism budget to cover the sites\u2019 operating costs.\n\nGov. Andrew M. Cuomo announced the statue's reopening on Sunday afternoon in Robert F. Wagner Jr. Park in Lower Manhattan, where ferry service passes on its way to the monument. He said the state would pay to keep the Statue of Liberty open for as long as it takes lawmakers in Washington to resolve their impasse.\n\n\u201cFrom our point of view it\u2019s a good investment, because the revenue we gain from the tourists is multiples of what it will cost to actually pay to open the Statue of Liberty,\u201d Mr. Cuomo said Sunday. \u201cWe want to see tourism flowing, we want to see people coming and we don\u2019t want any disruptions.\u201d", "title": "Statue of Liberty Will Reopen Despite Government Shutdown", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "There are many ways to approach a pescatarian dinner. The next time you buy a piece of fish for dinner, instead of pan-frying, poaching or broiling, why not consider steaming? It\u2019s fast, easy and makes a remarkably satisfying light meal.\n\nChinese cooks have long been experts at steaming fish \u2014 especially whole fish, which may seem daunting. But boneless fillets are also excellent when prepared in the same way. The technique is not at all difficult to master, and the aromatics \u2014 like ginger, scallion and sesame oil \u2014 are readily available.", "title": "Steamed Fish, Swimming in Flavor", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-07 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nStephanie Ghitis and Jeffrey Evan Kalmus were married Jan. 6 at the Eden Roc Miami Beach Resort, in Miami Beach. Rabbi Sholom D. Lipskar officiated.\n\nMrs. Kalmus, 28, is a senior consultant for strategy and operations at Deloitte, the New York audit, tax, consulting and advisory firm. She graduated summa cum laude from the University of Pennsylvania and received an M.B.A. from Harvard.\n\nShe is the daughter of Ruth Gilinski Ghitis and Leo V. Ghitis of Golden Beach, Fla. Her father is a hotel and commercial property developer in Miami. Her mother is an independent college counselor, also in Miami.\n\nMr. Kalmus, 27, is a senior director for finance in the New York office of Roivant Sciences, a Swiss biopharmaceutical company. He graduated magna cum laude from Harvard.\n\nHe is a son of Debra A. Kalmus and Kenneth A. Kalmus of Bellmore, N.Y. The groom\u2019s mother, a certified public accountant, is an administrator of Crestwood Country Day School and Camp in Melville, N.Y. His father, also a C.P.A., is a co-managing partner of Kalmus, Siegel, Harris, & Goldfarb, an accounting firm in Garden City, N.Y.\n\nThe couple met on a blind date in New York, in 2013, that was arranged by a mutual friend.", "title": "Stephanie Ghitis, Jeffrey Kalmus", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cAnywhere and everywhere I go, people talk about the transit issue,\u201d she said over coffee at Pennsylvania Station, where she was preparing to board an Amtrak back to Syracuse. \u201cPeople\u2019s frustration and anger is palpable. I think he bears a great deal of responsibility.\u201d\n\nSome political experts said that Mr. Cuomo could be damaged by another primary challenge by a progressive woman.\n\n\u201cIf she does primary Cuomo, I\u2019d be worried, if I\u2019m Cuomo\u2019s people \u2014 not necessarily that she would win or get within 10 points of him,\u201d said Doug Muzzio, a professor of political science at Baruch College. \u201cBut even a loss by her \u2014 if it were close \u2014 would be damaging. So the governor would have to go all out.\u201d\n\nMs. Miner, who years ago worked for Gov. Mario M. Cuomo as a regional representative, first asserted her independence from state Democrats in 2013 when she openly criticized Gov. Andrew Cuomo in an Op-Ed in The New York Times. The piece \u2014 a wonky exploration of rising pension costs and other big-city fiscal problems \u2014 concluded that Mr. Cuomo \u201chas left cities strapped.\u201d\n\nIn the interview on Thursday, she also faulted what she called the governor\u2019s \u201ctransactional\u201d approach to government, which, she said, was designed to get \u201cgood headlines,\u201d but has \u201cnot changed the dynamic of the upstate economy.\u201d\n\nMs. Miner\u2019s decision came as a disappointment for Democrats who were hoping she would challenge Rep. John Katko, a Republican who represents the district that includes Syracuse, where she was mayor for eight years until term limits forced her to step down on Dec. 31.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Cuomo has the strongest progressive record of any elected official in this country \u2014 period,\u201d he said. \u201cAnd we look forward to building on that record in the third term.\u201d\n\nThis is the second time Ms. Miner, 47, has publicly declared that she would not run for Congress. After the tax vote, she said she would reconsider an earlier decision not to challenge Mr. Katko. But this time, she sounded resigned.\n\nShe said she did not relish the idea of \u201cgetting on a plane on a Sunday night and coming back on a Thursday and having to raise money five hours a day, every day.\u201d\n\nAs for antagonizing state Democratic stalwarts by flirting with a run against Mr. Cuomo, the leader of the party, Ms. Miner said such concerns would not factor into her decision.\n\n\u201cI think now more than ever people realize that in a democracy, all of us have a responsibility to be active and voice our opinion about where we think we are going,\u201d she said. \u201cThere are lots of different ways to be active. But their gains are fragile and have come at significant cost.\n\n\u2022 The areas \u201care exceptions that prove the rule,\u201d our columnists write. \u201cMexico\u2019s crisis manifests as violence, but it is rooted in the corruption and weakness of the state.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThe Oprah Winfrey show\n\n\u2022 The Golden Globes on Sunday were the first major awards show since allegations of sexual misconduct swept Hollywood, but it was a rousing speech by Ms. Winfrey that defined the night and captured the #MeToo mood.\n\n\u201cWhat I know for sure is that speaking your truth is the most powerful tool we all have,\u201d Ms. Winfrey said, accepting a lifetime achievement award. \u201cI\u2019m especially proud and inspired by all the women who have felt strong enough and empowered enough to speak up and share their personal stories.\u201d (Read the full speech here.)\n\n\u2022 Our journalists discussed the show as it happened. Audio\n\nU.S. to end protected status for Salvadorans\n\n\u2022 Nearly 200,000 people from El Salvador who have been allowed to live in the U.S. legally for more than a decade will have to leave, officials in Washington said today.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHomeland Security is ending a humanitarian program that gave temporary protected status to Salvadorans after a pair of devastating earthquakes struck their country in 2001, said the officials, who spoke on the condition of anonymity.\n\n\u2022 It is the Trump administration\u2019s latest reversal of immigration policies, and one of the most consequential to date.\n\nBusiness\n\n\u2022 President Trump heads to Tennessee today, where he is to give a speech intended to cast him as a friend of farmers. But the weekend\u2019s big movie news was in China, where \u201cStar Wars: The Last Jedi\u201d earned only $28.7 million.\n\nNoteworthy\n\n\u2022 In memoriam\n\nJohn Young walked on the moon, commanded the first space shuttle mission and became the first person to fly in space six times. He was 87.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 Southern pride, Northern tune\n\nThe Georgia Bulldogs\u2019 unofficial fight song has roots in a Civil War rallying cry for the North. We retraced the song\u2019s history ahead of Georgia\u2019s game tonight against Alabama.\n\nCollege football\u2019s national championship game begins at 8 p.m. Eastern.\n\n\u2022 Quiz time!\n\nDid you keep up with last week\u2019s news? Test yourself.\n\n\u2022 Quotation of the day\n\n\u201cYou would think with water mains breaking all over town they would have a contingency plan. A couple of guys with squeegees doesn\u2019t seem to do the job.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2014 Michael Rossiter, of Jersey City, whose plans were disrupted by a water main break at Kennedy Airport.\n\nBack Story\n\nWhen unrest recently erupted in Iran, President Trump used Twitter to reach out directly to antigovernment demonstrators in dozens of towns.\n\nSuch public outreach is a lot easier than it used to be.\n\nPhoto\n\nOne hundred years ago today, President Woodrow Wilson outlined his terms for an end to World War I in a speech meant to appeal to the war-weary people of America\u2019s European foes.\n\nAmerican newspapers such as The Times printed the 14-point speech in full, but that did not mean the average German would get the message.\n\nA few days later, a report in The Times documented efforts to spread the speech behind enemy lines, after Berlin threatened to execute pilots of planes distributing copies.\n\n\u201cWhat is now wanted is some kind of flying craft which will travel fifty to a hundred miles or more, dropping propaganda on the way,\u201d The Daily Chronicle, a British paper, reported.\n\n\u201cHere is a chance for ingenious inventors to improve on the existing facilities for invading the enemy countries with moral munitions and scattering broadcast pamphlets, tracts and pictures.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nPatrick Boehler contributed reporting.\n\n_____\n\nYour Morning Briefing is published weekdays at 6 a.m. Eastern and updated all morning. The Northeast is bracing for a \u201cbomb cyclone.\u201d\n\nThe powerful winter storm has already walloped the Southeast, bringing snow and freezing temperatures to Florida, Georgia and the Carolinas. Above, an icy scene in Savannah.\n\nA \u201cbomb cyclone\u201d is a term meteorologists use to refer to a sudden drop in atmospheric pressure when warm and cold air meet. Flights are canceled up and down the East Coast, and New York City is forecast to get up to eight inches of snow overnight. Here\u2019s the latest.", "title": "Stephen Bannon, Nuclear Button, Iran: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-03 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nWelcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown that lets you sleep \u2014 and lets us get paid to watch comedy. What do you think of it? What else are you interested in? Let us know: thearts@nytimes.com.\n\nPlanes and Rocket Men\n\nBack from a long holiday vacation, Stephen Colbert dived right back into attacking President Trump on Tuesday. He lambasted Mr. Trump for seeming to suggest in a tweet that he deserved credit for the worldwide lack of commercial jet fatalities last year. (United States-certified airlines have not had a fatal crash since 2009.)\n\n\u201cTrump took credit for no one dying in a plane crash this year! That explains his new campaign slogan, \u2018Trump 2020: You got to Tulsa, didn\u2019t ya?\u2019\u201d \u2014 STEPHEN COLBERT\n\nMr. Colbert also criticized Mr. Trump for his continuing Twitter feud with North Korea\u2019s leader, Kim Jong-un.\n\n\u201c\u2018We will see!\u2019? That\u2019s a little nonchalant. \u2018Maybe it\u2019ll lead to peace, maybe it\u2019ll lead to thermonuclear war, no way of knowing. I as the president would do something about it, but I\u2019m too busy keeping all the planes in the sky.\u2019\u201d \u2014 STEPHEN COLBERT\n\nNoah Says Nonviolent Pot Offenders Deserve Clemency\n\nThe recreational use of marijuana became legal in California on Monday. Trevor Noah had some fun with that news, but then he pointed out that not everyone is celebrating.\n\n\u201cI\u2019ll tell you who I do feel bad for, though: all the O.G. black and Latino weed entrepreneurs. Think about it, they set up the weed business, they created the market, and right now they\u2019re watching all these white guys get rich while they\u2019re doing time for being ahead of their time. I say, every person who has served time for nonviolent weed offenses should automatically get a license to sell weed. That\u2019s what I believe. You don\u2019t even need to give them a certificate. You can just frame their rap sheet. It works.\u201d \u2014 TREVOR NOAH\n\nThe Punchiest Punchlines (Iran Edition)\n\n\u201cThese are the largest antigovernment protests in Iran since 2009, and in case you\u2019re wondering what drove these people into the streets, it wasn\u2019t that George Soros was paying them. It was that after the U.S. lifted sanctions on Iran in 2015, the Iranian government promised a big economic boom for everyone. But while the rich in Iran are getting richer, ordinary Iranians aren\u2019t noticing the benefits. And I know this third-world stuff is hard for some Americans to relate to, but just imagine if the U.S. government promised tax cuts for the middle class, but then only the rich benefited. I know, I know, that [expletive] would never happen. I know. But you know what I mean.\u201d \u2014 TREVOR NOAH, discussing the political unrest in Iran after a segment on the recently passed Republican tax bill \u201cOn the night of Christmas he tweeted that was fun, happy holidays, but \u2018back to work.\u2019 And then after tweeting, he golfed seven days in a row. It was like his version of Hanukkah: The golf was supposed to only last for a day, but instead it lasted a whole week. It was a miracle.\u201d \u2014 JIMMY KIMMEL, on President Trump\u2019s Christmas pledge\n\nThe Bits Worth Watching\n\nJimmy Kimmel\u2019s cousin Sal went to Colorado, where marijuana has been legal for three years.\n\nJordan Klepper and Tim Baltz have a pitch for the \u201cMake America Great Again football league.\u201d\n\nWhat We\u2019re Excited About on Wednesday Night\n\nJessica Chastain, the star of \u201cMolly\u2019s Game\u201d and a particularly outspoken advocate for diversity and inclusivity in Hollywood, will speak to Jimmy Kimmel on Wednesday.\n\nAlso, Check This Out\n\nPhoto\n\nHere\u2019s how our restless New Year\u2019s Eve reporter spent 14 hours on a New York City culture crawl.", "title": "Stephen Colbert Blasts Trump for Twitter Feud With Kim Jong-un", "authors": ["Giovanni Russonello", "Best Of Late Night"]} {"date": "2018-01-16 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nWelcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown that lets you sleep \u2014 and lets us get paid to watch comedy. That concept was scuttled for this year\u2019s game because of opposition in the player\u2019s union.\n\nThe format of the draft required that the captains select starting lineups from the pool of eight starters as determined through a combination of voting by fans, players and the news media.\n\nThe order of those picks was not revealed, but James picked first and ended up with an intriguing starting lineup that includes both his former teammate, Kyrie Irving of the Boston Celtics, and Curry\u2019s current teammate, Kevin Durant. The other two starters with James are Anthony Davis and DeMarcus Cousins of the New Orleans Pelicans. Irving is the only starter on James\u2019s roster shorter than 6 feet 8 inches.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Marc Stein He has covered Jordan. He\u2019s covered Kobe. But after so long a time I felt it only right to stand down and let others take the Baftas on to new heights and greater glories.\u201d\n\nMr. Fry served as host from 2001 to 2006, andfrom 2012 to 2017. The comedian and television presenter Jonathan Ross hosted in the intervening years.\n\n\u201cWhat fun it will be to watch Bafta 2018 without my heart hammering, mouth drying and knees trembling,\u201d Mr. Fry said, in reference to the pressure awards show hosts must endure.", "title": "Stephen Fry Steps Down as Bafta Film Awards Host", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "The 2018 PEN America Literary Service Award has been awarded to Stephen King, author of horror and suspense classics such as \u201cIt\u201d and \u201cThe Shining.\u201d\n\nThe award is meant for a critically acclaimed writer whose body of work \u201chelps us understand and interpret the human condition,\u201d according to a news release. Andrew Solomon, the president of PEN America, said Mr. King \u201chas inspired us to stand up to sinister forces through his rich prose, his generous philanthropy and his outspoken defense of free expression.\u201d\n\nMr. King has written more than 50 books, including \u201cUnder the Dome,\u201d about a town in Maine suddenly separated from the world by an invisible force, which draws terror from human nature. The book also includes social commentary; Marilyn Stasio, a critic for The Times, wrote that it has \u201cechoes of 9/11, Hurricane Katrina and Iraq that help to shape this small town\u2019s view of the wider world.\u201d Mr. King provides support to writers and artists who have suffered hardship through his Haven Foundation and is an outspoken advocate of free speech on Twitter and elsewhere, resulting in his being blocked by President Trump on the social media platform.\n\nMr. King will be honored with the award on May 22 at the American Museum of Natural History. His new novel, \u201cThe Outsider,\u201d will also be published on that date.", "title": "Stephen King to Receive PEN Literary Service Award", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-27 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nWASHINGTON \u2014 Stephen Wynn, the billionaire casino mogul and prominent political donor, has stepped down as finance chairman of the Republican National Committee. He left the post, for which he had been handpicked by President Trump, after being accused of a yearslong pattern of sexual misconduct with his casino employees.\n\nMr. Wynn had faced growing calls to step aside in the wake of a detailed investigative report in The Wall Street Journal on Friday that said Mr. Wynn had frequently demanded naked massages from female employees, and had sometimes pressured them to engage in sexual intercourse or to perform sex acts on him.\n\nIn a statement on Saturday, the committee\u2019s chairwoman, Ronna Romney McDaniel, said, \u201cToday I accepted Steve Wynn\u2019s resignation as Republican National Committee finance chair.\u201d The committee had remained silent for more than a day until Ms. McDaniel spoke to Mr. Trump, who has a longstanding friendship with Mr. Wynn.\n\nMr. Wynn said on Saturday evening that he was resigning to eliminate a \u201cdistraction\u201d for the party. \u201cThe unbelievable success we have achieved must continue,\u201d he said in a statement. \u201cThe work we are doing to make America a better place is too important to be impaired by this distraction. I thank the president for the opportunity to serve and wish him continued success.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nA day before, Mr. Wynn had dismissed any claims of sexual misconduct as \u201cpreposterous.\u201d\n\nThe committee is expected to consider a replacement at a previously planned meeting this coming week in Washington. \u201cThis is an important position, so they\u2019re going to have to look carefully to find the right person,\u201d said Ronald Weiser, a Michigan real estate developer and former finance chairman for the committee. Mr. Wynn\u2019s decision to step down was first reported by Politico.", "title": "Stephen Wynn Steps Down From R.N.C. Post After Sexual Misconduct Claims", "authors": ["Emily Cochrane", "Kenneth P. Vogel"]} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "Stephen Wynn\u2019s perch at the top of the casino industry was badly shaken on Friday following the disclosure of allegations that he engaged in a long pattern of sexual misconduct with employees of his casinos.\n\nA detailed investigative report in The Wall Street Journal portrayed Mr. Wynn, a billionaire casino magnate and prominent political donor, as a man who frequently demanded naked massages from female employees, sometimes pressuring them for sex and to masturbate him. The newspaper said that the activity had gone on for decades and that some female employees had complained to supervisors about Mr. Wynn\u2019s behavior.\n\nSome of the women told The Journal that they had tried to avoid having to give Mr. Wynn massages by hiding in bathrooms, or entering fake appointments in record logs to make it look as if some of their colleagues were busy. The newspaper relied on court records and interviews with dozens of people who worked at his casinos.\n\nMr. Wynn, chairman and chief executive of Wynn Resorts, denied the allegations in a statement, saying, \u201cThe idea that I ever assaulted any woman is preposterous.\u201d", "title": "Stephen Wynn, Casino Mogul, Accused of Decades of Sexual Misconduct", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-07 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cOprah! Don\u2019t want to run out of time, so let me thank my wife: Ryan Michelle Bathe, I love you so much. Thank you for supporting me through this whole thing. To my kids, Andrew and Amari, Daddy will see you. I will take you to school in the morning, I promise.\n\nI want to thank my cast, which is absolutely amazing. And we take turns leading and supporting one another. I love each and every one of you. To my network, NBC, to Bob and Jennifer, to Fox, to Gary, to Dana.\n\nBut also I want to thank Dan Fogelman. Now, Dan Fogelman, throughout the majority of my career, I have benefited from colorblind casting \u2014 which means, you know what, \u2018Hey, let\u2019s throw a brother in this role, right?\u2019 It\u2019s always really cool. But Dan Fogelman, you wrote a role for a black man. That could only be played by a black man. And so what I appreciate so much about this thing is that I am being seen for who I am and being appreciated for who I am. And that makes it that much more difficult to dismiss me, or dismiss anybody who looks like me. So thank you, Dan. Thank you, Hollywood Foreign Press. Peace.\u201d", "title": "Sterling K. Brown\u2019s Golden Globes Speech: \u2018I Am Being Seen for Who I Am\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-09 00:00:00", "text": "He accompanied Mr. Trump to the White House and became his chief strategist. With an office in the West Wing and a direct line to the Oval Office \u2014 he initially reported to no one but the president \u2014 he seemed well positioned to wreak havoc on the political institutions and leaders he railed against as corrupt and self-serving.\n\nBut after repeatedly clashing with Ivanka Trump, the president\u2019s eldest daughter, and Jared Kushner, her husband and Mr. Trump\u2019s senior adviser, Mr. Bannon was pushed out after less than eight months with the administration. Five months later, a clash with another Trump \u2014 Mr. Bannon called Donald Trump Jr.\u2019s meeting with Russians last year at Trump Tower in Manhattan \u201ctreasonous\u201d \u2014 cost him another job.\n\nNo one has been more closely identified with the Breitbart website or had more to do with emboldening its defiant editorial spirit than Mr. Bannon did after its namesake, Andrew Breitbart, died of a heart attack in 2012. In Washington, Mr. Bannon works and lives part time in a townhouse nicknamed the Breitbart Embassy.\n\nIn the statement announcing his move, Mr. Bannon said that he was \u201cproud of what the Breitbart team has accomplished in so short a period of time in building out a world-class news platform.\u201d\n\nOnce outside the administration and free to pursue his political enemies, Mr. Bannon set out on an audacious mission to challenge Republican incumbents he deemed insufficiently loyal to Mr. Trump\u2019s agenda. He vowed to replace Senator Mitch McConnell, the Republican leader, and started backing far-right candidates, some with questionable backgrounds and losing track records at the polls.\n\nHis full-throated, unfailing support of Roy S. Moore in Alabama, even after allegations surfaced that the former judge preyed on girls as young as 14, ended in an embarrassing setback: The state sent a Democrat to the Senate for the first time in a generation.\n\nSeveral people with knowledge of the dynamics at Breitbart said that Mr. Bannon had lost the confidence of executives and writers who had been fiercely loyal to him as he helped transform the website from a scrappy start-up to one of the biggest and most antagonistic megaphones on the right.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut that confidence faded in recent days and weeks as they came to believe he displayed serious lapses in judgment, according to interviews with half a dozen people close to the situation. Some associates and friends described Mr. Bannon as being detached from reality, unable or unwilling to grasp the severity of his falling out with the White House and its potential effect on Breitbart as a business.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nHis situation at Breitbart grew untenable, said one person close to the situation, in part because Ms. Mercer, whose family finances conservative causes with their hedge fund wealth, became concerned that she could face legal exposure. She feared that some of the website\u2019s cheerleading coverage of populist conservative campaigns \u2014 like the Senate race in Alabama \u2014 could be construed as corporate contributions to those candidates, which are barred under federal election law.\n\nNumerous people who have worked with Mr. Bannon over the past few months said that his attitude lately had grown more imperious and aloof than normal. And his outward lack of any emotion about his messy public breach with the president and the Mercer family struck some not as the calloused indifference of a political operative but as nihilistic.\n\nWhen Mr. Trump first denounced Mr. Bannon last week, saying, \u201cHe not only lost his job, he lost his mind,\u201d Mr. Bannon insisted to his writers and editors at Breitbart that it would all blow over. When reports began circulating that Ms. Mercer had cut him off, he denied it outright. And when friends started asking him about rumors that his job was in jeopardy, he insisted that everything was fine. \u201cThe Mercers haven\u2019t given me money in years,\u201d he told multiple people, playing down their significance in his work and insisting that an initial $10 million investment in the website was all they had provided.\n\nIn fact, recent tax filings suggest how difficult it will be for Mr. Bannon to fill the void left by the Mercers. The Mercer Family Foundation has donated more than $100 million over the past decade to mostly conservative nonprofit groups, including nearly $6 million to one that Mr. Bannon helped found, the Government Accountability Institute, which has also sought to distance itself from Mr. Bannon in recent days.\n\nMr. Bannon refused to admit any missteps or lapses in judgment, people close to him said.\n\nDespite putting his name on a statement in which he expressed regret \u2014 but did not apologize \u2014 for his comments about Mr. Trump\u2019s son, he resisted uttering any words of contrition until an unusual statement on Sunday morning.\n\nWhile Mr. Bannon edited and approved the version that ultimately became public, an associate sent out the statement without his knowledge, according to three people familiar with the situation. And when he learned that it had been given to Axios, a website read by Washington insiders, he was furious and blamed his colleagues for overreacting, these people said.\n\nEnvisioning Breitbart without Mr. Bannon \u2014 or Mr. Bannon without Breitbart \u2014 was almost inconceivable a month ago. Inside the townhouse called the Breitbart Embassy on Capitol Hill, where photographs of Mr. Breitbart still hang on the wall and half-filled coffee mugs emblazoned with the website\u2019s block \u201cB\u201d logo clutter the kitchen, Mr. Bannon\u2019s presence is just as prevalent.\n\nUpon entering, visitors see a table stacked with copies of the Time magazine from last year with Mr. Bannon on the cover under the headline \u201cThe Great Manipulator,\u201d along with other articles that have chronicled his rise to national prominence. On one ground-floor wall is a picture of a honey badger, the animal Mr. Bannon has claimed as his mascot because of its savage and relentless pursuit of prey.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFriends of both Ms. Mercer and Mr. Bannon have described their rupture like \u201ca bad divorce.\u201d But Ms. Mercer was just one person among a growing list of powerful onetime allies whose backing Mr. Bannon had lost in recent months. In addition to disparaging Mr. Bannon as \u201cSloppy Steve\u201d and calling into question his relevance during the 2016 presidential campaign, Mr. Trump blessed moves by the White House to further ostracize Mr. Bannon. And in the words of one associate of the president\u2019s, he wanted \u201ca scorched earth approach.\u201d Sarah Huckabee Sanders, the White House press secretary, took the unusual step last week of suggesting that Breitbart remove Mr. Bannon.\n\nOver the weekend, the White House dispatched Mr. Trump\u2019s allies on Capitol Hill and key members of the administration to the Sunday talk show circuit to defend the president and attack Mr. Bannon\u2019s credibility. The most vocal was Stephen Miller, who worked closely with Mr. Bannon in the White House and was someone Mr. Bannon considered a prot\u00e9g\u00e9. Mr. Miller appeared Sunday on CNN and declared Mr. Bannon\u2019s comments in the book by the journalist Michael Wolff \u201cgrotesque\u201d as he played down the significance of Mr. Bannon\u2019s role in the administration.\n\nMr. Bannon\u2019s expression of regret did little to soothe the anger at the White House. Asked on Monday whether the statement, in which Mr. Bannon said Donald Trump Jr. was \u201ca patriot,\u201d had changed anything, the deputy White House press secretary, Hogan Gidley, balked.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t believe there\u2019s any way back for Mr. Bannon at this point,\u201d he said.", "title": "Steve Bannon Steps Down From Breitbart Post", "authors": ["Jeremy W. Peters"]} {"date": "2018-01-07 00:00:00", "text": "Stephen K. Bannon, President Trump\u2019s former chief strategist, expressed regret on Sunday after an uproar over comments he made to Michael Wolff, the author of \u201cFire and Fury: Inside the Trump White House.\u201d In the book, Mr. Bannon is quoted as saying that a 2016 meeting in Trump Tower involving Donald Trump Jr. and a small group of Russians was \u201ctreasonous\u201d and \u201cunpatriotic.\u201d\n\nFollowing is the full statement that Mr. Bannon sent to The New York Times.\n\nRead more coverage \u00bb\n\n___________\n\n\u201cDonald Trump Jr. is both a patriot and a good man. He has been relentless in his advocacy for his father and the agenda that has helped turn our country around.\n\n\u201cMy support is also unwavering for the president and his agenda \u2014 as I have shown daily in my national radio broadcasts, on the pages of Breitbart News and in speeches and appearances from Tokyo and Hong Kong to Arizona and Alabama. President Trump was the only candidate that could have taken on and defeated the Clinton apparatus. I am the only person to date to conduct a global effort to preach the message of Trump and Trumpism, and I remain ready to stand in the breach for this president\u2019s efforts to make America great again.", "title": "Steve Bannon\u2019s Statement on Donald Trump Jr.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-29 00:00:00", "text": "I\u2019ve already heard people suggesting that my city is to blame for Mr. Wynn \u2014 that the Las Vegas Strip\u2019s overtly sexualized culture enables powerful men like him to maintain their patterns of sexual harassment. That may have contributed, but when it comes to women facing workplace abuse, another dynamic does just as much harm: the culture of income inequality.\n\nThe report of Mr. Wynn\u2019s misconduct reminds me, a casino worker, of every time a manager stepped across the line or a V.I.P. guest\u2019s behavior was excused because of his financial status. Here, low-income workers are made to feel indebted to the rich men like Mr. Wynn who pay their wages. In a city with little economic diversity, good middle-class jobs like those offered by Wynn Resorts are difficult to find.\n\nThe women coming forward were lower-paid employees at the times of the alleged harassment. They were hospitality workers trained to be welcoming and smiling, and to always strive to say yes. Most of Mr. Wynn\u2019s accusers had behind-the-scenes roles like food and beverage servers, manicurists and receptionists, employees whom executives often view as easily replaceable.\n\nIt is a similar approach taken by Harvey Weinstein, who preyed on female actors when they had little power \u2014 before their Hollywood debuts or successes. What many powerful sexual harassers seem to know is that when women don\u2019t have the economic agency or career security to speak out, they often will choose not to.\n\nThere is a reported $7.5 million settlement between Mr. Wynn and his former manicurist, which prohibits her from speaking publicly about her experience. Many working-class and low-income women who never report misconduct are informally making similar deals, on a much smaller scale. Each day at work, they may decide to remain silent about sexual harassment for the sake of their families and their own sense of safety, in exchange for a much-needed paycheck from someone who has astronomical wealth.", "title": "Opinion | Steve Wynn and the Economic Inequality Behind #MeToo", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-28 00:00:00", "text": "Yzerman, who has won four Stanley Cups and three Olympic gold medals as a player and executive, has been credited with much of the Lightning\u2019s sustained success the past eight seasons.\n\n\u201cWhatever you do in life, part of being successful is passion,\u201d said Red Wings General Manager Ken Holland, who began training Yzerman during his playing career and presided over Yzerman\u2019s three championships as a player before working with him when Detroit won another title in 2008. \u201cIt can\u2019t be work. If it\u2019s just a job, your energy level is going to be drained over time. That passion and desire to gather knowledge are what Steve had as a player and he\u2019s also taken into the front office.\u201d\n\nYzerman arrived in Tampa in 2010 after serving in the Red Wings\u2019 front office for four years and guiding Canada to Olympic gold in 2010 as the team\u2019s executive director \u2014 a feat the country would repeat under him in 2014.\n\nHe found success quickly in Tampa. During Yzerman\u2019s first season, the Lightning surprised the hockey world by reaching Game 7 of the Eastern Conference finals. When they reached the Stanley Cup finals in 2015, only three members of the 2010-11 team were on the roster. Just two of them, Stamkos and Victor Hedman, are still with the franchise.\n\nSuch has been the adaptive nature of the Lightning under Yzerman.\n\nIn 2015, Martin St. Louis, a former league scoring champion and the team\u2019s captain at the time, demanded a trade. Although he limited his list of possible destinations to one team \u2014 the Rangers \u2014 the Lightning managed to acquire a younger player and another former captain, forward Ryan Callahan, and valuable draft picks.", "title": "Steve Yzerman Keeps Adapting, and the Lightning Keep Winning", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nSteven Spielberg has a new film about sharks on the horizon. No, not another installment of \u201cJaws,\u201d but \u201cWest Side Story,\u201d about two gangs, the Sharks and the Jets, and the tragic love story of a man and woman caught in between.\n\nOn Thursday, Cindy Tolan, the film\u2019s casting director, posted an image of the announcement on Twitter.\n\nDetails are scarce. The call lists Mr. Spielberg as the film\u2019s director. Tony Kushner, the Tony- and Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright and screenwriter, is listed as its writer. Mr. Spielberg and Mr. Kushner have previously collaborated on the films \u201cMunich\u201d and \u201cLincoln.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Kushner\u2019s husband, Mark Harris, posted the call Thursday on Twitter, writing: \u201cExciting Harris/Kushner household news: Something\u2019s coming. Something good.\u201d\n\nThe casting call refers to the search for the four main characters, Tony, Maria, Anita and Bernardo. Tony, the call says, is set to be Caucasian. Maria and Anita will be Latina. Bernardo will be Latino. All four actors should be between 15 and 25 years old. Singing ability is a must. An updated casting call released by the film\u2019s producers on Friday said that a strong dance background is necessary. (The original call said that dance experience would be preferred.)\n\nThe original \u201cWest Side Story\u201d film, from 1961, was directed by Jerome Robbins and Robert Wise. It won 10 Oscars, including for best picture. It was based on the 1957 Broadway musical written by Arthur Laurents and Stephen Sondheim. Leonard Bernstein wrote the music for that show and Robbins choreographed and directed it.", "title": "Steven Spielberg and Tony Kushner\u2019s \u2018West Side Story\u2019 Is Casting", "authors": ["Peter Libbey"]} {"date": "2018-01-15 00:00:00", "text": "One of the biggest problems in trying to convince people that they need to immunize against things like the flu is that they don\u2019t really feel the pressure. After all, for most people, the flu shot is an inconvenience, and they\u2019re unlikely to get the flu in a given year. So why bother? Quite a few readers expressed this view after my article \u201cWhy It\u2019s Still Worth Getting a Flu Shot\u201d on Thursday, including this one.\n\nI promise this is an honest question: Are people routinely being destroyed by the flu or something? (I mean, first I\u2019d ask, \u2018Is everyone but me simply vaccinated, and thus gifting me with herd immunity?\u2019 And so I did. My first Google search brought me to yearly C.D.C. flu-vaccine coverage statistics, and for the last four years, the percentage of flu-vaccinated adults has been in the low 40s. So... nope.) I\u2019m not a particularly healthy person \u2014 I get colds, sinus infections, etc. \u2014 but I just can\u2019t recall ever having had the flu, or at least *knowing* I had it. This seems to indicate that the flu is either 1) rare enough that it\u2019s possible for me to have been lucky forever (in which case it\u2019s fairly rare, apparently), or 2) not severe enough of an illness for me to have noticed experiencing it. Both lead me to conclude that skipping the vaccine is fine. I\u2019m just a regular idiot, presumably representing other regular idiots, amenable to changing their habits, but who haven\u2019t done so \u2014 not due to obstinance or contrarianism, but due to signals so mixed as to inspire ambivalence \u2014 and if this article can be said to have provided the \u2018why\u2019 its headline promises, unfortunately it hasn\u2019t provided the \u2018why\u2019 idiots like me need to hear: Why is the flu a big deal literally at all? \u2014 Chrystie, Los Angeles\n\nAlthough I devote some of my articles to telling you not to worry so much about some diseases or other risks, influenza is one thing you actually should worry about. It\u2019s terrible; it\u2019s also far too common.\n\nInfluenza, commonly called the flu, spreads easily. You can catch it from someone who coughs, sneezes or even talks to you from up to six feet away. You can infect others a day before you show any symptoms, and up to a week after becoming sick. Children can pass along the virus for even longer than that.\n\nInfluenza is not a reportable disease, so its prevalence must be estimated. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention believes that, since 2010, between 9.2 million and 35.6 million people have come down with the flu in the United States each year. That means that in a bad year, more than one in every 10 people in the United States might get it.", "title": "Still Not Convinced You Need a Flu Shot? First, It\u2019s Not All About You", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-06 00:00:00", "text": "And empty.\n\nThe vessel was found at the entrance to a building site in Charlottenlund, an affluent district north of the Danish capital.\n\nImage A bottle of Vodka said to be worth $1.3 million was stolen from Caf\u00e9 33 in Copenhagen. The bottle was recovered. Credit Brian Ingberg/Ritzau Foto, via Associated Press\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s no doubt the thief got cold feet,\u201d Mr. Ingberg said in an interview on Saturday. \u201cHe placed it there because he wanted it to be found.\u201d\n\nThe Copenhagen police said in a Twitter post that the bottle was being examined for any leads and that no further information on the case would be released.\n\nShortly before the vessel was found, Mr. Ingberg said he had been contacted by a man who said that he knew who had the bottle and that the thief wanted to return it to the collector.\n\n\u201cI got the feeling that he felt he was in trouble because of the police and Leon in Russia wanting to send people out to look for it,\u201d Mr. Ingberg said, referring to Leonard F. Yankelovich, Dartz\u2019s founder and the actual owner of the bottle. \u201cIt\u2019s not the most fun item to possess.\u201d\n\nMr. Ingberg said the bottle, with the formal name of the Dartz and Russo-Baltique vodka bottle, was given to him by Mr. Yankelovich on an indefinite loan.\n\n\u201cHe said he felt this was the right place for the bottle to be,\u201d Mr. Ingberg said, adding that the bottle, more than its contents, was the reason for the theft\u2019s global headlines.", "title": "Stolen Vodka Bottle, Said to Be Worth $1.3 Million, Is Found Drained and Dented", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-22 00:00:00", "text": "In addition to keeping the government operating through Feb. 8, the bill would extend the popular Children\u2019s Health Insurance Program for another six years.\n\nSenate votes to end shutdown.\n\nThe Senate voted 81-18 on Monday to end the three-day-old government shutdown, with Democrats joining Republicans to fund the government through February 8 in exchange for a promise from Republican leaders to address the fate of young, undocumented immigrants known as Dreamers.\n\n\u201cIn a few hours, the government will reopen,\u201d said Senator Chuck Schumer of New York, the Democratic leader. \u201cWe have a lot to do.\u201d\n\nThe House must still vote on the measure later Monday afternoon or evening, but final passage is a formality. The bill also funds the popular Children\u2019s Health Insurance Program for six years and delays or suspends a handful of tax increases that were to help pay for insurance coverage under the Affordable Care Act.\n\nAfter a weekend of partisan finger-pointing \u2014 in which Democrats branded the shutdown the \u201cTrump Shutdown,\u201d after President Trump, and Republicans branded it the \u201cSchumer shutdown\u201d \u2014 Monday\u2019s vote offered Republicans and Democrats a way out of an ugly impasse that threatened to cause political harm to both parties.\n\nMr. Schumer, speaking on the Senate floor, announced that he and Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, the Republican leader, had \u201ccome to an arrangement\u201d to adopt the three-week spending measure while continuing to negotiate a \u201cglobal agreement\u201d that would include the fate of the dreamers, undocumented immigrants brought to the country as children.\n\nMonday\u2019s vote came after a frantic weekend of work by a bipartisan group of more than 20 senators, who on Sunday night were discussing a plan in which the government would stay open through early February, coupled with a promise from Mr. McConnell to allow a vote on a measure to protect the Dreamers from deportation.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. McConnell pledged Monday morning that he would create a \u201clevel playing field\u201d on immigration next month if the issue had not been resolved by then. But his promise was not enough for many Democrats, and on Monday morning, moderate Senate Democrats were still pressing for more in exchange for their votes to end the shutdown.\n\nBy noon, just before the first vote to end debate on the spending bill, the moderate Democrats were predicting passage.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re going to vote to reopen the government,\u201d Senator Mark Warner of Virginia, a Democrat whose state is home to thousands of federal workers, told reporters. Mr. Warner said there was now a \u201cpath clear on how we\u2019re going to get a full-year budget and we got a path clear on how we\u2019re going to start an immigration debate.\u201d\n\nSenator Angus King of Maine, an independent who caucuses with Democrats, said he was a \u201cstrong\u201d yes.\n\n\u201cI said before trust but verify,\u201d he said of Mr. McConnell. \u201cHe made this commitment publicly in the Senate floor. He was much more specific than he was last night. And frankly I think this is an important opportunity for him to demonstrate that he will carry through.\u201d\n\nHere Are the Senators Who Brokered a Bipartisan Solution to the Government Shutdown\n\n\u2014 Sheryl Gay Stolberg\n\nPhoto\n\nTrump: the Democrats \u201chave come to their senses.\u201d\n\n\u201cI am pleased that Democrats in Congress have come to their senses and are now willing to fund our great military, border patrol, first responders, and insurance for vulnerable children. As I have always said, once the Government is funded, my Administration will work toward solving the problem of very unfair illegal immigration. We will make a long-term deal on immigration if, and only if, it is good for our country.\u201d \u2014 Statement released by the White House\n\nWhite House insists Trump was part of the deal-making.\n\nSarah Huckabee Sanders, the White House press secretary, insisted that the deal that the Senatevoted on was not \u201cdrastically different\u201d than what was discussed on Friday between the president and Mr. Schumer.\n\nDespite what was characterized by both parties as Mr. Trump\u2019s invisibility this weekend, Ms. Sanders still insisted that he was responsible for making a deal happen.\n\n\u201cWhat the president did clearly worked,\u201d she said, calling the numbers more in Mr. Trump\u2019s favor \u201cthan in Senator Schumer\u2019s favor.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThe president stayed firm, Republicans stayed firm and Democrats Ithink realized that they had to move past that piece of legislation\u201d in order to discuss immigration going forward, Ms. Sanders said.\n\nBut she declined to clarify precisely what the parameters of an immigration deal would look like. She dodged several questions about how many of the so-called dreamers might be eligible for what she called a \u201cpermanent solution\u201d to their legal status, or how it might be put into effect, or when deportations of DACA recipients might begin.\n\n\u201cThey say they want to negotiate so much so that they were willing to shut down the government,\u201d Ms. Sanders said of Democrats in response to a specific question about when deportations would start.\n\nShe dodged a question about whether Mr. Trump had a role in dictating a web ad his campaign released over the weekend that said Democrats would be \u201ccomplicit\u201d in murders committed by undocumented immigrants. But she anticipated a full restoration of federal services by Tuesday morning.\n\nWhite House official Marc Short credited the president with impacting the tide turning by calling into the House Freedom Caucus meeting on Thursday. He then - mostly - held to a script that his aides prescribed that blamed Democrats. The White House consistently said they believed Democrats in red states would be forced to come around.\n\nBut aides at the White House, many of whom had never lived through a shut down before, were unsure how to spend their time. A group of press aides considered sending volunteers to the Mall to clean up after the women\u2019s rally on Saturday to highlight that the govenrment was shut, but they scuttled the plan when they found out that the Washington D.C. police were already doing it.\n\n\u201cPut this mess behind us.\u201d\n\nMr. McConnell said on Monday morning that the Senate would move ahead with a scheduled procedural vote at noon on a proposal to fund the government through Feb. 8, and he urged his colleagues to put an end to the shutdown.\n\n\u201cEvery day we spend arguing about keeping the lights on is another day we cannot spend negotiating DACA or defense spending or any of our other shared priorities,\u201d Mr. McConnell said, referring to Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals, the program put in place by the Obama administration that shields young undocumented immigrants from deportation.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. McConnell reiterated a pledge he offered on Sunday night that he intended for the Senate to take up immigration legislation in February if the issue has not been resolved by then. A major question as senators seek to end the shutdown is what kind of commitment Mr. McConnell is willing to make regarding the consideration of legislation for the young immigrants, a central issue in the current impasse.\n\nOn Monday, Mr. McConnell pledged that the Senate\u2019s immigration debate would have \u201ca level playing field at the outset and an amendment process that is fair to all sides.\u201d\n\n\u201cThe very first step is ending the government shutdown,\u201d he said.\n\n\u2014 Thomas Kaplan\n\nDemocrats wanted more than McConnell\u2019s word.\n\nModerate Senate Democrats Monday morning had sought a firmer commitment from Mr. McConnell that the Senate would move to address the fate of hundreds of thousands of young undocumented immigrants, known as Dreamers, in the coming weeks.\n\nThe Democrats were part of a bipartisan group of more than 20 senators working throughout the weekend to forge a compromise to reopen the government. Mr. McConnell signaled Sunday night that he was listening to their demands, saying from the Senate floor that he intended to move ahead with immigration legislation in February if the issue had not been resolved by then.\n\nBut on Monday, Democrats wanted more in exchange for the votes to end the shutdown.\n\n\u201cWell I think the first thing he needs to do is strengthen his statement from last night,\u201d said Senator Angus King of Maine, an independent who votes with the Democrats. \u201c \u2018I intend.\u2019 I would much rather he say, \u2018I commit\u2019 or \u2018I will move.\u2019\u201d\n\nAs senators from the group shuffled in and out of leadership offices, Senator Jeff Flake, Republican of Arizona and another member of the group, expressed optimism that such a public statement by Mr. McConnell would be enough to win over enough Democrats to vote to end the shutdown. Some Democrats called on Mr. McConnell to delay a procedural vote schedule for noon.\n\nThe crux issue, it seemed, was whether the majority leader could be trusted to keep his word. Democrats have not forgiven Mr. McConnell for blocking the Supreme Court nomination of Merrick Garland for almost a year pending the election of a Republican to the White House. And Mr. McConnell\u2019s promises to Republican Senators Flake and Susan Collins of Maine for votes on health care and immigration in exchange for their support of the tax cut have yet to materialize.\n\nVideo\n\nHow much of the issue is that mistrust?\n\n\u201cUh, most of it,\u201d said Senator Joseph Manchin III, Democrat of West Virginia.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2014 Nicholas Fandos\n\nLiberal activists weren\u2019t ready to relent.\n\nA broad array of liberal advocacy groups \u2014 including unions and immigrants\u2019 rights activists \u2014 stepped up pressure on Democrats not to accede on Monday to any deal that does not include protections for the young undocumented immigrants known as Dreamers.\n\nThe advocates made clear that they do not trust Mr. McConnell.\n\n\u201cTo anyone considering such a move, let me clear, promises won\u2019t protect anyone from deportation, because delay means deportation for us,\u201d said Greisa Martinez Rosas, advocacy director for America\u2019s Voice, an immigrant rights group.\n\nModerate Senate Democrats on Monday were seeking a firmer commitment from Mr. McConnell. But the groups remained skeptical. Vanita Gutpta, the president and chief executive officer of the Leadership Conference on Civil Rights, harked back to Democrats\u2019 vote on Friday to block a spending bill that would have kept the government open, without protecting the Dreamers.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019ve made it clear that the broad progressive movement is unified in saying the Democrats stood strong on Friday, they absolutely need to continue to do so,\u201d Ms. Gupta said. She added, \u201cSimply put a dream deferred right now is a dream denied for hundreds of thousands in our country.\u201d\n\nThe Sierra Club\u2019s executive director, Michael Brune, was blunt: \u201cEveryone in the Senate should have learned the lesson Senators Flake and Collins learned: you can\u2019t trust Mitch McConnell. His promises are empty from the start.\u201d\n\n\u2014 Sheryl Gay Stolberg\n\nThe White House comment line had an attitude.\n\nOn Monday morning, a telephone call to the White House comment line reminded callers that the federal government was shutdown and offered the Trump administration\u2019s explanation for why: \u201cUnfortunately, we cannot answer your call today because congressional Democrats are holding government funding for our troops and other national security priorities hostage to an unrelated immigration debate,\u201d a recording said. \u201cDue to this obstruction the government is shut down.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Get the Morning Briefing by Email What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox Monday through Friday. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nSetting aside the partisan nature of the call, its message was only half true, if that. Most of the government is functioning, at least for now. The Environmental Protection Agency and the Federal Communications Commission say they have enough money in the pipeline to operate normally. The White House ordered the National Parks to stay open, depriving the media of the most obvious signs of dysfunction.\n\nEven Robert S. Mueller III, the special counsel investigating Russia\u2019s intervention in the 2016 election and any possible collusion with the Trump campaign, is still in action. He has declared his investigators \u201cessential employees.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut was the recording legal? Norm Eisen, who served as the top ethics lawyer during Barack Obama\u2019s first term in the White House and is now on the board of the liberal Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics in Washington, said the message probably did not violate the Hatch Act, the statute that bars most executive branch employees from engaging in political activity. It certainly does run contrary to its policy, and therefore \u201cwould have been inconceivable in any other administration, of either party.\u201d\n\n\u201cThis telephone message falls in the very thin, gray area where this White House lives, which is quite a bit north of definitely wrong, but just south, or on the borderline, of illegal,\u201d Mr. Eisen said.\n\nHe said it violated the longstanding norm observed by presidents in both parties that the White House staff, particularly nonpartisan career employees such as the person likely to have recorded the message, is there to serve all Americans, not just those who voted for him.\n\nBut the recording would be unlikely to generate a formal complaint, Mr. Eisen said, because no specific political candidate was mentioned. The White House changed the message as the Senate headed toward a deal.\n\n\u2014 Eileen Sullivan and Julie Hirschfeld Davis\n\nWhite House shows signs it\u2019s on the offense.\n\nAfter a weekend of relative silence from the White House, Raj Shah, a White House spokesman, appeared on CNN to defend President Trump, who had been publicly criticized as disengaged on the negotiations and unduly influenced by his senior advisers.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re happy with how the president engaged,\u201d Mr. Shah said, before shifting blame to the Democrats. \u201cIt was them that were holding back funding for our military, our troops, our border patrol agents and our first responders.\u201d\n\nMr. Shah also defended a president who has been publicly accused by lawmakers in his own party of deferring to Stephen Miller, the adviser who is ideologically behind much of the White House\u2019s restrictive immigration agenda.\n\n\u201cThose charges are frankly ridiculous, and they\u2019re a little insulting,\u201d Mr. Shah said. \u201cThe views that the president is endorsing are his and his alone.\u201d\n\nMr. Trump, a president prone to hit back against his critics in real time, remained relatively restrained on Monday, except to accuse Democrats of being cowed by activists who want a fast decision on the fate of the Dreamers.", "title": "Stopgap Bill to End Government Shutdown Passes Congress", "authors": ["The New York Times"]} {"date": "2018-01-03 00:00:00", "text": "LONDON \u2014 The winter storm Eleanor tore through Europe on Wednesday with winds of up to 100 miles per hour, bringing lightning and heavy rain, battering houses with hail, flooding streets and uprooting trees.\n\nThe storm \u2014 named Burglind in Austria, Germany and Switzerland \u2014 arrived in tandem with a cold front, hitting Ireland before passing through Britain and on to Continent. Travelers were delayed, and adverse weather was expected to be felt as far north as the Baltics and as far south as Italy.\n\nWeather warnings were the order of the day, with forecasts of violent winds, mostly in coastal areas. Workers raced to restore power to thousands of homes, and to clear highways and train tracks of trees and overturned vehicles.", "title": "Storm Eleanor Batters Europe", "authors": ["Palko Karasz"]} {"date": "2018-01-04 00:00:00", "text": "There remains no evidence for Iranian leaders\u2019 claim that foreign meddling had instigated the protests, but history does offer reasons for such suspicion.\n\nEuropean reluctance to side more openly with the protesters is the latest divergence of approach with the Trump administration, which has openly praised demonstrators.\n\n_____\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 President Trump excommunicated his former chief strategist, Stephen Bannon, saying, in a written statement brimming with anger, that Mr. Bannon had \u201clost his mind.\u201d (Here\u2019s the full text.)\n\nMr. Bannon is quoted in a new book saying that a Trump team meeting with Russians during the campaign was \u201ctreasonous\u201d and that the special counsel in the Russia inquiry would \u201ccrack Don Jr. like an egg on national TV.\u201d\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s former campaign chairman, Paul Manafort, sued the special counsel, arguing that his investigation had exceeded its mandate.\n\nSeparately, Mr. Trump ended an inquiry spurred by his false claims of voter fraud in the 2016 election.\n\n_____\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 On his first working day in 2018, President Trump\u2019s 17 tweets offered a snapshot of his combative approach to this year\u2019s agenda.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAmong other things, Mr. Trump wrote that he wanted to tie Palestinian aid to peace talks. Many Israelis, even some who are generally critical of the Palestinians, see risks in that tactic.\n\nWe took a closer look at the United Nations agency known as Unrwa, which handles much of that aid.\n\n_____\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 Computer security experts have discovered two major security flaws in the microprocessors inside nearly all of the world\u2019s mobile devices, personal computers and servers running in cloud computer networks.\n\nThere is no evidence that hackers have taken advantage of the vulnerability, at least so far.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Morning Briefing What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox. (To be clear, there is no one button to trigger a nuclear war). [The New York Times]\n\n\u2022 President Emmanuel Macron of France proposed new legislation to combat \u201cfake news,\u201d which would allow the authorities to seek the blocking of websites and require sites to be more transparent on paid content. If you can\u2019t, here\u2019s what to do.\n\nNoteworthy\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 The diary above is a rare account of life in the Gulag, the Soviet system of forced labor camps. It is now being exhibited in Moscow, at a time when attitudes toward Russia\u2019s past have become less critical.\n\n\u2022 In Naples, a new exhibition that puts rarely seen ruins from Pompeii in contemporary confines speaks to the recent revitalization of a city that has seen so much in its long history.\n\n\u2022 Ulrich Wegener, the West German police commando who led the 1977 raid that rescued 90 people from a hijacked plane in Somalia, died at 88.\n\n\u2022 We talked to Meryl Streep and Tom Hanks about President Trump, the fallout from the Harvey Weinstein case and why they hadn\u2019t worked together until \u201cThe Post.\u201d\n\nBack Story\n\nPhoto\n\nA new year can bring many changes, but 1999 saw what the Times\u2019s Op-Ed page called the \u201cmost audacious gamble in the history of currency\u201d: the launch of the euro, the common European currency.\n\nAlmost 40 years in the works, the euro was toasted with champagne by finance ministers in the 11 countries where it debuted.\n\nThough euro bank notes and coins wouldn\u2019t be released until 2002, European banks were required to use the currency in transactions as soon as markets opened on Monday, Jan. 4.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFears of technical glitches meant banks brought in employees en masse: In Frankfurt, one bank alone had 3,200 people working to reprogram its computers.\n\nLondon had 30,000 workers on trading floors and in back offices, even though Britain wasn\u2019t even adopting the euro.\n\nThe switch took more than a year of planning, months of rewriting software, and full-scale dress rehearsals.\n\nBut the reward for the banking world\u2019s tireless efforts was simply a smooth debut when world markets opened for business.\n\nOthers received something more concrete to mark the launch: For sharing a birthday with the new currency, each baby born in France on New Year\u2019s Day received 100 euros from the Finance Ministry.\n\nAnna Schaverien contributed reporting.\n\n_____\n\nThis briefing was prepared for the European morning and is updated online. Contact us at europebriefing@nytimes.com.", "title": "Storm Eleanor, Iran, Stephen Bannon: Your Thursday Briefing", "authors": ["Patrick Boehler"]} {"date": "2018-01-31 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nWelcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown that lets you sleep \u2014 and lets us get paid to watch comedy. What do you think of it? What else are you interested in? Let us know: thearts@nytimes.com.\n\n\u2018I Do Not Know Where It Came From\u2019\n\nStephanie Clifford, the former pornographic-film actress known as Stormy Daniels, is not making life easy for the Trump administration. Just minutes after President Trump\u2019s first State of the Union address ended Tuesday night, Ms. Clifford appeared on \u201cJimmy Kimmel Live!,\u201d where she did not deny \u2014 or confirm \u2014 having an affair with Mr. Trump.\n\nOn Tuesday afternoon, a statement claiming to be from Stormy Daniels emerged that forcefully refuted all allegations of an affair. But on Mr. Kimmel\u2019s show, Ms. Clifford strongly implied that she had not written that denial letter. (A lawyer for Mr. Trump had issued a separate letter signed by Ms. Daniels on Jan. 10 denying the affair. That letter was not in question here.)\n\nMr. Kimmel pointed out that the signature on the more recent statement did not appear to match her autograph on other documents. She agreed, saying, \u201cIt does not look like my signature.\u201d He then asked where she thought the letter had come from. \u201cI do not know where it came from,\u201d she said. \u201cIt came from the internet.\u201d\n\nAccording to a report last month in The Wall Street Journal, Mr. Trump\u2019s 2016 campaign team paid Ms. Clifford $130,000 to sign a nondisclosure agreement about an alleged affair. While she did not explicitly admit to Mr. Kimmel that she had signed such an agreement, she seemed to come close.\n\nKIMMEL: Do you have a nondisclosure agreement? CLIFFORD: Do I? KIMMEL: You can\u2019t say whether you have a nondisclosure agreement. But if you didn\u2019t have a nondisclosure agreement, you most certainly could say, \u2018I don\u2019t have a nondisclosure agreement.\u2019 Yes? CLIFFORD: You\u2019re so smart, Jimmy.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAt the end of the interview, Mr. Kimmel tried one more trick to coax out a definitive response. Ms. Clifford deftly deflected it.", "title": "Stormy Daniels Deflects Jimmy Kimmel\u2019s Questions on Rumored Trump Affair", "authors": ["Giovanni Russonello", "Best Of Late Night"]} {"date": "2018-01-29 00:00:00", "text": "Video\n\nA fitness app that posts a map of its users\u2019 activity has unwittingly revealed the locations and habits of military bases and personnel, including those of American forces in Iraq and Syria, security analysts say.\n\nThe app, Strava, which calls itself \u201cthe social network for athletes,\u201d allows millions of users to time and map their workouts and to post them online for friends to see, and it can track their movements at other times. The app is especially popular with young people who are serious about fitness, which describes many service members.\n\nSince November, the company has published a global \u201cheat map\u201d showing the movements of people who have made their posts public. In the last few days, after the app\u2019s oversharing was identified on Twitter by a 20-year-old Australian university student, security analysts have started to take note of that data, and some have argued that the map represents a security breach.\n\nStrava \u201cis sitting on a ton of data that most intelligence entities would literally kill to acquire,\u201d Jeffrey Lewis of the Middlebury Institute of International Studies at Monterey, Calif., warned on Twitter.\n\nSome analysts have taken to social media to warn that, although the map does not name the people who traced its squiggles and lines, individual users can easily be tracked, by cross-referencing their Strava data with other social media use. That could put individual members of the military at risk, even when they are not in war zones.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe outlines of known military bases around the world are clearly visible on the map, especially in countries like Afghanistan, Iraq and Syria, where few locals own exercise tracking devices. In those places, the heat signatures on American bases are set against vast dark spaces. Tobias Schneider, a security analyst, wrote on Twitter that \u201cknown Coalition (i.e. US) bases light up the night.\u201d\n\nIn Afghanistan, for instance, two of the largest coalition bases in the country \u2014 Bagram Airfield, north of Kabul; and Kandahar Airfield, in southern Afghanistan \u2014 can easily be picked out. The same is true for smaller bases around the country whose existence has long been public.", "title": "Strava Fitness App Can Reveal Military Sites, Analysts Say", "authors": ["Richard P\u00e9rez-Pe\u00f1a", "Matthew Rosenberg"]} {"date": "2018-01-29 00:00:00", "text": "\u2022 The Vatican, seeking to end a schism with China, asked two \u201cunderground\u201d bishops to surrender their positions to individuals approved by the country\u2019s authoritarian government.
