Prison guards rejected that plan, calling it insufficient.", "title": "Striking French Prison Guards Stand Firm, Citing Safety and Pay", "authors": ["Aurelien Breeden"]} {"date": "2018-01-08 00:00:00", "text": "Lyndon Johnson is the only other first-term president in the era of modern polling with an approval rating under 50 percent while the jobless rate was below 5 percent. But this came after he\u2019d already been president about four years (having first finished out John F. Kennedy\u2019s term) and as the Vietnam War began to drag down his presidency.\n\nMr. Trump started in a far worse position than other incoming presidents. His initial approval rating was in the low-to-mid 40s, while most presidents enter with an approval rating over 60 percent. It was fair to speculate that his approval ratings would gradually rise with the benefit of a strong economy. Perhaps he would even benefit from low expectations, as many suspected he did during the presidential campaign.\n\nBut by now the economy would have been expected to lift his approval rating into the 50s, based on an analysis of presidential approval and economic data going back to 1950. This is despite the tendency for presidents\u2019 approval ratings to decline during their time in office. If the economy were to overcome Mr. Trump\u2019s unpopularity and send his approval ratings up, you would think we would have started to see signs of it.\n\nIt is certainly possible that the economy \u2014 or other good news \u2014 will still lift his ratings. But it seems just as likely that Mr. Trump will continue to feel the burden of his time in office. On average, a first-term president\u2019s approval rating drops by about a point per quarter after controlling for inflation and unemployment (and controlling for the large bump George W. Bush received after the Sept. 11 attacks).\n\nMr. Trump still has some of the advantages that helped him win despite low favorability ratings in 2016. He appears to maintain the support of his base and fairly high levels of Republican unity. Indeed, his favorability ratings are still higher than they were in the weeks heading into the 2016 election, when they were in the mid 30s. Many pollsters aren\u2019t asking the favorability question anymore, but those that do find it roughly equal to his approval ratings (high 30s).", "title": "Strong Economies Lift Presidents. The coalition has now compiled 10 years of data on diversity on New York stages.\n\nMusicals like \u201cHamilton,\u201d \u201cOn Your Feet!\u201d and \u201cThe Color Purple\u201d have provided opportunities for African-American and Latino performers in particular. During the 2015-16 season, 23 percent of all roles went to African-American actors and 7 percent went to Latino actors. But Asian-American performers dropped to 4 percent of all roles; the arrival of \u201cAllegiance,\u201d set at a Japanese internment camp during World War II, could not sufficiently offset the departure of \u201cThe King and I.\u201d\n\nPlays lagged far behind musicals, with minority actors in only 16 percent of those roles. And most of that casting \u2014 14 percent over all \u2014 went to African-American actors, boosted particularly by Danai Gurira\u2019s \u201cEclipsed,\u201d which is set in Liberia.\n\nMinorities are still underrepresented onstage compared to New York City\u2019s demographics: They make up 56 percent of the city\u2019s population, according to the 2010 census. And a 2016 study by Actors\u2019 Equity found that the problem extends beyond the city: Nationwide, white stage actors generally earn higher wages and hold a disproportionate percentage of theater jobs.", "title": "Study Finds Increasing Diversity on Broadway", "authors": ["Andrew R. While a news release was posted online on Tuesday, the actual wording of the charges is expected to be made public only next week.\n\nMs. Wall, a freelance journalist, vanished on Aug. 10 after leaving the port of Copenhagen on the UC3 Nautilus, a submarine that Mr. Madsen had built and operated. Her torso was found on a beach on Amager Island near Copenhagen after 11 days, and divers later recovered her severed head and legs in plastic bags.\n\nMr. Madsen, 47, has given various explanations for the disappearance of Ms. Wall, 30. But he eventually said that she had died onboard his vessel after a hatch unexpectedly collapsed, and that she had hit her head while she was climbing stairs in the submarine\u2019s tower. If you haven\u2019t yet done so, know that it provides direction and can help you solve.\n\nThe title of today\u2019s puzzle by Victor Barocas and Andy Kravis is \u201cSubstitutes.\u201d That\u2019s pretty clear, in my opinion. We\u2019re going to be swapping things for other things. Easy-peasy. The hard part is figuring out what those things are supposed to be, and keeping track of them.\n\nEven so, this is a nice, satisfying puzzle. It has a whopping 19 unique entries, and lots of fun stuff (GO PRO, all the theme entries, SNOG, TOTEBOARD, BOY\u2019S LIFE, ACE OF HEARTS (making its second appearance since 1981), PET GOAT (I wish!), WALK ON WATER, SEMIPRIVATE, GAYBORHOODS, SEAN YOUNG and (The) QUIET MAN.\n\nToday\u2019s Theme\n\nMr. Barocas and Mr. Kravis offer us a theme set that contains four common phrases at the top of the grid (all debuts, by the way). All of these phrases take the form \u201c___ FOR ___,\u201d as in 23A\u2019s PLAY FOR TIME (clued as \u201cStall\u201d). If you skip down to 95A\u2019s \u201cPlay of Shakespeare (remember 23-Across),\u201d the clue is worded in a wonky way, but we\u2019re not finished, are we?\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nRemember 23A, the clue says, and we have been asked to swap PLAY for TIME. New development plans would emerge from discussions between developers, community groups and city officials.\n\nBut any proposal would require the focused political will of two prominent officials who seem to spend more time sparring with each other than working together: the governor and the mayor. Much of the land along the waterfront is owned by the city and the Port Authority.\n\nThe mayor has planned a different transit solution for Red Hook and the waterfront: a light rail system stretching 14 miles from Sunset Park to Astoria, Queens, although the two projects are not mutually exclusive.\n\nScott Rechler, a developer and a member of the M.T.A.\u2019s board, said that Red Hook was a unique opportunity for a \u201csubway redevelopment corporation,\u201d not the M.T.A., to oversee construction and unlock the value of the waterfront land. Heather Nauert, a State Department spokeswoman, rebuked the Sudanese authorities last Friday for having prevented the journalists from doing their jobs.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. It said four others, arrested Tuesday, included a freelance journalist, Amal Habani, and three reporters, Magdi al-Ajib, Rishan Oushi and Imtenan Al-Radi, who worked for privately owned local newspapers.\n\nFor Reuters, one of the world\u2019s largest news agencies, Sudan was the second country in the past month in which its journalists had been seized by the government for doing their jobs. Two Reuters reporters were arrested in December in Myanmar while reporting on the persecution of that country\u2019s Rohingya minority.\n\nOfficials at Reuters and Agence France-Presse said Friday that the Sudanese government had not been forthcoming on why the journalists were arrested or what laws, if any, they may have violated.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nReuters said in an emailed statement that \u201cwe are actively seeking additional information about the situation.\u201d In its news story on the arrests, Reuters did not identify Mr. Abdelaziz by name and described him as a stringer, a term that refers to a local journalist who works for a news organization that is based elsewhere.\n\nThe Agence France-Presse bureau chief in Khartoum, Jay Deshmukh, said in an email that Sudanese authorities had informed the agency that the journalists were in a detention center in Khartoum run by the National Intelligence and Security Service.\n\n\u201cWe have no information as to when they might be released,\u201d he said.\n\nThe detentions of the journalists got the attention of the Trump administration, which has been slowly moving to improve relations with Sudan but has expressed concern about its history of rights abuses. Sudan is still listed on the State Department\u2019s state sponsor of terrorism blacklist, where it has been since 1993.\n\n\u201cWe condemn the harassment, arbitrary detention, and attacks on journalists in Sudan who are doing their jobs and exercising their fundamental right to freedom of expression,\u201d Heather Nauert, a State Department spokeswoman, said in a statement. \u201cWe remain deeply concerned about freedom of expression, including for members of the media, the closing of political space for all Sudanese, and Sudan\u2019s poor overall human rights record.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSudan government representatives in Khartoum did not immediately respond to requests for comment about the detentions. Mekki Elmograbi, the press attach\u00e9 at Sudan\u2019s embassy in Washington, said he had no information about the arrests.\n\nSherif Mansour, the Middle East and North Africa program coordinator for the Committee to Protect Journalists, said in a phone interview that Sudan\u2019s press repression had grown increasingly harsh.\n\nHe attributed the change partly to examples set by other authoritarian leaders, including Egypt\u2019s president, Abdel Fattah el-Sisi, whose government has harassed and intimidated many journalists to stifle dissident voices.\n\n\u201cThey look at Egypt and other countries in the neighborhood, and they have passed aggressive measures and gotten away with it,\u201d Mr. Mansour said. \u201cThey suppress popular dissent and go after anyone who tries to present it.\u201d", "title": "Sudan Jails Journalists in New Sign of Repression", "authors": ["Rick Gladstone"]} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nIt is not much past 7 a.m. and I am on my morning pre-rounds, pushing my rolling computer from room to room to examine patients, review their lab data and update their medical plans. I enter the room of one my sleeping patients. With each passing day, I\u2019ve watched his legs grow thinner and his energy wane. His body needs protein and calories now more than ever.\n\nSeveral boxes of a liquid nutritional supplement sit on my patient\u2019s tray table. There are a variety of flavors \u2014 vanilla, chocolate, strawberry \u2014 just as I had ordered. Like many of the patients I see, he has what we call \u201cprotein calorie malnutrition,\u201d which accompanies a range of conditions, from failure-to-thrive at home to critical illness in the I.C.U. The elderly and sick are more likely to lose their appetites and eat poorly, and at a time when the body is most dependent on good nutrition, it is betrayed by these symptoms. Untreated, the weak become weaker, the sick become sicker, and a terminal spiral ensues.\n\nSupplement shakes like these, with confidence-inspiring names like Boost and Ensure, are marketed aggressively to consumers and health care providers alike as a healthful panacea for all those struggling to take in enough daily calories. The theory behind these drinks is simple and makes sense: They provide a dense and palatable form of calories that can be tolerated even by those who have poor appetite, no teeth, difficulty swallowing or any of the other myriad symptoms that accompany illness.\n\nI pick up one of the colorful, cheery boxes and turn it over to look at its ingredient list. My eyes find the first and main ingredient: water. Then the second ingredient by quantity: corn syrup. There, farther down the list, is a milk-derived protein, and then, more sugar. The protein content is only 10 grams. The diminutive Greek yogurt I had that morning before work contained more protein and a fraction of the sugar.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nA wave of queasy guilt comes over me as I think to myself, \u201cThis is how I\u2019ve been treating malnutrition?\u201d Beverages that contain refined sugars like these have been linked in many rigorous studies to metabolic derangements like Type 2 diabetes, heart disease and fatty liver disease. When I see patients in the office, I remind them at every visit to avoid these kinds of heavily processed and sweetened foods and drinks.", "title": "Sugary Shakes in the Hospital Aren\u2019t Good Medicine", "authors": ["Dave Lieberman"]} {"date": "2018-01-17 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nMAIDUGURI, Nigeria \u2014 A double suicide bombing at a market in Nigeria\u2019s northern city of Maiduguri killed at least 12 people and wounded 48 others on Wednesday, residents and an emergency official said.\n\nIbrahim Usman, a trader in the Muna Garage market, said the first bomber attacked inside the market while the other remained outside, killing only himself.\n\n\u201cSuddenly there was a loud bang and everywhere became disorganized,\u201d Mr. Usman said. \u201cI counted 12 corpses and over 40 injured victims.\u201d\n\nThe official in charge of rescue operations for the State Emergency Management Agency, Bello Dambatta, said that the bomber who was inside the market was a woman and that the one who remained outside was a man.\n\nAlthough there was no immediate claim of responsibility, the attack was similar to many carried out by the Islamist extremist group Boko Haram. Muna Garage, the site of a camp for displaced people, has been attacked several times in the past few years by Boko Haram insurgents. Maiduguri, the capital of Borno State, has been a refuge for thousands of people displaced by the insurgency in Nigeria\u2019s northeast.\n\nBoko Haram, which was formed in Maiduguri, has killed more than 20,000 people in its nine-year insurgency. The group has used women and children as suicide bombers, often after abducting and indoctrinating them.", "title": "Suicide Bombers Attack Market in Nigeria, Killing at Least 12", "authors": ["The Associated Press"]} {"date": "2018-01-15 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nBAGHDAD \u2014 Two suicide bombers killed more than two dozen people in Baghdad on Monday, mostly street vendors and day laborers gathered at dawn in hopes of finding work at an open-air market, in the first major attack in the Iraqi capital since the government declared victory over the Islamic State.\n\nThe carnage in Tayaran Square punctured a growing sense of hope and pride that had permeated Baghdad after Iraq\u2019s security forces, bolstered by large numbers of volunteers and fresh recruits, successfully fought grueling battles against the insurgent group that had held one-third of Iraqi territory and terrorized millions of citizens.\n\nThere was no immediate claim of responsibility for the bombings, but officials in charge of security in the capital immediately cast suspicion on Islamic State sleeper cells, the target of Iraq\u2019s intelligence and counterterrorism forces since major military operations ended in the fall.\n\nEven as battles against Islamic State militants raged in northern Iraq and in its second-largest city, Mosul, Baghdad had largely been free of violence. The suicide bombings Monday morning caught many residents of the capital off guard, as they had become used to living relatively free of fear, taking their families to parks and shopping malls.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe attacks came a day after Prime Minister Haider al-Abadi and other politicians announced competing coalitions ahead of national elections scheduled for May. Since the overthrow of Saddam Hussein in 2003, campaign seasons in Iraq have been scarred by terrorist attacks and other violence.", "title": "Suicide Bombings in Baghdad Puncture Newfound Hope", "authors": ["Falih Hassan", "Margaret Coker"]} {"date": "2018-01-17 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nEven as the movie business continues to shift its models, the Sundance Film Festival remains a place where careers are born, Oscar dreams arise and top-dollar distribution deals are made. This year\u2019s edition starts Thursday, Jan. 18, in Park City, Utah and runs through Jan. 28. Here are five movies we\u2019re looking forward to that could make an impact.\n\n\u2018Sorry to Bother You\u2019\n\nThe rapper and activist Boots Riley, of the hip-hop act the Coup, is making his feature directorial debut with this trippy-looking movie set in an alternate present-day version of Oakland. The cast is great, with Lakeith Stanfield (\u201cAtlanta\u201d) starring as a telemarketer who makes a breakthrough to success at his company, Tessa Thompson (\u201cCreed,\u201d \u201cThor: Ragnarok\u201d) as his artist/activist girlfriend and Armie Hammer as an orgy-hosting C.E.O. With a score by Tune-Yards and music performed by the Coup, \u201cSorry to Bother You\u201d has the potential to sound as fun as it looks.\n\nVideo\n\n\u2018Leave No Trace\u2019\n\nIt\u2019s been eight years since the director Debra Granik showed her film \u201cWinter\u2019s Bone\u201d at Sundance, which garnered acclaim for her and showcased a breakthrough performance by then little-known Jennifer Lawrence. Ms. Granik is back with this drama about a father (Ben Foster) and his teenage daughter (Thomasin Harcourt McKenzie) who have lived undetected in the Oregon woods until discovered. Could this be a breakout performance that propels Ms. McKenzie\u2019s career to Lawrence-level heights? We\u2019re thrilled to see.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2018Hereditary\u2019\n\nThe director Ari Aster caused an internet stir with his 2011 short film \u201cThe Strange Thing About the Johnsons,\u201d an eyebrow-raising family melodrama that played like a horror film, approaching a taboo subject from a different angle (a son who molests his father). Now Mr. Aster\u2019s first feature is appearing in the midnight section of the festival, and it\u2019s another creepy, family-focused story about a clan who must reckon with a dark fate after the death of a grandmother. Toni Collette, Gabriel Byrne and Ann Dowd are part of the cast. Plus, A24 is already set to distribute, and its track record on releasing compelling films, including \u201cThe Florida Project\u201d and \u201cLady Bird,\u201d has been solid to say the least.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2018Wildlife\u2019\n\nAs an actor, Paul Dano brings determination and specificity to his work. He feels like the kind of artist who could succeed with that determination behind the camera. That\u2019s the hope here, as he directs Carey Mulligan, Jake Gyllenhaal and the young actor Ed Oxenbould in this adaptation of Richard Ford\u2019s novel. Set in 1960s Montana, the film tracks the changes in a family when the father leaves to fight a forest fire near the Canadian border. It seems like a compelling showcase for an always-impressive Ms. Mulligan and an opportunity for Mr. Dano to bring depth to this work.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2018The Miseducation of Cameron Post\u2019\n\nDesiree Akhavan created a kinetic and clever comedy in \u201cAppropriate Behavior,\u201d which played at Sundance in 2014. The Times review called that film \u201calive,\u201d with a screenplay \u201cpacked with smart remarks.\u201d Her new movie is set in 1993 and features Chlo\u00eb Grace Moretz as a small-town Montana high school student who is sent to conversion therapy when she is caught with another girl on prom night. Ms. Akhavan adapted the screenplay with Cecilia Frugiuele from the novel by Emily M. Danforth, and the project has the promise of more smart remarks and plenty of thought-provoking ones too.", "title": "Sundance Film Festival: 5 Movies to Watch", "authors": ["Mekado Murphy"]} {"date": "2018-01-21 00:00:00", "text": "Reed Hastings, Netflix\u2019s chief executive, is now the person who reporters for Hollywood trade publications track through the snow.\n\n\u201cHarvey was a moment in time,\u201d Robert Redford, who founded Sundance, said at the festival\u2019s opening-day news conference on Thursday.\n\nPhoto\n\nJohn Cooper, Sundance\u2019s director, acknowledged in an interview that his festival\u2019s 35-year history will be forever intertwined with Mr. Weinstein, who reached a settlement with the actress Rose McGowan after a 1997 festival encounter that she has since described, on Twitter, as rape. (Through a spokeswoman, Mr. Weinstein has repeatedly denied \u201cany allegations of nonconsensual sex.\u201d) But Mr. Cooper also said that the fallen mogul\u2019s impact on Sundance had long been overstated.\n\n\u201cNobody on the ground here ever gave him a crown,\u201d Mr. Cooper said. \u201cHe was just the loudest and the media followed and built him up.\u201d\n\nTom Bernard, the co-founder of Sony Pictures Classics, who has attended Sundance since its inception and shepherded such celebrated indie films as \u201cWhiplash\u201d and the current Oscar contender \u201cCall Me By Your Name,\u201d said in an interview that the festival had matured and diversified in ways that the news media often ignored. \u201cSundance coverage tends to play into a mystique that just isn\u2019t true anymore,\u201d Mr. Bernard said.\n\nSundance\u2019s anything-goes aura was established in the 1990s and the 2000s, when independent film reigned as the epitome of cool. Fueled by the DVD boom, almost all of the big studios created specialty divisions and poured money into Sundance distribution deals, leading to all-night bidding wars in luxury condos around Park City. Marketers for fashion labels, cellphone companies and vodka brands scrambled to capitalize on the heat, setting up gifting suites that attracted celebrities with no connection to the festival. (Paris Hilton, most infamously.) Films took a back seat to the circus.\n\nPhoto\n\nThere is still plenty of hot tub hopping. But the festival, which attracted 71,600 attendees last year, has matured into middle age. The swag suites are largely gone. Creative Artists Agency, which threw a Sundance party in 2013 featuring lingerie-clad women pretending to snort prop cocaine and exotic dancers outfitted with sex toys, has not had an event the past two years. A newly implemented Sundance code of conduct states that the festival can kick out anyone engaging in \u201charassment, discrimination, sexism and threatening or disrespectful behavior.\u201d A lot of gray hair can be seen on the festival shuttle buses; people who started coming here in their 20s are now in their 40s.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAs for those bidding wars, this year\u2019s Sundance opened on a quiet note. By Sunday afternoon, four days into the 11-day festival, only one significant distribution deal had been struck. Bleecker Street, founded in 2014 with backing from Manoj Bhargava, the 5-Hour Energy drink entrepreneur, and 30West, a company financed by the Texas billionaire Dan Friedkin, teamed up to pay roughly $5 million for distribution rights to \u201cColette,\u201d a costume drama starring Keira Knightley as the French novelist Sidonie Gabrielle Colette. (Amazon was also a bidder.)\n\n\u201cThere are two different worlds intersecting, one that is traditional and focused on ticket sales and one that only cares about signing up more subscribers,\u201d said Peter Broderick, a film distribution strategist. \u201cTraditional distributors have a lot of challenges. So many are looking backward \u2014 what has worked for us before. At the same time, they are being priced out of the market for the better films.\u201d\n\nDistributors, including relatively new players like A24, Neon and Annapurna, may be erring on the side of caution. Some sales agents cited the dampening effect of \u201cPatti Cake$,\u201d a rap-infused drama that sold to Fox Searchlight for an estimated $10 million last year and ended up taking in just $800,148 in theaters. But the mix of movies this time around could also be a factor; some distributors complained that films that premiered early in the festival were flawed, including the opening-night selection, \u201cBlindspotting.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s not as big of a marketplace for finished films as it was in the \u201990s and early 2000s,\u201d said Mr. Bernard of Sony Pictures Classics. \u201cBut it\u2019s still an enormous marketplace for talent: Casting people looking for actors, producers looking for directors and cinematographers.\u201d (One example from recent years: After gaining attention at Sundance for quirky films like \u201cHunt for the Wilderpeople,\u201d Taika Waititi went on to direct \u201cThor: Ragnarok\u201d for Disney.)\n\nThis year\u2019s primary festival lineup \u2014 122 feature-length films culled from 3,901 submissions \u2014 includes many movies that examine race. \u201cBlindspotting,\u201d starring Daveed Diggs, best known for winning a Tony for \u201cHamilton,\u201d is a raucous, hip-hop-infused story of racism, stereotypes and gentrification. (Mr. Cooper, Sundance\u2019s director, called it \u201cfun, to the point of being sassy\u201d as he introduced it. Reviews are mixed.)\n\nOther selections addressing race include \u201cSorry to Bother You,\u201d about a thirtysomething black telemarketer who climbs rungs by finding his inner \u201cwhite voice,\u201d and \u201cMonsters and Men,\u201d about a Puerto Rican man in Brooklyn who witnesses a white police officer wrongly gun down a black resident.\n\nMr. Cooper drew a connection between filmmakers wrestling with race and the #OscarsSoWhite outcry in 2015 and 2016. \u201cIt usually takes about two years for topics to permeate,\u201d he said.\n\nPhoto\n\nEven so, women are front and center at this year\u2019s festival, noted Trevor Groth, Sundance\u2019s director of programming.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThere are major documentaries on Supreme Court Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg, Jane Fonda, Joan Jett and the artist Yayoi Kusama, in addition to the one on Ms. Allred. Amy Adrion\u2019s \u201cHalf the Picture\u201d delves into gender bias in Hollywood. Alexandria Bombach\u2019s \u201cOn Her Shoulders\u201d looks at a young female activist and survivor of ISIS sex slavery.\n\nThe actresses Chlo\u00eb Sevigny, Laura Dern, Carey Mulligan, Chlo\u00eb Grace Moretz, Kathryn Hahn, Maggie Gyllenhaal, Rose Byrne, Daisy Ridley, Blythe Danner, Hilary Swank and Kelly Macdonald all anchor films. And 45 movies were directed by women, including indie stalwarts like Tamara Jenkins and Debra Granik.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s a really plentiful year for women,\u201d Mr. Groth said, \u201cwhich makes us enormously excited.\u201d\n\nAll the better to vanquish memories of Mr. Weinstein.", "title": "Sundance, Steeped in Weinstein Mystique, Enters a New Era", "authors": ["Brooks Barnes"]} {"date": "2018-01-21 00:00:00", "text": "On Sunday, the five projectors at the Sunshine Cinema beamed for the last time, the finale of a cultural mainstay on the Lower East Side of Manhattan. The movie theater, which had screened independent and foreign films since 2001, was sold last year to New York City developers with plans to demolish it.\n\nFor over a century, the building was a neighborhood cornerstone, first as a church, then as an athletic club, and later as a nickelodeon that drew hundreds of attendees a day to its Yiddish vaudeville performances.\n\nThe demise of the theater on Houston Street is the latest in a string of closings in the city, as cinemas struggle to stay relevant in the streaming age of Netflix and Hulu. Last month, the announced closing of the Lincoln Plaza Cinema, which opened in 1981, rattled the theater community\u2019s devotees.\n\nSunshine Cinema, operated by Landmark Theaters, became popular among neighbors and enthusiasts for its distinct selection of films, emblematic honey-colored brick facade and stadium seating. Its midnight screenings of classics like \u201cDog Day Afternoon\u201d and \u201cThe Room\u201d also attracted a cult following. In fact, the director of \u201cThe Room,\u201d Tom Wiseau, attended three screenings at the Sunshine this month.", "title": "Sunshine Cinema, a Beloved Manhattan Theater, Goes Dark", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "The first time Minneapolis hosted the Super Bowl, in 1992, a solitary sports bar and acres of parking lots surrounding the Hubert H. Humphrey Metrodome stood in testament to the stadium\u2019s failure to generate private investment in the neighborhood, an area east of downtown.\n\nBut football fans returning to the city to watch the New England Patriots and Philadelphia Eagles compete in Super Bowl LII on Feb. 4 are not likely to recognize the area, now known as East Town. The Metrodome, a walled-in colossus that dominated the barren landscape from 1982 to 2014, has been replaced by U.S. Bank Stadium, which opened in 2016. The roughly $1.1 billion bright and transparent edifice, designed by HKS architects, features a mostly clear, steep roof and has been likened to a Nordic long house, a Viking warship and an ice shard formation.\n\nNew offices, apartments, hotels, restaurants and a 4.2-acre park known as the Commons have replaced the parking lots. In all, more than $2 billion in private and public investment has been injected into East Town, according to the East Town Business Partnership, an organization that promotes the roughly 120-block district, which is bordered generally by the Mississippi River, downtown and three interstates.\n\n\u201cIf you had an aerial picture of this area 10 years ago, probably 15 blocks were surface parking lots, and now there are maybe five,\u201d said George Sherman, principal of Sherman Associates, a developer in East Town. \u201cI doubt if there will be any that haven\u2019t been developed in the next two to three years.\u201d", "title": "Super Bowl\u2019s Minneapolis Stadium Brings a Surge in Development", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-01 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nI found \u201c \u2018Dreamers,\u2019 in Jeopardy, Get Support From Range of Stars and Businesses\u201d (news article, Dec. 8) morally encouraging. But the success stories of young people in the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals, or DACA, program are not being recognized and are being denied by a substantial number of Republican politicians in Congress.\n\nAmong today\u2019s Dreamers it is possible to identify future architects, engineers, social workers, lawyers, doctors, scientists, artists, business executives and so forth. Such a precious educational investment in these talented youths by thousands of teachers should not be underestimated.\n\nTragically, the Dreamers\u2019 deportation clock is still ticking. If thousands of educated Dreamers get deported as a result of politics in Washington, it will be at our own peril, particularly in the coming decades of global competition.\n\nToday\u2019s Dreamers grew up American, socially, culturally and educationally! Legalization, and a clear path to United States citizenship, should be granted immediately to this vibrant sector of our future leadership.", "title": "Opinion | Support for the \u2018Dreamers\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-22 00:00:00", "text": "Others partygoers said that a woman named \u201cPeaches\u201d or \u201cTasty\u201d was renting the house and had invited them. A police officer called the woman, who gave evasive answers and declined to return to the party. The police then arrested the partygoers for unlawful entry and later charged them with disorderly conduct. The charges were eventually dropped.\n\nSixteen of the partygoers sued, saying there had been no probable cause to arrest them. A trial judge agreed, saying there was no evidence that the partygoers knew or should have known that they were trespassing. The judge awarded them damages and legal fees of almost $1 million, and a divided appeals court panel affirmed.\n\nJustice Thomas, writing for seven justices, said that in the circumstances the police officers had been entitled to assume that \u201cthe partygoers were knowingly taking advantage of a vacant house as a venue for their late-night party.\u201d Some of them fled or hid, he wrote, which was \u201can indication that they knew they were not supposed to be there.\u201d\n\nThere may have been innocent explanations for particular responses, Justice Thomas wrote. But taken as a whole, the scene at the party was enough to provide probable cause for the arrests.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cThe circumstances here certainly suggested criminal activity,\u201d he wrote. \u201cAs explained, the officers found a group of people who claimed to be having a bachelor party with no bachelor, in a near-empty house, with strippers in the living room and sexual activity in the bedroom, and who fled at the first sign of police.\u201d\n\nIn any event, he added, the officers were entitled to immunity from the lawsuit because there was no Supreme Court decision clearly establishing that the arrests were unlawful. In a concurring opinion, Justice Sonia Sotomayor joined only that part of Justice Thomas\u2019s opinion.\n\nJustice Ruth Bader Ginsburg also voted with the majority but did not embrace its reasoning. She suggested that the court should revise its approach to such cases. \u201cThe court\u2019s jurisprudence, I am concerned, sets the balance too heavily in favor of police unaccountability to the detriment of Fourth Amendment protection,\u201d Justice Ginsburg wrote.\n\nThe court also agreed to hear a case on the habitat of an endangered animal, the dusky gopher frog, in Weyerhauser Co. v. United States Fish and Wildlife Service, No. 17-71. In 2012, the federal government designated private land in Louisiana as \u201ccritical habitat\u201d for the frog, limiting the ability of the owners to develop the land and by one account potentially costing them about $34 million.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe landowners argued that the designation makes no sense, as the frogs are not currently present and the land is not a suitable habitat for them in any event. \u201cThe frog does not live there, cannot live there, and will not live there in the future,\u201d the landowners told the Supreme Court.\n\nThe government responded that the land was the best choice for an effort to protect the frog.\n\nThe landowners\u2019 objection that their land \u201cis not suited in all respects for immediate occupation by the frog,\u201d the government\u2019s lawyers wrote, \u201coverlooks the substantial practical challenges inherent in the identification of critical habitat for endangered species. Many species are endangered precisely because their ideal habitat has been severely diminished or eliminated altogether.\u201d\n\n\u201cWhere optimal habitat is unavailable,\u201d the brief said, \u201cthe service acts appropriately in prioritizing areas with those features that are rarest or most difficult to reproduce through human intervention \u2014 here, the unique ephemeral ponds necessary for the frog\u2019s breeding \u2014 while ensuring that any deficiencies in those areas could be addressed with \u2018reasonable effort.\u2019 \u201d", "title": "Supreme Court Considers a Raucous Party and an Endangered Frog", "authors": ["Adam Liptak"]} {"date": "2018-01-17 00:00:00", "text": "Justice Elena Kagan said Mr. English may have been an effective lawyer but nonetheless one who had betrayed his client.\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s nothing wrong with what this lawyer did, if the goal is avoiding the death penalty,\u201d she said. \u201cThe problem that this case presents is something different. It\u2019s the lawyer\u2019s substitution of his goal of avoiding the death penalty for the client\u2019s goal.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. McCoy, she said, was entitled to take his chances if his \u201cparamount goal\u201d was to insist that he had not committed the murders.\n\nMuch of the discussion on Wednesday involved a search for a constitutional line that would afford Mr. McCoy a new trial but not allow all disgruntled clients to second-guess their lawyers\u2019 strategic decisions.\n\nSeth P. Waxman, a lawyer for Mr. McCoy, said the Constitution guaranteed him the right to direct at least the most fundamental aspect of his defense.\n\n\u201cWhen a defendant maintains his innocence and insists on testing the prosecution on its burden of proof,\u201d Mr. Waxman said, \u201cthe Constitution prohibits a trial court from permitting the defendant\u2019s own lawyer, over the defendant\u2019s objection, to tell the jury that he is guilty.\u201d\n\nBut Elizabeth Murrill, Louisiana\u2019s solicitor general, said lawyers should be able to ignore their client\u2019s wishes in some cases.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIn a narrow class of death penalty cases,\u201d she said, \u201ccounsel sometimes might be required to override his client on a trial strategy when the strategy that the client wants counsel to pursue is a futile charade and requires him to defeat both their objectives of defeating the death penalty.\u201d\n\nMr. McCoy was convicted of killing Christine Colston Young, Willie Young and Gregory Colston, who were the mother, stepfather and son of Mr. McCoy\u2019s estranged wife. There was substantial evidence that he had done so and some reason to think that Mr. McCoy\u2019s belief in his innocence was both earnest and delusional.\n\nPhoto\n\nBut there was no dispute about Mr. McCoy\u2019s instruction to Mr. English. He was adamant that he was innocent and that others had committed the crimes. Mr. English disagreed.\n\n\u201cI met with Robert at the courthouse and explained to him that I intended to concede that he had killed the three victims,\u201d Mr. English recalled in a sworn statement. \u201cRobert was furious and it was a very intense meeting. He told me not to make that concession, but I told him that I was going to do so.\u201d\n\nDuring his opening statement at the trial, Mr. English did what he had promised. \u201cI\u2019m telling you,\u201d he told the jury, \u201cMr. McCoy committed these crimes.\u201d\n\nJustice Samuel A. Alito Jr. said there had been several questionable rulings in the case, suggesting that the precise problem in it was unlikely to recur. It was not clear, he said, that Mr. McCoy was competent to stand trial. It was possible that the trial judge should have allowed Mr. English to withdraw from the case, allowed Mr. McCoy more time to find another lawyer or allowed him to represent himself.\n\nIn the end, Mr. English\u2019s trial strategy failed. Mr. McCoy was convicted and sentenced to death. He appealed to the Louisiana Supreme Court, saying his lawyer had betrayed him. The court ruled against him.\n\n\u201cGiven the circumstances of this crime and the overwhelming evidence incriminating the defendant,\u201d the court said, \u201cadmitting guilt in an attempt to avoid the imposition of the death penalty appears to constitute reasonable trial strategy.\u201d\n\nThe decision relied on a unanimous 2004 ruling from the United States Supreme Court in Florida v. Nixon, which said lawyers need not obtain their clients\u2019 express consent before conceding guilt in a capital case. But the ruling did not address whether it was permissible for a lawyer to disregard a client\u2019s explicit instruction to the contrary.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThat is the question in the case argued Wednesday, McCoy v. Louisiana, No. 16-8255.", "title": "Supreme Court Skeptical of Lawyer\u2019s Conduct in Death Penalty Case", "authors": ["Adam Liptak"]} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "The judges noted that the legislator responsible for drawing the map had not disguised his intentions. \u201cI think electing Republicans is better than electing Democrats,\u201d said the legislator, Representative David Lewis, a Republican. \u201cSo I drew this map to help foster what I think is better for the country.\u201d\n\nThe plan worked. In 2016, the court said, Republican congressional candidates won 53 percent of the statewide vote. But they won in 10 of the 13 congressional districts, or 77 percent of them.\n\nThe Supreme Court has ruled that racial gerrymandering can violate the Constitution. But it has never struck down a voting map as an unconstitutional partisan gerrymander.\n\nRepublicans and, in private, many Democrats in North Carolina had expected the Supreme Court to stay last week\u2019s ruling, which ordered legislators to prepare a new map by Jan. 24. But elected officials and political strategists had been preparing for the possibility of a hasty redrawing of the congressional map and an upending of carefully laid plans for the midterm campaigns.\n\nEven the brief gap between the trial court\u2019s ruling and the Supreme Court\u2019s order left the state in turmoil weeks before the deadline to declare candidacies.\n\nFew states in recent years have seen as much political turbulence as North Carolina, where Republicans took control of the General Assembly in 2010 and now face off regularly with a Democratic governor. Many of the high-decibel clashes in North Carolina, even before Gov. Roy Cooper was elected in 2016, focused on elections and voting procedures.\n\nA voter ID law has been the subject of contentious litigation, and a different three-judge panel concluded that many of the state\u2019s legislative districts had been racially gerrymandered. In 2016, a court struck down a different version of the congressional map, saying it was a racial gerrymander.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut last week\u2019s ruling stirred particular anger in Raleigh, the state capital, with Republicans infuriated that the judges had begun making arrangements for a court-appointed expert to draw a map as an alternative to one that the Legislature might develop.\n\nAlthough observers said the three-judge panel\u2019s ruling, stayed or not, had offered Democrats a valuable talking point in the months before midterm elections, Republicans welcomed the Supreme Court\u2019s order on Thursday.\n\n\u201cWe did fully expect this, but we are still grateful,\u201d said Dallas Woodhouse, the executive director of the North Carolina Republican Party, who complained in an interview that the lower court had tried to \u201cinject chaos into our elections.\u201d Mr. Woodhouse said he fully expected that this year\u2019s elections would be carried out under the existing map.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Get the Morning Briefing by Email What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox Monday through Friday.
