Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nCritics of the map expressed disappointment and frustration with the court\u2019s order.\n\n\u201cWe still believe the day is coming soon for the General Assembly to be held to account for this madness,\u201d said Allison Riggs of the Southern Coalition for Social Justice, which represents the League of Women Voters of North Carolina, a group that challenged the map. \u201cThe law and the facts of this case make that clear.\u201d\n\nJ. Michael Bitzer, a political scientist at Catawba College, near Charlotte, said the Supreme Court\u2019s order was an important, if perhaps temporary, win for Republicans in North Carolina.\n\n\u201cCertainly, Republicans will view this as a victory but probably a short-term victory,\u201d he said. \u201cThey certainly dodged a bullet tonight. The question is: \u2018How long do we have before the Wisconsin decision comes down, and what kind of impact will that have on 2018\u2019s elections?\u2019\u201d\n\nIn October, the Supreme Court heard arguments in the case from Wisconsin. The trial court in that case had struck down a voting map for the State Assembly as an unconstitutional partisan gerrymander.\n\nThe Supreme Court has also agreed to decide whether Maryland Democrats crossed a constitutional line by redrawing House districts to flip a Republican-held seat to Democratic control.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn asking the Supreme Court to block the North Carolina ruling, state lawmakers said the trial court had made legal errors and unreasonable demands, notably in ordering new congressional maps to be drawn by Jan. 24.\n\nThe lawmakers\u2019 brief reminded the justices that they had granted a stay in the Wisconsin case. \u201cParticularly given the relief this court already granted to Wisconsin,\u201d they wrote, \u201cit makes no sense whatsoever to force North Carolina to immediately remedy a purported partisan gerrymandering violation and commence its 2018 election cycle under a new court-imposed map before this court can even decide whether and under what circumstances such claims may be adjudicated.\u201d\n\nIn their own brief, lawyers for Democrats challenging the map said the lawmakers\u2019 motive in seeking a stay was \u201cplain as day.\u201d\n\n\u201cThe Republican contingent of the legislature wants to enjoy the fruits of their grossly unconstitutional actions for yet another election cycle,\u201d the brief said.", "title": "Supreme Court Temporarily Blocks North Carolina Gerrymandering Ruling", "authors": ["Adam Liptak", "Alan Blinder"]} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "Justice Breyer fleshed out the point. \u201cEvery year a certain number of people die, and every year a certain number move to California,\u201d he said. \u201cWe don\u2019t want them on the voter roll. That used to be a big problem, voting dead people.\u201d\n\nThe case concerns Larry Harmon, a software engineer and Navy veteran who lives near Akron, Ohio. He voted in the 2004 and 2008 presidential elections but skipped the next one, saying he was unimpressed by the candidates. He also sat out the midterm elections in 2010 and 2014.\n\nIn 2015, Mr. Harmon did want to vote, against a ballot initiative to legalize marijuana. But his name had been stricken from the voting rolls.\n\nFederal laws prohibit states from removing people from voter rolls \u201cby reason of the person\u2019s failure to vote.\u201d But they allow election officials who suspect that a voter has moved to send a confirmation notice.\n\nA central question in the case was whether a failure to vote could be the reason to send out the notice.\n\nOhio is more aggressive than any other state in purging its voter rolls. After skipping a single federal election cycle, voters are sent a notice. If they fail to respond and do not vote in the next four years, their names are purged from the rolls.\n\nA few other states use similar approaches, but not one of them moves as fast. \u201cOhio is the only state that commences such a process based on the failure to vote in a single federal election cycle,\u201d said a brief from the League of Women Voters and the Brennan Center for Justice. \u201cLiterally every other state uses a different, and more voter-protective, practice.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAt Wednesday\u2019s argument, Eric E. Murphy, Ohio\u2019s state solicitor, said about eight states send out notices based on the failure to vote.\n\nJustice Ruth Bader Ginsburg said there was good reason to think that \u201cCongress didn\u2019t want failure to vote to be a trigger for this procedure.\u201d\n\nBut Justice Samuel A. Alito Jr. said the laws appeared to permit Ohio to use its notification process.\n\n\u201cWhy isn\u2019t the best interpretation of this that one cannot be removed from the list solely because of failure to vote?\u201d he asked. The failure to respond to the notice, he suggested, was an additional reason.\n\nPaul M. Smith, a lawyer for the challengers, said there were far more reliable methods of figuring out whether people had moved, including consulting records kept by the post office and motor vehicle departments.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nOn the other hand, Mr. Smith said, \u201cthe failure to vote for two years tells you almost nothing about whether or not anybody has moved.\u201d\n\nHe said more than half of Ohio voters sit out elections over a two-year period and 70 percent of people who receive notices from the state do not return them.\n\n\u201cThe process is vastly overbroad in its design,\u201d Mr. Smith said. \u201cYou\u2019re just going to end up with a lot of false positives.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Smith added that it is lawful for states to send nonforwardable notices based on the failure to vote, and take action based on the ones returned as undeliverable.\n\nChief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. seemed surprised by the concession. \u201cSo the triggering event can be the failure to vote?\u201d he asked. \u201cI would have thought that\u2019s inconsistent with the rest of your argument.\u201d\n\nBut the distinction between a failure to respond to a notice and one returned as undeliverable seemed to appeal to Justice Breyer.\n\nJustices Clarence Thomas and Neil M. Gorsuch asked no questions.\n\nThe United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit, in Cincinnati, ruled in favor of Mr. Harmon in 2016, saying that Ohio had violated the National Voter Registration Act of 1993 by using the failure to vote as a \u201ctrigger\u201d for sending the notices.\n\nWithout that decision, \u201cthe ballots of more than 7,500 eligible Ohioans would have gone uncounted in the November 2016 election,\u201d Mr. Harmon\u2019s lawyers at Demos and the American Civil Liberties Union wrote in a Supreme Court brief.\n\nA Reuters study in 2016 found that at least 144,000 people were removed from the voting rolls in recent years in Ohio\u2019s three largest counties, which are home to Cleveland, Cincinnati and Columbus.\n\n\u201cVoters have been struck from the rolls in Democratic-leaning neighborhoods at roughly twice the rate as in Republican neighborhoods,\u201d the study found. \u201cNeighborhoods that have a high proportion of poor, African-American residents are hit the hardest.\u201d\n\nTwelve states, generally led by Democrats, filed a brief supporting Mr. Harmon. Seventeen states, generally Republican, filed a brief on the other side.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe Justice Department for decades took the position that failing to vote should not lead to disenfranchisement. In the appeals court, the Obama administration filed a brief supporting Mr. Harmon.\n\nAfter the last presidential election, the department switched sides in the case, Husted v. A. Philip Randolph Institute, No. 16-980.\n\nQuestioning Solicitor General Noel J. Francisco, Justice Sotomayor said that it \u201cseems quite unusual that your office would change its position so dramatically,\u201d particularly where the new stance had \u201ca negative impact on certain groups in this society.\u201d\n\nMr. Francisco responded that further study of the key statute and a concern for states\u2019 rights had prompted the shift.\n\nLate in the argument, Justice Alito said the case must turn on the words of the governing federal laws.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s a very important subject,\u201d he said. \u201cIt\u2019s a sensitive subject. As a policy matter, there are strong arguments on both sides.\u201d\n\n\u201cCongress had struck a compromise,\u201d Justice Alito said. \u201cWhat we have before us is a question of statutory interpretation, not a question of what we think would be the ideal system for achieving the result of removing people who have moved from the voter lists.\u201d", "title": "Supreme Court Weighs Purge of Ohio Voting Rolls", "authors": ["Adam Liptak"]} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 The Supreme Court announced on Friday that it would consider a challenge to President Trump\u2019s latest effort to limit travel from countries said to pose a threat to the nation\u2019s security, adding a major test of presidential power to a docket already crowded with blockbusters.\n\nThe case concerns Mr. Trump\u2019s third and most considered bid to make good on a campaign promise to secure the nation\u2019s borders. But challengers to the latest ban, issued as a presidential proclamation in September, said it was tainted by religious animus and not adequately justified by national security concerns.\n\nThe decision to hear the case, Trump v. Hawaii, No. 17-965, came almost a year after the first travel ban, issued a week after Mr. Trump took office, caused chaos at the nation\u2019s airports and was promptly blocked by courts around the nation. A second version of the ban, issued in March, fared little better, though the Supreme Court allowed part of it go into effect in June when it agreed to hear the Trump administration\u2019s appeals in two cases.\n\nBut the Supreme Court dismissed those appeals in October after the second ban expired. There is no reason to think the latest appeal will fizzle out, as the September order, unlike the earlier ones, is meant to last indefinitely. The justices are likely to hear arguments in the latest case in the spring and to issue a decision in late June.", "title": "Supreme Court to Consider Challenge to Trump\u2019s Latest Travel Ban", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-13 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nSUNDAY PUZZLE \u2014 Yes, hi there, just a note to remind everyone that this is a cool puzzle in and of itself. No matter where you come from, or how you feel about things in the world today, Joel Fagliano\u2019s crossword theme is a really funny play on words, which is what we come here to enjoy.\n\nAnd that\u2019s exactly how I\u2019m going to talk about it. I hope you will, too.\n\nToday\u2019s Theme\n\nMr. Fagliano cuts one column off his puzzle today in order to show off his \u201cSupreme Intelligence.\u201d By doing so, he is able to stretch his revealer, OBSTRUCTION OF JUSTICE across the grid.\n\nThat\u2019s funny because Mr. Fagliano has also managed to pack six former and current Supreme Court justices in his puzzle, but their names are obstructed by black squares. That had to be incredibly hard to do and still fill the puzzle well.\n\nFor example, we have ANTONIN SCALIA stretching across 1-, 8- and 11-Across, and ABE FORTAS, EARL WARREN, ELENA KAGAN, SONIA SOTOMAYOR and STEPHEN BREYER appear as well. I\u2019m sad that Mr. Fagliano was not able to fit my own favorite Supreme, Ruth Bader Ginsburg, in the puzzle, but that would have been tough.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nTricky Clues\n\n18A: O.K., so we know that \u201cWorked on some screenwriting?\u201d doesn\u2019t have anything to do with writing for film because of that question mark at the end of the clue. What other kind of screens do you \u201cwrite\u201d on? How about that computer in front of you? The answer is EMAILED.", "title": "Supreme Intelligence", "authors": ["Deb Amlen"]} {"date": "2018-01-27 00:00:00", "text": "It turns out that all nine of the theme entries are the names of films, and the clues mostly describe the plot of each movie until \u2026 PLOT TWIST! A change in the last letter of the movie title leads to a change in the description of the movie and, of course, hilarity ensues.\n\nReady for an example? Let\u2019s start at the top. At 23A, the clue is \u201cPimp launches career in rap \u2026 BUT HAS AN EPIC FAIL!\u201d The first part of the clue (before the ellipsis) sounds a lot like the 2005 film, \u201cHUSTLE AND FLOW,\u201d whence the song \u201cHard Out Here for a Pimp\u201d came. Ms. Clark and Mr. Chen change that last W in the title to a P, making it HUSTLE AND FLOP, which is the \u201cEPIC FAIL!\u201d they mention in the clue.\n\nThe really neat part is the circled/shaded squares. Starting at the top and read down, they spell out the phrase PLOT TWIST.\n\nNow that you have the revealer and know that the theme entries are film titles, you should be able to work this theme out for yourself.\n\nSo: All film titles, the change is all in the last letters, they\u2019re all high quality puns clued brilliantly, and the circled/shaded letters spell out the very thing they are doing. That\u2019s what constructors and editors mean by a tight theme. And this one is done extraordinarily well.\n\nTricky Clues\n\n18A: TIL about AVOCETS, which are wading birds, and definitely not the main ingredient in guacamole.\n\n26A: Watch the spelling in clues! \u201cApple buy-product?\u201d is not the same as \u201cApple byproduct.\u201d A \u201cbuy-product\u201d would be something you buy, and today that an IPAD.\n\n36A: An ice shelf is a floating sheet of ice permanently attached to a landmass, and ice BERGs are what happen when pieces of the shelf break off, or are \u201ccalved.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n102A: An Interesting Historical Sidenote: The GORDIAN knot has been seen in clues in The New York Times Crossword lately, but the word GORDIAN has not been in the puzzle since 1944. What knots in ties are more popular today, I wonder?\n\n13D: Let\u2019s unpack this one. \u201cBussing\u201d is not the same as \u201cbusing,\u201d which means transporting people by bus. \u201cBussing\u201d means kissing. And if you do it on a bus, you are allegedly engaging in a public display of affection, or a P.D.A. for short.\n\n15D: Wordplay alert! A \u201cHigh mark in Spanish class?\u201d sounds on first read like it might be an \u201cA\u201d or a \u201cB,\u201d but the answer is TILDE, because the \u201c~\u201d is a mark written above the letters in a Spanish class.\n\nConstructor Notes\n\nPriscilla Clark: This is my second puzzle in The New York Times \u2014 both collaborations with Jeff Chen. My first one was a bucket list goal, which took almost ten years to achieve. I honestly thought I was done after that, but I found I missed the daily mental wrangling with themes and words, so I started sending theme ideas to Jeff. There were some very polite \u201cI\u2019m not sure \u2026\u201ds, but sometimes I got a \u201cVery funny \u2014 are there others like this?\u201d In spite of our best efforts, there often weren\u2019t more \u201clike this,\u201d but the search resulted in new possibilities. I have found that what appeals to me as a constructor is humor. I want to laugh when I\u2019m making a puzzle and hope solvers do also. It\u2019s what keeps me engaged. I so enjoy working with Jeff and learning from him, and the pleasure that comes from sharing creative energy is a wonderful added benefit. Jeff Chen: I love it when a collaborator is more than willing to put in the work. There are so many pretty good movie titles on our shared spreadsheet, but Pris was never happy until we found one that made us both laugh out loud. Took a long time to hit on LICENCE TO KILT, but man, do I love that one. Tough grid to put together. I wanted the circled P L O T T W I S T letters (hopefully you noticed that hidden phrase?) to look like they were twisting, like a DNA helix. Crossword symmetry didn\u2019t make that perfectly possible, but I hope this layout came close.\n\nYour thoughts?", "title": "Surprise Endings", "authors": ["Deb Amlen"]} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "The N.S.A. began collecting Americans\u2019 international phone calls and emails without a warrant in October 2001 as part of the Bush administration\u2019s post-Sept. 11 Stellarwind program. In 2008, after the program had come to light, Congress legalized a form of it by enacting Section 702 of the FISA law. That law enabled the program to expand to Silicon Valley firms, not just telecoms, and to all foreign intelligence purposes, not just counterterrorism.\n\nIn late 2012, Congress extended the law for five years without changes. But the pending expiration of Section 702 is forcing lawmakers to address its substance for the first time since the 2013 leaks about N.S.A. programs by Edward J. Snowden set off a major debate about 21st-century surveillance technology and privacy rights.\n\nOn Thursday, the House will vote on an Intelligence Committee bill that would extend the 702 program for six years with only minor changes. But House leaders are permitting lawmakers first to vote on a single proposed amendment that would make major changes.\n\nChief among them, the amendment would ban the practice whereby officials at the N.S.A., the F.B.I. and other security agencies, without a warrant, search for and read private messages of Americans that the government incidentally swept up under the 702 program. Instead, except in emergencies, officials would need to obtain a court order to query the repository for an American\u2019s information.\n\nThe amendment is chiefly sponsored by Representative Justin Amash, Republican of Michigan, and Representative Zoe Lofgren, Democrat of California. It would substitute in the text of another bill, dubbed the USA Rights Act, which would extend Section 702 by only four years.\n\nThe bipartisan coalition backing overhaul efforts \u2014 which includes some of the most conservative and most liberal members of the House \u2014 say that change is necessary to uphold the meaning and substance of Fourth Amendment privacy rights in light of 21st-century communications technology and surveillance powers.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nBut the F.B.I. and the intelligence community have balked at that proposal, saying it would impede their efforts to protect the country to require warrants to query information the government already possesses. There are also lawmakers of both parties \u2014 backed by House leadership \u2014 who oppose the amendment.\n\nAides to Representative Devin Nunes, the California Republican who chairs the House Intelligence Committee, distributed a one-page sheet this week denouncing the amendment as imposing \u201cunnecessarily severe requirements\u201d that would endanger Americans.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nComplicating matters, the base bill backed by Mr. Nunes contains a gesture toward a court-order requirement, too. It would apply only under narrow circumstances: if F.B.I. agents have already opened a criminal investigation into the American whose information they are searching for, and if the agents have no national-security rationale.\n\nRepresentative Adam Schiff of California, the ranking Democrat on the Intelligence Committee, said the warrant requirement in the base bill would be sufficient to \u201cprevent the database from being used as a general tool to gather evidence and introduce it in court in cases that have nothing to do with terrorism.\u201d\n\nBut the base bill would still permit routine queries for Americans\u2019 information without warrants. Its warrant requirement would not apply to national-security-related queries by a range of agencies, including the C.I.A., the N.S.A. and the F.B.I. Nor would it apply to F.B.I. queries when agents are merely pursuing tips about an American but do not yet have enough evidence of wrongdoing to open a criminal investigation.\n\nIn short, the base bill would give greater privacy protections to criminal suspects than to people the F.B.I. has no solid basis for thinking had committed any wrongdoing.\n\nSenator Ron Wyden, an Oregon Democrat, dismissed the base bill\u2019s limited warrant provision on Wednesday as \u201cfake reform\u201d that was really just \u201cbusiness as usual.\u201d\n\nAdding to the uncertainty, in 2014 and 2015, the House approved amendments to appropriations bills that would have required warrants to search the 702 repository for Americans\u2019 information, but they were rejected in negotiations with the Senate. When the idea came up again in 2016, shortly after the terrorist attack on a nightclub in Orlando, Fla., the House voted it down.\n\nAnother significant difference between the base bill and the amendment centers on the N.S.A.\u2019s old practice of scanning Americans\u2019 international emails and other internet messages and collecting those that mention a foreign target \u2014 but are neither to nor from that target. The technique came to light amid the Snowden leaks and ended last year.\n\nSuch collection is technically complex, and the N.S.A. shut it down after repeatedly running into trouble adhering to limits imposed by the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court. But the agency wants to retain the flexibility to turn it back on. The base bill would permit it to do so after briefing the congressional intelligence committees. The amendment would ban the practice.", "title": "Surveillance and Privacy Debate Reaches Pivotal Moment in Congress", "authors": ["Charlie Savage"]} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "I admit that I partake in ratings culture. When I booked that cottage online, I sifted through the reviews, trying to glean whether the location was as pristine as the pictures suggested. I didn\u2019t spend much time wondering how those depictions made the host feel \u2014 I just wanted to make sure the place wasn\u2019t a dump. I understand that hosts want reassurances, too. No one wants to rent to a person who used the last rental as a temporary brothel or drug den.\n\nBut if you think you belong on the good side of the bell curve, it hurts to hear someone tell you that perhaps you do not. When such a critique comes at the end of a long and intimate experience like a stay in an Airbnb house, you can\u2019t help but wonder if it\u2019s true. Maybe I am an incompetent housekeeper.\n\nStay in someone\u2019s home long enough and you feel like you know the person, even if you have never meet. For two weeks, I admired my host\u2019s book collection (she liked Mary Oliver, my husband\u2019s favorite poet) and looked at her artwork. I glanced at the muck boots in the garage, and imagined a quiet woman pruning those gorgeous hydrangeas in the garden. I spotted a box of art supplies in the closet, and wondered how long she had spent painting that seascape in the bedroom.\n\nIn text messages, I told her that we enjoyed the house and let her know when I noticed ants by the front door. Her replies were curt, but she gave me directions for how to address the issue, so I didn\u2019t hold it against her. I assumed she saw me as I saw myself: a considerate and attentive houseguest.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Real Estate Newsletter Every week, get updates on residential real estate news, covering the five boroughs and beyond. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nInstead, she saw me as a naughty one.\n\n\u201cOf course you take it personally,\u201d said Paul Levinson, a professor of communications and media studies at Fordham University and the author of \u201cNew New Media.\u201d\n\nAs I sat at my computer, absorbing the criticism, my mind drifted to the review I had left of the house. Since the process is double-blind, guests and hosts can only see each other\u2019s reviews after both have written them. You cannot revise what you wrote in light of new information from the other side, and no wonder. Like in the aftermath of a heated argument, I replayed the words I had written, imagining what I would have said if I had let loose \u2014 I\u2019m talking about that ant trail and the scant cleaning supplies (hello! a bottle of Lysol certainly would have helped get the job done).\n\nSince I couldn\u2019t rewrite my own assessment, I instead fired off a response to hers, in defense of my efforts. I hit send and my response appeared publicly below the one she had left of me. It didn\u2019t take long for the doubt to creep in: Maybe, by responding, I looked not only messy, but crazy, too. Mr. Levinson seemed to agree: \u201cThe best response is no response,\u201d he said. \u201cYou wind up looking defensive no matter what you say.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAirbnb, however, sees such an exchange in a different light. \u201cThat\u2019s how the system should work,\u201d said Nick Shapiro, the global head of trust and risk management at Airbnb. \u201cWhat\u2019s the alternative?\u201d\n\nHere\u2019s one alternative: Not having my cleaning skills publicly parsed. Other Airbnb guests have also felt burned by a harsh critique. Alrica Goldstein, 42, a book editor in Reno, Nev., was shocked by a bad review she received after staying in an apartment in Kuala Lumpur with her family in August 2016. \u201cI was terribly offended,\u201d she said.\n\nThe apartment was left in a sorry state, with a dirty stove and toilet, according to the host. But Ms. Goldstein had not seen the criticism coming. The host had stopped by on checkout day and stayed to chat for a while, never voicing any concerns. \u201cI feel like when you stay in an Airbnb, it\u2019s a community. There\u2019s a give and take and trust,\u201d she said. In this case, Ms. Goldstein felt the circle of trust had been broken.\n\nHow much does a bad review harm you? It\u2019s hard to say. But I suspect that naysayers have a way of sounding like soothsayers. \u201cI see just one negative review, and it makes me wonder,\u201d said Turner Wright, the digital media manager for AirbnbHell.com, a website that chronicles Airbnb miseries. \u201cMaybe that\u2019s the real one.\u201d\n\nMaybe Mr. Wright was right. Maybe I would be shunned. When it came time to book another stay a few months later, this time in Northampton, Mass., I admit, my heart was racing. \u201cWhat if they reject us?\u201d my son asked. To improve our chances, I wrote a witty note, one that would paint a picture of a responsible and charming little family. Maybe the owner would fall for it. The host \u2014 a superhost, in Airbnb speak, or someone considered experienced and a role model for other hosts \u2014 accepted my request within minutes. I had dodged a blacklist!\n\nThese reviews are meant to make us better versions of ourselves \u2014 next time that stove will sparkle \u2014 but maybe they just make us more neurotic.\n\nWhen we arrived in Northampton after a long drive, tired and disheveled, our host let us into the apartment. \u201cDon\u2019t worry about cleaning up when you leave,\u201d she said. \u201cWe\u2019ll take care of it.\u201d\n\nI wanted to believe that she said this to be helpful, but I couldn\u2019t help but wonder if she really said it because she knew I was a slob.", "title": "Surviving a Bad Airbnb Review", "authors": ["Ronda Kaysen", "Right At Home"]} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nLONDON \u2014 A British man accused of killing a worshiper and injuring several others when he rammed a van into a congregation of Muslims leaving a London mosque last year had been in contact with far-right groups before the attack, prosecutors said at his trial on Tuesday.\n\nThe BBC reported that the man, Darren Osborne, 48, had received a Twitter message from Jayda Fransen, the deputy leader of Britain First, a group that recently gained notoriety after President Trump recirculated unverified anti-Muslim videos it had posted online. Ms. Fransen was arrested in December on charges related to hate crimes.\n\nMr. Osborne, whom his former partner described as a \u201cloner,\u201d had also received an email from an account linked to the English Defence League, an extremist group that opposes what it claims to be the spread of Islam and Shariah law in Britain.\n\nOfficials say that Mr. Osborne plowed into a group of worshipers leaving the Finsbury Park Mosque in North London on June 19 during Ramadan, the holiest month in the Muslim calendar. One man was killed and at least 10 people were injured.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIt was among a spate of terrorist attacks that shook Britain. A month earlier, a homemade bomb had exploded at an Ariana Grande concert at the Manchester Arena, killing 22 people, many of them children, and injuring more than 500 others. The man identified as the bomber, Salman Abedi, had links to the Islamic State. And in June, attacks on London Bridge and at Borough Market, also inspired by the Islamic State, killed eight people.", "title": "Suspect in London Mosque Attack Had Contact With Far-Right Groups", "authors": ["Kimiko De Freytas-Tamura"]} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "KUTUBDIA, Bangladesh \u2014 Anyone who doubts climate change should come to this lovely low-lying island, lapped by gentle waves and home to about 100,000 people.\n\nBut come quickly, while it\u2019s still here.\n\n\u201cMy house was over there,\u201d said Zainal Abedin, a farmer, pointing to the waves about 100 feet from the shore. \u201cAt low tide, we can still see signs of our house.\u201d\n\nAlready much of Kutubdia has been swallowed by rising seas, leaving countless families with nothing. Nurul Haque, a farmer who lost all his land to the ocean, told me that he may have to pull his daughter, Munni Akter, 13, out of eighth grade and marry her off to an older man looking for a second or third wife, because he has few financial options left to support her.", "title": "Opinion | Swallowed by the Sea", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "If you keep swatting at a mosquito, will it leave you alone?\n\nSome scientists think so. But it depends.\n\nSome blood meals are worth a mosquito risking its life. But if there\u2019s a more attractive or accepting alternative to feed from, a mosquito may move on to that someone or something instead. That\u2019s because if you keep trying and missing, the mosquito may learn to associate your swatting vibrations with your scent, a study published Thursday in Current Biology suggests. And it just may remember: This is not a person who will tolerate me.\n\nMosquitoes, which transmit diseases like Zika, Malaria and West Nile, do not just bite anything, said Jeffrey Riffell, a neuroecologist at The University of Washington who led the study. They prefer people over other animals, and some people over others. Attraction depends on how a person looks, smells or acts. But when a feeding situation isn\u2019t favorable, a mosquito can switch preferences.\n\nTo find out more about mosquito biting preferences, Dr. Riffell and his colleagues put mosquitoes and different odors into a vortex that creates vibrations similar to those created when a hand swats a forearm, but misses. In just 15 minutes, the mosquitoes learned to associate the odors with the vibrations. Some once attractive odors became threatening signals that the mosquitoes learned to avoid. Rather than approach them again, the mosquitoes chose to approach a new odor instead. For at least 24 hours, they retained this memory.\n\n[READ: Mosquitoes Really Do Prefer Some People Over Others]\n\nRemembering the smell of a particularly defensive individual with a propensity to swat is important for a bug\u2019s survival. One good smack to a mosquito stuck biting, and splat. Knowing who smells like a splat-maker means mosquitoes can seek out potentially less risky hosts instead. Dr. Riffell thinks learning about odors helps drives these decisions.\n\nPhoto\n\nMosquito senses are tuned for locating perfect hosts. From far away, carbon dioxide from our breath draws them in and triggers their visual system to seek out high contrast objects for inspection. Up close, mosquitoes detect odor, temperature, sweat and even the presence of alcohol or pregnancy (pregnant women emit more carbon dioxide). If signs of a good host don\u2019t check out, the mosquito doesn\u2019t bite.\n\nBut just how the insect processes the more than 200 chemicals in a person\u2019s scent signature isn\u2019t fully understood. One thing that helps, the researchers determined, is dopamine, a chemical in the brain that contributes to learning in humans, honeybees and other animals. Dr. Riffell thinks dopamine works by helping mosquitoes pick out an individual\u2019s scent signature from other odors.\n\nPhoto\n\nDopamine travels through the brain and binds to receptors like a key in a lock, opening doors and creating connections between nerve cells that can drive behavior or thinking. When the researchers edited mosquito genes to remove these dopamine receptors, the insects lost their ability to learn. They also lost activity in the area of their brain associated with olfaction.\n\n[READ: How to Deal With All the Bites and Stings of Summer]\n\nUnderstanding more about how mosquitoes process information and select hosts can help people develop more targeted ways to control disease transmission, like combining traps or lures with bed nets and insecticides. Another possibility once more is known, said Dr. Riffell, would be to target dopamine and impair learning in mosquitoes with insecticides or genetic tools. While a dopamine-impaired mosquito may not recognize your scent, it also may not realize swatting is avoidable.\n\nUntil then, Dr. Riffell says: \u201cIf there are mosquitoes around and you\u2019re shooing them away (and you\u2019re mean) you could encourage your friend to talk a lot and move around and sweat, and they\u2019ll probably avoid you and go to your friend.\u201d", "title": "Swatting at Mosquitoes May Help You Avoid Bites, Even if You Miss", "authors": ["Joanna Klein"]} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "BEIJING \u2014 China on Tuesday publicly rebuffed demands by Sweden for information on the fate of a Swedish citizen who was snatched off a train in China by plainclothes officers despite being under the protection of Swedish diplomats.\n\nThe Chinese Foreign Ministry insisted that it had no knowledge of what had happened to the seized man, Gui Minhai. Instead, it issued a warning to all diplomats not to break Chinese law, without making any specific accusations against Sweden.\n\n\u201cThis is not a matter that falls under the purview of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs,\u201d a spokeswoman for the ministry, Hua Chunying, told reporters at a regular news briefing in Beijing when asked about Mr. Gui\u2019s seizure from the train. \u201cI don\u2019t understand this specific matter.\u201d\n\nSweden\u2019s Foreign Ministry, which has twice summoned the Chinese ambassador for meetings, said on Tuesday: \u201cGui Minhai was seized while in the company of diplomatic personnel who were providing a consular service to a Swedish citizen in need of medical attention. It was entirely in accordance with fundamental international rules that entitle us to give our citizens consular support.\u201d", "title": "Sweden Wants Answers About Its Seized Citizen. China Isn\u2019t Giving Any.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "As a candidate, Donald Trump warned against foreign wars, not least in Syria. A year into his presidency, he is adding Syria to a list of open-ended conflicts that already includes Afghanistan and Iraq.\n\nWe know President Trump\u2019s plan not because he asked Congress for authorization and funding for a continuing troop presence in Syria. We know because Secretary of State Rex Tillerson explained it in a speech on Wednesday at the Hoover Institution at Stanford University. \u201cThe United States will maintain a military presence in Syria focused on ensuring ISIS cannot re-emerge,\u201d he said. \u201cOur military mission in Syria will remain conditions-based.\u201d In other words, without any end date or public benchmarks for success.\n\nAs of last month, there were about 2,000 American troops in Syria \u2014 up from 500 a year ago \u2014 a mix of engineering units and Special Operations units that fight and train with local militias in the battle against the Islamic State. Now that we know they will be there indefinitely, who can say the number won\u2019t go higher and the mission won\u2019t creep more?\n\nSyria is a complex problem. But this plan seems poorly conceived, too dependent on military action and fueled by wishful thinking.", "title": "Opinion | Syria Is Now Mr. Trump\u2019s War", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-20 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nAcross Syria, buildings lie in ruin. Millions have fled their homes. And historic sites have been shattered, either by military bombardment or at the hands of the Islamic State.\n\nBut Syrian authorities were hoping that foreign visitors would look past that devastation, as they promoted the country at an international tourism fair in Spain on Saturday.\n\nWhile government officials say the country is experiencing a modicum of stability \u2014 the government has regained control of much of the territory lost in recent years to rebels \u2014 the push for tourism risks drawing criticism for ignoring the fallout of the yearslong war that has razed much of Syria.\n\nBefore the country\u2019s conflict began in 2011, Syria was home to an array of tourist landmarks, from Aleppo\u2019s citadel to the Roman-era ruins of Palmyra, and the travel sector was a major part of its economy. Many of those sites, however, have been badly damaged or destroyed entirely by the ongoing war. The widespread insecurity throughout the conflict has meant most governments advise their citizens against travel to Syria.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe country is hoping to change that. Officials from the tourism ministry attended the Fitur International Tourism Trade Fair in Madrid on Saturday in the hopes of attracting visitors back to the country.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. In his answers, Mr. Sulzberger spoke about his job, media bias and diversity.\n\nBack Story\n\nPhoto\n\nHere\u2019s a tale of innovation and why it\u2019s hard to stand in the way of progress.\n\nEighty-three years ago, the first-known canned beer was sold in the U.S., in Richmond, Va. The innovation soon spread to a brewer in Wales.\n\nThe cans were lighter and cheaper than bottles, and immediately proved a huge success.\n\n\u201cSales resistance to beer in cans has been overcome in every section of the country,\u201d The Times reported a few months later in 1935. \u201cThe product is selling more rapidly than it can be supplied.\u201d\n\nWithin two months, the American Can Co. was producing 25,000 to 30,000 beer cans every day.\n\nBy September, U.S. winemakers sought to package their product in cans, too, to \u201cinduce the American consumer to \u2018become wine-minded,\u2019 \u201d The Times reported.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBottle makers pushed back against the new competition.\n\nAt a conference in Atlantic City, they spoke of plans for lighter bottles, as well as ones that wouldn\u2019t require a deposit.\n\nRegardless of what it was packaged in, beer was popular in post-Prohibition America. Sales of bottled and canned beer grew more than 50 percent in the first half of 1936 over the previous year, The Times reported.\n\nBy 1970, beer cans had overtaken bottles.\n\n_____\n\nThis briefing was prepared for the European morning and is updated online. Booker and Oona A. Hathaway\u2019s article advising that \u201cCongress must tell the president he cannot engage our troops in an illegal war in Syria\u201d is misdirected.\n\nIf we know nothing else, we know that the Republican congressional leadership will not challenge this president on this or any other outrage, as he has the power to end their political careers.\n\nThere are exactly two remaining forces standing between President Trump and the complete wreckage of world order: the courts and the American electorate.\n\nAs the courts are relatively insulated from political pressure, Senator Booker and Ms. Hathaway\u2019s alarm needs to be aimed directly at those Americans who still value democracy and the rule of law.", "title": "Opinion | Syria, North Korea and the Inaction by Congress", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "With 1,500 delegates and few opponents of the Syrian government among them, \u201cit\u2019s obvious they\u2019re not intending to have serious discussions,\u201d said Hisham Marwa, an adviser to an opposition negotiating committee that refused to attend. \u201cThe Russians are trying to control us, if not directly, they will try to find a way.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nRussia\u2019s real goal, analysts said, was to replace the United States as the most engaged global power, while reshaping the diplomatic process to fit the military and political reality: President Bashar al-Assad\u2019s opponents have failed to unseat him.\n\nMr. Assad\u2019s government, with critical help from Russia and Iran, is reasserting control with a grinding military campaign. And it is resisting even the small political compromises that Russia says it is trying to wrest from Mr. Assad.\n\nNo one expected Sochi to produce a peace agreement. Instead, Sochi was supposed to broaden the range of Syrian voices in the talks, and it did draw in some civilian, nonviolent dissidents and officially tolerated opposition groups based in Damascus.\n\nPerhaps the most consequential negotiation in Sochi was between the United Nations and Russia. The United Nations agreed that its Syria envoy, Staffan de Mistura, would attend, lending Sochi gravitas, if Russia would stop trying to make Sochi, not Geneva, the site of discussions for rewriting Syria\u2019s Constitution.\n\nOn Tuesday, the issue was finessed, with the Sochi delegates proposing a list of committee members that can be approved only in Geneva. But if that agreement refocuses the Geneva talks on rewriting the Constitution instead of replacing the government, Russia will have scored another point for Mr. Assad.\n\nThe way Sochi played out also showed how far-off a real, productive debate between Syria\u2019s combatants remains.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nDelegates sent from Damascus were approved by the security services, participants said, and most were loyalists, from unions and other groups controlled by the ruling Baath Party. Even tolerated, Damascus-based dissidents \u2014 allowed to go as a counterbalance against the armed opposition \u2014 were given strict orders by Syrian officials on how to act at the talks.\n\nPhoto\n\nTwo days before the conference, hundreds of delegates \u2014 loyalist and Damascus-based opposition alike \u2014 filed into the Damascus Opera House, where a senior security official and Syria\u2019s foreign minister, Walid al-Moallem, gave them instructions. One participant said the officials spoke like teachers to students, giving lessons on Syrian patriotism. And they did not entirely toe Russia\u2019s line.\n\nThe Syrian officials, according to participants, gave the delegates red lines: no discussion of writing a new constitution, only modifying the one adopted in 2012. (The United Nations, Russia and others have all called for a new constitution.) No discussion of the country\u2019s army or security services. (United Nations principles call for reforms to make them abide by human rights and rule of law.) And above all, no discussion of changing the president.\n\nThe pan-Arab newspaper Al Sharq al-Awsat reported one additional detail: They were also told not to shake hands with opposition figures arriving from abroad.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nFootage from a plane headed from Damascus to Sochi \u2014 on the carrier Cham Wings, owned by Mr. Assad\u2019s cousin \u2014 showed rows of delegates joining in to sing a patriotic song.\n\nAfter long deliberations, a few Turkey-based opposition members decided to fly in. But upon arrival, they were confronted with banners emblazoned with the conference logo that featured only the current Syrian flag and not the older Syrian one they have adopted as a symbol of revolution.\n\nThey refused to exit the airport.\n\nThe delegation, including Lt. Col. Ahmad Saud, an army defector and rebel commander once backed by the United States, ended up stranded in the arrivals area.\n\nIn Syria, military tensions flared between Iran and Turkey, two of the Sochi talks\u2019 sponsors. Iranian-backed militias were said to have shelled a Turkish convoy that was operating inside Syria with Russian permission.\n\nPhoto\n\nAirstrikes by the Syrian government and Russia continued.\n\n\u201cSochi\u2019s white doves\u201d was what Moaz al-Shami called the warplanes flying over his town, Saraqeb, where a market and hospital were hit Monday.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cRussia is telling us, accept Bashar,\u201d he said, in a video of the destruction. \u201cAccept Sochi or you\u2019ll be destroyed.\u201d\n\nOne of the delegates to the Sochi conference was Mihrac Ural, a Syrian militia leader accused of inciting pro-government forces who killed scores of civilians, including children, in a raid on the Syrian coastal towns of Baniyas and Bayda in 2013.\n\nPhotographed with him was Qadri Jamil, a prominent delegate and member of a tolerated opposition party who once served in Mr. Assad\u2019s cabinet.\n\nIn perhaps the conference\u2019s sole moment of spontaneous public debate, Mr. Lavrov, Russia\u2019s foreign minister, was interrupted as he claimed in a speech that \u201cSyria, with Russian air support, managed to destroy the terrorist forces.\u201d\n\n\u201cStop your aircraft from bombing the Syrian people!\u201d a man shouted. Security guards appeared to speak to him sternly, as others cheered for Russia.\n\n\u201cIn Russia,\u201d Mr. Lavrov replied, \u201cit\u2019s polite to say please first.\u201d", "title": "Syrian Peace Talks in Russia: 1,500 Delegates, Mostly Pro-Assad", "authors": ["Anne Barnard"]} {"date": "2018-01-20 00:00:00", "text": "A major Republican donor, Mr. Pickens supported Swift Boat Veterans for Truth, which leveled false allegations against John Kerry during the 2004 presidential campaign. Along the way, he had five wives, became a major philanthropist and saw the football stadium at Oklahoma State University, his alma mater, named for him after a donation of hundreds of millions of dollars to the school.\n\nEven in his later years, he never stopped looking for another big score. He bought nearly 400,000 acres of water rights in the Texas Panhandle, hoping to sell that water to Dallas and Fort Worth. And last year he began drilling on his own ranch.\n\nYet Mr. Pickens\u2019s most lasting impact on business has nothing to do with oil. As a corporate raider in the 1980s, Mr. Pickens \u2014 along with men like Carl C. Icahn and Michael Milken \u2014 helped develop a shrewd new playbook for making money. He would take a small stake in a public company, call on it to slash expenses and return money to investors, and often pressure the company to sell itself. He was Gordon Gekko before \u201cWall Street,\u201d and his influence was profound.\n\nThat philosophy now shapes the investment decisions of big institutional investors and shareholder activists alike. Depending on whom you ask, it is responsible for the creation of a huge amount of wealth for a great many people, or for a reckless short-term perspective that is widening income inequality and destroying jobs. In either case, it happened, at least in part, because of T. Boone Pickens.\n\n\u201cToday you\u2019re seeing in corporate America a lot of the things that he espoused 30 years ago,\u201d said David Bradshaw, an investment banker at Moelis and Company who is close to Mr. Pickens. \u201cHe was ahead of his time.\u201d\n\nSmart and Shrewd\n\nMr. Pickens was born in Oklahoma\u2019s oil patch in 1928. His father was a landman, buying leases from farmers and selling them to oil companies, and his mother oversaw gasoline rationing for several counties during World War II.\n\nWhen Mr. Pickens was a teenager, the family moved to Amarillo, where his father began working for Phillips Petroleum. In 1951, Mr. Pickens earned a degree in geology from what is now Oklahoma State University, and went to work for Phillips.", "title": "T. Boone Pickens, a Texas-Size Businessman, Calls It Quits", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-02 00:00:00", "text": "The golden age of television programming is heading for a grisly finale. Netflix, Amazon, Apple and Hulu are on course to increase their spending on new shows and movies at a faster clip than the growth of the overall video-streaming market. Consolidation among traditional media groups is only adding to the frenzy. Something will have to give.\n\nNetflix set off the arms race. In 2017, the company, founded by Reed Hastings, directed $6 billion toward licensing and original series like \u201cStranger Things.\u201d In 2018, executives plan to earmark up to $8 billion for content, a 33 percent increase. Across the industry, the number of original television shows more than doubled from 2010 to 2016, to 455, according to the research firm MoffettNathanson.\n\nTotal spending on content by the big four media upstarts in 2018 will mushroom some 30 percent, year over year, to $18 billion, according to a Breakingviews forecast based on analysts\u2019 estimates. Yet the entire global video-streaming market is expected to increase 16 percent to about $21 billion, according to PwC.\n\nThat means there has never been a better time to be a couch potato, but it\u2019s glum news for the companies. The tangle of options in streaming services and programming, chasing a finite number of subscribers, suggests the industry is entering an unsustainable investment battle \u2014 and a price war may follow as players try to rake in extra market share.", "title": "TV Content Wars: Too Many Characters Chasing Not Enough Action", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-31 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cIn the early days of online media, the choice was essentially made \u2014 give it away for free, and advertising would produce the revenue,\u201d said Randall Rothenberg, the chief executive of the Interactive Advertising Bureau, a trade association that represents companies in the digital ad business. \u201cA lot of the things we see now flow out from that decision.\u201d\n\nMr. Rothenberg\u2019s organization has long pushed for stronger standards for online advertising. In a speech last year, he implored the industry to \u201ctake civic responsibility for our effect on the world.\u201d But he conceded the business was growing and changing too quickly for many to comprehend its excesses and externalities \u2014 let alone to fix them.\n\n\u201cTechnology has largely been outpacing the ability of individual companies to understand what is actually going on,\u201d he said. \u201cThere\u2019s really an unregulated stock market effect to the whole thing.\u201d\n\nFacebook, which reported its earnings on Wednesday, said its advertising principles hold that ads should \u201cbe safe and civil.\u201d It defended the targeted ad business\u2019s overall value, arguing that digital advertising connects people to products and services from small businesses and \u201ccreates jobs and helps the economy.\u201d\n\nThe company also pointed to several steps it had taken recently. \u201cWe\u2019ve tightened our ad policies, hired more ad reviewers, and created a new team to help detect and prevent abuses,\u201d said Rob Goldman, Facebook\u2019s vice president of advertising. \u201cWe\u2019re also testing a tool that will bring more transparency to ads running on our platform. We know there is more work to do, but our goal is to keep people safe.\u201d\n\nA spokesman for Google, whose parent company, Alphabet, reports earnings on Thursday, said it was constantly policing its ad system, pointing out recent steps it has taken to address problems arising from the ad business, including several changes to YouTube.\n\nThe role of the ad business in much of what\u2019s terrible online was highlighted in a recent report by two think tanks, New America and Harvard\u2019s Shorenstein Center on Media, Politics and Public Policy.", "title": "Tackling the Internet\u2019s Central Villain: The Advertising Business", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-31 00:00:00", "text": "TAIPEI, Taiwan \u2014 Prosecutors in Taiwan have accused a former judge and his son of violating United Nations sanctions on trade with North Korea, the second such case involving citizens of Taiwan so far this year. Both cases also involve Chinese nationals.\n\nThe Taipei District Prosecutors\u2019 Office said in a statement on Monday that Chiang Kuo-hua, previously a High Court judge, and his son, Chiang Heng, chartered a cargo ship through a Chinese middleman, which they used to transport coal to Vietnam from North Korea last summer.\n\nOn Sunday, prosecutors and police officers raided the offices of a company Mr. Chiang founded, as well as the residences of Mr. Chiang and his son and two other men believed to have been involved in the coal shipment. All four men were questioned on Sunday and have been accused of assisting terrorists and forging documents.\n\nProsecutors have accused Mr. Chiang and his son of purchasing four tons of anthracite coal at the North Korean port of Nampo, which they then shipped to the Vietnamese port of Cam Pha. To avoid detection, the crew reportedly switched off the ship\u2019s Automatic Identification System, a tracking device required of ships carrying a certain amount of tonnage.", "title": "Taiwan Citizens Accused of Violating U.N. Sanctions on North Korea", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-02 00:00:00", "text": "TAIPEI, Taiwan \u2014 It is an age-old arrangement, and one that is usually implicit: Parents pay for their children\u2019s educations, and hope that in their old age the children will support them.\n\nBut in a case that made its way to Taiwan\u2019s highest court, a mother who had financed her son\u2019s dental training sued him, asserting that he had broken a written agreement to support her from the proceeds of his dental practice.\n\nOn Tuesday, the Supreme Court sided with his mother.\n\nThe case attracted considerable attention because the mother and son had put down in a written contract \u2014 signed when he was 20 \u2014 what is often left unsaid, particularly in a heavily Confucian-influenced society that emphasizes filial piety. The principle is backed up by law in Taiwan, where adults are legally prohibited from abandoning their parents.\n\nEach side advanced arguments: The mother urged the court to enforce the contract. The son maintained that he had already paid his mother $1 million and should not have to pay her more.", "title": "Taiwan Dentist Must Pay His Mother Nearly $1 Million for \u2018Upbringing\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "In a statement released Tuesday morning about the dispute over the airspace, Taiwan\u2019s presidential office said protecting the safety of all people flying across the strait was \u201ca responsibility that cannot be abandoned.\u201d\n\nThe statement called on Beijing to return to the consensus reached in talks over the airspace in 2015, urging a resolution of the dispute for \u201cregional stability, cross-strait relations and flight safety.\u201d\n\nThe People\u2019s Republic of China claims Taiwan as its territory, but has never administered it since the republic\u2019s founding in Beijing in 1949. Taiwan is governed by the Republic of China government, which fled China to Taiwan in 1949 after losing to Mao Zedong\u2019s communist forces in the Chinese civil war.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nTaiwanese companies began investing and doing business in China in the 1980s, although direct commercial flights between China and Taiwan did not take place until 2008; citizens on either side had to detour through third destinations like Hong Kong, Macau or Okinawa in southern Japan.\n\nThe Lunar New Year is the most important holiday of the year on both sides of the strait, and expatriate workers traditionally return home to spend the time with their families.\n\nThe cancellations of the 176 flights serving Lunar New Year traffic will probably force Taiwanese determined to get home to scramble to book scarce flights on short notice.\n\nDespite waxing and waning diplomatic tensions, China and Taiwan are closely linked economically. Hundreds of thousands of Taiwanese live and work in China. Many of them work at Taiwanese companies with large-scale operations in China, such as Foxconn, an electronics maker, which employs more than a million Chinese.\n\nThe two airlines that canceled the flights will probably suffer significant economic losses. China Eastern said it would cancel 106 round-trip flights for close to 40,000 passengers. Xiamen Air said it would cancel 70 extra flights that had been planned.\n\n\u201cThis move has harmed the shared rights and interests of our company and customers,\u201d China Eastern said. Xiamen Air said the step had \u201cseriously hurt the feelings of people on both sides of the strait.\u201d", "title": "Taiwan Retaliates Against Chinese Airlines, Hampering Lunar New Year Travel", "authors": ["Chris Horton"]} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "Q. How long does Dropbox keep previous versions of Word files around?\n\nA. For those with free basic or Plus accounts, Dropbox keeps a complete version history of each file you have stored and edited online for 30 days. If you pay extra for a Dropbox Business or Dropbox Professional account, you get 120 days of version history for your files. (The company no longer sells an \u201cextended version history\u201d option for Dropbox Plus accounts that kept a year\u2019s worth of editing changes to a file.) With any plan, changes made to a file downloaded for offline editing are not included in the version history records.\n\nWhen you are working on a document and realize you want to go back to an earlier draft, you can time travel by logging into your account on the Dropbox site, clicking the three-dot Menu icon next to the name of the file and selecting Version History. The next screen shows a list of all the variations of a file within the version-history window. Click the file name to preview it or check the date. Click the Restore button when you find the one you want.\n\nIf you use the Dropbox badge \u2014 a pop-up icon that appears on the edge of Microsoft Office files \u2014 you have a shortcut. Click the Dropbox badge icon and select Version History from the menu to jump to the Dropbox website.", "title": "Take a Time Travel Trip With Dropbox and Word Files", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-22 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cI recognized that my time as the acting U.S. attorney would be limited,\u201d Mr. Kim said. \u201cI didn\u2019t know if it was going to be a matter of weeks or months but I knew it was a temporary term. So I gave a lot of thought to what I needed to be doing, what I needed to be focused on.\u201d\n\nMr. Kim had worked closely with Mr. Bharara for about four years, initially as his counsel, then as chief of the office\u2019s criminal division and, in July 2015, becoming his deputy.\n\nHis first major public act was the March 16, 2017, announcement that his office was closing the de Blasio campaign fund-raising inquiry without bringing charges, a decision reached before Mr. Bharara\u2019s firing.\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Kim said at the time that his office had examined several instances in which the mayor and \u201cothers acting on his behalf\u201d solicited donations from people who sought official favors from the city, \u201cafter which the mayor made or directed inquires to relevant city agencies on behalf of those donors.\u201d\n\nMr. de Blasio, responding to Mr. Kim\u2019s statement (and to a separate letter by the Manhattan district attorney\u2019s office, which had also investigated and declined to bring charges), said he, his staff and colleagues had \u201cacted in a manner that was legal and appropriate and ethical throughout.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThat has been confirmed by the results of this investigation,\u201d Mr. de Blasio said.\n\nMr. Kim, in the recent interviews, differed with Mr. de Blasio\u2019s synopsis, saying the office\u2019s conclusion was \u201cvery limited,\u201d based only on whether the provable evidence established guilt beyond a reasonable doubt.\n\n\u201cWe do not ask the question, \u2018Is the conduct ethical or appropriate?\u2019\u201d Mr. Kim said.\n\nHe added, \u201cAs a private citizen, I certainly hope that a decision by a prosecutor not to bring criminal charges is not the standard that we should expect from our leaders.\u201d\n\nMr. Kim departs as his office begins trying a series of corruption defendants, starting on Monday with Joseph Percoco, a former top adviser and close friend to Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo. Mr. Percoco has pleaded not guilty.\n\nThe office is also scheduled to retry Sheldon Silver, the former Democratic speaker of the New York Assembly, and Dean G. Skelos, a former Republic State Senate majority leader. The 2015 convictions of both men, once among the state\u2019s most powerful politicians, were overturned on appeal after the Supreme Court narrowed the legal definition of corruption, thus calling into question the validity of the jury instructions given in the cases.\n\nMr. Kim said it was \u201can easy decision\u201d to decide to retry the two men, noting that the rulings in the appeals \u201cmade clear that the evidence was more than sufficient for a conviction even under the new standard.\u201d\n\n\u201cWe won\u2019t fail to bring a case just because it\u2019s a difficult one,\u201d he said.\n\nThe Silver and Skelos convictions had been the culmination of Mr. Bharara\u2019s campaign to combat official corruption in New York.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAsked whether Albany had taken the necessary steps to begin cleaning up state politics, Mr. Kim said, \u201cThere hasn\u2019t been much noticeable change as far as I can see.\u201d\n\nHe said he remained impatient at the lack of progress. \u201cDid we hope that it would have more of an impact than it appears to have had? The answer is yes.\u201d\n\nMr. Kim, a first-generation American born in Los Angeles to Korean parents, moved around the world as his father, a diplomat, was posted to places like Amman, Jordan; London and Seoul, South Korea. After law school and a clerkship, Mr. Kim worked as a Southern District prosecutor in between stints in private practice.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHe said that he was \u201chopeful and confident\u201d that under his replacement, Geoffrey S. Berman, the Southern District \u201cwill continue to do great work, in the finest traditions of the office.\u201d\n\nPerhaps the highest-profile trial Mr. Kim oversaw was of the Turkish banker, Mehmet Hakan Atilla, who was convicted of helping orchestrate what Mr. Kim has called a \u201cmassive and brazen scheme that blew a billion-dollar hole in the Iran sanctions regime.\u201d\n\nMr. Kim\u2019s office also obtained a guilty plea and cooperation agreement from a co-conspirator, Reza Zarrab, an immensely wealthy gold trader who became the government\u2019s star witness, testifying that Recep Tayyip Erdogan, when he was Turkey\u2019s prime minister in 2013, knew and approved of the sanctions-busting activity.\n\nMr. Kim and his prosecutors found themselves in the unusual position of being the target of harsh attacks from Mr. Erdogan, now Turkey\u2019s president, who denounced the case as a plot against his government and even raised the matter in a phone call with President Trump. Turkish officials claimed the evidence had been fabricated by Gulenists, a movement banned in Turkey as a terrorist organization. Turkey even opened an investigation into Mr. Kim and Mr. Bharara, who had announced the charges in 2016.\n\n\u201cThe attacks from Turkey based on wild conspiracy theories were frankly ludicrous,\u201d Mr. Kim said.\n\nHe said he was glad the case could be presented in a full-blown trial, with Turkish reporters and crowds of spectators in attendance.\n\n\u201cIt was important for this evidence to come out in a public courtroom for everyone to assess,\u201d he said, \u201cto show to the public and others who are beyond our borders who are skeptical of our motivations, of our system, to see it work, including the public in Turkey.\u201d\n\nMr. Kim noted that Mr. Zarrab\u2019s guilty plea was critical because it validated the government\u2019s case and showed a key conspirator \u201caccepting responsibility for his crimes.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cHe pleaded guilty because he was guilty,\u201d Mr. Kim added. \u201cHe was not able to buy his way out of these charges.\u201d\n\nMr. Kim noted that the prosecutors from his office, which has long been called the \u201cSovereign District\u201d for the way it jealously guards its independence from Washington, were shown to be professionals \u201cwho were not going to be intimidated and who were just doing their jobs.\u201d\n\n\u201cWhat we realized,\u201d Mr. Kim said, \u201cwas that independence meant more than just resisting interference from other parts of the U.S. government, but also having the ability to withstand criticism and attacks from anywhere, including foreign governments.\u201d", "title": "Taking On Terrorists and a Turkish Scandal, Beneath a Fleeting Spotlight", "authors": ["Benjamin Weiser"]} {"date": "2018-01-29 00:00:00", "text": "Play is a universal, cross-cultural and necessary attribute of childhood, essential for development and essential for learning. Experts who study it say that play is intrinsic to children\u2019s natures, but still needs support and attention from the adults around them.\n\nChildren are natural players, right from the beginning. \u201cIt\u2019s hard to imagine when an infant or a toddler isn\u2019t playing,\u201d said Catherine Tamis-LeMonda, a professor of applied psychology at New York University who studies play and learning in babies and young children. She cited, for example, the joys of mushing food, pulling books off a shelf or making noises rattling a paper bag.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t like it when scientists think children are playing only when they sit down with some toys,\u201d she said. \u201cAlmost all the learning that goes on in the first years of life is in the context of exploration of the environment.\u201d\n\nDr. Tamis-LeMonda\u2019s research includes going into homes to look at everyday play, with a special focus on how play functions in language learning. \u201cWe think that all domains of development are informed by children engaging in play,\u201d she said. This certainly includes communication, with babies learning words and concepts as they engage with objects in their environment (ball, blue), spatial math concepts when they play with blocks (or pull the books off a shelf), getting motor practice as they climb and crawl and run.", "title": "Taking Playtime Seriously", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-04 00:00:00", "text": "Q. I hear desktop Linux has gotten to look more like Windows, but can you do everything on Linux that you can do on Windows?\n\nA. Linux, the open-source operating system project first developed by Linus Torvalds in 1991, is now used by millions of people on desktop computers, mobile devices and servers; Google\u2019s Android and Chrome OS even have Linux roots. Because the software has been free and open for developers to enhance and improve for years, Linux is now available in many versions (typically called \u201cdistributions\u201d) that vary in complexity and user interface.\n\nIn terms of being able to do everything a Windows desktop can do, a Linux system is certainly capable of most common tasks, like browsing the web, sending and receiving email, creating documents and spreadsheets, streaming music and editing photos. Many Linux distributions include all the basic programs you need, and you can install others from Linux software repositories online, but make a list of everything you need to do on the computer and make sure you have a Linux solution for it.\n\nMost Linux variations are freely available to download from their developers, but if you are new to the system, a more mainstream distribution like Ubuntu, Linux Mint, Elementary OS or Zorin OS might provide the easiest introduction. In most cases, you download the system files from the site, burn them to a DVD (or copy them to a USB external drive) and install the Linux system on the computer as you would a Windows or Mac operating system.", "title": "Taking a Look at Linux", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "Members who want to set their own schedule can create a flight and post it to JetSmarter\u2019s app so that other interested members can buy seats for the route and help reduce the cost of the charter; if all the seats on the plane sell, the member who created the flight flies for free. These crowdsourced trips usually top out at $2,000 a person, a fraction of the $8,000 or more per hour it can cost for a traditional charter. \u201cMy goal is to make private jet flying less elitist,\u201d Mr. Petrossov said.\n\nBlade, which doesn\u2019t require membership, also sells flights, but only from December through mid-March and on one route, between Westchester County Airport (with or without a helicopter transfer from Manhattan) and its own terminal in Miami-Opa Locka Executive Airport. From $1,285 each way, fliers travel on a Bombardier commercial jet retrofitted with 16 seats and receive an array of amenities such as catered meals from Dean & Deluca as well as iPad Pros loaded with first-run movies; they also get accommodations for the weekend at Faena Miami, a luxury beachfront hotel.\n\nThe Miami route made its debut two years ago and has been so popular, said company founder Rob Wiesenthal, that this season, the flights will be offered four days a week, instead of the two days that they previously were.\n\nPaul Cappuccio, who lives in Greenwich, Conn., and is the general counsel for Time Warner, flew to Miami on Blade most weekends last winter and plans to do the same this year. \u201cIt\u2019s such a relaxed way to fly, an elegant experience and so hassle-free,\u201d he said. While not necessarily budget-friendly, Mr. Cappuccio said that Blade hits the sweet spot on price. \u201cIt\u2019s not all that much more than a full-fare first-class ticket, but a small fraction of what it would cost to fly on a chartered private jet,\u201d he said.\n\nBut for travelers who only want their own chartered plane without having to pay an exorbitant price, there are options like JetSuite\u2019s \u201cSuiteDeals.\u201d The company\u2019s primary business is private jet charters for hourly rates of between $4,000 and $7,000 while \u201cSuiteDeals\u201d are sales of flights called empty legs \u2014 routes that jets are scheduled to fly on without any passengers.\n\nMeredith Broder, an adviser with the Villanova, Pa., travel company Avenue Two Travel, said that empty leg flights have changed the private jet game. \u201cRather than have the plane fly empty, air companies or private jet brokers try to sell that route at a discount,\u201d she said. \u201cThis strategy helps with fuel costs and puts private jet flying within reach to people who wouldn\u2019t normally be able to afford this luxury and convenience.\u201d\n\nMs. Broder frequently books private jets for clients and gets a weekly list from several private jet companies of empty leg availability for the coming week (other agents specializing in private jet travel also get similar lists). Recent flights included an $8,500 trip from Naples to Cleveland on a Beechjet 400A, a plane that seats seven people, and a $6,500 trip from Scottsdale, Ariz., to Colorado Springs on a Learjet 45XR, accommodating eight fliers.", "title": "Taking a Private Jet Could Be More Affordable Than You Think", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-16 00:00:00", "text": "MAZAR-I-SHARIF, Afghanistan \u2014 Taliban insurgents using sophisticated night vision and laser targeting equipment overran Afghan Army positions near the northern city of Kunduz on Tuesday, killing at least eight people and wounding five more, Afghan officials said.\n\nThe officials blamed what they said was a Taliban Red Unit, an insurgent formation that has increasingly featured in attacks on government positions, especially at night. \u201cThe unit is equipped with American weapons and night vision,\u201d said Imamuddin Rahmani, a spokesman for the police in Kunduz. \u201cThe Red Unit carried out several attacks on check posts in Kunduz, captured the check posts and killed several soldiers. The Red Unit is a headache for security forces in Kunduz.\u201d\n\nThe attack on Tuesday was centered on an Afghan National Army post in the village of Gholam Sakhi, about three miles from Kunduz city, said Nangyalay, an Afghan police commander who was stationed in the area. Commander Nangyalay, who like many Afghans uses only one name, said the attack started at 2:30 a.m. and fighting continued for two hours, leaving at least six soldiers and two police officers dead. In addition, the militants briefly occupied the base, destroying a Humvee vehicle and looting mortars and other weapons before fleeing, Commander Nangyalay said.\n\nThe Taliban\u2019s spokesman, Zabihullah Mujahid, said that the group was responsible. He added that the insurgents had used a \u201cspecial forces\u201d unit to carry out the attack, which he claimed had killed 20 soldiers. Such casualty claims are often inflated. Mr. Mujahid said the insurgents did not suffer any casualties, which government officials did not dispute.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe insurgents\u2019 Red Units have been active in several parts of the country. In November, they carried out a series of five attacks in less than two days, killing dozens of Afghan police officers with the aid of night-vision goggles and weapons with infrared sights. Afghan officials have described the weaponry as American-made, suggesting it was either captured, stolen or bought from Afghan forces.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box.
