View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nKunduz has been the scene of heavy fighting for more than two years, with the city twice falling to the insurgents for brief periods. Intervention by American Special Operations troops and heavy United States bombing has repeatedly fended off Taliban advances there.\n\nIn an unrelated event on Tuesday, at least five civilians were killed when mortar shells struck a bazaar area in the Khwaja Sabz Posh district of the province of Faryab, according to Abdullah Masoomi, the governor of the district. He said five or six mortar rounds had struck the bazaar around 11 a.m. Two women and a child were among the dead; an additional 25 people were wounded. Mr. Masoomi blamed the Taliban, and said the shelling was unprovoked, with no fighting reported in the area before the attack.", "title": "Taliban Fighters Using High-Tech Gear Kill Afghan Forces", "authors": ["Najim Rahim", "Rod Nordland"]} {"date": "2018-01-15 00:00:00", "text": "Now my historically sunny son has a pretty dark vision of things. \u201cEvery day something enrages me \u2026 Love Trumps Hate? Like, where?\u201d he asked me the other day. Sam has worked in public health since high school, and so has tried his best to mitigate the inequities and inequalities that have been spreading like poison ivy for most of his life. Mr. Trump\u2019s campaign rhetoric disturbed him; his victory left him disgusted.\n\nAs a mother who prides herself on possessing a skeptical but unshakable patriotism, this has been hard to take. Sure, I can chalk up some of Sam\u2019s cynicism to youthful hyperbole, but at this point \u2014 Mr. Kim coupled with the imminent destruction of the Affordable Care Act, DACA kids\u2019 uncertain futures, tax \u201creform\u201d that will cost us \u2014 I can\u2019t counter without sounding like someone who has lost her marbles. \u201cThis, too, will pass\u201d sounds pretty weak when I\u2019m texting Sam the location of his parents\u2019 wills.\n\nI guess I should be grateful to Mr. Trump. After all, he has forced me to take responsibility for my mortality, but why did this task have to include thoughts of where my small family should meet in the wake of a nuclear catastrophe? Sam is in New York, and we are in Texas. Does it really make sense to designate my in-laws\u2019 cottage on the Potomac our safe space? It would take us a long time to get there on foot from Houston once the gas runs out, and if the cell towers are down \u2014 well, you get the idea.\n\nSadly, this kind of thinking is not new to me. I was a second grader during the Cuban missile crisis and spent much of my childhood terrified that a Russian-launched nuclear attack was imminent. The threat was real, as inescapable in those days as the weather.\n\nDowntown buildings in my hometown, San Antonio, displayed yellow and black circular signs designating directions to air-raid shelters. My elementary-school classes practiced duck-and-cover drills, which did nothing more than compound our dread. We moved into a new house that came equipped with a bomb shelter in the basement. Its walls were reinforced with concrete, and it had an air pump powered by a hand crank. The thick wooden door had a peephole that was about three inches across, clearly built by someone who knew more about keeping out the neighbors than the effects of radiation.", "title": "Opinion | Talking Apocalypse With My Son", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-06 00:00:00", "text": "But now a de facto alliance against shared foes such as Iran, the Muslim Brotherhood, Islamic State militants and the Arab Spring uprisings is drawing the Arab leaders into an ever-closer collaboration with their one-time nemesis, Israel \u2014 producing especially stark juxtapositions between their posturing in public and private.\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s decision broke with a central premise of 50 years of American-sponsored peace talks, defied decades of Arab demands that East Jerusalem be the capital of a Palestinian state, and stoked fears of a violent backlash across the Middle East.\n\nArab governments, mindful of the popular sympathy for the Palestinian cause, rushed to publicly condemn it.\n\nEgyptian state media reported that President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi had personally protested to Mr. Trump. Egyptian religious leaders close to the government refused to meet with Vice President Mike Pence, and Egypt submitted a United Nations Security Council resolution demanding a reversal of Mr. Trump\u2019s decision. (The United States vetoed the resolution, although the General Assembly adopted a similar one, over American objections, days later.)\n\nKing Salman of Saudi Arabia, arguably the most influential Arab state, also publicly denounced Mr. Trump\u2019s decision.\n\nAt the same time, though, the kingdom had already quietly signaled its acquiescence or even tacit approval of the Israeli claim to Jerusalem. Days before Mr. Trump\u2019s announcement, the Saudi crown prince, Mohammed bin Salman, privately urged the Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, to accept a radically curtailed vision of statehood without a capital in East Jerusalem, according to Palestinian, Arab and European officials who have heard Mr. Abbas\u2019s version of events.\n\nPhoto\n\nSaudi Arabia publicly disputed those reports.\n\nThe hosts Captain Kholi called all heeded his advice, and most other voices in the state-owned and pro-government news media across the Arab world were also strikingly muted, even unemotional, about the status of Jerusalem. Such a response would have been all but unthinkable even a decade ago, much less during the period between 1948 and 1973, when Egypt and its Arab allies fought three wars against Israel.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nShibley Telhami, a scholar of the region at the University of Maryland and the Brookings Institution, called the Arab states\u2019 acceptance of the decision \u201ctransformational.\u201d\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t think it would have happened a decade ago, because Arab leaders would have made clear they wouldn\u2019t live with it,\u201d he said. Instead, he said, preoccupied by concerns about their own stability, the Arab leaders signaled that \u2014 while they may not like the decision \u2014 they \u201cwill find a way to work with it,\u201d and \u201cwith a White House that is prepared to break with what had been taboos in American foreign policy.\u201d\n\nTwo spokesmen for the Egyptian government did not respond to requests for comment for this article. Captain Kholi could not be reached.\n\nTelevision talk shows play a formative role in shaping public debate in Egypt, and Egyptian intelligence services often brief the presenters of the programs about messages to convey to the public. The hosts typically prefer to characterize the conversations as journalists talking to sources.\n\nIn addition to the call with Mr. Megahed, three other audio recordings of strikingly similar telephone conversations with the same intelligence agent, Captain Kholi, were all provided to The Times by an intermediary supportive of the Palestinian cause and opposed to President Sisi. The origin of the recordings could not be determined.\n\nMr. Megahed, in an interview, said that he had agreed with Captain Kholi based on his personal assessment of the need to avoid a fresh outbreak of violence, not on the orders of the intelligence service.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cI am friends with Ashraf and we talk all the time,\u201d Mr. Megahed said. \u201cAnother intifada would be bad. I have no problem saying all of the things you have heard in that call in public.\u201d\n\nAs for those who disagreed, he said, \u201cWe should have buses pick up all the people who say they want to go fight for Jerusalem and actually drive them to Jerusalem. Go fight if you are so tough. People are sick of the slogans and all that. I only care about the interests of my country.\u201d\n\nTwo of the calls were with other well-known Egyptian talk show hosts. One of them, Mofid Fawzy, quickly denied taking part in any such conversation and immediately hung up the phone.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe other host, Saeed Hassaseen, who is also a member of Parliament, stopped returning phone messages and backed out of plans for an interview after a journalist contacted Mr. Megahed and Mr. Fawzy about the calls.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe fourth call was with an Egyptian singer and actress known as Yousra, who could not be reached for comment.\n\nThe recordings all appear to match public recordings of their voices, and Captain Kholi\u2019s talking points in each of the calls follow the same lines as his conversation with Mr. Megahed.\n\n\u201cI was just calling to tell you what our public stance is, so if you go on TV or speak in an interview, I am telling you what is the stance of Egypt\u2019s national security apparatus and what it stands to benefit from in this matter of announcing Jerusalem to be the capital of Israel, O.K.?\u201d Captain Kholi began one conversation, with Mr. Hassaseen.\n\n\u201cGive me orders, sir,\u201d Mr. Hassaseen replied, according to the recording. \u201cI am at your command.\u201d\n\n\u201cWe, like all our Arab brothers, are denouncing this matter,\u201d Captain Kholi continued. But, he added, \u201cAfter that, this thing will become a reality. Palestinians can\u2019t resist and we don\u2019t want to go to war. We have enough on our plate as you know.\u201d\n\nThe Egyptian military has struggled for more than four years to try to defeat a simmering militant Islamist insurgence centered in the North Sinai, and Egyptian officials have sometimes accused Hamas, the militant Palestinian group that controls the adjacent Gaza Strip, of abetting violence against the government of Egypt.\n\n\u201cThe point that is dangerous for us is the intifada issue,\u201d Captain Kholi explained. \u201cAn intifada would not serve Egypt\u2019s national security interests because an intifada would revive the Islamists and Hamas. Hamas would be reborn once more.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cAt the end of the day, later on, Jerusalem won\u2019t be much different from Ramallah. What matters is ending the suffering of the Palestinian people,\u201d Captain Kholi concluded. \u201cConcessions are a must and if we reach a concession whereby Jerusalem will be \u2014 Ramallah will be the capital of Palestine, to end the war and so no one else dies, then we would go for it.\u201d\n\nAll three recipients of his calls pledged to convey his messages, and some echoed his arguments in broadcasts. \u201cEnough already. It got old,\u201d Mr. Megahed told his viewers about the issue of Jerusalem.\n\nIn his conversation with Mr. Megahed, however, Captain Kholi added an extra flourish. He charged that Egypt\u2019s regional foe Qatar and its ruler, Emir Tamim bin Hamad al Thani, were the ones guilty of collaborating with Israel.\n\n\u201cYou also will say that Tamim and Qatar have secret ties to Israel. You know all that,\u201d Captain Kholi told the talk show host.\n\n\u201cObvious ties,\u201d Mr. Megahed replied. \u201cMy pleasure. My pleasure. I will include it in the next episode, God willing.\u201d", "title": "Tapes Reveal Egyptian Leaders\u2019 Tacit Acceptance of Jerusalem Move", "authors": ["David D. Kirkpatrick"]} {"date": "2018-01-03 00:00:00", "text": "At night, my wife and I will often watch a streaming show. We just started \u201cWormwood\u201d on Netflix. And then I read actual physical books before going to sleep.\n\nYou study new opportunities for The Times to distribute its journalism. How do you decide which ventures are worth pursuing?\n\nLots of people have referred to this past year as a \u201cmedia apocalypse\u201d because of the harsh realities of digital advertising. But from a different angle, there\u2019s never been a more exciting time to tell important stories and reach more people in more ways. Our mission at The Times is to help people understand the world, so we pursue opportunities where we can further that in new ways.\n\nWe decided to push into virtual reality because we found the immersive power of the medium to be revelatory \u2014 the feeling of being able to inhabit physical spaces was a whole new way to understand the biggest stories of the day.\n\nWe started making a daily visual-first edition of The Times for Snapchat Discover for different reasons; we want to get our work in front of people who may not otherwise read The Times regularly. And we thought that the phone-friendly language of Snapchat \u2014 full-bleed images, graphics mixing with photos mixing with videos \u2014 was a language we should develop as part of our own mobile evolution.\n\nAnd then we made a major push into audio because we saw a giant opportunity to reinvent our journalism in a medium that is quickly rising in importance. We are living in a world where the mobile phone is dominant, and audio, which doesn\u2019t require your eyes or your hands, is the ultimate mobile medium. We launched The Daily in February, and it immediately became our best push toward rebuilding the daily habit of print reading. It\u2019s really working. The Daily was the top downloaded podcast in Apple podcasts in 2017.\n\nPhoto\n\nWe\u2019ve got more to come in 2018, but look for those common threads. We\u2019ll go to places where lots of people are already spending their time and mediums that allow us to help people understand the real world in new ways.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story How Do You Use Tech? Advice and tips on the technology changing how you live. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhat are some of your favorite new publishing strategies that you see The Times or other outlets experimenting with?\n\nI know some people find push alerts to be intrusive, but I\u2019m fascinated by them. I watch N.B.A. highlights right from my phone\u2019s lock screen: The great Bleacher Report app sends out push alerts with embedded videos of the key moments from the games, often in real time. I never even open the app, but it has totally changed how I watch basketball.\n\nI\u2019m also seriously interested in newsletters as a lo-fi way to form a deep relationship with readers. I\u2019m not sure I\u2019ve ever been to the Axios site, but I spend more time with Mike Allen\u2019s newsletter every week than I do with most publishers\u2019 home pages.\n\nI don\u2019t know if any media organization has quite cracked the best way to use Amazon\u2019s Alexa on Echos and Google Home, but I have both devices and am closely watching what works.\n\nI\u2019ve become intrigued by the trivia game HQ Trivia, which seems to be getting at a burgeoning and widespread desire for shared activities that break you out of your own siloed tech bubble. I tried to get my wife to play, but she thinks it\u2019s creepy and dystopian that everyone opens a phone at once.\n\nFinally, streaming TV feels like a new frontier where old rules about length, format and expectations are exploding in real time. When you\u2019re not locked into 30 minutes with commercial breaks, what other conventions can you throw out?\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhat is your advice for people who aspire to become reporters? What new digital tools should they start using today?\n\nReporters of the future should master the building blocks of traditional journalism. The coin of the realm, no matter the medium, is the ability to find out new facts and to uncover things that someone doesn\u2019t want you to uncover. If you can get inside the room and explain to people what happened there, and if you can do it quickly and reliably, you\u2019ll become a strong reporter no matter how or where you tell your stories.\n\nPhoto\n\nTechnology is so deeply embedded in our lives these days that you can\u2019t be a good reporter without being tech fluent. You will find sources and story ideas on Facebook, Instagram and Twitter. You will correspond with sources on encrypted apps like Signal and Telegram.\n\nYou should start your own newsletter. You\u2019ll want to understand what makes for a good podcast, and what makes for a good video \u2014 all the better if you develop skills to make them yourself.\n\nOutside your job, what tech product are you currently obsessed with in your personal life?\n\nI\u2019m on a wellness kick and have been using the Strava app for running and Headspace for meditating. And we\u2019ve jumped on the Instant Pot bandwagon, though I have to say I haven\u2019t yet become quite as obsessed as everyone else. Our tiny kitchen has not quite adapted to its modern new resident.\n\nWhat are some of your favorite podcasts other than The Daily?\n\nOne of the Daily producers turned me on to an insane podcast called Dissect, where a guy analyzes, at very great length, every song on a Kanye West record. It\u2019s like going to Kanye School, which I didn\u2019t expect to do.\n\nI\u2019m enjoying Slow Burn, Slate\u2019s new podcast about what it was like to live through Watergate. I loved Ear Hustle, a sharp and humane series about prison life. And \u201cThis American Life,\u201d of course, still offers a master class in storytelling every week.", "title": "Tapping Technology to Advance the Future of Journalism", "authors": ["Sam Dolnick", "Tech We Re Using"]} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nTarell Alvin McCraney, the playwright who won an Oscar for \u201cMoonlight,\u201d will be making his Broadway debut with \u201cChoir Boy,\u201d set to open early next year. The play, a Manhattan Theater Club production, had previously opened Off Broadway in 2013 at City Center.\n\nThe play centers on a boys\u2019 prep school and its gospel choir, and one enterprising student\u2019s quest to lead it. It opened to positive reviews; writing in The Times, Charles Isherwood made the Off Broadway production a Critic\u2019s Pick and praised Mr. McCraney\u2019s dialogue, which he said \u201cleaps from a slangy street style into a heightened lyricism.\u201d It will be directed again by Trip Cullman and is scheduled to open Jan. 22, 2019, at the Samuel J. Friedman Theater.\n\nIn addition to \u201cMoonlight,\u201d which won him the Academy Award for best adapted screenplay, Mr. McCraney has a deep body of theater work, including \u201cWig Out!\u201d and the trilogy \u201cBrother/Sister Plays.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cChoir Boy\u201d was one of three productions that the Manhattan Theater Club unveiled as part of its 2018 and 2019 season. The season will begin with the Broadway premiere of \u201cThe Nap,\u201d a play by Richard Bean, who was nominated for an Olivier Award in 2012 for \u201cEngland People Very Nice.\u201d \u201cThe Nap,\u201d directed by Daniel Sullivan, is a comedy about the dark underbelly of \u201csnooker,\u201d the British version of pool. It is slated to open Sept. 27, also at the Samuel J. Friedman Theater.\n\nJaclyn Backhaus, a Brooklyn-based playwright in residence at Lincoln Center, will be premiering \u201cIndia Pale Ale,\u201d an Off Broadway comedy about a Punjabi community\u2019s struggles. The play will be directed by Will Davis, who previously teamed with Ms. Backhaus for her best-known work, \u201cMen on Boats.\u201d It will open on Oct. 23 at City Center.", "title": "Tarell Alvin McCraney\u2019s \u2018Choir Boy\u2019 Heading to Broadway", "authors": ["Sopan Deb"]} {"date": "2018-01-07 00:00:00", "text": "In the early 1980s, Toyota wanted to start manufacturing in the United States, and Mr. Toyoda was tapped to head the effort. The goal was for Toyota to set up a factory with an American partner, teach them the Japanese way, even build the American brand\u2019s cars, and learn how to manage American employees, as well as dealing with voluntary import quotas. General Motors agreed to the partnership.\n\nImage An undated photograph of Mr. Toyoda. He instilled an egalitarian workplace culture in Toyota factories. Credit Tokyo Motor Corp., via Associated Press\n\nIn 1983, Mr. Toyoda was named president and chief executive of the joint company. American workers were sent 30 at a time for several weeks of training in Japan.\n\n\u201cBoth companies are totally committed to making New United Motor a successful model of industrial cooperation between our two nations,\u201d Mr. Toyoda said at the opening ceremony.\n\nFrom the beginning his approach was different. He spoke about collaborating with the United Auto Workers union in a way that was unusual at the time: \u201cIn a way, our company is a cooperative effort between Toyota, G.M. and the U.A.W.\u201d Mr. Toyoda said.\n\nThe changes Mr. Toyoda brought by putting in place the Toyota Production System were radical. In American car factories, workers were never supposed to stop the production line when they discovered problems; Toyota encouraged the practice and rewarded workers for finding mistakes or ways to improve the process.\n\nWhile the Japanese approach was to take the doors off a car to work on the interior and put the doors back on further down the line, American executives had resisted this technique and said it was too hard to fit the doors back on. In Fremont, the line frequently stopped, and the doors were removed.\n\nMr. Toyoda favored an egalitarian workplace culture, eschewing executive parking garages and dining rooms. \u201cI\u2019ve seen Mr. Toyoda park way out in the parking lot when he\u2019s arrived late,\u201d said Joel Smith, the top official of the United Automobile Workers unit at Fremont. And he kept a very low profile throughout his career.", "title": "Tatsuro Toyoda, Who Led Toyota\u2019s Global Expansion, Dies at 88", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-29 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 Andrew G. McCabe abruptly stepped down on Monday as the F.B.I.\u2019s deputy director after months of withering criticism from President Trump, telling friends he felt pressure from the head of the bureau to leave, according to two people close to Mr. McCabe.\n\nThough Mr. McCabe\u2019s retirement had been widely expected soon, his departure was nevertheless sudden. It added to what has already been a chaotic upheaval at the F.B.I. under Mr. Trump, who has responded to an investigation into his campaign with broadside attacks against both the bureau and the Justice Department.\n\nAs recently as last week, Mr. McCabe had told people he hoped to stay until he was eligible to retire in several weeks. Instead, he will immediately go on leave and retire on March 18.\n\nIn a recent conversation, Christopher A. Wray, the F.B.I. director, raised concerns about a forthcoming inspector general report. In that discussion, according to one former law enforcement official close to Mr. McCabe, Mr. Wray suggested moving Mr. McCabe into another job, which would have been a demotion.", "title": "Taunted by Trump and Pressured From Above, McCabe Steps Down as F.B.I. Deputy", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-08 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cIt\u2019s sort of an America-last tax policy,\u201d said Kimberly Clausing, an economist at Reed College in Portland, Ore., who studies tax policy. \u201cWe are basically saying that if you earn in the U.S., you pay X, and if you earn abroad, you pay X divided by two.\u201d\n\nWhat could be more dangerous for American workers, economists said, is that the bill ends up creating a tax break for manufacturers with foreign operations. Under the new rules, beyond the lower rate, companies will not have to pay United States taxes on the money they earn from plants or equipment located abroad, if those earnings amount to 10 percent or less of the total investment.\n\nThe Republican vision for the tax plan was to make the United States a more competitive place to do business. Supporters contend that the new rules do not encourage companies to locate overseas. Rather, they say, slashing the corporate rate will make it more attractive to set up shop at home, since many other advanced economies now have higher taxes.\n\nAnd manufacturers do not simply follow their accountants\u2019 advice. They consider taxes, but they also look at an array of other factors, including the local talent pool and transportation network, when deciding where to build a new plant.\n\nBefore the tax overhaul, companies had to pay the standard corporate tax on the money they earned abroad, with a top rate of 35 percent, but only when they brought that income back into the United States.", "title": "Tax Law May Send Factories and Jobs Abroad, Critics Say", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "SAN FRANCISCO \u2014 The last time that Congress approved a sweeping overhaul of the federal tax code, in 1986, it created a tax credit meant to encourage the private sector to invest in affordable housing. It has grown into a $9 billion-a-year social program that has funded the construction of some three million apartments for low-income residents.\n\nBut the Republican tax plan approved last month amounts to a vast cutback, making it much less likely that such construction will continue apace. Because the tax rate for corporations has been lowered, the value of the credits \u2014 which corporations get in return for their investments \u2014 is also lower.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s the greatest shock to the affordable-housing system since the Great Recession,\u201d said Michael Novogradac, managing partner of Novogradac & Company, a national accounting firm based in San Francisco.\n\nAccording to an analysis by his firm, the new tax law will reduce the growth of subsidized affordable housing by 235,000 units over the next decade, compounding an existing shortage.", "title": "Tax Overhaul Is a Blow to Affordable Housing Efforts", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "The new plan, like any tax loophole, is simple in theory and complex in execution, but it could work more or less like this: Paramus, for example, would start a charitable trust and a taxpayer who pays $20,000 in annual property taxes would contribute that exact amount to the charitable trust.\n\nThe charitable trust would then allocate the $20,000 to various entities \u2014 the schools, the police department and other agencies \u2014 as though the donation were a tax payment. The town would then credit the taxpayer for 90 to 95 percent of the donation, making it nearly entirely deductible. (The town could factor in administrative costs to lessen a donation\u2019s value.)\n\nBut building a town-run trust to take the place of a local tax collection process is relatively uncharted waters \u2014 for one thing such a change in municipal governance would require approval by each town\u2019s local governing body.\n\n\u201cOur attorneys are already going through the plan,\u201d said Richard LaBarbiera, the mayor of Paramus.\n\nStill, in New Jersey, which has the highest property taxes in the country and where municipalities rely on them to pay for schools, libraries, police departments, fire departments and other essential functions, the three towns want to alleviate what would be a major burden on taxpayers.\n\nGovernor-elect Philip D. Murphy, a Democrat who has made finding ways to lessen the impact of federal tax plan a high priority, supports the towns\u2019 efforts.\n\n\u201cWe are all in on this,\u201d Mr. Murphy said on Friday. \u201cNot just this \u2014 we\u2019ll continue to pursue all available means, legal, constitutionally, tax code and otherwise. But this one, we believe, has real legs and real precedent.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThe Trump administration seems keenly aware about efforts to come up with new loopholes.\n\n\u201cI understand what they are trying to do for their cities and their states and their taxpayers,\u201d Gary Cohn, Mr. Trump\u2019s top economic adviser, said in an interview on Friday with Bloomberg Television. \u201cWe at the federal government still have to collect revenue so we\u2019re going to have to evaluate what decisions they make in terms of what it does for overall collections at the federal level and the federal tax system.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIt is not clear that using charitable donations to fund government operations is actually feasible.\n\nThe conservative Tax Foundation released a report suggesting that such a maneuver could violate I.R.S. rules. The reason is that the donation is being given purely for the financial benefit of the donor.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cTo be deductible, charitable contributions must have a genuinely charitable aspect, and cannot primarily benefit the contributor or involve a quid pro quo,\u201d wrote Jared Walczak, a senior policy analyst at the Tax Foundation. \u201cPayments which function as taxes may be classified as taxes even if states choose to call them something else.\u201d\n\nMr. Gottheimer noted that the idea of using charitable donations to help taxpayers was a process that is already in place in various forms in other states, including Alabama, Arizona and California. In Alabama, residents can receive a dollar-for-dollar tax credit when they donate to an approved organization that funds education scholarships. In California, residents and local businesses can receive a 50-percent state tax credit for donations to a state-run fund that raises money to help students pay for college.\n\nThe move by New Jersey communities comes as confusion and frustration have spread across the country among anxious taxpayers.\n\nLast week, thousands of taxpayers scrambled to prepay their 2018 property taxes believing they could deduct them under the rules of the old tax code. But an I.R.S. advisory warned that not everyone would be eligible to write off property taxes from this year.\n\nIn response, Representative Leonard Lance, a Republican from New Jersey, said he planned to introduce legislation that would ensure that homeowners who prepaid their 2018 property taxes would be able to deduct the full amount, rather than just the portion of their 2018 property taxes that they had already been assessed.\n\n\u201cIt will not affect a lot of people, but it will affect those who paid their 2018 property taxes in 2017,\u201d Mr. Lance said.\n\nThe lack of clarity over the tax plan could lead to a wave of litigation, and state treasurers are anticipating that Congress will work to clarify murky parts of the law. In the meantime, state officials have been approaching tax experts for help in finding ways to diminish the tax burdens on residents since the federal tax plan now allows taxpayers to deduct a total of $10,000 in state and local taxes.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn Washington, Congress is likely to face pressure to find ways to close new loopholes, but Democrats, who were shut out of the process of rewriting the tax code, are unlikely to help Republicans do anything that would harm taxpayers in blue states seeking relief. This will be an especially fraught challenge in a midterm election year and it puts Republicans in the awkward position of trying to regulate state tax systems, despite the party orthodoxy that states know best how to regulate themselves.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s a classic federalism conflict,\u201d said Itai Grinberg, a Georgetown University law professor and former tax policy official at the Treasury Department.\n\nIn New Jersey, Mr. Gottheimer came up with the idea for a municipal charitable trust after a bipartisan bill he sponsored with Mr. Lance to save the state and local tax deductions never made it out of committee.\n\nBut the hope among all the Democrats involved in developing and promoting the donation idea was that the issue of taxes and helping New Jersey taxpayers would transcend politics.\n\n\u201cThis is not partisan,\u201d Mr. Murphy said. \u201cThis is a smart versus not smart.\u201d", "title": "Taxes as Charity? New Jersey Towns Try to Elude G.O.P. Tax Law", "authors": ["Nick Corasaniti", "Alan Rappeport"]} {"date": "2017-12-31 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\n\u201cA Tuition-Free College Takes a Hit\u201d (news article, Dec. 21) correctly identifies the polarized and flawed decision-making process in Congress. It misses the mark, however, by saying the goal of the 1.4 percent excise tax on certain private university endowment earnings is to encourage them to provide more funding for \u201cfinancial aid and lower tuition.\u201d\n\nIn fact, the tax includes no incentives for spending that would in any way make college more affordable. Rather, the tax is a blanket transfer to the federal government of funds that support student aid, research and other programs.\n\nTargeting the endowment funds of colleges and universities that provide the most generous student aid packages undermines the goal of making higher education more affordable and accessible to all students. The rhetoric claiming that this tax is pro-student is simply that, and it is unfortunate that politics have come to outweigh sound policy decisions.\n\nMARY SUE COLEMAN, WASHINGTON\n\nThe writer is president of the Association of American Universities.", "title": "Opinion | Taxing College Endowments", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-01 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nThe first Billboard chart of the new year belongs to Taylor Swift.\n\nMs. Swift\u2019s \u201cReputation\u201d (Big Machine) returns to No. 1 for a fourth time on the latest chart, with the equivalent of 107,000 sales, according to Nielsen. Of that total, 79,000 copies were sold as full albums, and the rest were made up of streams and downloads of individual tracks.\n\nThe latest chart counts sales made in the seven days through Dec. 28, which means that Ms. Swift probably benefited from last-minute holiday shopping, although the total for \u201cReputation\u201d was down slightly from the week before, when it logged 133,000.\n\nAlso this week, Huncho Jack, the new duo of the rappers Travis Scott and Quavo (of Migos), started at No. 3 with \u201cHuncho Jack, Jack Huncho\u201d (Quality Control), with cover art by the 81-year-old Ralph Steadman (\u201cFear and Loathing in Las Vegas\u201d). The album had the equivalent of 90,000 sales, the vast majority from streams.\n\nEd Sheeran\u2019s \u201c\u00f7\u201d is No. 2 in its 43rd week on the chart. Eminem\u2019s new \u201cRevival,\u201d last week\u2019s top seller, falls to No. 4 in its second week out. And the soundtrack to \u201cThe Greatest Showman,\u201d the P.T. Barnum biopic starring Hugh Jackman, is No. 5.\n\nIn the new year, Billboard will adjust its chart formulas to give greater weight to streams from paid subscription services, and less to free streams. That may penalize some genres, like rap and Latin pop, that have been most popular on streaming, and have come to dominate the charts because of it.\n\nIn an announcement in October, Billboard said that the changes were being made to \u201caccurately portray in an unbiased manner\u201d the way music is listened to, as well as the economic differences of various online formats.", "title": "Taylor Swift\u2019s \u2018Reputation\u2019 Takes Back No. 1 on the Chart", "authors": ["Ben Sisario"]} {"date": "2018-01-09 00:00:00", "text": "When it became apparent that Ms. Hargrave was being handcuffed in the hallway, the audience appeared startled. I am way smaller than you,\u201d she said.\n\nOutside, the marshal called for backup. There is something unsettling about how little these celebrities have to lose by taking these stances. They aren\u2019t risking financial ruin, nor are they vulnerable to violence, as is the norm for most who take a bold position.
