View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMany of the restaurants that provide passenger meals are not even told who they are for, said Susanna Bazzarelli, co-manager of the nearby Italian restaurant Bazzarelli. Still, clues slip through.\n\nAn order once arrived for a \u201chigh-profile\u201d customer who asked for several servings of kid-friendly foods such as pizza and pasta. Ms. Bazzarelli recalled thinking: \u201cOh, my God, like, it\u2019s got to be Angelina Jolie.\u201d (She later found out she was right.)\n\nTeterboro is also an important gateway for organ transplants and other medical services, said Michael Klein, chief executive of OpenAir, a charter company that operates out of Teterboro. Airlifting a kidney or a heart needs to be done on short notice \u2014 a difficult task at commercial hubs, where takeoffs and landings must be scheduled days in advance, Mr. Klein said.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019ll get a call in the middle of the night,\u201d he said. \u201cTypically within an hour we\u2019ll be in the air. Someone needs a liver, someone else dies and wants to donate a liver \u2014 that all comes together very quickly.\u201d", "title": "Teterboro Airport: Steeped in Glamour, History and Noise", "authors": ["Vivian Wang"]} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "Education Commissioner Mike Morath issued his own statement, noting that the state already had increased resources for parents and hired 39 additional special education workers across the state.\n\n\u201cI am committing today that there will be more,\u201d he said in the statement.\n\nThe federal review was prompted by a 2016 investigation by The Houston Chronicle, which revealed the enrollment target. The newspaper quoted dozens of teachers saying that the target had forced them to withhold services from students with autism, attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, dyslexia, mental illnesses, speech impairments or even blindness and deafness.\n\nIn the resulting outcry, Texas lawmakers ended the policy and passed several bills overhauling special education. Still, the federal review found that years of pressure from state officials to enroll fewer students in special education had created a culture of noncompliance with federal law that had outlasted the policy.\n\nAmong other issues, the federal regulators found that many Texas schools have trained teachers not to try to find out whether struggling students qualify for special education until regular classroom teaching techniques like Response to Intervention have been tried for years without success. That approach runs counter to federal law, which requires schools to evaluate students as soon as a disability is suspected.\n\nThe letter said regulators identified a statewide pattern of evaluations being \u201cdelayed or not conducted for children who were suspected of having a disability because these children were receiving supports for struggling learners in the general education environment.\u201d\n\nAdvocates for children with disabilities praised the federal government\u2019s action on Thursday, while cautioning that there was more work to do.\n\n\u201cThe Commissioner of Education must immediately embrace the corrective actions required by the U.S. Department of Education and take additional steps, in collaboration with stakeholders, to ensure that all students who were previously denied special education services now rightfully receive compensatory services,\u201d said Dustin Rynders, the education director at Disability Rights Texas, an advocacy group based in Houston that receives federal funds.", "title": "Texas Illegally Excluded Thousands From Special Education, Federal Officials Say", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "Texas state law enforcement officials will investigate allegations of sexual assault at the Karolyi Ranch, the former national gymnastics training center near Houston, the state\u2019s governor announced Tuesday.\n\nGovernor Greg Abbott said he asked the Texas Rangers to investigate accusations by scores of women that they were sexually assaulted by Dr. Lawrence G. Nassar, a former U.S.A. Gymnastics team doctor who treated athletes at the ranch and elsewhere. The women have said they were abused by Dr. Nassar under the guise of medical treatment, both at the ranch, in Walker County, Tex., and at Michigan State University, where he was a member of the staff.\n\nU.S.A. Gymnastics cut ties with the ranch earlier this month after a groundswell of criticism of its handling of the Nassar allegations. Many athletes, including Olympians like Simone Biles, said they were dismayed that they would have to return to ranch for national team training.\n\n\u201cThe public statements made by athletes who previously trained at the Karolyi Ranch are gut-wrenching,\u201d Mr. Abbott said. \u201cThose athletes, as well as all Texans, deserve to know that no stone is left unturned to ensure that the allegations are thoroughly vetted and the perpetrators and enablers of any such misconduct are brought to justice.\u201d", "title": "Texas Police Will Investigate Sexual Assault Allegations at Karolyi Ranch", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-08 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nBANGKOK \u2014 Thailand\u2019s prime minister evaded journalists\u2019 questions on Monday by turning to a life-size cardboard cutout of him and telling the reporters to quiz it instead.\n\nPrime Minister Prayuth Chan-ocha then turned on his heel and walked off, leaving the cutout behind, to bemused looks and awkward laughter from the journalists.\n\nThe prime minister had briefly spoken to the news media after attending an event promoting the coming Children\u2019s Day, but he deployed his dodging tactic before anyone could ask him about a number of pressing political issues.\n\n\u201cIf you want to ask any questions on politics or conflict,\u201d Mr. Payuth said, \u201cask this guy.\u201d\n\nIt was not the first time that Mr. Prayuth \u2014 a general who seized power in a bloodless coup in 2014 \u2014 had dumbfounded the news media. In the past he has fondled the ear of a sound technician for several minutes during an impromptu news conference, flung a banana peel at cameramen and threatened, with gruff humor, to execute any journalist who criticized his government.\n\nWhen it took power, his government, packed with members of the military, enjoyed considerable public support for having ended a prolonged period of often-violent street politics. But as the junta\u2019s rule has stretched on, criticism of its often repressive policies and lack of transparency has grown markedly.\n\nMr. Prayuth has promised elections in November, though he has made similar promises several times previously and then delayed the balloting.", "title": "Thailand\u2019s Leader Uses Cardboard Stand-In to Avoid Journalists\u2019 Questions", "authors": ["The Associated Press"]} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "Dear Diary:\n\nI was walking to work on 54th Street and First Avenue when I saw a young woman in a full Army uniform coming toward me.\n\nI stopped.\n\n\u201cThank you for your service,\u201d I said.\n\nShe started to laugh.\n\n\u201cOh no,\u201d she said. \u201cI\u2019m not in the military. I\u2019m an actress and we are filming a scene for the show \u2018Homeland.\u2019\u201d", "title": "Thank You for Your Service", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Moss\u2019s slippery, multilayered performance works use dance, theater, video and, frequently, audience participation. All come into play in \u201cPetra.\u201d In the Fassbinder film, Petra is a demanding, narcissistic fashion designer who rules over Marlene, her mute assistant. Karin, a stranger, arrives and Petra promptly falls in love with her. The relationship doesn\u2019t end well.\n\nPhoto\n\nA Bessie-award-winning choreographer as well as a respected curator who programmed dance for several years at the Kitchen, Mr. Moss, who is African-American, takes a closer look in \u201cPetra\u201d at the experience of the New York City artist, with race and gender playing an integral role. His \u201cPetra\u201d is set in a mythical southern realm and deviates from Fassbinder\u2019s film in another important way: Here Petra isn\u2019t a fashion designer, but a version of Mr. Moss himself.\n\nReflecting on the reputation of Fassbinder and of the film \u2014 a work, he said, by a \u201cgenius artist who is also a quintessential queer artist\u201d \u2014 Mr. Moss wants to explore what he calls \u201cthe queering of culture.\u201d The story of a same-sex relationship is no longer taboo. But by setting his production in the South, he can take his \u201cPetra\u201d into a new arena or, \u201cthe territory of brown, which is a world that I live in and love,\u201d he said. \u201cAlso for my viewer in New York, for the cosmopolitan who hasn\u2019t spent that much time there, it\u2019s a bit exotic.\u201d\n\nThe Rwandan actor and director Kaneza Schaal plays Petra, and Ms. Sinha, an Indian vocalist and composer, plays Petra\u2019s lover. Ms. Sinha also composed the score and is the audience-participation wrangler. At the beginning, she sits in the front of the audience and starts to vocalize as the houselights dim to black.\n\n\u201cAs the composer I actually open the whole piece,\u201d she said. \u201cThen I step into it as part of the story.\u201d\n\nFor her third role, she orchestrates a reading among audience members of a text about building diverse audiences, as Paz Tanjuaquio, another cast member, performs a solo. \u201cIt\u2019s like a sound meeting content meeting dance space,\u201d Ms. Sinha said. \u201cIt\u2019s a complex \u2014 I\u2019m not even sure if I call it a role. It feels like it\u2019s a world.\u201d\n\nThe other parts are just as vaporous. Mina Nishimura is Petra\u2019s sister; Sari Nordman is her daughter; and Ms. Tanjuaquio is her mother. Each performer also plays Marlene. These Marlenes, like the Marlene in the film, find a certain pleasure in Petra\u2019s mistreatment of them.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nA similar suffering, Mr. Moss said, occurs in the performing-arts world, not only from the point of view of artists, but also administrators. \u201cPeople involved in dance and the arts \u2014 when they are paid as low as they often are \u2014 have to get that enjoyment from that abuse,\u201d he said. \u201cIt\u2019s hard to stay in the job in an environment that\u2019s changing and devaluing so much of the arts. You get exhausted.\u201d", "title": "That Obscure, Unattainable Object of Desire: Your Own Art", "authors": ["Gia Kourlas"]} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nWant the latest climate news in your inbox? You can sign up here to receive Climate Fwd:, our new email newsletter.\n\nClimate change has made severe cold spells like the one that recently gripped the Northeast far less common than they used to be, a team of researchers has found.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Climate Fwd: Sign up for our newsletter to get our latest stories about climate change \u2014 along with answers to your questions and tips on how to help. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe reason is straightforward: The Arctic has warmed so much \u2014 twice as fast in recent decades than other parts of the world \u2014 that when polar air descends to lower latitudes, the cold snaps are warmer on average. So a spell of extremely cold weather like the recent one is rare, about 15 times rarer than a century ago, the scientists said.\n\n\u201cAlthough this cold spell would not have been unusual before global warming, it is now a relatively rare event in any one region,\u201d the study\u2019s authors, from a loose-knit international group called World Weather Attribution, wrote.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nPut another way, the most intense cold waves are on average about 4 degrees Fahrenheit (2 degrees Celsius) warmer now than previously, they said.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cThe trend in general for these cold waves is that they\u2019re warming,\u201d said Claudia Tebaldi, a research fellow with Climate Central, a news organization that focuses on climate science and coordinated the study.", "title": "That Recent Brutally Cold Weather? It\u2019s Getting Rarer", "authors": ["Henry Fountain"]} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "Murphy Brown had just aired its Season 4 finale in which Ms. Brown, an unmarried news anchor, gave birth to a baby boy.\n\nMr. Quayle said the character was \u201cmocking the importance of fathers, by bearing a child alone, and calling it just another \u2018lifestyle choice.\u2019\u201d\n\nThe blowback from liberals was swift, and an early skirmish in the culture war was on. Critics of the administration said it was hypocritical to condemn both abortion and single motherhood. In a fumbled response to Mr. Quayle\u2019s remarks, the White House \u201cfirst applauded, then dithered, then beat a befuddled retreat,\u201d The Times reported.\n\nA White House spokesman criticized the \u201cglorification of the life of an unwed mother\u201d on the morning after the speech. But shortly after that, he praised the show for its \u201cpro-life values.\u201d\n\nAnd that afternoon, President Bush, besieged by Murphy Brown questions at an appearance with the prime minister of Canada, threw up his hands in frustration.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t know that much about the show,\u201d he said. \u201cI\u2019ve told you, I don\u2019t want any more questions about it.\u201d\n\nMurphy Brown was a divorced career woman in her 40s who had battled addictions to cigarettes and alcohol, decided to raise a child on her own and tried medical marijuana after learning she had breast cancer. Her fans saw her as an icon \u2014 an older, saltier, more modern version of Mary Tyler Moore.\n\nPhoto\n\nThose fans may be happy to learn that Ms. Brown is coming back. The character \u201creturns to a world of cable news, social media, fake news and a very different political and cultural climate,\u201d CBS said in a statement on Wednesday.\n\nThis week, Ms. Bergen did not immediately return a request for a comment, nor did Diane English, the show\u2019s creator and producer. But she had plenty to say at the time.\n\n\u201cIf the Vice President thinks it\u2019s disgraceful for an unmarried woman to bear a child,\u201d Ms. English said, \u201cand if he believes that a woman cannot adequately raise a child without a father, then he\u2019d better make sure abortion remains safe and legal.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThere was no immediate response either from Mr. Quayle, who is perhaps better remembered for a gaffe he made about a month after his Murphy Brown comment: Telling an elementary school student that \u2018potato\u2019 is spelled with an \u2018e\u2019 at the end.\n\nThe Republicans, who had held the White House since President Reagan\u2019s 1980 victory, lost that fall to Bill Clinton and Al Gore.\n\nIn the context of Mr. Quayle\u2019s May 19 speech, the mention of Murphy Brown reads almost like an afterthought with the distance of 26 years.\n\nMr. Quayle had spoken at length about \u201cthe Los Angeles riots\u201d that erupted in late April, killing dozens of people. They were a reaction to the acquittals of four white police officers who had been captured on video severely beating Rodney King, a black taxi driver, the year before.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nDozens of people were killed. Properties were destroyed. A state of emergency was declared in California\u2019s most populous city. When he took the stage at the Commonwealth Club of California in San Francisco, Mr. Quayle talked about poverty, crime, race and \u201cfamily values\u201d before pivoting to the hit television show.\n\n\u201cIt doesn\u2019t help matters when prime time T.V. has Murphy Brown,\u201d he said.\n\nAt the Emmy Awards show in August, Ms. Bergen and Ms. English criticized Mr. Quayle\u2019s comments. He fired back the next day: \u201cThey said that I believe single mothers and their children are not families. That is a lie. Winning an Emmy is not a license to lie. Hollywood doesn\u2019t like our values.\u201d\n\nWhen a new season of Murphy Brown began in September 1992, Mr. Quayle was a good sport. He sent a card and a stuffed elephant to Ms. Bergen, and he sat down with a group of single mothers to watch an episode of the show. He said it was the first time he had seen it.\n\nIn the first episode of Season 5, the writers of Murphy Brown incorporated Mr. Quayle\u2019s comments into the plot and poked fun at the politician.\n\n\u201cWhat planet is he on?\u201d Ms. Brown, then a new mother, said to her friend Frank (Joe Regalbuto) after watching a video of the speech.\n\n\u201cTomorrow he\u2019s probably going to get his head stuck in his golf bag and you\u2019ll be old news,\u201d Frank said. \u201cMurph, it\u2019s Dan Quayle! Just forget about it!\u201d\n\nThe line separating fiction from reality blurred again in the season\u2019s second episode, in which the character Ms. Brown addressed Mr. Quayle, looking into real cameras on a fake news set.\n\n\u201cThese are difficult times for our country, and in searching for the causes of our social ills we could choose to blame the media, or the Congress, or an administration that\u2019s been in power for 12 years,\u201d she said.\n\n\u201cOr we could blame me.\u201d", "title": "That Time \u2018Murphy Brown\u2019 and Dan Quayle Topped the Front Page", "authors": ["Jacey Fortin"]} {"date": "2018-01-09 00:00:00", "text": "There are lots of others as well.\n\nThis would be the moment some readers \u2014 especially those, like me, who were painstakingly trained to be grammar snobs \u2014 might lament the atrociousness of the singular they, not to mention the strangeness of invented pronouns like ze and hir. There was a time when, if I heard an individual refer to himself or herself as \u201cthey,\u201d I would have assumed ze might be crackers.\n\nBut I use the singular they all the time now \u2014 as well as other nonbinary pronouns \u2014 because the absence of a gender nonspecific singular pronoun in English really does present a problem, not just for transgender folks but for all people who feel that every word out of their mouths need not necessarily reveal the mysteries of their underpants.\n\nAnd while conservatives \u2014 and others for whom the vexing issue of gender identity is considered a problem of no importance \u2014 might well resent any evolution in the mother tongue, it\u2019s worth remembering that English has a long history of adapting to cultural change. That\u2019s something we should celebrate, not lament.\n\nNone of this happens swiftly, though. The honorific \u201cMs.,\u201d first proposed in an issue of The Sunday Republican of Springfield, Mass., in 1901, was finally adopted by The New York Times in 1986. \u201cCisgender,\u201d meanwhile (to refer to someone who is not transgender), was first used by the paper in 2010. And although the first use of \u201cMx.\u201d as an honorific for people wishing not to be identified by gender dates to 1977, Merriam-Webster added it to its lexicon only last September. The Times does not use it as part of its house style. Yet.\n\nSome people find the singular they grating, and I get that: It once sounded funny to me, too. But lots of good things were unfamiliar at first, including (to name three) women\u2019s suffrage, Rhode Island-style hot-pepper calamari and the opening chord of \u201cA Hard Day\u2019s Night.\u201d Unless you\u2019re Roy Moore (who has lamented the passage of all the constitutional amendments after the 10th), most Americans really do yearn for a more just world, even if the changes that justice demands can take a long time to join the culture, or the language.", "title": "Opinion | That\u2019s What Ze Said", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "As the sexual misconduct scandals continue to unfold, our gender team is providing updates and analysis in a newsletter. Sign up here to receive future installments, and tell us what you think at nytgender@nytimes.com.\n\nToday, we present artwork inspired by the cultural reckoning \u2014 made by you, our readers.\n\nJudy Chicago established the first known feminist-art program in the United States, in the fall of 1970, at the California Institute of the Arts. Later, she formed the art collective known as \u201cWomanhouse\u201d because, as she put it, \u201cwomen artists were simply not taken seriously.\u201d\n\nTwo decades later, the Guerrilla Girls forced attention to the fine art world\u2019s gender and racial disparity with their gorilla masks and guerrilla-style stunts. (\u201cGuerrilla Girls\u2019 definition of a hypocrite?\u201d read one poster. \u201cAn art collector who buys white male art at benefits for liberal causes, but never buys art by women or artists of color.\u201d)\n\nFrom Picasso\u2019s Guernica \u2014 observed as a cry against the atrocities of the Spanish War \u2014 to the graffiti of the Arab Spring, social movements and injustice have long inspired art of all forms. The #MeToo Moment is no exception.", "title": "The #MeToo Moment: Art Inspired by the Reckoning", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-06 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nAs the sexual misconduct scandals continue to unfold, our gender team is providing updates and analysis in a new newsletter. Today, Bonnie Wertheim introduces us to \u201cThe New Red Carpet\u201d \u2014 and explains how The Times is covering the Golden Globes red carpet differently this year. Read back issues of The #MeToo Moment here, sign up for the newsletter here, and tell us what you think at nytgender@nytimes.com.\n\nThe first time I tried on a floor-length gown, I was 12 years old and on the cusp of \u201cbecoming a woman\u201d \u2014 or, at least, parading as one for my bat mitzvah. The dress was an iridescent lavender, with rhinestone-encrusted straps and a tulle-stuffed princess skirt. I would wear it in a room packed with peers, family friends and relatives the following year, an experience so terrifying that a stress-induced flu would swiftly follow. But alone in the dressing room, I already felt seen. That some people wore outfits so spectacular on a regular basis \u2014 that they made themselves so visible \u2014 was unimaginable to me.\n\nPhoto\n\nI didn\u2019t know the half of it then. Those celebrities, whose beauty and elegance and occasional sartorial slip-ups I\u2019d watched on E! for years, contained secrets their camera-ready appearances never let on. They were beholden to agreements unspoken and explicit, ones upon which their careers hinged and which are now, finally, coming to light.\n\nAt The Times, where I work on the Styles desk, red carpet slide shows are a mainstay of awards season. We watch, pick our personal bests and worsts, and publish images that millions of people then judge for themselves. The photographs, at best, reflect a desire for shiny distractions. But there is a complicity to scrutinizing and ranking these women, too.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nTheir dresses are not a reflection of their own style or their professional achievements. They speak to the larger economy of Hollywood, whose corruption becomes clearer with each turn of the news cycle. Moreover, our habitual participation in the red carpet industrial complex underscores the widely held perception that women\u2019s bodies are available for public consumption.", "title": "The #MeToo Moment: Covering \u2018The New Red Carpet\u2019", "authors": ["Bonnie Wertheim"]} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "When former Penn State assistant football coach Jerry Sandusky was accused in 2012 of raping young boys, Americans were outraged.\n\nWhere was that anger in 2016 when the Indianapolis Star first reported the allegations against Dr. Nassar? And outside of that case, gymnastics\u2019 \u201cculture of abuse\u201d had been long documented by journalists and former gymnasts themselves. Even when decorated Olympians like Simone Biles and Aly Raisman spoke publicly about the abuse, outside of the \u201cgymternet\u201d \u2014 yes, that\u2019s a thing \u2014 it felt like only crickets were being heard.\n\nIn the courtroom in Michigan, the assistant attorney general, Angela Povilaitis, said: \u201cWe teach our girls and daughters to be too nice. To just ignore and put up with uncomfortable situations, to stay silent when they should be allowed to be heard.\u201d\n\nThe women of gymnastics are no longer staying silent.\n\nThey called for the Michigan State president, Lou Anna Simon, to step down, and late Wednesday she announced she would resign. They are also demanding full investigations into the university, U.S.A. Gymnastics, the U.S. Olympic Committee and into John Geddert, the 2012 Olympic coach.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Gender Letter A weekly newsletter on women, gender and society. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAfter Penn State, the long-time football coach, Joe Paterno, was ousted. The university agreed to pay $59.7 million to 26 victims. Its former president was found guilty of child endangerment. The Times wrote then, \u201cThe fallout was swift and far-reaching in higher education, sports and even state politics.\u201d\n\nThe male victims in those cases saw justice. The women of gymnastics are now waiting. But no longer silently.\n\nA Look At the Coverage\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 More than 160 women say Dr. Nassar sexually abused them. Here are his accusers in their own words. Many of the women here, embracing the #metoo movement, contend that they have much more to say.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 The judge in the case, Rosemarie Aquilina, opened her courtroom to any victim who wished to speak. \u201cLeave your pain here and go out and do your magnificent things,\u201d she said.\n\n\u2022 Deadspin has continuously documented the allegations against Dr. Nassar; this account by Dvora Meyers is particularly worth your time.\n\n\u2022 Many of the parents of Dr. Nassar\u2019s victims discovered that they were present when he abused their children, using his body to block their view as he leaned over the examination table. Many found themselves asking, \u201cHow did I miss the red flags?\u201d\n\n\u2022 In The Times\u2019s Opinion section, staff editor and former rhythmic gymnast on the U.S. national team, Liriel Higa, wrote that it is time for a reckoning for U.S.A. Gymnastics. Some might argue, she noted, that America likes to win more than it likes to listen to the grave concerns of girls and women.\n\n\u2022 My colleague Juliet Macur, who has been covering the sport for some time, writes that a center of U.S.A. Gymnastics\u2019 success \u2014 the ranch owned by the coaches Bela and Martha Karolyi, where treatment by Dr. Nassar was mandatory at monthly training camps \u2014 had become a haunted house. In the Michigan courtroom, gymnasts said the atmospheres created by the Karolyis, and by Mr. Geddert in Michigan, enabled the doctor to mistreat them. They said they were conditioned not to question adults, or complain about pain and hunger.\n\n\u2022 Ms. Macur also shared the story of Rachel Denhollander, the first former gymnast to go public with accusations of abuse by Dr. Nassar. Ms. Denhollander said that her only choice was to stand up for what was right, \u201cno matter what it cost me.\u201d\n\n\u2022 And in case you missed it, last week we devoted a full page of The Times\u2019s print edition to Ms. Raisman\u2019s statement in court. You can read it here.\n\nSign up here to receive The MeToo Moment in your inbox. You can also read us on the web or listen to us on WNYC\u2019s The Takeaway. Share your feedback at nytgender@nytimes.com.", "title": "The #MeToo Moment: For U.S. Gymnasts, Why Did Justice Take So Long?", "authors": ["Carla Correa"]} {"date": "2018-01-31 00:00:00", "text": "Second, the men wondered how they could participate without being viewed as disingenuous \u2014 or elbowing out female voices. They sensed they could do more to help, but didn\u2019t know how.\n\nLastly, they wondered: How should they be assessing their own past behavior in this brave new world?\n\nOne man, a former human-resources director, said he was reported for harassment in the \u201890s \u2014 unfairly, he believed \u2014 when he told a female colleague that \u201cYou were in my dream last night.\u201d He didn\u2019t mean it sexually, he said.\n\nPhoto\n\nAnother said that while he logically knew that false accusations are rare, he couldn\u2019t help but worry that it could happen to him.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Gender Letter A weekly newsletter on women, gender and society. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nSome men said they saw a lot of themselves in Aziz Ansari, the actor who recently was accused in an online article of ignoring the verbal and nonverbal cues of a former date. In the article, she described his behavior as sexual assault. They wondered if and how often they missed those cues themselves.\n\nAt times, it seemed the men were seeking validation as much as solutions. As they revisited their own possible missteps and complicity, they said they were wrestling with the distinction between \u201cI am a bad person\u201d and \u201cI made a mistake.\u201d\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re all kind of guilty to an extent,\u201d one of the men said.\n\nAs the men unloaded, the event\u2019s female organizer, who goes by a pseudonym, \u201cLola Jean,\u201d sat silently as promised. She said that while she disagreed with some of what she heard, she felt it was important for men to air their apprehensions \u2014 with the goal of better understanding how to address them.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cUltimately, I believe it\u2019s going to be men helping men in order to be better humans, better allies and better advocates,\u201d she said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhat Readers Are Saying \u2026 About Men\n\n\u201cI\u2019d like to see more discussion about how men are supposed to behave in various situations, and especially how they (and women) can flirt and pursue without frightening or pissing off the object of their desire. People are saying a lot about what they don\u2019t want while assuming men always know what they do want. Let\u2019s help them out. Positive, clear direction is just what Ansari\u2019s partner did not provide. Let\u2019s not continue to make that mistake.\u201d \u2014 Janet C., Virginia\n\n\u201cOf course young women like \u2018Grace\u2019 can and should learn to speak up more clearly, protect themselves more carefully, and leave more quickly. But why is that the main takeaway? Why is it always a woman\u2019s obligation to avoid getting raped? Why isn\u2019t it at least as important to teach boys and men not to be rapists/harassers/boorish bad dates?.\u201d \u2014 Denell Downum, New York\n\n\u201cI agree that imitating Mike Pence is not the best of outcomes. If I were back supervising women in an office setting, though, I am almost certain that I would be much more guarded now. I probably would think twice about suggesting lunch or any other get together with women colleagues and particularly women on my staff. This is not a desirable situation, although I would prefer it for my granddaughters and great-granddaughters to the worst of past practice.\u201d \u2014 John Fremer, New Jersey\n\nWe Want to Hear From You\n\nMen, to what extent are you struggling with the current cultural reckoning? Do you feel comfortable talking about your concerns \u2014 and if not, why? How should men be thinking about their role in perpetuating abuse \u2014 or working to end it? Email us on this or other thoughts at nytgender@nytimes.com.\n\nSign up here to receive future installments of the MeToo Moment. You can see past issueson the web or listen to us on WNYC\u2019s The Takeaway. Share your feedback at nytgender@nytimes.com.", "title": "The #MeToo Moment: I\u2019m a Straight Man. Now What?", "authors": ["Daniel Victor"]} {"date": "2018-01-17 00:00:00", "text": "Meanwhile, a 33-year-old staff editor and writer, Bari Weiss, wrote in The Times Opinion section that Mr. Ansari was guilty of only one thing: Not being a mind reader.\n\nIn Vox, Jezebel and The Guardian, women in their 20s and 30s noted that while they considered the Babe piece to be poorly reported, it had sparked an important and necessary conversation about the complicated dynamics of sexual consent.\n\nWe gathered Ms. Weiss and two other Times staffers \u2014 ages 29 and 59 \u2014 to talk sexual consent, #metoo and the seeming generational divide.\n\nJESSICA BENNETT: This particular story has left me grappling with a particular question. Is it possible for something to be nonconsensual but also not sexual assault?\n\nBARI WEISS, STAFF EDITOR AND WRITER, OPINION, 33: One of the most remarkable aspects of this truly remarkable moment is that we are collectively and openly reassessing what we regard as kosher when sex and power is involved. But one of the more distressing and underreported aspects of this re-moralization is that some younger feminists are telling older feminists that they don\u2019t understand their own lives. They are telling women who experienced what they considered \u201cbad dates\u201d or \u201cbad sex\u201d that those experiences were, in fact, assault. Or worse.\n\nMany older feminists I know are sitting there saying \u201cHow dare you look at me \u2014 me who has kicked open the door of every room you occupy, who had to beg for the paid maternity leave you now enjoy, who endured the alienation of being the only woman at the table so that now you get to sit at its head \u2014 and tell me I\u2019m not self-aware enough to understand my own life?\u201d\n\nFAHIMA HAQUE, SOCIAL STRATEGY EDITOR, 29: I probably sound salty but it doesn\u2019t surprise me that women, generationally, are differing on the #MeToo movement. I am a younger feminist, but I\u2019m not an unthinking one who assumes I have no agency. I am a survivor of childhood sexual assault and I\u2019ve grappled with, nearly every day of my life, what needs to happen for men to be better and for women to feel strong enough to use their voice clearly to hold men accountable. So I fully admit that I\u2019m pretty militant about male behavior.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSUSAN CHIRA, SENIOR GENDER CORRESPONDENT, 59: I share my generation\u2019s general unease with labeling sexual awkwardness sexual assault. It\u2019s not only about refusing to see yourself as a victim, but also it\u2019s a fundamental act of fairness. I also think all generations are confronting that sex is an area of great uncertainty, vulnerability and, at times, abuse of power. Just because it\u2019s common to emerge from bad sexual encounters feeling bruised doesn\u2019t mean we shouldn\u2019t question why it\u2019s so common and what needs to change.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Gender Letter A weekly newsletter on women, gender and society. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThere seems to be one thing some younger women have insisted on: That Aziz did abuse his power in the situation, even if it wasn\u2019t professional power. What do you think?\n\nBW: Refusing to give a factory worker a promotion unless she blows you? That is an abuse of power. Going on a date and hooking up \u2014 however boorishly \u2014 with another person? That is simply not an abuse of power. If we are going to weigh every relationship on the scales of power, well, then investment bankers won\u2019t be allowed to date baristas. We need to draw a bright line between what happens in the workplace and what happens in the privacy of our apartments (or kitchens). Right now they are getting conflated.\n\nSC: I think it\u2019s crucial to make distinctions, and Aziz\u2019s accuser fell far short because she didn\u2019t. Yes, he was more powerful than she was \u2014 not only as a man who often takes the role of aggressor in sex, but also because of his celebrity. But he held no institutional power over her career or advancement. And yet if he behaved boorishly or insensitively, if he failed to pick up cues she may have been too embarrassed to verbalize, he, like other men who\u2019ve behaved this way, should be reflecting on why this encounter went so awry.\n\nBari, you wrote this week that the only thing Aziz is guilty of is not being a mind reader. That\u2019s true, but Grace also describes expressing her discomfort in multiple places. Shouldn\u2019t we have a higher bar for men\u2019s emotional intelligence?\n\nBW: Absolutely. But that is not going to happen overnight. And until that blessed day of universal male emotional intelligence is upon us \u2014 or when someone figures out how to clone Jeff Goldblum \u2014 I want fewer women to be harassed, assaulted and raped. In part that means telling women to use their common sense.\n\nFH: Aziz Ansari did write a (very good) book on modern romance, but this just highlights that even the most sensitive, thoughtful \u2014 dare I say \u2018woke\u2019 \u2014 kind of man also has a lot to learn. We need to have a higher bar.\n\nDaphne Merkin, a critic and novelist, recently made the point in our Opinion section that we are treating women like frail Victorian-era housewives. I heard similar from a middle-aged friend, who wondered why Grace didn\u2019t \u201cjust get up and leave.\u201d Thoughts?\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFH: The \u201cget up and leave\u201d theory is, in theory, a good one. But that just feels ugly and callous in practice. It paints some women as strong warriors and others as weak fools. I will always respect first- and second-wave feminists for taking those crucial first steps for women\u2019s rights, but to shun the new wave of women because their approach is different is divisive. We won\u2019t move forward. I get that Grace\u2019s actions are grating, because ideally she would have felt confident enough in herself to leave. But I remember that at 23 it can be daunting to be the one who says no.\n\nSC: Not sure this cuts generationally, though it may. That is, there are so many reasons women may be constrained from saying explicitly when they\u2019re uncomfortable, or they end up staying what turns out in hindsight to have been too long. Yes, it\u2019s important to learn to say no firmly. But we all know men don\u2019t always listen to that. And we also know that women themselves are often conflicted. Sex is always going to be messy and fumbling, to some degree. And I personally think we have to be tolerant of some uncertainty, some grayness. But if #MeToo is going to spur real changes, men have to curb their sense of entitlement.\n\nHere\u2019s a question we get often from readers: What about due process? Is it really fair to place Aziz Ansari\u2019s name on the same spectrum as Harvey Weinstein?\n\nBW: Our current situation \u2014 guilty because accused, as Margaret Atwood put it \u2014 is absolutely terrifying to me. And it should be to anyone that cares about justice and due process.\n\nFH: The #MeToo movement is the best part of social media. And trial by Twitter is the worst part of social media. But, most people aren\u2019t on Twitter exhaustively the way media folks are, so frankly while it\u2019s troubling that some bring out their 280-count pitchforks, I\u2019m just not too concerned that it\u2019s going to sideline the overall power and scope of such newfound, increased transparency.\n\nSC: What\u2019s extraordinary \u2014 and deeply unsettling \u2014 is that #MeToo gives women power that men have had for so long. Men could ruin reputations, undermine or destroy women\u2019s careers, act impulsively. I hope and believe that women can wield power more responsibly and more justly.\n\nThis interview has been edited and condensed.\n\nMake a friend\u2019s day: Forward this email.\n\nGet this from a friend? Sign up here.\n\nYou can also read us on the web or listen to us on WNYC\u2019s The Takeaway.\n\nShare your feedback at nytgender@nytimes.com.", "title": "The #MeToo Moment: Parsing the Generational Divide", "authors": ["Jessica Bennett"]} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "* I hope we talk about culture as much as we talk about individuals, and recognize that while the Weinsteins of the world are extreme, the messages we learn about sex, and power, and courtship, and consent, are deeply ingrained and start young \u2014 and will take far more than a workplace sexual harassment training to unlearn.\n\n* I hope we can have meaningful, nuanced discussions about due process and women\u2019s agency. What can someone accused of sexual misconduct reasonably expect, what is fair, and what range of punishments should be considered beyond the abrupt torching of someone\u2019s career? As Daphne Merkin put it in a Opinion column this week, \u201cIn our current climate, to be accused is to be convicted. Due process is nowhere to be found.\u201d How can we talk about the damaging nature of sexual assault as a whole without conflating the Harvey Weinsteins with the Al Frankens?\n\n(Listen to this episode of NPR\u2019s \u201cAll Things Considered\u201d for a conversation with constitutional law professor Elizabeth Price Foley on the subject; read Ms. Merkin\u2019s piece, \u201cPublicly, We Say #MeToo. Privately, We Have Misgivings,\u201d here.)\n\n* I hope we will start seeing what happens when women take over the reins at major institutions, filling in the gaps left by the fallen men who have long shaped our cultural narratives. (At the Today Show, Hoda Kotb is the latest, replacing Matt Lauer as co-host.) We know from research (ahem: I\u2019ll plug my own book here, because I spent a year looking at academic studies on the subject) that organizations with more women are more successful, more collaborative, more profitable, and more inclusive. What effect might those women\u2019s leadership have on media and culture at large?\n\n* Finally, I hope we\u2019ll see a change, or at least a bit of internal scrutiny, in the way we as journalists do our jobs. The Times, for example, has revamped its approach to covering the red carpet for the Golden Globes this weekend \u2014 assigning a Pulitzer Prize winning photojournalist, known for his political work, to photograph the event. (Read what Choire Sicha, the editor of The Times\u2019 Style section has to say about our plans, and tune in on Sunday to see how it plays out.)\n\nIn the meantime, I asked a few smart people \u2014 a law professor, a former NFL player, a television writer and more \u2014 about what they hope for the year ahead. Read what they had to say below, and check out previous installments of The #MeTooMoment here. As always, tell us whatyou think at nytgender@nytimes.com.\n\nWhat Do You Hope for #MeToo in 2018?", "title": "The #MeToo Moment: What\u2019s Next?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "But Ms. Dunne could not put the photo sessions behind her. She lost faith in herself.\n\n\u201cHe had given me these opportunities,\u201d she said, \u201cand after this happened, I started to feel that it wasn\u2019t based on my merit, and how could I have been so stupid, and really the only thing he was interested in was me as a sexual object.\u201d\n\nShe quit the circus world and drifted for several years. \u201cI just felt really confused and lost and ashamed,\u201d she said.\n\nAround 2008, while in therapy, she told her parents about the photos, Mr. Phillips said.\n\nIn 2011 or 2012, Ms. Dunne said, she went to the police in New York and they told her that the statute of limitations for pursuing any charges had expired. Federal child pornography law forbids sexually explicit depiction of someone younger than 18, and the definition of sexually explicit is broad. \u201cA picture of a naked child may constitute illegal child pornography if it is sufficiently sexually suggestive,\u201d the Department of Justice\u2019s website says.\n\nLater in 2012, Ms. Dunne wrote to Big Apple officials that Mr. Lubin had done things to her that were \u201csexual in nature.\u201d She asked to speak to him in the presence of a Big Apple representative. But Mr. Lubin, who joined the circus in 1982, had left.\n\n\u201cYour allegations against Barry Lubin are indeed serious,\u201d the circus\u2019s executive director, Lynn Stirrup, wrote to Ms. Dunne. But Mr. Lubin was no longer an employee and the circus could not compel him to meet with her, she explained. Ms. Dunne let the matter drop.\n\nMs. Stirrup, who left the circus in 2015, said Tuesday night that she did not remember Ms. Dunne\u2019s 2012 email or her response. \u201cI had no recollection of any of this, I\u2019m sorry to say,\u201d she said. \u201cThe circus was in complete crisis the entire time I was there. It was constant chaos.\u201d\n\nMs. Stirrup said she did not contact the circus after she learned that Mr. Lubin was rehired, nor does it appear that any of the other recipients of the 2012 email did, either.", "title": "The #MeToo Movement Hits the Circus: \u2018Grandma\u2019 the Clown Resigns", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "The research is here, and it\u2019s impressive. We learn about the Impressionists with whom Renoir traveled and the official Salon against which they sometimes rebelled. Manet, Monet, C\u00e9zanne and Pissarro all make appearances, as does the art dealer Paul Durand-Ruel, who created a market for these painters.\n\nAlong the way, we also learn a great deal about 19th-century French society and mores. Renoir came from a poor background, which helped shape his work since he was paid to paint portraits. It also meant he had to give up the two children he had with his model Lise, since neither could afford to raise them (which, White speculates, may have resulted in the death of his firstborn).\n\nThe only problem with the meticulousness of White\u2019s every-statement-backed-up-with-evidence-approach is that the prose can get very wooden, like a police report. Renoir the man is \u201ca remarkable individual whose life story is heroic and inspiring,\u201d but what about his work? Famous paintings are mentioned, but not explained or elaborated upon.\n\nContrary to White\u2019s conclusion that Renoir\u2019s \u201coptimistic, joyful art brings happiness to people around the world,\u201d a small anti-Renoir movement started with an Instagram account in 2015, with the handle \u201cRenoir Sucks at Painting,\u201d and included protests outside museums. However funny and (presumably) ironic, the insurgency gained traction as Renoir\u2019s soft-focus, saccharine Impressionism came under fire. It would have been interesting to read a committed scholar and champion of Renoir\u2019s work rebut the Instagram activists \u2014 and add a contemporary chapter to the tale.\n\nA GENEROUS VISION\n\nThe Creative Life of Elaine de Kooning\n\nBy Cathy Curtis\n\n304 pp. Oxford University. $34.95.\n\nPhoto\n\nElaine de Kooning was a big personality. A minister she once met while traveling told her, \u201cBeing married to you must be like being married to 20 women.\u201d As a native Brooklynite who attended Erasmus Hall High School and was inspired by titanic women like the track Olympian Babe Didrikson, she painted, she wrote about art \u2014 and, although estranged from him for many years, was married to the famous gestural abstract painter Willem de Kooning.\n\nSeparating her life from this last fact is part of the work of Curtis\u2019s biography: How to show the \u201ccreative life\u201d of Elaine de Kooning, without making her a mere accessory to the company she kept? She was not as consistent a painter as some of her associates, but she possessed talent and boldness (some of it alcohol-fueled; she got sober in the 1970s with the help of Alcoholics Anonymous).\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nDe Kooning\u2019s greatest achievements as an artist are her figurative paintings, including the \u201cfaceless men\u201d series from the 1950s and an official 1963 portrait of John F. Kennedy that was unveiled in 1965, a year and a half after he was assassinated. She was also a gifted writer, using expertise learned as a painter and personal knowledge of art and artists to analyze and explain the work of others.\n\nLike many prominent women of her generation, de Kooning didn\u2019t identify as a feminist, even pushing back against Linda Nochlin\u2019s famous feminist essay from 1971, \u201cWhy Have There Been No Great Women Artists?\u201d And yet de Kooning served as a role model for women by circulating within the elite New York art world and demanding access to institutions like the Club, the unofficial art school and salon.\n\nPerhaps most important in examining a creative life and career like this one is seeing how art is made in communities, rather than by isolated artists in garrets (or studios on 10th Street in Greenwich Village). Biographies like Curtis\u2019s offer a corrective to art history and the art market, which too often focus on mythical art stars and singular \u201cgeniuses.\u201d Friends, lovers and associates can contribute equally to making, explaining and preserving artists\u2019 work and their legacies.", "title": "The (Often Complicated) Lives of Artists", "authors": ["Martha Schwendener"]} {"date": "2018-01-03 00:00:00", "text": "His point was emphasized by his surroundings. The entrance-floor atrium, designed by the French artist Daniel Buren, evoked the blockier shapes of early Pompeian wall paintings but its mirrors added a fun-house dimension announcing that here the ancient and the contemporary would be bouncing back and forth, the old would seem new and the new old.\n\nMr. Buren\u2019s atrium, commissioned by the museum in 2015 for its 10th anniversary, is a site-specific piece that has become part of the museum\u2019s permanent collection. Those rooms, mostly on the elegant museum\u2019s first floor, are now repurposed as a modern reimagining of a Pompeian Domus, or home. The galleries are furnished with first-century artifacts on loan from the archaeological park\u2019s storehouses.\n\nIn an airy room painted with Neapalitan and Pompeian themes by the Italian artist Francesco Clemente, an ancient phallus sculpture hangs from the ceiling, and tables and reclining chairs create an updated triclinium, or dining room. In another room streaked with paint by Richard Long, the excavated pots and pans seem to be sitting amid the kitchen\u2019s splattered backsplash.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe then and the now conversed fluently where the British sculptor Anish Kapoor\u2019s meters-deep black rectangular hole in the ground yawned underneath busts of Pompeian divinities that connected the underworld and the heavens. They practically chattered in a white room featuring \u201c10,000 Lines,\u201d red and blue wall drawings by LeWitt, set against an intricate, ancient mosaic that curators placed on the floor between them.\n\nMr. Viliani explained how ancient artisans followed rules to assemble the mosaic the same way the assistants followed LeWitt\u2019s studio instructions to create his drawings. \u201cIt\u2019s absolutely analogous,\u201d he said.\n\nBut sometimes, Pompeii\u2019s denouement dominated the room.\n\nIn Mr. Paladino\u2019s white cubiculum, or bedroom, a figure stares at the wall, seemingly looking away from the plaster casts of Vesuvius\u2019s victims. It\u2019s hard to blame him. The man, doubled in agony, can do nothing as the child on his belly reaches for a final gulp of air.\n\nThe question of context and of a museum\u2019s role as a time machine is the theme of the second part of the show, which runs through November and is what organizers call an \u201cintellectual excavation\u201d of Pompeii\u2019s history. In the first archaeological mission in 1748, the area\u2019s Bourbon rulers had all the treasures sent to Naples, a plunder that damaged the integrity of the site but produced the wonderful collection in the city\u2019s grand National Archaeological Museum.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOn Madre\u2019s top floor, the process of uncovering Pompeii is examined. Handwritten notes, detailing the treasures shipped to Naples, sit under vitrines with shovels and picks used in the digs. They surround a work, \u201cRebirth,\u201d by the Argentine sculptor Adri\u00e1n Villar Rojas, in which nests and briaded wool rise from felled tree trunks. The idea that antiquity arrives to us in fragments is hammered home by Maria Loboda\u2019s \u201cInterrupted Pillar,\u201d a column hanging from the ceiling and sprouting from the floor but empty in between.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe past and present will be further fused next summer, when Mr. Viliani and Massimo Osanna, the director of the Archaeological Park of Pompeii, will help choose artists to sculpt new works from stone and ceramic archaeological fragments that were irreparably damaged when Allied forces bombed Pompeii in 1943. For the moment, these shards and fragments sit in two crates in an exhibition room under Andy Warhol\u2019s vivid, bursting pop canvas of Vesuvius, on loan from the Museo di Capodimonte in Naples.\n\nNaples and Pompeii are themselves experiencing rebirths, adding an extra dimension to a show about the irrepressibility of Pompeian life. After decades of crime, Naples is moving forward as a home to film shoots, celebrity chefs and contemporary art. The city\u2019s streets brim with life and its metro system is a contemporary art museum, with top-notch works strewn under the city.\n\nAnd Pompeii, where discoveries continue and contemporary instillations arrive, is experiencing a renaissance after structural collapses in 2010 raised alarms and prompted the Italian government and the European Union to invest more than 100 million euros, or around $120 million today, into a restoration campaign.\n\nA short distance outside Naples, Mattia Buondonno, Pompeii\u2019s celebrated guide, stopped in front of a storefront facade and pointed out the faded etchings of letters from the Roman alphabet. As two young visitors inspected the walls where their ancient predecessors practiced their ancient ABCs, Mr. Buondonno said, \u201cThe walls talk. The walls whisper.\u201d\n\nAnd back at Madre, curators are making sure contemporary art listens and talks back. Sometimes the dialogue is clear and sometimes it is hard to understand. But the stories are always the same. Life is fleeting, empires crumble, and sometimes quiet mountains aren\u2019t quiet mountains at all.", "title": "The (Really) Old and New Meet in Naples", "authors": ["Jason Horowitz"]} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "Thank you for Jeneen Interlandi\u2019s insightful and well-researched study of early-childhood education. As first a teacher and then a union representative of teachers in the Springfield, Mass., area, I was impressed by how well her article captured the reality.\n\nTeachers like Kejo Kelly work incredibly hard for poverty wages. They are entrusted with developing the next generation of citizens, yet they are provided with no resources. The things we have tried \u2014 academic studies of the field, proclamations of how important young children are, requiring teachers to have degrees they can\u2019t afford and drowning teachers in paperwork \u2014 have only made matters worse. What we need is a serious investment in courageous teachers like Kejo (living wages; affordable, accessible education opportunities for teachers) and qualified support staff (speech language; occupational therapy; and counseling). Providing high-quality education to young children would provide many long-term benefits to society, but it would cost money. This would be a much wiser and more loving choice than tax breaks for the rich. Brooks Ballenger, Amherst, Mass.\n\nLike the teacher in Jeneen Interlandi\u2019s article, I took a pay cut to become a \u201cpreschool\u201d teacher. It shouldn\u2019t be necessary to make a financial sacrifice to take on a job that is among the most valuable in our country.\n\nPhoto\n\nWe live in a country where we will happily spend billions on football stadiums and weapons systems but won\u2019t spend a few thousands on our young people. We miss the point that our future lies in providing education and opportunity to our young. Rich language and thinking skills and abundant opportunities to apply those skills are our most valuable weapons systems. These are the tools on which we can build a prosperous future. But we\u2019ve got to invest now. Craig Overbeck, Fayetteville, N.Y.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nRE: PENCILS\n\nChristopher Payne and Sam Anderson went inside one of the world\u2019s last pencil factories.\n\nI am a teacher, so I see my students interact with pencils daily. Many students have writing-tool preferences, and I see a sad trend that many are moving to the mechanical pencil. Watching these ratcheting graphite guns replace the perfected design of the classic yellow No.2 is yet another reminder of how many are losing touch with intimate interactions with the natural world \u2014 even if it is through bringing form to thoughts using dead wood and a little carbon. Great photo essay! Dan Kafader, Wilmington, Del., on nytimes.com\n\nPhoto\n\nI grew up in Jersey City, less than a mile away from General Pencil, and the factory was a cornerstone of the Jersey City Heights area. Everyone knew someone who worked or had worked there, and as Jersey City went through its ups and downs in the \u201970s and \u201980s, my parents often said that it was one of the few businesses willing to stay committed to the city and its employees. This was a fascinating look into a world that I would have never imagined to be as unique and colorful as these pictures portray. Thanks for bringing back and enriching so many memories. Donna Loftus, Colleyville, Tex.", "title": "The 1.14.18 Issue", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nRE: JORDAN PEELE\n\nWesley Morris wrote about the director Jordan Peele and what his pivotal film \u201cGet Out\u201d says about racism in America.\n\nMorris speculates that \u201cGet Out\u201d might be \u201cabout the terror of black America accusing you of \u2018talking white,\u2019 \u201d but he should go deeper if he\u2019s pursuing this argument. I would argue that this \u201cterror\u201d points to the lack of the black character\u2019s recognition of having a colonized mind, of being in the very sunken place, or liable to fall into it, as well as the subsequent body-colonization and zombification, before the fact, that the film dramatizes. In a broader sense, I see the film as a critique, whether unconscious or not, of a certain kind of Western liberalism that ultimately fails to establish true social, political and economic equality, keeps whiteness in control and power and continues to subjugate black people and other people of color as a whole. It\u2019s not like conservatism or ultraconservatism, but does it truly end or destabilize white supremacy? The film suggests that it cannot. Peele\u2019s film is perhaps more profound than many people realize. John Keene, Jersey City\n\nI stayed after hours at work to read this article. So well written and palpable, and allowing the reader to feel and laugh and \u201csee.\u201d I\u2019m so down with this one, I\u2019m printing it out for friends. Yes to more of understanding and celebrating blackness in America. Yes to Jordan Peele and everyone else in his circles and orbits who bring his creativity and visions to life. CreativiTea, on nytimes.com\n\nRE: GITMO\n\nJeffrey E. There was and will be no shortage of tributes to Tom Petty or Chris Cornell and other famous deceased. But DeMarlon Thomas? Tragic. S. Allen Counter? How amazing! I\u2019m so happy to read about these people I didn\u2019t know about so I can learn about new things instead of reading even more about those we all already know.\n\nThank you for this excellent, diverse and thoughtful roundup.
