Regan Wood, Brooklyn", "title": "The 12.31.2017 Issue", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-31 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201c3 Giants Form Health Alliance, Rocking Insurers\u201d (front page, Jan. 31):\n\nBefore spending lots of time, effort and money developing a new health care \u201cproduct,\u201d Warren E. Buffett of Berkshire Hathaway, Jeff Bezos of Amazon and Jamie Dimon of JPMorgan Chase should realize that using a market approach to health care has failed miserably in this country.\n\nThey should go with Mr. Buffett\u2019s earlier assessment. He suggested that despite \u201climited knowledge,\u201d he thought that single payer is probably the best system, adding: \u201cWe are such a rich country. In a sense, we can afford to do it.\u201d\n\nInstead of reinventing the wheel, they should consult a group of experts who understand the needs of patients and populations and who have for many years studied the public policies that can best fulfill these needs. Physicians for a National Health Program, on whose board I sit, would be glad to oblige.\n\nELIZABETH R. ROSENTHAL\n\nLARCHMONT, N.Y.\n\nThe writer is a dermatologist.", "title": "Opinion | The 3 Giants\u2019 Health Plan", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-08 00:00:00", "text": "It sounded like a dream job to many: one that would take a traveler to all 52 destinations on this year\u2019s Places to Go list. We received over 13,000 applications from an amazing variety of people, from a father-daughter team to a best-selling author. (We heard all about the submission process in a Q. and A. with Monica Drake, then the Travel editor.) Above is a look at some of those applicants. We will announce the winner, along with the full list of destinations, later this week.", "title": "The 52 Places Traveler: Meet the Applicants", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "Ms. Lockert\u2019s story is a good example of resilience, but it\u2019s a type of resilience that changes you and makes you grow. It\u2019s what the authors Stephanie and Ama Marston call \u201ctransformative resilience.\u201d In their book, \u201cType R: Transformative Resilience for Thriving in a Turbulent World,\u201d they argue that the way we generally think about resilience, as \u201cbouncing back,\u201d doesn\u2019t get us anywhere. Instead, we can use our setbacks as opportunities to better operate in and positively affect the world around us.\n\n\u201cAt some point, all of us, no matter what our socioeconomic background is, what our age is, what our situation is, we\u2019re going to go through a challenging circumstance,\u201d Stephanie Marston, a psychotherapist, said. \u201cSo how do we use those to our advantage?\u201d\n\nWhereas resilience is the ability to move on despite a setback, transformative resilience is the ability to improve because of a setback. Had Ms. Lockert simply recovered from her student debt crisis without learning the crucial lessons she did, she might have made the same financial mistakes again, never reflecting on what should be different.\n\nAfter interviewing hundreds of people like Ms. Lockert over the past 30 years and studying the phenomenon with her daughter, Stephanie Marston, along with her daughter, Ama, discovered that people typically experience six distinct stages of turning adversity into growth. These stages apply to groups, organizations, families and communities as well as individuals.\n\nStage 1: You\u2019re in your comfort zone ...\n\nBefore there is a storm, of course, there is calm.\n\n\u201cEach of us finds our place in the world,\u201d the authors write. \u201cWe allow ourselves to be defined by the structures and systems we\u2019ve put in place, from our job titles and accomplishments, to our partnerships, families, and the houses in which we live.\u201d", "title": "The 6 Steps to Turning Setbacks Into Advantages", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "MARANA, Ariz. \u2014 There may be no airliner as recognizable as the Boeing 747, the world\u2019s first jumbo jet, with its iconic hump of an upper deck. For aviation fans, the introduction of the \u201cQueen of the Skies\u201d was a triumph of engineering and grace: unprecedented size and speed with spiral-staircase international glamour.\n\nBut the airline business has changed, and the giant plane has become more expensive to operate. A couple of weeks ago, the final 747 flight by any commercial United States airline took to the sky.\n\nLike so many others before it, the plane was heading to the Southwest to retire.", "title": "The 747 Had a Great Run. But Farewell Doesn\u2019t Mean the End.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nAfter being in operation for almost a quarter of a century, the Actors Company Theater has announced that it will close this year.\n\nOn Friday, the company said that \u201cThree Wise Guys\u201d would be its final production. The play is scheduled to run from Feb. 28 to April 14 at the Beckett Theater at Theater Row.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Subscribe to the Theater Newsletter Every week, stay on top of the latest news, interviews and reviews from Broadway and beyond. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nScott Alan Evans, the company\u2019s artistic executive director, said by phone that the theater\u2019s leadership had decided it would be better to close while the company was successful rather than attempt to fill artistic vacancies that have occurred over the years. He said the city is no longer lacking in theater groups dedicated to under-appreciated and rarely seen plays, as it was when the Actors Company was founded in 1992. This, too, contributed to the decision.\n\nIn a statement Mr. Evans said, \u201cWe are proud to have actually fulfilled what we set out to do: to create an artistic home for a company of theater artists that reveals, reclaims and reimagines great plays of literary merit, creating an intimate theater experience for its audience by focusing on the text and the actor\u2019s ability to bring it to life.\u201d\n\nThe troupe\u2019s final production is based on two Damon Runyon stories, \u201cThe Three Wise Guys\u201d and \u201cDancing Dan\u2019s Christmas.\u201d The play, written by Mr. Evans and Jeffrey Couchman, is a comedy about three New Yorkers who flee the city to avoid a racketeer they\u2019ve run afoul of. It was developed for the troupe as part of its new play program.\n\nMore information is available at tactnyc.org.", "title": "The Actors Company Theater Set to Close This Year", "authors": ["Peter Libbey"]} {"date": "2018-01-02 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cSweden Adds Human Touch to a Robotic Future\u201d (front page, Dec. 28):\n\nThe record year we\u2019ve enjoyed here in North America at Brokk, a Swedish-owned manufacturer of demolition robots, reflects three macro trends: Our construction customers are finding it increasingly challenging to find labor willing to do the difficult and often dangerous work; the labor that is willing to do the work is aging out and suffering physically; and workers\u2019 compensation costs are crippling.\n\nAdd the inherent safety advantages of doing construction, mining, tunneling or nuclear work with robots, and the outcome seems inevitable. Those who embrace the technology appropriately will prevail in the marketplace.\n\nPETER BIGWOOD\n\nNORTHAMPTON, MASS.\n\nThe writer is vice president of sales and marketing for Brokk.", "title": "Opinion | The Advantages of Robots", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-06 00:00:00", "text": "The model-minority myth exists alongside another dangerous and limiting idea \u2014 one that is consistent with the alt-right\u2019s misogyny and core anti-feminist values. The main problem with white women, as many alt-right Asian fetishists have noted, is they\u2019ve become too feminist. By contrast, Asian women are seen as naturally inclined to serve men sexually and are also thought of as slim, light-skinned and small, in adherence to Western norms of femininity.\n\nThese stereotypes have roots in America\u2019s postwar military incursions into Asia. In Japan, a network of brothels permitted by American officials opened as United States troops began arriving in August 1945. The brothels employed tens of thousands of women until Gen. Douglas MacArthur declared them off limits in 1946.\n\nIn South Korea, an estimated 300,000 women were working in the sex trade by 1958 (after the end of the Korean War), with more than half employed in the \u201ccamptowns\u201d around the American bases. Vietnam\u2019s sex industry, centered largely on American bars, thrived during the Vietnam War. And the stereotype of docile Asian women persists. Nowhere is this more explicit than in sex ads and online pornography.\n\nTila Tequila \u2014 Playboy model, reality show star, aspiring rapper and one of a handful of female Asian-American celebrities \u2014 is often seen through this trope. Does she resent being typecast as the hot, horny Asian as much as I resented being seen as a \u201cmodel minority\u201d?\n\nYet after I was called \u201cwhite\u201d at age 14, it felt, paradoxically, like a compliment to be nicknamed Geisha Girl by another friend, a well-meaning gay white boy. This was not because I was delicate. But the nickname became our inside joke, and it symbolized the kind of femininity that attracted the boys I liked, but that I have never really possessed. Being in on the joke meant I was accepted. Since then, I have acted out in all manner of ways to dispel the \u201cmodel minority\u201d image. Still, I have never fully extinguished the belief that racking up an impressive lineup of achievements is the only way to gain respect.\n\nThe stereotypes that feed the Asian-woman fetish are not exclusive to the far right. They exist across the political spectrum and infect every aspect of life \u2014 not just the bedroom \u2014 and manifest themselves in figures as distant from America as the blond-haired, blue-eyed heroes and hypersexualized heroines of Japanese anime.\n\nThis fun-house mirror asks me to be smarter, nicer, prettier and more accomplished than my white counterparts for the same amount of respect, then floods my dating app inbox with messages that reek of Asian fetish. Thankfully, I\u2019m not required to care or let it define me; for what it\u2019s worth, I am even entitled to play up the stereotypes if I see something to be gained. Maybe this is where the Asian girlfriends of alt-right men stand. But none of us can escape the truth that the fun-house was built to justify systematic exploitation of everyone in this country who isn\u2019t white. That\u2019s important context. Otherwise, Richard Spencer\u2019s comments could almost sound nice.\n\n\u201cThere is something about the Asian girls,\u201d he once said to Mother Jones. \u201cThey are cute. They are smart. They have a kind of thing going on.\u201d", "title": "Opinion | The Alt-Right\u2019s Asian Fetish", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "As the fighting continued, Lansdale\u2019s villa at 194 Cong Ly Street took on, in his words, a \u201cgypsy air.\u201d Most of the Vietnamese household staff were not around because of the Tet holiday, so Lansdale and his two American aides had to scrounge for food and cook for themselves. One of his men liberated a supply of bread from the Brinks Hotel, which was being used as American bachelor officers\u2019 quarters. Lansdale and his men visited their Vietnamese friends, trapped in their houses, to bring them the contraband bread.\n\nAmbassador Bunker, nicknamed Old Man Refrigerator by the Vietnamese for his cool demeanor, came to Lansdale\u2019s house with his security detail to spend a night after his own residence was deemed insecure. Lansdale noted that the ambassador, after taking a nap, \u201cbecame acquainted with our F.O.V. cognac from Hong Kong for the first time.\u201d Lansdale also took in some Vietnamese refugees rendered homeless by the fighting \u2014 a former cook and her young daughter and niece. To celebrate Lansdale\u2019s 60th birthday on Feb. 6, friends and family sent food as gifts, ranging from a salami to San Miguel beer. \u201cSo,\u201d Lansdale wrote, \u201csome of the meetings at Cong Ly lacked the usual Vietnamese spirit of grand tragedy, looking more like old-fashioned picnics.\u201d\n\nIn the end, the Tet offensive did not succeed in igniting a general uprising, as Communist leaders had hoped. Official American statistics showed 58,373 enemy dead between Jan. 29 and March 1, 1968, compared with 3,895 American combat deaths, 4,954 South Vietnamese troops and 14,300 South Vietnamese civilians. American generals claimed this was a decisive defeat for the Vietcong. Lansdale, naturally, saw things differently.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Subscribe to the Vietnam \u201967 Newsletter This weekly newsletter includes eyewitness accounts, rare photos and historical insights about the Vietnam War. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nHe conceded that the enemy \u201chas been crushed militarily,\u201d but he warned on March 27, 1968, that the offensive had the potential to achieve Hanoi\u2019s objectives: It could strike \u201cfear into the hearts of the urban population by demonstrating the inability of the government to provide adequate security,\u201d and it could increase \u201cpressure on the U.S. at home and abroad to withdraw, by seeking to demonstrate the hopelessness of victory and the immorality of our cause (for example, the image of U.S. firepower destroying friendly Vietnamese cities).\u201d \u201cThe emotional factor in the Viet-Nam war has grown to immense size since the shock of the Tet offensive,\u201d Lansdale warned. In the coming months, \u201cit promises to become the real pivot factor.\u201d\n\nOnce again, Lansdale perceived more than most of his rivals in Saigon and back in Washington, who wrote him off as a dreamer and a has-been. The shock of Tet persuaded President Johnson to refuse Westmoreland\u2019s pleas for 200,000 more troops and to bring Westmoreland home to become Army chief of staff. Then, in a dramatic TV address on March 31, Johnson announced that instead of seeking re-election, he would apply all his energy toward bringing the war to an end.\n\nThe American quest for victory in Vietnam was over; the only question now was the pace of disengagement. But there was still plenty of fighting to come \u2014 more Americans would die after Tet than before \u2014 and Lansdale witnessed his share of it during the final months of his deployment.\n\nOn May 4, 1968, the Vietcong struck again across the South in what came to be known as Mini-Tet. \u201cAs during the Tet attacks,\u201d Lansdale wrote, \u201call the flowering trees and shrubs are still in bloom. Somehow, their beauty just makes the rest of it more ugly than ever.\u201d This attack, too, was repelled with heavy losses. But Lansdale was appalled by the level of destruction inflicted by the American counteroffensive.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHis aide, Charlie Sweet, visited a working-class section of Saigon known as District Eight and was startled by \u201cthe deep anger against all Americans\u201d because of the heavy firepower that American forces were employing against the 200 or so Vietcong guerrillas who had infiltrated their neighborhood. \u201cTwo hundred houses were being destroyed for every Vietcong killed,\u201d one man complained. The fighting in District Eight would destroy more than 5,000 buildings, kill more than 200 civilians, wound 2,000 more and create 40,000 refugees. \u201cI hope we never use these tactics in riots in the U.S.,\u201d Lansdale wrote, \u201cor we will lose all of our cities.\u201d\n\nSweet\u2019s memo about District Eight \u201cresonated,\u201d Defense Secretary Clark Clifford later wrote, and it led Westmoreland\u2019s successor, Gen. Creighton Abrams, to curtail the use of air and artillery strikes. This was part of Abrams\u2019s attempt to wage what one historian has called a \u201cbetter war,\u201d but it was too late: The American public had already turned against the war.\n\nBy mid-June 1968, when Lansdale was due to leave Vietnam for the last time, Saigon remained a city under siege. He noted: \u201cMasses of barbed wire, now rusting under the rains that had come with May, clogged streets here and there about the town. Trash and garbage were being heaped on the pavements, as public services slowed.\u201d Vietcong rockets were crashing into the capital, killing and wounding hundreds. \u201cThe blind caprice of enemy gunners,\u201d he added, \u201cmade each inhabitant feel that he might be the next target.\u201d\n\nAs he departed from Tan Son Nhut Airport on June 16, 1968, Lansdale tried to put on a brave face, but he knew that the war was being lost. Years later, he expressed \u201ca deep-seated feeling of grief over my failure to accomplish enough in my 1965-1968 service in Vietnam to have helped the people there prevent the tragedy which eventually overcame them.\u201d\n\nLansdale lived until 1987, and he would believe to his dying day that if only his advice \u2014 to focus more on politics and less on firepower \u2014 had been followed, America might have avoided a quagmire. There is no way to know whether he was right, and certainly North Vietnam would have been a formidable foe under any circumstances, with greater will to win than the United States. But it\u2019s hard to imagine that the path America did take \u2014 a defeat involving 58,000 dead Americans and millions of dead Vietnamese \u2014 was a superior alternative.", "title": "The American Who Predicted Tet", "authors": ["Max Boot"]} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cManagers don\u2019t last very long down there,\u201d Tarasco said in a recent interview. \u201cIt\u2019s like duck, duck, goose.\u201d\n\nStill, Gonzalez and Salvador Quirarte, the Charros\u2019 owner, retained Dahbura, finding value, for now, in his analytics.\n\nGuadalajara, where the Charros play, will host the Caribbean Series, a contest for the champions of the Puerto Rican, Dominican, Venezuelan and Mexican leagues, in February, and the two men seem to want every possible advantage to help their team be Mexico\u2019s representative.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Dahbura, who bought a piece of the Suns in 2010, was known in baseball circles as Shag, for his penchant for shagging fly balls during batting practice to get a workout.\n\nDahbura and Tarasco bonded over a shared passion for the analytical threads underpinning the game, and Tarasco marveled at Dahbura\u2019s background.\n\nBorn in the United States, Dahbura moved with his family to El Salvador when he was a young boy because his father was doing business there. His love of baseball led him to announce the 1976 World Series on national television in El Salvador \u2014 at age 16.\n\nIn college at Johns Hopkins, where he studied computer science and is now on the faculty in that field, he was an outfielder for the team.\n\nHe eventually began his own analytics consulting business with his wife, who has a baseball lineage, too. Her uncle was Bobby Hofman, an infielder for the New York Giants in the 1950s, and she and Dahbura bonded over their mutual love of the game.\n\nWhen Tarasco began managing the Charros in October, Dahbura would send detailed reports from his home in Maryland and, at Tarasco\u2019s request, three possible lineups the night before each game \u2014 one conservative, one middle-of-the-road and one radical. The exhibition \u201cPicasso Ceramics\u201d (Feb. 1 to May 27) includes 150 ceramics that reflect an experimental stage of the artist\u2019s career as he worked with new materials and glazes to create a range of sculptural pieces.\n\nPolitics is the topic of a coming exhibition at SITE Santa Fe in New Mexico. But what did you expect? Trump\u2019s whole business career has been a series of betrayals \u2014 failed business ventures from which he personally profited while others, whether they were Trump University students, vendors or creditors, ended up holding the bag. And he hasn\u2019t grown a bit in office, unless you count that mysterious extra inch.\n\nThere are two things you need to realize about Trump\u2019s utter unreliability. First, it has ramifications that go far beyond the recent shutdown. Second, it\u2019s made possible, or at least much worse, by his enablers in Congress.\n\nThink, for example, about the international consequences of a U.S. president whose word can\u2019t be trusted. Who can we count on to be a reliable ally, when no country knows whether America will stand by it if it needs help?\n\nSo far, at least, financial markets continue to regard the U.S. government as trustworthy, even though during the 2016 campaign Trump openly talked about forcing the nation\u2019s creditors \u2014 like creditors of some of his businesses \u2014 to accept less than they were owed. But does this government have any reserve of financial credibility if something should go wrong? Probably not.\n\nIn other words, Trump\u2019s unreliability is a big problem, over and above the substance of his policies. But here\u2019s the funny thing: While his instincts are clearly autocratic, the Constitution doesn\u2019t set him above the law. Congress has the power to constrain his actions, to force him to honor promises. His ability to keep betraying those who trust him depends entirely on the willingness of Republicans in Congress to go along.\n\nFor example, any two of the Republican senators currently wringing their hands over the betrayal of the Dreamers could have forced action by withholding their votes on the Trump tax cut. They didn\u2019t. Similar inaction explains why Trump has been able to violate all previous norms against exploiting his office for personal gain, and much more.\n\nThe result is that promises from the U.S. government are now as worthless as those from a tinpot dictator. We don\u2019t yet know how high a price we\u2019ll pay for that loss of credibility, but it probably won\u2019t be small.", "title": "Opinion | The Art of the Broken Deal", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "Ms. Napoleone recently gave an art tour of her home, wearing a baseball cap (\u201cbad hair day\u201d) and Yves Saint Laurent platform sandals (with dark pink socks). Above the living room fireplace is Nicole Eisenman\u2019s \u201cSaggy Titties\u201d (2007), the protuberant portrait of a topless woman whose breasts drop slightly below the edge of the canvas. Beside it is Margherita Manzelli\u2019s \u201cNeobros\u201d (1998), in which a woman with pigtails sits on a stool with her tights rolled down to her knees.\n\nThe bed in the middle of Ms. Napoleone\u2019s upstairs bedroom is also a commission: from Nanda Vigo, an Italian artist and designer who, in her early 80s, is finally getting more widespread recognition. It has a lit, mirrored frame and a fake-fur cover.\n\n\u201cMy collection is about liberating women,\u201d she explained. The following are edited excerpts from the conversation.\n\nWhy collect only female artists?\n\nI\u2019m a feminist, believing in equal opportunities. I was aware of the fact that women artists were not considered for gallery or museum representation and were dismissed, underrepresented. I couldn\u2019t figure out why we were missing so much talent just because of gender. From the very first piece, I told myself: \u201cI\u2019m going to create a collection only of female voices. I want to create a choir of voices of females who have been unheard, who have been silenced.\u201d\n\nCan you talk about the Nicole Eisenman work above your fireplace?\n\nIt\u2019s a matriarch, a female nude. It has the pretense of being important, in its size but also its presence, as would any portrait of a famous or important man. But it has a sense of humor \u2014 the smile, the eyes \u2014 and it\u2019s also so incredibly painted.", "title": "The Art on Her Walls Echoes Her Mission: Backing Bold Works by Women", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "ROME \u2014 The tormented artist Amedeo Modigliani is beloved both by art aficionados and forgers.\n\nNow, an art expert has written a report, leaked by the Italian news media, for state prosecutors that says a third of the works in a popular Modigliani exhibition last year in Genoa, Italy, are fakes.\n\nThe expert, Isabella Quattrocchi, said that seven drawings and eight oil paintings by Modigliani, as well as six oil paintings attributed to his friend and sometime collaborator, Moise Kisling, were not authentic. The art works were lent by private collectors and museums in Italy, Switzerland, Israel, Argentina and the United States.\n\nMs. Quattrocchi said in the report that the works had been \u201ccrudely forged,\u201d \u201cboth in terms of style and pigments,\u201d according to the news agency ANSA. She also wrote that the frames came from Eastern Europe and the United States, and had little to do with Modigliani in terms of context and historical period, ANSA reported this week.\n\nMs. Quattrocchi, an independent art expert, wrote her report for prosecutors in Genoa. Three people are formally under investigation, including Rudy Chiappini, the curator of the Genoa show, which ran for four months last year at the Palazzo Ducale, a prestigious exhibition venue \u2014 but no one has been charged. The exhibition was shut down three days early, after art experts began questioning the works. Ms. Quattrocchi and the Genoa prosecutor\u2019s office did not respond immediately to requests for an interview.", "title": "The Authenticity of Modigliani Paintings Questioned Once Again", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-16 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nFor almost a decade, The Awl implored the world to \u201cBe Less Stupid.\u201d There was a \u201cgreat big internet\u201d out there, the editors cautioned. And by writing intelligently about offbeat topics \u2014 from a locket meant to hold \u201cmad money\u201d to a deeply unsatisfying West Elm couch called \u201cthe Peggy\u201d \u2014 The Awl and its sister sites did their best to live up to the motto.\n\nOn Tuesday, though, editors of The Awl and one of the sister sites, The Hairpin, announced that the end had come. Statements on the sites said editorial operations would cease at the end of January.\n\nThe closings represent yet another loss for independent publishers that have long struggled to compete with larger ones, which can offer ad buyers a wider audience. And in an email, The Awl\u2019s publisher, Michael Macher, said that \u201ca steady decline in direct sales\u201d was \u201cthe root cause\u201d for closing.\n\n\u201cWe followed a dream of building a better internet, and though we did not manage to do that every day we tried very hard and we hope you don\u2019t blame us for how things ultimately turned out,\u201d one of the statements said. \u201cThe greatest achievement any site can claim is in the quality and fervor of its audience, and on that score we feel like we were the most successful organization ever.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe Awl\u2019s other sister sites, The Billfold and Splitsider, are not ceasing publication, Mr. Macher said, noting that \u201cit\u2019s business as usual in terms of publishing cadence and partnerships\u201d for both properties.", "title": "The Awl and The Hairpin, Eccentric Showcases for Writers, Are Shutting Down", "authors": ["Matt Stevens"]} {"date": "2018-01-03 00:00:00", "text": "The music was jolting and idiosyncratic and kind of maddening, in that it didn\u2019t directly resemble any particular influence. Where was this coming from? It didn\u2019t sound like the new-thing jazz of the 1960s, or glam rock, or a film soundtrack, or 19th-century Impressionism, though that was all source material. This became especially striking on its covers of pop and rock tunes like \u201cTeen Spirit\u201d and Black Sabbath\u2019s \u201cIron Man.\u201d The band didn\u2019t use jazz rhythms or cocktail harmonies, but it didn\u2019t just scale down the original songs either.\n\nThere are no covers on \u201cNever Stop II,\u201d which is not surprising; the Bad Plus has made albums of entirely original music before. (\u201cNever Stop,\u201d from 2010, was its first.) More notable is Mr. Evans\u2019s effect on his new comrades\u2019 compositions. The group\u2019s first five records (through \u201cProg,\u201d in 2007) found Mr. Iverson in constant tension with his band mates, creating dizzy urgency. His playing is crisp and vertical and grandiose; he often seemed to be headed toward some big argument about finality, or totalistic power. In many of the band\u2019s most exciting moments, that symphonic style \u2014 drawn from both Keith Jarrett and Benjamin Britten \u2014 scoured hard against the restless surge of Mr. King\u2019s drumming, which mixed busted Afro-Cuban rhythms with kinky rock shuffles. Mr. Anderson, with a big bass sound and a narrative impulse, synced up closely with Mr. King, giving Mr. Iverson a thick cushion.\n\nBut over the past 10 years, the group\u2019s approach became rather fixed, and the tension relented, even as the Bad Plus often introduced new collaborators. On albums like \u201cMade Possible\u201d (2012) and \u201cInevitable Western\u201d (2014), lullaby-like melodies sometimes felt too easy to get along with. Perhaps the three musicians knew too well what to expect from each other \u2014 or as good will dissipated, so did the willingness to inspirit each other.", "title": "The Bad Plus Greet the New Year With a New Lineup", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 The European Union is the West\u2019s last line of defense. The United States has historically been the world\u2019s anchor of republican ideals, but President Trump has abandoned the role, openly admiring strongmen like Vladimir Putin of Russia. As the temptations of nationalist populism spread, Europe has responsibility for holding down the Western fort. The primary battle right now is over Poland, which is deepening its descent into illiberalism. The European Union needs to take a firm stand in defense of Western values.\n\nSince coming to power in 2015, Poland\u2019s populist government has sought to control the news media, purged and politicized the civil service, and intimidated intellectuals and civil society organizations. Three weeks ago, Poland\u2019s president signed into law legislation that compromises judicial independence, effectively clearing the way for the ruling Law and Justice party to stack the courts.\n\nIn response, Brussels has taken the right steps, warning Warsaw of punishment if it continues to pursue policies inconsistent with the European Union\u2019s founding principles, which include \u201cdemocracy, equality, the rule of law and respect for human rights.\u201d In late December, the European Commission for the first time in the union\u2019s history started a formal procedure that could lead to disciplinary sanctions, including the suspension of Poland\u2019s voting rights in the European Union\u2019s main decision-making body.\n\nThese measures have not gone unnoticed in Warsaw. This week, Prime Minister Mateusz Morawiecki reshuffled his cabinet, replacing a number of ministers whose relationships with European leaders were particularly strained. And he flew to Brussels for dinner with Jean-Claude Juncker, the president of the European Commission. But these moves have yet to be accompanied by any concrete steps to reverse Poland\u2019s illiberal turn. The European Union must keep the pressure on.", "title": "Opinion | The Battle Line for Western Values Runs Through Poland", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-07 00:00:00", "text": "ROME \u2014 For generations of Romans, Epiphany, not Christmas, was the holiday season\u2019s main day for receiving gifts. They are dispensed overnight, according to Italian folklore, by the Befana, a broom-riding old hag with a strict naughty-or-nice ethic. To fall on her wrong side was to wake up on Jan. 6 to a stocking full of coal.\n\nThe Befana\u2019s traditional headquarters \u2014 a kiosk-filled market in the central Piazza Navona here where vendors hawk trinkets, toys and sticky sweets \u2014 was a beloved annual pilgrimage, a kid-magnet of excitement, fun and sugar highs.\n\nThis year, Roman families turned out as usual, many with strollers in tow, on a sunny and warm Saturday. But it was evident that times had changed, and a cloud hung over the market.\n\nConcerns about terrorism had choked off the event, and as lines formed at the entrances to the elegant Baroque square, police and carabinieri officers stood at steel barriers. Agents wielding metal detectors scanned knapsacks under the startled gaze of wide-eyed children. Earlier in the week, the square had been placed under \u201cspecial surveillance.\u201d", "title": "The Befana Market, a Beloved Roman Tradition, Is Imperiled", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "Roughly the same size as the 6-foot-6, 28-year-old Gronkowski, Zo was Gronk long before Gronkowski ever guzzled from a beer bong. Belichick was asked during a break in the taping of his show what Zolak, now 50, was like at that age.\n\nBelichick paused, smiled and said diplomatically, \u201cWe\u2019ve all matured.\u201d\n\nBut while Zolak may sound like an over-the-top homer to a Patriots hater, his commentary is mostly fair and often instructive. That might explain why Belichick respects and trusts him enough to collaborate.\n\nThe two men met in 1996, when Belichick joined the Patriots\u2019 staff as the assistant head coach to Bill Parcells, nominally responsible for the defensive backs. In that pre-dynastic iteration of the Patriots, Zolak was Drew Bledsoe\u2019s rowdy backup and the extra hand who ran the scout team for Belichick\u2019s defensive backs, impersonating the opposing quarterback in practices.\n\n\u201cI worked closer with him at that time than I did with Drew,\u201d Belichick said during a break in the taping of the show. \u201cHe was great at it. He knew the game, he\u2019s smart and he always had a great sense of humor. Everyone got along with him, plus he could throw the hell out of the ball.\u201d\n\nFrom the other side, Zolak witnessed Belichick\u2019s mind-boggling attention to detail.\n\n\u201cIf we were playing the Dolphins, I had to wear No. 13 just like Dan Marino,\u201d Zolak said. \u201cI had to have the sleeves cut off like Dan and wear the same face mask. Bill told me where Marino put his hands at his belt. He wanted the exact same mannerisms.\u201d\n\nBefore a game against the Broncos that year, Belichick admonished Zolak for failing to accurately capture John Elway\u2019s cadence at the line of scrimmage. \u201cNo, no, it\u2019s \u2018set HUT,\u2019\u201d Belichick instructed. To the coach, even something as microscopic as emphasizing the proper syllable in a scout-team drill was worth doing correctly.", "title": "The Belichick Whisperer", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "Cl\u00e9mence von Mueffling, the Paris-born editor of Beauty and Well Being, remembers the first time she heard about Martine de Richeville. \u201cI was told she had \u2018magic\u2019 hands and could help with cellulite and heavy legs,\u201d von Mueffling says of the French therapist with a discreet fashion-crowd following. \u201cAt the time, her name was like a secret that only a very good friend would give you.\u201d De Richeville specializes in r\u00e9modelage, a technique that involves pinching and kneading to break up fat deposits and flush toxins through lymphatic drainage. (\u201cIt definitely feels a little painful,\u201d von Mueffling concedes.) With regular sessions, devotees notice a slimmer, tighter silhouette. Or as von Mueffling explains, \u201cit\u2019s as if she puts your body in \u2018restart\u2019 mode.\u201d\n\nWhile this sounds like the stuff of French myth, the results are actually quite real. The New York-based dermatologist Dr. Ellen Marmur says that manual remodeling delivers \u201ca major circulation boost,\u201d adding that de Richeville\u2019s combination of massage and acupressure can \u201cimprove oxygenation, reduce pain, relax muscles and possibly allow for better realignment and rejuvenation of the body.\u201d In fact, Dr. Marmur describes the method as similar to one physical therapists use to help speed healing and increase tone. Patients, she says, \u201crave about it.\u201d\n\nWith all the growing enthusiasm, it\u2019s no surprise that the secret about de Richeville is out \u2014 the veteran practitioner now flies from Paris to New York City every few months to perform her signature treatment at a newly opened space within Saks Downtown. In between visits, clients can see Fatima Zegrani, her trained therapist. But for those who live outside the areas de Richeville services, there are a growing number of at-home body-contouring devices hitting the market.\n\nThe Fascia Blaster ($89), for example, is a self-treatment tool first developed for professional athletes that\u2019s now being embraced by wellness enthusiasts. The baton-like stick is covered with nubs or claws that, when rolled over your body, help loosen the fascia \u2014 the connective tissue around muscles and organs \u2014 to ease stiffness and, as an added bonus, dimpling of the skin that can lead to cellulite. Or consider the NuBody ($399, out in January), a spinoff of the popular NuFace micro-current device with spheres that emit low-level, painless currents to lift and firm multiple zones \u2014 currently it\u2019s cleared by the F.D.A. to treat the arms, abs, thighs and buttocks.", "title": "The Beloved French Practice of Body-Contouring Spreads Stateside", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "Paris couture week remained its usual feast for the eyes, from Giambattista Valli\u2019s cinched mounds of tulle to fluttery Philip Treacy headpieces atop Valentino models, not to mention Iris van Herpen\u2019s otherworldly 3-D printed dresses. There were, however, some very 2018 updates, like temporary neck tattoos courtesy of Christian Dior, an array of gowns with pockets at Chanel and Proenza Schouler\u2019s latest ready-to-wear collection off-schedule (as is the mode). See all of this and more, as captured by T photographers, in our slide show.", "title": "The Best Images from the Haute Couture Shows", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-02 00:00:00", "text": "Watching is The New York Times\u2019s TV and film recommendation website. Sign up for our thrice-weekly newsletter here.\n\nEvery month, Netflix Canada adds a new batch of movies and TV shows to its library. Here are the titles we think are most interesting for January, broken down by release date. Netflix occasionally changes schedules without giving notice. (Unfortunately, streaming information provided in our Watchlist listings applies only to viewers in the United States.)\n\n\u2018The Age of Shadows\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: Jan. 1\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nKim Jee-woon established a reputation as one of South Korea\u2019s premier directors with films like \u201cA Tale of Two Sisters,\u201d \u201cThe Good, the Bad, the Weird\u201d and \u201cI Saw the Devil.\u201d After making the Hollywood flop \u201cThe Last Stand,\u201d Kim returned to home turf with the period thriller \u201cThe Age of Shadows,\u201d but he didn\u2019t curb his ambitions. Set in the sumptuously realized world of Seoul in the 1920s, the film follows a group of Korean resistance fighters as they gather explosives for an attack on Japanese targets, risking exposure by enemy agents.\n\n\u2014\n\n\u2018Superbad\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: Jan. 1\n\nJan. 1 Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nThe screenwriting partners Seth Rogen and Evan Goldberg (\u201cPineapple Express,\u201d \u201cThis Is the End\u201d) dusted off a script they conceived as teenagers to create this 2007 revival of \u201980s high-school comedies. Jonah Hill and Michael Cera star in it as two high-school seniors who seek to end their virginity at a house party but get sidetracked along the way. (Their desperate reliance on their buddy\u2019s fake I.D., which states his name simply as \u201cMcLovin,\u201d is one of the film\u2019s most enduring gags.) Hill and Cera are a terrific comic team \u2014 one crude and aggressive, the other hopelessly put-upon \u2014 but \u201cSuperbad\u201d is distinguished most by the sincerity that underscores its humor.\n\n\u2014\n\n\u2018Super Dark Times\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: Jan. 1\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nAmong the most promising debut features of 2017, \u201cSuper Dark Times\u201d treats the year 1995 with the attentiveness of a nostalgia piece like \u201cStand by Me,\u201d although the memories here are more traumatizing than bittersweet. Owen Campbell and Charlie Tahan star as teenage best friends from upstate New York who watch an idle afternoon go tragically awry when one of them accidentally slays a classmate with a samurai sword. The effort to cover up the killing drives a wedge between the friends, and as the film gets progressively grimmer, director Kevin Phillips swathes the small-town exteriors in a cold gray that effectively mirrors the action.\n\n\u2014\n\n0\n\n\u2018The Babadook\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: Jan. 1\n\nJan. 1 Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nIn her auspicious debut feature, writer-director Jennifer Kent offers up a spooky nemesis in the form of the Babadook, a dark and malevolent creature sprung from the pages of a pop-up book. The film\u2019s nerviest element, though, might be maternal ambivalence: Essie Davis stars as a stressed-out mother who lost her husband in an accident en route to the delivery room, and her lingering resentment toward their 6-year-old son is part of what brings this storybook demon to life. Kent delivers the expected genre shocks, but it\u2019s the tortured family dynamic that makes the film special.\n\n\u2014\n\n\u2018The Rehearsal\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: Jan. 1\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nIt took over 15 years for director Alison Maclean to follow up her excellent feature from 2000, \u201cJesus\u2019 Son,\u201d but \u201cThe Rehearsal\u201d is a welcome and confident return. Set at a prestigious New Zealand drama school, the film is notable mainly for Kerry Fox\u2019s performance as an instructor with standards as exacting as those of J.K. Simmons\u2019s character in \u201cWhiplash,\u201d and a moral turpitude that nearly brings down the entire program. The action builds toward an original performance in front of an audience that includes agents, and the pressure to deliver is so immense that a group of students turns to a questionable source for inspiration.\n\n\u2014\n\n\u2018A Ghost Story\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: Jan. 3\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nThe ghost in this minimalist indie drama by David Lowery (\u201cPete\u2019s Dragon\u201d) dons a white sheet with two eyeholes, like the world\u2019s least creative Halloween costume. But it isn\u2019t out to scare anybody and neither is the film. Instead, \u201cA Ghost Story\u201d is about a dead man (Casey Affleck) who sticks around his home after he dies to observe what happens as his wife (Rooney Mara) mourns and moves on, and as the house changes ownership over the years. Lowery pulls off the neat trick of crafting a somber haunted-house movie from the ghost\u2019s perspective, and his experiments with time are particularly revelatory.\n\n\u2014\n\n\u2018The Polka King\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: Jan. 12\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nNetflix picked up the rights to this film starring Jack Black at Sundance, where it won some acclaim as a stranger-than-fiction biopic in the mold of Richard Linklater\u2019s dark comedy \u201cBernie,\u201d which also starred Black. In \u201cThe Polka King,\u201d Black plays Jan Lewan, a Polish polka singer who landed in prison after running a Ponzi scheme in Pennsylvania. \u201cThe Polka King\u201d chronicles his rise and fall, including his relationship with his wife (Jenny Slate), a former Miss Junior Pennsylvania, and his efforts to convince fans to invest in an expansion of his empire, which winds up taking the form of a sloppily conceived fraud.\n\n\u2014\n\n\u2018Carol\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: Jan. 14\n\nJan. 14 Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nTodd Haynes\u2019s impeccable adaptation of Patricia Highsmith\u2019s novel \u201cThe Price of Salt\u201d (originally published under the pseudonym Claire Morgan) continues the theme of stifled female domesticity that he has visited time and again in films like \u201cSafe,\u201d \u201cFar From Heaven\u201d and \u201cMildred Pierce.\u201d Here, it\u2019s Cate Blanchett, who suffers beautifully as Carol, a wealthy, dissatisfied housewife in 1950s New York who finds herself romantically drawn to a department store clerk (Rooney Mara). But the times \u2014 and Carol\u2019s husband, played by Kyle Chandler \u2014 are unsympathetic, forcing the couple to make some difficult choices.\n\n\u2014\n\n\u2018Dear White People\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: Jan. 18\n\nJan. 18 Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nBefore it was a Netflix series, \u201cDear White People\u201d was this 2014 campus satire in the mode of Spike Lee\u2019s \u201cSchool Daze\u201d about a black student (Tessa Thompson) whose radio show sparks uproar on the mostly white campus of Winchester University. The film\u2019s writer and director, Justin Simien, uses his heroine\u2019s radio monologues and a fiercely contested student election to expose casual and not-so-casual instances of college racism. The tart one-liners and the bright, irreverent tone makes the politics go down easy, and Teyonah Parris makes a particularly vivid impression as an aspiring reality-show star whose brazenness masks a hidden vulnerability.\n\n\u2014\n\n\u2018Kill the Messenger\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: Jan. 18\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nIn 1996, the investigative reporter Gary Webb published an explosive three-part series of articles in the San Jose Mercury News claiming that the C.I.A. had brought crack cocaine into the United States in the 1980s and funneled millions of the dollars of profit to the war against the Sandinistas in Nicaragua. Webb\u2019s reporting came under heavy scrutiny \u2014and Webb committed suicide in 2004 \u2014 but \u201cKill the Messenger,\u201d a biopic about the story and its aftermath, takes a sympathetic view of a journalist under fire. Jeremy Renner plays Webb as an intrepid truth-seeker who uncovers a conspiracy that\u2019s far more powerful than he can contain, a situation that aligns the film with paranoid post-Watergate thrillers like \u201cThe Parallax View\u201d and \u201cThree Days of the Condor,\u201d\n\n\u2014\n\n\u2018Spotlight\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: Jan. 18\n\nJan. 18 Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nThere\u2019s nothing showy about this meat-and-potatoes treatment of The Boston Globe\u2019s reporting on the child sexual abuse in the Catholic Church, but its unadorned style suits the agenda of reporters who are trying to nail down some extraordinary facts. \u201cSpotlight\u201d doesn\u2019t have the rich atmosphere of its chief inspiration, \u201cAll the President\u2019s Men,\u201d but it shares the same appreciation for good, tenacious journalism and the clear articulation of a sensitive and difficult story. Director Tom McCarthy also subtly depicts the shrinking fortunes of the news business in the early 2000s, when investigative units like the Globe\u2019s Spotlight team were becoming an expense few publications could afford.\n\n\u2014\n\n0\n\n\u2018Grace and Frankie\u2019 Season 4\n\nStarts streaming: Jan. 19\n\nJan. 19 Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nThis solid comedy-drama from Netflix has mostly moved past the heartbreak of its initial premise, which had the mismatched frenemies Grace and Frankie (Jane Fonda and Lily Tomlin) moving in together after their husbands (Sam Waterston and Martin Sheen) announced their romantic relationship. The fourth season brings in another comedy veteran, Lisa Kudrow, as a manicurist whose friendship with Grace presents a new crisis in her relationship with Frankie. And presumably they\u2019ll have to continue managing the cutthroat vibrator business that kept them occupied in the previous season.\n\n\u2014\n\n\u2018The Force\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: Jan. 29\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nStarting in 2014, the documentary filmmaker Peter Nicks embedded himself with the Oakland Police Department as it tried to reform and improve its reputation with the public. \u201cThe Force\u201d goes on ride-alongs through tense street-level confrontations and visits meetings in which officials discuss the finer points of \u201cconstitutional policing,\u201d often contentiously. Positioning himself on the fault line between the police and the activists who scrutinize them, Nicks adopts a fly-on-the-wall style that suggests the intractability of the problem without taking any one position on it.\n\n\u2014\n\n\u2018Cars 3\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: Jan. 31\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nPixar is stingy about the films it makes available on Netflix, so there\u2019s a take-what-you-can-get quality to seeing \u201cCars 3\u201d appear on the service instead of the studio\u2019s more original and inspired titles. But the film is a significant improvement on the noisy, globetrotting indulgence of \u201cCars 2,\u201d bringing the franchise back to a simpler treatment of friendship and aging that recalls the third \u201cToy Story\u201d movie. This time, Lightning McQueen (voiced by Owen Wilson) is a past-his-prime stock-car champion who faces a challenge from a jet-black newcomer named Jackson Storm, whom Armie Hammer voices with maximum arrogance and smarm.\n\n\u2014\n\nAlso of interest: \u201c13 Minutes\u201d (Jan. 1), \u201cGlac\u00e9\u201d Season 1 (Jan. 1), \u201cPirates of the Caribbean: Dead Men Tell No Tales\u201d (Jan. 2), \u201cRent\u201d (Jan. 2), \u201cShameless\u201d (American version) Season 7 (Jan. 2), \u201c6 Days\u201d (Jan. 3), \u201cDirk Gently\u2019s Holistic Detective Agency\u201d Season 2 (Jan. 5), \u201cThe Twilight Saga: Breaking Dawn: Part 2\u201d (Jan. 5), \u201cHouse of Z\u201d (Jan. 6), \u201cThe Man Who Would Be Polka King\u201d (Jan. 12), \u201cMr. Holmes\u201d (Jan. 18) and \u201cIn the Deep\u201d (Jan. 19).", "title": "The Best Movies and TV Shows New on Netflix Canada in January", "authors": ["Scott Tobias"]} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "Welcome to Watching, The New York Times\u2019s TV and movie recommendation site. Sign up for our thrice-weekly newsletter, here.\n\nEvery month, Netflix Australia adds a new batch of movies and TV shows to its library. Here are the titles we think are most interesting for February, broken down by release date. Netflix occasionally changes its schedule without giving notice. (Unfortunately, the streaming information provided in our Watchlist listings only applies to viewers in the United States.)\n\nMovies New to Netflix\n\n\u20189 to 5\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: Feb. 1\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nThe writer-director Colin Higgins struck gold in 1980 with this still-on-point comedy about sexual harassment in the workplace, with Dabney Coleman as a bullying executive who gets his comeuppance at the hands of three female underlings. Jane Fonda, Dolly Parton and Lily Tomlin play the vengeful administrative assistants, who kidnap their creepy boss and then change their office policies in order to make them more friendly to women. The plot of \u201c9 to 5\u201d is predictable and the jokes are stale, but all four stars are charismatic, and it\u2019s bracing to see how little some sociopolitical concerns have changed in the last four decades.\n\n\u2014\n\n\u201878/52\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: Feb. 1\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nOne of the most shocking moments in the history of cinema \u2014 the shower scene in Alfred Hitchcock\u2019s \u201cPsycho\u201d \u2014 gets thoroughly unpacked in Alexandre O. Philippe\u2019s documentary \u201c78/52,\u201d which is named for the number of camera angles and cuts used by Hitch to terrify motion picture audiences. Scholars and fans approach this single minute of film (which took seven days to shoot,) from multiple perspectives, talking about what it meant as a technical achievement, how it can be read symbolically and how it fits into cinematic history.\n\n\u2014\n\n\u2018John Mellencamp: Plain Spoken\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: Feb. 1\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nFans of John Mellencamp hits like \u201cJack and Diane\u201d and \u201cPink Houses\u201d should know that while this concert film features a lot of the singer-songwriter\u2019s best-known songs, it is not strictly a performance piece. Instead, the veteran roots-rocker takes an especially feisty set performance from his \u201cPlain Spoken\u201d tour and adds narration, talking over the tunes to share stories about his youth and early years in show business. The result is something uncommonly intimate, taking us inside Mellencamp\u2019s head as he and his band do their work.\n\n\u2014\n\n0\n\n\u2018Nightcrawler\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: Feb. 1\n\nFeb. 1 Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nThere\u2019s never been a shortage of movies, novels and television shows about the ratings-grabbing debasement of broadcast media, and yet in this \u201cfake news\u201d era, the 2014 thriller \u201cNightcrawler\u201d still seems eerily prescient. Writer-director Dan Gilroy and star Jake Gyllenhaal have created a timelessly unnerving character in the antihero Lou Bloom, an amoral freelance videographer whose facility with buzzwords and utter shamelessness helps him force his way into places no one else will go, in order to gather the kind of gory footage that makes TV producers light up. A twisty plot pulls viewers through what is ultimately a stinging commentary about sensationalism and trust.\n\n\u2014\n\n\u2018The Pianist\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: Feb. 9\n\nFeb. 9 Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nIn this drama directed by Roman Polanski and adapted by Ronald Harwood, Adrien Brody gives an Oscar-winning performance as the real-life Polish concert pianist Wladyslaw Szpilman. Adapted from Szpilman\u2019s memoir, the film shows how he evaded the Nazis for years by hiding amid Warsaw\u2019s bombed-out rubble. Largely dialogue-free, \u201cThe Pianist\u201d follows the usual beats of a Holocaust drama, then takes a sharp turn after the hero avoids being shipped off to a concentration camp, becoming a harrowing, masterfully constructed survivalist adventure.\n\n\u2014\n\n\u2018Close Encounters of the Third Kind\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: Feb. 14\n\nFeb. 14 Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nAlthough it\u2019s remembered as one of the movies that helped steer 1970s Hollywood toward broad-appeal blockbusters, Steven Spielberg\u2019s \u201cClose Encounters\u201d is actually pretty arty by today\u2019s standards. This story of an alien visitation \u2014 which is less of an invasion than a \u201cHi, how are ya\u201d \u2014 sprawls out into a shaggy riff on post-Watergate paranoia, suburban family angst and human curiosity. As a husband and father who\u2019s practically itching to leave home, Richard Dreyfuss makes for an appealing and relatable everyman, who conveys a proper sense of wonder as he hits the road with fellow lost souls, searching for meaning by chasing UFOs.\n\n\u2014\n\n\u2018John Wick: Chapter 2\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: Feb. 16\n\nFeb. 16 Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nIt took a while for audiences to catch up to the first \u201cJohn Wick,\u201d which was advertised as a grubby Keanu Reeves revenge thriller and only later revealed to be something far more imaginative and odd. The action-packed sequel doesn\u2019t waste any time getting freaky: From the opening scene, we\u2019re transported back to the bizarro \u201cJohn Wick\u201d world, where dapper criminals brutalize each other in an elaborate underground society. Reeves, meanwhile, is as cool as ever, playing a semiretired assassin who keeps getting pushed to prove how lethal he can be.\n\n\u2014\n\n\u2018The Final Year\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: Feb. 18\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nAn invaluable document of the American federal government\u2019s executive branch, this documentary from Greg Barker covers the Obama administration\u2019s mad scramble to complete some of the biggest items on its foreign policy agenda before the end of his second term. Supporters of the former president may find the prospect of watching his team\u2019s last days too depressing. But history is still history, and for generations to come it will be fascinating to look back at what mattered to the statesmen of this era, and how hard they fought to accomplish their agendas.\n\n\u2014\n\nAlso of interest: \u201c42 Grams\u201d (Feb. 1), \u201cThe Huntsman: Winter\u2019s War\u201d (Feb. 4), \u201cSharknado 5: Global Swarming\u201d (Feb. 6), \u201cI Know What You Did Last Summer\u201d (Feb. 7), \u201cBill & Ted\u2019s Excellent Adventure\u201d (Feb. 9), \u201cSaw II\u201d (Feb. 9), \u201cSaw III\u201d (Feb. 9), \u201cSparkle\u201d (Feb. 21), \u201cNeighbors 2: Sorority Rising\u201d (Feb. 25) and \u201cInsidious: Chapter 3\u201d (Feb. 26).\n\n\u2014\n\nNew Netflix Original TV Series\n\n\u2018Altered Carbon\u2019 Season 1\n\nStarts streaming: Feb. 2\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nIn the early 2000s, the novelist Richard Morgan published a trilogy of science-fiction stories about Takeshi Kovacs, a hard-boiled pulp hero living in a future where human beings can have their memories, skills and personalities transferred into a new physical \u201csleeve\u201d after they die. After spending over a decade trying to bring the character to the screen, the screenwriter Laeta Kalogridis has finally come through with \u201cAltered Carbon,\u201d based on the first book of the series. Joel Kinnaman (who was so good in \u201cThe Killing\u201d) stars as Kovacs, a long-shelved super soldier resurrected to investigate a death that was believed to be suicide, but may actually be murder.\n\n\u2014\n\n\u2018Queer Eye\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: Feb. 7\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nIn the early 2000s, when the L.G.B.T.Q. community was much less widely represented on TV, the Bravo series \u201cQueer Eye for the Straight Guy\u201d was a revelation. Its diverse panel of gay style experts patrolled a hearteningly idealized New York City, where different groups of people interacted amiably. Given all the ways that culture and society have changed over the past decade, it will be interesting to see whether the revamped version of the show \u2014 with an entirely new \u201cFab Five\u201d doing the makeovers and a scope extended beyond New York \u2014 will still feel vital.\n\n\u2014\n\n0\n\n\u2018Everything Sucks!\u2019 Season 1\n\nStarts streaming: Feb. 16\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nHaving already hit the jackpot with shows about awkward kids, like \u201cStranger Things\u201d and \u201cAmerican Vandal,\u201d Netflix is at it again with a comedy about the drama geeks and A/V Club nerds at a mid-1990s Oregon high school. The writing, directing and producing team includes the indie film stalwarts Ben York Jones (\u201cLike Crazy\u201d), Michael Mohan (\u201cSave the Date\u201d) and Ry Russo-Young (\u201cBefore I Fall\u201d), so expect the humor to be more gentle than broad, and interlaced with painful truths about how it feels to be an adolescent misfit with big creative dreams.\n\n\u2014\n\n\u2018The Joel McHale Show With Joel McHale\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: Feb. 18\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nEver since E! canceled its Friday night roundup show \u201cThe Soup,\u201d topical television has suffered from a Joel McHale-sized hole. This hole is about to be filled, however, with his new weekly Netflix show. Playing to his strengths, the puckishly cynical comedian will offer his take on what\u2019s happening in the world of news and entertainment, accompanied by clips, sketches and special guests. At its best, \u201cThe Soup\u201d could be more informative about the state of our culture than the nightly news, so the bar is pretty high for this 13-episode series.\n\n\u2014\n\n\u2018Seven Seconds\u2019 Season 1\n\nStarts streaming: Feb. 23\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nThe writer and producer Veena Sud alternately captivated and frustrated TV viewers with her AMC-Netflix series \u201cThe Killing,\u201d which overstretched its mystery plots while developing a finely textured study of troubled people in a forbidding Seattle. Her new crime drama \u201cSeven Seconds\u201d (based on 2013 Russian film,) is also about a death: the accidental killing of a black Jersey City teen by a white cop. With the \u201cwhodunit\u201d aspect minimized, Sud should be in her element, using tragedy as a lens through which to view various social ills. It should help that her cast includes Regina King, who has won two Emmys for her roles on \u201cAmerican Crime.\u201d\n\n\u2014\n\nAlso of interest: \u201cCoach Snoop\u201d Season 1 (Feb. 2) and \u201cUgly Delicious\u201d Season 1 (Feb. 23).\n\n\u2014\n\nNew Netflix Original Movies\n\n\u2018Seeing Allred\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: Feb. 9\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nThe feminist attorney Gloria Allred has spent decades fighting for causes she believes in, using the courts and the media. Sophie Sartain and Roberta Grossman\u2019s documentary \u201cSeeing Allred\u201d is a glowing portrait of the activist, combining her reflections on a tumultuous life with footage of her drumming up publicity for her clients and going after powerful men like Bill Cosby and Donald Trump. The film became unexpectedly relevant while it was in production, as the #MeToo movement erupted with the kinds of personal stories of injustice that Allred has spent her career trying to be heard.\n\n\u2014\n\n\u2018The Trader\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: Feb. 9\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nNetflix has become a surprisingly welcoming home for foreign-language movies, documentaries and even short films. \u201cThe Trader\u201d is all three at once: a 22-minute Georgian doc about a man who collects old clothes and housewares and swaps them for food at a community market. A winner of a jury award at the 2018 Sundance Film Festival, \u201cThe Trader\u201d is a touching piece of cultural anthropology.\n\n\u2014\n\nAlso of interest: \u201cThe Ritual\u201d (Feb. 9), \u201cWhen We First Met\u201d (Feb. 9), \u201cIrreplaceable You\u201d (Feb. 16), \u201cFullMetal Alchemist\u201d (Feb. 19), \u201cForgotten\u201d (Feb. 21) and \u201cMute\u201d (Feb. 23).\n\n\u2014", "title": "The Best Movies and TV Shows New to Netflix Australia in February", "authors": ["Noel Murray"]} {"date": "2018-01-02 00:00:00", "text": "Watching is The New York Times\u2019s TV and film recommendation website. Sign up for our thrice-weekly newsletter here.\n\nEvery month, subscription streaming services add a new batch of movies and TV shows to their libraries. Here are the titles we think are most interesting for January, broken down by service and release date. Streaming services occasionally change schedules without giving notice.\n\nNew to Netflix\n\nFrom left, Bill Paxton, Kevin Bacon and Tom Hanks in \u201cApollo 13.\u201d Universal Pictures\n\n\u2018Apollo 13\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: Jan. 1\n\nJan. 1 Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nIn June, it was announced that Ron Howard was replacing Phil Lord and Christopher Miller as the director of the coming \u201cStar Wars\u201d prequel about young Han Solo. But before Howard took on that story from a galaxy far, far away, he directed a space drama situated much closer to home. This 1995 movie follows the events of the doomed Apollo 13 and its crew\u2019s desperate attempt to make it back to earth. Not even Tom Hanks\u2019s calming presence as one of the astronauts can soothe my stress when watching this movie.\n\n\u2014\n\nKirsten Dunst, left, and Gabrielle Union in \u201cBring It On.\u201d Ken Jacques/Universal Studios\n\n\u2018Bring It On\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: Jan. 1\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nKirsten Dunst stars in this 2000 movie as a spunky cheerleading captain who thinks she\u2019s cursed. It\u2019s the only reason her character can think of when she discovers her champion squad has a problematic history of stealing routines from a poorer team in South Central Los Angeles (led by Gabrielle Union in one of her earliest films roles). \u201cBring It On\u201d isn\u2019t just the best cheerleading movie of all time. It\u2019s one of the best sports comedies. And now, I have the \u201cBrr, It\u2019s Cold in Here\u201d cheer stuck in my head.\n\n\u2014\n\nMarlon Brando in \u201cThe Godfather.\u201d Paramount Pictures\n\n\u2018The Godfather\u2019 trilogy\n\nStarts streaming: Jan. 1\n\nThe first and second entries of the \u201cGodfather\u201d trilogy are essential entries in the American movie canon. They have many unforgettable lines, shadowy cinematography that makes almost every character look ominous and great performances from Marlon Brando, Al Pacino, Diane Keaton, John Cazale, James Caan and Robert De Niro.\n\n\u2014\n\n0\n\nKate Hudson and Matthew McConaughey in \u201cHow to Lose a Guy in 10 Days.\u201d Michael Gibson/Paramount Pictures\n\n\u2018How to Lose a Guy in 10 Days\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: Jan. 1\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nRemember when Matthew McConaughey was the \u201cit\u201d guy for almost every romantic comedy in the early 2000s? I sure do. And \u201cHow to Lose a Guy in 10 Days\u201d is likely one of the better ones of the bunch. Here, he\u2019s an ad exec who needs to prove that he understands romance when he comes across a magazine writer (Kate Hudson) who, unbeknown to him, is on assignment to get a guy to dump her within 10 days. Don\u2019t you just love it when two unlikely characters played by really attractive people are the ones who find love?\n\n\u2014\n\nKirsten Dunst, center, in \u201cMarie Antoinette.\u201d Leigh Johnson/Columbia Pictures\n\n\u2018Marie Antoinette\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: Jan. 1\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nSofia Coppola delivers this imaginative spin on the story of the last pre-Revolution queen of France. As Marie Antoinette, Kirsten Dunst wears frilly dresses, prances through opulent rooms and luxuriates in riches in a na\u00efve girlish way. Anyone coming to this movie for a period-perfect recreation of Antoinette\u2019s story may be disappointed. The movie is more interested in the mood and inner life of the queen than in historical accuracy.\n\n\u2014\n\nTara Morice and Paul Mercurio in \u201cStrictly Ballroom.\u201d Miramax Films\n\n\u2018Strictly Ballroom\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: Jan. 1\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nThere\u2019s so much to love about this ostentatiously silly Australian film. Underneath the ridiculous \u201990s hairdos, sparkly costumes and silly dance routines, there\u2019s a lovely story about two unlikely partners \u2014 one a champion dancer, the other an untested and clumsy newcomer \u2014 who upend the stuffy ballroom scene with their unorthodox style. This was the film that launched Baz Luhrmann\u2019s career, so take note, fans of \u201cRomeo + Juliet\u201d and \u201cMoulin Rouge.\u201d\n\n\u2014\n\nJim Carrey in \u201cThe Truman Show.\u201d Paramount Pictures\n\n\u2018The Truman Show\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: Jan. 1\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nThis 1998 movie features one of Jim Carrey\u2019s best performances. (I have a soft spot, though, for Carrey\u2019s role in the sappy \u201cThe Majestic.\u201d) In it, Carrey combines his manic energy with a sensitive side audiences hadn\u2019t really seen when it was released. But \u201cThe Truman Show\u201d is also an interesting look at the rise of reality TV and how people cannibalize one another\u2019s experiences for entertainment.\n\n\u2014\n\nVera Farmiga in \u201cThe Conjuring.\u201d Michael Tackett/Warner Bros. Pictures\n\n\u2018The Conjuring\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: Jan. 8\n\nJan. 8 Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nDirector James Wan (\u201cSaw\u201d) channels the spirit of 1970s horror films like \u201cThe Exorcist\u201d and \u201cThe Amityville Horror\u201d to create a mythology around a real-life married pair of paranormal investigators. The premise may feel familiar, but Vera Farmiga and Patrick Wilson do wonders with their roles as the ghost-hunting couple.\n\n\u2014\n\nOther movies of interest: \u201cBatman\u201d (Jan. 1), \u201cBreakfast at Tiffany\u2019s\u201d (Jan 1), \u201cCaddyshack\u201d (Jan. 1), the \u201cLethal Weapon\u201d series (Jan. 1), \u201cLike Water for Chocolate\u201d (Jan. 1), \u201cThe Shawshank Redemption\u201d (Jan. 1) and \u201cDallas Buyers Club\u201d (Jan. 16).\n\nTV series of interest: \u201cLovesick\u201d Season 3 (Jan. 1), \u201cComedians in Cars Getting Coffee\u201d (Jan. 5) and \u201cEpisodes\u201d Seasons 1-5 (Jan. 6).\n\nNew Netflix Original TV Series\n\nFrom left, Lily Tomlin, Jane Fonda and Lisa Kudrow in \u201cGrace and Frankie.\u201d Melissa Moseley/Netflix\n\n\u2018Grace and Frankie\u2019 Season 4\n\nStarts streaming: Jan. 19\n\nJan. 19 Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nIt\u2019s time for TV fans to start paying more attention to Netflix\u2019s sweet and stinging sitcom \u201cGrace and Frankie,\u201d which by the end of January 2018 will have four seasons and more than 50 episodes available \u2014 an impressive run for any show. The series\u2019s co-creator Marta Kauffman made her reputation with the widely beloved \u201cFriends,\u201d and for this season of \u201cGrace and Frankie\u201d she\u2019s bringing along her old pal Lisa Kudrow, who joins the showbiz legends Jane Fonda and Lily Tomlin in this continuing story about two aging women looking to reinvent themselves.\n\n\u2014\n\nA scene from \u201cDirty Money.\u201d Netflix\n\n\u2018Dirty Money\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: Jan. 26\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nAlex Gibney is an impassioned and prolific activist documentarian, and one assumes he can\u2019t possibly find the time to research and shoot a feature film about every social ill that ignites him. So it makes sense that he would shift some of his production company\u2019s resources into a TV series, helping similarly passionate directors make a difference. The short documentaries presented under Gibney\u2019s \u201cDirty Money\u201d umbrella pursue blood-boiling tales of corporate malfeasance and corruption, with episodes tackling pharmaceutical price-gouging, the banking practices of drug cartels, Donald Trump\u2019s shady business history and more.\n\n\u2014\n\n0\n\nA scene from \u201cOne Day at a Time.\u201d Netflix\n\n\u2018One Day at a Time\u2019 Season 2\n\nStarts streaming: Jan. 26\n\nJan. 26 Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nThis reimagined revival of the long-running sitcom from producer Norman Lear landed on multiple \u201cBest of 2017\u201d lists, making the prospect of new \u201cOne Day at a Time\u201d episodes one of the year\u2019s most-anticipated TV events. Season 1 left off with the Alvarez family\u2019s embracing its eldest daughter, Elena, after she came out as gay, while Penelope was struggling to overcome her busy schedule as a single mother and nurse, along with the chronic injury she suffered in the military. Expect more poignant and pertinent complications in Season 2, as well as more scene-stealing moments for Rita Moreno as Penelope\u2019s Cuban immigrant mother.\n\n\u2014\n\nNew Netflix Original Movies\n\nJack Black, left, and Jason Schwartzman in \u201cThe Polka King.\u201d Netflix\n\n\u2018The Polka King\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: Jan. 12\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nBased on the true story of Jan Lewan \u2014 who is also the subject of a 2009 documentary \u2014 \u201cThe Polka King\u201d stars Jack Black as Lewan, a popular Pennsylvania polka bandleader who takes advantage of his mostly older fan base to raise money in a shady investment scheme. The film finally arrives on Netflix this month, almost exactly one year after it was well received in its debut at the Sundance Film Festival.\n\n\u2014\n\nPiercey Dalton and Dylan Minnette in \u201cThe Open House.\u201d Netflix\n\n\u2018The Open House\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: Jan. 19\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nOver the past year or so, Netflix has been quietly assembling a healthy library of original horror films, calling on fledgling creative teams and emerging genre auteurs to share their original visions. For \u201cThe Open House,\u201d the novice writer-director team of Matt Angel and Suzanne Coote collaborate with Dylan Minnette, the star of Netflix\u2019s \u201c13 Reasons Why,\u201d for a supernatural thriller about a teenager and his mother, who encounter menacing spirits in their new home.\n\n\u2014\n\nWill Forte, left, and Domhnall Gleeson in \u201cA Futile and Stupid Gesture.\u201d John P. Fleenor/Netflix\n\n\u2018A Futile and Stupid Gesture\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: Jan. 26\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nA hit list of notable comic actors pay homage to the influentially anarchic humor magazine \u201cNational Lampoon\u201d in this movie about the troubled genius of its high-living writer, editor and co-founder Doug Kenney. Will Forte plays Kenney, Joel McHale plays Chevy Chase, Seth Green is Christopher Guest, Paul Scheer is Paul Shaffer, and a host of other comedians play the likes of Bill Murray, John Belushi, Harold Ramis and Dan Aykroyd. The \u201cWet Hot American Summer\u201d director David Wain \u2014 who has more than a little experience with corralling brilliantly funny folk \u2014 directs what looks to be a raucous film about the tricky business of making people laugh.\n\n\u2014\n\nNew to Amazon Prime\n\nRobert Redford in \u201cAll Is Lost.\u201d Richard Foreman/Roadside Attractions\n\n\u2018All Is Lost\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: Jan. 1\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nRobert Redford plays a man all alone at sea. We never learn his name or who he is, we only see his struggle to survive after his boat is damaged by a wayward shipping container.\n\n\u2014\n\nPhilip Seymour Hoffman in \u201cCapote.\u201d Attila Dory/Sony Pictures Classics\n\n\u2018Capote\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: Jan. 1\n\nJan. 1 Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nPhilip Seymour Hoffman won an Academy Award for his portrayal in this film of the eccentric author Truman Capote. This movie covers the years Capote researched and wrote his landmark best-seller \u201cIn Cold Blood.\u201d\n\n\u2014\n\nJake Gyllenhaal and Chlo\u00eb Sevigny in \u201cZodiac.\u201d Merrick Morton/Paramount Pictures\n\n\u2018Zodiac\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: Jan. 1\n\nJan. 1 Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nBefore Robert Downey Jr. became one of the world\u2019s biggest movie stars in \u201cIron Man,\u201d he enjoyed a bit of a renaissance in movies like \u201cKiss Kiss Bang Bang\u201d and this David Fincher film. In it, Downey and Jake Gyllenhaal play two San Francisco newsmen trying to solve the case of the Zodiac killer. Mark Ruffalo and Anthony Edwards play the detectives on the case. The movie is a fascinating study of obsession \u2014 and of the idea that some questions just never get answered.\n\n\u2014\n\nA scene from \u201cA Ghost Story.\u201d A24\n\n\u2018A Ghost Story\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: Jan. 7\n\nJan. 7 Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nThis movie is not spooky \u2014 not even close. This ghost story is sad and existential. After a young married man dies, he returns to haunt his home and brood as his wife (and time) move on.\n\n\u2014\n\nAlso of interest: \u201cRequiem for a Dream\u201d (Jan. 1), \u201cReservoir Dogs\u201d (Jan. 1) and \u201cThelma & Louise\u201d (Jan. 1).\n\nNew to Hulu\n\nWesley Snipes, left, Alfre Woodard in \u201cDown in the Delta.\u201d Ben Mark Holzberg/Miramax Films\n\n\u2018Down in the Delta\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: Jan. 1\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nThe poet Maya Angelou directed one movie and it\u2019s a great one. Starring Alfre Woodard, \u201cDown in the Delta\u201d follows an exasperated and struggling young mother whose own mother forces her to spend a summer with relatives in the Mississippi Delta, in hopes that it will straighten out the family\u2019s problems. Woodard is amazing in just about every movie I\u2019ve seen her in, and this one is no different. Although Angelou didn\u2019t write the story, her sensitive and observational touch is all over the movie.\n\n\u2014\n\nGeena Davis in \u201cA League of Their Own.\u201d MGM\n\n\u2018A League of Their Own\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: Jan. 1\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nThis movie is a reliable choice if you\u2019re looking for a pick-me-up, with all the heartbreak and good cheer of a classic sports movie. Geena Davis stars alongside Tom Hanks, Madonna and Rosie O\u2019Donnell in this fictionalized retelling of the inaugural season of the All-American Girls Professional Baseball League. Remember, \u201cThere\u2019s no crying in baseball!\u201d\n\n\u2014\n\n0\n\nHayley Mills playing twins in \u201cThe Parent Trap.\u201d Disney\n\n\u2018The Parent Trap\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: Jan. 1\n\nThe original live-action Disney movie \u201cThe Parent Trap,\u201d from 1961, starred Hayley Mills in the dual role of twin sisters who try to get their divorced parents back together.
