In this 1998 remake, the mischievous twins are played by Lindsay Lohan, and they come up with a similar scheme. Now, you can watch both versions back to back as a double feature. Only one of them, however, has an adorably catchy song, and that\u2019s the original.\n\n\u2014\n\nMaggie Gyllenhaal in \u201cSecretary.\u201d Lions Gate Films\n\n\u2018Secretary\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: Jan. 1\n\nJan. 1 Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nBefore her role in HBO\u2019s \u201cThe Deuce\u201d as a porn industry pioneer, Maggie Gyllenhaal took on kink taboos in this cult favorite from 2002. In this role, she plays a submissive woman recovering from a breakdown who starts a sadomasochistic relationship with her boss (James Spader). Interestingly, Spader\u2019s character is named Mr. Grey, like the main love interest in the \u201cFifty Shades of Grey\u201d series. I much prefer Spader and Gyllenhaal\u2019s darkly comic relationship.\n\n\u2014\n\nJohn Candy, left, and Bill Pullman in \u201cSpaceballs.\u201d MGM\n\n\u2018Spaceballs\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: Jan. 1\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nIn a decade far, far away (kidding, it\u2019s just the \u201980s), Mel Brooks skewered the super-popular \u201cStar Wars\u201d films with this silly, pun-filled story about a kidnapped princess, a helmet-wearing villain, an unlikely hero and his tall, furry co-pilot. It\u2019s hard for me to pick a favorite joke from this movie, but the one that comes to mind first is the not-so-subtle jab at \u201cStar Wars\u201d merchandising, the \u201cSpaceballs\u201d version of which is peddled by Yogurt, Brooks\u2019s spoof of Yoda.\n\n\u2014\n\nMichael Fassbender as the title character in \u201cFrank.\u201d Magnolia Pictures\n\n\u2018Frank\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: Jan. 8\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nYou\u2019ve probably seen Michael Fassbender in one of his many serious roles, but his performance in this 2014 dark comedy is odder than usual. For most of the movie, his face is concealed by a big, bizarre papier-m\u00e2ch\u00e9 head that his character, a bandleader named Frank, wears at all times.\n\n\u2014\n\nTilda Swinton in \u201cWe Need to Talk About Kevin.\u201d Nicole Rivelli/Oscilloscope\n\n\u2018We Need to Talk About Kevin\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: Jan. 15\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nI\u2019ve yet to see a bad movie starring Tilda Swinton, and if there is one, don\u2019t tell me about it. \u201cWe Need to Talk About Kevin\u201d was one of the first movies that made me fall in love with her intense but understated acting style. In this tragic drama, she plays a mother who struggles to connect with her demanding and disturbed child (Ezra Miller). In many scenes, Swinton conveys her character\u2019s conflicted emotions without saying a word. Her performance is so good, it\u2019s haunting.\n\n\u2014\n\nElizabeth Olsen, left, and Aubrey Plaza in \u201cIngrid Goes West.\u201d Neon\n\n\u2018Ingrid Goes West\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: Jan. 22\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nA black satire of social media obsession, this movie follows a troubled young woman, Ingrid (Aubrey Plaza), as she becomes develops an unhealthy fixation on a boho chic Instagram celebrity (Elizabeth Olsen). Ingrid then plots to become this Insta-famous stranger\u2019s best friend in real life by moving to her neighborhood in Los Angeles and inserting herself into her life. This is a very dark comedy, but one with several funny performances from Plaza, Olsen and O\u2019Shea Jackson Jr., who plays Ingrid\u2019s Batman-obsessed landlord.\n\n\u2014\n\nAlso of interest: \u201cBill & Ted\u2019s Excellent Adventure\u201d (Jan. 1), \u201cCapote\u201d (Jan. 1), \u201cThe Karate Kid\u201d (Jan. 1), \u201cPunch Drunk Love\u201d (Jan. 1), \u201cRequiem for a Dream\u201d (Jan. 1), \u201cReservoir Dogs\u201d (Jan. 1), \u201cSaturday Night Fever\u201d (Jan. 1), \u201cSliding Doors\u201d (Jan. 1), \u201cThelma & Louise\u201d (Jan. 1), \u201cTotal Recall\u201d (Jan. 1), \u201cZodiac\u201d (Jan. 1), \u201cCoherence\u201d (Jan. 15), \u201cThe Diving Bell and the Butterfly\u201d (Jan. 15), \u201cMeek\u2019s Cutoff\u201d (Jan. 15), \u201cWendy and Lucy\u201d (Jan. 15) and \u201cAll Dogs Go to Heaven\u201d (Jan. 31).\n\nNew to HBO\n\nZooey Deschanel and Joseph Gordon-Levitt in \u201c(500) Days of Summer.\u201d Chuck Zlotnick/Fox Searchlight Pictures\n\n\u2018(500) Days of Summer\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: Jan. 1\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nI\u2019m semi-afraid to revisit this movie. I\u2019m not sure how well it has aged. It\u2019s possible Joseph Gordon-Levitt\u2019s sad sack character with attachment issues will get on my nerves. And it\u2019s likely I\u2019ll want to tell Zooey Deschanel\u2019s character that there are a lot of guys out there who like the Smiths, and that she should probably avoid dating in the workplace.\n\n\u2014\n\n0\n\nEmma Watson and Daniel Radcliffe in \u201cHarry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban.\u201d Murray Close/Warner Bros.\n\nThe Harry Potter movies\n\nStarts streaming: Jan. 1\n\nYou could watch \u201cFantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them\u201d (please don\u2019t), or you could binge the eight original Harry Potter movies instead. I recommend the latter. If you\u2019re a fan, the originals may spur memories of watching them for the first time. Did you wait in line all night for a midnight screening? Did you grumble about how much the later movies deviated from the books, or dress up as your favorite character? I know I wasn\u2019t the only one in those days wearing a wizard\u2019s robe to the movie theater.\n\n\u2014\n\nAlso of interest: \u201cBack to the Future\u201d (Jan. 1), \u201cHoles\u201d (Jan. 1), \u201cThe Hours\u201d (Jan. 1), \u201cNational Lampoon\u2019s Animal House\u201d (Jan. 1), \u201cThree Kings\u201d (Jan. 1) and \u201cSideways\u201d (Jan. 1).\n\nNoel Murray contributed reporting.", "title": "The Best TV Shows and Movies New to Netflix, Amazon and More in January", "authors": ["Monica Castillo"]} {"date": "2018-01-08 00:00:00", "text": "The Most Electrifying Speech (and Reaction)\n\nAll hail Queen Oprah. Her acceptance speech for the Cecil B. DeMille lifetime achievement award brought the house down and then some, not just as the most rousing speech of the night (among many calls to arms) but also as the instantly iconic address of the Time\u2019s Up and #MeToo movements.\n\nFew if any people blend the personal and political as well as Ms. Winfrey, and she wove together stories of her childhood, watching Sidney Poitier win an Oscar in 1964 while her mother, \u201cbone-tired from cleaning other people\u2019s houses,\u201d watched. She traced her own career rise, and praised journalists for unearthing stories of corruption and abuse.\n\n\u201cWhat I know for sure is that speaking your truth is the most powerful tool we all have,\u201d Ms. Winfrey said, as she settled into a preacher\u2019s rousing cadence. She recounted the story of Recy Taylor, a black woman who was raped in 1944 and whose white assailants were never charged. \u201cFor too long, women have not been heard or believed if they dared to speak their truth to the power of those men,\u201d Ms. Winfrey said. She paused, just for a moment. \u201cBut their time is up.\u201d The audience broke into applause. \u201cTheir time is up!\u201d The audience rose to its feet. \u201cTheir time is up!\u201d\n\nBut that wasn\u2019t the end of the speech. Ms. Winfrey closed by proclaiming that \u201ca new day is on the horizon,\u201d and envisioning \u201ca time when nobody ever has to say, \u2018Me too,\u2019 again.\u201d She delivered those lines over rapturous cheers and applause. Imagine if every awards ceremony had a speech like this. \u2014 Margaret Lyons", "title": "The Best and Worst of the Golden Globes", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-29 00:00:00", "text": "But the essential Cardi B moment of the night came before the Grammy telecast began, with a psychedelic red carpet interview with E!\u2019s Giuliana Rancic. Within the first 10 seconds, Cardi B said she had \u201cbutterflies in my stomach and vagina,\u201d sending Ms. Rancic for a loop.\n\nMs. Rancic might have read up on Cardi B, but she was not prepared. There is a pat, practiced rhythm to red carpet interviews, a give and take of sycophantry and aw-shucks ego. Cardi B operates on a more instinctual level, meaning that at every turn, Ms. Rancic was flummoxed, befuddled and playing catch-up. It was three-plus minutes of old-style celebrity fluff getting crashed into and unmoored by new-style celebrity self-creation. JON CARAMANICA\n\nThe Best Would-Be Host\n\nPhoto\n\nFor the second year in a row, James Corden, a full-time employee of CBS, hosted the Grammys. It should have been Dave Chappelle. The comedian \u2014 who went on to take home an award for best comedy album (one of nine televised awards, for some reason) \u2014 first appeared with Mr. Lamar, cutting a six-and-a-half minute, show-opening performance that was pure adrenaline with a few chances to catch one\u2019s breath.\n\nHis commentary was pitch-perfect, acute in a way that much of the show failed to live up to. \u201cI just wanted to remind the audience that the only thing more frightening than watching a black man be honest in America is being an honest black man in America,\u201d Mr. Chappelle said, deadpan. \u201cSorry for the interruption. Please, continue.\u201d After another blistering segment by Mr. Lamar, Mr. Chappelle again played narrator. \u201cIs this on cable? This is CBS?\u201d he said. \u201cIt looks like he\u2019s singing and dancing, but this brother\u2019s taking enormous chances. Rumble, young man, rumble!\u201d\n\nMr. Chappelle wasn\u2019t done. Before introducing the nominees for best rap album, he gave the Grammys another quick jab to the ribs, highlighting the career of A Tribe Called Quest, which was notably left out of the category, much to the dismay of its leader (and Mr. Chappelle\u2019s friend), Q-Tip. Mr. Chappelle did not quote the late Phife Dawg, but you could all but hear one of his classic rhymes between the lines: \u201cI never let a statue tell me how nice I am.\u201d JOE COSCARELLI\n\nKesha\u2019s #MeToo Moment\n\nPhoto\n\nAs the Grammys approached, it became increasingly clear that the burden of a #MeToo moment would fall on Kesha, the pop star who accused her longtime producer, Dr. Luke, of years of abuse in a 2014 lawsuit; Dr. Luke, whose real name is Lukasz Gottwald, has denied the accusations. The Grammys, unlike the Golden Globes and the Oscars, are not known for speeches, which is why Janelle Mon\u00e1e\u2019s introduction to Kesha\u2019s performance felt potent: \u201cWe say time\u2019s up for pay inequality, time\u2019s up for discrimination, time\u2019s up for harassment of any kind, and time\u2019s up for the abuse of power,\u201d she announced.\n\nKesha didn\u2019t stand alone \u2014 she came with backup, a chorus of women in white led by Cyndi Lauper, Camila Cabello, Julia Michaels, Andra Day and Bebe Rexha. Her performance of \u201cPraying,\u201d a ballad off \u201cRainbow,\u201d her first album since 2012, was an emotional exorcism. Singing directly to an antagonist \u2014 \u201cYou brought the flames and you put me through hell/I had to learn how to fight for myself\u201d \u2014 she trembled, she screeched, she slipped around the song\u2019s melody. And she fell into the women\u2019s arms as the audience rose to its feet. CARYN GANZ\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nA Newcomer Stands on Her Own\n\nPhoto\n\nAlthough none of her five nominations led to Grammy Awards, SZA still came out ahead in a way: She was the only nominee for best new artist who got to perform a full song on her own. In \u201cBroken Clocks,\u201d she sang about a frustratingly iffy relationship, topping a slow-swaying vamp with jazzy, asymmetrical vocal lines that could dart nervously ahead, pivot suddenly, linger over a quivering tone and declaim a chorus. She was too distinctive to shoehorn into some Grammy medley. JON PARELES\n\nThe Gutsiest Performance (by an Artist and a Child)\n\nPhoto\n\nChildish Gambino, the novelty rap-turned-soul rewind project of the polymath Donald Glover, was this year\u2019s left-field nominee for album and record of the year. But instead of playing it safe and using his performance slot to do \u201cRedbone,\u201d the nominated song and surprise hit from the nominated album, \u201cAwaken, My Love!,\u201d Mr. Glover did one of the only truly risky things that can be done to subvert this often overly reverential variety show: He played a song that pretty much no one has heard. And, with \u201cTerrified,\u201d backed by a band that did not appear to be miming to a prerecorded track, he stuck the landing.\n\nA cameo from the preteen child actor and musician J.D. McCrary, who nailed his notes, was an added bonus \u2014 not to mention great synergy for the forthcoming live-action remake of \u201cThe Lion King,\u201d in which Mr. McCrary was cast as the young Simba to Mr. Glover\u2019s grown Simba. Then, immediately after, an Apple commercial used a big chunk of \u201cRedbone.\u201d That\u2019s called having it both ways. JOE COSCARELLI\n\nCamila Cabello Speaks for Dreamers\n\nPhoto\n\nMs. Cabello, the former member of Fifth Harmony whose solo debut album just went to No. 1, stepped out of Kesha\u2019s backup choir to speak up for Dreamers. Born in Havana, Ms. Cabello was brought to the United States by her Cuban mother as a child and allowed in; her Mexican father later joined them. \u201cJust like the Dreamers,\u201d she said, \u201cmy parents brought me to this country with nothing in their pockets but hope. They showed me what it means to work twice as hard and never give up.\u201d\n\nShe quoted the Emma Lazarus poem on the Statue of Liberty and introduced U2, performing on a windblown barge with the statue behind the band. Every so often, Bono raised his arm the way the statue holds its torch. The song doesn\u2019t entirely add up \u2014 it veers between self-help and political resistance \u2014 but lines like \u201cThe face of liberty\u2019s starting to crack\u201d and \u201cThe promised land is there for those who need it most\u201d couldn\u2019t have had a better backdrop. JON PARELES\n\nThe Most Unexpected Shout-out\n\nAmong current artists least likely to ever be given a moment at the Grammys, Mozzy, the Sacramento street rapper who appears to operate a solar system away from the music industry (in a good way), would have seemed like a safe bet. So to hear Mr. Lamar invoke the budding cult favorite \u2014 \u201cAs my guy Mozzy say, you know, God up top all the time\u201d \u2014 in his acceptance speech for best rap album was a welcome gift for, probably, dozens, and not even ostentatious enough to be baffling for the millions who almost definitely missed it altogether. During a show that tends to work broad, to say the least, you\u2019ve got to take the Easter eggs where you can find them. JOE COSCARELLI\n\nRihanna Digs Deep\n\nPhoto\n\nOn a night where Lady Gaga, Pink and Miley Cyrus chose balladeering over strutting, the job of being a first-class pop star was left to Rihanna. The overarching aesthetic of this performance of DJ Khaled\u2019s \u201cWild Thoughts\u201d with Bryson Tiller may have been less than clear, but it was joyous, and Rihanna threw herself into the moment, delighting online observers by breaking into the South African dance called gwara gwara. She punched her choreography with extra oomph while singing live, throwing ferocious faces and showing the world that she was having the most fun of anyone in Madison Square Garden. CARYN GANZ\n\nThe Worst\n\nLimp Song Selection\n\nPhoto\n\nOn a night in which two of the most dynamic album of the year nominees, Jay-Z and Lorde, did not take the stage (with Jay-Z reportedly turning down his slot and Lorde having not been offered her own showcase), the static performances stuck out even more than usual. Aged songs with questionable or forced relevance \u2014 Sting\u2019s \u201cEnglishman in New York,\u201d Elton John\u2019s \u201cTiny Dancer,\u201d Patti LuPone\u2019s \u201cDon\u2019t Cry for Me Argentina\u201d \u2014 were well-executed but unnecessary, while ballads by a dressed-down, feet-on-the-ground Pink (\u201cWild Hearts Can\u2019t Be Broken\u201d), Broadway\u2019s Ben Platt (\u201cSomewhere,\u201d from \u201cWest Side Story\u201d) and a piano-bound Lady Gaga (\u201cJoanne,\u201d \u201cMillion Reasons\u201d) were limp or snoozy.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nEven what should have been a guaranteed gut-punch \u2014 the country music tribute to the victims of the Las Vegas concert shooting \u2014 ended up a head-scratcher because of the choice to cover Eric Clapton\u2019s \u201cTears in Heaven.\u201d As Bruno Mars put it when he won record of the year for \u201c24K Magic\u201d: \u201cCome on, turn it up one more time \u2014 too many ballads tonight!\u201d Untapped nominated acts like Migos, Lil Uzi Vert and even Cardi B, who was relegated to two quick guest verses, could only nod in agreement \u2014 that is, if they were still paying attention. JOE COSCARELLI\n\nShutouts\n\nPhoto\n\nForget winning Grammys, or even sweeping all the major categories: all the cool kids are getting shut out! Jay-Z was this year\u2019s most nominated artist, with eight nods for his album \u201c4:44\u201d and various songs and videos from it, but he went home empty-handed. Lorde was nominated for album of the year, but didn\u2019t win. (She was spotted in the audience clutching a flask, though.) Cardi B: two nominations and no awards. And SZA, nominated five times, won no trophies. What was it Phife Dawg said again? JON CARAMANICA\n\nNo Big Prize for \u2018Despacito\u2019\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cDespacito\u201d conquered the world in 2017 with billions of views and streams, but it couldn\u2019t get a top Grammy as record of the year or song of the year. That would have been a milestone for Spanish-language pop (even though the version featuring Justin Bieber boosted the song\u2019s popularity in the United States). Instead, the Recording Academy retreated to the funk nostalgia of Bruno Mars\u2019s \u201c24K Magic.\u201d\n\nOnstage at Madison Square Garden, \u201cDespacito\u201d was back to its original Puerto Rican performers, the singer and songwriter Luis Fonsi and the reggaeton rapper and singer Daddy Yankee. They sang and declaimed its come-ons with lascivious enthusiasm, surrounded by flashing pastel lights and gyrating showgirls suggesting Las Vegas \u2014 or the Latin Grammys. The song\u2019s global spread isn\u2019t over; a Spanish/Mandarin version by Mr. Fonsi with the Singaporean pop star JJ Lin appeared in November. JON PARELES\n\nSubway Karaoke\n\nPhoto\n\nJames Corden\u2019s trademark \u201cCarpool Karaoke\u201d is usually a harmless bit of talk-show host self-promotion. But Mr. Corden\u2019s comedy also has another recurring shtick: self-humiliation. He carried Sting and Shaggy into it with a fake-v\u00e9rit\u00e9 \u201csubway karaoke\u201d bit, as they sang old hits and a new collaboration to a stereotypically hostile Noo Yawk reception that was predictable from the setup. The Grammys tried to atone to Sting and Shaggy; that new song got two more plugs, as a stage performance and as walk-on music for Sting, who presented song of the year. JON PARELES\n\nA Choir to Lean On\n\nPhoto\n\nThe Grammys rarely if ever showcase actual gospel music \u2014 and this would have been a great year to do so! \u2014 but choirs abound, providing sturdy ballast for unsteady performers. Generally, the choirs are black, the performers white. To wit: Sam Smith performed his new ballad \u201cPray\u201d on Sunday night, but it was dolorous until the backing choir arrived to uplift him at the first chorus. But no choir in the world could make Mr. Smith any warmer than temperate, any cooler than lukewarm. JON CARAMANICA", "title": "The Best and Worst of the Grammys", "authors": ["Jon Pareles", "Jon Caramanica", "Joe Coscarelli", "Caryn Ganz"]} {"date": "2018-01-03 00:00:00", "text": "Imagine this: When you leave the house, your air conditioner and lights turn off automatically. Then when a motion sensor detects a person in the house, like your house cleaner, it sends an alert to your phone. When you arrive home, a camera recognizes who you are and the door automatically unlocks.\n\nAutomated technologies like these will be at the forefront of CES, one of the world\u2019s largest tech conventions, next week in Las Vegas. They underline one major trend: Increasingly, the innovations that are making their way into your personal technology aren\u2019t physical electronics or gadgets at all.\n\nThe real star is artificial intelligence, the culmination of software, algorithms and sensors working together to make your everyday appliances smarter and more automated. It is A.I. that is telling the door to unlock when the camera recognizes you, or sending an alert to your phone when sensors detect a person.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s less about the hardware, and more about what\u2019s inside,\u201d Carolina Milanesi, a technology analyst for Creative Strategies, said about the prominence of artificial intelligence and software innovations at CES. For consumers who are dazzled by flashy new devices, A.I. is never as exciting, she said \u2014 but it\u2019s the magic that is making hardware evolve.", "title": "The Big Tech Trends to Follow at CES 2018", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "If you were making a film and needed to cast a bird in the Edward G. Robinson role, you\u2019d hand the script to a great black backed gull. Large birds with attitude, great black backs are adaptable, tough and smart. They are as likely to be eating the lobster they stole from your unattended picnic plate in Maine as they are to enjoy a kid\u2019s leftover pizza crust on a park bench in Brooklyn. They also know how to put the squeeze on their neighbors, pilfering fish and other hard-won prey items from any number of other species.\n\nIf it was not enough to have their catch stolen, the gulls\u2019 neighbors should watch out for themselves. Black backs have an unerring sense for distinguishing weakened, winter-starved birds from the rest of their flocks. Unfortunately for their victims, gulls lack the specialized killing tools of raptors. When black backs move in for the kill, it is not pretty.\n\nTo most New Yorkers, a gull is a gull is a gull. It is easy to overlook the differences among individual gulls loafing on a pier. One would never guess from his screen presence that the thuggish Mr. Robinson was actually a cultured philanthropist. Similarly, one might never suspect that gulls play key roles in our local ecosystem: acting as scavengers, and rubbing out the unfit and the infirm. Gulls demonstrate an eerily human intelligence, and their social behaviors are fascinating to watch. Great black backs are well adapted to life in an increasingly human-dominated world.\n\nIt is interesting to note that this familiar New York City bird is the largest gull in the world, with a wingspan that can reach about five feet and a weight of more than four pounds. Locally, you need only make your way to a fishing pier, a Dumpster or even a frozen shoreline to see one. These large birds can also be found foraging well inland, in a variety of urban, suburban and rural settings. Here, everything from mice to snakes, McDonald\u2019s leftovers and Starbucks\u2019 scraps, can be fair pickings for these ultimate opportunists.", "title": "The Biggest Bully on the Beach", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "For months, they were invisible to me. My mind was filled with ruminations about the ways my life was collapsing. Would my husband decide to stay married to me? Would I ever have children? Would there be heat by Christmas?\n\nBridges are built to be flexible. They need to withstand the pervasive force of gravity, certainly, but also transient forces that work against them. The Manhattan Bridge, which is a suspension bridge, must cope with floods and lightning, traffic and age. Although the circumstances around the bridge may change, it must stand steady. To do this, a bridge must balance two opposing forces: compression (pushing inward) and tension (stretching outward). A balanced bridge is one that has been engineered to find the sweet spot in between.\n\nI know this to be true because, with time, the particulars of bridge engineering began to replace the rolling images of heartbreak in my mind while I balanced on my bike. Cycling was becoming easier. In the first month, grandmothers whizzed by me. By November I was the speed demon overtaking the casual riders. I got a better seat so my behind would stop hurting and gloves so I could keep biking as the weather turned cold.\n\nMy body was changing too. I hadn\u2019t dropped much weight, but I was stronger and my joints didn\u2019t ache. My cheeks were flush from the fresh air and exercise. My eyes, no longer filled with tears, were clear.\n\nOne evening, on my way home from work, I looked up and saw a giant harvest moon rising over the river. In the middle of the Manhattan Bridge, at its high point, is a notch, a small outpost that juts away from the path, allowing commuters to pause and breathe while the city rushes by.\n\nFrom this vantage point you can watch the boats ferry New Yorkers between the boroughs or take in the skyline of Manhattan, Queens and Brooklyn, all at once. You are at the center of the city but also apart from it, watching the chaos safely from your perch. That evening, as I watched the flaming orange ball climb in the night sky, I felt a rush of gratitude. I was not alone. The world still had plenty of beauty to offer.", "title": "The Bike That Saved My Life", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-04 00:00:00", "text": "Not only that, but its short existence was marked by a string of embarrassing missteps. There were the clumsy requests for voter data, in some cases partial Social Security numbers, that at least a dozen states, Republican and Democratic alike, rightly rejected. There were multiple lawsuits alleging that the commission was violating the Constitution by discriminating against voters of color or infringing on Americans\u2019 privacy rights. The commission was even sued by one of its own members, Matthew Dunlap, the Maine secretary of state and a Democrat, who said he was being kept in the dark about the commission\u2019s activities and called any claims of bipartisanship a \u201cfacade.\u201d\n\nThe commission\u2019s only real accomplishment was to give a national platform to the nation\u2019s most dogged vote deniers \u2014 men like J. Christian Adams, who has produced reports on noncitizen voting titled \u201cAlien Invasion,\u201d helpfully illustrated with pictures of U.F.O.s; Ken Blackwell, the former Ohio secretary of state who tried to toss out voter registrations for being printed on the wrong thickness of paper; and Hans von Spakovsky, who has been hawking phony tales of voter fraud at least since the George W. Bush administration, and who advocated staffing the commission with \u201creal experts on the conservative side on this issue,\u201d as opposed to Democrats or \u201cmainstream Republican officials\u201d \u2014 both of whom live in the reality-based world, where election administrators of both parties agree that fraud is rare to nonexistent.\n\nAnd then there is Kris Kobach, the commission\u2019s vice chairman and guiding light, the man more responsible than perhaps anyone else for keeping alive the bogus specter of voting fraud in America. Mr. Kobach is the secretary of state of Kansas, where he has worked tirelessly for years to smoke out illegal voting by noncitizens, dead voters and other malefactors. In place of actual evidence, he relies on an antifraud data collection program with a 99-percent error rate. His results? Nine convictions, mostly of older white Republican men who voted twice.\n\nMr. Kobach\u2019s failures have not induced in him any apparent humility. In September, he said it was \u201chighly likely\u201d that more than 5,000 fraudulent votes swung the 2016 Senate election in New Hampshire, which was narrowly won by a Democrat, Maggie Hassan, and suggested fraud was also responsible for Mrs. Clinton\u2019s victory in the state. Like almost all other claims of voter fraud, it wasn\u2019t true \u2014 most of those votes probably were cast by college students who legally registered and voted with out-of-state IDs. But that didn\u2019t stop Republican lawmakers in the state from passing a bill on Wednesday that would impose what is essentially a poll tax on students who want to exercise their right to vote.\n\nAll of this is laughable, but it would be a big mistake to assume that the collapse of the commission means the end of the voter-fraud inquisition. To the contrary, Mr. Kobach, who called Mr. Trump\u2019s lie about millions of illegal voters \u201cabsolutely correct,\u201d seems more than happy to continue his voter-suppression tactics in the dark. On Wednesday, Mr. Kobach told Politico, \u201cAnyone on the left needs to realize that by throwing the food in the air, they just lost a seat at the table.\u201d If you ask Mr. Dunlap, they never had a seat in the first place.", "title": "Opinion | The Bogus Voter-Fraud Commission Is Dead, but the Myths Aren\u2019t", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "Clare Waight Keller did not invite a lot of people to the Givenchy couture show \u2014 her first ever couture show, and the first for the brand in eight years.\n\nShe did not ask any celebrities. She didn\u2019t really gussy up the rooms in the National Archives where the show was held \u2014 just pushed some chairs against the walls, so any light shining through the towering windows created striations on the bare wood floors and cast shadows across the audience. She didn\u2019t make a big deal out of it beforehand on Instagram or Facebook, though she did send chunky, hardback books, all in black, as her invitations, with the title of her show, \u201cMysteries of a Garden at Night,\u201d etched in gold on the spine.\n\nBooks! In the age of the Kindle. Inside, the pages were blank.\n\nAt a time when there\u2019s much talk in fashion about \u201cnew chapters,\u201d mostly as a way to frame the seemingly endless and increasingly problematic entrances and exits of designers, it was both a pointed commentary and a dare, given that paper and couture are regularly declared dead.\n\nReally? You think so? Ms. Keller has a different idea. Sometimes, you have to write your own prosody and let people discover it for themselves.\n\nOn Tuesday, in an entirely assured debut, she did exactly that.\n\nShe mixed men\u2019s wear tailoring \u2014 sharp and sleek of line \u2014 with fringe and fancy, throwing military greatcoats faced in d\u00e9grad\u00e9 feathers over gowns dripping in silver; transparent latex trench coats over tiers of rough-cut silk; leotard tops with square shoulders and exposed backs over a swirling rainbow skirts. She added men\u2019s couture in similar materials, silhouette and silver. Hems were long and body parts mostly covered. That didn\u2019t make it any less sophisticated or alluring.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThere was very little excess verbiage, no pandering to the decorative or the shock of the underboob, and no falling back on the safety net of the tux. There was a nod to the severity of Givenchy\u2019s past in the cut of the jackets and the color palette, but it was recast in Ms. Keller\u2019s vernacular: modernism balanced with heritage on a knife edge. If her first ready-to-wear show for the house seemed like something of a throat-clearing, this was a bid to be the author of her own genre, as opposed to fan fiction.", "title": "The Book of Clare: Givenchy\u2019s Powerful Return to Couture", "authors": ["Vanessa Friedman"]} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "In recent years, threats of government shutdowns have come with the regularity and, until now, predictability of one of those TV channels running marathons of old sitcoms. And here we are again: the ticking clock, the last-minute demands, the congealing of positions, the happy ending until next week\u2019s episode.\n\nUnless the Senate passes the bill passed by the House to fund government operations, the government will shut down Friday at midnight. This time, however, the situation on Capitol Hill is different and more dangerous than it has ever been.\n\nI was a member of the House Democratic leadership as chairman of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee from 2011 to 2015 and the Democratic Policy & Communications Committee from 2015 to 2016. I had a front-row seat to a series of budget brinks, debt cliffs, shutdowns and potential shutdowns, including the close call in April 2011 over Planned Parenthood funding and the one in October 2013 over the Affordable Care Act. I was there for the February 2015 shutdown threat over an executive order Mr. Obama signed on immigration, and the 2011 and 2013 debt-ceiling crises. I sat in the office of Nancy Pelosi when she was the House Democratic leader and watched her negotiate a four-dimensional chess game between a Republican Speaker, the Senate, the White House and within her own caucus during each of these crises.\n\nHere\u2019s how it typically went: The speaker (John Boehner or Paul Ryan) would try to find the votes to fund the government in the Republican Conference, which was and remains a caucus of caucuses. Republican defense hawks would be unhappy with low levels of Pentagon funding. Moderate Republicans \u2014 barely enough to fill a members-only elevator \u2014 would be unhappy with extremist language on issues such as women\u2019s health. The Freedom Caucus would be unhappy about everything.", "title": "Opinion | The Breakdown in Trust That Could Shut Down the Government", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cWe spend an hour smelling,\u201d she said. \u201cThen we talk about editing down the choices to six to 15 ingredients. We go outside and evaluate. Then we talk about the direction of the fragrance. Perhaps it\u2019s an Oriental, heavy with amber or a beautiful powdery musk.\u201d\n\nOnce a decision is made, three different versions are created. Some ingredients may be swapped our or omitted, or the ratio of components changed. The couple goes home with these samples, decides on a winner, which is then sent to them in a larger, more ornate bottle.\n\nMs. Serrano-McClain said that a third to half of her requests are for weddings.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m not trying to recreate their love story, but I do want to create a perfume that symbolizes some piece of their love so that when they smell it again, it conjures up all of that love, and that special day,\u201d she said.\n\nCost: $450 for a 50 milliliter bottle. mcmcfragrances.com\n\nPhoto\n\nKILIAN HENNESSY\n\nMr. Hennessy, an heir to the long line of Cognac makers and grandson to the founder of the LVMH Group, offers four, in-person sessions and spends several months selecting specific oils and ingredients. (He keeps 200-plus notes in his Paris lab). He also consults with perfumers with niche specialties, from masculine scents to flowers.\n\nWhen crafting wedding scents, Mr. Hennessy considers how a perfume reacts on someone\u2019s skin and how it will expand throughout the night.\n\n\u201cI would build the scent with a few head notes to feel fresh, beautiful and romantic, because that\u2019s how one is feeling at the beginning of their wedding,\u201d he said. \u201cI want something that opens very lightly during the event, because perfume cannot take over the ceremony.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI would build with 80 percent in heavy, dry, down base notes, like woods, vanilla or Oriental,\u201d he continued, \u201cbecause they have long-lasting diffusion. As the body heats, perfume accelerates. At its peak is when you want it fully opened.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Of the Moment The lifestyle newsletter from the Styles, Travel and Food sections, offering the latest trends to news you can use. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. Hennessy has two boutiques, one on Washington Street and another on Madison at 74th Street.\n\nCost: $35,000. www.bykilian.com This includes a black lacquered box with a crystal carafe, made by the French crystal manufacturer Saint-Louis, containing 650 milliliters of the bespoke perfume; six additional glass 50-milliliter bottles with engraved plaques; two travel sprays; and a funnel.\n\nPhoto\n\nTHE FRAGRANCE SHOP NEW YORK\n\nIf an experience without the investment is what you seek, make an appointment with Lalita Kumut, the owner of the Fragrance Shop New York, on East 4th Street. For the last 25 years, she and her staff have been creating customized perfumes from more than 300 exotic oils. These include ylang-ylang from the Philippines, tea tree from Australia and black currant from South Africa.\n\nTwenty to 30 minutes are all that is needed, during which about 25 oils are sniffed and tried on. These are pared down to six to 14 oils, which Ms. Kumut personally blends. \u201cLayering is like music you\u2019re making with scented low, medium and high notes,\u201d she said.\n\nCost: $50 for a rollerball; $90 for a 2-ounce spray. fragranceshopnewyork.com\n\nPhoto\n\nTHE SCENTARIUM\n\nSue Phillips, the chief executive and founder of the Scentarium, a perfumery in TriBeCa, says business has tripled from last year, with same-sex couples making up about half her clientele.\n\n\u201cThe 90-minutes experience is about personalization and authentically reflecting who they are,\u201d she said. \u201cIt\u2019s how do you want that fragrance to reflect what someone feels on that special day?\u201d\n\nClients are first asked to fill out a short questionnaire. Among the questions: Describe your dream house. What kinds of foods do you like? What is your favorite season? Ms. Phillips then places clients in one of four fragrance families: fresh, floral, woodsy or Oriental.\n\nShe has already created 18 fully blended perfumes, which showcase a full fragrance palette. Each is smelled, and placed in order of preference. Then the top choices are combined together. \u201cI\u2019m looking to create a complete character, something smooth and consistent with no jagged edges,\u201d she added. \u201cI don\u2019t want one particular note jumping out over another.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nCost: $750 for an 20- milliliter atomizer scenterprises.com\n\nPhoto\n\nDESERT35\n\nSome couples might want to gift their \u201cwedding scent\u201d for guests to take home. This is a service provided by Sharon Farsijani, the owner of Desert35, a year-old luxury perfume and cologne company in the Gramercy area.\n\nHer clients first take a personality test. (She created this test with the help of students and professors from the psychology departments of N.Y.U. and Columbia.)\n\nAfter a couple answer nine questions, they\u2019re placed into one of four fragrance groups; natural and simple; floral; Oriental; and woody. During a one-hour session, four fragrance samples are designed using up to six oils from her 50 offerings. The couple then chooses the one they like best.\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s beauty in simplicity,\u201d she said. \u201cToo many scents and you don\u2019t know about the ratio of how they blend together or if the scent is based on quality.\u201d\n\nMs. Farsijani hired a master perfumer who creates a final fragrance. Two months later, 100 15-milliliter designer bottles, engraved with the couple\u2019s initials and celebration date, are ready.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s as powerful as a photo or a video,\u201d she said. \u201cThe smell takes you back to the memory of the event, which is based on the couple\u2019s creativity, which is really an extension of the couple.\u201d\n\nCost: $3,000 for 100 15-milliliter bottles. desert35.com", "title": "The Bride Wore Satin and a Woodsy Scent", "authors": ["Alix Strauss"]} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "Would somebody give Roger Deakins an Oscar already? The cinematographer has been wowing us for decades with his vivid, evocative camerawork. His collaborations with the Coen brothers have included the snowy, expansive visuals for \u201cFargo,\u201d the bleak, modern western feel of \u201cNo Country for Old Men\u201d and the period gritty western feel of \u201cTrue Grit.\u201d There\u2019s his sweeping imagery for Frank Darabont\u2019s \u201cShawshank Redemption\u201d and the breathtaking, mystical look he brought to Martin Scorsese\u2019s \u201cKundun.\u201d\n\nMr. Deakins, 68, received Oscar nominations for those films as well as for several others. Now he has his 14th nomination, this time for the sequel \u201cBlade Runner 2049,\u201d which stars Ryan Gosling as K, an android, or \u201creplicant,\u201d police officer tasked with eliminating renegade replicants. And yet, Mr. Deakins hasn\u2019t received any actual statuettes. Not that winning is everything, and the work does speak for itself, but what does this artist have to do to catch a break?\n\nPerhaps it\u2019s by expanding the world of a cult science-fiction movie into new realms. Here are four visual examples from \u201cBlade Runner 2049\u201d that illustrate his craft, and why he deserves that elusive Oscar.", "title": "The Bright (and Dark) Side of Roger Deakins", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "To understand the rigidity \u2014 and some would say absurdity \u2014 of Sweden\u2019s alcohol laws, step inside a Systembolaget, a government-run liquor store, on a Saturday afternoon. It\u2019s predictable chaos because these shops are the only retailers permitted to sell beverages containing more than 3.5 percent alcohol by volume (ABV). At precisely 3 p.m., the doors will shut until Monday morning, and anyone hoping to buy a bottle of wine for a spontaneous dinner party or a few beers for a Sunday cookout will be out of luck.\n\nBut increasingly, Stockholmers have other palatable options.\n\nGrocery stores are allowed to sell what is known as folkol (\u201cpeople\u2019s beer\u201d), containing 2.8 percent to 3.5 percent ABV. Long maligned as tasteless, watered-down pilsners, these low-ABV beers are now getting a reboot by craft brewers seeking to shake up the Swedish market. At the same time, a wave of new folkol-focused bars and bottle shops \u2014 all opened in the last two years \u2014 is fueling interest in this formerly low-prestige beverage.", "title": "The Buzz in Stockholm Is Craft Beer With Less Buzz", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "The workshop, Mr. Kelly said, \u201cis part of C.D.C.\u2019s longstanding and routine work, similar to work it does to prepare for other possible health emergencies, with the goal of ensuring the public health community is prepared for all types of health threats.\u201d\n\nThe public will be able to watch the event when it is live.\n\nThe last such C.D.C. workshop took place in 2010.\n\nThe agenda includes \u201cPreparing for the Unthinkable,\u201d to \u201cRoadmap to Radiation Preparedness,\u201d and \u201cUsing Data and Decision Aids to Drive Response Efforts.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s a predictable response to the Trump administration, which is inflaming tensions and raising the risk of nuclear war,\u201d said Dr. Edwin Lyman, senior scientist with the Union of Concerned Scientists, a research and advocacy group.\n\n\u201cNothing would offset the devastation,\u201d Dr. Lyman said, \u201cbut the question is, if North Korea sends one or two missiles to the U.S., are there things that the public should know, that could possibly reduce their risk?\u201d\n\nSince the end of the Cold War, public health officials have tried, without alarming the public, to send a new message to those who might be nuclear blast survivors: stay where you are, don\u2019t try to leave your building, or leave your town \u2014 at least until officials say it is safe. That is likely to be a key message of the C.D.C. presentation.\n\n\u201cWhat they are doing now is getting that message out ahead of time,\u201d said Dr. Mark Keim, a widely recognized disaster medicine expert who worked for the C.D.C. for 16 years. \u201cAfter a nuclear detonation is when the highest levels of radiation is in the environment. People who are survivors might try to go out to a hospital or evacuate the city. If that\u2019s the case, they would increase their exposure to radiation and that\u2019s where more deaths would occur, even more than the detonation itself.\u201d\n\nDr. Keim said he worked on one recent study that showed that more than 250,000 people could survive a ten kiloton nuclear bomb on a city by simply staying where they are.\n\nThe state of Hawaii has recently begun a public awareness campaign, including resurrecting and testing a warning siren system used during the Cold War. It is running a series of advertisements advising the public to remain indoors if such an attack were to occur.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMeanwhile, in New York, old Cold War signs designating nuclear fallout shelters that are now defunct have been removed of late, from many buildings, including schools.", "title": "The C.D.C. Wants to Get People Prepared for Nuclear War", "authors": ["Sheila Kaplan"]} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "One glance at the 205th Street station on the D line Thursday morning and you might think, case closed, the mayor has it right. The governor is too much in love with frills, not the unsexy nuts and bolts of keeping up the subway system.\n\nYellow caution tape blocked parts of the platform. Cladding on girders was crumbling. A water leak has mapped itself along the tile walls in rust brown lines.\n\nIt is as if the place is melting.\n\nYou could look at that mess, and think, no wonder Mayor Bill de Blasio said, \u201cWe\u2019re going to continue to make the point that we don\u2019t like the direction the M.T.A. is taking, and we\u2019re going to be speaking up about it. The countdown clocks and the Wi-Fi and painting, having lights on bridges \u2014 all that stuff doesn\u2019t matter compared to your subway actually arriving where it\u2019s supposed to arrive on time.\u201d\n\nBut what if the exact opposite is true?\n\nWhat if the problem is that our subway stations and all our infrastructure are not treated as public treasures, and are instead too utilitarian, too trampled, so purposefully unpleasant that no one cares when things are going wrong until the whole place starts falling down?", "title": "The Case for Fancier Subways: We Deserve Them", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-04 00:00:00", "text": "After years of digitizing your entire life, going back to paper can be vexing, though. If you want to make the switch, here\u2019s how.\n\nFirst, figure out how much you want to spend.\n\nPaper planners run the gamut on pricing: They can be $100 or more. \u201cThese are beautiful leather planners, but you may get it and find that you\u2019re just not using it,\u201d Reeve warned. Many of the planners Ms. Reeve reviewed are in the $25 to $35 range, including the Traveler\u2019s Notebook, their top pick.\n\nIf you\u2019re looking for an even more affordable option, the Japan-based retailer Muji sells a basic planner, which also made Wirecutter\u2019s list, for less than $2. Decide how much you want to spend, but consider starting small to test the waters.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nNext, decide what you want your planner to do.\n\nMake a list of things you want to be able to do with a paper planner that you\u2019re already doing digitally. \u201cAsk yourself, \u2018what does this planner need to do for me?\u2019 \u201d Ms. Reeve suggested. \u201cAnd then see what checks off the boxes that you need.\u201d To give you a guideline, Ms. Reeve said that planners typically serve one of five functions:\n\n\u2022 Strict scheduling: Look for a simple business planner that comes in monthly, weekly, daily, or even hourly formats. (Example: The Muji Craft Note Book Monthly A5.)\n\n\u2022 Goal planning: Look for a planner that allows you to write down your to-do list and also map out and track your goals. (Example: the Panda Planner.)\n\n\u2022 Artistic planning: Along with space for scheduling your planner should include pages where you can sketch and keep a journal. (Example: the MochiThings Medium Ardium Planner.)\n\n\u2022 Memory keeping: You might to turn your planner into a memory book of sorts, where you can use it to schedule and to scrapbook. Find a planner that encourages you to doodle or add stickers or photos to your schedule. (Example: the Erin Condren LifePlanner.)\n\n\u2022 Bullet journaling: Look for grid-based paper planners that allow you to use the bullet journaling method. You can keep track of tasks, as well as your schedule, using shorthand. (Example: Leuchtturm1917\u2019s Bullet Journal.)\n\nBefore you actually buy your planner, think about what you want it to do and how you want to use it, considering these five functions. This will make it so much easier to find the right journal for the job.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Smarter Living Newsletter A weekly roundup of the best advice from The Times on living a better, smarter, more fulfilling life. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMs. Reeve recommends starting with the Traveler\u2019s Notebook, because it\u2019s so customizable. \u201cYou can put a calendar in it, but you don\u2019t have to. You can use it as a notebook, you can get grid paper for it, and you can add as few or as many notebook inserts as you want,\u201d she said. \u201cThat one is pretty great if you want to be able to control what is in your planner but not have it be too bulky.\u201d\n\nNarrow down your options.\n\nOnce you know the function of your planner, ask yourself some additional questions to narrow down your choices. For example, does your planner need to be portable? \u201cThere are some bigger planners that we really like,\u201d Ms Reeve said. \u201cThey\u2019re folio-type planners that sit on your desk, but they give you a lot more room for writing.\u201d If you have a small desk or you move around when you work, that might not be ideal. So decide how much space you want for your writing. Will you need to take your planner with you everywhere you go, or can it live on your desk?\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nConsider the material, too. \u201cOne of the best things you can do is go out to a store and touch the planner, feel it and really look at it,\u201d Ms. Reeve said. Rather than ordering online, shopping for your planner in-person will give you a better idea of the paper quality. Plus, you can also see if it will fit in your purse, laptop bag or backpack.\n\nTransition strategically\n\nFinally, come up with a plan for your planner. If you\u2019re like me, your entire life is digital, and you track your schedule with an online calendar and to-do list app. Before you ditch them completely, keep tabs on the events you track with these apps \u2014 birthdays, deadlines, random notes \u2014 then add them to your paper planner accordingly.\n\nThis sounds obvious, but if you have recurring tasks that your to-do list app adds automatically, the process can get confusing. Make a list of those recurring tasks, and don\u2019t forget to put them on your planner each week, month or quarter. It might even help to write down those tasks on a separate page in your planner. For example, if you have a meeting at 2 p.m. every other Wednesday, write that down on a \u201cRecurring Reminders\u201d page that you check each time you plan out your day, week or month.\n\nRather than jump ship completely, you might also gradually introduce paper planning back into your life. For example, I use Google Calendar to keep track of important dates. Rather than write down these many, many dates in my new paper planner, I decided to keep my monthly digital calendar and simply use my paper planner as a weekly scheduler. Every Friday, I plan my upcoming week, look at my digital monthly calendar, and write down any important due dates. As I get into the habit of writing everything down, perhaps I\u2019ll add my monthly schedule to the mix.\n\nAll this said, I did find one downside to using a paper planner. As portable as it may be, it will never match the accessibility of your phone, which can make scheduling difficult. For example, one night as I hopped into bed, my phone buzzed. \u201cCan you have this assignment done by next Wednesday?\u201d a client asked. I wanted to check my schedule and email her back, but I remembered I wasn\u2019t using my digital app anymore, and I didn\u2019t have my paper planner in bed with me. \u201cI guess this will have to wait until tomorrow,\u201d I thought. I put down my phone and went to bed.\n\nCome to think of it, though, maybe that\u2019s not a bad thing.", "title": "The Case for Using a Paper Planner", "authors": ["Kristin Wong"]} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "Soda taxes are modeled on tobacco taxes, which have been hugely successful in reducing smoking and improving public health. But even tobacco taxes are still not high enough, as the economist Robert H. Frank explained recently. And taxes on soda could do far more good if they were higher and more widespread.\n\nToday, Mike Bloomberg, the former New York mayor, and Larry Summers, the former Treasury secretary, are announcing a new global group to advocate for these kinds of taxes. I think of them as \u201chealth taxes,\u201d and they can also cover alcohol and forms of sugar beyond soda. The group includes the president of Uruguay and the former prime minister of New Zealand, as well as leaders from Britain, China and Nigeria.\n\nWhen I spoke with Bloomberg and Summers this week, they said they were well aware of the tricky politics of these taxes. Some people are skeptical of having the government favor one kind of behavior over another, while others worry that taxes on soda, alcohol and tobacco predominantlyhurt the poor.\n\nBut Bloomberg argues that government has a duty to promote public health \u2014 and that obesity and the use of tobacco and alcohol are three big, and preventable, public-health problems. They are a large part of the reason that, for the first time in history, noncommunicable diseases now kill more people than communicable diseases. It\u2019s also clear that these taxes work: They reduce consumption, which means they don\u2019t overburden the budgets of poor families.\n\n\u201cI think this is about as close to free-lunch, win-win policy as economists have found,\u201d Summers said.", "title": "Opinion | The Case for the Health Taxes", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-03 00:00:00", "text": "II. WHY WE MUST SAVE THE SUBWAY\n\nThe subway has been saved before, and the man who saved it was Richard Ravitch. Stocky, white-haired and gruff, Ravitch, now 84, is the type of civic macher you don\u2019t see much anymore, an urban idealist who has spent his career moving back and forth between the public and private sectors. His grandfather fled the pogroms in Russia, and \u2014 classic New York story \u2014 created a successful construction business from nothing. He lost everything in the Depression, and then his son, Ravitch\u2019s father, made his name building apartment buildings on Central Park West.\n\nRavitch followed his father into the real estate business. In the 1960s, he served on President Lyndon Johnson\u2019s National Commission on Urban Problems, and in 1973, after 12 years of trying, he completed Waterside, a $78 million, 1,470-unit development for low-and-middle-income families on the East River, just south of the United Nations. A couple of years later, Ravitch played a critical role in rescuing New York City from its fiscal crisis, helping to persuade the teachers\u2019 union to invest $150 million of its pension fund in a new series of city bonds. And in 1979, he was named chairman of the M.T.A.\n\nRavitch didn\u2019t need the job or even really want it. He waived his salary and took to wearing a bulletproof vest in public after someone threatening to kill him shot an M.T.A. police officer at his office. But he was a child of the New Deal and a passionate believer in the subway, which at the time was in even worse shape than it is today.\n\nDuring the fiscal crisis, drastic funding cuts had spun the subway into a downward spiral of deteriorating tracks, malfunctioning cars, increasing crime and falling ridership, a steep decline that tracked the city\u2019s own postindustrial collapse. To reverse the trend, Ravitch prepared a detailed breakdown of the costs of repairing and replacing all of the system\u2019s outdated equipment and proposed a sweeping plan to help fund the work. He argued at the time: \u201cThe transit situation, though lacking the drama of imminent bankruptcy, represents an equally grave threat to our economy, the social equilibrium and the survival of the greatest city in the world.\u201d\n\nThe subway\u2019s importance to the city begins with a single, durable economic principle: Cities create density, and density creates growth. Economists call the phenomenon agglomeration. Not only does geographical proximity reduce costs, but it also facilitates the exchange of knowledge and spurs innovation. It\u2019s a principle that holds true for better and worse and regardless of the industry. The free-market economist Edward Glaeser has pointed out that the junk bonds and leveraged buyouts of \u201970s and \u201980s Wall Street were as much the product of human collaboration as they were of corporate greed. The urban-planning professor Elizabeth Currid-Halkett coined the phrase \u201cthe Warhol economy\u201d to describe how this same sort of cross-fertilization and idea-sharing works in New York\u2019s art, fashion and music worlds. As industries grow, they attract and create new, connected ones: Book publishers beget book agents, tech start-ups beget venture-capital firms and so on. It all begins with the ability to pack large numbers of people into small spaces and then unpack them at the end of the day. Without the subway, this process breaks down, and the city dissipates.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nRavitch took his case to editorial boards and legislative leaders. But there was a problem. No one wanted new taxes. So Ravitch cold-called David Rockefeller, the longtime head of Chase Manhattan Bank. \u201cI said, \u2018Mr. Rockefeller, this is an audacious request, but would you get up at 5 in the morning and let me show you the subway system?\u2019 \u201d he told me one afternoon in his office at Waterside. \u201cAnd he said yes.\u201d Ravitch then suggested that Rockefeller bring along the chairman of MetLife and the president of AT&T. All three went and saw the dirty, graffiti-scarred system firsthand. As Ravitch tells the story, that was all it took: Rockefeller called the majority leader of the State Senate and told him to \u201cgive Ravitch what he needs.\u201d The tax package passed, and Ravitch ultimately raised $7.7 billion \u2014 more than $17 billion in today\u2019s dollars \u2014 much of which was spent replacing cars, refurbishing stations and increasing maintenance.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe turnaround was not immediate. A year after Ravitch\u2019s tax plan was enacted, annual subway ridership dropped below one billion. But before long, as the system gradually became safer, more reliable and less unsavory, it started to trend up. By 2015, ridership had hit 1.7 billion, a level not seen since the late 1940s.\n\nThe rejuvenation of the subway has been intertwined with a protracted period of staggering economic prosperity \u2014 agglomeration at work. New York rebuilt the subway, and the subway rebuilt the city. It was one of the great urban renaissance stories of our modern era. But now that the city is thriving, it faces another challenge, perhaps an even greater one: how to spread this staggering wealth more evenly. The subway might again be a central part of the solution.\n\nIf the story of the subway is the story of density, it is also the story of land \u2014 and more to the point, the story of land value. Before the first tracks had even been laid, real estate speculators were gobbling up farmland and empty lots along the proposed route and then quickly flipping their parcels at huge premiums to builders. When the subway recovered from its last major crisis, it again began throwing off enormous returns for the owners of the land above it. From 1993 to 2013, the average price for a co-op or condo in TriBeCa rose from $182 per square foot to $1,569. In the process, prime real estate in Manhattan was transformed from a place where people lived and built businesses into a high-yield investment in which absentee owners parked their money and watched it grow.\n\nAs Manhattan\u2019s business-district centers became denser and its scarce real estate more expensive, the growth started to spill out, following the subway\u2019s snaking lines across the river, into Brooklyn and Queens. \u201cDevelopers build things where the subway works, and we build far fewer things where it doesn\u2019t,\u201d Jed Walentas, the 43-year-old principal of the real estate development company Two Trees Management, told me recently over lunch at a cafe in Dumbo, Brooklyn\u2019s answer to SoHo. \u201cWe put density where there\u2019s transit.\u201d Walentas, who was wearing the familiar Brooklyn uniform of jeans, New Balance sneakers and a blue hoodie, and his father, David, own a good chunk of Dumbo, an investment that has made them rich \u2014 house in the Hamptons, vacations heli-skiing \u2014 beyond the wildest dreams of most New Yorkers.\n\nI\u2019ve known Walentas since the early 2000s, when I rented a desk in one of his many buildings in the neighborhood, a turn-of-the-century factory that has since been converted into multimillion-dollar condominiums. This is pretty representative of Dumbo\u2019s overall trajectory over the last two decades. It\u2019s a stark transformation that would have been impossible to predict when his father first started buying up the neighborhood\u2019s underutilized properties in the early 1980s, before it was widely known as Dumbo. What enabled it to happen wasn\u2019t just the neighborhood\u2019s excellent subway access \u2014 it\u2019s sandwiched between the F line and the A line \u2014 or the city\u2019s economic recovery, or even the exodus of rich people priced out of Manhattan by even richer people. The transformation of Dumbo required something much simpler: a change in the zoning law. For years, the neighborhood had been restricted to only manufacturing uses, a legacy of the city\u2019s losing battle to retain industrial jobs in the 1960s. In the late \u201990s, Walentas and his father were able to persuade the city to jettison these old rules and allow them to completely remake the neighborhood, filling old factories with loft apartments, design-and-tech-centric offices, retail stores, artists\u2019 studios and new condo towers. In the subsequent 20 years, as the neighborhood changed, average condo prices rose from $200 per square foot to more than $1,500. More recently, Walentas has pushed north into Williamsburg, leveraging similar rezonings there to turn a former textile factory into the trendy Wythe Hotel (near the L train) and a 19th-century Domino sugar refinery (J, M and Z) into three million square feet of office space, retail stores, parks and apartments.\n\nLike most good-government tools, zoning sounds boring, but it is in fact a secret means by which cities are shaped and fortunes are made. If the subway delivers density, zoning determines where that density goes by doing things like placing limits on how tall buildings can rise or how many dwellings they can contain. New York\u2019s zoning codes are byzantine, the product of years of pushing and pulling between the desire to allow the city to evolve and grow and the impulse to keep development in check. These codes have helped preserve the city\u2019s historic buildings and neighborhoods while preventing its streets from being forever cast into darkness by endless rows of skyscrapers. But they have also had the effect of restricting the supply of housing, which has driven up prices, especially in neighborhoods with desirable buildings and good subway access. \u201cI rent studio apartments for $3,400 a month,\u201d Walentas told me. \u201cIt doesn\u2019t make any sense.\u201d", "title": "The Case for the Subway", "authors": ["Jonathan Mahler"]} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "One of the first things I asked her, on the record, was how she felt about the term \u201cscience fiction\u201d as applied to her work. The response she gave was preceded by a sound I would come to know well \u2014 a good-natured, contemptuous snort.\n\n\u201cWhere I can get prickly, Wray, is if I\u2019m just called a sci-fi writer,\u201d she said. \u201cI\u2019m not. I\u2019m a novelist and a poet. Don\u2019t shove me into your pigeonhole, where I don\u2019t fit, because I\u2019m all over. My tentacles are coming out of the pigeonhole in all directions.\u201d\n\nMy tentacles are coming out of the pigeonhole in all directions. If there\u2019s ever been a better description of Ms. Le Guin\u2019s astonishingly diverse and adventurous body of work, I\u2019ve yet to come across it. She\u2019ll doubtlessly be remembered for her sophisticated, nuanced and profoundly humanistic speculative fiction, and of course for her series of magical coming-of-age novels, the Earthsea series, without which the Harry Potter megafranchise could scarcely be imagined. But she was more than a sci-fi or fantasy writer, much more. She was more than her identity as a trailblazer in the overwhelmingly male (and chauvinistic) field of 1960s and \u201970s science fiction, as well, and more than an iconoclastic thinker on gender, or on ethics, or on the material world. The much-discussed fluidity of gender in her most famous novel, \u201cThe Left Hand of Darkness,\u201d could serve as a metaphor for Ms. Le Guin\u2019s entire approach to living, thinking and creating: She reserved the right to think, and write, and react as she saw fit \u2014 and to inhabit a completely different role as the occasion, or the project, demanded.\n\nMs. Le Guin cared passionately about many things, as is clear to any reader of her books: the rights of indigenous peoples, the search for alternatives to our pitiless economic scheme, the myth of innate gender difference, our slow collective murder of the planet. But what she cared about above all, it seems to me, was the paramount freedom \u2014 if not obligation \u2014 of all thinking individuals to define their personal enterprise strictly for, and by, themselves. By the time I came to know her, Ms. Le Guin had made peace with the nature of her legacy, and with the reductive effects of the passage of time. But it was, to the end, an anarchist\u2019s peace.\n\nI learned many things from Ms. Le Guin in the course of that first day, which we spent drinking tea and chatting on her slightly vertiginous veranda, with its glorious view of the snowy cone of Mount St. Helens. We talked about the usefulness of whispering one\u2019s writing aloud when revising, and how it somehow functioned better than reading at a normal volume, when trying to get the music of a sentence right. We talked about the advantages an interest in ethnography can give to writers interested in imagining entire societies, if not whole worlds. We talked about the mysterious power of artists in the last stages of their creative lives, when they were writing to please no one but themselves.", "title": "Opinion | The Category-Defying Genius of Ursula K. Le Guin", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-16 00:00:00", "text": "But for all the medals that flowed from the Karolyi ranch, it can no longer be the site of the national training center. The place is haunted now.\n\nDr. Lawrence G. Nassar, the former national team doctor, has been accused of molesting gymnasts there, as well as in his home and other workplaces. He has pleaded guilty to sexual assault and is to be sentenced this week in Michigan, where about 100 women are expected to speak or submit written statements about what Dr. Nassar did to them. He is already serving a 60-year prison term on federal child pornography charges.\n\nSimone Biles, one of the most decorated gymnasts in history and a star of the 2016 Rio Olympics, on Monday became the latest athlete to add her name to the long list of Nassar\u2019s accusers. Ms. Biles made a point of saying that she dreads training at the ranch.\n\n\u201cIt breaks my heart even more to think that as I work toward my dream of competing in Tokyo 2020, I will have to continually return to the same training facility where I was abused,\u201d she wrote on Twitter and Instagram.", "title": "The Center of U.S. Gymnastics\u2019 Success Is Now a Haunted House", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "Many members of Congress, like Mr. Cuellar, had expected Mr. Kelly to be a force for stability in a White House that has at times seemed consumed with dysfunction, but have found a different reality.\n\n\u201cHe brought some order to the chaos that was there, but it\u2019s a long way from a functioning White House,\u201d said Senator Richard J. Durbin of Illinois, the second-ranking Democrat, said in an interview for \u201cThe Daily,\u201d a New York Times podcast. \u201cHis role from time to time I\u2019ve considered to be destructive, sometimes constructive. I wonder, you know, if he really is the man I thought he was when I voted for him as secretary of D.H.S.\u201d\n\nMr. Durbin, who has clashed with Mr. Trump over his assertion that the president used a vulgar term in an immigration meeting last week, was referring to the Department of Homeland Security, which Mr. Kelly led before taking his current position.\n\nMr. Kelly has made little secret of the fact that he never wanted to be White House chief of staff, and took the job out of the same sense of duty that led him to a four-decade career in the Marines.\n\nIn the West Wing, Mr. Kelly seldom allows the staff to forget the dynamic, according to people who have observed him, often positioning himself as a one-man check against dangerous or reckless moves by the commander in chief. His loyalty is not to the president, \u201cbut to the Constitution and the country,\u201d he has said, according to two people with direct knowledge of his remarks.\n\nMr. Kelly, officials say, has made a conscious decision not to focus as much on curbing the president\u2019s penchant for tweeting or saying inflammatory things, and to instead pour his efforts into controlling who sees and talks to Mr. Trump and trying to shape his thinking on key issues.\n\n\u201cI have said many times I was not put in this job to change the way the president of the United States does business,\u201d he said in an interview with Fox News on Wednesday. \u201cI was put in the job to make sure the staff process better informs him on a range of issues.\u201d", "title": "The Chaos President vs. His Iron-Fisted Chief of Staff", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "\u2022 An organizer of the event, the businessman David Meller, has stepped down from a nonexecutive chairman position at the Department of Education.\n\n\u2022 British lawmakers demanded that companies that had attended the event publish their employee gender ratios quickly.\n\n\u2022 The Bank of England said that Mark Carney would not follow through on a lunch that was auctioned off at the dinner.\n\n\u2022 Reporters began looking into the charity\u2019s public financial reports, and were left unimpressed:\n\n\u2022 Britain\u2019s charity overseer has begun an investigation into the allegations of sexual harassment.\n\n\u2014 Michael J. de la Merced\n\nStrange bedfellows at Davos\n\nHere at Davos, people are buzzing about businesses\u2019 need to do good for society. (There\u2019s an Equality Lounge on site at the World Economic Forum, and attendees are still talking about BlackRock\u2019s new initiative.) And the singer Usher is here for a celebration of what would have been Nelson Mandela\u2019s 100th birthday.\n\nTravis Kalanick is at the World Economic Forum. He doesn\u2019t have an official attendee badge, but he made the rounds at dinners and parties last night.\n\nOf course, officially invited is Uber\u2019s current C.E.O., Dara Khosrowshahi, who was on a panel discussion that Andrew moderated yesterday. (Mr. Khosrowshahi told CNBC that his relationship with his predecessor was \u201cfine, but strained.\u201d)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhere it got awkward: Both men attended a dinner hosted by Jack Ma of Alibaba, according to our spies. They sat on opposite ends of the table.\n\nMore from the Swiss Alps\n\n\u2022 As President Trump prepares to fly to the World Economic Forum, he is likely to feel vindicated coming to a club of elites that had long scorned him. (NYT)\n\n\u2022 Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin argued that a weaker dollar is a good thing. (CNBC)\n\n\u2022 The #MeToo movement has sparked new discussions on gender equality. (NYT)\n\n\u2022 Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India urged attendees to embrace globalization and fight climate change. He is one of several world leaders expected to push back against Mr. Trump\u2019s more nationalistic agenda. (NYT)\n\n\u2022 China\u2019s point person here is Liu He, the architect of his government\u2019s economic policy. (Bloomberg)\n\n\u2022 David Rubenstein of the Carlyle Group is worried that people aren\u2019t worried. (CNBC)\n\n\u2022 The fashion industry is shaping the agenda of the World Economic Forum. (NYT)\n\nWhy a stronger dollar is good for the U.S.\n\nThe slide in the American dollar gained momentum Wednesday after Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin said a weaker dollar was good for the United States.\n\nRobert Rubin, who served as Treasury Secretary in the Clinton Administration, was sharply critical of Mr. Mnuchin\u2019s comments.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI\u2019ve always felt that our self interest was in having a strong dollar,\u201d Mr. Rubin said in an interview in his office at the Council on Foreign Relations, where he is chairman emeritus.\n\nThe best way for United States companies to compete globally, Mr. Rubin said, is for them to be \u201cproductive, efficient, and effective.\u201d And the best way for the government to help them do that, he said, is through investments in education, infrastructure and other programs that improve the country\u2019s long-term competitiveness.\n\n\u201cPromote our ability to export by our investments in our economy,\u201d Mr. Rubin said, \u201cnot by weakening our terms of trade.\u201d\n\nAbandoning the United States\u2019 longstanding strong-dollar policy, Mr. Rubin said, would carry risks to both the United States economy and the global financial system.\n\n\u201cA loss of confidence in our currency could also undermine our interest rate markets and our equities markets,\u201d he said. A strong-dollar policy, by contrast, will \u201cmaintain the confidence of the world in our currency and our economy.\u201d\n\n\u2014 Ben Casselman\n\nE.U. fines Qualcomm $1.2 billion\n\nThe big fine from European antitrust regulators bolsters Margrethe Vestager\u2019s standing as perhaps the world\u2019s most aggressive overseer of tech companies.\n\nMore from Chad Bray of the NYT:\n\nThe penalty of 997 million euros follows a two-year investigation into allegations that the company abused a dominant market position in Europe. Officials in Brussels say that Qualcomm offered financial incentives to Apple so that it would buy equipment solely from Qualcomm. Qualcomm can appeal the ruling, which would probably extend a case that was originally announced in the summer of 2015, for years to come.\n\nPhoto\n\nTech giants find fewer friends in Washington\n\nThe Democratic Party once embraced Silicon Valley. But with questions arising about the power of companies like Google and Facebook \u2014 as well as the role they played in Russia\u2019s interference with the 2016 election \u2014 politicians and activists alike are calling for tighter scrutiny and regulation.\n\nMore from Cecilia Kang and Daisuke Wakabayashi in the NYT:\n\n\u201cDemocrats and progressives still strongly feel that there are shared values with Silicon Valley, but there is also a real concern over the industry\u2019s increasingly concentrated wealth and power,\u201d said Daniel Sepulveda, an ambassador and deputy assistant secretary at the State Department for the Obama administration.\n\n(Democrats are also pressing for disclosures into whether Russian bots are helping to manipulate public opinion on Robert Mueller\u2019s investigation.)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMeanwhile, frenemies are applying pressure. AT&T is arguing that net neutrality rules should apply to Facebook and Google if they are to be applied to broadband service providers.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story The All-New DealBook Newsletter Our columnist Andrew Ross Sorkin and his Times colleagues help you make sense of major business and policy headlines \u2014 and the power-brokers who shape them. Och-Ziff is interviewing outside candidates for C.E.O. Mr. Levin is thinking about leaving. And some investors are considering withdrawing money amid the turmoil.\n\nWhat happened: As Mr. Levin grew in stature, he began to press for more responsibility and money, irritating his mentor, the newspaper reported.\n\nMore from Greg Zuckerman and Rob Copeland of the WSJ:\n\nIn late December, the five independent directors of Och-Ziff\u2019s seven-member board presented the plan to move forward with the succession this year and unanimously voted to approve it. \u201cThis is where the board wants to go,\u201d a board member told Mr. Och.
