She watched concerts on PBS, baked beautiful strudels, gossiped about her neighbors, and was interested in every aspect of our lives and life in general. One month after her 100th birthday, she died in her sleep. She had been living on her own for 12 years.\n\nWhen I moved to Massachusetts in my mid-20s, my father broke off a small branch of the ficus, as he had done when he was 8 years old, and gave it to me to plant in my new home.\n\nMany years later, shortly after my grandmother passed, I moved to New York with my own branch, clipped from the plant that had hit the ceiling of my Cambridge apartment. I put it in a water-filled cup in the cup holder of my Toyota hoping it would withstand four hours in transit. A friend told me it wouldn\u2019t survive.\n\n\u201cFicuses don\u2019t like change,\u201d he said.\n\nBut this wasn\u2019t any ficus. The roots from which it sprung clung to postwar soil. The trunk that birthed it guarded whispers in dark corners. Its leaves sank in the dirty Balkan air, and rose again and rooted and continued to root and rise, this great grand-plant of my grandmother\u2019s ocean-crossing ficus.", "title": "The Ficus That Crossed an Ocean", "authors": ["Ada Brunstein"]} {"date": "2018-01-21 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cMedical Research? Congress Cheers. Medical Care? Congress Brawls\u201d (news article, Jan. 7):\n\nAs an academic, I applaud political support for biomedical research. However, shortchanging health care is shortsighted and not self-serving, even for those of us with Cadillac health care plans.\n\nYou might not get that lifesaving stroke treatment in time if our world-class emergency rooms are clogged because of uninsured patients, understaffed or closing. Your primary care physicians will quit clinical work if they continue to burn out trying to care for an increasing number of underinsured patients, while navigating more and more paperwork to get compensated.\n\nOur academic medical centers will continue to see many of our brightest trainees avoid the grind of clinical work as they pursue research careers with better work-life balance and prospects for advancement.\n\nThink twice before the next health care vote.\n\nHENRY WU, ATLANTA\n\nThe writer is an assistant professor of medicine at Emory University.", "title": "Opinion | The Fight for Medical Funds", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nThere\u2019s a lot to look forward to, or at least be curious about, on television and streaming this winter. New series will arrive starring Anna Paquin (WGN\u2019s \u201cBellevue\u201d), Sean Bean (\u201cThe Oath\u201d on Crackle) and Tim Robbins and Holly Hunter (HBO\u2019s \u201cHere and Now\u201d). \u201cUnReal\u201d on Lifetime and \u201cStrike Back\u201d on Cinemax return after long hiatuses. High-profile projects like \u201cThe Alienist\u201d on TNT, \u201cPhilip K. Dick\u2019s Electric Dreams\u201d on Amazon, \u201cThe Looming Tower\u201d on Hulu and \u201cThe Assassination of Gianni Versace: American Crime Story\u201d on FX are generating their own buzz. And favorites like AMC\u2019s \u201cThe Walking Dead,\u201d PBS\u2019s \u201cCall the Midwife,\u201d Showtime\u2019s \u201cHomeland\u201d and IFC\u2019s \u201cPortlandia\u201d (in its final season) promise to bring happiness to their fans. All that plus this very abbreviated list of particular highlights.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2018DETECTORISTS\u2019 In its final season, this most wistful of comedies homes in on the essentials. Will the metal detectorists Lance (Toby Jones) and Andy (Mackenzie Crook) break through their passive-aggressive armor and not hopelessly fumble their love lives? And in one of the most quietly suspenseful story lines on TV, will they find their white whale, the Roman hoard they\u2019re convinced is buried in a local field? Answers are provided at the hands of the show\u2019s peerless cast, including Rachael Stirling, Diana Rigg, Rebecca Callard, Sophie Thompson, Mr. Crook and the endlessly expressive Mr. Jones. (Acorn TV, Jan. 15)\n\n\u2018HIGH MAINTENANCE\u2019 The comedy that gets the pretensions and anxieties of certain precincts of 21st-century Brooklyn just right opens its second season on HBO with a typically clever episode. The borough reacts with dismay to an unspecified but horrific event that immediately increases demand for the weed guy\u2019s product. (HBO, Jan. 19)\n\n\u2018PLANET EARTH: BLUE PLANET II\u2019 The further underwater adventures of David Attenborough, the manager of nature\u2019s Instagram account. Coming 17 years after the original \u201cBlue Planet,\u201d this seven-episode follow-up puts a greater emphasis on man-made threats to the world\u2019s oceans, but the spectacular, voyeuristic images are as purely pleasurable as ever. (BBC America, Jan. 20)\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2018COUNTERPART\u2019 Two types of thrillers \u2014 the paranoid Cold War and the dystopian science-fiction varieties \u2014 are overlaid in this nifty series, which posits alternate earths that intersect in a Berlin basement. The premise is explored in reasonably plausible ways, but the real incentive to watch is J. K. Simmons, who plays two roles: a gentle paper pusher in one world and a cynical tough guy in the other. It\u2019s as if the Simmons of \u201cGrowing Up Fisher\u201d met the Simmons of \u201cOz.\u201d Eventually, of course, the two men have to impersonate each other, at which point it\u2019s Simmons squared, which is pretty hard to beat. (Starz, Jan. 21)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u20182 DOPE QUEENS\u2019 Phoebe Robinson and Jessica Williams\u2019s popular live podcast gets a four-episode TV run, directed by Tig Notaro and filmed at the Kings Theater in Brooklyn. Each episode has a theme and a star guest, including \u201cNew York\u201d with Jon Stewart, \u201cHot Peen\u201d with Tituss Burgess and \u201cBlack Nerds\u201d with Uzo Aduba. (HBO, Feb. 2)", "title": "The Forecast: \u2018The Americans\u2019 Ends, J.K. Simmons Multiplies", "authors": ["Mike Hale"]} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cTrump Voters, One Year In\u201d (letters, Jan. 18):\n\nAs one who does think of President Trump\u2019s supporters as among the \u201cdeplorables\u201d \u2014 people who are racist and xenophobic, people who fear the world, people who blame others for all their challenges and woes, people who hate the very idea of government as a force for good \u2014 I was fascinated to read the letters from Trump voters.\n\nI thought it was a wise and striking decision on The Times\u2019s part to run them in its own editorial board\u2019s space. Indeed, that\u2019s the space they deserved to maximize their impact.\n\nThanks to these letters, I do have a better understanding now of what these writers see happening under Mr. Trump: an end to pussyfooted, mealy-mouthed weakness and to regulatory overreach; a return to forcefulness and certainty on the world stage and unleashed optimism at home.\n\nBut then I stop and think about what it is they\u2019re really so happy about: reckless threats and pointless insults passing for diplomacy; a rejection of fact, science and even the notions of decency, humanity and justice; a litany of lies and myths as the foundation of policy; and historic levels of incompetence and self-dealing across the agencies of government from the White House on down.", "title": "Opinion | The Furor Over a Forum for Trump Fans", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "Like Alexis de Tocqueville\u2019s \u201cDemocracy in America,\u201d Richard Hofstadter\u2019s \u201cThe Paranoid Style in American Politics\u201d is often cited but less often read, which is a shame because the landmark 1964 essay helps explain our times. Consider Ron Johnson, the Republican senator from Wisconsin.\n\nOn Tuesday, the chairman of the Homeland Security Committee described a text message between the F.B.I. lawyer Lisa Page and the counterespionage agent Peter Strzok as \u201cfurther evidence of corruption, more than bias, but corruption of the highest levels of the F.B.I.\u201d He also made reference to a \u201csecret society\u201d and an \u201can informant talking about a group that were holding secret meetings off-site.\u201d\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s so much smoke here, there\u2019s so much suspicion,\u201d Johnson warned on Fox News.\n\nUh-huh. By Thursday, Johnson was forced to backpedal when it turned out that the text message he had found suspicious was an office in-joke between two colleagues having an affair revolving around a Vladimir Putin-themed calendar. As for the off-site, Johnson also admitted he had no idea what it was for or about, not that it prevented him from painting it in the most sinister colors. Maybe there was a scavenger hunt for Hillary\u2019s missing emails.", "title": "Opinion | The G.O.P.\u2019s Bonfire of the Sanities", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "Why not? In the House, the main problem was ultra-right-wing members, who don\u2019t want to support even routine spending. Still, Republicans didn\u2019t need Democrats to get a bill through.\n\nHowever, passing the bill in the Senate will require 60 votes. With only 51 Republicans Democratic votes are needed.\n\nOnce upon a time a party that needed some help from across the aisle would have sought a deal that made some concessions to the other party\u2019s agenda. And until a few days ago it seemed as if normal political rules still applied.\n\nA bipartisan group of senators reached a deal that would have met a key Democratic priority: protecting the Dreamers \u2014 young people who were brought to the United States illegally as children, who want to remain in the only country they have ever known. And in return for that agreement \u2014 which actually involved a number of concessions to Republicans \u2014 Democrats would have been willing to help keep the government running.\n\nProtecting the Dreamers is, by the way, enormously popular, even among Republicans, who oppose deporting them by a huge margin. So it\u2019s not as if the G.O.P. would be giving up a lot. But Donald Trump torpedoed the deal, apparently because he doesn\u2019t want immigrants from \u201cshithole countries.\u201d\n\nThis sent Republican leaders back to the drawing board, and what they came up with was another doomsday threat, this time aimed at children.\n\nYou see, back in 1997 a bipartisan deal created the Children\u2019s Health Insurance Program, or CHIP, an expansion of Medicaid to cover children who might not otherwise have been eligible. CHIP has been a huge success story, at modest cost. And at this point the Congressional Budget Office says that extending CHIP for another 10 years would actually save the government money, because some families forced off the program would end up receiving subsidies for more expensive sources of coverage.\n\nBut Republicans allowed CHIP funding to expire almost four months ago. Since then, they\u2019ve kept promising to do something, but haven\u2019t. And now they\u2019ve attached an extension of the program to passage of a continuing resolution, believing that this will force Democrats to give them what they want.", "title": "Opinion | The G.O.P.\u2019s Doomsday-Machine Politics", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-28 00:00:00", "text": "People who care about basic American freedoms should be grateful to the Senate majority leader, Mitch McConnell, for one thing: He has given liberals another good reason to flock to the polls in November.\n\nMr. McConnell is set to hold a procedural vote this week on a bill that would ban abortion at 20 weeks of pregnancy. The so-called Pain-Capable Unborn Child Protection Act, sponsored by Senator Lindsey Graham, a South Carolina Republican, is part of a long-term legislative effort by the anti-abortion movement to gut Roe v. Wade and severely curtail abortion access nationwide.\n\nTwenty-week abortion bans, enacted in more than a dozen states and struck down in two, violate the Supreme Court\u2019s standard that abortion can be restricted only when a fetus is viable outside the womb. Many, including the one being considered by the Senate, are based on claims not supported by most scientists about when a fetus feels pain.\n\nOnly about 1 percent of women seeking abortions do so after 21 weeks, and they often make that decision because a fetal abnormality has been found or because their own health is in danger. Twenty-week bans particularly curb access for poor women, who often struggle to find the money and time for the procedure.", "title": "Opinion | The Gathering Threat to Abortion Rights", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-31 00:00:00", "text": "While there are a growing number of publishing houses that specialize in publishing works in translation and international literature \u2014 including Europa Editions, Archipelago Books, AmazonCrossing and Tilted Axis, which publishes contemporary Asian literature, mainly by women \u2014 translated literature still accounts for a tiny percentage of books published in the United States. And although international authors like Elena Ferrante, Haruki Murakami, Karl Ove Knausgaard and Han Kang have been embraced by American readers, there\u2019s still a lingering perception that translated literature doesn\u2019t sell well in the United States.\n\nIt\u2019s not the first time the National Book Awards has broadened its scope. In the 1960s and 1970s, an array of new categories were added, including prizes in science, philosophy and religion, history and biography, arts and letters, contemporary thought, autobiography, first novel, original paperback and children\u2019s books, as well as a prize for translation. Then, in 1986, the organization scaled back drastically, to just two awards, for fiction and nonfiction. It later added poetry and young people\u2019s literature.\n\nThe new translation prize marks the first time the foundation has added a category in more than two decades.\n\nOther literary institutions have also made efforts to highlight works in translation. PEN America, formerly the PEN American Center, has given out a translation prize to highlight international works since the 1960s. In 2015, the Booker Prize Foundation recast its international prize, which was previously open to novelists writing in English, as an award dedicated to fiction in translation.\n\nWhen other major literary awards have expanded their geographic reach, there\u2019s occasionally been a backlash. In 2014, the Man Booker Prize, which was previously open only to writers from Britain, Ireland, Zimbabwe and the Commonwealth, began considering any novel written in English and published in Britain, prompting complaints that the prize was sacrificing its British character. Some expressed concern that American writers would dominate the award, and those fears have been heightened in recent years as Americans have made up a disproportionate share of writers who make the shortlist. (For the last two years, the Booker has gone to Paul Beatty and George Saunders, who are both from the United States).", "title": "The Globalization of the National Book Awards", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-07 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Meyers wisecracked in his monologue about the notion that Ms. Winfrey \u2014 who has played down her political ambitions before \u2014 might run for president. By the end of her speech, it sounded a tiny bit less like a joke.\n\nStill, for all the consensus from the stage, the Globes still celebrated the power players of a system in which Harvey Weinstein, whose abuses precipitated the current moment, was active just a year ago. And at the awards, by and large, the men \u2014 half of any gender dynamic in Hollywood or elsewhere \u2014 let their \u201cTime\u2019s Up\u201d pins do the talking.\n\nAwards celebration has mingled with dissent before \u2014 like at last year\u2019s Globes, just before the inauguration of Donald J. Trump. (He still took a few digs this year.)\n\nIt\u2019s something else for the usually frothy Globes to be held at a moment when the industry, or at least a portion of it, is dissenting against itself.\n\nThe unsteady balance was apparent from the first footsteps on the red carpet. There were fewer questions about who the stars were wearing, and more about why. (Again, the women fielded a lot more of those questions than the men.)\n\nBut there was dissonance, too, in an awards-media system not usually equipped to handle matters weightier than a champagne bubble. \u201cLet me just tell you, our coverage is woke!\u201d said the E! correspondent Justin Sylvester, by way of introducing the 360-degree camera at the celebrity arrival area.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. It wasn\u2019t quite a celebration; it wasn\u2019t entirely a protest. (Even the black color scheme \u2014 a visual statement for the women, less so for the ordinarily tux-clad men \u2014 conveyed the feeling of a half-demonstration.) The Golden Globes always pitches itself as a televised party, but what kind?\n\nMaybe, as the color scheme suggested, the awards were meant to be a wake for a system of victimization. Women wearing the trousers was one of the major trends of the night, literally and metaphorically.\n\nPhoto\n\nDebra Messing, who used her moment on the red carpet being interviewed by Giuliana Rancic of E! to call out the network for a pay gap between male and female anchors, was also wearing a long tunic over trousers; ditto Christina Hendricks. Claire Foy, of \u201cThe Crown,\u201d went full-on tuxedo (so did Kyra Sedgwick), and Susan Sarandon wore her black suit with a white shirt and a ponytail. Tracee Ellis Ross added satin joggers to her one-shouldered satin gown and turban.\n\nIndeed, asymmetry (symbolism here, folks?) was another major theme, as seen on Emma Stone, Greta Gerwig and Reese Witherspoon. Also the addition of sparkles and surprises: Dakota Johnson\u2019s burst of diamant\u00e9 on her tulle bustle; Mary J. Blige\u2019s gauntlet/sleeve of rhinestones on one arm; the sprinkling of shine across the tops of Michelle Williams and her date, Tarana Burke, founder of the #MeToo movement, refracting the light.\n\nIf black seemed, initially, to be a restrictive dress code (and certainly men complain about it all the time), the reality was that the Beverly Hilton was full of individual interpretations of what, exactly, it could mean (which should show the complainers that they just need to think a little more creatively about their options).\n\nThere were portrait necklines that framed shoulders (Oprah, Meryl Streep) and sheer fabrics that veiled skin (Catherine Zeta-Jones, Halle Berry). Cutouts that played peekaboo with what lay beneath (Sharon Stone) and slits for a lot of leg (Zo\u00eb Kravitz). And armoring, of the most alluring kind: Saoirse Ronan\u2019s hints of crystal chain mail, and the power shoulders of Isabelle Huppert and Gal Gadot.\n\nThere was femininity, gloried in and defined multiple ways via dress.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story The Open Thread Fashion Newsletter A look from across The New York Times at the forces that shape the dress codes we share, with Vanessa Friedman as your personal shopper. Calvin Klein and Tiffany wisely topped theirs by first noting their support for Time\u2019s Up, and only then releasing the details of the outfits, but they were in the minority. (Other houses: take note.) There was no real name-checking on the red carpet, however, a fact that actually served to let everyone enjoy the clothes as much as the women who were wearing them seemed to, without the niggling suggestion that it was all about marketing.\n\nIt\u2019s a lesson worth absorbing, as was the success of the shade solidarity itself. This season, that hand threw the second-fewest passes since Brees arrived in New Orleans, and instead continually thrust the ball into the bellies of Mark Ingram and Alvin Kamara, the running backs responsible for transforming the Saints\u2019 identity.\n\nThe Saints have transformed from a team that depends on Brees to a team that benefits from his talent, but in no way does that diminish his ability to power them to victory. In outlasting the Carolina Panthers for the third time this season, with a 31-26 playoff win amid the din of the Superdome on Sunday, Brees reaffirmed his primacy.\n\nThere have been other instances across his playoff career when Brees sparkled, but those were back when the offense revolved around him and teams designed game plans to neutralize him.", "title": "The Golden Touch of Drew Brees Is Back", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cAs a result of this competition, we have sparked the conversation and changed expectations with regard to who can land on the moon. Many now believe it\u2019s no longer the sole purview of a few government agencies, but now may be achieved by small teams of entrepreneurs, engineers, and innovators from around the world,\u201d said a statement from Peter H. Diamandis, the foundation\u2019s founder and executive chairman, and Marcus Shingles, the chief executive.\n\nThe foundation raised the possibility of a new sponsor or continuing the competition without any cash prizes.\n\nThe competition started with more than 25 teams. The five remaining in the end were Moon Express, based in Cape Canaveral, Fla., SpaceIL in Israel, TeamIndus in India, Hakuto in Japan and Synergy Moon, an international collaboration.\n\nAt the end of last year, SpaceIL and TeamIndus both came up short in trying to raise needed financing. The parent company of the Hakuto team had the money \u2014 in December, it announced it had obtained $90 million in investment \u2014 but it was counting on piggybacking on TeamIndus\u2019s lander to get to the moon. Moon Express also has the money it needs, but it has yet to have the ribbon-cutting on the new facility where it will assemble its lander. Synergy Moon has said little about its progress.\n\n[READ: SpaceX\u2019s Big Rocket, the Falcon Heavy, Finally Reaches the Launchpad]\n\nWhen the competition was first announced, the deadline for launching was the end of 2014.
