Nobody Won.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-22 00:00:00", "text": "Gail: Whew, so glad you mentioned that terrorist. Otherwise I would have agreed with everything you said and then where would we be conversation-wise?\n\nIt is true that the guy who killed eight innocent people with a truck in Manhattan was a product of the visa program, a program that was started to give more Irish and Italians a chance to legally immigrate.\n\nBut what drives me nuts is that the president constantly points to this one terrible crime as an argument that the visa program is bad, while every single day we have stories about innocent people blasted to smithereens by guns, and we never hear a peep. If we wanted to keep America safe, we would really, really crack down on gun purchases.\n\nHowever, I am not demanding we do that to keep the government open.\n\nBret: Please don\u2019t get me wrong. My objection is to the visa lottery, not what\u2019s invidiously called \u201cchain\u201d migration. As you and many others have reminded us, this is how many of our ancestors arrived in this country and worked their tails off so that they could afford to pay steerage for their wives and children. Republicans used to be the \u201cpro-family\u201d party, but that was in days of yore, when George W. Bush was president.\n\nI wrote a column last week pointing out that the same stereotypes and slanders applied today by people like Jeff Sessions against present-day immigrants were made over a century ago against my impoverished Jewish ancestors, who didn\u2019t speak English, didn\u2019t have Ph.D.s, and in a few cases held dangerous political views. Yet just imagine how much worse off America would be today if it had kept out the parents of a Jonas Salk, a Leonard Bernstein or a Mike Bloomberg. The same goes for every single other immigrant group, past or present.\n\nExcept Norwegians, of course!\n\nGail: Isn\u2019t it interesting that Trump almost never talks about his immigrant ancestors? That\u2019s usually reflexive for a politician. The other day when Paul Ryan was trying to get past the \u201cshithole\u201d incident, he instantly began talking about his ancestors from Ireland coming here and laboring on the railroads. Trump\u2019s ancestors came from a terrible town in Germany \u2014 full of fertilizer fumes and impoverished grape-pickers \u2014 but he never mentions it.\n\nBut about that little shutdown. Any other thoughts?\n\nBret: My gut tells me the Democrats were smart to back away from the shutdown, however well founded their doubts might be about getting to a good immigration deal. Bill Clinton crushed the Gingrich Republicans over the shutdown in the mid-1990s. Barack Obama crushed the Republicans again in 2013. And I suspect that\u2019s what Trump is going to do to the Democrats, thereby helping himself politically when we might otherwise be focused on his alleged porn star liaisons and the possibility that the president is lying about it.", "title": "Opinion | The Government Is Dead. Long Live the Government!", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "But the Grammys are also an awards platform that recognizes music in a wide range of categories, 84 in total, most of which never make it to the television screen (apart from a text scroll at the bottom). Often the nominees in the major competitions \u2014 album, song and record of the year \u2014 inspire loud debates, whether about the age of the nominees (generally older) or their race (generally white, though less so this year) or their gender (generally male).\n\nBut the smaller categories can be just as baffling. Part of the problem stems from how the nominees are selected: In a system that can favor campaigning and name recognition over creative merit, the results are often unpredictable and deliriously wrongheaded.", "title": "The Grammy Gems You Won\u2019t Hear on \u2018Music\u2019s Biggest Night\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-04 00:00:00", "text": "Five Japanese television networks covered Hanyu\u2019s performance at the Rostelecom Cup in Moscow. So did several dozen print journalists and photographers who recorded his every jump, spin and utterance. Last spring, the skating website icenetwork.com found Hanyu on the cover of 19 publications called mooks \u2014 a combination of magazine and book \u2014 at a Japanese bookstore.\n\nThe bookstore was not in Tokyo. It was in Midtown Manhattan.\n\n\u201cIt reminds me of when Michael Jackson was in his heyday, or meeting the Pope,\u201d said Jackie Wong, a prominent skating blogger and former skater who lives in New York. \u201cPeople see Hanyu for the first time and they become hysterical or they\u2019re moved to tears. It\u2019s like their lives are complete. It\u2019s crazy.\u201d\n\nAs Hanyu was introduced in Moscow for the short program at the Rostelecom Cup, Japanese fans waved small national flags. On one side of the rink alone, there were 16 banners proclaiming \u201cGo Yuzu\u201d and other exhortations. As Hanyu began to perform to Chopin, the crowd grew so quiet that the scrape of his blades could be heard in the upper reaches of Megasport Arena.\n\nA month earlier, Hanyu had set a world record for points for a short program. But in Moscow, he landed clumsily on a quadruple loop and put his hands to the ice after an awkward combination jump. The judges placed him second to Chen. Still, Hanyu\u2019s appreciative fans showered the ice with dozens of Pooh dolls.\n\n\u201cDid you see the Poohs?\u201d Yoshiko Kobayashi, the high-performance director of the Japanese Skating Federation, later asked an American reporter. \u201cThe ice turned yellow.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAfter a news conference with international reporters, Hanyu was engulfed on a dais by Japanese reporters and photographers.\n\nKobayashi pulled a stopwatch from her purse.\n\n\u201cI control,\u201d she said.\n\nThe Japanese reporters would have five minutes, she said. She gave them almost seven, then freed Hanyu from the scrum.\n\nThe next day, Hanyu\u2019s fans again gathered to watch his free skate. Among them was Saori Kanayama, 30, a Japanese flight attendant who had traveled from Dubai for the competition. She had planned her vacation to attend the Olympics. All she needed was a ticket.\n\nHanyu\u2019s fans wrote thousands of letters to him, made dolls in his likeness and sent him origami, cookies and towels to wipe his face after training. Kanayama brought rock music CDs with her.\n\n\u201cHe has too many Poohs,\u201d she said.\n\nHer reasons for following Hanyu\u2019s career so closely were partly cultural. \u201cJapanese people are shy, we are not supposed to show our honest feelings,\u201d she said. \u201cAs a skater, Yuzuru doesn\u2019t hesitate to show how much he wants to be No. 1.\u201d\n\nWearing a white tunic and skating as a character out of Japanese folklore, Abe no Seimei, a kind of soothsayer and supernatural protector, Hanyu landed a quadruple lutz for the first time in competition. It is the most difficult of the four-revolution jumps currently being performed, requiring the jab of a toe pick, a liftoff from the back outside edge of one skate and a landing on the back outside edge of the other skate.\n\nBut the performance was not flawless. Hanyu finished second over all to Chen. Some of his fans cried in the stands, including one wearing a costume identical to Hanyu\u2019s.\n\nFrank Carroll, a renowned American coach who guided Evan Lysacek to a 2010 Olympic gold medal, attended the Rostelecom Cup. In his view, Hanyu seemed diminished.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t see what he had a few years ago,\u201d Carroll said. \u201cI\u2019m sorry. I know he does some beautiful things, but I don\u2019t see the inspiration.\u201d\n\nAt a news conference, Hanyu complimented Chen as \u201ca wonderfully talented person who does great jumps with a balletic expression.\u201d\n\n\u201cI need to practice more and more,\u201d Hanyu said.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe next evening, Hanyu\u2019s supporters were newly ebullient in filling the lobby of Moscow\u2019s Aerostar Hotel, where the skaters were feted at a banquet. The fans formed two lines through which skaters walked, some stopping briefly for photos and autographs.\n\nA kind of spirit seemed to overtake Hanyu when he skated, lending him endearing masculine and feminine qualities, said one fan, Junko Ino, 36, a teacher from Fukuoka, Japan.\n\n\u201cHe\u2019s powerful and tender,\u201d Ino said. \u201cHis emotion will heal your heart.\u201d\n\nSayuri Arimoto, 50, a software engineer, had traveled from San Mateo, Calif., to see Hanyu, even if it left her co-workers puzzled. \u201cYou travel to Europe just for figure skating?\u201d they asked her.\n\nWhen Hanyu was home in Japan, he sometimes skated at midnight for peace and quiet, his coach said. And in Toronto, where he trained most of the time, he occasionally called his coach to ask for a ride, uncomfortable with some fans who knew his daily routine and waited to ride the bus with him.\n\nAt the Toronto Cricket, Skating and Curling Club, Hanyu\u2019s team makes a great effort to answer his fan mail and to keep fans, bloggers and other journalists from intruding to videotape his practices.\n\n\u201cYou can have a bad day and nobody\u2019s going to be writing about it,\u201d said Orser, Hanyu\u2019s coach.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhen he did not receive a desired result, Hanyu said, he felt a need to apologize to his fans, but did not consider the expectations of his supporters and the news media to be a burden.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cHonestly,\u201d he said through an interpreter, \u201csometimes I\u2019m feeling like they treat me as a celebrity or an idol, but I\u2019m not quite that. But I understand they\u2019re all here to support me and I appreciate that passion.\u201d\n\nIn the lobby of the Aerostar Hotel, Hanyu emerged through a side door, wearing a black suit for the banquet. He almost reached the elevators before fans noticed him. They hurried to take photos and videos. Among them was Hiroko Sato, 49, a neighbor of Hanyu\u2019s in Sendai, Japan. Her family\u2019s construction company had sustained damage during the 2011 earthquake.\n\nHanyu was training at the Sendai rink and, terrified, ran outside in his skates when the ice began to rumble. He and his parents and his sister were left without electricity or drinking water. They spent three days at an emergency shelter at a gymnasium. The rink closed for several months, leaving him a skating vagabond.\n\nUpon winning a gold medal at the 2014 Olympics, Hanyu, then 19, worried aloud that his victory would be a frivolous gesture to those who had suffered in Sendai. That was not true, said Sato, his neighbor. Hanyu skated in a benefit for victims of the earthquake and donated royalties from his two autobiographies to the rink in Sendai.\n\nHanyu had called her after the earthquake, she said, asking, \u201cAre you O.K.?\u201d and telling her, \u201cHang in there.\u201d\n\n\u201cHe gave hope for us,\u201d Sato said. She teared up as she recounted the destruction of the earthquake. \u201cHe got the gold medal at the Olympics.\u201d\n\nThe second week of November, Hanyu was set to compete in his second major pre-Olympic event of the season, the NHK Trophy in Osaka, Japan. Orser, his coach, had described Hanyu as being \u201cso focused, so driven\u201d that he was \u201con the verge of manic\u201d in his determination to win a second Olympic gold medal.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOrser tried to convince Hanyu that there should be a natural ebb and flow to a long skating season. Button, the 1948 and 1952 Olympic champion, cautioned Hanyu not to overtrain. And one of Hanyu\u2019s idols, Evgeni Plushenko of Russia, the 2006 Olympic champion, suggested that Hanyu would not need five quadruple jumps in his Olympic free skate as Chen of the United States aspired to.\n\nShoma Uno, a Japanese teenager who finished second to Hanyu at the 2017 world championships, was also a magnificent jumper. But Hanyu had a decided edge over other skaters in the completeness of his performance \u2014 spins, skating skills, transitions between jumps and musical interpretation, Plushenko said.\n\n\u201cIf he has three quads and skates clean, he can win the Olympics one more time,\u201d Plushenko said. \u201cIf he does all the things he can, he\u2019s going to win easily.\u201d\n\nThe biggest hurdle to his own failed attempt to repeat as Olympic champion, Plushenko said, was injury: \u201cIn my head I was ready to skate but my body is sometimes going, \u2018No, wait, please, please.\u2019\u201d\n\nHis words were prescient. On Nov. 9, a day before the NHK Trophy began, Hanyu attempted a quadruple lutz in practice, but his legs landed in a pretzled position. More than 100 Japanese journalists turned up at a news conference that evening to learn of Hanyu\u2019s condition.\n\nThe next day, it was announced that he had ligament damage in his right ankle but would try to compete. Instead, he withdrew. (Weeks later, it would be revealed that the ankle had also sustained tendon and bone damage.)\n\n\u201cI am very sorry to have everyone worried,\u201d Hanyu said in a statement.\n\nAt Osaka\u2019s Municipal Central Gymnasium, where the NHK Trophy went on without Hanyu, his fans were left dejected. Zeng Yuemeng, 28, an Osaka airport worker, said she had moved to Japan from China in July because of her favorite skater. She carried a Pooh keychain on her purse.\n\n\u201cBecause this is his country,\u201d Zeng said of Hanyu, \u201cmaybe I can see why he has become such a perfect human.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOther fans took a half-hour train ride to pray for Hanyu at a Shinto shrine in Kobe, Japan. Because the shrine\u2019s name \u2014 Yuzuruha \u2014 resembled the first name of the skater, it had become a popular place for fans to write their well-wishes to Hanyu on round wooden plaques. Hundreds of plaques hung on racks at the shrine.", "title": "The Greatest Figure Skater Ever Is Michael Jackson on Ice, Surrounded by Winnie the Poohs", "authors": ["Jer\u00e9 Longman"]} {"date": "2018-01-15 00:00:00", "text": "LONDON \u2014 The Guardian, the British newspaper that won a Pulitzer Prize for its coverage of national security leaks in the United States but whose aggressive international expansion has brought heavy losses, switched to a tabloid print format on Monday as part of efforts to cut costs.\n\nThe newspaper\u2019s shift comes with the British journalism industry in a state of flux, as declining advertising revenues have forced various storied publications to make major changes, from firing hundreds of journalists to shutting down print operations entirely. The challenges mirror many of the difficulties faced by legacy publications the world over as they attempt to transition to more digitally savvy operations.\n\nThe Guardian had long been a standard-bearer in Britain for that shift. The left-wing publication focused on courting vast numbers of readers around the world, and it hired dozens of reporters in the United States and Australia in particular. It has ardently refused to set up a paywall \u2014 the preferred strategy of many of its rivals, from The Times of London to The Wall Street Journal and The New York Times \u2014 opting instead to ask its readers for donations, even setting up a nonprofit arm to help fund its journalism.\n\nFor a while, that strategy appeared to bear fruit. The Guardian shared a Pulitzer Prize with The Washington Post in 2014 for coverage of documents leaked by Edward J. Snowden, the former National Security Agency contractor. That a British newspaper won a prestigious award that had largely been the domain of American publications illustrated the scale of its ambition.", "title": "The Guardian, Britain\u2019s Left-Wing News Power, Goes Tabloid", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-13 00:00:00", "text": "Presidential history also includes the social Darwinism of Theodore Roosevelt, the federal-government-segregating, \u201cBirth of a Nation\u201d-praising Woodrow Wilson \u2014 and the bigotry that came from the mouths of presidents who are generally seen as essential to racial progress. President Lyndon B. Johnson said \u201cnigger\u201d nearly as often as Ku Klux Klansmen did.\n\nThis denial of racism is the heartbeat of racism. Where there is suffering from racist policies, there are denials that those policies are racist. The beat of denial sounds the same across time and space.\n\nI grew up to the beat of racist denial in Queens, not far from where Mr. Trump grew up. I was raised in the urban \u201chell\u201d of neighborhoods he probably avoided, alongside immigrants from countries he derided last week. In school or elsewhere, we all heard recitals of the American ideal of equality, especially on the day we celebrate the life of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Those events often feature recitals of the words \u201call men are created equal,\u201d which were written by a slaveholder who once declared that black people \u201care inferior to the whites in the endowments both of body and mind.\u201d\n\nThomas Jefferson was not a founding father of equality. He was a founding father of the heartbeat of denial that lives through both Mr. Trump\u2019s denials and the assertion that his racial views are abnormal for America and its presidents.\n\nFifty years ago, Richard Nixon transformed this historic heartbeat of denial into an intoxicating political philosophy. His presidential candidacy appealed to George Wallace-type segregationists while also attracting Americans who refused to live near \u201cdangerous\u201d black residents, obstructed the desegregation of schools, resisted affirmative action policies, framed black mothers on welfare as undeserving, called the black family pathological and denigrated black culture \u2014 all those racists who refused to believe they were racist in 1968.\n\nNixon designed his campaign, one of his advisers explained, to allow a potential supporter to \u201cavoid admitting to himself that he was attracted by\u201d the \u201cracist appeal.\u201d\n\nA new vocabulary emerged, allowing users to evade admissions of racism. It still holds fast after all these years. The vocabulary list includes these: law and order. War on drugs. Model minority. Reverse discrimination. Race-neutral. Welfare queen. Handout. Tough on crime. Personal responsibility. Black-on-black crime. Achievement gap. No excuses. Race card. Colorblind. Post-racial. Illegal immigrant. Obamacare. War on Cops. Blue Lives Matter. All Lives Matter. Entitlements. Voter fraud. Economic anxiety.", "title": "Opinion | The Heartbeat of Racism Is Denial", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-07 00:00:00", "text": "LONDON \u2014 It was so cold in some parts of the world this past week that iguanas were falling from trees, sharks were dying and eyelashes were freezing in the shadow of a mountain where the wind chill could make the air feel as cold as minus 100 Fahrenheit.\n\nThe world became familiar with the phrase \u201cbomb cyclone\u201d \u2014 also known as a winter hurricane.\n\nAmid the face-freezing misery, one phenomenon that is a staple of winter has drawn greater attention in an era of prolific social media use: the frozen pond rescue. Twitter and Facebook users shared video footage of the heroes of winter who dived into icy waters to save men, women and animals.\n\nThe rescues unfolded as winter\u2019s icy grip unleashed a storm named Eleanor that barreled across Europe, setting off a deadly avalanche in the Austrian Alps, where two German skiers were killed on Friday near Kals in Tyrol State, according to Bild. Twenty skiers also had to be rescued from cable cars in Kitzb\u00fchel, Austria.\n\nThe storm whipped up dangerous winds in Britain, where it knocked out power to thousands. The gusts blew a train car off its tracks in Sweden, injuring eight people.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn Spain, snow blanketed half the country this weekend, including in southern cities like Granada, trapping hundreds of drivers overnight Saturday in their cars. The army\u2019s emergency units were called in on Sunday to help clear the snow off a highway near Madrid.", "title": "The Heroes of Winter: Frozen Pond Rescues", "authors": ["Yonette Joseph", "Nilo Tabrizy"]} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\n\u201cCrime Is Falling, but Police Levels Remain Robust\u201d (news article, Jan. 8) raises important questions about the need to keep expanding police forces as crime falls. The United States spends a staggering $100 billion on policing a year. It also comes with serious trade-offs for municipalities short of cash.\n\nLast year, the Center for Popular Democracy, the Law for Black Lives and the Black Youth Project 100 examined a dozen jurisdictions and found that most of the cities studied spent a third to nearly half of their general funds on police departments, while grossly underinvesting in affordable housing, transit, mental health and youth services.\n\nExpanding police forces may not only be ineffective, as the article suggests, but it also undermines the ability of governments to provide the resources that ensure public safety and let communities thrive.\n\nKUMAR RAO, BROOKLYN\n\nThe writer is a senior staff attorney at the Center for Popular Democracy.", "title": "Opinion | The High Cost of Policing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-22 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cInside Winemaking\u201d with its focus on the process of winemaking, is educational. Like \u201cGrapeRadio\u201d it emphasizes West Coast producers. Another podcast, \u201cWine for Normal People,\u201d produced by a wife-and-husband team in Atlanta, tries, as the title suggests, to eliminate anything that sounds like wine snobbery.\n\n\u201cI\u2019ll Drink to That\u201d is different. It does not pretend to be a wine primer, and it makes few concessions to newcomers who are not already familiar with the intricacies of wine or its places and people.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t want to talk about, \u2018If you don\u2019t know what ros\u00e9 is, here\u2019s an explanation,\u2019\u201d Mr. Dalton said. \u201cMy strength is talking to people who are already committed to wine, and I want to take them further.\u201d\n\nEven so, one does not need to be a Barolo expert to be inspired by the writer Ian d\u2019Agata\u2019s almost vineyard-by-vineyard deconstruction of Barolo terroir as he walks the audience through the various differences among them and how they affect the wines. I wanted to listen to it a second time, with a glass of Barolo in hand.\n\nYou could say that Mr. Dalton, 41, was born to the restaurant business. His mother worked as a waitress in Los Angeles and later at the Timberline Lodge on Mount Hood in Oregon, before moving to Montclair, N.J. His father was a cook. They divorced when Levi (pronounced LEH-vee) was young, and he often found himself in the company of restaurant workers.\n\n\u201cIt was a little like a surrogate family,\u201d he said. \u201cI didn\u2019t have siblings, so I hung out with career waiters, people with life experience.\u201d\n\nBy the late 1990s, he was supporting himself at Boston University by working as a busboy. Hoping to earn more as a waiter, he applied for a job at the Federalist, a restaurant that was renowned for its wine list.", "title": "The History of Wine in 442 Podcasts", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "Dear Diary:\n\nIt was late on a Saturday night, probably around 1 a.m. Sunday, in September, 1969, and the rain was pouring down. I lived in Flatbush, Brooklyn, and my girlfriend lived in Glendale, Queens. I was driving home alone, following a route that took me from the Interboro Parkway to Empire Boulevard.\n\nI stopped at a red light. Standing on the corner, in the middle of what was considered a \u201cbad\u201d neighborhood, was a young man getting drenched in the downpour. He had his jacket over his head so that all I could see was his thumb sticking out, asking for a ride.\n\nI did not hesitate. If I had, I might not have rolled down my window and asked, \u201cHow far?\u201d\n\n\u201cNew York Avenue,\u201d he said. It was not too far.\n\n\u201cGet in,\u201d I said. As he did, he apologized for getting my seat so wet, then said something about how crazy it was that I would stop and give him a ride.", "title": "The Hitchhiker", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "The company decided to introduce its product not on grocery shelves but at specialty coffee shops, where baristas could act as oat-milk ambassadors to customers and other professionals within the brewing and roasting communities. In just a year, Oatly has spread from 10 locations in New York to more than 1,000 locations nationwide.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Of the Moment The lifestyle newsletter from the Styles, Travel and Food sections, offering the latest trends to news you can use. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nOver oat-milk hot chocolates at La Colombe on Vandam Street, a shop regularly flooded by workers from nearby tech companies and art galleries, Josey Markiewicz, who manages training and quality assurance at the cafe, described the Oatly onslaught.\n\n\u201cTheir ground team was composed of former coffee folks, and the coffee scene is a scene,\u201d he said. \u201cWe\u2019re all buds, we throw down against each other in milk competitions and brewing competitions, and the industry\u2019s pretty tightknit.\u201d Oatly\u2019s barista-grade product, which steams better than most nondairy milks and performs just as well cold, he said, stirred up excitement at trade events and among friends in the business.\n\nBecause almonds require over six times as much water to grow as oats do, according to the Water Footprint Network, the choice to switch from almond milk to oat milk also seemed environmentally sensible to Mr. Markiewicz.\n\nTo those participating in today\u2019s restrictive food culture, Oatly\u2019s lack of dairy, nuts, gluten, soy or genetically modified organisms (GMOs) is a plus. It\u2019s rich in soluble fiber (recalling an oat-bran madness of 30 years ago) and is comparable to other milk alternatives in terms of sugar content, but relatively high in carbohydrates and calories, with about double those that a serving of almond milk contains.\n\nNot everyone has been convinced that the milk-alternative boom is a health boon.\n\n\u201cFrom a nutritional standpoint, they have some value,\u201d Marion Nestle, a professor of nutrition, food studies and public health at New York University, wrote in an email, \u201cbut as is the case with most processed foods, eating the original \u2014 almonds, oatmeal or whatever \u2014 is always better.\u201d\n\nSara Haas, a culinary dietitian in Chicago, sees oat milk not as a dairy substitute but as part of a trend, referring to its popularity in Britain.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIf you\u2019re using it just to enjoy in your coffee, and you\u2019re not really looking at it as an equal replacement for dairy, in a nutritional sense, it\u2019s fine,\u201d she said. But as with any dietary alternative, \u201cyou have to learn to be a label reader, because they\u2019re not all equal.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nNor so in price.\n\nAt Onyx Coffee Lab, whose three cafes and roastery are in northwest Arkansas, Oatly is a recent addition to the shop\u2019s ever-changing menu, which has included barrel-aged cold brew and drinks made from cascara, the husk of the fruit from a coffee plant. Most of the shop\u2019s plant-based milks \u2014 almond, coconut and macadamia \u2014 cost an additional 75 cents per cup.\n\nBecause of a higher wholesale price, Oatly comes with a surcharge of $1. But Andrea Allen, who owns Onyx with her husband, Jon, and was impressed by Oatly\u2019s flavor when she sampled it at a trade show, says this hasn\u2019t discouraged customers, many of whom were converted by an oat-milk-focused seasonal menu last fall.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re always on the lookout for something new and tasty that\u2019s in the alternative realm,\u201d Ms. Allen said.\n\nThose trying to get their fix at home can buy six-packs of unrefrigerated Oatly on the company\u2019s website and from Amazon, if you\u2019re comfortable schlepping a 14-pound box inside and have ample storage. You can also order chilled quarts of Oatly from FreshDirect for day-of delivery. But you won\u2019t find it in your local grocery store \u2014 yet.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019ve heard stories, particularly here in New York, of some of our coffee partners selling Oatly over the counter, almost like black-market oat milk, to their regulars,\u201d Mr. Messersmith said.\n\nStarting next week, however, Oatly will be available at Wegmans. It will arrive on shelves at Fairway, ShopRite and the California grocery chain Bristol Farms in February. After grocery stores, the next logical step may be Big Coffee: Starbucks, Dunkin\u2019 Donuts and the death knell of Swedish oat milk\u2019s exclusionary allure.\n\nMr. Markiewicz of La Colombe would be just fine with that.\n\n\u201cI would prefer that oat milk become as commonplace as nonfat or whole milk, where people think of it as a third option,\u201d he said. \u201cBecause that\u2019s what sustainability is about: eventually making it a part of the fabric of our lives. I don\u2019t care much about the cool factor. Even saying \u2018oat milk\u2019 doesn\u2019t sound cool.\u201d", "title": "The Humble Ascent of Oat Milk", "authors": ["Bonnie Wertheim"]} {"date": "2018-01-01 00:00:00", "text": "SANTA ROSA, Calif. \u2014 When a firestorm swept down the hillsides of Sonoma County, bringing terror to this tight grid of thousands of homes, dogs tended to rush to their masters.\n\nBut cats went in the opposite direction, ignoring the pleas of panicked owners and disappearing amid the chaotic evacuation.\n\nFinding the missing cats that fled the October wildfires has been an impassioned quest for Jennifer Petruska, an animal lover whose home, pets included, was one of the few in her neighborhood to be spared.\n\nMs. Petruska has spent nearly every night since the fires tracking and trapping fire cats, as she calls them, the felines that for weeks have remained missing because of stubbornness, trauma, instinct, or a mix of all three.", "title": "The Hunt for \u2018Fire Cats\u2019 Amid Northern California Ashes", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-04 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nRead the latest on the bitter cold along the East Coast with Friday\u2019s live updates.\n\nBeware the falling iguanas in South Florida.\n\nWhen temperatures dip into the 30s and 40s, people from West Palm Beach to Miami know to be on the lookout for reptiles stunned \u2014 but not necessarily killed \u2014 by the cold. They can come back to life again when it warms up.\n\nIn Boca Raton, Frank Cerabino, a Palm Beach Post columnist familiar with the critters, stepped outside and saw a bright green specimen by his pool on Thursday morning, feet up.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s one of those ethical things: What do you do?\u201d he said in an interview.\n\nIguanas, which can be as long as six feet, are not native to South Florida. They have proliferated in the subtropical heat, causing headaches for wildlife managers \u2014 and occasionally popping up in toilets. It took a prolonged cold spell to significantly reduce their population in 2010. (The same cold snap also resulted in the deaths of many invasive Burmese pythons.)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIguanas climb up trees to roost at night, said Ron Magill, communications director for Zoo Miami.\n\n\u201cWhen the temperature goes down, they literally shut down, and they can no longer hold on to the trees,\u201d he said. \u201cWhich is why you get this phenomenon in South Florida that it\u2019s raining iguanas.\u201d (Including on windshields.)", "title": "The Iguanas Falling From Trees in Florida? They Probably Aren\u2019t Dead", "authors": ["Patricia Mazzei"]} {"date": "2018-01-07 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cThe World Is Inside Your Hospital\u201d (Op-Ed, Jan. 1):\n\nI applaud Tom Brokaw for calling attention to the great diversity of national origins in the United States health care delivery system. My husband had myeloma, like Mr. Brokaw, and frequently interacted with doctors, nurses and certified nursing assistants in hospitals and doctors\u2019 offices as well as chemotherapy and radiation centers. He and I appreciated the intelligence and tenacity of the people delivering health care, who often had inspirational stories of their own or their parents\u2019 migration to the United States and of overcoming great obstacles.\n\nI would also like to call attention to another segment of the work force where there is a preponderance of immigrants: in assisted-living facilities and nursing homes. During her journey with dementia, my mother was treated with great kindness by people (mostly women) who often had low-paying jobs. As the United States population ages, we will not be well served by our increasingly restrictive immigration policies.\n\nANNETTE EVANS, BOCA RATON, FLA.\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nImmigrants not only staff our hospitals but also are a vital component of the labor force for delivering in-home health care and elder care. Working one-on-one with seriously ill and/or cognitively impaired patients many hours each day over extended periods makes significant emotional demands on caregivers. The lived experience of immigrants and refugees who have dealt with major obstacles and risks equips them with the empathy, patience and sensitivity needed for quality in-home care.\n\nIn terms of formal education and professional training, many of today\u2019s home caregivers would not be admitted to the United States under the Raise Act proposed by Senators Tom Cotton and David Purdue and touted by President Trump as the solution to many of our imagined immigration ills. The legislation would sharply reduce our intake of low-skilled labor. But home caregivers are essential workers. It would be extremely difficult to replace them with American-born workers, who shun the long hours, dirty tasks, emotional demands and low pay of in-home care.", "title": "Opinion | The Immigrants Who Deliver Health Care", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-08 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nIn estuaries off the coast of Georgia, the water is so murky that if you were to dive in, you couldn\u2019t see your hand in front of your face. There, blue crabs feast on mud crabs, oysters, fish and more.\n\nYou may eagerly approach these hand-sized arthropods when they\u2019re cracked into pieces and doused in butter. But in muddy water, tiny mud crabs, no bigger than the tip of your thumb, steer clear of the hungry blue crab predators. In this crab-eat-crab world, they can\u2019t see their enemies coming \u2014 but they can smell them.\n\nChemicals in blue crab urine are scented death messages to mud crabs. The language is different, but the warning is clear: Hide, or be eaten.\n\n\u201cBlue crabs probably don\u2019t want to send out the message, but they can\u2019t help it. We all have to pee,\u201d said Julia Kubanek, a marine chemical ecologist at Georgia Institute of Technology.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOf more than 600 chemicals that make up blue crab urine, only two signal danger for mud crabs, Dr. Kubanek and her colleagues found in a study published Monday in Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences. These chemicals, produced when blue crabs break down dinner, tell the mud crab what was served. They\u2019re especially powerful if the last meal was mud crab.", "title": "The Invisible Underwater Messaging System in Blue Crab Urine", "authors": ["Joanna Klein"]} {"date": "2018-01-22 00:00:00", "text": "Nonetheless, the spotlight is now where it should be: on the failure of President Trump and Republicans in Congress to take care of the Dreamers, despite their repeated claims that they want to.\n\nMr. Trump has sent wildly contradictory messages. The Dreamers, he said last February, are \u201cabsolutely incredible kids\u201d who deserve to be treated \u201cwith heart.\u201d And yet, in September he created this problem by ordering an end to the program if Congress didn\u2019t find a permanent fix by March 5. Two weeks ago he promised to deliver them a \u201cbill of love.\u201d But two days later he rejected a bipartisan deal to that end. On Friday, hours before the shutdown deadline, Mr. Trump reportedly reached an agreement with the Senate minority leader, Chuck Schumer, which would have protected Dreamers and increased border security, but he then reversed course at the urging of the anti-immigrant hawks who circle the Oval Office \u2014 mainly his chief of staff, John Kelly, and senior adviser, Stephen Miller. On Sunday, the president unleashed his inner Mr. Miller and attacked Democrats who, he said, \u201cjust want illegal immigrants to pour into our nation unchecked.\u201d\n\nSo what does this White House want? No one seems to know, including Mr. Trump himself. Mr. Schumer said dealing with the president is \u201clike negotiating with Jell-O.\u201d And that was a key factor precipitating the weekend\u2019s shutdown. One Republican strategist said Mr. Trump\u2019s lack of any clear convictions, combined with his ignorance of basic policy matters, \u201cemboldens all parties to take positions that they won\u2019t compromise.\u201d\n\nContrast this with what happened in 2013, when Republican hard-liners shut down the government after President Barack Obama refused to give in to their demand to defund the Affordable Care Act, his signature legislative achievement. Mr. Obama, who was clear from the start that he would not negotiate on that point and stood his ground, eventually prevailed.\n\nIn 2018, the White House is occupied by a man with no evident principles beyond promoting his own brand and chalking up \u201cwins,\u201d however he might define them. He\u2019s so uninterested in the particulars of governing that he recently told lawmakers that he would sign whatever immigration bill they sent him. How do you negotiate with a chief executive who doesn\u2019t know what a good deal is?\n\nThe other stumbling block is more familiar: an anti-immigrant faction of congressional Republicans that has scuttled immigration reform for nearly two decades even as it falls further out of step with public sentiment. There\u2019s good reason to worry that this will be no different in three weeks; whatever the Senate might agree on, the House speaker, Paul Ryan, has not committed to bringing a bill to the floor.", "title": "Opinion | The Jell-O President and the Shutdown", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "Peterson tells young men to never do that. Rise above the culture of victimization you see all around you. Stop whining. Don\u2019t blame others or seek revenge. \u201cThe individual must conduct his or her life in a manner that requires the rejection of immediate gratification, of natural and perverse desires alike.\u201d\n\nInstead, choose discipline, courage and self-sacrifice. \u201cTo stand up straight with your shoulders back is to accept the terrible responsibility of life.\u201d Never lie. Tell your boss what you really think. Be strict with your children. Drop the friends who bring you down. Break free from the needy mother who controls you.\n\nMuch of Peterson\u2019s advice sounds to me like vague exhortatory banality. Like Hobbes and Nietzsche before him, he seems to imagine an overly brutalistic universe, nearly without benevolence, beauty, attachment and love. His recipe for self-improvement is solitary, nonrelational, unemotional. I\u2019d say the lives of young men can be improved more through loving attachment than through Peterson\u2019s joyless and graceless calls to self-sacrifice.\n\nBut the emphasis on strength of will, the bootstrap, the calls to toughness and self-respect \u2014 all of this touches some need in his audience. He doesn\u2019t comfort. He demands: \u201cStop doing what you know to be wrong. \u2026 Say only those things that make you strong. Do only those things that you could speak of with honor.\u201d\n\nAnd Peterson personifies the strong, courageous virtues he champions. His most recent viral video, with over four million views, is an interview he did with Cathy Newman of Britain\u2019s Channel 4 News. Newman sensed that there was something disruptive to progressive orthodoxy in Peterson\u2019s worldview, but she couldn\u2019t quite put her finger on it. So, as Conor Friedersdorf noted in The Atlantic, she did what a lot of people do in argument these days. Instead of actually listening to Peterson, she just distorted, simplified and restated his views to make them appear offensive and cartoonish.\n\nPeterson calmly and comprehensibly corrected and rebutted her. It is the most devastatingly one-sided media confrontation you will ever see. He reminded me of a young William F. Buckley.\n\nThe Peterson way is a harsh way, but it is an idealistic way \u2014 and for millions of young men, it turns out to be the perfect antidote to the cocktail of coddling and accusation in which they are raised.", "title": "Opinion | The Jordan Peterson Moment", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nAaron Mattocks, a Bessie Award-nominated dancer and producer who has worked with the Mark Morris Dance Group and Big Dance Theater, will be the Joyce Theater\u2019s next director of programming, the organization announced on Thursday.\n\nMr. Mattocks will start on Feb. 1 and succeeds Martin Wechsler, who led the theater\u2019s programming for 22 years before stepping down at the end of last year.\n\n\u201cAfter an extensive search that produced several wonderfully talented candidates, I am extremely confident that we have identified the best person for the position,\u201d Linda Shelton, the Joyce\u2019s executive director, said in a statement. \u201cAaron\u2019s multilayered background as a dancer, artist and administrator is sure to enhance our programming on many levels.\u201d\n\nMr. Mattocks is the executive director of Big Dance Theater, the troupe led by the artistic directors Annie-B Parson and Paul Lazar. He has also worked with Ms. Parson on her choreography for the film \u201cRicki and the Flash,\u201d starring Meryl Streep. He is the producing director for Pam Tanowitz and, from 2002 to 2010, was the company and general manager of Mark Morris Dance Group.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHis most recent project with Ms. Tanowitz was last fall: He produced \u201cNew Work for Goldberg Variations,\u201d a collaboration with the pianist Simone Dinnerstein. (Read more about the piece, and see what our critic thought of it.)\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn a statement, Mr. Mattocks said that programming at the Joyce \u201crepresents a delicate and intricate challenge of balancing excellence, accessibility, diversity of aesthetic voices, innovation and the global breadth of creativity, constantly striving to find a potent mixture of local, national and international artists of distinction across contemporary, popular and traditional forms.\u201d", "title": "The Joyce Theater\u2019s Latest Hire Comes From Deep in the Dance World", "authors": ["Joshua Barone"]} {"date": "2018-01-02 00:00:00", "text": "When it comes to pork, most home cooks know the chop, the tenderloin, the loin roast, even the Boston butt. But because I am a sucker for the underdog and the oddball, I have a new favorite cut of pork: the country-style rib.\n\nWhy oddball? First, it suffers from something of an identity crisis, since despite its name it\u2019s not really a rib. Second, it has an indeterminate composition, consisting of both light and dark meat. Finally, it has a tendency to slide into disreputable territory, since its name is sometimes appropriated for less desirable cuts.\n\nBut like any good antihero, the country-style rib has hidden virtues. It has rich, deep pork flavor; it is generally the most inexpensive cut of pork at the meat counter; and it is ideal for those slow-cooked dishes we crave in cool weather.\n\nTo understand this cut, you first need to know the blade pork chop. This chop is cut from the two ribs at the shoulder end of the pork loin. Because it comes from the intersection of the tender loin and the more fat-laden and gnarly shoulder, it has qualities of both.\n\nPhoto\n\nButchers used to have difficulty selling this chop, because it didn\u2019t look as lean and smooth as those from the center of the loin. So it generally ended up as an ingredient in sausages or, less reputably, secreted at the bottom of a wrapped package of \u201cloin chops.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThen sometime back in the late 1960s or early \u201970s, a Chicago-area butcher, Cliff Bowes, came up with the idea of taking advantage of the popularity of ribs by fashioning these lowly chops into strips that resembled ribs. To do so, he butterflied the chops and cut through the ribs.", "title": "The Kindest Cut of All: A Pork Rib With Slow-Cooked Comforts", "authors": ["John Willoughby"]} {"date": "2018-01-16 00:00:00", "text": "American construction teams built six new seaports with 29 berths for deep-draft transport ships at Da Nang, Cam Ranh Bay, Qui Nhon, Vung Ro, Vung Tau and Newport, in Saigon; six new naval bases, with slips for amphibious shipping, were also built. In many cases, pier sections were prefabricated in the Philippines and floated over.\n\nTo care for the growing number of American and Vietnamese service members, Americans built 26 hospitals with 8,280 beds. To receive and hold the millions of tons of supplies shipped over, contractors built 10.4 million square feet of covered storage, as well as 5.5 million square feet of ammunition storage and enough tanker farms to hold 3.1 million barrels of petroleum products. Finally, the military built 26 major base camps around Vietnam, some with shopping malls and movie theaters, as well as hundreds of smaller combat firebases.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Subscribe to the Vietnam \u201967 Newsletter This weekly newsletter includes eyewitness accounts, rare photos and historical insights about the Vietnam War. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nConventionally, the design and construction of such facilities would be handled by military construction teams. But the size and urgency of the project were too much for the military\u2019s engineers (many of whom were in the reserves, and so were not called up in time). Therefore, the Pentagon decided to rely on civilian construction contractors. In 1962, the Navy, which oversaw most of the large construction efforts, signed a contract with a joint venture between two large firms, Raymond International and Morrison-Knudsen, to build jet-capable airfields at Saigon, Da Nang and Pleiku.\n\nBy mid-1965, it was clear that the construction program was growing beyond the joint venture\u2019s capacity, so the Navy broadened the construction consortium by adding Brown & Root, Inc. and J. A. Jones Construction Company. The consortium was then known as RMK-BRJ, and was managed by Morrison-Knudsen. By July 1966, the consortium had 51,000 employees, more than two-thirds of whom were Vietnamese. At its high point of activity, in March 1967, the consortium was spending $64 million a month, or $478 million in 2017 dollars.\n\nConstruction materials and equipment were provided to the contractor by the government. In 1966, the Navy put in an order for 196 million board-feet of lumber to build troop barracks \u2014 an order that, to be fulfilled, absorbed virtually all of the West Coast\u2019s timber capacity for the entire year. The Navy also ordered 10,000 doors and 750,000 tons of cement. To construct the various facilities, the government provided RMK-BRJ with 5,560 pieces of equipment; the consortium also leased or chartered 16 aircraft, two landing ships, 10 landing craft, 14 dredges, 30 barges and 10 tugboats.\n\nAlongside the contractors, at the peak of activity in 1968 more than 55,000 military engineers were in South Vietnam, including Navy Seabees, Army engineers, Air Force \u201cRed Horse\u201d squadrons and Marine combat engineers. In addition to building the forward combat bases, the military engineers constructed roads in operational areas as well as cantonment facilities \u2014 i.e., barracks, dining halls and training sites \u2014 at major bases. Later in the war, the Seabees and Army construction units participated in the largest single military construction effort, a network of highways strung around the country called the Lines of Communication, which cost about $500 million, or $3.7 billion today.\n\nThese units didn\u2019t just build big; they built fast. In 1966, Navy Seabees rebuilt the damaged airfield at Khe Sanh in four days, with 3,900 feet of 60-foot-wide aluminum matting to serve cargo planes. Westmoreland \u201ccalled it one of the most outstanding military engineering feats in Vietnam.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAs the war wound down, the construction program grew again to build up the ability of South Vietnam to prosecute the war and boost the economy. The Lines of Communication construction program was central to this effort in order to provide access for farmers to markets, comprising 1,750 miles of highways and bridges. The Americans also built housing for 450,000 Vietnamese servicemen and their families to improve the morale of the Vietnamese military, and thereby increase military capabilities.\n\nThe Navy closed out the RMK-BRJ construction contract in July 1972, for a grand total of $1.9 billion (equivalent to $14 billion today), not including government-furnished materials and equipment. While this contract allowed the combat mission of the Americans to proceed, it also left in place projects that continue to serve the Vietnamese people today, especially the seaports, airports, highways and bridges.\n\nIt also developed a Vietnamese construction industry, which allowed the Navy to award fixed-price construction contracts to Vietnamese contractors in 1971 and 1972. RMK-BRJ trained 200,000 Vietnamese employees in construction trades as well as administrative services, creating a skilled work force that remained long after the Americans had left.\n\nAt the July 3, 1972, closeout ceremony for the RMK-BRJ contract, Ambassador Ellsworth Bunker stated: \u201cConstruction in the cause of war has also brought construction in the cause of peace and progress.\u201d Amid the terrible destruction of nearly a decade of conflict, he called the American military\u2019s construction blitz \u201cone of the finest episodes in our nation\u2019s history.\u201d", "title": "The Largest Military Construction Project in History", "authors": ["Mel Schenck"]} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "Lawrence G. Nassar, the former physician for the American gymnastics team, was sentenced on Jan. 24 to 40 to 175 years in prison for sex crimes.\n\nIt capped more than a week of victim impact statements by young women and teenagers who described how, as aspiring athletes, they were sent to Dr. Nassar at gymnastics camps, gyms, his home and the Michigan State University clinic. For decades, he molested athletes under the guise of medical treatment.\n\nOne week later, he appeared in another courtroom on similar charges. After more than 60 women testified \u2014 including some of the same athletes who spoke at the earlier sentencing \u2014 he was sentenced to 40 to 125 years in that case.\n\nHere is a look at coverage by The New York Times.", "title": "The Larry Nassar Case: What Happened and How the Fallout Is Spreading", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "Apart from chastening the cybersecurity experts in the Pentagon, the Strava debacle underscores a crucial misconception at the heart of the system of privacy protection in the United States. The privacy of data cannot be managed person-by-person through a system of individualized informed consent.\n\nData privacy is not like a consumer good, where you click \u201cI accept\u201d and all is well. Data privacy is more like air quality or safe drinking water, a public good that cannot be effectively regulated by trusting in the wisdom of millions of individual choices. A more collective response is needed.\n\nPart of the problem with the ideal of individualized informed consent is that it assumes companies have the ability to inform us about the risks we are consenting to. They don\u2019t. Strava surely did not intend to reveal the GPS coordinates of a possible Central Intelligence Agency annex in Mogadishu, Somalia \u2014 but it may have done just that. Even if all technology companies meant well and acted in good faith, they would not be in a position to let you know what exactly you were signing up for.\n\nAnother part of the problem is the increasingly powerful computational methods called machine learning, which can take seemingly inconsequential data about you and, combining them with other data, can discover facts about you that you never intended to reveal. For example, research shows that data as minor as your Facebook \u201clikes\u201d can be used to infer your sexual orientation, whether you use addictive substances, your race and your views on many political issues. This kind of computational statistical inference is not 100 percent accurate, but it can be fairly close \u2014 certainly close enough to be used to profile you for a variety of purposes.\n\nA challenging feature of machine learning is that exactly how a given system works is opaque. Nobody \u2014 not even those who have access to the code and data \u2014 can tell what piece of data came together with what other piece of data to result in the finding the program made. This further undermines the notion of informed consent, as we do not know which data results in what privacy consequences. What we do know is that these algorithms work better the more data they have. This creates an incentive for companies to collect and store as much data as possible, and to bury the privacy ramifications, either in legalese or by playing dumb and being vague.", "title": "Opinion | The Latest Data Privacy Debacle", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nThe league-leading Tampa Bay Lightning\u2019s top stars will be on full display when the city hosts N.H.L. All-Star Weekend later this month.\n\nTop scorer Nikita Kucherov, goaltender Andrei Vasilevskiy and defenseman Victor Hedman will join captain Steven Stamkos for the skills competition and 3-on-3 tournament Jan. 27-28 in Tampa, Fla. Kucherov has the most points in the league and Vasilevskiy the most victories in leading the Lightning to an N.H.L.-best 65 points so far this season.\n\nWith four players on the Atlantic Division team, Tampa Bay has the most representation for the showcase event. The Los Angeles Kings will send three players to Tampa: center Anze Kopitar, defenseman Drew Doughty and goalie Jonathan Quick. The league announced the full All-Star rosters on Wednesday as selected by the N.H.L.\u2019s hockey operations department.\n\nSidney Crosby and Kris Letang of the defending Stanley Cup-champion Pittsburgh Penguins were added to the Metropolitan Division team that also includes Washington Capitals winger Alex Ovechkin and goalie Braden Holtby. Rangers goalie Henrik Lundqvist was selected to his fourth All-Star Weekend.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe surprise Vegas Golden Knights got two All-Stars: goalie Marc-Andre Fleury and winger James Neal. The reigning Hart Trophy winner Connor McDavid of the Edmonton Oilers is also on the Pacific Division roster.", "title": "The Lightning, the All-Star Host, Lead the N.H.L. All-Star Rosters", "authors": ["The Associated Press"]} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "Others, like @gleamingrazor, look ahead practically to how things can be done differently in the future. The Islamic State experience, he notes, has made it clear that \u201ca state cannot be declared amid the fog of war and uncertainty.\u201d Mr. Baghdadi demanded that millions emigrate to his \u201cstate\u201d but couldn\u2019t offer them security or employment. Next time, any leader presuming to declare statehood would need to control territory with industry and scientific research facilities; he would need an economic policy, the ability to conduct trade and commerce, and control over an electricity grid. Mr. Baghdadi\u2019s caliphate was a \u201cdisgrace,\u201d but it \u201cimbued in us a renewed sense of hope and longing.\u201d It also demonstrated that any feasible Islamic state would require the taking over of an existing state. \u201cMaybe, just maybe, a Muslim general somewhere would be inspired.\u201d\n\nPerhaps to be expected, the emotional commitment to a caliphate holds strong among those who joined the Islamic State, only to be devastated by the outcome. One woman from Tunisia I met in a refugee camp outside Raqqa this past summer, who fled with her children and was later detained by Syrian Defense Forces, said: \u201cIf the Islamic State was real, I would not have left it. I would prefer to have died there than leave it.\u201d Instead, she said, it turned out to be a band of vicious men intent on collecting cars and women. The Tunisian woman wanted to go home, but most of the Islamic State women detained alongside her didn\u2019t. They wanted to live in Turkey, the closest thing to an Islamic state they felt was on offer today.\n\nCaliphate intellectuals are united in reviling the Islamic State, but beyond that, their projections of the future vary widely. Would an idealized Muslim community be a conventional state, but governed by the Shariah? Would it be a federation of Muslim-majority countries under the banner of Islam, a proto-Islamic bloc like the European Union? Would it be a caliphate in the classical, historical form, a sort of empire in God\u2019s name with a modern commitment to Islamic banking? Would it be sectarian? There are no solid contours yet to what form all these inchoate yearnings would take, but the sentiments are there, as real and inescapable a part of the modern landscape of the Muslim world as celebrity imams and Nike hijabs.\n\nAs we survey the husks of the cities the Islamic State controlled and speculate about the future, it is worth remembering: The Islamic State caliphate grew out of Syria\u2019s civil war, but it was also made possible by thousands of Muslims from across the world \u2014 not just the Arab world, but Europe, the United States, Indonesia, Russia \u2014 boarding planes, leaving their countries behind, in pursuit of the dream of a Muslim homeland.\n\nThe discussion about the post-Islamic State world purports to be about security, but it fundamentally neglects the fact that what the Islamic State claimed to represent \u2014 the idea of a caliphate \u2014 remains squarely in the minds of Muslims, even if many forces conspire to keep those sentiments from the public view. The majority who long for an Islamic state are not jihadist-minded, nor do they advocate the murder of civilians. But these views are banned from the public sphere across most of the Arab Middle East; such thoughts are not permissible in civil society or on mainstream media platforms. You are much more likely to see a buffoon conservative on television (like the Egyptian figure who recently called the rape of women wearing skinny jeans a national duty) rather than the razor-sharp Islamist lawyer in Tunis.\n\nThe question that captivated Western audiences as the Islamic State gained ground was how Islamic it was. Perhaps a better query might have been why what it claimed to represent appealed to so many. As we struggle to formulate better questions looking forward, we should think about why the idea of a Muslim homeland bubbles up as needed \u2014 an old notion that has never had, in living memory, such depths beneath it.", "title": "Opinion | The Lingering Dream of an Islamic State", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-22 00:00:00", "text": "Three years ago I arrived \u201con the mountain,\u201d as they say around here, for my first weekend at Rivendell. I have a graduate degree in creative writing and spent a dozen years making my living as a writer, but by the time I got to Rivendell I was working as an editor and had written hardly a word of my own in years. I was exhausted by caregiving \u2014 by raising children and simultaneously tending needy elders \u2014 and I longed for an uninterrupted chance to read and write and walk in the woods.\n\nBy the time I left two days later, I\u2019d finished a draft of the first essay I published in this newspaper. That essay is also the centerpiece of an essay collection to be published next year, a book entirely written or revised at Rivendell over the last three years. Becoming a debut author at the age of 57 is nothing less than a miracle, and it\u2019s not too much to say that this work would not exist if it weren\u2019t for Rivendell Writers\u2019 Colony.\n\nI\u2019ve come to think of Rivendell as my spiritual home, and of Carmen Toussaint, Rivendell\u2019s executive director, as a kind of literary midwife. Toussaint\u2019s preternatural calm and kindness make it possible to move past the anxiety and despair endemic to writers, and her gift for unintrusive organization is the invisible scaffolding that has kept the place running and made it possible for writers to settle in and write.\n\nAs news that the Rivendell campus would soon become a \u201ccenter for spiritual healing and exploration\u201d made its way across the literary South, authors took to email and social media to mourn its loss. \u201cRivendell is already a spiritual healing and exploration center,\u201d wrote Karen Hayes, co-owner (with the novelist Ann Patchett) of Parnassus Books in Nashville, on Facebook. \u201cThat is the power of the written word, whether it is through the creation of a work of literature, or the reading of it.\u201d\n\n\u201cI was devastated to hear that Rivendell \u2014 Walker Percy\u2019s former stomping grounds \u2014 is closing its doors,\u201d emailed Jamie Quatro, author of the new novel \u201cFire Sermon.\u201d", "title": "Opinion | The Literary South Is in Mourning", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "One thing that sets Rich Torrisi and Mario Carbone apart from other very talented chefs is how happy they seem to be creating restaurants that are not about them, or even primarily about cooking. While their peers were putting their kitchen skill front and center, through tasting menus or through restaurants where decoration was minimal and amenities were pared back until there was almost nothing left but the plates, they went in the opposite direction.\n\nFrom their first restaurant, Torrisi Italian Specialties, inside a fake Italian grocery store, their places have been highly distracting in ways that serious chefs tend to shun. The interiors are ornamental and over the top; the servers are dressed in uniforms that we might as well call costumes; the playlists are what your friend for whom entertaining is a life-or-death matter would put together for a highly specific theme party.\n\nOther chefs would have worried that their precious food would be overshadowed by the rest of the production. Mr. Torrisi and Mr. Carbone always seemed confident that wasn\u2019t going to happen. Before they opened their Japanese restaurant, the Lobster Club, they were right.\n\nNow two months old, the Lobster Club is the third and final stage in the annexation of the Seagram Building\u2019s dining spaces by the Major Food Group, run by the two chefs and Jeff Zalaznick. The first two stages were the Grill and the Pool, carved out of what used to be the Four Seasons.", "title": "The Lobster Club Does Japanese, From Raw to Half-Baked", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-21 00:00:00", "text": "As things turned out, that first concert in 1968 gave little sense of the direction the Sinfonietta would eventually pursue, but it had impact: The main item being the auspicious premiere of a raucously anarchic oratorio by John Tavener called \u201cThe Whale.\u201d\n\n\u201cI\u2019d been at school with Tavener,\u201d Mr. Snowman said, \u201cand knew about this piece he\u2019d written for the Bach Choir \u2014 who didn\u2019t want it, for perhaps obvious reasons. So I suggested it to Atherton, and he said, \u2018Why not?\u2019\n\n\u201cThat\u2019s how we went about things then. There was no policy, no business plan \u2014 we just went for what we thought interesting.\u201d\n\n\u201cThe Whale\u201d proved an overnight sensation, making Tavener\u2019s name and that of the Sinfonietta in a single strike. William Glock, the august controller of music at the BBC who believed in giving listeners not what they liked already but (as he insisted) \u201cwhat they will like tomorrow,\u201d immediately offered it a second performance in Royal Albert Hall during the Proms, one of the world\u2019s largest classical music festivals. The Beatles also took an interest, wanting to record it for their otherwise pop-oriented Apple label.\n\nMr. Snowman took an active role in the recording sessions. \u201cAmong the paraphernalia the piece required, like amplified metronomes and football rattles, was a phalanx of loudhailers,\u201d he said. \u201cI played one, my dad another. On a third was Ringo Starr.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nAfter this racy start, the Sinfonietta found its true m\u00e9tier with the arrival of Pierre Boulez. Mr. Boulez was in conflict with the French Ministry of Culture and refusing to conduct any orchestras in his native France. Instead, he started working with the Sinfonietta, leading major European tours from 1971 that pulled in other stars of contemporary music, including the Italian composer Luciano Berio.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThen the penny dropped,\u201d Mr. Snowman said. \u201cI realized that with big names like that we could get engagements anywhere. And the money we earned abroad \u2014 which seemed to fall from the trees in those days \u2014 would pay for otherwise unaffordable projects here in Britain.\u201d\n\nThe ensemble\u2019s chief executive, Andrew Burke, looks back on the past 50 years as a history of rising standards in performance. \u201cFrom the start,\u201d he said, \u201cwe were a pool of solo-status virtuosi: a core group of around 16 players who were the best \u2014 and not just the best at contemporary music but across all genres.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cThe Sinfonietta,\u201d Mr. Burke added, \u201craised the bar for what could be achieved in terms of technical performance \u2014 then went on raising it.\u201d\n\nThis remains true, although half a century later other elite new-music bands are jumping over those once barely surmountable bars. Most of them, like the Ensemble Intercomporain, Ensemble Modern or Klangforum Wien, were created in the Sinfonietta\u2019s image.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re not the only act in town any more,\u201d Mr. Burke said. \u201cWe have competition, but that\u2019s to be celebrated. The other ensembles are part of our legacy. If they didn\u2019t exist, there would be serious questions about what our relevance has been.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThere may be other questions about the Sinfonietta\u2019s record of achievement in persuading audiences to love some of the tougher sounds that it has championed in the past. But its choice of repertoire has never been a hard-line one. The Boulez and Xenakis have always been tempered with the softer voices of John Adams or Steve Reich. Indeed, Henryk Gorecki\u2019s Symphony No. 3 became an easy-listening hit when the Sinfonietta recorded it in 1991.\n\nThe Sinfonietta\u2019s repertoire now reflects the anything-goes pluralism of a music scene that stretches beyond concert halls into the kind of clubs where rock, pop and experimental music freely coexist. The current season takes in improvisation workshops, a collaboration with the photographer Andreas Gursky, and a piece described as a \u201cpolitically charged multimedia game show\u201d in which the composer Philip Venables invites the audience to question their ideas about gender.\n\nMore conventional, although it takes place in a disused printing plant rather than a theater, is the premiere of \u201cThe Cave,\u201d an opera by the British composer Tansy Davies. She said in an interview that she loved the Sinfonietta for \u201ctheir fearlessness, their readiness to shred a piece, if that\u2019s what it requires, with heavy-metal energy.\u201d\n\nAnd there\u2019s a conscious focus on the work of women, with premieres from Charlotte Bray, Unsuk Chin and Rebecca Saunders: three different voices ranging from the tuneful to the tough.\n\n\u201cOur sole criterion in programming,\u201d Mr. Burke said, \u201cis whether we believe a piece is good.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIt\u2019s not for nothing is the Sinfonietta\u2019s anniversary season is running with the tag \u201cUnfinished business.\u201d", "title": "The London Sinfonietta, a Contemporary Music Trailblazer, Turns 50", "authors": ["Michael White"]} {"date": "2018-01-20 00:00:00", "text": "The early days of the federal government shutdown won\u2019t slow the American economy much. No workers are missing paychecks yet, and because it is a weekend, few businesses expect to feel the effects of lost customers or suppliers.\n\nThat could change, quickly, if the impasse drags out. The longer the government is shut down, the bigger the economic impact \u2014 and this time, the bigger the chances that the economy\u2019s recent growth spurt could stall, at least temporarily.\n\nShutdowns bring the government to a partial stop, though so-called essential personnel keep working, and many services continue to be provided.\n\nThat partial stop costs the economy productive work time, historical evidence suggests, along with revenue that the federal government collects from daily fees at parks and museums. Private-sector companies that contract with the government have their work temporarily disrupted, and travel spending is reduced, affecting local economies.", "title": "The Longer It Lasts, the More a Shutdown Could Hurt the Economy", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-06 00:00:00", "text": "Almost all modern microprocessors employ tricks to squeeze more performance out of a computer program. A common trick involves having the microprocessor predict what the program is about to do and start doing it before it has been asked to do it \u2014 say, fetching data from memory. In a way, modern microprocessors act like attentive butlers, pouring that second glass of wine before you knew you were going to ask for it.\n\nBut what if you weren\u2019t going to ask for that wine? What if you were going to switch to port? No problem: The butler just dumps the mistaken glass and gets the port. Yes, some time has been wasted. But in the long run, as long as the overall amount of time gained by anticipating your needs exceeds the time lost, all is well.\n\nExcept all is not well. Imagine that you don\u2019t want others to know about the details of the wine cellar. It turns out that by watching your butler\u2019s movements, other people can infer a lot about the cellar. Information is revealed that would not have been had the butler patiently waited for each of your commands, rather than anticipating them. Almost all modern microprocessors make these butler movements, with their revealing traces, and hackers can take advantage.\n\nThere has been a rush to fortify our computing systems, and it may work for the moment. But at best, potential temporary fixes will entail a performance cost, since they involve rolling back strategies for optimizing performance. And since the problem is built into the hardware \u2014 billions of chips that cannot easily be replaced \u2014 fixing this class of problems may also be prohibitively expensive.\n\nAt worst, these fixes are too late. The vulnerabilities announced last week were found by three independent teams whose investigations converged on the same flaw at the same time. It is possible that less-responsible actors were also converging on this flaw and may have already succeeded in exploiting it.", "title": "Opinion | The Looming Digital Meltdown", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-29 00:00:00", "text": "Midwesterners are a tad luckier as they will be able to see more of the event. For them, the moon enters the penumbra at 4:51 a.m. Central Time and starts to turn reddish around 6:15 a.m. Central Time. Between 6:15 a.m. and 6:30 a.m. local time will be the best chance for anyone living in the Midwest to see the spectacle before the sun rises, according to Mr. Johnston.\n\nThe show starts to get good for people in the Mountain States. The umbra kisses the moon at 4:48 Mountain time. Its red lipstick becomes most visible around 6:30 a.m. local time, until it gets washed away by the sun around 7 a.m.\n\nViewers on the West Coast will have the best seats in the continental United States. They will be able to watch the eclipse from start until finish, unabated by sunrise. The blood moon portion of the eclipse will enter totality at 4:51 a.m. and peak at 5:30 a.m. It will end about 6:05 a.m. local time.\n\nSkygazers in Australia and eastern Asia will be able to watch the event on Wednesday night as the moon rises.\n\nHowever, only some parts of Australia will experience the lunar triple threat, according to Tanya Hill, an astronomy curator at Museums Victoria in Australia. Writing in The Conversation, she noted that Australia\u2019s eastern states will not experience a blue moon because those areas observe Daylight Saving Time, which pushes the full moon and the lunar eclipse to Thursday morning on Feb. 1 and thus the next month and out of blue moon territory. Still, they will have a front-row seat as the moon goes red.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n[READ: Debunking the Myth That Earthquakes and Full Moons Are Linked]\n\nWestern Europe, western Africa and most of South America will all miss out.\n\nWhere should I go to watch the eclipse?\n\nThe best tip for anyone trying to see the eclipse is to get a clear view of the horizon and look in the west-northwest direction.\n\n\u201cThe farther west you are, the higher in the west-northwest the moon will appear, the darker the sky will be,\u201d said Mr. Johnston, \u201cand the longer you will be able to view the eclipse before sunrise and moonset.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nYou can leave those fancy eclipse glasses from summer at home. You can watch this safely with your naked eyes, though using a telescope could make for a fun experience.\n\nWhat does it look like on the moon?\n\nPerhaps the best view of Wednesday\u2019s celestial activity is from the moon itself, according to Mr. Johnston. Standing on the lunar soil looking back at Earth, you would see quite the sight as the planet\u2019s shadow consumes you.\n\n\u201cYou would see a red circle of sunlight scattered toward the moon by the Earth\u2019s atmosphere,\u201d Mr. Johnston said. \u201cYou would be seeing the glow of all the sunrises and sunsets on Earth, all at the same time.\u201d", "title": "The Lunar Eclipse and Super Blue Moon Are Here. Needs Riders!", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "It is your land, all 400 million acres of it, though you wouldn\u2019t know by the way the Trump administration has ceded control to the private predators from the oil, gas, coal and uranium industries.\n\nIt is also your water, the near entirety of the outer continental shelf that Trump is opening to extractive drilling. Almost a dozen states have protested. The waters off the coast of Mar-a-Lago, in Florida, were given an exemption after Zinke met with the governor, who said drilling was bad for tourism. Your public servant at work.\n\nZinke is upending a century of bipartisan values as part of a Trumpian culture war. When asked why the president shrank national monuments in the Southwest by two million acres, Zinke said it was a way to strike back against \u201can elitist sort of hunter and fisherman.\u201d Huh?\n\nCould this be the same regular guy who took a helicopter to ride horses with Mike Pence? The cabinet member who wants to charge $70 to get into our most iconic national parks? The man whose nomination was championed by Donald Trump Jr., elephant killer and dictionary definition of elite hunter and fisherman?\n\nDefenders of public land have pushed back. This week, a majority of the nonpartisan National Park Service advisory panel resigned in frustration. The board, federally chartered to help guide the service, said Zinke had refused to convene a single meeting with the members last year. Silly bird-lovers. Don\u2019t they know you need to charter a plane for Zinke if you want to get his attention?\n\nA much less-connected group, the Backcountry Hunters and Anglers, responded with an essay from a board member who lives in a 500-square-foot abode in the Rocky Mountains. \u201cWe hunt, gather, garden, can, smoke, dry, jelly and pickle as much of our own food as we can,\u201d wrote Tom Healy. \u201cAccording to Mr. Secretary, I am an elitist.\u201d\n\nThe writer is from Whitefish, Zinke\u2019s hometown in Montana. Where have you heard that before? Ah, yes, a tiny energy company from Whitefish with two employees \u2014 three if you count Zinke\u2019s kid when he was an intern on a side project \u2014 finagled a $300 million, no-audit, no-bid contract to help rebuild Puerto Rico\u2019s electric grid.
