Zinke said he had absolutely, positively nothing to do with it.\n\nLook, it could have been worse: Sarah Palin was an early favorite for interior secretary. Zinke is an ex-Navy SEAL, and looks the part. Enough nutty things come out of his mouth to make him a perfect Trump guy.", "title": "Opinion | The Mad King Flies His Flag", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-22 00:00:00", "text": "Hardly a day goes by without President Trump tweet-bragging about the relentless rise of the stock market to fresh record highs \u2014 Exhibit A in his mind about how he is, indeed, making America great again.\n\nBut, while strong equity markets are certainly a Good Thing, let\u2019s not forget that, like so many effects of Mr. Trump\u2019s policies, those higher share prices are propelled upward in considerable measure by the new president\u2019s pro-business policies and benefit the wealthy far more than the average American.\n\nThe unsurprising reality is that the rich are far more likely to hold stocks, and when they do, they own them in much larger chunks than their less-well-off brethren.", "title": "Opinion | The Market Isn\u2019t Bullish for Everyone", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-13 00:00:00", "text": "Michael Funk, the former chief executive of United Natural Foods, among the world\u2019s largest wholesale distributors of natural and organic products, has known the couple from the beginning of their relationship \u2014 they met over a glass of wine at Friar Tuck\u2019s in Nevada City, Calif. \u2014 and says he has always been impressed by Brad and Susan\u2019s \u201cdrive and integrity.\u201d In a recent phone interview, Mr. Funk said he had seen \u201cthousands of small suppliers coming through the door and five years later many of them aren\u2019t around. You never know if who you meet is going to be one of those stories. Given where the two of them came from, which was a start-up that didn\u2019t have much financial backing, makes it even less likely.\u201d\n\nPerhaps had Mr. Funk known that the couple was whipping up a foaming shower gel containing an alternative to sodium laurel sulfate \u2014 an ingredient that some studies have linked to cancer, but without which it is difficult to create a lather \u2014 in the sort of three-gallon stainless steel stockpots that you make soup in, he would have been even more skeptical about the odds of EO Products lasting over the long haul. (Mr. Black compares that experiment to an \u201cI Love Lucy\u201d moment.) But when the couple went from selling to mom-and-pop boutiques to winning a Whole Foods account in 2000, their position in the natural marketplace was solidified. Eventually the company became a cornerstone of the $3.7 trillion global wellness industry and paved the way for such competitors as the Honest Company and eos.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut let\u2019s start at the beginning.\n\nA Garage Turned Laboratory\n\nThe couple met in 1989, when they exchanged business cards \u2014 she was working in the American offices of Neal\u2019s Yard Remedies, a British organic skin care company; he was designing and manufacturing clothing made of organic cotton \u2014 and began having lunch. They were both in a series of on-and-off relationships during this period; Susan was recently divorced with a young son. The two were fast friends from the beginning but it would take a few years before they began dating.", "title": "The Marriage Ended. The Company Thrived.", "authors": ["Daphne Merkin"]} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "If a letter from the lawyer is deemed necessary and sent, the ring is often sent back, Ms. Chemtob said. But sometimes it isn\u2019t, and \u201cwe hear that it was sold to buy a couch, because there\u2019s a lot of animosity when there\u2019s a broken engagement,\u201d she said. \u201cEighty percent of the time, it comes back.\u201d\n\nThe engagement ring, after the wedding, is the only piece of jewelry that is separate from marital assets. The bride gets to keep it, no matter where the marriage ends up.\n\nImage Diane Lloyde Roth, who owns L\u2019Armoire, a New Canaan, Conn., clothing, home and jewelry boutique, has created something of a side business out of designing new pieces from divorce remnants. She wears frog pins, purchased from the sale of a bracelet from her third spouse.\n\nBut in the case of all other jinxed jewels, there are plenty of jewelers ready and waiting to repurpose them. Ms. Roth, who owns L\u2019Armoire, a clothing, home and jewelry boutique in New Canaan, Conn., has created something of a side business out of designing new lives for divorce remnants.\n\nShe took apart a client\u2019s sapphire engagement ring and diamond wedding band and transformed them into a Maltese cross-style cuff. Another client owned a large ring \u2014 \u201cGarish, she thought it was hideous, but it was a gift,\u201d Ms. Roth said \u2014 that she turned into a platinum and diamond ankle bracelet. She has taken diamonds from wedding bands and placed them in lizard pins, in necklaces. She has taken pink and blue sapphires and the cacophony of colors in tourmaline and turned them into bracelets.\n\n\u201cDivorce is the death of a relationship, a defining moment,\u201d Ms. Roth said. \u201cThis gives people, in my case, for the most part, women, a sense of control.\u201d\n\nAnd a reminder that life goes on. People become attached to their jewelry, said Danielle Halikias, a sales consultant for M.S. Rau Antiques in New Orleans. \u201cThey don\u2019t want the original object to remind them of the sadness,\u201d she said. \u201cA lot of people don\u2019t want to part with the stone. There\u2019s an energy to it, so they transform it.\u201d", "title": "The Marriage Is Over, but the Jewelry Is Mine", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "Do you have questions about climate change? We\u2019re answering them in this newsletter. Send us yours via the form at the bottom of our climate Q. and A. This one was sent to us from Sue Pfeffer in Toronto:\n\nHow much of the problem is caused by methane gas emitted from raising farm animals for the meat industry?\n\nThe impact of agriculture, a category that includes everything from growing lettuce to raising livestock, is tricky to express because the gasses produced \u2014 mostly methane and nitrous oxide \u2014 have much more warming potential than carbon dioxide but also dissipate more quickly. According to the latest thinking, though, farming is responsible for the equivalent of 574 million metric tons of carbon dioxide emissions in the United States each year and 56 million metric tons in Canada.\n\nThat\u2019s about 8 percent of each country\u2019s total greenhouse gas emissions.\n\nMethane is increasingly drawing attention from researchers because its worldwide levels have doubled in less than 10 years after remaining flat since the 1990s. The reasons behind the increase are not well understood.", "title": "The Meat Question, by the Numbers", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-29 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nMedieval Times, the dinner theater with a faux jousting tournament, draws an estimated 2.5 million customers each year. Here\u2019s how the food operation breaks down by the numbers:\n\n25,000\n\nMeals served on a Saturday night, counting all nine Medieval Times locations\n\n200,000\n\nGallons of tomato soup served each year\n\n750,000\n\nPounds of russet potatoes roasted each year\n\n5 million\n\nPounds of chicken bought each year\n\n365 degrees\n\nRoasting temperature for the chickens\n\n400,000\n\nGallons of free Pepsi consumed by guests each year\n\n4\n\nPercentage of the 2,000 employees who work in the kitchen\n\nFollow NYT Food on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter and Pinterest. Get regular updates from NYT Cooking, with recipe suggestions, cooking tips and shopping advice.", "title": "The Medieval Math", "authors": ["Kim Severson"]} {"date": "2018-01-16 00:00:00", "text": "DUBLIN \u2014 If you watched MTV in the winter of 1994, it was impossible to ignore \u201cZombie\u201d by the Cranberries. The music video\u2019s director, Samuel Bayer, drew from a palette he\u2019d used on Nirvana\u2019s \u201cSmells Like Teen Spirit,\u201d and positioned the band\u2019s lead singer, Dolores O\u2019Riordan, painted in gold, in front of a large cross. \u201cIt\u2019s the same old theme since 1916,\u201d Ms. O\u2019Riordan snarled, referring to the quashed rebellion that gave birth to the Irish republic, between clips of British soldiers on the streets of Northern Ireland and play-fighting children. \u201cIn your head, in your head, they\u2019re still fighting.\u201d\n\nThere were many breaking points during the war in Northern Ireland, but the second Warrington bombing in England in 1993 was significant enough to set off street protests in Dublin. Johnathan Bell, 3, and Tim Parry, 12, were killed when the Irish Republican Army detonated two bombs in trash cans. Touring in England at the time, the Cranberries digested the news, and wrote \u201cZombie,\u201d their protest song.\n\nBy the time the single was released in 1994 \u2014 two weeks after a cease-fire announcement from the I.R.A., and a month before one from the unionist paramilitaries who opposed them \u2014 the Cranberries were one of the biggest rock bands in the world, with Ms. O\u2019Riordan at the helm, a frontwoman so prominent that the Cranberries meant her. They were an Irish band whose global success was instigated by how America embraced them, by MTV giving their moody music videos heavy rotation, and, crucially, by American radio, a medium that prompted album sales of more than 40 million, mostly for their first two albums: \u201cEverybody Else Is Doing It, So Why Can\u2019t We,\u201d in 1993, and \u201cNo Need to Argue,\u201d in 1994.\n\nNow, the Cranberries\u2019 music reminds me of the inside of bedrooms, of school discos where everyone swayed, bored, until \u201cZombie\u201d came on and the moshing began, awkward at first. The songs evoke the smell of damp school sweaters and the ennui of suburban bus shelters, as well as the money scraped together to buy Dr. Martens boots.", "title": "The Memories in Dolores O\u2019Riordan\u2019s Fierce, Fragile Voice", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "Much has been said about why we allowed such behavior to go unchecked. What has remained unsaid, because it is so obvious, is what would make someone so shameless in the first place: These people believed they were invincible. They saw their own bodies as entirely theirs and other people\u2019s bodies as at their disposal; apparently nothing in their lives led them to believe otherwise.\n\nHistorically, this is a mistake that few women would make, because until very recently, the physical experience of being a woman entailed exactly the opposite \u2014 and not only because women have to hold their keys in self-defense while walking through parking lots at night. It\u2019s only very recently that women have widely participated in public life, but it\u2019s even more recently that men have been welcome, or even expected, to provide physical care for vulnerable people.\n\nOnly for a nanosecond of human history have men even slightly shared what was once exclusively a woman\u2019s burden: the relentless daily labor of caring for another person\u2019s body, the life-preserving work of cleaning feces and vomit, the constant cycle of cooking and feeding and blanketing and bathing, whether for the young, the ill or the old. For nearly as long as there have been humans, being a female human has meant a daily nonoptional immersion in the fragility of human life and the endless effort required to sustain it.\n\nObviously not everyone who provides care for others is a saint. But engaging in that daily devotion, or even living with its expectation, has enormous potential to change a person. It forces one to constantly imagine the world from someone else\u2019s point of view: Is he hungry? Maybe she\u2019s tired. Is his back hurting him? What is she trying to say?\n\nThe most obvious cure for today\u2019s gender inequities is to put more women in power. But if we really hope to create an equal society, we will also need more men to care for the powerless \u2014 more women in the boardroom, but also more men at the nurses\u2019 station and the changing table, immersed in daily physical empathy. If that sounds like an evolutionary impossibility, well, it doesn\u2019t violate the laws of physics, so we can achieve it. It is surely worth at least as much investment as defeating death.\n\nPerhaps it takes the promise of immortality to inspire the self-absorbed to invest in unsexy work like Alzheimer\u2019s research. If so, we may all one day bless the inane death-defiance as a means to a worthy end.\n\nBut men who hope to live forever might pause on their eternal journey to consider the frightening void at invincibility\u2019s core. Death is the ultimate vulnerability. It is the moment when all of us must confront exactly what so many women have known all too well: You are a body, only a body, and nothing more.", "title": "Opinion | The Men Who Want to Live Forever", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-07 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cThe Met to Non-New Yorkers: $25, Please\u201d (Arts pages, Jan. 5), about the Metropolitan Museum of Art\u2019s plan to end its \u201csuggested\u201d admission fee for out-of-state visitors:\n\nThe Met is the greatest place for a world education, to appreciate the achievements and intelligence of peoples throughout time and across geographical and cultural boundaries. It is an education that all people need, young and old, rich and poor, black, brown and white \u2014 especially in these times of exclusion and nationalistic arrogance. You can\u2019t learn more about the world than at the Met.\n\nSo I beg the Metropolitan Museum leadership, let it be accessible to all. Let people pay what they can, and no ID carding. This is not a luxury destination. It is a public good, an extremely necessary one. It is not about art for art connoisseurs. It is about world history and ideas. Everyone should have the chance to casually drop by.\n\nLYDIA CHEN, NEWTON, MASS.\n\nThe writer is a filmmaker.\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cThe Museum Should Be Open to All\u201d (\u201cA Critics\u2019 Conversation,\u201d Jan. 5): I am in complete agreement with the critics Roberta Smith and Holland Cotter. As an art history professor I have, over 30 years, brought more than a thousand students to the Met, many for their first visit. Mismanagement and bad decisions have put the Met in its current financial situation.\n\nFor wealthy museum board members, $25 may seem to be a pittance. For normal people, $25 only furthers the widespread and unfortunate impression that art is a pastime for the elite. To expect visitors who earn in a year what many of the board members make in a week to cover the museum\u2019s budget shortfall is outrageous.", "title": "Opinion | The Met\u2019s New Required Fee for Non-New Yorkers", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-27 00:00:00", "text": "PG But I was asking about the tribalism of the moment, whether your devil is the 1 percent or the bad hombres. Can science and reason really unbundle tribal thinking?\n\nSP One of the biggest enemies of reason is tribalism. When people subscribe to an ideology, they suck up evidence that supports their preconceptions and filter out evidence that goes against them. Contrary to the belief of most scientists that denial of climate change is an effect of scientific illiteracy, it is not at all correlated with scientific literacy. People who believe in man-made climate change don\u2019t know any more about climate or science than those who deny it. It\u2019s almost perfectly correlated with left-wing versus right-wing orientation. And a move toward greater rationality would unbundle them and let evidence inform what the optimal policies ought to be.\n\nPG But breaking deadlock surely requires more than asking people to be rational.\n\nBG I don\u2019t think we\u2019ve come to the point yet where democracy and science is going to stop working to improve lives. I was at a climate conference in Paris, and, honestly, there were as many nonscientific things said there in a good cause as I imagine were said at the non-climate convention that I didn\u2019t happen to attend. But I\u2019m optimistic. I do think awareness of how things have worked is important to recreate a conservative center \u2014 that is, make us careful about what we change.\n\nPG And here I thought you were going to say: Innovation drives progress, not Washington.\n\nBG But the problem now is that innovation is not viewed as an unalloyed way to improve the human condition. And that\u2019s fair, because it\u2019s not pure. Does social media split us into tribes in a way that\u2019s dangerous? Does it create, even in high school social circles, a channel for bullying, or a desire to look perfect in photos? Is A.I. going to proceed so quickly that work, which is something people worship, will suffer bad distributional effects, and people won\u2019t know what to do? This is an unfortunate time for saying, \u201cTake all your damn negative thoughts, and I\u2019ll innovate away from them.\u201d People are seeing difficulty with that argument.\n\nSP There\u2019s also a dichotomy between the roles of innovation and policy. There are certain things that governments are always going to do better than private innovators. Basic research, for instance. Also, governments can do things that might be necessary to accelerate the development of innovations. And in terms of numbers, the Gates Foundation is smaller than government by a significant margin, right?", "title": "The Mind Meld of Bill Gates and Steven Pinker", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "#SpeakingInDance is a weekly visual exploration of dance on Instagram. Watch the video from our most recent post below, and follow us at@nytimes.", "title": "The Moment of Seduction", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "Tom Brady, Bill Belichick and the New England Patriots have been here before. It was Feb. 6, 2005, and they were facing the Philadelphia Eagles. The Patriots won that game, Super Bowl XXXIX, 24-21.\n\nSince then, so much has changed in the N.F.L., from the commissioner to the rules to the shoulder pads. On the eve of Super Bowl LII, there\u2019s one thing that hasn\u2019t: Brady and Belichick are still on top.\n\nHere\u2019s a look at how the league, the players and the game have changed, for better or worse, since 2005:\n\nTagliabue\u2019s Out, Goodell\u2019s In\n\nPaul Tagliabue was nearing the end of a 17-year run as the N.F.L. commissioner in 2005. He was widely praised as a rock of stability in the highly popular and profitable league, lauded in particular for removing the 1993 Super Bowl from Arizona when the state would not recognize Martin Luther King Jr.\u2019s birthday.", "title": "The More Things Change, the More Brady and Belichick Stay the Same", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-06 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Drollinger was an early, passionate supporter of Donald Trump\u2019s presidential candidacy. The \u201cinstitution of the state\u201d is \u201can avenger of wrath,\u201d he explains, and its \u201cGod-given responsibility\u201d is \u201cto moralize a fallen world through the use of force.\u201d Apparently, President Trump excels in these biblical criteria for leadership.\n\nMr. Drollinger is dedicated to communicating those views in weekly Bible study groups. The participants in his groups, however, aren\u2019t just anybody. They include Mike Pompeo, the director of the C.I.A.; Attorney General Jeff Sessions; Vice President Mike Pence; Betsy DeVos, the secretary of education; and other senior officials in the Trump administration. Mr. Drollinger seeks to institute similar if less-star-studded Bible study groups in all 50 state capitals.\n\nMr. Drollinger claims to have planted 24 operations overseas and hopes \u201cto create 200 ministries in 200 foreign federal capitals.\u201d In 2015, his group was invited to \u201cplant a discipleship Bible study ministry\u201d in Belarus for the benefit of that nation\u2019s political leaders. His wife, Danielle Drollinger, attended as a representative of the Museum of the Bible, with a promise that the museum\u2019s Bible curriculum would soon be translated into Russian.\n\nThis fall, the museum also hosted Revive Us 2, a \u201cnational family meeting\u201d organized by Kirk Cameron, a television actor who has become a conservative Christian celebrity. The event was broadcast live from the museum to movie theaters around the country with the message that national unity can be achieved only through a religious \u201cawakening\u201d and allegiance to conservative Christianity.\n\nThe intensely politicized religion that appears to be taking up residence at the Museum of the Bible isn\u2019t there by accident. When Steve Green, the museum\u2019s founder and the president of the Hobby Lobby crafts chain, formed the museum\u2019s parent organization in 2010, he informed the I.R.S. that its purpose was \u201cto bring to life the living word of God, to tell its compelling story of preservation, and to inspire confidence in the absolute authority and reliability of the Bible.\u201d In 2012, the language was changed to say that the aim was simply \u201cto invite people to engage with the Bible.\u201d\n\nMr. Green rose to fame by getting the conservative majority on the Supreme Court to confer on Hobby Lobby the right to withhold federally mandated reproductive health care coverage from its female employees. The Green family lent artifacts to the Creation Museum in Kentucky and offers support to a \u201creligious literacy\u201d program aimed at public school students detailing the consequences they face if they disobey God.\n\nJoining the Hobby Lobby stores on the donor wall that memorializes large gifts to the Museum of the Bible are a dozen-plus foundations that routinely back conservative Christian causes. There is also a lot of Amway money supporting the museum, including the Dick and Betsy DeVos Family Foundation and other foundations connected to the DeVos family.\n\nGiven the theologico-political goals of its founders and patrons, it isn\u2019t hard to see that the location of this museum was an act of symbolic and practical genius. If you\u2019re going to build a Christian nation, this is where you start.", "title": "Opinion | The Museum of the Bible Is a Safe Space for Christian Nationalists", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "When we exercise, far-flung parts of our bodies apparently communicate with one another, thanks to tiny, particle-filled balloons that move purposefully through the bloodstream from one cell to another, carrying pressing biochemical messages, according to an important new study of the biology of exercise.\n\nThe study helps to clarify some of the body-wide health effects of working out and also underscores just how physiologically complex exercise is.\n\nFor some time, scientists have suspected that the body\u2019s internal organs are as gossipy and socially entangled as any 8th-grade classroom. It is thought that, under the right conditions, fat cells chat with muscle cells, and muscle cells whisper to brain cells and everybody seems to want to be buddies with the liver.\n\nThese interactions are especially abundant during exercise, when continued movement demands intricate coordination of many different systems within the body, including those that create cellular energy.", "title": "The Mysterious Interior World of Exercise", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-03 00:00:00", "text": "During that 2013 campaign, the writer Kyle Smith \u2014 making an argument that was then widespread among conservatives \u2014 blasted de Blasio and the voters supporting him. \u201cNew Yorkers have evidently decided that the crime wave is over and it\u2019s time to get lax about mayhem and disorder,\u201d Smith wrote for Forbes.\n\nAs you probably know by now, I\u2019m a fan of journalistic self-criticism, and Smith has engaged in some of it this week. His piece for National Review is called simply, \u201cWe Were Wrong About Stop-and-Frisk.\u201d He notes that crime has continued to decline under de Blasio. \u201cTo compare today\u2019s crime rate to even that of ten years ago is to observe a breathtaking decline,\u201d Smith adds.\n\nThe vast majority of stop-and-frisks did little to reduce crime, it seems. They instead amounted to harassment of innocent New Yorkers, many of whom were African-American men. (This six-minute Op-Docs film, by Julie Dressner and Edwin Martinez, puts a human face on the toll. It focuses on a Brooklyn teenager named Tyquan who was stopped about once every month, for years.)\n\nThe demise of stop-and-frisk is worth celebrating. Its costs were clearly high, and its benefits now appear to have been tiny. But the larger mystery remains: What does explain a decline in crime that has improved life in almost every major city over the last few decades \u2014 and which almost nobody saw coming?\n\nRelated: If you still think there is an easy answer, read Matt Ford\u2019s various debunkings in The Atlantic. And Jarvis DeBerry of The Times-Picayune argues that Senator John Neely Kennedy of Louisiana should now stop advocating stop-and-frisk as the answer to New Orleans\u2019s crime problems. Wesley Lowery of The Washington Post notes that Kennedy isn\u2019t the only person still peddling stop-and-frisk.", "title": "Opinion | The Mystery of the Crime Decline", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "When pressed, Guo claims a record of unblemished integrity in his business dealings, both in real estate and in finance (when it comes to his personal life, he strikes a more careful balance between virility and dedication to his family). \u201cI never took a square of land from the government,\u201d he said. \u201cI didn\u2019t take a penny of investment from the banks.\u201d If you accept favors, he said, people will try to exploit your weaknesses. So, Guo claims, he opted to take no money and have no weaknesses.\n\nYet when Guo left China in 2014, he fled in anticipation of corruption charges. A former business partner had been detained just days before, and his political patron would be detained a few days afterward. In 2015, articles about corruption in Guo\u2019s business dealings \u2014 stories that he claims are largely fabrications \u2014 started appearing in the media. He was accused of defrauding business partners and colluding with corrupt officials. To hear Guo tell it, his political and business opponents used a national corruption campaign as a cover for a personal vendetta.\n\nWhatever prompted Guo to take action, his campaign came during an important year for China\u2019s president, Xi Jinping. In October, the Communist Party of China (C.P.C.) convened its 19th National Congress, a twice-a-decade event that sets the contours of political power for the next five years. The country is in the throes of a far-reaching anti-corruption campaign, and Xi has overseen a crackdown on dissidents and human rights activists while increasing investment in censorship and surveillance. Guo has become a thorn in China\u2019s side at the precise moment the country is working to expand its influence, and its censorship program, overseas.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn November 2017, the Tiananmen Square activist Wang Dan warned of the growing influence of the C.P.C. on university campuses in the United States. His own attempts to hold \u201cChina salons\u201d on college campuses had largely been blocked by the Chinese Students and Scholars Association \u2014 a group with ties to China\u2019s government. Around the same time, the academic publisher Springer Nature agreed to block access to hundreds of articles on its Chinese site, cutting off access to articles on Tibet, Taiwan and China\u2019s political elite. Reports emerged last year that China is spending hundreds of thousands of dollars quarterly to purchase ads on Facebook (a service that is blocked within China\u2019s borders). In Australia, concerns about China\u2019s growing influence led to a ban on foreign political donations.\n\n\u201cThat\u2019s why I\u2019m telling the United States they should really be careful,\u201d Guo said. China\u2019s influence is spreading, he says, and he believes his own efforts to change China will have global consequences. \u201cLike in an American movie,\u201d he told me with unflinching self-confidence. \u201cIn the last minutes, we will save the world.\u201d\n\nPropaganda, censorship and rewritten histories have long been specialties of authoritarian nations. The aim, as famously explained by the political philosopher Hannah Arendt, is to confuse: to breed a combination of cynicism and gullibility. Propaganda can leave people in doubt of all news sources, suspicious of their neighbors, picking and choosing at random what pieces of information to believe. Without a political reality grounded in facts, people are left unmoored, building their world on whatever foundation \u2014 imaginary or otherwise \u2014 they might choose.\n\nThe tight grip that the C.P.C. keeps on information may be nothing new, but China\u2019s leadership has been working hard to update the way it censors and broadcasts. People in China distrusted print and television media long before U.S. politicians started throwing around accusations of \u201cfake news.\u201d In 2016, President Xi Jinping was explicit about the arrangement, informing the country\u2019s media that it should be \u201csurnamed Party.\u201d Likewise, while the West has only recently begun to grapple with government-sponsored commenters on social media, China\u2019s government has been manipulating online conversations for over a decade.\n\n\u201cThey create all kinds of confusion,\u201d said Ha Jin, the National Book Award-winning American novelist born in China\u2019s Liaoning Province, and a vocal supporter of Guo. \u201cYou don\u2019t know what information you have and whether it\u2019s right. You don\u2019t know who are the informers, who are the agents.\u201d\n\nOnline, the C.P.C. controls information by blocking websites, monitoring content and employing an army of commenters widely known as the 50-cent party. The name was used as early as 2004, when a municipal government in Hunan Province hired a number of online commenters, offering a stipend of 600 yuan, or about $72. Since then, the 50-cent party has spread. In 2016, researchers from Harvard, Stanford and the University of California-San Diego estimated that these paid commenters generated 448 million social-media comments annually. The posts, researchers found, were conflict averse, cheerleading for the party rather than defending it. Their aim seemed not to be engaging in argument but rather distracting the public and redirecting attention from sensitive issues.\n\nIn early 2017, Guo issued his first salvos against China\u2019s ruling elite through more traditional channels. He contacted a handful of Chinese-language media outlets based in the United States. He gave interviews to the Long Island-based publication Mingjing News and to Voice of America \u2014 a live event that was cut short by producers, leading to speculation that V.O.A. had caved to Chinese government pressure. He called The New York Times and spoke with reporters at The Wall Street Journal. It did not take long, however, before the billionaire turned to direct appeals through social media. The accusations he made were explosive \u2014 he attacked Wang Qishan, Xi Jinping\u2019s corruption czar, and Meng Jianzhu, the secretary of the Central Political and Legal Affairs Commission, another prominent player in Xi\u2019s anti-corruption campaign. He talked about Wang\u2019s mistresses, his business interests and conflicts within the party.\n\nIn one YouTube video, released on Aug. 4, Guo addressed the tension between Wang and another anti-corruption official named Zhang Huawei. He recounted having dinner with Zhang when \u201che called Wang Qishan\u2019s secretary and gave him orders,\u201d Guo said. \u201cThink about what Wang had to suffer in silence back then. They slept with the same women, and Zhang knew everything about Wang.\u201d In addition, Guo said, Zhang knew about Wang\u2019s corrupt business dealings. When Zhang Huawei was placed under official investigation in April, Guo claimed, it was a result of a grudge.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cEveryone in China is a slave,\u201d Guo said in the video. \u201cWith the exception of the nobility.\u201d\n\nTo those who believe Guo\u2019s claims, they expose a depth of corruption that would surprise even the most jaded opponent of the C.P.C. \u201cThe corruption is on such a scale,\u201d Ha Jin said. \u201cWho could imagine that the czar of anti-corruption would himself be corrupt? It is extraordinary.\u201d\n\nRetaliation came quickly. A barrage of counteraccusations began pouring out against Guo, most published in the pages of the state-run Chinese media. Warrants for his arrest were issued on charges of corruption, bribery and even rape. China asked Interpol to issue a red notice calling for Guo\u2019s arrest and extradition. He was running out of money, it was reported. In September, Guo recorded a video during which he received what he said was a phone call from his fifth brother: Two of Guo\u2019s former employees had been detained, and their family members were threatening suicide. \u201cMy Twitter followers are so important they are like heaven to me,\u201d Guo said. But, he declared, he could not ignore the well-being of his family and his employees. \u201cI cannot finish the show as I had planned,\u201d he said. Later, Guo told his followers in a video that he was planning to divorce his wife, in order to shield her from the backlash against him.\n\nGuo quickly resumed posting videos and encouraging his followers. His accusations continued to accumulate throughout 2017, and he recently started his own YouTube channel (and has yet to divorce his wife). His YouTube videos are released according to no particular schedule, sometimes several days in a row, some weeks not at all. He has developed a casual, talkative style. In some, Guo is running on a treadmill or still sweating after a workout. He has demonstrated cooking techniques and played with a tiny, fluffy dog, a gift from his daughter. He invites his viewers into a world of luxury and offers them a mix of secrets, gossip and insider knowledge.\n\nWang Qishan, Guo has claimed, is hiding the money he secretly earned in the Hainan-based conglomerate HNA Group, a company with an estimated $35 billion worth of investments in the United States. (HNA Group denies any ties to Wang and is suing Guo.) He accused Wang of carrying on an affair with the actress Fan Bingbing. (Fan is reportedly suing Guo for defamation.) He told stories of petty arguments among officials and claimed that Chinese officials sabotaged Malaysia Airlines Flight 370, which disappeared in 2014 en route to Beijing, in order to cover up an organ-harvesting scheme. Most of Guo\u2019s accusations have proved nearly impossible to verify.\n\n\u201cThis guy is just covered in question marks,\u201d said Minxin Pei, a professor at Claremont McKenna who specializes in Chinese governance.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe questions that cover Guo have posed a problem for both the United States government and the Western journalists who, in trying to write about him, have found themselves buffeted by the currents of propaganda, misinformation and the tight-lipped code of the C.P.C. elite. His claims have also divided a group of exiled dissidents and democracy activists \u2014 people who might seem like Guo\u2019s natural allies. For the most part, the democracy activists who flee China have been chased from their country for protesting the government or promoting human rights, not because of corruption charges. They tell stories of personal persecution, not insider tales of bribery, sex and money. And perhaps as a consequence, few exiled activists command as large an audience as Guo. \u201cI will believe him,\u201d Ha Jin said, \u201cuntil one of his serious accusations is proved to be false.\u201d\n\nPei, the professor, warns not to take any of Guo\u2019s accusations at face value. The reaction from the C.P.C. has been so extreme, however, that Pei believes Guo must know something. \u201cHe must mean something to the government,\u201d he said. \u201cThey must be really bothered by this billionaire.\u201d In May, Chinese officials visited Guo on visas that did not allow them to conduct official business, causing a confrontation with the F.B.I. A few weeks later, according to The Washington Times, China\u2019s calls for Guo\u2019s extradition led to a White House showdown, during which Jeff Sessions threatened to resign if Guo was sent back to China.\n\nGuo has a history of cultivating relationships with the politically influential, and the trend has continued in New York. He famously bought 5,000 copies of a book by Cherie Blair, Tony Blair\u2019s wife. (\u201cIt was to give to my employees,\u201d Guo told me. \u201cI often gave my employees books to read.\u201d) Guo has also cultivated a special relationship with Steve Bannon, whom he says he has met with a handful of times, although the two have no financial relationship. Not long after one of their meetings, Bannon appeared on Breitbart Radio and called China \u201can enemy of incalculable power.\u201d\n\nDespite Guo\u2019s high-powered supporters and his army of online followers, one important mark of believability has continued to elude him. Western news organizations have struggled to find evidence that would corroborate Guo\u2019s claims. When his claims appear in print, they are carefully hedged \u2014 delivered with none of his signature charm and bombast. \u201cWhy do you need more evidence?\u201d Guo complained in his apartment. \u201cI can give them evidence, no problem. But while they\u2019re out spending time investigating, I\u2019m waiting around to get killed!\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe details of Guo\u2019s life may be impossible to verify, but the broad strokes confirm a picture of a man whose fortunes have risen and fallen with the political climate in China. To hear Guo tell it, he was born in Jilin Province, in a mining town where his parents were sent during the Cultural Revolution. \u201cThere were foreigners there,\u201d Guo says in a video recorded on what he claims is his birthday. (Guo was born on Feb. 2, or May 10, or sometime in June.) \u201cThey had the most advanced machinery. People wore popular clothing.\u201d Guo, as a result, was not ignorant of the world. He was, however, extremely poor. \u201cSometimes we didn\u2019t even have firewood,\u201d he says. \u201cSo we burned the wet twigs from the mountains \u2014 the smoke was so thick.\u201d Guo emphasizes this history: He came from hardship. He pulled himself up.\n\nThe story continues into Guo\u2019s pre-teenage years, when he moved back to his hometown in Shandong Province. He met his wife and married her when he was only 15, she 14. They moved to Heilongjiang, where they started a small manufacturing operation, taking advantage of the early days of China\u2019s economic rise, and then to Henan. Guo got his start in real estate in a city called Zhengzhou, where he founded the Zhengzhou Yuda Property Company and built the tallest building the city had seen so far, the Yuda International Trade Center. According to Guo, he was only 25 when he made this first deal.\n\nThe string of businesses and properties that Guo developed provide some of the confirmable scaffolding of his life. No one disputes that Guo went on to start both the Beijing Morgan Investment Company and Beijing Zenith Holdings. Morgan Investment was responsible for building a cluster of office towers called the Pangu Plaza, the tallest of which has a wavy top that loosely resembles a dragon, or perhaps a precarious cone of soft-serve ice cream. Guo is in agreement with the Chinese media that in buying the property for Pangu Plaza, he clashed with the deputy mayor of Beijing. The dispute ended when Guo turned in a lengthy sex tape capturing the deputy mayor in bed with his mistress.\n\nThere are other details in Guo\u2019s biography, however, that vary from one source to the next. Guo says that he never took government loans; Caixin, a Beijing-based publication, quoted \u201csources close to the matter\u201d in a 2015 article claiming that Guo took out 28 loans totaling 588 million yuan, or about $89 million. Guo, according to Caixin, eventually defaulted. At some point in this story \u2014 the timeline varies \u2014 Guo became friends with the vice minister of China\u2019s Ministry of State Security, Ma Jian. The M.S.S. is China\u2019s answer to the C.I.A. and the F.B.I. combined. It spies on civilians and foreigners alike, conducting operations domestically and internationally, amassing information on diplomats, businessmen and even the members of the C.P.C. Describing Ma, Guo leans back in his chair and mimes smoking a cigarette. \u201cMa Jian! He was fat and his skin was tan.\u201d According to Guo, Ma sat like this during their first meeting, listening to Guo\u2019s side of a dispute. Then Ma told him to trust the country. \u201cTrust the law,\u201d he told Guo. \u201cWe will treat you fairly.\u201d The older master of spycraft and the young businessman struck up a friendship that would become a cornerstone in Guo\u2019s claims of insider knowledge, and also possibly the reason for the businessman\u2019s downfall in China.\n\nFollowing the construction of Pangu Plaza in Beijing, Guo\u2019s life story becomes increasingly hard to parse. He started a securities business with a man named Li You. After a falling-out, Li was detained by the authorities. Guo\u2019s company accused Li and his company of insider trading. According to the 2015 article in Caixin, Li then penned a letter to the authorities accusing Guo of \u201cwrongdoing.\u201d\n\nAs this dispute was going on, China\u2019s anti-\u200bcorruption operation was building a case against Ma Jian. In Guo\u2019s telling, Ma had long been rumored to be collecting intelligence on China\u2019s leaders. As the anti-corruption campaign gained speed and officials like Wang Qishan gained power, Ma\u2019s well of intelligence started to look like a threat. It was Guo\u2019s relationship with Ma, the tycoon maintains, that made officials nervous. Ma was detained by the authorities in January 2015, shortly after Guo fled the country. Soon after Ma\u2019s detention, accounts began appearing in China\u2019s state-run media claiming that Ma had six Beijing villas, six mistresses and at least two illegitimate sons. In a 2015 article that ran in the party-run newspaper The China Daily, the writer added another detail: \u201cThe investigation also found that Ma had acted as an umbrella for the business ventures of Guo Wengui, a tycoon from Henan Province.\u201d\n\nIn the mix of spies, corrupt business dealings, mistresses and sex scandals, Guo has one more unbelievable story to tell about his past. It is one reason, he says, that he was mentally prepared to confront the leaders of the Communist Party. It happened nearly 29 years ago, in the aftermath of the crackdown on Tiananmen Square. According to Guo, he had donated money to the students protesting in the square, and so a group of local police officers came to find him at his home. An overzealous officer fired off a shot at Guo\u2019s wife \u2014 at which point Guo\u2019s younger brother jumped in front of the bullet, suffering a fatal wound. \u201cThat was when I started my plan,\u201d he said. \u201cIf your brother had been killed in front of your eyes, would you just forget it?\u201d Never mind the fact that it would take 28 years for him to take any public stand against the party that caused his brother\u2019s death. Never mind that the leadership had changed. \u201cI\u2019m not saying everyone in the Communist Party is bad,\u201d he said. \u201cThe system is bad. So what I need to oppose is the system.\u201d\n\nOn an unusually warm Saturday afternoon in Flushing, Queens, a group of around 30 of Guo\u2019s supporters gathered for a barbecue in Kissena Park. They laid out a spread of vegetables and skewers of shrimp and squid. Some children toddled through the crowd, chewing on hot dogs and rolling around an unopened can of Coke. The adults fussed with a loudspeaker and a banner that featured the name that Guo goes by in English, Miles Kwok. \u201cMiles Kwok, NY loves U,\u201d it said, a heart standing in for the word \u201cloves.\u201d \u201cDemocracy, Justice, Liberty for China.\u201d Someone else had carried in a life-size cutout of the billionaire.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe revelers decided to hold the event in the park partly for the available grills but also partly because the square in front of Guo\u2019s penthouse had turned dangerous. A few weeks earlier, some older women had been out supporting Guo when a group of Chinese men holding flags and banners showed up. At one point, the men wrapped the women in a protest banner and hit them. The park was a safer option. And the protesters had learned from Guo \u2014 it wasn\u2019t a live audience they were hoping for. The group would be filming the protest and posting it on social media. Halfway through, Guo would call in on someone\u2019s cellphone, and the crowd would cheer.\n\nDespite this show of support, Guo\u2019s claims have divided China\u2019s exiled dissidents to such an extent that on a single day near the end of September, two dueling meetings of pro-democracy activists were held in New York, one supporting Guo, the other casting doubt on his motivations. (\u201cThey are jealous of me,\u201d Guo said of his detractors. \u201cThey think: Why is he so handsome? Why are so many people listening to him?\u201d) Some of Guo\u2019s claims are verifiably untrue \u2014 he claimed in an interview with Vice that he paid $82 million for his apartment \u2014 and others seem comically aggrandized. (Guo says he never wears the same pair of underwear twice.) But the repercussions he is facing are real.\n\nIn December, Guo\u2019s brother was sentenced to three years and six months in prison for destroying accounting records. The lawsuits filed against Guo for defamation are piling up, and Guo has claimed to be amassing a \u201cwar chest\u201d of $150 million to cover his legal expenses. In September, a new set of claims against Guo were made in a 49-page document circulated by a former business rival. For Ha Jin, Guo\u2019s significance runs deeper than his soap-opera tales of scandal and corruption. \u201cThe grand propaganda scheme is to suppress and control all the voices,\u201d Jin said. \u201cNow everybody knows that you can create your own voice. You can have your own show. That fact alone is historical.\u201d In the future, Jin predicts, there will be more rebels like Guo. \u201cThere is something very primitive about this, realizing that this is a man, a regular citizen who can confront state power.\u201d\n\nHo Pin, the founder of Long Island\u2019s Mingjing News, echoed Jin. Mingjing\u2019s reporters felt that covering Guo was imperative, no matter the haziness of the information. \u201cIn China, the political elite that Guo was attacking had platforms of their own,\u201d Ho said. \u201cThey have the opportunity, the power and the ability to use all the government\u2019s apparatus to refute and oppose Guo Wengui. So our most important job is to allow Guo Wengui\u2019s insider knowledge reach the fair, open-minded people in China.\u201d Still, people like Pei urge caution when dealing with Guo\u2019s claims. Even Guo\u2019s escape raises questions. Few others have slipped through the net of China\u2019s anti-corruption drive. \u201cHow could he get so lucky?\u201d Pei asked. \u201cHe must have been tipped off long before.\u201d\n\nAt the barbecue, a supporter named Ye Rong tucked one of his children under his arm and acknowledged that Guo\u2019s past life is riddled with holes. There was always the possibility that Guo used to be a thug, but Ye didn\u2019t think it mattered. The rules of the conflict had been set by the Communist Party. \u201cYou need all kinds of people to oppose the Chinese government,\u201d Ye said. \u201cWe need intellectuals; we also need thugs.\u201d\n\nGuo, of course, has his own opinions about his legacy. He warned of dark times for Americans and for the world, if he doesn\u2019t succeed in his mission to change China. \u201cI am trying to help,\u201d he told me. \u201cI am not joking with you.\u201d He continued: \u201cI will change China within the next three years. If I don\u2019t change it, I won\u2019t be able to survive.\u201d", "title": "The Mystery of the Exiled Billionaire Whistle-Blower", "authors": ["Lauren Hilgers"]} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "Between gasping at falls and shouting encouragement, many parents were asking a variation of the same question: Had everyone seen the latest testimony in the sentencing hearing?\n\nMs. Matson and her husband discussed how they should talk about sexual assault with Macy after Dr. Nassar pleaded guilty last year. Another mother said she participated in the women\u2019s march with her daughter, but wondered if disclosing the details of the Nassar case would cause her daughter to fear men.\n\nOn top of that, parents of older teenagers wondered what their children may have seen on social media that they were not aware of.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cThe Olympic team and the elite girls \u2014 they follow them on Instagram; these are their role models and their heroes,\u201d Kelly Craig said of her 12- and 14-year-old daughters, who practice at Chelsea Piers. \u201cMy 14-year-old has read all the statements. When they closed the ranch, my daughter showed me \u2014 she knew before I did.\u201d\n\nDr. Nassar was previously sentenced to 60 years in prison on child pornography charges. During his sentencing hearing in Lansing, Mich., over the past two weeks, more than 150 women \u2014 including prominent Olympians \u2014 spoke about the abuse they endured.\n\nThere is no one set of guidelines to teach parents how to talk to their children about sexual assault. Laura Palumbo, the director of communications at the National Sexual Violence Resource Center, said that there was appropriate information to give children about sexual violence at every stage of development.\n\n\u201cOne of the biggest misconceptions is that these conversations are too advanced or harmful for children to hear about,\u201d Ms. Palumbo said. \u201cIn reality, the more information that we can give children from an early age about understanding your bodies and your boundaries and what types of touch are appropriate \u2014 not only does it give your child that information, it also lets them know that these are safe topics to talk to you about.\u201d\n\nSienna Livengood, 10, had no idea why her idols were in the national spotlight. She worships the Olympic gymnasts so much that in her free time, she is creating a short film about the journey of the Fierce Five, as the 2012 United States gymnastics team was called, to the London Olympics.\n\nSienna\u2019s mother, Jen Livengood, said she talked to her daughter about sexual violence in general terms, but had not let her watch or read about the trial. The two of them talk about self-worth and having the confidence to speak up if something isn\u2019t right.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cEvery parent has to be open to conversation, and not just in sports \u2014 it\u2019s at church and in school,\u201d said Brandy Bauman, the owner of Go for It USA gymnasium in Las Vegas and a mother of two. \u201cIt\u2019s everywhere you are trusting someone else with your child. Our sport is getting a wake-up call.\u201d", "title": "The Nassar Case Presents Difficult Parenting Questions", "authors": ["Malika Andrews"]} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "About two dozen paintings, photographs and works on paper by Mr. Close were to have been shown in tower three of the National Gallery\u2019s East Building, as part of a rotating series of installations known as \u201cIn the Tower,\u201d Ms. Guthrie said.\n\nThe gallery also canceled an exhibition of photographs planned for September by Thomas Roma, a documentary photographer and former professor who had also been accused of sexual misconduct, Ms. Guthrie said. The photographs focused on worshipers in African-American churches in Brooklyn.\n\nMr. Roma retired earlier this month from Columbia University, where he had been the director of the School of the Arts photography program, after The Times published accounts of sexual harassment and assault from five women who had been his students there and the School of Visual Arts.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe National Gallery\u2019s decision is unusual, and most institutions are not reconsidering their decision to hang work by Mr. Close on their walls.\n\nThe Metropolitan Museum of Art is not changing the Close painting currently on view in its Modern and Contemporary galleries.\n\nKim Sajet, director of the National Portrait Gallery in Washington, said in an emailed statement on Friday that the institution had not received any inquiries about Mr. Close\u2019s portrait of Bill Clinton, which remains on loan in a permanent gallery there.\n\n\u201cLike others in the art world, we have been giving this news serious consideration,\u201d she added.\n\nThe Broad Museum in Los Angeles has one work by Mr. Close on display, \u201cJohn,\u201d from 1971.\n\nIn response to a Times inquiry over whether it was rethinking the artist\u2019s presence on its walls, it stated: \u201cWe are dismayed by accounts we have read of misconduct in Chuck Close\u2019s interactions with many women.\n\nWe are engaged in active internal discussion, considering both The Broad museum\u2019s primary mission to present contemporary art and foster dialogue, and the complexity and seriousness of the issue.\u201d", "title": "The National Gallery of Art Cancels a Chuck Close Show After Misconduct Accusations", "authors": ["Colin Moynihan", "Robin Pogrebin"]} {"date": "2018-01-20 00:00:00", "text": "DALLAS \u2014 Dana Loesch has a biblical inscription tattooed on her forearm, a reference to a passage in the Book of Ephesians that calls for Christians to wear holy armor to protect themselves from a dark world. It is an apt precept for Ms. Loesch, a 39-year-old conservative radio talk-show host and political commentator who views the world through a lens of fear and violence.\n\nIt is why she has an arsenal of firearms strategically placed in safes throughout her home. She keeps a handgun near her bed in the event of an intruder, she said, which she can use until she finds a more powerful shotgun or rifle nearby. She sometimes tucks a gun in the small of her back. Other times, she keeps a knife in her purse.\n\n\u201cEvil is real,\u201d she said over a plate of barbecued sausage last month in a suburban restaurant.\n\nAnd if there is a question about what God has to do with any of this, she keeps a sign in the window of the house that she and her family recently vacated. \u201cThis home protected by the good lord and a gun,\u201d it read. \u201cIf you came here to steal or do harm you might meet them both.\u201d", "title": "The National Rifle Association\u2019s Telegenic Warrior", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "But Mr. Bryant\u2019s speech detoured to praise a local journalist\u2019s coverage of the epidemic, saying she \u201chas done an outstanding job informing us all of the horrific events resulting from opioid and illegal drug-related criminal activity.\u201d\n\n\u201cWe should all thank Therese Apel of The Clarion-Ledger for shining a light on the horrible consequences of this behavior,\u201d Mr. Bryant said. \u201cTherese, you stand as an example of a journalist who has made a difference.\u201d\n\nSuch public praise for a reporter might be rare in a governor\u2019s annual address at any time, but seemed especially notable in a political climate in which President Trump and some Republicans have sought to label the mainstream press as \u201cfake news.\u201d\n\nDays later, Mr. Bryant and his allies critiqued coverage of Mr. Bryant\u2019s speech, with the governor retweeting a Mississippi Republican Party assertion that a news organization \u201cwould have 5 reporters fact check the governor and not one fact check the Democrats.\u201d\n\nHawaii: Missile alarm? What missile alarm?\n\nPhoto\n\nGov. David Ige, a Democrat, apologized earlier this month when a state worker sent an erroneous alert to cellphones that falsely warned of an imminent missile attack.\n\nA few days later, Mr. Ige delivered his State of the State speech, in which he lauded Hawaii as \u201cthe most beautiful place on earth\u201d and pledged to counter the \u201chateful and hurtful policies of the Trump White House.\u201d\n\nNoticeably absent from Mr. Ige\u2019s speech was any mention of the botched missile warning, which sent residents into a panic and prompted criticism of his administration. The omission was noted in a headline from The Honolulu Star-Advertiser: \u201cIge highlights accomplishments, skirts false-alert fiasco.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMissouri: A speech eclipsed by a scandal\n\nPhoto\n\nGov. Eric Greitens, a Republican, gave his State of the State address just hours before he admitted having an extramarital affair.\n\nThe speech itself was mostly standard fare, or at least it seemed that way in the moment: Mr. Greitens paused to praise his wife and boasted that he had been elected to work \u201cfor those who have felt counted out and forgotten.\u201d\n\n\u201cWe promised the people of Missouri we would do different,\u201d Mr. Greitens said. \u201cWe have, and we will.\u201d\n\nBut on that night\u2019s newscast, a St. Louis television station publicized Mr. Greitens\u2019s affair and reported accusations that he had blackmailed the woman. In the days that followed, a local prosecutor announced an investigation and some lawmakers, including fellow Republicans, urged him to resign.\n\nMr. Greitens says he did nothing illegal and has resisted calls to quit.\n\nCalifornia: So much for cheery platitudes\n\nPhoto\n\nMost governors use their State of the State addresses to talk about taxes, crime, education or other issues facing the state in the year ahead. Gov. Jerry Brown of California did all of that. But he also used his speech on Thursday to warn about the end of the world.\n\n\u201cOur world, our way of life, our system of governance \u2014 all are at immediate and genuine risk,\u201d said Mr. Brown, a Democrat. \u201cEndless new weapons systems, growing antagonism among nations, the poison in our politics, climate change.\u201d\n\nThe governor, who is 79 and beginning his last year in public office, explained the reason for his concern.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cJust this morning, the pre-eminent science and security board of the Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists moved the minute hand of the Doomsday Clock 30 seconds closer to catastrophe,\u201d he said. \u201cIt is now 2 minutes to midnight, as close as it was at the height of the Cold War in 1953.\u201d\n\nThese are hardly new themes for Mr. Brown who, over the course of 45 years in public life, has frequently spoken out on global issues, and in particular, global warming. Still, it was a little jarring to hear such alarming words in the midst of a more standard address about education funding and the state\u2019s health care system.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAlaska: A call to fight climate change \u2014 and drill for oil\n\nPhoto\n\nGov. Bill Walker, a political independent, labeled Alaska \u201ca ground zero for climate change\u201d and called for action to address the challenge.\n\n\u201cRetreating sea ice and glaciers and thawing permafrost are not partisan issues \u2014 they are social, environmental and economic ones,\u201d Mr. Walker said, highlighting an issue that also figured prominently in addresses by the Democratic governors of Washington and Hawaii.\n\nBut Mr. Walker\u2019s call to combat climate change included a twist unlikely to hearten environmentalists: a goal of expanding energy production in his resource-rich state.\n\n\u201cWe make nothing on oil discovered but left in the ground,\u201d Mr. Walker said. \u201cAccess and production are key.\u201d\n\nColorado: Spanish, French or coding?\n\nPhoto\n\nGov. John Hickenlooper, a Democrat, told legislators that Colorado students sometimes graduated without the skills desired by employers.\n\nMr. Hickenlooper was one of several governors who pointed in their speeches to job training as a major issue, and he called for an expansion of computer coding classes in middle schools and high schools.\n\nHe also offered an unorthodox idea on how to categorize those courses.\n\n\u201cWhy not give those schools with a foreign language requirement the choice to offer coding as an alternative language?\u201d Mr. Hickenlooper said.\n\nKansas: A $600 million request on the way out\n\nPhoto\n\nFew expected Gov. Sam Brownback, a Republican known for fiscal conservatism, to be around for another State of the State address after President Trump nominated him for an ambassadorship last summer.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut amid a long and awkward wait for a confirmation vote, Mr. Brownback returned to the Capitol for a final address. The governor, known best for a sweeping philosophy of tax-cuts, stunned lawmakers by calling for a $600 million increase in public school funding over five years \u2014 in what looked like an about-face from what he had been advocating in years past.\n\n\u201cThis multiyear approach will provide the time necessary for school districts to plan and spend this additional money more effectively,\u201d Mr. Brownback said. \u201cMy proposal does not include a tax increase.\u201d\n\nMany of Mr. Brownback\u2019s fellow Republicans were openly unimpressed. One of them, State Representative Tom Cox, told The Wichita Eagle that the proposal seemed like \u201ca final \u2018screw you\u2019 to the Legislature,\u201d without laying out a real plan for how to pay for such a plan.\n\nAlas, Mr. Brownback will soon be leaving Topeka. He was confirmed as an ambassador on Wednesday.", "title": "The Nation\u2019s Governors Spoke, and We Found a Few Surprises. (Yes, Really.)", "authors": ["Mitch Smith"]} {"date": "2018-01-27 00:00:00", "text": "After 12 years of failed attempts at immigration reform, the current round of negotiations are turning on a strangely personalized question: When a deal is being made, should Stephen Miller be at the table?\n\nMiller is the White House\u2019s point man for immigration policy (and for strange and strident encounters with the press). He is also an immigration restrictionist: He wants a policy that favors skills-based recruitment over extended families, and he wants a lower immigration rate overall. He says he\u2019s concerned about assimilation and crime and native wages; his critics say he just wants to keep America as white as possible, and that by even bringing him to meetings Trump is making a deal impossible to reach.\n\nThe critics are right about this much: Having someone like Miller involved is a change from the way prior immigration negotiations have proceeded. As Jim Antle points out in a column for The Week, those negotiations have been consistently bipartisan, bringing together John McCain and Ted Kennedy, Marco Rubio and Chuck Schumer, now Lindsey Graham and Dick Durbin \u2014 but \u201cthey have mostly taken place between people who are fundamentally in agreement on immigration,\u201d who favor both amnesty for illegal immigrants and reforms that would probably increase immigration rates.\n\nThe problem with this approach is that it doesn\u2019t represent the actual divisions in the country. Americans have become more pro-immigration since the 1990s, but there is still a consistent pattern when you ask about immigration rates: About a third of Americans favor the current trend, slightly fewer want higher rates, and about a third, like Miller, want immigration reduced.", "title": "Opinion | The Necessity of Stephen Miller", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "Mark Zuckerberg is discovering the cost of factory-farming Facebook\u2019s users. The $550 billion social network\u2019s success in harvesting advertising dollars through mass-appeal content has made it very profitable. The snag is that users are increasingly unhappy. The founder and chief executive\u2019s return to focusing more on their welfare may limit short-run earnings but should improve sustainability.\n\nThe Facebook farm has become increasingly unwholesome. The company is at the center of a storm over the promotion of false news stories, some potentially placed with the intention of interfering with the 2016 presidential election. Time spent per user on the core site has been falling, albeit from a high base, according to Pivotal Research. Mr. Zuckerberg\u2019s stated goals for 2018 are fixing the site, cleaning up abuse, limiting interference by nation states and \u201cmaking sure time spent on Facebook is time well spent.\u201d\n\nNow Facebook is changing its algorithms, according to a post on Thursday, to put a priority on News Feed items that users\u2019 friends share and interact with and reduce the amount of third-party non-advertising content. Multiple studies link time spent on social networks with unhappiness, and watching mass-produced videos and reading clickbait articles on a screen surely don\u2019t help.\n\nFacebook hopes higher-quality feeds will work better. \u201cWe feel a responsibility to make sure our services aren\u2019t just fun to use, but also good for people\u2019s well-being,\u201d Mr. Zuckerberg wrote.", "title": "The New Facebook\u2019s Long-Term Benefit to the Bottom Line", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "Update: See our Golden Globes red carpet coverage here.\n\nHarvey Weinstein helped build the awards circuit as we know it. He\u2019ll be gone from this year\u2019s Golden Globes \u2014 denounced, derided, joked about \u2014 but his presence, and questionable legacy, will be everywhere.\n\nBack in the days of VHS, he helped pioneer the practice of sending out screener copies of his movies, asking his staff to hunt down the addresses of members of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences. Disney acquired his company, Miramax, partly because it wanted the Oscars that Mr. Weinstein would win; the 1993 sale gave Mr. Weinstein vastly more cash and power.\n\nHe ran awards campaigns like wars, winning six best picture Oscars along the way. Even in recent years, when his power began to wane, Mr. Weinstein threw one of the splashiest parties after the Golden Globes ceremony.\n\nWhat no one knew was that Mr. Weinstein allegedly used the awards as an instrument of harassment \u2014 luring the French actress Judith Godreche to a Cannes hotel room, for instance, on the pretext of discussing his strategy to pursue an Oscar for her.", "title": "The New Red Carpet", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-17 00:00:00", "text": "David Axelrod, Mr. Obama\u2019s former senior adviser, said in 2011 that the president had \u201calways been on my butt about this, and as a result, my butt is a little bit smaller.\u201d\n\nBut outside many cart-assisted games of golf, Mr. Trump has declined to latch on to an exercise program. Fitness experts say persuading Mr. Trump to change his lifestyle will be a matter of figuring out what might motivate him to add small amounts of movement to his day, be it a stroll in the Rose Garden or a walk on the golf course.\n\n\u201cPeople are not inclined to do what they\u2019re told,\u201d Jessica Matthews, a senior health adviser at the American Council on Exercise, said in an interview. \u201cWhen they come up with their own solutions, you\u2019d be surprised how readily excited and how able they are to make that change and do it long term.\u201d\n\nThis might be particularly true for Mr. Trump, a man known to balk when told what to do. Ted Vickey, a former director of the White House Athletic Center, a fitness complex for employees of the executive branch, said in an interview that Mr. Trump\u2019s love of golf \u2014 and, perhaps, maybe a wearable fitness tracker like a Fitbit \u2014 could be the key to improving his exercise routine.\n\n\u201cI\u2019d say, \u2018Mr. President, we could knock four strokes off your golf game if you exercised for the next three months,\u2019\u201d Mr. Vickey said. \u201cAnd the Secret Service probably wouldn\u2019t like it, but I\u2019d tell him to walk the golf course rather than ride a golf cart.\u201d\n\nWhatever route he chooses, Mr. Trump has the ability to install whatever equipment he wants in the White House. (Past presidents used a converted bedroom on the top floor to work out in privacy.) Mr. Vickey, who said he was involved in helping get a treadmill installed on Air Force One for George W. Bush, said that Mr. Bush also at one point requested an elliptical machine to be installed near a private outdoor pool and cabana in the White House. The equipment was there within 24 hours.\n\nDenise Evans, who worked at the White House Athletic Center during the Reagan, Clinton and George Bush administrations, said that she would recommend that the president limit his Diet Coke habit to one a day, and start small with exercise.", "title": "The Next Hurdle for a Healthy Trump? Getting Some Exercise", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-29 00:00:00", "text": "Hotels across the country are rushing to introduce robots with the promise of enhancing the guest experience and increasing efficiency. The automated companions can do everything from make and pick up deliveries to help guests find their way around.\n\nAloft Cupertino in the Silicon Valley (rates from $150) was the first hotel in the United States to debut Savioke\u2019s Relay robot in 2014. The three foot tall autonomous robot, nicknamed Botlr, weighs 90 pounds and makes deliveries throughout the hotel using multiple sensors, 3D cameras and Wi-Fi to operate the elevators. Marriott has since begun mobile robot service at four other Aloft properties.\n\n\u201cBotlr\u2019s most popular guest deliveries are forgotten toiletry items, bottled water, microwave popcorn and coloring books for kids \u2014 all complimentary, of course,\u201d said Andy Evers, Aloft Cupertino\u2019s general manager.\n\nOther hotels are following suit. H Hotel Los Angeles\u2019s Relay robot, named Hannah, made 610 front desk deliveries and 42 room service deliveries, traveling a total of 50 miles, in the first three months since the hotel opened last October (rates from $249). \u201cIt\u2019s a great timesaver for our team because no one has to leave their station to make a delivery,\u201d said Tiffany Jassel, a manager. The robot cruises at a speed of 1.7 miles per hour and has a two-cubic-foot bin to carry items, which guests unlock by typing in a code on its 7-inch touch-screen. When a delivery is complete, the robot celebrates with a swivel dance and chirpy sounds.", "title": "The Next Time You Order Room Service, It May Come by Robot", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-08 00:00:00", "text": "Not that his neighborhood choice hasn\u2019t inspired a few eye-rolls. \u201cWhen I tell people I moved to Williamsburg, they say, \u2018Of course, you did,\u2019\u201d he said, adding that being somewhat off the beaten path had, at least, garnered a little more respect.\n\nMr. Lebon, who has traveled to New York City for work frequently over the past decade, had ruled out Manhattan as too manic for a couple with two young children (their son, Hugo, is 4, and their daughter, Indie, 2). And he liked the relative calm of the southern side of the Williamsburg waterfront.\n\nCalm, that is, if not exactly quiet.\n\nThey were among the first to move into their building, which is part of a site being developed by Two Trees (as well as the first building to open there). And now they are surrounded by construction. \u201cEvery day, they start with the jackhammers next door at 7 a.m. and they finish at 6 p.m.,\u201d Ms. Lebon said. \u201cBut we moved to New York to be amid the noise. We love that we get to see all the construction.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nDuring the summer, they were likewise charmed by the parties and pop-up events at the temporary park across the street, Mr. Lebon said: \u201cWe\u2019d open the window and listen to live music. Once there was a huge line around the block when we came home \u2014 Shake Shack was giving away burgers.\u201d\n\nOn a recent morning, arctic temperatures were keeping all but a few ardent cyclists off Kent Avenue, but the Lebons\u2019 apartment was bathed in warm sunlight. They had specifically sought a space with good natural light, but the view \u2014 their living room windows look directly out at the Williamsburg Bridge \u2014 was an unexpected bonus.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cEven when it\u2019s raining, it\u2019s still beautiful. You can watch the boats,\u201d said Ms. Lebon, whose mother, visiting from Australia and unaccustomed to having so many windows, kept pulling down the blinds. \u201cWe were like, \u2018Mom! We\u2019re paying for the view!\u2019\u201d\n\nThe apartment rents for $5,450 a month, though a month of free rent brought it down to just under $5,000. Still, that is quite a bit more than the $4,000 budget they had set. But as they plan to stay for only two years, they decided that splurging on a place they loved was worth it.\n\nNames: Vince and Kat Lebon Ages: 33 and 37Occupations: Mr. Lebon is a footwear designer and founder of the company Rollie Nation; he created its trademark Oxford for Ms. Lebon, who until recently was a flight attendant for Qantas. The couple has a retail store in Melbourne called Lost in Seasons, which Ms. Lebon manages. Rent: $5,450 a month, though a free month brought it down to just under $5,000 a month.Taking the ferry: The couple\u2019s 4-year-old son, Hugo, goes to school in Dumbo, Brooklyn, so Ms. Lebon catches the ferry four times a day (for pickup and drop-off) \u2013 \u201ca thing I would never do back in Melbourne; it\u2019s exciting.\u201d They are amazed by: The convenience of New York, specifically services like Instacart, Uber and Seamless. \u201cI can get my wine delivered in two hours,\u201d Mr. Lebon said. \u201cI\u2019ve downloaded more apps since I\u2019ve been here than in the last 10 years.\u201d Why they chose Brooklyn over Manhattan: \u201cThis feels much more at home,\u201d Mr. Lebon said. \u201cYou can get to the city, but also escape the city.\u201d Even so, his favorite neighborhood for walking is SoHo: \u201cI\u2019m a bit of a sneakerhead,\u201d he said. \u201cI like NikeLab, Kith and Acne. Also, the MoMA store. And I\u2019m a designer, so whatever I see and feel inspires me, which sounds like a clich\u00e9, but it\u2019s true.\u201d\n\n\u201cIt was really important that my wife and kids were happy, because I was asking them to move here for my work,\u201d said Mr. Lebon, who is introducing his footwear company, Rollie Nation, to the United States market and recently began online sales here. Several pop-up stores are also in the works. Ms. Lebon, who left her job as a flight attendant for Qantas shortly before they moved, manages the apparel store, Lost in Seasons, that the couple owns in Melbourne.\n\nWhile they are here, they are renting out their place in Australia, a renovated four-story warehouse of approximately 4,300 square feet. The move has shown them \u201cthat bigger isn\u2019t better,\u201d Ms. Lebon said. \u201cHere, we utilize every single room. And the kids are willing to sleep by themselves because they\u2019re in bunk beds.\u201d\n\nAs Mr. Lebon said, \u201cNow every purchase is really considered. We\u2019re living the minimalist life.\u201d\n\nHe added: \u201cThe house in Melbourne had a very different vibe, very Restoration Hardware. With a four-story house, you don\u2019t realize that it\u2019s getting cluttered until it\u2019s too late.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nAnother difference, they said, is the dress code in New York. In Melbourne, \u201cPeople judge everything: how you color your hair, what you wear to take your kids to kinder,\u201d Ms. Lebon said.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s even worse for a guy,\u201d Mr. Lebon said. \u201cIf I wear camo or Off-White sneakers, people would be like, \u2018What the hell is that?\u2019 Here people wear whatever they want. You can express yourself, and no one is judging you. I\u2019m a footwear designer and my wife runs a fashion retail store, so it\u2019s our life and our living.\u201d\n\nSuch openness, he has found, extends beyond fashion. \u201cYou don\u2019t feel like you\u2019re trying to do your own thing alone,\u201d he said. \u201cThere\u2019s a lot of collaboration and much more of a can-do atmosphere.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAs Ms. Lebon put it, \u201cYou feel like anything is possible.\u201d\n\nThey like New York so much, she said, that they are reconsidering their two-year plan: \u201cI think we\u2019re already looking at longer.\u201d", "title": "The Noisy Charms of New York", "authors": ["Kim Velsey"]} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "This article is part of the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive the newsletter each weekday.\n\nFirst, a few words on the State of the Union address.
