There will be a lot of meaningless commentary about President Trump\u2019s speech tonight. His critics will criticize him, his supporters will praise him and pundits will throw around the word \u201creset.\u201d\n\nYou can safely ignore most of it.\n\n\u201cState of the Union speeches have a celebrated history of not making much of an impact,\u201d HuffPost\u2019s Ariel Edwards-Levy wrote in 2016, when Barack Obama was president. The speeches are rarely memorable, and many of the people who watch are already supporters of the president, Edwards-Levy explained.\n\nThe most important part of the speech is the process of winnowing policy ideas that happens behind the scenes, before the speech. But Trump\u2019s erratic and uninformed approach to policy means that he may lack that benefit, Jonathan Bernstein argues in Bloomberg View.", "title": "Opinion | The Nunes Conspiracy", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-31 00:00:00", "text": "On Dec. 22, Gov. John Kasich of Ohio signed Senate Bill 164 banning doctors from performing abortions in cases in which a fetus is likely to have Down syndrome according to prenatal testing. Despite being staunchly pro-choice, I was primed to sympathize with the bill\u2019s supporters more than ever, given my personal circumstances.\n\nI\u2019d just moved to Ohio shortly after giving birth to my daughter in August. My husband and I are both (very differently) disabled: he, quadriplegic; me, neuroatypical (anxiety and obsessive compulsive disorders). Moreover, one of his close family members has Down syndrome. Rhetorical gestures toward \u201cprotecting\u201d the lives of disabled individuals constitute a familiar refrain in anti-abortion justifications for legislation like SB 164, with supporters claiming to combat the systemic devaluation of the lives of people with disabilities. But the reality of how this brand of legislation uses the idea of disability to gain political traction is much more complicated.\n\nThe business of birth itself is often structured around the specter of disability. My husband and I had just been made privy to this via my own pregnancy and birth experience. An early ultrasound revealed our daughter\u2019s possible congenital lung malformation; that, coupled with my own neuroatypicality, our family history of Down syndrome and my husband\u2019s spinal cord injury, made us an eyebrow-raising trio for every clinician we encountered over the course of my prenatal care.\n\nFor six months, I dutifully shuffled into Southern California business parks for twice-weekly ultrasounds, nonstress tests and countless appointments with specialists, growing ever more anxious at the looming prospect of we-didn\u2019t-know-what. Our daughter\u2019s potential lung problem fully resolved on its own in utero \u2014 she was born asymptomatic at birth and has been ever since \u2014 but I remained designated as \u201chigh-risk,\u201d the pregnancy now haunted by solemnity and fear.", "title": "Opinion | The Ohio Abortion Ban\u2019s Distortion of Disability Rights", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "As Turkey\u2019s political and economic situation deteriorates, the risk grows that further pressure will be counterproductive. Any sanctions with real bite would only increase the already serious possibility of a major economic crisis in Turkey. Rather than leave Turkey more dependent on Washington, such a crisis could well empower those in Ankara who already believe that Turkey has less to lose and more to gain by breaking with the West completely.\n\nGiven the grip on power that he now enjoys, Mr. Erdogan is unlikely to be voted out, regardless of how bad the economy gets. If he decides to cling to power at all costs, even his fall would be more likely to unleash violence than facilitate a smooth return to some form of democracy. In these circumstances, pushing the country toward the brink would do little to advance America\u2019s ideals or interests, much less those of the Turkish people.\n\nFor all of Mr. Erdogan\u2019s anger at America, he now stands to benefit from the very American cynicism he regularly denounces. However infuriating and dangerous American policy makers find him, they will ultimately find the alternative \u2014 chaos in Turkey \u2014 scarier. Having missed the opportunity to apply pressure earlier in Mr. Erdogan\u2019s tenure, when it might have been effective, Washington is likely to end up quietly hoping he maintains his hold over the country for the same reason it has supported many other authoritarian leaders: stability.\n\nWith this in mind, American policy should look toward helping Turkey emerge intact from an inevitable period of authoritarian rule as early as realistically possible. Congress should focus any future sanctions on concrete issues affecting bilateral relations, like the targeting of American government employees and citizens. American leaders should remain consistent in their public and private criticism of Mr. Erdogan\u2019s undemocratic behavior, rather than withholding or deploying it selectively as a diplomatic tool.\n\nFinally, it is important to prevent further escalation of Turkey\u2019s Kurdish conflict. The United States can use its military and diplomatic leverage in Syria to forestall both Turkish attacks on Kurdish forces there and renewed terrorist attacks by Kurdish groups in Turkey.\n\nBeyond this, though, Americans can do little but brace for what\u2019s next. Turkey\u2019s political turmoil, like its relationship with the United States, will almost certainly get worse before it gets better. In the end, the only interest Washington and Ankara share may be a desire to keep Turkey from becoming even less stable.", "title": "Opinion | The Only Thing Turkey and the U.S. Can Agree On", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "But within these conventions, Coetzee is as perspicacious and erudite a guide as one could hope for. His biographical sketches of the life and times of the authors he addresses are excellent, concretely informative while also marbled with interesting tidbits. (Robert Walser, I learned, developed \u201cpsychosomatic cramps\u201d in his right hand that he attributed to an unconscious enmity for the pen, leading him to adopt an alternative form of script he called his \u201cpencil system.\u201d) But the meat of Coetzee\u2019s overviews can be found in other good introductions by other critics. What can\u2019t be found anywhere else, where Coetzee is unparalleled, is his ability to capture the psychology of individual characters, to lay bare the inner working of their minds, and in so doing bring to light the source of their enduring interest to readers.\n\nPhoto\n\nOf Defoe\u2019s heroine Roxana, for example, Coetzee writes: \u201cRoxana does not pretend that the virtue whose loss she intermittently laments is something she deeply and sincerely believes in. On the contrary, she is happy to remain in a divided, ambivalent state in which she wants to resist seduction but equally wants her resistance to be swept away. She is well aware of this division or ambivalence within herself. \u2026 Implicitly she recognizes that she finds being seduced more interesting (more engaging, more thrilling, more erotic, more seductive in prospect) than giving herself in a direct, unambiguous way; that the prelude to the sexual act can be more desirable, more erotically fulfilling, than the act itself. Seduction, the thought of seduction, the approach of seduction, the imagined experience of seduction, turns out to be profoundly seductive, even irresistible.\u201d\n\nIf one is to appreciate Coetzee\u2019s essays, one must recognize how precisely, with what concentration, he lays bare a terrifically complex psychology, giving readers a handhold on which to build even more complex readings of their own. (Readings that would likely, in today\u2019s atmosphere, quickly point out that \u201cirresistible\u201d seduction isn\u2019t the fruit of effective persuasion but rape, a fact Coetzee draws attention to elsewhere in the chapter.) One must also admire the subtle brilliance of Coetzee\u2019s sentences, as in the last line of the passage quoted above, in which seduction is discussed in a manner that itself impersonates seduction, with the repetition of phrases (the thought of seduction, the approach of seduction and so on) heightening the thrill for the reader until the sentence succumbs to the seduction it has performed by landing upon \u201ceven irresistible.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cLate Essays\u201d is filled with many moments of such perfect insight, moments when the reader is left enthralled by Coetzee\u2019s powers of perception. Another example is this gem, on the Polish poet Zbigniew Herbert: \u201cWhat is wrong with systems, to Herbert, is that they are systems. What is wrong with laws is that they are laws. Beware of angels and other executives of perfection.\u201d\n\nAt certain points, \u201cLate Essays\u201d can suddenly become \u201cLast Essays.\u201d At this stage of Coetzee\u2019s career, one might of course expect reflections on matters of mortality and finality, or at least an interest in the late style of literary giants. But Coetzee doesn\u2019t dwell on such issues any more than a younger writer would. In one instance, however, he lets slip his admiration for a particular scene at the end of Philip Roth\u2019s \u201cEveryman,\u201d where the protagonist observes at his work, and then converses with, the aging gravedigger who dug his parents\u2019 graves and who will perform the same service for the protagonist when the time comes. After the gravedigger has carefully described the process by which a grave comes to be dug, Roth\u2019s unnamed Everyman says, \u201cI want to thank you. \u2026 You couldn\u2019t have made things more concrete. It\u2019s a good education for an older person.\u201d\n\nIn these essays, Coetzee is doing for the writers who came before him what I imagine he hopes will be done for him by the writers who will follow. He is gravedigging, with probity, with the greatest reverence for the craft they share, and in this way is saying thank you in the only way one writer can really say it to another, which is by writing about them well.", "title": "The Outlaw Novelist as Literary Critic", "authors": ["Benjamin Ogden", "J.M. Coetzee"]} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "Other changes include the increasing presence of outsider artists in galleries where you\u2019d least expect them. David Lewis, who oversees a large, pristine and hip gallery on the Lower East Side, is working with the Souls Grown Deep Foundation on a show of the work of Thornton Dial, a towering figure among outsiders of the South, known for his startlingly rough-hewed paintings whose surfaces can include basically anything: rugs, tree branches and wire. On Jan. 25 Mr. Lewis\u2019s gallery will inaugurate its representation of the artist with a show intriguingly titled \u201cMr. Dial\u2019s America.\u201d Until Sunday, there\u2019s a big Dial front and center at the fair: \u201cA Bird Will Always Try to Fly\u201d (1991), an avian creature with the markings of a tiger pursued by two figures, at Fred Giampietro.\n\nTwo major museum exhibitions signal greater inclusion in the art historical scheme. On Jan. 28, the National Gallery of Art in Washington will unveil \u201cOutliers and American Vanguard Art,\u201d an exhibition of some 300 works by about 90 artists trained and self-taught. It will examine how attention to folk and outsider art \u2014 from artists, collectors and museums \u2014 has ebbed and flowed through the 20th century. And in May the Metropolitan Museum of Art, which has a large collection of mostly 19th-century American folk art will take the plunge with a show centering on the 57 works by black Southern outsiders \u2014 including Dial \u2014 it recently received from the Souls Grown Deep Foundation. It\u2019s inspiring title: \u201cHistory Refused to Die.\u201d That refusal rings loud and clear in this year\u2019s Outsider Art Fair. Some of the supporting evidence:", "title": "The Outsider Fair Once More Confirms That Art Is Everywhere", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-16 00:00:00", "text": "But the risk is not evenly shared: Poor and minority populations are more often exposed. The rate among African Americans was almost 7 percent, according to the C.D.C. Among people living below the poverty line, the infection rate was 10 percent.\n\nThe odds of a positive test rise with age, but it\u2019s unknown whether this reflects recent infections or simply an accumulation of antibodies from past encounters.\n\nDr. Peter Hotez, dean of the National School of Tropical Medicine at Baylor College of Medicine in Houston, calls Toxocara both one of the most common parasites in the country and arguably the most neglected.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cWe know in some cases it is linked to lower intelligence and epilepsy,\u201d he said. \u201cSo if you were to look at disadvantaged kids living in poverty who are also doing lower on tests of school performance, what percentage of that can be attributed to this worm?\u201d\n\nWhile much is still unknown, \u201cthere\u2019s enough here to warrant doing a major study on a large number of children.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAt the moment, research into Toxocara among Americans is so lacking that the National Institutes of Health funding website lists no grants to study it. Even many of the most basic questions are unanswered, including how often ingested eggs progress to full-blown infection.\n\nAmong the country\u2019s overlooked parasitic infections, \u201cToxocara is probably the one that affects the broadest range of people,\u201d said Sue Montgomery, lead of the epidemiology team at the parasitic diseases branch of the C.D.C. \u201cDogs and cats are everywhere. Many of them may carry the parasites.\u201d\n\nStudies indicate that owned pets who receive regular veterinary care rarely carry Toxocara. Poorer neighborhoods bear a disproportionate share of strays. In one survey, 8,700 unowned dogs were said to be roaming parts of Dallas.\n\nA survey of New York City playgrounds, presented at a medical conference last year, sampled 21 parks across the city. Toxocara eggs were found in nine parks. Three quarters of samples taken in the Bronx contained eggs in the larval stage, which are more infectious. No parks in Manhattan had eggs with larvae.\n\n(The researchers declined to name the parks, saying the data were preliminary.)\n\nIn some cases, larvae from Toxocara enter the eyes and cause blindness. They can also infect the liver and lungs, leading to a potentially damaging inflammatory reaction.\n\nUsually, however, signs of infection are more subtle: a slight fever, fatigue, abdominal pain and cough \u2014 symptoms that describe any number of illnesses. Few pediatricians think to test for Toxocara.\n\nPhoto\n\nUntreated, the infection may clear on its own after months or even years, \u201cbut we don\u2019t know for sure,\u201d Dr. Hotez said.\n\nA C.D.C. survey published in October found that 85 percent of pediatricians admitted to only passing familiarity with the infection, called toxocariasis; given a description of symptoms, slightly less than half of the doctors correctly diagnosed it.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhen infection is recognized, it can be treated with the anti-parasitic drug albendazole, Dr. Hotez said.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cNobody is dying here,\u201d he said, \u201cbut it is potentially causing developmental delays that are affecting quality of life, and the economic impact is far greater. It could trap children in poverty.\u201d\n\nIn 2014, he published his only contribution to a mental health journal, in JAMA Psychiatry, arguing that parasitic infections such as toxocariasis \u201clikely account for a substantial yet hidden burden of mental illness in the United States.\u201d\n\nTo what extent, no one can say. The scientific literature contains only scattered reports of Toxocara worms discovered in the central nervous system.\n\n\u201cWe know that larvae go to the brain in humans,\u201d said Celia Holland, a parasitology professor at Trinity College Dublin in Ireland. But beyond that fact, she says, \u201cwe know very little.\u201d\n\nDr. Holland has conducted experiments finding that mice with Toxocara larvae in the brain showed reduced learning ability and less inclination to explore.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe greater the degree of infection, the greater the impairment. In prolonged research on mice with extreme infections, \u201cwe had to terminate the experiments for ethical reasons because their locomotion started to be affected,\u201d she said.\n\nOne of the few studies to examine whether cognitive achievement correlated with Toxocara infection in people was published in the International Journal for Parasitology by two researchers at SUNY Downstate Medical Center in Brooklyn.\n\nUsing a cross-section of national data, they found that the mean test scores were lower among children who tested positive for exposure to Toxocara, even after accounting for other known influences such as household income and lead levels in blood. Another study by researchers at Brigham Young University, published in 2015, found a similar association in adults.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIn an economy where expertise and performance is increasingly valued, increasingly measured and increasingly plays a role in the work force, this could have broad implications,\u201d said Lance Erickson, a sociology professor at Brigham Young University and one of the report\u2019s authors.\n\nNonetheless, the impairment does not appear to be severe, which is likely why Toxocara receives little notice. \u201cWhat we don\u2019t see is easy to ignore,\u201d Dr. Erickson said. \u201cThere isn\u2019t a story to wrap around it to make it emotionally salient for people. That\u2019s what tends to get political attention and financial attention.\u201d\n\nDr. Hotez is more blunt: \u201cIf this were a disease of wealthy kids in Brookline, Mass., and Bethesda, Md., and Westchester, N.Y., we\u2019d be all over it.\u201d\n\nAfter unsuccessful attempts to obtain government grants to research Toxocara, Dr. Hotez approached Congress, meeting in December 2016 with Sen. Cory Booker, Democrat of New Jersey. According to a spokesman, Mr. Booker plans to introduce legislation to further examine the impact of overlooked infections in the United States, Toxocara among them.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s hard for people to accept that it could be having the effect that it is,\u201d said Dr. Holland, of Trinity College. \u201cWe don\u2019t really know its impact, which is frustrating. These are larvae burrowing through the brain. It\u2019s not something that any mother or father of a child would welcome.\u201d", "title": "The Parasite on the Playground", "authors": ["Laura Beil"]} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "For each lucky birder who saw the Cedar Beach corn crake, there are thousands of others who wish they had, myself included. Each of us has nurtured our own private dreams of someday encountering it. As a Connecticut birder, Paul Desjardins, put it, \u201cIt only took me 58 years to see this bird.\u201d\n\nWhere do birding dreams come from? Mostly, they come from books. Next to high-quality optics, the most important resources for a birder are books. Behind every birder is a library \u2014 a privately curated collection of dozens \u2014 even hundreds \u2014 of volumes, including field guides, bird-finding guides and specialized monographs on specific groups like warblers, sparrows or gulls. And, just as seed catalogs induce a gardener\u2019s visions of glorious future harvests, there are bird books whose goal is simply to inspire dreams about birds, the love of birds and plans for future birding trips.\n\nSimon Barnes\u2019s \u201cThe Meaning of Birds\u201d is a book of essays that explore the biology of birds and our abiding fascination with them. Barnes is the former chief sportswriter for The Times of London, and the author of more than a dozen books on sports, horses and horse racing, cricket and bird-watching.\n\nPhoto\n\nLoosely organized as a series of conceptual chapters, the book is passionate, inviting, even lyrical. In the opening passage, Barnes shows us that the angels carved into the ceiling of an ancient church in East Anglia fly on the wings of marsh harriers \u2014 the same charismatic raptor we can observe in American wetlands today. He compares the effortless buoyant flight of the harriers to the graceful presence of the angels, and brings us closer to the bird-loving artisans who carved them long ago. Having never imagined angel wings as coming in any variety other than generic swan white, I was grateful to Barnes for opening my eyes to the ornithological inspiration for angels.\n\nBarnes\u2019s book is like a lively, meandering pub conversation with a birdy companion \u2014 chatty, but often choppy and a little repetitive. Few topics are sustained for more than a page or two, and we never wade into the depths.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBarnes can also be a bit sloppy with biological details. For example, there is no evidence that the tubes in an albatross beak function like pitot tubes to measure their air speed; rather, these nasal channels are for the outflow from their salt glands and allow them to survive in a high-sodium, oceanic environment. Before one conjecture, Barnes suggests that the reader may \u201cmiss this bit if you have taste for scientific rigor.\u201d Although I felt that way at times about the whole book, Barnes provides a companionable view of why we love birds, their lives and futures.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nBernd Brunner\u2019s \u201cBirdmania\u201d is a cultural history of the varieties of human ornithological obsession. Much like Barnes\u2019s book, \u201cBirdmania\u201d is also a series of choppy vignettes organized into topical chapters. However, Brunner focuses more on the mania than the birds.\n\nTo Brunner, birdmaniacs are mostly an odd, selfish and even cruel bunch. The English bird illustrator and publisher John Gould is described as an \u201cunscrupulous profiteer.\u201d The travelogues of Hugo Weigold, a pioneer bird bander in the early 20th century, are described as \u201cfull of cold-blooded arrogance.\u201d The pioneering American bird-watcher Phoebe Snetsinger, who traveled the world to observe 8,674 bird species before being killed in a traffic accident during a birding trip in Madagascar, is presented as an example of \u201cwealthy people who cut themselves off almost completely from their partners, children and other family obligations \u2026just to add one entry or another to a fervently kept list of bird sightings.\u201d\n\nTo make sure his pessimistic message is right up front, a third of Brunner\u2019s 19 chapters focus on famous liars in ornithology. We meet the French ornithologist Fran\u00e7ois Levaillant, who cribbed some illustrations for his \u201cNatural History of the Birds of Africa (1805-08)\u201d from other sources, and incompetently (or deviously?) included numerous species not found on the continent. We are also introduced to the 20th-century aristocratic British ornithologist, spy and sociopath Richard Meinertzhagen, who switched tags among bird specimens to support his hypotheses and who might have shot his first wife to hide the deception before running off with his children\u2019s nanny.\n\nBrunner has a special gripe against the scientific collectors of birds. Yet he never acknowledges, or perhaps comprehends, the vital contributions that museum collections make to our understanding of the biology of birds.\n\nOf course, birdmaniacs are people, too, with human foibles and faults. But Brunner makes little attempt to understand the cultural or intellectual contexts in which these historical birdmaniacs lived and loved birds. Even if some of his harsh judgments are accurate, \u201cBirdmania\u201d does not portray birdmania as very attractive. Perhaps the censorious tone is exaggerated by the translation from the German original, but I was left wondering whether Brunner actually likes birds, bird people, or even people in general.\n\nNoah Strycker\u2019s \u201cBirding Without Borders\u201d is a firsthand account of a serious case of birdmania. In 2015, at age 28, Strycker set out to see as many bird species as he could in a single calendar year. This feat of extreme birding is called a Big Year, and it can be pursued on the local, state, continental or global scale. Strycker\u2019s goal was to be the first person to see more than half the world\u2019s roughly 10,100 species of birds in one year. Starting in Antarctica on Jan. 1, Strycker took 112 plane flights and traveled through 41 countries on all continents to observe 6,042 species of birds, smashing the previous record of 4,341.\n\nThe birding travelogue genre was invented in 1955 by Roger Tory Peterson and James Fisher with the publication of \u201cWild America,\u201d a sort of ornithological \u201cOn the Road\u201d about their year bird-watching across North America. \u201cBirding Without Borders\u201d is an updated, global birding travelogue for the modern age. Strycker is a digital native, and his is a decidedly digitally enabled Big Year. Strycker used the internet to find local birders to guide him in every country he visited. Throughout the year, he tallied his observations on eBird, an electronic bird-sighting database, and posted daily descriptions of his adventures on a blog maintained by the Audubon Society. When Strycker finds himself on Christmas night in Western Australia just 30 birds shy of 6,000, he uses eBird to calculate which country he should visit last to maximize his remaining week. (The answer? Northern India!)\n\n\u201cBirding Without Borders\u201d is lighthearted and filled with stories of exotic birds, risky adventures and colorful birding companions. You don\u2019t get deep insights into why Strycker did this, but you get the sense that he would be fun to bird with. I would have liked deeper discussion about how to plan the best Big Year route. Of course, I would love to have heard Strycker\u2019s stories about what it was like to see specific birds that I have dreamed of, like the white-necked rockfowl in Ghana, and the sapayoa in Panama. To really appreciate Strycker\u2019s book, readers must have moved beyond merely enjoying local birds to dream about the dizzying diversity of the birds of the world, and have imagined how rewarding it may be to see them all. It\u2019s a beautiful dream.", "title": "The Passion and Peril of Birding", "authors": ["Richard O. Prum"]} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "Butter tarts have long been beloved in their native Canada. But our recent article on the sugary treat drew hundreds of comments, many from readers who had never heard of it and some from those who had never known its name.\n\n\u201cI can\u2019t believe I\u2019m finally reading the recipe solution to a baking mystery that\u2019s followed me all my life,\u201d said Nancy Berman of Wyncote, Pa. \u201cMy first babysitter, Mrs. Hughes, used to make these and bring them over nights when my parents would go out and she would mind me. I adored these tarts.\u201d\n\nWe asked readers for family butter-tart recipes and variations, and dozens poured in from both sides of the border.\n\n\u201cFinally, a treasured old recipe from my grandmother has its story,\u201d said DMS in San Diego. \u201cShe was an Irish immigrant who came over on a coffin ship \u2014 eventually sneaked into the U.S. from Canada. The only thing I have of hers is her recipe for \u2018butter tarts,\u2019 written in pencil on parchment paper blotchy with what I assume is melted butter. No measurements, just \u2018butter, egg, brown sugar, currants.\u2019 Like her, it is simplicity and heavenly.\u201d", "title": "The Passions of the Butter Tart", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-27 00:00:00", "text": "That may not seem like much money, but it\u2019s more than three times the additional Medicaid funding, both state and federal, provided to more than 4,100 nursing home residents this year. Scarce resources for that care, and other programs, will inevitably be robbed if federal inaction persists.\n\nBRENDAN W. WILLIAMS\n\nPEMBROKE, N.H.\n\nThe writer is president and chief executive of the New Hampshire Health Care Association.\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nMy son was addicted off and on for many years. He was in detox and rehab more than a dozen times and always relapsed. When he died two months ago, he had four drugs in his system, and we assumed that was the cause of death. The medical examiner ordered an autopsy and discovered that he had died from sepsis caused by a ruptured bowel.\n\nThe years of abusing drugs in combination had ravaged his body, not just his liver and kidneys but also his entire G.I. tract. I am sharing his story to alert others so as to spur them to accept treatment and avoid the tragic end our son suffered. Even if he had gained sobriety, it was too late for him; the damage had been done.\n\nWe are gratified to know that Patrick Griffin is in recovery, and we wish him and his family all the best.", "title": "Opinion | The Path Out of Opioid Addiction", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-20 00:00:00", "text": "James Goodale: My name is James Goodale. I first came in contact with the Pentagon Papers when I was at this fancy black-tie dinner in Washington, D.C., male only by the way, and [NYT Washington bureau chief] Max Frankel whispered into my ear, \u201cHave you heard, we\u2019ve got classified documents?\u201d That was it. One sentence. But those documents turned into the Pentagon Papers.\n\nDunlap: \u201cThe importance of the classified documents is critical to this discussion because what The Times had in its possession were 7,000 pages of documents that were a top-secret, classified history of American involvement in Vietnam, in Indochina, going back to the Truman administration, every page of which had been stamped \u201ctop secret,\u201d \u201csensitive,\u201d \u201cclassified.\u201d\n\nPart of the mission of The Times was to present the history of the Vietnam War as it had been recorded under the orders of then-Secretary of Defense Robert McNamara who wanted to find out, how did we get into this mess?\n\nThe people who compiled the report had access to all kinds of cables, memos and notes, which betrayed \u2014 when you read them closely \u2014 that one administration after the next had engaged in exactly the kind of double-dealing that critics of the war had always maintained was going on. But here was the Pentagon saying it, in its own voice.\n\nBecause of that, it was critical, as far as The Times saw it, to reproduce the documents themselves. Not simply interpret them or rely on them for narrative articles, but to actually expose the public to the words of the decision makers. And that meant that we were trading in classified information on a scale that perhaps had never been undertaken before.\n\nWhat kind of pause did that give any of you as you worked with this material?\n\nAmster: Well, I was among the first people to join the team and I knew nothing about it. It was very early on.\n\nWhen I was taken to the Hilton Hotel where the team was working on the papers \u2014 not in the headquarters of The Times but in the hotel \u2014 I was told that we had these papers and it was of course against the law to have these papers and it could even be treasonous to have these papers, and if I did not want to work on them, I was free not to work on them.", "title": "The Pentagon Papers Team Tells How The Times Defied Censorship", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "I started thinking about this over three decades ago, when I was working among civilian nuclear strategists, war planners, weapons scientists and arms controllers. What struck me was how removed they were from the human realities behind the weapons they discussed. This distancing occurred in part through a professional discourse characterized by stunningly abstract and euphemistic language \u2014 and in part through a set of lively sexual metaphors.\n\nThe human bodies evoked were not those of the victims; instead, there were conversations about vertical erector launchers, thrust-to-weight ratios, soft lay downs, deep penetration and the comparative advantages of protracted versus spasm attacks \u2014 or what one military adviser to the National Security Council called \u201creleasing 70 to 80 percent of our megatonnage in one orgasmic whump.\u201d\n\nBut it quickly became clear that the role of gender in national security discourse went deeper than not-so-subtle metaphors. Even more disturbing was how it shaped what could be said, or even thought, within the confines of these male-dominated spaces. \u201cWhat are you, some kind of wimp?\u201d was an insult readily lobbed at anyone who urged restraint in responding to a provocation or attack. Discussion of whether political leaders \u201chad the stones for war\u201d suggested that the desire to solve a conflict through nonmilitary measures would mean you were less than fully manly. During the Cuban missile crisis, when Assistant Secretary of Defense Paul Nitze disparaged some of President John F. Kennedy\u2019s more cautious decisions by calling him a \u201cpantywaist,\u201d he made it clear that anyone who let himself be governed by fear of setting off a nuclear war was a sissy.\n\nOvert impugning of masculinity is still only the most surface level at which ideas about gender play out in strategic thinking. They work in deeper, more subtle ways too. The culturally pervasive associations of masculinity with dispassion, distance, abstraction, toughness and risk-taking, and of femininity with emotion, empathy, bodily vulnerability, fear and caution, are embedded within the professional discourse.\n\nAnd there they function to make some kinds of ideas seem self-evidently \u201crealist,\u201d hard-nosed and rational, and others patently inadmissible, self-evidently inappropriate. (One white male physicist told me that he and colleagues were once modeling a limited nuclear attack when he suddenly voiced dismay that they were talking so casually about \u201conly 30 million\u201d immediate deaths. \u201cIt was awful \u2014 I felt like a woman,\u201d he said.)", "title": "Opinion | The Perils of Mixing Masculinity and Missiles", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-03 00:00:00", "text": "He graduated with top marks from the conservatory in 2009, and by 2012 had signed with Sony; his first recording, of late Beethoven sonatas, won wide acclaim. The Guardian praised his poise, maturity and purity of tone in its review, proclaiming him \u201cthe real deal, and definitely a pianist to watch.\u201d Noting the audacity of starting a recording career with late Beethoven, usually the province of masters, Gramophone declared it \u201cneither reckless nor arrogant, but a debut of true significance.\u201d\n\nAlong the way he was aided by moments of serendipity: In 2014 he served as a concert stand-in for two more established pianists, H\u00e9l\u00e8ne Grimaud and Maurizio Pollini. Mr. Levit said that while he has always been serious about his playing, it was only in the last few years that he had found \u201ca certain kind of inner freedom\u201d as a musician.\n\nAt the same time, his politics \u2014 shaped in part by the experience of being a Jewish immigrant in a Germany with a newly ascendant right flank \u2014 were beginning to evolve. The euro crisis, Occupy Wall Street and the international conflict over migration all played a role.\n\n\u201cThe refugee crisis,\u201d he said, \u201cwas a point of no return for me.\u201d\n\nWhen Mr. Levit gave his North American debut recital at the Park Avenue Armory in 2014, Alex Poots, who was then its artistic director, was taken by his musicianship and thoughtfulness. He came up with the idea of pairing him with Ms. Abramovic \u2014 but first he had to get them together to see if they had chemistry.\n\nThey all went out to the Chiltern Firehouse, a chic London hotel, where the deal was sealed at a noisy, crowded bar after midnight, when Ms. Abramovic turned to Mr. Levit and asked him to play something on the piano.\n\n\u201cI said, \u2018Marina, I can\u2019t play the piano here, everyone\u2019s dancing,\u2019\u201d Mr. Levit recalled. But the owner silenced the D.J., and Mr. Levit played the final movement of Beethoven\u2019s \u201cHammerklavier\u201d Sonata.", "title": "The Pianist of the Resistance Captures a Surprise Award", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-17 00:00:00", "text": "Ask people why they chose a parrot as a pet and they\u2019ll usually say they wanted a companion of exotic beauty, gaiety and intellect.\n\nBut parrots can also be noisy, needy, destructive and temperamental.\n\n\u201cFor some reason, I thought a bird was going to be simple,\u201d said Marty Sokoloff, who owns two parrots, an eclectus and a cockatoo, with his wife, Suzie Marchlen. \u201cBoy, was I mistaken.\u201d\n\nMany people interested in parrots don\u2019t realize \u2014 until it\u2019s too late and they\u2019ve become owners \u2014 that the birds cry for attention and throw tantrums like a toddler. Not to mention, they can live upward of 50 years.\n\nBut people continue to want them as pets. In 2011, Best Friends Animal Society, an animal rescue organization, estimated that the number of owned parrots in the United States had jumped from 11.6 million in 1990 to 60 million in 2010, and could increase to as many as 100 million by 2020.", "title": "The Pied Piper of Parrots", "authors": ["Britta Lokting", "Pet City"]} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "Observe the elder Mr. Farago for a while and you\u2019ll see him stocking the five-seat snack bar, then spraying deodorizer in the shoes, then ringing up a customer, then wiping down the scoring tables and laying out fresh scoring sheets, then scooting to the back to check on the pinsetter machines.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m a worker, I\u2019m a mechanic, I\u2019m the janitor, I\u2019m the electrician, I maintain the A.C., the heating,\u201d said Mr. Farago, who on a recent weekday was also a babysitter, dashing frequently into his back office to check on his granddaughter.\n\nThe lanes serve a working-class clientele that Mr. Farago knows by first name. Some years back, a local couple, both postal workers, held their wedding here.\n\nAfter the ceremony \u2014 \u201cOn lanes six and seven,\u201d Mr. Farago recalled \u2014 the couple changed into their bowling league uniforms and spent their reception bowling.\n\nBowlers who have scored a perfect 300 have their names immortalized on a banner \u2014 The Kid, Roach, Benny \u2014 and get a Van Nest jacket courtesy of Mr. Farago.\n\nThe prices are far less than at Manhattan lanes \u2014 $25 an hour and no charge for bowling shoes. Budweiser bottles are $3.50. Of course, the place is cash only.\n\nPhoto\n\nPhoto\n\nPhoto\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Farago said he grew up four blocks away from the lanes and began working here in his teens in 1964 as a pin chaser, \u201cdoing the same thing I\u2019m doing now.\u201d He bought into the business in 1979 and still lives nearby.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHe was once an estimable bowler, he said, but was so incessantly interrupted by the unending tasks around the lanes that he quit one day in 1972 and has not bowled a frame since.\n\nUp to three times a day, he lovingly oils Van Nest\u2019s wood lanes, a rarity now since most alleys have synthetic floors.\n\n\u201cOther lanes are like this Formica,\u201d he said smacking the snack bar counter. \u201cWith wood, you get more friction, so the ball breaks sooner. Visiting bowlers are not used to it because they don\u2019t see it anywhere else.\u201d\n\nThis creates a home court advantage for bowling clubs that call Van Nest home. Joe Perez, 53, a regular whose Team Apocalypse bowls out of Van Nest, walked in and showed off new team T-shirts bearing the slogan, \u201cYou got to be good to bowl on wood.\u201d\n\nThe subtle imperfections pounded into the wooden lanes over the years \u201cmake it hard for visiting teams to beat us here,\u201d he said.\n\nMr. Farago, who is married with three grown children, said he attended Cardinal Spellman High School in the Bronx. Stints at City College and at Con Edison were short-lived, he said, because the Van Nest Lanes needed him.", "title": "The Pin Chaser in Charge", "authors": ["Corey Kilgannon", "Character Study"]} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week\u2019s most notable new songs and videos \u2014 and anything else that strikes them as intriguing. This week Yeah Yeah Yeahs\u2019 Karen O releases a solo song, the first new Lil Peep song since the rapper\u2019s death arrives and Hayley Kiyoko puts a twist on the jealousy song.\n\nJust want the music?
