In hearing these individual tales, we\u2019re not only learning about individual trespasses but for the first time getting a view of the matrix in which we\u2019ve all been living: We see that the men who have had the power to abuse women\u2019s bodies and psyches throughout their careers are in many cases also the ones in charge of our political and cultural stories.\n\nAnd in \u201cThe #MeToo Moment: What\u2019s Next?\u201d Jessica Bennett writes for The Times:\n\nI hope we talk about culture as much as we talk about individuals, and recognize that while the Weinsteins of the world are extreme, the messages we learn about sex, and power, and courtship, and consent, are deeply ingrained and start young \u2014 and will take far more than a workplace sexual harassment training to unlearn.\n\nIn this section, students explore how the pervasiveness of sexual harassment affects all of us on personal, professional and societal levels. They also begin to address some of the many questions the #MeToo conversation has sparked on the nature of sexual misconduct: Why does it happen? Why has it persisted? Why do victims often not speak up against their abusers? Is it about sex, power, both or something else?\n\nJigsaw\n\nPhoto\n\nAssign, or allow students to choose, one of the following articles to read in small \u201cexpert\u201d groups for a jigsaw activity.\n\nRemind them that each of these articles provides just one opinion, with which they may agree or disagree. You might provide them with some guiding questions and ask them to annotate as they read:\n\n\u2022 What is the author\u2019s overall argument about the root causes of sexual harassment?\n\n\u2022 What points resonate with you? Which challenge your beliefs? Why?\n\n\u2022 What evidence does the author provide to support his or her argument? Is it credible and substantial?\n\n\u201cHow Wall Street Bro Talk Keeps Women Down\u201d critiques men\u2019s participation in the objectification of women:\n\nFor my entire life, I\u2019ve heard men talk about women. On baseball fields, in wrestling locker rooms, at frat parties and in private conversations, I\u2019ve listened to men dissect women into body parts. When I was younger, I did it, too. Casually objectifying women \u2014 speaking in an unguarded way, using language we never would in mixed company \u2014 brought us together.\n\n\u201cSexual Harassment: It\u2019s About Power, Not Lust\u201d was written in 1991, but its premise remains relevant:\n\nOne of a flood of tales that have surfaced in the wake of Anita F. Hill\u2019s accusations of sexual harassment in hearings on Clarence Thomas\u2019s Supreme Court nomination, the story underscores a picture that is emerging from extensive research on such harassment: it has less to do with sex than with power. It is a way to keep women in their place; through harassment men devalue a woman\u2019s role in the work place by calling attention to her sexuality.\n\n\u201cThe Unexamined Brutality of the Male Libido\u201d offers a contentious counterpoint to that power argument:\n\nMen arrive at this moment of reckoning woefully unprepared. Most are shocked by the reality of women\u2019s lived experience. Almost all are uninterested or unwilling to grapple with the problem at the heart of all this: the often ugly and dangerous nature of the male libido.\n\n\u201cWhen Saying \u2018Yes\u2019 Is Easier Than Saying \u2018No\u2019\u201d examines the tricky subject of consent in intimate relationships:\n\nSometimes \u201cyes\u201d means \u201cno,\u201d simply because it is easier to go through with it than explain our way out of the situation. Sometimes \u201cno\u201d means \u201cyes,\u201d because you actually do want to do it, but you know you\u2019re not supposed to lest you be labeled a slut. And if you\u2019re a man, that \u201cno\u201d often means \u201cjust try harder\u201d \u2014 because, you know, persuasion is part of the game.\n\n\u201cShe Didn\u2019t Fight Back: 5 (Misguided) Reasons People Doubt Sexual Assault Survivors\u201d challenges myths about sexual assault:\n\nThere are all sorts of reasons women who report sexual misconduct, from unwanted advances by their bosses to groping or forced sex acts, are not believed, and with a steady drumbeat of new reports making headlines, the country is hearing a lot of them.\n\n\u201cMen and Women Say They\u2019re More Different Than Similar\u201d explores the traditional notions of gender that underlie a culture of sexual harassment:\n\nMen are tough; women are in touch with their feelings. Men are providers; women are nurturers. Men should punch back when provoked; women should be physically attractive. These stereotypical beliefs about gender differences remain strong, found a new survey from the Pew Research Center on Tuesday.\n\nThen, create \u201cteaching\u201d groups with one or two students from each \u201cexpert\u201d group. Allow each student to present his or her article and ask the other students to take notes on the different perspectives in a graphic organizer such as this one.\n\nClass Discussion\n\nAfter all students have presented their points, invite them to discuss in their small groups or as a whole class the factors that contribute to a culture of sexual harassment. Encourage them to respectfully agree or disagree by citing evidence from the articles or their own experiences. Some conversation starters might include:\n\n\u2022 Why does sexual harassment happen?\n\n\u2022 If this has been happening all along, why are we just hearing about it now?\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 Why is the problem of sexual misconduct so widespread?\n\n\u2022 What is the role of gender in sexual harassment?\n\n\u2022 What can we do as a society? What can we do as individuals?\n\n\u2022 Based on your reading, do you think discussing and learning about sexual harassment is important? Why or why not?\n\nTwo Ways to Close This Section of the Unit: A Barometer Activity or a Gallery Walk\n\nBarometer\n\n\n\nIn a barometer activity, students listen to a statement and then stand up and move to a point between \u201cStrongly Agree\u201d and \u201cStrongly Disagree\u201d that reflects their opinion. Begin by stating the prompt, then allow students to find their place on the continuum. After all students have moved, ask a few to explain why they chose that position. If they feel so moved by the discussion, let them change their place on the barometer and explain why they did so. You may also want students to prepare their answers in writing before engaging in the discussion.\n\nSome possible prompts include:\n\n\u2022 Stereotypes about men and women are harmful.\n\n\u2022 It\u2019s hard to tell the difference between sexual harassment and flirting.\n\n\u2022 Sexual harassment is natural.\n\n\u2022 If we wanted to end sexual harassment, it would be easy to do.\n\n\u2022 Sexual harassment is mostly a women\u2019s issue.\n\n\u2022 Sexual harassment is a problem at our school.\n\nGallery Walk\n\nOr, invite students to share the implications of what they learned with the rest of the class in a gallery walk. On a piece of poster paper, have each student create a \u201cone-pager\u201d about the article they read. In this format, students create a visual of some kind that captures a key aspect of the article, literally or symbolically, but they also include a quotation from the article that seems important, and pose a question for the journalist or for someone mentioned in the article. Here is an activity sheet that can guide them.\n\nAfter students have completed their work, post it on the walls or leave it at individual desks and invite the class to move around silently and respond to what they see on sticky notes with questions, comments or connections.\n\nFinally, as a class, discuss the larger patterns among the different articles. How does sexual harassment affect individuals? How does it affect society? What might our world look like without it?\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n__________\n\nHas #MeToo Gone Too Far? Debate the Issue\n\nPhoto\n\nThe #MeToo movement has tried to hold sexual abusers accountable for their actions in the workplace and in broader society. As with any movement toward widespread social change, though, a backlash has been brewing, with some saying the movement has gone too far.\n\n\n\nIn \u201cPublicly, We Say #MeToo. Privately, We Have Misgivings.,\u201d Daphne Merkin writes:\n\nFor many weeks now, the conversation that has been going on in private about this reckoning is radically different from the public one. This is not a good sign, suggesting the sort of social intimidation that is the underside of a culture of political correctness, such as we are increasingly living in. The women I know \u2014 of all ages \u2014 have responded by and large with a mixture of slightly horrified excitement (bordering on titillation) as to who will be the next man accused and overt disbelief. Publicly, they say the right things, expressing approval and joining in the chorus of voices that applaud the takedown of maleficent characters who prey on vulnerable women in the workplace. In private it\u2019s a different story. \u201cGrow up, this is real life,\u201d I hear these same feminist friends say. \u201cWhat ever happened to flirting?\u201d and \u201cWhat about the women who are the predators?\u201d Some women, including random people I talk to in supermarket lines, have gone so far as to call it an outright witch hunt.\n\nWhere do your students stand within the debate? What do they really think about the conversations being had and the ways men are being held accountable for sexual misconduct? Do they think #MeToo has gone too far \u2014 or not far enough?\n\nEngage students in a structured discussion, such as a debate, a Fishbowl or a Four Corners activity, where they can voice their opinions honestly and listen to other perspectives respectfully.\n\nWe recommend the articles below for a wide variety of perspectives. You might choose to have half the class read one side of the issue and the other half read the other side. Or, have every student read at least one article from each point of view to get a well-rounded understanding of the debate.\n\nArticles generally in support of the #MeToo movement\n\nYes, This Is a Witch Hunt. I\u2019m a Witch and I\u2019m Hunting You.\n\nAmber Tamblyn: I\u2019m Not Ready for the Redemption of Men\n\nResponse to French Letter Denouncing #MeToo Shows a Sharp Divide\n\nHow the Myth of the Artistic Genius Excuses the Abuse of Women\n\nWhen Sexual Assault Victims Are Charged With Lying\n\nArticles that question the movement:\n\nPublicly, We Say #MeToo. Privately, We Have Misgivings.\n\nWhen #MeToo Goes Too Far\n\nCatherine Deneuve and Others Denounce the #MeToo Movement\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nI\u2019m Not Convinced Franken Should Quit\n\nThe Limits of \u2018Believe All Women\u2019\n\nTo facilitate the discussion, you might ask:\n\n\u2022 Has the #MeToo movement gone too far? If so, what is the limit? If not, why not and is there a limit?\n\n\u2022 What should happen to people who are accused or guilty of sexual harassment and assault?\n\n\u2022 Should we always \u201cbelieve all women\u201d? What are the benefits and drawbacks of doing so?\n\n\u2022 Do these conversations around sexual harassment and assault make relations between men and women better or worse? Why do you think so?\n\n__________\n\nBring It Home: Sexual Harassment and Teenagers\n\nPhoto\n\nNote to teachers: Any discussion of sexual harassment in our society will quickly involve students\u2019 own experiences, in and out of school. Below are several ideas for how students might consider some of the questions raised by the activities above in terms of how they affect their own communities. This is obviously a sensitive thing to take on in a classroom, and we welcome your ideas. How have you addressed these issues with your students? Please post thoughts to our comments section.\n\n1. Research School Practices and Policies\n\nA recent survey by The Upshot reports:\n\nThe victims of sexual harassment who have recently come forward are far from alone: Nearly half of women say they have experienced some form of it at work at least once in their careers. But there has been little research about those responsible. In a new survey, about a third of men said they had done something at work within the past year that would qualify as objectionable behavior or sexual harassment.\n\nDo your students think peer-to-peer sexual harassment is a problem at your school? How do they know?\n\nInvite them to investigate the policies and protocols already in place school-wide, and perhaps even district- or statewide. Students might interview teachers, administrators and fellow students to learn the following:\n\n\u2022 How comprehensive, thoughtful and practical are the policies we have now?\n\n\u2022 How well do they seem to work?\n\n\u2022 How might they be improved?\n\nBased on their analysis, what recommendations might your students make about these policies? How can they communicate these recommendations? For example, might they write a piece for the school newspaper? Send a letter to administrators? Create an annotated reading list for their peers? Sponsor an awareness-raising campaign or \u201cteach-in\u201d around the issue for the school as a whole?\n\n2. Revise Your Sex Ed Curriculum\n\nHow much does your school\u2019s sex education curriculum address sexual harassment? Consent? Gender roles? Healthy relationships?\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn California, lessons about sexual consent are now required:\n\nThe legislation requires school districts that already include health as a graduation requirement to teach about \u201cyes means yes\u201d and sexual violence prevention starting next year. It also asks state education officials to update curriculum guidelines for high school health classes with information about those topics. Under a \u201cyes means yes\u201d standard, sexual activity is considered consensual only when both partners clearly state their willingness to participate through \u201caffirmative, conscious and voluntary agreement\u201d at every stage.\n\nAsk your students to do an audit of their sex education curriculum, either by sharing experiences they have had in class or by analyzing learning materials like worksheets and textbooks. What do they learn about sexual harassment, consent and gender? What messages do boys get about these topics? What messages do girls get? In their opinions, is what they learn about sex helpful in combating the social norms that have allowed sexual misconduct to continue? Or does it perpetuate them?\n\nInvite students to do further research into how to address these issues with young people. In addition to the above resources on sexual harassment, they might also read some of these articles for a deeper look at sex education and consent:\n\nSex Ed Lesson: \u2018Yes Means Yes,\u2019 but It\u2019s Tricky\n\nTeaching Good Sex\n\nCampus Sex \u2026 With a Syllabus\n\nMaking Consent Cool: Students Advocate for Consensual Sex\n\nAffirmative Consent: Are Students Really Asking?\n\nTalking to Children About Consent\n\nTalking With Both Daughters and Sons About Sex\n\nAfter they complete the reading, assign them to groups and ask them to outline the sex education curriculum they would like schools to teach. Encourage them to consider gaps in learning about gender, consent and sexual harassment. How can their curriculum help students understand the many factors that contribute to sexual misconduct? How can it disrupt harmful stereotypes about boys and girls? How might the curriculum be balanced to encourage all students to share their voices? Students might even create a sample lesson plan for one of these issues and teach it to the class.\n\nTo increase the academic rigor of the exercise, have students compare what\u2019s taught in their school to the National Sexuality Education Standards.\n\n3. Examine the Role of Technology and Social Media in Sexual Harassment\n\n\n\nShould sexting be a crime? Invite your students to watch and respond to this video by our colleagues at KQED\u2019s Above the Noise.\n\nThen, have them read \u201cTeenagers, Stop Asking for Nude Photos.\u201d In the article, Lisa Damour writes:\n\nTeenagers are drafted into a sexual culture that rests on a harmful premise: On the heterosexual field, boys typically play offense and girls play defense. This problematic framework underlies the findings of a new study that documents, in alarming detail, girls\u2019 reports of the common coercive practices boys use to solicit nude digital photographs. An analysis of nearly 500 accounts from 12- to 18-year-old girls about their negative experiences with sexting found that over two-thirds had been asked for explicit images. \u2026 \u2026 In the wider culture, it appears we have suddenly come to the limit of our tolerance for the sexualized abuse of power by adult men. A logical next step is to recalibrate some of the toxic norms that have taken hold among teenagers. Most schools and many parents already tell teenagers not to send sexualized selfies. But why don\u2019t we also tell adolescents to stop asking for nude photos from one another?\n\nWe posed our own Student Opinion question about this article, asking What Advice Should Parents and Counselors Give Teenagers About Sexting? One student wrote:\n\nI find it concerning that the statistics proving males\u2019 higher likelihood of pressuring girls for photos of this nature is so distinct. In light of all that is going on regarding sexual misconduct, in particular the \u201cMe Too\u201d movement, it makes me think that \u2014 although it could not be entirely eliminated \u2014 the awareness of this issue could prevent this sexting issue, which is the \u201cnorm\u201d in today\u2019s world, from expanding into sexual harassment and assault such as molestation and rape. Both the \u201cMe Too\u201d movement and sexting stories provided in the article draw uncanny parallels which must be addressed and cured.\n\nHave your students participate in the conversation by reading other students\u2019 responses and then writing to us with their own ideas about the advice teenagers should get about sexting \u2014 and the kinds of support they need when dealing with this issue.\n\n4. Consider What One Individual Can Do\n\nPhoto\n\nWhat actions \u2014 big or small \u2014 can your students commit to as individuals to help create a safe and inclusive society for all people and prevent the continuation of a culture of sexual assault and harassment in their generation?\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nYou might invite your students to write down ideas \u2014 as many as they each can come up with \u2014 on sticky notes, and post those notes all over a wall of your classroom. Then, as students walk around and read what others wrote, they can think about which of the suggested actions they would be willing to take. They might then keep a private journal of their actions and thoughts around this issue, and report back to class in future days about the results.\n\nIf they need help coming up with ideas, you might have students read one or more of these articles and identify the strategies that the authors suggest men and women can use to stop sexual harassment:\n\nThis Is a Man Problem\n\nHow to Help Kids Disrupt \u2018Bro Culture\u2019\n\nThe #MeToo Moment: How to Be a (Good) Bystander\n\nSteinem, Sandberg and Judd on How to End Sex Harassment\n\n__________\n\nRespond to What You\u2019ve Learned by Creating Something\n\nPhoto\n\nAt the end of a unit on this topic, students can deepen their reflections and voice their opinions through creative responses like the following. They might work individually on the project of their choice, work together in small groups, or, as a class, choose one of these ideas to do together.\n\n1. Make Art Inspired by the Reckoning\n\nThe Times\u2019s gender editor, Jessica Bennett, writes:\n\nFrom Picasso\u2019s Guernica \u2014 observed as a cry against the atrocities of the Spanish War \u2014 to the graffiti of the Arab Spring, social movements and injustice have long inspired art of all forms. The #MeToo Moment is no exception.\n\nThe Times asked readers to submit work based on this theme and published it with comments from the artist. Let students view the artwork readers created and then ask them to create their own visual representations of the #MeToo moment.\n\nOr, they can design an editorial cartoon in response to an article on sexual harassment, as several students did in our 2017 Editorial Cartoon Contest.\n\n2. Weigh In Like a Late Night Talk Show Host\n\nLate night talk show hosts often use their platforms to respond to the news. Many, like Samantha Bee, Stephen Colbert, Trevor Noah and Jimmy Fallon have been weighing in on the #MeToo movement with passion and humor. Let students watch one or more of the excerpts from the shows above, using it as a mentor text for their own late night talk show.\n\nWhich topics from the conversation around sexual harassment get your students most animated? Have them choose an article from The Times Topics Sexual Harassment page or another source and prepare a monologue in response to it. Just as late night hosts do, they should use specific evidence from the article, other resources and their own experiences to defend their position. They should also consider how they can effectively use humor, emotion, empathy and logic to communicate their message.\n\nNote to teacher: Some of the linked videos do use expletives.\n\n3. Remix Beauty Standards\n\nPhoto\n\nAt the Golden Globes this year, women and men wore black in solidarity with victims of sexual misconduct and effectively redefined the purpose of the red carpet. The Times followed suit, as Bonnie Wertheim writes:\n\nAt The Times, where I work on the Styles desk, red carpet slide shows are a mainstay of awards season. We watch, pick our personal bests and worsts, and publish images that millions of people then judge for themselves. The photographs, at best, reflect a desire for shiny distractions. But there is a complicity to scrutinizing and ranking these women, too. Their dresses are not a reflection of their own style or their professional achievements. They speak to the larger economy of Hollywood, whose corruption becomes clearer with each turn of the news cycle. Moreover, our habitual participation in the red carpet industrial complex underscores the widely held perception that women\u2019s bodies are available for public consumption. So we\u2019re switching things up this year. We\u2019re sending a Pulitzer Prize-winning photojournalist, Damon Winter, to document the Golden Globes red carpet as a news event (you can see some of his coverage of Donald Trump here). We will have a slate of reporters watching and listening for smart, critical quotes from celebrities, not about what they\u2019re wearing, but about the future they envision for their industry \u2014 and the world.\n\nThe Times has also written about the ways that clothing and beauty companies are responding to the #MeToo moment by changing the way they represent women in their industry.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHave students look at some of the examples above. Then ask them to do their own research in magazines, on social media or on other online platforms and collect images of women and men. Ask them to consider the following questions:\n\n\u2022 How are women generally portrayed?\n\n\u2022 How are men generally portrayed?\n\n\u2022 How might these portrayals contribute to a culture of sexual harassment and assault?\n\nThen, as The Times did on the red carpet this year, invite students to choose one of the images they found and \u201cremix\u201d it in a way that challenges \u201cthe widely held perception that women\u2019s bodies are available for public consumption.\u201d\n\n4. Record Oral Histories of #MeToo Experiences by Earlier Generations\n\nPhoto\n\nThe Times asked readers to share the conversations they have had with their families about unwanted sexual encounters. The Times received more that 140 responses, mostly from women, and interviewed members from seven of those families.\n\nHave students listen to one or more of these interviews. What do they notice about how different generations think about sexual harassment? Jessica Bennet parses the results in this piece, interviewing Times staffers of different generations and focusing in part on reactions to recent allegations against Aziz Ansari that raise the question, Is it possible for something to be nonconsensual but also not sexual assault?\n\nAfter students have listened to or read some of these pieces, invite them to prepare their own questions and interview someone of a different generation to understand their experiences on or thoughts about the #MeToo movement. They can record the interview on audio or video if they like.\n\nStudents can and should consider the topics about which they are personally curious, but they might use these questions as starting points:\n\n\u2022 Did you learn about sexual harassment when you were my age? If so, what advice did you get? If not, do you wish you had?\n\n\u2022 Have you ever had an experience with an unwanted sexual encounter that you want to share with me? What was that like for you?\n\n\u2022 What advice do you have for me when it comes to sexual harassment and assault?\n\n\u2022 Do you think progress has been made in addressing gender inequality and abuses of power since you were young?\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 What do you think about the #MeToo movement? Is it necessary? Has it gone too far?\n\nIf students are comfortable, they can share what they learned from their interviews with the class. Discuss the commonalities and differences across generations. If they find differences, why do they think those generational differences exist? Do they think that progress has been made in the conversation around sexual harassment and assault? What do people in older generations have to teach your students on this issue? What does your students\u2019 generation have to teach older generations?\n\n5. Create an Anti-Harassment Campaign Aimed at Your Peers\n\nPhoto\n\nSince the Harvey Weinstein story broke, people across industries have been looking for ways to fight the problem in their own worlds. Earlier in this lesson we invited students to think about what their schools could do, but this activity goes further by asking them to actually create a campaign that will help educate their peers.\n\nThey might first study some examples of campaigns, such as the Time\u2019s Up anti-sexual harassment action plan:\n\nDriven by outrage and a resolve to correct a power imbalance that seemed intractable just months ago, 300 prominent actresses and female agents, writers, directors, producers and entertainment executives have formed an ambitious, sprawling initiative to fight systemic sexual harassment in Hollywood and in blue-collar workplaces nationwide. The initiative includes: \u2014 A legal defense fund, backed by $13 million in donations, to help less privileged women \u2014 like janitors, nurses and workers at farms, factories, restaurants and hotels \u2014 protect themselves from sexual misconduct and the fallout from reporting it. \u2014 Legislation to penalize companies that tolerate persistent harassment, and to discourage the use of nondisclosure agreements to silence victims. \u2014 A drive to reach gender parity at studios and talent agencies that has already begun making headway. \u2014 And a request that women walking the red carpet at the Golden Globes speak out and raise awareness by wearing black.\n\nStudents can view Time\u2019s Up\u2019s open letter and website as mentor texts. What are the plan\u2019s purpose and goals? What steps does it outline for achieving those goals?\n\nAs students begin to brainstorm about what kind of campaign they want to create and what issues they will address, they might borrow ideas from these Times articles:\n\nSexual Harassment Training Doesn\u2019t Work. But Some Things Do.\n\nIt\u2019s Not Just Fox: Why Women Don\u2019t Report Sexual Harassment\n\nHow to Stop the Predators Who Aren\u2019t Famous\n\nMen at Work Wonder if They Overstepped With Women, Too\n\nStepping Up to Stop Sexual Assault\n\n_________\n\nReflect on Your Learning\n\nAs your students finish their final projects, encourage them to return to some key questions we posed at the beginning of this unit:\n\n\u2022 How does sexual harassment affect individuals and society?\n\n\u2022 How do social and cultural norms contribute to sexual harassment?\n\n\u2022 What can individuals do to put an end to sexual misconduct?\n\n\u2022 Why is this such a difficult topic to address in class and in wider society?\n\n\u2022 Do you think discussing and learning about sexual harassment is important? Why or why not?\n\nHave their answers changed? Become more nuanced or informed? How? What advice might they have for future teachers and students of a class like this one?\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n__________\n\nRelated Resources\n\nPhoto\n\nAdditional Times Resources\n\nThough our unit focuses on how this movement has played out in the United States, it is also surfacing in countries around the globe, from Indonesia and Afghanistan to Italy, Sweden, China and France. You can keep up with reporting on thse issues worldwide through the Times Topics page on sexual harassment.\n\nLearning Network Resources\n\nLesson | Women on the March: A Lesson Plan on Imagining the Future of Feminism\n\nLesson | Crossing the Line Online: Sexual Harassment and Violence in the Age of Social Media\n\nLesson | Text to Text | \u2018Speak\u2019 and \u2018Waking Up to the Enduring Memory of Rape\u2019\n\nLesson | Text to Text | \u2018The Scarlet Letter\u2019 and \u2018Sexism and the Single Murderess\u2019\n\nStudent Opinion Question | What Is Your Reaction to the #MeToo Movement?\n\nStudent Opinion Question | What Should We Do to Fight Sexual Violence Against Young Women?\n\nStudent Opinion Question | Have You Experienced Sexual Harassment?\n\nStudent Opinion Question | What Have Been Your Experiences With Catcalling or Other Kinds of Street Harassment?\n\nAdditional Resources From Around the Web\n\nKQED | The Fight Against Sexual Harassment\n\nStop Sexual Assault in Schools | #MeTooK12 Resources\n\nEqual Rights Advocates | Sexual Harassment at School\n\nUnited States Equal Employment Opportunity Commission | Youth @ Work: Sexual Harassment Is Against the Law", "title": "The Reckoning: Teaching About the #MeToo Moment and Sexual Harassment With Resources From The New York Times", "authors": ["Natalie Proulx", "Christopher Pepper", "Katherine Schulten"]} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "It\u2019s hard to pinpoint when the red carpet became an economy unto itself \u2014 somewhere back in the late 20th century \u2014 but it has been a carefully cultivated marketing tool for generations now, built on an illusion into which we all buy: the largely fabricated pretense that actresses (and actors) are choosing their own gowns, and that what we see is a pure expression of their personal style.\n\nFact is, what we are seeing is often a look that has been bought, and created, by a global brand, or group of brands, from clothes to shoes, bags, jewels, watches and hairstyles. And the individuals involved have been more than willing to secure their financial future by selling it: swirling in it, name-checking it and otherwise promoting it.\n\nFor any major awards show (and the Globes certainly qualifies) many boldface nominees will have contractual relationships with fashion brands \u2014 negotiated by managers and agents \u2014 that require them to wear a gown or a tuxedo by that brand to that event. They may have input into the final product. They may even, with the help of a stylist (who is also often paid by both actor and brand) have chosen it themselves. But the idea that they chose it from all the gowns on option? The idea they \u2014 gasp! \u2014 shopped for it? Utter hooey. They chose it under very specific guidelines from a very specific selection.\n\nIt began, as most sell-your-soul initiatives do, innocently enough. As the advent of the fashion police and the worst-dressed lists began to shine a light on the occasionally terrible taste of Hollywood (remember the Demi Moore bicycle shorts ball gown?), designers seemed to provide a safe harbor of expert advice. Giorgio Armani was, famously, the first to realize the potential benefits, and became the founding father of the fashion/Hollywood axis. Soon, however, most of his peers followed. It was, largely, a mutually beneficial relationship of like-minded individuals where everyone benefited: A celebrity got a great dress, and a brand got a great-looking famous person in their dress, and we all got to ogle them.\n\nAs movie receipts fell, however, fashion exploded, and money entered the picture. Soon talent (and their managers) realized that income lost in choosing, say, a small indie film to bolster acting cred, could be offset by agreeing to become an \u201cambassador\u201d for a runway brand, a job that could range from a single appearance to ad campaigns, show and party attendance, and sometimes even product collaborations. Sometimes the payments went straight to a charity. Sometimes they went to support artistic choices. And thus the slippery slope was oiled by the best intentions, and down everyone slid.", "title": "The Red Carpet Is Its Own Economy", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-08 00:00:00", "text": "Welcome to the season of unauthorized public ice.\n\nWith extreme cold blanketing parts of the East Coast this winter, the slick allure of ice has been too tempting to pass up for some. There have been plenty of opportunities for sliding, slipping and skating \u2014 even in places where it is risky and not allowed \u2014 from Boston to New York to the nation\u2019s capital.\n\nIn the past week, parks authorities in Washington reminded visitors that where there is ice, there is usually water, after a number of people trying to skate or walk across the surface of the Reflecting Pool on the National Mall broke through the ice.\n\nNo one was injured. But with temperatures dipping to the single digits on some days and winds bestowing a chill that makes the air feel below zero even if you\u2019re not wet, anyone who gets dipped into the water, even if just knee-deep, risks hypothermia, the National Mall and Memorial Parks said in a Facebook post over the weekend.\n\n\u201cIce skating can lead to a cold and dangerous swim,\u201d the post added.\n\nThe Reflecting Pool, more than a third of a mile long and over two feet deep in some parts, is a centerpiece of the capital\u2019s National Mall, hosting millions of visitors a year. In the summer, parks authorities have warned people not to swim or wade in it. In the winter, the pool turns into an impromptu winter playground.", "title": "The Reflecting Pool Isn\u2019t a Skating Rink, Washington Tells Visitors", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nNo, I have not watched the new Star Trek series. Sore subject. CBS is airing the latest spinoff, \u201cStar Trek: Discovery,\u201d only on CBS All Access, yet another paid video streaming service, in this case for $5.99 a month, or $9.99 without commercials. And I\u2019m not doing that.\n\nI\u2019ve got Netflix. I\u2019ve got Amazon. I\u2019ve got cable. I\u2019m done.\n\nLet\u2019s not pretend this was a decision made lightly. The only political offices I\u2019ve ever held were as vice president, and then president, of my high school Star Trek Club. These roles came with a lot of self-sacrifice and certainly a monkish devotion, since they effectively ended my dating prospects at the time, though a curly mullet didn\u2019t help either. But it was the path I chose. I have no regrets. Some of us view \u201cThe Wrath of Khan\u201d as a major work of American cinema. Others have no idea what I\u2019m talking about. That\u2019s fine. I just want my bona fides to be clear so you understand the principled stand that I\u2019m taking.\n\nThe point is, I don\u2019t know how I\u2019m supposed to watch TV anymore. In industry jargon, we\u2019re years into the great \u201cunbundling\u201d of cable television. Comcast lost another 125,000 residential cable subscribers in its most recent quarter, while DirecTV lost 90,000. ESPN\u2019s subscriber base has fallen by about 12 percent since 2010. Now we patch together hardware and software from different companies and make the best of it.\n\nFor consumers, this is not going to get any easier. Disney has two streaming services in development, one for entertainment and another for sports. If Disney\u2019s acquisition of much of Fox goes through, that would further alter the landscape. And then there\u2019s net neutrality, which could take the whole picture and shake it up like a snow globe.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMartin Kon, a partner at the Boston Consulting Group, in the firm\u2019s technology, media and telecommunications practice, said that \u201cover time, all major content owners will have ways of presenting their content offerings\u201d in what he referred to as on-demand \u201cbouquets of content.\u201d", "title": "The Remote Control, Out of Control: Why \u00e0 la Carte TV Is Too Much for a Trekkie", "authors": ["Danny Hakim"]} {"date": "2018-01-02 00:00:00", "text": "We told Congress that from Manhattan to Sunny Isles Beach, Fla., and from Toronto to Panama, we found widespread evidence that Mr. Trump and his organization had worked with a wide array of dubious Russians in arrangements that often raised questions about money laundering. Likewise, those deals don\u2019t seem to interest Congress.\n\nWe explained how, from our past journalistic work in Europe, we were deeply familiar with the political operative Paul Manafort\u2019s coziness with Moscow and his financial ties to Russian oligarchs close to Vladimir Putin.\n\nFinally, we debunked the biggest canard being pushed by the president\u2019s men \u2014 the notion that we somehow knew of the June 9, 2016, meeting in Trump Tower between some Russians and the Trump brain trust. We first learned of that meeting from news reports last year \u2014 and the committees know it. They also know that these Russians were unaware of the former British intelligence officer Christopher Steele\u2019s work for us and were not sources for his reports.\n\nYes, we hired Mr. Steele, a highly respected Russia expert. But we did so without informing him whom we were working for and gave him no specific marching orders beyond this basic question: Why did Mr. Trump repeatedly seek to do deals in a notoriously corrupt police state that most serious investors shun?\n\nWhat came back shocked us. Mr. Steele\u2019s sources in Russia (who were not paid) reported on an extensive \u2014 and now confirmed \u2014 effort by the Kremlin to help elect Mr. Trump president. Mr. Steele saw this as a crime in progress and decided he needed to report it to the F.B.I.\n\nWe did not discuss that decision with our clients, or anyone else. Instead, we deferred to Mr. Steele, a trusted friend and intelligence professional with a long history of working with law enforcement. We did not speak to the F.B.I. and haven\u2019t since.\n\nAfter the election, Mr. Steele decided to share his intelligence with Senator John McCain via an emissary. We helped him do that. The goal was to alert the United States national security community to an attack on our country by a hostile foreign power. We did not, however, share the dossier with BuzzFeed, which to our dismay published it last January.", "title": "Opinion | The Republicans\u2019 Fake Investigations", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "During O. J. Simpson\u2019s trial for murder, his lawyers needed to throw the blame on someone besides their client. They settled on a vague story about drug dealers somehow tied to a close friend of his wife, Nicole Brown Simpson. The defense never even tried to explain why these malefactors \u201cwould have wanted to kill Nicole Brown Simpson (much less Ron Goldman),\u201d Jeffrey Toobin wrote in his book about the trial. \u201cThat wasn\u2019t the point of the defense strategy.\u201d All the defense had to do was muddy the proverbial waters and gesture at an alternative theory of the crime.\n\nThe behavior of Republicans in Congress who are ostensibly investigating Russia\u2019s interference in the 2016 election makes sense if you imagine them acting like Simpson\u2019s lawyers. Though pretending to examine a crime against America, they are instead working to cover one up. To do so, they are spinning wild alternative scenarios with just enough surface plausibility to persuade the easily persuadable.\n\nBecause Republicans don\u2019t have to prove their alternative theory, you rarely see it fully elaborated. But it goes something like this: Hillary Clinton\u2019s campaign hired Fusion GPS to gather anti-Trump misinformation from Russia. Fusion GPS, working with the retired British spy Christopher Steele, then delivered the Russian smears to the F.B.I., which was determined to thwart Trump. So if anyone was guilty of collusion with Russia in the 2016 election, it was Clinton and her allies.\n\nOn Tuesday, Senator Sheldon Whitehouse, Democrat of Rhode Island, gave a speech on the Senate floor about all the rabbit holes into which Republicans have tried to divert the Russia investigation. His Republican colleagues, he said, \u201chave been repeating, in chorus with the White House and conservative media, the disproven claim that the Russians somehow commissioned the Steele dossier, or that Steele somehow got suckered by the Russians, or that some deep-state F.B.I. set up the whole thing to pressure Trump.\u201d", "title": "Opinion | The Republicans\u2019 Fantasy Investigation", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "For the past week or so, Mr. Nunes \u2014 who supposedly recused himself from the Russia inquiry last April \u2014 has been dangling something even juicier: a classified memo by the committee\u2019s Republican staff that is said to allege that the investigation was corrupted from the start by law enforcement officials intent on toppling Mr. Trump. In the heat of the 2016 presidential race, the memo reportedly claims, the F.B.I. tricked the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court into issuing a warrant to spy on the Trump campaign.\n\nSounds pretty serious! One would assume Mr. Nunes, who has previously appeared very concerned about the improper handling of classified information, would do all he could to protect any potentially sensitive material from public exposure. Yet he is refusing to show the memo to the Justice Department or the F.B.I. \u2014 an \u201cextraordinarily reckless\u201d approach, as Assistant Attorney General Stephen Boyd, a Trump appointee, wrote in a harsh rebuke to Mr. Nunes on Wednesday. \u201cWe do not understand why the committee would possibly seek to disclose classified and law enforcement sensitive information without first consulting with the relevant members of the intelligence community,\u201d Mr. Boyd wrote.\n\nHe added that neither Mr. Nunes nor most of the committee members had even seen the highly classified materials on which the memo appears to be based \u2014 and the release of which could be damaging to national security.\n\nDemocrats have called the memo \u201cprofoundly misleading\u201d and have said its factual allegations are taken out of context. They have prepared their own classified memo addressing the origins of the warrant, which they say was properly sought and approved.\n\nBut even if Mr. Nunes\u2019s memo never sees the light of day, it has done its job \u2014 spawning a new wave of conspiracy theories as well as suspiciously timed calls to #ReleasetheMemo amplified across social media, many coming from what a German Marshall Fund tracking project found to be part of Russian-linked influence networks.", "title": "Opinion | The Republicans\u2019 Real Fake Scandal", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-29 00:00:00", "text": "And while celebrities have always used awards shows to advance a cause \u2014 whether it was Marlon Brando sending out a Native American activist to decline his 1973 Oscar for best actor or Vanessa Redgrave denouncing \u201cZionist hoodlums\u201d in 1978 \u2014 Democrats and Republicans alike said Monday that the organized, concerted effort by the Grammys, topped off with Mrs. Clinton\u2019s appearance, could only make the nation\u2019s red state-blue state divide more pronounced.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s a shot from a part of the culture that is perceived as offensive and hostile by another part of the culture,\u201d said Steve Schmidt, a Republican strategist who has been critical of Mr. Trump. \u201cTo a working person in Youngstown, Ohio, that\u2019s an alien communication from another tribe.\u201d\n\nBut Mr. Trump\u2019s election victory, policies and rhetoric have so shocked and antagonized liberal-minded celebrities that the last thing they want to do is remain silent. Instead, many liberals eagerly watch award shows in hopes that high-profile performers will stick it to Mr. Trump. Even a speech from Oprah Winfrey at the Golden Globes this month led to presidential speculation.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s this resurgence of political activism that goes back to the 1960s and Vietnam taking on a new type of involvement,\u201d said Adrienne Elrod, a longtime former aide to Mrs. Clinton who now helps progressive causes connect with Hollywood. She likened the awards circuit to the Women\u2019s March, saying \u201cit seems like a necessary component in the resistance.\u201d\n\nWhether viewers of the Oscars want to listen to the resistance is another matter. Producers who specialize in awards telecasts have said that post-show research, compiled mainly from Nielsen, indicates that most viewers dislike it when celebrities turn a trip to the stage into a political bully pulpit. One recent producer of the Oscars said that minute-by-minute post-show ratings analysis indicated that \u201cvast swaths\u201d of people turned off their televisions when celebrities started to opine on politics. He spoke on the condition of anonymity to discuss confidential metrics.\n\nThe Grammys drew 19.8 million viewers on Sunday, a 24 percent decline from last year and the lowest ratings since 2009. Over the past few years, most awards shows, including the Oscars, have seen a steep decline in viewership.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cCan\u2019t we just enjoy a big TV event without being lectured?\u201d the conservative activist L. Brent Bozell III wrote in 2015 about pleas for racial equality during that year\u2019s Oscars ceremony.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhile it\u2019s too soon for jokes and skits to be finalized for the coming Oscars, many performers and industry insiders expect the show to grapple with the serious nature of the #MeToo movement. How Mr. Trump fits into that discussion has yet to be determined, though some actors have called him out for once bragging about groping women against their will. The producers and writers of the Oscars could feel pressure to tie Mr. Trump and #MeToo, which would energize liberals but risk upsetting viewers who support Mr. Trump and simply want to watch a movie awards show.\n\nThe pull of the Oscars toward smaller, independent movies rather than multiplex blockbusters has already hurt the show, said Marty Kaplan, the Norman Lear professor of entertainment, media and society at the University of Southern California. Viewers could be further alienated by the anti-Trump tirades.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s a verdict on Hollywood\u2019s sensibility going into it,\u201d Mr. Kaplan said. \u201cWould the 35 percent of the country likely to be offended by a highly politicized Oscars tune in in the first place?\u201d\n\nJimmy Kimmel, a genial comedian who dips into politics sparingly but memorably, will host the Academy Awards, and he and a team of writers will hammer out the monologue and jokes. During election years, networks must try to maintain balance, and the Oscars also come at a time of sensitivity for ABC\u2019s corporate owner; Disney needs the Justice Department\u2019s approval for its deal to buy most of 21st Century Fox.\n\n\u201cIf you\u2019re going to make a joke about one, you should about the other,\u201d said Bruce Vilanch, a comedy writer who has written material and jokes for the Academy Awards for some 25 years. As often as not, he said, whoever\u2019s being targeted \u201clet it slide, and won\u2019t dignify it with a reply.\u201d\n\nEven with dwindling viewership, Democrats see opportunity in awards season \u2014 and in the Oscars, in particular \u2014 as a way to reach critical constituencies of young, Latino and African-American voters, as candidates look to the midterm elections.\n\n\u201cWhen a famous person can use their celebrity to spread information about why someone should get off the sidelines and vote, that\u2019s a good thing,\u201d said Rebecca Katz, a Democratic strategist from the party\u2019s progressive wing.\n\nBut, she added it\u2019s a fine line. \u201cYou never want a celebrity to make a voter feel like they\u2019re wrong or that opinion\u2019s stupid.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nMrs. Clinton\u2019s unexpected skit \u2014 taped near her home in Chappaqua, N.Y., on Friday \u2014 thrilled many supporters who exalted on Twitter at the former Democratic nominee\u2019s giving a cheeky grin and trolling Mr. Trump. The response was strikingly different from the one Michael Moore received when he was drowned out by boos for lashing out against President George W. Bush and the Iraq war during his 2003 Oscar acceptance speech for best documentary for \u201cBowling for Columbine.\u201d\n\nWhether Mrs. Clinton\u2019s appearance annoyed Mr. Trump \u2014 or whether the politics of awards shows is getting to him \u2014 is unclear: He didn\u2019t hit back. But the dismal ratings for the Grammys didn\u2019t go unnoticed by the TV-obsessed Mr. Trump.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s not lost on the White House that the overwhelming majority of the country did not tune in to watch,\u201d said Hogan Gidley, a White House spokesman. \u201cPolitical statements and faux moral outrage are unwanted additions to the program.\u201d", "title": "The Resistance Has Come to Celebrity Award Shows", "authors": ["Amy Chozick"]} {"date": "2018-01-01 00:00:00", "text": "Imagine three kids running around a maypole, forming a chain with their arms. The innermost kid is holding the pole with one hand. The faster they run, the more centrifugal force there is tearing the chain apart. The tighter they grip, the more centripetal force there is holding the chain together. Eventually centrifugal force exceeds centripetal force and the chain breaks.\n\nThat\u2019s essentially what is happening in this country, N.Y.U.\u2019s Jonathan Haidt argued in a lecture delivered to the Manhattan Institute in November. He listed some of the reasons centrifugal forces may now exceed centripetal: the loss of the common enemies we had in World War II and the Cold War, an increasingly fragmented media, the radicalization of the Republican Party, and a new form of identity politics, especially on campus.\n\nHaidt made the interesting point that identity politics per se is not the problem. Identity politics is just political mobilization around group characteristics. The problem is that identity politics has dropped its centripetal elements and become entirely centrifugal.\n\nMartin Luther King described segregation and injustice as forces tearing us apart. He appealed to universal principles and our common humanity as ways to heal prejudice and unite the nation. He appealed to common religious principles, the creed of our founding fathers and a common language of love to drive out prejudice. King \u201cframed our greatest moral failing as an opportunity for centripetal redemption,\u201d Haidt observed.", "title": "Opinion | The Retreat to Tribalism", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "At times, Ms. McIntyre indulges a flourish or two more than is necessary. The opening tumult, presumably intended to show a society in terminal disrepair, merely brings to mind the Sharks and the Jets: The faux-thuggishness is singularly unconvincing. Nor does it work when Mr. Troughton hands a baby (not a real one) into the audience. The breaking of the fourth wall is a distraction from Titus\u2019s unraveling.\n\nThe happier news is that for much of its three-hour running time, the modern-dress production serves as a reminder of the glory days of high-definition acting that was once the R.S.C.\u2019s norm. For all the excesses of the writing, Mr. Troughton is able to calibrate the degrees by which Titus surrenders to the baseness around him. \u201cThou art a Roman, be not barbarous,\u201d Titus\u2019s brother Marcus (Patrick Drury, excellent) advises near the start, only to watch as barbarity becomes the societal benchmark.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cAntony and Cleopatra\u201d is comparable in that it features a leading actor in assured control \u2014 in this case Josette Simon, who takes center stage as the Egyptian queen. Too long absent from the company where she began her career, Ms. Simon brings a lissome sensuality to one of Shakespeare\u2019s greatest female characters \u2014 a part that tends to overshadow its Antony, notwithstanding the clarity that a robust Antony Byrne brings to the grizzled Roman general. (The role will be taken by no less a presence than Ralph Fiennes when the National Theater here tackles this same play later in the year.)\n\nAdopting a playful, devil-may-care persona, Ms. Simon revels in the outsize posturing of a ruler who is also given some of Shakespeare\u2019s most luxuriant language. Elsewhere, one is aware of a falling-off in the supporting roles, as if to suggest that the R.S.C. isn\u2019t finding the strength in numbers in evidence when Mr. Fiennes was cutting his teeth at this company some years back. (Ben Allen\u2019s Octavius Caesar, for one, is too earnest by half.)\n\nThe director, Iqbal Khan, retains period trappings \u2014 which is to say, togas and sandals aplenty \u2014 that here come tethered to a lushly exotic score by the British singer-songwriter Laura Mvula. And in Ms. Simon, a variable production boasts an ennobling presence that Shakespeare goes to some lengths to describe \u2014 \u201cshe did make defect perfection,\u201d we are told \u2014 and that the audience can see right there before them.\n\nPhoto\n\nWomen play second fiddle in \u201cJulius Caesar,\u201d which also happens to be the least interesting of the triptych. It isn\u2019t quite the revelatory window on the past or the present that we might have hoped for. A prequel of sorts to \u201cAntony and Cleopatra,\u201d with which it shares the central character of Antony, \u201cJulius Caesar\u201d offers a mostly male study in realpolitik that, in Angus Jackson\u2019s becalmed production, leaves us wondering where the star equivalents to Ms. Simon and Mr. Troughton have got to this time.\n\nAndrew Woodall\u2019s Caesar is certainly a crisper, more commanding presence than is usual in a play whose title character gets bumped off fairly early on. But Alex Waldmann\u2019s little-boy-lost Brutus is at physical and temperamental odds with such a grandly conspiratorial role. The same play will resurface here in London in a matter of weeks, at the director Nicholas Hytner\u2019s Bridge Theater. My advice for the moment is to wait on \u201cJulius Caesar,\u201d but don\u2019t let Ms. Simon or Mr. Troughton slip away.", "title": "The Royal Shakespeare Company Goes to Rome, With Mixed Results", "authors": ["Matt Wolf", "London Theater Reviews"]} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "This article is part of the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive the newsletter each weekday.\n\nFirst, a few words on road safety: What portion of Americans killed in vehicle crashes are not wearing seatbelts?\n\nI was stunned by the answer when I saw it yesterday. It has hovered between 48 percent and 51 percent in each of the past five years.\n\nFor many people, a seatbelt has become second nature. They can\u2019t imagine traveling without one \u2014 or even allowing someone riding in their car to do so. But lack of seatbelt use remains a major public-health problem in this country. About 15 percent of American drivers don\u2019t wear one, compared with less than 5 percent in several European countries.", "title": "Opinion | The Russian \u2018Cycle of Distraction\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-03 00:00:00", "text": "When Orrin Hatch\u2019s career in the United States Senate ends on Jan. 3, 2019, it will have spanned an audacious 42 years, or seven full terms. Assuming he completes his final term, Mr. Hatch will become the sixth-longest-serving senator ever.\n\nHis service truly has been epochal. Unfortunately, the epoch has not been a happy one. Mr. Hatch\u2019s career reflects the sad trajectory of our times, from a Congress where legislators had differences but actually tried to legislate, to one in which legislators \u2014 especially Republicans, terrified of facing a well-financed primary from the right \u2014 do nothing of the sort.\n\nMr. Hatch was elected in 1976 in one of the most improbable Senate victories, still, in recent American history. He was a Mormon, but a Pittsburgher; he had moved to Salt Lake City only in 1969 (though he had earlier done his undergraduate work at Brigham Young University, in Provo). He had no political experience and few political contacts when, the day before the deadline, this complete unknown filed his papers of candidacy for the mighty United States Senate.\n\nThe incumbent was \u2014 and how strange does this sound today? \u2014 a Utah Democrat. Frank Moss had won the seat freakishly in 1958, when the Republicans split and ran two candidates. But he\u2019d gotten himself re-elected twice and was a key leader on consumer issues. In 1976, Utah was still a centrist enough state that Moss had reason to think he\u2019d win a fourth term.", "title": "Opinion | The Sad Trajectory of Orrin Hatch", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "It\u2019s early morning, but Sal, Kris & Charlie\u2019s Deli, a small shop in Astoria, Queens, which specializes in supersize sandwiches, is full of customers with lunch on their minds.\n\nThe deli, set between a laundry and a private house in the shadow of the Amtrak overpass near the Astoria- Ditmars Boulevard subway station, announces itself only with an awning the color of a bluebird\u2019s wings.\n\nIt doesn\u2019t need to advertise.\n\nIn 1987, Charlie Gordon became the shop\u2019s third owner. He named the business after Sal (the legendary counterman who came with the shop), Kris (his wife) and himself. Around that time, customers called him \u201cthe Sandwich King of Astoria.\u201d Mr. Gordon decided to use that as his slogan.\n\n\u201cThey used to sell canned goods and some small $1 sandwiches,\u201d said Nick Gordon, Charlie\u2019s 30-year-old son, who works in the shop alongside his brother, John, 26. \u201cBut my dad, who had been in the bakery business, likes heavy sandwiches.\u201d", "title": "The Sandwich King of Astoria", "authors": ["Nancy A. Ruhling", "Neighborhood Joint"]} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "One year ago, people at Women\u2019s Marches across the country and around the world donned pink headgear to protest an administration headed by a man who, by his own account, thought he had a right to grab anything he wanted. We asked readers what they\u2019ve done with their pussy hats since.\n\nNicole Cesare of Philadelphia stashes hers in a \u201cgo bag\u201d along with pens, a notebook and snacks in case she needs to rush to a protest. Whitney Logan of Fairway, Kan., puts hers on when she makes phone calls to her senators and representatives: \u201cIt gives me courage,\u201d she said. Emily Kilbourn, in Bethlehem, Connecticut, wears hers when she\u2019s going somewhere she knows she\u2019ll run into conservatives: \u201cAmazing what a smile, wave, and a tip of the pussy hat will do!\u201d\n\nFor some readers, they\u2019ve become complicated objects, representative of an unserious sort of activism, unsuited to the times. For others, they\u2019ve become a kind of talisman, to be worn at pivotal moments, good and bad (the Alabama special Senate election in December was a popular occasion for digging them out). And for others, they\u2019re just a hat \u2014 special, perhaps, but ultimately a head warmer: \u201cI wear it!\u201d said Maureen Thomas, of Columbus, Ohio. \u201cWhy wouldn\u2019t I?\u201d\n\nSeveral stories and photos from readers are below. Submissions have been edited for length and clarity.", "title": "Opinion | The Second Lives of Pussy Hats", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nThai red curry paste is the condiment that\u2019s started a thousand meals in my kitchen. Simmered with a little coconut milk, it becomes a fragrant, spicy sauce for all manner of meat, fish, vegetable, tofu or noodles. It\u2019s fast, convenient and tasty \u2014 better than my local takeout \u2014 which is all I ask for on most days of the week.\n\nThere are, however, times when I crave something a little more ambitious, a dish that\u2019s deeper, more complex and closer to the curries I can get in a good Thai restaurant. But I want it without having to track down the galangal, lime leaves and dried shrimp necessary to make an authentic Thai red curry paste from scratch.\n\nDoctoring up the stuff in the jar is a good middle ground. The prepared paste has the base flavor that I can build on by adding a few fresh aromatics \u2014 ones that I can easily pick up en route from the subway to my front door \u2014 garlic, chiles, cilantro, ginger and shallot. These can revive even an old half-used jar (the one that lives behind the miso and the tahini), giving it brightness and verve.\n\nIf you can\u2019t easily find the lemongrass, feel free to leave it out. There\u2019s already some in the jarred paste. And if you\u2019re lucky enough to come across a bumpy-skinned and highly aromatic makrut lime, whirl its zest and juice into the paste in place of the regular lime. It will make the curry even livelier.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOnce you\u2019ve done your shopping and chopping, the paste comes together quickly in the blender, and you\u2019ll have enough left over to make this dish again. Store the extra paste in the refrigerator for up to three weeks or the freezer for up to three months.\n\nPhoto\n\nAs for the noodles themselves, use any kind of thin noodles you like. Even gluten-free varieties work well as long as you don\u2019t overcook them. I generally lean toward skinny Chinese egg noodles because I like the added richness of the yolk. But springy rice noodles are a close second.\n\nThis dish requires a bit more work than your average weeknight dinner, and a lot more work than ordering in. But with its gorgeous combination of crunchy vegetables, slippery noodles and heady sauce, no one will ever guess it all started in a jar.", "title": "The Secret to Better Thai Dishes May Already Be in Your Fridge", "authors": ["Melissa Clark", "A Good Appetite"]} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "That is why many manuals offer advice for navigating communication traps. They counsel asking your partner whether it is a good time to talk (since couples routinely broach complicated topics on the fly), and striking a balance between empathy and problem-solving. If your partner is an avoider, don\u2019t give up trying to connect. If your partner is an emoter, stay compassionate and firm: \u201cI\u2019ll be able to respond better if you take it down a couple of notches.\u201d In bad moments, we all need these skills.\n\nIn our conflict-averse culture we don\u2019t necessarily think of these skills as part of romance. But I\u2019ve seen how the best marriages involve people who can deal with strong negative emotions \u2014 and who are cleareyed about how hard it can be. They don\u2019t avoid anger, but they don\u2019t indulge it. They tackle hard issues without shutting down. They apologize for their own bad behavior.\n\nWhat will matter most in marriage is what\u2019s possible on the other side of love\u2019s first blush: conversations that are rewarding, intimate and real. It\u2019s not that we come together in electric recognition and pure understanding, then fall away from that through conflict. Rather, we come together in a rush of passion, then we achieve love through continuing conversation.\n\nThrough that conversation we cultivate the essential emotional attitude in marriage: I can try to understand what you think and feel, without it taking away from my own experience. Your reality doesn\u2019t cancel out mine.\n\nAll this may seem an awfully low priority when the to-do list is a mile long and the wedding planner needs an answer now. But in married life, a sense of emotional emergency almost always means it\u2019s time to slow down. Emotions are often inconvenient.\n\nThe artist Georgia O\u2019Keeffe said, \u201cNobody sees a flower \u2014 really \u2014 it is so small it takes time \u2014 we haven\u2019t time \u2014 and to see takes time, like to have a friend takes time.\u201d What most people want from marriage is an intimate friend. The key to lasting love is taking time to understand and respond.\n\nA wedding is a one-shot celebration of tying the knot, but marriage is an open-ended practice of disentangling misunderstandings. I wish the newly engaged great happiness. I also wish that in between picking a caterer and a font for the invitations, they pause to think about how they fight, and how they want to talk.", "title": "Opinion | The Secret to a Happy Marriage Is Knowing How to Fight", "authors": []} {"date": "2017-12-31 00:00:00", "text": "Looking at this panoply of options for correcting errors of appearance I had carelessly committed with my 56-year-old skin and my drugstore moisturizer, I did not think, \u201cGosh, I should really look into getting myself some free-radical protection.\u201d What I thought was, \u201cWouldn\u2019t it be a luxury to spend any amount of time worrying about underarm sweat?\u201d What I thought was, \u201cI wish I lived in a world where my greatest worry was underarm sweat.\u201d\n\nI spent last year in mourning for my country. I volunteered on behalf of people imperiled by the results of the 2016 election. I wrote checks to resistance efforts, hoping they would make a bigger difference than I could make by myself, and blog posts about nature, hoping they would focus my mind on eternal things. The devastations \u2014 to the poor, to the environment, to immigrants, to people of many faiths and races, to our nation\u2019s very institutions \u2014 kept coming anyway. And all because a minority of my fellow citizens, through the auspices of an antique electoral system, had sent a lying, selfish, irrational, jingoistic, uneducable, race-baiting misogynist to the White House.\n\n\u201cYou\u2019re a sentient being, and this is a stressful time to be a sentient being,\u201d my longtime primary-care doctor said at my annual checkup in November. Since there is very little he can do to reform American politics, this wonderful doctor has devised an eating plan designed to reduce the flood of stress hormones into the bloodstream. He gave me a handwritten instruction sheet, suggesting I try it for a month after the holiday fire hose of brownies and Brie had shut down for another year.\n\nI wasn\u2019t completely convinced. Not all that long ago, I publicly disavowed diets, and my doctor\u2019s eating plan for sentient beings is so low in carbohydrates that it carries a strong whiff of dieting. Also, red wine does not appear on his list of permissible food items, so I made him no promises.\n\nInstead, I\u2019m pledging this year to fight despair any way I can. Not just my own despair, but the despair of people who largely put this president in office. A republic cannot survive in a state of cataclysmic despair. A democracy relies on optimism, but the very wealthy are the only people who have any reason to enter the new year in a state of optimism, and their giddiness won\u2019t last through even the first quarter of 2018. (Very wealthy people tend to be uncommonly gloomy. Which only goes to show that money truly can\u2019t buy love or happiness, though it can buy the United States Congress.)", "title": "Opinion | The Sentient-Being Diet", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "Consider our broken bail system. On any given day, some 450,000 Americans languish in jails without being convicted of a crime. A great majority of them simply can\u2019t pay bail. Nonprofits like the Bronx Freedom Fund and the Bail Project have emerged to address this problem. These initiatives offer to pay bond for some of the poor people charged with crimes. Their work is fundamental. Just one night in jail can cause a person to lose his or her job, home or even custody of children.\n\nAnother inventive fix is the free repair clinics for brake lights now run by several local chapters of the Democratic Socialists of America. These chapters have been conducting these clinics because broken car lights are one of the main reasons police stop undocumented immigrants and people of color, and give them tickets \u2014 police encounters that can lead to brutality or even death.\n\nBut these programs, though wonderful and needed, shouldn\u2019t have to exist in the first place. Of course, they should be praised and supported. But they should also be understood for what they are: temporary palliatives that we should not accept as long-term solutions. Changes in policing tactics are indeed the key.\n\nYet the repair clinics and bail funds and the broader shadow social net must exist because the world we exist in can seem dangerously close nowadays to a dystopia. As a character says in \u201cChildren of Men,\u201d a science fiction novel and film about a future of worldwide infertility where a few hardy souls try to save the human race on their own: \u201cI can\u2019t really remember when I last had any hope and I certainly can\u2019t remember when anyone else did either.\u201d It can seem as if America is a ship and we are stuffing rags into its hull, but the view from steerage is that this ship is going down.\n\nTo be transparent, I run a nonprofit that supports journalists reporting on inequality. I believe that the hard work and good intentions of many nonprofit organizations are saving America\u2019s soul. Some of our group\u2019s reporters might stay on welfare or food stamps if we didn\u2019t underwrite their efforts, given the diminished status of news gathering today. Our organization shouldn\u2019t need to exist. But it is very necessary.\n\nAs we embark on a new year, we should consider the tragedy of the dystopian social net and be thankful for its existence \u2014 for now.", "title": "Opinion | The Shadow Safety Net", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-20 00:00:00", "text": "A result is that Congress hasn\u2019t completed the entire budget process, with all the spending bills, on time in more than 20 years. Many years, it has not passed any budget resolution at all. This is perhaps the most basic responsibility of the legislative branch, yet for decades, Congress has repeatedly come up short.\n\nDuring the Obama administration, Republicans talked about changing this. Senator Mitch McConnell promised that he would pass a budget every year if and when Republicans gained a Senate majority. But in 2016 there was no budget resolution at all, which led us to the unusual situation we saw last year, where there were two budget resolutions, one to set up the failed Republican health care bill and another, later in the year, to set up tax reform.\n\nThat Congress can fail to pass a budget with so little consequence \u2014 if anything, it boosted Republicans, by giving them two opportunities to try major partisan legislation \u2014 shows what a cynical charade the process has become. The eventual budget resolutions that were passed reveal how disconnected the process has become from actual budgetary considerations. The Republican resolution a year ago was what\u2019s known as a \u201cshell budget\u201d \u2014 essentially just a set of instructions that would have allowed the health care bill to be passed with a simple majority vote.\n\nThe health care bill, whatever its merits, was not a budget, or a central component of anyone\u2019s conception of what a budget should be. But that\u2019s what the budget resolution was used for. And that is, in many ways, the problem: The budget process is not really about budgeting anymore.\n\nIn other years, the budget process has become bogged down, and Congress has kept the government funded through temporary extensions known as continuing resolutions (C.R.s) that fund government operations based on current levels, or rolled everything into an omnibus \u2014 or in some cases, a \u201cCRomnibus,\u201d combining a budget omnibus bill and a continuing resolution. It\u2019s kludgy language to describe a kludgy process.\n\nThe reliance on an ad hoc system of budgeting has made it even more difficult for Congress to keep the nation\u2019s fiscal house in order. The continuing resolution passed by the House this week would have added about $30 billion to the national debt.\n\nThe stalemates that have come to define the budget process have helped set the stage for repeated shutdown showdowns. It is a broken process that has enabled and empowered partisan bad faith by setting up a situation in which everything is riding on a few enormous bills. So lawmakers try to hook other priorities \u2014 immigration, say, or health care \u2014 to \u201cmust pass\u201d legislation in hopes of using the leverage to push them through.\n\nFrom a purely tactical perspective, pursuing political objectives to the point of a shutdown is rarely an effective strategy. The last government shutdown, in 2013, grew out of Republican opposition to Obamacare, which at the time was an unpopular program. The shutdown started on the same day the health law\u2019s insurance exchanges opened, and crashed \u2014 but during the few weeks the government was closed, Obamacare actually grew more popular. I am highly sympathetic to the plight of the Dreamers who have become central to the current fight, but I would not be surprised if this shutdown goes for Democrats the way the last one did for Republicans.", "title": "Opinion | The Shutdown Shows the Twisted Rules of a Broken Congress", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Mehsud and his family are part of a community of hundreds of thousands of Pashtuns who used to live in the tribal areas of Pakistan and were displaced to Karachi over years of violence with the Taliban and other militant groups that dominated some of those places.\n\nMr. Mehsud\u2019s relatives insist that he has never had militant ties and was targeted just because he was Pashtun. \u201cWe\u2019re still in shock about what happened,\u201d said Manzoor Ahmed, a family friend and social activist. \u201cHis entire family is trying to understand why this happened to Naqeebullah.\u201d\n\nAn internal police investigation into the supposed Taliban shootout supports the family\u2019s side of events, finding the superintendent\u2019s account of the clash \u201cdoubtful\u201d and uncovering no apparent links between Mr. Mehsud and any militant group.\n\nPhoto\n\nWhat he did have, however, was a Facebook page with a large following, fans of the glamorous photos he posted as he tried to develop a modeling career. When news of Mr. Mehsud\u2019s death was posted there, it spread quickly.\n\nOutraged fans and activists rejected the characterization of Mr. Mehsud as a militant, claiming his innocence with posts under #JusticeforNaqeeb. Protesters took to the streets of Karachi in the days after, demanding that the commander be removed.\n\nSuperintendent Anwar\u2019s crusading style and triumphant announcements of terrorists killed or arrested had made him a regular on Karachi television over the years. But for just as long, his name and claims had become bywords for suspicious police encounters. Though he has been suspended several times since joining the force in 1984, nothing has ever stuck, and he has inevitably resumed his post after a few days or weeks.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box.
