View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThis time seems different. The superintendent was dismissed outright on Saturday. And after he failed to appear for a mandatory interview before the National Commission for Human Rights on Monday, the local police said they were preparing to issue an arrest warrant if he skips another session.\n\nOn Tuesday, the former superintendent was turned away by immigration officers at Rawalpindi\u2019s international airport \u2014 roughly 900 miles north of Karachi \u2014 when he tried to take a flight to Dubai, officials said. In a long statement he released by WhatsApp afterward, Mr. Anwar appeared to put the blame for Mr. Mehsud\u2019s death on Pakistan\u2019s weak judicial system, in effect saying that he did what he had to do.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cKarachi, don\u2019t forget the blasts. Karachi, don\u2019t forget the target killings,\u201d he wrote. \u201cIf you take that into consideration, then you know that some of the work that should have been done by judges was done by officers like Rao Anwar.\u201d\n\nMr. Anwar may be the biggest focus of criticism right now, but concerns about the security\u2019s forces methods are far from uncommon. A 2016 Human Rights Watch report found several police officers \u201copenly admitted to the practice of false or faked \u2018encounter killings,\u2019 in which the police stage an armed exchange to kill an individual already in custody.\u201d By the Karachi police\u2019s own estimation, \u201c184 criminals and 73 terrorists\u201d were killed in roughly 480 police encounters in 2017 alone.\n\n\u201cThis isn\u2019t a recent phenomenon,\u201d said Amir Rana, director of the Pak Institute for Peace Studies, an independent think tank based in Islamabad. Mr. Rana said it had been difficult to get successful convictions of militants through the courts, leaving the police and other security forces more likely to simply shoot to kill. \u201cThe easiest solution to that problem for agencies is extrajudicial killings,\u201d he said.\n\nThough many law enforcement agencies in Karachi stand accused of similar tactics to Mr. Anwar\u2019s, they appear to be responding to public outrage by closing ranks against him.\n\n\u201cThis is an opportunity to deter extrajudicial and unjust killings, and for law enforcement to correct itself,\u201d said the head of Karachi\u2019s counterterrorism department, Sanaullah Abbasi. \u201cIt\u2019s an opportunity to give justice to the people.\u201d", "title": "The Slain \u2018Militant\u2019 Was a Model, and a Karachi Police Commander Is Out", "authors": ["Meher Ahmad"]} {"date": "2018-01-21 00:00:00", "text": "Juan Villacis wakes each morning, looks at the bedroom ceiling and is hit by the sobering realization that he is far from home. Until November, he and his family had carved out a modest life in the Woodhaven neighborhood of Queens, where he and his wife worked as physical therapists while their twin daughters completed college. They are a close-knit family who paid taxes, kept up their house and stayed out of trouble.\n\nAnd now they are being deported.\n\nDenied political asylum, they are seeing the slow-motion unraveling of their immigrant family. Mr. Villacis, 57, was deported in December to Quito, Ecuador, the country where he was born, but where he has not lived for 31 years. His wife, Liany Guerrero, had been ordered to return to her native Colombia last week \u2014 which she and her family fled in 2001 to escape rebel threats of violence and kidnapping \u2014 but serious medical issues resulted in her getting a final 30-day extension for treatment of breast cysts and other conditions. Their twin daughters, 22, who came to this country when they were 5, are facing uncertainty given the congressional debate over the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals program, or DACA, that would allow them to stay and work.\n\nAll of this has played out at a time when President Trump has maligned immigrants from Haiti and Africa while sending conflicting messages about what will be done with DACA.\n\n\u201cIt breaks my heart that families all over the country are dealing with this,\u201d said Jillian Hopman, the family\u2019s lawyer. \u201cAs we\u2019ve seen over the past week with what we thought was going to be reform with DACA, I don\u2019t think Trump knows what he wants. It\u2019s only a political thing to appease his base. But I find it just disgusting and unnecessarily cruel that they\u2019re not looking at any of these people as individuals.\u201d", "title": "The Slow-Motion Unraveling of an Immigrant Family", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-29 00:00:00", "text": "Imagine this: The author of the most popular book in the country goes on Bill Maher\u2019s show and says the following about President Barack Obama: \u201cThere is something in the book that I was absolutely sure of but it was so incendiary that I just didn\u2019t have the ultimate proof,\u201d he says. \u201cI didn\u2019t have the blue dress.\u201d\n\nThe host pushes the coy writer for a hint. \u201cYou just have to read between the lines toward the end of the book,\u201d the writer answers. \u201cWhen you hit that paragraph you\u2019re going to say, \u2018Bingo!\u2019\u201d\n\nWithin moments, every person with a copy turns to the last bit. The woman\u2019s name jumps out as if it was printed in boldface: Samantha Power, the United Nations ambassador. \u201cThe president has been spending a notable amount of private time,\u201d the book says, with her on Air Force One.\n\nDo I have to tell you what the reaction to this rumor-mongering would be? Heads would explode on every cable channel (except for Fox, of course, which would be calling for a special investigation). Editorials would issue forth condemning this gutter journalism as thinly veiled sexism. Some would insist that it be viewed as a #MeToo moment \u2014 unambiguous evidence of the deep discomfort men feel in the face of powerful women.", "title": "Opinion | The Slut-Shaming of Nikki Haley", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "Martin McDonagh: He was seen as a shoo-in in the best director category, after earning Directors Guild and Golden Globe nominations for \u201cThree Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri,\u201d a heavy favorite in the Oscar race. Chances are that Mr. McDonagh was edged out by Paul Thomas Anderson, whose \u201cPhantom Thread\u201d ended up with six nominations.\n\n\u201cJane\u201d: This documentary by Brett Morgen about the beloved primatologist Jane Goodall had all the markings of an Oscar hit. It won precursor awards and nominations, including a best documentary prize from the Producers Guild, earned a 99 percent \u201cfresh\u201d rating on Rotten Tomatoes, and held the top spot on many prognosticators\u2019 lists. Yet the academy\u2019s documentary branch voters largely opted for grittier fare.\n\nJessica Chastain: Given the competition for best actress, it wasn\u2019t a shocker that this two-time nominee was passed over for her lead performance in Aaron Sorkin\u2019s \u201cMolly\u2019s Game.\u201d Playing a former ski champion who runs a high-stakes poker game, Ms. Chastain displayed a variant of the detached steeliness that has been a through-line in many of her recent characters (in, for example \u201cZero Dark Thirty\u201d and \u201cA Most Violent Year\u201d) but it wasn\u2019t enough to woo the academy.\n\nArmie Hammer: He has been working hard in recent years to break from commercial fare. He portrayed a conflicted slave owner in the 2016 \u201cThe Birth of a Nation,\u201d and, more stirringly, a golden-boy graduate student who falls for a teenage boy in \u201cCall Me by Your Name,\u201d a gay coming-of-age story set in Italy. The performance earned him a nomination for a Golden Globe but not a SAG Award, which meant the Oscar nomination was a tougher get.\n\n\u201cThe Big Sick\u201d and Holly Hunter: Kumail Nanjiani and his wife, Emily V. Gordon, drew this tenderhearted rom-com from their own love story, which also served as a window into the dislocation and racism endured by immigrants \u2014 especially Muslim ones. Still, the film was indubitably a comedy, a genre that academy members tend to dismiss as lightweight, making it a long shot for best picture, even if it did earn a Screen Actors Guild Award nomination for best ensemble. Holly Hunter was expected to get a supporting actress nomination, but was also left out. The film landed just one nomination, for best original screenplay.\n\nSteven Spielberg: \u201cThe Post\u201d had all the trappings of a traditional Oscar shoo-in \u2014 Meryl Streep, Tom Hanks, a story from the history books that feels more urgent than ever \u2014 and while it claimed a spot on the best-picture list, Mr. Spielberg was outshone by fresher up-and-coming directors like Greta Gerwig and Jordan Peele. This is a pattern the academy tends to hew to when it comes to Mr. Spielberg, a two-time Oscar-winning director. \u201cWar Horse\u201d and \u201cBridge of Spies\u201d both ended up with nods for best picture but not director.", "title": "The Snubs and Surprises of the 2018 Oscar Nominations", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "I haven\u2019t been paying a lot of attention to quarterly GDP numbers. For one thing, they do tend to bounce around a lot; for another, claims that a good number in a particular quarter somehow validates the Trumpian claim to be able to achieve high growth for a decade are almost too stupid to argue with.\n\nBut there are a couple of points I think are worth making about growth over the past year.\n\nFirst, as Jason Furman notes, a good part of the 2.5% growth seems to be cyclical \u2013 the result of the economy moving closer to full employment, not a pickup in the underlying growth rate of potential output, which looks more like 1% than the 3% Trump et al need to make their numbers work.\n\nSecond, as Jason also notes, that cyclical expansion doesn\u2019t look too healthy when you look at it closely. It is not being driven mainly by rising business investment. Here\u2019s biz investment as a share of GDP in recent years: it bounces around some, largely because of the rise, fall, and partial recovery of fracking, but is not especially high:", "title": "Opinion | The Spendthrift Economy", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "As a child growing up in Bulgaria, Guenadiy Lazarov was mesmerized by great accordionists tearing off serpentine melodies over uneven Balkan rhythms, as they played for tips at weddings and parties.\n\n\u201cThe accordion was king \u2014 there was a special respect for the instrument in our culture,\u201d said Mr. Lazarov, who runs one of the last accordion repair shops in the New York City area.\n\nThe Accordion Gallery, his small showroom and repair shop in a nondescript house in New Jersey, is where many of today\u2019s accordion kings \u2014 from polka stars to Charlie Giordano, an accordionist who plays with Bruce Springsteen \u2014 go to have their instruments maintained and repaired.\n\nMr. Lazarov began playing the accordion when he was 10 and continued to play professionally on the side even while pursuing a career in physics.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn his hands, the accordion seems like some magical music box, but inside it is a complex network of mechanical rods and reeds that can sometimes confound even a trained physicist.", "title": "The Squeezebox Surgeon", "authors": ["Corey Kilgannon", "Character Study"]} {"date": "2018-01-13 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nWhile the lives of squid are mysterious in many ways, one gruesome truth is that after mating comes death.\n\nFirst the male dies. Next the female, after making a little pouch of eggs, begins to starve.\n\n\u201cShe is unable to feed because the egg mass is in front of the mouth,\u201d explains Henk-Jan Hoving, a deep sea biologist at Geomar Helmholtz Centre for Ocean Research in Kiel, Germany. \u201cShe probably gets energy from the breakdown of her own tissue, either from the liver or the mental tissue. This is how she stays alive, basically.\u201d\n\nThen, once the female is dead and the eggs have hatched, her body will often float to the ocean\u2019s surface and get eaten by birds.\n\nMore Reporting on Octopuses, Squid and Cuttlefish\n\nBut for some species, it appears, the bodies sink. In a paper published recently in Proceedings of the Royal Society B, Dr. Hoving and colleagues at the Monterey Bay Aquarium Research Institute, where he was formerly a researcher, described happening upon the remains of 64 squid and squid egg cases during dives with a remotely operated vehicle or ROV in Mexico\u2019s Gulf of California. If squid in other locations are also found to drift to the bottom like this, they may play a previously unidentified part in the ocean\u2019s role as a storage place for carbon, which could have implications for the study of climate change.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nDr. Hoving recalls the 2012 trip when the researchers first realized they were seeing something interesting. \u201cWhen we visited the bottom of one of the dives with the ROVs, we saw a dead squid and then another one,\u201d he says. Video footage from other outings to the area also showed bodies, they later learned, and in 2015 they returned again, finding more squid carcasses scattered across the floor, some nearly 10,000 feet down.", "title": "The Squid That Sink to the Ocean\u2019s Floor When They Die", "authors": ["Veronique Greenwood"]} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "In the current governor\u2019s race, Hart has endorsed Mike Johnston, 43, a Democrat who left the Colorado Senate last January, after eight years. Johnston has Kennedyesque looks, polished speaking skills, policy fluency and a detailed pitch for what he told me was one of the biggest challenges not just for Coloradans but for all Americans: \u201cWhat does the future of work look like in an era of automation?\u201d\n\nHe wants to provide Coloradans at any point in their careers with up to two years of debt-free education or training; in return, they\u2019d do some sort of state service. \u201cIt\u2019s like a civilian version of the National Guard,\u201d he said.\n\nAlthough he has been raising funds at a brisk pace, the low limits on political contributions in Colorado mean that he\u2019d be hard pressed to match Polis\u2019s financial resources and might need aid from outside groups. That would open him up to charges from Polis that he\u2019s indebted to special interests.\n\nPolis has already made a big public deal of not taking any donations over $100. But he can do that because he\u2019s worth tens of millions of dollars. When I twice asked him whether there was a limit to how much of his own wealth he\u2019d pump into the race, he twice didn\u2019t answer, merely noting that he\u2019s \u201cinvesting alongside\u201d more than 3,000 donors to his campaign so far and feels good about that precisely because so many Coloradans clearly feel good about him.\n\nBetween Johnston, Polis and Cary Kennedy, 49, the former state treasurer, Democrats have three politicians under the age of 50 to consider, which may be why Donna Lynne, the state\u2019s lieutenant governor, pointedly said to me: \u201cI\u2019m a young 64. I\u2019ll challenge any of them to get up a mountain faster than I can.\u201d She\u2019s the Democratic candidate with 58 summits to her credit.\n\nFormerly a high-ranking official with the health care giant Kaiser Permanente, she frames herself as a restrained, responsible executive, in a way that traces the fault line between progressives and moderates in the party. \u201cFree college, free kindergarten \u2014 you need a realistic plan to achieve these, because voters have rejected tax increases,\u201d she told me. As it just so happens, free daylong kindergarten for all Coloradan children is one of Polis\u2019s three signature proposals.\n\nOn both the Democratic and Republican sides, there are candidates selling themselves as disrupters who would bring private-sector savvy into government. What else explains Mr. Trump\u2019s talk about North Korea and nuclear weapons? Purging federal employees, while it may satisfy the president\u2019s need to punish his enemies, would mean, given his hiring record, that there would be fewer people in place to uphold our laws and carry out policies that help millions of Americans. The historic lows in African-American and Latino unemployment that he mentioned last night are partly a direct result of the productivity of hundreds of thousands of workers he wishes to deport.\n\nPresident Trump made tokens of his minority guests, which underscored the point that he doesn\u2019t quite consider nonwhite people to be on a par with white Americans. Corey Adams, a black welder, was brought out as cover for the tax cut his employers at Staub Manufacturing Solutions in Dayton, Ohio, received under the Republicans\u2019 tax plan. Mr. Adams was in fact a reminder that working-class black people could reap minuscule benefits from tax cuts that will largely make the rich richer. But that\u2019s not all: President Trump also needed to tell us that Mr. Adams was an \u201call-American worker\u201d to assure his xenophobic base that Mr. Adams couldn\u2019t possibly hail from somewhere else.\n\nPresident Trump also introduced us to Celestino Martinez, an Immigration and Customs Enforcement agent who led an operation on Long Island to track down gang members, including members of MS-13. Mr. Trump introduced Mr. Martinez right after saying, \u201cAmericans are dreamers, too,\u201d to insult recipients of Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals and illustrate that his American dream, instead of meaning the freedom to seek refuge on our shores and work toward a satisfying future, is based on arresting gang members. To make a Latino the face of ICE is a wink to Mr. Trump\u2019s base. It also says that Latinos can be trusted to follow the Trump agenda and throw people who look like them out of the country if they need to.\n\nThe most egregious case of tokenism was that of Evelyn Rodriguez and Freddy Cuevas, a couple whose daughter, Kayla Cuevas, was killed by MS-13 gang members on Long Island in 2016. Three days ago, Ms. Rodriguez said in an interview that she was happy to be invited to attend the State of the Union address but that her attendance wasn\u2019t about immigration. \u201cI want him to ensure that we\u2019re going to get the proper funding for the resources for our kids,\u201d she said. \u201cI\u2019m not here for anyone\u2019s political gain.\u201d She added, \u201cEveryone has the right to the American dream, and that should be there for them.\u201d", "title": "Opinion | The State of the (White Nationalist) Union", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-31 00:00:00", "text": "We\u2019d start with the fact that the administration has pushed to dismantle nearly all federal regulations related to climate change. That includes the Clean Power Plan to reduce emissions from power plants and a federal flood standard that would have required new infrastructure projects to prepare for a changing climate. (See our updated deregulation tracker for the full list.) And it includes a disavowal of the Paris climate agreement.\n\nBut you\u2019d also want to note that Mr. Trump hasn\u2019t been able to halt many of the most important trends around the country toward lower emissions. Plenty of states, like California and New York, are still pressing ahead with their own local climate policies. The coal industry, responsible for a quarter of the nation\u2019s emissions, continues to shrink, edged out of the energy market by less expensive natural gas despite Mr. Trump\u2019s efforts to save it.\n\nOn top of that, the cost of wind and solar continues to drop rapidly as technology advances. Even after Mr. Trump\u2019s recent tariffs on solar imports, more utilities are turning to renewable energy as the lowest-cost source of new power. Electric vehicles are making inroads. Other countries are still crafting an international climate treaty without the United States.\n\nIt\u2019s fair to say that those two broad dynamics \u2014 the Trump administration\u2019s regulatory rollbacks and the stubborn march of clean energy \u2014 have fought each other to a standstill. America\u2019s carbon-dioxide emissions fell to a 25-year low in 2017, though some forecasters think they could rise slightly this year. When it comes to climate action, the country is in a holding pattern.\n\nThe catch, as scientists have warned, is that we\u2019ve reached the point on climate change where a holding pattern is no longer sufficient to give us a decent shot at stabilizing global temperatures this century and avoiding irreversible changes to Earth\u2019s weather patterns, polar caps and fragile ecosystems. It won\u2019t be enough for emissions in the United States and other major economies to flatline or decline slowly in the years ahead. They need to fall sharply to nearly zero by midcentury. Even a few years of delay could make that task much harder.", "title": "The State of the Climate, One Year Into the Trump Era", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-29 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nArticle II, Section 3 of the United States Constitutions stipulates: The president \u201cshall from time to time give to the Congress Information of the State of the Union, and recommend to their Consideration such Measures as he shall judge necessary and expedient.\u201d\n\nWill you be watching President Trump\u2019s first State of the Union address? Why or why not?\n\nUntil the start of the speech, we invite students to share their predictions for it.\n\nThen, starting at 9 p.m. Eastern on Tuesday, we invite students to share their reactions as they watch and we live-moderate comments. The forum will stay open for student reactions throughout the week and beyond.\n\nIn \u201cState of the Union Preview: Will Trump Stick to the Script?,\u201d Michael D. Shear and Mark Landler write:\n\nWASHINGTON \u2014 President Trump has spent his first year in office breaking every rule of presidential communication, conducting policymaking and diplomacy by Twitter and eschewing the careful, subdued tones of most presidents in favor of no-holds-barred attacks on his adversaries and allies alike. But on Tuesday, Mr. Trump will embrace the most traditional of presidential venues \u2014 appearing before a joint session of Congress for his first State of the Union address \u2014 to deliver what aides describe as an optimistic speech that will seek to reach beyond the people who voted for him in 2016. If he sticks to the script, the president is expected to call on Congress to spend at least $1 trillion to rebuild bridges, freeways, sewers and airports. And he will use the speech to lobby millions of viewers on behalf of his plan to make a series of conservative changes to the nation\u2019s immigration system while also granting citizenship to as many as 1.8 million young immigrants. But if his first year has proved anything, it is that there are no guarantees when Mr. Trump faces a television camera. Cabinet meetings have veered into presidential rants. Memorial speeches have turned into self-congratulatory moments. Short photo ops have become long news conferences. \u201cTeleprompter Trump sounds like a regular president,\u201d said Michael Waldman, who was director of speechwriting for President Bill Clinton from 1995 to 1999 and wrote four State of the Union speeches. \u201cOff-the-Teleprompter Trump sounds like a fill-in radio talk show host.\u201d When Mr. Trump delivered his first address to a joint session of Congress last February \u2014 not technically a State of the Union speech \u2014 he offered a mostly optimistic vision of America, speaking soberly and almost verbatim from a prepared text. But former speechwriters said traditional State of the Union speeches were a poor fit for Mr. Trump because they tended to be long lists of policy proposals, cobbled together over months in a process that involves agency employees across the federal government. During his first year, the president showed only a sporadic interest in the nuts and bolts of policymaking. Jonathan Horn, who was a speechwriter for President George W. Bush, said Mr. Trump\u2019s Twitter habit could undermine the political benefits of the speech. Hovering over the address is an accelerating Russia investigation and a congressional stalemate over spending. \u201cThe next day there could be a tweet, and then the work on a very, very long speech is overshadowed by 280 characters,\u201d said Mr. Horn, who was part of a team that drafted Mr. Bush\u2019s 2008 State of the Union address.\n\nStudents: Read the entire article, then post a comment.\n\nPredictions before the State of the Union address:\n\n\u2014 What predictions can you make about this address? What will the president say? What topics will he take on? What tone do you expect him to take? But Democrats were more ruthless in their mockery.", "title": "The State of the Union Is \u2026 Misspelled", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-07 00:00:00", "text": "By Tara Dennis\n\nHave you ever stepped on a bee before? I have. Many times.\n\nWhen we were kids, we could tell summer was fast approaching when the purple flowers from the jacaranda trees would begin to fall, making a thick blanket of purple petals on the driveway.\n\nWhile beautiful in theory, and eye-catching from afar, in reality the flowers were cause for anxiety. We knew we\u2019d soon be asked to complete the dreaded cleanup every weekend until the flowers had run their cycle.\n\nThe flowers, beautiful when dangling from a branch, would turn into dirty brown mush once on the ground and smashed by my parents routinely driving their cars over them. That mush was as slippery as socks on a timber floor, but more dangerously it would attract bees. Lots of bees.", "title": "The Sting of Spring", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-03 00:00:00", "text": "Three related species of manakins occupy adjacent parcels of the Amazon rain forest: Opal-crowned, snow-capped and golden-crowned. They are all plump like sparrows, small enough to cup in a hand and have radiant yellow-green upper bodies with golden undersides.\n\nBiologists are now unlocking the mystery of how these neighboring birds became distinct species. Last week, a team of scientists confirmed in Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences that the golden-crowned manakin is a unique hybrid species that emerged from a cross between the opal-crowned and snow-capped manakins about 180,000 years ago.\n\nThough one-off mating events between different species occur across the animal kingdom \u2014 think pizzly bears, occasional crosses between polar and grizzly bears \u2014 the establishment of an entirely separate hybrid species is thought to be relatively rare.", "title": "The Strange Origin of a Manakin\u2019s Golden Crown", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "Like most struggling artists, Harry Bertschmann is hoping to be discovered. Unlike them, he already has a pedigree: he has shown his work alongside Mark Rothko, Franz Kline and Robert Motherwell while they were still alive and in their prime. In 1958, a large Bertschmann canvas was featured in the Carnegie International exhibition in Pittsburgh, a rarefied achievement for any artist, let alone one in his mid-20s. Since then, Mr. Bertschmann has painted or drawn nearly every day of his adult life, producing a body of work that has been praised by some of the art world\u2019s foremost tastemakers. Yet he has remained virtually unknown.\n\n\u201cI had to make money,\u201d Mr. Bertschmann, 86, said one morning in late November as he sat at the dining table of his light-filled, art-filled apartment-studio near the South Street Seaport. And he did, working as a freelance graphic designer creating logos, packaging and advertising for brands like Pond\u2019s cold cream and Bufferin. His success at his day job ensured that he wasn\u2019t hungry, and while he has produced thousands (he has no idea how many thousands) of fine-art paintings, drawings and collages in wildly varied styles, he never persistently sought gallery representation.\n\n\u201cHarry\u2019s never been a salesman,\u201d said Mary Bertschmann, his wife of more than 50 years. \u201cHe didn\u2019t get his art out there for them to see.\u201d Nor did he carouse with his more exhibitionistic contemporaries at Cedar Tavern, participate in splashy happenings or attract art-world gossip. \u201cAlso, we had started our own small press, and Harry was doing great designs for Harper & Row, like this wonderful thing,\u201d she said, pointing to a fetchingly illustrated poetry anthology published in the 1970s. \u201c We were so into our world, plus, of course, with a child.\u201d\n\nOver the years there were some exhibitions and acquisitions, notably a 140-work retrospective in 1997 of both his commercial and fine art in Basel, Switzerland, where Mr. Bertschmann was born and raised. But these accomplishments never amounted to a self-sustaining fine art career. As he reached his 80s, humility and obscurity started getting old, and costly.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nNow the Bertschmanns find themselves in a tenuous financial position. Mr. Bertschmann no longer does much graphic design, and Mrs. Bertschmann recently retired as the executive director of the Huguenot Society of America. She said that they have been \u201csuffering financially.\u201d Despite living in a lofty one-bedroom apartment near the South Street Seaport, they are retired renters who will not benefit from the gentrification of the neighborhood.\n\nPhoto\n\nOn the bright side, she added, a man named Peter Hastings Falk had arranged for a couple of gallery owners to visit in December.", "title": "The Struggling Artist at 86", "authors": ["Susan Chumsky"]} {"date": "2018-01-29 00:00:00", "text": "The governor\u2019s proposal has opened yet another front in his continuing war with Mayor Bill de Blasio, a Democrat whose aides maintain that Mr. Cuomo\u2019s value capture plan would commandeer the process of setting property taxes, a paramount responsibility of the city. They said state officials never discussed the proposal with the city. \u201cThis is not the way to address the problems of the M.T.A.,\u201d the first deputy mayor, Dean Fuleihan, said.\n\nMichael Slattery, the senior vice president of research for the Real Estate Board of New York, which represents New York\u2019s developers, said the proposal \u201craises serious questions that need to be evaluated, especially when it deals with a property tax system that we know already has serious problems.\u201d\n\nThere is little dispute that access to public transit often results in higher real estate prices. Neighborhoods like trendy Williamsburg in Brooklyn would not have had a resurgence without the access provided by the L line, whose ridership grew at three times the rate of the system as a whole from 1998 to 2012 and which has benefited from an upgraded signal system that allows more trains to run.\n\nThe Cuomo proposal calls for before and after assessments in neighborhoods where a new transportation project, like the extension of a subway line, raises property values. Officials would determine the difference between the previous assessment and the new, higher one.\n\nVideo\n\nOf the tax on that difference, 75 percent would go to the transit agency and 25 percent to the city.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s not going to pay in its entirety for the capital requirements for any one project,\u201d said Patrick J. Foye, the president of the transit authority, \u201cbut it could over years or decades provide significant new funding.\u201d\n\nWhether value capture could work, given the antagonism between City Hall and Albany, is an open question. Carl Weisbrod, who was named to the transit agency\u2019s board by Mr. de Blasio and was the chairman of the city\u2019s Planning Commission from 2014 until early last year, said value capture demanded \u201cclose cooperation between the M.T.A. and the city on a case-by-case basis.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cTo simply impose it on the city isn\u2019t going to work,\u201d he said.\n\nState officials said an existing four-person review panel would have the power to veto proposals the city opposed \u2014 and one member is appointed to represent the city. Joseph J. Lhota, the chairman of the transit agency, said that the panel \u201cworks under what I call U.N. Security Council rules,\u201d meaning that if one of the members is against a project, \u201cthe entire proposal goes down.\u201d\n\nSome public transportation advocates have been calling for special property taxes for years, and the M.T.A. raised the idea in December after a column by Jim Dwyer in The New York Times discussed the subway\u2019s impact on real estate values.\n\nAs proposed, the governor\u2019s value-capture plan would apply only to transit projects costing more than $100 million. It could not be used to pay for already completed projects, like the $4.4 billion segment of the Second Avenue subway. But it could raise money for future segments planned to extend that line north to 125th Street.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe proposal also listed other major projects that value capture could be applied to, including East Side Access, which will connect the Long Island Rail Road to Grand Central Terminal, as well as the existing Metro-North and subway stations along 125th Street in Manhattan.\n\nCity officials maintain that including railroad projects is unfair because they largely benefit suburban commuters who would not be charged under the governor\u2019s tax plan. Mr. Fuleihan, the first deputy mayor, said 70 percent of the revenue for the transit agency comes from the city through taxes and fares, but suburban commuters who use the subway once they arrive in the city pay nothing but the fare.\n\nThe governor\u2019s proposal would allow the transit agency to establish districts around new projects for value capture that could extend as far as a mile from a station. But city officials scoffed, arguing that living a mile from a stop is too far to consider it a convenience.\n\nWhat improved public transit can mean for a neighborhood is easy to see on the Upper East Side, which became a transit wasteland after elevated trains on Second and Third Avenues were demolished more than 60 years ago. Until the Second Avenue subway opened, residents on the eastern edge of the neighborhood had to trudge blocks to squeeze onto the Nos. 4, 5 and 6 trains on Lexington Avenue, the nation\u2019s most crowded subway line.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s all good, plus people love the way the stations look,\u201d said Lydia H. Sussek, a senior global real estate adviser with the Corcoran Group. \u201cI\u2019ve sold new condos as a result of it, and I had a couple who moved to East End Avenue knowing they\u2019d have transportation, whereas before people never would have looked east.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nChristian Moulin, a co-op owner who has lived on East 85th Street between York Avenue and East End Avenue for 17 years, said the Upper East Side used to be \u201cthe less expensive place \u2014 rents were reasonable.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThat\u2019s changing,\u201d he added, \u201cand it\u2019s all because of the subway.\u201d\n\nHe said one indication was that fliers from brokers seeking apartments now appear in his and his neighbors\u2019 mailboxes every couple of weeks. \u201cWe never had that before,\u201d he said.\n\nBeth Fisher, a senior managing director for the Corcoran Sunshine Marketing Group, which is handling sales for three new apartment buildings north of East 86th Street, said the distance to the subway had long been \u201ca metric for how people live\u201d but that value capture put too much of an emphasis on the subway\u2019s influence.\n\n\u201cThe Second Avenue subway, sure, is the protagonist, the key driver of value,\u201d she said. \u201cBut it is not the only driver. It ought not be singled out in that manner.\u201d\n\nValue capture is a familiar concept outside New York and has been used as a way to fund transit projects in other cities, including Los Angeles, Seattle, London and Hong Kong. In New York, Mr. Wright, of the Regional Plan Association, called the Second Avenue subway \u201ca lost opportunity\u201d in terms of value capture.\n\nThe extension of the No. 7 line to the Far West Side of Manhattan was financed by what amounted to value capture on Hudson Yards, the megaproject near the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center. Under Mr. de Blasio\u2019s predecessor, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, the city took the unusual step of offering to pay the $1.8 billion cost of the extension based on anticipated tax revenues.\n\nBut Mr. Wright cautioned that value capture in already developed neighborhoods would be more modest.\n\n\u201cIn developed areas \u2014 say, the Upper East Side where you\u2019re not looking at new virgin development on a rail yard, what you\u2019re talking about is increased values of buildings,\u201d he said. \u201cThe New York property tax system is such that that\u2019s not going to generate short-term and immediate returns.\u201d", "title": "The Subway Is Next Door. Should New Yorkers Pay Extra for That?", "authors": ["James Barron"]} {"date": "2018-01-31 00:00:00", "text": "It\u2019s not every morning that you get the opportunity to witness a triple lunar coincidence in the pre-dawn skies before you\u2019ve even brewed your coffee. But on Wednesday morning in the United States, early morning skygazers were treated to what the internet has dubbed a \u201csuper blue blood moon.\u201d (Many of you in Australia and eastern Asia got to see this during your Wednesday evening, in which case you might have needed to brew something strong to help you stay up).\n\nThere\u2019s a lot packed into that phrase \u201csuper blue blood moon.\u201d\n\n\u2022 A BLUE moon happens when there are two full moons within a single calendar month.\n\n\u2022 A supermoon occurs when the moon orbits closer to planet Earth than usual. There was a supermoon on Jan. 1 to start off the year, too. That\u2019s how we get a \u201cSUPER blue moon.\u201d\n\n\u2022 Now comes the \u201cblood part.\u201d During a lunar eclipse, Earth passes between the moon and the sun, and the planet casts its shadow over its lunar satellite. It\u2019s nothing like the spectacle of a total solar eclipse, but the red tinge the moon takes on is striking. And it gives us the \u201csuper blue BLOOD moon.\u201d", "title": "The Super Blue Blood Moon: Pictures From an Astronomical Hat Trick", "authors": ["The New York Times"]} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "Dr. Elwood got the idea for researching lobster pain about a dozen years ago at his local pub. Celebrity chef Rick Stein, known for his seafood dishes, was having a pint, and Dr. Elwood introduced himself. The chef stumped him by asking if lobsters felt pain when cooked.\n\nIn several studies since, Dr. Elwood has shown that crustaceans guard wounded limbs and avoid areas where they\u2019ve been shocked \u2014 even leaving their shells behind if necessary. When he traveled to Singapore, he said he watched as street sellers kept grabbing live crabs as they scuttled off a barbecue grill, keen to get away.\n\nHe\u2019s now convinced that those responses are the crustacean equivalent of pain. As David Foster Wallace observed in his famous article \u201cConsider the Lobster,\u201d lobsters remain the only animals we still kill in our own kitchens. We have to face the ethics of that decision, he noted, while we more easily ignore such feelings about other animals in our diet.\n\nBoiling might take as long as a minute to kill a lobster, long enough for it to suffer, Dr. Elwood said. A skilled chef who slices right into a lobster\u2019s head should be able to kill the animal faster, he said. \u201cThat should be a reasonable way of doing it.\u201d\n\nHe also mentioned a commercial device called a Crustastun that zaps the animal with electricity, promising to kill it instantly. The Swiss government cited electrocution as a preferred method of killing, though the Crustastun, which reportedly costs $3,400, is meant to be used by processors or large restaurants.\n\nDr. Ayers dismissed the method, saying he\u2019s seen animals moving for minutes after being stunned. He said he loves lobsters as much as anyone \u2014 he\u2019s devoted his career to studying them, and his son is a lobster fisherman \u2014 but he said he doesn\u2019t see a more humane way of killing lobsters than dunking them headfirst into a pot of boiling water.\n\nDr. Tlusty has an alternative strategy: He puts lobsters on ice to slow their nervous system before they meet the pot.", "title": "The Swiss Consider the Lobster. It Feels Pain, They Decide.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "M.G.M. may have seemed its invincible self, but behind the scenes there was panic. \u201cGee whiz, Louis,\u201d fretted the media baron (and movie producer) William Randolph Hearst to Mayer in a letter about the party recently discovered in Hearst\u2019s private archive and quoted here for the first time, \u201cdo you realize how damaging that is to the whole moving picture industry and fraternity?\u201d\n\n\u201cI am going to do everything I can now to help this situation, of course,\u201d promised Hearst. \u201cBut the public will be sympathetic with a poor little extra girl.\u201d\n\nDouglas gave no interviews, letting her lawsuit speak for itself. Meanwhile M.G.M. unleashed a smear campaign: Pinkerton detectives subjected her to surveillance; pressured her doctor to falsely say she had gonorrhea; and strong-armed fellow dancers to sign statements tagging her a promiscuous drunk. (In our own era, Harvey Weinstein would follow his forebears, hiring outside help to besmirch accusers.)\n\nA Los Angeles County judge dismissed Douglas\u2019s suit. Yet again she could have given up; instead the next day she refiled in United States District Court. For the first time in our nation\u2019s history, a woman made rape a federal case by invoking its violation of her civil rights.\n\nDouglas used every legal resource available to her, but a young dancer was no match for M.G.M., which best evidence shows now bought off her mother, the court-appointed guardian in her lawsuit. Blackballed by the studios, shunned as \u201cdamaged goods,\u201d Douglas disappeared without a trace, spending the rest of her life in seclusion. \u201cWe had her killed,\u201d I was told Mannix wisecracked. So thoroughly did M.G.M. expunge Patricia Douglas from the historical record that when I first stumbled upon her story, no reference source whatsoever cited her case, while a Google search of her name yielded nothing.\n\nIt\u2019s a brave new world now, though Douglas did not live to see it. Sixty-five years after her landmark lawsuit and just before her death in 2003, Douglas shrugged off her pioneering importance. \u201cIt wasn\u2019t for glory,\u201d she told me. \u201cIt was just to make them stop having those parties.\u201d In this sense, she achieved her aim: M.G.M. would never lure women under false pretenses to such events again.\n\nShe did so in another sense, too. \u201cThe truth will out,\u201d Douglas declares in \u201cGirl 27,\u201d and with each new account of sexual assault and harassment, her example serves as a call to arms. Injustice can thrive only in silence, and finally, thankfully, explosively, the story of Patricia Douglas and others like her now resonates in Hollywood and beyond. Sometimes winning is just being heard. And sometimes being heard is just the start of much more.", "title": "Opinion | The Systematic Crushing of a #MeToo Pioneer", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "Those figures suggested to American planners that pacification could target more than a quarter of the population and over half of the country\u2019s land area. Pacification on such a scale, however, was infeasible for the Saigon government to undertake, so only so-called priority villages \u2014 those near military bases, air fields, transportation arteries, and towns and cities \u2014 were subjected to pacification. Those under the control of Viet Cong were designated as \u201cfree fire zones\u201d and bombed and shelled, under the assumption that anyone who lived there was Viet Cong by definition.\n\nThe bombing and shelling drove people to flee into areas under government control in greater numbers. Statistics published in January 1975 by the Subcommittee to Investigate Problems Connected With Refugees and Escapees, part of the Senate Committee on the Judiciary, indicated that the number of refugees registered by the government in 1965 was 772,000. This number grew to 906,000 in 1966. By 1967, the government had registered 2.1 million refugees. In addition to those the government registered \u2014 those placed in squalid camps of dilapidated huts \u2014 there were an estimated two million who were not registered, including about one million in Saigon.\n\nIn mid-1967, Samuel Huntington of Harvard, working as a consultant to the State Department, visited Vietnam. On his return, he wrote an article in Foreign Affairs, \u201cThe Bases of Accommodation,\u201d in which he stated that \u201cthe most dramatic and far-reaching impact of the war in South Vietnam has been the tremendous shift in population from the countryside to the cities.\u201d\n\nHe went on to say, \u201cIn an absent-minded way the United States in Vietnam may well have stumbled upon the answer\u201d to the insurgency. The answer lies in \u201cforced-draft urbanization and modernization,\u201d which would drive the rural population from the villages into urban areas and deprive the insurgency the support it needed \u201cto generate enough strength to come to power.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Subscribe to the Vietnam \u201967 Newsletter This weekly newsletter includes eyewitness accounts, rare photos and historical insights about the Vietnam War. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAlthough Professor Huntington wrote that \u201cthe social costs of this change have been dramatic and often heart-rending,\u201d he ultimately believed that the forced movement of peasants was a positive outcome. The article shocked many people and turned Mr. Huntington into a controversial figure among those opposed to the war. Nevertheless, his piece significantly influenced the latter phases of pacification.\n\nAt first, pacification was left in the hands of the South Vietnamese armed forces. The policy changed in 1966 when the slow progress of pacification prompted an effort to speed it up, and the American Ninth Division was dispatched to Dinh Tuong, a province in the upper Mekong.\n\nThe division\u2019s mission was to act like a bulldozer, clearing the path for South Vietnamese officials and troops to move in and establish a government presence, and to keep the enemy\u2019s main force units from disrupting that effort. The ferocious operations by the Ninth Division and its enormous firepower inflicted heavy civilian casualties, culminating in operation Speedy Express in 1969, during which American forces counted 10,000 \u201cViet Cong\u201d killed but captured only 900 weapons.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn 1968, the insurgents carried the war to the towns and cities up and down the length and breadth of the country in the Tet offensive. American and South Vietnamese armed forces launched a furious counteroffensive, which inflicted additional destruction and casualties. Another million people were estimated to be displaced during the Tet offensive and another offensive in May 1968. The losses incurred by the Viet Cong during those counterattacks opened the way for the American and South Vietnamese governments to push an accelerated pacification program. The few restraints that had been in place to prevent indiscriminate killing of civilians were lifted, and the extensive use of firepower in populated areas was applied with deadly results to \u201cdrain the pond to catch the fish.\u201d\n\nOver the next year, large areas of the countryside became depopulated. Besides registered and unregistered refugees who fled from their villages, the displaced included peasants who simply moved to another hamlet or area in a hamlet, or who moved to an open field, away from the clumps of trees and vegetation targeted by bombing and shelling. As an added precaution, they began to wear white clothing instead of the usual peasant \u201cblack pajamas\u201d that Americans had come to associate with the Viet Cong, to avoid getting killed. In addition, there were also temporary refugees who moved in or out of a village for a few weeks at a time, or who would come back to their land occasionally to salvage what they could from their orchards.\n\nAs part of accelerated pacification, the C.I.A. created the Phoenix Program to root out the Viet Cong infrastructure. Critics of Phoenix have called it an assassination program, aimed at Viet Cong cadres as well as innocent civilians. Besides killing guilty and innocent alike, Phoenix also provided local officials and policemen a sanctioned program to abuse power with false arrests, settling of scores and extortion. Phoenix did seriously damage the Viet Cong infrastructure, but the cost was high for the government as well, since the program sowed fear, resentment and distrust among the population.\n\nPacification worked, in a narrow sense: By 1970, the Saigon government had control over a larger area of the country than it did five years before. However, the South Vietnamese Army, reluctant to take on Viet Cong and North Vietnamese forces, relied even more on bombing and shelling to retain and enlarge the gains made during the high tide of American military intervention. It also resorted to forced relocation of peasants remaining in the heavily contested and Viet Cong areas, destroying or burning the houses of those who refused to move closer to the military posts that had been erected so that they could be kept under close surveillance.\n\nIn the Central Highlands, Gen. Ngo Dzu, the regional commander, began an extensive program of forced relocation of the Montagnard ethnic minorities; given a few days\u2019 notice, thousands of villagers had to abandon their homes and belongings and move to dismal resettlement centers, where they lacked housing, water and health care. Hundreds died after being forced to relocate.\n\nThe cease-fire of 1973 did not bring peace to the battered rural area and its people. Before and after it went into effect, the government and the Communists each engaged in land-grabbing. The January 1975 report by the Senate subcommittee on refugees, issued a few months before the Communists defeated the South Vietnamese government and won the war, estimated that the total number of refugees had grown to 11.6 million.\n\nWhen the war ended, South Vietnam and its rural population had been profoundly transformed. Before fighting escalated, 80 percent of the people lived in the rural areas. By 1975, South Vietnam had gone through a \u201cforced-draft urbanization.\u201d The influx of refugees from the countryside into the urban areas had swelled their population, so that 65 percent of South Vietnamese were now living in towns and cities.\n\nThe war had taken from the peasants who had been driven into urban areas to find safety what they cherished most: the land that their forebears had walked and tilled, and the homes that had sheltered them for generations. It had also shattered the families that had sustained them from birth. These were the things that had made their life whole before they became victims of the Americans\u2019 \u201cforced-draft urbanization\u201d of their society, accomplished with bombing and shelling rather than with the industrialization that had \u201curbanized and modernized\u201d the United States and other Western countries.", "title": "The Terrible Violence of \u2018Pacification\u2019", "authors": ["Mai Elliott"]} {"date": "2018-01-09 00:00:00", "text": "To reduce waste and cut costs, Ms. Hofmann sifted through the boxes that had been sitting in the living room all those years, to see what could be salvaged. The cabinet interiors were put to good use \u2014 some of them to cover the exposed steam pipe \u2014 with new glossy white doors covering them. The backsplash tiles, however, were so old that they were falling apart, and after an unsuccessful attempt to save them, she substituted subway tile.\n\nMs. Hofmann, who said she doesn\u2019t ever \u201cthrow away anything that can be reused or repurposed,\u201d was also able to make a contribution of her own: A white oak door left over from another job was transformed into open shelving.\n\n\u201cHalina redesigned the tiny kitchen footprint with Jenga-like efficiency,\u201d said Ms. Yeoh, who was able to move three sets of china and her crystal collection into her new kitchen cabinets, emptying two alcoves that flank the living room fireplace.\n\nAnd it didn\u2019t hurt that Ms. Hofmann lived just a few blocks away, making it easy for her to pop in and offer extra hand-holding throughout the process. \u201cShe really took a lot of the anxiety out of the process,\u201d Ms. Yeoh said. \u201cMy general contractor is a unicorn.\u201d\n\nOnce the kitchen was complete, she continued, \u201cwe added cosmetic touches throughout the rest of the apartment, staining the original wood flooring black, replacing hollow with solid wood doors in the hallway, adding sconces from Restoration Hardware and dark floral wallpaper from Ellie Cashman Design \u2014 all on budget and on time.\u201d\n\nThe cost: $45,000, not including materials.\n\n\u201cIt was a process I was dreading at first,\u201d Ms. Yeoh said, recalling the frustration she felt over her false start. But \u201cI ended up saying, \u2018I want to do this again. What\u2019s my next project?\u2019\u201d", "title": "The Tiny Jenga Kitchen", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "9. In the Beauty Department, It Was Fifty Shades of Pink\n\nHaute couture week is always a feast for the eyes \u2014 and not just in terms of fashion. Beauty, too, is about fantasy, and an escape from the practicalities of everyday life. The spring/summer 2018 couture season proved to be a good one for makeup artists, as the trend of natural fresh faces was less prevalent than it has been during recent ready-to-wear seasons. Instead, many shows featured beautiful color on the face, especially in terms of blush. At Chanel, models\u2019 cheeks were rosy pink, and at Armani, a pastel pink blush was applied on the apples of the cheeks and extended up to the temple. The look became more extreme at RDVK; it could only be described as \u201980s, Kabuki-style rouge. \u2014 M.J.G.\n\nImage Hedi Slimane Credit Getty Images\n\n10. Hedi Slimane\u2019s Move to Celine Was the News of the Week\n\nOn a quiet Sunday in Paris, the fashion industry was alerted to the most unexpected news: that Hedi Slimane would be taking the reins at C\u00e9line, following the departure of Phoebe Philo. Since he left Saint Laurent in 2016, rumors have circulated about where he would end up. Many speculated that he would return to LVMH, but Celine was a total surprise. Slimane devotees were elated \u2014 especially with the announcement that Slimane will introduce men\u2019s wear to Celine \u2014 while Philo loyalists worried that they may have to trade in their voluminous trousers for skinny jeans. Either way, the appointment is exciting \u2014 and we\u2019re looking forward to seeing what Slimane dreams up come September. \u2014 M.J.G.", "title": "The Top 10 Moments From Couture Week", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "6. There Was a Tender Moment at Balmain\n\nBalmain shows are typically over-the-top productions to complement Olivier Rousteing\u2019s equally over-the-top designs. And this season was no different, but amid the bright lights, thumping music and beaded and chain mail clothing, there was a softer, more unexpected moment that occurred in the front row.\n\nWhile Cindy Crawford patiently sat in the front row, waiting for the show to begin, she shared with those around her (including the actor Orlando Bloom) that she was there to cheer on her son Presley Gerber, who was cast in the show. Crawford excitedly videotaped her son as soon as he appeared on the runway \u2014 and kept the shot rolling as he crossed the entire length of the catwalk. The moment, which can be seen in a video posted on the Instagram account of Anders Christian Madsen, the fashion critic of British Vogue, was a sweet reminder that no matter how rich and famous you may be, a proud mom will always embarrass you.\n\nImage The designer Martine Rose and her baby. She distributed Polaroid cameras to guests to capture photos during the meal.\n\n7. Martine Rose Hosted a Very Personal Dinner\n\nEvery season it\u2019s a tossup as to how the designer Martine Rose will showcase her latest collection. For the past two seasons, she has held fully-fledged runway shows on the outskirts of London, but in seasons past she has staged quieter presentations \u2014 in spring 2015, for example, she showed just one look. And sometimes she doesn\u2019t show at all, which was the case this season. Instead, Rose went to Paris for a buying appointment and quietly released her fall/winter 2018 look book, which featured oversized teddy coats, colorful jean jackets and silk shirts and snakeskin trousers.\n\nBut it was a dinner that Rose hosted to celebrate her continued collaboration with Slam Jam (a streetwear distributor) and Napapijri (an activewear brand) that kept her squarely in the center of men\u2019s fashion month. The dinner was held at L\u2019Epi D\u2019or, a small classic Parisian bistro that she closed down for the evening. Rose said she wanted the event to be an insight into her life, a peek inside an authentic \u201cMartine Rose\u201d atmosphere. She filled her guest list with friends and family (her parents and baby son were there), and just a few members of the press \u2014 and distributed Polaroid cameras for people to use. All in all, the night felt like a welcome respite from fashion week.", "title": "The Top 10 Moments from the Men\u2019s Shows", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-29 00:00:00", "text": "10. If All Else Fails, Wear a Blanket\n\nWhen the weather is unbearable and there\u2019s hardly any motivation to leave the comforts of bed, sometimes the easiest solution is just to bring the bed with you. At Marni, a pair of models came down the runway in patchwork striped blankets that must have inspired those in attendance to replicate the look later in the week: While in Paris, designers with outdoor or unheated venues were considerate enough to provide blankets to guests. Thanks to Sacai, Thom Browne and Herm\u00e8s, people left the shows wrapped up in their own cozy throws.", "title": "The Top 10 Styling Tips from the Men\u2019s Shows", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "With friends, Prokofiev came up with the idea for a ballet adaptation of Shakespeare, after considering \u201cTristan und Isolde\u201d (but deciding he couldn\u2019t contend with Wagner) and \u201cPell\u00e9as et M\u00e9lisande\u201d (feeling the same about Debussy). Then he spent a summer at the artists\u2019 retreat Polenovo, writing a complete annotated piano score in just four months.\n\n\u201cThis ballet was conceived in paradise,\u201d Simon Morrison, a music professor at Princeton University and the author of \u201cThe People\u2019s Artist: Prokofiev\u2019s Soviet Years,\u201d said in an interview. \u201cProkofiev was about to create this astonishing diversity of music from his own imagination.\u201d\n\nStill, the ballet was idiosyncratic to a fault. In its original form, it included a Victory Day parade plopped in the middle of the plot. And the divertissements, a parade of showcase dances that are a staple of classical ballet, were inserted right after Juliet takes the potion: \u201cthe worst possible moment,\u201d Mr. Morrison said.\n\nBut the most unconventional decision Prokofiev made was in the ending: It was happy.\n\nAccording to the ballet\u2019s original scenario, by Adrian Piotrovsky, Romeo wants to stab himself but is stopped by Friar Laurence. While they are entangled in a struggle, Juliet begins to breathe. Then the stage fills with people, who watch as Romeo and Juliet begin to dance. The music is bright as the young lovers leave the stage in an Orphic apotheosis.", "title": "The Tortured History Behind Prokofiev\u2019s \u2018Romeo and Juliet\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-01 00:00:00", "text": "But in the administration and across the business community, there is a perception that years of increased environmental, financial and other regulatory oversight by the Obama administration dampened investment and job creation \u2014 and that Mr. Trump\u2019s more hands-off approach has unleashed the \u201canimal spirits\u201d of companies that had hoarded cash after the recession of 2008.\n\nSome businesses will essentially be able to get away with shortcuts that they could not have under a continuation of Obama-era policies. The coal industry, for instance, will not have to worry about a regulation, overturned by Congress and Mr. Trump, that would have protected streams from mining runoff.\n\nBrett Hartl, the government affairs director at the Center for Biological Diversity, said the Trump administration might avoid big-splash regulatory rollbacks this year and instead would make it harder for federal agencies to block business expansion.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s not going to be sexy things like \u2018We\u2019re killing the Clean Power Plan,\u2019\u201d Mr. Hartl said, referring to the Obama-era rule aimed at curbing greenhouse gas emissions from coal-fired power plants. \u201cBut you can make it systematically harder for an agency to do the right thing.\u201d\n\nOnly a handful of the federal government\u2019s reams of rules have actually been killed or slated for elimination since Mr. Trump took office. But the president has declared that rolling back regulations will be a defining theme of his presidency. On his 11th day in office, Mr. Trump signed an executive order \u201con reducing regulation and controlling regulatory costs,\u201d including the stipulation that any new regulation must be offset by two regulations rolled back.\n\nThat intention and its rhetorical and regulatory follow-ons have executives at large and small companies celebrating. And with tax cuts coming and a generally improving economic outlook, both domestically and internationally, economists are revising growth forecasts upward for last year and this year.\n\nEven before it became clear that Republicans would pass a major tax cut, capital spending had risen significantly, climbing at an annualized rate of 6.2 percent during the first three quarters of last year. Surveys of planned spending also show increases.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Trump bragged in a news conference last month that he has rolled back 22 regulations for every new one \u2014 67 deregulatory actions, versus three new regulations. Often in conjunction with the Republican Congress, his administration has canceled several rules approved at the end of the President Barack Obama\u2019s term, including a regulation on limiting mining debris in streams, a requirement that broadband providers obtain permission from customers to collect and use online information, and a ban on plastic bottles in national parks.\n\nAdministration officials said last month that, since January 2017, federal agencies have delayed, withdrawn or made inactive nearly 1,600 planned regulatory actions. Further rollbacks will affect financial services as well as energy and labor rules, among others.\n\nAnd Mr. Trump has appointed outspoken critics of regulation to lead several federal agencies, including the Environmental Protection Agency and the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau.\n\nThe evidence is weak that regulation actually reduces economic activity or that deregulation stimulates it. But business executives are largely convinced that the cost of complying with rules diverts money that could be invested elsewhere. And economists see a plausible connection between Mr. Trump\u2019s determination to prune the federal rule book and the willingness of businesses to crank open their vaults. Measures of business confidence have climbed to record heights during Mr. Trump\u2019s first year.\n\n\u201cThe notion that deregulation unleashes growth is virtually impossible to find in the data,\u201d said Jared Bernstein, a senior fellow at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities who served as the chief economic adviser to Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. \u201cWhat does matter is this idea that confidence matters. If their expectations about the future are positive, then it does make a difference.\u201d\n\nBusinesses acknowledge that the most important reason for their increased optimism is the simple fact that the domestic economy continues to expand, with few clouds on the horizon.\n\nBetter yet, the world\u2019s major economies all are growing for the first time since the financial crisis. Confidence among European manufacturers hit a high in more than a decade, according to European Commission data that goes back to 1985, even without tax cuts or less regulation.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn Japan, now in the middle of its longest period of growth since the early 1990s, the central bank said corporate investment was exceeding its expectations, and it raised its forecast.\n\n\u201cThe fundamental backdrop here is that this is a global synchronized expansion lifting everyone\u2019s spirits, from Tokyo to New York,\u201d said Mark Zandi, chief economist at Moody\u2019s Analytics in West Chester, Pa. \u201cThe entire global economy is on one page for the first time in over a decade. We\u2019re all moving in sync and that has everyone feeling good, not just here but across the globe.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe low unemployment in the United States may also be prompting increased spending, just as it did in the 1990s, as corporations invest in technology to make workers more productive, or replace them entirely. Wendy\u2019s is adding self-service kiosks at 1,000 restaurants.\n\nBut business executives say the Trump administration deserves credit. Mr. MacDonald said home builders have benefited from the killing of regulations written by the Obama administration, including a rule that broadened the definition of wetlands, which could have restricted home building in certain areas. The National Labor Relations Board also reversed a decision that made builders more responsible for the working conditions of their contractors\u2019 employees.\n\nIn some industries, the administration\u2019s actions will allow companies to engage in activities they might not have been able to otherwise; electric utilities, for example, might be able to invest in upgrading power plants that run on fossil fuels, thanks to a promised rollback of Mr. Obama\u2019s Clean Power Plan to fight climate change.\n\nThe Business Roundtable, a corporate lobbying group in Washington, reported last month that \u201cregulatory costs\u201d were no longer the top concern of American executives, for the first time in six years. Mr. Zandi said that regulation was still the top concern in Moody\u2019s survey of business confidence, but that it was rapidly losing ground to concerns about the availability of labor.\n\nThe National Association of Manufacturers\u2019 fourth-quarter member survey found that fewer than half of manufacturers cited an \u201cunfavorable business climate\u201d \u2014 including regulations and taxes \u2014 as a challenge to their business, down from nearly three-quarters a year ago.\n\nSome industries have seen particularly clear changes in fortune. The Trump administration has reversed a number of environmental protections that would have imposed significant costs on energy companies. Mr. Trump\u2019s appointees to the Federal Communications Commission voted last month to repeal so-called net neutrality rules, which treated internet services as a regulated industry, like power lines, and prohibited broadband providers from charging for faster internet service or from blocking or slowing some websites.\n\nThat decision helped prompt Comcast to announce that it would invest more than $50 billion in infrastructure over the next five years.\n\nThe banking industry, in particular, has been buoyed by a relaxed approach to financial regulation as the Trump administration moves to ease many of the postcrisis rules put in place to prevent another financial meltdown. The Treasury Department has issued a series of reports calling for sweeping changes to rules required under the 2010 Dodd-Frank law, and a council set up to designate firms that pose risks to the financial system is in the process of removing those companies from heightened federal oversight.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Trump has also installed individuals who have publicly questioned the need for many of the postcrisis rules in major policy roles, including at the Federal Reserve and the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau. Bank stocks have been on a winning streak and ended 2017 up more than 15 percent, according to the KBW Nasdaq Bank Index.\n\n\u201cThere has been some regulatory fixes for a lot of industries, and they would tell you that matters a lot,\u201d said Jamie Dimon, the chairman of JPMorgan Chase, who also leads the Business Roundtable. \u201cIt\u2019s just hard to do a direct correlation. It doesn\u2019t mean it isn\u2019t real.\u201d\n\nThe confidence is translating to industries that have not, as of yet, seen any obvious benefit or policy changes.\n\n\u201cWe have spent the past dozen years or longer operating in environments that have had an increasing regulatory burden,\u201d said Michael S. Burke, the chairman and chief executive of Aecom, a Los Angeles-based multinational consulting firm that specializes in infrastructure projects. \u201cThat burden has slowed down economic growth, it\u2019s slowed down investment in infrastructure. And what we\u2019ve seen over the last year is a big deregulatory environment.\u201d\n\nMr. Burke said he expected the actions to speed future projects for his company, though he declined to offer details, citing competitive risks.\n\nThe White House sees its efforts as having their intended effect. Mr. Trump boasted about his deregulatory efforts last month at an event where he stood in front of a small mountain of printouts representing the nation\u2019s regulatory burden and ceremonially cut a large piece of \u201cred tape.\u201d\n\nThe chairman of the White House Council of Economic Advisers, Kevin Hassett, said in an interview that the administration\u2019s freeze on new regulations, in particular, appeared to have buoyed confidence. Though he cautioned that it could take years of research to pin down the magnitude of the effects, he said deregulation was \u201cthe most plausible story\u201d to explain why economic growth in 2017 had outstripped most forecasts.\n\n\u201cOur view is, the \u2018no new regulations\u2019 piece has to be more powerful than we thought,\u201d he said.", "title": "The Trump Effect: Business, Anticipating Less Regulation, Loosens Purse Strings", "authors": ["Binyamin Appelbaum", "Jim Tankersley"]} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "Arkansas, Indiana, Kentucky and seven other states are seeking waivers from federal law to initiate the policy, and the agency says it is ready to grant them the waivers in the coming days if the states meet certain minimal conditions, like exempting people who are pregnant, disabled or caring for family members.\n\nThe new policy would be attempting to solve a problem that doesn\u2019t exist. About two-thirds of Medicaid beneficiaries are either seniors, disabled people or children. Of the remaining one-third, nearly 80 percent are in families with at least one working person and 60 percent have full- or part-time jobs, according to the Kaiser Family Foundation. This policy change is merely a bureaucratic obstacle to keep poor people from obtaining Medicaid. Eligibility for the program varies from state to state, but the national median income limit for a single person to qualify for Medicaid is $16,642 a year.\n\nRepublican lawmakers who have demonized the program as welfare for \u201cable-bodied adults\u201d have long sought to require Medicaid beneficiaries to work. Those lawmakers have been particularly angry about the expansion of Medicaid under the Affordable Care Act, which they have been trying to repeal since it was passed in 2010.\n\nTaking Medicaid away from people who are out of work would damage some of the most vulnerable people in the country. Among them are residents of rural areas who are struggling with opioid addictions and, as a result, cannot hold down permanent jobs. It will also hurt people who, through no fault of their own, lose their jobs and are not able to quickly find another one because they live in a depressed area or because economic changes have made their skills less valuable. Then there are people with chronic conditions like diabetes who do not qualify for disability, but are often unable to work.\n\n\u201cEven though sometimes I can get a job, you\u2019ve got to understand \u2014 sometimes I can\u2019t even walk,\u201d Jimmy Brunson, a diabetic in Arkansas, told The Times last year.\n\nIt is not clear that the Trump administration can legally allow states to impose a work requirement. Experts say federal law allows the government to grant waivers only if they help to advance the aims of Medicaid, which is to provide medical care to low-income people. It strains credulity for the administration to argue that denying health insurance to people on the basis of their employment status meets that test. Public interest groups acting on behalf of Medicaid recipients are likely to challenge such waivers in court.", "title": "Opinion | The Trump Plan to Hurt the Poor by Pretending to Help Them", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-16 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cI set out to write a normal-length book in a few years time, but Vann turned out to be the most extraordinarily complicated man I ever met,\u201d Mr. Sheehan, 81, said from his Washington home. \u201cI never thought I wouldn\u2019t finish the book, but it was extremely draining.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Subscribe to the Vietnam \u201967 Newsletter This weekly newsletter includes eyewitness accounts, rare photos and historical insights about the Vietnam War. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nA poor Irish farm boy from Holyoke, Mass., Mr. Sheehan first went to Vietnam in 1962 for United Press International. He soon befriended Vann, a distinguished veteran of the Korean War serving as an adviser to the South Vietnamese Army.\n\nAlthough he was a gung-ho warrior type and always believed the Vietnam War was winnable, Vann came to realize the attrition strategy was a failure, the constant bombing of the countryside was helping Vietcong recruitment, and the rampant corruption in the Saigon leadership, funded through American dollars, was devastating to the cause. He fought back through the news media, leaking information sometimes through Mr. Sheehan, who eventually was hired by The New York Times, some of which directly contradicted what was coming out Washington.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nTo Mr. Sheehan and other reporters in Vietnam, Vann\u2019s version of what was going on rang truer than the sunny propaganda emanating from the White House. In April 1963, Vann left Vietnam, and it seemed to all the world that the Pentagon was punishing him for speaking out when he resigned from the Army that July. As the years went on, Mr. Sheehan increasingly regarded Vann as the personification of America\u2019s long, painful war effort. But it took his death for the book idea to coalesce.\n\n\u201cA Bright Shining Lie\u201d opens with an incredible scene, Vann\u2019s funeral, full of Washington power: Senator Edward Kennedy and the Pentagon Papers leaker Daniel Ellsberg were in the pews; pallbearers included the former commander of United States forces in Vietnam, William Westmoreland, and a future head of the C.I.A., William Colby. Seated up front were Vann\u2019s widow, Mary Jane, and his four sons. (Their lone daughter had just given birth.) Mr. Sheehan found himself standing in the back of the chapel. The bird\u2019s-eye view of the high-profile crowd gave him his opening line: \u201cIt was a funeral to which they all came.\u201d\n\n\u201cI was watching all these important people coming in one after another, like a class reunion,\u201d Mr. Sheehan told me. \u201cI talked to Susan that night and she said it sounds like this is a book.\u201d\n\n(\u201cHad I known how long the book was going to take, I would\u2019ve committed hara-kiri,\u201d Susan Sheehan said with a laugh. \u201cI ended up writing a piece for The New York Times Magazine, \u2018When Will the Book Be Done?\u2019\u201d )\n\nMr. Sheehan himself makes a smart tactical decision by letting readers get to know Vann as a soldier first. He\u2019s a compelling figure: tough, brash, energetic, hardheaded, and with enough charisma for a dozen Audie Murphy movies. His idealism and bravery shone through after he returned to Vietnam in 1965 as a civilian pacification officer for the Agency for International Development. In 1971, Vann was made a senior adviser for the Central Highlands in charge of all military personnel, effectively a major general in the Army.\n\nThe following spring, the North Vietnamese Army launched the Easter offensive, surrounding and attacking the provincial capital Kontum with three enemy divisions. Vann was instrumental in leading the ARVN\u2019s defense of Kontum, which prevented South Vietnam from being bisected, but as protests mounted back home, the feat barely made a ripple. The day after Kontum was secured, Vann perished in the mountains.
