A week later, at his Washington memorial service, Vann\u2019s family felt that he wasn\u2019t getting the respect he deserved.\n\n\u201cWe all felt a pride in dad for standing up for his beliefs, because he was having a wonderful military career that was cut short,\u201d says his eldest son, John Allen Vann, now 69.\n\nJohn Allen led the family in refusing to stand at the end of the service for several dignitaries, including Secretary of State William Rogers. However, there were limits to the Vann family rebellion. Following the burial in Arlington National Cemetery, other members of the family talked middle son Jess out of handing President Richard Nixon half of his draft card, which he\u2019d torn up in advance of an Oval Office photo op.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cAt Dad\u2019s funeral, I had long hair, but I was never a radical. I didn\u2019t march and always respected the military, but I think my father\u2019s career has an empty all-for-nothing feeling to it, like the Vietnam War itself,\u201d said Jess Vann, 67.\n\nIt was, indeed, a \u201cfuneral to which they all came,\u201d (credit Susan Sheehan for astutely changing \u201ceveryone\u201d to \u201cthey all\u201d), because of Vann\u2019s stature as a military strategist and a civilian warrior. What nobody knew at the time, Mr. Sheehan included, was how much more there was to the story. John Paul Vann had secrets, including the reason he left the military.\n\nVann was never going to be made a general not because of his rebellions against the Pentagon, but because in 1959 he\u2019d been charged with the statutory rape of a 15-year-old babysitter for the Vann children. As Mr. Sheehan notes, Vann \u201cturned himself into an amateur specialist on the polygraph,\u201d passed a lie-detector test, and beat the rap, but he went to Vietnam knowing his career was already lost.\n\nThe depths of Vann\u2019s sexual compulsions are thoroughly examined in \u201cA Bright Shining Lie,\u201d and they were overwhelming. Even in a world of macho libertine behavior, Vann stood out, bedding women everywhere he lived, traveled and worked, often multiple times a day. He had two longstanding mistresses in Vietnam; one he forced to get an abortion, the other had a child. Women were to be conquered. He certainly never took the feelings of his wife, Mary Jane, into consideration.\n\nAlthough they eventually separated, Mary Jane stood by her man for years, even though he didn\u2019t care if she suffered. After the statutory rape charges were dropped, she asked if he\u2019d learned his lesson. He replied that next time he\u2019d make \u201cgoddamn sure they\u2019re old enough.\u201d\n\n\u201cAs the oldest, I knew a lot of what went on. Neil dug up a lot more and unfortunately, it\u2019s all true,\u201d John Allen Vann said. \u201cIn retrospect, Neil was actually kind to my father and didn\u2019t plumb the depths of what was there. When my father wasn\u2019t serving overseas, ours was a household of violent abuse.\u201d\n\nRemarkably, even with the rampant womanizing and misogyny, Mr. Sheehan is able to create empathy for John Paul Vann through his diligent reporting. He went to Vann\u2019s home of Norfolk, Va., and found out the boy was born out of wedlock to a prostitute whose clients were upper-class men who preferred not to visit the brothel. It wasn\u2019t out of desperation either \u2014 she was a hard-drinking partyer who kept all her earnings for herself. John Paul, his stepbrother and two stepsisters were raised by Frank Vann, a decent, passive man who was intermittently employed and took the brunt of her cruelty.\n\nThings would get worse for John Paul when he came under the wing of a young Methodist pastor, Garland Hopkins. At 14, Vann unburdened himself to Hopkins, who persuaded him to join his Boy Scout troop. Hopkins was a pedophile, and Mr. Sheehan writes there is no doubt he molested Vann. Years later, a few weeks before returning to Vietnam, Vann was staying with Hopkins. By now, the pastor had been left by his wife and child, dismissed by his church, and was facing prosecution for his continued pedophilia. Hopkins drank rat poison with strychnine, knowing Vann would find his body.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn \u201cA Bright Shining Lie,\u201d the pain John Paul suffered in childhood somewhat mitigates the pain he caused as an adult, but the relationship with Hopkins was more even more depraved. Dad allowed him to be around his sons unsupervised.\n\n\u201cHopkins is the genesis of our family\u2019s issues because he was an evil person who molested me and one of my brothers,\u201d John Allen says. \u201cWhen I tried to tell dad about it, he beat me. You can imagine what that does to a young boy. Hopkins caused both of us shame and dad took it out on me.\u201d\n\nA half-century later, the hurt Vann caused the family lingers. John Allen Vann, who went on to have a successful investment banking career, spent many years in therapy to break the cycle of violence. Yet the combination of the abuse at home and the absenteeism of a military father caused rifts. John Allen avoids contact with his sister and one of his brothers. Jess Vann talks to everyone now and again, and believes the family isn\u2019t close because of lack of proximity and the demands of modern existence, but he\u2019s also spent most of his life alone in the mountains, working as an ecologist in Colorado.\n\nThe Vann family realities are murky. What is clear is that both sons separate their father from the soldier.\n\n\u201cJohn Paul Vann had a horrific upbringing, but during wartime, he had focused energy and was a great strategist and tactician, which is rare in an officer. Usually the military teaches its officers strategy and its noncoms tactics,\u201d John Allen says. \u201cBack home, for my father, was close to being captured. He became a starved shark whose only goal was to trash and conquer blindly.\u201d\n\n\u201cA Bright Shining Lie\u201d forced the Vanns to publicly reckon with their father\u2019s failings, but at least for John Allen and Jess, there is no ill will for the author. Their mother, Mary Jane, 90, has never read it, but they both love the book and have warm memories of getting to know the Sheehans.\n\nMr. Sheehan took a leave from The Times to write his book, but he never returned. By 1988, the family was $295,000 in debt to his publisher, Random House, and The New Yorker, for which he wrote regularly and which had lent him money (as magazines did back in those days), keeping afloat through fellowships, teaching gigs and Susan Sheehan\u2019s freelance work. The longer the book took, the worse his anxiety, insomnia and stress became, but the passage of time gave his 861-page masterpiece the breathing room to become a hit.\n\nWhen it finally came out, the political climate in America surrounding the war had changed immensely. The reconciliation and reflection that started with the Vietnam Veterans Memorial in 1982, and helped \u201cPlatoon\u201d win the Academy Award for best picture in 1986, opened up the public conversation surrounding America\u2019s first losing war.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cA Bright Shining Lie\u201d was published to great acclaim. It won the National Book Award, the Pulitzer, a special achievement award from the Vietnam Veterans of America, and in 1989, the Robert F. Kennedy Center for Justice and Human Rights Book Award. It sold 165,00 copies worldwide, which wiped out the debt and righted the family\u2019s financial ship.\n\nPerhaps the most appropriate tribute was detailed in a 1988 Washington Post profile by William Prochnau. He wrote that the Sheehans\u2019 21-year-old daughter, Maria, a Wellesley graduate by this point, wore a T-shirt saying, \u201cDaddy\u2019s Book Is Done.\u201d\n\n\u201cA Bright Shining Lie\u201d lives on as a lasting work of scholarship, and a staple of high school and college history and literature course syllabuses. Neil Sheehan has Parkinson\u2019s, and his career has slowed down, but he is still writing about Vietnam and was most recently seen in \u201cThe Vietnam War.\u201d His dapper appearance and the Irish lilt in his voice offered a fitting tribute to his writing life.\n\n\u201cThey filmed Neil in 2011 and he looks great,\u201d says Susan Sheehan, a Pulitzer Prize winner for her 1982 book about schizophrenia, \u201cIs There No Place on Earth for Me?\u201d \u201cIt\u2019s lovely that our grandsons get to see him strong and healthy, not the man who needs a walker.\u201d\n\nAlthough he did not follow through with his threat to never write another book after \u201cA Bright Shining Lie \u2014 he wrote two \u2014 Mr. Sheehan is most proud of the work for which he, and John Paul Vann, will always be remembered.\n\n\u201cI was enormously gratified to have written the book; it felt like I\u2019d truly accomplished something,\u201d he said. \u201cWhen the splendid reviews came out, and even more when I heard from friends in the military who liked it, I was thrilled. I hope it endures as a piece of history to be read again and again. All I can say in my later days, I am deeply satisfied.\u201d\n\n\u201cA Bright Shining Lie\u201d opens with a funeral to which they all came. It ends with \u201cJohn Vann was not meant to flee to a ship at sea, and he did not miss his exit. He died believing he had won his war.\u201d So too, will Neil Sheehan.", "title": "The Truth Behind \u2018A Bright Shining Lie\u2019", "authors": ["Patrick Sauer"]} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThe government is not giving the exact number of Iranians who fled the countryside and are now living in shanty towns, but it should well be over 16 million, up from 11 million in 2013,\u201d added Kowsar, who, besides his water/geology expertise, is one of Iran\u2019s most followed political cartoonists, which is what got him exiled. \u201cThese cities, where employment is scarce, have become hot spots of unrest,\u201d particularly as the government cut back subsidies.\n\nA Jan. 8 essay on ClimateWire by Scott Waldman explained: \u201cFormer President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad understood that climate change and water mismanagement was ravaging family farms, and his government provided subsidies to families who struggled to put food on the table, said Amir Handjani, a senior fellow at the Atlantic Council\u2019s South Asia Center.\n\n\u201cWhen the current president, Hassan Rouhani, signaled that he would reduce those benefits, enraged Iranians across the nation\u2019s arid countryside joined the wave of protests. \u2018You have climate change, shortage of water, they can\u2019t grow their crops, and now they\u2019re getting their cash handouts taken away,\u2019 said Handjani. \u2018It\u2019s a panoply of issues coming together at once.\u2019\u201d\n\nThe Los Angeles Times reported from Iran on Jan. 17: \u201cIn the mountains of western Iran, the province of Chaharmahal-Bakhtiari is known for mile-high lagoons, flowing rivers and wetlands that attract thousands of species of migratory birds. But years of diminishing rainfall have shriveled water sources. Conditions worsened, residents say, after Iranian authorities began funneling water 60 miles away to the lowland city of Esfahan, sparking protests as far back as 2014. On Dec. 30 of last year, about 200 people gathered in front of the provincial governor\u2019s office to protest the water transfer project. Their slogans soon morphed into chants of \u2018Death to the dictator.\u2019\u201d\n\nThe Tehran Times reported on Jan. 8 that, according to the head of drought and crisis management at Iran\u2019s Meteorological Organization, \u201cnearly 96 percent of Iran\u2019s total area is suffering from different levels of prolonged drought.\u201d\n\nLake Urmia was once a giant saline lake, 87 miles wide, in northwest Iran. Beginning in the 1990s, though, Hashemi Rafsanjani, the president at the time, started building lots of dams around the lake, an initiative followed by his successors, constricting the water flowing into Urmia. And because of those dams, a group of people \u2014 Revolutionary Guards contractors, people close to the Ministry of Energy and large agribusinesses that siphoned off the water \u2014 \u201cgot very rich,\u201d explained Kowsar.\n\nAs National Geographic put it in an August 2015, essay: \u201cNow the lake, once one of the largest in the Middle East, looks more like a gigantic crime scene.\u201d Its dried salts now mix with sand, fueling toxic wind storms.\n\nThe Iran story is repeating itself across the Middle East \u2014 environmental stresses mixing with resentment over corruption and misgovernance, sparking uprisings. And it is only going to get worse.", "title": "Opinion | The Tweet Trump Could Never Send Tehran", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-31 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\n\u201cMapping Your Daily Jog, or Route to an Air Base\u201d (news article, Jan. 30) reports that a fitness app \u201chas unwittingly revealed the locations and habits of military bases and personnel, including those of American forces in Iraq and Syria.\u201d\n\nThe Strava app illustrates an entire generation\u2019s blind spot. Raised with internet-connected mobile devices, young Americans have embraced the convenience of perpetual connectivity without recognizing the implicit trade-offs.\n\nHence Pentagon secrets end up being exposed by the very same type of data aggregation platforms that the United States intelligence community helped pioneer.\n\nSome observers, particularly in countries targeted by American surveillance technology, might view this as karmic justice.", "title": "Opinion | The Twist in a Fitness App", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-09 00:00:00", "text": "LONDON \u2014 They\u2019re tiny, colorful and harmless-looking, but these little pellets are being blamed for causing big problems for the world\u2019s oceans and seas.\n\nThe items in question are plastic microbeads, and on Tuesday, Britain made good on a pledge to ban the manufacturing of personal care products containing them.\n\nSo what are these pellets, and what\u2019s all the fuss about?\n\nWhat are microbeads?\n\nMicrobeads are itty-bitty plastic orbs that can be found in exfoliating facial scrubs, shower gels and toothpaste, among other products. They are part of a larger class of microplastics, or pieces of plastic less than five millimeters, or 0.2 inch, long. (Roughly the size of a grain of rice.)\n\nMicroplastics exist elsewhere, too. They can be found in chewing gum, industrial cleaning products, synthetic clothing fibers and tires.", "title": "The U.K. Has Banned Microbeads. Why?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "Of course, people live longer and have healthier lives in rich countries. With only a few (and usually scandalous) exceptions, water is safe to drink, food is safe to eat, sanitation is universal, and some sort of medical care is available to everyone. Yet all these essentials of health are more likely to be lacking for poorer Americans. Even for the whole population, life expectancy in the United States is lower than we would expect given its national income, and there are places \u2014 the Mississippi Delta and much of Appalachia \u2014 where life expectancy is lower than in Bangladesh and Vietnam.\n\nBeyond that, many Americans, especially whites with no more than a high school education, have seen worsening health: As my research with my wife, the Princeton economist Anne Case, has demonstrated, for this group life expectancy is falling; mortality rates from drugs, alcohol and suicide are rising; and the long historical decline in mortality from heart disease has come to a halt.\n\nI believe, as do most people, that we have an obligation to assist the truly destitute. For those who believe that aid is effective, this is reflected in their own giving, or by supporting national and international organizations like the United States Agency for International Development, the World Bank or Oxfam.\n\nFor years, in determining this spending, the needs of poor Americans (or poor Europeans) have received little priority relative to the needs of Africans or Asians. As an economist concerned with global poverty, I have long accepted this practical and ethical framework. In my own giving, I have prioritized the faraway poor over the poor at home.\n\nRecently, and especially with these insightful new data, I have come to doubt both the reasoning and the empirical support. There are millions of Americans whose suffering, through material poverty and poor health, is as bad or worse than that of the people in Africa or in Asia.\n\nPractical considerations reinforce the argument for recognizing America\u2019s poor in the global context. There is a better chance of monitoring the effects of domestic spending than of foreign spending. Money spent by and for fellow citizens, either individually or collectively, is subject to democratic evaluation by both donors and recipients, who can see the effects and who can show their approval or disapproval in the voting booth. Those who donate for projects in Africa often find it difficult to know what good their gifts are doing, let alone to discover whether the intended beneficiaries actually receive or appreciate them.", "title": "Opinion | The U.S. Can No Longer Hide From Its Deep Poverty Problem", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "Other data also shows that women are less likely to leave the work force after they have children. More women are working at all ages, especially during their 20s and 30s, when they used to drop out to care for children. Mothers with college degrees are most likely to keep working: 78 percent of those with children under 18 are in the labor force, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.\n\n\u201cWomen have more education, they\u2019re in jobs that are more fulfilling, and they stay with them,\u201d said Claudia Goldin, a Harvard labor economist who studies women\u2019s work force participation.\n\nIf educated women leave work now, they\u2019re more likely to be in their late 30s or early 40s \u2014 reflecting the fact that they are having children later. Research shows that policies like paid family leave and subsidized child care would make it possible for even more mothers to work.\n\nFertility data is more complicated than it might seem because there are many ways to measure fertility rates, and each gives a different snapshot. The general fertility rate measures the number of births for every 1,000 women of childbearing age in a given year, and the total fertility rate estimates how many children women will have based on current patterns.\n\nBoth have been declining. The general fertility rate in the United States is at a record low, and the total fertility rate in the United States is down to 1.84 births per woman.\n\nCompleted fertility \u2014 the share of women who give birth by the time they are 44 \u2014 peaked in the late 1970s, when baby boomers were having children. It declined to a low in 2006 before rising again, and is now near the level of the late 1970s.\n\nStill, that measurement does not necessarily reflect what women are doing today. Women who are 40 to 44 planned their families during a different atmosphere for childbearing, since many of them had children in the late 1990s and early 2000s. The economy was strong, and in vitro fertilization and other assisted reproductive technologies were becoming more accessible and successful.", "title": "The U.S. Fertility Rate Is Down, Yet More Women Are Mothers", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-02 00:00:00", "text": "With no N.H.L. players available for the 2018 Winter Olympics in Pyeongchang, South Korea, the United States men\u2019s hockey team unveiled on Monday includes four college players, three from the American Hockey League, 15 playing in European leagues and 38-year-old Brian Gionta, who has not played for any pro team this season.\n\nGionta will be the captain of the American team, as he was for the Buffalo Sabres and the Montreal Canadiens over his 15 N.H.L. seasons. But he is the only player on the United States roster that has played in the Olympics before, participating in the 2006 Games, in which the Americans lost in the quarterfinals.\n\n\u201cI loved the N.H.L. players, but there\u2019s something fresh about the format this time,\u201d said U.S. Coach Tony Granato, an American Olympian himself in 1988 in Calgary. \u201cWe\u2019re going to take advantage of that. We have to see how good we are.\u201d\n\nThe four college players selected \u2014 Denver\u2019s Troy Terry, Boston University\u2019s Jordan Greenway, St. Cloud State\u2019s Will Borgen and Harvard\u2019s Ryan Donato \u2014 have won medals for the United States at the world junior championships over the past two years.", "title": "The U.S. Hockey Team\u2019s Mystery Men", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "LONG PHU, Vietnam \u2014 The towering lattice of blue steel girders rising above banana and lemongrass crops near Vietnam\u2019s southern coast stands as public testament to the country\u2019s drive to burn coal.\n\nWith help from a Kremlin-connected Russian bank, Vietnam is building a coal-fired power plant called Long Phu 1 that will produce an estimated 5.4 million tons of carbon dioxide a year, generating enough electricity to power millions of homes.\n\nBut the project needs something else first: help from the United States government.\n\nThe plant\u2019s state-controlled owner has applied for assistance with the project from the Export-Import Bank of the United States. If the bank agrees, American taxpayers will shoulder the financial risk behind Vietnam\u2019s purchase of millions of dollars\u2019 worth of turbines and other equipment from General Electric.\n\nThe bank has not yet decided whether it will back the project. If it did, it would show that the Trump administration\u2019s commitment to using more coal at home also extended overseas. Critics say it would also challenge a growing global consensus that developed nations and groups like the World Bank should stop funding high-polluting energy projects in developing countries. Britain\u2019s equivalent of the Export-Import Bank has already declined to participate in the project.", "title": "The U.S. May Back a Vietnam Coal Plant. Russia Is Already Helping.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "UNITED NATIONS \u2014 Efforts by the Trump administration to marshal a muscular international response to Iran\u2019s crackdown on anti-government protesters appeared to backfire on Friday, as members of the United Nations Security Council instead used a special session called by the United States to lecture the American ambassador on the proper purpose of the body and to reaffirm support for the Iran nuclear agreement.\n\nIt was an afternoon of high diplomatic theater that began with a passionate denunciation of Iran\u2019s \u201coppressive government\u201d by the American ambassador, Nikki R. Haley, and ended with the Iranian ambassador delivering a lengthy history of popular revolt in the United States \u2014 from the violent demonstrations at the Democratic National Convention in 1968 to the Occupy Wall Street protests in 2011.\n\nIn the interim, Council members did, one by one, condemn the Iranian government\u2019s response during more than a week of protests. As of Friday, more than 20 people had been killed and hundreds had been arrested. The authorities have blocked access to social media and have blamed foreign \u201cenemies\u201d for instigating the unrest, a common refrain at times of upheaval that in this case the government has provided no evidence to support.\n\nIn her remarks, Ms. Haley said that the United States would remain steadfastly behind the Iranian protesters.", "title": "The U.S. Wanted to Discuss Iran. Russia Brought Up Black Lives Matter.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "But that was fantasy in more ways than one, because I wasn\u2019t capable of loving her. As awful as it seems to say this, it was because she was Japanese. I\u2019d been raised to be wary of the people from the Land of the Rising Sun. That\u2019s what I was taught, by my mother.\n\nNot all Asians get along. You might assume because we are all of the same race, there\u2019d be a built-in kind of solidarity, and there probably is among the younger generation. But my mother was born in 1940, during the Japanese occupation of Korea. Although it ended when she was 5, her parents were affected and raised her with a deep distrust of their imperialist neighbors.\n\nAs I grew into my adolescence, I began to doubt and then reject my mother\u2019s simplistic, racist views of the Japanese, but old habits die hard. And my latent bias emerged the night that Lisa stood me up for a dinner date at a steakhouse. This was 1994, back in the era of technological innocence, so if somebody didn\u2019t show for a rendezvous, one couldn\u2019t pull out a smartphone and text \u201cwhere r u?\u201d No, all I could do was wait, silent and brooding, and let my imagination worm its way through the blackness of my soul.\n\nIf the first half-hour of my vigil was in the domain of concern for her well-being, the next half-hour was spent in a pool of pure paranoia. I\u2019d known this girl only since the beginning of the semester, a scant three months. Who was she, really? It was possible, was it not, that our friendship didn\u2019t mean much to her at all? Perhaps she had gained what she needed from me and had moved onto her next victim.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nWrithing inside those anxious 60 minutes, I could almost hear my mother\u2019s voice calling me a fool for falling for a Japanese woman.\n\nWhen I returned from the restaurant to my apartment, the answering machine blinked its red message light. It was Lisa, who sounded mortified as she told me she was racing to finish a huge psych paper and she completely forgot about our date. I felt like the dope that I was and told her not to worry about it. We met up for dinner the very next night, her treat.\n\nTwenty-three years later, as I gazed at my ancestry results with a sense of guilt that I had even entertained a racist bias against my own people, I had a thought. If I was more than a quarter Japanese, then there was a chance one of my parents was even more Japanese than the other. How fitting would it be if my mother had a full Japanese grandparent?\n\nThe next time I saw her, I handed her a DNA test kit of her own.\n\n\u201cHow much did you spend on this thing?\u201d she asked.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cRelax, I got it on sale.\u201d I did get it on a Mother\u2019s Day special.\n\nA month later, the test results were back: My mother was almost 40 percent Japanese. There was an option to link her DNA to mine. And when I did so, something strange happened: her Japanese percentage shot down to 21.1 percent while mine rose to 30.7 percent. The site explained it as \u201cphasing,\u201d and said that once a biological parent and child\u2019s genes are matched, the accuracy increases for both.\n\nWhen I showed her the results, she shrugged.\n\n\u201cWhy should I care about something that happened a hundred years ago that I had no control over?\u201d she said.\n\nWhy indeed. She gave the printout a final glance.\n\n\u201cEven if you got it on sale, you spent too much.\u201d", "title": "The Unexpected Branch on the Family Tree", "authors": ["Sung J. Woo"]} {"date": "2018-01-09 00:00:00", "text": "Bret: Fuhgeddaboudit. The number of Republican candidates who will expressly denounce Trump\u2019s behavior is probably less than zero. The only question is the ardor with which they\u2019ll express their admiration for and fealty to the president. Then again, one consequence of Wolff\u2019s book is that it has pretty much destroyed the political career of one Stephen K. Bannon. That might mean that the G.O.P.\u2019s taste for nominating Roy Moore-like figures may abate, at least for a while. Mitch McConnell must be smiling.\n\nGail: Yeah, in fact, tweeting a grin.\n\nBret: All this being said, I continue to think that Democrats are gulling themselves if they think they can retake one or both houses of Congress merely on the strength of opposition to Trump. Constantly calling the president an idiot is another way of insulting everyone who voted for him and may do more to galvanize them come November than to persuade them to flip their vote. And Democrats will be even less persuasive to voters if the economy continues to perform well, or if middle-class voters see their taxes go down thanks to the tax bill.\n\nAll of which means that Democrats have to develop a political slogan at least as effective as MAGA. I would humbly suggest MASA: Make America Sane Again.\n\nGail: I can imagine Chuck Schumer having a flag made. But let me ask you a question about the economy. It\u2019s been doing very well ever since \u2014 ahem \u2014 Barack Obama resurrected it. It\u2019s been a good ride but people are beginning to question how long it\u2019ll last. I\u2019m worried that any artificial heft the economy got from the tax cuts could just hasten the popping of our current balloon. Or, at minimum, make it harder for the government to deal with a recession crisis since there\u2019s less revenue coming in, even from the folks who can afford to send it.\n\nBret: Morgan Stanley\u2019s Ruchir Sharma had an excellent Op-Ed essay in The Times the other day on the subject of economic forecasting. As he tells it, economic forecasters \u201chave not predicted a single United States recession since the Federal Reserve began keeping such records a half-century ago, and missed many revivals,\u201d including the worldwide resurgence in 2017. Which is only to say that the answer to your question about how long the recovery will last is, \u00bfQui\u00e9n sabe?\n\nGail: Bret, if we only conversed about things we had solid information about, we would have to spend all our time discussing yesterday\u2019s weather. Come on, take a jump.\n\nBret: Let\u2019s say the recovery has some legs in it. For starters, it\u2019s coming on the heels of seven years of extremely sluggish growth, so the 3 percent growth figures we are seeing now are really a return to normal growth, not a sign of overheating. Also, the recovery is a global phenomenon, reaching from Japan to Europe. And continued growth likely means gradually higher interest rates, which would give the Fed some running room in the event of a recession or a crash.", "title": "Opinion | The Very Stable Genius in the Very Stable White House", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-22 00:00:00", "text": "Before this all began, I was covering financial markets and banks from New York. That gave me a grounding to begin understanding this, but Bitcoin has turned into a very different kind of financial market. At the banks, I kept hearing about how they were taking this technology seriously as something that might change their business in the long run. That is because beneath the digital tokens, Bitcoin introduced a new kind of crowdsourced financial infrastructure, known as the blockchain, that allows for the creation of money and financial records that aren\u2019t maintained by any central authority like a bank or a government.\n\nClaims about Bitcoin\u2019s longevity differ dramatically. If you listen only to virtual currency aficionados, you would think that digital money is certain to dethrone the dollar as the global reserve currency and kill Wall Street, to boot. I get dozens of emails every day from entrepreneurs who tell me how they are going to use the technology introduced by Bitcoin to revolutionize the music industry, or shipping business, or even democracy itself. Meanwhile, very smart people like Warren Buffett and Joseph Stiglitz have continued to say that the whole thing is just a bubble waiting to burst.\n\nHow is a single journalist supposed to work through it all? It can feel a bit like being there at the invention of the stock market, but with no certainty that stocks would actually work as promised \u2014 and with everything hinging on software that few people understand.\n\nCertainly one part of this requires understanding the technical details of how Bitcoin and other digital tokens work. The time I\u2019ve spent grappling with the inner workings of virtual currencies has given me a sense of why so many computer scientists see the Bitcoin network as real technological innovation and not just a token that people buy and sell. I have a good stable of geeks who help walk me through the details when I get confused. And when I go to dinner parties it comes in handy \u2014 everyone these days wants to talk about how Bitcoin works and whether it is a bubble.\n\nBut from that first article about the Winklevoss twins, I have tried to focus, whenever possible, on the real people who are buying and using Bitcoin and other virtual currencies, and what is motivating them. That has taken me to Argentina, where I saw how people are using virtual currencies to escape the inflation their local currency is experiencing. It has also led me to the online black markets, where virtual currencies have made it easier for addicts to buy deadly drugs from China and for criminals to collect ransom payments.\n\nIt is also the real-world usage that tests whether Bitcoin and other virtual currencies are able to live up to the big promises that they are making. With most virtual currency projects, I\u2019ve found that there are relatively few real-world transactions to back up the big, speculative bets that investors are making.\n\nPerhaps most fascinating is how these new currencies draw communities around them. It\u2019s a potent reminder that all money is a social construct: The more people who believe a Bitcoin or dollar will retain its value in a week, the greater the value the currency will have.\n\nBut these are still early days. The death of Bitcoin has been wrongfully proclaimed many times already. For my part, The Times\u2019s rules against investing in what we write about has allowed me to be equally open to this going up or down.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBeyond that, these virtual currencies are all living economics experiments, testing how different sorts of incentives create different behaviors. Bitcoin has an elaborate system of carrots and sticks designed to attract followers and to increase the cybersecurity of the Bitcoin network. But these incentives don\u2019t always work as expected. That uncertainty is what makes it so interesting to watch \u2014 and to report on.", "title": "The View From the Bitcoin Bubble", "authors": ["Nathaniel Popper"]} {"date": "2018-01-31 00:00:00", "text": "Dear Diary:\n\nIt was late July and humid. We were on the roof of his apartment building in Alphabet City, drinking beer and listening to a Spotify playlist he had made for me. The sun started to fall, creating shadows against the concrete. It couldn\u2019t have been more than our fourth or fifth date.\n\nLooking into the windows of a nearby building, we saw a couple fighting in their bedroom. They were stripped down to their underwear. The woman was sitting on the bed, her face in her hands as the man yelled at her using words we couldn\u2019t hear. She was weeping.\n\nWe sat and watched them, the sounds of the city muted by the six stories below us. Then he turned to me.\n\n\u201cSo for dinner tonight, I\u2019m thinking somewhere in the East Village?\u201d he said. \u201cItalian food maybe.\u201d\n\nThat will never be us, I thought, looking into the window across the way.\n\nBy winter, it was.", "title": "The Voyeurs\u2019 Fate", "authors": ["Taylor Majewski", "Metropolitan Diary"]} {"date": "2017-12-31 00:00:00", "text": "Maria stood outside the Metropolitan Detention Center in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, on a recent evening, looking up. The jail loomed above, a concrete bulwark more than a dozen stories high and lined in narrow windows. Behind one of them was her husband.\n\nMaria, who wished to be identified only by her first name because of her husband\u2019s notoriety, had been standing there for hours. She had flown in from Bogot\u00e1, Colombia, for the weekend, only to learn she would not be allowed inside.\n\nThe sun was going down and it was time to go; she had a flight to catch. But first, she went to her rental car and pulled out what looked like a rolled-up poster and some packing tape. \u201cA little message for my husband,\u201d said Maria, 33, in Spanish, walking over to a warehouse across the street from the jail.\n\nA section of the wall had been covered in signs. \u201cHappy Father\u2019s Day Chris B.\u201d \u201cHappy Thanksgiving Luchie.\u201d \u201cI Love You Payroll.\u201d \u201cStay Strong Hubberz. We Got This.\u201d There were signs in Spanish, posters in Hebrew. Some were handwritten and covered in tape to protect them from the elements. Others were printed on durable plastic. They hung amid scraps of tape, deflated balloons and the tattered remnants of even older signs.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMaria\u2019s sign said, in pink marker, \u201cTe amo, Gordo.\u201d \u201cI love you, Big Guy.\u201d", "title": "The Wall of Love Outside a Jail", "authors": ["Annie Correal"]} {"date": "2018-01-09 00:00:00", "text": "This proved to be the high point of Lansdale\u2019s influence in Saigon \u2014 and, for that matter, Washington. Diem grew tired of the American upbraiding him for undemocratic moves like closing opposition newspapers. \u201cDo you think that\u2019s the right thing for \u2018the father of his country\u2019 to do?\u201d Lansdale asked, to which Diem replied, \u201cStop calling me papa!\u201d\n\nEven as his clout diminished and his worries grew over the regime\u2019s coercive actions, Lansdale extolled Diem\u2019s achievements and urged continued American support. No other plausible leader existed who could take the fight to the Vietcong. For Lansdale, as for Boot, Diem\u2019s ouster and murder in a coup d\u2019\u00e9tat in late 1963 backed by the United States was a watershed moment, a calamitous development from which the war effort never fully recovered.\n\nThere\u2019s something to this argument \u2014 it required about four years for the politics in South Vietnam to settle, and the Communists took advantage of the turmoil \u2014 but it misses how bleak and unsustainable the situation was with Diem. Communist forces were already gaining momentum in the countryside after 1962, which is partly why the South Vietnamese military had grown so disgruntled and why the Kennedy administration wanted a change. With his shallow conception of leadership and easy resort to repression, Diem, a Roman Catholic, had long since alienated powerful segments of South Vietnamese society, including the leaders of the Buddhist majority, and his regime enjoyed scant support among the peasantry. The coup against him was enormously popular. It\u2019s hard to see Diem surviving in power for long regardless of what John F. Kennedy did in the fall of 1963.\n\nTo his credit, Lansdale always emphasized the need to focus on developments within South Vietnam. More than many American officials, he understood that even if one somehow stopped the flow of men and mat\u00e9riel from the North, the southern insurgency would remain a formidable threat to the Saigon regime. Bombing North Vietnam was therefore no solution. Unshakable in his conviction that the American way was right for everyone, Lansdale nevertheless insisted on the need to show empathy for local values and practices, to spend time with villagers, and he perceived \u2014 to a degree at least \u2014 the dilemma at the heart of American strategy: What do you do when the destruction deemed necessary to defeat an insurgency alienates the very population you seek to bring over to the government\u2019s side?\n\nMany of Lansdale\u2019s ideas, however, were kooky: He advocated distributing counterfeit official documents in North Vietnam to sow confusion and fear, providing the Vietcong with booby-trapped ammunition intended to blow up in their faces and having Saigon leaders give \u201cfireside chats\u201d \u00e0 la Franklin D. Roosevelt \u2014 and he understood Vietnamese society and politics less well than this admiring book suggests. His well-founded concern about the problems posed by pervasive South Vietnamese official corruption (grasped, contrary to Boot\u2019s claim, by virtually every American intelligence analyst after 1965) did not keep him from championing the unscrupulous, impetuous and flamboyant Nguyen Cao Ky for Saigon\u2019s leadership \u2014 he of the aviator sunglasses, purple silk scarf and pearl-handled revolver. Ky\u2019s embrace of American largess made him the very symbol of corruption in the eyes of a great many Vietnamese (and he once told stunned journalists that his only hero was Adolf Hitler).\n\nThere is power in Boot\u2019s conclusion that Lansdale \u201cnever wanted to see half a million American troops thrashing around Vietnam, suffering and inflicting heavy casualties. His approach, successful or not, would have been more humane and less costly.\u201d In this sense, the Lansdale way was indeed \u201cthe road not taken.\u201d Whether that road would have led to the destination he so wanted to reach, however, is doubtful. As much as this irrepressible Cold Warrior might have thought otherwise, Vietnam for the United States was destined to be what it had always been: a riddle beyond American solution.", "title": "The War That Never Goes Away", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-31 00:00:00", "text": "The first is an absence of trust between Washington and Kabul. The longer the Americans stayed the more difficult it became to persuade Afghans that their presence was helpful and their purposes benign. Over time, Hamid Karzai, the West\u2019s chosen leader of \u201cliberated\u201d Afghanistan, came to see the United States as an occupying power \u2014 part of the problem, rather than part of the solution. Karzai believed, not without reason, that United States officials paid lip service to his concerns, were willing to cut deals behind his back and on occasion plotted to replace him with someone more accommodating.\n\nFor their part, Americans who dealt regularly with Karzai concluded that he was indecisive, unstable and given to bouts of paranoia. When he first became leader of Afghanistan in December 2001, Washington had celebrated Karzai as an Afghan Mandela. By the time he vacated the premises 13 years later, he had become in American eyes an Afghan Mugabe.\n\nOf even greater significance, in Coll\u2019s view, is Washington\u2019s dysfunctional relationship with the government of Pakistan, or more specifically with the Pakistani Army, which effectively calls the shots on all matters related to internal and external security. Pacifying Afghanistan was always going to pose a challenge. Absent full-throated Pakistani collaboration, it would become next to impossible. The United States needed two things from Pakistan: first, that it would permit supplies bound for coalition forces in landlocked Afghanistan to transit its territory; and second, that it would prevent Qaeda and Taliban remnants from using Pakistan as a sanctuary and operating base.\n\nFrom Washington\u2019s perspective, these expectations, premised on an assumption that Pakistan could be cajoled into complying with America\u2019s purposes in Afghanistan, seemed eminently reasonable. Yet that assumption proved wildly off the mark. While the generals commanding the Pakistani Army and directing the Inter-Services Intelligence made a show of cooperating, they were simultaneously working to undermine coalition military efforts. Imbued with the conviction that Afghanistan is vital to Pakistani national security, they had no intention of allowing the United States to determine its fate. So while accepting subsidies amounting to hundreds of millions of dollars \u2014 Washington even elevated Pakistan to the status of \u201cmajor non-NATO ally\u201d \u2014 the Pakistanis still actively supported the Taliban.\n\nPakistan\u2019s military leaders were playing a double game. United States officials knew they were being had, yet could do little about it. With its own well-established record of having broken promises to Pakistan, Washington was not exactly in a position to call in any markers.\n\nDespite being nominally the superior power, the United States found that it could exert minimal leverage. Officials could ask, but not demand, while Pakistan\u2019s nuclear arsenal limited its susceptibility to threats and sanctions. Although American officials went to almost comic lengths in attempting to befriend or flatter their Pakistani counterparts \u2014 Adm. Mike Mullen, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, called on Pakistan\u2019s army chief no fewer than 27 occasions \u2014 such efforts proved to no avail.\n\nIn Afghanistan, Pakistan has never ceased to support the very enemy that the United States and allied forces have been struggling to defeat. Its army and intelligence service remained throughout \u201can incubator and enabler of extremism.\u201d Coll concludes that Washington\u2019s inability \u201cto solve the riddle\u201d of Pakistan\u2019s Inter-Services Intelligence and \u201cto stop its covert interference in Afghanistan\u201d constituted the \u201cgreatest strategic failure of the American war.\u201d\n\n\u201cI believe victory is closer than ever before.\u201d The words are Mike Pence\u2019s, uttered during his recent trip to Kabul, but the sentiment is one that any number of high-ranking American officials, civilian and military alike, have expressed over the years. Readers of \u201cDirectorate S\u201d will find no reason to take such assurances seriously. No matter: The Afghanistan war will no doubt continue on its endless course.", "title": "The War That Will Not End", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-15 00:00:00", "text": "The businesses grew quickly. By the 1800s and the early 1900s, the owners of watch companies were living in elegant townhouses built of the region\u2019s distinctive pierre de Chailluz, a limestone in mottled tones of gray and beige. Ateliers, with extra-wide windows to let in the light so workers could see the tiny pieces they assembled, were tucked behind the homes.\n\nThe Mus\u00e9e du Temps reflects the city\u2019s role in timepieces \u201cfrom sundials to atomic clocks,\u201d according to its director, Laurence Reibel (and plays host in June each year to the Les 24H du Temps fair held in its courtyard).\n\nPhoto\n\nThe museum\u2019s displays include an example of a timepiece from Besan\u00e7on\u2019s glory days: the Leroy 01, completed in 1904. It has 24 complications, and for decades, Ms. Reibel said, was considered the world\u2019s most complicated watch.\n\nThe watch industry here, which now employs around 1,500 people, had 20,000 workers then.\n\nThe decline came to Besan\u00e7on in what locals call La Crise du Quartz, the sharp downturn in mechanical watch production and sales that followed the rise of quartz watches in the 1970s.\n\nLip, the timekeeper of the Tour de France in the 1950s, closed its doors in 1977. The change in the city was palpable. Afterward, when 5 p.m. rolled round \u2014 the time the Lip workers usually went home \u2014 \u201cthe streets of Besancon were silent; no one was driving their car home,\u201d said Fr\u00e9d\u00e9rique Coobar, the city\u2019s public relations manager, who grew up here. Over the years, other companies closed.\n\nThe watch school, \u00c9cole Nationale d\u2019Horlogerie de M\u00e9canique d\u2019\u00c9lectricit\u00e9, closed. The company that made movements, France Ebauches, closed.\n\nPhoto\n\nBecause the city\u2019s residents were known for their precision work on watches, their skills soon were transferred to work on the microtechnologies required to manufacture medical devices and instruments for the defense and aeronautics industries. \u201cBesan\u00e7on became the capital of microtechnology,\u201d Mr. Laporte said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut since the 1990s, watch and clock making has been coming back.\n\nLong case clocks with a distinctive hourglass shape, called Comtoise clocks, have long been made in ateliers in the outskirts of the city and in the villages of the surrounding Jura mountains. Now, two men are keeping them alive: Philippe Vuillemin bought an old factory 12 years ago, and after making the necessary tools \u2014 \u201cThey were all gone during the war,\u201d he said \u2014 he began producing about 100 Comtoise clocks a year at his Manufacture Vuillemin business.\n\nIt would be safe to say the tall clocks that Mr. Lebru makes at Utinam were inspired by the Comtoise design, but their stainless steel cases bear little resemblance to the originals. Also, he patented his design for a suspended cage to hold the internal mechanism so the clocks no longer have to rest on flat surfaces.\n\nMr. Lebru was the designer of the clock, a six-ton wall installation, that greets visitors at the TGV train station in Besan\u00e7on. He said that a Swiss company has ordered one; \u201cThis means so much, that the Swiss should come to me, a Frenchman.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Lebru also makes watches with a twist, like the one with hands that circle counterclockwise, intended for left-handed wearers. His shop on Grande Rue sells the watches made in Besan\u00e7on by brands such as Humbert-Droz, Lornet, March LA.B and FOB Paris.\n\nIn the spring he plans to open a glass-fronted workshop in the mostly pedestrian Old Town so people can watch him work, and to sell online. \u201cThings are changing,\u201d he said. \u201cThree young French watchmakers are coming to Besan\u00e7on, because of its renown for horlogerie. Today, with the computer for knowledge and Kickstarter for funding, it\u2019s easier to design and make a watch.\u201d\n\nThe quartz crisis also led to the closure of many of Besan\u00e7on\u2019s repair shops, which serviced the mechanical watches made in the city. But gradually that sector has been reviving, too. In 2012 Breitling opened a new glass and blond wood service center in an industrial park; its director, Steve Napias, arrived in the region last year from Breitling\u2019s operations in Toronto. \u201cThere people would tell me, \u2018Oh, I\u2019ve never met a watchmaker before,\u2019\u201d he said. \u201cHere, everyone knows a watchmaker.\u201d\n\nOther watch service centers are in and around Besan\u00e7on, said Pierre Dieterle, the economic director for greater Besan\u00e7on: \u201cThere\u2019s Swatch, Festina from Spain, Seiko from Japan, Tissot and Longines.\u201d Audemars Piguet has a center, too.\n\nPhoto\n\nAccording to Mr. Dieterle, there are also companies producing watches or watch components for Zadig & Voltaire, Cerrutti, Christian Lacroix, Ted Lapidus, Mugler and what he described as \u201cles grandes marques de la Place Vend\u00f4me,\u201d the luxury jewelry and watch houses grouped around the famous square in Paris.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAnother Bisontin institution also has made a comeback. The Observatoire de Besan\u00e7on, opened in 1880 to certify the accuracy of timepieces using the stars, has worked its way back to certifying about 100 watches a year. It had shut down in 1970 but reopened in 2002 and now is operated by the university.\n\nFran\u00e7ois Vernotte, who ran the observatory for 10 years after its reopening, displayed the operation of the old meridian telescope, which looks like a cannon but is, in fact, accurate \u201cto one-tenth of a second,\u201d he said.\n\nNow atomic timekeepers are used to check watches for accuracy, and Jo\u00ebl Petetin, a technician at the Observatoire, said requests come from \u201cmostly independent watchmakers, like Kari Voutilainen and Laurent Ferrier.\u201d\n\n\u201cWe only certify chronometers now, and our requests have doubled every year,\u201d Mr. Petetin said. The process takes about two weeks and costs 400 euros ($480); watches that pass can be stamped with the city\u2019s emblem, the head of a viper, and receive a certificate.\n\nSo much history \u2014 yet, back at the Vuilleman workshop, the future is being trained.\n\nEmilien Theurot, 14, was sorting gears at a work desk as his \u201cstage,\u201d the one-week work experience required of all French students.\n\nLike all good Bisontins, horlogerie is in his blood; \u201cmy grandmother worked with watches,\u201d he explained.\n\nAnd why do his work experience here? \u201cBecause,\u201d he said, \u201cI\u2019m passionate about movements.\u201d", "title": "The Watch Capital of France? But it isn\u2019t all bad out there. This feature is meant to send you into the weekend with a smile, or at least a lighter heart.\n\nHere are seven great things we wrote about this week:\n\nParrots are beautiful, affectionate and intelligent, and many people enjoy keeping them as pets. But when something goes wrong, they can shriek endlessly, pull out their own feathers and throw tantrums like a toddler.\n\nThat\u2019s where Glenn Sorino comes in.\n\nA bird aficionado, he\u2019s been helping parrots and their owners for more than 20 years. He currently serves 40 clients and their pets, including Charlie, a brilliant blue macaw who has had a tough time since her owner died.\n\nMr. Sorino\u2019s own parrot, Sara, enjoys swinging from his belt and taking baths. We\u2019re back on the good news beat after the holidays. While we were away (hiking around the jaw-dropping otherworld of Sedona, Ariz.), a lot of positive things happened in the world. It\u2019s our goal to bring you more of the good stuff this year.\n\nTo start, here are seven pieces of good news we wrote about recently.\n\nYuzuru Hanyu of Japan, 23, has been called \u201cthe most complete athlete in figure skating, probably ever,\u201d by the 2006 Olympic silver medalist. He\u2019s the first Japanese man to win an Olympic gold medal in the sport, and he competes while a Winnie the Pooh doll watches from the sidelines.\n\nBefore his routines, he squeezes his Pooh doll (which doubles as a tissue dispenser), pats its head and shakes its paw. But it isn\u2019t all bad out there. This feature is meant to send you into the weekend with a smile, or at least a lighter heart.\n\nHere are seven great things we wrote about this week:\n\nMultiple studies have shown that singing, songwriting and listening to music can improve quality of life and reduce pain among the terminally ill. The sessions are becoming more prevalent in nursing homes and hospices.\n\nKaitlyn Kelly, a music therapist, decided to pursue end-of-life work after visiting an infirmary in Jamaica. As she strummed her guitar, one woman sat up in bed, lifted her arms and began to move rhythmically.", "title": "The Week in Good News: \u2018Frost Boy,\u2019 Dolphins and Art Selfies", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "Of the big-name developers investing in the neighborhood \u2014 a list that includes TF Cornerstone, the Elad Group and Taconic Investment Partners \u2014 perhaps the most notable might be the Moinian Group. It has helped shape the look of the modern Far West Side.\n\nA pair of existing Moinian towers on West 42nd Street form a sort of bookend of the area. There is Atelier, a condo at No. 635 with 469 units, and Sky, a rental at No. 605. The developer believes Sky\u2019s 1,175 apartments to be the most packed into a single high-rise in the country.\n\nSoon joining Atelier and Sky around the corner will be Oskar, a rental building with a terra-cotta facade at 572 11th Avenue, at West 43rd Street. A far smaller undertaking, it has just 164 apartments, from studios to three-bedrooms, across 13 stories.\n\nPhoto\n\nBut what Oskar may lack in scale it makes up for in style. It was originally designed as a condo, a generally more luxurious property type, said Joseph Moinian, the firm\u2019s chief executive. Despite the change in use, which gives the developer more \u201clongevity\u201d at the site, the building\u2019s design was never downgraded, Mr. Moinian said. Finishes like Caesarstone kitchen counters were retained, he said, adding, \u201cthe quality is very, very high.\u201d\n\nAmenities will include an airy second-floor lounge with a 100-inch television over a wide fireplace and access to an adjacent landscaped terrace. For a fee, residents will also be allowed to use many of the amenities at the nearby and well-appointed Sky, including its basketball court, spa and pools.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe building is named for Oskar Brecher, the Moinian Group\u2019s former development director, who died in 2016. In mid-January, Oskar had not yet set specific rents, as it won\u2019t open until the spring. Mr. Moinian said that studios will likely be about $3,000 a month and one-bedrooms about $4,500.\n\nIn the broader Hell\u2019s Kitchen neighborhood, west of Eighth Avenue, studios average $2,700 a month, according to StreetEasy.com data, while one-bedrooms average $3,400.\n\nOf Oskar\u2019s apartments, 46 will be available at below-market rents for those who are eligible based on their incomes. Those affordable units were required because the $180 million project is benefiting from state bond financing.\n\nMr. Moinian and other developers in the area have been helped by rezoning. In 2011, the city approved a plan to allow more apartments on the blocks between 10th and 11th Avenues, while permitting bigger industrial buildings between 11th and 12th Avenues. But because of lingering effects of the last recession, brokers say, residential development has been scattered until now.\n\nPhoto\n\nOskar\u2019s site previously held the Market Diner, which opened in 1962 and closed in 2015. It was one of a handful of diners that once sparkled amid the area\u2019s brick factories and warehouses. Most are now gone.\n\nOther projects in western Hell\u2019s Kitchen that are part of the recent surge include 535 West 43rd Street, a 280-unit dark-brick complex from a team that includes DHA Capital. This apartment house, which welcomed renters in 2016, was built on the site of parking lots. Studios at the building were listed this month for prices starting at $2,800. The building has a gym, a pet spa and two roof decks.\n\nAnd last year saw the opening of Frank 57 West, a 10-story, 65-unit rental at 600 West 58th Street, with one- to three-bedroom apartments, from the Durst Organization.\n\nFrank is clustered on the same block with earlier Durst rental projects like Helena 57 West and Via 57 West. Frank can also seem to represent an extension of the collection of apartment towers that have bloomed in recent years just to north, on West End Avenue, which is what 11th Avenue turns into north of West 59th Street.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut if West End enjoyed buzz before, 11th Avenue might be next. Standing tall on the skyline is the Max, a rental from TF Cornerstone that is under construction at 606 West 57th Street. Set to open this spring, the 1,028-unit complex will become New York\u2019s second largest residential building, the company said, second only to Sky. (Silver Towers, a rental complex on West 42nd Street, which opened in 2009, at the edge of the neighborhood, has 1,359 apartments, but in two connected high-rises.)\n\nThe Max is named for Max Elghanayan, son of the TF Cornerstone co-founder Frederick Elghanayan; Max Elghanayan died earlier this month. The Max will also have a school, a spokesman for TF Cornerstone said.\n\nPhoto\n\nContinuing south, there is 525 West 52nd Street, a two-towered complex from Taconic Investment Partners and Mitsui Fudosan America, with 392 apartments, including market-rate and affordable units. The building, which also has 35,000 square feet of amenities, opened last June.\n\nCondos, more rare in a somewhat untested market, are also going up; Charlie West, a 123-unit version from the Elad Group and Mi&Co, which has its main entrance on West 43rd Street.\n\nAlthough this project was unveiled in 2014, it is not expected to open until 2019, according to Michael Lorber, an associate broker with Douglas Elliman Development Marketing, which is handling sales. It sits atop railroad tracks, on a platform, and next to a rental-car office. In early January, the least-expensive one-bedroom was $1.85 million. Affordable units are also part of the mix.\n\nIn comparison, in the entire Hell\u2019s Kitchen neighborhood, one-bedroom condos list for an average of $1.34 million, including existing units and those in new buildings, according to StreetEasy data.\n\nLess far along appears to be 615 10th Avenue. It is a block-wide project between West 44th and West 45th Streets, where there was once a gas station. Here, an 82-unit building is planned in a seven-story building, according to public filings. Target said that one of its stores will occupy the building\u2019s storefront, with about 29,000 square feet, and will open in 2019, a Target spokeswoman said.\n\nA Target store would be a major change for this area. Though 10th Avenue has many restaurants, there is just a smattering of retail offerings west of this busy thoroughfare. An exception is Gotham West Market, an enclosed food hall at 11th and West 44th Street that has Japanese, Mexican and Chinese food in a casual setting with industrial d\u00e9cor. It sits at the base of Gotham West, a nearly full-block apartment complex that opened in 2013.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Real Estate Newsletter Every week, get updates on residential real estate news, covering the five boroughs and beyond. Ad agencies have also arrived in recent years.\n\nA Lexus showroom will be razed to make room for a 225-unit condo. The condo, at 646 11th Avenue, will have an auto dealership at its base said Scott Shnay, a principal at CBSK Ironstate, the development entity behind the project. Mr. Shnay said he hopes to finalize the purchase of the site this summer.\n\nSeparately, a Lexus dealership at 11th Avenue and West 56th Street is being demolished to allow for a new 83-unit, 35-story condo from a partnership of Sumaida and Khurana, a Manhattan-based firm, and Leny Group, of Israel.\n\nAmit Khurana, a founding partner of Sumaida and Khurana, said he hopes to begin sales in spring 2019. He added that the area, north of Hudson Yards, is distinctive enough to warrant its own name, \u201cHudson West.\u201d\n\n\u201cNew York is a city where neighborhoods evolve, and a transformation can happen so quickly,\u201d Mr. Khurana added. \u201cIt can just take a few years, with a few developers and a few new buildings.\u201d", "title": "The Western Edge of Hell\u2019s Kitchen Goes Residential", "authors": ["C. J. Hughes"]} {"date": "2018-01-28 00:00:00", "text": "Tamesha Means had been pregnant for just 18 weeks when her water broke in 2010. In pain, she rushed to a hospital near her house in Michigan. But because it was a Catholic health center, doctors there did not tell her that continuing her pregnancy could threaten her health and that abortion was her safest option. Instead they sent her home. They did so again when she returned the next day, bleeding, with painful contractions. They were preparing to send her home for a third time when she miscarried at the hospital.\n\nCases like this, in which a provider\u2019s religious beliefs take precedence over a patient\u2019s needs, could become more common because of a series of recent White House decisions that please the anti-abortion movement. The decisions may make it more difficult for teenagers wanting to get tested for sexually transmitted diseases, for gay men looking to prevent HIV and even for women seeking breast exams or pap smears.\n\nEarlier this month, the Department of Health and Human Services announced the creation of a \u201cConscience and Religious Freedom Division\u201d to enforce laws protecting health care providers\u2019 right to opt out of certain procedures, including post-abortion care or gender-affirming surgery, because of religious objections. The Winter Antiques Show has increasingly been a reflection of those changes, with art included in the fair in addition to the furniture, decorative arts, tapestries and other artifacts. Some of the objects at this year\u2019s show are museum quality \u2014 a special exhibition on loan from the Virginia Museum of Fine Arts spearheads the art on display here. But alongside high-end paintings and portraits are smaller curios and oddities, which means quite a few themes run through the show. Here is a roundup of some of the highlights.\n\nVIRGINIA MUSEUM OF FINE ARTS The booth at the entrance to the fair is more like a mini-museum, courtesy of the Virginia Museum of Fine Arts in Richmond, Va. The exhibition here celebrates a century of art patronage and serves as an ode to its founding collectors and the objects they donated to create the collection. Among the standouts are a George Bellows painting, \u201cTennis at Newport\u201d (1920), composed around a rushing, dynamic take on linear perspective, as well as paintings by Childe Hassam, Robert Henri, Max Pechstein, Beauford Delaney, Berthe Morisot and Eastman Johnson. Donald Trump is a raving idiot. Every sentient person knows this, and if Michael Wolff is to be believed, so does most everyone in the White House. So why are we talking about Wolff\u2019s book \u201cFire and Fury\u201d as if it\u2019s the news sensation of the decade?\n\nThe answer lies in that timeless definition of the word \u201cgossip\u201d: Hearing something you like about someone you don\u2019t. \u201cFire and Fury\u201d is catnip for everyone who detests this president. Trump gorges on burgers in a bed he doesn\u2019t share with his wife! He barely reads and constantly repeats himself! He has mastered the fine print in the Bill of Rights \u2014 all the way from the First to the Third Amendment!\n\nBut gossip isn\u2019t journalism. And Wolff\u2019s book is Exhibit A in how not to damage Trump\u2019s presidency, much less his chances of re-election.\n\nSo much was apparent in Tuesday\u2019s televised meeting of the president with congressional leaders to discuss immigration. This was not a good performance by past presidential standards: Trump seemed unable to grasp what a \u201cclean\u201d bill meant, or where Republicans stood on it. Oklahoma Senator James Lankford acknowledged as much when he said the meeting got \u201cconfusing.\u201d", "title": "Opinion | The Wolff Eats Its Own", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "From the beginning, the founders told me, Birth Choice struggled to find support for women who feel too poor to have their babies. In 1986, a woman was referred to them from an adoption agency. Her prior pregnancies had ended in abortion and in placement for adoption. She had planned to give up her current pregnancy for adoption, but it became clear that she wanted to keep this child. She needed help parenting, she needed housing, and she owed the adoption agency thousands of dollars when she withdrew from that process.\n\nBirth Choice responded by taking her in as the first resident of Rose Home, a shelter where the most vulnerable of its clients can live during and immediately after their pregnancies. At any given time, it houses five pregnant women and a maximum of 13 children.\n\nThe Rose Home shelter is a rarity among crisis pregnancy centers, a large majority of which, according to Ms. Chishko, follow \u201crigid rules: no shelters, no clinical services, just administer pregnancy tests and give out baby clothes. Just persuade the women not to abort their babies.\u201d And the dominant mode of persuasion, according to a congressional report on federally funded crisis pregnancy centers, involves providing either false or misleading information about the health effects of abortion.\n\nBy contrast, Rose Home\u2019s five residents get support to help them throughout pregnancy and beyond. They have weekly meetings with caseworkers to articulate goals and plan their futures. They receive counseling, drug abuse treatment and vocational training. They get help making court dates, permitting them to regain custody of their children currently in foster care.\n\nThe rhetoric of \u201cchoice\u201d and \u201clife\u201d encourages us to see a pregnant woman as if she\u2019s balancing a scale, with abortion on one side and motherhood on the other. Which will she choose? Tilt her one way and she might get to finish high school or college, gaining time to plan for the child she wants. Tipped another way, she might become a mother or allow a childless couple to adopt.\n\nThe women living at Rose Home reveal the shallowness of that metaphor.\n\nWomen face the surprise of an unplanned pregnancy as if on train tracks, with a locomotive barreling toward them. The only variation lies in how many other trains are coming from other directions. Homelessness, violence, addiction and the biggest of all: poverty.\n\nI don\u2019t mean to suggest money is the only factor that shapes many women\u2019s response to an unplanned pregnancy, but let\u2019s be clear about how much it matters. One of the largest research studies on the question of why women choose abortion surveyed about 1,200 abortion patients and found 73 percent said they could not afford a baby at the time.", "title": "Opinion | The Women the Abortion War Leaves Out", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-20 00:00:00", "text": "While the marches were the first tangible demonstration of women\u2019s anger and resolve, the health care fight proved the first test of how to channel that energy. Women took the lead, spurred by advocacy groups that married traditional community organizing tools with online templates.\n\nWith Congress poised to end Obamacare, women deluged their representatives with calls and letters, and confronted them at town halls. In one survey conduced by Celinda Lake, the veteran Democratic pollster, women placed 86 percent of 28,000 calls and texts to Congress on health care through Daily Action, another postelection resistance group. Planned Parenthood funneled more than 350,000 such calls, according to Kelley Robinson, its national organizing director. T he Women\u2019s March estimates that its participants sent 250,000 postcards to senators. And at town halls during congressional recesses, women offered vivid accounts of what would happen to them or their families without affordable health care.\n\nThe furor about health care crossed usual partisan lines, and along with internal fractures within the Republican Party, prompted enough Republican defections to thwart repeated attempts to end Obamacare through legislation.\n\nAs for #MeToo, the pink hats that became the emblem of the marches offered an early clue to the persistence of an issue many women believed was buried by Mr. Trump\u2019s election. The hats were a reference to Mr. Trump\u2019s comments, caught on an Access Hollywood tape, bragging about kissing women and grabbing their genitals without their consent. The emergence of the tape just before the election provoked an outpouring of women testifying about sexual harassment. It was not until this most recent wave, though, that men lost jobs \u2014 and in some cases, women are taking their places.\n\nThe broader cultural conversation that #MeToo is generating will lend the movement additional momentum, its organizers contend. \u201cThe words \u2018patriarchy\u2019 and \u2018misogyny\u2019 have probably been used more in the past two months than over the past two decades,\u201d said Kathy Bonk, long active in the women\u2019s movement.\n\nMs. Lake said an overview of current polling, as well as focus groups and polls her own firm has conducted, suggest that health care and sexual harassment are the issues that matter most to women, and give female candidates the most traction.\n\nGalvanized by the election, women are proclaiming their intent to run for office at record levels \u2014 a trend that began right after the election and has only intensified since.", "title": "The Women\u2019s March Became a Movement. What\u2019s Next?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "In November, David Malpass, who oversees international affairs at the Treasury Department, said at a congressional hearing that those benefiting from the World Bank\u2019s lending practices were \u201cthe people who fly in on a first-class ticket to give advice to governments.\u201d\n\nAnd Adam Lerrick, Mr. Trump\u2019s nominee to be a deputy under secretary responsible for the relationship with the World Bank, was a leading contributor to a study that questioned the relevance of the institution. The argument was that growing investment flows into developing countries rendered World Bank lending mostly superfluous.\n\nNearly 20 years later, the report\u2019s critique remains pointed. Last year, the World Bank dispensed $61 billion in loans and investments. By contrast, investors now inject more than $1 trillion a year into emerging markets, financing every manner of corporate or government investment. That is more than the $900 billion the World Bank has doled out in its history.\n\nThe Middleman\n\nIt was 8 a.m. at World Bank headquarters in Washington, and Mr. Kim took his seat at the boat-sized table that dominates the bank\u2019s board room. Its vast length evokes a more majestic time for the bank, when its voice \u2014 and loan book \u2014 loomed large across continents.\n\nMr. Kim, 58, was on a video feed, urging financiers in Egypt, Jordan and Tunisia to put more of their own money to work in local markets.\n\nIn effect, he was pitching the bank\u2019s services as a middleman, ready to back projects with guarantees and other incentives. No longer could the World Bank be the sole provider of loans, which, he said, are \u201ccrowding out\u201d the private sector.\n\nMr. Kim is, by nature, a cheery person, but there was no mistaking the edge to his voice when he started talking about the World Bank economists whose pay is tied to how many loans they churn out. In his view, the bank needs to reward staff, Wall Street-style, for devising innovative financial solutions.", "title": "The World Bank Is Remaking Itself as a Creature of Wall Street", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-02 00:00:00", "text": "The unexpected triumph of the mild-mannered, bookish, Occident-curious Mohammad Khatami in the 1997 presidential election fueled the possibility of change. But the regime\u2019s attack on student demonstrators demanding free speech in 1999 \u2014 Mr. Khatami failed to defend them, while Hassan Rouhani, Iran\u2019s current \u201cmoderate\u201d president, threatened them with death \u2014 brought an end to any organized reform movement.\n\nThe longing for change among the Iranian people hasn\u2019t abated, however. The 1979 revolution had two contradictory ambitions: clerical Islamism and democracy. As theocracy has lost its appeal, the attraction of democracy, ever more secular in its expression, has spread from the college-educated to the working class.\n\nThe Obama administration, like so many well-intentioned Western journalists and scholars, locked onto this hope for gradual transformation from theocracy to democracy even though within Iran it had been shattered. The death of this dream was the electoral triumph in 2013 of Mr. Rouhani, a founding father of the regime\u2019s dreaded Intelligence Ministry. Iranians, who would surely down theocracy in a free vote, have a political system that gives them the option of voting for Mr. Rouhani or even more distasteful candidates.\n\nMany Americans still want to believe that the Islamic Republic can peacefully evolve into something less malign. After all, American foreign policy is much more difficult if Iran remains an aggressive theocracy. The nuclear deal seems less astute if, when the sunset clauses kick in and the atomic restrictions start coming off in six years, Iran has tens of thousands of loyal Shiite militiamen spread across the Middle East and has increased the capacity of its long-range ballistic missiles.\n\nBut as Misagh Parsa of Dartmouth has written in \u201cDemocracy in Iran: Why It Failed and How It Might Succeed,\u201d a depressing but essential read, gradual change isn\u2019t in the offing. The demonstrators in the streets of Iran today instinctively know this, which is why they rail against the system, chanting: \u201cDeath to Khamenei! Death to Rouhani!\u201d\n\nThese brave men and women deserve America\u2019s rhetorical and material support. They expected in it 2009 after President Obama\u2019s Cairo speech, in which he called for human rights in the Muslim world, but it never came.\n\nThis time around, the Trump administration can do better. The president\u2019s tweets in support of the protesters were a good start. Washington should also let loose a tsunami of sanctions against the Revolutionary Guards, the linchpin of Iran\u2019s dictatorship. Policy-wise, that would be a good place to start.\n\nContrary to received wisdom, the absolute worst thing that the United States can do for the Iranian people is to stay silent and do nothing.", "title": "Opinion | The Worst Thing for Iran\u2019s Protesters? U.S. Silence", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-08 00:00:00", "text": "Second, our system of checks and balances has restrained presidents who might otherwise have been tempted to ignore the rule of law or abuse their position. While we\u2019ve probably had chief executives who longed to jail their critics or enrich themselves while in office, none of them dared act on those desires.\n\nBut that was then. Under the Very Stable Genius in Chief, the old rules no longer apply.\n\nWhen the V.S.G. moved into the White House, he brought with him an extraordinary collection of subordinates \u2014 and I mean that in the worst way. Some of them are already gone, like Michael Flynn, whom Trump appointed national security adviser despite questions swirling even back then about his foreign ties, and who last month pleaded guilty to lying to the F.B.I. about those ties. Also gone is Tom Price, secretary of health and human services, done in by his addiction to expensive private plane trips.\n\nOthers, however, are still there; surely the thought of Steve Mnuchin at Treasury has Hamilton rolling over in his grave. And many incredibly bad lower-level appointments have flown under the public\u2019s radar. We only get a sense of how bad things are from the occasional story that breaks through, like that of Trump\u2019s nominee to head the Indian Health Service, who appears to have lied about his credentials. (A spokeswoman for the Department of Health and Human Services says a tornado destroyed his employment records.)\n\nAnd while unqualified people are marching in, qualified people are fleeing.
