There has been a huge exodus of experienced personnel at the State Department; perhaps even more alarming, there is reportedly a similar exodus at the National Security Agency.\n\nIn other words, just one year of Trump has moved us a long way toward a government of the worst and dumbest. It\u2019s a good thing the man at the top is, like, smart.", "title": "Opinion | The Worst and the Dumbest", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-31 00:00:00", "text": "The outdoor workroom in a lush garden not far from the mighty Mekong River seems a world apart from Paris. A dozen Laotian women talk among themselves as the city traffic from the streets of Vientiane swirls by. Their wooden shuttles make a soft slithering sound as they hand weave large swathes of silk fabric in rich colors on handcrafted looms.\n\nWell before the success of handmade crafts on the e-commerce site Etsy, the studio of Carol Cassidy, an American master weaver, has been a favorite stop for travelers in this corner of Southeast Asia. Ms. Cassidy has been working with Laotian weavers in the backyard of a grand old colonial mansion in central Vientiane for nearly three decades. Together they have kept alive age-old traditions of Laotian design in woven cloth and the natural colors of a palette extracted from plants in the forests: reds, pinks, yellows, greens.\n\nJust steps from the garden, her showroom, Lao Textiles, on the mansion\u2019s wood-paneled first floor \u2014 a cool retreat from the city\u2019s blazing heat \u2014 is a haven for easy-to-pack gifts. Day and evening silk scarves, zippered all-purpose silk pouches and elegant cushion covers are arrayed on tables, all at fairly reasonable prices for handmade pieces.\n\nFew know that they are buying the creative efforts of weavers who also make top-of-the-line drapes, sofa and cushion coverings for the retail palaces of luxury fashion houses in Paris, London and Milan.", "title": "The Woven Art of Laos", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-17 00:00:00", "text": "Before Joe Thompson switched treatments for his opioid addiction, he was a devoted stay-at-home father, caring for his infant son after his wife returned to work. His recovery was aided by the anticraving medication buprenorphine. But after over two years free of heroin, Mr. Thompson, a former United Parcel Service worker from Iowa, relapsed and decided to try another kind of treatment program.\n\nUnfortunately, his new counselors insisted that continuing his buprenorphine, though it was approved by the Food and Drug Administration, was just as bad as using heroin, according to his wife, Deborah. He wasn\u2019t even allowed to start therapy until he\u2019d been abstinent for several weeks. Stressed by withdrawal, he went to a third center. It, too, banned medication. Within a week of entering the program, he was dead from a heroin overdose. He was 35.\n\nBuprenorphine is one of only two treatments proven to cut the death rate from opioid addiction by half or more. But the programs Mr. Thompson tried viewed abstinence as the only true recovery \u2014 even though abstinence treatment has not been shown to reduce mortality and is less effective than medication at preventing relapse.\n\nUnfortunately, Mr. Thompson\u2019s experience is more the rule than the exception. Only about one-third of American addiction programs offer what many experts worldwide see as the standard of care \u2014 long-term use of either methadone or buprenorphine. Most programs view medication as a crutch for short-term use and provide only talk therapies.", "title": "Opinion | The Wrong Way to Treat Opioid Addiction", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cI love the change of the seasons,\u201d I mutter, through gritted teeth, as a 20-mile-per-hour gust renders my pants irrelevant.\n\nClothing choices aren\u2019t my only failure to adapt to my climate. I drink iced coffee nearly every morning and many afternoons year-round. Often I walk past my subway station and two fancy cold-brew spots at the end of my block, cross the street to Dunkin\u2019 Donuts and then double back with a clear plastic cup big enough to hydrate a hockey team, were it full of water and not chilled, low-grade stimulant.\n\nWhen temperatures dip below freezing, I take off my gloves to pay for my purchase and put them on when I go back outside. There are probably more sensible beverages I could enjoy over the full third of the year when nature itself is essentially a series of physical and psychological tortures. But caving in to that impulse runs counter to my native stoicism.\n\n\u201cThey gave up, but I\u2019m no quitter\u201d is what I tell myself when friend after friend leaves the Northeast for a more temperate location. I see their Instagram pictures of palm trees and flip-flops as signs of weakness. Toughing out the winter is a dedication to my heritage, both in terms of not going \u201csoft\u201d by kowtowing to nature\u2019s volatility, and staying physically close to my family in New England. I don\u2019t run from that kind of pressure. I stare down the adversity and let it seep into my bones, the way slush fills your shoe when you step into one of those puddles that\u2019s somehow a foot deep.\n\nA few years ago, on a 60-degree day in January when I was visiting Los Angeles, a barista at a West Coast coffee chain handed me an iced coffee, and he had put an extra cardboard sleeve over the cup to insulate my hand against the cold. My face didn\u2019t register it, but on the inside, I felt as insulted as if he\u2019d put on a rubber glove before shaking my hand, or offered me my drink in a sippy cup. I fumed as I walked out the door, and I flung the sleeve into a nearby trash can. I walked to my rental car sipping my coffee, and I realized \u2026 my hand was more comfortable with the cardboard. He wasn\u2019t judging me at all. He was just trying to make my day a little more pleasant.\n\nAt the time I wasn\u2019t ready to absorb the lesson, but this winter something changed. Maybe a few years of what feels like increasingly extreme weather have worn me down. Or maybe, a little more established in my life and career, I feel less sentimentality toward the punishing climate of my childhood. I am not a wimp, nor am I a traitor to my New England upbringing, if I wear a real winter coat.", "title": "Opinion | The \u2018Bomb Cyclone\u2019 That Broke Me", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-09 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nWhen Marcella Hazan, the cookbook author who revolutionized the way Americans cook Italian food, died in September 2013, The Times asked readers to submit their favorites of her recipes. Many wrote in to sing the praises of her famous (and contentious) red sauce made with just four ingredients \u2014 tomatoes, a stick of butter, an onion and salt \u2014 and others gushed about her roast chicken with lemons, pork braised in milk and minestrone.\n\nStill more answered with one word: Bolognese. One reader called Ms. Hazan\u2019s meat sauce from \u201cThe Classic Italian Cookbook,\u201d her 1973 debut, \u201cthe gold standard.\u201d\n\nIt\u2019s that ideal cold-weather recipe that we reintroduce to you here. If you\u2019re not familiar with Italian recipes for Bolognese, be warned: It is not the traditional Italian-American meat sauce, punctuated by strong notes of tomato, garlic and oregano. Hers is influenced by the flavors of northern Italy (particularly the city of Bologna), so there is no garlic or olive oil, but there is milk and butter and a hint of nutmeg. It might seem like an odd combination, but the milk and butter mellow the intensity of the acidic tomatoes. The wine, nutmeg and vegetables create a complex flavor profile that transforms this sauce into something truly spectacular.\n\nKeep in mind that the finished sauce is very rich, so when serving, dole it out with a light hand. As one NYT Cooking reader wrote: \u201cThe noodles should show under a coating of sauce, like varnish rather than paint.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMs. Hazan called for using ground beef, or a mixture of beef and pork, but some readers have had happy results using a mixture of veal, beef and mild Italian sausage. The sauce also freezes well, so consider making a double batch.\n\nFinally, you\u2019ll need at least four hours to make it (some readers prefer to let it simmer for at least five), so set aside a weekend afternoon \u2014 preferably a chilly one \u2014 when you have plenty of time to allow it to simmer to perfection. It is not to be rushed.", "title": "The \u2018Gold Standard\u2019 Meat Sauce", "authors": ["Margaux Laskey", "The New York Times"]} {"date": "2018-01-29 00:00:00", "text": "Let\u2019s begin with a basic fact. The capacities of autonomous weapons are designed by humans, programmers whose intentions are written into the system software. Let us remember, though, that the essence of computation needn\u2019t be restricted to a silicon substrate or to any metaphysically privileged medium.\n\nImagine that rather than having a programmer\u2019s intentions written into a robot\u2019s silicon substrate, we instead have a group of people physically carrying out the identical set of decisions and procedures. Given such a case, the decision-procedure being realized by the group of people would be functionally identical to the decision-procedure being realized on silicon. Supposing such a case, we might then ask, would an army realizing an institutional plan that was functionally identical to the algorithms of a killer robot be any less morally problematic? Would we want to then ban that particular army arrangement as well? If so, how?\n\nThe main point here is to emphasize the serious problem policymakers would face in isolating just what exactly it is that should be banned. Furthermore, such considerations highlight the fact that the deep moral issues raised by autonomous weapons are the very same ones raised by conventional warfare.\n\nWhen we start to look at killer robots this way, we see that they are the mechanical realizations of much larger sets of institutional intentions, involving the plans of designers and the decisions of people who follow such plans, individuals who accept certain jobs, develop certain software and put such software to military use.\n\nIndeed, there is the problem of determining who exactly within such a causal chain is morally responsible for potential harm and to what degree. However, the problem of determining where specifically within a given causal chain to assign moral responsibility to individual members is a problem endemic to any collective action whatsoever, from the Challenger disaster, to the BP oil spill, to global poverty.\n\nThe current language in the killer robot debate suggests that those weapons are capable of acting without meaningful human control, and that their creation and use is somehow distinct from other sorts of collective actions. It also suggests that potential harm arising from that creation and use may be morally unattributable to those who create and use them. This is not the sort of moral detachment we should foster in our technology and military communities, especially in relation to what is perhaps the gravest and most consequential of all human activities: war.\n\nOne common response to this view is that A.I. experts are particularly worried about learning machines, and that something about the complexity of these systems gives rise to emergent properties that are metaphysically irreducible to the sum of their parts. This would suggest that the robots possess an agency, and should then be subject to moral accountability, with the accompanying rights and interests. I am skeptical of this.", "title": "Opinion | The \u2018Killer Robots\u2019 Are Us", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-03 00:00:00", "text": "Richard M. Nixon told advisers during the Vietnam War that he wanted the North Vietnamese to believe he was an unpredictable \u201cmadman\u201d who could not be restrained \u201cwhen he\u2019s angry, and he has his hand on the nuclear button.\u201d\n\nDuring the 2016 presidential election, Hillary Clinton said of her opponent, \u201cTrump shouldn\u2019t have his finger on the button, or his hands on our economy.\u201d\n\nVideo\n\nHow would President Trump launch an attack?\n\nEach nuclear-capable country has its own system for launching a strike, but most rely on the head of government first confirming his or her identity and then authorizing an attack.\n\nDespite Mr. Trump\u2019s tweet that he has a \u201cmuch bigger & more powerful\u201d button than Mr. Kim, the fact is, there is no button.\n\nThere is, however, a football. Except the football is actually a briefcase.\n\nThe 45-pound briefcase, known as the nuclear football, accompanies the president wherever he goes. It is carried at all times by one of five military aides, representing each branch of the United States armed forces.\n\nInside the case is an instructional guide to carrying out a strike, including a list of locations that can be targeted by the more than 1,000 nuclear weapons that make up the American arsenal. The case also includes a radio transceiver and code authenticators.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nTo authorize the attack, the president must first verify his identity by providing a code he is supposed to carry on him at all times. The code, often described as a card, is nicknamed \u201cthe biscuit.\u201d\n\nIn his 2010 autobiography, Gen. Henry H. Shelton, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff during the final years of Bill Clinton\u2019s presidency, wrote that Mr. Clinton had lost the biscuit for several months without informing anyone.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThat\u2019s a big deal,\u201d General Shelton wrote, \u201ca gargantuan deal.\u201d\n\nThe president does not need approval from anyone else, including Congress or the military, to authorize a strike \u2014 a decision that might have to be made at a moment\u2019s notice.\n\nNevertheless, some politicians have called for more layers of approval.\n\n\u201cThe longer I\u2019m in the Senate, the more I fear for a major error that somebody makes,\u201d Senator Dianne Feinstein, Democrat of California, said in 2016. \u201cOne man, the president, is responsible. He makes an error and, who knows, it\u2019s Armageddon.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nHow would Kim Jong-un order a strike?\n\nMuch of North Korea\u2019s nuclear program is shrouded in mystery.\n\nMr. Kim, however, is the undisputed ruler of his isolated country. Any decision to initiate an attack would most likely be his alone. In recent months, Mr. Kim has threatened to ignite an \u201cenveloping fire\u201d of missiles near the Pacific island of Guam, an American territory, and has warned that North Korean intercontinental ballistic missiles are capable of reaching the mainland United States.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s not a mere threat but a reality that I have a nuclear button on the desk in my office,\u201d Mr. Kim said in a speech on Monday. \u201cAll of the mainland United States is within the range of our nuclear strike.\u201d\n\nIt is doubtful that there really is a button on his desk. Furthermore, an intercontinental attack from the North probably could not happen in minutes, let alone seconds.\n\nThe North\u2019s longest-range missiles are believed to be powered by liquid rocket fuel. That means the missiles cannot be stored and ready-to-fire at a moment\u2019s notice. They must be loaded with fuel before launch, a process than can take hours.\n\nNewer, shorter-range missiles, are loaded with solid fuel, however, making them easier to launch before the North\u2019s enemies detect an attack.", "title": "The \u2018Nuclear Button\u2019 Explained: For Starters, There\u2019s No Button", "authors": ["Russell Goldman"]} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cWe\u2019d get done with work, the staff would go out together, we\u2019d get drinks, then we\u2019d make out and think, \u2018That was a bad idea, we should just be friends,\u2019\u201d he said. \u201cThen a week would pass, we\u2019d go out again, and the same thing would happen.\u201d Inevitably, they started dating. Months later they moved in together. Two years after that, he proposed. \u201cI didn\u2019t have any money at the time, and we didn\u2019t own a restaurant yet, so I borrowed a ring from a friend,\u201d he said. \u201cI lined the hallway with balloons which had different notes attached to them. The last one had the ring.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Of the Moment The lifestyle newsletter from the Styles, Travel and Food sections, offering the latest trends to news you can use. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nWhat I\u2019ve Learned\n\nMr. Symon: When you work together in a restaurant, there are natural boundaries. Liz runs the front; I run the back.\n\nI\u2019ve learned there are things I\u2019m right about, and things Liz is right about. If she feels strongly about something, I don\u2019t debate her, and I\u2019ve learned not to doubt her and to trust her instincts in business and in this marriage.\n\nOur relationship history has taught me that we both have our strong points, to not fight the boundaries, that there are things I can\u2019t control, and that you need to give the other person room to try something they believe in. It\u2019s work to care for someone as much as you care for yourself \u2014 with marriage and with children.\n\nEarly in our marriage, I thought there\u2019s the wrong way, or my way. I\u2019m still like that about a lot of things, but not with Liz. I\u2019m used to being the one who says, \u2018Don\u2019t worry, I\u2019ll fix it. I got it.\u2019 It\u2019s very comforting to know someone who stands by you can also fix it, regardless of what people might think of you. She\u2019s enjoyable to sit with and listen to. We have a heightened sense of connection, communication and passion. If you don\u2019t look at your wife as the most special person in the world, why are you with her?\n\nMrs. Symon: This is my second marriage, but this is the first time I\u2019ve been able to breathe. Michael is very chill and nonconfrontational. When you\u2019re around that, it gives you the ability to trust and gain confidence.\n\nWe had a great friendship first and that helps because you learn to like the person you\u2019re with. With Michael, I\u2019ve learned I don\u2019t always have to be right. I don\u2019t always have to be first. And to have the confidence to admit when I\u2019m wrong. That\u2019s very beneficial. If you\u2019re constantly combative, it doesn\u2019t bode well for a relationship. I can take a step back now and listen to what someone else is saying. I used to say anything, and that can be hurtful.\n\nI\u2019m also little O.C.D. \u2014 coffee handles to the right. Michael tries to live with it, but I\u2019ve learned to let go more. It\u2019s my weirdness, not his, though he still believes a toilet-paper fairy exists and changes the roll, so I\u2019ve also learned patience. Our marriage is intertwined in personal and business because we work together, which is how we started, and really, that\u2019s all we know. The business part is simple. We have defined roles in what we do. Marriage is harder. It\u2019s a world without rules. You have to make your own.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWe\u2019ve found our own strengths, and, in that, found each other\u2019s strengths and weaknesses. I will always have his back and he will always have mine. I don\u2019t think we\u2019d be married if we didn\u2019t have that.", "title": "Their Marriage Is a Little Like Comfort Food", "authors": ["Alix Strauss"]} {"date": "2018-01-14 00:00:00", "text": "By Don Defenderfer\n\nThere is the first full moon of autumn\n\nRising through the gums\n\nSlanting up the river valley\n\nSpreading silver on the river\u2019s whirls.\n\nThe moon humbles my candle\n\nAnd seduces an owl to call.\n\nThe moonlit gums become full of silky boughs and velvet shadows\n\nAnd every leaf stands individual and clear,\n\nEvery boulder gains a distinct shadow and\n\nThe river glows like mercury\n\nAs it sluices through the buttongrass sedge.\n\nThe Earth tilts and time passes;\n\nThere is no going back to summer.\n\nThis is the time to reflect and make amends.\n\nThis is the first full moon of autumn,\n\nRising above the eucalyptus trees,\n\nSlanting up the river valley,\n\nSpreading light\n\nKnowingly.", "title": "There Are Poets Among Us", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-21 00:00:00", "text": "But there is disagreement over the real value of Bitcoin and the network that supports it.\n\nFor people who consider Bitcoin nothing more than a speculative bubble \u2014 or a speculative bubble that has enabled online drug sales and ransom payments \u2014 any new contribution toward global warming is probably not worth it.\n\nBut Bitcoin aficionados counter that it has allowed for the creation of the first financial network with no government or company in charge. In countries like Zimbabwe and Argentina, Bitcoin has sometimes provided a more stable place to park money than the local currency. And in countries with more stable economies, Bitcoin has led to a flurry of new investments, jobs and start-up companies.\n\n\u201cLabeling Bitcoin mining as a \u2018waste\u2019 is a failure to look at the big picture,\u201d Marc Bevand, a miner and analyst, wrote on his blog. The jobs alone, he added, \u201care a direct, measurable and positive impact that Bitcoin already made on the economy.\u201d\n\nBut even some people who are interested in all that innovation have worried about the enormous electrical use.\n\nMr. de Vries, who keeps track of the use on the site Digiconomist, estimated that each Bitcoin transaction currently required 80,000 times more electricity to process than each Visa credit card transaction, for example.\n\n\u201cVisa is more centralized,\u201d Mr. de Vries said. \u201cIf you really distrust the financial system, maybe that is unattractive. But is that difference really worth the additional energy cost? I think for most people that is probably not worth the case.\u201d\n\nThe figures published by Mr. de Vries have been criticized by Mr. Bevand and other Bitcoin fans, who say they overstate the energy costs by a factor of about three. Many critics add that producing and securing physical money and gold also require lots of energy, in some cases as much as or more than Bitcoin uses.", "title": "There Is Nothing Virtual About Bitcoin\u2019s Energy Appetite", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "DAVOS, Switzerland \u2014 In the year and a half since Britain\u2019s shocking decision to sever itself from the European Union, Prime Minister Theresa May has labored to portray her country\u2019s future as one of glorious progress. She has described a bold new era in which Britain would look beyond the confines of Europe, striking trade deals and reclaiming its place as a global power.\n\nAll the while, an uncomfortable reality has been sinking in. Britain\u2019s stature on the world stage has diminished, and its economy has sagged. The former colonial empire has been reduced to a lesser actor, a reality that hit home on Thursday as Mrs. May delivered a sparsely attended speech before the World Economic Forum.\n\nMrs. May devoted part of her speech to declaring Britain\u2019s steadfast commitment to global trade and international engagement. But one of her primary examples of that commitment \u2014 highlighting Britain\u2019s role in a European bloc it is actively leaving \u2014 underscored the strange moment she inhabits.\n\n\u201cThe U.K. has been at the forefront of championing new trade deals including the E.U.\u2019s deals with Canada and Japan,\u201d Ms. May said. \u201cAnd as we leave the European Union, the U.K. will continue to be a global advocate of free trade.\u201d", "title": "Theresa May Arrives in Davos as U.K.\u2019s Post-\u2018Brexit\u2019 Slide Continues", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-08 00:00:00", "text": "Even though Mrs. May\u2019s de facto deputy, Damian Green, stepped down last month after he was found to have misled the public about pornography found on his work computer, she appeared to be in a stronger position now than at any time since the general election in June.\n\nThe prime minister reached an agreement with European Union leaders in December to proceed with talks on trade relations after Britain leaves, a process known as Brexit that is scheduled to take effect in March 2019. The accord was achieved without reawakening acute tensions in the Conservative Party over the extent of the post-Brexit ties between Britain and the bloc.\n\nBut the party\u2019s internal truce is fragile, and Mrs. May knows that her position remains vulnerable. Her cabinet has been carefully constructed to balance those, like Mr. Hammond, who want to keep a close economic relationship with the European Union, and those, like Mr. Johnson, who argue for a cleaner break.\n\nA desire to maintain that equilibrium partly explains why the two men remained in their posts, despite criticism of Mr. Johnson\u2019s performance as foreign secretary and calls from hard-line Brexit supporters for Mr. Hammond to be fired.\n\nMrs. May\u2019s reluctance to risk moving any senior colleagues, and the botched announcement of the new Conservative Party chairman, were described by some commentators in the British news media as the \u201cday of the blunt knives.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe headline on the website of the right-leaning Daily Telegraph described the reshuffle as \u201cchaotic.\u201d The BBC\u2019s political editor, Laura Kuenssberg, noted the slow pace of announcements and made an ironic reference to Mrs. May\u2019s widely mocked statement, made after modifying plans for social care during last year\u2019s election campaign, that \u201cnothing has changed.\u201d\n\n\u201cYou might almost say, almost \u2018nothing has changed\u2019 (so far),\u201d wrote Ms. Kuenssberg about the reshuffle on Twitter.\n\nOne minister who did leave the cabinet was James Brokenshire, who resigned as secretary of state for Northern Ireland for medical reasons, telling Mrs. May in a letter that he needed surgery to remove a small lesion in his right lung.\n\nA more problematic departure was that of Justine Greening, who resigned as education secretary after refusing to be moved to another job, according to British news media reports.\n\nMeanwhile, Mr. Green\u2019s position at the Cabinet Office was filled by David Lidington, who moved from his job as justice secretary.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMrs. May wanted to try to use the reshuffle to try to freshen the government\u2019s approach to domestic issues, after nearly a year of obsessive focus on Brexit.\n\nBut most analysts believe that she is likely to be stymied in that objective. Lacking a parliamentary majority, Mrs. May must often rely on 10 lawmakers from the ultraconservative Democratic Unionist Party of Northern Ireland to push legislation through. That weakness was implicitly acknowledged on Sunday, when Mrs. May said that she had abandoned plans for a vote on whether to reverse a ban on the divisive issue of fox hunting.\n\nAnd, despite her intention to focus more on domestic matters, the next 12 months are likely to be dominated by negotiations with the European Union, leaving ministers with little time or energy to tackle issues like health, transportation and housing.\n\nThe withdrawal negotiations are likely to be tougher than those that took place in 2017, which focused on issues like Britain\u2019s outstanding financial commitments to the bloc, the rights of European Union citizens and the Irish border.\n\nThe next round of talks, involving efforts to secure a transition period after Britain leaves the bloc and to map future trade ties, could further destabilize Mrs. May\u2019s government.", "title": "Theresa May Reshuffles U.K. Cabinet, but Little Changes", "authors": ["Stephen Castle"]} {"date": "2018-01-20 00:00:00", "text": "Pioneer Valley is one of 165 cohousing communities nationwide, with another 140 in the planning stages, according to the Cohousing Association of the United States. Most of these so-called intentional communities are multigenerational, while a growing number are either predominantly or exclusively occupied by senior residents. People own their own homes and can sell them on the open market. Residents pay into a fund to maintain facilities and collectively agree on how they should be used. Some, like Pioneer Valley, are rural. Others are suburban, and even urban.\n\n\u201cA lot of cohousing is out in rural areas, but we wanted to be in the city to be near things,\u201d said Janet Boys, 68, of Denver. She and her husband, Don McGuire, 73, left Philadelphia in August to move into the Aria Cohousing Community, a former convent close to parks and Regis University. The convent\u2019s dwindling community of seven nuns vacated the building when they could no longer maintain it, said Aria\u2019s developer, Susan Powers of Urban Ventures LLC in Denver. The initial group of residents, who in 2013 expressed interest in transforming the building into a cohousing community, had a bit in common with the previous tenants.\n\n\u201cThey were a group of single women, empty-nesters, who each lived in a single-family home and didn\u2019t want to live alone anymore,\u201d Ms. Powers said. Aria, which opened in August, now includes men and residents of every age.\n\nThe self-determination of Aria\u2019s founding residents is a hallmark of cohousing, along with clusters of houses or living spaces gathered around shared public areas. The heart of each community is the common house, or a space, where group meals are offered once or twice a week, together with activities and events. Houses are connected by pathways. Instead of a lawn mower in every garage, there often are no attached garages. Cars are exiled to peripheral parking areas, while a single, shared lawn mower suits the needs of everyone.\n\nThe common house is also where residents gather to make decisions about governance. Cohousing communities are most commonly set up as homeowners\u2019 associations, with residents adhering to legally binding bylaws. Yet with cohousing, there is one critical difference.\n\n\u201cWe are our own board, since most cohousing communities operate by consensus,\u201d said Karin Hoskin, executive director of the Cohousing Association of the United States and a resident of Wild Sage, a cohousing community in Boulder, Colo. Though typically not required, residents are expected, or at least encouraged, to attend the group dinners and pitch in where they feel most comfortable: maintaining the grounds, for example, or serving on committees. When it comes to finalizing decisions about maintaining common areas, or questions like noise levels in public spaces after certain hours, the entire community must agree. The objective, Ms. Hoskin said, was to regain a lost sense of community.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cI know all of my neighbors. If I need to borrow some eggs, I know which houses I can go to where they\u2019ll probably have eggs,\u201d she said. \u201cIf they\u2019re not home, there is a good chance I\u2019ll have a key to their house. It\u2019s really reminiscent of old-fashioned neighborhoods.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nCohousing can be traced to Copenhagen, where the first \u201cliving communities,\u201d or bofaellesskaber, opened in 1970. A decade later two architecture students, Charles Durrett and Kathryn McCamant, were on a year abroad at the University of Copenhagen. During Mr. Durrett\u2019s daily commute through mundane suburbs, he noticed one complex that stood out.\n\n\u201cPeople in this one development were always out there talking to each other, sitting at picnic tables drinking tea. There were children running from house to house, and people coming and going to this building, the common house, where nobody lived and apparently everybody lived,\u201d he recalled.\n\nMr. Durrett and Ms. McCamant later married and, in 1984, returned to Denmark to learn more about the concept. In 1988, they self-published a book on the topic, and three years later built America\u2019s first cohousing community, Muir Commons, in Davis, Calif. Since then, their Nevada City, Calif., firm, McCamant & Durrett Architects/The Cohousing Company, has designed 55 cohousing communities across the United States, with more in development.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe momentum for cohousing had been growing. The National Building Museum in Washington noted the recent \u201cboom in cohousing communities nationwide\u201d in a current exhibition. One reason for the boom is that cohousing construction is seen as a good investment, said Robert Jenkens, director of social impact initiatives at the National Cooperative Bank, a Washington lender that finances cohousing projects.\n\nSixty-two percent of people polled in a Cohousing Research Network survey last spring said that sale prices of cohousing units in their communities have been rising, according to an analyst for the network, Angela Sanguinetti. But, substantial down payments are not always required for prospective residents. Many developments offer units eligible for F.H.A. loans.\n\n\u201cI\u2019ve seen some terrific examples of cohousing developments that incorporate a number of low-income units, as many as 20 to 40 percent,\u201d Mr. Jenkens said.\n\nStill, there are those for whom cohousing might not work.\n\n\u201cSome people feel that cohousing is too much togetherness,\u201d said the social scientist Bella DePaulo, who wrote about cohousing in her book, \u201cHow We Live Now: Redefining Home and Family in the 21st Century.\u201d The model is also not for those who bristle at the self-governing element, she added. Then there is cohousing\u2019s association with hippies.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cPeople immediately think communes, but cohousing is not a commune where everyone lives under one roof,\u201d Dr. DePaulo said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFor aging hippies and baby boomers, however, dedicated senior cohousing offers an alternative to a retirement home.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s definitely a good aging-in-place or downsizing model for people in their 50s and early 60s who still have quite a bit of life ahead of them, but want to move out of the old family house because they want less maintenance,\u201d said Jim Leach, 77, a founder of Silver Sage Village, a cohousing community of mostly seniors in Boulder.\n\nCommunity living can also be a balm for the documented isolation and loneliness plaguing older Americans, which researchers say threatens public health. According to a 2010 AARP survey, social networks ease the loneliness that can follow the loss of a spouse, or family members\u2019 moving, Ms. Hoskin said.\n\n\u201cPeople aren\u2019t staying where they grew up anymore, and a huge trend among seniors is that they don\u2019t have their siblings or their kids around them because they\u2019ve gone away to university or moved out of state for a job. Living in a community can help people feel connected,\u201d Ms. Hoskin said.", "title": "There\u2019s Community and Consensus. But It\u2019s No Commune.", "authors": ["Tom Verde"]} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "And it has worked. Think of Bloomberg, which serves as the name of not only the company founded by Michael R. Bloomberg, the former New York mayor, but also a philanthropic foundation and a highly profitable terminal that sits on thousands of trading desks around the world.\n\nOr consider Donald J. Trump, who before he became president was the head of one of the country\u2019s best-known namesake brands. Nothing he owned, managed or marketed lacked the Trump name, from high-rises and golf courses to wine and water.\n\nMany other namesake companies have become so enmeshed in the business landscape that consumers forget they were once associated with a person: Procter & Gamble (a candle maker and a soap maker), Bose (an engineer), Duncan Hines (a restaurant critic), Doc Martens (a doctor who wanted comfortable shoes) and even institutions like the Mayo Clinic (not for mayonnaise but two brothers).\n\nMr. Donner said he had named his band after himself in the tradition of big-band leaders like Lester Lanin and Glenn Miller, whose orchestra still performs even though he died in 1944.\n\nPeter Thomas Roth, the founder and formulator of a cosmetics company that bears his name, said he had realized when he was starting his company in the early 1990s that it could take a week to come up with a name and two to three more weeks to check with the Patent Office to see if it had already been taken.\n\nPhoto\n\nHe remembered preparing for a trade show and needing a name, so he chose all three of his. He added the product\u2019s ingredients and intended purpose on the label.\n\n\u201cAt the beginning, there were no disadvantages or advantages because no one cared,\u201d Mr. Roth said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOccasionally, buyers wanted to meet him. \u201cSometimes, they\u2019d want me there because I was the face of the brand,\u201d he said. \u201cIt didn\u2019t always work. They\u2019d say, \u2018Can Peter come?\u2019 I\u2019d say, \u2018No, he can\u2019t come to Ohio for a $1,000 order because the airfare and hotel cost more.\u2019\u201d\n\nEarly on, Mr. Roth learned the extent and limits of having the company named for him. \u201cI can call the head of a company, and they actually take the call,\u201d he said. What he could not do, though, was call the same company\u2019s accounts payable department: \u201cYou can\u2019t call a customer to ask for money. You look like a loser.\u201d\n\nFor some entrepreneurs, their name is the only logical choice for a company.\n\nChris Kappler won gold and silver medals in equestrian events at the 2004 Olympic Games in Athens, which topped a career of some 100 horse-jumping victories on the Grand Prix circuit. He now runs Chris Kappler Inc., which helps people select and train horses and teaches riders of all levels in training facilities in New Jersey and Florida.\n\n\u201cIf you took myself out of it, there isn\u2019t much to it,\u201d he said. \u201cIt\u2019s a service business in a lot of ways.\u201d\n\nWith a namesake business, problems arise with success and failure. If the company is successful, selling it with your name on it can be difficult \u2014 and changing the name can create problems with how consumers identify with the brand.\n\n\u201cAll the great things you\u2019ve done to build your brand reside with you,\u201d said Kevin Lane Keller, the E. B. Osborn professor of marketing at Dartmouth\u2019s Tuck School of Business. \u201cIn technology, the chief executives and the founders are real important to the brands, the way Steve Jobs was to Apple. But they chose names that allow them to do many different things.\u201d\n\nThere\u2019s also the more mundane problem of what happens after an eponymous owner departs. Anyone looking for a job this new year might think of Russell Reynolds or Spencer Stuart, two gigantic recruiting firms named for people who are no longer there. Mr. Stuart died in 2011, and Mr. Reynolds is running a smaller firm after he left the company that bears his name in 1993.\n\nMr. Keller said savvy entrepreneurs could pivot, even at the smallest level. His dentist, Roger McWilliams in Hanover, N.H., removed his name from the practice a few years ago, and it is now known as Lyme Road Dental, after the street it\u2019s on.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cYou can\u2019t sell the firm, otherwise,\u201d said Mr. Keller, who takes no credit for the marketing move. \u201cHe came up with it on his own. I applauded the move, and it made a lot of sense.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nA name can also saddle others who share it with an association they might not want.\n\n\u201cIf you look at a brand like Steinway, that was originally a family name,\u201d Mr. Calkins said. \u201cToday, if your name is Joe Steinway, people will think you know a lot about classical music and have this association with you that isn\u2019t true.\u201d\n\nWhat a name can give a company is a story, which David Aaker, vice chairman of Prophet, a branding firm, said companies needed to get their brand noticed.\n\n\u201cFacts don\u2019t work,\u201d said Mr. Aaker, who is also an emeritus professor at the Haas School of Business at the University of California, Berkeley. \u201cPeople counterargue. They\u2019re skeptical. But if you tell them a story, that all goes away.\u201d\n\nMr. Kappler, the equestrian, used this approach to his advantage. He started riding when he was 9 years old and won Olympic gold at 37.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s helped because people who know me identify me as very methodical with my approach,\u201d he said. \u201cI take my time with the horses and riders. I develop them with confidence, so they\u2019re very prepared to any competition they go into. We\u2019re always thinking long term.\u201d\n\nOn the negative side, entrepreneurs can hurt their brand with personal mistakes. Several professors pointed to the example of Martha Stewart, who built a lifestyle brand around her aesthetic and perfect-lifestyle choices before going to prison in 2004.\n\nMs. Stewart was convicted of lying about selling stock based on inside information \u2014 and not of doing something related to her company \u2014 but it was not a choice any lifestyle guru would want to encourage.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cPeople have secret lives, people are fallible, they make mistakes, and sometimes they\u2019re scandalous,\u201d Mr. Aaker said. \u201cOr if you have a founder who is associated with failure rather than success, it\u2019s going to be harder to turn around than a failure connected to a product.\u201d\n\nPersonal squabbles become magnified, too. Mr. Roth had a run in the New York tabloids during divorce proceedings from his wife, who is also an executive at the company.\n\nRegardless of the growth that entrepreneurs achieve with the namesake companies, they need to keep doing what got them there in the first place: Work. Mr. Donner plays about a third of the 150 balls, galas and soirees his orchestras are hired for each year. And he said he called every client to get feedback.\n\n\u201cIf there is a small downside to the business, it\u2019s that I have to realize I\u2019m constantly the face of this business and I have to make sure that I\u2019m always appropriately dressed and handle myself in a professional manner,\u201d he said. \u201cSo I have a good time at a party but not too good of a time.\u201d", "title": "There\u2019s More to Naming a Company After Yourself Than Ego", "authors": ["Paul Sullivan", "Wealth Matters"]} {"date": "2018-01-29 00:00:00", "text": "Getting a mature plant in just a few months \u2014 with less fertilizer than needed for industrial crops like corn, and without chemical fertilizers or bug sprays \u2014 makes the potential for profit huge. As hemp taps water underground, its long roots circulate air, which improves soil quality \u2014 another boon for farmers looking to rotate crops.\n\nBattling the plant\u2019s powerful drug connotation might be the toughest hurdle for farmers and builders, and is possibly a more formidable obstacle during the Trump administration. The plant is still highly regulated.\n\nThis January, though, California legalized use of the plant in full. And the federal farm legislation of 2014 legalized hemp\u2019s cultivation for research purposes in universities in states where it\u2019s been approved by law. New York now funds a research initiative for as much as $10 million in grants toward hemp businesses, with participation in the pilot program from institutions that include Cornell University.\n\nStill, in the United States special permits are needed to build with hemp, and the requirements can vary by county and state. The first modern hemp house was constructed in 2010, in North Carolina. There are now about 50 such homes in the country.\n\nBut not much hemp is grown here; a little less than 10,000 acres so far, enough for about 5,000 single-family homes. Cultivated acreage in Canada is double that, and in China\u2019s Yunnan province, 10,000 farmers grow it. Roughly 30 nations now produce hemp, including Spain, Austria, Russia and Australia.\n\nHemp was rediscovered in the 1980s across Europe, where cultivation is legal, and France has became the European Union\u2019s largest hemp producer. Hundreds of buildings across the continent use the substance as insulation to fill walls and roofs, and under floors in wood-framed buildings.\n\nManufacturers say it\u2019s ideal for low-rise construction, a product that\u2019s stucco-like in appearance and toxin-free. Its promoters also boast that it has a lower carbon footprint, requiring three times less heat to create than standard limestone concrete.", "title": "There\u2019s No Place Like Home, Especially if It\u2019s Made of Hemp", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-16 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cWe\u2019ve made a show that by definition that a gay man that\u2019s lived through this experience is going to have a richer, deeper connection to this material than a straight guy who lived through that period of time,\u201d Mr. Landgraf said. \u201cThat\u2019s probably not the most commercial choice you could make in America, but the way you get to great television is to ask people to go into experiences that are compelling but that are challenging.\u201d\n\nSuch experimentation makes FX an appealing line item on the slate of properties that the Walt Disney Company is looking to buy from 21st Century Fox, in a deal that will depend on regulatory approval. Mr. Murphy, a hitmaker whose contract expires later this year, has said he is not sure if he will stay with Fox after the Disney sale.\n\nHe said he was inspired to do the show because he was living in Los Angeles at the time and gay men in all major national metropolises were transfixed by the story, and terrified Mr. Cunanan would be arriving in their city next. But when Mr. Murphy proposed a season about Mr. Cunanan three years ago \u2014 well before the Simpson series debuted \u2014 it gave his colleagues pause.\n\nNina Jacobson, a producer of the series, politely nodded along before she went home to Google the killer. \u201cI was pretty much in the dark,\u201d she said. Brad Simpson, another producer, had a dim memory, too, and wondered if there was \u201cenough meat on the bone.\u201d\n\nCompared with the abundance of coverage around the O.J. Simpson case (tons of books, boundless archives of material), the public\u2019s fascination with Mr. Cunanan\u2019s murder spree was faded like a pair of acid-washed jeans.\n\nBut the producers saw bigger themes in Ms. Orth\u2019s book. If Mr. Simpson\u2019s trial touched on racism and sexism, the Cunanan tale connected to something else: the shame of the closet, the remarkable difficulty of being openly gay in the 1990s.", "title": "There\u2019s Not That Much Fashion in FX\u2019s Big Versace Drama", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-22 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cAll the finger pointing has overshadowed the discussion about the actual substance of the budget deal,\u201d said Maya MacGuineas, president of the Committee for a Responsible Federal Budget, \u201cand many lawmakers don\u2019t even seem to care that the deal they are considering \u2014 which will almost certainly include even more tax cuts following the unaffordable tax bill Congress just passed, as well as new spending increases \u2014 will add tens of billions to the deficit. There is almost zero discussion of the ongoing damage on the nation\u2019s finances.\u201d\n\nThe health care taxes were all created as part of the Affordable Care Act, where they were designed to offset the cost of expanding insurance coverage to low- and middle-income Americans. But many of them, such as a tax on medical devices, have remained unpopular, and their implementation has been suspended or postponed before.\n\nThose delays have been preferable to lawmakers than eliminating the taxes entirely, given a total repeal would have added an estimated $310 billion to federal budget deficits over the next decade, Ms. MacGuineas\u2019s organization calculates. That price tag was too high to be included in the 2017 tax bill, which was limited in scope by Republicans\u2019 decision to pass the bill on party lines using a budget reconciliation bill that only allowed for $1.5 trillion in revenue losses over a decade.\n\nThe bill to end the shutdown, which funds government operations through Feb. 8 and also includes a six-year reauthorization of the Children\u2019s Health Insurance Program, did not move through budget reconciliation, the parliamentary procedure that circumvents filibusters in the Senate. That allowed Republican leaders to include the delays in the health insurance taxes without worrying about their fiscal cost, a move that drew few objections from Democrats.\n\nAll three health care taxes have been extensively discussed and debated by Congress since the passage of the Affordable Care Act.", "title": "There\u2019s a Surprise in the Government Funding Bill: More Tax Cuts", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 The North American Free Trade Agreement may not be a topic of frequent discussion in your household, but the trade pact probably plays a big role in your daily life.\n\nFrom the clothes you wear to the food you eat and the car you drive, many everyday products traveled on winding journeys across international borders before landing in your closet, your refrigerator or your driveway.\n\nMany of their paths are set by Nafta, a 24-year-old agreement that President Trump has called a \u201cdisaster.\u201d The president pledged to withdraw from the pact entirely if Canada and Mexico don\u2019t agree to his demands to reshape the agreement.\n\nNafta has had a profound effect on the three countries. It has encouraged United States companies to expand across the continent by abolishing the tariffs charged on products moving across borders. It has strengthened some industries, and hollowed out others.", "title": "These 3 Everyday Products Show Who Won and Lost From Nafta", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "A willingness to wager on the unloved also prompted his investment in Resolute Forest Products, a lumber, paper and pulp company based in Montreal. \u201cThere\u2019d been a tremendous investor focus on declining newsprint sales,\u201d he said. \u201cThe advent of the internet and digital delivery has changed the news business, and this was causing huge declines in newsprint demand.\u201d\n\nAhead of the Market How three of the better performers of the fourth quarter of 2017 fared against the market \u2014 and against their peer groups of funds. Delaware Smid Cap Aegis Value Chou Opportunity + 25 % + 25 % + 25 % + 20 + 20 + 20 + 15 + 15 + 15 + 10 + 10 + 10 + 5 + 5 + 5 S. & P. 500 TOTAL RET. S. & P. 500 TOTAL RET. S. & P. 500 TOTAL RET. 0 0 0 \u2013 5 \u2013 5 \u2013 5 O N D O N D O N D FOURTH-QUARTER RETURNS Aegis Value Chou Opportunity Delaware Smid Cap +21.7% +16.9% +18.0% Small-cap value Allocation \u2014 50% to 70% Equity Small-cap growth +3.8% +3.6% +5.2% Aegis Value + 25 % + 20 + 15 + 10 + 5 S. & P. 500 TOTAL RET. 0 \u2013 5 O N D FOURTH-QUARTER RETURNS Aegis Value +21.7% Small-cap value +3.8% Chou Opportunity + 25 % + 20 + 15 + 10 + 5 S. & P. 500 TOTAL RET. 0 \u2013 5 O N D FOURTH-QUARTER RETURNS Chou Opportunity +16.9% Allocation \u2014 50% to 70% Equity +3.6% Delaware Smid Cap + 25 % + 20 + 15 + 10 + 5 S. & P. 500 TOTAL RET. 0 \u2013 5 O N D FOURTH-QUARTER RETURNS Delaware Smid Cap +18.0% Small-cap growth +5.2%\n\nResolute is the world\u2019s biggest producer of newsprint. But, having emerged several years ago from a bankruptcy, it had restructured, emphasizing tissue making and lumber production. As a result, Mr. Barbee said, \u201cPeople are now seeing this as a lumber company instead of a declining newsprint business.\u201d That translated into a fourth-quarter surge, when the stock rose more than 100 percent.\n\nThat jump contributed to an overall fourth-quarter gain for Aegis Value of 21.66 percent, compared to 6.64 percent for the Standard & Poor\u2019s 500-stock index. The fund, whose retail shares have a net expense ratio of 1.75 percent, will celebrate its 20th anniversary this year. Over its life, it has returned an annualized average of more than 10 percent.\n\nResolute also helped propel the fourth-quarter gains of the Chou Opportunity Fund. Like Mr. Barbee, the fund\u2019s manager, Francis S. M. Chou, is value investor. He said he aims to buy a stock for no more than $60 a share if he estimates its value at $100. \u201cThat\u2019s my margin of safety.\u201d\n\nResolute, for example, \u201cwas really cheap,\u201d he said. \u201cThe book value was about $20 a share, and I bought at about $4. Even if you took the value of the newsprint away, it was still worth more than $4.\u201d\n\nMr. Chou\u2019s United States funds are relatively new \u2014 Opportunity began in 2010, as did his United States bond fund \u2014 but he has managed money in Canada for more than 30 years. His biography is unusual. He didn\u2019t attend business school or toil at another investment company. Rather, he was a telephone-company technician, enamored of the stock market, and persuaded several friends to start an investment club. The club evolved into his first Canadian mutual fund.\n\nHe likens his investing style to bargain hunting at the store. \u201cWhen you go shopping, you try to buy at a discount,\u201d he said. \u201cI do the same thing. I just need to understand accounting to evaluate the companies.\u201d He\u2019ll hold off buying unless he sees what he considers a great deal. \u201cYou have to have patience and buy when stocks are selling off for some negative temporary reason \u2014 like Resolute. Its valuation seemed as if it was totally dependent on newsprint.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMorningstar, the investment information company, classifies Mr. Chou\u2019s fund as a small-cap value offering, based on its holdings. But the fund can invest more broadly. Lately, for example, it has held large quantities of bonds and cash \u2014 the cash accounted for about one-fifth of its assets at September\u2019s end.\n\nFind Your Fund Explore Fund Results \u00bb See how the largest, leading and lagging funds compare. Search by Category \u00bb Find funds by their type, performance, risk or expenses. For more fund information, search morningstar.com.\n\n\u201cIf you\u2019re really picky, you may not be able to buy anything for a while,\u201d he said. \u201cIf I can\u2019t find anything I like, I\u2019ll stay in cash.\u201d\n\nMr. Chou\u2019s fund returned 16.94 percent in the fourth quarter. It has a net expense ratio of 1.2 percent. For the last several years, Mr. Chou has not taken a management fee because he said he has been unsatisfied with the fund\u2019s performance \u2014 the fund lost money in 2015 and 2016. He said he plans to begin taking the fee again.\n\nPhoto\n\nUnlike Mr. Barbee and Mr. Chou, Alex Ely, portfolio manager of the Delaware Smid Cap Growth Fund, doesn\u2019t obsess over cheapness. Rather, he seeks companies that can increase their earnings at well-above-average rates. \u201cWe\u2019re fanatic growth investors,\u201d he said. (Smid is a neologism for \u201csmall and mid cap,\u201d though Morningstar groups the fund with small-cap growth offerings.)\n\nTo find potential investments, he first identifies big economic themes \u2014 two recent favorites are \u201cmoney in motion\u201d and \u201chigh-quality construction\u201d \u2014 and then buys stocks that stand to benefit.\n\n\u201cMoney in motion\u201d means online banking, especially enabled by smartphones. While banks have offered online services for several years, Mr. Ely said consumer acceptance has advanced as the services have become easier to use. \u201cI don\u2019t think my son has ever been to a bank,\u201d he said. \u201cAnd soon we\u2019re all going to do our banking online.\u201d That\u2019s why his fund holds both Epam Systems, a tech company whose offerings include financial-services software and LendingTree, an online lender and financial marketplace.\n\n\u201cHigh-quality construction\u201d is Mr. Ely\u2019s shorthand for where he sees growth in home building. Residential construction has been sluggish since the financial crisis, but the market is providing pockets of promise, he said. People continue migrating to places with \u201clower taxes and better weather,\u201d like Tampa, Fla., Charleston, S.C., and Austin, Texas. So home building there is picking up, as are the stocks of builders that operate in the region, like LGI Homes, a recent top holding of the fund. Even in parts of the country where new construction remains slow, like the Northeast, people are increasingly renovating homes, he said.\n\nBy investing in American Woodmark, a cabinet manufacturer, Mr. Ely said, he aims to exploit both trends. New houses need cabinetry, and cabinet-heavy kitchens and bathrooms are \u201cthe leading areas people look to for improvements to their homes,\u201d he said.\n\nThe Delaware fund, whose A shares carry an expense ratio of 1.21 percent, returned 18 percent in the fourth quarter.", "title": "These 3 Mutual Funds Reaped Big Gains From Small Companies", "authors": ["Tim Gray"]} {"date": "2018-01-08 00:00:00", "text": "Extreme weather events caused a total of $306 billion in damage in the United States last year, making 2017 the most expensive year on record for natural disasters in the country, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration said Monday.\n\nA trio of major hurricanes, Harvey, Irma and Maria, contributed hundreds of billions to the total. But the year was seemingly mired in disaster, from a freeze in the Southeast that damaged fruit crops in March, to hail storms that whipped across Colorado, Oklahoma and other central states in May, to the tornadoes that struck the Midwest in June.\n\nUnusual consequences of extreme weather could be found all over the map. Thirteen cows died in a field in Pennington County, S.D., after ingesting anthrax spores from the soil; they had changed their grazing patterns during a drought that lasted much of the year in South Dakota, North Dakota and Montana. The cows\u2019 demise was a small part of the $2.5 billion of damage that struck the three states.\n\nIn all, there were 16 natural disasters that caused more than $1 billion of damage in 2017. In 1980, when NOAA first started tallying records, there were only three such disasters, adjusted for inflation. This year\u2019s $306 billion in damage broke a record set in 2005, when Hurricane Katrina contributed to a total of $215 billion in damage, also adjusted for inflation.", "title": "These Billion-Dollar Natural Disasters Set a U.S. Record in 2017", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "Theoretically, had Mr. Saipov obtained citizenship, he could have petitioned for his parents and three sisters (whose spouses and children under 21 could have also immigrated with them) to gain residency. Even in this hypothetical, it would have taken more than a decade for Mr. Saipov to sponsor 22 to 24 relatives.\n\nBecause there are numerical limits for family-based immigration each year, there is a long queue for visas. (As of Nov. 1, more than 3.9 million people were waiting in line.) After a petition is filed and approved, would-be immigrants are essentially handed a ticket number called the \u201cpriority date\u201d and can only apply for a green card when the State Department calls their number.\n\nThe waiting period can last a few months to more than two decades, depending on the country of origin, the sponsor\u2019s immigration status and the applicant\u2019s relationship to their sponsor. In January, for example, Uzbek immigrants sponsored by American-citizen siblings could begin to apply for a green card if their priority date was before June 22, 2004, a waiting period of 13.5 years.\n\nSome Republican claims about DACA exacerbating \u201cchain migration\u201d have been overstated.\n\nSenator Tom Cotton of Arkansas argued on the Senate floor on Monday that immigrants who came to the United States as children could petition their relatives for green cards, including \u201cthe very parents who brought them here, in violation of the law, in the first place.\u201d Representative Dave Brat of Virginia, in an interview this month on Bloomberg, estimated that giving legal status to some 800,000 people who entered the country as part of the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals policy could lead to an influx of \u201cthree to four million\u201d\n\npotential relatives when \u201cmultiplied by chain migration.\u201d\n\nA spokeswoman for Mr. Brat said the congressman based his estimate on research showing one immigrant could lead to an average of an additional 4.2 people coming to the United States, with higher numbers from South and Central America. That figure comes from a 2008 book on chain migration by Bin Yu, a professor at Rhode Island College.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Get the Morning Briefing by Email What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox Monday through Friday. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn an interview, Mr. Yu said he believed chain migration also included the American-born children of immigrants, whom he included in his 4.2 immigration multiplier average. It should be noted, however, that people who are born in the United States are generally given American citizenship. By confining so-called chain migration to foreign relatives, Mr. Yu\u2019s research shows that one immigrant could result in the sponsorship of an average of 2.1 additional people.\n\nMarta Tienda, a Princeton University professor and an author of a 2013 study that updates Mr. Yu\u2019s work, said it was inaccurate to just apply the estimated multiplier to the Dreamer population. Her study estimated that each immigrant sponsors an even higher average of relatives \u2014 3.45 \u2014 but she emphasized that included all immigrant groups and was driven by employment visas holders, who are much likelier to be naturalized and sponsor foreign relatives.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cYou can\u2019t just multiply by 800,000. That\u2019s crazy,\u201d Ms. Tienda said, adding the average number of relatives sponsored by Dreamers would \u201cabsolutely be much lower\u201d than 3.45.\n\nTo apply for the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals program, immigrants had to be younger than 31 on June 15, 2012, and must have proof of having arrived in the United States before 16. So their children are likelier to be American citizens, and their spouses also legal residents, citizens or Dreamers themselves.\n\nIf Dreamers are given a pathway to citizenship through legislation, their parents could indeed eventually obtain legal status. But those who entered the United States illegally are required to leave the country and wait three or 10 years before applying for an immigration visa. That\u2019s \u201ca significant barrier most would be unlikely to contemplate,\u201d according to the Migration Policy Institute.\n\nBecause these factors, the Dreamers would sponsor, on average, about one family member over their lifetime, the institute estimated.\n\nSome Democrats have misrepresented the Republicans\u2019 position on family-based immigration.\n\nRepresentative Adriano Espaillat of New York characterized chain migration as parents who want to \u201creunite with their children.\u201d Representative Luis V. Guti\u00e9rrez of Illinois defined it as immigrations petitioning for their spouses.\n\nRepublicans are not suggesting the elimination of family-based immigration, but rather limiting it to a so-called nuclear family \u2014 that is, a set of parents and their children.\n\nOver the summer, Mr. Trump endorsed a bill sponsored by Mr. Cotton that eliminates family-based immigration for parents, siblings and adult children. But the bill would still allow American citizens and green card holders to sponsor their spouses and children under 21.\n\nIt also establishes a visa class for foreign parents to visit their children who are American citizens. House Republicans introduced a similar bill on Wednesday that limits family-based green card programs to spouses and children who are minors.\n\nIn 2013, the Senate passed a bill that also eliminated visas for siblings and married sons and daughters over 31, and instead established a point-based system for their immigration. No Democrat voted against it. Though the House did not consider that legislation, Mr. Guti\u00e9rrez was a sponsor of a bill with similar provisions that year, despite characterizing Mr. Trump\u2019s demands to end chain migration and to build a border wall to limit immigration as \u201cransom.\u201d", "title": "These Claims About \u2018Chain Migration\u2019 Are Not Accurate", "authors": ["Linda Qiu"]} {"date": "2018-01-31 00:00:00", "text": "It started, as these things sometimes do, with a recurring dream: There is a woman lying prostrate on a bed. It is unclear who she is \u2014 mother? sister? lover? \u2014 but always she is dead. The dreamer has arrived, seemingly fresh from the battlefield, just in time to mourn her. The vision haunted the nighttime hours of the dreamer for 16 years.\n\nIf that dream seems ripe for interpretation and artistic reimagining, well, that\u2019s kind of the idea. For the Kolkata-based photographer, Soumya Sankar Bose, the dream (whose dreamer is a lesbian and close friend of Mr. Sankar Bose\u2019s) formed the kernel around which he crafted his new project, \u201cFull Moon in a Dark Night,\u201d in which he explores the psychological ramifications of anti-L.G.B.T.Q. laws and culture in present-day India.", "title": "These Dreamlike Portraits Explore L.G.B.T.Q. Identity in India", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "This \u201ctakeover\u201d of an art space by an ensemble of musicians is an experiment to explore how contemporary classical music can be experienced as a form of contemporary art. Mr. Meyers and Ms. Chong Cuy hope that when experimental music is freed from its traditional settings and brought into the \u201cwhite cube\u201d of a gallery, both the musicians and the audience will experience it in a completely new way.\n\n\u201cIf you think about the concert house, the opera house, the theater or even the club, these are spaces that have very specific rules that begin before you even enter the space,\u201d said Mr. Meyers, during a break between rehearsals. Although these types of performance venues have been the norm for hundreds of years, he said, they may not always be the optimal setting for contemporary classical music.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cFor the composer, these rules dominate the situation even before you step into the space, and sometimes even before you sit down to compose a piece.\u201d About a decade ago, Mr. Meyers started to compose work for museum and gallery settings \u2014 large open spaces, usually with white walls and bare concrete floors, without fixed audience seating or even set performance times.\n\n\u201cI found that I could have a different relationship to the audience,\u201d said Mr. Meyers, who is from New York and now lives in Berlin. \u201cFirst of all, they had agency \u2014 they could come and go. If they didn\u2019t like it they could leave, if they liked it they could stay. If they weren\u2019t in the mood, they could come back tomorrow.\u201d\n\nHe came up with the idea of a musical \u201ckunsthalle,\u201d the German word for a public building where art is displayed, and discussed it at length in an interview with Marie-France Rafael that later became the substance of the 2016 book \u201cMusic on Display.\u201d Defne Ayas, who was the director of Witte de With until last year, read the book and became intrigued with the notion, deciding to try it out at the arts center, as a \u201ctest drive for a new type of institution.\u201d\n\nThere is a long history of music in the context of visual art, from the Futurists in the early 20th century through 1960s conceptual art and John Cage, Ms. Ayas said in a telephone interview from Berlin, where she now lives. She added, however, that the exhibition in Rotterdam was \u201cthe first time we\u2019re really looking in a keen way at the structures and processes and social situations that come with music.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Meyers drew a distinction between music and sound art, which is often created specifically for art spaces. \u201cI don\u2019t consider myself to be a sound artist, I\u2019m a composer,\u201d he said. But the list of 38 musical compositions that he has put together for the exhibition contains both experimental pieces in the classical music tradition, and other works which have more to do with contemporary art.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe range of music on display begins with excerpts from Erik Satie\u2019s \u201cVexations\u201d (a single page of musical notation meant to be played 840 times) from around 1893, through Steve Reich \u201cClapping Music for Two Performers\u201d from 1972, up to Mr. Meyers\u2019s own \u201cElevator Music,\u201d a 2016 piece that will be performed live in the Witte de With elevator by a cellist.\n\nThe musical s\u00e9ance, one of four new commissions, was created by Ms. Gonzalez-Foerster, a French artist who described herself as a visual artist with \u201ca strong relationship to music\u201d rather than a musician or a composer. (In one of her recent works, she appears in a projected hologram dressed as the opera singer Maria Callas.)\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cA lot of music is made to be rehearsed and you think it\u2019s only good when you\u2019ve played it many times, but this is really the opposite,\u201d she said in an interview between rehearsals. \u201cIt very much relies on this first moment. It also depends on the person who is watching how it works in an emotional sense.\u201d\n\nFor her \u201cS\u00e9ance,\u201d she gave the musicians only a few instructions: to enter the gallery space and to take their seats one at a time; that the last person into the room should pick one of the pieces of paper out of the hat. Rather than calling up a particular composition by the dead composer, she asked the musicians to channel the idea of the person. And she also told them \u201cto forget about doing it well or doing it right.\u201d\n\nHalfway through \u201cS\u00e9ance,\u201d the music had escalated into a pounding, rhythmic maelstrom of sound, with strains of blues and the saxophone wailing. The music swelled and dipped, swelled again and then waned, until the instruments stopped and only a few voices were left singing unintelligible words, breathy and prayerful. Then silence, while the musicians sat again with heads bent. Then they stood quietly and walked one by one out of the room.", "title": "These Gallery Walls Are Empty. Here, You Listen to the Art.", "authors": ["Nina Siegal"]} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "Most striking is the fastidiously painted surface of the tabletop. It could almost pass for a plank of real wood. The wood grain seems to be of a higher order of reality than either the collaged-on snippets of newspaper or the human figure who is represented. The man lacks the sharpness, the physical thereness, of the objects around him.\n\nCornell, too, was a shadow of a man who read voraciously and disappeared into his books. As the writer Susan Sontag, a friend of his, once observed, \u201cCornell seemed to be a person who lived in his head rather than in his body.\u201d He no doubt felt a temperamental affinity with Gris\u2019s idiosyncratic version of Cubism, which was more cerebral than Picasso\u2019s, more measured, less an evocation of omnivorous appetite than of calm and patient craftsmanship.\n\nMuch about Gris\u2019s life appealed to the part of Cornell that valorized the marginal. A Spaniard who settled in Paris, Gris was the overshadowed, tag-along third in the Cubist triumvirate that featured Picasso and Braque. By the 1950s, Picasso was an international celebrity posing bare-chested for photographers at his villa in Cannes, but Gris didn\u2019t live long enough to garner worldly perks. He died of uremia in 1927, at the age of 40.\n\nCornell always worked in series, and his Juan Gris boxes, of which there are more than a dozen, would consume him intermittently from 1953 into the \u201960s. They\u2019re easy to recognize. They stand about 18-inches tall and feature the same attractive bird \u2014 a paper cutout of a great white-crested cockatoo that the artist lifted from a 19th-century British book on ornithology. Gris\u2019s influence at times asserted itself with remarkable specificity. For starters, Cornell adapted the telltale human shadow that appears in the upper right of the Gris painting. Cutting out silhouettes and reverse silhouettes from black paper, and pasting them to the back wall of his boxes, Cornell equipped each bird with an inseparable companion.\n\nAt other moments, the Gris influence feels more generalized, especially in the Philadelphia Museum of Art\u2019s magnificent \u201cHomage to Juan Gris\u201d (1953-54). The interior is wallpapered with pages from a French history book, as if to lend the bird never-ending hours of reading pleasure. The lesser boxes, by contrast, lack such unity. In \u201cUntitled (Juan Gris Series),\u201d circa 1953-54, the familiar cockatoo rests amid bare white walls, and assorted paper cutouts \u2014 including the bird\u2019s shadow \u2014 lie in loose disarray on the bottom of the box, as if the artist became distracted and forgot to finish what he had started.", "title": "These Shadow Boxes Are Striking. The Story of Their Origin Is, Too.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-17 00:00:00", "text": "Climbing into the driving simulator transports you from Hubneo\u2019s sterile confines into a rumbling car on a European racetrack, the growl of the engine blasting into your headphones. As the virtual speedometer climbs, a human driver\u2019s jaw will clench involuntarily, or relax into a grin. The steering wheel feels heavy with the friction of the tires on the asphalt, and the machines are sensitive to what\u2019s happening on the track. If the driver skids into a curve, the driver\u2019s stomach lurches too.\n\nNan Wen, 18, an attendant who was overseeing Hubneo on a recent Saturday night, assured the gamers that mild motion sickness is common for first-timers, though a customer has yet to actually throw up on his watch.\n\n\u201cWe have one regular who comes in, she can stay on the flight simulator forever,\u201d Mr. Wen said, \u201cbut she can\u2019t get on the racing machine.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAdam May, a graphic designer originally from Melbourne, Australia, said it was precisely these simulated G-forces that kept him coming back to Hubneo at least once a week.\n\n\u201cThese machines are the best that\u2019s been built so far,\u201d Mr. May said. \u201cYou ever heard the expression \u2018flying by the seat of your pants\u2019? You get all of the sensations on your bum, and you can\u2019t get that on a normal machine.\u201d\n\nMr. Wen estimated the cost of one of Hubneo\u2019s racing machines at around $15,000, and Hubneo is among the pricier VR spaces in town \u2014 $25 per experience, or $80 for four. At VR World, a two-hour pass costs $39.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cPeople get to know about us from their friends and from the community of gamers,\u201d Ilya Polokhin, Hubneo\u2019s chief executive and founder, wrote in an email. \u201dWe don\u2019t rely on and are not really interested in random foot traffic.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Polokhin said that Hubneo has angel investors, which may help answer the question: Can virtual reality survive New York\u2019s cutthroat commercial rents?\n\nMichael Deathless, one of the owners of another virtual reality space on Orchard Street, Jump Into the Light, said that the landlords on his block were expecting exorbitant rents. A 1,200-square-foot retail space next door is listed for $12,000 per month.\n\n\u201cWe just got a reduction, our landlord is so nice,\u201d Mr. Deathless said. \u201cBut it\u2019s still a ton of money. We are paying the bills, every week it\u2019s getting bigger and bigger, but it\u2019s a ridiculous way to try and make money.\u201d\n\nMr. Deathless, who is originally from Boston \u2014 and whose name is listed on his LinkedIn page as \u201cDeathless\u201d \u2014 said he is a software developer and compared Jump Into the Light to a kind of software incubator.
