He too, is working with partners and investors.\n\n\u201cThe people with an angle, they\u2019re going to survive,\u201d he said. \u201cThe people who just think they\u2019re going to have an arcade and make a lot of money \u2014 it\u2019s not going to happen.\u201d", "title": "They Have Seen the Future, and It\u2019s Wasting Zombies at the Arcade", "authors": ["Christopher Robbins"]} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "To better understand why the Jahai have this knack with naming smells, researchers compared a different group of hunter-gatherers on the peninsula, the Semaq Beri, with neighbors who are not hunter-gatherers. Even though they shared related languages and a home environment, the Semaq Beri had a superior ability at putting words to odors. These results challenge assumptions that smelling just isn\u2019t something people are good at. They also show how important culture is to shaping who we are \u2014 and even what we do with our noses.\n\n[READ: Ancestral Climates May Have Shaped Your Nose]\n\nIn the rainforests of the Malay Peninsula, the Semaq Beri, like the Jahai, are hunter-gatherers. But the Semelai, a group that lives nearby, cultivate rice and trade collected forest items.\n\nPhoto\n\nTo test their color and odor naming abilities, the researchers asked members of each group to identify colors on swatches and odors trapped inside pens. When it came to naming more than a dozen odors including leather, fish and banana, the differences were clear. The Semaq Beri used particular terms to describe odor qualities. But when the Semelai tried to identify the source, they often got it wrong. The difference between the two groups was as pronounced as the gap in the earlier study between the Jahai and English-speaking Americans.\n\n\u201cI thought the differences would be more subtle between the two groups,\u201d said Nicole Kruspe, a linguist at Lund University in Sweden who co-authored the study.\n\nPerhaps the importance a culture places on odor influences how people describe it. And if you depend on the forest\u2019s produce to live, you may want to know more subtle attributes that indicate origin, safety or quality.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cA cultural preoccupation with odor is useful in the forest with limited vision,\u201d said Dr. Kruspe.\n\nThe Semaq Beri value odors as food-locating resources but also as important pieces of life that can indicate a person\u2019s identity and guide taboos and rules for behavior. But \u201cthat in itself doesn\u2019t explain it,\u201d Dr. Kruspe said.\n\n[READ: The Nose, an Emotional Time Machine.]\n\nPerhaps well-practiced skills preserved odor-detecting genes or primed brains to be better odor-detectors \u2014 which suggests that without continuing to use this ability, it could one day be lost.\n\nAsifa Majid, a linguist at the Max Planck Institute for Psycholinguistics in the Netherlands and co-author of the paper, has also studied hunter-gatherers with comparable skills in Mexico and worries that pressures of globalization may disrupt these lifestyles, limit access to odors and threaten a vibrant odor lexicon.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOne way to explore that possibility would be to see what happens to the lexicon for odors of descendants of hunter-gatherers who have been removed from that lifestyle. \u201cUnfortunately,\u201d said Dr. Kruspe, \u201cwe will probably be able to test for that in a couple of generations.\u201d", "title": "They Hunt. They Gather. They\u2019re Very Good at Talking About Smells.", "authors": ["Joanna Klein"]} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "SALVADOR, Brazil \u2014 This northeastern Brazilian city is famous for its Afro-Brazilian drumming traditions; the internationally acclaimed bloco-afro band Olodum has broadcast its colorful drums and pounding syncopation internationally for decades through music collaborations including Michael Jackson\u2019s \u201cThey Don\u2019t Really Care About Us\u201d and Paul Simon\u2019s \u201cThe Obvious Child\u201d. To see that band \u2014 which is composed almost exclusively of men \u2014 or any of the city\u2019s other renowned bloco-afros, like Il\u00ea Aiy\u00ea, perform live in the streets of Salvador is a deep dive into the roots of this country\u2019s musical traditions.\n\nBut traditions change. Try Telling That to Banda Did\u00e1.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-01 00:00:00", "text": "In this era of alternative \u201cfacts\u201d and rising industrial sway in Washington, the well-being of Americans depends more than ever on financially and politically independent organizations that inform consumers and advocate for policy changes that help to keep all of us healthy.\n\nOne of the most influential such groups is the Washington-based Center for Science in the Public Interest, or C.S.P.I., led for more than four decades by Michael Jacobson, who recently stepped down as executive director to work in semiretirement as a senior scientist.\n\nInspired by Ralph Nader and armed with a degree in microbiology from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Dr. Jacobson and two co-founders burst onto the nutrition scene in 1971. Backed by the best scientific evidence of the day, C.S.P.I. relentlessly attacked the ingredients, marketing practices and dietary habits that research showed can undermine the health of Americans.\n\nWith a natural bent as a communicator, Dr. Jacobson was able to sell serious science with catchy phrases and humor, alerting the public to foods to avoid and offering suggestions for more wholesome alternatives. Today, the organization\u2019s Nutrition Action Healthletter still counters unwholesome products (it calls them \u201cFood Porn\u201d) with healthier options (\u201cThe Right Stuff\u201d).", "title": "They Took On the Food Giants \u2014 and Won", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-20 00:00:00", "text": "Two months later, he pardoned the socialist Eugene V. Debs, who had been imprisoned for speaking out against World War I; he even insisted that Debs (who had run against him for president from prison) pay a visit to the White House. In public Harding was a paragon of dignity, and his death was universally mourned.\n\nRichard M. Nixon\u2019s first year in office produced mixed results. He continued the Vietnam War but floated reforms such as a guaranteed annual income for the poor. He hinted at retreating from civil rights laws and court rulings, but enforced them. The year also yielded innovations like the National Environmental Policy Act, which Nixon signed into law in January 1970. The mixture of arrogance and paranoia that would lead to the Watergate scandal did not take hold until later.\n\nGeorge W. Bush has made some worst-presidents lists because of the disastrous Iraq war and the collapse of the economy under his watch. But his first year was notable for his post-Sept. 11 leadership, when he rallied the country\u2019s spirit while cautioning Americans not to turn their grief and outrage into reprisals against Muslims. He ended his first year with an approval rating in the Gallup poll of 83 percent.\n\nOnly two of the failed presidents had horrendous first years, which, like Mr. Trump\u2019s, were a result largely of their own actions. James Buchanan, a wealthy bachelor, at all times courteous and dignified, connived behind the scenes even before he was inaugurated to help coax the Supreme Court into the calamitous Dred Scott decision of 1857, handed down a few days after his swearing-in and widely considered among the court\u2019s worst.\n\nCalculated to suppress antislavery politics once and for all, the decision instead alarmed Northerners by allowing the expansion of slavery \u2014 and it helped set the nation on the political course that ended in civil war. The financial panic of 1857 and subsequent depression, the splintering of the Union and the later exposure of rampant corruption inside the executive branch added to the sense of Buchanan\u2019s fecklessness.\n\nAndrew Johnson, a vituperative racist, was temperamentally and politically unsuited to succeed the slain Abraham Lincoln. His troubles began when he showed up for his swearing-in as vice president drunk and belligerent. Lincoln, aghast, is supposed to have said that he never wanted to speak to Johnson again.\n\nAfter becoming president through assassination, Johnson at first signaled he would take a hard line against the defeated rebels, but then switched to attacking civil rights for the former slaves, siding with the ex-Confederates and engaging in abusive tirades against the Radical Republicans in Congress. He closed his first year by vetoing the Civil Rights Bill, which would have given the former slaves citizenship. Both houses of Congress swiftly overrode the veto, setting in motion the events that would end with Johnson\u2019s impeachment in 1868.", "title": "Opinion | They Were Bad. He May Be Worse.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Thiel, who has an estimated net worth of $2.5 billion, according to Forbes, has the means to beat almost any rival bidder. Gawker.com had published a black-and-white sex tape of Mr. Hogan, whose real name is Terry G. Bollea; a Florida jury awarded damages to the wrestler after a two-week trial.\n\nIt also emerged that Mr. Thiel had spent about $10 million in secretly backing the lawsuit, a move that many Gawker employees interpreted as an attempt at revenge. Mr. Thiel told The New York Times: \u201cIt\u2019s less about revenge and more about specific deterrence. I saw Gawker pioneer a unique and incredibly damaging way of getting attention by bullying people even when there was no connection with the public interest.\u201d\n\nUnivision bought Gawker Media at auction in August 2016 for $135 million. The company changed the name of its new asset to Gizmodo Media Group, after the group\u2019s Gizmodo tech blog, and jettisoned the Gawker.com flagship site, which remains online, albeit in a static form, a digital orphan. They were part of his collection of some 270 Indian and Indian-inspired gems and jewels, some dating from the 16th century, according to a news release for the exhibition, \u201cTreasures of the Mughals and the Maharajas,\u201d which opened in September.\n\nThe declared value of the stolen items on the customs form was 30,000 euros (about $36,000), but the Italian news media reported that they were most likely worth much more, as much as several million euros. Even so, the foundation that runs the museum told Italian reporters that the jewels were of less historical value than other items in the exhibition.\n\nPhoto\n\nAt least two thieves struck around 10 a.m. in plain view of closed-circuit television cameras. One opened the case, and the other acted as a lookout, Italian news outlets reported.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nDetectives were summoned from Rome to examine the crime scene, and Venetian prosecutors opened a file on the theft \u2014 for the moment, against persons unknown.", "title": "Thieves Steal Qatari Jewels in Brazen Theft at Ducal Palace in Venice", "authors": ["Elisabetta Povoledo"]} {"date": "2018-01-15 00:00:00", "text": "Thomas Collins, a preservationist who asked the commission to consider landmark status for the interior as well as the exterior after becoming \u201calarmed by the renderings\u201d from the new owners, called the landmarks commission\u2019s rationale \u201cflimsy.\u201d\n\n\u201cThe lobby is quite refined,\u201d he said. \u201cIt\u2019s a beautiful interior, clad in the same granite that covers the exterior. It\u2019s replete with historical motifs and sources that Johnson had mined throughout history. The same themes he was exploring on the exterior are magnified on the interior. The two are really inseparable.\u201d\n\nElizabeth Goldstein, the president of the Municipal Art Society of New York, echoed that idea.\n\n\u201cThe arcades, the open space, all of that was really designed with a single aesthetic vision in mind,\u201d she said last week, \u201cand that includes the lobby, no question about it.\u201d\n\nThe preservationists are upset that work has begun in the lobby. Liz Waytkus, the executive director of Docomomo US, a nationwide organization that works to preserve modernist buildings, said, \u201cWe were of the understanding that no work would be done, including in the lobby, until the exterior designation has been made and that more was needed to be known about the lobby area.\u201d\n\nA spokesman for the developers said by email that \u201call work being performed is in accordance with appropriate permits and approvals.\u201d\n\nTara Kelly, the vice president for policy and programs of the Municipal Art Society, described meetings with the developers and said that the work that is going on \u201cis very much contrary to the good-faith conversations that we had with them.\u201d\n\nThe spokesman for the developers, Jeremy Soffin, said he \u201cvehemently disagreed\u201d with that characterization.\n\nThe preservationists say the lobby should have been left untouched.\n\n\u201cJohnson knew exactly what he was trying to do,\u201d said Mr. Eddy, who is working on a documentary about Mr. Johnson, \u201cwhich was to create a monumental space made out of half-foot-thick panels of Stony Creek granite, the same material as Grand Central Terminal, the same material as base of the Statue of Liberty. You don\u2019t have to like the architecture, but you have to respect the thought that went into the corporate headquarters of, and this sounds insane now, what was then the largest company in the world.\u201d", "title": "This Building Could Be a Landmark. Should Its Lobby Be One, Too?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-03 00:00:00", "text": "Of the many small humiliations heaped on a young oncologist in his final year of fellowship, perhaps this one carried the oddest bite: A 2-year-old black-and-white cat named Oscar was apparently better than most doctors at predicting when a terminally ill patient was about to die. The story appeared, astonishingly, in The New England Journal of Medicine in the summer of 2007. Adopted as a kitten by the medical staff, Oscar reigned over one floor of the Steere House nursing home in Rhode Island. When the cat would sniff the air, crane his neck and curl up next to a man or woman, it was a sure sign of impending demise. The doctors would call the families to come in for their last visit. Over the course of several years, the cat had curled up next to 50 patients. Every one of them died shortly thereafter.\n\nNo one knows how the cat acquired his formidable death-sniffing skills. Perhaps Oscar\u2019s nose learned to detect some unique whiff of death \u2014 chemicals released by dying cells, say. Perhaps there were other inscrutable signs. I didn\u2019t quite believe it at first, but Oscar\u2019s acumen was corroborated by other physicians who witnessed the prophetic cat in action. As the author of the article wrote: \u201cNo one dies on the third floor unless Oscar pays a visit and stays awhile.\u201d\n\nThe story carried a particular resonance for me that summer, for I had been treating S., a 32-year-old plumber with esophageal cancer. He had responded well to chemotherapy and radiation, and we had surgically resected his esophagus, leaving no detectable trace of malignancy in his body. One afternoon, a few weeks after his treatment had been completed, I cautiously broached the topic of end-of-life care. We were going for a cure, of course, I told S., but there was always the small possibility of a relapse. He had a young wife and two children, and a mother who had brought him weekly to the chemo suite. Perhaps, I suggested, he might have a frank conversation with his family about his goals?\n\nBut S. demurred. He was regaining strength week by week. The conversation was bound to be \u201ca bummah,\u201d as he put it in his distinct Boston accent. His spirits were up. The cancer was out. Why rain on his celebration? I agreed reluctantly; it was unlikely that the cancer would return.", "title": "This Cat Sensed Death. What if Computers Could, Too?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-21 00:00:00", "text": "But Mr. Corp nevertheless contrasted the promises of prosperity made in 1989, when Canada signed a trade deal with the United States that became Nafta, with the pending G.E. shutdown and Peterborough\u2019s unemployment rate, which spiked at 9.6 percent last summer, Canada\u2019s highest at the time.\n\nHis views about Nafta \u2014 for which the latest round of talks begins in Montreal on Tuesday \u2014 echo those of labor leaders in declining industrial communities in the United States.\n\n\u201cThey said it was going to be great,\u201d said Mr. Corp, who looks younger than his 57 years. \u201cIf this is great, then maybe nothing would be better.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nPeterborough isn\u2019t an isolated example among industrial communities in Ontario. The Mowat Institute, a research organization focused on the province, calculates that between 2000 and 2011, Ontario as a whole lost about 300,000 manufacturing jobs. Those that remain are concentrated in food processing \u2014 Peterborough has both Quaker Oats and Minute Maid juice plants \u2014 and in production of cars and car parts, a sector that was never dominant in this city.\n\nBut Peterborough doesn\u2019t fit the image of a down-at-the-heels Rust Belt town. It sits at the heart of a spectacular series of lakes that draw vacationers from urban centers like Toronto. A canal popular with recreational boaters winds through the city and raises boats 65 feet in a massive lift lock, an aquatic elevator that has become a local landmark. North of town, the campus of Trent University is widely considered one of Canada\u2019s most important collections of mid-20th-century architecture.\n\nDespite its industrial woes, Peterborough has been growing. Many of the newcomers are people at or near retirement age who have sold their houses in Toronto\u2019s inflated real estate market and replaced them with much cheaper, and sometimes superior, homes here.\n\nYet old factory sites linger as landmarks. The Westclox clock factory, converted into condos and offices, still sits on a hill above the lift locks, though its clock tower no longer functions. The remains of the Outboard Marine Canada plant, where chain saws and Evinrude boat motors once moved along assembly lines, is now a celebrated museum devoted to canoes.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMayor Daryl Bennett is not among those who blame Nafta for Peterborough\u2019s industrial losses, and many economists share his view.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cThis community has changed immensely from where we were back in the \u201960s,\u201d said Mr. Bennett, a businessman whose holdings include a taxi service. \u201cYou could come out of high school here and go to any one of the factories in the city and have a very viable career, raise a family and maintain a good quality of life.\u201d\n\nThe mayor said that the shift of jobs away from large factories to federal and provincial government offices, tourism, hospitals, the local university and college and smaller manufacturers had begun before the introduction of free trade in 1989. The city\u2019s unemployment rate, he added, fluctuates, but is often near the national average. Last month it was 4.9 percent. But he, too, is dissatisfied with the current pact.\n\n\u201cNafta is a very interesting agreement,\u201d he said in his somewhat cramped City Hall office. \u201cMr. Trump is certainly not far-off on the need to make some changes to that agreement, quite frankly. But what those are is better left to the experts.\u201d\n\nAt the union hall, Mr. Corp\u2019s mood was more mourning than anger. G.E.\u2019s last 350 unionized employees make electric motors and generators so large that electrical lines sometimes must be lifted if the products leave town on extra-heavy-duty trucks. Peterborough-made motors turn cruise ship propellers, pump oil, power factories and mines and generate electricity around the world. (G.E. has not disclosed which of its remaining factories will pick up Peterborough\u2019s work.)\n\n\u201cThe guy that runs a lathe or a guy that runs a C.N.C. machine or a guy that winds large motors \u2014 they\u2019re skilled guys,\u201d Mr. Corp said. \u201cBut where are they going to get a job as far as government jobs in town? I don\u2019t mean that they don\u2019t have the smarts to do it. But they\u2019re in their mid-40s, mid-50s and they\u2019ve been tradesmen their whole lives.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThose who do manage to find something, he added, are unlikely to find jobs that include G.E.\u2019s generous benefits or match its pay rates, which start at about 30 Canadian dollars an hour.\n\nSome of Peterborough\u2019s industrial icons have survived. Before free trade, picture framers in Canada mostly turned to Peterboro Matboards. But as products from two large American mat board makers moved into the Canadian market after the trade deals, Peterboro failed to introduce new products or modernize its production. By 2001, the company was insolvent and had just seven employees. Then Alan Yaffe, a Toronto picture framer, stepped in, selling his business in downtown Toronto and mortgaging his house to buy the company.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSince then, Peterboro has become something of a trade success story. Mr. Yaffe invested in the plant and expanded the market for its products not just in the United States, but also in Australia and Europe, particularly Russia. The factory now employs 34 people, including two who have been with Peterboro for 50 years.\n\nStill, Mr. Yaffe feels that Mexico\u2019s low wages have sent too much work south. Whenever Peterboro Matboards advertises a job, about 100 people apply within a couple of days, he said.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s totally discouraging, I feel so badly for them,\u201d Mr. Yaffe said. \u201cPeterborough\u2019s got a good work force, there\u2019s no question of that. There\u2019s just not places for those people to work. It\u2019s crazy what\u2019s going on here.\u201d", "title": "This City Once Made Much of What Canada Bought. But No More.", "authors": ["Ian Austen"]} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "It is too early to estimate how many children will die this season, Dr. Jernigan said, because it still has weeks to run, and because the agency often does not learn of deaths \u2014 especially of children who die at home \u2014 until weeks after they take place.\n\nDespite the late date, the agency still recommends that Americans get flu shots. Because some doctors and pharmacies have none left, Dr. Jernigan suggested checking vaccinefinder.org to find providers with stocks.\n\nSome areas also have shortages of antivirals like Tamiflu, he said, and the C.D.C. is trying to help the supply chain move medicines to where they are needed most.\n\nMore people fell ill during the 2009 \u201cswine flu\u201d pandemic, but that was a new virus. This year\u2019s dominant virus, H3N2, has been circulating for 50 years \u2014 it emerged as the \u201cHong Kong flu\u201d in 1968 \u2014 but it is usually the most lethal of the seasonal strains.\n\nH3N2 also was responsible for bad seasonal flu years in 1997-1998 and 2003-2004, Dr. Jernigan said.\n\nAs is typical, people over 65 are the most likely to be hospitalized. But in an unusual twist, those aged 50 to 64 \u2014 rather than infants \u2014 are the age cohort right behind the elderly.\n\n\u201cBaby boomers have higher hospitalization rates than their grandchildren right now,\u201d Dr. Jernigan said.\n\nHow This Flu Season Compares With Recent Ones This chart shows percentage of outpatient visits for flu-like symptoms in this and previous flu seasons. % 7 6 5 4 3 2 1 0 10 20 30 40 50 2017\u20132018 flu season 2013\u20132017\n\nflu seasons\n\nWeeks from the early October start of flu season % 7 6 5 4 3 2 1 0 5 10 15 20 25 30 35 40 45 50 2017\u20132018\n\nflu season\n\n2013\u20132017\n\nflu seasons\n\n\n\nWeeks from the early October start of flu season % 7 6 5 4 3 2 1 0 5 10 15 20 25 30 35 40 45 50\n\nWeeks from the early October start of flu season\n\n2013\u20132017\n\nflu seasons\n\n2017\u20132018\n\nflu season\n\n\n\nHospitalizations and deaths among people in that age group can hurt the economy more than deaths of the elderly, he noted, since they are in their peak earning years and often in supervisory positions.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThey are also less likely to be protected. Recently, about 41 percent of that age group has gotten flu shots, while 57 percent of those over age 65 have; and the elderly usually get shots that are four times as powerful because their immune systems are weaker.\n\nDespite the efforts of public health officials, the number of people getting shots each year has begun falling slightly.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe intense 2009 swine flu pandemic, which sent demand for vaccines soaring, was followed by several mild flu years. Then the \u201cmoderately severe\u201d season of 2014-2015 was all but ignored by health reporters because they were focused on the Ebola outbreak in West Africa.\n\nIn this year\u2019s outbreak, \u201cflu intensity\u201d \u2014 a measure of how many catch the disease \u2014 is now widespread, but hospitalization rates have varied widely by region.\n\nCalifornia and the West Coast have been hit hard, with four times as many people hospitalized as in 2014-2015, Dr. Jernigan said. Minnesota had twice as many. New York and the Northeast \u201care beginning to catch up,\u201d he added.\n\nIntensity is high by two different measures the C.D.C. uses. For three weeks straight, the health departments of 49 states \u2014 all except Hawaii \u2014 have reported \u201cwidespread\u201d flu activity.\n\nAlso, sentinel sites in 39 states, New York City and Puerto Rico are reporting \u201chigh\u201d flu levels. (The sites include more than 2,000 emergency rooms, clinics and doctor\u2019s offices that report each week what percentage of their patients have flu symptoms.)\n\nAccording to the C.D.C.\u2019s weekly FluView, 6.6 percent of all patients visiting doctors now have flu symptoms. The 2014-2015 season peaked at 6 percent, while the 2009 \u201cswine flu\u201d season peaked at 7.7 percent.\n\nThree weeks ago, the C.D.C. thought cases had peaked during the week between Christmas and New Years Day. But they have climbed since, and Dr. Jernigan said it appeared to be due to \u201ckids returning to school.\u201d\n\nUntil recently, the severity indexes had languished behind the measures of intensity.\n\nThe agency\u2019s national \u201cPneumonia and Influenza Mortality Surveillance Index\u201d ripples like a sine wave, rising in winter and falling in summer. Until recently, the red line indicating deaths had remained firmly below the \u201cepidemic threshold\u201d even as the red line on a different index tracking doctor\u2019s visits was following the pattern set by the 2014-2015 season with eerie exactness.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThen, two weeks ago, the intensity line plodded steadily beyond the 2014-2015 Christmas week peak, but the mortality line initially did not budge. But it is now shooting upward at the high trajectory angle of a North Korean rocket, has passed the peaks of the last two seasons and is on track to match or surpass 2014-2015.", "title": "This Flu Season Is the Worst in Nearly a Decade", "authors": ["Donald G. Mcneil Jr."]} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "And the practice shows no sign of abating. Last year, there were \u201cAmityville: The Awakening\u201d (\u201cinspired by true events\u201d), the 18th in the series, and the U.F.O. thriller \u201cPhoenix Forgotten\u201d (\u201cbased on shocking untold true events\u201d); \u201cConjuring 3\u201d is still to come. But these are horror films. Do we need them to be authentic as well?\n\n\u201cIf you can establish that there\u2019s a true story, or that there are factual elements being woven into the story, then you\u2019ve taken a big step in inducing a creepy mood in your audience,\u201d said Stephen Prince, a cinema studies professor at Virginia Tech and editor of \u201cThe Horror Film,\u201d a collection of essays about the genre.\n\nBut how true to life can a horror film be, particularly ones, like \u201cWinchester,\u201d that are filled with spirits and apparitions? And who would believe these claims in the first place?\n\n\u201cThe audience for horror films is a very self-selected audience, in a way that\u2019s not true for a lot of other genres,\u201d Mr. Prince said. \u201cPeople who go to these films are ready to believe.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nInterestingly enough, the \u201ctrue story\u201d of Sarah Winchester, the one that keeps crowds flocking to the San Jose tourist attraction, was in doubt long before the Spierig brothers had their go at it. Sure, there was a real Sarah Winchester, and she did build a house in San Jose, but much of what people think they know about the woman and her house involves spook stories cooked up by journalists of her day, said the Winchester biographer Mary Jo Ignoffo, author of \u201cCaptive of the Labyrinth: Sarah L. Winchester, Heiress to the Rifle Fortune.\u201d\n\nThe stairs to the ceiling and the doors that lead nowhere? The result of earthquake damage left unrepaired after the 1906 San Francisco earthquake. All those rooms? A reflection of Ms. Winchester\u2019s interest in architecture and interior design \u2014 she came from a long line of woodworkers \u2014 not her belief in spiritualists or the supernatural. Her supposed \u201cgun guilt\u201d?\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s no evidence for that,\u201d Ms. Ignoffo said. \u201cNobody felt guilty about guns at the turn of the 20th century. Everybody used them and needed them.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cThe fundamental lie is that the building of the house went on 24/7,\u201d Ms. Ignoffo continued. \u201cShe didn\u2019t even live in the house for the last 15 years of her life.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nNone of which will lessen a viewer\u2019s enjoyment of the film \u2014 nor should it, particularly when it comes to horror movies. \u201cI think with horror, \u2018based on a true story\u2019 is much more loosely applied,\u201d said Jonathan Vankin, author of \u201cBased on a True Story: Fact and Fantasy in 100 Favorite Movies.\u201d\n\nAnd with horror films about ghosts and paranormal sightings, you\u2019re often getting what people say they saw, amplified by all the appropriate special effects. \u201cSo there are really two levels of reality there,\u201d he said. \u201cIt becomes very meta. So yes, it\u2019s a \u2018true story,\u2019 but maybe one with an unreliable narrator.\u201d\n\nEven so, the filmmakers read all they could about the house and its owner, consulted historical documents and period photographs, and visited the home five times. (While exterior shots were filmed in San Jose, much of the film was shot on a set in Australia, where the directors are based.) Among the completely true elements included in the film are the home\u2019s weird switchback staircase and the very unspooky reason for it. Ms. Winchester had rheumatoid arthritis, and the low-stepped stairs functioned as something of a ramp.\n\nWhile the film and the biography couldn\u2019t be less alike, both reach similar conclusions about Ms. Winchester: She was considerably more heroic, and considerably less nuts, than she has sometimes been painted. In Ms. Ignoffo\u2019s book, Ms. Winchester is a savvy businesswoman; a beloved employer; and a generous sister, aunt and philanthropist. In \u201cWinchester,\u201d she\u2019s a tough heroine out to protect her family and home from evil spirits and greedy company executives alike.\n\nIf the film often strays from the truth for the sake of a good scare \u2014 there\u2019s no record that Ms. Winchester was ever attacked by a boy possessed by the ghost of a murderous Confederate soldier, for example \u2014 that\u2019s fine with its creators. \u201cUltimately you\u2019re not making a documentary,\u201d Michael Spierig said. \u201cYou\u2019re making a piece of entertainment.\u201d", "title": "This Horror Movie Is Based on a True Story. Sort Of.", "authors": ["Robert Ito"]} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "In the new study, led by Alan Wilson, a professor of locomotor biomechanics at the Royal Veterinary College in London, researchers captured thousands of high-speed runs by fitting five cheetahs, seven impalas, nine lions and seven zebras with custom collars that could record each animal\u2019s location, speed, acceleration, deceleration and turning performance many times per second. They also took tiny muscle biopsies from each animal.\n\n[READ: In DNA, Clues to the Cheetah\u2019s Speed and Hurdles]\n\nThough cheetahs and impalas were universally more athletic than lions and zebras, both cheetahs and lions had a similar advantage over their prey \u2014 they were 38 percent faster, 37 percent better at accelerating, 72 percent better at decelerating and their muscles were 20 percent more powerful.\n\nThis makes sense because the predators are always a step behind, Dr. Wilson said. They have to run faster to catch up, but they must also be able to decelerate quickly in case their targets decide to suddenly slow down and turn.\n\nThe data also showed that impalas and zebras were typically moving at only half their maximum speed when running from their pursuers. To confirm why, the scientists created a computer model that simulated the last moments of a hunt, after a predator has closed in enough to capture its prey within two strides.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe model showed that impalas and zebras have the best chance of making a getaway if they run at moderate speeds, because that leaves more options for maneuvering away at the last second.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIf you\u2019re running flat out, there\u2019s not much you can do to stop a lion from anticipating exactly where you\u2019re going to be in two strides\u2019 time,\u201d Dr. Wilson said.\n\nRunning at a lower speed, however, means an animal can speed up or slow down. It can also make far sharper twists and turns than if it were running at full steam.\n\n[READ: Cheetahs\u2019 Secret Weapon: A Tight Turning Radius]\n\nThe consistent difference in athleticism between the cats and their prey helps maintain balanced numbers of each group in the savanna, Dr. Wilson added. Generally, cheetahs and lions are successful at catching their prey one out of every three hunts.\n\n\u201cThis research suggests that these predator-prey pairs have been co-evolving in an evolutionary arms race,\u201d said Talia Yuki Moore, a postdoctoral fellow studying biomechanics at the University of Michigan who did not participate in the study. \u201cOne\u2019s trying to eat, and the other\u2019s trying not to get eaten.\u201d", "title": "This Is How You Escape a Cheetah, if You\u2019re an Impala", "authors": ["Steph Yin"]} {"date": "2018-01-14 00:00:00", "text": "Asked if she was in the carriage for a long time, she replied dryly, \u201cHalfway around London.\u201d\n\nThe big day began with her parading around the British capital, going from Buckingham Palace to Westminster Abbey and stopping at Trafalgar Square.\n\nMr. Bruce told InStyle: \u201cThere is a tradition in the English coronation that if you have a monarch who slips or drops something or anything like that \u2014 in fact, Richard II\u2019s slipper fell off when he was being carried back to bed because he had fallen asleep during the ceremony, and everyone saw that as a bad omen.\u201d\n\nHe added: \u201cThis is a huge challenge, I would imagine, for anybody to perform without fault through a medieval ceremony that has unbelievable symbolism and meaning.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThe crown was too big for her head.\n\nAnd heavy.\n\nThe version of the Imperial State Crown that the queen wore at the end of the ceremony was also donned by her father, George VI, at his coronation in 1937.\n\nIt is set with 2,868 diamonds, 17 sapphires, 11 emeralds and hundreds of pearls. It features a gemstone known as the Black Prince\u2019s Ruby, believed to have been worn by Henry V at the Battle of Agincourt in 1415.\n\nThe rest of her regalia was already a handful, but the crown was its own challenge. So she practiced wearing it before the coronation, while going about her ordinary day, such as reading the newspaper or taking tea.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe crown, which she has worn for most state openings of Parliament since the coronation, was adapted slightly after the death of her father, with its arches lowered to create a smaller, more feminine object for the queen.\n\n\u201cYou see, it\u2019s much smaller isn\u2019t it?\u201d she says in a BBC trailer, gesturing to the height of the crown\u2019s arches. It had been \u201cvery unwieldy,\u201d she added.\n\n\u201cFortunately, my father and I have about the same sort of shaped head. But once you put it on it stays. I mean, it just remains on.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThe crown could break your neck.\n\nThe queen notes that the crown forces one to take a certain posture when giving a speech.\n\n\u201cYou can\u2019t look down to read the speech; you have to take the speech up,\u201d she said, \u201cbecause if you did, your neck would break; it would fall off,\u201d she said, smiling.\n\n\u201cSo there are some disadvantages to crowns, but otherwise they\u2019re quite important things.\u201d\n\nAs the queen handles the crown, she points to four pearls hanging underneath the arches, two of which are believed to have belonged to Mary, Queen of Scots and bought by Elizabeth I.\n\n\u201cThey were meant to be Queen Elizabeth\u2019s earrings,\u201d she said, joking, \u201cThey don\u2019t look very happy now. Most pearls like to be sort of living creatures, so they\u2019ve just been out, hanging out here for years. It\u2019s rather sad.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe Crown Jewels were once buried in a biscuit tin.\n\nThe Crown Jewels are usually kept under armed guard at the Tower of London. But gemstones from the collection were hidden in a biscuit (cookie) tin at Windsor Castle for safekeeping during World War II to keep them out of the hands of the Nazis.\n\nThe stones, including the Black Prince\u2019s Ruby from the Imperial State Crown, were placed in the metal box and buried below a secret exit on the orders of King George VI.\n\nThe rediscovery of those mysterious details were credited to Oliver Urquhart Irvine, the librarian and assistant keeper of the Royal Archives.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nDocuments describe a hole being dug in chalk earth, which had to be covered to hide it from enemy bombers, and two chambers with steel doors being created. The trap door used to access the secret area at Windsor Castle, where the queen spent the war years for safety, still exists today.\n\nThe queen, who at one point in the documentary wonders aloud what she has done with her scepter (her own scepter!), intimates that her favorite gem in the Imperial State Crown is the Black Prince\u2019s Ruby.\n\nPhoto\n\nHer robes became stuck on the carpet.\n\nThe queen\u2019s coronation gown and robes were so heavy that they got caught in a thick carpet pile as she glided through the abbey.\n\n\u201cI couldn\u2019t move at all,\u201d she declared.\n\nThe gown and robe were created by Norman Hartnell, the couturier who had made her wedding dress five years before, according to The Telegraph.\n\nMr. Hartnell and the queen chose motifs from across the United Kingdom and the Commonwealth: maple leaves for Canada, wheat sheaves for Pakistan, lotus flowers for South Africa, the English Rose, Welsh leeks, Scottish thistles and Irish shamrocks.\n\nDiamonds, crystals, pearls, amethysts and rose-color stones were used as twinkling embellishments to the gold and colored silk threads.\n\nSix embroiderers took 3,000 hours to complete the design.\n\nIn footage of the coronation, a maid of honor is seen tripping while the queen giggles, and a young Prince Charles and Princess Anne play underneath her robes.\n\n\u201cNot what they\u2019re meant to do,\u201d the queen remarked.", "title": "This Is What We Learned When the Queen Opened the Vault", "authors": ["Yonette Joseph"]} {"date": "2018-01-03 00:00:00", "text": "BUFFALO \u2014 There are two kinds of defendants who enter Judge Craig D. Hannah\u2019s courtroom: Those who stand on the far side of the bench to have their cases considered in the usual way, and those invited to step closer. Close enough to shake the judge\u2019s hand or shout obscenities in his face, depending on their mood that day.\n\nBoth kinds are facing criminal charges, but those in the second group have volunteered to take part in an experiment where the primary goal is to save their lives. Arrested for crimes related to addiction, they are participants in what is believed to be the nation\u2019s first opioid court.\n\nUnlike typical drug courts, which can end in punishment if defendants relapse, this one recognizes that failure is part of the recovery process.\n\nIts measure of success \u2014 preventing death \u2014 is arguably a low bar. Then again, few initiatives have made much of a dent in an epidemic that is killing more people each year than car accidents do. The criminal justice system may not be the ideal place to address addiction, but the reality is that it is a place where drug users are a captive audience. And the court, by linking with nonprofits, offers treatment for those who could not otherwise afford it. Court systems around the country are watching Buffalo as a potential model.", "title": "This Judge Has a Mission: Keep Defendants Alive", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "Q. What is the robot made of, and how does it work?\n\nA. Our robot is made of an elastomer rubber, which is filled with many magnetic, small particles. We program the magnetic properties of these particles so that from outside, when we apply a magnetic field, the elastic sheath-shaped robot changes its shape to anything that we want.\n\nThen it does all these different motions. When you look at this tiny thing crawling and jumping and all these things, it looks like a creature.\n\nWhere do you see work on this new robot heading? Where will future versions go?\n\nOne of the current major goals is to put this tiny soft robot into our digestive system or urinary system \u2014 and in the future, the vascular system \u2014 and for it to be able to navigate across all these complex tissues, surfaces which are fully filled with fluids or semi-filled, or no fluids.\n\nIf you look at the medical devices we have, the smallest ones are catheters, which are a millimeter in diameter, and they are always tethered. So our main goal in making tiny robots is to really access hard-to-reach or even not-possible-to-reach areas in our body with minimal invasion.\n\nThe robots already are small enough for our digestive system and urinary system. We\u2019d like to go smaller, even down to tens of microns, so that we can reach almost anywhere inside your body.\n\nAnd you think it could one day deliver drugs?\n\nOne of the functions we have been exploring is how to deliver a cargo, which could be drugs, inside the body. There are different ways. With a shape change, we can grab the cargo and then deliver it by opening the shape.\n\nThe second way is we make a small pocket on the robot that only opens with a special shape change that we can control.", "title": "This Tiny Robot Walks, Crawls, Jumps and Swims. But It Is Not Alive.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-06 00:00:00", "text": "The only on-call nurse was helping another family two hours away. So my sister and I experimented with Ativan and more oxycodone, then fumbled through administering a dose of morphine that my mother found in a cabinet, left over from a past hospital visit. That was lucky, because when the nurse arrived at midnight, she brought no painkillers.\n\nAfter the nurse left, my father\u2019s pain broke through the morphine. I called the switchboard again, and it took three hours for a new nurse to come. She was surprised he hadn\u2019t been set up with a pump for a more effective painkiller. She agreed that this constituted a crisis and should trigger the promised round-the-clock care. She made a phone call and told us the crisis nurse would arrive by 8 a.m.\n\nThe nurse did not come at 8 a.m. Or 9 a.m. When his case worker was back on duty, she told us \u2014 apologetically \u2014 that the nurse on that shift had come down with strep throat. Her supervisor stopped by, showed us the proper way to deliver morphine (we\u2019d been doing it wrong) and told us a pain pump and a crisis nurse should arrive by noon.\n\nNoon passed, then 1 p.m., 2 p.m. No nurse, no pump.\n\nBy this time, my father had slipped into a coma without our noticing; we were thankful his pain was over but heartbroken he wouldn\u2019t hear our goodbyes. Finally, at 4 p.m., the nurse arrived \u2014 a kind, energetic woman from Poland. But there was little left to do. My father died an hour later.\n\nAt the end of life, things can fall apart quickly, and neither medical specialist nor hospice worker can guarantee a painless exit. But we were told a palliative expert would be at my father\u2019s bedside if he needed it. We were not told this was conditional on staffing levels.\n\nI didn\u2019t realize how common our experience was until a few months after his death, when two reports on home hospice came out \u2014 one from Politico and one from Kaiser Health News. According to their investigations, the hospice system, which began idealistically in the 1970s, is stretched thin and falling short of its original mission.\n\nMany of the more than 4,000 Medicare-certified hospice agencies in the United States exist within larger health care or corporate systems, which are often under pressure to keep profit margins up.", "title": "Opinion | This Was Not the Good Death We Were Promised", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-08 00:00:00", "text": "Inspecting the tiny roundworms Caenorhabditis briggsae and Caenorhabditis nigoni through a microscope, you\u2019d have trouble telling them apart. Both are about a millimeter long and transparent. On the evolutionary tree, they\u2019re closer together than horses and donkeys.\n\nThe key distinction between the two nematodes is their sex lives. Sex in C. nigoni takes place between a male and female. But only a small minority of C. briggsae are males. The rest are hermaphroditic females that reproduce by self-fertilizing, or selfing. They have evolved the ability to produce sperm that merge with their own eggs.\n\nThis sexual switch may have caused profound changes at the genetic level for C. briggsae. In a study published last week in Science, biologists reported that C. briggsae lost thousands of genes \u2014 a staggering quarter of its genome \u2014 since it diverged from C. nigoni a million years ago.\n\n\u201cMany of these genes had been around, and were presumably needed, for tens of millions of years or longer,\u201d said Eric Haag, a biology professor at the University of Maryland, College Park, and an author of the paper. \u201cIn the blink of an eye, they disappeared.\u201d He and his co-authors believe that a large portion of the genes shed are related to male reproduction.", "title": "This Worm Evolved Self-Fertilization and Lost a Quarter of Its DNA", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-31 00:00:00", "text": "Over a year ago my I moved to New Zealand with my family. It has been amazing in so many ways, but I do have to admit to being lonely sometimes.\n\nI miss my friends. I miss the friends who have celebrated with me during moments of great joy and have mourned with me when times were tough.\n\nThere is a sense of connection that comes from sharing one another\u2019s burdens that is impossible to replicate with a \u201clike\u201d or a tweet. Deep friendship requires an investment of time and energy, and that seems harder now that there are so many shallow, counterfeit versions of friendship that give us the false sense of being connected but lack any depth.\n\nTo address this feeling, I\u2019ve decided to invest in friendship and human connection this year. And it feels contrived. Who needs a plan for friendship?!", "title": "This Year, Make an Investment in Your Friendships", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "Hurrah! For the second year running, the Oscars won\u2019t be so white.\n\nSure, the nominations on Tuesday had some lamentable omissions \u2014 Dee Rees for best director, for one, along with her movie \u201cMudbound.\u201d But one of its stars, Mary J. Blige, got two nominations, and Jordan Peele got three, with \u201cGet Out,\u201d his evisceration of smug white liberalism, landing on the best picture list.\n\nTo quote Tiffany Haddish, as she stumbled over the \u201cGet Out\u201d star Daniel Kaluuya\u2019s name while announcing the nominees, \u201cKallelujah!\u201d\n\nAlso, wahoo, the Oscars won\u2019t be so male. Greta Gerwig became only the fifth woman to ever get a directing nomination, for \u201cLady Bird,\u201d Rachel Morrison became the first female Oscar-nominated cinematographer, for \u201cMudbound,\u201d and four of the nine best picture finalists are about women.\n\nBut check out the list of nominated actresses. It\u2019s hard to find an ing\u00e9nue \u2014 to use a term long past its sell-by date \u2014 in the bunch. And by and large, the women these actresses portray onscreen are not \u201clikable\u201d in the traditional sense but instead wily, ferocious and unbowed.", "title": "This Year\u2019s Oscars Belong to Strong Women in Fierce Roles", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "You\u2019ve been herding cattle for much of the decade. What lured you back to television?\n\nI did \u201cSmart People\u201d with S.J. [in 2008] and just enjoyed her humor and her intelligence, and as a professional I thought she was almost peerless. And she called me, I guess it will be three years [ago] in January, and said: \u201cHey, would you read this? I\u2019d really like you to do it with me.\u201d\n\nWhat\u2019s it like working with her?\n\nShe\u2019s a wonderfully kind person, and you\u2019re like, \u201cThis is somebody that I\u2019d like to be in business with.\u201d I don\u2019t know what S.J. would be doing if she wasn\u2019t where she is at the table of life. I think she\u2019d be an astronaut or running a multinational corporation or a champion Nascar driver.\n\nThis season, Robert and Frances are moving on, which I find bittersweet.\n\nWell, don\u2019t start dressing that carriage just yet. We never know what can happen in the post-mortem of that divorce. Last year, wow, we really did explore the darkness of a family being torn apart, and there\u2019s still some of that conflict here and there. But now it\u2019s principally about parenting, and getting that right with a 17- and a 13-year-old.\n\nAnd you acquire a new love, played by Becki Newton.\n\nI was concerned at first about that because Becki and I are, like, 18 years apart. But her character has a grown daughter, and we have our children, and you can make that connection emotionally after a certain age. Becki and I talked about it a good bit, and she\u2019s like, \u201cYou know, it doesn\u2019t seem awkward to me.\u201d And I was like, \u201cAll right, I\u2019ll roll with it.\u201d\n\nYou might have to shave that mustache. It\u2019s a character unto itself.\n\nI had grown it right before we did the pilot for a role in \u201cDaddy\u2019s Home,\u201d and Will Ferrell told me, \u201cYou look like a Civil War general.\u201d I thought that\u2019s a great look for me right now. And the mustache just turned into this cottage industry.", "title": "Thomas Haden Church Is Keeping That Mustache", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "At another church festival, Mr. Luken followed Steve Chabot, his Republican opponent in a congressional election, as he handed out plastic cups with his name on them. Howard Wilkinson, a political reporter for WVXU Radio in Cincinnati, recalled on the station on Thursday that Mr. Luken had then promised potential voters: \u201cIf you come up to me with a Chabot for Congress cup, I\u2019ll fill it with beer.\u201d\n\n\u201cThat won him a lot of votes,\u201d Mr. Wilkinson said.\n\nThomas Andrew Luken was born in Cincinnati on July 9, 1925. His father, Walter, was a factory worker; his mother, the former Minnie Kisbert, was a homemaker. After graduating from Xavier University and the Salmon P. Chase Law School, both in Cincinnati, he served in the Marines. (The law school later moved across the Ohio River to become part of Northern Kentucky University.)\n\nHe was elected city solicitor of Deer Park, a suburb of Cincinnati, before being named first assistant United States attorney for the Southern District of Ohio. That appointment was helped by his brother Jim, a labor leader whose friendship with Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy was based in part on their dislike of the Teamsters union president, Jimmy Hoffa. Jim Luken pulled his milk deliverers union out of the Teamsters in 1961.\n\nAfter serving on the City Council, which included a year as mayor, from 1971 to 1972 \u2014 at the time, the council elected the mayor \u2014 Mr. Luken won a special election to fill a vacant seat in Congress in 1974. The vote came amid a backlash against Republicans in the wake of the Watergate scandal.\n\nHe lost an election for a full term later that year but returned to Congress when he moved to another district in 1976. He was re-elected six times.\n\nMr. Luken found a major issue in the late 1980s: the power of tobacco companies.\n\n\u201cHe had lost three siblings to lung cancer,\u201d Charlie Luken said, \u201cand he took on Big Tobacco full throttle.\u201d\n\nMr. Luken introduced legislation that would have prohibited the sale of cigarettes in vending machines, stiffened warnings about the health risks of cigarettes and required that tobacco be regulated as a toxic substance by the Environmental Protection Agency.", "title": "Thomas Luken, Veteran Ohio Democrat, Is Dead at 92", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-03 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cIt changed the whole view of what women would do: that they would go just like the men,\u201d Professor Bushman said. \u201cThere was a great surge of readiness. It changed their mentality.\u201d\n\nTwo years of missionary work abroad or in the United States are a rite of passage and a duty for able Mormon men, a preparation for service in a church operated by its male laity. Women\u2019s missionary service is 18 months and optional. The surge of female volunteers after the age limits were lowered suggested that many had long been eager to go.\n\n\u201cSisters always had that little thought of serving a mission, but by the time 21 comes, you\u2019re married or onto something else,\u201d Shoushig Tenguerian, a student at Southern Virginia University, a private Mormon college, told The Times in 2012. \u201cThis age change changes everything.\u201d\n\nDespite persistent demands for change on another feminist issue, Mr. Monson \u2014 who as president was considered by adherents to be God\u2019s \u201cprophet, seer and revelator\u201d \u2014 did not open the door to women in the priesthood, which, like the Mormon hierarchy, has been male since the church was founded in the early 19th century. Critics say the ban on female priests has no explicit basis in church Scripture, but efforts to overturn it were sometimes dealt with harshly.\n\nSome Mormons faced sanctions for questioning church positions on women\u2019s roles. Kate Kelly, a feminist Mormon lawyer, was excommunicated on a charge of apostasy in 2014 after founding the organization Ordain Women.\n\nAs the 16th president of the Latter-day Saints, succeeding Gordon B. Hinckley, Mr. Monson faced another test when church members, increasingly scouring online sources, found apparent contradictions between historical records and church teachings.\n\nAlthough the church officially abandoned plural marriages in 1890, it was a defiantly polygamous theocracy in the mid-19th century. In a 2014 teaching, \u201cPlural Marriage in Kirtland and Nauvoo,\u201d the church said that Joseph Smith, the church founder, had married as many as 40 women, some of them already married. It said that Smith was a reluctant polygamist, agreeing to multiple marriages only after an angel threatened him with a sword.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSome critics said that the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints had previously contended that Smith had been happily married to only one woman, and that the new teaching \u2014 in the words of the website OnceDelivered.net, which identified itself as an expression of the Baptist faith \u2014 had used Scripture to \u201caddress the inconvenient truth of Smith\u2019s polygamy.\u201d\n\nIn recent years, the church allowed historians access to church documents and records to a remarkable degree. Some published their findings online and in printed volumes, although they were usually vetted by church leaders. In allowing such access, students of church policy said, Mr. Monson presided over an unprecedented era of openness about church history, while reassuring the faithful that theirs was the one true, unerring faith.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe church\u2019s historic partnership with the Boy Scouts of America, which dated from 1913 and prepared Mormon boys for missionary work and adulthood as lay priests, was threatened late in Mr. Monson\u2019s tenure. For a century, nearly all Mormon boys became scouts, and the church became scouting\u2019s largest sponsor. By 2011, Mormon-sponsored packs and troops represented one-third of the nation\u2019s 421,000 scouts.\n\nBut the church and the Boy Scouts found themselves at loggerheads in 2014, when scouting admitted gays for the first time, and a year later, when it accepted gay adults as scout leaders. Mr. Monson said nothing publicly, and the church did not withdraw its support for scouting, as a church lawyer had threatened to do in a 2000 Supreme Court hearing on exclusionary scouting practices. While calling homosexuality immoral, church policy said \u201cnonpracticing\u201d gays could have the same rights and privileges as other church members.\n\nIt was clear, however, that a rift over sexual orientation had been laid bare. For years, the church treaded lightly on the subject. In 2009, it supported a Salt Lake City ordinance banning discrimination against gays in jobs and housing.\n\nBut in 2015, Mr. Monson responded to the Supreme Court\u2019s decision legalizing same-sex marriage with a letter read in Mormon churches saying that sexual relations outside heterosexual marriage were \u201ccontrary to the laws of God.\u201d And, further drawing the line, the church declared same-sex couples to be apostates and restricted their children from baptisms and other rites.\n\n\u201cRestrictions on the children of gay parents who are faithful church members struck some Mormons as severe,\u201d Professor Bushman said. \u201cThat was a tough one. It\u2019s not just an abstraction \u2014 it affects people\u2019s lives. It bothered a lot of Mormons.\u201d\n\nAfter the declaration, more than 1,000 people, many of them with deep ties to Mormonism, staged a rare public protest against the restrictions outside the church\u2019s spired temple in Salt Lake City, and demanded that their names be stricken from the membership rolls. A church spokesman said later that 1,500 resignations had been received.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Monson posted a message for the wavering faithful on Twitter: \u201cI plead with you to avoid anything that will deprive you of your happiness here in mortality and eternal life in the world to come.\u201d\n\nThomas Spencer Monson was born in Salt Lake City on Aug. 21, 1927, the second of six children of George Spencer Monson and the former Gladys Condie. He grew up in a tight-knit extended Mormon family that lived in proximity and that often worked, vacationed and worshiped together. At 12, he began working in a printing business his father managed.\n\nHe graduated from West High School in Salt Lake City in 1944. After starting at the University of Utah, he joined the Naval Reserve in 1945. World War II ended months later, and after stateside training, his tour of duty ended in 1946. He re-entered the University of Utah, graduating in 1948 with honors and a bachelor\u2019s degree in marketing, and earned a Master of Business Administration degree from Brigham Young University in 1974.\n\nIn 1948, he married Frances Beverly Johnson. She died in 2013. Survivors include their three children, Thomas and Clark Monson and Ann Dibb; eight grandchildren; and 12 great-grandchildren.\n\nAs is common in Mormonism, Mr. Monson\u2019s life straddled the worlds of business and religion. A printer by trade, he was an advertising executive with The Deseret News in the 1940s, and rose in the 1960s to general manager of the Deseret News Press, a church-affiliated printing firm. He was a longtime director and board chairman of the Deseret News Publishing Company.\n\nHe rose steadily in the church, too. In the 1950s, he was the bishop of a ward, akin to a parish, of 1,000 Mormons, including 85 widows whom he visited regularly and 23 men serving in the Korean War to whom he wrote personal letters weekly. From 1959 to 1962, he was president of the church\u2019s Canada mission, covering Ontario and Quebec.\n\nIn 1963 he became a member of the Quorum of Twelve Apostles, the church\u2019s second-highest governing body. The highest authority is the church president, followed by two counselors, positions based on seniority, which makes transitions free of politics but puts a mantle of age at the top.\n\nAwaiting his turn for the presidency, he embraced humanitarian causes with Christian, Jewish and Muslim groups supporting homeless shelters, food banks, nursing homes and disaster relief efforts in the United States and abroad.\n\n\u201cWe don\u2019t ever meet on doctrinal matters,\u201d he said. \u201cIt\u2019s strictly on the social side.\u201d", "title": "Thomas Monson, President of the Mormon Church, Dies at 90", "authors": ["Robert D. Mcfadden"]} {"date": "2018-01-03 00:00:00", "text": "That stature carries considerable influence, beyond the usual power disparity between professor and student: In the field of photography, Mr. Roma could make a difference by providing letters of reference, recommendations for grants, and introductions to art dealers and collectors.\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Roma, provided with details about the accounts of the women, declined to be interviewed. His lawyer told The Times that Mr. Roma disputes any suggestion that his behavior was ever coercive and that the professor had cooperated fully with Columbia\u2019s inquiry into Ms. Marno\u2019s complaint.\n\nThe lawyer, Douglas Jacobs, issued a statement saying that Mr. Roma was \u201cshocked\u201d by the accusations from the other four women.\n\n\u201cThe statements they are making about his asserted misconduct are replete with inaccuracies and falsehoods,\u201d Mr. Jacobs said. \u201cAll four have taken isolated, innocent incidents, none of them predatory, and have created fictitious versions of reality that are libelous and in the present political climate designed to damage his career and his personal life. Professor Roma\u2019s sympathies then and now lie with those who have been mistreated in any way and he completely fails to understand why these women have chosen to create these complaints two decades after the alleged facts supposedly occurred.\u201d\n\nFour of the five women attended the School of Visual Arts around the same time; some were friends there and have stayed close. Joyce Kaye, a spokeswoman for S.V.A., said the school \u201cdoes not have a record of any complaints against Mr. Roma\u201d when he taught there in the 1980s and \u201890s.\n\nSuzanne Goldberg, Columbia\u2019s executive vice president for university life, said in response to the accusations against Mr. Roma: \u201cIt is our standard practice to investigate whenever we receive a report that a faculty member may have sexually harassed a student.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Gender Letter A weekly newsletter on women, gender and society. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMs. Goldberg said that university policy forbids faculty members from having sexual relationships with students they oversee. Columbia, like many schools, has been trying to navigate ongoing campus debates about how best to handle student allegations of sexual misconduct. Ms. Goldberg said Columbia \u201clooks differently at these matters today than 20 years ago\u201d when Ms. Marno filed her complaint. \u201cOur policies on faculty conduct have been strengthened accordingly in recent years,\u201d she said. In December, William V. Harris, a professor of Greco-Roman history, retired after accusations that he had harassed three students.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Roma, whose best known work includes black-and-white images of worshipers in African-American churches and portraits of people at the Brooklyn criminal courthouse, has received two Guggenheim fellowships and had solo shows at the Museum of Modern Art and the International Center of Photography. He is married to a daughter of Lee Friedlander, a giant in the world of documentary photography, and has published 15 monographs with introductions by writers like Henry Louis Gates Jr. and Norman Mailer. His teaching career includes stints at Fordham, Cooper Union and Yale, according to his website.\n\nThe five women described Mr. Roma as a charming and charismatic teacher who cultivated a streetwise persona and emphasized perseverance, sacrifice and dedication to craft. The women, as well as some former students who posted anonymously online about Mr. Roma\u2019s teaching, said that he could be an unsparing critic, but also had the ability to instill confidence and inspire.\n\nOne of the women, Ash Thayer, a filmmaker and artist in Los Angeles, said she studied with Mr. Roma in the mid-1990s at S.V.A., then in the graduate program at Columbia, where she was also his teaching assistant. In 1999, Ms. Thayer said, she was working in Mr. Roma\u2019s office at Columbia shortly after a mutual friend, the photographer Raghubir Singh, had died. Ms. Thayer said that she was sitting at a desk when Mr. Roma asked her to turn around. His penis was erect, she said, and he moved toward her. She repeatedly said \u201cno,\u201d but Mr. Roma placed his penis in her mouth before she pushed him away and left, Ms. Thayer said, estimating that the encounter lasted perhaps 30 seconds.\n\n\u201cI froze,\u201d she said. \u201cHe committed oral rape against me.\u201d\n\nAllison Ward, a student at S.V.A. in the mid-1990s, said she had several sexual encounters with Mr. Roma. One occurred in a classroom, she said, recalling that she \u201cwas mortified and embarrassed but went along with it.\u201d Ms. Ward said that she had wanted to please Mr. Roma and gain his acceptance, adding \u201che was the first person in my life who had connected my passion for photography with a path forward.\u201d Mr. Roma did not force any contact, she said, but had been \u201cpredatory\u201d and had \u201ccrossed a line\u201d by seeking a sexual relationship.\n\n\u201cHe was coercive and would keep trying,\u201d she said. \u201cHe was a little relentless.\u201d\n\nAnother S.V.A. student in the mid-90s, Angela Cappetta, said that after repeated requests she allowed Mr. Roma to photograph her in her apartment. There, she said, Mr. Roma asked to touch her breast and put her hand on his crotch. \u201cI thought I\u2019d have to go along with it or it would be detrimental,\u201d she said. She drew the line when he asked to have sex, she added.\n\nOn campus, Mr. Roma often surrounded himself with a coterie of male and female students who would sort his negatives and act as teaching assistants, the five women said, adding that Mr. Roma would regularly invite students on outings or to gatherings at his house in Park Slope.\n\nIn 1997, Ilana Rein, a graduate student at S.V.A., said that Mr. Roma, who was then her thesis adviser, invited her to a backyard gathering. He asked her into his photo studio, then bluntly stated that he needed something from her and placed her hand on his crotch, Ms. Rein said. Taken aback, she did not object, but soon began feeling ill, removed her hand and left.\n\n\u201cI was blindsided because I thought we were going to look at photographs,\u201d Ms. Rein, now a filmmaker in Los Angeles, said. \u201cThis is someone who I trusted.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSome of the former students stayed in touch with Mr. Roma after these encounters, saying that they were intimidated, sought his help or wanted to believe that his behavior had been out of character. But, some added, Mr. Roma could be dismissive or even cruel to those who had rebuffed him.\n\nMs. Rein said that during a trip to Coney Island with students after her encounter with Mr. Roma, he repeatedly singled her out for mockery, while others laughed. \u201cThere was a kind of violence to it,\u201d she said. \u201cHe had such a vise grip on us back then.\u201d\n\nMs. Thayer said she blocked out memories of the office incident and, after graduating, remained in sporadic touch with Mr. Roma, exchanging emails and sometimes asking for recommendations or advice. In 2014, she said, she met Mr. Roma in Brooklyn and let him know that a book of her photographs was about to be published. He told her he might be able to help her get a teaching job at Columbia, Ms. Thayer said, but then implied that he would expect intimate contact in return. She has not seen or spoken with Mr. Roma since.\n\n\u201cI just kept wanting him to be the mentor that he was supposed to be,\u201d Ms. Thayer said. \u201cBut I realized that there was not going to be a time when he was not inappropriate with me and asking for a sexual relationship.\u201d", "title": "Thomas Roma, Photographer and Professor, Accused of Sexual Misconduct", "authors": ["Colin Moynihan"]} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nLONDON \u2014 What is now Thomson Reuters came to life a decade ago in a $17 billion merger of the Thomson financial information business and the Reuters news service.\n\nNow, the company has reached another potentially transformative deal: selling a majority stake in its financial and risk division to the Blackstone Group, the private equity giant.\n\nA consortium led by Blackstone announced on Tuesday that it had taken a 55 percent stake in the unit in a deal that values the division at $20 billion, including debt. It is the private equity firm\u2019s biggest acquisition since the global financial crisis.\n\nThe consortium includes Blackstone, the Canada Pension Plan Investment Board and GIC, a sovereign wealth fund established by Singapore\u2019s government.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nStriking a deal with Blackstone helps Thomson Reuters buttress its biggest division, which has faced headwinds amid lower spending by banks and other clients and competition from rivals like Bloomberg L.P.", "title": "Thomson Reuters Sells Stake in Unit to Blackstone-Led Group", "authors": ["Chad Bray"]} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "Q. I often see standpipes with \u201cSiamese connections\u201d outside of buildings. Why do some of them have spikes on top?\n\nA. To stop you from sitting on them or placing things on them, of course. Or to use more political language: to prevent loitering. Spikes of all kinds have a history of deployment against the homeless, in particular. And although it\u2019s unlikely, someone sitting on a Siamese connection could damage the system, potentially causing serious problems should a fire occur.\n\nOfficially known as fire department connections and more casually called couplers, Siamese connections are so named because, like the conjoined twins Chang and Eng Bunker, they have two heads. During a fire, firefighters can connect a hose from a nearby hydrant to one or both couplers, boosting pressure and providing additional water to systems inside the building.\n\nA 2009 city law governs the color-coding of a Siamese connection. If it is painted green, it connects to the building\u2019s automatic sprinkler system; red indicates it connects to the building\u2019s standpipe system, the vertical pipes in stairwells from which firefighters inside the building can draw water. Yellow indicates a connection to a combination sprinkler and standpipe system.", "title": "Those Dastardly Standpipe Spikes", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-01 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cWe\u2019re focused on the fact that most people are bringing devices on,\u201d Mr. Ingram said.\n\nBut industry experts say airlines risk alienating those travelers who do not want to rely on their own device to be entertained while they fly.\n\nPatrick Ligonde, a self-proclaimed \u201cairplane nerd,\u201d travels with his smartphone for his job in airline ground operations. But when he has to fly from his home base in Philadelphia, he said, he makes sure the seats he purchases have seatback screens, even going so far as to research the aircraft configuration before making a seat selection.\n\n\u201cI try to use the seatback entertainment as much as possible,\u201d he said. \u201cFrom a passenger perspective, it makes it easier to have the monitor right there rather than having to use my own device.\u201d One other advantage, he said, is that he does not arrive at his destination with a dead battery.\n\nMr. Harteveldt said his company\u2019s research indicated that many road warriors had the same preference. \u201cBusiness travelers have said there\u2019s no room to have a smartphone on their tray if they\u2019re working on a laptop, or if they\u2019re using a tablet or smartphone for work, it\u2019s difficult to use that for watching entertainment. Having the separate screen is a plus for them,\u201d he said.\n\nSome airlines are betting that they can peel away market share from their competitors by catering to travelers like Mr. Ligonde, making in-flight entertainment a brand differentiator. In 2017, Delta rolled out free in-flight mobile messaging, and the airline is in the process of installing new screens and making more content available in-flight.", "title": "Those Seatback Screens on Planes Are Starting to Disappear", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "Nevo breaks this taboo, and when a taboo is broken, guilt awakens. Trying to escape guilt, his characters photoshop the truth. What first seems like an honest confession turns out to be a brilliant act of self-deception. The confessors tell us their secrets, but choose to remain blind to the real secret \u2014 not what they did, but why they did it.\n\nPhoto\n\nHani\u2019s attraction to Eviatar, the brother-in-law, can be seen as a betrayal of her husband, but it is also an abandonment of the sacred duty of motherhood. It could be that the father suspecting a sexual assault against his daughter is actually projecting his own hidden violent libido. There\u2019s a political dimension to this psychology: We Israelis often have a \u201csiege mentality\u201d in which we are the victim of evil neighbors, defending ourselves from external threat. The aggressiveness of the in-group is projected onto the outside world, along with all moral responsibility for the conflict. Did Nevo intend his building to be a metaphor? Reading these striking stories, one wonders about the Israelis who lock their doors against external evil, but never stop to question their own morality.\n\nAfter meeting the id on the first floor, and the ego on the second, we face the superego on the third. A retired judge leaves voice messages on her dead husband\u2019s answering machine, confessing that she has reconnected with their estranged son. While listening to this woman, you start to wonder whether the criminal is indeed the son, who caused a deadly accident, or the mother, who is incapable of loving her child when he fails to live up to her standards.\n\nThough quite radical in his exploration of parenthood, Nevo is rather conservative on the question of which character deserves punishment and which achieves atonement. I somehow wished it were the other way around. And yet, this book and its conflicted apartment dwellers stayed with me long after I finished reading.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cYou can never tell what goes on with people behind their reinforced metal doors,\u201d says Arnon, the father on the first floor. Freud argues that you can\u2019t even tell what\u2019s going on behind your own locked door, or inside your own head. Freud\u2019s name is spoken, in a rare explanatory line. But luckily, for the most part, the story speaks for itself. The characters whisper confessions to us; we decide whether to judge or to forgive their sins \u2014 which are, of course, variations of our own.", "title": "Three Floors, Three Different Israeli Stories", "authors": ["Ayelet Gundar-Goshen", "Eshkol Nevo"]} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "The annual Under the Radar festival continues at various venues through Jan. 15.
