Here critics respond to three very different festival shows running at the Public Theater; 212-967-7555, publictheater.org.\n\nAfter\n\nThrough Sunday\n\nHallucinatory. Psychotropic. Miraculous. A show like Andrew Schneider\u2019s \u201cAfter\u201d invites baroque descriptors. But I should probably just tell you that for most of the show I thought the stage was floating. The stage was not floating.\n\nWith \u201cYouarenowhere,\u201d which played at the Coil festival in 2015, Mr. Schneider established himself as a sorcerer of technical theater, able to control light and darkness, sound and silence, with astonishing precision. At one point he renovated the theater midshow. \u201cAfter\u201d doubles down on that wizardry. Expect your eyes and ears to play tricks on you. Your nose may also get in on the game.\n\nBefore the show begins, ushers stride up and down the aisles, asking people to silence their phones and warning them that the show will include 30 minutes of total darkness and that if they need to leave at any point they should raise a hand for assistance.", "title": "Three Journeys Under the Radar: Trippy, Unsettling and Affectionate", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "The North Vietnamese were slowly closing in, but we didn\u2019t realize it. As the fighting moved up and down the peaks, lush jungle landscape was ripped apart by airstrikes and artillery fire and reduced to craters and shattered tree stumps, with body parts protruding from the pulverized earth.\n\nMarine patrols battled an often elusive enemy and the equally challenging jungle. Grunts wore condoms to protect themselves from leeches that could burrow inside genitals. Once, when I was sprawled on the jungle floor during one halt, a huge snake slithered across my hand, and to this day I am convinced I levitated several feet in shock.\n\nWe\u2019d be submerged for days by monsoon rains, wading through rice paddies and shivering at night in sodden jungle fatigues until our feet began to rot and we felt as cold as being naked on winter\u2019s day in Chicago. The cold wetness was often followed, within hours, by tropical heat so stifling that Marines fell like ninepins from dehydration despite gulping handfuls of salt tablets.\n\nWe lived in terror of a night ambush \u2014 every sound and movement was undoubtedly an enemy soldier. It took hours to \u201ccome down\u201d from that experience even when there was no contact. Marines doused themselves with mosquito repellent so evil-smelling that experts said the North Vietnamese and Vietcong soldiers could identify us over long distances and avoid contact. Eventually a less toxic mosquito formula was introduced.\n\nAs the North Vietnamese stranglehold tightened around the Khe Sanh combat base itself, Marines burrowed into often shallow trenches, reminiscent of those of World War I, that offered only modest protection against incoming fire. Streams of visiting civilian journalists refused shelter in the public information trench and bribed Navy Seabees with liquor to share their impressively constructed bunker.\n\nMy commander was bitten by rats. Despite his violent protests, he was medevaced \u201cto the rear\u201d for rabies treatment, which meant taking two helicopter or fixed-wing trips on the \u201cdeath run\u201d from the Khe Sanh airfield as North Vietnamese gunners bracketed aircraft and the airstrip with nonstop shelling.\n\nWhat became known as the siege of Khe Sanh \u2014 probably the most reported fight of the entire war \u2014 began in late January 1968 and stretched into a protracted artillery slugfest, a grim daily struggle for survival dominated by a virtual curtain of death rained down by high-flying bombers we rarely saw but constantly blessed in our prayers.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Subscribe to the Vietnam \u201967 Newsletter This weekly newsletter includes eyewitness accounts, rare photos and historical insights about the Vietnam War. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAs the encirclement was finally lifted in April, I returned to Khe Sanh as a civilian correspondent for U.P.I., having recently finished my military service. In an awesome fleet of gunships (yes, war can look beautiful at times) and clean jungle fatigues, the Army\u2019s First Air Cavalry Division hopscotched from hilltop to hilltop into Khe Sanh base and planted a sign declaring, \u201cUnder New Management.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nI accompanied a sullen unit of Marines who had not changed their fatigues, taken a proper shower or eaten a good meal for weeks or months, as they left by battered trucks or on foot, some muttering their admiration for the North Vietnamese Army rather than any gratitude to the Air Cav.\n\nI had first become aware of this Army-Marine animosity during a stopover in Japan en route to war, when frustrated Marines confined aboard a troop ship had tossed overboard dozens of inebriated soldiers returning from shore leave. And now it had resurfaced in Khe Sanh, and I feared an all-American shootout.\n\nThe base was abandoned shortly after the siege itself was lifted, but controversy swirls around Khe Sanh even today. Why were the Marines there in the first place, and why were so many lives sacrificed, seemingly in vain?\n\nWere the North Vietnamese determined to seize Khe Sanh, or was the siege a feint to camouflage the forthcoming nationwide Communist 1968 Tet offensive? Common sense suggests that it was a combination of both. Had the North Vietnamese overrun the base it would have been their biggest victory of the war, affecting the outcome even more decisively than the Tet offensive.\n\nAnd though the North Vietnamese were not successful in that aim, the battle did distract Gen. William Westmoreland and the Americans from developments in other parts of South Vietnam. Under pressure from Saigon, the Marines had also abandoned their promising hearts and minds campaign in the northern operational area, known as I Corps.\n\nI arrived at Khe Sanh and the surrounding Quang Tri Province as a Marine with a rifle, but returned a half-century later with a piece of chalk as a full-time volunteer English teacher in a Vietnamese high school.\n\nToday, the region, which was subject to possibly the heaviest aerial bombing and defoliation campaign in history, is still dotted with unexploded ordnance despite years of mine clearance and more than 7,000 postwar casualties. Farmers, children and mine clearers themselves continue to be victims. Families suffer the lingering effects of Agent Orange and babies continue to be born deformed.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSome 100,000 tons of ordnance were dropped around Khe Sanh itself, turning the region into a wild moonscape of pulverized red soil. But the mountains are again cloaked in green. Bomb craters have been transformed into duck ponds. The ghostly armies of camouflaged North Vietnamese soldiers slipping down the nearby Ho Chi Minh Trail have been replaced by commercial traders traveling to and from neighboring Laos and Cambodia.\n\nCoffee plantations and split-level homes steadily encroach on the former Marine base, A Vietnamese victory museum there bizarrely claims \u201c80 ships were destroyed\u201d during the climactic battle, even though the base is 70 miles from the sea or other navigable waterways.\n\nThe Vietnamese are remarkably generous in their forgiveness of a war that devastated their country and killed one million to three million people (estimates depend on the source), or as high as 10 percent of the population. American deaths were slightly more than 58,000. Despite this carnage, locals have overcome the trauma of the war more quickly than Americans, and I am warmly welcomed into homes and classrooms everywhere, including Khe Sanh.\n\nOne skinny kid who begged candy from passing Marines in 1967 is now a friend and a successful businessman. A farmer friend was a South Vietnamese soldier. His wife was a Vietcong antiaircraft gunner. Their daughter, Nhung, attempts to teach me Vietnamese, a language most Marines did not need because we were not allowed to fraternize with locals, only shoot at them.\n\nI recently met Lan, who had been at Khe Sanh as a N.V.A. nurse at the same time I was. She survived by snuggling close to the Marine wire in a strip of land around the base that American bombers avoided to prevent friendly casualties. Thousands of her fellow soldiers were \u201csimply blown apart \u2014 we could do nothing for them,\u201d she recalled.\n\nUntil our meeting, Lan said she had never talked about Khe Sanh except with her husband, though a picture of a beautiful young woman in uniform sits proudly on the wall of her home. After forging that deepest bond, possible only amid the horror and memories of war, sometimes even with former enemies, we agreed to revisit Khe Sanh \u2014 this time together as friends.", "title": "Three Journeys to Khe Sanh", "authors": ["Ray Wilkinson"]} {"date": "2018-01-03 00:00:00", "text": "Waste not\n\nThis doesn\u2019t mean we shouldn\u2019t care about food-related emissions. Worldwide, agriculture accounts for 18 percent of greenhouse gas emissions. Luckily, we can help slash emissions \u2014 and save money \u2014 without drastically altering our diets.\n\nOne way is to waste less food. According to the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations, about a third of the food produced worldwide never gets eaten. Throughout the world, some of that waste happens during production and distribution. But consumers and restaurants in North America throw away almost 40 percent of available food.\n\nGeremy Farr-Wharton, a researcher at the Queensland University of Technology, found that color-coding our refrigerator contents (green for fresh produce, red for meat) can reduce food waste. There are even refrigerator management apps like FridgePal and Best Before that track the food in your fridge and when it will spoil. If apps aren\u2019t your thing, a weekly refrigerator check \u2014 preferably before grocery shopping \u2014 can also help, as can monthly fridge eat-downs where you spend the last few days of the month using up everything that\u2019s left in your fridge.\n\nA number of businesses are also stepping up to cut waste on the production side by selling ugly produce. Producers toss about half of all fruits and vegetables in the United States, in part because they think we won\u2019t buy \u201cimperfect\u201d produce that fails to meet aesthetic standards. Businesses like Imperfect Produce hope to bridge that gap by selling ugly but otherwise normal produce at a discount of 30 to 50 percent.\n\nMeasure up\n\nThere\u2019s some truth to the saying \u201cWhat gets measured gets managed,\u201d and quantification has become something of a cultural obsession. Oroeco, an app available on both Android and iOS, takes that zeal and applies it to tracking personal carbon emissions.\n\nOroeco helps quantify the carbon emissions associated with purchases, investments, dietary choices and preferred modes of transport. It allows users to set goals, track performance and even compare their performance with friends. The app is still relatively new, and it isn\u2019t perfect, but it can be a useful tool to get you moving in the right direction.\n\nOther apps can help you lower your carbon footprint, too. My colleague Hiroko Tabuchi recently detailed the apps that she uses to stay aware of her personal contribution to global warming. The list includes the CO2 app from the International Civil Aviation Organization that she uses to track her greenhouse-gas emissions when she flies so she can invest in carbon offset credits. You can check out Hiroko\u2019s full list here.\n\nFollow Kendra on Twitter: @KendraWrites", "title": "Three New Year\u2019s Resolutions That Can Help Fight Climate Change", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-29 00:00:00", "text": "Watching is The New York Times\u2019s TV and film recommendation website. Sign up for our thrice-weekly newsletter here.\n\nI Love Sports and Science\n\nMae Berenice Meite at the Sochi Olympics. Streeter Lecka/Getty Images\n\n\u2018Anatomy of\u2019\n\nWhen to watch: Now, on the Olympic Channel\u2019s website.\n\nThis web series profiles a different Olympic athlete in each episode \u2014 a Polish biathlete, a Jamaican diver and a French figure skater among them. But the focus is less on their personalities and more on their physiques and athletic prowess. How high can they jump? How efficiently do their bodies use oxygen? Are their bodies particularly suited to their sports? All the kinesiology is fascinating, as are the unusual instruments used in the sports lab. Yes, you will feel a little bit like your body is a sad gummy worm made out of consolation prizes, but that gives way to sheer admiration.\n\nI Love Historical Dramas\n\nAmaia Salamanca and \u00c1lex Garc\u00eda in \u201cMorocco: Love in Times of War.\u201d Bamb\u00fa Producciones\n\nMorocco: Love in Times of War\u2019\n\nWhen to watch: Now, on\n\nNow, on Netflix Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nThis Spanish series (subtitled, or with corny dubbing) is set in the early 1920s and follows a group of nurses dispatched to the front lines of the Rif War, between Spanish colonial forces and the Riffi peoples of northern Morocco. Ill prepared for the endeavor is Julia, who has no meaningful training as a nurse and really just volunteered because she wanted to track down her fianc\u00e9 and her brother, both of whom are missing in action. The show has a soapy side, for sure \u2014 enhanced by a score that sounds a lot like the one from \u201cDownton Abbey\u201d \u2014 but not everyone wants \u201cDunkirk\u201d all day. If you like Spanish soaps, or you wish \u201cCall the Midwife\u201d had warfare, try this.\n\nI Hate Saying Goodbye\n\nFrom left, D\u2019Arcy Carden, Manny Jacinto, Kristen Bell and William Jackson Harper in \u201cThe Good Place.\u201d Colleen Hayes/NBC\n\n\u2018The Good Place\u2019\n\nWhen to watch: Thursday at 8:30 p.m., on NBC.\n\nThursday at 8:30 p.m., on NBC. It\u2019s basically a miracle. What to do in a bad situation? Throw a Molotov cocktail. \u201cAny time I had a problem,\u201d quoth he, \u201cI threw a Molotov cocktail, and boom, I had a different problem.\u201d\n\n0", "title": "Three Shows to Watch This Week", "authors": ["Margaret Lyons"]} {"date": "2018-01-22 00:00:00", "text": "The United States Olympic Committee, which also has been criticized for its inaction in the Nassar case, praised the resignations. He said those talks escalated over the weekend, after days of victim-impact statements by former gymnasts in Michigan, and culminated in the decision by the three board members to give up their roles.\n\n\u201cNew board leadership is necessary because the current leaders have been focused on establishing that they did nothing wrong,\u201d Mr. Blackmun said in his statement. \u201cThe Olympic family failed these athletes and we must continue to take every step necessary to ensure this never happens again.\u201d\n\nMark Jones, a spokesman for the U.S.O.C., said that top Olympic committee officials met with Parilla on Jan. 11 to ask him to resign.\n\nThe Olympic committee has decertified other federations in the past for mismanagement, stripping them of their authority as the national governing bodies. Gymnastics Board Members Resign", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "(Why, too, does the author devote the whole middle section of her book to what is essentially a scene-by-scene recap, from opening logo to closing moments? Those who are interested in \u201cSeduced by Mrs. Robinson\u201d have presumably seen the movie, and those who have not seen the movie will not be enlightened by Gray\u2019s chatty narration for the visually impaired.)\n\nA half-century has passed since the bewildered college graduate Benjamin Braddock, played with star-making originality by a then largely unknown Dustin Hoffman, floated, directionless, in his parents\u2019 glassy Beverly Hills pool, and was told (by someone of his Parents\u2019 Generation) that the future lay in \u201cplastics.\u201d It has been a half-century since Anne Bancroft smoldered as the seductive Mrs. Robinson, an unhappy woman who was the opposite of bewildered \u2014 an adult mature enough to know she was trapped in the hell of plastic marital conventions. It has been 50 years since Hoffman, Bancroft and the incandescently creative team of the director Mike Nichols and the screenwriter Buck Henry took Charles Webb\u2019s small 1963 novel of domestic discontents and turned it into a movie that epitomized huge shifts in both popular culture and Hollywood commerce.\n\nThen again, all this has been recounted before, with nuanced and perceptive synthesis, by Mark Harris in his popular 2008 history, \u201cPictures at a Revolution: Five Movies and the Birth of the New Hollywood,\u201d now a classic of cultural reporting and analysis. (Gray refers to Harris, a friend of mine, more than once.) And, for a fine magazine-length version, a reader can call up Sam Kashner\u2019s 2008 Vanity Fair piece \u201cHere\u2019s to You, Mr. Nichols: The Making of \u2018The Graduate.\u2019\u201d\n\nImage\n\n\u201cSeduced by Mrs. Robinson\u201d is a puzzling project. It is also a compilation of an awful lot of distracting clich\u00e9s. The famous camera shot of Hoffman framed by the crook of Bancroft\u2019s stockinged leg is a moment \u201cthat lives on in film history.\u201d The voices of the movie\u2019s fans \u201cstill echo through the years.\u201d Gray cites notebook entries the producer Lawrence Turman made \u201cwhen the project was merely a gleam in his eye.\u201d She explains that \u201cThe Graduate\u201d appealed to \u201chigh-spirited young rebels who delighted in thumbing their noses at the status quo.\u201d She interviews Hoffman \u201cat a film industry gathering, held at an upscale Beverly Hills Mexican eatery,\u201d where \u201che proved surprisingly approachable, despite the throngs of fans waiting their chance to schmooze with the star.\u201d Recent allegations of sexual harassment by Hoffman may dim a reader\u2019s envy at the opportunity for schmoozing.\n\nDo not take this as a nose-thumb so much as a brow-furrow. The author\u2019s interview with Hoffman took place in 2008 \u2014 and here we come to a clue to understanding the book\u2019s tortured structure, its pained search for an angle: Most of the research seems to have taken place a decade ago. The majority of Gray\u2019s direct reporting comes from two long interviews with Turman, now 91, who, as a Hollywood novice, was canny enough to obtain the rights to Webb\u2019s novel. The first of those interviews took place in 2007. Turman published his own book, \u201cSo You Want to Be a Producer,\u201d in 2005. That closed out a second-round 71 and enabled him to make his first PGA Tour cut since August 2015.\n\nThat was before chronic back problems led to several surgical procedures and two lengthy layoffs from competition.\n\nWoods finished tied for 65th, 10 shots behind the leader, Ryan Palmer (11 under), and nine shots behind the defending Farmers champion, Jon Rahm (10 under). But Woods said he was pleased merely to make a back-nine run and to be able to keep playing at a place where he has won nine tournament titles.\n\n\u201cI grinded my way around the golf course today,\u201d Woods said. \u201cI didn\u2019t quite hit it as good as I would like, but I fought hard. I chipped and putted well and posted a number. It was tough out there. The greens were firm.\u201d\n\nWhen he made the turn at two over par \u2014 the result of a double-bogey 6 on the par-4 13th, where he drove his tee shot into a hazard well left of the fairway \u2014 Woods said his goal was to get under par by the end of the round.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Equally important was a par save on No. 6, where his flop-shot wedge from deep rough stopped four feet from the cup.\n\n\u201cMy short game\u2019s been good all week,\u201d Woods said. \u201cIt\u2019s been a long 12 months. I\u2019ve been away from it for a very long time, so it\u2019s nice to get out there and compete. I still need more rounds under my belt.\u201d\n\nThis was Woods\u2019s first PGA Tour event since last year\u2019s Farmers, where he missed the cut, and only his third since a tie for 10th at the 2015 Wyndham Championship in North Carolina. It was also his first tour event since spinal fusion surgery last April, which, he said, eliminated all of his pain.\n\n\u201cThis is a different body,\u201d he said, adding: \u201cI\u2019m fused now. That\u2019s why I\u2019m excited to play the weekend. I need more time under the fire of competition.\u201d", "title": "Tiger Woods Birdies Final Hole to Narrowly Make Cut", "authors": ["Randy Youngman"]} {"date": "2018-01-28 00:00:00", "text": "Woods finished the tournament with a 3-under 285, putting him in a tie for 23rd, seven shots behind the leaders Jason Day, Alex Noren and Ryan Palmer, who tied at 10 under and went to a playoff.Palmer was eliminated on the first extra hole. Day and Noren played the first five playoff holes without a winner before play was suspended for darkness. They are set to resume at 11 a.m. on Monday.\n\nIt was Woods\u2019s best finish since he tied for 10th at the Wyndham Championship in August 2015, 29 months ago, and only the third time in his past 20 PGA Tour events that he played four rounds at par or better: 72-71-70-72.\n\n\u201cOverall, I\u2019m very pleased,\u201d Woods said Sunday. \u201cAfter not playing for a couple of years and coming out here on tour, you know, it was a solid four days. I had to fight for every score on every hole, and sometimes those are more pleasing than boring rounds. I can grind it out with the best of them.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nHis statistics gave evidence of how hard he had worked to play at or under par. On Sunday, he hit only 3 of 14 fairways for the third consecutive round, and he finished tied for last in driving accuracy among the 77 players who made the cut. He compensated for wayward driving with excellent chipping, putting and bunker play, making par or better on 19 holes on which he failed to reach the green at least two strokes before par.\n\n\u201cThe short game wasn\u2019t something I was worried about coming in this week,\u201d he said. \u201cI need to work on my driving. These are some of the narrowest fairways on the whole tour, so when I don\u2019t have my best stuff, and now it\u2019s windy, it just compounded it. It made it very difficult for me.\u201d\n\nWoods said he could take many positives from his first tour event since last year\u2019s Farmers, where he missed the cut. Roughly half of the 156-player field missed the cut this year, including Rickie Fowler, ranked No. 7 in the world, and the 2017 Tour Championship winner Xander Schauffele, ranked 26th.\n\nOn Sunday, Woods finished ahead of No. 2 Jon Rahm, the defending champion who shot 75-77 on the weekend; No. 22 Francesco Molinari, No. 36 Patrick Cantlay and No. 46 Phil Mickelson, among others.\n\nNext on Woods\u2019s schedule is the Genesis Open at Riviera Country Club in Los Angeles starting Feb. 15, a tour event that benefits Woods\u2019s foundation. He said after Sunday\u2019s round that he was totally pain-free and would go home to \u201creassess where I\u2019m at\u201d and how he feels physically, coming off a full tournament, before announcing his schedule.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m trying to build toward April,\u201d he said. \u201cI\u2019m looking forward to playing a full schedule and getting ready for the Masters, and I haven\u2019t done that in a very long time.\u201d", "title": "Tiger Woods Leans on Short Game for Strong Finish at Torrey Pines", "authors": ["Randy Youngman"]} {"date": "2018-01-27 00:00:00", "text": "His erratic driving began on his first hole; he hooked a 3-wood into the left rough on No. 10. His second shot found the right greenside bunker, and then he blasted out to 12 feet and made the par putt that set off the day\u2019s first roar. It was the first of nine holes in this round on which he needed only one putt.\n\nWoods hit eight drives into the left rough and four into the right rough. He said he had tried and failed to make adjustments, attributing some of the problem to a lack of tournament competition.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s not the driver; it\u2019s just my swing,\u201d said Woods, 42, who had spinal fusion surgery in April. \u201cMy feels are different. Some of my go-to shots aren\u2019t there. Some of my shots I like to hit under certain circumstances aren\u2019t there, either.\u201d\n\nWoods\u2019s first birdie \u2014 on the 504-yard, par-4 12th \u2014 came after a 196-yard shot from the deep right rough stopped on the green. He rolled in a 10-footer to loud cheering. He also birdied from the right rough on the par-5 13th, the par-5 18th and the 560-yard par-5 6th, where he reached the green in two shots and two-putted from 40 feet.\n\nHis par saves were equally impressive. He escaped greenside bunkers on No. 14 and No. 15 (both par-4s), and he got up and down with sand-wedge flop shots from the rough on No. 3 and No. 8 (both par-3s).\n\nAsked what his score might have been if his short game had not been sharp on Saturday, Woods smiled and said his scorecard might have had a few 8s. He called them \u201csnowmen.\u201d\n\n\u201cThe only thing I have is my short game and my heart,\u201d he said, \u201cand that got me through today.\u201d\n\nWoods, who was born and reared in nearby Orange County, thanked the fans in Southern California for their enthusiastic support.\n\n\u201cI haven\u2019t had people yelling like that in a while,\u201d he said. \u201cSo many of the people I haven\u2019t seen in a long time have come out this week, which is fantastic. I\u2019ve played well here over the course of my career, and I think a lot of these fans just want to see some of that. And, trust me, I\u2019m trying.\u201d", "title": "Tiger Woods Moves Up at Torrey Pines, but Calls His Round \u2018Gross\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "SAN DIEGO \u2014 A new, surgically modified version of Tiger Woods, armed with new equipment and downsized expectations, launched his latest comeback on the PGA Tour on Thursday by shooting an even-par 72 on the South Course at Torrey Pines during the opening round of the Farmers Insurance Open.\n\nA seven-time winner of the event, Woods finished the round tied for 84th, seven shots behind the early leader Tony Finau (who shot a 65 on the North Course). Woods will most likely have to shoot under par on the North Course in the second round on Friday to make the 36-hole cut.\n\nHuge galleries lined the fairways and surrounded every tee and green as he made his way around the course. The scene was reminiscent of his 2008 United States Open triumph here, as was his opening tee shot on No. 1 \u2014 a pulled drive into the deep rough on the left side, on the way to a greenside bunker and a two-putt bogey. He won the 2008 Open, his most recent major title, despite making three double-bogeys on the opening hole.\n\nThough admittedly \u201ca little bit rusty,\u201d Woods was smiling after the first round on Thursday and said he was encouraged by his performance at his first PGA Tour event since last year\u2019s Farmers, where he missed the cut after the longest layoff of his career. A week later, he had to withdraw from a European Tour event in Dubai because of back spasms, leading to spinal fusion surgery in April and another season-ending layoff.", "title": "Tiger Woods Returns to PGA Tour With \u2018Tempered\u2019 Expectations", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-17 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 American troops will remain in Syria long after their fight against the Islamic State to ensure that neither Iran nor President Bashar al-Assad of Syria take over areas that have been newly liberated with help from the United States, Secretary of State Rex W. Tillerson said on Wednesday.\n\nStaying in Syria, Mr. Tillerson said, will help ensure that the Trump administration does not repeat what he described as the mistakes of former President Barack Obama, who withdrew troops from Iraq before the extremist threat was doused and failed to stabilize Libya after NATO airstrikes that led to the overthrow of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.\n\n\u201cWe cannot allow history to repeat itself in Syria,\u201d Mr. Tillerson said during a speech at the Hoover Institution at Stanford University near San Francisco. \u201cISIS has one foot in the grave, and by maintaining an American military presence in Syria until the full and complete defeat of ISIS is achieved, it will soon have two.\u201d\n\nISIS is another name for the Islamic State.\n\nThere were roughly 2,000 American troops in Syria last month, a mix of engineering units that build fortifications and Special Operations units that fight and train with local militias. Additionally, American military contractors in Syria help demine recaptured areas as the Islamic State is pushed back.", "title": "Tillerson Says U.S. Troops to Stay in Syria Beyond Battle With ISIS", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-08 00:00:00", "text": "It was a demanding process, which Mr. Rollins oversaw from beginning to end. The authors he selected were challenging and included Shakespeare, Daniel Defoe, Lewis Carroll and Malcolm X. Digesting their writings could take weeks, and arriving at a a suitable motif, a process they called jammin\u2019, could take months. Some books were put aside for years and returned to later. The individual variations that the students made had to pass muster with the group as a whole before being added to the large paper-covered canvases.\n\nTheir first series remained their best known: densely wrought compositions of convoluted golden horns whose intricacies could evoke lattices, weapons or bodies. They were inspired by the trumpets played by angels in the final chapter of Franz Kafka\u2019s \u201cAmerika.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nEqually distinctive, and almost as popular with museums, were the gold-trimmed red capital A\u2019s inspired by Nathaniel Hawthorne\u2019s \u201cThe Scarlet Letter.\u201d\n\nThe group covered pages of \u201cThe Red Badge of Courage\u201d with widely spaced images of wounds, and of \u201cA Midsummer Night\u2019s Dream\u201d with densely arranged petal-like blurs of color.\n\nFor George Orwell\u2019s \u201cAnimal Farm,\u201d they painted farm animals with the heads of world leaders.\n\nTheir texts often had contemporary relevance: Their interpretation of Gustave Flaubert\u2019s \u201cThe Temptation of Saint Anthony,\u201d for example, with red-soaked suggestions of diseased cells, resonated with the AIDS crisis.\n\nTheir work was part of the widespread experimentation in the 1980s in combining form and narrative, usually using aspects of Conceptual and Minimal art. The alluring grid and hazy textures of the book-page surfaces paralleled the painting-collages of painters like Philip Taaffe, Jean-Michel Basquiat and Julian Schnabel. And the collective structure of the group presaged the growing interest in combining art and social activism.\n\nTimothy William Rollins, a loquacious man whose speech sometimes assumed the evangelical cadences of the preachers he listened to while growing up in Maine, and later in Harlem, was born on June 10, 1955, in Pittsfield, Me. He was the oldest of four children of Carlton Rollins, who worked in shoe and furniture factories, and the former Charlotte Imogen Hussey, a hospital ward clerk.\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Rollins, who once said he considered himself \u201ca city kid in a country body,\u201d drew and read voraciously as a child. (Emerson, Thoreau and the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. were heroes.) With money from part-time jobs, he amassed a comic-book collection that he would sell to attend art school in New York.\n\nIn 1973, Mr. Rollins entered a new art program at the University of Maine at Augusta, where he read everything he could find about the New York art world, including an essay by the prominent Conceptual artist Joseph Kosuth, who was teaching at the School of Visual Arts in Manhattan. In 1975, after Mr. Rollins earned an associate\u2019s degree in art, his application to that school was accepted, and he moved to New York.\n\nIn short order he was studying with Mr. Kosuth, who was then at the height of his Marxist fervor and teaching the merits of collective politicized action. He was also working as Mr. Kosuth\u2019s assistant, a job he called \u201cmy real education.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn 1979, Mr. Rollins and Julie Ault, a classmate from the University of Maine, along with several others, among them Marybeth Nelson, Patrick Brennan and Beth Jaker, founded Group Material, which operated a small gallery in the East Village. He also studied art education at New York University.\n\nMr. Rollins and his students started exhibiting in 1981 in Group Material\u2019s gallery, initially identifying themselves as \u201cTim Rollins and 15 Kids From the South Bronx.\u201d (The number would vary.) The students chose the name Kids of Survival in 1982 as invitations to exhibit began to increase. In 1985, the cohort unveiled the first \u201cAmerika\u201d painting in a group show at the Gladstone Gallery in SoHo. Grace Glueck, writing in The New York Times, called it the \u201ccoup\u201d of the exhibition.\n\nIn 1985 and 1986, the group had solo shows at Hostos Community College and Fashion Moda in the Bronx and at Jay Gorney Modern Art, which was then in the East Village. Within a few short years, Tim Rollins + K.O.S. exhibited in the Venice Biennale, at Documenta 8 in Kassel, Germany, and at two Whitney Biennials. The \u201cAmerika\u201d paintings had their own show at the Dia Art Foundation in Chelsea.\n\nIn 1984, Mr. Rollins received grants to establish the Art and Knowledge workshop, an after-school project in a community center near I.S. 52, with students from other schools sometimes participating; attendance was predicated on maintaining a C average.\n\nPhoto\n\nHe gave up his teaching job in 1987, and the group moved to its first rented studio in 1989. A documentary, \u201cKids of Survival: The Art and Life of Tim Rollins + K.O.S.,\u201d directed by Dan Geller and Dayna Goldfine, was released in 1996 and won an Emmy.\n\nIn later years the group consisted of six longtime members: Mr. Abreu, his brother Jorge, Robert Branch, Ala Ebtekar, Ricardo Nelson Savinon and Benjamin Volta. They conducted workshops in schools across the country and around the world, with Mr. Rollins, collaborating with students to make paintings for exhibitions in local museums.\n\nMr. Rollins and K.O.S. were not without controversy. Some people in the art world accused him of being a white interloper using Hispanic and African-American youths as a publicity vehicle. When they left Mr. Gorney in 1991 for the Mary Boone Gallery in SoHo, the epicenter of hot \u201980s art stars, Mr. Rollins\u2019s more collectively minded friends accused him of selling out.\n\nIndeed, the group occupied a strange position: Their collaborative working method opposed the idea of art stardom and individual authorship, yet they were embraced by the art market.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSometimes the issues were more personal. In an article in New York magazine in 1991, several former members of K.O.S. accused Mr. Rollins of being emotionally abusive, and of spending too much money on himself. Mr. Rollins said they were retaliating for being kicked out of K.O.S., and several current members defended him.\n\nMr. Rollins never married, although he had a long-term relationship with the singer Kate Pierson of the rock group the B-52\u2019s. He is survived by his mother; his brother, Ronny; and his sisters, Carlene and Cindy Rollins.\n\nMr. Rollins was highly motivated from an early age. He said that when he was about 5 he wrote a note to his parents: \u201cDear Mom and Dad, when I grow up I\u2019m going to be an artist, a teacher and a scientist. Don\u2019t get in my way.\u201d", "title": "Tim Rollins Dies at 62; Turned Bronx Teenagers Into Art Stars", "authors": ["Roberta Smith"]} {"date": "2018-01-04 00:00:00", "text": "Never heard of Felix Varela, Marm Mandelbaum, E.A. Calahan, Kahlil Gibran and J. Clarence Davies? They\u2019re among the unsung characters you\u2019ll meet in \u201cNew York at Its Core: 400 Years of New York City History\u201d (Museum of the City of New York).\n\nThis lavishly illustrated catalog is a fitting companion to the permanent exhibition of the same name that opened in 2016 at the revivified Museum of the City of New York on Fifth Avenue.\n\n\u201cNew York at Its Core\u201d is both a perfect keepsake and a timely primer that introduces adults and younger readers to the full spectrum of the city\u2019s metamorphosis from a vulnerable Dutch trading outpost to a world capital poised to celebrate its 400th birthday.\n\nLike the exhibition, the book is organized chronologically and thematically.\n\nSome of the artifacts and featured players, taken individually, might come across as spoon-fed doses of politically correct multiculturalism. But collectively, they validate the book\u2019s premise that diversity was, in fact, one of the four foundational themes that produced the city we know today, along with money, density and creativity.", "title": "Time Flies When You\u2019re the Capital of the World", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "These works, by the German artist Sylvia Ballhause, are in fact photographs of photographs: faithful replicas of a piece by the pioneering scientist, painter and printmaker Louis-Jacques-Mand\u00e9 Daguerre. Made in 1839, \u201cThe Munich Triptych\u201d was Daguerre\u2019s three-part demonstration of an image-making technology he had invented and named, immodestly, after himself \u2014 two \u201cdaguerreotype\u201d photographs of a Paris boulevard, which he framed alongside a domestic still life. Keen to attract publicity, Daguerre presented the triptych to King Ludwig I of Bavaria.\n\nInnovative though daguerreotypes were, they were also doomed: Printed laboriously on silver-coated copper, they were quickly overtaken by cheaper and simpler techniques. Daguerre\u2019s triptych ended up in a regional museum, where it rusted into near oblivion. Ms. Ballhause\u2019s reproduction doesn\u2019t so much bring these images back to life as remind us of their lingering and painful death.\n\nIt\u2019s strange to see a 19th-century Frenchman\u2019s work on the walls of Foam, the Netherlands\u2019 most fashionable contemporary photography gallery, and the new exhibition here springs plenty more surprises. There are recent prints developed with the use of moonlight, alongside Victorian images of celestial bodies. Another display places plant photographs by the early-20th-century artist and botanist Karl Blossfeldt next to a 3D-printed aluminum-and-resin sculpture based on their contours. The room next door contains sepia-tinted emojis printed onto animal hides.", "title": "Time Travel for Photographers", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-21 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cA Flu Pandemic Is Coming,\u201d by Michael T. Osterholm and Mark Olshaker (Op-Ed, Jan. 9):\n\nYes, by all means, let\u2019s get a universal flu vaccine. But in the meantime, let\u2019s get Congress to pass the Healthy Families Act.\n\nA pandemic may be in the future, but lots of nasty influenza germs are here right now. All employees need to earn paid sick days in order to follow doctor\u2019s orders to stay home (or keep kids home) until symptoms go away without losing their pay or their jobs.\n\nELLEN BRAVO, MILWAUKEE\n\nThe writer is co-director of Family Values @ Work, a network of 27 state coalitions.", "title": "Opinion | Time for Paid Sick Leave", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-06 00:00:00", "text": "The Reader Center is one way we in the newsroom are trying to connect with you, by highlighting your perspectives and experiences and offering insight into how we work.\n\nAttorney General Jeff Sessions, long a vocal opponent of the legalization of marijuana, rescinded on Thursday an Obama-era policy that discouraged federal prosecution of marijuana-related crimes in states that had legalized the drug. The announcement came just days after the first retail cannabis shops opened in California, the sixth state to legalize recreational marijuana use.\n\nAs the tug of war between state and federal authorities continues, we asked readers for their questions about marijuana policy. Two of our reporters \u2014 Thomas Fuller, our San Francisco bureau chief, and Charlie Savage, a Washington correspondent \u2014 answered some of the 700 questions we received. The questions have been condensed and edited for clarity.\n\nPolicy and Enforcement\n\nWhat is the federal policy? How will it affect state legalization movements?\n\nWhat do the federal laws against marijuana actually say? \u2014 Rick Goldberg", "title": "Times Reporters Answer Your Questions About U.S. Marijuana Policy", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-07 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nLast year at the Oscars, the accessory of the evening was a blue American Civil Liberties Union ribbon; tonight at the Golden Globes, it is the black-and-white Time\u2019s Up pin, as seen on the lapels and collars of stars like Justin Timberlake, Daniel Kaluuya, Ewan McGregor, Michelle Pfeiffer, William H. Macy, Joseph Fiennes, Joe and Nick Jonas and Ryan Seacrest. Time\u2019s Up, announced last Monday, is an initiative created by several hundred actresses and female agents, writers, directors and entertainment executives to fight sexual misconduct across the country. It has no leadership and members include Ashley Judd, Eva Longoria, America Ferrera, Natalie Portman, Rashida Jones, Emma Stone, Kerry Washington and Reese Witherspoon.\n\nMs. Witherspoon asked Arianne Phillips, a costume designer and stylist who has worked with Madonna and on movies like \u201cKingsman: The Golden Circle\u201d and the Tom Ford-directed \u201cNocturnal Animals,\u201d to design the pins last month, according to The Hollywood Reporter. The pins complement the decision by many actors to wear all black to the awards as a show of support for those who have experienced sexual misconduct.\n\n\u201cReese asked me to come to the actors\u2019 group, and told me they were going to be wearing black and would I consider creating a pin for the nominees and male presenters,\u201d Ms. Phillips told The Hollywood Reporter. \u201cWe were up against the holidays, but I said I could do it, and the first person I called was my partner-in-crime, Michael Schmidt.\u201d (Mr. Schmidt is a designer who has worked with Rihanna, Cher and Lady Gaga, among many others). Together, the two of them designed the pin and had 500 versions of it produced within two weeks.\n\nMs. Phillips posted a photo of herself wearing the pin to Instagram, with the caption, \u201clet\u2019s all toast & post in solidarity with women on the red carpet and everywhere standing up for change.\u201d\n\nTime\u2019s Up includes a legal defense fund, backed by donations from members, that is intended to help less privileged women pursue action against those who violate them; a working group developing ideas for legistlation; and a drive to push studios and talent agencies to have a more even balance of men and women in their employment.", "title": "Time\u2019s Up Pins Are the Political Accessory at the Golden Globes", "authors": ["Valeriya Safronova"]} {"date": "2018-01-16 00:00:00", "text": "Timoth\u00e9e Chalamet, the breakout star of the movie \u201cCall Me By Your Name,\u201d has become the latest actor to distance himself from Woody Allen, announcing that he is donating the salary from his role in Mr. Allen\u2019s latest film to charities fighting sexual abuse and harassment.\n\nIn a post on his Instagram account, Mr. Chalamet said he was giving his wages from his work on Mr. Allen\u2019s \u201cA Rainy Day in New York\u201d to the Hollywood-backed anti-harassment initiative Time\u2019s Up; the L.G.B.T. Center in New York; and RAINN, an organization that supports victims of sexual violence.\n\nMr. Chalamet also sought to explain his previous reticence about his decision to appear in a film directed by Mr. Allen, who faces allegations dating back to 1993 that he sexually abused his adopted daughter Dylan Farrow. Mr. Allen has denied the allegations.\n\nMr. Chalamet said that, owing to \u201ccontractual obligations,\u201d he had been unable to answer questions posed by reporters and critics on the subject. \u201cI don\u2019t want to profit from my work on the film,\u201d Mr. Chalamet said. \u201cI want to be worthy of standing shoulder to shoulder with the brave artists who are fighting for all people to be treated with the respect and dignity they deserve.\u201d", "title": "Timoth\u00e9e Chalamet Promises Salary From Woody Allen Film to Charity", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-22 00:00:00", "text": "From Pearl Divers to Porsche Drivers\n\nThat the other Gulf countries even care about Qatar enough to despise it is a relatively new development.\n\nFor much of the 20th century, the country was a barren Persian Gulf backwater where pirates once lurked. Its people were desperately poor, typically diving for pearls in the summer and herding camels in the winter. For decades they lagged far behind their Saudi neighbors, who were in the midst of a heady oil boom. The ruling al-Thani family was riven by vicious internecine squabbles and periodic coups.\n\nThen, in 1971, Qatar struck gas.\n\nThe discovery of the world\u2019s largest gas field was initially a source of bitter disappointment. \u201cPeople hoped for oil,\u201d said Abdullah bin Hamad al-Attiyah, a former energy minister. But by the 1990s, new technology allowed gas to be liquefied and exported in tanker ships.\n\nThe emir, Tamim\u2019s father, Sheikh Hamad bin Khalifa al-Thani, took a huge gamble. Ignoring naysayers, he poured $20 billion into a sprawling liquefaction plant at Ras Laffan, on Qatar\u2019s north coast, with help from the energy giant Exxon Mobil. Among the Exxon Mobil executives who helped develop the plant was Rex W. Tillerson, who is now secretary of state.\n\nThe bet paid off spectacularly. Gas boomed, and by 2010 Qatar accounted for 30 percent of the global market.\n\nSince then, Qatar\u2019s citizens, today numbering 300,000, have become very rich, very fast. Their average income of $125,000 is the highest in the world, over twice that of the United States or Saudi Arabia. The state cocoons them with free land, cushy jobs and American universities. Gleaming supercars and limousines cruise along Doha\u2019s palm-lined corniche. Poor Qataris are hard to find.\n\nThe metamorphosis was equally dramatic for the Thanis. Once the lords of a desolate peninsula of sand dunes and salt flats, they have become strutting sophisticates on the global stage: style icons who are celebrated in Vanity Fair and Vogue; art titans who splurge hundreds of millions on a C\u00e9zanne or a Gauguin; and media moguls who built Al Jazeera, the groundbreaking television network that helped fan the Arab Spring in 2011.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn June, Qatar\u2019s national colors lit up the Empire State Building, in which it owns a stake, a mark of its punchy ambition.\n\nBut Qatar\u2019s swagger is deeply contentious among its neighbors. In their reach for global influence, the Thanis have pursued ambidextrous, sometimes contradictory policies \u2014 preaching the virtues of peace, education and women\u2019s rights while bankrolling Islamist extremists in Syria and hosting the biggest United States military base in the Middle East.\n\nTo Saudi Arabia and the Emirates \u2014 and Bahrain and Egypt, who have joined them in the boycott \u2014 Qatar is a nation of vexatious meddlers, intoxicated by its own wealth, that needs to be cut down to size.\n\nThree dueling, headstrong royals are at the center of the dispute.\n\nSaudi Arabia\u2019s Prince Mohammed, 32, is leading a campaign to overhaul and energize his stultified society, including with outlandish proposals such as a $500 billion city on the Red Sea run by robots. He has a staunch ally in Sheikh Mohammed bin Zayed al-Nahyan, 56, the hawkish crown prince of Abu Dhabi and the effective ruler of the Emirates, who has built a formidable military and shares his Saudi counterpart\u2019s deep hostility toward Iran.\n\nBoth princes are arrayed against Tamim, the emir of Qatar. A towering man with a diplomatic mien, Tamim is in many respects a classic Gulf potentate: educated like his father at the Royal Military Academy Sandhurst in England, he has three wives and 10 children, and lives in several luxurious palaces in Doha, a futuristic city of glass towers and curling highways.\n\nHis rise to power in 2013, at the age of 33, offered a stark contrast with the gerontocracy of Saudi Arabia, where rulers clung to their thrones till reaching their deathbeds. And his easy manner belies a stubborn streak that his neighbors see as the mark of a dangerous gadfly.\n\nThe baroque feuding among the three leaders \u2014 a twisting tale of cyberespionage, propaganda salvos, palace intrigue and high-stakes desert hunts \u2014 is worthy of an ancient Gulf power drama. Played by rich men in flowing white robes known as thobes, it has been called the \u201cGame of Thobes.\u201d But it also represents a profound moment of reckoning for the glimmering city-states of the Gulf.\n\nHaving largely avoided the turmoil of the Arab Spring in 2011, they find themselves hurtling toward an uncertain new economic and political order. At the center of the tumult is Qatar, the Lilliputian contender that for years punched above its weight and is now thrust into the fight of its life.", "title": "Tiny, Wealthy Qatar Goes Its Own Way, and Pays for It", "authors": ["Declan Walsh"]} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "It\u2019s fair to say that was a vote of not-so-confident in his potential successor.\n\nMr. Brown\u2019s years in public life mean he can be a challenging interview; he almost certainly knows the subject better than you do. I spent a lot of time preparing questions and talking to editors about what we wanted to learn before walking into the mansion: How much, for example, should we ask him about his legislative plans for his final year, his views on national politics, his future plans and his legacy (darn)?\n\nAnd he can be prickly. Every lame-duck politician has to deal with losing power as attention turns to the next generation. Mr. Brown has managed to hold on to his clout longer than most; still, he bristled at the admittedly conventional suggestion that his power was now ebbing.\n\n\u201cGive me an example where my power \u2014 I don\u2019t think you can,\u201d he said. \u201cI\u2019ve done a lot of these things. Now it\u2019s implementation. I\u2019m certainly being sought by the congressional people. They don\u2019t see my power diminishing.\u201d\n\nMr. Brown may have expressed concern about a lengthy sit-down, but these things take time: It might be a while before Mr. Brown finally answers a question that you know he wants to answer.\n\nAs we began, Mr. Brown harrumphed at questions about the potential impact of federal tax reform on California; how could he possibly know until he had a chance to really study it? Before long, we returned to the subject, and Mr. Brown offered a vivid excoriation of the new law \u2014 the \u201cblah-blah detail,\u201d as he put it, be damned.\n\nThroughout our time, Mr. Brown was as fidgety as a teenager with an iPhone \u2014 making side remarks to aides; keeping an eye on his dog, Colusa, in the next chair. His eyes darted away as his smartphone buzzed with a call.\n\n\u201cWho is Doug Ducey?\u201c he asked, glancing at the caller ID. \u201cThe state of Arizona. That\u2019s the governor of the state of Arizona! Should I take a call from the governor of Arizona?\u201d\n\nHis press secretary, Evan Westrup, suggested that he wait.\n\nI saved the question about his you-know-what until we were almost done. \u201cI don\u2019t think people remember governors that much,\u201d Mr. Brown responded. \u201cDo you remember Pete Wilson?\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe interview stretched to more than 70 minutes. It would have gone on longer had Mr. Westrup not called time. For all of Mr. Brown\u2019s protestations about a long interview as we sat down, it was pretty clear by the end that the soon-to-retire governor of California would have been delighted to keep talking into the night.", "title": "Tips for Interviewing Jerry Brown", "authors": ["Adam Nagourney"]} {"date": "2018-01-02 00:00:00", "text": "Yu Ming Wu\n\nCo-founder, Sneaker Con\n\nWhat is your favorite sneaker?\n\nThe Nike Air Max 1. If we have to kind of go down to actual colorway, it would be the 2002 or 2003 Atmos colorway. It has a very safari, fun print to it.\n\nYou told me that you\u2019ve waited years to find a pair of shoes. Which ones were they?\n\nThe Nike Air Max 1s in the Amsterdam colorway. I\u2019ve probably spent now nine or 10 years looking for them. For the longest time, I refused to pay the high prices for them. I broke down this year.\n\nHow much?\n\n$1,500.\n\nWhat is the most you would pay for sneakers?\n\nMost recently I have been contemplating purchasing the real auto-lacing Nike Air Mags, the \u201cBack to the Future\u201d shoes which were released last year. Today they go for anywhere from $23,000 to about $60,000. I found a pair on eBay for $33,000, and I talked them down to $27,000. If I do get them, that will be the most expensive pair of shoes I will ever purchase in my life. The price of a nice decent car.\n\nTips for getting your hands on hard-to-get sneakers?\n\nIt\u2019s tough. Today I try to be as safe as possible. I use eBay much more rarely. I am involved with the resell shop Stadium Goods here in New York City. I try to buy most of my shoes from there, just because they\u2019re authenticated.\n\nWhat are some tips for eBay?\n\nI generally look at sellers that have excellent feedback on eBay. I always look at people who write their name.\n\nHow do you care for your sneakers?\n\nI do sometimes use Mylar bags. For people who\u2019ve collected comic books out there, they use Mylar bags to keep them from getting the acid air or whatever it is from boxes. I also sometimes take out the insoles and throw them in with my bleach cycle, or I also use vinegar. You wash your underwear and your socks, but you\u2019d never wash insoles. Those guys get pretty nasty.", "title": "Tips from Sneaker Heads on Scoring the Hottest Shoes and Keeping Them Fresh", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-29 00:00:00", "text": "At least one of the women protesting on Monday was arrested by the police, a shopkeeper who witnessed the arrest said.\n\nThe protests, still small in number, are nevertheless significant as a rare public sign that dissatisfaction with certain Islamic laws governing personal conduct may have reached a boiling point. As the 28-year-old woman said, \u201cI took my scarf off because I\u2019m tired of our government telling me what to do with my body.\u201d\n\nAnd some said this might just be the beginning. \u201cMy guess is that more of these protests will follow,\u201d said Nasrin Sotoudeh, a lawyer and human rights activist. \u201cIt\u2019s obvious that some women want to decide for themselves what to wear.\u201d\n\nThat remains to be seen, but the protests have already gained enough attention to provoke angry reactions in some quarters.\n\n\u201cThese protests are done by instigators, saboteurs and vandalists and anarchists,\u201d said one critic, Kazem Anbarlooie, the editor in chief of the hard-line newspaper Resalat. \u201cRecently our enemies were communists and liberals, now Americans are provoking masochists against us.\u201d\n\nThe first protest in December took place on a Wednesday and seemed connected to the White Wednesday campaign, an initiative by Masih Alinejad, an exiled Iranian journalist and activist living in the United States. Ms. Alinejad has reached out to Iranian women on Persian-language satellite television and through social media, and via a website she runs called My Stealthy Freedom. On the website, women post images of themselves without head scarves, demanding an end to the compulsory head scarf law.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nDuring Monday\u2019s protests some women waved white scarves, the symbol of Mrs. Alinejad\u2019s campaign.\n\nHard-liners say that foreign intelligence agencies, including the Central Intelligence Agency, have been nurturing protests in Iran, like those that broke out in 80 cities at the end of last year. Nearly 4,000 people were arrested and 25 died, according to official statistics. The hard-liners have not provided proof to back up their claims.\n\nThe Islamic head scarf, or hijab, is seen by Iranian ideologues as a pillar of the Islamic Republic of Iran. The law regarding the scarf has been enforced since the 1979 Islamic Revolution, and a head scarf is obligatory for every woman in the country, even tourists and visiting foreign dignitaries.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhile discriminatory Islamic divorce and inheritance laws pose problems for individual women, the head scarf is a highly public symbol of a set of personal rules imposed by Iran\u2019s clerical leaders, who decide what people can wear, what music they can listen to and what television programs and movies they get to see. Men are also the subject of clothing laws: They are forbidden to wear shorts in public.\n\nDuring the past decade, influenced by the rise of the internet, satellite television and cheap foreign travel, many Iranians have grown deeply resentful of rules that they can see for themselves are out of step with most of the rest of the world. Many have become relatively secular and feel increasingly unwelcome in the fixed-in-stone state version of Shiite Islam, and many have taken to flouting the rules whenever and wherever they feel free enough to do so.\n\nIn past years, the morality police zealously enforced the rules, arresting women and men who violated them. But under the current president, Hassan Rouhani, a moderate, those officers have largely been taken off the streets.\n\nTheir removal was a gesture to a radically changed society, but it was also a recognition that there were not enough enforcers available to control a society that resents and rejects the rules. Women without head scarves can be seen everywhere in Tehran, in their cars, in shopping centers and even on the street, but always with the scarves draped over their shoulders, as if they have only just slipped off.\n\nBut the public protests are different because they are a symbolic rejection of authority and a statement that some young women are apparently ready to emulate. \u201cI was working when I saw the image of another woman protesting on social media,\u201d the 28-year-old said in a telephone interview. She said she informed some friends and co-workers about her intentions.\n\n\u201cIf a lot of people do this, it will have more influence, I thought, so I went,\u201d she said. At Ferdowsi Square, one of the busiest places in Tehran, she used a tree branch to clamber on top of the utility box next to a traffic light.\n\n\u201c \u2018Good going,\u2019 \u201d she said many people shouted. \u201cAfter five or six minutes people urged me to step down.\u201d They did not have a problem with her protest, she said, but they had what they wanted. \u201cThey had taken enough pictures to put on social media,\u201d she said.", "title": "Tired of Their Veils, Some Iranian Women Stage Rare Protests", "authors": ["Thomas Erdbrink"]} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cI wrote behind the cloak of anonymity, because when you write something against the government, about the children who are orphaned in this war on drugs, and if you call out the administration for false claims, you receive hate from the government\u2019s army of trolls,\u201d Ms. Laurio said in an interview during an event for the release of a book based on her blog. \u201cBut the threats are not enough to invalidate the issue that I am trying to point out: that the government lies.\u201d\n\nStill, she is worried, despite having the bodyguards her friends are helping to pay for. And there is cause.\n\nOn Monday, the government revoked the license for Rappler, an independent news outlet that has been a leading reporter of deaths and abuses in Mr. Duterte\u2019s drug war. One of Mr. Duterte\u2019s backers has directly taken aim at Ms. Laurio, accusing her in a lawsuit of online libel. She has countersued.\n\nAnother sent her an online message in which he threatened to smash her face with a baseball bat the next time he saw her \u2014 suggesting he was watching.\n\nThrough all that, Ms. Laurio\u2019s posts on the Pinoy Ako Blog, written in Tagalog, have lost none of the dark humor and sarcasm that made the site so popular to begin with. Her admirers say her work has been brave and vital.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cI think P.A.B. filled in a particular niche quite effectively, providing real-time, punchy and resonant attacks against a real and perceived purveyor of so-called fake news,\u201d said Richard Javad Heydarian, a political analyst who wrote the book \u201cThe Rise of Duterte: A Populist Revolt Against Elite Democracy.\u201d\n\nThe attention given to Ms. Laurio and other outlets that are critical of Mr. Duterte speaks volumes \u201cabout the shift of information warfare\u201d to the social media landscape, Mr. Heydarian said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMaria Ressa, the veteran journalist who runs Rappler, has long been a target of such warfare. In a particularly bad time, Ms. Laurio used the Pinoy Ako Blog to come to her defense.\n\nA wave of online harassers, many of them openly from the armed forces, were attacking Ms. Ressa. Ms. Laurio publicly called on the military chief to rein in his troops, and published several posts about soldiers discussing Ms. Ressa\u2019s looks and whether they would have sex with her.\n\nThe military later apologized, and Ms. Ressa credited Ms. Laurio\u2019s blog for giving her \u201ca sense of justice.\u201d\n\n\u201cI realized that I had stopped defending myself, and here was someone I didn\u2019t know pointing out the horrors of what social media had become and the values it was rewarding,\u201d said Ms. Ressa, who has documented the weaponization of social media by Duterte loyalists.\n\nLong before she was dragged into the public eye, Ms. Laurio experienced one struggle after another.\n\nShe was orphaned at an early age: She was 10 when her mother died of appendicitis, she said, and her inconsolable father turned to alcohol and quickly followed suit. She was passed among a series of relatives, mostly on the central Philippine island of Masbate, until she turned 16, when she was officially adopted by an aunt.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nShe decided to go to Manila to study law, she said, because she wanted to help those who cannot afford legal help.\n\nHer online critics have attacked her credibility by saying she suffered a breakdown a decade ago and tried to commit suicide. Ms. Laurio was ready with an answer: She not only bluntly confirmed it, she went deeper, saying she has struggled with repressed anger since being molested as a child.\n\nThen there have been the political accusations, among them that she was being paid by the political campaign for Mr. Duterte\u2019s closest rival in the 2016 election, Mar Roxas, to smear the president.\n\nShe acknowledges volunteering for the Roxas campaign during the election, but insisted that she took no money for her work there.\n\nPhoto\n\nOne of her first popular blog posts, posted on Facebook three months after Mr. Duterte was sworn in, was a list of 10 reasons she could not support the president. She noted the sharply increasing number of victims in his war on drugs, as well as his unabashed support for the family of Ferdinand Marcos, the former dictator.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThat post was shared at least 28,000 times on social media. Shortly afterward, threats flooded her social media accounts, and her Facebook page was suspended repeatedly because of complaints from Duterte supporters. She decided to move the blog to a dedicated website.\n\nThe site now has double the number of followers it had when Ms. Laurio was identified as the author late last year.\n\nAsked for comment, a spokesman for Mr. Duterte, Harry Roque, discounted Ms. Laurio\u2019s blog. \u201cI don\u2019t read her,\u201d he said.\n\nMs. Laurio credits her blog\u2019s popularity to a sense that ordinary Filipinos are growing more impatient with the government. Many have also been struck by her courage since government officials identified her. In naming her one of its Filipinos of the Year, the Philippine Daily Inquirer said that Ms. Laurio \u201cstood out for her patriotic daring.\u201d\n\nIt has been difficult, though. Her higher profile made it impossible to continue her work at an Australian call center. And her boyfriend, an avid supporter of Mr. Duterte, distanced himself after Ms. Laurio went public.\n\nThey have since reunited, having agreed to avoid talking about politics, and to unfollow each other\u2019s social media accounts. They\u2019re planning their wedding for 2020, she said.\n\nShe acknowledges that she has thought at times about quitting as the threats have piled up. But an outpouring of support from friends and online followers has kept her going.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThe situation that we have right now is not acceptable,\u201d Ms. Laurio said. \u201cOur countrymen are dying on the streets each day. At the same time these politicians feel that they can just do whatever that they want.\n\n\u201cRight now, I am jobless. But still doing the same thing \u2014 exposing and fighting the spread of fake news,\u201d she added. \u201cMy love for this country is greater than the fear that I have about the administration or my detractors.\n\n\u201cEvery day, my mantra is: \u2018I inhale courage and exhale fear.\u2019\u201d", "title": "To Criticize Duterte in Public, \u2018Inhale Courage and Exhale Fear\u2019", "authors": ["Felipe Villamor", "The Saturday Profile"]} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "The city comptroller, Scott M. Stringer, who sat next to Mr. de Blasio at the news conference, tempered his enthusiasm on the pension divestments, saying, \u201cWe\u2019re setting a formal goal to divest from fossil fuels.\u201d He added that any decision would be complex, take time and must be viewed through a \u201clens of sound fiscal stewardship.\u201d He said the goal was to complete the divestment within five years.\n\nTrustees for the city\u2019s five pension funds would need to approve any divestment, weighing its effect on the funds\u2019 performance. A resolution submitted on Wednesday to the boards of the five funds called for them to \u201cinitiate a process for determining a prudent divestment\u201d strategy in keeping with the fiduciary duty to responsibly manage the funds. It called for the boards to hire a consultant to study the issue and its impact on risk and return.\n\nMr. de Blasio said that a majority of the trustees on two of the funds \u2014 one for teachers and another for many employees not including police officers or firefighters \u2014 were ready to support divestment.\n\nSome participants in the news conference noted that under Mayor de Blasio, the city\u2019s pension funds had previously divested from companies involved in the coal industry, as well as from private prison companies. But those investments represented a total of about $60 million, far less than the estimated $5 billion invested in fossil fuel companies. The total amount managed by the funds is about $189 billion.\n\nThe divestment announcement comes less than a month after Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo promised to cease the state\u2019s investments in entities \u201cwith significant fossil-fuel activities,\u201d and created an advisory committee to \u201cdevelop a decarbonization road map.\u201d\n\nThe news conference Wednesday was held at a Lower Manhattan community center that Mr. de Blasio said had been flooded during Hurricane Sandy. into a dead-end entitlement trap but rather to be given a path forward and upward so they can do for themselves.\u201d\n\nAdvocates for Medicaid beneficiaries said they disagreed with the Trump health.\n\n\u201cConsidering that it will seriously harm over 100,000 Kentuckians, in violation of numerous provisions of Medicaid law, we are very seriously considering taking legal action \u2014 and "title": "To Get Medicaid in Kentucky, Many Will Have to Work. Advocates for the Poor Say They Will Sue.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "Since making his inaugural appearance just 175 miles from his hometown, Calgary, Glass has registered a 3-2-1 record and a .910 save percentage while splitting time with his fellow backup Anton Forsberg.\n\nAs so often happens in sports, Glass owes his good fortune to another player\u2019s misfortune. The Blackhawks\u2019 top goalie, the veteran All-Star Corey Crawford, remains sidelined and on injured reserve with an upper-body injury. The Blackhawks have declined to comment on Crawford\u2019s injury or a timetable for him to return. Several published reports this week indicated that Crawford could miss the remainder of the season, which could keep Glass in a N.H.L. uniform for the foreseeable future.\n\nSince being called up, Glass has maintained a day-to-day, businesslike approach and has avoided becoming awe-struck in a room full of superstars. The Blackhawks (22-17-6) have struggled in ways that predate their three Stanley Cup championships since 2010. They are currently not in playoff position.\n\nBut Glass\u2019s feel-good story has resonated around the N.H.L. and even more so within the confines of the Blackhawks\u2019 dressing room, where stars like Patrick Kane and Jonathan Toews have become big-time Glass supporters.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s been pretty cool to have a front-row seat for it,\u201d Kane said.\n\nGlass was playing in Canada\u2019s Western Hockey League when the Ottawa Senators drafted him in 2004 with the 89th pick. From there he went to Charlotte of the East Coast Hockey League, then moved to Binghamton of the American Hockey League. In 2009 he signed with Barys Astana in Kazakhstan and headed to the Kontinental Hockey League.\n\nA world away from the N.H.L. rinks he aspired to play on, Glass discovered a passionate fan base and the opportunity to grow and develop in a place he could not even imagine living with his wife, Allie. Then his agent mentioned the possibility of continuing his career there. Glass\u2019s K.H.L. journey took him to Spartak Moscow, CSKA Moscow, Lada Togliatti, Novosibirsk Sibir and Dinamo Minsk.\n\nPhoto\n\nGlass landed on the Blackhawks\u2019 radar in 2014, when team officials were seeking a third goaltender to round out their system. Mark Bernard, the Blackhawks\u2019 general manager of minor league affiliations, became aware of Glass\u2019s track record and penchant for hard work, leadership and attention to detail.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut Glass instead elected to return to the K.H.L., where he would play until 2016, when he decided his best route to the N.H.L. would probably travel through North America, where his career had started so many years before.\n\nGlass got a training camp invitation from the Toronto Maple Leafs and played briefly with the club\u2019s A.H.L. affiliate. Glass later signed with the Blackhawks and was assigned to their A.H.L. team in Rockford, Ill., just 90 minutes outside Chicago. Bernard immediately sensed Glass was prepared to do whatever was necessary to reach the N.H.L.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cHe\u2019s a guy that had a goal in mind \u2014 \u2018I\u2019m going to play in the N.H.L.,\u2019\u201d Bernard said.\n\nGlass made 20 starts for Rockford\u2019s IceHogs last season, and another 18 this season. He had just returned from a two-day holiday break in Calgary when he received word the Blackhawks had placed Crawford on injured reserve.\n\nGlass was instructed to meet the team in Vancouver. Glass first contacted his wife, who was in Calgary with the couple\u2019s newborn daughter, Lucy.\n\nAs thrilled as he was, Glass realized he could not allow the promotion to change his approach.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s a big deal, but you try to remember, I\u2019ve been doing this for a long time, this isn\u2019t my first year pro by any means,\u201d Glass said. \u201cIt\u2019s definitely a step up from where I had been playing, but all the years in Russia prepared me for this.\u201d\n\nNews of Glass\u2019s call-up spread quickly. The congratulatory text messages and phone calls poured in from friends and family members, some of whom, Glass said, had not been in touch for years. As he prepared to join the Blackhawks, the freshly minted N.H.L. rookie could not help but think back on all of the steps that had brought him to this point.\n\n\u201cMost guys might have said, \u2018Hey, I want to get a real job and get on with Plan B,\u2019\u201d Blackhawks Coach Joel Quenneville said. \u201cThat\u2019s a testament to how competitive he is and that dream of playing in the N.H.L. has got to be part of it.\u201d\n\nGlass refuses to let the speed of the N.H.L. intimidate him. Same goes for the pressure of playing a role in moving the Blackhawks closer to a playoff berth. He cannot afford to predict how long he will remain while Crawford\u2019s next steps are up in the air.\n\nTaking each day as it comes has always been part of Glass\u2019s routine, and so he isn\u2019t about to change a formula that has served him so well.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cAt the end of the day,\u201d Glass said, \u201cit\u2019s just a matter of going out and stopping hockey pucks.\u201d", "title": "To Get to the Blackhawks\u2019 Net, Jeff Glass Took the Long Way", "authors": ["Jeff Arnold"]} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 Remember the infamous \u201cBridge to Nowhere\u201d? The Montana Sheep Institute or the now-shuttered North Carolina teapot hall of fame?\n\nCongress years ago eliminated funding for these types of pet projects, known as earmarks, after they became derided as government boondoggles, largess and a pathway to corruption.\n\nPresident Trump now wants to bring them back.\n\nIn a freewheeling meeting about immigration with congressional Republicans and Democrats this week, Mr. Trump lamented the gridlock that has gripped the capital in recent years and suggested that earmarks, the practice of stealthily stuffing funding for pet projects into legislation, be exhumed from the legislative graveyard.\n\n\u201cOur system lends itself to not getting things done, and I hear so much about earmarks \u2014 the old earmark system \u2014 how there was a great friendliness when you had earmarks,\u201d Mr. Trump said Tuesday. \u201cMaybe all of you should start thinking about going back to a form of earmarks.\u201d", "title": "To Grease Wheels of Congress, Trump Suggests Bringing Back Pork", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "The Trump administration, which has promised that the new tax law will put money back in workers\u2019 pockets, is eager to ensure that the transition to a new tax code does not devolve into chaos and to show evidence that taxpayers are faring better under the new law.\n\nSteven Mnuchin, the Treasury secretary, said on Thursday that 90 percent of wage earners would see an increase in their take-home pay once businesses change their withholding tables to reflect the new tax code.\n\nPhoto\n\nTreasury Department officials said on Thursday that they did not expect significant changes in the number of taxpayers who receive tax refunds. Taxpayers who do not immediately receive larger paychecks will still benefit from the tax cuts at the end of the year, once they file their tax returns.\n\nDemocrats have been critical of a push by the Treasury Department and the I.R.S. to get companies to quickly adopt the new withholding tables and warned earlier this week that taxpayers could get hit with big tax bills if they withhold too little in anticipation of the lower rates. Senator Ron Wyden of Oregon and Representative Richard E. Neal of Massachusetts, the top Democrats on the Senate and House tax writing committees, sent a letter to the Government Accountability Office asking it to analyze the 2018 withholding tables and determine whether they will result in \u201csystematic under-withholding.\u201d\n\nMr. Mnuchin on Thursday said that the release of the new tables had not been rushed and that the I.R.S., which is under the umbrella of the Treasury Department, wants taxpayers to withhold the correct amount of money.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later.
