View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cI think this is another ridiculous charge,\u201d Mr. Mnuchin said at a briefing at the White House. \u201cOur objective is not to have taxpayers over-withhold so they owe money at the end of the year.\u201d\n\nWhile companies and workers try to figure out the new tax landscape, states are trying to mitigate some of the tax hits in the law. California, New York and New Jersey are among the states that have been considering changes to their tax codes to blunt the pain that their residents could feel from the scaling back of the state and local tax deduction in the new law. States have considered switching to a payroll tax system or classifying local taxes as charitable contributions so they can be deducted at the federal level.\n\nMr. Mnuchin would not say if the administration would try to halt such efforts, but he assailed the strategy as being in bad faith.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI think it\u2019s one of the more ridiculous comments to think you can take a real estate tax that you\u2019re required to make and dress that up as a charitable contribution,\u201d Mr. Mnuchin said. \u201cI hope that states are more focused on cutting their budgets and giving tax cuts to their people in their states than they are on trying to evade the law.\u201d\n\nTrump administration officials continued to point to corporate announcements of pay increases and bonuses to promote the early success of the tax cuts. Mr. Mnuchin on Thursday singled out wage increases at Walmart as a sign that Mr. Trump\u2019s policies were working. However, he declined to accept any blame for the store closings and expected layoffs that Walmart announced at its Sam\u2019s Club chain.\n\nMr. Mnuchin also dismissed questions about Mr. Trump\u2019s tax returns, which he has refused to release. Democrats have said that he should make his returns public so that voters can see if he is benefiting from the tax cuts.", "title": "To Lift Paychecks, Treasury Urges Companies to Act Quickly on New Tax Law", "authors": ["Alan Rappeport"]} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "If you want to know how reading saves the lives of people behind bars, listen to the poet and lawyer Reginald Dwayne Betts. At 16, in 1996, Mr. Betts was sentenced to eight years for a carjacking. Books, he has said, \u201cbecame magic.\u201d Reading became the way that he \u201clearned about what it means to be human.\u201d After being released from prison, Mr. Betts got his bachelor\u2019s degree from the University of Maryland, received a Master of Fine Arts from Warren Wilson College and graduated from Yale Law School.\n\nOr ask Michelle Jones. Last fall, after serving more than two decades in prison for murdering her son, Ms. Jones began a Ph.D. program at New York University. While incarcerated, she\u2019d read avidly and discovered her love for history \u2014 including the history of the prison where she was locked up. In 2016, along with another woman in prison, she won the award for Indiana Historical Society\u2019s best research project.\n\nMr. Betts and Ms. Jones may be exceptional people, but their experience is backed up by research that reading and education lead to lower recidivism rates. One 2013 study found that people who participate in correctional education programs while incarcerated had a 43 percent lower odds recidivating than those who did not.\n\nSo it\u2019s mind boggling that this month, in an effort to \u201cenhance the safety and security of correctional facilities,\u201d the New York State Department of Corrections and Community Supervision began implementing a ban that forces incarcerated people in New York state prisons to receive packages from only a handful of select state-approved sellers. The new rule, which has so far been enforced in three state prisons (Green, Taconic and Green Haven) and will be expanded to the entire state in September, has the effect of banning not just items typically sent to them in care packages from loved ones and organizations, like fresh produce, but also many books.", "title": "Opinion | To Make Prisons \u2018Safer,\u2019 Some Are Banning . . . Books", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nCoogan\u2019s restaurant and bar, a civic fixture in Washington Heights for 32 years, reached a new agreement with its landlord late Friday afternoon, just three days after its owners announced they would be closing in May because of a demand for a $40,000 monthly rent increase.\n\nA wave of public support for the establishment, including from Lin-Manuel Miranda, the creator of \u201cHamilton\u201d who has been a patron since his boyhood, led its landlord, NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital, to reopen discussions with the owners of Coogan\u2019s. A lease extension was agreed upon shortly after 4 p.m. Friday. Terms were not disclosed.\n\nThe restaurant, on Broadway between 168th and 169th Streets, was an anchor of the neighborhood in the years when that part of Upper Manhattan was racked with violence from the illegal drug trade. With roots as a traditional Irish bar, Coogan\u2019s has become well-known as a multiethnic gathering spot. More than 15,000 people signed an online petition supporting the restaurant.\n\n\u201cNewYork-Presbyterian and Coogan\u2019s are delighted that this has been resolved in a way that satisfies everyone involved, and that Coogan\u2019s will continue to be a very special part of the Washington Heights community,\u201d the hospital and the restaurant said in a joint statement. They acknowledged that Representative Adriano Espaillat and the Manhattan borough president, Gale Brewer, had been instrumental in bringing about the agreement. Also taking part was Luis A. Miranda Jr., a political consultant who is the father of the Broadway star.\n\nBoth Mirandas were among those at an impromptu celebration in Coogan\u2019s on Friday evening. The younger Mr. Miranda joined one of its owners, Peter Walsh, in serenading a diner who was celebrating her birthday. They were cheered by the entire restaurant when they finished, and then again after Mr. Miranda pumped his fist in the air and shouted, \u201cCoogan\u2019s!\u201d", "title": "To New Yorkers\u2019 Delight, Coogan\u2019s Says It Isn\u2019t Closing After All", "authors": ["Jim Dwyer"]} {"date": "2018-01-08 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cPeople that are dealing with this issue know that a third-century solution to a 21st-century problem is not going to fix this long-term,\u201d said Representative Will Hurd, Republican of Texas and a former C.I.A. officer. Mr. Hurd, whose district includes more than 800 miles of border territory with Mexico, has pushed for more funding for sensors and other border security technologies.\n\nHomeland Security officials have long and frequently described border security as a holistic system, made up not just of walls and fencing but also patrol routes, lighting, cameras, sensors and personnel.\n\nDavid Bier, a policy analyst with the Cato Institute, said a border wall would do little to stop the drug trade. Most of the cocaine, heroin and methamphetamines smuggled into the United States come through legal ports of entry rather than areas that would be stopped by a wall, according to the Drug Enforcement Administration.\n\nNor would a wall stop illegal immigration, other experts said. Data from the Department of Homeland Security and research groups like the New York-based Center for Migration Studies show that most undocumented immigrants now simply overstay legally obtained short-term visas \u2014 and did not sneak across the border.\n\n\u201cSo unless the wall is 35,000 feet high, it's not going to do much to stop those overstaying these visas,\u201d said Robert Warren, a fellow at the Center for Migration Studies who has worked on immigration issues for Republican and Democratic presidents.", "title": "To Pay for Wall, Trump Would Cut Proven Border Security Measures", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-31 00:00:00", "text": "This notion of balance, of limits that should not be pushed, would undergird the increasingly shrill alarms Vogt issued in his books and articles, and from various insecure perches in the global conservation hierarchy, where his disdain for economic growth cost him one post after another. He committed suicide in 1968, thinking his cause lost, just as Paul Ehrlich published \u201cThe Population Bomb,\u201d Earth Day drew millions into the streets in 1970 and a groundbreaking 1972 report, \u201cThe Limits to Growth,\u201d firmly established the argument he\u2019d helped pioneer.\n\nPhoto\n\nBorlaug\u2019s story is more epic, even in its condensed form. A classic product of the Midwest land-grant colleges that are one of America\u2019s greatest successes, he found his way to a dusty plant-breeding station in a desolate part of Mexico, where he figured out how to breed wheat that combined high yields with resistance to the ancient plague of stem rust. The new varieties made full use of fertilizers and other inputs \u2014 harvests soared first in South America and then, crucially, in India. (The story of getting the seed to the subcontinent, amid wars between India, China and Pakistan, is a fine Cold War saga.) What followed were honors, and also questions \u2014 the Green Revolution did raise yields, at least for a while, but it also wrecked much of peasant agriculture, driving poor people to the big cities and polluting farmlands with pesticides.\n\nAs he showed in his earlier books \u201c1491\u201d and \u201c1493\u201d Mann\u2019s storytelling skills are unmatched \u2014 the sprightly tempo with which this book unfolds, each question answered as it comes to mind, makes for pure pleasure reading. But you may find yourself troubled a little along the way by the analytical framework he\u2019s imposed on the material, the division between the technologically minded Wizards and the limits-embracing Prophets. His distinction works pretty well when he applies it to food (GMOs vs. organics) and water (dams and desalination vs. drip irrigation) but it starts to break down when we reach climate and energy, perhaps the planet\u2019s central problems.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMann gives a typically brief but enchanting history of the solar panel (the 1904 World\u2019s Fair in St. Louis featured a solar array built by a Portuguese priest so powerful that it fried birds flying 40 feet above) and then he assigns the technology to the sandal-wearing Prophets on the grounds that it is distributed, not centralized like coal-fired or nuclear power plants. \u201cIt is small-scale, flexible and respectful of environmental limits; it fosters community control and democracy.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nFair enough, but in straightforward terms a solar panel seems pretty wizardly. I mean, you point a sheet of glass with some inlaid silicon at the sun, and out the back flows cold, light and communications. That\u2019s pure Hogwarts. What\u2019s more, it can be deployed (as Mann notes) in giant centralized arrays as well as house by house \u2014 so much sunlight falls on the Earth that in theory an area smaller than Texas would suffice to power the whole planet. Mann\u2019s analysis of solar power also shows the inevitable danger of writing a book that takes several years when the subject is changing so quickly: He refers to renewable energy as \u201csurprisingly expensive\u201d and finds only one installation, in Nevada, that provides reliable round-the-clock power. But the price of panels and batteries has continued to plummet. In the past few months, bids for new solar farms in Mexico and Saudi Arabia have produced the cheapest electrons ever generated on the planet, and Elon Musk (who seems an unbreakable alloy of Borlaugish wizardliness and Vogtian alarmism) has built (in less than 100 days) the world\u2019s largest battery, turning South Australia\u2019s abundant sun into a 24/7 source of power.\n\nThis analytical muddle doesn\u2019t matter greatly because Mann refuses to say which set of solutions he thinks holds most promise for the future. \u201cIn our internet era, there are entirely too many pundits shouting out advice,\u201d he writes, which seems inarguable. \u201cI believe I stand on firmer ground when I try to describe what I see around me than when I try to tell people what to do.\u201d Safer ground, anyway.\n\nHe confines what may be his most controversial points to a pair of appendixes, one on just how bad we can expect global warming to be, and the other in which he explains that the most reputable scientific bodies have by now agreed that genetically modified food is safe to eat. That\u2019s an important fact, but as he acknowledges, it doesn\u2019t satisfy critics\u2019 main objections to the technology: \u201cWhether the current version of industrial agriculture can, with the addition of new technologies, provide for a world of 10 billion in a long-lasting way \u2014 or if the perils involved (ecological, economic, spiritual) are large enough to require it to be radically revamped.\u201d\n\nThe great virtue of Mann\u2019s book \u2014 and much of his journalism over many years \u2014 is that it raises very large questions like these that are usually either ignored or answered in slogans. He provides detail enough, and simplicity enough, that anyone who is struggling with these puzzles will be enlightened and informed. And entertained, which, given the subject matter, is no small feat.", "title": "To Respect the Earth\u2019s Limits \u2014 or Push Them?", "authors": ["Bill Mckibben", "Charles C. Mann"]} {"date": "2018-01-22 00:00:00", "text": "NEW DELHI \u2014 For the first time ever, the Taj Mahal, India\u2019s monument to eternal love, is getting a serious cleaning.\n\nFor more than 350 years, monsoon rains in Agra, the bustling city where the monument sits, were enough to wash dirt off the structure\u2019s walls. But pollution has worsened over the last couple of decades, and parts of the marble facade have turned yellow and black.\n\nSince 2015, workers have scaled the monument\u2019s minarets and walls to correct discoloration and remove layers of grime from the 17th-century structure, which was built by the Muslim emperor Shah Jahan as a mausoleum for his favorite wife, Mumtaz Mahal.\n\nBehind the monument, the Yamuna River has also filled with sewage and other waste, worsening the problem by attracting millions of mosquito-like insects. They settle near the backside of the Taj Mahal and excrete a green substance on its walls during mating flights.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nCleaning the monument is time-consuming and challenging. To remove discoloration, workers suspended on scaffolding are caking Fuller\u2019s earth \u2014 a mud paste that absorbs dirt, grease and animal excrement, and that is commonly used to treat skin impurities \u2014 on the entire monument. The mud is then washed off, leaving a pristine surface.", "title": "To Rid the Taj Mahal of Its Grime, India Prescribes a Mud Bath", "authors": ["Kai Schultz"]} {"date": "2018-01-02 00:00:00", "text": "Ejiao was once prescribed primarily to supplement lost blood and balance yin and yang, but today it is sought for a range of ills, from delaying aging and increasing libido to treating side effects of chemotherapy and preventing infertility, miscarriage and menstrual irregularity in women.\n\nWhile ejiao has been around for centuries, its modern popularity began to grow around 2010, when companies such as Dong-E-E-Jiao \u2014 the largest manufacturer in China \u2014 launched aggressive advertising campaigns. Fifteen years ago, ejiao sold for $9 per pound in China; now, it fetches around $400 per pound.\n\nAs demand increased, China\u2019s donkey population \u2014 once the world\u2019s largest \u2014 has fallen to fewer than six million from 11 million, and by some estimates possibly to as few as three million. Attempts to replenish the herds have proved challenging: Unlike cows or pigs, donkeys do not lend themselves to intensive breeding. Females produce just one foal per year and are prone to spontaneous abortions under stressful conditions.\n\nSo Chinese companies have begun buying donkey skins from developing nations. Out of a global population of 44 million, around 1.8 million donkeys are slaughtered per year to produce ejiao, according to a report published last year by the Donkey Sanctuary, a nonprofit based in the United Kingdom.\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s a huge appetite for ejiao in China that shows no signs of diminishing,\u201d said Simon Pope, manager of rapid response and campaigns for the organization. \u201cAs a result, donkeys are being Hoovered out of communities that depend on them.\u201d\n\nIn November, researchers at the Beijing Forestry University warned that China\u2019s demand for ejiao may cause donkeys \u201cto become the next pangolin.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cChina chooses to import donkeys from all over the world at high cost, which may lead to potential crisis of donkeys throughout the rest of the world,\u201d the researchers wrote in the Equine Veterinary Journal.\n\nPhoto\n\nDonkey skins find their way to China from nations as varied as Kyrgyzstan, Brazil and Mexico. But Africa is the epicenter of the trade, both in terms of the number of animals killed and the impact on the ground.\n\n\u201cIn 2016, this business of donkeys erupted,\u201d said Obassy Nguvillah, a police superintendent in Tanzania\u2019s Monduli district, near the Kenyan border. \u201cThere were increasing numbers of cases of guys passing into the Maasai area, taking people\u2019s donkeys and transporting them to the Chinese-owned processing plant.\u201d\n\nIn Esilalei \u2014 a village located on a sprawling, drought-plagued savanna under Mr. Nguvillah\u2019s watch \u2014 residents lost nearly 475 donkeys in a single year. While about 175 of the animals were recovered by tracking the thieves into the bush, police believe the remainder were sold to slaughterhouses. Unable to afford replacements, the former owners are still reeling.\n\n\u201cNowadays, we are no longer happy because our vehicles, our donkeys, are no longer here,\u201d said Katasi Moko, who was left with just one donkey after four others were stolen.\n\nWith five donkeys, Ms. Moko was able to complete two tasks each day: collecting water from distant wells, say, or gathering firewood. But with just one donkey, she has time to accomplish just one, because several back-and-forth trips are needed.\n\n\u201cOur workload has increased,\u201d she said.\n\nFourteen African countries, along with Pakistan, have enacted various bans against the international donkey trade. Tanzania joined the list in June, citing concerns that its donkeys would soon be wiped out if the slaughter continued.\n\nRimoinet Shamburi, chairman of Esilalei village, said that donkey thefts have decreased since the ban but have not ceased altogether. He believes the legal trade in Kenya is to blame.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThings are still bad because there\u2019s an industry in Nairobi that\u2019s supporting the stealing of donkeys,\u201d he said.\n\n\u2018They Come From All Over\u2019\n\nUnlike Tanzania, Kenya\u2019s donkey skin trade shows no signs of slowing. In 2016, prices for skins were fifty times higher than in 2014, while prices for live donkeys have nearly tripled, from about $60 to $165.\n\nThe country\u2019s three abattoirs \u2014 all of which have Chinese owners or partners \u2014 reported processing just under 100,000 donkeys in two years, according to a government memo. Both skin and meat are exported to China, usually through Vietnam or Hong Kong.", "title": "To Sate China\u2019s Demand, African Donkeys Are Stolen and Skinned", "authors": ["Rachel Nuwer"]} {"date": "2018-01-15 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cAnybody representing themselves in a death penalty case is guaranteeing a death sentence,\u201d Mr. English said. \u201cI knew Robert and I knew his family, and he needed my help.\u201d\n\nAbout a month before the trial, Mr. English told Mr. McCoy that the case was unwinnable because of the evidence the prosecution had against him, including that when Mr. McCoy was discovered, the gun used in the killings was under a seat of the vehicle he was traveling in.\n\nAlso, in a 911 recording, Ms. Colston Young could be heard telling \u201cRobert\u201d that her daughter was with the police, before a gunshot rang out and the call ended. A car registered to Mr. McCoy and his estranged wife was spotted leaving the scene by the police, and the phone Ms. Colston Young had used to call the police was found in the vehicle.\n\nMr. English urged Mr. McCoy to plead guilty in exchange for life in prison. Mr. McCoy maintained his innocence, saying that he wanted to mount a defense that he was out of town at the time of the murders and was framed by the police because he knew they were running a drug trafficking ring. Mr. English said it was Mr. McCoy\u2019s delusions of a grand conspiracy that made his client unable to participate in his defense and that led him to believe he had no choice but to try to save his client\u2019s life.\n\nTwo weeks before the trial, Mr. English told Mr. McCoy that he was going to admit that Mr. McCoy was guilty because maintaining credibility with the jury was the best chance to keep him alive.\n\nMr. McCoy furiously objected and tried to have Mr. English removed from the case. Mr. McCoy\u2019s parents wrote to the judge also seeking Mr. English\u2019s removal.\n\nBridgett Brown, 57, a lawyer in Alexandria, La., has been friends with Mr. English for nearly two decades. She has had three capital punishment cases that ended in plea deals and consulted with Mr. English almost daily before and during Mr. McCoy\u2019s trial.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cLarry kept saying to me that he didn\u2019t want this boy to die on his watch,\u201d Ms. Brown said. \u201cHe felt the jury had death in their eyes.\u201d\n\nDuring opening statements, Mr. English followed through with his plan. \u201cI\u2019m telling you, Mr. McCoy committed these crimes,\u201d Mr. English told the jury, according to court records. Mr. McCoy immediately objected, saying, \u201cMr. English is simply selling me out\u201d and disregarding \u201call aspects\u201d of his due process.\n\nMs. Brown said that Mr. English \u201chad a job nobody wanted.\u201d\n\n\u201cThe only people who wanted Robert McCoy alive in that courtroom was his momma and Larry,\u201d she added.\n\nBut Mr. English saw saving Mr. McCoy\u2019s life as part of a larger struggle against injustice.\n\n\u201cThe criminal justice system in this country is so racked by racism and classism that there is no way the death penalty can be implemented in a way that\u2019s constitutional,\u201d Mr. English said.\n\nMr. English, who is 62, grew up poor with six siblings on a sharecropper\u2019s farm in rural Louisiana. He said he had \u201ca better chance of being the starting point guard for the New York Knickerbockers than graduating from Tulane Law School.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn Louisiana, he served as the president of an N.A.A.C.P. chapter and a local school board.\n\nHe was moving to Harlem when he took Mr. McCoy\u2019s case, which he described as the \u201cclosing of a chapter\u201d on his life in Louisiana.\n\nIn Harlem, Mr. English, who no longer practices law, is the chairman of a firm that deals in real estate infrastructure development. As the chairman of Community Board 9 in Harlem, he fought for minority businesses to get more city contracts. Yellowed articles on his office wall show him during a sit-in.\n\nMr. English displays a copy of a 2004 article that says he was able to get quadruple homicide charges dropped against a 24-year-old Walmart clerk, even though he had confessed.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI\u2019m confident I kept five innocent people from spending the rest of their lives in jail,\u201d Mr. English said.\n\nWhen he was asked to recall those cases, a sly smile spread over his face. He said he loved the \u201cgunslinger\u201d aspect of being a criminal lawyer. But then there was the dark, more depressing side of the job.\n\n\u201cBeing a criminal lawyer in the American justice system is like doing triage for black men,\u201d Mr. English said. \u201cBy the time they get to you, you\u2019re dealing with the effects of absent fathers and poverty. They are 19 years old and about to go to jail for 20 years. All these lives are coming in, and you are doing everything you can to save them. It was my way of fighting the system.\u201d\n\nPhillip Collier, 62, has been best friends with Mr. English since they were in seventh grade at Lanier Jr.-Sr. High School in Shreveport, La.\n\nMr. Collier remembered being the new student in school when a teacher instructed Mr. English to escort him to his next class. To Mr. Collier\u2019s surprise, Mr. English showed up at the end of that class and walked him to his next class, and his next class, and the class after that, until the day had ended.\n\n\u201cAs a kid, Larry was looking out for his community, even though I was a total stranger,\u201d Mr. Collier, a retired Ford Motor Company executive, said in a phone interview from his home in El Dorado Hills, Calif.\n\nThe two enrolled in the Army together after graduating from high school to escape what they were sure was a bleak future in Louisiana.\n\n\u201cI would have been surprised had he chose anything else other than criminal law,\u201d Mr. Collier said. \u201cMost of the people we knew, friends and families, had experienced injustices with the legal system that he wanted to do something about.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIt is not unusual for lawyers to admit their client\u2019s guilt, especially in death penalty cases. Usually, the strategy is carried out with the cooperation of the accused. To go against a client\u2019s wishes, however, violates the role lawyers are supposed to play in the legal system, said Lawrence J. Fox, a lecturer at Yale Law School.\n\n\u201cThis is one of the most difficult questions that we\u2019ve identified in being a lawyer,\u201d said Mr. Fox, who filed a brief with several colleagues from the Ethics Bureau at Yale on Mr. McCoy\u2019s behalf. \u201cYou start with the fundamental proposition that we are our client\u2019s servants.\u201d\n\nAs long as the client is not asking the lawyer to do anything illegal, and unless the client has been declared incompetent, the lawyer has to take instruction from the client regarding the admission of guilt, he added.\n\n\u201cIt means some clients on death row may be committing suicide, but that\u2019s their choice to make,\u201d Mr. Fox said.\n\nThe Louisiana Supreme Court has allowed lawyers to concede their client\u2019s guilt over their client\u2019s objections at least four times since 2000, according to a brief supporting Mr. McCoy filed by the Louisiana Association of Criminal Defense Lawyers and the Promise of Justice Initiative.\n\n\u201cWe are looking for guidance. This area of the law is ripe with ambiguity and mistakes,\u201d Mr. Fox said.\n\nMr. McCoy has been fighting for a new trial since he was sentenced to death in 2012. He appealed to the Louisiana Supreme Court, saying that he was denied his Sixth Amendment right to assistance of counsel, but the court ruled against him.\n\nMr. English fell silent when asked if he regretted taking the case.\n\nThen he said, \u201cThe greatest thing I ever did as a lawyer, and the most important thing I ever did as a lawyer, was to take Robert McCoy\u2019s case.\u201d", "title": "To Try to Save Client\u2019s Life, a Lawyer Ignored His Wishes. Can He Do That?", "authors": ["Jeffery C. Mays"]} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "Violent winds and snow, temperatures in the negative numbers \u2014 humans have it easy these days.\n\nStaring out the window into the heart of a blizzard, I have only to walk over to the thermostat for heat. But life continues in the brutal conditions outside. There are plants that lose their leaves, or even their entire aboveground stems in preparation for winter. And though some animals sleep through the worst of winter, some simply have no choice but to live through the frigid weather.\n\nWinter is not an easy time for most plants and animals; even in the best circumstances, it often means the grinding, slowing-down of existence. It often spells the end of weak or incapacitated individuals. So it may seem odd for winter\u2019s symbol, snow, to be a force of moderation. In the northeast, snow can be a surprising game changer for its smallest residents.\n\nOne of the miraculous, tiny creatures that remain active below the snow is a small, warm gray mammal, the meadow vole. Chief among its attributes, Microtus pennsylvanicus is cute. Measuring five to eight inches from the snout to the tip of a tail just a bit longer than a hamster\u2019s, they are pudgy, with short rounded ears, a rounded head, and though perpetually active, they\u2019re somehow not very mousy. They forage throughout the four seasons, and during warmer months can even be observed in broad daylight, scurrying through the matted vegetation in damp meadows and fields. Active night or day, they are driven by an enormous appetite and the ever-present need to feed their young. Locally, meadow voles may produce six or seven broods a year, which is handy for an animal at the bottom of the food chain.\n\nAlso handy for the meadow vole are the mysterious and contradictory insulating qualities of snow.\n\nThe white blanket that winter throws over the northeast is actually a fluffy, air-filled barrier between worse weather, and many plants and animals have learned to use it as a tool for survival. Though hardly balmy, temperatures beneath the snow rarely dip much below freezing. Just a few inches of powder is all the insulation necessary between brutal and tolerable. With arctic cold fronts and \u201cbomb cyclones\u201d assaulting New York with -9 degree results, temperatures under the snow remain roughly 32 degrees \u2014 about 40 degrees warmer.", "title": "To the Vole Cave!", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-01 00:00:00", "text": "Please take your seats.\n\nIt is that time of year again: our annual closing dinner, where we look back at the year that was, to toast and roast the year\u2019s deal makers on Wall Street and in Washington and look ahead to what may come next.\n\nAnd what a year it was.\n\nThis year, we decided to hold our dinner at the Breakers in Palm Beach, Fla., just down the road from the Mar-a-Lago resort, better known as the Winter White House. Given that President Trump has spent nearly a third of his presidency \u2014 that\u2019s not a typo \u2014 at one of his properties, as The Wall Street Journal reported, we figured we would try to make it convenient for him. There were a surprising number of free openings at Mar-a-Lago given all the cancellations by foundations and charities, but ever since an artist projected \u201cPay Trump Bribes Here\u201d on the Trump International Hotel in Washington, our conflicts committee suggested that hosting the dinner at Mar-a-Lago would be a bad idea.\n\nWe also figured holding the dinner in Florida would be convenient for so many of you moguls and machers already down here looking for real estate since the tax bill was signed into law. The other bonus of buying here, of course, is that your home is protected even if you file for bankruptcy.\n\nSitting at the dais are Mr. Trump along with the first lady. (Ivanka, Jared and the rest of the family were away on vacation.) Next to him are Rupert Murdoch and his new B.F.F., Robert Iger of the Walt Disney Company, who just gave up any hope of running for president in 2020, a condition of his deal to buy most of 21st Century Fox\u2019s assets. To their right are the chief negotiators for the tax plan: Gary Cohn and Steven Mnuchin (and Ms. Mnuchin\u2019s wife, Louise Linton, who I should mention \u2014 and I\u2019ll be sure to hashtag this on Instagram \u2014 is wearing a beautiful scarf from Hermes and gown by Valentino).", "title": "Toasts to the Deals (and Other Winners) of 2017", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-09 00:00:00", "text": "Filmmaker Gotham Chopra was granted sweeping access to Brady in an array of intimate settings that the inscrutable signal-caller would normally be loath to allow. There is extensive footage of Brady at his Brookline, Mass., home, with his children, with his wife, Gisele B\u00fcndchen, on family retreats to Costa Rica, on a bro-trip to Montana (with teammates Julian Edelman and Danny Amendola), on a summer tour of China with his son Jack, and in the car during Brady\u2019s commute to and from work in Foxborough, Mass.\n\nThe sequence of the Brady children singing along to Vance Joy\u2019s \u201cRiptide\u201d while dad drives home from the stadium after a November win over Miami is, to use the artistic term, rather precious.\n\nOne venue where Brady is barely seen: Gillette Stadium, or pretty much anywhere in the Patriots\u2019 facilities. For a player who has been the epitome of the Patriots team-first philosophy, Brady would seem an unlikely candidate to open such a close-up lens upon his off-field self, especially during the season \u2014 and especially for a project set to drop during the playoffs. A player not placing undue attention upon himself would constitute a first principle of Coach Bill Belichick\u2019s colorless \u201cDo Your Job\u201d collectivism. That is one of the many remarkable aspects of \u201cTom vs. Time.\u201d\n\nIt is unclear if Brady has even told his coach about the project. The Patriots spokesman Stacey James said the team was nominally aware that a Brady documentary was in the works, and tried to be helpful in providing credentials on the few occasions Chopra sought access to home games. Beyond that, the answer of how much Brady\u2019s bosses were informed about \u201cTom vs. Time\u201d remains shrouded in some Patriot-esque mystery.\n\nThis takes on some added resonance in light of an ESPN report last week describing deep tensions between Brady and Belichick, the twin pillars of the N.F.L.\u2019s 21st Century dynasty. No doubt \u201cTom vs. Time\u201d could provide more grist for the distraction mill that N.F.L. teams avoid so strenuously, nowhere more so than Bunker Bill, this famously locked-down football enclave between Boston and Providence.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn addition, Belichick is almost completely absent in the series. His offensive coordinator, Josh McDaniels, rather, is portrayed as Brady\u2019s ever-present coaching foil, making cameos via speakerphone (or video chat) as Brady pores through game film and brainstorms ideas for new plays for upcoming games.\n\nChopra, son of the prolific New Age author Deepak Chopra, grew up a Patriots fan in Lincoln, Mass. He spent several years working as a television journalist around the world before settling in Los Angeles, where he met Brady though mutual friends nearly a decade ago.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nChopra had become interested in exploring the spiritual side of sports and competition, the deep connections drawn and emotions elicited around the games we play and watch. He had spoken from time to time with Brady about this, and for years had been trying to get him interested in some kind of film treatment around his obsessive relationship to football.\n\nAfter the odyssey of last season \u2014 with Brady\u2019s Deflategate suspension, his mother\u2019s battle with cancer and the Patriots\u2019 surreal comeback win in the Super Bowl \u2014 Brady finally agreed to participate in a film about his off-season training regimen.\n\n\u201cWe thought it would be fun to record what an off-season of training looks like for a 40-year-old athlete,\u201d said Brady, reached by email Monday night.\n\nThe off-season ended, but Chopra and his camera stuck around into the season. \u201cTom is not a sentimental guy, necessarily,\u201d Chopra said. \u201cBut I do think, as we talked, he was sort of discovering parts of himself. It\u2019s like therapy. It\u2019s the process of saying it and giving voice to it.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nPutting aside any significance the series might hold in the broader Patriots Kremlinology, \u201cTom vs. Time\u201d is pure candy for football geeks, celebrity lifestyle voyeurs and pretty much any N.F.L. enthusiast curious about one of sports\u2019 more enigmatic superstars. In the fifth installment (\u201cThe Spiritual Game\u201d), Brady ruminates on the karmic satisfactions he derives through sports.\n\n\u201cI do want to know the whys in life,\u201d Brady said. \u201cI do want to know why we\u2019re here, where we\u2019re going; trying to find that deeper purpose. To live it, through sports in a very authentic way, makes so much sense to me.\u201d\n\nLater in the fifth episode, Brady and B\u00fcndchen sit for a joint interview in which B\u00fcndchen, a Brazilian model, describes what it\u2019s like to have to share her husband with his \u201cfirst love,\u201d football. \u201cIt really is his main love,\u201d B\u00fcndchen says, going further. \u201cFrankly it\u2019s true.\u201d She mentions that when she and Brady first met, he said he only wanted to play 10 years and would have been happy to win one more Super Bowl. But of course, love dies hard.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s effortless because it\u2019s so synonymous with my being,\u201d Brady says of football. \u201cIn front of 70,000 people, I can be who I am. If I want to scream at somebody I can scream at somebody. I can be who I am in a very authentic way.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nAs Brady says this, it\u2019s impossible not to extend the thought a beat further \u2014 and then he does so himself: \u201cThat is hard for me when I walk off the field.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOne of the more fascinating scenes involves Brady\u2019s staring like a zombie at a computer screen, intense and serene. It is as if he is linked to the game film he is watching.\n\n\u201cI could literally watch football all day,\u201d Brady says. \u201cI could go four or five hours without getting up from this chair.\u201d He begins watching plays from what might be the most difficult loss of his career, the Giants\u2019 victory over the Patriots in the Super Bowl in 2008, New England\u2019s only loss that season.\n\n\u201cYou\u2019re becoming a failure in front of everybody else,\u201d Brady says, using an odd second-person construction while reliving the dormant nightmare in real time. \u201cIt\u2019s a talent show you did when you were a kid. And you\u2019re a failure.\u201d\n\nGiven some of the events of this season \u2014 both around the league and with the Patriots \u2014 the first four and a half installments that were available for viewing by The New York Times contained some big elephants that go unmentioned to this point.\n\nThere is no discussion, for instance, of the player protests around the national anthem that dominated much of the early season. (President Trump, who ignited much of the discord around the protests, took every opportunity during the 2016 campaign to mention his close friendship with Brady.) Nor is there any mention of the midseason trade that sent Brady\u2019s backup and possible heir apparent Jimmy Garoppolo to the 49ers; or, for that matter, of Brady\u2019s polarizing \u201cbody coach,\u201d business partner and best friend, Alex Guerrero, who was reportedly told by Belichick that he was no longer permitted to work at the stadium.\n\n(There is no discussion of this friction surrounding Guerrero, though he appears several times in the film, mostly as we watch him put Brady through the so-called \u201cpliability\u201d treatments that the two men developed as the cornerstone of their sports training and lifestyle business, \u201cTB12\u201d.)\n\nChopra said he most likely would cover some of that material in the final installments, though much of it depends on the Patriots\u2019 playoff trajectory. \u201cThere\u2019s still some ground to cover and a lot of the story left to unfold,\u201d he said.\n\nFacebook said the release date for the series is uncertain; it depends on when the Patriots\u2019 season ends. The team hosts Tennessee in a playoff game this weekend.\n\nAnother N.F.L. quarterback no longer alive in the playoffs steals one scene. Brady is at home being put through some massage by Guerrero when his oldest son, Jack, walks into the room. Jack tells his father about some N.F.L. fantasy or simulation game that he and a friend are engaged in.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cWho\u2019s your quarterback,\u201d Brady asks. His son is decisive and cold with his answer. \u201cCam Newton,\u201d he says.", "title": "Tom Brady Gave a Filmmaker Unusual Access to His Private Life", "authors": ["Mark Leibovich"]} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "It is difficult to age gracefully. Ask anyone approaching 40, or well past it. Most of us get to grapple with that milestone before a limited and understanding audience. Professional athletes, of course, are not granted that luxury, as New England Patriots quarterback Tom Brady is reminding us.\n\nBrady, 40, has won five Super Bowls. He has been the most valuable player in four of them, and recently he was selected to his 13th Pro Bowl. But throughout another dominant N.F.L. season, which continues Saturday night with a divisional round playoff game against the Tennessee Titans, Brady has taken the poet Dylan Thomas to heart and refused to go gentle into that good night.\n\nWith the help of a book, a controversial side business and a new documentary series \u2014 coming soon to a smartphone near you \u2014 his midlife crisis is unfolding before packed stadiums, millions of television viewers and social media followers, and an eager news media horde.\n\nBrady\u2019s book, \u201cThe TB12 Method: How to Achieve a Lifetime of Sustained Peak Performance,\u201d and his lifestyle website, tb12sports.com, purportedly offer inside looks at how Brady has done what he has done \u2014 a blend of so-called \u201cpliability\u201d exercises, nutritional bars, supplements and lots of water. The new documentary series, which will drop later this month via Facebook\u2019s mobile video platform, says right there in its title what it will address: \u201cTom vs. Time.\u201d", "title": "Tom Brady\u2019s Midlife Crisis", "authors": []} {"date": "2017-12-31 00:00:00", "text": "President Trump is vowing to return to two of his favorite goals in 2018: a crackdown on immigration and the dissolution of the Affordable Care Act.\n\nWhen congressional Republicans passed the sweeping tax bill in December, they eliminated the A.C.A.\u2019s health care mandate. But President Trump wants to knock out the entire program.\n\nAs I have learned in the past four years, immigration and health care in America have an organic relationship that may escape the president and his supporters if they experience health care only from the outside looking in.\n\nI\u2019ve been an active pilgrim in our medical culture, as a cancer patient, a kidney stone carrier, a victim of a mysterious vertigo condition and the owner of a battered elbow resulting from a hard fall on a New York City street.", "title": "Opinion | Tom Brokaw: You Can Find the Entire World Inside Your Hospital", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cA lot of people were wondering how that was going to work, and will Tom let Doug be Doug,\u201d said Jeff Lageman, who was one of the first free agents Coughlin signed in Jacksonville, and who is now an analyst for Jaguars Radio. \u201cThat\u2019s the thing that has impressed me most. Tom has stayed in the background and let him Doug do what he needs to do.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nCoughlin\u2019s penchant for precision and discipline are everywhere, including the focus on getting to meetings early and the way uniforms are worn. For a team that has had a reputation as one of the league\u2019s most undisciplined organizations, little things like that matter.\n\nAlthough Coughlin remains intense, he has also softened, particularly when it comes to trying to understand his players.\n\nThis was evident during the most crucial weekend of the 2017 N.F.L. season in late September. The crisis began on a Friday night, when President Donald J. Trump urged owners to fire players who refused to stand for the national anthem. The Jaguars were in London to play their annual game there. Waking up to the news overseas on Saturday, many players were aghast and eager to protest. Because of the time difference, the Jaguars and the Baltimore Ravens were going to be the first teams to play that weekend.\n\nShahid Khan, the Jacksonville owner, and his staff spent Saturday night discussing what to do but reached no conclusion. When they arrived at Wembley Stadium before the game, Khan met with Marrone and Coughlin. Coughlin, a big supporter of the military, might have had his own feelings on the matter, but he knew that whatever was decided, the players had to be on board.\n\n\u201cHe said that you have to understand where these players came from, their upbringing, and if you don\u2019t, the team will fall apart,\u201d Khan said of Coughlin.\n\nCoughlin wanted to go with Marrone to the locker room to meet with the players. But Marrone realized that would be unwieldy, so they invited the captains to speak with them in a small meeting room at the stadium. They ultimately decided that the entire team should lock arms on the sideline, and Khan joined them, a sight that set the tone for the rest of the league.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nCoughlin and Marrone were too busy preparing for the Steelers to be interviewed for this article. But friends describe Coughlin\u2019s return to the city and the team that he built and, in some ways, never left \u2014 as a happy one. He never sold his house in Jacksonville, and continued to run his local charity, the Jay Fund, which helps families of cancer patients. (It is named for the former Boston College safety Jay McGillis, who played for Coughlin there and died of leukemia.)\n\nPhoto\n\nWhen Coughlin left Jacksonville after the 2002 season, supporters said he was a scapegoat, and critics said he had worn out his welcome.\n\nSo it was after the 2015 season with his rocky exit from the Giants, with whom he won two titles but posted losing seasons the last three of his dozen years there. Nearing 70, he was eager to keep coaching, and his name surfaced as a candidate for some jobs. But he ended up spending the 2016 season behind a desk at N.F.L. headquarters working as an adviser, with an eye toward returning to a club.\n\n\u201cIt was more than an itch,\u201d Commissioner Roger Goodell said before the Jaguars\u2019 game against the Bills. \u201cI always knew he wanted to get back and help build a team and help build a championship team.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nBy the end of the 2016 season, Khan knew changes were needed in Jacksonville. During the five full seasons after he bought the team for $760 million in 2011, the Jaguars won just 17 games, three fewer than the lowly Cleveland Browns. He fired Coach Gus Bradley in the final month of the season and wanted to keep Marrone, the interim coach. But Khan felt the team needed what he called \u201ca veteran presence\u201d to guide both the coach and general manager to lift the franchise out of the doldrums.\n\n\u201cIt couldn\u2019t be someone random, but someone who had the passion and had the Jaguars blood that went through their veins,\u201d Khan said. \u201cTom Coughlin was the ideal candidate, and he was available and he was looking for a position.\u201d\n\nCoughlin, he said, wanted to coach, so he took his time considering the offer before taking it. Although one can imagine that Coughlin wanted to prove to the Giants that he could still win, friends of his say that he was not driven by spite.\n\n\u201cHe left the Giants reluctantly; I don\u2019t think that\u2019s a secret,\u201d said Ernie Bono Sr., a close friend who helped Coughlin establish the Jay Fund. \u201cBut he\u2019s not the retiring type. He doesn\u2019t care about showing anyone up. He told me he felt for the Giants when they were losing.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nStill, having a former coach oversee a current coach and general manager can be tricky. If he takes too heavy a hand and creates tension, an insecure coach may feel the boss is trying to undermine him and take over. Some recent examples \u2014 Mike Holmgren in Cleveland and Bill Parcells in Miami \u2014 did not last long.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nKhan was aware of these potential pitfalls, so he asked Coughlin which coaches he would want to work with. Coughlin named two, the first being Marrone. Khan, who did not tell Coughlin beforehand that he intended to keep Marrone, had his man.\n\nCoughlin and Marrone have a long history that centers on Syracuse, where they each played and coached. Nearly 20 years younger than his boss, Marrone sees Coughlin as a mentor, not a threat. He shares his game plans with Coughlin, who attends practices and will pull players aside to deliver instruction.\n\nCommenting on Coughlin after the regular-season finale, Marrone said he had learned more in the past year from his boss than ever, on topics including running a practice, scheduling and dealing with players.\n\n\u201cI talk to him more than I talk to my wife,\u201d he said.\n\n\u201cYou can see his fingerprints all over the team,\u201d said Jay Feely, a former kicker for Coughlin\u2019s Giants and who is now an analyst for CBS Sports. \u201cHe deflects all credit from himself. But if you\u2019re truthful, you\u2019d say he deserves a lot of credit\u201d for turning the team around.\n\nIn Week 5, the Jaguars beat the Steelers, 30-9, in Pittsburgh. They intercepted quarterback Ben Roethlisberger five times, returning two of the picks for touchdowns. The rookie running back Leonard Fournette, a big, physical presence, ran for 181 yards and two scores. Fournette has become an emblem of Jacksonville\u2019s bruising offense, a Coughlin trademark.\n\nThe temperature will be a lot colder this Sunday, something that could favor the home team. But if the Jaguars upset the Steelers, Coughlin will no doubt celebrate, but quietly \u2014 again.\n\nFor at least another weekend, the Jaguars, too.", "title": "Tom Coughlin\u2019s Return Coincides With Jacksonville\u2019s Revival", "authors": ["Ken Belson"]} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nTom Petty, the chart-topping singer and songwriter, died in October from an accidental drug overdose as a result of mixing medications that included opioids, the medical examiner-coroner for the county of Los Angeles announced on Friday, ending the mystery surrounding his sudden death last year.\n\nThe coroner, Jonathan Lucas, said that Mr. Petty\u2019s system showed traces of the drugs fentanyl, oxycodone, temazepam, alprazolam, citalopram, acetyl fentanyl and despropionyl fentanyl.\n\nBarely a week after Mr. Petty, 66, had concluded a tour with his band, the Heartbreakers, with three shows at the Hollywood Bowl, representatives said the singer had suffered cardiac arrest at his home in Malibu, Calif. on Oct. 2. But Mr. Petty\u2019s official death certificate, released about a week later, listed his cause of death as \u201cdeferred\u201d pending an autopsy.\n\nIn a statement posted to Mr. Petty\u2019s Facebook page on Friday, his wife, Dana, and daughter, Adria, wrote that Mr. Petty suffered from \u201cmany serious ailments including emphysema, knee problems and most significantly a fractured hip,\u201d but that he continued to tour, worsening his conditions. \u201cOn the day he died he was informed his hip had graduated to a full on break and it is our feeling that the pain was simply unbearable and was the cause for his over use of medication,\u201d the statement said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThey said: \u201cWe knew before the report was shared with us that he was prescribed various pain medications for a multitude of issues including Fentanyl patches and we feel confident that this was, as the coroner found, an unfortunate accident.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Louder Newsletter Every week, stay on top of the latest in pop and jazz with reviews, interviews, podcasts and more from The New York Times music critics. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cAs a family we recognize this report may spark a further discussion on the opioid crisis and we feel that it is a healthy and necessary discussion and we hope in some way this report can save lives,\u201d Mr. Petty\u2019s family said. \u201cMany people who overdose begin with a legitimate injury or simply do not understand the potency and deadly nature of these medications.\u201d", "title": "Tom Petty Died From Accidental Drug Overdose Involving Opioids, Coroner Says", "authors": ["Joe Coscarelli"]} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "All these years later, she\u2019s still punished for what she did, but also for what she didn\u2019t do. People still think she herself held a baton over Ms. Kerrigan\u2019s leg that day. People still think she was married to Mr. Gillooly (who has since changed his last name to Stone), who planned the attack and was sentenced to two years in prison for racketeering, but they were divorced by then.\n\nAt the very least, people still think she herself hired the guy who attacked Ms. Kerrigan, Shane Stant, and they have never forgiven her for it. \u201cI\u2019ve had rats thrown into my mailboxes, [expletive] left on my door, left in my mailbox, all over my trucks. You name it, it\u2019s been done to me.\u201d Sometimes she pulls up to a traffic light and a man in the next car will make oral sex gestures at her.\n\nSo yes, she said. Please call her Tonya Harding. It was Tonya Harding who was the punch line to just about every late-night monologue joke in 1994. Tonya Harding was the name Barack Obama used as a verb in talking about metaphorically kneecapping the competition during the 2007 presidential primaries. \u201cTonya Harding\u201d is the title of a new and quite lovely Sufjan Stevens song (\u201cThis world is a bitch, girl,\u201d it goes. \u201cDon\u2019t end up in a ditch, girl.\u201d) And Tonya Harding is the name invoked in a pile of recent feminist think pieces coinciding with the opening of the movie \u201cI, Tonya,\u201d in which she is played by the famous, beautiful actress Margot Robbie, explaining her side of the story.\n\nMaybe I could just call her Tonya in the story, I said. Just to avoid confusion. She put her hands on mine. Her nails are unicorn purple with glitter particles that she swears are not fake (which, I don\u2019t know) and they are unchipped the way they need to be when you are chopping wood one day and promoting a movie the next. \u201cYou have to say Tonya Harding,\u201d she said. Tonya Price hasn\u2019t done anything wrong. She is a relatively recent invention with nothing on her rap sheet. It\u2019s Tonya Harding who has a few things she would like to clear up.\n\nFOR AS MANY people who are mean or crude when they realize who she is, there are just as many who love her. We had met earlier in the day at an ice rink in Vancouver that shares a building with a megachurch. When she entered, the 10 or so teenage wonders who had been jumping and spinning during serious-skater-only hours rushed off the ice to envelop her with hugs. \u201cShe\u2019s such a good influence on the girls,\u201d one of their mothers told me.\n\nMs. Harding was trailed by her BFF, Erica Manary, an E.R. nurse she met because their husbands are friends; they got married within a week of each other and then had sons within a year of each other and that just sealed it. Ms. Manary liked her instantly when they met in 2010, and made a conscious decision not to Google her. \u201cI didn\u2019t want to refresh myself,\u201d she said. \u201cI wanted to learn from her perspective.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMs. Harding swiped on her lipstick perfectly without a mirror: one coat of Wet n Wild 523B (Light Berry Frost) covered by a layer of Wet n Wild 530D (Dark Pink Frost). She laced up her tiny Harlick skate boots that she had painted pantyhose beige, which were attached to gold-plated MK Vantage blades, and put stirrups over her leggings and beneath the blades so that her lines would look longer and she would look taller. (She\u2019s barely 5-foot-1.) She took a puff from her asthma inhaler, straightened her ponytail in its pink scrunchie, aligned her bangs, and stood up. The song \u201cLow\u201d came on and she said, \u201cI love this song!\u201d and hopped out onto the ice while Ms. Manary shimmied her shoulders to the music from behind the plexiglass.\n\nWhen Ms. Harding got out there with her first jump, the girls who had been practicing all morning now looked like total amateurs by comparison. At 47, she still holds so much power in those thighs and so much grace in her hands and posture. People said that her sin \u2014 before her other sins \u2014 was not being the Disney princess Barbie doll that the Figure Skating Association demanded of its skaters. \u201cI hated the word \u2018feminine,\u2019\u201d she said. \u201cIt reminded me of a tampon or a panty liner.\u201d Has anyone ever interrogated the notion of why the highest achievement in the female-centered sport of figure skating is exertion without expression of exertion? Has anyone ever said screw it all and flipped on the Tone L\u014dc and just gone for it like she did? Has anyone ever made skating look so fun?\n\nPhoto\n\nMs. Harding skates sometimes, but not as much as she used to. What would be the point? Her ban by the U.S.F.S.A. as a skater and a coach should leave her open to professional skating \u2014 say like in an exhibition or the Ice Capades \u2014 but \u201cbecause everything is owned by the association,\u201d she said, there are very few corners of it in which she can still meaningfully participate. Say she taught young skaters for $50 an hour at the rink, she wouldn\u2019t be allowed to bring them to competition, so, again, what\u2019s the point?\n\nWhen she got the call from Mr. Rogers, she\u2019d been doing fine. She could take care of herself. She had other skills. She\u2019d worked as a welder, a painter at a metal fabrication company, a hardware sales clerk at Sears, where every day some guy would ask if there was a man who could help him, and every day she\u2019d school that guy on how much more she knows about tools than just about anyone. She faced Paula Jones in a celebrity boxing bout in 2002, and started an unremarkable boxing career in earnest in 2003. But she wasn\u2019t a great fighter, and she didn\u2019t like it very much, either. She never bought the idea that hitting something could help you work out aggression. They told her, \u201cPretend it\u2019s someone else\u2019s face.\u201d But it wasn\u2019t, so what\u2019s the point?\n\nShe married and had her boy, who changed her life by refocusing her attention on someone who wasn\u2019t her. She and her husband would spend hours hunting together, just as she used to do with her beloved father \u2014 Mr. Price with a muzzleloader and Ms. Harding with a bow and arrow because she wanted \u201cto give the animal a 50-50 chance to make it interesting and fair\u201d (and also because felons aren\u2019t technically supposed to possess guns in Washington State). Do you know how good of an archer she is? She says she has successfully done no fewer than eight Robin Hoods \u2014 shooting an arrow that splits another arrow, which itself was already in a bull\u2019s-eye, 30 yards away \u2014 and that\u2019s nothing compared to her fishing skills. (But she doesn\u2019t want to elaborate. \u201cSome people,\u201d she said. \u201cIf you eat a carrot you\u2019re killing it.\u201d) Also, she can build anything. She can fix anything. She had a life. It was going fine. She had made some kind of peace with the idea that she\u2019d never really be understood.\n\n\u201cI, TONYA,\u201d which is based on hours of interviews with Ms. Harding and her ex-husband, honors its feisty subject by showing not just the abuse she endured, but how she fought back. It gives added context to the scandal for which she is now principally known. It even posits new information: The paper that the F.B.I. found in a Dumpster that showed Ms. Kerrigan\u2019s practice location and schedule in Ms. Harding\u2019s handwriting supposedly existed in order to help her co-conspirators locate where to send threatening letters. (Ms. Harding has maintained that she did not help plan the physical attack on Ms. Kerrigan; no word on why you\u2019d need practice times in order to send letters.)\n\nVideo\n\nThe story is told in the tone in which Ms. Harding speaks, and there are scenes in it you\u2019ve seen a hundred times before in Lifetime movies: a young girl being hit by her mother, a young wife being hit by her husband \u2014 that aren\u2019t portrayed as tragic as much as a particular kind of wide-eyed Oregon gothic. The film has been generally well-received and on Sunday Allison Janney won a Golden Globe for her portrayal of Ms. Harding\u2019s mother. But there have also been reviews (including in this paper) that wonder if the protagonist is a punching bag for cheap laughs and classism.\n\nPhoto\n\nFor the record, Ms. Harding loved the movie. \u201cMagnificent,\u201d was her word, especially after she\u2019d seen it a few times. You have to remember, that was her life. That those beatings were very specifically hers, not composite beatings. And that they weren\u2019t even shown in full: \u201cPeople don\u2019t understand that what you guys see in the movie is nothing,\u201d she said. \u201cThat was the smallest little bits and pieces. I mean, my face was bruised. My face was put through a mirror, not just broken onto it. Through it. I was shot. That was true.\u201d Mr. Gillooly, er, Stone shot at the ground, she said, and it ricocheted onto her face. (He has denied this and other abuse.) She said her mother threw a knife at her. (Her mother has also denied allegations made by Ms. Harding.) But \u201cthat\u2019s all true,\u201d she said. The people charged with taking care of her didn\u2019t.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSo she watched it a few times, and the shock wore off, and there from the comfort of her living room, sitting beside the only romantic partner she has ever felt loved by and safe with, she watched what had happened in her life and realized that she never really stood a chance.\n\nWhich is not to say that the movie is totally accurate. As I said, there are some things she would like to clear up. Such as:\n\nFirst, because of the way it\u2019s edited, it makes it look as though she hunted for rabbits and that is how she got her fur coat. Not true. She bought that coat. She loves fur coats and has two now, one of them a mink that she would like to wear to the premieres but the last thing she needs is those carrot-rights people telling her she\u2019s a monster for wearing mink.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nSecond, the movie made it seem as if she has a dirty mouth. She wants you to know she does not. \u201cTrust me I don\u2019t say the word [expletive] 120 times a day. That might come out once in a while when something really bad happens or I hurt myself. I mean, the movie portrayed me as this person who cussed every 10 seconds and I don\u2019t cuss like that.\u201d There\u2019s a scene in the movie in which she confronts a table of judges about her low scores despite a stellar performance. In it, she gets frustrated and gives them an obscene directive involving male anatomy. Never happened, she said. \u201cI would never say that.\u201d\n\n\u201cI did not go to the judges on the ice and talk to them like that in front of everyone. When I spoke to the judges they were in the back hallway room telling me you need to have better dresses. I go, \u2018Well if you can find me $5,000 to make me a dress then I\u2019ll wear it and I won\u2019t have to sew these anymore.\u2019 I go, \u2018You know what? Out of my face!\u2019\u201d\n\nThat\u2019s it? I asked. That\u2019s it, she confirmed. Those are her only objections. Which was confusing, because the movie doesn\u2019t vindicate her by a long shot. It presents both sides of the story, both her and her ex-husband\u2019s, and neither comes across looking particularly innocent. Nothing else you want to clear up? I asked.\n\nOn a couch at 38 Below, she leaned back, frustrated, made her hands into fists and rubbed her eyes. It\u2019s exhausting. Nobody ever gets it. She\u2019s been waiting for a way to tell the world that the abuse she endured was so much worse than they thought, that she was so much poorer than people could imagine. And then all people want to know is whether or not there\u2019s something she\u2019s not admitting to.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe reason she loves the movie is because it conveys something she doesn\u2019t feel was ever conveyed before. There were mitigating circumstances. Her life was terrible. She was beaten. She was threatened. You don\u2019t get this way unless you were counted out completely. Her own mother didn\u2019t seem to love her. The only time in her life she ever got anywhere was when she circumvented the rules and took for herself what appeared to be given to the Nancy Kerrigans of the world. Ms. Kerrigan was from a working-class family too, but she was loved. Her parents drove her to practices and cheered for her and cried with joy. She had Vera Wang skating outfits! Tonya had nothing. She had costumes that her mother made with sequins everywhere so that her thighs got cut up; then she had to make them herself, earning point deductions for the quality. She danced to ZZ Top while the others were dancing to Mozart. They had trainers and dietitians and Tonya was eating broccoli and cheese from the Spud City where she worked at the mall. She had asthma. She had muscles.\n\n\u201cI was always told I was fat. I was ugly. I wouldn\u2019t amount to anything. \u2018If you don\u2019t smile and follow through they\u2019re not going to give you the marks. If you wear that ribbon they\u2019re not going to give you the marks. If you wear that dress they\u2019re not going to give you the marks.\u2019\u201d\n\nThis has nothing to do with exoneration; it hasn\u2019t for a long time. Her side of the story is not about guilt or innocence \u2014 the discussion over guilt and innocence ended right about the time she completed her community service, as far as she\u2019s concerned \u2014 but about the finer points of being Tonya Harding: respect, mitigating circumstances, how we treat people and what we expect from them in the first place.", "title": "Tonya Harding Would Like Her Apology Now", "authors": ["Taffy Brodesser-Akner"]} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "BERLIN \u2014 One of the most striking images in the new retrospective of Torbjorn Rodland\u2019s photographs currently on display at C/O Berlin greets visitors as they enter the exhibition. It is a picture of a young woman, lit from the side by a powerful red light, with honey streaming down her cheeks onto her chin. Like many of Mr. Rodland\u2019s works, the image \u2014 titled \u201cGoldene Tr\u00e4nen,\u201d or \u201cGolden Tears\u201d \u2014 looks like the kind of high-gloss photograph that might appear on a billboard or in a magazine advertisement, but it is unsettling in a way that can be hard to pin down.\n\nSitting on a windowsill in the gallery, Mr. Rodland explained that the photograph was meant to arouse a variety of reactions depending on a viewer\u2019s cultural interests. An art historian, he said, might see it as a reference to the weeping Virgin Mary, while a 22-year-old consumer of online pornography would see something more obscene. \u201cIf there\u2019s only one possible reading of a photograph, then I\u2019m less interested,\u201d Mr. Rodland added. \u201cThe photographs are reading you if you\u2019re reading them.\u201d\n\nLast year was a banner year for Mr. Rodland, who is 47 and spent the early part of his life in Stavanger, a city on the southwestern coast of Norway, but now mostly makes his home in Los Angeles. In the fall, the Serpentine Galleries in London hosted a retrospective of his work and, with the C/O Berlin exhibition, he has his first institutional show in Germany. \u201cHe is currently a shooting star,\u201d said Ann-Christin Bertrand, the curator of the C/O show. \u201cHe is a mirror for how we interact with photography today.\u201d", "title": "Torbjorn Rodland\u2019s Puzzling Photos Are Unsettling and Arousing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-29 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nA Toronto landscaper killed at least five men and hid some of their remains in planters where he worked, the police said on Monday.\n\nThe suspect, Bruce McArthur, 66, who was arrested on Jan. 18 and charged in two killings then, was charged on Monday with three additional murders.\n\nBecause of the access his job afforded him, Mr. McArthur may have hidden additional remains in numerous locations, Sgt. Hank Idsinga, a homicide detective with the Toronto Police Service, said at a news conference. He added that additional victims were expected to be found.\n\n\u201cWe do believe there are more,\u201d he said.\n\nSeveral of the victims and Mr. McArthur himself had ties to the Gay Village, a predominantly gay neighborhood, according to the authorities.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe police have identified and started searching about 30 properties where Mr. McArthur worked, Sergeant Idsinga said. Investigators have collected more than a dozen planters to examine.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Get the Morning Briefing by Email What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox Monday through Friday.
