View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019ve never seen anything quite like this, with the number of crime scenes that we have to process,\u201d he said.", "title": "Toronto Landscaper Killed at Least 5 Men, Police Say", "authors": ["Niraj Chokshi"]} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "When he arrived in Toronto, Rasoul imagined it would take him 30 years to open his own business. But the bakery has become so successful that the brothers are already planning to expand.\n\nCanada\u2019s warm welcome to Syrian refugees was a hallmark of Justin Trudeau\u2019s election as prime minister in late 2015, and for many, it remains a potent symbol of Toronto\u2019s multicultural identity. (The city\u2019s motto is \u201cDiversity Our Strength.\u201d) Syrian food businesses drew an overwhelming degree of media attention, and a customer base that extended well beyond people with Middle Eastern backgrounds.\n\n\u201cIt was almost too much media,\u201d said Amir Fattal, 27, who arrived from Aleppo in 2016 and set up a supper club, catering company and part-time street food stall called Beroea Kitchen with his wife, Nour Amammana.\n\nThe response has been overwhelming. The couple have been invited to cater events at City Hall, the University of Toronto and the local offices of Uber. But while Mr. Fattal feels great pride in sharing the story of Aleppo\u2019s grand culinary tradition, he questions whether some Canadians are fetishizing Syrian refugees.\n\n\u201cThere are other people who are refugees,\u201d he said, \u201cand they need opportunities, too.\u201d\n\nNo Syrian food businesses has felt the spotlight more acutely than Newcomer Kitchen, a nonprofit group of women who come together each Wednesday to cook a traditional Syrian meal in a small cafe and food business incubator called the Depanneur.\n\nNewcomer Kitchen began in March 2016 as a way of giving newly arrived Syrian refugees who were temporarily living in airport hotels a chance to cook a meal. But it has grown into a collective of 60 cooks, who rotate in groups of eight to make 50 three-course takeout dinners each week, for $20 apiece.", "title": "Toronto Suddenly Has a New Craving: Syrian Food", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-03 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nPainting a vivid picture of bullying and sexual degradation at Toronto\u2019s largest nonprofit theater, four actresses have sued Soulpepper Theater Company and its longtime artistic director, Albert Schultz, accusing him of sexual harassment and assault and the company of allowing his behavior.\n\nIn separate claims, each of which calls Mr. Schultz \u201ca serial sexual predator\u201d and \u201cthe controlling mind of Soulpepper,\u201d the women are seeking combined damages of more than $6.2 million.\n\nThe company\u2019s board of directors has instructed Mr. Schultz, 54, to step down temporarily while it investigates the allegations, Soulpepper said in a statement Wednesday. Mr. Schultz\u2019s wife, Leslie Lester, the company\u2019s executive director, is taking a voluntary leave of absence until the investigation is complete.\n\nContaining section headings like \u201cAlbert Creates a Culture of Fear\u201d and \u201cAlbert Proposes a Stripping Game at His House,\u201d the legal documents outline instances between 2000 and 2013 in which Mr. Schultz, a co-founder of Soulpepper, is accused of touching, ogling or exposing himself to the actresses against their will.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe lawsuits also charge that he belittled the actresses or pressured them to engage in uncomfortably sexual conversations. The plaintiffs in the cases are Kristin Booth, Diana Bentley, Patricia Fagan and Hannah Miller.", "title": "Toronto Theater Company Leader Steps Aside Amid Harassment Suits", "authors": ["Laura Collins-Hughes"]} {"date": "2018-01-04 00:00:00", "text": "TORONTO \u2014 You could call it Canada\u2019s Weinstein moment, take two.\n\nOne of the country\u2019s most powerful theater directors, Albert Schultz, on Thursday resigned from his post as leader of the Soulpepper Theater Company after four actresses said this week that they had been sexually harassed, groped, touched and repeatedly propositioned by him over 13 years.\n\nThey filed a lawsuit against him and the company, a nonprofit he co-founded, for a combined $6.2 million, or $7.85 million Canadian dollars.\n\nMr. Schultz said he planned to \u201cvigorously defend myself against the allegations that are being made.\u201d\n\nBefore he announced his resignation, the actresses spoke at a news conference in the Toronto offices of one of their lawyers. They said they had felt emboldened to come forward now, in part, because of what they said was a culture shift that began in Hollywood, with actresses openly talking about the behavior of the producer Harvey Weinstein.", "title": "Toronto Theater Director Resigns Amid Sexual Misconduct Accusations", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-07 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nHere in the valley of my mid-50s, I try not to get into a swivet over my occasionally faulty memory: Sometimes the mind has a mind of its own. But when I read this chilling passage \u2014 \u201cI am dementing. I am dementing. I am dementing.\u201d \u2014 from Gerda Saunders\u2019s recent memoir \u201cMemory\u2019s Last Breath: Field Notes on My Dementia,\u201d I found myself starting to panic.\n\nIn a world increasingly dominated by the Google/Apple/Facebook/Amazon hegemony, we hear a lot about the threat to privacy. But isn\u2019t memory just as vulnerable? Now that, as the former New Republic editor Franklin Foer writes in \u201cWorld Without Mind: The Existential Threat of Big Tech,\u201d \u201cour phone is an extension of our memory; we\u2019ve outsourced basic functions to algorithms,\u201d doesn\u2019t the world seem like an ever-larger parking lot that has mysteriously swallowed our Toyota? Don\u2019t we all wish, now more than ever, that acquaintances came equipped with their own \u201cPreviously on this series \u2026\u201d trailer?\n\nMr. Foer and Ms. Saunders aren\u2019t the only writers on this beat. Recent books by Robert Sapolsky, Michael Lemonick, Felicia Yap, Emily Barr, Dale Bredesen, Val Emmich, Oliver Sacks and Elizabeth Rosner, among others, have addressed the theme of non-historical memory. Last July alone, more than a dozen books specifically about the topic, most of them self-published, were released.\n\nYou\u2019d expect the themes of amnesia or powers of recall to be prevalent in thrillers or in memoirs by trauma survivors or over-beveraged rock stars, but even literary fiction is getting in on the act. In Rachel Khong\u2019s sly, diaristic \u201cGoodbye, Vitamin,\u201d a 30-year-old who moves back home learns she has to care for a dementing father who has started leaving his pants in trees. In Alissa Nutting\u2019s outrageous sex comedy \u201cMade for Love,\u201d a woman on the lam from her tech pioneer husband discovers that he has implanted a chip in her brain that allows him to download all her experiences.\n\nPhoto\n\nPhoto\n\nA majority of the recent or upcoming books about the topic, though, are nonfiction works that take a prescriptive approach to memory loss. I recently spent a month trying to follow the dictates of two of them, both written by doctors: Daniel G. Amen\u2019s \u201cMemory Rescue: Supercharge Your Brain, Reverse Memory Loss and Remember What Matters Most\u201d and Andrew E. Budson and Maureen K. O\u2019Connor\u2019s \u201cSeven Steps to Managing Your Memory: What\u2019s Normal, What\u2019s Not, and What to Do About It.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe first thing I noticed about these two workbook-type tomes is, because they\u2019re not intended to be read straight through, they repeat information so frequently as to render a reader frantic about his mental health. I kept wanting to ask Dr. Amen, a physician with his own chain of clinics: Didn\u2019t you pimp turmeric 10 pages ago? Before reading the books, I\u2019d taken eight memory tests that I\u2019d found on various websites, to get a baseline of my powers of recall. Consolingly, I\u2019d tested slightly above average for my age. But once turmeric started to ominously reappear, I felt like Jennifer Lawrence in \u201cMother.\u201d", "title": "Total Recall: A Reader\u2019s Guide to Memory Gain", "authors": ["Henry Alford"]} {"date": "2018-01-08 00:00:00", "text": "The popular electronic toymaker VTech Electronics agreed to pay $650,000 to settle charges that it had collected digital data on children without parents\u2019 permission and failed to keep that information secure from hackers, the Federal Trade Commission said Monday.\n\nIt was the first enforcement action against a company that makes internet-connected toys by the F.T.C., which has received several complaints about privacy violations and online advertising aimed at children. Some child advocates have complained that the agency has been slow to respond to the complaints, which cover a variety of products including toys and apps for smartphones and tablets.\n\nThe F.T.C. said that the action against VTech, a Hong Kong-based maker of online apps and toys, showed the agency\u2019s dedication to child safety and privacy issues \u2014 particularly given the fast growth of the connected toy market.\n\n\u201cAs connected toys become increasingly popular, it\u2019s more important than ever that companies let parents know how their kids\u2019 data is collected and used and that they take reasonable steps to secure that data,\u201d said Maureen K. Ohlhausen, the commission\u2019s acting chairwoman. \u201cUnfortunately, VTech fell short in both of these areas.\u201d", "title": "Toymaker VTech Settles Charges of Violating Child Privacy Law", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-09 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nToyota Motor and Mazda Motor are expected to announce on Wednesday that they have chosen a location in northern Alabama, near Huntsville, for the $1.6 billion car plant the Japanese automakers are planning to build together, according to a person familiar with the companies\u2019 plans.\n\nDetails of the assembly plant, which is expected to employ about 4,000 people and open by 2021, will be disclosed at a news conference with state and local officials in Montgomery, this person said.\n\nA Toyota spokeswoman, Amanda Roark, declined to comment.\n\nToyota already operates four auto assembly plants in the United States, in Kentucky, Indiana, Mississippi and Texas. It also has two in Ontario and a small truck plant in Mexico. Mazda has a single North American plant in Salamanca, Mexico.\n\nThe location of the plant was first reported by Reuters.\n\nThe new Alabama plant, when completed, is expected to assemble a new version of the Toyota Corolla compact car. Mazda has not yet said which automobile the joint plant will produce. The factory, which will have the capacity to make up to 300,000 cars a year, is part of an initiative by Toyota to invest $10 billion in the United States over the next five years.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhen the companies revealed in August that they would cooperate on a new plant in the United States, the news was hailed by President Trump, who has called on auto manufacturers to produce more vehicles here in hopes of creating jobs. The president also criticized Ford Motor, General Motor and others for building or expanding factories in Mexico.\n\nToyota and Mazda are moving forward with the plant at a time when new-vehicle sales in the United States have started to decline. Total sales fell 1.8 percent in 2017, to 17.2 million, ending a seven-year run of growth. Analysts forecast further declines in 2018 and 2019.", "title": "Toyota and Mazda Are Said to Pick Alabama for $1.6 Billion Plant", "authors": ["Neal E. Boudette"]} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cDemand has leveled off, so now it\u2019s a battle over market share,\u201d said Ron Harbour, an auto manufacturing expert at Oliver Wyman, a consulting firm. \u201cAnd somebody\u2019s going to lose.\u201d\n\nBob Carter, executive vice president for vehicle sales for Toyota Motor North America, shrugged off any concerns about the new plant\u2019s prospects. \u201cA plant is a 50-year investment,\u201d he said. \u201cYou can\u2019t make plant-investment decisions based on the business cycle.\u201d\n\nThe plant will make a redesigned version of the Corolla compact, one of Toyota\u2019s top-selling models. The car is also made 140 miles away in Blue Springs, Miss. Mr. Carter said the proximity of the two Corolla plants could allow them to share many suppliers.\n\nStill, fewer and fewer consumers are shopping for cars like the Corolla. Toyota sold more than 308,000 Corollas in the United States last year, but that was 14 percent fewer than the year before.\n\nMark Wakefield, global co-head of automotive and industrial at AlixPartners, another consulting firm, sees a modest decline in vehicle sales this year and a steeper drop in 2019 and 2020. The main factors, he said, will be higher interest rates and an increasing supply of affordable used cars that were leased in the last few years. Other forecasters said the aging of baby boomers, and the emergence of a younger generation less keen on owning cars, would also dampen demand.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s risk there,\u201d Mr. Wakefield said. \u201cToo much production can cause an imbalance in the market.\u201d\n\nThe Toyota-Mazda plant will be about 14 miles from an existing Toyota engine plant. The new site encompasses 2,500 acres, enough to have suppliers of major components like seats or dashboards set up adjacent plants.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Carter said no decision had been made on such an arrangement.\n\nThe plant will be Toyota\u2019s fifth vehicle factory in the United States, joining assembly factories in Indiana, Kentucky, Mississippi and Texas, along with six component plants.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe Corolla is also made in Cambridge, Ontario. That plant will eventually stop making the Corolla and focus on the other model it assembles, the RAV4, a small sport-utility vehicle that is now Toyota\u2019s best-selling vehicle. The company sold more than 407,000 RAV4s in the United States last year for the first time, passing the Camry, long Toyota\u2019s sales champion in the American market.\n\nMazda has not yet disclosed what car it will make at the Huntsville plant.\n\nAlabama is already the home of major auto plants owned by Daimler\u2019s Mercedes-Benz division, Honda Motor and Hyundai Motor.\n\nAuto plants are considered highly desirable employers because they tend to have a significant impact on local employment. In addition to hiring by suppliers that provide parts for cars, auto plants stimulate home building, spending in restaurants and stores, and the creation of companies to provide services ranging from office cleaning to technology support.\n\n\u201cIf you have a plant with a work force of 3,000, you need a lot of other businesses that support the plant, not just parts suppliers,\u201d Mr. Harbour said. \u201cCar plants have a significant impact on the regional economy. That\u2019s why states want to get them.\u201d\n\nWhen Volkswagen decided to add 2,000 jobs at its plant in Chattanooga, Tenn., in 2015, a University of Tennessee study found the expansion created 9,800 other jobs in the region.\n\nThe new Alabama plant is part of an initiative by Toyota to invest $10 billion in the United States over the next five years. In announcing the cooperation between Toyota and Mazda in August, Toyota said it was also taking a 5 percent stake in its new partner.\n\nThe companies\u2019 plan was hailed by President Trump, who has called on auto manufacturers to produce more vehicles in the United States in hopes of creating jobs. In often-caustic Twitter messages, the president also criticized Ford Motor, General Motors and other automakers for building or expanding factories in Mexico, and threatened to tax any vehicles imported from south of the border.\n\nFacing pressure from Mr. Trump, Ford canceled a planned Mexican car factory and diverted some of the planned investment to Michigan. He also took aim at Toyota for deciding to build a new truck plant in Mexico.\n\nToyota is moving forward with its Mexico plant, but it has reduced its investment there and halved the number of vehicles it will eventually produce to 100,000 a year.", "title": "Toyota and Mazda Choose Alabama for $1.6 Billion Car Plant", "authors": ["Neal E. Boudette"]} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "The company\u2019s owners \u2014 the private equity firms Bain Capital and Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and the real estate investor Vornado \u2014 bought the company in 2005 in a leveraged buyout.\n\nToys \u201cR\u201d Us has followed a familiar playbook of private equity-owned retailers: loading up on debt, now totaling about $5 billion, and then seeking to discharge its obligations and shutter stores through bankruptcy. During the bankruptcy, an army of bankers, lawyers and consultants is being paid large fees to steer the company to solvency.\n\nThe company\u2019s lawyers, for instance, told a bankruptcy court that they were charging as much as $1,745 an hour for their work on the case.\n\nLate last year, the United States trustee overseeing the case in federal court in Richmond, Va., objected to a proposal to pay its 17 most senior executives up to $32 million in bonuses if the company hit certain financial targets. The proposed bonuses, the trustee said, came on top of the $8.2 million in retention bonuses that five of those executives received immediately before the bankruptcy filing.\n\n\u201cApparently, this Christmas, Toys \u2018R\u2019 Us intends to deliver not only \u2018children their biggest smiles of the year\u2019 but the insiders, too,\u201d the trustee, Judy Robbins, said in the filing in late November.\n\nIn the court filing on Tuesday, Toys \u201cR\u201d Us sought the judge\u2019s permission to hire a new group of consultants to run the liquidation of the closing stores.\n\nThe company said it anticipated laying off such a large number of workers in such a short period that its payroll department might not be able to comply with certain state laws requiring that laid-off workers be paid immediately after their last day.\n\nToys \u201cR\u201d Us also said it would seek to pay bonuses of up to $3.6 million to employees who work at the stores that are closing and help them meet their liquidation targets.", "title": "Toys \u2018R\u2019 Us to Close 182 Stores as Part of Restructuring", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-15 00:00:00", "text": "The Pittsburgh Pirates chose Andrew McCutchen in the first round of the draft in 2005, when they were deep into a two-decade stretch of losing. McCutchen was in high school then, and as he nurtured his talent in the Pirates\u2019 farm system, the franchise slowly stirred to life. In 2013, when the Pirates returned to the playoffs for the first of three consecutive trips, McCutchen was the National League\u2019s Most Valuable Player. His contract bound him to Pittsburgh for years to come.\n\nNow he is on his way out, as the latest Pirates mainstay to be traded this month. Two days after shipping starter Gerrit Cole to the Houston Astros, the Pirates traded McCutchen to the San Francisco Giants on Monday for reliever Kyle Crick, the outfield prospect Bryan Reynolds and $500,000 in international bonus-pool money.\n\nEarly Monday evening, McCutchen said goodbye to Pittsburgh with a message on Twitter: \u201cPittsburgh. With Love and respect, Cutch.\u201d\n\nOn Tuesday, McCutchen talked about the mixed emotions of being traded.\n\n\u201cThere are a lot of emotions that of course come along with this,\u201d he told reporters at his introductory news conference with the Giants. \u201cI was there for nine seasons. It also gives the Wasp wings and blasters that Ant-Man never received.\n\nPerhaps that\u2019s because the creator of both mini-heroes is Hope\u2019s father, the scientist Hank Pym (Michael Douglas, reprising his role from the first movie). There\u2019s no sign in the trailer of Hope\u2019s mother and the original Wasp, Janet van Dyne (played by onetime Catwoman Michelle Pfeiffer), but we do get a brief glimpse of Laurence Fishburne as Pym\u2019s former assistant, Bill Foster, who becomes the superhero Black Goliath and later Giant-Man in the comic books.\n\nThe sequel looks just as irreverent as its predecessor, with a motorcycle-riding villain taken out by a gigantic Hello Kitty Pez dispenser.", "title": "Trailer: \u2018Ant-Man and the Wasp,\u2019 With Paul Rudd and Evangeline Lilly", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-31 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Ryan spoke by phone with President Trump to update him after the crash, White House officials said.\n\nThe crash was a jarring start to an annual tradition that is intended to let lawmakers escape the noise of the Capitol for a few days to socialize and set priorities for the coming year. This year\u2019s retreat is scheduled to include remarks by Mr. Trump, Vice President Mike Pence and other members of the cabinet.\n\nInstead, lawmakers still tired from attending Tuesday night\u2019s State of the Union address found themselves staring out the window at a violent crash scene, wondering whether anyone had been hurt as what appeared to be a large, white garbage truck lay mangled on its side. The trailer of the truck was separated from its cab during the collision and garbage was strewn in all directions around the vehicle.\n\n\u201cIt was a pretty shocking event,\u201d said Representative Tom Cole of Oklahoma, who was seated in the last car of the train and had a clear view through the window. Mr. Cole was standing in the aisle at the time of impact and managed to stay on his feet, but others were knocked to the floor.\n\nSenator Bill Cassidy, a first-term Republican from Louisiana, said he was sleeping when a loud noise and jarring motion awoke him. He saw fellow lawmakers and staff members knocked over in the train\u2019s center aisle.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m a physician and when you are a physician you are aware that at any moment bad things can happen,\u201d Mr. Cassidy said in an interview later.\n\nA group including Mr. Cassidy, Senator Jeff Flake of Arizona and a handful of former doctors, including Representatives Brad Wenstrup of Ohio, Michael C. Burgess of Texas, Phil Roe of Tennessee, Larry Buschon of Indiana and Roger Marshall of Kansas all raced backward through the train to find an exit. Mr. Cassidy\u2019s wife, a retired doctor, as well as a House doctor soon joined them. So did Mr. Buschon\u2019s wife, Kathryn, an anesthesiologist; she tried unsuccessfully to intubate one of the victims.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Cole watched them stream through his car one by one and argue with Amtrak personnel to let them disembark.\n\n\u201cThey were demanding, \u2018Get me off this train,\u2019\u201d he said in an interview. \u201cWe weren\u2019t going to stop them.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cYou think of them as members of Congress, but they\u2019re trained physicians,\u201d he added. \u201cThey really wanted off this train.\u201d\n\nAt the crash site, Mr. Cassidy said, it was quickly clear that one of the three men who had been riding in the truck was already dead. From inside, Mr. Cole could see a tarp pulled over the man. Another was on his feet, hurt but not seriously.\n\nMr. Cassidy said he and the others focused on a third man in serious condition. They lifted his legs to try to get blood to his head and heart. Another performed CPR. Eventually paramedics arrived to take the man to the hospital.\n\n\u201cWe worked on him for about 20 minutes, and then put him on a stretcher and carried him to the ambulance,\u201d Mr. Flake said.\n\nAuthorities did not immediately identity the truck\u2019s passengers. The mangled truck indicated that it belonged to Time Disposal, a waste and recycling collection service that operates in the area.\n\nFor lawmakers like Mr. Flake, the episode brought back memories of another still-fresh tragedy: when a lone gunman opened fire on members of the congressional baseball team last June, gravely wounding Representative Steve Scalise of Louisiana, members of the Capitol Police and a lobbyist.\n\n\u201cIt was all too reminiscent of the baseball shooting,\u201d Mr. Flake said. \u201cSimilar type of feeling.\u201d\n\nBy the time the train was moving again, Mr. Cassidy said, the mood was somber.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t think anybody\u2019s gathered their thoughts as to what to do next,\u201d he said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn a statement after the crash, the group putting on the conference said the retreat would proceed mostly as planned. The retreat would now include a moment of prayer for the victims, as well as a security briefing from the House sergeant-at-arms and the Capitol Police.", "title": "Train Carrying Republican Lawmakers to Retreat Crashes Into Truck", "authors": ["Nicholas Fandos", "Emily Cochrane", "Jonah Engel Bromwich"]} {"date": "2018-01-04 00:00:00", "text": "MOSCOW \u2014 Presidential elections are normally a major affair. The competition may be more or less open, the candidates more or less exciting, the outcome more or less uncertain, but electing a head of state usually captures a nation\u2019s attention. These days in Moscow, though, with glitzy \u201c2018\u201d signs illuminating the city center, you would be forgiven for thinking that the soccer World Cup, hosted by Russia, is the event to watch this year.\n\nVladimir V. Putin is so used to presidential elections that he almost forgot to announce his candidacy for the next one. On Dec. 6, he finally confirmed that he would run for a fourth term on March 18 \u2014 incidentally, the fourth anniversary of Russia\u2019s annexation of Crimea. Since his approval ratings hover around 80 percent, that puts him on course to be in office until 2024. By then, he will have been in power for 24 years. No wonder he is running as an independent candidate this time: President Putin does not need a party to support him \u2014 he just needs to run as President Putin. His legitimacy stems from holding power since the day the millennium was born.\n\nAmong pollsters, \u201capathy\u201d is the word that best describes voter sentiment. Journalists noted that the president himself looked slightly bored during his annual news conference on Dec. 15, even though he kept it going for 3 hours 40 minutes. His first term was dedicated to restoring order in Russia\u2019s post-Yeltsin chaos. The second term focused on the economy. During his third term, Mr. Putin made Russia great again \u2014 abroad. So far, mystery surrounds his next goal. No electoral slogans, no major campaign theme. If the candidate has a big idea for his fourth term, he is keeping it to himself.\n\nThat makes the real question what will happen not on March 19 but in 2024. The idea of post-Putinism is emerging slowly as an object of political study. The Constitution does not allow a president to run for more than two consecutive terms, and Mr. Putin has already used the stratagem of switching with his prime minister, Dmitri A. Medvedev, from 2008 to 2012. He is on record saying that he will not change the Constitution to stay indefinitely in power.", "title": "Opinion | Training Early for Post-Putin Politics", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 They are being heralded as a key part of President Trump\u2019s new strategy to resolve the nearly 17-year war in Afghanistan. But their training has been cut short by months, and units are still short-staffed, as some of the estimated 1,000 additional military advisers prepare to arrive in Afghanistan in time for the spring fighting season, officials said.\n\nThe Army soldiers are deploying as the Pentagon begins shifting resources from the fight against the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria back to Afghanistan. As part of its new assault against an increasingly tenacious Taliban, the Trump administration is planning to send some of the advisers back to small bases scattered across rural parts of the country to help train Afghan forces.\n\nThe new brigade of advisers was formed in August and is based at Fort Benning, Ga. Two military officials said its leaders were still trying to ensure that each small team had enough soldiers to train Afghans.\n\nOne of those officials, and an additional one, said that the advisers\u2019 brigade was supposed to have around a year of training before deploying. Advisers in the new brigade are expected to begin deploying by early spring \u2014 roughly eight months after the brigade was created.", "title": "Training Quick and Staffing Unfinished, Army Units Brace for Surging Taliban", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-31 00:00:00", "text": "Like many American hometowns, Fall River has faced its share of storms. But people here are tough. They fight for each other. They pull for their city.\n\nIt is a fitting place to gather as our nation reflects on the state of our union.\n\nThis is a difficult task. Many have spent the past year anxious, angry, afraid. We all feel the fault lines of a fractured country. We hear the voices of Americans who feel forgotten and forsaken.\n\nWe see an economy that makes stocks soar, investor portfolios bulge and corporate profits climb but fails to give workers their fair share of the reward.\n\nA government that struggles to keep itself open.\n\nRussia knee-deep in our democracy.\n\nAn all-out war on environmental protection.\n\nA Justice Department rolling back civil rights by the day.\n\nHatred and supremacy proudly marching in our streets.\n\nBullets tearing through our classrooms, concerts, and congregations. Targeting our safest, sacred places.\n\nAnd that nagging, sinking feeling, no matter your political beliefs: this is not right. This is not who we are.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIt would be easy to dismiss the past year as chaos. Partisanship. Politics.\n\nBut it\u2019s far bigger than that. This administration isn\u2019t just targeting the laws that protect us \u2014 they are targeting the very idea that we are all worthy of protection.\n\nFor them, dignity isn\u2019t something you\u2019re born with but something you measure.\n\nBy your net worth, your celebrity, your headlines, your crowd size.\n\nNot to mention, the gender of your spouse. The country of your birth. The color of your skin. The God of your prayers.\n\nTheir record is a rebuke of our highest American ideal: the belief that we are all worthy, we are all equal and we all count. In the eyes of our law and our leaders, our God and our government.\n\nThat is the American promise.\n\nBut today that promise is being broken. By an administration that callously appraises our worthiness and decides who makes the cut and who can be bargained away.\n\nThey are turning American life into a zero-sum game.\n\nWhere, in order for one to win, another must lose.\n\nWhere we can guarantee America\u2019s safety if we slash our safety net.\n\nWe can extend health care to Mississippi if we gut it in Massachusetts.\n\nWe can cut taxes for corporations today if we raise them for families tomorrow.\n\nWe can take care of sick kids if we sacrifice Dreamers.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWe are bombarded with one false choice after another:\n\nCoal miners or single moms. Rural communities or inner cities. The coast or the heartland.\n\nAs if the mechanic in Pittsburgh and the teacher in Tulsa and the day care worker in Birmingham are somehow bitter rivals, rather than mutual casualties of a system forcefully rigged for those at the top.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Get the Morning Briefing by Email What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox Monday through Friday. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAs if the parent who lies awake terrified that their transgender son will be beaten and bullied at school is any more or less legitimate than the parent whose heart is shattered by a daughter in the grips of opioid addiction.\n\nSo here is the answer Democrats offer tonight: we choose both. We fight for both. Because the strongest, richest, greatest nation in the world shouldn\u2019t leave any one behind.\n\nWe choose a better deal for all who call this country home.\n\nWe choose the living wage, paid leave and affordable child care your family needs to survive.\n\nWe choose pensions that are solvent, trade pacts that are fair, roads and bridges that won\u2019t rust away, and good education you can afford.\n\nWe choose a health care system that offers mercy, whether you suffer from cancer or depression or addiction.\n\nWe choose an economy strong enough to boast record stock prices and brave enough to admit that top C.E.O.s making 300 times the average worker is not right.\n\nWe choose Fall River.\n\nWe choose the thousands of American communities whose roads aren\u2019t paved with power or privilege, but with honest effort, good faith, and the resolve to build something better for their kids.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThat is our story. It began the day our Founding Fathers and Mothers set sail for a New World, fleeing oppression and intolerance.\n\nIt continued with every word of our Independence \u2014 the audacity to declare that all men are created equal. An imperfect promise for a nation struggling to become a more perfect union.\n\nIt grew with every suffragette\u2019s step, every Freedom Riders voice, every weary soul we welcomed to our shores.\n\nAnd to all the \u201cDreamers\u201d watching tonight, let me be clear: Ustedes son parte de nuestra historia. Vamos a luchar por ustedes y no nos vamos alejar.\n\nYou are a part of our story. We will fight for you. We will not walk away.\n\nAmerica, we carry that story on our shoulders.\n\nYou swarmed Washington last year to ensure no parent has to worry if they can afford to save their child\u2019s life.\n\nYou proudly marched together last weekend \u2014 thousands deep \u2014 in the streets of Las Vegas and Philadelphia and Nashville.\n\nYou sat high atop your mom\u2019s shoulders and held a sign that read: \u201cBuild a wall and my generation will tear it down.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nYou bravely say, me too. You steadfastly say, black lives matter.\n\nYou wade through floodwaters, battle hurricanes, and brave wildfires and mudslides to save a stranger.\n\nYou fight your own, quiet battles every single day.\n\nYou drag your weary bodies to that extra shift so your families won\u2019t feel the sting of scarcity.\n\nYou leave loved ones at home to defend our country overseas, or patrol our neighborhoods overnight.\n\nYou serve. You rescue. You help. You heal.\n\nThat \u2014 more than any law or leader, any debate or disagreement \u2014 that is what drives us toward progress.\n\nBullies may land a punch. They might leave a mark. But they have never, not once, in the history of our United States, managed to match the strength and spirit of a people united in defense of their future.\n\nPoliticians can be cheered for the promises they make. Our country will be judged by the promises we keep.\n\nThat is the measure of our character. That\u2019s who we are.\n\nOut of many. One.\n\nLadies and gentlemen, have faith: The state of our union is hopeful, resilient, enduring.\n\nThank you, God bless you and your families, and God bless the United States of America.", "title": "Full Transcript and Video: Joe Kennedy Delivers Democratic Response to the State of the Union", "authors": ["The New York Times"]} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "He described feeling \u201cscrutinized and degraded\u201d when administrators repeatedly tried to keep him out of the boys restrooms, or when they used female pronouns after he had asked them not to. He added that he suffered from anxiety, depression, migraines and other health problems related to dehydration because he had tried to avoid restroom trips by drinking less water.\n\nA Federal District Court judge granted an injunction that allowed Mr. Whitaker to use boys bathrooms during his senior year. The school district appealed that decision to the Seventh Circuit Court of Appeals. The district\u2019s lawyers argued in part that \u201ca student cannot unilaterally declare their gender then demand that they be treated like \u2018all others\u2019 in that sex classification.\u201d\n\nBut the appeals court judges upheld the injunction in May 2017.\n\nThe school district then filed a petition to appeal that ruling to the United States Supreme Court. But on Tuesday, the school board voted 5 to 2 to pay an $800,000 settlement to Mr. Whitaker instead and to withdraw its petition, according to The Kenosha News.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. Whitaker, in a statement emailed by the Transgender Law Center, which represented him, said he was \u201cdeeply relieved\u201d that the court case was over and he could focus on being a college student. \u201cWinning this case was so empowering and made me feel like I can actually do something to help other trans youth live authentically,\u201d he said.\n\nRonald S. Stadler, the board\u2019s lawyer, said that the district \u201cnever engaged in any acts of overt discrimination against transgender individuals,\u201d although he acknowledged that Mr. Whitaker had been told not to use the boys bathroom. He said the decision to settle was made partly because the district wanted to avoid the cost of continuing litigation.\n\n\u201cI think eventually the Supreme Court is going to have to take this issue and issue a ruling,\u201d he said, \u201cbecause we have lower courts all across the country that have looked at it in various ways, and it\u2019s not always consistent.\u201d\n\nLynly S. Egyes, the director for litigation at the Transgender Law Center, a California-based advocacy group, said that while many court decisions about transgender issues had relied on guidance from the executive branch (like the guidelines under President Barack Obama that were rescinded under President Trump), the Seventh Circuit\u2019s decision to uphold the injunction relied instead on the Equal Protection Clause of the 14th Amendment and Title IX, the federal law that prohibits gender discrimination in schools that get public funds.\n\n\u201cThis is one of the most sweeping decisions for transgender people at the federal level that we have seen,\u201d Ms. Egyes said.\n\nJoseph J. Wardenski, a civil rights lawyer with the Washington-based firm Relman, Dane & Colfax who also represented Mr. Whitaker, said that the Seventh Circuit\u2019s decision \u201cwill also benefit many transgender people across the country.\u201d He noted that the opinion had already been cited by courts outside of the Seventh Circuit, which covers Illinois, Indiana and Wisconsin.", "title": "Transgender Student\u2019s Discrimination Suit Is Settled for $800,000", "authors": ["Jacey Fortin"]} {"date": "2018-01-29 00:00:00", "text": "So I want thrilling plots, yes \u2014 but also thrilling language. I want sentences I\u2019ll stop to read twice. This is why standard throwaway airport thrillers don\u2019t migrate well beneath ground. The writing may be \u201cmuscular\u201d and \u201cspare,\u201d but if it\u2019s not also \u201cinventive\u201d and \u201cexcellent\u201d there\u2019s a good chance the book will wind up abandoned on a platform bench. With a long day behind me and a wearying commute ahead of me, I don\u2019t want to settle for distraction; I want to look forward to reading my book with the palpitating excitement of a second date with someone I\u2019ve already fallen for. I want to miss my stop. Ideally, I\u2019ll miss a few.\n\nMy quest for the perfect \u201csubway read\u201d has affected me as a writer, too. When I sat down to start what would become my first novel, \u201cShovel Ready,\u201d a crime thriller set in New York, I hoped to evoke an experience that encompassed exactly the qualities mentioned above. The book is jittery, dark, occasionally jarring and, ideally, unpredictable \u2014 you know, like a ride on the M.T.A. And one of my most rewarding experiences came later, via the Twitter account @CoverSpy, which chronicles the books people are spotted reading on the subway. One day, a mention sneaked into my timeline: Male, 20s, navy N.H.L. cap, on the R train, reading \u201cNear Enemy,\u201d a book of mine. Writers are always happy to encounter their readers, but a subterranean one was especially meaningful to me.\n\nHerewith, a few of the best contenders for the category that I\u2019ve discovered recently. \u201cThe Transmigration of Bodies,\u201d by Yuri Herrera, is a slim and potent novel about an unnamed city emptied out by plague, and one character\u2019s desperate scramble to unite two warring clans (think Baz Luhrmann\u2019s film \u201cRomeo and Juliet,\u201d but set in the landscape of \u201cChildren of Men\u201d and written in the jagged-glass prose of James Cain). Jenny Offill\u2019s \u201cDept. of Speculation\u201d also fits the bill; it\u2019s a shiv of a book about a blocked writer watching her marriage unravel. But perhaps my favorite \u201csubway read\u201d to date is James Ellroy\u2019s \u201cL.A. Confidential,\u201d which is even more sprawling, sordid and satisfying than its film adaptation. I devoured it in less than a week, or about three or four round trips. You\u2019ll find yourself racing to the end, even as you don\u2019t want the end to arrive \u2014 a truly rare feeling when it comes to the urban commute.", "title": "Transportive Reading for Underground Transportation", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-17 00:00:00", "text": "Early on Saturday, amid blowing snow and temperatures at minus 13 Fahrenheit, three caribou were blindfolded, earplugged and bundled into a helicopter on an island in Lake Superior.\n\nThe animals, survivors of a herd that was decimated by wolves in recent years, were among nine animals relocated by the Ontario government last weekend in an attempt to save them from disappearing from around Lake Superior, where they once thrived. A team of pilots, veterinarians, research scientists and animal handlers moved eight cows and one bull from Michipicoten Island to the Slate Islands some 80 miles away, where the government hopes the animals will have a chance to repopulate.\n\nAfter being herded by helicopter to an open area on Michipicoten Island, the caribou were captured with a gun net, restrained and sedated. Loaded on another helicopter, they took an hourlong ride to their new home.", "title": "Trapped on an Island With Wolves, the Only Way Out for These Caribou Was Up", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Roth gave a public summary of the report\u2019s finding to members of Congress last November. But the full report, even though it redacts key pieces of information, provides a more detailed view of the Trump administration\u2019s attempts to craft the travel ban without significant input from the department that would be charged with enforcing it.\n\nThat includes John F. Kelly, the Homeland Security secretary at the time, who could not say for sure that he was shown a draft of the executive order before it was signed. Mr. Kelly, now the White House chief of staff, told investigators that he believed he saw draft copies of the ban and discussed it with a member of Mr. Trump\u2019s presidential transition team, as well as with Ms. Nielsen.\n\nJoseph B. Maher, the department\u2019s acting general counsel, told investigators that he saw a draft of the order an hour before it was signed and had no role in helping to craft it. The report issued on Friday said Mr. Kelly and Mr. Maher appear to be the only people at the department who saw the travel ban before it was signed.\n\nThe draft order was never sent to Customs and Border Protection, the agency that had to enforce the ban at airports. The inspector general\u2019s office found that Kevin K. McAleenan, the acting commissioner of the customs agency, received the most details about the order\u2019s contents from congressional staffers who \u201cwere better informed.\u201d\n\nThe report also concluded that although the Justice Department\u2019s Office of Legal Counsel reviewed the draft executive order, it failed to analyze the rights of legal permanent residents, who were left in limbo while customs officials scrambled to determine if they could re-enter the United States.", "title": "Travel Ban Caught Homeland Security by Surprise, Report Concludes", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "The comedian Tom Segura doesn\u2019t necessarily like traveling, but he knows what works for him, and it doesn\u2019t involve fancy outfits (though sleep masks do come into play).\n\n\u201cI see people glammed up and it\u2019s like, dude, you should dress like a fugitive when you get on a flight,\u201d Mr. Segura, whose latest comedy special, \u201cDisgraceful\u201d is now streaming on Netflix, said. \u201cYou should make travel as comfortable as possible.\u201d\n\nHe does, though, have his limits on casual wear \u2014 more on that below. And you also have to be prepared to react to other people\u2019s actions, he said, which is where the sleep mask comes in.\n\n\u201cOn early a.m. flights there\u2019s always one jackass who still wants to watch the sun rise and then stare into it for the next five hours,\u201d Mr. Segura said. \u201cMeanwhile, everyone in the whole cabin has their window shade down and it\u2019s dark but there\u2019s that one guy. So now I just put on a sleep mask.\u201d", "title": "Travel Tips From Comedians: Tom Segura", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 A probe into the Treasury Department\u2019s role in crafting and assessing the Trump administration\u2019s tax plan found no evidence of any improper political interference with the career tax staff, but cast doubt on whether the department\u2019s robust economic growth projections were achievable.\n\nThe Treasury Department\u2019s Office of Inspector General launched a probe into the practices of Treasury\u2019s Office of Tax Analysis after The New York Times reported on the lack of a Treasury analysis of the $1.5 trillion tax plan and concerns that career tax staff were shut out of the tax bill process. Steven Mnuchin, the Treasury secretary, had repeatedly asserted that the tax bill would pay for itself and that Treasury staff were working on a detailed analysis of the plan\u2019s costs that would bear out that assertion.\n\nThe Treasury Department did not provide that analysis before the Senate voted on the tax bill and did not provide Senator Bob Corker, Republican of Tennessee, a promised analysis showing the tax plan would not add to the federal deficit. The lack of the analysis raised questions whether Treasury\u2019s team of tax experts could really back up Mr. Mnuchin\u2019s claims that the tax bill would not balloon the deficit.\n\n\u201cIt is unclear whether the Department\u2019s involvement in the tax legislating process in 2017 has been any more or less \u2018political\u2019 than it has been in past years,\u201d Rich Delmar, the counsel to the inspector general, wrote in a report outlining its findings. \u201cI do not see a basis to conclude that the process employed by Treasury this past year was contrary to law, an abuse of authority or otherwise improper.\u201d", "title": "Treasury Inspector General Finds No Political Meddling in Tax Analysis", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "D.B.: Can you say more about Diego?\n\nN.B.H.: Diego had growth failure, but he also had asthma, eczema and behavior problems. The frame shift for me was instead of doing the standard treatment for each of his four diagnoses, I asked, \u201cIs it possible that the trauma that he\u2019s been exposed to could be the underlying cause of all these problems?\u201d When I consulted hormone specialists, I was told that\u2019s likely the case. O.K., well, then, the thing we need to treat is the trauma.\n\nThat\u2019s when I began diving into the research literature. In 2008, I came across the ACE Study, which had been published in 1998. I was absolutely shocked that I had never heard about it and that as a doctor I was never trained on it. And so for me that began a mission to translate the science into something useful for patients.\n\nD.B.: What needs to happen?\n\nN.B.H.: No. 1, universal screening. The best tools we have right now are early detection and prevention. Studies show that when kids received early high quality intervention, their brain scans ended up looking more like those of children who had never been maltreated than children who had been maltreated. Ultimately, every pediatrician in America needs to be screening for ACEs.\n\nD.B.: How do you make screening doable?\n\nN.B.H.: At our center, we screen for the number of ACEs, but we don\u2019t ask folks to identify each individual one. We recognize that these are sensitive questions to ask in a clinical setting. But we need to screen the entire population, and the only way to screen everyone is in primary care. If you\u2019re waiting until you get to a mental health practitioner, you\u2019re going to be too late, and a lot of kids will be missed. Our screening can be done in three minutes or less. It\u2019s quick to interpret. A doctor can look at it and say this child is at low risk, moderate risk or high risk of having a toxic stress physiology. For me it\u2019s no different than laying a stethoscope on a patient\u2019s chest.\n\nD.B.: What are the treatment implications?\n\nN.B.H.: One of the key ingredients for keeping the body\u2019s stress response out of the toxic stress zone is the presence of a healthy buffering caregiver. So we need to educate parents and caregivers about the impact a child\u2019s environment and exposures may be having on their health. We also know that if a caregiver is able to self-regulate, their kids have much better outcomes. Good old-fashioned mental health care really does help. In research studies, certain types of interventions, including child-parent psychotherapy, can help to normalize cortisol levels and get the body\u2019s stress response back on track. We designed our services at the Center for Youth Wellness with this science in mind. We provide mental health and wellness services to either the child or the parent. It\u2019s really important that we do this two-generational work.\n\nD.B.: What else is helpful?\n\nN.B.H.: The six core pieces that are key to addressing the biology of toxic stress are sleep, exercise, nutrition, mindfulness, mental health and healthy relationships. Certain diets support a healthy immune system and neuroplasticity. And when you exercise, it helps to metabolize stress hormones and release other hormones that counteract effects of stress and also support cardiovascular health and reduce chronic inflammation.\n\nD.B.: What social problems can this science help us understand better?\n\nN.B.H.: Substance dependence: An individual with four or more ACEs is 10 times more likely to be an IV drug user as someone with no ACEs. Education and underperforming schools is a big one: When we did a chart review of 702 patients, we found that if a child had an ACE score of 4 or more, they were 32.6 times more likely to have learning or behavior problems. The justice system: When you look at the proportions of folks in our jails who have high adversity, especially our juvenile incarcerated population, we\u2019re talking about greater than 90 percent.", "title": "Opinion | Treating the Lifelong Harm of Childhood Trauma", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-17 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cIn doing the healing work, you look at what the patient\u2019s support systems are, \u201c said Priscilla Dass-Brailsford, a trauma psychologist and an adjunct professor in the department of psychiatry at Georgetown University. \u201cThe biggest supports are parents and family. These kids don\u2019t have that. The parents were the aggressors.\u201d\n\nExperts interviewed for this article, who underscored that they had no direct knowledge of the California case, said that because the siblings\u2019 primal assurance of unconditional love and safety had been ripped away, they would almost certainly struggle to trust and attach to future supportive figures.\n\n\u201cThe notion that this was done by parents increases a child\u2019s helplessness and hopelessness,\u201d said Nora J. Baladerian, a Los Angeles psychologist who often treats traumatized individuals.\n\nDr. Dass-Brailsford compared the 13 siblings\u2019 situation to that of prisoners of war, who have been deprived of food, freedom and sufficient nurturing.\n\n\u201cOne glimmer of hope is that they did not go through this alone,\u201d she said. \u201cPrisoners of war are isolated as part of their torture. These children at least had each other.\u201d\n\nBefore formal therapy can begin, the siblings must be placed in a safe, nurturing environment where kind treatment will be a positive constant they can rely upon, experts said. They added that keeping as many siblings together as possible would be important, to sustain their bonds.\n\nPhoto\n\nDaniel L. Davis, a forensic psychologist in Columbus, Ohio who has treated victims and perpetrators and evaluates children for juvenile court, said that there is not one behavioral model that adequately describes a typical parent perpetrator.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThere are risk factors, certainly,\u201d he said. A list might include a prior history of abuse, domestic violence, and a cluster of personality disorders such as antisocial personality disorder, borderline personality disorder and narcissistic personality disorder. Such people, he said, might be overly emotional, unpredictable, manipulative and exploitative.\n\nBut like other trauma experts, Dr. Davis emphasized that children can be remarkably resilient. He treated an elementary school-age boy whose parents had kept him locked away for such a long period that the child showed significant developmental delays. \u201cBut with intensive treatment and real effort by a support team, his growth was impressive,\u201d said Dr. Davis. \u201cHis parents were sent to prison.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nOther examples of children locked away from society by parents do occasionally emerge. A documentary \u201cThe Wolfpack\u201d tells the story of seven siblings isolated in a Lower East Side apartment by their father. In 2015, three siblings were found locked by their parents in a urine-and-feces infested room in Spotsylvania County, Virginia. That same year, a teenage girl in Murfreesboro, Tenn., was also discovered having been locked in her bedroom for months by her parents, who had allowed her three siblings to travel at will.\n\nDr. Davis said that while poverty is an element in many cases, it is certainly not a signature characteristic; indeed in the California case, the family lived in a middle-class neighborhood and the father, David Allen Turpin, had reportedly once been employed as an engineer. But poverty-afflicted situations may come to light more often, Dr. Davis noted, \u201cbecause the perpetrators don\u2019t have the resources to keep shielding from public scrutiny.\u201d\n\nFormal treatment begins after children are placed in a secure home and assessed for trauma-related symptoms, including post-traumatic stress disorder. They may be unwilling or unable to describe their experience. Nightmares may roil them. The slightest trigger \u2014 the rattle of keys, for example \u2014 might send them into a hysterical tantrum. They may seem hyper-aroused or vigilant, ever alert and cringing, braced to flee or fight. Younger children may act out the trauma as they play; for others, the emotional pain may be so overwhelming that they seem numb.\n\n\u201cBut the majority of these children can bounce back, \u201c said Anthony P. Mannarino, director of the Center for Traumatic Stress in Children and Adolescents at Allegheny General Hospital in Pittsburgh. \u201cI\u2019m not saying they\u2019ll forget it but they can find a way to go forward.\u201d\n\nDr. Mannarino is a co-developer of trauma-focused cognitive behavioral therapy (TF-CBT). The typical treatment, he said, is 12 to 16 sessions.\n\nFirst, a therapist works with a child to manage terrifying thoughts and feelings about the experience. Next a therapist helps the child gradually discuss the trauma.\n\n\u201cThose memories are really scary,\u201d Dr. Mannarino said. \u201dMaybe the parents said, \u2018You deserve what you\u2019re getting, it\u2019s your fault,\u2019 and the child may have internalized shame. Helping them talk and processing that distortion gives them a chance to understand that they are not to blame.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFinally, TF-CBT involves the child\u2019s new caregivers. \u201cWe work with them to understand that the child\u2019s behavior expresses what happened to the child, as opposed to who they really are,\u201d said Dr. Mannarino.\n\nOf numerous therapies developed to address traumatized patients, TF-CBT is one of the most studied. In a 2004 randomized, multisite study published in the Journal of the American Academy of Child and Adolescent Psychiatry, 203 children between eight and 14 who had symptoms of PTSD related to sex abuse, and their caretakers, were randomly assigned to TF-CBT or \u201cchild-centered\u201d therapy \u2014 a talk therapy model often use in rape-crisis or sex-abuse treatment centers. TF-CBT patients showed significantly more improvement in markers such as PTSD, depression and behavior.\n\nDr. Baladerian hoped that not only would the California family receive sufficient services, but that \u201cthe attention will also help other victims whose cases might not have been attended to with such alacrity.\u201d", "title": "Treatment Offers Hope for Imprisoned California Siblings", "authors": ["Jan Hoffman"]} {"date": "2018-01-17 00:00:00", "text": "It was a story that captivated social media this week, but Monday\u2019s contentious game between the Houston Rockets and Los Angeles Clippers, and its movie-like aftermath, resulted in Trevor Ariza and Gerald Green of the Rockets being suspended for two games each.\n\nChris Paul and James Harden of the Rockets, as well as Blake Griffin of the Clippers \u2014 all of whom were key players in the drama-filled evening \u2014 were not penalized.\n\nThe game, which the Clippers eventually won, 113-102, marked Paul\u2019s return to Los Angeles, where he played for six years before being traded to the Rockets last June. Instead of an enthusiastic welcome for a player who had been the face of the Clippers\u2019 franchise, the game turned into a mess of technical fouls and ejections on the court, and something far more surprising off it: a locker room invasion.\n\nShortly after the game, reports emerged of a group of Rockets players \u2014 Harden, Green, Ariza and Paul \u2014 entering the Los Angeles locker room through a connecting hallway in order to confront the Clippers. Some even included an added flourish, indicating that Houston\u2019s Clint Capela had been sent to the front door of the locker room to act as a distraction as his teammates invaded.", "title": "Trevor Ariza and Gerald Green Suspended Over Rockets-Clippers Melee", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nWelcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown that lets you sleep \u2014 and lets us get paid to watch comedy. What do you think of it? What else are you interested in? Let us know: thearts@nytimes.com.\n\nWhy Collude, if You Don\u2019t Want to Win?\n\nLate-night hosts on Thursday pored over the bombshell accounts of the Trump administration\u2019s first year contained in \u201cFire and Fury,\u201d a forthcoming book by the journalist Michael Wolff. A major assertion is that President Trump was disappointed when he won the 2016 election. Trevor Noah said Mr. Trump might actually want to embrace that narrative.\n\n\u201cI will say this: If you believe that he didn\u2019t want to win, then it\u2019s hard to believe that he colluded with the Russians, right? If anything, instead of trying to shut this book down, Trump should be sending a copy to Robert Mueller to be like, \u2018You see? It exonerates me!\u2019 \u2018The part where it says you\u2019re an idiot?\u2019 \u2018No, no, go on further!\u2019\u201d \u2014 TREVOR NOAH\n\nStephen Colbert pointed out that Steve Bannon, the president\u2019s former chief strategist, is in hot water with allies after being shown roundly criticizing Mr. Trump in the book.\n\n\u201cBannon has caught holy hell from his own supporters. In the last 24 hours alone, candidates he has endorsed have abandoned him; he lost his biggest billionaire donor; even the alt-right is turning its back on Steve Bannon. It\u2019s true, they\u2019re so embarrassed of Bannon that a lot of the alt-right have started covering their faces with hoods!\u201d \u2014 STEPHEN COLBERT\n\nNot-as-High Horse\n\nThe Trump administration on Thursday authorized prosecutors to go after marijuana offenders even in states where consumption of the drug is legal. Mr. Colbert said the decision revealed something about Attorney General Jeff Sessions, who spearheaded the move.", "title": "Trevor Noah Says Trump Should Embrace \u2018Fire and Fury\u2019 Book", "authors": ["Giovanni Russonello", "Best Of Late Night"]} {"date": "2018-01-31 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cWhatever skills I may have are better utilized in a courtroom than in Congress, and I enjoy our justice system more than our political system,\u201d he said in a statement. \u201cAs I look back on my career, it is the jobs that both seek and reward fairness that are most rewarding.\u201d\n\nMr. Gowdy, 53, made his name on Capitol Hill as one of Congress\u2019s most strategic and polarizing investigators. As the chairman of the House Select Committee on Benghazi, he led one of the longest and most bruisingly partisan congressional investigations in history. The committee ultimately found no new evidence of culpability or wrongdoing by Hillary Clinton in the 2012 attacks in Libya that left four Americans dead.\n\nBut the committee\u2019s work had another lasting effect: It discovered that Mrs. Clinton had used a private email server during her time as secretary of state. The revelation would lead to an F.B.I. investigation and would dog Mrs. Clinton\u2019s presidential campaign.\n\nMr. Gowdy won the chairmanship of the powerful Oversight Committee last year, after the early retirement of another rising Republican, Jason Chaffetz of Utah. He has been criticized in that role by Democrats who say he was more interested in using the committee\u2019s powers to look backward and investigate the administration of President Barack Obama than that of Mr. Trump.\n\nAt the same time, Mr. Gowdy has taken a prominent role in one of the highest-profile investigations on Capitol Hill in years: the House Intelligence Committee\u2019s inquiry into Russian meddling in the 2016 election. Mr. Gowdy helped lead the questioning of witnesses for Republicans on the committee, and he has played a significant role in assembling a contentious secret memo that purportedly shows that the F.B.I. and the Justice Department abused their authority to obtain a warrant to spy on a former Trump campaign adviser.", "title": "Trey Gowdy, Who Led House Benghazi Inquiry, Will Not Seek Re-election", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-08 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nIn the last few months, the #MeToo movement has broken down walls of traditional male bastions in Hollywood, the news media and Washington. Now, a criminal trial in Brooklyn is poised to expose a world where activists have not yet gone \u2014 the one behind bars.\n\nThis week, a former lieutenant at the Metropolitan Detention Center, the federal jail in Brooklyn, will go on trial, accused of using his position of authority to repeatedly rape a female inmate in his charge. At least five times from December 2015 to April 2016, prosecutors say, the defendant, Carlos Richard Martinez, assaulted the woman while she was on an assignment to clean an office in the jail. To ensure no one walked in during the attack, he watched a feed from a security camera outside the office, prosecutors say.\n\nThe trial, which began on Monday with jury selection in Federal District Court in Brooklyn, comes eight months after Mr. Martinez, 48, was charged in a federal indictment that brought to a head one of the largest sexual assault investigations to confront the federal Bureau of Prisons in at least a decade. The indictment also named another lieutenant at the jail, Eugenio Perez, who is awaiting trial, and a rank-and-file corrections officer, Armando Moronta, who pleaded guilty in November to sexually abusing three female inmates.\n\nThe charges against all three men cast the jail, often known as the M.D.C., in a particularly troubling light. The M.D.C. holds about 1,800 inmates, only about 3 percent of whom are women. In 2016, a federal judge expressed reluctance about sending women there because, as she put it at the time, its conditions made it sound like it was in \u201csome third-world country.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe alleged victim in Mr. Martinez\u2019s case \u2014 a Dominican woman in her 20s who was being held on a drug trafficking charge \u2014 is scheduled to testify at trial and will probably tell the jury, prosecutors say, how the abuse began with sexually explicit comments, but quickly escalated into a series of rapes that took place in a deserted office late at night on weekends when she was directed to leave her dormitory on cleaning duty. During the attacks, the woman is expected to say, Mr. Martinez forced her to have sex, usually while she was lying facedown on a desk and he was watching surveillance footage of the area on a desktop computer.", "title": "Trial Begins in Brooklyn of Jail Guard Accused of Raping Female Inmate", "authors": ["Alan Feuer"]} {"date": "2018-01-29 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Rich, who served as the editor in chief of The Daily News for a 13-month period that ended in 2016, will return to his former post on Wednesday, Tronc said. Most recently, he was the executive editor of HuffPost, a job he left in December, when he said he planned to start a nonprofit news site.\n\nDuring his last stint at the tabloid, Mr. Rich, 46, distinguished himself with attention-grabbing headlines that excoriated Republican leaders. After Donald J. Trump won the New Hampshire primary during the 2016 presidential campaign, for instance, the Daily News front page included an image of the candidate in clown makeup with the headline \u201cDawn of the Brain Dead \u2014 Trump comes back to life with N.H. win.\u201d\n\nMr. Rich, whose departure from the Daily News in 2016 shocked staff members, will take over for Arthur Browne, who retired at the end of December.\n\nIn a statement announcing the changes, Justin C. Dearborn, the chief executive of Tronc, said, \u201cWe are continuing to invest in high quality journalism, which will always be the company\u2019s top priority.\u201d He called Mr. Kirk a \u201ctalented news veteran\u201d and Mr. Rich \u201ca well-established media professional.\u201d\n\nTronc, which publishes newspapers including The Chicago Tribune and The Baltimore Sun, is trying to leave behind a bruising period marked by rising turmoil in the newsrooms of The Daily News and The Times.\n\nThe Daily News, which Tronc acquired in September from the real estate and media mogul Mortimer B. Zuckerman, recently suspended its managing editor, Rob Moore, and its Sunday editor, Alexander Jones, because of sexual harassment allegations made against them by current and former employees.\n\nPhoto\n\nAt The Times, Ross Levinsohn, who was named publisher in August, was put on leave after National Public Radio published an article that detailed sexual harassment allegations made against him while he worked at other companies. On the same day, the newsroom announced that it had voted to unionize by an overwhelming margin \u2014 a move that followed years of discontent.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nTronc vetted Mr. Levinsohn, a former Yahoo executive, before he was hired as The Times\u2019s publisher, but company executives were not aware that he had twice been a defendant in sexual harassment lawsuits while employed by other companies, according to two people briefed on the matter who were not permitted to speak publicly about it.\n\nThe fallout from the N.P.R. report on the allegations against Mr. Levinsohn, which was published Jan. 18, reached beyond Tronc on Monday, when Tribune Media disclosed in a regulatory filing that Mr. Levinsohn had notified the company last week that he was taking leave from its corporate board. (Tribune Media and Tronc, formerly called Tribune Publishing, had been one corporation, Tribune Company, before a spinoff of the newspaper business in 2014.)\n\nMr. Kirk joined Tronc in August and became a jack-of-all-trades for the company, serving as the interim executive editor of The Times and the interim editor in chief of The Daily News. His new appointment was largely met with a sense of relief within the Times newsroom but also a recognition that his appointment will not undo years of frustration among employees or rid the paper of its underlying financial challenges.\n\nThe man he replaced, Mr. D\u2019Vorkin, faced suspicion in the newsroom almost from his arrival, partly because of his previous role at Forbes, where he broadened the company\u2019s native advertising offerings and introduced a product that allowed advertisers to contribute material alongside Forbes articles. Newsroom skeptics feared that he would focus more on clicks and advertising innovations than quality journalism.\n\nTronc executives decided to move Mr. D\u2019Vorkin, 65, out of the top newsroom job at a time when they were also revisiting a companywide reorganization plan, according to two company officials briefed on the discussions. The proposal seemed intended to cut costs and increase the emphasis on making Tronc\u2019s journalism better suited to digital media. Mr. Levinsohn, the publisher now on leave, was a main architect of the restructuring plan. But the plan is now in flux, according to the two people.\n\nMr. Levinsohn\u2019s leave came at the end of an aggressive attempt by Times management to thwart the newsroom\u2019s ultimately successful union drive \u2014 a campaign that occurred as the paper\u2019s editors and reporters were distinguishing themselves with aggressive coverage of sexual harassment in Hollywood and natural disasters in California.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nTensions between the paper\u2019s employees and its management team had been rising since a dispute between The Times and the Walt Disney Company. After Disney banned Times journalists from attending advance film screenings following the publication of an investigative series on the company\u2019s ties to the city of Anaheim, some people in the newsroom questioned how Mr. D\u2019Vorkin had handled the paper\u2019s response.\n\nDuring a staff meeting, after learning that a recording of an earlier meeting had been leaked to a New York Times reporter, Mr. D\u2019Vorkin said that anyone involved with the act was \u201cmorally bankrupt,\u201d according to several people in attendance. His admonition further escalated the divide between employees and management.\n\nSeveral journalists at The Times said they worried that the company, eager to stanch the steady stream of reports other news organizations were publishing about it, had begun monitoring their phones and computers in pursuit of leaks. Two journalists said they had been warned that the company was monitoring employees\u2019 emails.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn a statement, Tronc said that it was committed to respecting employees\u2019 privacy. \u201cThere\u2019s never to our knowledge been a situation where the company is monitoring people\u2019s emails,\u201d the company said.\n\nThe tensions intensified last week, when the business editor, Kimi Yoshino, was abruptly suspended without a public explanation. In a note to Mr. D\u2019Vorkin that was widely circulated on social media, Times employees wrote that Ms. Yoshino was \u201casked to take a leave of absence and not even permitted to return to her office to collect her belongings and turn off her laptop.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cWe are deeply troubled by the way this situation is being handled,\u201d they wrote.\n\nTimes journalists also said they were concerned by what they had learned of the reorganization plan \u2014 which seemed to be the subject of a presentation given by Mr. Levinsohn to investors earlier this month that described a \u201cLos Angeles Times Network.\u201d\n\nUnder the proposal, newly hired editors would supervise reporting that could be fed to all Tronc publications, according to several people briefed on the potential restructuring.\n\nThat system, two of these people said, would include the creation of sites that would generate their own revenue. It would rely on Tronc employees and outside contributors who are not part of any existing Tronc newsroom.\n\nIn recent weeks, newsroom employees were puzzled to discover the names of several apparently newly hired editors in an internal human resources database, an image of which was shared with The New York Times. Among them were Bruce Upbin, formerly of Forbes, who was listed as an assistant managing editor; Sylvester Monroe, formerly an editor at The Washington Post, who was also listed as an assistant managing editor; and Louise Story, a former New York Times reporter and editor who was listed as a managing editor.\n\nMs. Story has since decided not to join Tronc, writing in an emailed statement, \u201cI had agreed to work at Tronc and at The Los Angeles Times in very high-level managerial roles. But, as a result of recent significant changes in those roles, I decided not to work there in any capacity.\u201d\n\nIn the internal database, the new hires were shown under Rob Angel, the chief of business development at The Times, but are now expected to report to Mr. D\u2019Vorkin, according to a person at Tronc familiar with the personnel decision.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSince Mr. Levinsohn went on leave, Tronc and Times executives met in Chicago to discuss which parts of the restructuring plan could continue, according to the people familiar with the discussions.\n\nThe recent unrest has its roots in the frustration that Times employees had with previous leaders. Last year, some grew critical of several top managers \u2014 including Davan Maharaj, the editor and publisher \u2014 in part over the handling of an investigation into the former dean of the medical school at the University of Southern California. Tronc removed Mr. Maharaj and several other newsroom leaders in August, saying that The Times had failed to transform fast enough on the digital side.\n\nMany employees expressed optimism that the D\u2019Vorkin-Levinsohn team would foster the kind of journalism that has garnered the paper more than 40 Pulitzer Prizes. Now they are looking toward a new leader.\n\nThe Los Angeles Times Guild congratulated Mr. Kirk in a statement. \u201cWe also look forward to working together in the future as one team \u2014 and we look forward to hearing his plans for the paper.\u201d\n\nMr. Kirk said that his goal as the top editor at The Times was to \u201cdouble down our great coverage of California and Los Angeles and beyond.\u201d\n\n\u201cThat\u2019s what readers expect from us, and we want to continue that,\u201d he added.", "title": "Tronc Names New Editors at The Daily News and The Los Angeles Times",
