state.\u201d\n\nAttacking Hillary Clinton, his former Democratic opponent from the 2016 presidential election, and taking aim at his own Justice Department struck familiar tones for the new year. Almost 14 months after the election, Mr. Trump has kept up a regular drumbeat of attacks on Mrs. Clinton. Last year, Mr. Trump also criticized the Justice Department and Attorney General Jeff Sessions for not pursuing investigations of his political opponents.\n\nThe Twitter post on Tuesday morning followed an article in The Daily Caller, a conservative publication that Mr. Trump closely monitors. The article said the aide, Huma Abedin, forwarded some government passwords to her private Yahoo email account in 2009, when Mrs. Clinton was secretary of state. Yahoo was hacked in 2013, which affected all three billion of its accounts. After the breach, the data was offered for sale by a hacking collective based in Eastern Europe. Mr. Trump also implored his administration to investigate Ms. Abedin.\n\nThe term \u201cdeep state\u201d typically refers to a shadow government of agency officials who secretly plot to influence policy; they are usually associated with countries that have authoritarian elements that undercut democratically elected leaders.", "title": "Trump Accuses Former Clinton Aide of Failing to Follow Security Protocols", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-08 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cA \u2018Stable Genius\u2019: Trump Declares He\u2019s Mentally Fit\u201d (front page, Jan. 7): The discussion of whether President Trump\u2019s sanity and intellect can be evaluated from afar is somewhat beside the point, since his actions are sufficient to show that this is not someone who should be in office.\n\nCan we prove he\u2019s a narcissist? Perhaps not, but we can certainly see that his behavior reflects someone who is narcissistic, lacking in empathy, corrupt, incurious, inept, lacking in knowledge, focused on reality-show norms and unwilling to think of country over self.\n\nWe don\u2019t need to know his serotonin level or degree of physical decay to know that he\u2019s wrong for the job.\n\nDAVID OATES, ATHENS, GA.\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nWhen I see a patient with obesity, I screen for diabetes. When I see a patient with exertional chest pain, I screen for coronary artery disease. When I see a patient with word-finding difficulties or new behavioral challenges, I screen for cognitive impairment. If President Trump\u2019s doctor does not screen for cognitive impairment, he is not doing his job. If President Trump does not participate in the screening tests, he is afraid of the results.", "title": "Opinion | Trump Addresses His Mental Fitness", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-09 00:00:00", "text": "But the move to lift the ban on drilling also put the Trump administration at odds with a number of coastal states. Governor Scott is expected to challenge Mr. Nelson for his Senate seat in November.\n\n\u201cI have spent my entire life fighting to keep oil rigs away from our coasts,\u201d Mr. Nelson said in a statement. \u201cBut now, suddenly, Secretary Zinke announces plans to drill off Florida\u2019s coast and four days later agrees to \u2018take Florida off the table\u2019? I don\u2019t believe it. This is a political stunt orchestrated by the Trump administration to help Rick Scott.\u201d\n\nFlorida lawmakers of both parties have long opposed offshore drilling, saying it could harm the state\u2019s tourism industry, which was hit hard after the Deepwater Horizon oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico sent waves of oil to the state\u2019s shores in 2010.\n\nEnvironmental groups accused Mr. Zinke of currying political favor with Governor Scott while pushing ahead with opening up coastal waters elsewhere.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cSuch a quick reversal begs the question: Will the Trump administration give equal consideration to all the other coastal governors from both parties who overwhelmingly reject this radical offshore drilling plan?\u201d said Diane Hoskins, a spokeswoman for the ocean conservation group Oceana.\n\nIn a post on Twitter addressed to Mr. Zinke, Xavier Becerra, California\u2019s attorney general, demanded that drilling also be banned off his state\u2019s shores.\n\nInterior officials had said they intended to hold nearly 50 lease sales between 2019 and 2024, including 19 off the coast of Alaska and 12 in the Gulf of Mexico. Seven areas offered for new drilling would be in Pacific waters off California, where drilling has been off limits for decades.\n\nBut finalizing the new plan could take as long as 18 months, experts said, and challenges are expected in the courts and in Congress.\n\nThe National Ocean Industries Association, which represents the offshore drilling industry, did not immediately respond to a request for comment.\n\nThe move to open America\u2019s coastal waters to drilling is the latest in a series of efforts to reverse restrictions on energy production. The Interior Department has also repealed offshore drilling safety regulations that were put in place after the Deepwater Horizon disaster.", "title": "Trump Administration Drops Florida From Offshore Drilling Plan", "authors": ["Hiroko Tabuchi"]} {"date": "2018-01-04 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cIt\u2019s terrible news,\u201d said Gustavo Velasquez, who was the assistant secretary for fair housing and equal opportunity at HUD during the final three years of the Obama administration. \u201cI am concerned, though, that this is not actually the worst news.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nDuring the delay, he fears that the Trump administration will entirely undo the rule, which has been a goal of many Republicans in Congress ever since it was adopted. Critics of the rule \u2014 including Ben Carson, before he became HUD secretary \u2014 argue that it amounts to an aggressive intrusion by the federal government into some of the most intimate decisions local citizens and communities make: about where to live, who lives next door and how to design their neighborhoods. Since joining the agency, Mr. Carson has said that he wants to \u201creinterpret\u201d the rule.\n\nHUD\u2019s notice argues that a delay is necessary because local communities need more technical assistance from the agency and have struggled to figure out how to measure their progress toward affirming fair housing. The agency notes that among the first 49 assessments submitted, about a third were initially returned by HUD as unacceptable. But the system was designed to include that kind of back and forth, former HUD officials said.\n\nSara Pratt, a former deputy assistant secretary for fair housing at the agency, said HUD had provided consultants and a hotline that jurisdictions could call for help. Many of the communities that fell short on their assessments had simply failed to follow HUD\u2019s road map, said Ms. Pratt, who left the department in November 2015 and now works as a civil rights lawyer in private practice.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s like having a teacher in a classroom saying, \u2018Too many people aren\u2019t passing the test, so I\u2019m just going to change the test,\u2019 \u201d she said.\n\nWhat worries her most, she said, is that HUD will allow cities to revert to prior standards for assessing fair housing. Under the old system, many cities submitted assessments that were of poor quality and lacked basic data, she said.\n\nBen Metcalf, director of the California Department of Housing and Community Development, said the 2015 rule had spurred local and state governments to understand their housing patterns and make smarter policy decisions around them.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSome cities, like Philadelphia, have already finished their assessments.\n\nPaul Chrystie, a spokesman for Philadelphia\u2019s Division of Housing and Community Development, said the process was critical in getting comments from the community and from a range of sectors \u2014 like education, transportation and banking. One important thing they learned was that residents did not want to move from their distressed neighborhoods, but wanted to see them improved, he said. That led to programs to expand pre-K and to improve libraries, parks and recreation centers, he said.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nNew York City is scheduled to begin the community outreach for its review this year. \u201cWe\u2019re confident in the approach New York City is taking,\u201d Leila Bozorg, the deputy commissioner of neighborhood strategies for the city\u2019s Department of Housing Preservation and Development, said in a statement. \u201cThis will include working closely with a diverse group of experts, practitioners and advocates and hearing directly from New Yorkers about their housing needs and how where they live impacts their life.\u201d\n\nThe Obama rule was devised to address unfinished business of the 1968 Fair Housing Act, which forbids discrimination in the housing market based on race, color, religion, sex and national origin. The original language of the law also required communities to \u201caffirmatively further\u201d fair housing \u2014 to, in effect, promote desegregation in addition to prohibiting discrimination.\n\nThe federal government never fully enforced that element of the law, however. And 50 years after the Fair Housing Act was passed, many communities have made little progress toward desegregation, while some programs funded with federal support have had the effect of reinforcing segregation.\n\nThe 2015 rule \u2014 the \u201caffirmatively furthering fair housing rule\u201d \u2014 required communities to analyze policies that contribute to segregation. These might include locating low-income housing projects only in black neighborhoods, or barring multifamily housing from neighborhoods with good schools. The rule broadly required analysis of housing opportunities available not just to minorities, but also to the disabled, the poor and other disadvantaged groups.\n\nThe new HUD notice reiterates that local communities still have a legal obligation to further fair housing, and to pledge that they\u2019re doing so. But a reversion to the policies in place before the 2015 rule makes critics fear that the government will go back to a time when it turned a blind eye to segregation, giving taxpayer dollars to communities actively thwarting a central goal of the Fair Housing Act.\n\n\u201cIt says \u2018segregate as usual,\u2019 \u201d said Myron Orfield, a law professor at the University of Minnesota.\n\nThe 2015 rule was imperfect, he said, but it also amounted to the federal government\u2019s first major effort to strengthen civil rights around housing since the Lyndon Johnson era.\n\n\u201cResidential segregation is at the heart of racial inequality in the country,\u201d Mr. Orfield said. \u201cAll of the disparities in the U.S. \u2014 in education, in income, wealth, employment, health \u2014 between the races are all fundamentally linked to residential segregation. There\u2019s no real way to deal with disparities between black and white people without dealing with this.\u201d", "title": "Trump Administration Postpones an Obama Fair-Housing Rule", "authors": ["Emily Badger", "John Eligon"]} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 The Trump administration said on Thursday that it would allow states to impose work requirements in Medicaid, a major policy shift that moves toward fulfilling a conservative vision for one of the nation\u2019s largest social insurance programs for low-income people.\n\nFederal officials said they would support state efforts to require able-bodied adults to work or participate in other \u201ccommunity engagement activities\u201d as a condition of eligibility for Medicaid.\n\n\u201cOur fundamental goal is to make a positive and lasting difference in the health and wellness of our beneficiaries, and today\u2019s announcement is a step in that direction,\u201d said Seema Verma, the administrator of the federal Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services.\n\nMs. Verma said the Trump administration was responding to requests from Medicaid officials in 10 states that wanted to run demonstration projects testing requirements for work or other types of community engagement like training, education, job search, volunteer activities and caregiving.", "title": "Trump Administration Says States May Impose Work Requirements for Medicaid", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-08 00:00:00", "text": "And despite its name, the administration says, the Temporary Protected Status program, known as T.P.S., had turned into a quasi-permanent benefit for hundreds of thousands of people.\n\nThe Department of Homeland Security said that because damaged roads, schools, hospitals, homes and water systems had been reconstructed since the earthquakes, the Salvadorans no longer belonged in the program.\n\n\u201cBased on careful consideration of available information,\u201d the department said in a statement, \u201cthe secretary determined that the original conditions caused by the 2001 earthquakes no longer exist. Thus, under the applicable statute, the current T.P.S. designation must be terminated.\u201d\n\nThe ending of protection for Salvadorans, Haitians and Nicaraguans leaves fewer than 100,000 people in the program, which was signed into law by President George Bush in 1990.\n\nPhoto\n\nIt provides temporary lawful status and work authorization to people already in the United States, whether they entered legally or not, from countries affected by armed conflict, natural disaster or other strife. The homeland security secretary decides when a country merits the designation and can renew it for six, 12 or 18 months.\n\nThere is no limit to the number of extensions a country can receive. Countries that have received and then lost the designation in the past include Bosnia and Herzegovina, which endured a civil war in the 1990s, and Guinea, Sierra Leone and Liberia during the Ebola crisis. El Salvador was one of the first countries in the program because of its civil war; that designation expired in 1994.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe administration is giving Salvadorans in the program until September 2019 to get their affairs in order. After that, they no longer will have permission to stay in the country, forcing them into a wrenching decision.\n\nMs. Lagunas said that she would remain in the United States illegally, risking arrest and deportation. But she would lose her job of 12 years without the work permit that comes with the protection. Her family would lose medical insurance and other benefits.\n\n\u201cThere is nothing to go back to in El Salvador,\u201d she said, speaking in Spanish. \u201cThe infrastructure may be better now, but the country is in no condition to receive us.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nWith his protected status, Carlos Jiron, another Salvadoran, started a small contracting business and won bids for big jobs, including to paint federal buildings in the Washington area.\n\n\u201cWe have built a life here,\u201d said Mr. Jiron, 41, who lives with his wife and two American-born children in a four-bedroom house they bought in Springfield, Va.\n\nHe will have to decide whether to take his children to El Salvador, where he says they would not maximize their potential and would face safety threats; leave them with guardians in the United States; or remain in the country at the risk of arrest and deportation as one of the millions of undocumented immigrants.\n\nHis 14-year-old daughter, Tania, a fan of Disney movies and hip-hop music, said she could not fathom starting over in El Salvador. \u201cThis is where I was born and am supposed to be raised,\u201d she said.\n\nTemporary protections were granted to Salvadorans who were in the United States in March 2001 after two earthquakes in January and February of that year killed more than 1,000 people and destroyed hundreds of thousands of homes. Over the next 15 years, the George W. Bush and Obama administrations extended the protections several times.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn 2016, the final time, the government cited several factors, including drought, poverty and widespread gang violence in El Salvador, as reasons to keep the protections in place.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nEl Salvador has rebuilt since the earthquakes. But the violence \u2014 San Salvador, the capital, is considered one of the most dangerous cities on Earth \u2014 has inhibited investment and job creation, and prompted tens of thousands to flee. The country\u2019s economy experienced the slowest growth of any in Central America in 2016, according to the World Bank.\n\nBut officials in the Trump administration say the only criteria the government should consider is whether the original reason for the designation \u2014 in this case, damage from the earthquakes \u2014 still exists.\n\nSome lawmakers have introduced legislation to enable people with temporary protection to remain in the United States permanently. At the same time, instability in Venezuela has prompted some members of Congress from Florida to call for protected status for Venezuelans.\n\nThe government of El Salvador had asked the Trump administration to renew the designation for its citizens in the United States, citing drought and other factors. Money sent home from Salvadorans abroad is a lifeline for many in the country, where four out of 10 households subsist below the poverty line, according to the World Bank. In 2016, the $4.6 billion remitted from abroad, mostly from the United States, accounted for 17 percent of the country\u2019s economy.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nEl Salvador\u2019s president, Salvador S\u00e1nchez Cer\u00e9n, spoke by phone with Kirstjen Nielsen, the homeland security secretary, on Friday to make one last plea. After Ms. Nielsen\u2019s decision was announced on Monday, Mr. S\u00e1nchez posted on Twitter, calling it an 18-month \u201cextension\u201d of T.P.S. The post prompted a flurry of angry replies accusing him of trying to spin the bad news.\n\nFlor Mejia, who works in a day care center on the outskirts of San Salvador, said her family gets by with the help of money sent regularly by her sister and brother-in-law, who recently bought a home and have two children born in the United States. Her parents live in Chalatenango, a rural province in the northern part of the country, and are subsistence farmers, growing corn and beans for the family\u2019s food supply.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s going to be very difficult for my parents, not having this income anymore,\u201d Ms. Mejia said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe United States Chamber of Commerce and immigrant advocacy organizations also had urged the administration to extend the protection, noting the Salvadorans\u2019 deep connections to America. According to an analysis by one group, the Center for Migration Studies, Salvadoran beneficiaries have 192,700 American-born children; 88 percent participate in the labor force, compared with 63 percent for the overall United States population; and nearly one-quarter have a mortgage.\n\nDonald M. Kerwin Jr., the center\u2019s executive director, called rescinding protection for Salvadorans a \u201cbaffling ideological decision that is extraordinarily destructive on all ends. They are deeply vested and embedded in the U.S.\u201d\n\nIn Houston, the elimination of protected status would aggravate a labor shortage already delaying repairs after Hurricane Harvey, said Stan Marek, the chief executive of Marek Brothers, a large construction company with offices across Texas and in Atlanta. At least 29 Salvadorans on his payroll are program recipients.\n\n\u201cDuring hurricane recovery, I especially need those men,\u201d Mr. Marek said. \u201cIf they lose their status, I have to terminate them.\u201d\n\nBut Mark Krikorian, executive director of the Center for Immigration Studies, which favors restrictions on immigration, said the Trump administration was correctly abiding by the original intent of the program.\n\n\u201cWe need to put the \u2018T\u2019 back into T.P.S.,\u201d he said. \u201cIt has to be temporary. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThis week, Sigal Mandelker, Treasury\u2019s under secretary for terrorism and financial intelligence, traveled to Asia to hold talks with officials in Beijing, Hong Kong, Tokyo and Seoul about ways to combat North Korea\u2019s illicit financing and money laundering practices. During a stop in Hong Kong on Wednesday, she urged the Chinese to do more to crack down on shell companies that North Koreans set up in other countries and use to evade sanctions.\n\nIn testimony before Congress last week, Ms. Mandelker noted that North Korea has been using cover representatives and front companies to hide and transfer funds that finance its weapons program.\n\nSanctions experts have suggested that the United States faces limited options targeting North Korea\u2019s illicit financing schemes because of the broad swath of sanctions that already have been imposed on the isolated Asian nation. The designation on Wednesday of two Chinese trading companies, Beijing Chengxing Trading Co. Ltd. and Dandong Jinxiang Trade Co., Ltd., signals that the Treasury Department is looking more broadly for ways to squeeze North Korea.\n\n\u201cThe Chinese trading companies that were targeted are the most interesting,\u201d said Mike Casey, a sanctions expert at the law firm Kirkland & Ellis International. \u201cEven though the U.S. hasn\u2019t been able to get a ton of direct economic pressure on North Korea, it certainly hasn\u2019t given up on exerting indirect economic pressure on North Korea.\u201d\n\nThe sanctions enable the United States to freeze the assets of the people or businesses that are designated and blocks Americans from doing business with them.\n\nOn Wednesday, Japan said that a military plane had spotted a North Korean tanker and a Dominican-registered tanker side by side in the East China Sea on Saturday, apparently transferring cargo. In his memo to United States attorneys, he called the earlier policy \u201cunnecessary\u201d and pointed to federal laws that \u201creflect Congress\u2019s determination that marijuana is a dangerous drug and that marijuana activity is a serious crime.\u201d\n\nDemocrats and some Republicans condemned the move. It was delivered to Congress last week in a funding request asking for $33 billion for border security over the next decade, including $18 billion for a nearly 1,000-mile wall on the Mexican border that President Trump has made a top priority to combat illegal immigration.\n\nThe department already has sweeping authority exempting it from a wide range of federal regulations that would otherwise limit its ability to build border fencing and access roads, or add sensors and cameras on land. It is unclear why the requested changes are needed, and a Customs and Border Security spokesman declined to discuss the proposal, \u201cas a matter of policy.\u201d\n\nThe budget document said the proposal would \u201cclarify and expand\u201d the Homeland Security secretary\u2019s authority to waive federal laws to quickly build border walls. He made them during a discussion of an emerging bipartisan deal to give legal status to immigrants illegally brought to the United States as children, those with knowledge of the conversation said, speaking on the condition of anonymity to discuss the meeting.\n\nWhen Mr. Trump heard that Haitians were among those who would benefit from the proposed deal, he asked whether they could be left out of the plan, asking, \u201cWhy do we want people from Haiti here?\u201d\n\nThe comments were reminiscent of ones the president made last year in an Oval Office meeting with cabinet officials and administration aides, during which he complained about admitting Haitians to the country, saying that they all had AIDS, as well as Nigerians, who he said would never go back to their \u201chuts,\u201d according to officials who heard the statements in person or were briefed on the remarks by people who had. The 90-minute session \u2014 more than half of which played out on national television \u2014 appeared to produce some progress: Mr. Trump agreed to a framework for a short-term immigration deal to couple protection for young, undocumented immigrants with border security.\n\nBut in suggesting that a broader immigration measure was possible next, Mr. Trump was giving a rare public glimpse of an impulse he has expressed privately to advisers and lawmakers \u2014 the desire to preside over a more far-reaching solution to the status of the 11 million undocumented immigrants already living and working in the United States. Passage of a comprehensive immigration law would give Mr. Trump success where Presidents Barack Obama and George W. Bush failed.\n\nThe push for an immigration deal with Democrats has the potential to alienate the hard-line anti-immigration activists who powered his political rise and helped him win the presidency, many of whom have described it as amnesty for lawbreakers. If he succeeds, it could be compared to Richard Nixon\u2019s historic trip to China. Only an anti-Communist hard-liner could have made the opening acceptable to his supporters.", "title": "Trump Appears to Endorse Path to Citizenship for Millions of Immigrants", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "The proposal follows a series of aggressive changes in posture at the agency since last fall, when Republicans gained a majority on the five-member board.\n\nIn early December, a mere two weeks into his tenure, Mr. Robb released a memo announcing the end of many of his predecessors\u2019 initiatives, including a campaign against employers who improperly classify workers as contractors, and featuring a long a list of hot-button issues on which regional directors were required to seek input from his office.\n\n\u201cNew general counsels will at some point signal cases they want to look at,\u201d said Wilma B. Liebman, a former chairwoman of the labor board. \u201cBut this was so sweeping and so fast that it was just kind of startling.\u201d\n\nThat same month, the agency overturned a key Obama-era ruling that had made it easier to hold companies responsible for labor-law violations at companies they do business with, such as franchisees and contractors.\n\nMr. Robb came to his position after a career largely spent representing management, including handling part of the Reagan administration\u2019s litigation against the air traffic controllers\u2019 union that waged an illegal strike in 1981. Most labor historians say the government\u2019s hard line in firing the controllers contributed to organized labor\u2019s decline in subsequent decades, said Joseph A. McCartin, a history professor at Georgetown University.\n\nThe labor board\u2019s general counsel is confirmed by the Senate. The counsel has independent authority as a prosecutor, derived from the National Labor Relations Act, and performs other duties on behalf of the agency\u2019s board, which acts as its highest court of appeals.\n\nDemoting the regional directors \u2014 there are 26, including two vacancies \u2014 and inserting a new group above them would most likely require board approval. The regional directors\u2019 account suggested that the new officials would probably be civil servants as well, rather than political appointees.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMichael J. Lotito, a lawyer with the management-side firm Littler Mendelson, who has discussed the proposal with officials at the agency, said they had assured him that it was largely a response to budget cuts reflecting a significant decline over several decades in the number of labor charges filed.\n\nHe said some of the savings could come from staff reductions among managers and supervisors at the regional offices, achieved in part through attrition.\n\nThe agency itself said that \u201cgiven budgetary issues, the general counsel is assessing the current organizational structure for possible changes,\u201d but added, \u201cNo specific plan involving the restructuring of our organization has been developed.\u201d\n\nMr. Robb\u2019s proposal was reported earlier by Bloomberg Law.\n\nLabor advocates and even management-side lawyers often praise the professionalism of the regional directors, but critics consider them too sympathetic to workers and unions.\n\n\u201cSome are way more ideologically pro-union than others, but they all tend to be fairly ideological,\u201d Mr. Lotito said. \u201cThe agency tends to promote \u2014 I think that it should \u2014 individuals who want to protect the rights of employees. But if you\u2019ve been doing that all your life, you can miss the rights of the employer.\u201d\n\nThe proposed changes appear consistent with a broader Trump administration suspicion of longtime civil servants. President Trump\u2019s former chief strategist, Steve Bannon, called for the \u201cdeconstruction of the administrative state.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nDuring the administration\u2019s first year, dozens of senior career officials resigned or retired from the State Department and the Environmental Protection Agency as many complained of being sidelined or ignored by political overseers.\n\nThe Interior Department reassigned a few dozen senior civil servants to posts that often made little use of their expertise. In one case, a top climate policy official was reassigned to the office that collects royalty payments from oil and gas companies. He quit not long after.\n\nAccording to the N.L.R.B. regional directors\u2019 letter, Mr. Robb said on the conference call on Jan. 11 that the changes were necessary and independent of budget considerations \u2014 implying a lack of confidence in the directors\u2019 ability to investigate and adjudicate allegations of labor-rights violations.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Robb, according to the letter, said the agency might hire a handful of district directors, each with authority over a portion of its 26 regions, and proposed lowering the regional directors\u2019 rank within the Civil Service.\n\nThe letter expressed concerns that Mr. Robb was intent on \u201cremoving many of the core responsibilities of the sitting regional directors,\u201d though it acknowledged that it was unclear how much authority he intended to shift to district directors, how many there would be, and whether any regional offices would be closed or consolidated.\n\nMr. Lotito, the management lawyer who has discussed the concept with agency officials, said the idea was to keep most or all of the regional offices in place and allow management and labor to appeal decisions to the district directors.\n\n\u201cThe regional directors are their own fiefdoms,\u201d he said. \u201cIf there was an ability to go to a district director, who oversees eight regions, chances are that would drive consistency.\u201d\n\nLike the civil servants who were reassigned at the Interior Department, the regional directors at the labor board are members of the Senior Executive Service, which was established by Congress in the late 1970s as an elite corps of executives who could be deployed to tackle the government\u2019s thorniest challenges.\n\nConservatives and some nonpartisan experts have complained that members of the Senior Executive Service are far less mobile than Congress envisioned, burrowing into particular agencies.\n\nBy proposing to downgrade the regional director positions into the ranks of standard government workers, where they would make less money and have narrower authority, Mr. Robb in some respects proposed going further than Interior Secretary Ryan Zinke, who reassigned Senior Executive Service members but preserved their status.\n\nThe changes proposed by Mr. Robb \u201cwould have a severe and negative impact on our agency and our stakeholders,\u201d the directors wrote.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWilliam Valdez, president of the association representing the senior executives, said the labor board could eliminate such positions, making the regional directors eligible for comparable jobs elsewhere in government, but could not demote them en masse. As a practical matter, he said, many of the regional directors may choose to reapply for their jobs at lower rank.\n\nEven many management-side lawyers consider the regional directors effective. \u201cSome people are better than other others, but I think the standards are pretty high,\u201d said Steven M. Swirsky, a former field lawyer for the labor board who has spent decades representing employers.\n\nAt a Jan. 19 meeting with an American Bar Association committee whose members represent both management and labor, Mr. Robb argued that the reaction to his proposal was overblown.\n\nAccording to someone familiar with the discussion, Mr. Robb acknowledged that he would need the approval of the agency\u2019s board for any changes, and he said he would seek public comment as well as input from the regional directors.\n\nIn the meantime, the letter from the regional directors indicates that many may take Mr. Robb\u2019s proposal as a cue to resign or retire, as some of their counterparts at the State Department, the Environmental Protection Agency and the Interior Department did.\n\n\u201cWe believe the changes you suggest, including the removal of directors from the Senior Executive Service, will cause senior directors and managers, whose institutional knowledge is a valuable asset to the agency, to retire sooner than they otherwise intended,\u201d the directors wrote to Mr. Robb. \u201cAs you can imagine, the information you provided to the regional directors has created much uncertainty and has disheartened us.\u201d", "title": "Trump Appointee Is Trying to Squelch Us, Labor Board Staff Says", "authors": ["Noam Scheiber"]} {"date": "2018-01-20 00:00:00", "text": "Most of Mr. Higbie\u2019s offensive comments, which were unearthed by CNN, were made in 2013 and 2014.\n\nWhile hosting an internet radio broadcast, \u201cSound of Freedom,\u201d in 2013, Mr. going to these people who think that breeding is a form of employment,\u201d CNN reported.\n\nMr. Higbie, 34, who is from Greenwich, Conn., said that at the time, he was trying to make a name for himself as a controversial radio host who taunted liberal guests and garnered ratings through \u201cshock and awe.\u201d\n\n\u201cI picked and prodded at every single guest I had in order to try to get a rise out of them,\u201d he said on Saturday. \u201cAnd it was just poor class.\u201d\n\nIn one \u201cSound of Freedom\u201d broadcast, Mr. Higbie said he opposed homosexuality in part because he was \u201cmolested by a gay guy\u201d when he was a child, CNN reported.\n\n\u201cSo I, I just, I really don\u2019t care for them,\u201d he said in 2013. \u201cYou know what, you want to be gay? I don\u2019t like them. Not that I hate them. I just didn\u2019t understand the ideology. And I was wrong to have that opinion.\u201d\n\nMr. Higbie also drew criticism in 2016, while serving as a spokesman for the pro-Trump group Great America PAC, when he said during an interview with Megyn Kelly on Fox News that there was \u201cprecedent\u201d for creating a registry for immigrants from Muslim countries, a proposal met with strong opposition by civil rights activists.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019ve done it based on race, we\u2019ve done it based on religion, we\u2019ve done it based on region,\u201d Mr. Higbie told Ms. Kelly. \u201cWe\u2019ve done it with Iran back \u2014 back a while ago. We did it during World War II with Japanese.\u201d\n\nHe later explained to The New York Times that he had been alluding to the United States Supreme Court, which had \u201cupheld things as horrific as Japanese internment camps.\u201d\n\nMr. Higbie is one of many White House officials who have resigned or were fired, dismissed or reassigned over the past year, including Stephen K. Bannon, Mr. Trump\u2019s chief strategist; Omarosa Manigault Newman, director of communications for the White House Office of Public Liaison; and Tom Price, the health and human services secretary.\n\nThe White House on Saturday confirmed that it had accepted Mr. Higbie\u2019s resignation but offered no additional comment.", "title": "Trump Appointee Resigns and Apologizes for Racist Comments", "authors": ["Christina Caron"]} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cOver the past year, we have made extraordinary strides in the United States,\u201d Mr. Trump said. \u201cAfter years of stagnation, the United States is once again experiencing strong economic growth.\u201d\n\nEconomists note that the American economy is into its ninth year of expansion, a trend that speaks to how the aftermath from the 2008 financial crisis has finally run its course. A surge of cash delivered by the Federal Reserve has stimulated commercial activity.\n\nThe International Monetary Fund this week lifted its forecasts for American growth in large part because of Mr. Trump\u2019s tax cuts. Economists note that the benefits fall overwhelmingly on corporations and wealthy American households, exacerbating economic inequality.\n\nVideo\n\nBut Mr. Trump framed the tax cuts as a broad source of what will be better days for all Americans. And he gained the unbridled endorsement from the man who heads the World Economic Forum, Klaus Schwab, whose eagerness to flatter his interlocutors is legendary.\n\n\u201cOn behalf of the business leaders here in this room let me particularly congratulate you for the historic tax reform,\u201d Mr. Schwab said, adding that the tax cuts were \u201cfostering job creation while providing a tremendous boost to the world economy.\u201d\n\nWhatever the optics of the head of an institution dedicated to reducing economic inequality offering his unqualified support for Mr. Trump\u2019s tax cuts, Mr. Schwab was indeed speaking for business.\n\nJeffrey Rosen, deputy chairman of the financial advisory firm Lazard, said: \u201cU.S. tax reform makes it more economic to do business in the United States. Deregulation makes it easier. These messages appear to be resonating with C.E.O.s of businesses outside the U.S.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nPrivately, corporate executives have continued to voice discomfort that the White House is under the control of a figure who, on any given day, can offend an entire continent of people, stoke worries of nuclear apocalypse or threaten to tear up a trade deal that is central to the global supply chain. But many departed Davos with an enhanced sense that there might be more method to Mr. Trump\u2019s fits of pique than they assumed.\n\nIn the days before Mr. Trump\u2019s arrival, European leaders, as well as India\u2019s prime minister, Narendra Modi, devoted speeches to mounting defenses of the global trading system in what resonated as an advance rebuttal of the American president.\n\nMany worried that Mr. Trump\u2019s attacks on the World Trade Organization, his threats to pull the United States out of the North American Free Trade Agreement and his frequent intonations of a trade war with China could undermine the global economic expansion.\n\nBut some European leaders suggested that Mr. Trump\u2019s bellicose rhetoric \u2014 so long as it does not seep into policy \u2014 could play a useful role in forcing countries that breach trading rules to take measures to restrain subsidies for favored industries.\n\nIn a briefing with reporters on Thursday, Cecilia Malmstrom, the European Union trade minister, expressed concerns about the Trump administration\u2019s threats of a trade war with China. But she added that Europe has its own problems with China and would welcome a chance to coordinate its response.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story The All-New DealBook Newsletter Our columnist Andrew Ross Sorkin and his Times colleagues help you make sense of major business and policy headlines \u2014 and the power-brokers who shape them. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cThere are some grave concerns on China, who are massively subsidizing state-owned companies,\u201d Ms. Malmstrom said. \u201cAnd there, yes, we could work with the U.S.\u201d\n\nOther European officials suggested that Mr. Trump\u2019s rhetoric might have the effect of pressuring China to roll back production of steel, alleviating a global glut that has depressed prices. It might spur China to limit subsidies for solar panels and other manufactured goods.\n\nOne senior German official noted that the president needed to be measured by his deeds, not just his words, adding that China is not the embodiment of free trade and that countries shouldn\u2019t necessary just accept what China does.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe director general of the World Trade Organization, Roberto Azev\u00eado, told reporters that he was focused on what actually emerged in the realm of trade policy, rather than worrying about every rhetorical volley.\n\n\u201cI haven\u2019t seen anything at this point that we are in a trade war,\u201d he said.\n\nThose inclined to the view that protectionism is an intensifying threat have pointed to the Trump administration\u2019s decision this week to slap punitive tariffs on imported solar panels and washing machines \u2014 a step that ratcheted up fears of a hostile Chinese response.\n\nThe World Trade Organization chief dismissed that view. \u201cThe tensions between the U.S. and China are not new,\u201d he said. \u201cThey have been there for some time.\u201d\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s reception here appeared to signal a normalizing phase of his presidency among the business elite. Many of those who absorbed his speech were struck by his restraint, his apparent desire to ingratiate himself.\n\n\u201cIt was not what people would have expected,\u201d said Ishmael Sunga, chief executive of the Southern Africa Confederation of Agricultural Unions, a trade group. \u201cHe made no controversial statements. He was talking to the crowd of people that he\u2019s been brought up to be part of.\u201d\n\nNot that the charm offensive worked on everyone.\n\nAs she departed Mr. Trump\u2019s speech, Lyn Cobley, chief executive of Westpac Institutional Bank, Australia\u2019s oldest bank, took home the message that the United States was eager for investment. But she could not shake her discomfort with the messenger.\n\n\u201cAs a female, the things we found out about him prior to his taking office, I find very disturbing,\u201d she said. \u201cIt was a very pro-business speech, but you\u2019re always left questioning his intent.\u201d", "title": "Trump Arrived in Davos as a Party Wrecker. He Leaves Praised as a Pragmatist.", "authors": ["Peter S. Goodman", "Keith Bradsher"]} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 Barely more than a week after boasting that he has a bigger nuclear button than Kim Jong-un, the North Korean leader, President Trump portrayed himself on Thursday as having good relations with the autocratic leader of the rogue nation.\n\n\u201cI probably have a very good relationship with Kim Jong-un,\u201d Mr. Trump told The Wall Street Journal in an interview. \u201cI have relationships with people. I think you people are surprised.\u201d\n\nMr. Trump declined to say whether he had directly spoken with his North Korean counterpart. \u201cI\u2019m not saying I have or haven\u2019t,\u201d he said.\n\nBut the rosy description of his relationship with the North Korean leader was another jarring reversal in tone from a president who has spoken admiringly of Mr. Kim in some moments and mocked him in others, referring to him as a fat \u201cLittle Rocket Man.\u201d", "title": "Trump Boasts of \u2018Very Good Relationship\u2019 With North Korean Leader", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-03 00:00:00", "text": "Cheering the breakup on Wednesday were establishment Republicans who resent Mr. Bannon\u2019s bomb-throwing style and his vows to wage war on incumbent lawmakers in the party primaries this year. Senate Republicans could barely contain their glee as they redistributed Mr. Trump\u2019s statement blasting Mr. Bannon with the note \u201cin case you missed it\u201d and a smiling face symbol. By afternoon, candidates whom Mr. Bannon has endorsed in a handful of races faced pressure to disavow his remarks about the president\u2019s son.\n\nAt the White House on Wednesday morning, aides who had kept a watchful eye on Mr. Bannon\u2019s efforts to make himself a kingmaker saw an opening to finally rid themselves of him. They encouraged the president to hit back publicly, and Mr. Trump went through at least three drafts of a statement with his communications director, Hope Hicks, and other aides before sending out a final version unlike any issued by a president against a top adviser in modern times.\n\n\u201cSteve pretends to be at war with the media, which he calls the opposition party, yet he spent his time at the White House leaking false information to the media to make himself seem far more important than he was,\u201d Mr. Trump said in the statement. \u201cIt is the only thing he does well. Steve was rarely in a one-on-one meeting with me and only pretends to have had influence to fool a few people with no access and no clue, whom he helped write phony books.\u201d\n\nA private lawyer representing Mr. Trump sent Mr. Bannon a letter on Wednesday directing him to cease and desist making derogatory comments about the president and his family and threatening a defamation lawsuit. \u201cLegal action is imminent,\u201d said the letter, first reported by ABC News and confirmed by a person close to the president.\n\nMr. Bannon declined to comment on Wednesday. But people close to him said that he believed that the president would eventually come around because Mr. Trump would need help with his base at a moment when his political muscle appeared to be on the wane. Mr. Bannon\u2019s Breitbart site reported the contretemps but did not return fire against Mr. Trump on Wednesday.\n\nThe president was responding to comments attributed to Mr. Bannon in a new book, \u201cFire and Fury: Inside the Trump White House,\u201d by Michael Wolff. The book, due out next Tuesday, was obtained by The Guardian, which first reported Mr. Bannon\u2019s remarks, and New York magazine then posted an excerpt. A copy of the book was later obtained by The New York Times.\n\nIn the book, Mr. Bannon was quoted suggesting that Donald Trump Jr.; Jared Kushner, his brother-in-law; and Paul Manafort, then the campaign chairman, had been \u201ctreasonous\u201d and \u201cunpatriotic\u201d for meeting with Russians after being promised incriminating information on Hillary Clinton during a June 2016 meeting at Trump Tower in Manhattan.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThe three senior guys in the campaign thought it was a good idea to meet with a foreign government inside Trump Tower in the conference room on the 25th floor \u2014 with no lawyers. They didn\u2019t have any lawyers,\u201d Mr. Bannon said after The Times revealed the meeting in July 2017, according to Mr. Wolff\u2019s book.\n\nRead Trump\u2019s Reaction to Steve Bannon\u2019s Comments\n\n\u201cEven if you thought that this was not treasonous, or unpatriotic, or bad shit, and I happen to think it\u2019s all of that, you should have called the F.B.I. immediately,\u201d Mr. Bannon continued, according to the book.\n\nHe also said that the chance that Donald Trump Jr. did not introduce the Russians to his father \u201cis zero,\u201d a supposition rather than an assertion but one that would contradict the president\u2019s insistence that he knew nothing about the meeting at the time.\n\nAccording to Mr. Wolff, Mr. Bannon also predicted that a special counsel investigation into Russia\u2019s interference in the 2016 election and any coordination with Trump aides would ultimately center on money laundering, an assessment that could lend credibility to an investigation the president has repeatedly called a witch hunt. \u201cThey\u2019re going to crack Don Jr. like an egg on national TV,\u201d Mr. Bannon was quoted as saying.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nDonald Trump Jr. did not immediately respond to a request for comment. But he jabbed at Mr. Bannon on Twitter on Wednesday when he reposted a message noting that Alabama now had a Democratic senator. \u201cThanks Steve,\u201d the younger Mr. Trump wrote. \u201cKeep up the great work.\u201d\n\nThe president and his advisers blamed Mr. Bannon for backing Roy S. Moore for the Republican nomination in Alabama and then pressing Mr. Trump into endorsing Mr. Moore even after he was accused of sexual misconduct with several women and girls as young as 14. Mr. Moore ended up losing last month, embarrassing Mr. Trump and souring his already complicated and strained relationship with Mr. Bannon.\n\nMr. Trump grew more upset about an interview Mr. Bannon gave to Vanity Fair that criticized Mr. Kushner\u2019s contacts with Russians. During his Christmas break in Florida, Mr. Trump stewed and consulted with aides and relatives, according to advisers, but ultimately opted against responding publicly to avoid drawing more attention to Mr. Bannon\u2019s remarks.\n\nBut accusing the president\u2019s eldest son of treason crossed the line. \u201cGoing after the president\u2019s son in an absolutely outrageous and unprecedented way is probably not the best way to curry favor with anybody,\u201d said Sarah Huckabee Sanders, the White House press secretary.\n\nThe book presents Mr. Trump as an ill-informed and thoroughly unserious candidate and president, engaged mainly in satisfying his own ego and presiding over a dysfunctional White House. It reports that early in the 2016 campaign, one aide, Sam Nunberg, was sent to explain the Constitution to the candidate. \u201cI got as far as the Fourth Amendment,\u201d it quotes Mr. Nunberg as saying, \u201cbefore his finger is pulling down on his lip and his eyes are rolling back in his head.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe book cites an email from an unnamed White House aide offering a harsh assessment of Mr. Trump\u2019s operation that was said to reflect the view of Gary D. Cohn, the president\u2019s national economics adviser: \u201cIt\u2019s worse than you can imagine. An idiot surrounded by clowns. Trump won\u2019t read anything \u2014 not one-page memos, not the brief policy papers; nothing. He gets up halfway through meetings with world leaders because he is bored.\u201d\n\nThe book also asserts that Mr. Cohn and other advisers and associates of Mr. Trump deride him in private, calling him an \u201cidiot,\u201d a \u201cdope\u201d or \u201cdumb\u201d as dirt. Thomas J. Barrack, a friend and adviser to Mr. Trump, was quoted telling a friend that the president is \u201cnot only crazy, he\u2019s stupid.\u201d\n\nReached by telephone on Wednesday, Mr. Barrack said that account was \u201ctotally false.\u201d Mr. Barrack added, \u201cIt\u2019s clear to anyone who knows me that those aren\u2019t my words and inconsistent with anything I\u2019ve ever said.\u201d He said that Mr. Wolff never ran that quotation by him to ask whether it was accurate.\n\nA longtime media columnist and author, Mr. Wolff brings a high profile, vivid writing style and years of experience but sometimes mixed reviews to the task of chronicling Mr. Trump\u2019s White House. Interview subjects have complained in the past that he took comments meant to be off the record and used them. In a 2004 profile, the journalist Michelle Cottle wrote that \u201cthe scenes in his columns aren\u2019t recreated so much as created \u2014 springing from Wolff\u2019s imagination rather than from actual knowledge of events.\u201d\n\nMr. Wolff clearly benefited from close cooperation from Mr. Bannon and the book is infused with his views. The author was frequently seen in Mr. Bannon\u2019s office while he was still working in the White House. According to Ms. Sanders, Mr. Wolff spoke with the president just once, for five to seven minutes, in the first month of the administration, when Mr. Trump called Mr. Wolff to thank him for his criticism of a Times article that the president did not like.\n\nGoing beyond the president\u2019s pushback on Mr. Bannon, Ms. Sanders attacked the book as a whole, hoping to discredit its reporting. Ms. Sanders released a statement calling it \u201ctrashy tabloid fiction\u201d that is \u201cfilled with false and misleading accounts from individuals who have no access or influence with the White House.\u201d\n\nMr. Wolff, responding by email, said he was \u201cwholly comfortable with my numerous sources.\u201d", "title": "Trump Breaks With Bannon, Saying He Has \u2018Lost His Mind\u2019", "authors": ["Peter Baker", "Maggie Haberman"]} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "Just 37 percent of Americans approve of the job he is doing, according to the latest survey by the Pew Research Center, lower than any modern president after a year in office and no better for all of his efforts. Forty-one percent think he will be an unsuccessful president, twice as many as last year and nearly twice as many as those who think he will be successful. Far fewer Americans think he keeps his promises than thought so when he was inaugurated.\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s outsize personality has so polarized the country that he may not be able to win over many converts easily, even with opportunities like a national television audience of tens of millions. His goal for the speech was to reach beyond his base and put forward a more optimistic, bipartisan face to a presidency that has been exceedingly divisive, but he has demonstrated before that such moments rarely last before he begins lobbing political artillery shells all over again.\n\n\u201cEvery major address like this is an opportunity for reset, but that is unlikely in this case and even more unlikely still given that it\u2019s an election year,\u201d said Lanhee J. Chen, a scholar at the Hoover Institution at Stanford who advised Mitt Romney\u2019s presidential campaign in 2012. \u201cThe current narrative, both for those who oppose the president and those who support him, has been established over the better part of two years \u2014 during a campaign and one year in office. It\u2019s hard to see that changing dramatically.\u201d\n\nMatt Latimer, a former speechwriter for President George W. Bush, said the effect of a State of the Union address could be overstated, especially if it was not followed up consistently, and Mr. Trump has shown little capacity for that. \u201cIf past history is any guide, the president will only bask in praise for so long before he demonstrates his self-destructive tendency to undo it all in the form of an avoidable controversy or an offensive tweet,\u201d he said.\n\nMr. Trump largely stuck to the script as he read from the teleprompters, hailing American successes in fighting the Islamic State, challenging the nuclear aspirations of North Korea and calling for bipartisan deals on immigration and infrastructure. Unlike other presidents, who used this platform to unveil a fresh legislative agenda, Mr. Trump offered little new in the way of policy proposals.", "title": "Trump Can Sell an Improved Economy, but Not Himself", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-15 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThe appropriate word to describe their reactions to the president\u2019s comments is fury,\u201d he said, \u201cnotwithstanding the fact that the president has said that he didn\u2019t say what was attributed to him. To have insulted an entire continent in the most vile terms is manifestly harmful to our interests.\u201d\n\nPatrick Gaspard, the United States ambassador to South Africa from 2013 to 2016, said that progress on trade, public health, security and education, among many areas, had been \u201cthrown into question by the irresponsible and vulgar comments made by the president.\u201d\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s long history of racially insensitive or insulting comments include several that have rankled Africans: Last June, he mused that Nigerians in the United States would not \u201cgo back to their huts\u201d in Africa, and he told African leaders in September: \u201cI have so many friends going to your countries trying to get rich,\u201d a comment that critics said smacked of colonialism.", "title": "Trump Comments, Infuriating Africans, May Set Back U.S. Interests", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "They can be hard to spot \u2014 let alone take at face value \u2014 amid the usual spray of insults and bombast, but every now and then President Trump emits a sensible idea.\n\nMr. Trump offered at least the appearance of such an idea when he strode into the White House briefing room late Wednesday and announced that he was open to a multiyear path to citizenship for the so-called Dreamers, about 700,000 immigrants brought to the United States illegally as children and granted protection from deportation by President Barack Obama. His words sent his surprised staff scrambling and heartened Democrats who have been seeking a just solution for these young people.\n\nBut the price of the offer became clear Thursday afternoon, when White House officials said that citizenship for the Dreamers, and about 1.1 million other young immigrants who could qualify for the status but didn\u2019t apply, would come only as part of a bargain that included an additional $25 billion for border security and a crackdown on legal immigrants, including family members of those already in the United States.\n\nMr. Trump, who canceled the Dreamers\u2019 protection in September, has professed his \u201clove\u201d for them, but the real policy is being made by hard-liners in the White House.", "title": "Opinion | Trump Dangles Hope for Dreamers", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "The president \u2014 who never likes it when someone characterizes his thinking \u2014 vented his anger to Mr. Kelly and to allies, according to the person familiar with the president\u2019s thinking. It was similar to a moment during the campaign in April of 2016, when Paul Manafort \u2014 who had just been hired to the Trump campaign \u2014 was caught on tape at a meeting with Republican National Committee members saying of Mr. Trump, \u201cthe part he\u2019s been playing is evolving.\u201d\n\nWhen a president\u2019s chief of staff speaks to members of Congress, it should be a \u201cconsistent message,\u201d Representative Henry Cuellar, a Democrat of Texas, said on Thursday in an interview with CNN. Mr. Cuellar, who attended Wednesday\u2019s meeting with Mr. Kelly, said the inconsistency \u201cmakes it hard\u201d to negotiate.\n\nLawmakers who attended the meeting on Wednesday described Mr. Kelly\u2019s remarks. Representative Luis V. Guti\u00e9rrez, a Democrat of Illinois who was at the meeting, said Mr. Kelly told the group that \u201ca 50-foot wall from sea to shining sea isn\u2019t what we\u2019re going to build.\u201d\n\nMr. Guti\u00e9rrez told reporters that Mr. Kelly referenced Mr. Trump\u2019s campaign promises to build a wall and said, \u201cThere were statements made about the wall that were not informed statements.\u201d\n\nIn an interview with Fox News on Wednesday night, Mr. Kelly defended his comments to the Democratic lawmakers and said, \u201cThere\u2019s been an evolutionary process that this president has gone through, as a campaign, and I pointed out to all of the members that were in the room that they all say things during the course of campaigns that may or may not be fully informed.\u201d\n\nMr. Kelly also said the president has \u201cevolved in the way he\u2019s looked at things,\u201d in reference to what should constitute a wall along the southern border.\n\nCongress is currently working on a deal that would protect some 780,000 young immigrants from deportation. During the meeting on Wednesday, Mr. Kelly relayed confidence that negotiations would move forward for a permanent solution to preserve protections under the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals program, or DACA, the Obama-era policy that Mr. Trump moved in September to end.", "title": "Trump Denies Changing His Position on Border Wall", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-03 00:00:00", "text": "But Mr. Kobach insisted in an interview that the commission\u2019s work would not end but rather would be transferred to the Department of Homeland Security, one of the federal agencies charged with ensuring election integrity and one that he said critics would find more difficult to target.\n\nAs a White House commission, the voter-fraud panel was subject to public-disclosure requirements and other restrictions that Mr. Kobach said opponents of the inquiry had seized on in \u201ca determined effort by the left\u201d to hamstring its investigation. At last count, he said, the panel faced at least eight lawsuits accusing it of ignoring various federal requirements, including one from a commission member, Matthew Dunlap, the Maine secretary of state, that claimed he had been illegally excluded from its deliberations.\n\n\u201cIt got to the point where the staff of the commission was spending more time responding to litigation than doing an investigation,\u201d Mr. Kobach said. \u201cThink of it as an option play; a decision was made in the middle of the day to pass the ball. The Department of Homeland Security is going to be able to move faster and more efficiently than a presidential advisory commission.\u201d\n\nA spokesman for homeland security, Tyler Q. Houlton, said on Wednesday that \u201cthe department continues to focus our efforts on securing elections against those who seek to undermine the election system or its integrity.\u201d\n\n\u201cWe will do this in support of state governments who are responsible for administering elections,\u201d he added.\n\nBut states may well not cooperate with the department any more than they did with the panel.\n\nAs a first step, Mr. Kobach, who said he would remain as an informal adviser to homeland security, said the department would marshal its files on immigrants, legal and otherwise, so that they can be matched with lists of registered voters nationwide to detect foreign citizens who are illegally casting ballots in American elections. Both Mr. Trump and Mr. Kobach have insisted that voting by noncitizens is endemic \u2014 Mr. Trump falsely claimed that millions of illegal voters cost him a popular-vote victory in 2016 \u2014 but investigations, including ones by Mr. Kobach and the Justice Department under President George W. Bush, turned up scant evidence of fraud.\n\nMany Democratic secretaries of state had said they believed the commission had a goal of laying the groundwork for restrictions that will mostly make it harder for traditional Democratic constituencies \u2014 minorities, young people and the poor \u2014 to cast ballots, which would benefit Republican candidates.", "title": "Trump Disbands Commission on Voter Fraud", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "Longtime Miami residents kept their distance from the newcomers who spoke Creole and sometimes mixed in voodoo rituals with Catholicism. Native-born Miamians would sometimes describe a person with psychiatric problems as \u201cacting Haitian.\u201d\n\nMany Haitian immigrants and their descendants contend they are still treated worse than other groups. Still, they can also point to achievements in an array of realms, having emerged as a crucial source of remittances for the Haitian economy and a constituency to be courted in American elections for both Democrats and Republicans.\n\nDuring the 2016 campaign, Mr. Trump himself visited Miami\u2019s Little Haiti, a bastion of the Haitian community, in which he told the small gathering, \u201cI really want to be your biggest champion.\u201d\n\nGeorges Sami Saati, 65, a Haitian-American businessman and Republican who was in the crowd to greet Mr. Trump that day, said he remained in the president\u2019s camp, emphasizing the president\u2019s capacity for \u201cstraight talk.\u201d\n\n\u201cLook, I don\u2019t agree with 100 percent of what Trump says,\u201d said Mr. Saati, adding that his comments on Haiti \u201care something that many people say every day.\u201d\n\nStill, with Haitian-American politicians wielding greater influence in South Florida than ever, political leaders in the community, which is heavily Democratic, are forging strategies to counter what they view as the Trump administration\u2019s hostility toward them.\n\nThey point to the administration\u2019s move in November to end a humanitarian program allowing more than 45,000 Haitians to live and work in the United States since Haiti\u2019s 2010 earthquake; a December report that Mr. Trump said that Haitians \u201call have AIDS\u201d; and just this week, the removal of Haiti\u2019s eligibility for a small number of temporary visas to do agricultural or seasonal work. Among other reasons for the decision, the administration cited Haitians\u2019 history of overstaying their visas.", "title": "Trump Disparaged Their Home Country. Here\u2019s What Miami\u2019s Haitians Think.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "The officials who discussed the proposal did so on condition of anonymity because they were not authorized to discuss it in draft form. Though budget plans can change, the officials said the A.T.F. language has remained in place through multiple revisions.\n\nA spokesman for the A.T.F. did not immediately comment. A Treasury Department spokesman did not respond to messages for comment.\n\nThe peculiar division in tobacco enforcement began in the aftermath of the Sept. 11 attacks, when Congress moved the A.T.F. from the Treasury Department to the Justice Department. It seemed a logical move, given the A.T.F.\u2019s criminal justice focus. But A.T.F. at the time was also the government\u2019s lead tobacco and alcohol regulator, a mission that made no sense for the Justice Department.\n\nSo Congress told Treasury to keep its authority to regulate alcohol and tobacco. That left the question of who would investigate smuggling. And Treasury had just lost all of its agents.\n\n\u201cThere was some discussion about leaving alcohol and tobacco criminal enforcement in the Treasury at the time, but there wasn\u2019t anybody who had the ability to investigate,\u201d said Bradley A. Buckles, who served as director of the A.T.F. under Presidents Bill Clinton and George W. Bush and oversaw the transition. \u201cTreasury wasn\u2019t interested in building up a new criminal investigative function. I think they were happy to let it all go.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAt the heart of the proposal is cigarette smuggling, a venture that becomes more lucrative with every tax increase. Cigarette taxes vary wildly. Virginia charges $3 per carton. New York charges $43.50. A simple plot to buy cigarettes in one state and sell them in another can generate tens of thousands of dollars. Criminal organizations rely on more complicated schemes to move untaxed cigarettes in bulk, evading federal and state taxes. By some estimates, more than half of New York\u2019s cigarettes come from the black market.\n\nThe A.T.F. once made tobacco investigations a priority, with ruinous results. The New York Times revealed last year that one major investigation spawned a multimillion-dollar slush fund for agents to tap for both business and personal expenses. An inspector general report in 2013 also found widespread mismanagement in tobacco enforcement operations. Since then, the A.T.F. has redirected all but a tiny amount of its tobacco enforcement budget to fighting violent crime.\n\nThe Trump administration has called on the A.T.F. to lead its crackdown on gun violence and criminal networks. The White House dispatched an A.T.F. task force to Chicago last summer to combat violence, and the bureau has been at the forefront of efforts to dismantle gangs like MS-13.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAlcohol and tobacco enforcement is now regarded by many agents as a backwater. \u201cIt\u2019s a big part of the name, but a very little part of the resource expenditure,\u201d said Mr. Buckles.\n\nThe A.T.F.\u2019s 2018 funding request, which has still not been passed, describes an agency on the cusp of financial crisis, unable to keep up with demands and starved for critical resources. Agents are unlikely to mourn the loss of tobacco enforcement, said Michael Bouchard, a former agent and president of the A.T.F. Association, an unaffiliated group that supports current and former bureau officials.\n\n\u201cViolent crime is the biggest priority and always has been,\u201d he said. \u201cIf it\u2019s going to make it a more focused mission, then they\u2019ll probably look at that as a plus.\u201d\n\nWith billions of dollars in tax revenue being lost to smuggling each year, preliminary discussions about restoring the old authority began last year at Treasury. Senior A.T.F. officials supported the idea, the two administration officials recalled.\n\nIt is not clear what would happen to the small number of A.T.F. agents assigned to investigate tobacco and alcohol smuggling. One official said the agents would likely be reassigned to investigate violent crime. As drafted, the plan envisions Treasury hiring its own investigators \u2014 a modest staffing increase of about a few dozen people in an agency with more than 100,000 employees.\n\nThe Justice Department\u2019s inspector general and a congressional oversight committee are investigating mismanagement and abuse in A.T.F. cigarette investigations. Records show that, in one case, a pair of informants received $6 million each and agents spent freely from an unofficial account. One agent steered hundreds of thousands of dollars in real estate, electronics and money to his church and his children\u2019s sports teams.", "title": "Trump Envisions an A.T.F. Without the A or T", "authors": ["Ali Watkins", "Matt Apuzzo"]} {"date": "2018-01-14 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nPALM BEACH, Fla. \u2014 President Trump on Sunday morning ratcheted up a dispute with The Wall Street Journal, accusing the newspaper of purposely misquoting him as saying in an interview that he has a good relationship with the leader of North Korea.\n\nIn two tweets from his Mar-a-Lago estate in Palm Beach, Fla., the president applied a familiar denigrating term \u2014 \u201cfake news\u201d \u2014 to a Journal report on Thursday that said Mr. Trump had boasted during an interview: \u201cI probably have a very good relationship with Kim Jong-un. I have relationships with people. I think you people are surprised.\u201d\n\nMr. Trump insisted that he had actually started his sentence with the contraction \u201cI\u2019d,\u201d not \u201cI,\u201d which would change the meaning from a surprising boast of an existing relationship into a prediction that he could have a good relationship with the dictator if he wanted it.\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s attack came hours after Sarah Huckabee Sanders, the White House press secretary, posted on Twitter what she called the \u201cofficial audio showing WSJ misquoting @POTUS.\u201d She also posted an image with the words \u201cFAKE NEWS\u201d in a bright red banner and saying: \u201cTHE WALL STREET JOURNAL. FAKE NEWS IS AT IT AGAIN. FALSELY QUOTING PRESIDENT TRUMP.\u201d\n\nLater on Sunday, Ms. Sanders wrote on Twitter that the White House had first requested a correction from The Journal on Friday morning, the day after the interview.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Get the Morning Briefing by Email What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox Monday through Friday. Shear"]} {"date": "2018-01-17 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cBelieve it or not, through all this negative coverage, they did a survey of 600,000 people about how black America views this president. His numbers have actually doubled,\u201d Brian Kilmeade, a \u201cFox & Friends\u201d host, said during the segment that was broadcast Tuesday morning.\n\nMr. Kilmeade was almost certainly referring to a distorted finding from SurveyMonkey, an online polling company. Since Mr. Trump\u2019s inauguration, the company has conducted 602,134 interviews with adults of every race group \u2014 not just \u201cblack America,\u201d as Mr. Kilmeade said.\n\nSurveyMonkey\u2019s results, provided to The New York Times, show that Mr. Trump\u2019s approval ratings among black Americans actually declined from 20 percent in February 2017, his first full month in office, to 15 percent in December. (This is consistent with polling from the Pew Research Center and Reuters.)\n\nHow did Mr. Kilmeade and, by extension, Mr. Trump arrive at his approval doubling among black Americans?\n\nSurveyMonkey broke out some of the results for The Atlantic, telling the magazine in a report that was published last week that 23 percent of black men and 11 percent of black women approved of Mr. Trump\u2019s performance.\n\nBreitbart News followed with its own report on Sunday, comparing the SurveyMonkey results with exit polls from the 2016 presidential campaign.", "title": "Trump Falsely Claims His Approval Among Black Americans Has Doubled", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "Eric D. Hargan, the acting secretary of health and human services, said that the creation of the new civil rights unit carried out an executive order issued last year by Mr. Trump, who said that religious people would no longer be \u201cbullied by the federal government because of their religious beliefs.\u201d\n\nMr. Severino said that several federal laws protected the \u201cconscience rights\u201d of health care providers, and he reported that complaints of violations had increased significantly since Mr. Trump was elected. From 2008 to October 2016, the civil rights office received 10 complaints, Mr. Severino said, and since the election it has received 34.\n\nFor too long, Mr. Severino said, the federal government has ignored such complaints or treated them with \u201coutright hostility.\u201d\n\nThe administration is drafting rules to define the circumstances in which health care workers could refuse to provide services to which they had religious or moral objections.\n\nThe department\u2019s announcement was greeted with alarm and applause, a testament to the divisions over the hot-button social issues of abortion, gender and sexual identity.\n\nSocial conservatives said the new unit would be a bulwark of religious liberty.\n\n\u201cPresident Trump\u2019s promises are becoming a reality,\u201d said Tony Perkins, the president of the Family Research Council. \u201cAmericans should not be forced to choose between their faith and their desire to help patients.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Get the Morning Briefing by Email What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox Monday through Friday.
