Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nCritics said the administration was giving health care providers a license to discriminate and raised the possibility that some doctors might deny fertility treatments to lesbian couples and that some pharmacists might refuse to fill prescriptions for certain types of contraceptives. In such situations, they said, patients could suffer, and health care workers could violate professional or ethical obligations.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nDr. Hal C. Lawrence III, the chief executive of the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists, said the government should be helping women get the care they need, not putting up new impediments.\n\n\u201cNo individual, employer, politician or entity should be given legal cover to deny a patient needed medical care,\u201d Dr. Lawrence said.\n\nThe White House\u2019s efforts to appeal to the religious right appear to have given Mr. Trump a thick insulation from the scandals that might otherwise undermine his support among churchgoing conservatives, like the recent allegations that he cheated on his wife with a pornographic film actress who was reportedly paid $130,000 in hush money shortly before the 2016 election.\n\nIn recent months, Mr. Trump has ordered the Pentagon to stop accepting transgender people in the armed services, announced his intention to move the United States Embassy in Israel to Jerusalem and released a revised shortlist of potential nominees to a future Supreme Court vacancy that included the addition of five conservative judges.\n\nIf the report involving the actress bothered religious conservatives, most were keeping quiet.\n\n\u201cWe continue to support him because he is doing what he promised he would do,\u201d said Richard Land, the president of the Southern Evangelical Seminary. \u201cThat does not mean we endorse everything he does.\u201d\n\nA few evangelical Christians warned that Mr. Trump was making their entire movement look like fools.\n\nWriting on his website this week, the blogger and radio host Erick Erickson said, \u201cIt is harder and harder to champion a sound policy, like tax reform, regulatory reform, or even some stellar judicial picks because they are all tainted by the man whose signature is on the paperwork.\u201d\n\n\u201cOur increasing national affection for cults of personality will affect the conservative agenda moving forward on issues like life, the Second Amendment, and individualism itself,\u201d Mr. Erickson added. \u201cAs the president wraps himself in those issues, many Americans will connect them to the farce.\u201d\n\nOutside the religious conservative movement, the recent moves have won little applause.\n\nFatima Goss Graves, the president of the National Women\u2019s Law Center, a research and advocacy group, said that, far from protecting religious liberty, the new unit would protect health workers who \u201cuse their religious or moral beliefs to deny patients care.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nRachel B. Tiven, the chief executive of Lambda Legal, a gay rights group, said the new initiative could lead to an increase in discrimination against lesbians, gay men, bisexuals and transgender people. Discrimination, she said, is already widespread, as \u201cL.G.B.T. people have been turned away from hospitals and doctors\u2019 offices.\u201d\n\nAs a presidential candidate, Mr. Trump expressed strong support for religious groups like the Little Sisters of the Poor, who challenged Obama administration policies that generally required employers to provide insurance coverage of birth control for women.\n\nIn October, the Trump administration issued rules allowing many employers to opt out of providing such coverage if they had religious or moral objections. But in December, two Federal District Court judges blocked the rules, saying they were inconsistent with the Affordable Care Act.", "title": "Trump Gives Health Workers New Religious Liberty Protections", "authors": ["Robert Pear", "Jeremy W. Peters"]} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "On the same day it was reported that the C.I.A. director, Mike Pompeo, had said he expected Russia to meddle in the 2018 midterm elections, the Trump administration failed to fulfill a congressional mandate to punish Russia for its meddling in the 2016 election.\n\nBoth houses of Congress almost unanimously approved legislation last year requiring more sanctions against Russia, and those who do business with Russia, in response to the hacking and disinformation campaign with which American intelligence agencies say Moscow sought to swing the election to Donald Trump. But in an announcement Monday night, the administration ignored the law\u2019s core intent.\n\nWhile the law has been in effect for six months, not one new sanction has been imposed even as Russia has continued to interfere in democratic institutions here and abroad.\n\nThe law was forced on Mr. Trump because he not only refused to punish the Russians, he refused then and refuses now to even acknowledge the Russian role in this assault on the American democratic process. Heck, the head of Russian foreign intelligence met with administration officials outside Washington last week even though he is under sanctions, according to the Senate minority leader, Chuck Schumer. How does that happen?", "title": "Opinion | Trump Gives Putin a Pass for Trashing American Democracy", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "The America First groups have been viewed as something of an enigma in campaign finance circles. While many of the Republican Party\u2019s traditional elite donors have publicly kept their distance from the groups, the organizations have the blessing of the administration and have projected confidence in their fund-raising.\n\nBut Republican operatives have grumbled that the amount the groups say they have raised have dwarfed the amount they have spent to support Mr. Trump\u2019s political and policy goals during his first year in office.\n\nReports filed with the election commission show that the groups combined to spend about $3.2 million \u2014 just over 10 percent of what they raised \u2014 supporting Republican candidates in special elections, including former Senator Luther Strange and Roy S. Moore, who lost their bids for an Alabama Senate seat, and Karen Handel, who won her House campaign in Georgia.\n\nFigures provided by a Republican ad buyer indicate that the groups spent an additional $2.8 million on television ads promoting efforts championed by Mr. Trump to overhaul the tax code and repeal the Affordable Care Act, though there were no records of television ad spending by the groups since the passage last month of the tax overhaul. Other Republican groups have been advertising heavily this year to bolster public approval of the tax overhaul, which is considered critical to the party\u2019s midterm election prospects this year.\n\nPhoto\n\nBrian O. Walsh, the president of America First Policies, said the group had paid for online ads \u201chighlighting President Trump\u2019s leadership on key issues.\u201d Those ads can be harder to track, and Mr. Walsh declined to provide an \u201citem-by-item breakdown at this time.\u201d\n\nA person close to the groups told Axios that they had $14 million in the bank headed into this year, which could provide the basis for a major midterm election campaign.\n\nBut very few of the party\u2019s elite donors were listed among the contributors to America First Action in the report filed on Wednesday with the election commission.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nBy far the biggest donor was the Los Angeles developer Geoffrey H. Palmer, who donated $2 million of the $3.7 million raised in the second half of the year by America First Action. Mr. Palmer donated generously in 2016, giving $3 million to a different super PAC that supported Mr. Trump, and an additional $310,000 to a committee associated with Mr. Trump\u2019s campaign.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAn additional $1 million came from Murray Energy, a coal company based in Ohio that has assiduously courted Mr. Trump as it pressed the new administration to repeal President Barack Obama\u2019s climate change policies intended to shut down old coal-burning power plants. The company had previously donated a combined $550,000 to help fund the Republican convention in Cleveland and Mr. Trump\u2019s inauguration.\n\nIn the weeks after Mr. Trump\u2019s inauguration, Murray\u2019s chief executive officer, Robert E. Murray, wrote confidential memos to Vice President Mike Pence and the energy secretary, Rick Perry, laying out a wish list of environmental rollbacks, which he discussed in a meeting with Mr. Perry. The administration is on track to fulfill many of the items on Mr. Murray\u2019s list.\n\nMurray Energy\u2019s donation to America First Action came about five months after Mr. Murray\u2019s meeting with Mr. Perry. Asked whether there was any connection between the donation and the administration\u2019s receptiveness to Mr. Murray, Gary M. Broadbent, a spokesman for Murray Energy, said that \u201cPresident Trump and his administration have always supported the United States coal industry.\u201d\n\nAmerica First Action has spent heavily to try to court other major donors, as well, paying consultants with significant fund-raising experience, including Cara Mason, the former finance director of the Republican National Committee, and Marty Obst, a longtime aide and current policy adviser to Mr. Pence. Their respective firms were paid $60,000 each in the second half of last year by America First Action.\n\nThe super PAC hosted a Christmas party for donors at the Trump International Hotel, which has emerged as a go-to destination for donors and others seeking to rub elbows with Trump family members and insiders. The party was attended by Mr. Pence, as well as Trump family members and several members of Congress. In addition, America First Action spent more than $57,000 on gifts for donors at upscale jewelry stores, the White House Historical Association and 800-CEO-READ, a company that sells bulk orders of books about business, including many of Mr. Trump\u2019s titles.\n\nThe super PAC also paid $55,000 to a firm owned by Mr. Lewandowski, $40,000 to one owned by Ms. Pierson and $137,000 to one owned by Mr. Parscale. He is in charge of digital outreach for America First Action and Mr. Trump\u2019s campaign, and it is possible that his firm is using the money it received from the PAC to buy digital advertising. Vogel", "Rachel Shorey"]} {"date": "2018-01-17 00:00:00", "text": "Taken as a whole, Mr. Trump\u2019s examples of grievances came as no surprise to anyone who has read his complaints about the media on Twitter.\n\nThe various reports singled out by Mr. Trump touched on serious issues, like the media\u2019s handling of the investigation by the special counsel Robert S. Mueller III into the Trump campaign\u2019s possible ties to Russia, and frivolous matters, like the manner in which journalists conveyed how the president fed fish during a stop at a koi pond on his visit to Japan.\n\nThe first item on the list referred not to a news article but to a short opinion piece posted on The Times\u2019s website at 12:42 on the night Mr. Trump became president: \u201cThe New York Times\u2019 Paul Krugman claimed on the day of President Trump\u2019s historic, landslide victory that the economy will \u2018never\u2019 recover,\u201d the entry read.\n\nWhat Mr. Krugman actually wrote was this: \u201cIf the question is when markets will recover, a first-pass answer is never.\u201d Mr. Krugman concluded his election night take by predicting that a global recession was likely, while adding the caveat, \u201cI suppose we could get lucky somehow.\u201d\n\nThree days later, Mr. Krugman retracted his prediction of an economic collapse, saying he overreacted.\n\nThe next target was Brian Ross of ABC News, who was suspended by the network last month because of an erroneous report.\n\nPhoto\n\nABC apologized for and corrected Mr. Ross\u2019s report that Michael T. Flynn, the former national security adviser, planned to testify that Mr. Trump had directed him to make contact with Russian officials when Mr. Trump was still a candidate.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn fact, Mr. Trump had directed Mr. Flynn to make contact after the election, when he was president-elect.\n\nAt the time of Mr. Ross\u2019s suspension, Kathleen Culver, the director of the Center for Journalism Ethics at the University of Wisconsin-Madison, said that the president was likely to use the mistake as ammunition against his political opponents \u2014 an observation that seemed borne out by the \u201cFake News Awards.\u201d\n\nThe third entry on the GOP.com list went after CNN, a favorite target of the president, for reporting incorrectly last month that the president\u2019s eldest child, Donald Trump Jr., had received advance notice from WikiLeaks about a trove of hacked documents that it planned to release during last year\u2019s presidential campaign.\n\nIn fact, the email to the younger Mr. Trump was sent a day after the documents, stolen from the Democratic National Committee, were made available to the general public. The correction undercut the main thrust of CNN\u2019s story, which had been seized on by critics of the president as evidence of coordination between WikiLeaks and the Trump campaign.\n\nAnother entry on the list took on The Washington Post, claiming that it had \u201cFALSELY reported the President\u2019s massive sold-out rally in Pensacola, Florida was empty. Dishonest reporter showed picture of empty arena HOURS before crowd started pouring in.\u201d\n\nThe reporter in question was David Weigel, who had posted the photo in question on his Twitter account before quickly deleting it. The Post itself did not publish the photo or a report on the size of the crowd at the Trump event. The \u201cFake News Awards\u201d entry, however, conflated a reporter\u2019s tweet with the publication itself. It also omitted the fact that Mr. Weigel deleted his tweet and apologized for it when it was pointed out to him that it was misleading. Further, it did not mention that Mr. Trump had called for Mr. Weigel to be fired over the tweet. (He was not.)\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe content of the 11-point list was perhaps less notable than its premise: a sitting president using his bully pulpit for a semi-formalized attack on the free press.\n\nIn two subsequent tweets on Wednesday night, Mr. Trump added that there were \u201cmany great reporters I respect\u201d and defended his administration\u2019s record in the face of \u201ca very biased media.\u201d\n\nThe technical anticlimax seemed a fitting end to a peculiar saga that began in November when Mr. Trump floated the bestowing of a \u201cFAKE NEWS TROPHY.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe idea matured into the \u201cFake News Awards,\u201d which the president initially said in a Jan. 2 Twitter post he would give out on Jan. 8 to honor \u201cthe most corrupt & biased of the Mainstream Media.\u201d\n\nWith the date approaching, Mr. Trump wrote on Twitter that the event would be moved to Wednesday because \u201cthe interest in, and importance of, these awards is far greater than anyone could have anticipated!\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nFrom the beginning, the awards were the sort of Trumpian production that seemed easy to mock but difficult to ignore. Members of the news media joked about the speeches they would prepare, the tuxedos and gowns they would fetch. It would be an honor, they said, just to be nominated.\n\n\n\nHere, it seemed, was the op\u00e9ra bouffe climax of Mr. Trump\u2019s campaign against the media, a bizarro-world spectacle that both encapsulated and parodied the president\u2019s animus toward a major democratic institution.\n\nLate-night comedy shows created satirical Emmys-style advertising campaigns to snag what some referred to as a coveted \u201cFakey.\u201d\n\n\u201cThe Late Show With Stephen Colbert\u201d bought a billboard in Times Square, nominating itself in categories like \u201cLeast Breitbarty\u201d and \u201cCorruptest Fakeness.\u201d Jimmy Kimmel, who has emerged as a Trump b\u00eate noire, called it \u201cthe Stupid People\u2019s Choice Awards.\u201d\n\nPolitico reported that the awards could even pose an ethical issue for White House aides, with some experts arguing that the event would breach a ban on government officials using their office to explicitly promote or deride private organizations.\n\nAnd press advocates cringed at the prospect of a gala dedicated to the phrase \u201cfake news,\u201d which has already helped corrode trust in journalism in the United States and around the world. In response to Mr. Trump\u2019s endeavor, the Committee to Protect Journalists this month recognized the president among the \u201cworld leaders who have gone out of their way to attack the press and undermine the norms that support freedom of the media.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nTwo Republicans from Arizona, Senator John McCain and Senator Jeff Flake, denounced Mr. Trump\u2019s anti-press attacks, with Mr. Flake noting in a speech on the Senate floor on Wednesday that the president had borrowed a term from Stalin to describe the media: \u201cenemy of the people.\u201d\n\nThe buzz around the president\u2019s latest anti-press stunt has contributed to a larger shift in American attitudes toward the press.\n\nIn a study released this week by Gallup and the Knight Foundation, 66 percent of Americans who were surveyed said most news organizations blurred opinion and fact, up from 42 percent in 1984. \u201cFake news\u201d was deemed a threat to democracy by a majority of respondents.\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s list did not mention BuzzFeed, a media outlet that drew his ire last year when it published a salacious and largely unsubstantiated intelligence dossier that purported to lay out how Russia had aided the Trump campaign. On Jan. 8, President Trump\u2019s longtime lawyer, Michael D. Cohen, filed a defamation lawsuit in federal court against Fusion GPS, the firm behind the report, as well as a separate lawsuit against BuzzFeed in state court.\n\nMr. Trump also did not mention Michael Wolff, the author of the slashing, if error-specked, best seller, \u201cFire and Fury: Inside the Trump White House,\u201d although a lawyer working on his behalf had sent a letter demanding that the publisher Henry Holt and Company halt publication of the book.\n\n\u201cFire and Fury\u201d did not come out until Jan. 5, so perhaps the author will receive a prominent mention next January, if the president sees fit to give out the 2018 Fake News Awards.", "title": "Trump Hands Out \u2018Fake News Awards,\u2019 Sans the Red Carpet", "authors": ["Matt Flegenheimer", "Michael M. Grynbaum"]} {"date": "2018-01-16 00:00:00", "text": "But he did say that Mr. Trump\u2019s weight is 239 pounds and that he is too sedentary. His cholesterol is too high, despite medicine to lower it, and Dr. Jackson said Mr. Trump would be increasing the 10-milligram dosage of Crestor to better control it.\n\nAt 6 feet 3 inches tall, Mr. Trump has a body mass index of 29.9, which is just shy of officially being obese. A New York driver\u2019s license issued in 2012 listed him as 6 feet 2 inches tall, which would put him just into the obese category.\n\n\u201cThe president, he and I talked,\u201d Dr. Jackson said. \u201cHe would like to lose 10 to 15 pounds. We talked about diet and exercise a lot. He\u2019s more enthusiastic about the diet part than the exercise part, but we\u2019re going to do both.\u201d\n\nDr. Jackson said that despite expressions of concern, a cognitive test was not indicated for Mr. Trump and he had not planned to conduct one at the Walter Reed National Military Medical Center in Bethesda, Md., where the president underwent his annual physical on Friday.\n\n\u201cThis has been the narrative for a while. He saw doing the physical as an opportunity to put some of that to rest,\u201d Dr. Jackson said during a nearly hourlong question-and-answer session in the White House briefing room. \u201cHe actively asked me to include that in it, so we did.\u201d\n\nDr. Jackson said that Mr. Trump received a score of 30 out of 30 on the Montreal Cognitive Assessment, a well-known test regularly used at Walter Reed and other hospitals.\n\nThe test is described as a \u201crapid-screening instrument for mild cognitive dysfunction\u201d that focuses on \u201cattention and concentration, executive functions, memory, language\u201d and other mental skills. It asks patients to repeat a list of spoken words, identify pictures of animals like a lion or a camel, draw a cube or draw a clock face set to a particular time.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nDr. Jackson said the president did \u201cexceedingly well\u201d on the screening test, adding evidence to the doctor\u2019s own assessment that the president has been \u201cvery sharp\u201d during numerous interactions he has had with him during the past year.\n\nPsychiatric experts said the brief, 10- to 15-minute screening test is not comprehensive and might not catch all patients with early stages of dementia. Dr. Bandy Lee, the author of \u201cThe Dangerous Case of Donald Trump,\u201d which expresses concern about the president\u2019s mental health, said in a brief interview that the president requires a full, detailed neuropsychiatric evaluation.\n\nHowever, Dr. Jackson said he had observed Mr. Trump closely, often several times a day, for the past year, and was satisfied that the Montreal test is \u201csensitive enough\u201d to have picked up serious cognitive issues if they were present.\n\nAsked about a much-discussed episode in which the president seemed to slur his words during a televised speech in December about the Middle East, Dr. Jackson said that he and his team of a dozen specialists conducted several tests, including an ultrasound of his carotid arteries, to determine whether there might be a clinical explanation.\n\nDr. Jackson said that the tests all were normal, leading him to believe that the slurred words might have been caused by Sudafed, a medicine for nasal congestion, that he prescribed for the president. He said Mr. Trump does not wear dentures \u201cof any kind,\u201d a popular theory on Twitter for the slurred words.\n\nIn response to speculation on television and elsewhere that the president has mental health problems, Dr. Jackson said, \u201cIn my opinion, that\u2019s just tabloid psychiatry.\u201d\n\nThe president\u2019s most fierce critics are unlikely to be satisfied by Dr. Jackson\u2019s pronouncements, but even top aides to former President Barack Obama were quick to praise Dr. Jackson, who also served as the White House physician to Mr. Obama.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cDr. Jackson is a phenomenal doctor and a really great guy,\u201d Dan Pfeiffer, Mr. Obama\u2019s senior adviser, posted Tuesday on Twitter. \u201cHe and his team took great care of all of us for many years.\u201d\n\nDr. Jackson said several times that he did not hold back any information about the president\u2019s health or the medicines he takes. He said the president had urged him to be forthcoming.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cHe said, \u2018I want you to get out there, and I want you to talk to them, and I want you to answer every question that they have,\u2019\u201d Dr. Jackson said, adding that Mr. Trump told Sarah Huckabee Sanders, the White House press secretary, not to pull the doctor off the podium until reporters were finished.\n\nOverall, Dr. Jackson repeatedly said he was impressed by the president\u2019s health, saying tests revealed no evidence of cancer, lung problems, diabetes or joint problems. Tests of the liver, kidney and thyroid were all normal.\n\nIn addition to the cholesterol medicine, Mr. Trump takes small doses of aspirin for heart health and a small dose of Propecia, a medicine to treat male-pattern baldness.\n\nDr. Jackson said tests of the president\u2019s heart indicated \u201cexcellent\u201d cardiac health, especially for someone of his age. An echocardiogram showed that he had normal function of his main pumping chamber, at 60 to 65 percent. Mr. Trump also performed above average on a treadmill exercise test.\n\nThe president\u2019s cholesterol was elevated, at 223, with an LDL measurement of 143 and an HDL level of 67. Dr. Jackson said that he hoped the higher dose of Crestor would help Mr. Trump lower his LDL to under 120 over the next year.\n\nDr. Richard A. Chazal, the immediate past president of the American College of Cardiology and the medical director of the Heart and Vascular Institute for Lee Memorial Health System in Fort Myers, Fla., called the report of Mr. Trump\u2019s health \u201cvery reassuring.\u201d\n\nBased on the information Dr. Jackson provided about the president\u2019s cholesterol, Dr. Chazal said the decision to increase the statin drug the president is taking is \u201cthoughtful\u201d and \u201ca very reasonable approach.\u201d Speaking of the remainder of the laboratory tests, \u201call else is very favorable,\u201d Dr. Chazal said.\n\nIn December 2015, Dr. Harold N. Bornstein, Mr. Trump\u2019s personal doctor, released a four-paragraph letter saying that, if elected, Mr. Trump would be \u201cthe healthiest individual ever elected to the presidency.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nDr. Jackson declined to repeat that statement, saying that it was his job to \u201cgive you my assessment of President Trump today.\n\n\u201cAnd I\u2019m not going to make any comparisons with presidents over the last 200 years or anything,\u201d he said.\n\nDr. Jackson said the president sleeps only four to five hours a night, but he said he was not concerned about it. He said he rarely sees the president overly stressed, saying that Mr. Trump \u201chas a unique ability to just get up in the morning and just reset. He gets up and he just starts a new day.\u201d\n\nAsked about reports that Mr. Trump watches numerous hours of television each day, Dr. Jackson said that, as far as he was concerned, \u201cHe can watch as much TV as he wants.\u201d\n\nBut Dr. Jackson repeatedly expressed concern about the president\u2019s sedentary lifestyle, noting that Mr. Trump does not have a \u201cdedicated, defined exercise program.\u201d\n\nStill, he said that the president has \u201ca lot of energy and a lot of stamina,\u201d and he said he is asking for a nutritionist to consult with the White House chefs to cut calories and fat in dishes served to the president. But he said the president remains healthy.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s called genetics,\u201d Dr. Jackson said. \u201cI told the president if he had eaten healthier over the last 25 years, he might live to be 200.\u201d", "title": "Trump Has Perfect Cognitive Test Score, White House Physician Says", "authors": ["Michael D. Shear", "Lawrence K. Altman"]} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "Reports that President Trump ordered the White House counsel, Donald F. McGahn II, to bring about the firing of the special counsel Robert Mueller last June are deeply troubling \u2014 not only as evidence of what the president has already done, but what he may yet do to obstruct justice and undermine the rule of law.\n\nWhether Mr. Trump engaged in obstruction of justice is, of course, yet to be determined. But we already know the F.B.I. director James Comey said that Mr. Trump asked him to back off on the Russian election meddling inquiry, and in particular on investigating his national security adviser, Michael Flynn, and that Mr. Trump fired Mr. Comey when he refused to abide by these instructions. We have also seen reports that Mr. Trump directed Attorney General Jeff Sessions not to recuse himself from the Russia investigation, despite Mr. Sessions\u2019s clear legal obligation to do so.\n\nAll of that, together with Mr. Trump\u2019s involvement in a misleading public statement about the June 2016 Trump Tower meeting between close campaign advisers and Russian agents, strongly suggests that President Trump has been wrongfully trying to block the investigation.\n\nNow there are reports that President Trump ordered the firing of Mr. Mueller last June. This is yet more evidence that the president is determined to block the investigation at all costs. It suggests Mr. Trump has something to hide about himself, his family or another associate. Therefore it goes to an element in any obstruction case, that of \u201ccorrupt intent\u201d \u2014 whether a person\u2019s actions were motivated by an improper purpose. An effort to fire Mr. Mueller would be particularly incriminating because it replicates the key moment when mere disgruntlement may have soured into illegality: Mr. Trump\u2019s termination of Mr. Comey.", "title": "Opinion | Trump Hasn\u2019t Fired Mueller \u2014 Yet", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-27 00:00:00", "text": "Last weekend, on the anniversary of the inauguration, Melania Instagrammed a throwback picture of herself in her powder-blue Jackie suit, not with her husband but with a hunky Marine escort. She wore a delighted ear-to-ear smile, the kind she never seems to flash around the Donald. (It would have been even funnier, of course, if she had posted a photo of herself in front of some empty stands and a sparse crowd, but we\u2019re talking more grounds for divorce there.)\n\nAfter the Stormy Daniels story broke \u2014 about Trump cavorting and watching Shark Week with the porn star and telling her not to worry about Melania, at home with a new baby, and then having his lawyer allegedly pay Stormy $130,000 during the campaign to hush her up \u2014 a wintry Melania canceled her plan to accompany her husband to Davos.\n\nInstead, while the kid from Queens was abroad trying to impress the soul-sucking global elites he got elected railing against, pathetically bragging that he had \u201ca crowd like they\u2019ve never had before in Davos,\u201d Melania made a solo visit to the Holocaust Museum here for Holocaust Remembrance Day. This looked like a subtle reproach to Trump for his unspeakable defense of the \u201cvery fine people\u201d among the neo-Nazis in Charlottesville, Va., and an allusion to the president\u2019s statement last year on remembrance day, which somehow neglected to remember Jews or anti-Semitism. What a Stephen Miller special that was.\n\nAfterward, the always elusive first lady became even more elusive, slipping out of Washington, much to the surprise of the press. Suddenly, as Stormy Daniels began her media tour on \u201cInside Edition\u201d and booked an appearance on \u201cJimmy Kimmel,\u201d Melania was making a stealthy landing in Florida on an Air Force plane.\n\nTrump could humiliate his wife by being a big, horny pig, but he is the one who comes off as the embarrassment. He\u2019s an embarrassing husband and an embarrassing president and an embarrassing leader of the free world. Barack Obama was always calling to our better angels. Donald Trump is paying off porn stars and denigrating struggling countries that send minorities to the U.S. as \u201cshitholes.\u201d How did we drop so far and so fast from class to crass?", "title": "Opinion | Trump Hits Alps, but Melania Is Frosty in Florida", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "Senate passage of a bipartisan bill could perhaps leave Mr. Trump with the take-it-or-leave-it decision. Just over two weeks ago, in a televised negotiating session at the White House, Mr. Trump said he would sign anything that got to him.\n\nSenators Lindsey Graham of South Carolina and Jeff Flake of Arizona \u2014 Republicans who have in the past fought against hard-line immigration policies \u2014 said the Senate was unlikely to simply accept the president\u2019s legislation.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re getting started without them,\u201d Mr. Flake said. Mr. Graham said bluntly, \u201cThis is a negotiation.\u201d\n\nMembers of both parties said that legislation would have a better chance of passing if it focused on legal status for DACA recipients without a dramatic crackdown on illegal immigrants or new restrictions on legal immigration for extended family members.\n\n\u201cIf you start putting in all of these highly charged toxic issues, it\u2019s just not going to work,\u201d said Senator Bill Nelson, Democrat of Florida.\n\nVideo\n\nAnti-immigration activists also assailed the plan, though for the opposite reason. Breitbart News greeted word of the president\u2019s plan with the headline \u201cAmnesty Don Suggests Citizenship for Illegal Aliens.\u201d\n\nUnder Mr. Trump\u2019s plan, described to reporters by senior White House officials, young immigrants who were brought into the United States illegally as children would be granted legal status, would be allowed to work, and could become citizens over a 10-to-12-year period if they remained out of trouble with the law.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn exchange, Congress would have to create a $25 billion trust fund to pay for a southern border wall, dramatically increase immigration arrests, speed up deportations, crack down on people who overstay their visas, prevent citizens from bringing their parents to the United States, and end a State Department program designed to encourage migration from underrepresented countries.\n\nWhite House officials said that the list of enhanced security measures \u2014 which have been on anti-immigration wish lists for decades \u2014 were nonnegotiable. They warned that if no deal is reached, DACA recipients will face deportation when the program fully expires on March 5.\n\nOne senior official said the young immigrants would not be targeted, but are \u201cillegal immigrants\u201d who would be processed for deportation if they came into contact with immigration officers.\n\nEddie Vale, a Democratic consultant working with a coalition of immigration groups, described the president\u2019s proposal as an effort to sabotage bipartisan talks and win passage of \u201ca white supremacist wish list.\u201d\n\nOfficials said the president\u2019s decision to formally present a plan to Congress was a direct response to members of Congress, including Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, the majority leader, who had complained that they did not know where the president stood in the immigration debate.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re basically signaling that this is the bill the president can sign,\u201d one senior official said during the briefing.\n\nOfficials said they expected Mr. McConnell to bring the president\u2019s plan to the Senate floor for a vote during the week of Feb. 5, just days before the Feb. 8 expiration of a short-term government spending plan.\n\nThe president\u2019s legislative proposal is designed to exert maximum pressure on Democrats, who are desperate to protect the young immigrants, known as Dreamers, but who fiercely oppose the policies embraced by hard-liners like Mr. Miller.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe strategy would work only if the Senate fails to reach a broad bipartisan accord on an alternative: legislation that would protect the Dreamers and bolster border security, but reject the most draconian aspects of the White House\u2019s proposal.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. Trump hinted at the proposal to come on Wednesday evening in impromptu comments suggesting that he was open to allowing some of the young immigrants to become citizens in 10 to 12 years. But his comments were quickly followed on Thursday morning by a White House email warning of a flood of immigrants into the country and demanding an end to policies that allow families to sponsor the immigration of their immediate relatives.\n\nAnd even as Mr. Trump was offering reassuring words to the Dreamers \u2014 \u201ctell them not to worry,\u201d he told reporters Wednesday evening \u2014 senior White House officials were emphasizing the more hard-line features of their forthcoming immigration proposal.\n\nIn September, Mr. Trump ended the DACA program and set it to expire at the beginning of March, when recipients would no longer be able to work legally in the United States and would once again face the threat of deportation.\n\nDemocratic lawmakers and activists say they will refuse to accept any proposal that requires them to forsake the well-being of other immigrants, including the parents of the Dreamers, to secure the fate of the young immigrants themselves.\n\n\u201cIt is shameful that the White House is holding these youth hostage in exchange for their extreme immigration agenda,\u201d said Kevin Appleby, the senior director of international migration policy for the Center for Migration Studies.\n\nOn Thursday, a bipartisan group of senators calling itself the Common Sense Coalition gathered in the office of Senator Susan Collins, Republican of Maine, to discuss the immigration issue. At issue is the scope of the bill. Some senators want to draft a narrow bill that bolsters border security and codifies protections now extended to DACA recipients, which do not include a path to citizenship. Others say the legislation should take Mr. Trump up on his offer of citizenship, but to do that, lawmakers might have to take the rest of the White House\u2019s deal.\n\n\u201cDo we simply codify what DACA is and extend it out over a period of time, or do we try to go farther than that as the president is suggesting?\u201d asked Senator Mike Rounds, Republican of South Dakota. \u201cIf you do that, you have to address the issue of chain migration, and that\u2019s where it becomes a lot more complicated.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHard-liners, apparently led by Senator John Cornyn of Texas, the No. 2 Republican in the Senate, say the White House\u2019s strategy needs to be considered \u2014 and that means four elements: Dreamers; border security and a wall; chain migration; and an end to the diversity visa lottery.\n\n\u201cEverybody wants to alter reality in a way that sort of suits their needs,\u201d Mr. Cornyn said. \u201cBut the reality is the president said there has to be four pillars. People just need to accept that and deal with it.\u201d\n\nSenator Richard J. Durbin, Democrat of Illinois, and Mr. Graham have been leading bipartisan talks on immigration. Their initial proposal \u2014 which did not include the president\u2019s more hard-line proposals \u2014 was rejected by Mr. Trump during a White House meeting in which the president used vulgarities to describe Africans.\n\nOn Wednesday night, Mr. Graham held a meeting with a far larger group of about 30 senators. They decided that Mr. Durbin, the No. 2 Democrat in the Senate, and Mr. Cornyn would each function as a clearinghouse for ideas on immigration from their respective parties.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019ve got more people in the room, which is good,\u201d Mr. Graham said. \u201cWe\u2019re getting more input. We\u2019ve just got to turn it into more output.\u201d", "title": "Trump Immigration Plan Demands Tough Concessions From Democrats", "authors": ["Michael D. Shear", "Sheryl Gay Stolberg"]} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "Several officials said they expected Mr. Trump to warn that he would not waive the sanctions again unless Congress agreed on legislation to tighten the nuclear deal. He is also expected to demand that European leaders fall in line \u2014 something that seems even less likely after the political unrest in Iran.\n\nStill, Mr. Trump\u2019s expected action is most important for what he will not do: reinstate sanctions on Iran\u2019s central bank and oil exports, which were lifted as an inducement to Tehran for constraining its nuclear program. That would have almost certainly unraveled the agreement \u2014 and it may yet, since Mr. Trump has warned he will dismantle the deal if he cannot improve it.\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s decision came after a Thursday meeting with his national security team on a turbulent day, during which he made a vulgar reference to immigrants in a meeting with senators and told The Wall Street Journal, \u201cI probably have a very good relationship with Kim Jong-un.\u201d\n\nStarting on Friday, Mr. Trump faces a series of deadlines related to the nuclear deal and sanctions that were waived as a result of it. The first of those deadlines \u2014 for extending or terminating the waiver for the central bank and oil sanctions \u2014 is by the far the most significant.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn October, Mr. Trump refused to certify the agreement \u2014 a decision he is expected to reaffirm next week. At the time, the president warned that he would take further action to nullify the deal if Congress and the allies did not act.\n\n\u201cIn the event we are not able to reach a solution working with Congress and our allies,\u201d he said over the fall, \u201cthen the agreement will be terminated.\u201d\n\nRepublicans in the Senate have drafted legislation that would amend the deal by eliminating its \u201csunset provisions,\u201d under which Iran is allowed to resume activities like enriching uranium. On Thursday, hours before Mr. Trump made his decision, European foreign ministers met in Brussels with Iran\u2019s foreign minister, Mohammad Javad Zarif, ostensibly to press Tehran about its destabilizing activities in the region, which are putting the nuclear deal at risk.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut to some in Washington, the meeting amounted to a show of unity between Europe and Iran \u2014 and of defiance toward the United States. There were images of a smiling Mr. Zarif, seated among smiling European officials, followed by a parade of statements in favor of the deal.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t think anybody has so far produced a better alternative,\u201d said the British foreign secretary, Boris Johnson. \u201cThe Iran nuclear deal makes the world safer. European partners were unanimous today in our determination to preserve the deal and tackle Iran\u2019s disruptive behavior.\u201d\n\nThe European Union\u2019s foreign affairs chief, Federica Mogherini, said, \u201cThe deal is working \u2014 it is delivering on its main goal which means keeping the Iranian nuclear program in check and under close surveillance.\u201d\n\nIn a phone call, President Emmanuel Macron of France also urged Mr. Trump not to scrap the deal. Mr. Macron \u201creaffirmed France\u2019s determination to see the agreement strictly enforced and the importance for all of its signatories to abide by it,\u201d his office said in a statement.\n\nPrivately, some White House officials complained about the phone call with Mr. Macron, which they said could have provoked Mr. Trump. Others said the diplomatic meeting in Brussels was similarly ill conceived, and they expressed frustration that the legislative efforts in Congress were not progressing quickly enough.\n\n\u201cLegislative gimmicks that don\u2019t permanently fix the Iran nuclear deal under U.S. law, regardless of which party controls the White House, and continued European photo-ops with Javad Zarif are like waving a red flag in front of an angry bull,\u201d said Mark Dubowitz, the chief executive of the Foundation for Defense of Democracies.\n\n\u201cIt could lead Trump to kill the deal, now or soon,\u201d he said.", "title": "Trump Is Expected to Stop Short of Reimposing Strict Sanctions on Iran", "authors": ["Mark Landler"]} {"date": "2018-01-22 00:00:00", "text": "When I was growing up, the American dream meant you had a house with a white picket fence, 2.5 children and a dog. I\u2019m from a small city in Wisconsin, which has a well-regarded state university system that an overwhelming majority of my peers expected to and did attend. The promise of that university education was why the people I grew up with believed in the dream.\n\nWe made fun of the white picket fence part, which seemed stiff and boring to our 1990s teenage tastes. We cracked bad jokes about the best way to split the third kid in half. I lived in a white, straight, Christian city, but my friends who didn\u2019t fit in those boxes and I believed in the dream too. My parents had fled there from a larger, dangerous city and worked their way up from apartments to a spacious house on the edge of town. Many of my friends were children of immigrants who had covered longer distances to achieve the same goal. Our parents had bettered themselves. We could too.\n\nThe American dream has been endangered for some decades now. I\u2019m not the first person to point that out, and President Trump\u2019s policies aren\u2019t the first set of developments that have called it into question. The long decline of labor unions and the rise of automation, among other things, have made it harder for many people to afford a picket fence or 2.5 kids.\n\nBut the Trump administration\u2019s racist and classist policies are hastening the demise of the American dream. His cruel, unnecessarily hard-edged approach to immigration enforcement goes after law-abiding, taxpaying residents. That, along with the recent tax cut on the rich that will be funded by the middle and lower classes, and Education Secretary Betsy DeVos\u2019s lack of interest in public education, all serve as proof that the dream is dying.", "title": "Opinion | Trump Is Killing the American Dream", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-02 00:00:00", "text": "Signs of disarray were palpable before the regime led by Ayatollah Ali Khamenei cracked down through the thugs of the Basij militia. As I wrote at the time, \u201cThere\u2019s nothing more repugnant than seeing women being hit by big men armed with clubs and the license of the state.\u201d\n\nIn Tehran, then, the silence of the Obama White House was deafening: too little, too late. Former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton expressed regret over this in 2014. Excessive caution was the mother of the Obama administration\u2019s worst failures, not least in Syria. The slippery slope school of foreign policy has its limitations. Inaction, in the name of the ninth unanswerable \u201cAnd then what?\u201d question from the president, is as emphatic a statement as action. President Vladimir Putin, among other American rivals, took note.\n\nSo Trump \u2014 even if he understands little or nothing of Iran, even if his talk of Iranian \u201chuman rights\u201d sounds hollow from a sometime advocate of torture, even if his support of the Iranian people today is grotesque from the man who has wrongheadedly barred most Iranians from entering the United States \u2014 is right to speak up in solidarity and tweet that the \u201cwealth of Iran is being looted\u201d by a \u201cbrutal and corrupt Iranian regime.\u201d It is. Given where American-Iranian relations stand, there is not much downside to this bluntness.\n\nAmong the most powerful slogans of demonstrators have been those expressing fury at money wasted in Syria, Lebanon and elsewhere when President Hassan Rouhani had promised jobs, not more of the surrogate wars of the Islamic Revolutionary Guards Corps.\n\nThe demonstrations, this time, are different. They are smaller, but more widespread. They reflect the economic woes of the working class more than middle-class disaffection. They are happening, as Karim Sadjadpour has pointed out in The Atlantic, in an Iran of 48 million smartphones, against fewer than one million in 2009 (which is why the regime is trying to block the hugely popular Telegram messaging app). They originated in Mashhad and went on to Qum, two traditional regime strongholds \u2014 a sign of the regime\u2019s ideological bankruptcy.", "title": "Opinion | Trump Is Right, This Time, About Iran", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-14 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cRacism\u201d and \u201cracist\u201d are simply words that have definitions, and Trump comfortably and unambiguously meets those definitions.\n\nWe have unfortunately moved away from the simple definition of racism, to the point where the only people to whom the appellation can be safely applied are the vocal, violent racial archetypes.\n\nRacism doesn\u2019t require hatred, constant expression, or even conscious awareness. We want racism to be fringe rather than foundational. But, wishing isn\u2019t an effective method of eradication.\n\nWe have to face this thing, stare it down and fight it back.\n\nThe simple acknowledgment that Trump is a racist is the easy part. The harder, more substantive part is this: What are we going to do about it?\n\nFirst and foremost, although Trump is not the first president to be a racist, we must make him the last. If by some miracle he should serve out his first term, he mustn\u2019t be allowed a second. Voters of good conscience must swarm the polls in 2020.\n\nBut before that, those voters must do so later this year, to rid the House and the Senate of as many of Trump\u2019s defenders, apologists and accomplices as possible. Should the time come where impeachment is inevitable, there must be enough votes in the House and Senate to ensure it.\n\nWe have to stop thinking that we can somehow separate what racists believe from how they will behave. We must stop believing that any of Trump\u2019s actions are clear of the venom coursing through his convictions. Everything he does is an articulation of who he is and what he believes. Therefore, all policies he supports, positions he takes and appointments he makes are suspect.", "title": "Opinion | Trump Is a Racist. Period.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "It remains unclear whether doctors performed any mental acuity, cognitive or neurological tests during the president\u2019s physical exam. That prompted Mr. Trump to insist that he is a \u201cstable genius.\u201d\n\nIt is also unclear whether Mr. Trump had tests common for men of his age, such as a treadmill stress test to detect heart problems.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Get the Morning Briefing by Email What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox Monday through Friday. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn December 2015, as a presidential candidate, Mr. Trump posted on Twitter that his medical report would \u201cshow perfection.\u201d About a week later, his personal physician released a four-paragraph letter saying that the candidate was in perfect health.\n\n\u201cIf elected, Mr. Trump, I can state unequivocally, will be the healthiest individual ever elected to the presidency,\u201d the physician, Dr. Harold N. Bornstein of Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan, concluded in the letter.\n\nDr. Bornstein wrote that a \u201ccomplete medical examination\u201d had indicated \u201conly positive results,\u201d though it gave few specifics and did not reveal Mr. Trump\u2019s weight at the time. Dr. Bornstein claimed that his patient\u2019s blood pressure and lab results were \u201castonishingly excellent.\u201d\n\nIn an interview with The New York Times last year, Dr. Bornstein revealed that Mr. Trump takes a small dose of finasteride, a drug that is marketed as Propecia, to treat male-pattern baldness; the drug lowers levels of prostate-specific antigen, an enzyme made by the prostate. Dr. Jackson, the president\u2019s current doctor, did not reveal whether Mr. Trump is continuing to take that medicine.\n\nAnnual medical exams for the president are a tradition that goes back decades.\n\nIn 1985, the doctors for President Ronald Reagan detected a cancer during what officials had described as a routine colonoscopy. The president had surgery that weekend and the cancer was removed, along with a section of his intestine. Doctors said at the time that the cancer did not require chemotherapy.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn 1990, doctors for President George Bush detected an early glaucoma in his left eye and prescribed eye drops. More than a decade later, in 2001, doctors for President Bill Clinton, concerned about an increase in his weight and elevated LDL cholesterol levels, started the president on statin drugs to treat those symptoms.\n\nPresident George W. Bush was diagnosed in 2004 with a \u201clow\u201d to \u201cvery low\u201d risk of coronary artery disease. Doctors recommended that Mr. Bush, then 58, take aspirin and a statin. In August 2013, when Mr. Bush was 67 and after he left office, doctors inserted a stent into one of his coronary arteries.\n\nDuring checkups for President Barack Obama, his doctors expressed concern about the difficulty Mr. Obama had quitting smoking. But they never disclosed how often Mr. Obama smoked, making it impossible to calculate what doctors call pack-years, a measure of the risk of developing cancers from smoking.", "title": "Trump Is in \u2018Excellent Health,\u2019 Doctor Says After Exam", "authors": ["Michael D. Shear", "Lawrence K. Altman"]} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "DAVOS, Switzerland \u2014 President Trump didn\u2019t say how delighted he was to be in Sweden, he didn\u2019t call any countries s-holes, he didn\u2019t threaten to \u201ctotally destroy\u201d another nation, and he didn\u2019t brag that his \u201cnuclear button\u201d was \u201cmuch bigger\u201d than anyone else\u2019s. In other words, Trump\u2019s speech here at the World Economic Forum was a resounding success.\n\nO.K., fact-checkers found at least two falsehoods, and the audience booed when Trump went off script and raged at \u201chow nasty, how mean, how vicious and how fake the press can be.\u201d Yet on the whole, he read an anodyne speech perfectly well off the teleprompter, making it a personal triumph for him \u2014 albeit also probably the weakest speech delivered by any leader in Davos this year.\n\nThe past week has underscored how much the world needs American leadership, and how badly Trump is falling short \u2014 or, more precisely, when he provides leadership, it\u2019s often in the wrong direction, setting us back.\n\nThe upshot is that there\u2019s now a global vacuum of practical and moral leadership.\n\nThere are challenges from North Korea to Yemen, from climate to refugees, plus atrocities in Myanmar that probably amount to genocide. South Sudan is collapsing, and in Syria, 16 bombings of hospitals or clinics have been reported just since Christmas \u2014 and barely an eyebrow has been raised.", "title": "Opinion | Trump Leads the World, Backward", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-09 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cFor the government to negotiate there, we would have to have a single national formulary that restricted access to all seniors for medicines,\u201d Mr. Azar told the Senate Finance Committee. \u201cI don\u2019t believe we want to go there in restricting patient access.\u201d\n\nAt the same time, Mr. Azar said, \u201cit\u2019s worth looking at\u201d proposals to allow price negotiations for drugs in Part B of Medicare. Under this part of the program, patients receive cancer drugs and other medications, often by infusion or injection, in doctor\u2019s offices and hospital outpatient clinics.\n\nMr. Azar, who worked for six years in the administration of President George W. Bush, is expected to win confirmation, with support from Republicans and perhaps a few Democrats, who view him as a pragmatic problem solver rather than an ideologue. He would take charge of a cabinet department that spends more than a trillion dollars a year providing health insurance to more than 130 million Americans.\n\nSenator Bill Nelson, Democrat of Florida, asked Mr. Azar whether he would support cuts in Medicare, Medicaid or Social Security to offset increases in the federal budget deficit that would be caused by the recently passed tax legislation.\n\n\u201cThe president has stated his opposition to cuts to Medicare, Medicaid or Social Security,\u201d Mr. Azar replied. \u201cHe said that in the campaign, and I believe he remains steadfast in his views on that. He\u2019s made that commitment. I will live up to that if I\u2019m confirmed.\u201d\n\nBut like many Republicans, Mr. Azar said that cuts in the growth of federal benefit programs were not really cuts if federal spending on the programs continued to increase.\n\nDemocrats kept returning to the question of drug prices. Mr. Azar said that the expertise he acquired in the pharmaceutical industry would help him rein in drug costs as a federal official.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cAcross the board,\u201d he said, \u201cdrug prices are too high. Insulin prices are too high. All drug prices are too high in this country.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nDemocrats were generally skeptical, based on Lilly\u2019s record during Mr. Azar\u2019s time at the company.\n\n\u201cThe price of Lilly\u2019s bone-growth drug Forteo, used to treat osteoporosis, more than doubled on Mr. Azar\u2019s watch,\u201d said Senator Ron Wyden of Oregon, the senior Democrat on the Finance Committee. In the same period, Mr. Wyden said, the company more than doubled prices for other drugs including Humalog, used to treat diabetes, and Strattera, for attention deficit hyperactivity disorder.\n\nMr. Wyden asked Mr. Azar if, as head of Lilly\u2019s operations in the United States, he had ever approved a reduction in the price of a Lilly drug.\n\nMr. Azar avoided a direct answer and blamed \u201cthe system.\u201d\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t know that there is any drug price of a branded product that has ever gone down from any company on any drug in the United States because every incentive in this system is toward higher prices,\u201d Mr. Azar said, adding: \u201cNo one company is going to fix that system. That\u2019s why I want to be here working with you.\u201d\n\nMr. Azar said he saw no need for the government to negotiate prices for drugs covered by Part D of Medicare, which pays for pills and other products that patients can give themselves and purchase from neighborhood drugstores and mail-order pharmacies.\n\nMedicare\u2019s Part D drug benefit is delivered entirely by private companies under contract with the government. These companies and their agents, known as pharmacy benefit managers, negotiate with drug manufacturers, and Mr. Azar said he did not believe the government could get lower prices by negotiating directly with drug companies.\n\nA 2003 law prohibits the Department of Health and Human Services from interfering in negotiations between drug manufacturers and insurers that provide drug coverage under Part D of Medicare. \u201cYou would not get better pricing by removing\u201d that prohibition, Mr. Azar said.\n\nIn the 2016 campaign and since taking office, Mr. Trump has said that Medicare could save large sums by negotiating directly with drug companies. But drug companies adamantly oppose that idea, and Mr. Trump has not taken steps to translate that into practice.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAsked specifically if Medicare should negotiate drug prices, Mr. Azar said: \u201cIn Part D, we do significant negotiation through pharmacy benefit managers that get the best rates of any commercial payers. We don\u2019t do that in Part B, which is where we have physician-administered drugs. We basically pay sales price plus 6 percent or some other number.\u201d\n\nAs an alternative, Mr. Azar said he supported proposals to link the pricing of prescription drugs to an assessment of how well they work for patients. Under such arrangements, known as value-based pricing, insurers would pay more for medicines that were highly effective and less for those that did not work well.\n\nMr. Azar also said he supported an agency created by the Affordable Care Act to test novel ways of delivering and paying for health care. And he said that some of the experiments could require doctors and hospitals to participate. Republicans in Congress have generally opposed mandatory participation.", "title": "Trump Likes Drug Price Negotiations; His Nominee for Health Secretary Doesn\u2019t", "authors": ["Robert Pear"]} {"date": "2018-01-04 00:00:00", "text": "The governors of New Jersey, Delaware, Maryland, Virginia, North Carolina, South Carolina, California, Oregon and Washington have all opposed offshore drilling plans. Virginia\u2019s governor-elect, Ralph S. Northam, a Democrat, said in a statement Thursday that expanding drilling would jeopardize his state\u2019s tourism and fishing industries, as well as military installations. Gov. Roy Cooper of North Carolina, also a Democrat, called drilling a \u201ccritical threat\u201d to his state\u2019s economy.\n\nMr. Zinke said the drilling plan was part of \u201ca new path for energy dominance in America,\u201d but said he planned to speak with Governor Scott and other state leaders before the proposal was finalized. \u201cIt\u2019s not going to be done overnight,\u201d he said.\n\nOil industry leaders cheered the reversal, calling it long overdue.\n\n\u201cI think the default should be that all of our offshore areas should be available,\u201d said Thomas J. Pyle, president of the American Energy Alliance. \u201cThese are our lands. They\u2019re taxpayer-owned and they should be made available.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThe Obama administration blocked drilling on about 94 percent of the outer continental shelf, the submerged offshore area between state coastal waters and the deep ocean. Mr. Zinke charged that those restrictions had cost the United States billions of dollars in lost revenue and said the new proposal would make about 90 percent of those waters available for leasing.\n\nThe Interior Department would open 25 of 26 regions of the outer continental shelf, leaving only the North Aleutian Basin \u2014 which President George Bush protected in an executive order \u2014 exempted from drilling.\n\nInterior officials said they intended to hold 47 lease sales between 2019 and 2024, including 19 off the coast of Alaska and 12 in the Gulf of Mexico. Seven areas offered for new drilling would be in Pacific waters off California, where drilling has been off limits since a 1969 oil spill near Santa Barbara.\n\nPresident Trump signed an executive order in April requiring the Interior Department to reconsider Mr. Obama\u2019s five-year offshore drilling plan, which had invoked an obscure provision of a 1953 law, the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act, to block new lease sales in large areas of the Arctic and Atlantic. The ban \u201cdeprives our country of potentially thousands and thousands of jobs and billions of dollars in wealth,\u201d Mr. Trump said at the time.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFinalizing the new plan could take as long as 18 months, experts said, and in the meantime challenges are expected in the courts and in Congress.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn a joint statement, 64 environmental groups called the plan a \u201cshameful giveaway\u201d to oil companies. Many said they were exploring legal options.\n\nSenator Edward J. Markey, Democrat of Massachusetts, vowed to pursue \u201call legislative tools\u201d to block drilling off the East Coast, including the Congressional Review Act, which allows agency actions to be undone by Congress. Xavier Becerra, California\u2019s attorney general, said the state is \u201cevaluating all of our options\u201d to protect its coast. And, several groups warned, a future Democratic administration could again redraw the boundaries of allowable drilling.\n\nBut for now, Republicans\u2019 efforts to roll back restrictions on energy production are winning the day. Last month Congress opened the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge, or ANWR, to oil and gas drilling as part of the tax overhaul. And last week the Interior Department rescinded an Obama-era rule that would have added regulations for hydraulic fracturing, or fracking, on federal and tribal lands. It also repealed offshore drilling safety regulations that were put in place after the Deepwater Horizon spill.\n\nJody Freeman, director of the environmental law program at Harvard Law School and a former Obama climate adviser, said the latest Trump proposal was more about sending a message. In the Arctic in particular, she said, low oil prices and the decision by Royal Dutch Shell to give up all but one of its federal oil leases indicate drilling is not on the near horizon.\n\n\u201cBut the decision is a signal, just like the one Congress sent with ANWR, that Republicans want to open the nation\u2019s public lands and waters for business,\u201d she said.\n\nFrank Knapp, president of the Business Alliance for Protecting the Atlantic Coast, said thousands of small businesses, from restaurants to hotels to commercial fishing operations, oppose drilling off their states\u2019 waters.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s not consistent with our vibrant tourism, fishing and recreation,\u201d Mr. Knapp said. \u201cTheir concern is their livelihood, the local economies. We all saw what happened to the Gulf Coast with Deepwater Horizon.\u201d\n\nOf particular interest to oil companies \u2014 and concern to many Florida lawmakers \u2014 will be the decision to open the eastern Gulf of Mexico, said Kevin Book, an energy consultant and managing director of ClearView Energy Partners. He noted the area is attractive to the energy industry because there is already a large amount of infrastructure in the region.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cYou can talk about the Atlantic all you want, but you\u2019re 10 years, 15 years from production,\u201d Mr. Book said.\n\nAnalysts said the oil industry was unlikely to rush headlong into new areas. While oil companies have eyed regions like the East Coast for years, oil and gas operators are still smarting from the steep fall in oil prices that began in 2014 because of a global oil glut, which has only recently eased.\n\nDespite the recent sharp rise in prices to about $68 a barrel for Brent crude, companies remain wary of spending, particularly in areas where the amount of oil and gas present is unknown and production is likely to be expensive without existing pipelines and other infrastructure.\n\n\u201cIt is going to be a really long story,\u201d said William Turner, an analyst at Wood Mackenzie in Houston. \u201cIt is not going to be gangbusters.\u201d", "title": "Trump Moves to Open Nearly All Offshore Waters to Drilling", "authors": ["Lisa Friedman"]} {"date": "2018-01-09 00:00:00", "text": "In his ruling, Judge Alsup questioned the administration\u2019s contention that the DACA program had not been put into place legally. He asserted that the secretary of the Department of Homeland Security has long had the authority to grant the kind of temporary protections that formed the basis of the program.\n\nJudge Alsup also cited several of Mr. Trump\u2019s Twitter posts that expressed support for the program. He noted that in September, the president wrote: \u201cDoes anybody really want to throw out good, educated and accomplished young people who have jobs, some serving in the military? Really!\u201d Such tweets, the judge said, bolstered the idea that keeping the program going was in the public\u2019s interest.\n\nThe judge wrote that previous beneficiaries of DACA, known as Dreamers, must be allowed to renew their status in the program, though the government will not be required to accept new applications from immigrants who had not previously submitted one. The judge also said the administration could continue to prevent DACA recipients from returning to the United States if they leave the country.\n\nPhoto\n\nIt is unclear what the legal effect could be from the judge\u2019s ruling, but the Trump administration may be headed for more intense legal wrangling like the kind that happened after the president\u2019s travel bans.\n\nA spokesman for the Justice Department, Devin O\u2019Malley, said that the ruling did not change the department\u2019s stance.\n\n\u201cDACA was implemented unilaterally after Congress declined to extend these benefits to this same group of illegal aliens,\u201d he said. \u201cAs such, it was an unlawful circumvention of Congress, and was susceptible to the same legal challenges that effectively ended DACA. The Department of Homeland Security therefore acted within its lawful authority in deciding to wind down DACA in an orderly manner. Promoting and enforcing the rule of law is vital to protecting a nation, its borders, and its citizens.\u201d\n\nThe administration could quickly appeal the judge\u2019s ruling, hoping that an appeals court would prevent the injunction from taking effect and allowing the shutdown of the DACA program as the president announced in September.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut such a ruling could itself be appealed all the way to the Supreme Court, potentially tying the fate of the DACA program in court action for days, weeks or longer.\n\nVideo\n\nEither way, the ruling could have serious political effect.\n\nIf the court\u2019s order to restart the DACA program stands, that could take pressure off Republicans and Democrats to find a political solution for the young immigrants who could be deported if the program ends.\n\nAlmost immediately after the president rescinded the DACA program in September, Mr. Trump expressed sympathy for the young immigrants who were children when their parents brought them to the country illegally. Mr. Trump repeated his sympathies on Tuesday at the White House meeting.\n\nDemocrats have seized on the president\u2019s attitude, urging their Republican colleagues to support legislation that would permanently legalize the Dreamers to work in the United States, and give them an eventual path to American citizenship.\n\nBut hard-line conservatives say that would amount to an amnesty program for lawbreakers, and some Republicans in Congress have been pressing for other immigration changes before they will support legislation for the Dreamers.\n\nIn particular, Republicans at the White House meeting demanded an end to rules that allow immigrants to sponsor their extended family members \u2014 aunts, uncles, cousins \u2014 to enter the United States. And they want an end to a State Department visa lottery program that prioritizes legal immigration from certain countries in Africa and elsewhere.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. He hailed the judge\u2019s ruling in a statement.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cToday\u2019s ruling is a huge step in the right direction,\u201d Mr. Becerra said. \u201cWe will fight at every turn for their rights and opportunities so they may continue to contribute to America.\u201d\n\nBut some advocates expressed concern that the legal efforts, while well intentioned, could undermine the push to earn permanent relief for the young immigrants.\n\nCamille Mackler, the director of immigration legal policy at the New York Immigration Coalition, said that while advocates were relieved that more DACA recipients would be able to renew their membership, they expected the government to appeal the judge\u2019s ruling.\n\nIn the meantime, she said, only legislation offering legal status to Dreamers would suffice to protect them.\n\n\u201cThis is not a win for us,\u201d Ms. Mackler said. \u201cWe\u2019re obviously glad that this is going to provide some relief, but what we really need is a clean Dream Act,\u201d a reference to a bill that only legalizes the young immigrants without also imposing other immigration changes that Republicans are demanding.", "title": "Trump Must Keep DACA Protections for Now, Judge Says", "authors": ["Michael D. Shear"]} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 In a notable back flip, the Trump administration has decided that maybe the Obama administration was right in its efforts to change the way doctors and hospitals are paid under Medicare.\n\nThe Trump administration said late Tuesday that it was starting a Medicare payment model very similar to the ones it canceled and curtailed last year. The Obama administration devised the earlier projects using authority in the Affordable Care Act.\n\nIn the new program, as described by Trump appointees, Medicare will make a single \u201cbundled payment\u201d for nearly all the services provided in a 90-day period to certain Medicare patients who are admitted to a hospital or have certain outpatient medical procedures.\n\nHealth care providers can receive a bonus if they hold Medicare spending for these patients below a target set by the government, and they may have to repay the government if Medicare spending for them exceeds the target.", "title": "Trump Officials, After Rejecting Obama Medicare Model, Adopt One Like It", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. McGahn was also concerned that firing the special counsel would incite more questions about whether the White House was trying to obstruct the Russia investigation.\n\nAround the time Mr. Trump wanted to fire Mr. Mueller, the president\u2019s legal team, led then by his longtime personal lawyer in New York, Marc E. Kasowitz, was taking an adversarial approach to the Russia investigation. The president\u2019s lawyers were digging into potential conflict-of-interest issues for Mr. Mueller and his team, according to current and former White House officials, and news media reports revealed that several of Mr. Mueller\u2019s prosecutors had donated to Democrats.\n\nMr. Mueller could not legally have considered political affiliations when making hiring decisions. But for Mr. Trump\u2019s supporters, it reinforced the idea that, although Mr. Mueller is a Republican, he had assembled a team of Democrats to take down the president.\n\nAnother option that Mr. Trump considered in discussions with his advisers was dismissing the deputy attorney general, Rod J.
