Peters"]} {"date": "2018-01-28 00:00:00", "text": "LONDON \u2014 President Trump said he would take a \u201ctougher\u201d attitude toward Brexit negotiations than the approach now being used by Prime Minister Theresa May of Britain.\n\n\u201cWould it be the way I negotiate? No, I wouldn\u2019t negotiate it the way it\u2019s negotiated ... I would have had a different attitude,\u201d he said in an interview with ITV, a British television network, that was broadcast Sunday night.\n\n\u201cI would have said that the European Union is not cracked up to what it\u2019s supposed to be,\u201d he said.\n\nBritain is preparing to leave the European Union in March 2019. The complex negotiations have moved slowly and Mrs. May\u2019s cabinet seems deeply divided over how best to separate Britain from the 28-nation bloc.\n\nMr. Trump expressed annoyance with European Union trade policy. \u201cWe cannot get our product in,\u201d he said. \u201cIt\u2019s very, very tough. And yet, they send their product to us \u2014 no taxes, very little taxes.\u201d", "title": "Trump Tells British TV He Would Take \u2018Tougher\u2019 Stance on Brexit", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-31 00:00:00", "text": "In this sense, and also in the canny and sometimes moving choices of inspirational figures in the balconies, I suspect the speech was effective, that it might help lift Trump temporarily upward from his mean of 38 percent approval toward the \u201cwe\u2019re holding the House by our fingernails\u201d promised land of 44 percent.\n\nBut an effective speech is not the same thing as an effective agenda, and right now there are no prospects for Trump\u2019s popular ideas getting enacted or even really considered on the Hill. His party\u2019s ideologues don\u2019t want them, the opposition party doesn\u2019t want to make a deal with Trump to get them, and his White House doesn\u2019t actually have any detail behind the rhetoric. The ideas are just things that the president would probably like to do but that someone will talk him out of, or that he\u2019ll forget about, or that he\u2019ll offer in a halfhearted way and that Congress will never bother to take up.\n\nThe only exception, the only issue where he does actually have some details to offer, is immigration reform. But here the speech\u2019s appeal to the assembled legislators to make a version of the deal he\u2019s offering on DACA \u2014 essentially an amnesty and path to citizenship now in exchange for future immigration reductions \u2014 was undercut by all the fearmongering about immigrant crime that Trump wrapped it in. For Democratic politicians whose base doesn\u2019t want to compromise and whose own political interest isn\u2019t served by any kind of major immigration deal, the bloody-shirt business with MS-13 murders was a permission slip for intransigence: Why make a bargain with a president who talks like half your immigrant constituents are gangbangers?\n\nSo this State of the Union both showed what a more successful version of the Trump presidency would look like \u2014 still conservative on many fronts but more genuinely populist, less same-old G.O.P. \u2014 and why the possibility of that success has probably already slipped from this administration\u2019s grip. There were ideas here that could make Trump\u2019s second year more successful than the first, but there was no plan to actually enact them, no sign that Trump is prepared to build bridges where he\u2019s burned them, no plan for getting more out of this speech than just a temporary polling bump.\n\nWhat there was instead was something you can expect to hear a lot of between now and November 2020: If you like this economy, you should like me, too.\n\nPoliticians have won re-election with that sort of messaging. But few of them have had as far to climb to reach even basic likability as President Donald J. Trump.", "title": "Opinion | Trump Tries for a Reset", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cWe are waging a campaign of maximum pressure to prevent that from happening,\u201d he said. \u201cPast experience has taught us that complacency and concessions only invite aggression and provocation. I will not repeat the mistakes of past administrations that got us into this dangerous position.\u201d\n\nMr. Trump did not, as he has before, issue specific threats of a military strike on the North. But he outlined an unrelenting case for what he called the North Korean government\u2019s \u201cdepraved character,\u201d echoing a speech he delivered to the South Korean National Assembly in Seoul in November.\n\nVideo\n\nThe president drew on the stories of two victims of North Korean cruelty: an American college student, Otto F. Warmbier, who fell into an irreversible coma while in detention in Pyongyang, the capital, and later died; and a North Korean man who lost his leg while searching for food for his starving family. He later defected.\n\nGesturing to Mr. Warmbier\u2019s parents, Fred and Cindy, who watched from the visitors\u2019 gallery in the House, their eyes wet with tears, Mr. Trump said, \u201cYou are powerful witnesses to a menace that threatens our world, and your strength truly inspires us all.\u201d\n\nThe defector, Ji Seong-ho, was also in the gallery and held up his wooden crutches in triumph when Mr. Trump hailed him.\n\nHours before the speech, the president\u2019s Korea policy was buffeted by the administration\u2019s decision to abandon a long-delayed plan to nominate a prominent Korea scholar, Victor D. Cha, as its ambassador to Seoul.\n\nMr. Cha, 57, had voiced opposition to the administration\u2019s threat to carry out a preventive military strike against North Korea, said two people with knowledge of the decision. He had already undergone an extensive vetting process, and his name had been submitted for approval to the South Korean government \u2014 normally an indication that the background check was complete.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOfficials in Seoul had already signed off on the ambassadorship; Mr. Cha is a Republican who identifies as a hawk on North Korea. But friends said he told Pentagon and other administration officials his concerns about ordering a pre-emptive, or preventive, military strike on North Korea before it had the capacity to fire a nuclear-armed missile at the United States.\n\nAdministration officials, particularly the White House national security adviser, Lt. Gen. H. R. McMaster, have raised the prospect of such a strike \u2014 sometimes called the \u201cbloody nose\u201d strategy \u2014 though they emphasize they would prefer to solve the confrontation with Pyongyang through diplomacy.\n\nMr. Cha has also publicly voiced the high cost to both Washington and Seoul of ripping up the Korea Free Trade Agreement, as Mr. Trump has threatened to do, unless the South Koreans agree to renegotiate the deal.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe White House declined to comment Tuesday on the reasons for its decision, though a senior official played down policy disagreements as the cause. The administration had not formally submitted Mr. Cha\u2019s name to the Senate, even after he had undergone months of vetting.\n\nThe White House had initially hoped to have a new ambassador in place in time for the Winter Games, which begin in 10 days in the South Korean town of Pyeongchang. But as the deadline approached, Mr. Cha told friends he had heard nothing from the White House or the State Department about the status of his nomination. The Washington Post first reported that the White House was not moving forward with his nomination.\n\nMichael J. Green, a colleague of Mr. Cha, said the dropped ambassadorship was \u201cdiscouraging in terms of what it says about the administration\u2019s North Korea policy, but also their ability to attract qualified people to come into these kinds of jobs.\u201d\n\nIn his speech, Mr. Trump made no mention of the Winter Olympic Games. Nor did he mention a budding d\u00e9tente between North and South Korea, which have agreed to march their teams into the opening ceremony under a single flag and to field a unified women\u2019s ice hockey team.\n\nVideo\n\nFor the president, cataloging the horrors inflicted by North Korea was part of an exercise that he called \u201crestoring clarity about our adversaries.\u201d He said he had stood up for antigovernment demonstrators in Iran and asked Congress to fix the flaws in the \u201cterrible\u201d nuclear deal that world powers brokered with the country in 2015.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe president also said the United States had imposed sanctions on Cuba and Venezuela, though he made no mention of new penalties against Russia, which lawmakers had passed in a lopsided majority but which the administration has so far declined to impose.\n\nMr. Trump said much less about America\u2019s role in alliances like the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. And he barely mentioned China or Russia, two countries his own administration identified as the nation\u2019s greatest geopolitical adversaries in the recent National Security Strategy.\n\nWhile he mentioned his decision to recognize Jerusalem as the capital of Israel, Mr. Trump said nothing about his administration\u2019s effort to broker a peace accord between Israel and the Palestinians. That effort seemed more elusive than ever, given Palestinian outrage over Jerusalem.\n\nRather than talk about peace, Mr. Trump emphasized his determination to punish countries that split with the United States over what he called \u201cAmerica\u2019s sovereign right to make this recognition.\u201d\n\n\u201cThat is why, tonight, I am asking Congress to pass legislation to help insure American foreign-assistance dollars always serve American interests, and only go to America\u2019s friends,\u201d he said.", "title": "Trump Vows a Muscular America to Confront a World of Enemies", "authors": ["Mark Landler"]} {"date": "2018-01-17 00:00:00", "text": "But in telling lawmakers that Mr. Trump had essentially erred from the start in promoting a wall and by claiming credit for dissuading him, Mr. Kelly appeared to be voicing a sentiment some in the West Wing have heard him express privately \u2014 that it is his job to tutor a sometimes ill-informed president who has never served in public office before.\n\nAt the same time, it suggested that Mr. Kelly, who served as secretary of homeland security before coming to the White House and has hard-line views on immigration that mirror the president\u2019s restrictionist approach, was positioning himself now as a moderating influence.\n\nMr. Kelly made the remarks at a meeting with members of the Hispanic Caucus, as a group known as the Twos \u2014 the No. 2 Democrat and Republican in both the House and Senate \u2014 worked toward negotiating a deal to protect from deportation the young undocumented immigrants known as Dreamers. The meeting with the Hispanic caucus was first reported by The Washington Post.\n\nMr. Kelly expressed confidence that the negotiations to preserve the protections provided by the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals program, or DACA, the Obama-era policy that Mr. Trump moved in September to end, would succeed, though not necessarily this week. The president gave Congress six months to enact a replacement for the program, which protects about 780,000 young people.\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s no doubt in my mind there\u2019s going to be a deal, so long as men and women on both sides are willing to talk,\u201d Mr. Kelly said in an interview with Fox News.\n\nAs recently as Sunday, Mr. Trump was far more pessimistic about the program\u2019s future and criticized its Democratic supporters. \u201cDACA is probably dead because the Democrats don\u2019t really want it, they just want to talk and take desperately needed money away from our Military,\u201d he wrote on Twitter.\n\nMr. Kelly told lawmakers that \u201che was the one who tempered\u201d Mr. Trump \u201con the issue of the wall, on the issue of DACA,\u201d said Representative Ra\u00fal Grijalva, Democrat of Arizona, who attended the session.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nRepresentative Luis V. Guti\u00e9rrez, Democrat of Illinois, who was also at the meeting, quoted Mr. Kelly as having told the group that, \u201ca 50-foot wall from sea to shining sea isn\u2019t what we\u2019re going to build.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. Guti\u00e9rrez told reporters that at the meeting, Mr. Kelly said that during the presidential campaign, \u201cthere were statements made about the wall that were not informed statements.\u201d\n\nMr. Trump often cited his promise to build a \u201cbig, beautiful wall\u201d to energize his campaign rallies.\n\nMarc T. Short, the White House director of legislative affairs, denied the Democrats\u2019 characterization of Mr. Kelly\u2019s comments about the president\u2019s familiarity with immigration issues, telling CNN in an interview: \u201cI don\u2019t recall General Kelly saying the president was uninformed.\u201d\n\nBut he did not dispute the notion that the president has changed his view of what is needed to secure the border, based in part on information from Customs and Border Protection, the government agency charged with immigration enforcement.\n\nThe wall has been a prominent issue in the negotiations over DACA, with Mr. Trump insisting that funding to build it be part of any such bill, along with measures to limit the extended family members immigrants can sponsor for entry into the United States and an end to the diversity visa lottery.\n\nAs Mr. Trump\u2019s first secretary of homeland security, Mr. Kelly presided over the beginnings of the president\u2019s immigration crackdown, including the enactment of his travel ban and tougher interior enforcement measures.\n\nBut Mr. Kelly did not push the idea of a solid wall across the entire southern border, arguing from the outset that \u201ca physical barrier will not do the job.\u201d More recently, he has prevailed upon Mr. Trump not to dwell on the idea of Mexico paying for the wall, a notion that the president has not mentioned for some time.\n\n\u201cHe used the word \u2018evolved,\u2019\u201d Mr. Grijalva said, adding that Mr. Kelly said Mr. Trump has \u201cevolved, in the general context of the wall and DACA, and he said you make campaign promises; that\u2019s different from governing.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nTwo House Democratic aides who attended the meeting confirmed the accounts given by Mr. Grijalva and Mr. Guti\u00e9rrez.\n\nRepresentative Lucille Roybal-Allard, Democrat of California, said she sought a clarification from Mr. Kelly about what would constitute the border wall that Mr. Trump is seeking, since \u201cso many people have different ideas about what the wall actually is.\u201d\n\nMr. Kelly said that since taking office, Mr. Trump \u201crealizes what the realities are, and that they are no longer considering the wall to be what was described in the campaign,\u201d Ms. Roybal-Allard said.\n\n\u201cIt wasn\u2019t until he got to the White House that he was better informed in terms of what were the possibilities in terms of barriers,\u201d Ms. Roybal-Allard added, recalling what Mr. Kelly said about Mr. Trump.", "title": "Trump Was Not \u2018Fully Informed\u2019 in Campaign Vows on Wall, Chief of Staff Says", "authors": ["Julie Hirschfeld Davis", "Sheryl Gay Stolberg", "Thomas Kaplan"]} {"date": "2018-01-03 00:00:00", "text": "Above all, the officials said, the Trump administration will resist efforts by the North to drive a wedge between the United States and its ally. North Korea, they said, has a long history of using such overtures to sow dissent between South Korea and the United States, particularly at times, like now, when the countries have governments with divergent politics.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe White House also reiterated that Mr. Trump would continue to defy Mr. Kim, regardless of any diplomacy underway. The press secretary, Sarah Huckabee Sanders, defended the president\u2019s Twitter message late Tuesday about Mr. Kim in which he said, \u201cI too have a Nuclear Button, but it is a much bigger & more powerful one than his, and my Button works!\u201d\n\nPeople, Ms. Sanders said on Wednesday, should question Mr. Kim\u2019s mental fitness, not Mr. Trump\u2019s.\n\n\u201cOur policy with North Korea has not changed,\u201d Ms. Sanders added. \u201cWe\u2019re fully committed to continuing to apply maximum pressure and working with all of our partners in the region, including South Korea, who we have a better relationship with now than ever before.\u201d\n\nBut that relationship will be tested by the opening to the North, according to officials and outside analysts. The Trump administration already has a strained relationship with South Korea\u2019s progressive president, Moon Jae-in, who has called for dialogue with the North since his inauguration in May.\n\nAfter North Korea tested a nuclear bomb in September, Mr. Trump said on Twitter, \u201cSouth Korea is finding, as I have told them, that their talk of appeasement with North Korea will not work, they only understand one thing!\u201d\n\nDuring Mr. Moon\u2019s first visit to the White House, Mr. Trump delivered a harsh critique of South Korea\u2019s trade surplus with the United States. Negotiating teams from the two countries are scheduled to meet on Friday in Washington to begin discussing possible changes to the five-year-old Korea Free Trade agreement, which Mr. Trump has derided as \u201cnot exactly a great deal.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s a dilemma for the administration,\u201d said Michael J. Green, who was the top Asia adviser to President George W. Bush.\n\nVideo\n\n\u201cThe default position of the United States should be to support North-South dialogue,\u201d he said. \u201cAt the same time, they are understandably nervous about the Moon government, which has some members who are too breathless about the prospects for dialogue.\u201d\n\nMr. Green said he was guardedly optimistic because the Trump administration\u2019s strategy of imposing sanctions on North Korea had shown some signs of success, which would give South Korea confidence to stick with the United States.\n\nSouth Korea\u2019s public, he said, also remained suspicious of the North, which he said would limit the scope of Mr. Moon\u2019s diplomats to make overly generous concessions.\n\nDiplomats said it was important that South Korea appear to be in lock step with the United States. That would be easier to do, they said, if the talks remain focused on relatively narrow issues, like security at the Winter Olympics.\n\n\u201cIt is fine for the South Koreans to take the lead, but if they don\u2019t have the U.S. behind them, they won\u2019t get far with North Korea,\u201d said Daniel R. Russel, a former assistant secretary of state for East Asian and Pacific Affairs in the Obama administration. \u201cAnd if the South Koreans are viewed as running off the leash, it will exacerbate tensions within the alliance.\u201d\n\nMr. Russel and Mr. Green both said Mr. Trump would be a wild card in the delicate d\u00e9tente. So far, the president has shown skepticism about the opening, although he has not dismissed it. \u201cRocket man now wants to talk to South Korea for first time,\u201d Mr. Trump tweeted on Tuesday. \u201cPerhaps that is good news, perhaps not \u2014 we will see!\u201d\n\nBut the president has not hesitated to weigh in with provocative tweets if he judges that events have gone badly.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn the fall, he spent weeks praising President Xi Jinping of China for putting increased economic pressure on North Korea. Then, last month, Mr. Trump abruptly shifted his tone after reports that Chinese ships were transferring fuel to North Korea.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cCaught RED HANDED,\u201d he wrote on Twitter, \u201cvery disappointed that China is allowing oil to go into North Korea. There will never be a friendly solution to the North Korea problem if this continues to happen!\u201d\n\nOn Tuesday, Mr. Trump took shots at Pakistan and the Palestinian Authority, in addition to North Korea. Those tweets reverberated with both governments and could cause lasting damage. His message about his and Mr. Kim\u2019s nuclear buttons \u2014 coming on the day that the North made contact with the South \u2014 left diplomats shaking their heads.\n\n\u201cThis is where his Twitter account can cause an inflection point in the relationship,\u201d Mr. Green said.\n\nHe said it would be vital for Mr. Trump\u2019s national security and intelligence advisers to brief him on the diplomatic opening in a way that did not nurture his suspicions.\n\nBut the president\u2019s aides have little control over outside forces, like Mr. Kim\u2019s assertion in his New Year\u2019s Day speech that he had a nuclear button on his desk, and that all of the mainland United States was in range of a North Korean nuclear strike.\n\nThat was the claim that provoked Mr. Trump\u2019s tweet.\n\n\u201cCalling his nuclear arsenal too small is not the best way to persuade him to constrain that arsenal,\u201d Mr. Russel noted, referring to Mr. Kim.\n\nReferring to South Korea, Mr. Russel asked, \u201cWho is going to bear the brunt of this taunt?\u201d", "title": "As North and South Korea Begin to Talk, Trump Watches From Sidelines", "authors": ["Mark Landler"]} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "In a statement released on Friday the United States Embassy in London said that, in 2007, a plan was developed \u201cto finance a new embassy project through a property swap for existing U.S. government property in London. This solution allowed construction of a new chancery that meets all security standards, yet used no tax payer dollars to fund the project.\u201d\n\nVideo\n\n\u201cThe project budget was approximately $1 billion and includes the site purchase, design, and construction costs. The project has been executed within the established budget,\u201d the statement added.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn response to Mr. Trump\u2019s statement, Britain\u2019s foreign secretary, Boris Johnson, accused the opposition Labour Party\u2019s leader, Jeremy Corbyn, and the London mayor, Sadiq Khan, of having endangered the trans-Atlantic relationship.\n\nBut the furor illustrates the extent to which any potential visit by Mr. Trump to Britain has become politically polarizing, even as the country\u2019s establishment grapples with the question of whether to invite the president to the wedding of Prince Harry and the American actress Meghan Markle.\n\nMr. Trump visited several continental European countries last year, including France, where President Emmanuel Macron\u2019s handling of his American counterpart appeared to make the British look fumbling.\n\n\u201cMacron treated Trump with respect and warmth on the one hand,\u201d said Mark Leonard, director of the European Council on Foreign Relations, a research institute, \u201cbut on the other hand was principled in defense of French interests, and didn\u2019t give an iota on the substance.\u201d\n\nBy contrast, Mrs. May was \u201call over the place,\u201d Mr. Leonard added.\n\n\u201cThere was the attempt to rush over to the U.S. to embrace him, then she became implicated in the things he was doing, and then she had to pull back, so she\u2019s been zigzagging,\u201d he said. \u201cBritain then gets the worst of all worlds because it has confused everyone.\u201d\n\nWhile Mrs. May is keen to create closer ties with Washington, on many global issues her approach is more closely aligned with the positions of the European Union. She has expressed support both for the Paris climate change accord and the Iran nuclear deal, for example.\n\nAnd at home, Mr. Trump\u2019s statements have caused her problems. Last year Mr. Trump denounced Mr. Khan after his response to a bombing in June, misconstruing a call for calm as lack of concern about terrorist threats. And his tweets about a bombing in London in September suggested that the police had been monitoring attackers but had done nothing.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s retweets of a far-right group\u2019s anti-Muslim videos in November stirred criticism from across the political spectrum in Britain, and prompted Mrs. May to criticize him.\n\nMr. Khan said the president\u2019s Twitter postings made clear that Mrs. May had been mistaken to extend an invitation to Mr. Trump so quickly. \u201cIt appears that President Trump got the message from the many Londoners who love and admire America and Americans but find his policies and actions the polar opposite of our city\u2019s values of inclusion, diversity and tolerance,\u201d he said Friday in a Twitter post.\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s most vocal supporter in Britain, Nigel Farage, former leader of the United Kingdom Independence Party, told the BBC that he regretted that the president would not be opening the embassy.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s disappointing. He\u2019s been to countries all over the world and yet he\u2019s not been to the one with whom he\u2019s closest. I would say it\u2019s disappointing.\n\n\u201cBut maybe, just maybe, Sadiq Khan, Jeremy Corbyn and the Labour Party planning mass protests, maybe those optics he didn\u2019t like the look of,\u201d Mr. Farage added.\n\nSpurred on by the dispute, Madame Tussauds placed a statue of Mr. Trump outside the new embassy.\n\nYet there was no disguising the delight of some of Mr. Trump\u2019s critics at the news. One opposition Labour Party lawmaker, David Lammy, wrote on Twitter: \u201cHappy Friday everyone.\u201d", "title": "Trump Won\u2019t Visit London to Open Embassy. His U.K. Critics Say He Got the Message.", "authors": ["Stephen Castle", "Austin Ramzy"]} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "A year later, many of the business and political elites remain dismissive of him, privately rolling eyes and using words like \u201cmadman,\u201d but there was excitement about economic growth, and the tax cuts and regulatory rollback he has ushered in.\n\nThe real test of how the two sides will deal with each other will come Friday when Mr. Trump addresses the World Economic Forum. Mr. Trump\u2019s plan is not to stick his thumb in anyone\u2019s eye, aides said, but to soberly promote his view that trade should be fair and reciprocal while selling his story of economic energy and soliciting foreign investment. Whether he will follow the script, they acknowledged, was anyone\u2019s guess.\n\n\u201cThe question is whether he\u2019s here to be congratulated by the billionaires of Davos or to scold them on behalf of the people who elected him,\u201d said Robert A. Johnson, president of the Institute for New Economic Thinking, a research institution in New York. \u201cHe will act like he\u2019s doing both.\u201d\n\nAsked his message for Davos, Mr. Trump said: \u201cThe real message is we want great prosperity and we want great peace, and I think that\u2019s the message. It\u2019s been going really well. A lot of people are coming back to the United States. We are seeing tremendous investment, and today has been a very exciting day.\u201d\n\nDavos has never encountered anyone quite like Mr. Trump. For one week each year, this ski town is transformed into a festival of deal-making capitalism, international wonkery, late-night parties and earnest save-the-world panel discussions. Heads of state, corporate chieftains, policymakers and celebrities slip and slide along icy streets to stop in glass-enclosed, tech-heavy spaces set up by countries like India and South Africa and companies like Facebook and Google along the Promenade, the main drag.\n\nAt times, the tensions of the outside world follow them here. The Ukrainians were chagrined to discover this year that the space they rented at Promenade 73 turned out to be right across the street from Russia House at Promenade 72. Grim jokes ensued about the Russians crossing the road to take over a room in Ukraine House.\n\nUnlike other visitors, Mr. Trump did not wander the pavilions. He attended a reception in his honor by the forum, and then was host at a dinner for about 15 chief executives from firms like Siemens, Nokia, Nestle, HSBC, Anheuser-Busch and Bayer.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAs the executives tucked into grilled beef tenderloin or fried Swiss pikeperch with purple carrot pur\u00e9e, Mr. Trump flattered them as \u201csome of the greatest business leaders in the world\u201d and invited them to talk about their businesses, much as he does at cabinet meetings back home. Like his cabinet secretaries, many of the guests volunteered praise of the president and gratitude for his efforts to cut taxes and regulation.\n\nThe greeting did not surprise everyone. \u201cTrump made a Christmas gift to everyone with those tax rebates,\u201d said Charles-Edouard Bou\u00e9e, chief executive of Roland Berger, a global consultancy with offices in Shanghai and Munich.\n\nPhoto\n\nEven leaders with grievances against the Trump administration seemed intent on playing up to him.\n\n\u201cI found him to be a different person from his public persona,\u201d Prime Minister Shahid Khaqan Abbasi of Pakistan said at a breakfast on Thursday, recalling their encounter at the United Nations, while putting aside Mr. Trump\u2019s threat this month to suspend most security aid because of what he called Pakistan\u2019s \u201clies and deceit\u201d in dealing with terrorism. \u201cHe is a very warm person and he engaged me.\u201d\n\nAn aide to Mr. Trump who arrived before him expressed astonishment that he was being received so warmly by people he had criticized so harshly. But outside the president\u2019s earshot, there was still plenty of skepticism and concern.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAt a separate dinner on Thursday night, George Soros, the liberal financial trader and philanthropist, called Mr. Trump the vanguard of a new wave of authoritarian rulers that threatens open society.\n\n\u201cThe survival of our entire civilization is at stake,\u201d said Mr. Soros, while pointing a finger at \u201cthe rise of leaders like Kim Jong-un and Donald Trump.\u201d\n\nIn the days before Mr. Trump\u2019s arrival, the leaders of India, Canada, France and Germany used a series of high-profile speeches to mount an aggressive defense of the global trading system, while other officials worried that Mr. Trump and other nationalists posed grave risks.\n\n\u201cThe whole world is concerned that the United States is disengaging from the global trade arena,\u201d said Cecilia Malmstrom, trade minister for the European Union. \u201cI\u2019m extremely concerned.\u201d\n\nUnlike Bill Clinton, the only other sitting president to attend Davos, Mr. Trump has threatened to scrap the North American Free Trade Agreement with Mexico and Canada and a separate pact with South Korea in addition to the Trans-Pacific Partnership, or TPP, that he withdrew from shortly after taking office. Before leaving Washington this week, he slapped new tariffs on imported solar panels and washing machines.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut as he has on immigration in recent days, Mr. Trump toggled between being hard-line and accommodating. In an interview with CNBC to be aired on Friday before his speech, Mr. Trump raised the possibility of rejoining the Pacific partnership, which was negotiated by President Barack Obama but never submitted to Congress amid bipartisan opposition.\n\n\u201cI would do TPP if we were able to make a substantially better deal,\u201d Mr. Trump said. \u201cThe deal was terrible; the way it was structured was terrible. If we did a substantially better deal, I would be open to TPP.\u201d\n\nFor other Davos participants, more disturbing than his trade views were his utterances on race and gender, most recently in his resistance to immigrants from Haiti and Africa.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s disappointing to be written off by some ill-judged words,\u201d said Nicky Newton-King, chief executive of the Johannesburg Stock Exchange. \u201cOur exchange is regarded as world class. We\u2019re completely proud of what we\u2019re able to do in one of these countries the president is so dismissive of.\u201d\n\nLynette Wallworth, a virtual reality filmmaker from Australia who has traveled the world to introduce viewers to diverse cultures, expressed hope that Mr. Trump would use his time here to absorb challenging points of view.\n\n\u201cHe seems to talk about barriers,\u201d she said. \u201cHe needs to listen to the people who are gathered here, who are trying to make an inclusive world.\u201d\n\nTolu Oni, a professor at the University of Cape Town in South Africa, asked if Mr. Trump was capable of absorbing opinions that conflict with his preconceptions.\n\n\u201cI wonder what he will get from this,\u201d she said. \u201cI hope that in coming here, there is some degree of learning that national interests are not necessarily in contradiction with being a responsible global citizen.\u201d", "title": "Trump and Davos: Not Exactly Best Friends, but Not Enemies Either", "authors": ["Peter Baker", "Peter S. Goodman"]} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "Saturday is International Holocaust Remembrance Day. For President Trump, it is a shot at redemption.\n\nHe failed a moral test on the same occasion a year ago when he issued a message that strangely left out any specific reference to the six million Jews murdered in the Nazis\u2019 industrialized genocide. The White House cast the omission as somehow an \u201cinclusive\u201d approach because, it said, Roma, gays, the disabled and others were also victims. But Jews were unique targets. Failing to mention them was as bizarre as it would be to write a history of slavery and ignore the ordeal of Africans brought to America in chains.\n\nIt was an example of Mr. Trump\u2019s complex, at times disturbing, instincts in regard to Jews.\n\nOn one hand, his elder daughter is a convert to Judaism, married to an observant Jew. His years in New York real estate involved frequent dealings with Jewish counterparts. He has thrilled many American Jews by recognizing Jerusalem as Israel\u2019s capital (though he\u2019s displeased many more of them, who fear that this will impede the search for Middle East peace). At a ceremony on Capitol Hill in April, he spoke forcefully about the Holocaust as he pledged \u201cnever again.\u201d\n\nBut there\u2019s always another hand with Mr. Trump, and it can be unsightly.\n\nAfter a march that included neo-Nazis in Charlottesville, Va., last summer, the president said that there were \u201cvery fine people\u201d among them. No, there weren\u2019t. There are no very fine Nazis, neo or otherwise. He has passed along tweets from unabashedly anti-Semitic accounts, and has been slow to denounce assaults, vandalism and other Jew-hating acts, which the Anti-Defamation League says have risen sharply. In the first nine months of 2017, the latest period with available numbers, the league reported there were 1,299 such episodes, an increase of 67 percent over the 779 recorded in the same stretch of 2016.", "title": "Opinion | Trump and the Holocaust Remembrance: A Second Chance", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-31 00:00:00", "text": "Here\u2019s an annotated transcript of the speech, and some of the best writing about it from across the political spectrum.\n\n____\n\nPhoto\n\n3. In other news from the Justice Department:\n\nWe got an exclusive look at legal documents that show that prosecutors are seeking information on FIFA and Olympic organizations in a far-reaching investigation of international sports corruption.\n\nAbove, Hayward Field in Eugene, Ore., which was chosen to host the 2021 world track and field championships without a bidding process.\n\nAnd prosecutors moved to dismiss the corruption case against Senator Robert Menendez, the New Jersey Democrat. That will allow him to run for re-election without the cloud of an indictment hanging over him.\n\n____\n\nPhoto\n\n4. An Amtrak train carrying numerous Republican lawmakers to an annual retreat crashed into a large truck in Virginia.\n\nThe White House said that at least one person was killed and another seriously injured, but that the lawmakers and their staff members were fine.\n\nSenator Jeff Flake said in a TV interview that he had been in one of the front cars and helped carry an injured man from the truck to an ambulance.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n____\n\nPhoto\n\n5. The director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention resigned after criticism of her financial investments in tobacco and health care companies.\n\nDr. Brenda Fitzgerald, above, was appointed to the agency in July by Tom Price, who served as Mr. Trump\u2019s first Health and Human Services secretary \u2014 until he too was forced to resign, for traveling on private jets and charging them to the government.\n\n____\n\nPhoto\n\n6. The Federal Reserve left its benchmark interest rate unchanged at its final meeting under its departing chairwoman, Janet Yellen, above.\n\nThe rate remains in a range between 1.25 percent and 1.5 percent.\n\nJerome Powell, a member of the Fed\u2019s board since 2012, will take the oath of office as the new chairman on Monday.\n\n____\n\nPhoto\n\n7. Larry Nassar, the former doctor for the U.S. gymnastics team sentenced to more years than any human has ever lived, is back in court.\n\nBut it\u2019s a different courtroom in Michigan, handling a separate case involving sex abuse against minors. About 65 women and girls have signed up to speak for this sentencing.\n\nThe judge in this case, Janice Cunningham, said that there were more than 265 victims in total.\n\n____\n\nPhoto\n\n8. An amateur fossil hunter led experts to a rare cluster of dinosaur footprints on a slab of rock under a NASA parking lot in Maryland.\n\nAt one end of rock, above, is a single footprint from a young, long-necked sauropod. At the other end is one from a nodosaur, an armored plant-eater as heavy as a small elephant. Alongside are smaller footprints from a baby nodosaur, following its parent.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI was in ecstasy as a tracker,\u201d the fossil hunter said.\n\n____\n\nPhoto\n\n9. The Super Bowl\u2019s coming up this weekend, and our Cooking team has recipes at the ready for staples like chili, wings and dips.\n\nBut they suggest eating sensibly in preparation, offering, for instance, this Italian potato-pasta soup with greens.\n\nMarket Snapshot View Full Overview\n\n____\n\nPhoto\n\n10. Finally, the former adult film actress known as Stormy Daniels appeared on \u201cJimmy Kimmel Live!\u201d just moments after the State of the Union ended. She didn\u2019t confirm \u2014 or deny \u2014 reports of an affair with the president.\n\nOn another channel, and in another vein, \u201cThe Good Place,\u201d above, airs its season two finale on Thursday. Our critic says the NBC show\u2019s optimism about human nature is refreshing in an era of artistic bleakness.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s made humane and sidesplittingly entertaining television out of the notion that people \u2014 and even the occasional immortal demon \u2014 are redeemable,\u201d he writes.\n\nHave a great night.\n\n____\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story The Evening Briefing by Email Get a nightly rundown of the day\u2019s top stories, delivered to your inbox every Monday through Friday. But all but one of the lawmakers she briefed are Democrats. While some Republicans have raised concerns, they do so mostly in private. Others scoff at the question, dismissing it as outrageous character assassination.\n\nFew questions irritate White House aides more than inquiries about the president\u2019s mental well-being, and they argue that Mr. Trump\u2019s opponents are trying to use those questions to achieve what they could not at the ballot box.\n\n\u201cThis shouldn\u2019t be dignified with a response,\u201d said Kellyanne Conway, the White House counselor.\n\n\u201cThe partisans on Capitol Hill consulting with psychologists should reorient their spare time: support the president\u2019s positive agenda of middle class tax cuts, rebuilding infrastructure and the military, investing in our work force,\u201d Ms. Conway said later in an email. \u201cThe never-ending attempt to nullify an election is tiresome; if they were truly \u2018worried about the country,\u2019 they\u2019d get to work to help it.\u201d\n\nThomas J. Barrack, a friend of Mr. Trump\u2019s, was quoted in Michael Wolff\u2019s new book, \u201cFire and Fury: Inside the Trump White House,\u201d as telling a friend that the president was \u201cnot only crazy but stupid.\u201d In interviews, Mr. Barrack denied that and insisted that many people miss Mr. Trump\u2019s actual brilliance.\n\n\u201cPotus has learned over time that Socratic testing and a lack of predictability is a worthy weapon in both negotiations and in keeping his team well honed, unentitled and on alert,\u201d he said, using the initials for president of the United States. \u201cHe has no truck with political correctness, self-promotion or personal hubris of his team. This may cause him to appear at times to be overly realistic, blunt or to be politically insensitive even to his own subordinates. However, that is not the case.\u201d\n\nStill, in private, advisers to the president have at times expressed concerns. In private conversations over the last year, people who were new to Mr. Trump in the White House, which was most of the West Wing staff, have tried to process the president\u2019s speaking style, his temper, his disinterest in formal briefings, his obsession with physical appearances and his concern about the theatrics and excitement of his job.\n\nIn conversations with friends, Jared Kushner, the president\u2019s son-in-law and senior adviser, has said Mr. Trump is \u201ccrazy but he\u2019s a genius.\u201d Other advisers speak about the president as a volatile personality who has to be managed carefully. Mudslides in Montecito, Calif., wiped out entire blocks, killing at least 18 people with a brute force that shocked residents in areas that were hit hard by last month\u2019s wildfires.\n\nThe fires left the earth scorched, bare and vulnerable to sudden mudslides. Some faulted the authorities for not ordering a mandatory evacuation.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s apocalyptic,\u201d one resident said. This video shows the devastation.\n\n____\n\nPhoto\n\n4. Emilie K\u00f6nig, 33, spent the past five years living in Syria, where she became a prominent propagandist and recruiter for the Islamic State.\n\nNow she wants to return home \u2014 to France. The quandary her case poses is an increasingly common one for European countries: What should they do when citizens, who are also militants, want to come back?\n\n____\n\nPhoto\n\n5. At 54, Jeff Bezos of Amazon is the world\u2019s richest person, with a net worth of more than $100 billion.\n\nHe had stayed out of the limelight for years, but he\u2019s building a public persona now. He bought The Washington Post in October 2013, and this past week, he and his wife announced a $33 million donation for scholarships to Dreamers.\n\n\u201cHe\u2019s getting thanked at the Golden Globes and targeted by presidential tweet tantrums \u2014 not even Steve Jobs had that kind of pop-culture currency,\u201d one observer noted.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n____\n\nPhoto\n\n6. Facebook announced changes to its News Feed around the world. The company said it was trying to increase \u201cmeaningful interaction\u201d by drawing attention to content from family and friends while de-emphasizing feeds from brands and publishers.\n\nBut that could actually intensify the spread of fake news. We looked at a pilot program that Facebook ran last year in Slovakia, Sri Lanka, Cambodia, Bolivia, Guatemala and Serbia. It doesn\u2019t bode well. Above, Mark Zuckerberg.\n\n____\n\nPhoto\n\n7. Male models and assistants are accusing the fashion photographers Bruce Weber and Mario Testino of sexual misconduct.\n\nBoth are huge names: Mr. Weber is best known for his racy advertisements for Calvin Klein and Abercrombie & Fitch, while Mr. Testino is a favorite of the British royal family and Vogue. (He shot Serena Williams for the magazine\u2019s latest issue.)\n\nAbove from left, Ryan Locke, Robyn Sinclair and Terron Wood. Each said he had experienced sexual harassment during his time modeling.\n\nRepresentatives for both photographers said they were dismayed and surprised by the allegations. Cond\u00e9 Nast said it would stop working with the two men, at least for now.\n\n____\n\nPhoto\n\n8. Uber once paid a hacker a $100,000 bounty over a security breach that exposed the data of 57 million riders and drivers. Now the episode, which was not disclosed for a year, is turning into a serious black eye for the company.\n\nIt\u2019s the subject of four lawsuits, with attorneys general opening inquiries into whether the company broke the law. And Uber\u2019s response is fueling a wider debate about whether companies can scrupulously work with hackers at all.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n____\n\nPhoto\n\n9. As the Pittsburgh Steelers begin their march to a potential seventh Super Bowl championship on Sunday afternoon, we caught up with the family of Mike Webster, the stalwart center of the team\u2019s 1970s dynasty.\n\nWebster, who died in 2002, was the first N.F.L. player to receive a diagnosis of chronic traumatic encephalopathy, or C.T.E., the degenerative brain disease linked to repeated head hits. His case led to hundreds of others filed by retired N.F.L. players.\n\nBut Webster\u2019s family was excluded from a settlement because he died too early to be eligible. They\u2019re fighting the decision in court. Above, his son Garrett and ex-wife Pam.\n\n____\n\nPhoto\n\n10. \u201cSaturday Night Live\u201d welcomed back two alumni as guest stars in a sketch parodying the news show \u201cMorning Joe.\u201d Bill Murray appeared as the former Trump adviser Stephen Bannon, while Fred Armisen played Michael Wolff, the author of a new White House tell-all.\n\nAsked about inaccuracies in the book\u2019s reporting, Mr. Armisen was unapologetic. \u201cLook, you read it, right?\u201d he said. \u201cAnd you liked it, you had fun? Well, what\u2019s the problem? You got the gist, so shut up. Even the stuff that\u2019s not true, it\u2019s true.\u201d\n\nMarket Snapshot View Full Overview\n\n____\n\nPhoto\n\n11. Finally, a long weekend is a great time to daydream about a getaway.\n\nTo aid in that effort, here\u2019s our annual list of 52 places to inspire travelers.\n\nIt includes popular spots like New Orleans and lesser-known gems like Gansu, in China, and S\u00e3o Tom\u00e9 and Pr\u00ednc\u00edpe, on Africa\u2019s West Coast. Above, Lake Chaiquenes in Chile.\n\nThis year, for the first time, we are sending one writer to visit each and every place. We got 13,000 applications for the job. The icy wind steals your breath and freezes your eyelashes. You can\u2019t blink. Your lungs burn. The cold stabs your fingers and numbs your earlobes to rubber.\n\nThat was the status atop Mount Washington in New Hampshire, where the wind chill recently reached 89 below zero. We sent two (elated) reporters to experience it for themselves.\n\nMuch of the Northeast and Midwest spent the week locked in a snowy, unrelenting and dangerous freeze. Here\u2019s a breakdown by agency.", "title": "Trump, Syria, Women\u2019s March: Your Weekend Briefing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "2. The president made barely any mention of geopolitics, or major international issues like climate change. China was not noted at all. Nor was India, nor Iran nor even Europe.\n\nMr. Trump did, however, soften some of his nationalist rhetoric. He said he would \u201calways put America first, just as the leaders of other countries should put their countries first.\u201d\n\n\u201cBut America first does not mean America alone,\u201d he continued. \u201cWhen the United States grows, so does the world.\u201d\n\n3. Mr. Trump predicted the recently passed tax cuts \u2014 including a reduction in the corporate tax rate to 21 percent from 35 percent \u2014 would result in billions of dollars in new investments and jobs.\n\nThe actual impact remains unclear. But the president claimed that several business leaders had made such promises to him in private meetings.\n\n4. The president can stick to the script when he wants to. He read his entire speech carefully from a Teleprompter and did not go off-message \u2014 a tendency that has gotten him into trouble in the past.\n\nStill, he could not resist referring to \u201cfake news\u201d outlets in a brief question-and-answer session after his speech.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIt wasn\u2019t until I became a politician that I realized how nasty, how mean, how vicious, and how fake the press can be,\u201d he said.\n\n5. There is at least one new way for companies to curry favor with Mr. Trump: giving their workers payouts related to the tax cut.\n\nThe cascade of bonuses, the president said, had been \u201clike a big, beautiful waterfall.\u201d\n\nOf note: One company he specifically mentioned was the telecommunications giant AT&T, which is locked in a legal battle to get approval of its merger with Time Warner. \u2014REBECCA BLUMENSTEIN\n\nVideo\n\nPragmatist or populist? Trump walks a fine line.\n\nSpeakers at the World Economic Forum usually celebrate globalization, praise diversity and decry climate change. So Friday\u2019s speech by President Trump, who has at times voiced skepticism on all three stances, was warily awaited by the assembled business and government leaders.\n\nThey need not have worried.\n\nSounding more like the businessman he used to be than the outspoken populist he has become, Mr. Trump delivered a broad endorsement of recent Republican tax legislation. He said he favored free trade, provided that abusive trade practices by other countries were curbed. And he emphasized the importance of raising the prosperity of all Americans, particularly mentioning low unemployment among African-Americans.\n\nBut almost completely missing from his remarks was the sometimes confrontational nationalism of his election campaign and many of his tweets.\n\nMr. Trump instead portrayed the United States and other nations as having common interests.\n\nHe said that the United States was \u201clifting up forgotten communities,\u201d and was fulfilling the dreams of Americans for \u201ca great job, a safe home and a better life for their children.\u201d\n\nThe president also took credit for rising share prices: \u201cThe stock market is smashing one record after another.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. Trump took visible delight in talking about companies that have already responded by offering bonuses to their workers. The rapidity with which companies acted, Mr. Trump said, was \u201csomething we didn\u2019t anticipate.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut discerning the future direction of American economic policy, and particularly American trade policy, was hard to do from Friday\u2019s speech, as Mr. Trump instead appeared to be providing a broad vision of leadership. \u201cI think I\u2019ve been a cheerleader for our country,\u201d he said. \u2014KEITH BRADSHER\n\n\u2022 For more on the intersection of business and policy at Davos, check out the DealBook Briefing.\n\nQuotable\n\n\u201cThis was Donald Trump\u2019s Sinatra global leadership moment. He was able to say, \u2018I came to Davos, and I did it my way.\u2019 \u201d \u2014 Carlos Pascual, a former United States ambassador to Mexico and Ukraine who is now a senior vice president at IHS Markit. \u201cIt was impossible to guess what direction he will take.\u201d \u2014 Brian Mikkelsen, Denmark\u2019s minister of industry, business and financial affairs, on what trade policy Mr. Trump would pursue in the coming months.\n\nNow, about that Apple cash.\n\nDuring his speech, President Trump zeroed in on a recent announcement by Apple that it would bring the bulk of its foreign earnings back to the United States under a lower tax rate passed as part of the recent tax reform. Apple had said it estimated it would have a $350 billion impact on the American economy over the next five years.\n\nHow much of that goes beyond what Apple would have spent anyway?\n\nThe technology company\u2019s current pace of spending in the United States is $55 billion for 2018, so it was already on track to spend $275 billion over the next five years. After a $38 billion tax payment for repatriating money is subtracted, that leaves its new investment at roughly $37 billion over the next five years.\n\nHow much of that, if any, would go toward manufacturing was unclear. Apple has said it plans to open a new domestic campus that, at least initially, will house technical support for customers. More than $10 billion of planned capital expenditures will go toward American data centers. More than 20,000 new jobs will be spread across facilities old and new. \u2014TIFFANY HSU\n\nDid the president consider firing Mueller? \u2018Fake news,\u2019 he says.\n\nUpon arrival at the Congress Center in Davos, President Trump was greeted by a scrum of the forum\u2019s participants snapping cellphone photos and a large group of reporters asking why he had ordered the firing last June of Robert S. Mueller III, the special counsel, as The New York Times reported.\n\n\u201cFake news, folks,\u201d Mr. Trump replied. \u201cFake news. A typical New York Times fake story.\u201d \u2014ELISABETH BUMILLER\n\nIn Davos, politics at home is still at issue.\n\nWhile he is meeting with world leaders, President Trump is still partly focused on negotiations back home over immigration, asserting in an interview that he thought he could win over hard-liners in his party to a compromise deal.\n\nHe mentioned, in particular, Senators Tom Cotton of Arkansas, David Perdue of Georgia and John Cornyn of Texas, and Representative Robert W. Goodlatte of Virginia. \u201cThese are people that really have shifted a lot,\u201d he told CNBC. \u201cThey\u2019ve really shifted a lot and I think they\u2019re willing to shift more, and so am I.\u201d \u2014PETER BAKER\n\nVideo\n\nMending fences? Not with everyone.\n\nThe president expressed regret for sharing anti-Muslim videos originally posted by an ultranationalist fringe group in Britain, but he made no apology on Friday for calling African nations \u201cshithole countries,\u201d or some variant of that phrase.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Trump said that when he retweeted the videos, which portrayed Muslims as violent attackers, he knew nothing about Britain First, the group that had originally posted them.\n\n\u201cIf you are telling me they\u2019re horrible people, horrible, racist people, I would certainly apologize, if you\u2019d like me to do that,\u201d Mr. Trump told Piers Morgan of the British broadcaster ITV, in an interview scheduled to air on Sunday.\n\nThe rare expression of repentance \u2014 one of Mr. Trump\u2019s rules is \u201cnever apologize\u201d \u2014 came as the president sought to patch up a badly strained relationship with Britain.\n\nBut Mr. Trump\u2019s contrition and efforts at fence-mending went only so far: He ignored reporters\u2019 questions on Friday about his derogatory remarks about African countries this month.\n\nDuring a meeting with lawmakers, the president had said he thought the United States should accept more immigrants from countries like Norway, rather than Haiti or \u201cshithole countries\u201d in Africa, according to multiple reports. Mr. Trump has disputed the reports and some have suggested that he actually said \u201cshithouse countries.\u201d\n\nAfter the remark was made public, Paul Kagame, president of Rwanda and chairman of the African Union, issued a statement demanding a retraction and \u201can apology to not only the Africans but to all people of African descent around the globe.\u201d\n\nMr. Trump and Mr. Kagame met on Friday, shortly before Mr. Trump\u2019s scheduled address to the World Economic Forum.\n\nMr. Kagame said that he had \u201cgood discussions\u201d with Mr. Trump about the economy and trade, and he thanked Mr. Trump for his support. But the Rwandan leader made no mention of the furor over the comments. \u2014PETER BAKER", "title": "Trump, in Davos Speech, Sticks to Script as He Declares America Open for Business", "authors": ["The New York Times"]} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nDAVOS, Switzerland \u2014 President Trump sought to repair one diplomatic rift while widening another on Thursday as he smoothed over months of friction with Britain but threatened to cut financial aid to the Palestinians after they withdrew from peace discussions.\n\nSeparate meetings with the prime ministers of Britain and Israel showcased the wide disparity in Mr. Trump\u2019s ties with key counterparts. His session with Prime Minister Theresa May of Britain was tense as they tried to put the relationship back on track, while his sit-down with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel was warm as the two agreed on what they cast as Palestinian intransigence.\n\nThe strain between the United States and Britain, its closest ally, increased when Mr. Trump retweeted anti-Muslim videos posted by an ultranationalist British group, which Mrs. May called \u201cwrong,\u201d and culminated in his decision to cancel a scheduled visit to London, where the mayor declared him unwelcome. Sitting down on Thursday with Mrs. May, Mr. Trump said he was now exploring a visit later in the year and dismissed talk of discord as a \u201cfalse rumor.\u201d\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re on the same wavelength, I think, in every respect,\u201d Mr. Trump said. \u201cAnd the prime minister and myself have had a really great relationship, although some people don\u2019t necessarily believe that, but I can tell you it\u2019s true.\u201d He expressed respect for Mrs. May, and said he thought \u201cthe feeling is mutual from the standpoint of liking each other a lot,\u201d adding that the two were \u201cvery much joined at the hip\u201d on military matters.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMrs. May was polite but less effusive and offered no personal testimonial to Mr. Trump, keeping her comments focused on their mutual national interests. \u201cWe, too, have that really special relationship between the U.K. and the United States,\u201d she said. \u201cIt\u2019s at each other\u2019s shoulders. We face the same challenges across the world, and as you say we\u2019re willing to go and to defeat those challenges and meet them.\u201d", "title": "Trump, in Davos, Mends Split With Britain and Widens One With Palestinians", "authors": ["Peter Baker"]} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "So, what\u2019s being sold here? Trump gave a big number, $1.5 trillion. But a leaked draft of the plan says that it will involve only $200 billion of federal money. The rest is supposed to be induced spending from private investors. That\u2019s quite a trick. How does it work?\n\nThe answer is, basically, that it doesn\u2019t. Private investors won\u2019t spend on public infrastructure unless guaranteed a return. This only works if they\u2019re given ownership, and the ability to collect future revenue from the public.\n\nFirst point: lots of infrastructure just can\u2019t work that way. There\u2019s no way to turn sewer systems, protective levees on rivers, and lots of other stuff into profit centers.\n\nSecond, even where it does work \u2014 say, on toll roads and bridges \u2014 that private investment doesn\u2019t come free; it\u2019s in return for the ability to collect fees from the public, which is just taxation in another form. And there\u2019s no evidence that doing public investment this way saves any money. On the contrary, it usually ends up costing taxpayers more than just having the government build the thing.\n\nWait, it gets worse. Where does even the $200 billion come from? It\u2019s not at all clear that it\u2019s new money; much of it would probably be money that would have been spent on public projects anyway.\n\nWhat this means is that we aren\u2019t talking about a program to build infrastructure so much as a plan to convert what should have been public projects into private ventures, presumably with big tax breaks.", "title": "Opinion | Trumpfrastructure Is a Scam", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-22 00:00:00", "text": "Under the pressure of anti-racist and immigrant rights pressure, the system fell in 1965 with the passage of the Hart-Celler Act, which foregrounded family reunification, refugee admissions and the entry of the highly skilled and educated. But racism persisted in both policy enforcement and popular attitudes.\n\nNew caps on Western Hemisphere migration \u2014 flying in the face of United States demand for workers, an entrenched labor migration industry and poverty and repression in Latin America that forced thousands into exile \u2014 outlawed decades-old migration flows. In the 1990s new nativist movements directed against Latin Americans arose, as well as efforts to eliminate migrants\u2019 rights to basic services and the expansion of immigrant incarceration and mass deportation. In the aftermath of Sept. 11, the principle that immigrants from Muslim-majority countries required special scrutiny and restriction was central to the remaking of immigration policy in the name of national security.\n\nThe prevailing questions we\u2019re conditioned to ask about immigrants have all been deeply shaped by histories of racial restriction. Can \u201cwe\u201d assimilate and civilize \u201cthem\u201d? Will \u201cthey\u201d \u2014 despite their negative features and the risks they pose \u2014 make \u201cus\u201d wealthier and more powerful? Will \u201cthey\u201d sap \u201cour\u201d resources?\n\nThis past week, liberals, progressives and others protesting Mr. Trump\u2019s comments about Haiti, El Salvador, and the countries of Africa understandably rushed to defend them as beautiful, dignified places unworthy of his vulgar derision. But in this defensive posture of response, which inadvertently legitimates the questions it answers, one can also feel the overwhelming presence of racist suspicion and hostility roaring out of the past into our time.\n\nWe will not, ultimately, succeed in deposing Mr. Trump\u2019s hateful, racist approach toward immigrants unless we refuse not only his nastiest word choices, but also the underlying questions he and others insist we ask.\n\nWe can choose to ask different questions: To what extent are the countries of the global north implicated in forces that prevent people in the global south from surviving and thriving where they are? In what ways do restrictive immigration policies heighten the exploitation of workers? How does the fear of deportation make migrant workers easier to discipline, hurt and rob? In what ways does mass migration from the poorer parts of the earth to centers of wealth and power reflect the larger problem of global inequality?\n\nElites in the United States and elsewhere \u2014 long before Donald Trump\u2019s presidency \u2014 have long known they could sustain their power by capitalizing on, deepening and, where necessary, inventing divisions between self and other, friend and enemy. This political strategy, with troubling successes to its name, has been updated and rescaled for our globalized age, in which the fault lines are those of bordered nationality: There will be no protection offered from polluters or health insurance companies, but the threat of Muslims and Mexicans will be met.\n\nTo the white nationalists\u2019 war cry against migrants, \u201cYou will not replace us,\u201d we can and should reply, as have many before, \u201cYou will not divide us.\u201d", "title": "Opinion | Trump\u2019s Anti-Immigrant Racism Represents an American Tradition", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-02 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nWASHINGTON \u2014 President Trump claimed undue credit on Tuesday for keeping the skies safe.\n\n\u201cSince taking office I have been very strict on Commercial Aviation. Good news - it was just reported that there were Zero deaths in 2017, the best and safest year on record!\u201d Mr. Trump posted on Twitter.\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s claim came on the heels of two reports that there were no fatal commercial passenger jet accidents in 2017; however, there were several fatal crashes involving smaller planes. The Aviation Safety Network said there were 10 fatal charter and cargo plane accidents last year, and To70, a Dutch aviation consulting firm, noted two fatal accidents on regional airliners in Angola and Russia.\n\n\u201cPresident Trump has raised the bar for our nation\u2019s aviation safety and security,\u201d Raj Shah, a White House spokesman, said in a statement. Mr. Shah cited Mr. Trump\u2019s push to privatize air traffic control and the Department of Homeland Security\u2019s guidelines for enhanced screening of passengers and electronics on flights bound for the United States.\n\nA bill proposing air traffic control privatization has stalled in Congress, so it is implausible that it had any effect on airline safety \u2014 in the United States or anywhere else in the world. The last fatal accident in a passenger plane operated by a domestic airline was in 2009, according to the National Transportation Safety Board, when a commuter plane headed for Buffalo crashed, killing all 49 people on board.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Get the Morning Briefing by Email What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox Monday through Friday. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe enhanced screenings were meant to deter terrorism, but fatalities on airlines in 2016 largely resulted from crashes, To70 reported.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOf the seven fatal accidents that occurred that year \u2014 on Somali, Nepalese, Emirati, Egyptian, Bolivian and Pakistani airlines \u2014 four were caused by bad weather or technical malfunction and one by a suicide bombing. Two are currently under investigation. None were bound for the United States.", "title": "Trump\u2019s Aviation Boast Fails to Get in the Air", "authors": ["Linda Qiu"]} {"date": "2018-01-31 00:00:00", "text": "He took full credit for every good thing that has happened in the last year, and if he did it with less grace and more braggadocio than most, well, that is what politicians do. The economy, in the ninth year of its expansion, is good, and the Islamic State has been vanquished, for now, even if it had already been reduced to a single, besieged city in the desert.\n\nIf it seems remarkable that this thrice-married serial groper, who demonstrated during the campaign that he did not understand the most basic tenets of Christianity, would shout out: \u201cWe know that faith and family, not government and bureaucracy, are the center of American life. The motto is \u2018In God We Trust!\u2019\u201d \u2014 well, that\u2019s par for the course as well, in our post-hypocrisy age.\n\nThere was the expected laundry list of hoary, right-wing shibboleths, grudges and chimeras. We have, somehow, a military that is not yet \u201cfully\u201d funded, and a nuclear arsenal that we need to \u201crebuild\u201d so that it will \u201cdeter any acts of aggression.\u201d We have \u201creleased hundreds and hundreds of terrorists, only to meet them again on the battlefield,\u201d but under Mr. Trump, we have at least deported or jailed \u201cthousands and thousands and thousands\u201d of deadly gang members. It seems that \u201cwe are now very proudly an exporter of energy to the world\u201d (we were before) and \u201cour warriors in Afghanistan\u201d will \u201cno longer\u201d be \u201cundermined by artificial timelines,\u201d and we will \u201cno longer tell our enemy our plans.\u201d (Translation, warriors: you\u2019re going to be there forever.)\n\nIt was at its heart, though, a nasty little speech, one in which Mr. Trump brought the already odious State of the Union tradition of exploiting human props to a shameless new low. Again and again, he used actual people in the audience to turn real human tragedies and triumphs into taunting slaps at the opposition.\n\nA little boy\u2019s campaign to put American flags on the graves of veterans was turned seamlessly into another smack at the black athletes who dared to protest racism by kneeling during the national anthem. Conversely, one of the most horrific mass shootings in American history was heralded for \u201cstrangers shielding strangers from gunfire on the Vegas Strip.\u201d\n\nMost revolting of all, though, was the moment when Mr. Trump sank to using the weeping parents of two murdered teenage girls on Long Island to associate the MS-13 gang first with the tens of thousands of unaccompanied minors who seek refuge in the United States every year from the violence in their home countries and then by implication with Latino immigrants and even the Dreamers. Mr. Trump pivoted quickly from the parents to this:\n\nMy duty, and the sacred duty of every elected official in this chamber, is to defend Americans \u2014 to protect their safety, their families, their communities, and their right to the American dream. Because Americans are dreamers too.\n\nHis turning on the Dreamers like this even as he supposedly advocated for them was a blood libel beyond anything I have heard from an American president. It was cheered to the rafters by the members of Mr. Trump\u2019s party, which proved once again how much they deserve one another.", "title": "Opinion | Trump\u2019s Besotted Republicans", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "A few hours before Donald Trump\u2019s first State of the Union speech on Tuesday evening, the news broke that the White House was scrapping its choice for ambassador to South Korea, a position that remains unfilled a year into the administration.\n\nAccording to The Washington Post, the nomination of Victor D. Cha, a hawkish veteran of the George W. Bush administration, was very close to being sent to the Senate, but was derailed when Cha privately expressed reservations about a preventive American strike on North Korea. The Financial Times reported that Cha was asked if he was \u201cprepared to help manage the evacuation of American citizens from South Korea,\u201d which would be necessary in the event of an American bombing. This is terrifying, because it suggests that Trump is serious about starting a war.\n\nIndeed, Cha himself seems frightened; just before the State of the Union started, he published an op-ed in The Washington Post arguing against a preventive attack. Apparently assuming that some readers would be indifferent to millions of potential Korean deaths, Cha emphasized that many Americans would also die in a military confrontation. \u201cTo be clear: The president would be putting at risk an American population the size of a medium-size U.S. city \u2014 Pittsburgh, say, or Cincinnati \u2014 on the assumption that a crazy and undeterrable dictator will be rationally cowed by a demonstration of U.S. kinetic power,\u201d he wrote.\n\nCha\u2019s warning made Trump\u2019s State of the Union bellicosity toward North Korea particularly frightening. More than an hour into an interminable speech, Trump said, \u201cNorth Korea\u2019s reckless pursuit of nuclear missiles could very soon threaten our homeland.\u201d He added: \u201cPast experience has taught us that complacency and concessions only invite aggression and provocation. I will not repeat the mistakes of past administrations that got us into this very dangerous position.\u201d", "title": "Opinion | Trump\u2019s Boring, Utterly Terrifying Warmongering", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-17 00:00:00", "text": "With the report in hand, Mr. Trump has broad license to apply tariffs, quotas or both to steel imports. And he can do it safely: While there has been speculation about potential retaliation against the United States if it raises import restrictions, an exception in the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade permits them for security purposes.\n\nMr. Trump should make use of his authority in this case. Even in this digital age, steel undergirds our military power, not to mention critical infrastructure. Tanks, aircraft carriers and the energy grid all rely on high-strength, lightweight steel. That steel has been made in America for generations.\n\nThe security of our own steel industry, though, has been in doubt for a long time. Domestic steel production peaked in 1973. The industry is now operating at less than three-fourths of its capacity. Thousands of steelworkers have been laid off since 2015, and those still working know their jobs are under constant threat. Only one American company makes essential electrical steel, and only one other supplies the type of steel needed to make Virginia-class submarines, the generation of attack submarines that are expected to be in production until 2043.\n\nThe main culprit? In this case, Mr. Trump is right to blame China, which has added 550 million metric tons of steel capacity \u2014 more than six times total American production \u2014 since 2007, when Beijing first acknowledged it was making more steel than it could use. A significant amount of that steel has flooded global markets. Today, most of the world\u2019s largest steel companies are state-owned Chinese firms. Whether or not you believe Beijing\u2019s intent was to disrupt our own industry, that has certainly been the effect.\n\nWhile Mr. Trump deserves credit for opening the national security review of steel imports, he has made plenty of mistakes regarding trade along the way. Initiating the 232 investigation and then sitting on it for months was feckless; American steel imports spiked by 15.5 percent in 2017 as foreign steel makers rushed in products ahead of tariffs that have yet to materialize.", "title": "Opinion | Trump\u2019s Chance to Save American Steel", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "He also ordered targeted sanctions against the head of Iran\u2019s judiciary, Sadeq Larijani, a powerful figure whom the administration holds culpable for the violent crackdown on the protests, as well as against an Iranian cyberwarfare unit that it accuses of internet censorship.\n\nThe nuclear deal, Mr. Trump said, drove Iranians into the streets because the government misused the proceeds from the lifting of sanctions. \u201cIt has served as a slush fund for weapons, terror and oppression, and to further line the pockets of corrupt regime leaders,\u201d he said in a statement.\n\nBut that is precisely why European leaders argue that keeping the deal in place makes even more sense now: because it keeps a harsh spotlight on Iran\u2019s leaders, and their malfeasance, rather than allowing the Iranians to paint the United States and its allies as the villains.\n\nDiplomats from several European countries said that renegotiating the deal was a nonstarter. The best Mr. Trump could hope for, one official said, would be a commitment from Europe to begin work on a new and separate agreement. Such a step, they said, would require the participation of China and Russia, which are also signatories to the deal, as well as Iran itself \u2014 something the White House ruled out.\n\n\u201cIf we want seriously to be able to raise the price to the Iranians of what they are doing internally and externally, we need the Europeans,\u201d said Dennis B. Ross, a former adviser to President Barack Obama who helped devise his Iran policy. \u201cBut if they think that we are only interested in walking away from the nuclear deal, they won\u2019t join us.\u201d\n\nThe administration, other experts said, is locked into a policy that has two major pillars: dismantling Mr. Obama\u2019s nuclear deal and confronting Iran on its aggression in the region, through its support of militant groups like Hezbollah in Lebanon and other proxies in Yemen, Syria and Iraq.\n\nThat is not surprising, given that the defense secretary, Jim Mattis, and the national security adviser, Lt. Gen. H. R. McMaster, are former commanders who served in Iraq and blame Iran for the death of American soldiers there.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nEven below that level, the administration\u2019s Iran policy is heavily influenced by the military. Joel Rayburn, the top Iran policymaker at the National Security Council, is a former military intelligence officer, as is Andrew L. Peek, a senior Iran policymaker at the State Department. Several of the department\u2019s nonmilitary Iran experts have been pushed out in recent months.\n\nPhoto\n\nNow, the administration is suddenly grappling with an Iranian government that is weakened and divided by the protests \u2014 a political development that the Americans did not anticipate.\n\n\u201cWhen you\u2019re dealing with Iran\u2019s regional affairs, you\u2019re dealing with how it supplies proxies and militias,\u201d said Ray Takeyh, an Iran expert at the Council on Foreign Relations who worked in the Obama administration. \u201cIf you\u2019re thinking about Iran\u2019s internal problems, that is a more difficult problem. You\u2019re thinking about fissures, and how to exploit them.\u201d\n\nMr. Takeyh said Mr. Obama was similarly caught off guard in 2009 by the protests that became known as the Green Movement. At the time, he was trying to entice Iran\u2019s supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, into talks. That is one reason he reacted so little to those protests \u2014 a reaction that Mr. Trump criticized in his statement on Friday.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box.
