Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIdeally, Mr. Ross said, policy toward Iran would be a mix of coercive measures and diplomatic inducements. \u201cWith Obama, one could argue that the coercive part of the equation was not believable,\u201d he said. \u201cWith Trump, the diplomatic side of the equation may prove not to be believable.\u201d\n\nThe White House appears to recognize the weakness in its diplomatic ranks. It is considering the appointment of a special envoy for Iran, who could negotiate with the Europeans on the nuclear deal, as well as marshal a stronger response to Iran\u2019s behavior in the region.\n\nAny envoy would face a tough task: Administration officials said Mr. Trump was demanding an agreement that would eliminate all \u201csunset clauses,\u201d under which Iran can resume activities like enriching uranium, and would explicitly link its nuclear and ballistic missile programs. Iran fought against both of these demands in the negotiations that led to the 2015 deal.\n\nWith North Korea, the administration\u2019s policy has been more balanced between diplomacy and military planning. But the talks between the Koreas have undermined Mr. Trump\u2019s strategy, which is to impose maximum pressure on Pyongyang \u2014 including the threat of a military strike \u2014 to pressure Mr. Kim into giving up his nuclear arsenal.\n\nThe White House has sent General McMaster and the N.S.C.\u2019s top Asia policymaker, Matthew Pottinger, to San Francisco, where they will meet with their counterparts from South Korea and Japan to discuss the implications of the North-South dialogue.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nGeneral McMaster has spoken publicly about the need to prepare for a \u201cpreventive war\u201d against North Korea. Mr. Pottinger, a retired Marine, also has a background in military intelligence, though at other times, he worked as a journalist and for a hedge fund.\n\nWhite House officials are deeply skeptical of the overture from Mr. Kim to South Korea. They say he is trying to drive a wedge between South Korea and the United States. And they have urged the South Koreans to keep the exchanges limited to narrow issues, like security at the coming Winter Olympics in the South Korean town of Pyeongchang.\n\nMr. Trump, however, appears caught between continuing to heap ridicule on Mr. Kim and taking credit for the diplomatic opening. At Camp David last weekend, the president said he hoped the talks ranged far beyond the Olympics, and he backed them in a call with South Korea\u2019s president, Moon Jae-in.\n\nThe trajectory of the talks may be out of Mr. Trump\u2019s control anyway, according to experts on the region. Mr. Moon was elected on a platform of reducing tensions with the North. Young South Koreans, in particular, view Mr. Trump\u2019s threats of war on North Korea with alarm \u2014 sometimes even more than the danger posed by Mr. Kim.\n\n\u201cThe North Korea issue may be entering a new phase,\u201d said Evan S. Medeiros, the top Asia adviser in Mr. Obama\u2019s N.S.C. \u201cMoon\u2019s agenda and perceptions seem to be evolving, and, as cynical as we all are about North Korea, it is worth asking the question: Is Kim actually looking for a negotiated off-ramp, and what would such behavior look like?\u201d\n\n\u201cIs the Trump administration, which has understandably focused on coercive tools to date, nimble enough to respond to this evolution?\u201d he said.", "title": "Trump\u2019s Demand to Rewrite Iran Deal Tests a Weakened Diplomatic Corps", "authors": ["Mark Landler"]} {"date": "2018-01-04 00:00:00", "text": "After almost a year in office, President Trump has yet to name a science adviser and director of the White House Office of Science and Technology Policy. Since World War II, no American president has shown greater disdain for science \u2014 or more lack of awareness of its likely costs.\n\nThe O.S.T.P. was authorized by Congress in May 1976 to give the president \u201cindependent, expert judgment and assistance on policy matters which require accurate assessments of the complex scientific and technological features involved.\u201d It has played an important role in coordinating national science and technology activities and policies among federal agencies.\n\nThe director of the office, who is nominated by the president and requires Senate approval, typically serves as the president\u2019s science adviser, providing him with confidential, unbiased counsel. Much of what the federal government does and the many policy changes the president and his appointees are now making or hope to make have scientific and technological underpinnings.\n\nThe science adviser is the one individual who can quickly pull all the relevant information together for the president, cut through conflicting advice coming from other senior advisers and Cabinet secretaries, and get evidence-based options in front of him. Especially important has been the adviser\u2019s role in helping the president deal with crises \u2014 Sept. 11, the subsequent anthrax attacks, the Fukushima nuclear nightmare in 2011, the Ebola and Zika outbreaks, hurricane devastation and cyberattacks.", "title": "Opinion | Trump\u2019s Disdain for Science", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "Thursday\u2019s report in The Times that President Trump ordered the firing of the special counsel Robert Mueller last June, only to back off after the White House counsel, Donald McGahn, threatened to resign, is explosive on many levels.\n\nOn the surface, the revelation is one more piece of damning evidence in the now-overwhelming case of obstruction of justice that Mr. Mueller has assembled. The core of the case \u2014 the Feb. 14 meeting in which Mr. Trump asked the director of the F.B.I., James Comey, to drop the investigation against the national security adviser, Michael Flynn; Mr. Trump\u2019s subsequent sacking of Mr. Comey; and Mr. Trump\u2019s serial lies about Mr. Comey\u2019s firing \u2014 has long been solid. And Mr. Mueller has added significant pieces of circumstantial evidence, such as Mr. Trump\u2019s apparent knowledge that Mr. Flynn had lied to the F.B.I. when he buttonholed Mr. Comey.\n\nThursday\u2019s revelation seals the deal. The president\u2019s attempted ouster of Mr. Mueller seems plainly to have been intended to squelch Mr. Mueller\u2019s investigation. Moreover, Mr. Trump\u2019s attempts to conceal the obvious with a rank, virtually comical explanation provide additional evidence of guilty intent. Mr. Mueller, the president argued, could not serve because, years before, he had resigned his membership at the Trump National Golf Club in Virginia because of a dispute over fees; or he needed to be fired because he had worked at the law firm that previously represented Mr. Trump\u2019s son-in-law, Jared Kushner.\n\nWhy strain to concoct such feeble rationales unless the truth is indefensible?\n\nThen there is the provocative point that Mr. Trump\u2019s efforts were parried by the threat to resign of his own White House counsel, Mr. McGahn. White House counsels are not in the habit of bucking their bosses that way; it\u2019s an extraordinarily rare event.", "title": "Opinion | Trump\u2019s Efforts to Oust Mueller Show the \u2018Cancer\u2019 on This Presidency", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cIt bobs up and down day to day, and if you spend all your time worrying about that, then you\u2019re probably going to get the long-term strategy wrong,\u201d he said.\n\nAt the same time, he observed, stocks had fallen so far after the financial crisis that their price-to-earnings ratios were nearing their bottom. Given that, and the government\u2019s enormous fiscal stimulus program, Mr. Obama said it might be a good time to get back into the market.\n\n\u201cHe got substantial blowback for those comments and was advised \u2014 and took the advice \u2014 not to prognosticate on the market again,\u201d said Jason Furman, who was one of Mr. Obama\u2019s economic advisers.\n\nFor all the mocking he got, Mr. Furman noted that Mr. Obama was right. The stock market bottomed out six days after his remarks and had bounced back 21 percent a month later. Mr. Obama mentioned the market several other times during his presidency, but Mr. Furman said he stayed away from commenting on day-to-day gyrations.\n\nPresident Bill Clinton also presided over a bubbly stock market but resisted the urge to gloat about it. Former aides said he was repeatedly invited to ring the bell at the New York Stock Exchange to open trading, but they always told him to decline. That reluctance proved wise when the bubble in technology stocks began bursting almost a year before Mr. Clinton left office.\n\n\u201cWe had a view that markets could go up, markets could go down, markets could be overvalued, markets could be undervalued,\u201d said Gene Sperling, an economic adviser to Mr. Clinton. \u201cBut it would take your eye off the ball to focus on that rather than on the real economy.\u201d", "title": "Trump\u2019s Enthusiasm for Stock Market Collides With His Trade Plans", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 In an early-morning Twitter post, President Trump insisted on Thursday that he has been unwavering in his stance for building a border wall between Mexico and the United States to thwart illegal immigration.\n\nHe was responding to \u2014 and directly contradicting \u2014 private statements by John F. Kelly, his chief of staff, who told the Congressional Hispanic Caucus on Wednesday that Mr. Trump had not been \u201cfully informed\u201d when he first promised the wall, and that the president\u2019s position on building it had \u201cevolved\u201d over time.\n\n\u201cThe Wall is the Wall, it has never changed or evolved from the first day I conceived of it,\u201d Mr. Trump wrote on Twitter at 6:15 a.m. Thursday.", "title": "Trump\u2019s Evolving Words on the Wall", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-03 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 President Trump kicked off the new year with more than a dozen Twitter posts castigating his enemies and political foes and complimenting himself.\n\nSeventeen times on his first work day of the new year in Washington, the president thumbed his thumbs at convention. The objects of his attention had a vast and seemingly disconnected range, from taunting Kim Jong-un about his nuclear prowess to flaunting his own successes. But there was more. He made an only-in-the-Trump-era kind of news by announcing a reality-style creation unique in presidential history: awards for the \u201cmost dishonest & corrupt media.\u201d\n\nHe also threw in a couple of posts that were utterly bland in comparison, good wishes to Senator Orrin G. Hatch, the Republican from Utah who announced his retirement, and a pledge of support for the nation\u2019s veterans. He also showed a fixated consistency by again railing against \u201ccrooked\u201d Hillary Clinton and her aide, Huma Abedin.\n\nIf there was a strategy to his post-vacation social media burst, it was not readily apparent.\n\nOn Iran", "title": "Trump\u2019s First Big Twitter Day of 2018: Analyzing Nuclear Buttons and the \u2018Corrupt Media\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-09 00:00:00", "text": "Historically, presidential checkups tend to buoy whatever image the candidate and president have presented about his health. For that reason, said Robert Dallek, a presidential historian, physicals should be of \u201cprobably zero\u201d interest to the public.\n\n\u201cDid the White House always tell us what the doctors found?\u201d Mr. Dallek said in an interview. \u201cAre the doctors candid? If they found signs of early dementia, and they told him, would he tell the public?\u201d\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s physical is scheduled to take place at the Walter Reed National Military Medical Center in Bethesda, Md., with a post-physical readout to be given by Dr. Ronny L. Jackson, a rear admiral in the Navy and the current White House physician. Dr. Jackson oversaw Mr. Obama\u2019s physicals and was part of the medical team involved in at least one of Mr. Bush\u2019s physicals.\n\nDr. Jackson assumed care of the president when Mr. Trump entered office and has spent a \u201csignificant\u201d amount of time with him over the past year, Ms. Sanders said. Dr. Jackson is also the physician from the White House medical unit who is with Mr. Trump most often.\n\nBecause Mr. Trump is a commander in chief who is selective about releasing information about his personal life, questions have been raised about the reliability of the information he shares with the public. In the past, physicians examining presidents have mischaracterized or hidden illnesses to present them as healthier: President Franklin D. Roosevelt readily acknowledged his polio, for instance, but his White House doctor hid the severe high blood pressure that led to heart failure.\n\nThe Trump White House has not disclosed the names and specialties of the medical professionals who will be evaluating the president, as a number of his predecessors have. The responsibility of determining the types of medical tests needed and specialists included in the physical falls to Dr. Jackson.\n\nMr. Trump was observed to have slurred speech during a December speech acknowledging Jerusalem as Israel\u2019s capital, but it is unclear if a neurologist or speech pathologist will be involved in the physical. (\u201cThe president\u2019s throat was dry,\u201d Ms. Sanders said at the time. \u201cNothing more than that.\u201d)\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAs questions about Mr. Trump\u2019s mental health have increased, psychiatrists are openly debating the so-called Goldwater Rule. Generated after the erratic candidacy of Senator Barry Goldwater, the 1964 Republican presidential nominee, the rule bars members of the American Psychiatric Association from evaluating anyone they have not personally examined.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Trump would still be expected to be screened for problems like unusual anxiety or stress: The physicians involved in the president\u2019s care are trained to observe him as any other patient and ask questions for clues to such problems.\n\nAs he recently defended his mental acuity, Mr. Trump invoked the name of a predecessor who faced similar scrutiny while in office, though not to this degree.\n\nIn a tweet last weekend, Mr. Trump wrote:\n\nAt 69, Ronald Reagan was the oldest person elected to the office \u2014 a record Mr. Trump surpassed in 2016 when he was elected at 70. Reagan, who, like Mr. Trump, had a family history of Alzheimer\u2019s, said in an interview in 1980 before he took office that he would resign if deemed unfit. In 1994, nearly six years after leaving office, Reagan was diagnosed with Alzheimer\u2019s, though there is no conclusive evidence he had the disease while in office.\n\nWhether or not Reagan showed signs of the disease while in office \u2014 and if those symptoms affected his decision-making ability \u2014 has become a contentious issue of interest to historians and policymakers. Doctors are increasingly paying attention to screening for cognitive function in all older people.\n\nBoth Mr. Trump and his former Democratic opponent, Hillary Clinton, were urged to undergo baseline cognitive testing for comparative purposes if symptoms developed during their presidency. Neither candidate is known to have undergone brain scans or other related tests, which are considered useful but not definitive.\n\nMr. Obama\u2019s physicians noted his levels of prostate specific antigen, or PSA, a marker for prostate cancer. Dr. Harold N. Bornstein, Mr. Trump\u2019s former personal physician, wrote in letters during the campaign that Mr. Trump\u2019s PSA level was 0.15. Urologists not connected with Mr. Trump said they suspected that he had been treated for an enlarged prostate or prostate cancer.\n\nThen Dr. Bornstein said in an interview with The New York Times last February that Mr. Trump takes a small dose of finasteride, a drug that is marketed as Propecia to treat male-pattern baldness and lowers PSA levels.\n\nMr. Trump played sports as a youth but appears to have dropped the habit as an adult. The consequences of Mr. Trump\u2019s sedentary lifestyle may be reflected in the readout. Documented substantial weight gain may raise concerns about the state of his heart. Doctors may recommend an exercise tolerance test and other measures of heart function.\n\nMr. Trump is said to get little daily activity beyond walking the stairs in his residence and, on days when he has trips, strolling across the White House lawn to Marine One. At the group of Group of 7 summit meeting last May, Mr. Trump took a golf cart a short distance while other leaders walked.", "title": "Trump\u2019s First Full Physical Is Approaching. What He Discloses Is Up to Him.", "authors": ["Katie Rogers", "Lawrence K. Altman"]} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "But aside from a few offerings to the Democrats, mainly he appealed to enthusiastic Republicans. He did propose paid family leave and backed vocational schools and job training, winning grudging applause from Democrats.\n\nBut his policy proposals were conservative: Keep open the military prison at Guant\u00e1namo Bay, Cuba, burn coal, and above all, take on an immigration system that favors family reunification over skills-based migration.\n\nAt one hour and 20 minutes, it was also the third longest State of the Union speech in the last 50 years.\n\nAn annotated copy of Mr. Trump\u2019s speech can be read here \u00bb.\n\nHe had an economy to sell, but could he sell himself?\n\nWhen he took office, President Trump painted a bleak picture of a country ravaged by economic turmoil, a landscape of \u201cAmerican carnage,\u201d as he so memorably put it. A year later, he presented the nation on Tuesday night with a different narrative, one of a booming economy and a \u201cnew American moment.\u201d\n\nThe stock market has \u201csmashed one record after another.\u201d Retirement accounts have \u201cgone through the roof.\u201d Companies are \u201croaring back\u201d to the United States. \u201cWe haven\u2019t seen this in a long time,\u201d he exulted from the rostrum of the House chamber as he delivered his first formal State of the Union address. \u201cIt\u2019s all coming back.\u201d\n\nNever mind that in some fundamental ways the economy is growing no faster than it did at points during President Barack Obama\u2019s second term. Mr. Trump is at heart a salesman, and he rarely lets details get in the way of a good story. And by some measures, he has managed to convince many Americans, especially corporate leaders, that the economy really is surging in a way it has not for years.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe challenge for Mr. Trump is that even as he sells the economy with the fervor of a real estate developer, he has not been able to sell himself. His approval ratings remain at historic depths, and effectively unchanged after a year in office. His success at passing tax cuts and the continued progress of the economy he inherited have not changed the dismal views that a sizable majority of Americans hold of their president.\n\nRead more of Peter Baker\u2019s analysis here \u00bb\n\nA Kennedy gave the Democratic response \u2014 from Fall River, Mass.\n\nRepresentative Joseph P. Kennedy III, the grandson of Robert F. Kennedy, emerged on the national stage to give the Democratic response \u2014 from \u201ca proud American city, built by immigrants.\u201d\n\nVideo\n\nHere are some excerpts:\n\n\u201cIt would be easy to dismiss the past year as chaos. Partisanship. Politics. But it\u2019s far bigger than that. This administration isn\u2019t just targeting the laws that protect us \u2014 they are targeting the very idea that we are all worthy of protection.\u201d\n\n\u201cWe choose A Better Deal for all who call this country home. We choose the living wage, paid leave and affordable child care your family needs to survive. We choose pensions that are solvent, trade pacts that are fair, roads and bridges that won\u2019t rust away, and good education you can afford. We choose a health care system that offers mercy, whether you suffer from cancer or depression or addiction. We choose an economy strong enough to boast record stock prices and brave enough to admit that top CEOs making 300 times the average worker is not right.\u201d\n\nAnd here\u2019s a full transcript \u00bb\n\nBernie Sanders speaks to the faithful.\n\nHe wasn\u2019t chosen as the official Democratic responder. But Senator Bernie Sanders, independent of Vermont, spoke to his faithful with his own response to the State of the Union address.\n\n\u201cThe simple truth is that, according to virtually every poll, Donald Trump is the least popular president after one year in office of any president in modern American history. And the reason for that is pretty clear. The American people do not want a president who is compulsively dishonest, who is a bully, who actively represents the interests of the billionaire class, who is anti-science, and who is trying to divide us up based on the color of our skin, our nation of origin, our religion, our gender, or our sexual orientation.\u201d\n\nA dispute over infrastructure.\n\nPresident Trump called for an infrastructure that would leverage federal dollars, state and local government contributions and private sector funds to total $1.5 trillion.\n\nBut Democrats, who have pressed for infrastructure spending since Barack Obama was president, were not satisfied.\n\n\u201cPresident Trump is saying he has a $1.5 trillion infrastructure plan. He actually has an infrastructure plan with only $200 billion in federal funding over 10 years. He expects states, localities, and the private sector to come up with $1.3 trillion on their own,\u201d said the office of Representative Nancy Pelosi, the House Democratic leader.\n\nA Twitter record for the Twitter president.\n\nTonight\u2019s speech became the most Tweeted #SOTU or #Joint session address ever, passing last year\u2019s record of 3 million Tweets, according to Twitter.\n\n\u201cBeautiful, clean coal.\u201d\n\nVideo\n\nIn his State of the Union address, Mr. Trump returned to a phrase he has used many times before: \u201cbeautiful, clean coal.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut it has never been entirely clear what he means by it.\n\nOur colleague Brad Plumer wrote in August that the term \u201cclean coal\u201d typically refers to \u201ccoal plants that capture the carbon dioxide emitted from smokestacks and bury it underground as a way of limiting global warming.\u201d Only one coal plant in the country uses that technology, which is very expensive. And even with it, coal plants still produce far more carbon dioxide and other pollutants than renewable energy sources.\n\n\u2014 Maggie Astor\n\nThe first boos of the speech.\n\nVideo\n\nDemocrats were generally stone-faced for the president\u2019s address. But when Mr. Trump denounced \u201cchain migration,\u201d some of them spoke out \u2014 with boos.\n\nFor decades, immigrants who become American citizens have been able to sponsor their family members to join them from abroad. The \u201cfamily-based migration system\u201d has been relabeled \u201cchain migration\u201d by opponents, a new nomenclature not appreciated by many Democrats.\n\nGuant\u00e1namo Bay stays open.\n\nMr. Trump has announced, as expected, that he has signed an executive order to keep the Guant\u00e1namo Bay prison open. Essentially a symbolic act, it brings official executive branch policy into line with what it has effectively been all along: the prison remains open for business, at least for those detainees who are already there.\n\n\u201cI just signed an order directing Secretary Mattis to re-examine our military detention policy and to keep open the detention facilities at Guant\u00e1namo Bay,\u201d he said.\n\nSpecifically, Mr. Trump\u2019s order revokes an ill-fated January 2009 order signed by former President Barack Obama directing the government to close the prison within a year \u2014 a goal Mr. Obama failed to achieve. He did, however, winnow down the number of detainees, from the 242 he inherited from President Bush, to the 41 remaining there when Mr. Trump took office.\n\nMr. Obama also refused to bring any new detainees to the prison. Mr. Trump vowed during the campaign that he intended to fill it back up \u201cwith some bad dudes,\u201d but to date his administration has not added any newly captured terrorism suspects to the inmate population, instead following the Obama approach of using law enforcement procedures and civilian courts to handle them.\n\nThe order Mr. Trump signed had a long bureaucratic history. Its first draft, circulated days after he took office, would have gone much farther, including laying the groundwork for reopening the Central Intelligence Agency\u2019s defunct \u201cblack site\u201d prisons, where it formerly tortured high-value detainees during the Bush administration.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAfter an uproar in Congress, including pushback from Secretary of Defense James Mattis, Mr. Trump shelved that idea. The executive order went through various further drafts, eventually being pared to little more than repealing Mr. Obama\u2019s defunct directive.\n\nIn August, Mr. Trump was on the cusp of signing it when he appointed the John Kelly, a retired marines general who formerly oversaw the prison operation as the leader of Southern Command, as his chief.\n\nOne of Mr. Kelly\u2019s first acts was to send the draft order back to national security agencies and departments for further reworking. Among the apparent changes in the final document was a direction that Mr. Mattis to establish criteria about what should be done with newly captured terrorism suspects.\n\nWhat are those purple ribbons?\n\nPhoto\n\nAt least a dozen members of Congress wore purple ribbons at President Trump\u2019s State of the Union address on Tuesday night to help raise awareness about the country\u2019s opioid epidemic.\n\nIn October, Mr. Trump declared that the crisis had become a \u201cpublic health emergency.\u201d Overdoses killed about 64,000 Americans in 2016, making it the leading cause of death for people under 50.\n\nMr. Trump mentioned the opioid crises again in his speech on Tuesday.\n\n\u201cWe must get much tougher on drug dealers and pushers if we are going to succeed in stopping this scourge,\u201d Mr. Trump said, noting the number of overdose deaths in 2016. \u201cMy administration is committed to fighting the drug epidemic and helping get treatment for those in need. The struggle will be long and difficult \u2014 but, as Americans always do, we will prevail.\u201d\n\nTrump backs new declaration of force against ISIS\n\nMr. Trump appeared to throw his support behind having Congress enact legislation to update the 16-year-old statute that provides the legal basis for most counterterrorism operations around the world, making it explicitly cover the Islamic State \u2014 also known as ISIS.\n\n\u201cI am also asking the Congress to ensure that, in the fight against ISIS and Al Qaeda, we continue to have all necessary power to detain terrorists \u2014 wherever we chase them down.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nCongress enacted the Authorization for Use of Military Force, or A.U.M.F., in September 2001. It authorized war against the perpetrators of the Sept. 11 attacks and those who harbored or aided them \u2014 that is, Al Qaeda and the Taliban. But in 2014, the Obama administration stretched it to justify combat operations against the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, without new Congressional sanction.\n\nThat step was legally contentious because even though Islamic State grew out of an Al Qaeda affiliate, the two organizations had split and gone to war with each other. One of the reasons the Trump administration has not brought any Islamic State detainees to the wartime prison at Guant\u00e1namo is warnings by legal specialists that doing so would risk giving a judge an opportunity to rule that the A.U.M.F. does not cover the group, jeopardizing the broader war.\n\nThe Obama administration had fruitlessly asked Congress to enact a specific military force authorization for the Islamic State as well, while also saying it was legally unnecessary. But disputes over what it should say \u2014 including whether it should contain limits on duration, geographical scope, or the use of ground forces \u2014 prevented any consensus.\n\nLast fall, Mr. Mattis and Secretary of State Rex Tillerson said the Trump administration did not support Congress overhauling the war authorization law.\n\nManufacturing, yes, but not a tech guy.\n\nPresident Trump praised Apple for a promise made earlier this month to invest $350 billion in the United States and create 20,000 domestic jobs over five years.\n\nBut his speech was devoid of any mention of the role of technology in his vision for the economy. He called for legislation for $1.5 trillion in infrastructure investments for \u201creclaim our building heritage.\u201d He mentioned roads, bridges, highways, railways and waterways. But he did not mention any of those funds going to the expansion and improvement of broadband internet networks.\n\nTrump talked about investing in work force development and job training. But instead of training for science, technology, engineering or math \u2014 or STEM \u2014 training, he talked about opening vocational schools.\n\nHis words stood in contrast to State of the Union speeches by President Obama, who called for universal broadband for all Americans and the importance of spreading faster networks to close the digital divide.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSonny Perdue, agriculture secretary, designated survivor.\n\nYeah, there\u2019s the first lady\u2019s clothes or which big wig will fall asleep this year. But the State of the Union proceedings also have this bit of intrigue: Which cabinet official will earn the distinction of designated survivor?\n\nThe mystery this time was solved two hours before Mr. Trump was due to give his address on Tuesday, when the White House said that the honor would go to Mr. Perdue, the former governor of Georgia and the president\u2019s agriculture secretary.\n\nGlamorous in title but, thankfully, not so far in practice, the designated survivor does not attend the president\u2019s address, and is poised to take over the commander-in-chief\u2019s responsibilities in the event that catastrophe strikes the Capitol and wipes out most of the government. If tradition holds, Mr. Perdue will be watching from a distant and secure location while Mr. Trump speaks.\n\nThe short tenure of the designated survivor has an oversize presence in the public imagination: There is a TV series by the same title, about a low-profile cabinet member who suddenly assumes the presidency after a terror attack.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nHow might he measure up in the Oval Office? Mr. Perdue, a conservative Republican, shares something in common with Mr. Trump: As governor of Georgia, he faced ethical criticisms for not appearing to fully separate himself from his business interests. He once ran a grain and fertilizer business.\n\n\u2014 Katie Rogers\n\n\u201cYou\u2019ve gotta have heart.\u201d\n\nHours before his first State of the Union address, President Trump told a group of news anchors at a lunch in the White House that his first year in office has taught him that the biggest difference between excelling in business and performing his current job is that governing takes compassion.\n\n\u201cI\u2019ve really learned a lot,\u201d Mr. Trump told the reporters, according to a partial transcript of an off-the-record lunch released publicly by the White House. \u201cIn doing what I\u2019m doing now, a lot of it is heart, a lot of it is compassion, a lot of it is far beyond money \u2014 such as immigration.\u201d\n\nMr. Trump, who is expected to use Tuesday night\u2019s speech to call for a bipartisan compromise that pairs legal status for a group of undocumented immigrants brought to the United States as children with funding for a border wall, tougher enforcement and new restrictions on legal immigration, recently said he was hoping to sign a \u201cbill of love.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThat tone is sharply at odds with the president\u2019s approach on immigration thus far, which has included a travel ban against visitors from six countries, slashing refugee resettlement and revoking temporary protected status for people from El Salvador and Haiti. He has been more publicly conflicted about his decision last fall to rescind DACA, or Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals, the Obama-era program that has given legal status to certain people brought illegally to the United States as children.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI\u2019m telling you, the immigration is so easy to solve if it was purely a business matter, but it\u2019s not,\u201d Mr. Trump said. \u201cAnd I think that\u2019s something that I\u2019ve learned maybe more than anything else: You have to \u2014 you govern with all of the instincts of a businessperson, but you have to add much more heart and soul into your decisions than you would ever have even thought of before.\u201d\n\nHere\u2019s a peek at the transcript:\n\n\u2014 Julie Hirschfeld Davis\n\nDreamers head to the Capitol \u2014 despite the risk.\n\nDemocratic lawmakers have decided to put a face on the difficult negotiations happening in Congress over the fate of young, undocumented immigrants brought to the country as children. They are bringing scores of such \u201cDreamers\u201d to the Capitol for Tuesday night\u2019s State of the Union address.\n\nRepresentative Nancy Pelosi\u2019s guest, Melody Klingenfuss, is just one of them. Born in Guatemala, she was brought to Los Angeles when she was 9, earned a degree in communications and political science from California State University, Los Angeles, a master\u2019s degree from the University of Southern California, then won protection under the Obama-era Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals program in 2015.\n\n\u201cTonight, when President Trump looks into the gallery during his State of the Union, he will see the dignity, courage and patriotism of dozens of Dreamers,\u201d said Ms. Pelosi, the House Democratic leader.\n\nBut there is a flip side. Representative Paul Gosar, Republican of Arizona, has called the cops.\n\nSo much for the warm welcome.\n\nMr. Gosar\u2019s fellow Arizona Republican, Senator Jeff Flake, didn\u2019t take kindly to his colleague\u2019s citizen\u2019s arrest.\n\nAre we facing a \u201cConstitutional crisis\u201d?\n\nThe Trump administration\u2019s announcement on Monday that it would not impose sanctions on countries that buy Russian military equipment sparked an angry response in Congress, where the Senate and House overwhelmingly approved the sanctions to punish Russia for interfering in the 2016 election.\n\nSenator Claire McCaskill, Democrat of Missouri who faces a difficult re-election campaign this year, set the tone with a blast on Twitter.\n\nThat concern is bipartisan, at least in some quarters of the Republican Party. Senator Susan Collins, Republican of Maine, was flummoxed by the administration\u2019s decision:\n\n\u201cThat bill passed with only two dissenting votes in the Senate. It was not partisan in the least,\u201d she said on CNN. \u201cThe one thing we know for sure already is the Russians did attempt to meddle in our elections, and not only should there be a price to pay in terms of sanctions, but also we need to put safeguards in place right now for the elections for this year, because we know that the Russians have not given up on their disinformation campaign and their attempt to sow discord in this country and also to undermine faith in democratic institutions.\u201d\n\nTestifying before a Senate panel on Tuesday morning, Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin said his department had followed instructions under the sanctions law and drawn up a list of Russian targets for sanctions. An imposition of sanctions could still follow.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSenator Bob Corker, Republican of Tennessee and one of the authors of the sanctions legislation, declined to criticize the administration\u2019s actions. He did say, \u201cI look forward\u201d to the implementation of the sanctions.\n\nSpeaker Ryan weighs in on Russia memo.\n\nSpeaker Paul D. Ryan of Wisconsin spent part of the morning before Mr. Trump\u2019s speech tamping down expectations about a secretive Republican memo that some House members have claimed contains evidence that could undercut the Russia investigation.\n\nIn a closed-door meeting of House Republicans this morning, Mr. Ryan \u201cimplored\u201d his fellow lawmakers not to overstate the facts of the memo, which the House Intelligence Committee voted to release Monday night. And he urged them not to tie the contentious document \u2014 which Democrats call dangerously misleading \u2014 to the work of the special counsel, Robert S. Mueller III, according to a person in the room.\n\nMr. Ryan reiterated some of those points during a public news conference an hour later, saying that he had faith in the F.B.I. and Justice Department\u2019s broadly and that he thought Deputy Attorney General Rod J. Rosenstein, the man overseeing the Russia investigation, was \u201cdoing a fine job.\u201d Still, Mr. Ryan defended the Republicans\u2019 overall approach, saying that they were following proper processes and that only transparency would lead to accountability at the agencies.\n\nThat was not enough to quiet the most ardent proponents of the notion that federal law enforcement agents have conspired to bring down the Trump White House. Representative Matt Gaetz, Republican of Florida, called on the president to release the memo during the State of the Union.\n\n\u2014 Nicholas Fandos\n\nAbout those stock market brags, Mr. President.\n\nPresident Trump loves to brag about the stock market setting record highs, but on the day of his first State of the Union speech, the market isn\u2019t loving him back \u2014 for reasons that probably have nothing to do with him or his policies.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nStocks fell sharply at their opening this morning and have stayed down all day. As of 2:30 p.m., the Dow Jones industrial average was down nearly 400 points, or about 1.7 percent, from Monday\u2019s close. The S&P 500 was down about 1.4 percent.\n\nIt appeared that the sell-off was driven by rising bond yields and a tumble in health insurer stocks, on the news that Amazon, JPMorgan Chase and Berkshire Hathaway are launching a health care effort.\n\nAs of midafternoon, Mr. Trump had not tweeted about the market news.\n\n\u2014 James Tankersley\n\nThe president and the black felt marker.\n\nOne constant refrain from White House officials when it comes to State of the Union speeches is this: the president was personally involved in drafting the speech.\n\nIt was no different on Tuesday as officials in President Trump\u2019s White House described a \u201crobust,\u201d monthslong process in which Mr. Trump actively reviewed drafts of the speech and repeatedly made suggestions of phrases or anecdotes or words that he wanted to be used when he delivers the address.\n\nThe speech was assembled over weeks, with agency heads and cabinet secretaries offering suggestions on accomplishments that the president should highlight or priorities he could push for. Speech-writing meetings at the White House with Stephen Miller, the president\u2019s top speechwriter, John F. Kelly, the chief of staff, and others were coordinated by Rob Porter, the president\u2019s staff secretary.\n\nAides said that in the last two weeks, Mr. Trump received printed drafts of the speech \u2014 with ample margins \u2014 and used a black felt marker to make additions, deletions and changes. They said he often edited the drafts in the Oval Office, but sometimes would come down from the residence in the morning with a new draft that he had marked up overnight.\n\n\u2014 Michael D. Shear\n\nTrump donors get their names in lights.\n\nAs the president prepares to speak, his campaign is preparing to cash in.\n\nIn a text message to supporters, the Trump campaign offered a few seconds of quasi-fame to donors who give money before his speech. Their names will appear as the speech streams on the Trump campaign website.\n\n\u201cThis is a movement,\u201d reads the State of the Union donation form on the campaign site, \u201cwhich is why your name deserves to be displayed during tonight\u2019s speech.\u201d The Trump campaign offered similar recognition to small donors in the run-up to the Republican National Convention in 2016.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhile campaigns regularly raise money based on major events, the Trump campaign\u2019s solicitation is unusual. The names of donors giving more than $200 in a single election cycle must be reported to the Federal Election Commission and are public record, but the voluntary disclosure of the names of small donors is uncommon. Additionally, previous presidents\u2019 campaigns did not raise money for re-election so early in their first term. Former President Barack Obama\u2019s campaign did not file paperwork with the Federal Election Commission and begin raising money until the third year of his presidency.\n\n\u2014 Rachel Shorey\n\nFour Supreme Court justices will be in the crowd.\n\nPhoto\n\nChief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. has called the State of the Union address \u201ca political pep rally.\u201d But he is expected to attend tonight, along with three colleagues: Justices Stephen G. Breyer, Elena Kagan and Neil M. Gorsuch, whom President Trump appointed to the court last year.\n\nAmong the missing will be Justice Clarence Thomas, who has said that he cannot tolerate \u201cthe catcalls, the whooping and hollering and under-the-breath comments.\u201d Justice Samuel A. Alito Jr., who has called the addresses \u201cvery political events\u201d and \u201cvery awkward,\u201d is also not expected to attend.\n\nJustice Alito famously mouthed \u201cnot true\u201d at the address in 2010 after President Obama\u2019s loose characterization of the Supreme Court\u2019s decision in the Citizens United campaign finance case.\n\nThree members of the court will be out of town tonight: Justices Anthony M. Kennedy, Ruth Bader Ginsburg and Sonia Sotomayor.\n\nThe justices who do attend usually make coordinated choices about what statements from the president are uncontroversial enough to warrant applause.\n\nThat is hard, Justice Alito said in 2010, because presidents \u201cwill fake you out.\u201d They may start with something bland, he said, like, \u201c \u2018Isn\u2019t this the greatest country in the world?\u2019 \u201c\n\n\u201cSo you get up and you start to clap,\u201d he said, \u201cand the president will say, \u2018Because we are conducting a surge in Iraq\u2019 or \u2018Because we are going to enact health care reform,\u2019 and then you immediately have to stop.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2014 Adam Liptak\n\nThe State of the Union guest list\n\nThe White House released on Monday the list of people President Trump and his wife, Melania, invited to attend the State of the Union address.\n\nAn eclectic cohort will join the first lady: emergency medical workers, service members and faces of Mr. Trump\u2019s tax and immigration overhaul narratives. Here are a few of the people you\u2019ll see:\n\nDavid Dahlberg, a fire prevention technician, who saved 62 children and staff members from a blaze-encircled summer camp in July during the wildfires in Southern California.\n\nOfficer Ryan Holets, of the Albuquerque Police Department, who, according to the White House, was twice shot at during his time as an officer. He and his wife adopted a child from parents who were addicted to opioids.\n\nSteve Staub and Sandy Keplinger, who are the leaders of a Dayton, Ohio, contract manufacturing company focused on metal fabrication. They founded Staub Manufacturing Solutions two decades ago. Over the past year, the company acquired a new building and saw a 60 percent increase in employees \u2014 from 23 to 37. Crediting the passage of the tax law, the company gave large Christmas bonuses to all employees.\n\nFour parents whose daughters, the authorities say, were most likely killed by members of the MS-13 gang: Elizabeth Alvarado and Robert Mickens, who lost Nisa Mickens, 15; and Evelyn Rodriguez and Freddy Cuevas, who lost Kayla Cuevas, 16. The teenagers were killed in 2016 on Long Island.\n\nFor the full list, read on \u00bb\n\n\u2014 Emily Baumgaertner\n\nLawmakers to wear black for Time\u2019s Up.\n\nAfter the women of Hollywood, the women of Congress.\n\nTaking a cue from the call that went out before the Golden Globes for all attendees to wear black in support of Time\u2019s Up and its spotlight on systemic sexual harassment, members of the Democratic Women\u2019s Working Group \u2014 Representatives Lois Frankel of Florida, Bonnie Watson Coleman of New Jersey and Jackie Speier of California \u2014 invited all members of Congress (men included) to wear black to the State of the Union.\n\nPhoto\n\nSo far, a number of House members have complied, including Representative Nancy Pelosi, the House minority leader.\n\nIt is not, as it happens, the first time women have used clothing to send a message: at Mr. Trump\u2019s first address to a joint session of Congress last year, many of them wore suffragist white. In both cases, they let their clothes do the talking for them.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2014 Vanessa Friedman\n\nVoices from speechwriters past.\n\nJonathan Horn, speechwriter for former President George W. Bush, has these thoughts:\n\n\u201cThat\u2019s part of the problem for Donald Trump going into the State of the Union. He could come out with a very traditional State of the Union and for a normal president, that would help set the agenda for at least, you know, maybe a few weeks. In Washington, you\u2019d plan other policy speeches to follow up on certain aspects of the State of the Union and there would be an entire rollout around the State of the Union. I think with this president, you would expect it would be much shorter. Even if there is a surprise \u2014 Oh, look, Donald Trump sounded presidential \u2014 but then the next day there could be a tweet, and then, you know, work on a very, very long speech is overshadowed by a 280 characters. That\u2019s my one prediction. In some sense, whatever he ultimately says is overshadowed by a 280-character tweet.\u201d\n\nMichael Waldman, president of the Brennan Center for Justice at N.Y.U. School of Law and a speechwriter for former President Bill Clinton, also weighed in:\n\n\u201cThe power of that podium is not just the audience watching. It\u2019s the sense that the president is somebody who speaks for the whole country. And the way he has governed over the past year has been so filled with denunciations and racial division and flat-out falsehoods that he doesn\u2019t have a lot in the tank when it comes to credibility for anybody who isn\u2019t already an avid supporter. Often, these State of the Union addresses can be a time when the panoply of the presidency can give whoever the president is, sort of, a second chance with a lot of people. I\u2019d be surprised if that\u2019s the case here.\u201d\n\nCody Keenan, chief speechwriter for former President Barack Obama, also had concerns:\n\n\u201cPresident Obama always wanted to close his State of the Union addresses with an argument about the state of our politics. You know, what can we do to make them better? What can we do to be better citizens? I always remember reading criticisms the next day, certainly from the left, saying why is he wasting real estate in the speech on that? It\u2019s never going to happen. \u201cWell, that\u2019s part of leadership. You know, there\u2019s a vision of what we should be, even if the odds of us getting there in one year or eight years is pretty slim.\u201d\n\n\u2014 Interviews by Michael D. Shear\n\nUnfamiliar with the guests in the first lady\u2019s box? Here\u2019s some history.", "title": "Trump\u2019s First State of the Union Address: A Call for Unity That Wasn\u2019t Always Heard That Way", "authors": ["The New York Times"]} {"date": "2018-01-16 00:00:00", "text": "Peter Baker, the chief White House correspondent for The New York Times, had a problem. He was hosting a party whose guests included a bipartisan group of former White House staffers, and there wasn\u2019t enough ice. While he was driving to the store, his phone rang. It was his wife, the journalist Susan Glasser. \u201cDon\u2019t worry, I\u2019m getting the ice,\u201d he told her. \u201cNo, no, no, you don\u2019t understand,\u201d she said. \u201cThe president just fired the F.B.I. director.\u201d\n\nHe returned, bag of ice in hand, to a room full of White House veterans, Democrat and Republican, stunned by the news. \u201cIt was striking to have all these people, very experienced people in Washington, there in that moment,\u201d he said, \u201cmouths agape, trying to process what had just happened and what it might mean.\u201d He excused himself from his own party and ran upstairs to write.\n\nThere was no indication that the May 9 firing of the F.B.I. chief, James B. Comey, had been coming. The White House correspondent Michael D. Shear broke the news for The Times, as he happened to be at the White House that afternoon to run an errand. When Sean Spicer, then the president\u2019s press secretary, appeared in the almost-empty briefing room to announce the news, Mr. Shear sent an email to The Times\u2019s Washington bureau from his phone: Comey fired. \u201cIt was all on the fly,\u201d he said. \u201cIn a different White House, it would be mapped out to the nth degree.\u201d\n\nFor the journalists who have covered the first year of Donald J. Trump\u2019s presidency, such episodes have come to be expected. \u201cIt\u2019s relentless, the unpredictability of it,\u201d said Elisabeth Bumiller, the Washington bureau chief. \u201cI knew it would be really wild and different, but I expected him to be somewhat different than the candidate Trump, and he really hasn\u2019t been.\u201d", "title": "Trump\u2019s First Year, as Told by Our Washington Bureau", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-15 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cTrump\u2019s Petticoat Government,\u201d by Ross Douthat (column, Jan. 7):\n\nMany lament the coarsening of the presidency under this administration, but Donald Trump\u2019s greatest legacy may be showing that our Republic is not only strong enough to endure but also to course-correct.\n\nLISA M. SHULMAN, BALTIMORE", "title": "Opinion | Trump\u2019s Greatest Legacy", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-21 00:00:00", "text": "Vice President Mike Pence, an evangelical Christian, visits Israel this week, the culmination of his years of support for the country on religious grounds. But the Trump administration\u2019s policies, while lauded by American evangelical groups, are opposed by Palestinian Christians and have been questioned by Pope Francis.\n\nThose policies, in other words, align poorly with either the religious solidarity or foreign policy realism that supposedly animated them, but align perfectly with American identity politics.\n\nMr. Trump, with his penchant for indulging his nationalist impulses and disregarding foreign policy doctrine, is a perfect vessel for carrying that culture war abroad, with potentially far-reaching consequences.\n\nPhoto\n\nHow a Mideast Conflict Divided Americans\n\nAmericans, more polarized than at perhaps any other point in their modern history, tend to be less divided on foreign policy. But they split on Israel as if it were a domestic issue, suggesting that, whether they realize it or not, they experience it as such.\n\nAsked whether they sympathize more with Israelis or Palestinians, Republicans answer the former nearly seven to one, according to a Pew survey. Democrats sympathize with the groups about equally. Within the parties, conservatives tilt more pro-Israeli.\n\nThat partisan gap is at it widest since Pew began asking the question in 1978. And it applies to nearly any policy question related to Israelis and Palestinians, suggesting that Americans derive their views by identifying with one side over the other.\n\nPicking sides has long been taboo in American policy, with presidents asserting that the United States must remain neutral in order to negotiate peace. Mr. Trump, breaking with this practice, answers a major conservative demand.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut this demand is relatively new. Its origins goes a long way to explaining Mr. Trump\u2019s actions on Israel \u2014 and how they fit within his instincts for stoking American divisions.\n\nWhen evangelical Christians organized as a political bloc in the 1980s, they made Israel a priority. Some interpreted the Bible as asserting Israel\u2019s right to control the Palestinian territories. In the 1990s, as Democrats pushed for social changes, evangelicals sorted into the Republican Party.\n\n\u201cIsrael isn\u2019t an \u2018issue\u2019 for evangelicals in the same way that deregulation and a better tax policy are issues,\u201d Robert Nicholson, who leads a Christian advocacy group, said in an email. \u201cIt is a matter of identity.\u201d\n\nWhile this bolstered Republicans\u2019 pro-Israel attitudes, the parties did not polarize on the issue. Many evangelicals expressed their support as a matter of spiritual kinship rather than prevailing over Palestinians. After all, a number of Palestinians are Christian themselves. And Mr. Trump, though popular with evangelicals, is hardly one himself.\n\nResearch by Amnon Cavari, an Israeli political scientist, found that hard-line views on Israel had spread among conservatives only recently, and largely because of partisan polarization over domestic issues. Though conventional wisdom often suggests that evangelical and Jewish groups energized conservative views on Israel, in fact it was the other way around.\n\nThat began with the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, which divided Americans over issues of terrorism, torture and inclusion, particularly of Muslims.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Subscribe to the Interpreter Newsletter Understand the world with sharp insight and commentary on the major news stories of the week. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThis became the basis of a culture war that, largely by chance, aligned almost perfectly with a real conflict just then unfolding between Israelis and Palestinians.\n\nA period of terrible violence known as the second intifada \u2014 in which Palestinian militants staged shocking terrorist attacks and Israeli military actions killed scores of civilians \u2014 resonated with Americans. Israeli leaders, seeking Washington\u2019s support, encouraged Americans to see their conflicts as one and the same.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBeing tough on terrorism became a core conservative value that was expressed, in part, as support for Israel \u2014 specifically, as support for harsh Israeli policies toward the conflict. This also aligned with increasingly negative attitudes toward Muslims. And an atmosphere of us-versus-them politics equated supporting Israelis with opposing Palestinians.\n\nThough George W. Bush, then the president, encouraged both inclusion of Muslims and neutrality on Israel, polarization pulled some conservatives toward a zero-sum view of the conflict, in which maximally opposing Palestinians became a matter of identity.\n\nPhoto\n\nTrump Exports the Culture War\n\nThis opened a gap between the identity politics of the Republican base and the policies of its leaders \u2014 precisely the sort of gap that Mr. Trump would exploit in his presidential primary bid. As he rose by saying what others would not, he supercharged the Israeli-Palestinian conflict\u2019s salience to identity issues among what would become his base.\n\nMr. Trump advocated severe restrictions on legal and illegal immigration, particularly from Muslim-majority countries whose citizens he said posed a threat. In doing so, the president aligned fear of demographic change with fear of terrorism.\n\nThere is no reason that those positions must necessarily line up with support for Israel, but Mr. Trump leveraged culture war passions to try to bring them together.\n\n\u201cHorrible killing of a 13 year old American girl at her home in Israel by a Palestinian terrorist.\u201d Mr. Trump tweeted in 2016, adding, in a line that became his slogan for a travel ban on people from several majority-Muslim countries, \u201cWe must get tough.\u201d\n\nMr. Trump also exploited polarization over Israel to rally supporters against Barack Obama, whom he repeatedly suggested was foreign-born, Muslim and suspiciously hostile toward Israel.\n\n\u201cIs President Obama trying to destroy Israel with all his bad moves?\u201d Mr. Trump asked on Twitter, also in 2016. \u201cThink about it and let me know!\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn office, this is one of a handful of issues, along with sharply curtailing legal immigration, on which Mr. Trump has taken concerted, unilateral action. He is now pressing to move the United States Embassy from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem as early as next year.\n\nThese policies meet rising conservative demands that the United States abandon its traditional neutrality on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, and instead side overtly with Israel.\n\nWhile some say pro-Israel groups are responsible for this shift, Mr. Trump, who has had an icy relationship with those groups, in fact appears to be following the Republican base. In 2014, 51 percent of Republicans said the United States should lean toward Israel in peace talks. That number has since grown to 58 percent.\n\nMr. Trump represents the culmination of a trend that pro-Israel groups resisted for years: the loss of Jewish support. Even as Jews grew more liberal, many supported strongly pro-Israel policies. But as \u201cpro-Israel\u201d becomes synonymous with \u201cconservative Republican,\u201d Jews are drifting away. They oppose moving the embassy by almost 3-to-1.\n\nParty politics started this process. In 2015, Republicans invited Benjamin Netanyahu, Israel\u2019s right-wing prime minister, to address Congress in opposition to Mr. Obama\u2019s policies on Iran. Though intended to turn American Jews and others against Mr. Obama, it had the opposite effect, polarizing them against Mr. Netanyahu.\n\nMr. Trump has taken it drastically further. He has indulged hard-core conservative instincts to a degree that, deliberately or not, attracted support from a white nationalist fringe that also tends to be hostile to Jews.\n\nHe is moving the idea of being \u201cpro-Israel\u201d even further right, separating it even from the Jewish support that is ostensibly critical to Israel\u2019s long-term survival.\n\nRevoking aid from refugees to punish Palestinian leaders, for instance, aligns with Mr. Trump\u2019s nationalist tendencies to treat foreign populations as monolithic blocs. This, too, has its roots in American culture wars over immigration.\n\nLike his immigration restrictions, Mr. Trump\u2019s Israel policies can be unpopular outside his base. A December poll by the Brookings Institution found that only 31 percent of Americans support moving the embassy. But the base has shown itself often able to overwhelm party leadership.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Pence\u2019s religiosity may embody the old mode of American support for Israel, driven by groups with strong views on the conflict itself. That still exists, but is increasingly subsumed by a broader, blunter worldview that treats the Israeli-Palestinian issue as an extension of another conflict that can seem just as intractable: American partisanship.", "title": "Trump\u2019s Hard-Line Israel Position Exports U.S. Culture War Abroad", "authors": ["Max Fisher", "The Interpreter"]} {"date": "2018-01-16 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cNo one here is going to pretend like the president is always politically correct \u2014 he isn\u2019t,\u201d Ms. Sanders said, adding that it was \u201cone of the reasons the American people love him\u201d and he won the presidency.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019ve wasted five days fighting over one word, when we should be fighting over the people that are involved in the DACA program,\u201d she said, using the acronym for Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals, a program created by President Barack Obama that Mr. Trump rescinded in September, setting a six-month clock \u2014 until March 5 \u2014 before recipients would begin to lose their special status.\n\nSeveral people familiar with the immigration meeting said last week that the president had used the vulgar phrase and questioned why Haitians should receive protection in the plan, as Mr. Durbin and Mr. Graham pushed back on his language and his characterization of immigrant populations.\n\nThe White House initially did not dispute the account, and Senators Tom Cotton of Arkansas and David Perdue of Georgia, two Republicans who were also present, first said they could not recall what was said. But the senators changed their stories over the weekend, attacking Mr. Durbin\u2019s account of the meeting. Mr. Perdue said flatly that the word was never used; Mr. Cotton said he did not hear it used.\n\nOn Tuesday, Mr. Durbin told CNN, \u201cI stand by every word I said.\u201d\n\n\u201cSenator Cotton and Senator Perdue should remember a word as gross as that in the course of a conversation with the president of the United States,\u201d he added.\n\nAsked about whether Mr. Cotton and Mr. Perdue could be technically correct if Mr. Trump had instead said \u201cshithouse,\u201d Mr. Durbin was incredulous.\n\n\u201cLet me say they\u2019re wrong,\u201d he said. \u201cI can tell you explicitly they are wrong. And let me also say, is that their defense? That s-house is acceptable, s-hole he would never say? Come on. To think that the president of the United States would refer to any country on earth as an s-house country, for goodness\u2019 sakes, what does that say?\u201d", "title": "Trump\u2019s Harsh Words, Not His Plan for Wall, Dominate Hearing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "Hours before the news of Mr. Trump\u2019s comments broke on Thursday, the United Nations secretary general, Ant\u00f3nio Guterres, spoke about the need for more \u201csafe, orderly and regular\u201d migration.\n\nHe implored nations to \u201cuse facts, not prejudice\u201d to address the challenges of migration.\n\n\u201cGlobally, migration remains poorly managed,\u201d he acknowledged. \u201cThe impact can be seen in the humanitarian crises affecting people on the move, and in the human rights violations suffered by those living in slavery or enduring degrading working conditions. It can be seen, too, in the political impact of public perception that wrongly sees migration as out of control. The consequences include increased mistrust and policies aimed more at stopping than facilitating human movement.\u201d\n\nMr. Knaus, of the European Stability Initiative, was one of several commentators who expressed fear that Mr. Trump would only embolden xenophobic rhetoric.\n\n\u201cThis will have consequences because it\u2019s widely followed,\u201d he said. \u201cIn every Austrian and German village, they follow what the U.S. president is doing.\u201d\n\nIn Western Europe, heads of government have sometimes described migrants in terms of floods and hordes \u2014 but the most abusive language has usually been restricted to far-right opposition politicians like Marine Le Pen in France and Geert Wilders in Holland.\n\n\u201cWhat is dangerous is if this kind of language migrates from the far-right to the mainstream,\u201d Mr. Knaus added.\n\nBut some in migration policy circles fear this transition has already begun.\n\nSeveral European heads of government were proudly xenophobic in their responses to a refugee crisis in 2015, when more than one million asylum seekers arrived by boat on European shores, prompting a surge in support for far-right parties and nativist rhetoric \u2014 particularly in Central and Eastern Europe.", "title": "Trump\u2019s Immigration Remarks Outrage Many, but Others Quietly Agree", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "Yet friends and even family members have had difficulty getting through the tight protective screen that Mr. Kelly has built around the president. From some of those family members, Mr. Trump recently learned that his chief of staff has canceled meetings with some of their old friends, without letting Mr. Trump know first, according to three people familiar with what happened.\n\nIvanka Trump, the president\u2019s daughter, has at various times expressed frustration with Mr. Kelly, according to people familiar with the conversations. Other White House aides have said that Mr. Kelly has at times appeared dismissive of her in meetings or on email exchanges with other advisers, and has sought to limit the portfolios of both her and her husband, Jared Kushner. Mr. Kelly has struggled to handle the couple, who are in the unusual position of being official members of the staff and who have hosted policy dinners at their homes. But Mr. Kelly has insisted that he has no personal animus toward them, according to one White House aide.\n\nMs. Trump has also complained to colleagues that people try to use her as a cudgel against Mr. Kelly, imparting a level of anger at him that she says she herself does not feel.\n\nIn a statement on Thursday, she denied that she had issues with Mr. Kelly and praised the job he was doing as chief of staff.\n\n\u201cI typically ignore false rumors spread by bad actors in an attempt to sow internal division,\u201d she said, \u201cbut I feel compelled to respond and say that it is an honor to work for Chief Kelly, who is doing a fantastic job.
