Mr. Trump has not engaged in the speculation \u2014 at least, not yet.", "title": "Trump\u2019s Impromptu News Conference: An Unplanned Drop-By or a Deliberate Dig?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-09 00:00:00", "text": "Republican lawmakers have repeatedly claimed that the dossier could have been mishandled by the F.B.I. as it was opening its own investigation into the Russian effort, though they have provided no evidence to support those claims. And last week, two influential Republican senators made the first known congressional criminal referral in connection with the meddling \u2014 against Christopher Steele, the former British spy who was hired by Fusion and compiled the dossier. They said that he lied to federal investigators about his contacts with the news media.\n\nThe move infuriated Democrats. They characterized it as an attempt to discredit a crucial source in the investigations by Congress and the special counsel, Robert S. Mueller III, and distract from the central question: whether the Trump campaign knowingly sought aid from Russia.\n\nThat question remains unanswered. Though investigators and journalists have developed extensive evidence linking some of Mr. Trump\u2019s associates to operatives for the Russian government, no evidence of a direct connection between Mr. Trump himself and the Kremlin has emerged.\n\nThe same is true of Mr. Cohen, who has vehemently denied any role in the conspiracy claimed in the dossier. In August, Mr. Cohen went so far as to give Congress a point-by-point rebuttal of the dossier\u2019s allegations that he has deep ties to Russian officials. He specifically denied one of the best-known allegations against him \u2014 that he secretly met in Prague with a Russian official last summer.\n\nIn the lawsuit, Mr. Cohen\u2019s lawyers say that Fusion acted recklessly and then disseminated the dossier to reporters without being able to back up its explosive claims.", "title": "Trump\u2019s Longtime Lawyer Sues BuzzFeed and the Firm Behind Russia Dossier", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "Instead of requiring states to increase and strengthen coverage, C.M.S. will now allow them to use waivers to promote \u201cupward mobility\u201d or \u201cresponsible decision-making.\u201d If those sound good to you, understand that they are known euphemisms for work requirements. The key point, as the Medicaid analyst Jessica Schubel points out, is that neither of those goals align with Medicaid\u2019s mission of providing comprehensive health insurance to low-income people. They would instead, she said, \u201clet states kick people off coverage if they don\u2019t comply with new requirements that have nothing to do with health insurance.\u201d\n\nPeople losing coverage could suffer severe harm. A study of Medicaid expansion in Kentucky and Arkansas found that it led to significant gains in access to care, financial security and health, with increases in the share of low-income adults going for checkups, getting regular care for chronic conditions and reporting that they are in excellent health. It also found large decreases in the share of people struggling to pay medical bills and relying on hospital emergency rooms for care. Under the new waivers, these gains will be reversed.\n\nIt\u2019s also essential to recognize that Medicaid work requirements won\u2019t work. There\u2019s no evidence that Medicaid discourages work, which comports with common sense: You can\u2019t pay rent or buy groceries with health coverage. About 80 percent of able-bodied adult Medicaid recipients are part of working families (that is, either they or their spouses work), and about 60 percent work themselves. Among adults on Medicaid who don\u2019t work and could be subject to the work requirement, more than a third have a chronic health problem or disability, about half take care of their family or go to school, and just under 10 percent can\u2019t find work.\n\nIt\u2019s far more likely that Medicaid work requirements will backfire, at least in terms of improving beneficiaries\u2019 living standards. By providing coverage for workers in jobs that are unlikely to provide such benefits, and by helping to stabilize the finances of people with illnesses, Medicaid has been found to help people stay employed or find work.\n\nOf course, not all of the Republicans\u2019 efforts to shrink Medicaid are occurring through executive, as opposed to congressional, action. The new tax law\u2019s repeal of the Affordable Care Act\u2019s individual mandate could, according to the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office, cut five million from the Medicaid rolls by 2027. That\u2019s because, absent the mandate, fewer low-income people will find out that they\u2019re eligible for Medicaid, especially in expansion states.", "title": "Opinion | Trump\u2019s Medicaid Work Requirement Will Backfire", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-09 00:00:00", "text": "Senator Lindsey Graham, Republican of South Carolina, who was a harsh critic when he faced Mr. Trump in the Republican primaries in 2016 but has lately become one of his chief allies, called Tuesday\u2019s session \u201cthe most fascinating meeting I\u2019ve been involved with in 20-plus years in politics.\u201d\n\nDemocrats used other adjectives. \u201cIt\u2019s fairly bizarre that the president has to show that he\u2019s actually balanced and sane,\u201d Senator Mazie K. Hirono, Democrat of Hawaii, said in an interview afterward.\n\nDid he succeed in doing that? \u201cMore than some other kinds of other behaviors that he\u2019s engaged in,\u201d she said cautiously.\n\n\u201cIt was more constructive than I believed it was going to be,\u201d added Senator Michael Bennet, Democrat of Colorado. \u201cI went into it thinking that it was just an opportunity to have a photo op and maybe allow him to demonstrate that he was not the person he was accused of being over the weekend. But I think it was more constructive than that.\u201d\n\nMr. Trump used the occasion to suggest restoring the banned congressional practice of allowing members to designate money for projects in their districts, a process known as earmarks but conventionally called pork. For Mr. Trump, it was a nod to Washington institutionalists who say such spending makes it easier to forge legislative compromises, but it seemed to conflict with his promise to \u201cdrain the swamp.\u201d\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s outreach to Democrats came on the same day the \u201cAmerica First\u201d president announced that he would travel this month to Davos, Switzerland, for the World Economic Forum, a gathering that is ground zero for the wealthy elite and globalist leaders that he has derided. By happenstance, it was the same day that Stephen K. Bannon, the architect of the president\u2019s build-the-wall nationalist appeal and enemy of all things Davos, was pushed out of Breitbart News after his critical comments in Mr. Wolff\u2019s book.\n\nAdded together, it gave the impression of a shift, but Mr. Trump has been down this road before. He broached the idea of comprehensive immigration legislation on the same day he addressed Congress for the first time nearly a year ago, then set about enacting some of the toughest anti-immigration policies in generations. He cut a short-term spending deal with Democrats in the fall, predicting a new bipartisan era, only to torpedo any follow-up with Twitter attacks and a move back to the right.", "title": "Trump\u2019s Negotiation on Immigration, Unfolding on Camera", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cFlorida Is Exempted in Offshore Drilling Plan\u201d (news article, Jan. 10):\n\nCountless citizens, environmental experts, and civic and political leaders on both sides of the aisle have condemned the president\u2019s plan to reopen offshore waters to drilling as an economic mistake and a threat to the environment.\n\nMany, if not most, of the states with affected shoreline have said that reopening the coast to drilling will hurt their states\u2019 economy and environment. And the only state that got an exemption from the president is Florida, after Florida\u2019s Republican governor pleaded that it would threaten the state\u2019s tourism industry.\n\nAny coincidence that business interests like Mar-a-Lago or Trump luxury condo buildings are in Florida? If it\u2019s not good for Florida or President Trump\u2019s properties to be vulnerable to the inevitable damage caused by accidents at offshore drilling sites, why is it O.K. for the other states and property owners?\n\nWhat about the homes owned by people the president purports to represent, the blue-collar families that live and work in the other coastal states? Why aren\u2019t their jobs and property values worth protecting?", "title": "Opinion | Trump\u2019s Offshore Drilling Plan", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-06 00:00:00", "text": "The material in Wolff\u2019s book provides more grist for that argument; the book may be dubious in some particulars but as the consummate insiders Jim VandeHei and Mike Allen wrote on Thursday, the parts about Trump\u2019s capabilities and mental state \u201cring unambiguously true.\u201d (And again, one does not need to be a well-sourced insider to recognize this fact; one need only have access to the president\u2019s own Twitter feed.)\n\nBut op-ed provocations notwithstanding, the 25th Amendment option isn\u2019t happening \u2014 not without some major presidential deterioration in the midst of a major crisis, and probably not even then. And while I blame Republicans for a thousand things that brought us to this pass, it\u2019s too extreme to blame them for not pursuing an option that\u2019s never been tried before, against a president who was recently and (yes) legitimately elected, especially when that option requires extraordinary coordination across the legislative and executive branches and could easily fail \u2026 with God-only-knows what kind of consequences.\n\nSo unless Robert Mueller has more goods than I expect, we are going to live for the next few years in the way that America lived during the waning days of Nixon, the end of the Wilson administration, and perhaps at other moments known only to presidential inner circles \u2014 with our own equivalent of the petticoat government, which in this case includes military uniforms, dress suits and whatever outfits Ivanka and Kellyanne Conway favor (but not, any longer, the layering of collared shirts perfected by Steve Bannon).\n\nWhich means the central question of these years is not a normal policy question, or even the abnormal sort that the Resistance and other fascism-fearers expect to face. The idea of a right-populist agenda died with Bannon\u2019s exit from the White House, the standard-issue G.O.P. agenda has little left after the tax cuts, and Trump\u2019s authoritarian impulses, while genuine, seem unlikely to produce even aggrandizement on the scale of past presidents from F.D.R. to Nixon, because he has no competence to execute on them.\n\nRather, the big question is organizational, managerial, and psychological: Can the people who surround Donald Trump work around his incapacity successfully enough to keep his unfitness from producing a historic calamity?", "title": "Opinion | Trump\u2019s Petticoat Government", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-17 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 Cardiologists not associated with the White House said Wednesday that President Trump\u2019s physical exam revealed serious heart concerns, including very high levels of so-called bad cholesterol, which raises the risk that Mr. Trump could have a heart attack while in office.\n\nDr. Ronny L. Jackson, a rear admiral and the White House physician, said Tuesday in his report on the president\u2019s medical condition that Mr. Trump was in \u201cexcellent\u201d cardiac health despite having an LDL cholesterol level of 143, well above the desired level of 100 or less.\n\nDr. David Maron, the director of preventive cardiology at Stanford University\u2019s medical school, said Wednesday that it was alarming that the president\u2019s LDL levels remain above 140 even though he is taking 10 milligrams of Crestor, a powerful drug that is used to lower cholesterol levels to well below 100.\n\nDr. Maron said he would \u201cdefinitely\u201d be worried about Mr. Trump\u2019s risk for having a heart attack if the president were one of his patients. Asked if Mr. Trump is in perfect health, Dr. Maron offered a blunt reply: \u201cGod, no.\u201d", "title": "Trump\u2019s Physical Revealed Serious Heart Concerns, Outside Experts Say", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cImmigration Offer: Citizenship and Stern Tactics\u201d (front page, Jan. 26):\n\nPresident Trump, who based his campaign on criticizing undocumented immigrants, is now proposing legislation that puts the interests of \u201cillegal\u201d immigrants ahead of those of United States citizens. Mr. Trump offered a path to citizenship to some 1.8 million young undocumented immigrants in exchange for limiting family sponsorship by American citizens and lawful permanent residents. That represents a direct attack on those who do things legally and follow the rules, despite our chaotic immigration system.\n\nFamily-based petitions allow American citizens to bring legally to the country their foreign-born parents, siblings, spouses and children. It\u2019s the basis of our immigration history and represents the core value of our nation: family values. Sponsoring an immediate relative costs thousands of dollars and takes several years. Also, the family member needs to pass a rigorous process of background checks and interviews.\n\n\u201cThe family is the bedrock of our nation,\u201d says the G.O.P. website. Most Americans want to find a solution for the Dreamers to become citizens of this great nation, but not at the expense of American families.\n\nFAVIO RAMIREZ-CAMINATTI\n\nSTATEN ISLAND\n\nThe writer is the executive director of El Centro del Inmigrante, an immigrant organization based on Staten Island.", "title": "Opinion | Trump\u2019s Proposed Deal on Immigration", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-31 00:00:00", "text": "President Trump gave a bravura performance on Tuesday night. Among presidential speeches, the State of the Union address comes closest to the long, disjointed, episodic form of the campaign rally \u2014 the form of oratory at which he excels. So even though virtually every word of the speech is scripted, it has the shout-outs, the self-applause, the knowing smiles and mugs that this president enjoys and that allow him to engage the congressional and the television audience over a long evening.\n\nHe became almost as much a conductor as a speaker, expertly cuing the soloists, as it were, a dozen or so times during the speech \u2014 surely the largest number of hero-witnesses crammed into one of these events since Ronald Reagan had the dubious idea of turning the State of the Union into a report card on the State of the People.\n\nThe rhetorical flourishes in last night\u2019s address owed much to Reagan: not merely the heroes and volunteers, but above all the business and personal tax cuts, the largest in a generation, and with them the whirring and turning of economic gears, lifting citizens (in a nice phrase) \u201cfrom welfare to work, from dependence to independence, and from poverty to prosperity.\u201d\n\nA few hard edges were smoothed away. The phrase \u201cradical Islamic terrorism\u201d did not appear in the speech, as it had in Mr. Trump\u2019s Inaugural Address and his message to the joint session of Congress last year. He did not mention the news media, libel laws or Russia (except to criticize it alongside China as rivals \u201cthat challenge our interests, our economy and our values\u201d). The phrase \u201cAmerica First\u201d is gradually softening (another Reagan touch?) into putting \u201cAmericans first.\u201d As Mr. Trump put it winningly: \u201cI want our youth to grow up to achieve great things. I want our poor to have their chance to rise.\u201d", "title": "Opinion | Trump\u2019s Debt to Reagan", "authors": []}
